column2: The Association of Bond Brokers, which is composed of members of firms represented in the "bond crowd" on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the nomination of Paul V. Mravlag of Vilas Hickey for president to succeed William W. Struthers of Struthers Dean.

SOME ONE who had not seen "Victoria Regina" was expressing the other evening a complete lack of interest in England's most obdurate Queen. "I never thought she was an interesting person," the skeptic declared. "I don't see how a good play could be written about her."

Mayor La Guardia banned the issuance of city licenses yesterday to all operators of so-called pin ball games who offer coupons redeemable in cash or catalogued prizes in return for high scores. He ordered, also, the revocation of such licenses now outstanding.

In that part of his message to Congress which was devoted to domestic affairs, the President had several sound and hopeful things to say. He shared the good cheer of the country over the signs of positive business recovery. He pointed to the marked increase in the national income.

The State Mortgage Commission began yesterday mailing to the 200,000 holders of certificated mortgages under its Jurisdiction a letter warning them against "misleading statements" that were being circulated by some persons interested in mortgage reorganizations.

Construction of the East River vehicular tunnel to link Manhattan and Queens, for which $58,365,000 in Federal funds has been tentatively allotted, will begin within thirty days, it was announced yesterday.

MR. SIMMONS has performed a valuable service in writing this book. Few know how vast an influence English literature has exercised on Russian culture: the facts collected here constitute something of a revelation.

MR. HADZSITS has given us yet another volume of that useful series known by the name of Our Debt to Greece and Rome, of which more than two-score volumes have already been published. The author of these volumes, who is also editor of the series, presents a defense of Lucretius the poet and the thinker.

Woodrow Wilson set the precedent April 2, 1917. Escorted to the Capitol by a troop of cavalry (a precaution against pacifist demonstrations), he read to a joint night session of the Senate and the House his war message, which contained the words that then glowed so brightly: "The world must be made safe for democracy."

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- The Boerse still is hobbled by the financial community's evident determination to do its business elsewhere. The market opened today with a display of insignificant and futile variations and then became weak, closing soft.

Although some buyers arrived in the markets here immediately after the first of the year to replenish badly depleted stocks, the first large contingent of store representatives here is expected tomorrow, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Company.

THE aristocrat of potted table evergreens is the Norfolk Island Pine, or Araucaria excelsa. Both in this country and abroad specimen plants, one to three feet high, in pots and ornamental containers, are sold.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- Revocation of the charter of the New York State organization controlled by the "old guard" and recognition of the secessionist left wing group headed by Norman Thomas by the national executive committee of the Socialist party, controlled by Mr. Thomas, was strongly indicated as the committee, meeting here today, began consideration of the New York feud.

THERE must be some quite ordinary people in Hollywood, but you rarely hear of them. Nor will you meet many of them in this book. You will meet actors, actresses, dancers, directors, politicians, newspaper men and press agents -- headline hunters all.

Expecting their most active season since the pre-depression days, manufacturers of various types of home furnishings will start showing their Spring lines tomorrow, with various trade shows scheduled for here and other parts of the country until the end of the month.

The Emile Tabbagh collection of Near Eastern and early Mediterranean art brought $102,015 at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries. Its sale, which opened on Friday, was com-pleted yesterday afternoon when $90,432.50 was realized.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

An entertainment reflecting many phases of Polish life, temperament and culture will be held in the grand ballroom of the Astor on the night of Feb. 1 when the Kosciuszko Foundation will give its annual Night in Poland Ball. Many prominent members of Polish colonies here and in other cities are actively interested in the event which is expected to have an attendance of many hundred persons.

BUENOS AIRES. -- Argentina continues to increase its production and exportation of cotton at a surprising rate. Exports during eleven months of 1935 were 26 per cent higher than for the corresponding period of 1934, and the 1934 exports had been 32 per cent higher than those for 1933.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 4. -- The annual invitation squash racquets doubles at the Greenwich Country Club and Field today and tomorrow were featured by a dinner dance at the Greenwich Country Club tonight. W. Stapley Wonham, Albert Tilt Jr., Anson W.H. Taylor, Ira H. Washburn and Henry C. Banks compose the tournament committee.

The trustees of the Celotex Corporation and Celotex Company, which are in receivership and trusteeship, reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31 a combined profit of $221,215 after interest, provision for exchange and operating loss on foreign operations, depreciation and other deductions, but before provision for services of trustees and trustees' counsel.

Prompt to launch its seasonal program of offense and defense on the State bills in which it is interested, the New York League of Women Voters will go into action tomorrow with the departure for Albany of its chairman of legislation, Mrs. John F. Russell Jr.

"ASIDO" is not so much a story as it is the account of the impression made by California and Mexico on an English visitor. The book tells how an Englishman and his 16-year-old daughter, both lovers of horses, purchase a fine mare, Dulce, and Asido, her even finer colt, taking into their employ at the same time Pedro, the old Mexican who owns them, and his adopted son, Filipi.
RADIO'S outlook for 1936 is bright. The industrialists and research workers, the showmen and performers have entered the new year in a happy mood.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Prosecutors in Idaho and Utah are carefully mapping courses for two murder trials which they hope will wipe the West's slate clean against five men blamed for twenty-two brutal killings.

ASMARA, Eritrea. -- The African conflict has added a chapter to the history of newspaper photography that deserves a large measure of attention and appreciation from a not always observant public. The boys with cameras have had lots of "tough" assignments since the World War, but nothing in any way comparable with what they have had to go through, and are still experiencing, here in Eritrea and Northern Ethiopia.

MORE symphonic and chamber music, more famous artists and music ensembles were heard over the National Broadcasting Company's network during 1935 than ever before. Nineteen of the leading musical organizations purveying symphonic music to the public were heard in regular series over the company's networks in the course of the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The Athletics tonight announced the trade of infielder Eric McNair and outfielder Doc Cramer to the Boston Red Sox in exchange for pitcher Henry Johnson, infielder Alfred Niemiec and an undisclosed sum in cash.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- President Roosevelt's advice about the future of the bonus argument was sought today by Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee, and tomorrow or Monday Vice President Garner and Senators Robinson and Harrison will call upon him to acquaint him further with the situation and seek his advice on the course to be followed.

AS fresh snow whitens the Rockies and the High Sierras the national parks again become inviting to lovers of invigorating Winter frolics amid some of Nature's grandest scenery. The parks had a record-breaking Summer season and the number of visitors doubtless will reach a new high in the cold months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Jesting suggestions that the Supreme Court would follow the road of the New Deal by appointing a "press agent" or "publicity director" were put to rest this week when the court named one of the clerk's staff to act as contact officer with newspaper correspondents but purely in a formal and non-interpretative role.

Criticizing Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, for saying that Senator William E. Borah would receive no support as a candidate for the Presidential nomination in New York, Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. held out the olive branch yesterday to the party organization and urged the election of a national convention delegation unpledged and uncommitted for or against any candidate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- John Morrell Co., meat packers, of Ottumwa, Iowa, reported today the smallest earnings in ten years. They reported also a tax burden increased 1,300 per cent by processing levies and shortages of hogs and feed.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The split in Democratic party leadership in California was projected today into the coming Presidential campaign.

MOSCOW, Jan. 3. -- The Russian Army and Navy are the hardest things to find out about in Moscow. The censorship, which is generally urbane and reasonable enough, throws "conniption fits" at the mere thought that military secrets may be divulged.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 4. -- An increase in weight by 95.8 per cent of a recent class during four years at Wesleyan University and a considerable improvement in health is shown in figures released by Dr. Edgar Fauver, Professor of Physical Education.

President Roosevelt's address to Congress was attacked yesterday by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. as a partisan political speech and the use of Congress as "window-dressing and a springboard to uphold and spread the New Deal and spread partisan propaganda among the people for campaign purposes over a national radio hook-up at night."

DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Pre-fabricated steel houses soon may begin coming off the automobile industry's production lines along with the beer barrels and bathtubs with which some motor body concerns now are diversifying their business.

PHILANTHROPIST: The government of Austria last week conferred the Knight's Cross, First Class, Austrian Order of Merit, on Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok in recognition of her "outstanding and meritorious propagation of the art of music."

ROME, Jan. 3. -- Many Italians are saying that sanctions may in the long run prove to have been a blessing in disguise, for they will oblige Italy to attain that state of economic self-sufficiency which has for many years been one of her unrealized dreams.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Governor Talmadge of Georgia and John Henry Kirby, heading the "Southern Committee to Uphold the Constitution," issued today a call to the "Jeffersonian Democrats of Southern and border States to meet at Macon, Ga., on Jan. 29 to repudiate the New Deal. The call read:

INVARIABLY it is with misgivings that we reach the week during which it has become usual to go over what has been issued during the past year, from it select that which seems to us is good and make a public statement as to the findings.

ANGORA, Turkey, Jan. 2. -- One of the most interesting sidelights on the present European tension over the Italo-Ethiopian situation is the reversal of the traditional relationship between the Balkan States and the big Western powers.

THE eleventh program of the Cleveland Orchestra on Thursday evening and Saturday afternoon in Cleveland, Ohio, will be conducted by Rudolph Ringwall, in the absence of Artur Rodzinski, who is on his midseason holiday. Mr. Ringwall will also direct six concerts for children in the course of the week of Jan. 13.
Plans of the automobile industry for production in 1936 indicate a bright outlook for business in general, according to K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation.

PARIS. THE Paris evening holiday stylescape is as scintillating as a Christmas tree: frosted with beading; glittering with touches of metallic embroidery; starred with jewels. Women are entering heartily into the spirit of the holiday season and dressing the part to the last detail.

Under sensational circumstances, Charles A. Lindbergh has taken his family from the United States. For this dramatic change of domicile, there is stated to be a general reason. The Lindberghs wish to live a normal life and in search of "quiet and rest" have gone to Wales.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The fact that the tide of invasion in Northern Ethiopia had come to a halt and that even its eddies had become stagnant was clear long before Premier Mussolini spoke on Monday of "indispensable pauses." He can hardly have been surprised if the world, even his own people, interpreted that statement as a confession of difficulties greater than were implied.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 4 (AP). -- Jimmy Hines, hefty young Eastern pro, blasted the favorites into the background today in the Riverside $3,000 open with a sizzling 66, six under par. Jumping into the lead in the second round of play, the Garden City (L.I.) star finished 36 holes with 136.

BALANCED GREETINGS: Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas, who is in the running for the Republican Presidential nomination, mailed 10,000 New Year's greetings last Monday. Before sending them out the Governor (who is praised for his thrifty administration and his budget balancing) ordered an eighth of an inch shaved from each card, thereby saving himself $50 in postage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Those were happy days when the old Clipper ships carried practically all of our commerce. The American flag was seen on the seven seas and our country held a proud place among the maritime nations.

AN autogiro is now being prepared for public display which will do these things: It will fly 150 miles an hour. It will demonstrate both a zero landing speed and a zero take-off speed. In it the pilot will be able to land on a lawn or on a wide strip beside a highway.

THE title of this novel suggests to the reader that it is a romantic love story destined, like all proper romances, to find its way through a maze of obstacles to a happy ending on the last page. Stripped to its bare bones that is precisely what it is.

THOUGH the movies are forging ahead somewhere, the screen is beginning to look more like old times. Venerable Westerns have been revived, to the enthusiasm of the fans and the plaudits of the highbrows, who have discovered these are art or folklore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- An active movement is resurgent throughout the United States with the definite objective of bringing back constitutional prohibition. Prohibitionists declare they are marching to victory, not immediately but within a few years, and they predict that it will be a final victory this time, with John Barleycorn forever driven from the land.

It is not often police at the lineup at headquarters show more than cold disdain toward the criminals being examined on the brilliantly lighted platform. But yesterday morning the assembled detectives were thrown into an uproar when 55-year-old Charles Crispi of 412 East Sixty-ninth Street, who was arrested the preceding night on a burglary charge, suddenly appeared on the platform and waved to them with the familiarity of long acquaintance.
PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Looming brightly on the horizon of sports lovers here are many important golf events listed for the island's clubs, which are now open and daily thronged with players.

IN some parts of this world there still exists a few native peoples who are living in the Stone Age. Very few they are, and even these few are rapidly dying out, unable to withstand the violent changes brought by the white civilization which is everywhere displacing the primitive cultures.

Miss Thelma Richmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Stanley Richmond of Laurel, Miss., was introduced to society here at a tea given yesterday by her brother, James Stanley Richmond of this city, in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. The debutante is attending school in this city.

Apart from the merits of the African dispute between the principals themselves, a grave question facing Americans of all racial extractions keeps constantly popping to the front when the question of what our neutrality is or should be is discussed.

Reapportionment of the State's legislative and Congressional districts and amendment of the city Home Rule Law to permit initiation of amendments to the city charter by petition of a percentage of qualified voters are among important items on the Citizens Union's legislative program, announced last night by William J. Schieffelin, its chairman, in a radio speech from Station WHN.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- Some of the mystery surrounding the Belgian King's recent visits to England was cleared up tonight when it was learned he visited the financier Sir Leonard Franklin at the latter's Goudhurst, Kent, home.

THE reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Canada which went into effect last week represents a logical step in the unique relationship of the two countries. Despite many high-flown sentimentalities Canadian-American friendship has been characterized to a remarkable degree by the virtue of common sense.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Joe Louis settled down today to the task of increasing his earnings to $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Federal regulation of "protective" committees acting for holders of municipal, county and district bonds was proposed today by Representative Wilcox, Democrat, of Florida.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4. -- A heavy downpour of rain extending from Central California north to the Canadian border this week was highly beneficial to farmers who have been delaying planting operations due to a lack of moisture. Figures for the season today are now close to normal and conditions in agricultural areas are most satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The possibility of action concerning the Federal courts as a result of President Roosevelt's statement in his message to Congress regarding protection of its prerogatives was discounted on Capitol Hill today.

A foul goal in the final seconds of play gave New York University a 23-22 victory over the University of Kentucky last year and these two quintets will clash again at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday in the fourth of the college court double-headers that have evoked such tremendous response from the basketball public this season.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- Seventy-five voices from the University of Pennsylvania Glee Club will make up the chorus for this year's Mask and Wig Club production, "Red Rhumba," it was announced today by Francis J. Kelly Jr., '30, chairman of the committee on production.

COMPULSORY inspection of automobiles operated in New York State, no matter in what State they are registered, is provided for in a bill which Senator John T. McCall, New York Democrat, has just offered for the consideration of the 1936 Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The 1936 Presidential campaign started with a rush today as the political foes of the President replied to his attack on critics of the New Deal, made yesterday in his annual message to the Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- President Roosevelt followed with cheerful interest today the response to the radio broadcast of his message to Congress last night, as telegrams arrived at the White House in volume indicating that a total of several thousand would be received.

WHILE the newly formed Radio Education Committee undertakes the task of studying the place of teachers in broadcasting, the United States Office of Education will be experimenting with a new kind of educational program.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4. -- A ten-year program of expansion costing $3,000,000 is proposed by Remsen B. Ogilby, president of Trinity College, in his annual report to the trustees, which extols the growing usefulness of this country's small colleges.

When Samuel Strauss, wealthy 74-year-old wholesale butcher, appeared yesterday morning on a stretcher at West Side Court to sign a complaint for assault and robbery against two men, one of whom is his son-in-law, Magistrate Overton Harris refused to allow him to enter the court room.

Deft stroking by Carl Pflug played a prominent role as Squadron C's efficient and unbeaten trio defeated the First Division, 12 1/2 to 6, last night at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn to continue as the pace-setter in the current Metropolitan Indoor Polo League competition.

BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- For the first time since 1931, Harvard's hockey team defeated the University of Toronto tonight, outplaying the Dominion sextet to register a 6-to-4 victory before 3,000 spectators in the Boston Garden.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 4. -- Starting its basketball campaign against the University of Baltimore today, a green Naval Academy five, after trailing by a point at the end of the half, found itself in the second period to triumph, 38 -- 25.

The statistical position of the petroleum industry during 1935 was the best since 1920, according to an analysis to be released today by William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist. Demand for all petroleums was the largest since 1929; exports were the largest since 1930, and domestic consumption was the largest in the history of the industry, the report states.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- American farmers in 1935, for the third successive year, cooperated with the national government in efforts to adjust their production to the available market, domestic and foreign. They realized from the year's production a gross farm income of approximately $8,110,000,000, as compared with $7,300,000,000 from the production of 1934, and $5,337,000,000 from the production of 1932, when the depression was at its worst.

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- The scathing indictment of National Socialist political, racial and religious persecution and the call for League of Nations intervention in Germany "in the name of humanity and the public law of Europe," as made in his letter of resignation by James G. McDonald, the League's High Commissioner for Refugees (Jewish and Other) Coming From Germany, have been studiously ignored by the German Foreign Office thus far.

About 75 per cent of the students who were graduated last June from the various schools of Columbia University have obtained positions, it was announced by W. Emerson Gentzler, secretary of appointments in his annual report to the university trustees, made public yesterday.
THE broadcasters are wondering what the second session of the Seventy-fourth Congress will do about broadcasting. Numerous bills pertaining to radio were left over from the first session.

TWICKENHAM, England, Jan. 4. -- An irresistible back division that ran the redoubtable All-Blacks off their feet for the greater part of the game brought a 13 -- 0 victory to England today in the closing fixture of the New Zealand rugby team's tour and avenged two defeats inflicted on the mother country in the past thirty years.

On Page 6 of this week's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine a description is given of a plan to increase the flow of Lake Tana's waters into the Blue Nile in Ethiopia so as to provide a greater supply of water to irrigate the cotton fields of the Sudan.

TIN PAN ALLEY is at it again. What is more, it is working under pressure, fighting time deadlines and a possible disgrace. Composers and lyricists in a thousand furnished rooms, penthouses, estates, night clubs and cabarets are seeking the perfect dissonances, the ideal rhymes for the City of New York.

OFFICIAL announcements of the two next major contract bridge tournaments are out, augmenting the information given in this column last month. The Eastern championships to be conducted by the Knickerbocker Whist Club, will take place at the Commodore Hotel from Monday, March 2, to Saturday, March 7.

IT is always interesting, but also meaningless, to use family relationships in art as a medium of comparison, but one aspect of such an effort seems really fruitful. "Journey Into Freedom" is the product of a man in his late twenties; the Thomas Mann who wrote "Buddenbrooks" was younger, but the difference in years and the question of individual talent seem momentarily irrelevant here.

BOSTON, Jan. 3. FROM the looks of things, the new "Ziegfeld Follies," which opened at the Opera House here Monday night, will not be ready for New York before another three weeks at least. The best word available is that the preliminary engagement in Boston will run until Jan. 11, and then will move to Philadelphia for a fortnight's engagement there.

APPARENTLY this reviewer occupies a position of conspicuous solitude in regarding the performance of Trudi Schoop and her "dancing comedians" as merely pleasant entertainment which blazes no trails for the dance and dates no epochs.

BOY MEETS GIRL," is, I think, the best play that has as yet appeared about Hollywood. It is the real thing. And it is the real thing because Bella and Samuel Spewack are reporters as well as dramatists and they report what they see and observe, not what convention would want them to see.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Authority to acquire 25,280 new shares of capital stock of the Southeastern Massachusetts Power and Electric Company and rights to subscribe to all or any part of such shares was sought today by the Massachusetts Utilities Associates of Boston, a subsidiary of the New England Power Association.

Deputy Commissioner John T. Gibbs of the New York State Conservation Department came down from Albany yesterday afternoon to pinch-hit for his chief, Commissioner Lithgow Osborne, as the speaker on a fishing and hunting program inaugurated by the municipal radio station WNYC. Mr. Osborne was confined to his home in Auburn with a cold.

From a retail standpoint the 1 per cent tax on payrolls required this year under the unemployment insurance provisions of the Social Security Act, which went into effect last Wednesday, will approximate one-sixth of 1 per cent on sales, according to estimates made yesterday in department store circles here.

MRS. SUTRO rounded out her "first seventy years" with a very active, interested and much-enjoyed Summer in Russia -- the Summer of 1934 -- touched off at the end with a trip by airplane from Leningrad to Paris, which so delighted her that she hopes never again to have to go anywhere by train.

UNION CITY, N.J., Jan. 4. -- The John Marshall College of Law basketball team of Jersey City remained in the ranks of the unbeaten by vanquishing Yale, 50 -- 28, before a crowd of 1,200 persons at the Thomas A. Edison School gymnasium tonight.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 4. -- Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, accompanied by Miss Constance Morrow, her daughter, left the United States for England this morning for an "indefinite stay" it was revealed today.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- It is almost an axiom, because few will be found to dispute it, that the tranquillity of Europe this year will depend largely upon relations between Great Britain and Germany. For that reason these relations are worth study.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (AP). --The Boston Bruins and the Montreal Canadiens battled through 70 minutes of speedy play to a 1-1 tie tonight in a National League Hockey game that was featured by brilliant work on the part of both goalies.

ITHACA, Jan. 4. -- Cornell students will return from their midyear recess next week prepared for the most intensive period of study of the college year. Final examinations begin Jan. 27 and extend to Feb. 5. Then follows the traditional junior week of social festivities.

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- More than 9,000,000 German boys and girls between the ages of 10 and 18 years face conscription in the new Reich Youth League under National Socialist supervision and control, according to plans just announced by Baldur von Schirach, Reich Youth leader.

THE International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, in moving its Health Center to larger quarters, has taken another step in the development of a medical service that is without parallel. The center, formerly located in an old four-story building in East Seventeenth Street, is now housed on a single floor of a sunny loft twenty-five stories above the ground at 275 Seventh Avenue, in the downtown section of the garment district.

ALTHOUGH the opening of Congress has been awaited in some quarters with misgivings, the automobile industry relies on the present session to clear up some of the overhanging transportation issues with little disturbing effect.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The first chapter of the Museum of Modern Art Film Library's animated history of the motion picture will be unrolled Tuesday night at 8:30 o'clock at the museum, 11 West Fifty-third Street, before an audience of its trustees, members and representatives of the film industry. Another showing will be held there on the following night.

LAKE PLACID. -- Now that the holiday program of "spectator sports" has reached its height at Lake Placid, Winter visitors are settling down to a more strenuous program of participant events. The daily ski runs of five, ten and sometimes fifteen miles over the wooded trails are always popular among the true sportsmen.

"CQ: calling CQ; please come in, somebody; this is -- in East Peoria calling on twenty-meter phone." A few seconds later a "voice" from the English countryside replied; the American's call had been heard across the Atlantic and a Briton was answering.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 4. -- The Rutgers University campus bank, operated by students in the course in "Money and Banking," has declared dividends of 9 per cent to its student and faculty stockholders though a number of loans are still outstanding.

PARIS, Jan. 4. -- Viewing President Roosevelt's message to Congress as a "political act of capital importance," French opinion inclines toward what may be termed defensive criticism in its first reactions to the message and to the presentation of the Neutrality Bill.

Permit us to raise two loud bu harmonious voices in protest against Ludwig Lewisohn's statement in his article in Sunday's TI,'6:s that Richard Wagner "* * * had a small, spiteful, ugly mind-the mind of a stage-struck Fascist. There was in him no goodness, as Ithere was so overwhelmingly t Shakespeare; no gentleness, love or loving kindness.

GENEVA, Jan. 4. -- In a note that was published today by the League of Nations, the Soviet Union asks that Uruguay's rupture of diplomatic relations with Moscow be considered by the League Council at its session Jan. 20.

VIENNA, Jan. 4. -- An audience here tonight applauded to the echo an 18-year-old play written by the octogenarian playwright, George Bernard Shaw. Our fathers who rocked at every witty line at the premiere of "Pleasant Plays" could not have been more tickled than we were by Mr. Shaw's "Die Millionaerin" ("The Millionairess"), which had its world premiere in the Vienna Akademie Theatre tonight.

RYE, N. Y., Jan. 4. -- Scoring all of its goals in the first two periods, Dartmouth's hockey team tonight turned back the Williams College sextet by 5 -- 2 before a capacity crowd of 1,800 at the Playland rink.

THE Dutch of South Africa have had to wait for an American woman to make the story of the Great Trek of 1836 live in fiction; but even if the writer had been born in the country she would have been hard put to it to render its predominantly Dutch atmosphere in more effective and sympathetic manner.

AFTER a series of highway tests, lighting specialists of the General Electric Company report that a pedestrian on an unlighted road after dark is virtually invisible to a driver going at normal speed until it is too late for the car to be stopped before hitting him, even though the car's headlights are fully turned on.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Calling Senator Borah the "outstanding liberal candidate," Senator Peter Norbeck, Republican of South Dakota, today put himself on record for the Republican nomination of the Idahoan for President.

Copies of the Securities and Exchange Commission's comprehensive report on the problem of trading in unlisted securities, which was submitted to Congress late on Friday, were in demand yesterday both by members of the New York Curb Exchange and by members of the New York Security Dealers Association, the two groups that stand to gain or lose trade through the ultimate solution devised by the Federal Government.

LUIGI LUCIONI does puzzling things sometimes. One of our more confidently "predictable" young painters, he departs now and then from his formula long enough to bring a subject to life in a way that is quite unexpected.

I hope the New Dealers who have spent their time on earth inventing devilish tortures for men in small business will when they go to hell be given a dose of their own medicine. I hope I have a reserved seat (air-conditioned) so I can watch them trying to solve their unsolvable problems.

An increase in the number of money orders printed by the Government Printing Office in Washington this year was reported last week by A.E. Giegengack, Public Printer of the United States, as an indication of better business conditions.
BELLEAIR, Fla. -- A full program of sports and social events will mark the Winter season at the Belleview Biltmore at Belleair, Fla., which will open for its forty-first season next Friday.

In sharp contrast to the holiday lull, women's organizations face a calendar for January topheavy with important dates. Rising to one of the peaks of the club season, the next few weeks will bring a plethora of legislative activities, both State and national, annual meetings, election of officers and conferences.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington were dinner hosts at Tre Fontane.

CAPE TOWN, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press). -Defeated by an innings and 78 runs today in the third test match with Australia, South African cricketers lamented the turn in the weather that forced them to bat yesterday and today on sticky wickets that practically assured their opponents of victory.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 4. -- The average Princeton freshman is 18 years old, is studying for an A.B. degree, is a member of the Episcopal Church and is a son of a lawyer or a business executive who was graduated from Princeton, according to a study of The Freshman Herald, class handbook, issued here this week.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 4. -- The tenth anniversary of the opening of the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, Strong Memorial Hospital and the School of Nursing will be observed with a two-day program Friday and Saturday.
TORONTO, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons and Toronto Maple Leafs played to a 1-1 tie tonight. By taking the point for a tie the Maroons moved into second place in the International group.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4. -- Postoffice receipts in St. Louis are best since 1930 in the last week and this is accepted as an evidence of general strength in business throughout the Eighth Federal District. Statements accompanying the annual reports of the International Shoe Company and the First National Bank are also optimistic in character, if warning signs are occasionally evident.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- For the two weeks ended Dec. 21, there were 579 certificates of automobile registration and licenses to drive either revoked or suspended by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. Of this number 173 will be required to give proof of financial responsibility before applications for new licenses will be given consideration.

Just a century after it began to be applied to Democratic nominations for the Presidency, the Jacksonian two-thirds rule will in 1936 confront the likelihood of abolition. The last Democratic National Convention left to its successor the question of whether the traditional two-thirds of the delegates, or merely a majority, should determine the nominee.
VIENNA, Jan. 3. -- Indications are multiplying that the Austrian Government is contemplating a gradual reorientation of its foreign policy, which may have important results throughout Europe.

PARIS. -- The French Academy recently marked another milestone on its perpetual journey through the French language. It issued its seventh and for the present at least, last section of the revised dictionary which forms the chief routine work of the institution.

Dr. Harris Taylor, Supervisor of the Education of the Blind and Deaf of the New York Special Schools Bureau, was the guest of honor at the golden jubilee dinner of the Deaf-Mutes' Union League held last night at the Hotel Astor. Several hundred members of the league attended the dinner, at which Nathan Schwartz, president of the group, presided.

A bill to establish a National Tourist Commission was introduced in the last Congress by Senator Copeland. The purpose of this bill is to promote tourist travel from foreign countries to the United States. It provides that a commission of five members be appointed by the President to consist of the Secretary of State, the Secretary of the Department of Commerce and three experienced travel men.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- As the old year ended, the Illinois Emergency Relief Commission gathered at the bedside of Governor Horner and laid before him what it termed the "most serious crisis in the State's relief situation since the commission was organized."

ANNOUNCED by two challenging bugle calls, Mayor La Guardia recently climbed on the back of a truck to proclaim a ban on the racket-controlled sale of small artichokes in New York City. This open declaration of war on underworld characters who prey on the city's food has focused attention on the vast buying and selling of foodstuffs -- approximately 7,000,000,000 pounds every year -- for Gotham's tables.

IN the beautiful portrait of Saint-Just by Greuze, belonging to Mrs. Pierre Chavrier, and visible in the treasure room of the Widener Library at Harvard, one is conscious of the comely and chilling quality which caused the subject of Professor Curtis's study to be called the angel of extermination.

WINTER camps amid the tall timber bedded in snow are now calling Boy Scouts in many sections of the country. When the busy holidays are gone, with their special good turns in toy repairing and distribution of food and clothing for the needy, most councils open up Winter quarters in the out-of-doors.

Italian bombs destroyed a Swedish Red Cross unit in Ethiopia last week, arousing widespread public concern as well as sharp protests from several official quarters. In the seventy-two years of its existence the Red Cross has come to symbolize mercy and compassion in a war-torn and disaster-ridden world, and the man on the street is likely to consider any affront to it as an affront to all humanity.
ANOTHER of the season's large group shows has just opened at the American Fine Arts Building. This is the sixty-ninth annual of the American Water Color Society, which will continue through Jan. 21.
OTTAWA, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press). -- A world-wide scientific investigation begun in 1933 so far shows no definite indications that the continents are shifting their positions.

ATLANTA, Jan. 3 -- Eugene Talmadge, Governor of Georgia, entered yesterday on an adventure in dictatorship which has had no precedent in the history of the State and probably no parallel in the nation.

IN no one year in history, I believe, has any other nation so run the gauntlet of emotions as did Ireland from October, 1890, to October, 1891. The play entitled "Parnell," now running so successfully in New York, has wakened in my mind a host of memories of that tragic year.

Many younger members of society at home for the holidays attended the Dolphin Dance last night at the Pierre. The subscribers to these dances, which are patterned after the Patriarch Dances of several decades ago, are mainly debutantes of next season. Several dinners were given before the fete.

Nominally and officially a detective, Frank Hall, familiarly known as "Satan," is really a killer. His method of combating crime is to provoke criminals to attack him, thus giving him the right to kill them in self-defense. "Satan" takes his orders directly from the Commissioner of Police, and his job is to expose and destroy big racketeers.

It is indeed a just and worthy tribute to Guiomar Novaes, the Brazilian pianist, that after many seasons of concertizing, one always finds every availabe seat filled and that she constantly evokes fresh admiration. Thus it was yesterday afternoon in her second recital of the season at the Town Hall.

Giving away four goals on handicap and just falling short with two exciting rallies that had the crowd at Squadron A Armory shouting with excitement, the New York Athletic Club riders went to defeat last night as they started defense of their title in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League.

Mischa Elman, who, for some curious reason, has not appeared In seasons as soloist with a major symphonic organization of New York, gave the first of six concerts yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, in which he will deliver himself of the stupendous task of fifteen violin concertos in conjunction with the National Symphony Orchestra.

The procession of railroads into bankruptcy, which virtually halted in 1934, was resumed in 1935 with imposing statistical results. Fifteen lines, including seven major systems, took refuge in the courts in the year, bringing the mileage of companies in receivership or bankruptcy to about 73,000, the greatest total in history.

At the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences in Rockefeller Center, the most extensive aeronautical index ever compiled is reaching formidable proportions, it was revealed yesterday by the Works Progress Administration. Specially qualified workers of the WPA, under the sponsorship of the Dock Department, are gathering the material under the direction of Major Lester D. Gardner, secretary of the institute.
TORONTO, Jan. 4. -- Back in 1927, when the harvest was heavy, they hailed Albert (Frenchy) Berlanger as king of the flyweights. Now they send him out for a 10-cent beer.

Extension of the special Druckman grand jury to investigate "the entire administration of justice in Brooklyn" and particularly the administration of labor laws was urged upon Governor Lehman last week by Norman Thomas and a group of trade union representatives.

LACKING living composers of genius, the world is more and more reminding itself, instructing itself, as to the great ones of the past. If books about them are any criterion, these are now more honored than ever before.

An international event of major size is assured for 1936 in the world of outboard racing as a result of the action of President George W. Sutton Jr. of the American Power Boat Association on New Year's Eve, a few minutes before the time limit closed at midnight.

WHEN Fiorello La Guardia became Mayor of New York two ago, he invited me to spend a day with him so that I might get a clear idea of what his job was like. I called for him at 8 o'clock in the morning, drove around the city with him, and sat in his office while he conducted municipal affairs.

With few exceptions, the demands of the Dressmakers Union are regarded as "utterly unacceptable" by the manufacturers, it was reported yesterday by the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc., which is conducting an informal canvass of the industry.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 4. -- Mrs. Elizabeth Tramsek, 30 years old, of 146 Fairmount Avenue, Newark, was being questioned by the police here tonight following the discovery that strangulation was a contributing cause in the death of her mother, Mrs. Margaret Kane, 68, with whom she lived.
PARIS, Jan. 2. -- A novelty in millinery is a Flemish hat of bright green felt; around its narrow crown is a pewter band engraved with fleurs-de-lis.
ATLANTIC CITY. -- With a strong contingent of the New Year holiday crowd still remaining in the resort, Atlantic City's Winter sport and social program is getting under way.

GENEVA, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- Dr. William Alfred Eddy, Professor of English at Dartmouth College, has been named president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges to succeed the Rev. Dr. Murray Bartlett, who will retire next May after an administration of seventeen years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 4. -- To increase the general knowledge of airplane engine performance, a research program has been started under the auspices of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics in cooperation with the automotive engine laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt will be 77 years old on Thursday, but she thinks nothing of it. There will be no celebration as far as she is concerned.

A nation-wide poll of shipping interests, editors, trade bodies, educators and recognized leaders in thought on the merchant marine has produced an expression in favor of a permanent government policy designed to aid the upbuilding of the merchant fleet, it was announced yesterday by the Propeller Club of the United States.

PANAMA. -- There is no three-mile emit of jurisdiction to the air above a country as is the case seaward from its shores, hence it appears that Juan Rivera Reyes, president of the Panaman Society for International Action would have that fact considered during the negotiations of a new treaty with the United States.

Hundreds of doll enthusiasts, both young and old, attended the close of the "Dolls of the World" display yesterday afternoon at B. Altman Co., Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The exhibit, which began Dec. 27 for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement, was termed a success by Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, who was honorary chairman of the committee.

A tense moment of the boards was enacted last night at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn as Glenn Cunningham, the present world's fastest human, sped to victory in the 800-meter run, the featured event on the tenth annual Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, indoor track meet program, which ushered in the 1936 season.

Because tomorrow is the Feast of the Epiphany, or the traditional anniversary when the three Wise Men came from the East to bring their gifts to the new-born Christ-Child, pastors will today preach sermons on the Magi. Also because it is the Sunday before Epiphany there will be pageants and dramas of the story and special oratorios will be sung.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- New York City, which supplies from 38 to 47 per cent of the water used by residents of Westchester County, is charging too much for its water, the Institute of Public Administration said in a report to the Westchester Commission on Government, made public today.

When the United States liner Manhattan sailed Friday with the American teams scheduled to take part in the Winter Olympics in the Bavarian Alps, the American Olympic Association placed in charge of Dr. Joel H. Hildebrand of the University of California, coach and manager of the skiing team, the official Olympic ode, "The Olympic Games, Past, Present and Future," written by Byrd Mock and hand- illuminated by Charles Sindelar, painter.

THE Magistrates' Courts Social Service Bureau, which will deal exclusively with the social problems presented by individuals arraigned before city magistrates, will begin to function early next Spring.

SINCE any hit breeds rumors that its producer was just lucky and could never do it again, Alex Yokel is taking no unnecessary chances with "Julie." When it opens in Washington, on Jan. 13, its two acts, ten scenes, seven sets and cast of eighteen will have cost some $25,000.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 4. -- A government communique states an Egyptian-Ethiopian ambulance unit outside Daggah Bur was bombed and machine-gunned this morning without casualties.

A tea dance will be given at the Pierre on Thursday for the benefit of the medical service of the Adopt-a-Family Committee. The general committee for the undertaking is headed by Miss Margaret H. Gillmore, with Mrs. Johnston L. Redmon as treasurer.

ALTHOUGH the gardenia, or Cape Jessamine, is a difficult subject outside the greenhouse -- where temperature, ventilation and humidity can be exactly regulated -- many careful amateurs are successful with it as a house plant. Even a second season of bloom is achieved when suitable Summer conditions are arranged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Backed by a reduced government investment of $1,000,000, a distillery in the Virgin Islands has begun the manufacture of 250,000 gallons of rum a year. National prohibition dealt a severe blow to one of the economic mainstays of Virgin Islanders.

SOVIET students at the various universities and institutions of Moscow live in colonies which are complete little cities in themselves. Studgorod, located in the outskirts of the city, is one of nine such colonies, and is made up of dormitories, reception rooms, clubs, a theatre and a cinema, library, tailors, hairdressers, nursery and a commissary, where prices are exceptionally low.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- Wearing a business suit and soft felt hat, City Controller S. Davis Wilson will drive, unaccompanied save for his chauffeur, to Convention Hall to take the oath of office as Mayor at noon on Monday.

Mrs. James Roosevelt has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the third annual Birthday Ball for the President, her son, which is to be held on Jan. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Members of the arrangements committee for the event also have been announced, this group including Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. James W. Gerard, Mrs. Charles Fellowes Gordon, Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw, Mrs. Gordon Auchincloss and Mrs. Eugene W. Ong.

Revision of the conditions of racing for the Brooklyn Yacht Club Ocean Challenge Cup, from which present-day deep-sea contest really sprang, is being undertaken by a committee of the Brooklyn Club, that it may be placed in competition again.

DETROIT, Jan. 4. -- Charles F. Kettering, vice president of and director of research for the General Motors Corporation, leaned back, smiling with hands clasped over one knee and told me a story of a visit to a Detroit book store.
TORONTO, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Existence in a Toronto art gallery of a replica or "second version'' of Paul Peel's notable painting "After the Bath" was disclosed today in The Toronto Telegram.

GENEVA, Jan. 4. -- Ethiopia "urgently requests" the League of Nations, in a note published today, to conduct "an impartial inquiry into the way in which hostilities are being conducted by the two belligerent armies in Ethiopian territory.''

Arrangements to purchase the Syndicate Trading Company have been completed by Lew Hahn, formerly president of the Hahn Department Stores, and Ralph Gensel, vice president and general manager of the company for the last five years, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Hahn.

Plunged into feverish activity following President Roosevelt's night message to Congress, the security markets showed no signs of discouragement yesterday; on the contrary, there were points in the address which were distinctly reassuring, and many sections of the stock and bond lists rose to new heights on the movement.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 4. -- A magic putter, which accounted for six birdies and a scintillating 31 on the second nine holes, today lifted Gene Sarazen of Brookfield Center, Conn., former United States and British open champion, into the lead at the half-way mark in the seventy-two hole medal competition of the $2,500 Miami open golf tournament at the Miami Springs Country Club.

The status of the bondholders stockholders and creditors under the final reorganization plan for the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Corporation, confirmed on Friday by Federal Judge William Bondy, was further explained yesterday by Lucius Boomer, president of the corporation.

Every taxicab driver and owner seeking a new license this year will be required by the Police Hack Bureau to sign a pledge to cooperate in the city's anti-noise campaign, it was announced yesterday at City Hall.

It has been my custom for a good many years to accept what the critics say of operatic performances as being probably more accurate and analytical than could be my own, for I am nothing more than an operagoer and am apt to observe in any performance of any opera only the more obvious wonders or detriments.

WHEN the unemployment tax went into effect last week the United States was formally launched on its first nation-wide adventure in social-security legislation. Soon, if Congress appropriates the necessary funds, the Federal Government will begin the disbursement of approximately $100,000,000, which, under the terms of the Social Security Act, was to constitute its investment in this field during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1936.

AMAZED CCC workers tn the eroded and deforested areas of Iauai, northwest of Waimea Canyon, T. H., recently ran upon an unknown forest of many hundreds of sturdy young trees waving fresh green foliage under the brilliant sun.

A campaign workers' dinner Tuesday night at the Hotel Commodore will launch the city-wide drive for $600,000 for 1936 current expense funds of the Young Men's and Young Women's Christian Associations. Following the dinner, 1,000 men and women will commence active solicitation.

THE great popular success of Irving Stone's novel about Van Gogh, "Lust for Life," began with an edition of 10,000 and the book went into best-seller lists almost from the date of publication. Although it has well maintained its popularity, the publishers report a decided spurt in sales since the opening of the Van Gogh exhibition, necessitating two reprintings.

Members of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects who acted in executive capacities for the Beaux-Arts Ball, held last month, have arranged a Beaux-Arts Society cruise to Nassau as a further means to aid the educational program of the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design, the Architects Emergency Committee and the American School of Fine Arts at Fontainebleau, France, each of which organizations benefited by the ball.

SURELY, a monumental cookbook, this, with its over eight hundred pages and its dimensions suggestive of an unabridged dictionary! The cuisine of twenty-nine nations has representation within its covers and its recipes include soups, fish, meat, poultry and game dishes, light entrees, vegetables, salads, sweets, a few sundries, French cheeses and beverages and a short article on French wines.
The following editorial comments on President Roosevelt's message were gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press:

TESSA BENNETT was a business girl who loved London and all the gay good times it meant to her -- theatres, dancing, compliments and pretty clothes. She would never have believed that she could fall in love with a poor farmer.

The regulations for the administration of the "unincorporated business tax," released for publication by the New York State Tax Commission as of Dec. 30, go a long way toward answering many knotty questions of application of this new emergency income tax.

While municipal bonds continued their sustained improvement throughout 1935, as is evidenced by the current high price level and large volume of financing, the proposals by several States for tax limitation on the municipalities stand as a serious threat to municipal bond credit, according to Lebenthal Co., specialists in odd-lot municipal bonds.

IT is reported from Canada that a Grand Opera Association has been formed which will make the Dominion the possessor of a national opera organization. All of the singers, musicians and members of the chorus are to be Canadians.

THE well-ship Seahorse wallows frequently oft Sandy Hook, returning with her dark bold swishing smacking with skates, rays and puffers. From steaming Malay come silvered archer fish, whose voyage has to be broken up because they can't stand the rigors of travel.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Police arrested sixteen young men and three young women tonight, ten of whom they said were delegates to the Congress of the American League Against War and Fascism, in breaking up mass picketing in front of a theatre where a motion picture called the "Red Salute" is shown.

WHAT sort of fellow is the American boy, 19 to 25 years of age, who will be the citizen of tomorrow and the man on whom the future of the nation will rest? What of his physical and mental make-up, his morals, his responsibility, his orderliness, his attitude toward his fellow men and his government?

HOLLYWDOD. WHILE the world took a new grip on life with the turn of the year, the cinema, ever perverse, regarded Jan. 1 as merely another holiday, for this is the screen's mid-season. Most studios are completing their commitments for the year and have not begun scheduling their product or buying stories for the 1936-37 season.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra has taken to heart the celebrated injunction "to go West" and has arranged a tour that will take the ensemble as far as the Pacific Coast, with of course, Leopold Stokowski in the lead.

GENEVA, Jan. 4. -- President Roosevelt's message, in treating the peace issue as essentially one between peace-loving democracies and a small, heavily armed minority of aggressive autocracies, was welcomed today in League of Nations quarters.

Before we ever heard of genes, hormones and vitamins a battle raged around the issue of spontaneous generation. Did life originate all by itself? The Victorians decided that life must always spring from life. Latterly we have heard new doubts about the validity of this doctrine.

THE present vague line separating Communist Russia and the Soviet protege, Outer Mongolia, from Japan's new continental empire is today the longest unsettled border in the world. It lies between two vigorous nations whose populations are rapidly increasing; each believes in a great and prosperous national future and each regards itself as responsible for a great world mission.

Only about 80,000 of the city's nearly 800,000 motor vehicle owners have obtained the 1936 license plates, it was revealed yesterday at the headquarters of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, 155 Worth Street. Every motor vehicle in New York State must be re-registered before Feb. 1.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Jan. 4. -- The American scene as it appeared just prior to the Civil War will serve as the theme of two student-written plays to be presented at Mount Holyoke College, January 13 and 14, by undergraduates enrolled in the elementary Playshop Laboratory course.

IN a few days more Rene Clair's first film in English, "The Ghost Goes West," an Anglo-American Gallicism at the expense of the removers of ancient castles and supplemented by the presence in our midst of Mr. Clair, himself, "in person," will irradiate New York.

HE who would seek his fortune as a writer would do well to be off to an early start. For, by and large, literary productivity is greatest on the hither side of age 45. By that time a writer has usually published about two-thirds of all the work he is destined to do.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Singing Wood, the favorite, captured the featured Santa Margarita Handicap at the Santa Anita race track today, defeating Tick On and Sound Advice, which finished behind the winner in that order.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 4. -- The city government faces the necessity in 1936 of asking voters to authorize a special tax levy to meet an operating deficit estimated from $4 000,000 to $8,000,000.
BOSTON Jan. 3 -- The story of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company is the story of the New England textile industry.

IT is a test of one's capabilities to write convincingly and with interest of the things nearest at hand. Your true travel writer may go no further afield than his own back yard for his inspiration and produce a masterpiece, while a less inspired scrivener might make a dull story about a year's sojourn among the snake men of Tanganyika.

I AM more interested in life than in the shadows of life," once wrote AE., and in that sentence he gave us the root of his thought. By life he meant immortal life; by its shadows, the earthly symbols of that immortal life -- nature, the garment of God, and beauty, the language of the soul, to speak with the mystic's metaphors.
The National Committee for Religion and Welfare urged cooperation between major religious faiths in a statement signed by prominent Catholics, Protestants and Jews.

Completing a visit which started with the world series last Fall, N. Yamaguchi, Japanese baseball official, left this city last night for Los Angeles, en route to Yokohama and his resumption of baseball duties there.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 4. -- New records in Canada's production and value of gold were established in 1935 and greater achievements are expected in 1936. In 1935 the output was 3,290,664 ounces, worth $115,798,466, while the corresponding figures for the previous year were 2,972,074 ounces, valued at $102,536,553.

CORRESPONDENTS remind us of certain composers who were passed over in last Sunday's article upon musical events, individualities and anniversaries of the year 1935. One of them remarks that while considerable space was devoted to Jean Sibelius and his seventieth birthday, no mention was made of the distinguished Russian Alexandre Glazunoff, who in that year reached the same age.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 4. -- Italian fliers showered bombs over wide areas of Ethiopia today. An American field hospital was reported to have been among the places struck in the aerial assault.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 4 (AP). -- F. Brandon Smith Jr. marshaled his forces tonight for a renewed assault on the Cannon textile millions for $250,000 "heart balm" he claims because his former father-in-law arranged a divorce in Hot Springs for his wife, Anne Cannon Reynolds Smith.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Ghaffar Khan Djalal, the Iranian (Persian) Minister, who was involved in a traffic incident with Elkton, Md., police on Nov. 27 last, has been recalled by his government and will leave the United States on March 20, it was announced at the legation today.

With industry showing renewed confidence in large financial investment, industrial and management engineers are enjoying their most sustained period of activity since the crash in 1929, executives of leading companies reported here yesterday.

Three thousand Soviet university students, mostly girls, are studying basic English to qualify as tourist guides in their home land, according to Albert Knox Dawson, manager of the Russian travel division of the American Express Company. Soviet educators have adopted the vocabulary of 850 words collated by Professor C.K. Ogden of London in the training of these girls to deal with the growing volume of tourist traffic.

AN excited clergyman made a speech one night in 1884 which fixed the national trend against James G. Blaine in favor of Grover Cleveland. A miners' strike late in 1892 junked the great political organization that had been built up to re-elect Benjamin Harrison.

Japanese dominance over China and the Far East will be extended at the expense of the Western powers, it was agreed by three speakers who arrived at their conclusions from different points of view, at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

There is no one more pathetio than the Marxian plowing wearily over the word "propaganda" unless it's the non-Marxian[ When Arthur lqobinson (THE TIMES, Dec. 29, 1935) tries to draw the line and says "Propaganda, as such, ceases to be propaganda when it becomes good drama" he is merely putting black and white stripes before the zebra's eyes.

Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the murder of Samuel Drukman, spent all yesterday going over the evidence with the half-dozen aides of his legal staff, preparatory to the actual opening of the case tomorrow morning in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

Whatever further effect may be expected from the bombing of the Swedish Red Cross camp, with its resultant loss of life, more than ever the Scandinavian countries have been aroused to stand by the League of Nations should more complete sanctions be ordered against Italy.

PAUL GRAETZ was a prominent German actor in pre-Hitler days. He hailed from Berlin, where he was born and bred. His pronounced Berlinism was reflected in his art, his humor and his peculiar way in singing a song.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- With the defeat of the national court tennis doubles champions, Ogden Phipps and William Rand Jr. of New York, featuring the play, the Philadelphia team won from the metropolitan representatives in the annual intercity matches at the Racquet Club today, 4 to 2.
DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 4 (AP). -- Nine Negroes, eight of whom once were under death sentence, will face the Morgan County Circuit Court to enter pleas in the Scottsboro attack case Monday.

In issuing the pamphlet reports of Second, Third and Fourth National Investors Corporation, Fred Y. Presley, president of all three investment companies, calls attention to the increases in tax rates that became effective on Jan. 1.

THE automobile industry faces the new year with about as many uncertainties as a year ago, reports The Associated Press. However, manufacturers anticipate a measurable return on the more than $100,000,000 they invested during 1935 in new equipment and hope for at least a partial solution of the used-car problem.
It is just ten years since Miss Suzanne Lenglen added to her tennis triumphs by defeating Miss Mary K. Browne in a match at Madison Square Garden under the sponsorship of C.C. Pyle.

THE American Association for the Advancement of Science met last week at St. Louis, and, as is its annual custom, roamed over the vast universe, discussing cosmic rays and atoms, men's minds and heart disease, archaeology and vitamins.

'][TORK on he West Side ele%/%/ vated highway made much progress during 1935. Between Seventy-second Street and Seventy-sixth Street literally acres i of steel and concrete were laid over the railroad tracks separating !Riverside Park from the I-Iudson River.

The period of annual stockholders' meetings of banks and trust companies will begin this week under conditions promising less excitement but more satisfaction for both bank executives and shareholders than at any similar period in many years.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 4. -- The Philadelphia team of Brendon R. (Rudy) Walsh and Don Strachan, who won here a year ago, scored two victories today in the Greenwich invitation squash racquets doubles tourney to advance to the semi-final round.

AT an auction held in New York recently an American cent of 1799 was sold for $310 -- while an Egyptian gold piece more than 2,000 years old brought only $90. Many persons who read the news story about the sale must have wondered why a comparatively modern copper piece should so out-value a coin of such great age.

ALTHOUGH Robert Nathan has occupied himself more with prose fiction than with poetry, his novels standing five to one to his books of verse, he is, nevertheless, a poet of no mean talent, as this sheaf of selections will convince those who do not know such collections as his "Youth Grows Old" and "A Cedar Box."
LLANDAFF, Wales, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The Charles A. Lindberghs arrived in this secluded Welsh community tonight. A heavy police guard was immediately thrown about their haven.

RECENT news dispatches from London and Paris announcing that the Cunard White Star Line has applied for cabin class designation for the giant Queen Mary and that the French Line has entered into an agreement to reduce fares on the Normandie next Summer to a parity with those on the new British ship, are significant items in an accumulating mass of evidence that points to something very important taking place in the world of travel.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- Syracuse University's sharpshooters buried a determined but outclassed Princeton basketball team tonight under a 55-to-30 score. The home team held the Tigers to 15 points in each half and kept the visitors on the defense with a fast attack and deadly accuracy from the field.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- While trade in wheat futures on the Board of Trade was not active today, the market had a firm undertone and responded to commission-house and local buying. Prices closed 1/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel higher than yesterday, the May leading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Intensification of the Federal war against organized crime through expanded activity by the Department of Justice and development of cooperation with local enforcement agencies was urged today by Attorney General Cummings in his annual report to Congress.
EVELYN WAUGH is a novelist rather than a historian, and "Edmund Campion" is done with the verve and the dramatic fervor of the born storyteller.

THE business of plant breeding and plant improvement has developed to a point where each new season now sees an ge of about 200 new flowers, all over the world, presented rdeners. Each introducer just ally believes his own "novelty" better than anything else of nd.

THE spirit of fascism is not new in America. We had an elegant illustration of it in the Ku Klux Klan during the early Nineteen Twenties, which might have gone further if its promoters had not become so absorbed in collecting dues and selling hooded nighties that they forgot their nobler objectives, fell to squabbling among themselves, became objects of mirth and faded away.

SO rarely does it happen that a reviewer can unreservedly endorse a publisher's blurb that the occasion deserves acknowledgment. And therefore it is but just to say that when the reader finds the comment on the paper jacket of this volume, "This is a noble book, passionately written, as befits its theme," he can accept the sentence at even more than its face value.

David Mannes and his orchestral opened their eighteenth season of free concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night before an audience of 8,700 persons, who filled the Main Gallery and the surrounding corridors. This was the first of eight concerts to be given by the same forces under Mr. Mannes's direction at the Museum this season.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 4. -- Jay Gibson Gates, son of Dr. Thomas S. Gates, president of the University of Pennsylvania, died of carbon-monoxide poisoning here tonight.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 4. -- Edward Gylling, Finnish-born former Premier of the Soviet Karelian Republic in Northern Russia, who recently was deposed by Joseph Stalin for alleged pro-Finnish leanings, has been murdered, according to reports from Russia.

Ciro Terranova, long known as the artichoke king of the underworld, painfully announced yesterday on the occasion of his fourteenth arrest that he had abdicated that high place. He must prove in Bronx Magistrate's Court next Friday, however, that he has not fallen to the low estate of vagrant.

A UTOPIA for mature scholars and scientific investigators is the aim of Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, in his long-cherished plan for the creation of a system of roving professorships. The first step in this direction was achieved by the recent gift of $500,000 to Harvard from Thomas W. Lamont, New York banker.

Brooklyn College's quintet ran up the largest total in the history of the college to overwhelm Oglethorpe University of Atlanta, Ga., 63 -- 30, at Union Temple in Brooklyn last night before a capacity crowd of 1,200 persons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- With the shadow of the Supreme Court looming across the Capitol Mall and the certainty of judgment at the polls appearing more distinctly down the lane of months, the Seventy-fourth Congress convened in final session on Friday and headed into an uncertain future.

A four-block area in the Greenwich Village section was deprived of its water supply at 6 o'clock last night when a defective valve caused the water main at Eleventh Street and Seventh Avenue to burst underground.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- The financial prospects of educational and charitable institutions for 1936 are brighter than they have been for the past several years, according to a forecast made by Charles D. Bostwick, controller of Cornell University.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Joe Crosson, piloting a transport plane, swept into Fairbanks tonight with scarlet fever serum he brought from Juneau in a 1,600-mile roundtrip flight in the elapsed time of 9 hours 24 minutes.

LAKELAND, Fla., Jan. 3. -- A report made recently by the War Department to dispel the fears of those who are convinced that the cross-State ship canal now under construction will ruin much of Florida's water supply has had little effect in changing the opinion of many directly interested in the project.

READING, Pa., Jan. 4. -- Socialists from all parts of the country are heading here for Monday's inauguration of the new Socialist city government, elected for a term of four years. Replacing every Republican and Democrat in the present Fusion government except one man, the Socialists will take control of every department, retaining this regardless of the outcome of what might be called the "by-election" of 1937, when two more Councilmen are to be chosen.

Reuben Fine was born in this city on Oct. 11, 1914, and was not yet 15 when he was graduated from Townsend Harris Hall High School. As a member of two champion teams at City College he first came into prominence in metropolitan chess circles and, two years ago, be obtained his degree of Bachelor of Social Sciences.

WITH the best-picture-of- the-year discussion engaging both coasts and with the probability that the academy will be forced into naming "The Informer" as the most distinguished offering and John Ford as the outstanding director of the season, the town is beginning to ask questions about both the film and the man who wielded the megaphone.

THE eyes of the nation will turn again tomorrow to the Supreme Court, meeting after the Christmas recess to consider matters of extraordinary importance. Statesmen, attorneys and large groups of plain citizens await with concern the opinions which the court will hand down before many weeks -- opinions certain to influence profoundly the course of politics and daily life.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4. -- With some economies effected and an improved collection of taxes certain, Mayor Diekmann is hopeful of balancing this city's budget when the current 1935-36 fiscal year ends next April.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- Facts presented by the Federal Reserve Bank afford much encouragement to business interests of this district. Industrial production now is 77 per cent of the 1923-25 average and is fifteen points better than toward the end of 1932.

Has not Nazimova gone Ibsen one better in the version of "Ghosts" now at the Empire? The final scene, as Mrs. Fiske used to play it, employing, if memory serves, William Archer's translation, ended in doubt and confusion, with the great actress further confounding its intent by a completely artificial and mystifying pose with Oswald under a spotlight in the center of the stage.

Judge and Mrs. David H. Kinchelos gave a dinner last night at their home, 115 East Eighty-sixth Street, for United States Assistant Attorney General Joseph R. Jackson and Mrs. Jackson. Other guests were Judge and Mrs. Murray Hulbert, Judge and Mrs. William J. Tilson, Judge and Mrs. William J. Keefe, Miss Jean Hulbert, Miss Margaret Austin and Leonard Davis of Washington.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The Pinehurst colony, with many additions from various cities in the East, will devote its attention this week to field trials. The program of the Pinehurst Field Trial Club occupies the full six days, with the open stakes tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday and the amateur stakes on the last three days of the week.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4 (AP). -Judge Leer, 5-year-old gelding, a son of Sweep On, owned by C.W. Pershall, scored a smart victory today in the featured sixth race at the Fair Grounds.

The recent proposal of the National Resources Board to subdivide the United States into a number of "regions," each with its "little capital," has stirred up a considerable amount of comment, some of it approving, some disapproving and much of it based on a misconception of what is really suggested.

Every precaution to avoid overproduction of dresses in anticipation of a strike will be taken by the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Jack Mintz, chairman. He declared that up to yesterday, despite the fact that little tangible progress toward an actual adjustment of the different viewpoints has been made, the industry is not experiencing any unusual increase in orders or in anticipatory production operations.

A triple attack on rackets in New York City will soon be under way. In a few days an extraordinary grand jury will be selected to inquire into the disputed Druckman killing in Brooklyn, for it is believed inevitable that that murder will be found linked with the flour-trucking racket.

CONSPICUOUS among the Christmas cards sent out to collectors was the beautiful catalogue of books and autographs which had been brought together by the late Mr. and Mrs. William A. Read. This fascinating volume (small folio, pages VIII and 288) is issued by the American Art-Anderson Galleries, which will sell the Read library in three sessions, Jan. 8 and 9.

BELGRADE, Jan. 4. -- Speaking to newspaper men tonight on the amount of compensation received by Yugoslavia in accordance with the League of Nations' promises to help overcome losses sustained through participation in sanctions against Italy, Milan Vrbanitch, Minister of Commerce, told of measures taken by Britain to increase Yugoslavia's exports.

MARATHON, Greece. -- Common malaria in children, in the form prevalent here, may be cured by the transfusion of blood from an immune adult, according to a discovery made at the joint health clinic of the Near East Foundation by Dr. Nicholas T. Lorando.

Portraits by George Romney, Sir Thomas Lawrence, Gilbert Stuart and other artists, as well as paintings by Jean Jacques Henner, Diaz de la Pena, William Adolphe Bouguereau, Adolph Schreyer, Thomas Moran, Albert Pinkham Ryder, George Inness, Ralph Blakelock, Childe Hassam, and others will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday evening.

The future looms bright for Josephine Antoine, youthful coloratura soprano, who made her debut in yesterday afternoon's first "Mignon'' of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Despite the nervousness attendant on an initial appearance, Miss Antoine, in the exacting role of Philine, sang her music with such charm and animation that she scored an immediate hit with the large matinee audience.

CARNEGIE HALL will be filled next Saturday with one of its most important audiences of the season -- an assemblage of youthful music lovers of the future, come to hear "Uncle Ernest" Schelling inaugurate the twelfth series of Philharmonic-Symphony concerts for young people.
