PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4. -- Union Trust Company books and records were ordered turned over to Federal Internal Revenue attorneys today by Federal Judge Robert M. Gibson in the income tax suit against Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury.

DETROIT, Jan. 4. -- This city, whose position has shown a consistent improvement since the low point of 1932-33, has started the new year with prospects of increased revenues and determination to restrict its expenditures so far as possible.

LONDON. THERE was a glade of silver-green trees, a broad flagged path which led to a round lake in which a fountain played and two swans disported themselves. Beyond was a pillared pavilion, brilliantly white in the sunshine, and beyond that a larger lake shimmering at the base of a fairy-tale palace.

THERE is a quaint, old-fashioned charm about the beginning of this novel which promises sympathetic reading for a wintry evening. Its setting is a very ugly London maisonette, presided over by Lavinia Cree, a young, not exactly pretty, girl half French, half English Lavinia's big problem is caring for her widowed father, a handsome, aristocratic little man with a mysteriously interesting past.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- As the 1936 session of the Legislature opens Democrats and Republicans in State and nation are lining up for the intensive partisan struggle that will come in the Autumn, when a President is to be elected and in the State a Governor, together with other elective State officials and forty-five members of the House of Representatives.

THREE appointed fellows of the General Education Board, founded by John D. Rockefeller in 1902, will be awarded use of the Columbia Broadcasting System facilities, beginning Jan. 6, to study methods of planning and producing radio programs.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- Warned by Senator Guffey that a certified check for $150,000 must be "on the line" next Thursday if Philadelphia is to press successfully her bid to entertain the Democratic National Convention in June, campaign workers pushed the city's subscription fund to the $122,000 mark today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Four States that were dry during the first full year of repeal were among the ten that had the biggest gains in deaths from alcoholism that year, a special study by the Census Bureau disclosed today.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 4. -- The Essex Troop poloists of Newark defeated the Ponolo Polo Club of Red Bank, 5 1/2 to 4 1/2, in a thrilling overtime battle tonight at the Essex Troop Armory.

AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 4. -- In an analysis of the demand for financial aid for students at Amherst College the fact that an increasing number of needy freshmen were entered in 1933 and 1934 suggests the gradual exhaustion of family resources.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The Countess Carnarvon, the former Catherine Wendell, prominent in New York society, has filed suit for divorce against the Earl of Carnarvon, it was revealed today.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 4. -- The Monaco Court of Appeals today invalidated the will of Mrs. Marie Delphine van Baele, in which Luis Baeza della Guadra, a young Brazilian who is a professional dancer, was the sole heir.

FAITH BALDWIN, whose books are never heavy reading, has done a particularly light bit of fluff in "The Moon's Our Home." Turning from her smooth business girls and pretty suburban wives, she has gone to Hollywood for a more frivolous subject.

WHO can tell me why certain artists and others with a public talent are inevitably called after and perhaps before death "Grand Old Men," unmistakably in capitals? Of course they have to be old, so have many of us, but that is not enough to make us grand or to give us the title whether or not we win it.

BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- Boston enters 1936 with the brightest financial outlook in several years. The city expects a budget reduction, less borrowing for maintenance, no increase in tax rate and a reduction in welfare disbursements.

BEIRUT, Syria. THE forests comprising the famous cedars of Lebanon, in Syria, which have been dying away throughout the centuries until there are relatively few left, are to be restored through the efforts of governments in the Near East.

QUINCY, Mass., Jan. 4. -- Armed with hot-water bottles which they rushed from hand to hand after the manner of an old-time fire bucket brigade, an entire neighborhood stood by for six hours today as Quincy firemen, doctors and police used fifteen tanks of oxygen in an unsuccessful attempt to save the life of William Ballou, 6, of Squantum, who was drowned when he ventured on thin ice.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 4. -- The annual Bachelors' Ball, one of the leading events of the New Haven holiday season, was held in the Delta Kappa Epsilon house tonight and attracted more than 300 persons, including many from out of town. Many dinners preceded the dance, which is a tradition for the first week of each new year.

ONE of the deterrents to travel in China -- a lack of clean, modern hotels -- has been reduced by the establishment of a chain of hotels in inland cities at the direction of the China Travel Service, a group interested in the development of tourism in the Orient.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- Professor Martin A. Brumbaugh, Professor of Statistics of the University of Buffalo, said today The Literary Digest poll on national political sentiment was biased because "a larger fraction of the Hoover voters than of the Roosevelt voters" in the 1932 election were voting.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4. -- The second annual midwinter tennis tournament will be concluded tomorrow when Wilmer Allison, top-ranking tennis player of the nation, meets Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., in the final of the men's singles event.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The new Congressional directory, distributed in the capital today, found several members competing for the shortest biographical sketch by piling their statements into less than a line.

IF any answer were needed as to why Sidney Lanier has failed to win that firm hold on the hearts of poetry lovers which in so many respects he would seem to deserve, it is supplied by latest biography, though perhaps without any such intention on Mr. Lorenz's part.

DOUBTLESS book will be more amusing to members of the bar than to laymen. For it is true of every profession that its distinctive customs clothe it in a body of meanings that appeal to those who are familiar with them with a significance lost to those outside.

T.H. Lewis and E.W. Hammons tied for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each finished the regular event with 99 out of a possible 100 targets. In the shoot-off Lewis prevailed by 24 to 22. The high handicap prize went to A.F. MacNichol.
The anniversary of the birth of Benjamin Franklin on Jan. 17 will be observed in the city's public schools with exhibits and demonstrations of printing and assembly and classroom talks on Franklin.

THE driver of an automobile who bullies pedestrians because be has the advantage of mass and momentum over them is everything his acerbated victims call him and deserves the extreme and unusual punishments they would inflict on him if they could, but in many instances of conflict between motorist and pedestrian it is the pedestrian and not the motorist who is the bully.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 4. -- The issue of Pan-Americanism versus internationalism was raised at this morning's session of the labor conference when Luis Solis, Chilean workers' delegate, replied to Jose Antuna, Uruguayan Government delegate, who in a speech yesterday declared regional economic ententes were an urgent necessity and expressed the opinion that American problems must be settled by the Americas.

THERE have been many evidences of the marked growth of interest in gardening throughout the United States. None, however, is more striking or definite than the number of books published on all phases of gardening.
RAWLINS, Wyo., Jan. 4 (AP). --Wyoming's self-styled "White Masked Robin Hood of the Rails," last of the old West's "bad men," will walk from Wyoming prison Wednesday a free man.

QUEBEC. -- Members of the Quebec colony from the United States are finding plenty to do in the Quebec district. The combination of zero weather and much snow is proving ideal for Winter sports, with the result that space is at premium on the Chateau Frontenac skating rink and the Quebec Ski Club jump at Lake Beauport is well patronized.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- Three theories were being considered by police tonight in their search for the motive of the slayer of Dr. Silber C. Peacock, specialist in children's diseases, who was found killed last night in his automobile, twenty-one hours after he had been lured from his home "to attend a sick baby."

With world consumption of cotton running above probable production this year, together with a general upward trend of world business, prospects are hopeful in the cotton trade for the coming year, according to John H. McFadden Jr., president of the New York Cotton Exchange.

One year ago -- Jan. 3, 1935 -- Ethiopia formally appealed to the League of Nations to take measures to preserve the peace against Italian aggression. The protest, it is needless to recall, was of no avail. Italy went to war.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- There release date for the announcement of the second half of the Athletics Red Sox wholesale player deal, set for next Tuesday, was moved up to tonight when Eddie Collins telephoned his old boss, Connie Mack.

With confidence stronger in the outlook for continued business recovery and with retail inventories in sound condition, many thousands of buyers will be in the local markets during the next three weeks. The vanguard of buyers' arrivals this week is expected to be large, with an early peak of buying activity tending to be forecast by the earlier date of Easter.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 4. -- Reuben Fine of New York today drew his game with C.H. Alexander of London in the ninth and final round of the international masters' tournament of the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club, thereby finishing undefeated with a total score of 7 1/2 -- 1 1/2 to capture first prize.

A suit seeking to force the officers and directors of the North American Company, public utility organization, to restore to the company damages estimated at $6,921,146, alleged to have been lost through the stock operations of the Edison Securities Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary, was filed yesterday in Supreme Court.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Society's series of concerts for children and young people will open this Saturday morning at Carnegie Hall, under the direction of Ernest Schelling, with a program designated as an "instrumental resume."

Captain Orvil A. Anderson and Captain Albert W. Stevens, the men who made the recent stratosphere record, were the guests of honor at the thirty-second annual dinner of the Explorers Club last night at the Hotel Plaza. Each of them said they would like to go into the stratosphere again.

Concerted work by Protestant churches in home mission and other fields is praised by the Rev. Dr. Ernest M. Halliday in a New Year's message to the twenty-three denominations represented in the Home Missions Council of the United States and Canada.

EVERY one was bored a year or so ago by the appearance in the daily papers of lists of books which certain literary lights would choose to have with them "if and when" they were cast away on a desert isle. Their tastes were necessarily varied, and everything was mentioned from Amiel's Journal to Clemence Dane's "Broom Stages."

A gloomy picture of the outlook for European peace, with mounting armaments, national fears and political demagoguery overshadowing the sincere desire of the masses for peace, was drawn yesterday by James G. McDonald, until last week League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Coming From Germany.

The course of business activity in the markets for cotton textiles and for all products made of the staple over the next three months will be guided entirely by whatever decision the Supreme Court renders tomorrow or on Jan. 13 on the validity of the Agricultural Administration Act, executives in the local market agreed yesterday.

It was in "Death in a Little Town" that we first met Matilda Perks, the elderly ex-schoolmistress with the sharp tongue and the keenly logical mind, and now we meet her again as the guest of her bachelor nephew, Herbert Ingram Winstanley.

THOUGHTFUL observers are coming around to the view that too much attention has been paid to dictators in the world of letters. Library shelves are filled with books on Mussolini, Hitler, Stalin, while fascism and bolshevism have won the day in the battle of the printed word.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., -- The Sand Hills Steelplechase and Racing Association, headed by Verner Z. Reed as president, Nelson C. Hyde as vice president and Livingston Biddle 2d as treasurer, has announced that the second annual race over brush and timber at the new course on Midland Road will be held on March 14.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP). -- A "who's who among Michigan traffic violators," a permanent record in the Secretary of State's office, is to be a part of the Michigan State Safety Council's drive to curtail traffic accidents.

The swimming team of De Witt Clinton High School, winner last year of the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the Public Schools Athletic League, yesterday moved up from second place in the triborough title series to tie George Washington for the lead by downing Stuyvesant in its home pool.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 4. -- The textile industry has hopes in this new year that the legislative mills will slop grinding so that it can settle itself into natural change, Thomas H. Webb of Concord, N.C., president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association, said today.

Post-holiday retail trade in the metropolitan area did not reveal any marked letdown and good customer response was reported for clearances and offerings of Winter merchandise. Liquor sales picked up sharply following the cut in prices due to the Canadian trade pact.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the recital by Jascha Heifetz, violinist, which will take place the night of Jan. 14 at Carnegie Hall in aid of the Women's Trade Union League. Miss Phyllis Konta heads a group of younger members of society aiding in the sale of tickets for the benefit.

A pleasant story of a family of three, Mrs. Chatton and her two children, Tony and Diana, whose financial losses force them to leave London and go to live at Somerset, where a cousin has left them a house and land.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- The possibility of a complete world-wide embargo on oil shipments to Italy appeared today to be ruled out by President Roosevelt's intimation that the United States would continue to send normal peace-time exports -- League or no League.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, spent a busy day here today conferring with party chieftains over allotment of committee chairmanships in the Assembly in the hope of preventing another party outbreak.

THERE has been so much confusion and misunderstanding about what the Federal Theatre Project is and what it is trying to do that I welcome the invitation of THE NEW YORK TIMES to write an expository piece for the enlightenment of that section of the public which is still interested in the theatre.

SMETANA'S opera, "The Bartered Bride," with an English libretto, will be given in concert form in a subway circuit beginning next Thursday evening at Curtis High School, Staten Island, according to George Crandall, manager of the concert division of the Federal Music Project.

Although midwinter may be cold and bleak and desolate to the devotees of other warm weather seasonal sports, the Northern yachtsman is unknown who doesn't get a new and excited lease on life when January comes around and he begins impatiently to look forward to the National Motor Boat Show in New York.

COMPACT and concise, this small volume collects into its pages an amazing amount of detailed information. It had its origin, Mr. Wills explains, in a course offered by him in 1931 in the School of Education, New York University, on the history of higher education in the United States.

Preparations are now under way for the annual Russian Students' Ball for the benefit of the Russian Student Fund and the Russian Alumni and Student Association. The event will be held on Jan. 24 at the Ritz-Carlton and will mark the fifteenth anniversary of the founding of the fund and of the Russian Student Christian Association and the tenth anniversary of its Alumni Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan 4. -- Rapid increase in the nation's Federal prison population despite prohibition repeal and a heavy rise in the number of officially identified predatory criminals were reported today by Sanford Bates, director of the Bureau of Prisons, and J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Bureau of Investigation, in connection with the annual report of Attorney General Cummings.

MIDDLEBURY, Jan. 4. -- Latin and mathematics will be dropped from the list of required entrance subjects at Middlebury College, beginning with the class of '40, it was announced today. The action was taken by the faculty following the abandonment of the two subjects as graduation requirements.

The first showing here of British photographs from the Royal Photographic Society's 1935 exhibition in London will be opened Wednesday afternoon at 4:30 o'clock in the British Empire Exhibition on the seventh floor of the British Building in Rockefeller Center by Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The year 1936 will be recorded in American history as one in which the United States made its first effort, on a nation-wide basis, to provide some reasonable degree of economic security during unemployment, other than on a relief basis, for those who ordinarily are employed.

ENOUGH gayety and glamour, fun and frolic to furnish a dozen ordinarily happy childhoods were crowded into the lives of the four children who lived in "A Nursery in the Nineties," as Eleanor Farjeon's charming book was called in England.

Two names familiar in the Washington scene and one prominent in international news of the moment will headline the programs of Westchester organizations this week. Tomorrow morning Sir Wilmot Lewis, Washington correspondent for The Times of London, will address the Bronxville Women's Club.

Reports from the leading cities of the country show a decided improvement in municipal finances compared with a year ago. Even those cities which have had a slower recovery are better off than they were, and their remaining difficulties to a large extent are attributed to the unusually heavy blows they suffered at the depth of the depression.

THE $10,000 prize offered for the best first novel in The Pictorial Review-Dodd Mead contest has been awarded to Margaret Flint of Bay St. Louis, Miss., for her novel, "The Old Ashburn Place." Although the author lives in Mississippi, her novel deals with life in rural New England, where she was born.

TURN o' the year -- and time for the new catalogues! To many a home, even where drifts of snow obliterate all semblance of garden beds and borders, their colorful pages bring the cheerful message that another planting season is at least sufficiently near to be looked forward to and planned for.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- While industrial activity in the week ended on Dec. 28 was curtailed by holiday and year-end influences, indications are that the December re cession was probably less than seasonal, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business survey.

The virtual suspension of routine buying of cotton by consumers pending the United States Supreme Court's decisions which are expected tomorrow, caused hedging on the Cotton Exchange yesterday that depressed prices 2 to 8 points.
Thirty-four contributers sent $932.14 yesterday to the Fund for New York's Neediest Cases, increasing the grand total to $247,013.77.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Drastic reorganization of the Pacific Coast locals of the International Seamen's Union as the first step toward breaking the hold of Harry Bridges, left wing leader in the Maritime Federation of the Pacific, will be proposed when the I.S.U. convenes in this city on Jan. 13, it was learned today.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press). -- A retired accountant's clerk who is 72 years old and lives in a small apartment at Guildford, Surrey, has succeeded to one of the oldest titles in Scotland, but with it come neither lands nor money.

MONACO, Dec. 10, 1935. THE subject of Mediterranean music was discussed by Darius Milhaud in an illustrated lecture in connection with the Congress of the Academy of Monaco recently held in the ancient fortress-capital of the diminutive Grimaldi principality, for consideration of the "principles of a Mediterranean humanism."
ORLANDO, Fla. -- Winter guests in this city will lay aside the holiday spirit next week for the seasonal program, which resumes with two amateur golf tournaments for men and women.

The financial position of the leading oil companies was improved last year by the retirement of $341,155,557 of bonds, according to Carl H. Pforzheimer Co. Most of these securities, the firm says were redeemed either through private or bank loans or by public offering of new bonds.

MANY a heart is captured on the rebound, as every veteran fiction reader well knows. But it is a little surprising to find a heart bounding back and forth as the hero's does in Freeman Lincoln's new novel.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4. -- The $1,000 prize of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, given at its annual meeting to the author of "a noteworthy paper" on original research, was awarded today to Dr. P.W. Zimmerman and Dr. A.E. Hitchcock of the Boyce Thompson Institute, Yonkers, N.Y.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 5. -- Either because the New Year celebrations are not yet over or because of failure to realize that parts of it were obviously addressed to Japan the press treats President Roosevelt's message as a matter of American domestic politics.

LONDON, Dec. 13. PERHAPS because the censorship might object to certain parts of it, H.M. Harwood's new play, "These Mortals," was given its first performance by a private society, the Repertory Players. An idea of its kind and purpose may most easily be given by suggesting "Helen of Troy and All That" as an alternative title.

The twelfth annual series of auditions for pianists, violinists, 'cellists and singers "who are of mature talent and ready for professional careers, but who have not already had a New York recital reviewed by critics," was announced yesterday by the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation.

WITH 1936 well launced, and the major Winter wardrobe purchasing over, it only remains to give to the clothes one owns a few rejuvenating touches that they may weather through until the first Spring robin appears.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 3 -- Cincinnati has no Mayor. Nor is there any indication that the near future will see a break in the Council deadlock which has forced this unusual situation upon the Queen City.

Two veterans of world travel will be aboard the Hapag Lloyd liner Reliance as members of her executive staff when the ship sails Thursday on her 40,000-mile trip around the world. Captain Fritz Kruse, her master, will be starting his fifteenth world trip and William Querner, cruise director, his seventh.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,817,629,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The course of municipal credit during the last two years is summarized in a study of State and municipal bonds issued by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company. The report lists year-end prices and yields of selected medium and long-term bonds in each of the forty-eight States having direct debt outstanding and in at least one city in each State.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 5. -- Staging a whirlwind finish which enabled him to establish a new record for the event, Willie Klein of Miami Beach and the Wheatley Hills Golf Club at East Williston, L.I., won the $2,500 seventy-two-hole Miami open golf championship on the course of the Miami Springs Country Club today.

Vito Genchi scored four goals to lead the Brooklyn Hockey Club to a 6-0 victory over the Jamaica Eagles last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. The triumph was the fourth in as many starts for the winners in the Brooklyn-Long Island Hockey League.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 5. -- Jimmy Hines, former Long Island caddie, won the Riverside $3,000 open golf tournament today with a score of 276 for seventy-two holes, 12 strokes under par.
The University of Toronto hockey team will clash with Princeton at Madison Square Garden tonight in the only college game scheduled for the Eighth Avenue arena this season.

While activity in the local wholesale markets slowed down somewhat last week, the cold weather in many sections of the country revived the demand for Winter clothing and substantial orders were placed on these items. Men's overcoats, for instance, were bought freely at a time when demand for these types has usually subsided.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 5. -- After being thwarted by unfavorable weather conditions for several weeks, the Manhasset Bay frostbite dinghy fleet resumed activities today, a brisk northwest wind and clear skies greeting the hardy skippers and their crews.

The hall of the Brooklyn Labor Lyceum, 949 Willoughby Avenue, resounded with the cooing of 800 pigeons yesterday as the Brooklyn Concourse Association opened its thirteenth annual open homing pigeon show. The association also is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 5 (AP). -- A charge that the Scottsboro case is being exploited by Communist organizers in a revival of efforts to gain converts in Alabama was made today on the eve of the reappearance in court of the nine Negro defendants accused of attacking two white women.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- Episcopalians composing the Church Unity Octave Council, which recently characterized American Protestantism as "bankrupt" and appealed for a reunion with the Roman Catholic Church, were accused here today of "promoting disunion rather than reunion."

ROME, Jan. 5. -- The second month of sanctions is drawing to a close without any visible sign of a weakening in the Italian determination to see things through to the end. Complaints, grumblings and criticisms of some detail or other of the government's policies are heard sporadically here and there, but they are not intense enough or widespread enough to be taken as evidence of any substantial change in Italian public opinion.

The city's credit is once more in the "gilt-edge category" and its bonds may be expected to rise rapidly in value so that refunding will make possible in the near future a substantial reduction of outstanding bonded debt, Controller Frank J. Taylor declared in a report made public yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 5. -- French delegates to the Naval Conference were ready tonight to do most of the talking at Clarence House, where the second stage of the parley opens tomorrow.
The sale of a downtown loft building, a West Side housing lease and various transactions in the Bronx were announced over the week-end.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, was still conferring on chairmanships of Assembly committees late tonight as the members of the Legislature began drifting back into town for the second week of the 1936 session.

A plan of reorganization for the American Writing Paper Company, Inc., has been filed in Federal Court in Massachusetts under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, it was announced yesterday. Under the plan a new company will be formed in which will be vested substantially all of the properties of the old company except three mills at Holyoke and two mill sites in Connecticut.

Searchlights from police launches played on the black tide off Gouverneur Slip and the prying beams of hand flashlights illuminated littered cellars and vacant flats on the East Side last night as more than 400 detectives and patrolmen hunted for Jacob Horowitz, 10 months old, of 364 Madison Street.
It will take the automobile industry two years at least to equip the country with up-to-date transport equipment, Charles W. Nash, chairman of Nash Motors Company, said in a year-end statement.
Thirty-five contributions, totaling $543.55, increased the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to $247,557.32.

Although Glenn Cunningham's victory over Chuck Hornbestel in the 800-meter invitation run in Brooklyn Saturday night was, more or less, a hollow one, the Kansan left the impression that he is ready for another great year on the boards.

BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 5. -- General Vincencio Perez Soto, Governor of the rich oil State of Zulia in Venezuela during the Gomez regime, who was forced to resign after General Juan Vicente Gomez's death, has been appointed Governor of the State of Lara, according to information received here by air mail.

The Job of moving the Federal courts and other government agencies into the new Federal Building at Foley Square, which starts today, will require 150 men working at least twelve hours a day, and the use of twenty vans to carry more than 22,000 packing cases in 1,250 loads.
Brooklyn industrial properties were taken in leasing contracts announced by brokers.

Man is inevitably religious and it is bad psychology as well as false theology to say that any man has no religion, the Rev. Dr. Rockwell Harmon Potter of the Hartford (Conn.) Congregational Theological Seminary said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71.4 on Jan. 1, against 71.4 a fortnight before, 71.1 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
N.Y.U. further added to its laurels during the past week in intercollegiate basketball circles and L.I.U. and St. John's continued unbeaten. Fordham lost for the first time.

One of the season's largest crowds saw what was probably amateur hockey's finest game of the current campaign yesterday as Hershey gained a 1-to-0 triumph over the New York Rovers in the feature contest of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP). -- Dr. A.P. Haake, managing director of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers, predicted today an increase of at least 30 per cent in furniture sales in 1936.

The gondola of the balloon Explorer II, in which Captain Albert W. Stevens and Captain Orvil A. Anderson made their record stratosphere flight, was installed in the sunken plaza of Rockefeller Center yesterday morning. It will be on exhibition there until the end of this month.

The Lehman Corporation, an investment company managed by the banking firm of Lehman Brothers, reports that on Dec. 31, 1935, the net asset value of its stock was $111.34 a share, after allowing $6.15 a share for taxes and other expenses, computed on unrealized appreciation of securities held.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines reported today that unemployment among ex-service men "has greatly stimulated the demands for the cash payment of the adjusted service certificates."

Seven awards for achievements in civil engineering will be presented at the opening session of the eighty-third annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, which will take place from Jan. 15 to 18 in the society's headquarters, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 5. -- The Montclair Athletic Club and Plainfield Country Club lead the New Jersey Division of the Metropolitan Class B Squash Racquets League as a result of today's play.

PARIS, Jan. 3. -- Financial circles here are making no effort to forecast gold migrations in 1936 throughout the world. It is considered that the United States most likely will continue to receive the metal from Europe by reason of its normally favorable trade balance, also by reason of its economic recovery backed by a general confidence for its continuance.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- United States Ambassador Robert W. Bingham and Mrs. Bingham were among the hundreds of persons who flocked from London today to watch Ishbel MacDonald, the daughter of Ramsay MacDonald, former Prime Minister and now Lord President of the Council, in action for the first time as proprietress of Ye Olde Plow Inn in the heart of the Buckinghamshire countryside.

For seventy minutes last night the Rangers and the Americans battered away at each other. They packed as much action into the game as any one would want to see, but there was no score and so the New York rivals had to skate off the Madison Square Garden ice deadlocked at 0 to 0.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries report for the year ended on Nov. 30 a balance of $1,443,406 available for parent company preferred dividend requirements of $2,323,537, against $972,090 in the preceding year, after all prior deductions including unearned and unpaid preferred dividends of certain subsidiaries.

A gift of $10,000 by Mr. and Mrs. George F. Baker, an additional gift of $3,500 from Harold S. Vanderbilt and an additional $5,000 from an anonymous donor for the United Hospital Campaign were announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the campaign committee which is seeking to raise a minimum of $2,000,000 to meet the financial crisis confronting the voluntary hospitals of the city.

Outstanding artists of the operatic and concert stage checked their dignity at the cloak room of the Hotel Waldorf Astoria last night to pay tribute to Mrs. Vincent Astor at a dinner and entertainment arranged in recognition of her services to music.

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- New Year business analyses and forecasts, including those from official and banking sources and by the press set the Ethiopian question in the foreground as a factor which has most materially affected international trade and is destined to be a determining influence on the world's economy in the coming months.

A telegram urging Senator William E. Borah of Idaho to become an active candidate for the Republican nomination for President was sent to him yesterday, following a dinner for his supporters given by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. at the Harvard Club Saturday night.

CAIRO, Jan. 5. -- Egyptians were angered today by the news of the Italian bombing of the Egyptian Red Crescent medical mission in Ethiopia. The mission, which left here about three months ago, headed by Prince Ismail Daoud, a member of the royal family, was composed of Moslem and Coptic Christian doctors and men nurses.

Judged from the necessarily meager data provided since the month began, the new year is beginning hopefully. On the stock market, a spirit of cheerfulness prevailed in the three days after Jan. 1. The averages advanced -- this despite reconvening of Congress on Friday, and a "fighting message" from the President that same evening, and notwithstanding also promise of an early "bonus drive."

By breaking 99 out of 100 targets, P. Garino won the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Then came A.L. Burns, who finished with 97. Ten gunners tied for the handicap trophy, each with 100 full targets.

PARIS, Jan. 5. -- The report current tonight in the Jewish community of London regarding German suggestions for mass deportations of Jews in Germany is not taken too seriously by leading Jews of France. They regard the suggestions as economically impossible and the motive alleged to have inspired them as too transparent to obtain any official backing.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The Jewish communities of Great Britain and the United States are about to be confronted with the gravest problem they have faced since the World War brought turmoil to the life of Europe. They will have to make a decision involving mental anguish whichever way it may fall, and the fate of the Jews of Germany will hang on it.

PARIS, Jan. 3. -- In the face of the drop in foreign exchanges at the beginning of the week and the complete cessation of the gold exodus, the Bank of France decided on Tuesday to lower its discount rate from 6 to 5 per cent, this becoming effective yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- McGill University's powerful hockey team had little trouble putting the Dartmouth College sextet to rout tonight before a crowd of almost 2,000 which jammed the Playland Casino rink. The score was 12 to 2. Campbell Dickison scored four goals.
Eight dual matches have been carded for the New York University varsity fencers and six dual tests have been listed for the Violet freshman team, according to schedules announced yesterday.

The appearance of the late Charles R. Miller, editor-in-chief of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1883 to 1922, before a Senate investigating committee at Washington in 1915 was dramatized last night in a radio program, "Echoes of New York Town," broadcast over WEAF.

A sharp increase in the spread between nearby futures contracts and the distant positions was the feature of trading in the cotton futures market last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange, net price changes for the week were from 19 points up to 7 points down.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- The twelfth annual meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board here Wednesday and Thursday will bring together about 500 Eastern industrial and railroad representatives to consider various important transportation matters and present the outlook for some forty commodity groups that are expected to be moved in this territory during the first quarter of 1936.

Brisk gains in reviving activity were features in the trading on the local commodity exchanges last week. An exception to this trend were the metals, which eased, and sugar, which was virtually unchanged Sluggishness in the latter was ascribed to trade uncertainty over the effects of a possible adverse Supreme Court decision on the processing tax issue, which may be handed down today.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Republican State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton met the new drive of Representative Hamilton Fish for the Presidential nomination of Senator William E. Borah with a firm reiteration of his stand that New York delegates to the national convention must be uninstructed and unpledged.

A year ago the Charity Organization Society approved the tentative use of the name "Institute of Family Service" for the family department of the society. The reason for making this experimental change was that many people came to the society who did not want "charity" as the word is usually defined.

Employment and payrolls throughout the country will be 95 per cent of normal within twelve months if the 1935 rate of recovery continues, but New York State will require four years to reach 95 per cent of normal unless business revival in this State is speeded up, it was declared yesterday by Bailey B. Burritt, general director of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.
WESTFIELD, Mass., Monday, Jan. 6. -- Six bodies had been recovered early today from the ruins of the Van Deusen Hotel, which flames destroyed late last night. At least one other person was missing.

Ellis Parker, the Burlington County, N.J., detective who began to be active in the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann early in December, had luncheon yesterday with C. Lloyd Fisher, chief defense counsel, in Flemington, N.J.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade last week closed within a fraction of the top of the week, with the exception of July oats, which cost 3/8 cent a bushel. Quotations for the week follow:

State ownership of the currently "leased" Federal emergency landing fields that dot the air mail routes, their equipment with hard surface runways and a provision for clearing them of snow in Winter, was urged yesterday in the annual report of the New York State Aviation Commission to Governor Herbert H. Lehman.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 5. -- Official Ethiopian communiques announced today that the "whole town" of Daggah Bur and its Egyptian Red Crescent unit had been destroyed by a deluge of Italian aerial bombs.

The season for round-the-world cruises will get under way tonight with the departure of the Cunard White Star liner Franconia on a voyage of 34,500 miles with about 300 passengers. This is the tenth world cruise the Franconia has made since the line entered the field in 1924.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 48 per cent of capacity for a six-day week, against 50 per cent for the five working days of the preceding week and 56 per cent for each of the two weeks before.

An order just issued by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Department sets up definite terms of the Supreme Court in Kings and Queens Counties for the trial of condemnation proceedings instituted by the City of New York for taking property for public uses during this year, continues the designation of Justice Charles C. Lockwood as the Presiding Justice at these terms.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- Dr. S.M. Berry, Moderator of the Federal Council of Evangelical Free Churches, declared today that Pope Pius had refused to cooperate in today's "Peace Day" observances in which European Protestant Churches participated.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- P.M. McHugh was the principal winner at the traps of the Westchester Country Club today, taking the high scratch cups at singles and doubles, breaking 92 and 45, respectively. The handicap singles prize was captured by G. Pinner, while R.E. Boesel defeated C.M. Loeb, 42 to 36, to triumph in the doubles.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 5. -- Extermination of racketeers before they become powerful enough to usurp control of the city was demanded in a county grand jury report placed in the hands of Minneapolis law enforcement agencies today.
Earle A. Miller is with Williams, Bailey Benjamin as manager of their public-utility preferred stock department.

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- Last year witnessed further consolidation of the position of the Hitler regime in the economic domain and, except for the scarcity of certain foodstuffs in the Autumn and Winter, no acute troubles developed. Government regulation of trade increased, but in the main it was confined to issues raised by the shortage of foreign exchange and the ideological conflict between Nazi socialism and capitalism.

An offer of a $5,000 scholarship in any American college or university for an essay on the subject "How Can America Stay Out of War?" was made last night by Eddie Cantor, stage, screen and radio comedian. The offer, a personal one, with "no commercial affiliation whatsoever," according to the comedian, was made at the close of his regular broadcast over the WABC-Columbia network.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 4. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84, which compares with 84.1 the week before, 84.4 two weeks before, 84 three weeks before and 84.6 four weeks before.

The world consumption of all growths of cotton from Aug. 1 to Nov. 30, constituting the first third of the current season, was almost at the highest rate on record for that part of the season, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

A Negro who described himself as Professor Rouse Samuels, 30 years old, of 317 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, and laid claim to the title of "master mind" because of his ability to see into the future, was held in $1,000 bail in Washington Heights Court yesterday for trial in Special Sessions on a charge of practicing medicine without a license.

Foreign exchanges moved irregularly last week and at the close the mixed list of advances and declines was unimportant in size. Business was small, giving effect to the holiday, Swiss bank difficulties and continued complications in the Italo-Ethiopian situation.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- As the implications of the United States Neutrality Bill continued to be studied today, it began to dawn upon the people of this island that Britain would be placed in the same class with an aggressor in case she should be drawn into military or naval sanctions on behalf of the League of Nations.

The Church of Christ must confess its social responsibility to exist usefully in this age, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver said yesterday in a sermon at the Old John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street.

While motor-vehicle fatalities reached a new high mark of about 36,400 in 1935, according to the preliminary report of the National Safety Council, the death rate was about the same as in 1934, due to the estimated increase in population, while the number of deaths in proportion to mileage actually dropped, since gasoline consumption increased 6 per cent over 1934.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5. -- Coincident with the protest of Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Foreign Commissar, filed with the League of Nations as a result of the break in relations between Russia and Uruguay, the Rio de Janeiro press offered today to provide Uruguay with additional proof that Soviet agents were responsible for the revolt in Brazil last November.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- The National Executive Committee of the Socialist party, by a vote of 8 to 2, tonight deposed the party State committee of New York, headed by Louis Waldman, and appointed in its place a temporary committee of fifteen to run the State organization under a party receivership.

In The Nineteenth Century Mr. OSBERT BURDETT has an article, a full meal rather, "Cheese and Beer and Wine." These must be Mr. PRIESTLEY'S "Good Companions." In the days before automobiles the traveler on the rolling English roads, refreshing himself with bread and cheese and bitter, had an ample as well as simple feast for all the senses.
A variety of realty, including vacant lots, houses and a taxpayer, was sold in New Jersey over the week-end.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- City Controller S. Davis Wilson immediately after his inauguration as Mayor tomorrow will send an order to his cabinet members instructing them to "readjust the personnel" of their departments in accordance with provisions of the 1936 budget, which eliminated several hundred positions.

Pearl S. Buck's new book is a biography of her mother, but it will be published next month by John Day: Reynal Hitchcock with the format of a novel. The facts were gathered from family records, diaries and the author's memories, but the names of characters have been changed.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 5. -- Luis Baese de la Cuadra, Chilean gigolo who inherited a million-dollar estate from his elderly Belgian benefactor, was deprived of the legacy today by the Appeals Court.

Ludlow Shonnard of 15 Park Avenue, retired executive of the Otis Elevator Company, was killed yesterday in an automobile accident at Katonah, N.Y., when his machine left the highway of Route 118, plunged down a thirty-foot embankment and hurtled over rocks and gullies into the Croton Reservoir.

The first in a series of Wednesday morning lectures on the arrangement of flowers for the benefit of the Hudson River Community Music School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will take place on Jan. 15 at the Colony Club, this city. It will be given by Mrs. Yoneo Arai of the Japanese Women's Club.

A series of cartoon poster stamps attacking the New Deal, promoting the cause of the Republican party and editorializing on current issues, which have been issued by the National Republican Council to be used on mail by opponents of the Roosevelt administration, are available for use only at the mercy of Postmaster General Farley, Democratic National Chairman, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The naval conference will reassemble tomorrow with agreement as far off as ever and with no progress made toward averting the deadlock that became apparent even before the opening session a month ago.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5. -- America's tennis ace, Wilmer Allison, conqueror of England's Fred Perry, fell before the dogged driving of youthful Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., in a grueling four-set duel in the final of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today.

The Rev. Dr. Fridolin E. Oberlander, pastor of the St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street, explained in German to his congregation yesterday morning that there would not be any confusion in Ethiopia, or threats of another major conflict, if many statesmen did not "use language so as to conceal thought" as King Herod did.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- The bullish aspects in the world's wheat situation continue to develop fairly rapidly, and the change that has come about in the foreign demand for overseas grain since the announcement that the Argentine Government would pay 90 cents a bushel for this year's crop in that country is now regarded as one of the most drastic witnessed in years.

The Charity Organization Society announced yesterday that its family service department would operate henceforth under the name of the Institute of Family Service as the result of a quiet test of the new name during the past year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- A warning to prepare against the overthrow of church by State was sounded tonight by George Cardinal Mundelein in his annual message to 3,000 members of the Holy Name Society of the Chicago Archdiocese at the Holy Name Cathedral.

A revision of the examination system for high school teaching licenses to permit examiners to find "the inspired teacher" as against the teacher with only "a fact-absorbing brain" is urged in an article in the current issue of the monthly civil service magazine, The Answer, published and edited by B. Barnett Newman, a former teacher.

The Cunard White Star liner Franconia will arrive today from England and France and sails at midnight on her world cruise via the Southern Hemisphere with 300 passengers. Prominent persons due to arrive today on the Franconia include:

Will you publish a brief observation by a resident Englishman on an aspect of American neutrality which, to the best of my belief, has passed almost without consideration in the press of this country?

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Although, generally speaking, the financial and industrial outlook for 1936 appears moderately good, it varies considerably in different countries. Abroad, there still are confusion and uncertainty in finance and politics. In Great Britain, there are political stability and rising industrial prosperity.

Two major Jewish groups backed yesterday the plea of James G. McDonald, who resigned last week as League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (Jews and Others) Coming from Germany, for vigorous intercession by the League to end persecution of Jews and other "non-Aryan" residents of Germany.

Immediate passage by the State Legislature of a bill which would permit unescorted children under 16 years of age to attend motion picture theatres under proper supervision was urged yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- With the budget, the soldiers' bonus, and neutrality legislation under the spotlight, Congress will reassemble tomorrow amid a sharply partisan atmosphere for what promises to be a lively and perhaps historic week.

One of the major activities of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in 1936 will be to give further impetus to the movement initiated last Autumn to bring about the nomination and election of experienced and representative business men to Congress, according to an announcement made yesterday by Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the chamber, who is also president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The "decisive role" played by the Roosevelt administration in Cuban affairs will be difficult for it to justify in this year's Presidential campaign in the United States if constitutional government is not established in the island republic as a result of the forthcoming elections there, the Foreign Policy Association declared in a report issued today on "The Cuban Revolution."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Net disbursements of the Veterans Administration for all purposes during the fiscal year 1935, which ended last June 30, aggregated $618,522,341.50, according to the annual report issued today by Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs.
The administration of criminal justice in New York City is in the hands of "a lawless, corrupt and indefensibly rotten political machine," the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise declared yesterday.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Jan. 5. -- A report that no Swedes were killed in the Dolo bombing, where a Swedish hospital tent was hit, was received here with utmost satisfaction. The early report caused dismay for the deplorable effect of such news on world opinion is fully realized.
Man advances by intelligent peace, not by wars, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie asserted in his sermon yesterday morning at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and East Tenth Street.

A campaign to exert political pressure on Congress and State Legislatures to equalize competition between railroads and other carriers will be started immediately by the Society of Officers of the United Associations of Railroad Veterans, representing 900,000 railroad employes with twenty years or more experience.
Two statements made by me on the subject of minimum wage legislation from which erroneous conclusions have been drawn by Mrs. Jane Norman Smith of the National Woman's Party need clarification.

SO far in the Winter baseball sessions not a single big league manager has been heaved out into the snow, which may be a new indoor record. The incumbents appear to be sitting fairly comfortably by the fireside undisturbed by irate owners. Possibly the return of prosperity has softened the dispositions of the club owners.

T.E. McClintock, president of the Denver, Col., Joint Stock Land Bank, has notified holders of bonds issued or assumed by the bank of a plan for voluntary liquidation of the bank and readjustment of its obligations. The plan provides for an exchange of bonds for certificates of indebtedness which would permit distribution to participating holders, from time to time as funds accumulate, of the proceeds of the liquidation.
It will help to set the stage for the budget message which Mr. ROOSEVELT plans to send to Congress today if the traditional procedure in this matter is briefly summarized.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5. -- Two feminists, allegedly behind a movement which police have characterized as a "women's revolt," were in jail here tonight.

OGDEN, Utah, Jan. 5. -- Former President Herbert Hoover tonight attacked President Roosevelt's Friday night message to Congress as one of "ill will," and said that new powers vested in the administration "never should be possessed by anybody in these United States."

ROME, Jan. 5. -- Further casualty lists, made public today, bring the total number of officers and men who lost their lives in active service in Africa up to Dec. 31 to 390, to whom must be added fourteen who are unaccounted for, making a total of 404.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- Alba B. Johnson, retired president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works and president of the State Chamber of Commerce, who died on Jan. 8 last, left a personal estate of $2,812,675, according to an inventory and account filed at Norristown.

Nearly 200 persons interested in the proposed New Jersey Federal subsistence homestead community project for garment workers met yesterday at 91 East Fourth Street to discuss means of expediting action on the proposal.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 5. -- When Eduardo Suarez, Mexican Minister of Finance, flew to Washington several days ago with his family, it was explained in official quarters here that he was "taking a short holiday."

Walter Esposito, 2-year-old son of Mrs. Adele Esposito of 748 Greene Avenue, near Sumner Avenue, Brooklyn, spent three hours yesterday afternoon eating lollypops and watching the sale of tickets in the cashier's booth of a movie theatre near his home while his tearful mother, anxious neighbors and puzzled detectives searched for him, fearing a kidnapping.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5. -- President Roosevelt's message and the details of the new United States Neutrality Bill were published here only today, but much prominence was given to them, and they were accompanied by cabled comment from London, Paris, Berlin, Rome and Tokyo.

Victor C. Leroy, 39 years old, a bank clerk, of 754 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, was arraigned in the Flatbush Court yesterday morning, charged with petit larceny. The specific complaint was that he had taken a bottle of milk from outside the apartment of William Hargrave, an engineer, in the same building.
The New York Americans, leaders in the American Soccer League, nosed out the St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn, 1 to 0, at Starlight Park yesterday before 3,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Decisions involving the future of two of the central pillars of the New Deal structure and affecting the 130,000,000 people resident in the continental United States may be handed down tomorrow when the Supreme Courts convenes after a two-week recess.

The first Sunday of the new year should be a time of "good wishes for our friends and good resolutions for ourselves," the Rev. Thomas L. Graham declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin took up a vigorous defense today of the Patman Bonus Bill and declared that President Roosevelt "put himself on the spot" Friday night when he lashed out at the "money changers" in his message to Congress.
The American cousin team of Jimmy and Bobby Walthour annexed the thirty-mile international motorpaced team relay race which featured the cycling program at the New York Coliseum last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- A Neutrality Bill setting forth rigid standards of Executive procedure in efforts to keep the United States from involvement in a foreign war will be introduced in both houses of Congress tomorrow. Its sponsors in the Senate will be Senators Nye and Clark, and Representative Maverick of Texas will introduce it in the House.
" Truly Valiant," the Irving Stone play which Gustav Blum had planned to present this evening, has been postponed. Thursday night, at the Forty-ninth Street, is the date now given for its premiere.

That deservedly popular duo-piano team, Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, appeared in recital yester day afternoon at the Town Hall, where their delightful artistry captivated a large audience. Without fuss or feathers or any attempt at display for its own sake, the talented English couple went through their interesting program with rare unanimity of spirit and perfection in ensemble.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Officers and directors of registered public utility holding companies were called upon today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to show the extent of their equities in parent or subsidiary concerns in excess of 10 per cent, and to keep the commission currently informed of any changes in such stock holdings.
The navy seems safe for the more Spartan seadogs.

All those liberal Republicans who have learned from Mr. BORAH'S precise definition that a liberal is not a conservative are waiting hopefully to see millions rise in their might and force the nomination of Lone Chief. In Maine, carried weeks ago by his mathematicians, the invisibility of the risers is as yet complete.

PARIS, Jan. 2. -- Before the debate in the Chamber of Deputies which culminated on Dec. 27 in a victory for the Laval government, a wave of pessimism swept over France and the appreciation of the dollar caused some small withdrawals of gold.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP). -- After spotting the Chicago Black Hawks a two-goal lead, the world champion Montreal Maroons came raging back to punch out a 3-to-2 victory in a rough, ragged and highly entertaining National League Hockey match tonight in the Chicago Stadium.
Hunters in New York State shot 7,110 deer during the 1935 season, the Conservation Department reported yesterday after final tabulation of the figures. The kill was 985 under the total for 1934.

After the holiday lull, the art world of New York has awakened to some two-score exhibitions, what with the shows opening in the next day or two and those initiated over the week-end. A number of group shows and at least one new venture are among the number, and several hardy perennials make their appearance.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- A program of aid for the municipalities of the State was presented today to Governor Lehman and the Legislature by the State Conference of Mayors. The program, approved among others by Mayor La Guardia, called for broadening the municipal tax base, severely restricting mandatory State increases in the cost of local government and limiting municipal borrowing power.

Mayor La Guardia is prepared to renew, in more drastic form and with more powerful support, last year's drive to strip the Transit Commission of all jurisdiction over the unification of rapid transit lines.

The modernist in physics no longer talks of silver but of silvers. There is a heavy silver and a light silver, chemically indistinguishable from each other, the one outweighing the other in the ratio of 109 to 107. Professor ARTHUR J. DEMPTSTER of the University of Chicago, an expert in these matters, rose at St. Louis to tell the American Association for the Advancement of Science that something ought to be done about this.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 5. -- The Socialist party, through an official party observer, proposed to the third Congress Against War and Fascism today "a broad federation of all peace and anti-Fascist forces, centered about the trade unions as the basic organizations."

An exhortation to Christians to exert an active and beneficial influence in the world and to resist pagan forces was voiced yesterday morning by the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in his sermon at St. Thomas Chapel, 226 East Sixtieth Street.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 5. -- Several hundred persons attended a reception given by Miss Margaret Mallory, Miss Barbara Mallory and Clifford D. Mallory Jr. at their home here this afternoon for the twenty-fifth wedding anniversary of their parents, Commodore and Mrs. Clifford D. Mallory.
On Jan. 1 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a statement made by the Rev. Dr. Edward Roberts Moore, director division of social action of the Catholic Charities of the New York Archdiocese.

The program that Sir Thomas Beecham conducted at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon and Saturday evening might well be termed the second in his visit with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, for it was changed completely from that of his opening pair last Thursday evening and Friday afternoon.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 5. -- Johnny Weissmuller's fourteen-year-old national seventy-five-yard back-stroke swimming record was lowered today by Adolph Kiefer, Chicago high school boy, in the final time trials of the Orlando Olympic stars' aquatic meet.
The story of Sarah Victor threads back to the rim of slave days in the South, but for most purposes begins somewhere in New York a quarter-century ago.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 5. -- For the second year in succession Donald Strachan, the national champion, and his partner, Brendon R. Walsh of Philadelphia, carried off the honors in the annual Greenwich invitation squash racquets doubles tourney today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP). -- The Democratic party will try to eat itself out of debt Wednesday night.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 5. -- One of the largest fields of the Winter took part in the open shoot of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. In the skeet event the best work was done by A. Snouder, who returned a card of 47, 5 -- 50. He took the scratch trophy, the other gunners with 50 full targets competing for the handicap prize.

PARIS, Jan. 5. -- Almost without exception all comment in today's French newspapers and in diplomatic and parliamentary circles on President Roosevelt's message to Congress and on the neutrality bill is far more concerned with whether the neutrality of the United States will be prejudicial to France in time of war than whether it will add strength to the existing machinery for preventing war.

TORONTO, Jan. 5 (Canadian Press). -- The order of finish in the National Hockey League race, beginning with this season, will determine the amount of money the first, second and third place teams in each group will receive. The money is a proportion of play-off and Stanley Cup receipts.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- Cornelius Shields in Prudence and Walter Rowe in Liza carried off the honors in their respective divisions today in the Frostbite dinghy races held under the auspices of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

More than once during the last few years the Municipal Art Society has suggested the possibility of placing all of the properties abutting on City Hall Park within the jurisdiction of the Art Commission; in other words, making it necessary that all plans for new buildings or exterior alterations of existing properties facing on the park be subject to the approval of the Art Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 5. -- Editorials in Argentine newspapers say all South America unites in supporting the policies set forth in President Roosevelt's address to Congress. La Nacion says Mr. Roosevelt had previously demonstrated his belief in the inter-American relationship that should exist among all American nations when he abolished dollar diplomacy and instituted the good-neighbor policy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Important objectives set for itself two years ago by the Labor Department were attained in the year ending June 30, 1935, Secretary Perkins stated in her annual report made public today.

In one of your editorials of Dec. 29 you described the measures by means of which in Nazi Germany science has been "coordinated" with Nazi doctrines and international scientific conventions are to be exploited by tamed German scholars to spread the Nazi doctrine among foreigners.

President ROOSEVELT must have anticipated tart comments from Europe. No nation, no Government, likes to be made the subject, even indirectly, of such remarks as Mr. ROOSEVELT made in his message to Congress. He spoke in the true Wilsonian tradition. Lord ROSEBERY once said that England had reserved to herself the right to read a moral lecture to European countries.

The arraignment on charges of burglary of two former convicts, both released from jail only recently, before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in the West Side Court yesterday drew the following comment from the magistrate:

An offering to the public will be made today of a new issue of $900,000 city of Waterbury (Conn.) funding and improvement bonds, due on Jan. 15, 1937 to 1966, by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; Goldman, Sachs Co., Darby Co. and the R.F. Griggs Company of Waterbury.

The city's schools and particularly the high schools face the worst overcrowding in their history when they begin the new term on Feb. 3, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools. He held the current strike of electrical workers against fifteen school projects largely responsible.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- A stronger tone developed last week in the market for hogs here, shippers, packers and butchers buying fairly, and prices on Friday advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, the latter on butchers' hogs weighing around 232 pounds.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 5 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings, with a third period scoring burst which produced three goals, defeated the Montreal Canadien, 5 -- 2, before 9,000 spectators tonight to take sole possession of the lead in the National Hockey League's American Group.

The darksome mirrors lining the back bar at Billy Ray's Baymen's Rest Hotel and Cafe in Canarsie are no longer to be trusted, what with the propensity of the gray little proprietor for peopling his dimly lighted place with every sort of varmint and crittur -- man, beast or robot -- that finds its way down to the Jamaica Bay end of Rockaway Avenue.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Because the Bank of England recently ceased buying gold, opinion here had it that the institution was satisfied with its stronger gold reserve position built up through its purchases since last August. But this impression was modified during the week when further moderate purchases of the metal were made.

KREFELD, Germany, Jan. 5. -- Only a little more than a year after Vittorio Giannini's "Lucedia" was given in Munich, Nazi Germany heard tonight the first performance of an operatic work by another American as "Leon and Edrita," a four-act opera by the New York composer, Charles Frick-Steger, received its world premiere in the Krefeld Municipal Theatre.

After a conference yesterday of school officials and a representative of labor it was announced that "progress has been made" toward the settlement of a strike of 125 electrical workers on school building projects. A decision will be made at a meeting of union members on Thursday night in the Central Opera House, 205 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Prices of food, textile and tobacco stocks advanced sharply yesterday in response to the decision of the Supreme Court scrapping the AAA. Other groups of stocks advanced for a short time, and then sagged abruptly, as it became apparent that the court's ruling not only invalidated the processing taxes levied by the AAA, but also outlawed benefit payments to farmers, through which the purchasing power of rural areas has been sustained.
Last Friday evening I listened to President Roosevelt's address to Congress with a sense of keen disappointment.

New York University still is unbeaten on the court and looks very much as though it might stay that way for quite some time. And yet there is a strong group which believes very firmly that the University of Kentucky quintet is the one that will perform the feat of snapping that long Violet streak.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Resettlement Administration, headed by Rexford Guy Tugwell, announced today a program including 228 projects for rural families, and the transfer to an inactive list of 26 projects and 19 proposals for subsistence homesteads.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 6. -- Lester Wallace, retired vice president of the New York importing firm of Old Wallace, was found dead here today of carbon monoxide poisoning in the garage of his home at 115 Ridgewood Avenue. The police listed the death as a suicide.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- A bitter fight for control of the national convention of the Socialist party between the left wing national committee, dominated by Norman Thomas, and the New York "Old Guard," headed by Louis Waldman and supported by members in other States, began to take form today following suspension by the NEC meeting here last night of the charter of the New York organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP). -- William F. Wigmore of the New York Curb Exchange testified before the Securities Commission today that M.J. Meehan, Wall Street operator accused of rigging Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock, bought and sold the stock in the same telephone conversation with him last year.
Manhattan's unbeaten basketball team won its seventh straight game last night, defeating Brooklyn College, 25-23, on the home court before 1,000 persons.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 (AP). -- The magazine Steel predicted today a year "at least 10 per cent better than 1935" for the steel industry in 1936.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Abbot Low Moffat, representating the Fifteenth, banner Republican district of Manhattan, was appointed chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly this evening by Speaker Ives, who made the announcement from the Assembly rostrum soon after the night session began.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- A record national shoe fair got under way today under the joint auspices of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association and the National Shoe Retailers Association, with about 800 exhibitors and an estimated 10,000 buyers in attendance.

CHICAGO, Jan, 6. -- A sharp advance in the price of hogs followed the announcement of the Supreme Court decision holding the Agricultural Adjustment Act unconstitutional. Early sales showed a loss of 25 cents a hundred weight or more compared with Friday's levels, and with a top of $9.55. It was estimated 80 to 90 per cent of the receipts were sold before the decision was announced.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 6. -- Mrs. Francoise M.D. Barstow, wife of William Slocum Barstow, retired utility official and president of the Edison Pioneers, has donated a site and a clubhouse to the Woman's Club of Great Neck, of which she is a charter member and former president, it was announced today by Mrs. A. Bruce Bielaski, chairman of the building committee.

BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- The project for a mass exodus of Jews from Germany and the transfer of the property by increased German exports has aroused considerable interest in German official quarters. It was said it was important and contained possibilities that would have to be studied thoroughly before a definite decision could be rendered regarding its feasibility.
MERION, Pa., Jan. 6. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, women's national golf champion, said today that motherhood has improved her game.

President ROOSEVELT submitted to Congress yesterday a budget which leaves in mid-air the most important fiscal question before the Government. It is that of relief expenditures. It is the Government's outlay on this account that caused the enormous deficit of 1935 and now forces the Treasury to borrow heavily in 1936.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 6. -- After defeating the New Jersey women's squash racquets team by 6 -- 1 in the morning, the New York players won from their Westchester rivals by a one-match margin in the afternoon, 4 -- 3, to emerge victorious in the triangular metropolitan team series for the second year in succession.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court by a 4-to-3 decision today declared unconstitutional the legislative act passed last Spring creating a State authority to condemn land, issue bonds and engage in various enterprises with Federal funds.

Police seemed convinced last night that Jackie Horowitz, 10 months old, who was stolen in his perambulator from in front of 45 Gouverneur Street on Sunday afternoon, lies somewhere, in the East River.

Thirty-eight South African mining students stood at the top of the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon and peered into a snowstorm. Tiring of this, they transferred their interest to a voice recording machine which shook, along with the tower and everybody in it, when they began shouting this university "war cry": Umpoe quoni noni tenea

READING, Pa., Jan. 6. -- Action of the Socialist National Executive Committee in Philadelphia yesterday, revoking the charter of the New York State party, was reflected in today's inauguration of Socialist city officials here. It prevented the holding of a proposed friendly meeting of party chiefs at odds over the New York troubles.

The Lawyers Trust Company, known as the Lawyers County Trust Company before a change in name effective on Dec. 25 last, reports as of Dec. 31 deposits of $38,094,088 and resources of $42,611,561, compared, respectively, with $33,501,236 and $37,718,963 on Dec. 31, 1934.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- In an atmosphere of tranquillity President Roosevelt received word of the Supreme Court's decision against the AAA and the administration's farm program.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Jan. 6. -- The Quartermaster Depot today awarded to William Whitman Company the army contract for 72,366 yards of eighteen-ounce serge at the following net prices: For 70,908 yards of olive drab, $2.114 per yard; for 1,458 yards of sky blue, $2.36.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 6. -- Plans for a new $2,000,000 parkway to link the Northern and Southern State Parways at Westbury and Wantagh were outlined at a meeting of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today by Arthur E. Howland, chief engineer of the Long Island State Park Commission.

The Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., and subsidiaries yesterday reported for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30, a net profit of $682,538 after depreciation, interest, rentals and ordinary taxes, but before Federal and capital stock taxes, capital gains or losses and other nonoperating adjustments.
The Frazier-Lemke act, providing for the relief of insolvent farmers throughout the country, was held unconstitutional yesterday by Federal Judge Mortimer Byers in Brooklyn.

The New York Fire Insurance Exchange was called on yesterday in a letter from Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to put into effect strict prohibitions against payment of excess commissions in obtaining fire insurance business.

No wonder that Controller TAYLOR is enthusiastic about the condition of city finances. They are in better shape than they have been for some years. Taxpayers are obviously having less difficulty in meeting city charges for services rendered. Back in the lush days of 1929 and 1930 the amount of each year's tax levy which stood uncollected at the end of the year used to run about 15 per cent.

If any one had questioned whether formal eighteenth century music had vitality and charm for a modern audience, he need only have attended the concert -- third of a series of five -- given last night in Town Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Music Orchestra, Hans Lange, conductor, for the benefit of the Scholarship Fund of Bennington College.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The statement by J.P. Morgan Co. in connection with the Senate Munitions Committee inquiry read as follows:

BERLIN, Jan. 6 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Government officials said today they were aware of the plan reported abroad for transferring between 100,000 and 250,000 Jews from Germany to Palestine and British territories with the financial backing of British and American Jews.
A Hoboken business building deal was included in the New Jersey transactions reported yesterday.
President Roosevelt's latest message is in very truth a funeral oration upon his Democratic predecessor, Woodrow Wilson.

An old brownstone residence at 62 West Fifty-third Street, remodeled and refurbished with WPA funds, became yesterday what is believed to be the country's first municipal art gallery for the free and uncensored exhibition of work by artists and sculptors living in the city.

Due to prolonged illness, Georgia O'Keeffe has produced comparatively little work in the last few years. It is a great pleasure to welcome her back. The one-man show that has just opened at An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, is composed altogether of canvases painted in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Since the whole effort of the pending neutrality legislation is to legislate policy, the measure introduced today by the Senatorial group led by Senator Nye is more logical and consistent than Senator Pittman's administration bill. It is designed to reduce to a minimum executive authority over policy in time of foreign war.
