ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 6 (AP). -- Discerning in the Supreme Court decision an "indication that many of the acts of the administration probably are unconstitutional," Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, termed "momentous" today the court's decision killing the AAA.

DOLO, Ethiopia, Jan. 6 (AP). -- Italy's southern army, resuming an offensive, routed the Ethiopians in a bitter two-day battle in which 150 Ethiopians were believed killed and one white Italian soldier was slain.

More than 100 dancers filled a small room in the Union Auditorium, 229 West Forty-eighth Street, last night, and organized the Dancers Association, which will seek establishment of a Federal dance project under the WPA.

About 105,000 workers in the dress industry here are "going right ahead with completing the machinery for a strike" while employer groups engage in "too much shadow boxing" on the eve of the expiration of the labor agreement, it was declared yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, parent body of the dressmakers organization.

Sears, Roebuck Co. -- Sales for the four weeks and forty-eight weeks ended on Dec. 31 were the largest for those periods since 1929. With the remaining four weeks to complete the year, the volume of sales is expected to exceed the total for any other full year in the history of the company.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, following the practice it inaugurated several years ago, yesterday sent to shareholders a full list of its security holdings. In addition, the bank this year enlarged the scope of its report by including a detailed profit and loss statement.

GENEVA, Jan. 6. -- A possibility of the problem of the strategic Japanese mandated islands being solved in a few years by Japanese immigration entirely supplanting the native population the mandate was meant to safeguard is raised indirectly in the minutes of the November session of the Mandates Commission.

While the Supreme Court's decision on the AAA is expected to result in hand-to-mouth buying in all branches of the food industry during the immediate future, due to the uncertainty over the price situation, manufacturers and distributors generally felt that release from the burden of the taxation would benefit the industry within a short time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP). -- The government's attempt to collect nearly $3,000,000 as a result of the Soviet recognition agreement was thwarted today by the Supreme Court.
Following is stenographic transcript of Mayor F.H. La Guardia's message to the Board of Aldermen yesterday:

Offering will be made to the public today of a new issue of $9,200,000 of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., first-mortgage 4 1/4 per cent sinking-fund bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1956, by a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and including Edward B. Smith Co., Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Hayden, Stone Co.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Following is the text of the President's budget message:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today nominated Joseph B. Keenan of Cleveland, Ohio, as assistant to Attorney General Cummings, a post which makes him the third ranking official in the Department of Justice.

TOKYO, Jan. 6. -- Eiji Amau, spokesman for the Foreign Office, declared at a press conference today that he had not read President Roosevelt's message of Friday night, which scored territorial adventures on the part of foreign nations.

Relief from the legalistic confusion developing from the administration of the State unemployment insurance law and which was threatening to tie up building construction being done through subcontracting, has been obtained under a special ruling from Glenn A. Bowers, director of unemployment insurance, it was announced yesterday by W.G. Wheeler, secretary of the Building Trades Employers Association.

Eugene List, 17-year-old American pianist, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His program encompassed Bach-Liszt's Organ Prelude and Fugue in A minor, Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 10, No. 3; Chopin's Ballade in F and a group by Shostakovich, Debussy, Scriabin, Rachmaninoff and Liszt.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Miss Evelyn F. Allenspach, 33 years old, of 1,825 Beverly Road, Brooklyn, was injured seriously when she fell or jumped under an express train at 9:20 A.M. yesterday in the Times Square subway station of the I.R.T. She was taken to Roosevelt Hospital with a fractured skull and possibly internal injuries.

ISHBEL MACDONALD now runs an inn very near Chequers Court where she used to preside as week-end hostess for her father, the Prime Minister. All one can say is that it is too bad G.K. CHESTERTON does not share the political views of the MACDONALDS.

Directors of the Bon Ami Company declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents and an additional dividend of 50 cents on the Class B stock and the regular quarterly dividend of $1 on the Class A stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- In anticipation of tomorrow's beginning of the Senate Munitions Committee's inquiry into the wartime financing operations of J.P. Morgan Co., the firm issued a statement tonight designed to give a picture of its part in financing British, French and other Allied activities in this country in the two years and nine months preceding the entry of the United States into the World War.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Supreme Court by a two-thirds majority vote today demolished the Agricultural Adjustment Act (the AAA) as completely as last year it destroyed the NRA. These two were the major legislative devices of the New Deal for orderly recovery in industry and agriculture, and for economic parity between them.

Nick Montana, 36 years old, known as "vice overlord," who was convicted on Dec. 9 by a jury on a compulsory prostitution indictment as a second offender, was sentenced by Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions yesterday to a twenty-five-year prison term.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- An agreement which was described as "mutually satisfactory" to both the United States and to Mexico developed from a series of silver stabilization conferences which terminated today at the Treasury Department.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6. -- The plea for clemency of Bruno Richard Hauptmann will be heard by the Court of Pardons, sitting at Trenton, next Saturday morning. Hauptmann, convicted ten months ago of the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., had been sentenced to die next week in the electric chair.
Rules and regulations governing the $2,000 contest for a winning city anthem were laid down yesterday by the executive committee named recently by Mayor La Guardia to conduct the competition.

Traffic executives representing nationally known shippers and trade groups discussed the functions of the Federal Motor Carrier Act of 1935 yesterday for three hours at a "town meeting" called by the Shippers Conference of Greater New York, in the assembly room of the Merchants Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration has paid out about $1,200,000,000 in various benefits and administrative costs under its program for restoring prosperity to farmers, according to official estimates.

SIR BASIL ZAHAROFF has been called "the mystery man of Europe." But the picture that emerges from Robert Neumann's "Zaharoff: The Armaments King" (Knopf, $2.75) is only mysterious in the inessentials; the palpable fact of Sir Basil's amazing and sulphurous career as a "drummer for Mars," a man who became incredibly wealthy by selling guns to all nations, is indubitably established.

Chain and department store executives displayed a mixed reaction yesterday to the Supreme Court decision invalidating the AAA. Several leading retail executives felt that the effect upon business would be limited as was the case with the ruling on the NRA last May.
ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The decision of the Supreme Court invalidating the AAA was hailed tonight by Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman.
Stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased $1,994,991,204 in value in December, figures released by the Exchange revealed yesterday.

A "categorical denial" that the three distinguished British Jews who are coming to the United States this month would sponsor a plan "whereby the emigration of Jews from Germany is to be stimulated through a world-wide distribution of German-made goods," was issued last night by the executive committee of the Zionist Organization of America.

The vitality and drawing power of Bizet's "Carmen" were further evidenced by the size and excitement of last night's audience at the Metropolitan Opera House. The cast was the same as the one that appeared in the first performance of the current revival, save that Charles Kullmann was a new Don Jose. Rosa Ponselle was again the Carmen, Ezio Pinza the Escamillo and Hilda Burke the Micaela, with Louis Hasselmans conducting.

The St. John's University freshman quintet recorded its eighth consecutive triumph of the season by downing Bryant High School, 38 -- 14, on the losers' court in Queens yesterday. The contest was one of five staged in the metropolitan area in which scholastic teams figured.

The cotton market fluctuated nervously yesterday following the decision of the Supreme Court invalidating the Agricultural Adjustment Act, through which cotton in the United States for the last three years had been regulated.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- Edwin F. Jaeckle, Erie County Republican chairman, declared tonight that selection of Abbot Low Moffat as chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee "substantiates the charge that Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the State Republican Committee, is subservient to the self-seeking leaders in the metropolitan district who have used their influence for personal advantage with the result that the Republican party in the greater city is thoroughly demoralized."

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Jan. 6 (AP). -- Indictments obtained against eighty-six persons in New York State's investigation of race-track tipster services are valid, Supreme Court Justice O. Byron Brewster ruled today. Motions to dismiss them were denied.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6(AP). -- Ann Cooper Hewitt accused her mother here today of duping her into a sterilization operation that tightened the mother's hold on her income from a $10,000,000 trust fund.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 6 -- Jorge Gustavo Silva, speaking in behalf of the Haitian delegation at this morning's session of the Pan-American Labor Conference declared its opposition to a proposal to establish a Pan-American Labor Institute, which will be discussed at the next Pan-American Conference at Lima in 1938, and suggested the establishment of an agency branch of the Geneva office on this continent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Hailing a turning point in the fiscal affairs of the government, with expenditures definitely declining and revenues at a peace-time high, President Roosevelt today submitted his budget to Congress with recommendations for a total of at least $6,752,000,000 to finance the multitudinous Federal activities for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1936, and ending June 30, 1937.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Solution of the farm problem becomes one of the chief issues of the 1936 campaign in the opinion of some leaders of the major parties, as a result of the Supreme Court's decision yesterday declaring invalid the administration law controlling agricultural production.

By all odds the most important development yesterday, so far as the financial markets were concerned, was the Supreme Court's ruling, at noon, that the program contemplated in the Agricultural Adjustment Act was unconstitutional.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6. -- Exactly duplicating last year's score, McGill, outplaying Yale from start to finish tonight, barely outscored the home hockey team, 2 to 1. Two weeks ago the Blue was blanked in Montreal by McGill 10 -- 0.
The famous little black cocker spaniel, Champion Torohill Trader, last night gained the title of best in show at the nineteenth specialty show of the American Spaniel Club in the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- AAA officials estimated, following the Supreme Court's decision today, that about $979,000,000 of processing taxes had been collected by the end of October, when the multitude of suits to prevent further imposition of the taxes first became apparent.

Give the nation's industry not a "breathing spell" but a reasonably predictable future and progress is certain, James A. Emery, general counsel of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared last night, in offering a definition of specifications that will lead toward recovery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- President Roosevelt, following the AAA decision, conferred for two and a half hours with Government officials and Congressional agricultural leaders. Although no announcement was made it was believed the conferees discussed methods of offsetting the effect of the Supreme Court's decision.

James Hagan, who hasn't been represented since "One Sunday Afternoon" back in 1933, is the author of "Mid-West," which is to come this evening to the Booth Theatre. It is a play about life on the American farm, and playing some of its parts are Curtis Cooksey, Jean Adair, Van Heflin, Frank Wilcox, Bernardine Hayes and Edgar Nelson.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 6 (AP). -- Defense attorneys filed motions today to transfer the retrial of the Scottsboro mass assault cases from the State to Federal court, asserting that hostile feeling toward the nine Negro defendants prevented a fair hearing here.

The schedule of twelve games for the third annual championship series of the Quadrangular Hockey League was announced last night by Asa Bushnell of Princeton, secretary-treasurer of the circuit, through The Associated Press. Members of the league are Yale, Harvard, Princeton and Dartmouth.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- Those who may still want to purchase tickets for the Olympic track and field competition next Summer are doomed to disappointment. Director Lessing of the organization committee's ticket department announced today that all tickets for the track and field events already have been sold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Visibly stunned by the sweeping nature of the Supreme Court's AAA decision, commodity and legal chiefs of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration met throughout the day and up to late tonight, seeking some way of keeping farm crops of the future within the limits of actual demand.
First place in the American Group of the National Hockey League will be at stake tonight when the New York Rangers oppose the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.
MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 6. -- In belated comment this morning on President Roosevelt's message to Congress Friday night Mexican newspapers differed in interpretations of the speech.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- After conferences this evening between United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, Governor Lehman and the legislative leaders, it was decided to rush to final passage at the session tomorrow a bill providing for the setup of an authority to undertake the construction of a Manhattan-Queens tunnel under the East River, with its Manhattan starting point at Thirty-eighth Street.

Franklin D. Roosevelt's address to the American people, ostensibly for the benefit of the joint session of Congress, was the most astounding exposition of American foreign policy ever delivered by any President from the foundation of the Republic. No useful purpose was served in launching an assault which befitted a stump speaker rather than the responsible head of a mighty nation.

A large audience attended Albert M. Bagby's 386th Musical Morning yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Mme. Lotte Lehmann and Richard Bonelli of the Metropolitan Opera, and Mischa Elman, violinist.

BOSTON, Jan. 6. -- Steadily increasing its gains during the Summer and Fall months, New England business and industrial activity concluded, with the passing of 1935, its best year since 1931, according to an announcement today by the New England Council, an all-New England economic research and development organization.

Ten new college scholarships for blind students have been created through a recent gift of William Nelson Cromwell, lawyer and philanthropist, to the American Foundation for the Blind, it was announced yesterday. The scholarships, each for $250, are the same as those yearly awarded to vocationally ambitious blind students by the foundation, of which Mr. Cromwell has been a trustee for the past five years.

The Marine Midland Trust Company, trustee for 5 per cent secured debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, soon will distribute an aggregate of $950,830 on these debentures -- or $20 for each $1,000 debenture and $10 for each $500 debenture, according to an announcement by Baldwin Maull, vice president of the bank.

Sugar futures broke 23 to 24 points in price yesterday afternoon following the decision by the Supreme Court invalidating the AAA. The daily limit of fluctuation is 25 points. The net loss for the day was 16 to 18 points, due to early gains and a slight recovery at the close, but active months ended only slightly above the seasonal lows.

Mr. Justice ROBERTS, writing the opinion of the majority of the Supreme Court, alluded to the "grave sense of responsibility" which judges must feel in setting aside an act of Congress as unconstitutional. No doubt, the three dissenting Justices felt the same responsibility.

The decline in sugar almost attained yesterday the 25-point limit for price change in a single day on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. It followed the AAA decision by the Supreme Court, but the market appeared to have had the blow softened by an early gain of 5 points and a late rally of 1 or 2 points.

The special committee of the New York Yacht Club chosen for the purpose of creating a new one-design class of combination racing and cruising yachts for its members announced through its chairman, Robert M. Bavier, yesterday that the craft would be constructed from designs submitted by Sparkman Stephens, Inc., of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Alcoholic liquor taxes for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1935, amounting to $411,000,000, were larger than in any similar period, even in preprohibition days, except during 1918 and 1919, when there were exceptional withdrawals of intoxicants from bond in anticipation of the prohibition of these beverages, Secretary Mongenthau told Congress today in his annual report.

For those who deplore the mechanization of modern life and the patterned monotony of a machine age there should be comfort in the annual Poultry Show which opens in New York today. This exhibition of some 5,500 chickens, ducks, turkeys, geese and pigeons is indeed at once the stimulus and the reward of the individualist.

ROME, Jan. 6 (AP). -- A sharp skirmish on the southern front, in which the Ethiopians suffered more than 150 casualties and lost an encampment on the Ganale Doria River, was reported today in the official Italian war communique.

Trial of a $10,000,000 suit against the Chase National Bank, the Equitable Trust Company which it absorbed; the New York Trust Company, and the Manufacturers Trust Company by a group of investors in the bonds of one of the Insull holding companies began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Rosenman.

A suit against the Manufacturers Trust Company to recover collateral valued at about $200,000 for the benefit of creditors of S.W. Straus Co., Inc., of New York came to trial yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn after almost three years of preliminary legal motions, arguments, appeals and rearguments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The far-reaching scope of the Supreme Court's decision invalidating the Agricultural Adjustment Act astounded members of Congress. There were few outspoken expressions of approval, however much certain members may have been pleased at the court's action, for farm relief, like the veterans' bonus, is a delicate question which cuts across party lines.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- The two January furniture exhibitions opened in a snowstorm, with attendance and buying well ahead of last year. With prices 5 to 15 per cent higher on low-priced lines, retailers were in a mood to make immediate commitments as protection against new advances.

The revival of Puccini's "La Rondine" after an absence of six years, the first appearance of Gertrud Wettergren in the role of Carmen and the assumption by Susanne Fisher of the part of Marguerite in "Faust" will mark the fifth week of the Metropolitan Opera season next week.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- Unsuccessful efforts by Democratic minority members to change the "gag rule" which permits the budget committee during Summer sessions to act without knowledge of the board featured the reorganization this afternoon of the Westchester Board of Supervisors for 1936.

Lower prices for refined sugar, flour, meat and other processed farm products were gradually taking effect yesterday in the wholesale markets, following the invalidation of the AAA by the Supreme Court.

Princeton's hockey team displayed a wealth of power in defeating the University of Toronto sextet in the annual clash between the rivals at Madison Square Garden last night. The Orange and Black skaters struck forcibly in the third session, after being held even in the first two, and scored four tallies to register a 7-to-4 triumph over the visitors from the North.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 6. -- Although the Chinese Government is definitely ready to negotiate with Tokyo a reasonable settlement of any or all outstanding Chino-Japanese differences, the Nanking authorities are gloomy on the possibilities of easing the tension between the two nations.

Albany County, N.Y., yesterday made the award of a new issue of $627,000 of refunding, relief and public works bonds to Phelps, Fenn Co. and F.S. Moseley Co., Boston, at a price of 100.52 for 2s. The bonds are to be dated Jan. 1, 1936, and will mature serially on Jan. 1, 1937 to 1946.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- The Naval Conference reassembled somewhat gloomily today under a realization that an agreement upon any plan of naval limitation would be even more difficult than envisaged when the delegates first assembled. The day's developments did not succeed in dissipating this gloom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- In the action brought against the Securities and Exchange Commission in the District Supreme Court by J. Edward Jones, New York oil royalty dealer, to restrain enforcement of over-the-counter rules, the commission is expected to agree to a stipulation that nothing will be done pending a hearing to determine whether activities such as carried on by Mr. Jones bring him within the provisions of Section 15 of the Securities Exchange Act.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- The Supreme Court's AAA decision invalidating the structure which maintained the processing taxes and production control was an unsettling influence in grain markets of the nation, with wheat fluctuating erratically within a range of as much as 3 cents a bushel.

Net assets of General American Investors Company, Inc., at the close of 1935 were $30,079,817, equivalent to $4,558 a $1,000 debenture and to $11.90 a share of common stock, without giving effect to the possible exercise of outstanding warrants, comparing with $23,088,962 at the end of 1934, or $6.53 a share of common stock.
Donald R. Richberg has written a narrative of the development and results of the NRA. This is scheduled for publication on Feb. 7 by Doubleday, Doran with the title "The Rainbow."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The majority opinion of the Supreme Court on the Agricultural Adjustment Act, read by Justice Roberts, was as follows:

Mr. and Mrs. Sanford R. Knapp of Mount Kisco, who are at the St. Regis, gave a supper there last night in the Maisonette Russe for Miss Katherine Gray, whose marriage to Edrington Penn of Reidsville, N.C., will take place Saturday in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
A Bronx apartment house investment deal, a Manhattan bank lease for expansion and an East Side residential purchase featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 6. -- Newell Bent Jr., 25 years old, of 85 Prescott Street, Cambridge, a graduate of Harvard in 1933, died of a heart attack while climbing Mount Aconcagua, on the Chilean-Argentine border, the highest peak in the Western Hemisphere, dispatches from Puente del Inca said today.

Indian Hurtado, Panama lightweight, preserved his unblemished American ring record last night at the St. Nicholas Palace in his most important engagement since coming here. He earned the decision over Leo Rodak, hard-hitting Chicagoan, in a ten-round bout before 3,000 fans.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- "Ethan Frome," the new dramatization of Edith Wharton's novel by Owen Davis and Donald Davis, received more than a cordial greeting tonight at its premiere at the Garrick Theatre here.
The Neediest Cases Fund was increased to $247,896.32 yesterday by twenty-seven contributors, who gave $339.

After a period of strength in early trading, bonds turned highly irregular yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as a result of the conflicting influences created by the Supreme Court's decision on the AAA.

The body of a 16-year-old girl, prematurely gray, was found yesterday afternoon lying across the bed in a dingy furnished room which she had occupied with her widowed mother at 320 West Ninety-sixth Street. When police entered the room they found the mother, Mrs. Ann Haynes, 50 years old, seated beside the bed in a dazed condition.

While the cotton textile and garment sections of the wholesale markets here were affected by the AAA decision of the Supreme Court yesterday, other branches of the wholesale trade reported a substantial degree of activity. Mail orders were heavy and the number of buyers here showed an increase.

The manufacturers, distributors, jobbers and operators of the pin ball games, which Mayor La Guardia has banned, have appealed to Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, former Police Commissioner, it became known yesterday, to help them clean house.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 6. -- Glory Greenock, carrying the black and white-dotted silks of the Memphis sportsman, Curtis King, breezed home an easy winner today at Tropical Park in the first half of the Boca Chica Purse, a five-and-a-half furlong dash split into two divisions.
ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Governor Lehman expressed his regret today at the death of Dr. Walter N. Thayer Jr. He said:

THE door was opened by the blond-haired, bespectacled Tex O'Rourke of the James J. Braddock forces and the seated occupants of the room were Jerseyman James himself, the heavyweight champion of the world, his chipper manager, little Joe Gould, and a small dark fellow who turned out to be M'sieu or Signor or Professor Scarnie who, among other accomplishments, does astonishing tricks with the cards.

The opinion of Mr. Justice Roberts against the constitutionality of AAA is plainly of historic importance. To reach a decision in this case the Supreme Court was obliged to consider a phrase of the fundamental law which had never been brought before it for definition -- the "general welfare" limitation upon the taxing power of Congress contained in Article 1, Section 3 of the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Cartoon stamps attacking the New Deal cannot legally be attached to mail matter, under the regulations of the Postoffice Department, Walter E. Kelly, assistant to the Solicitor of the Postoffice Department, said today.

Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, acting yesterday in a test case brought by the Birth Control Clinic, through Dr. Hannah M. Stone, its director, ruled that contraceptive devices could be imported into the United States if they were not to be put to illegal use.

In the first of a series of lectures in civics for provisional members of the New York branch of the Junior League, Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman of the New York School for Social Work spoke to eighty debutantes yesterday morning in the Junior League clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.

BOSTON, Jan. 6. -- With virtual unanimity, New England business leaders today hailed the decision of the Supreme Court invalidating the AAA as the beginning of a renaissance of the textile industry here and as presaging the death knell of virtually all New Deal legislation from the Social Security Act to the Wagner Labor Bill.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The dissenting opinion of Justice Stone, signed also by Justice Brandeis and Justice Cardozo, on the AAA decision was as follows:

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Dr. Stephen Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, were honored yesterday by the government of Chile, Dr. Butler for his efforts to promote international peace and Dr. Duggan for his work in education.

The murder of Samuel Drukman, a cause celebre involving rumors of bribery, became yesterday the concern of a special grand jury in Brooklyn. This body, the third within ten months to inquire into the case, was chosen and sworn in before Justice Erskine C. Rogers, presiding by designation of Governor Lehman at an extraordinary term of the Supreme Court.

Terming the past year the "greatest" in so far as athletic activities were concerned, and "epochal" as regards finances, President William A. Dalton of the New York Athletic Club yesterday accounted for the 1935 stewardship of the Board of Governors to Winged Foot members in the sixty-seventh annual report of the world's largest athletic club.

" Rose of the Rancho," in which Gladys Swarthout of the Metropolitan Opera will make her screen debut, will have its premiere at the Paramount at 9 o'clock tonight. Others in the cast are John Boles, Charles Bickford, Willie Howard and Herb Williams.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sullivan of Cedarhurst, L.I., gave a reception with dancing yesterday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club for their daughters, Miss Marjorie Sullivan and Miss Florence Dodd Sullivan, the latter a debutante who was introduced to younger members of society at a dinner dance given earlier in the Winter by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm.

With one important exception, in which prices were cut sharply, Spring rug and carpet lines were officially opened by leading mills yesterday with quotations practically unchanged from those prevailing on the Fall ranges. Hard-surface floor coverings were also brought out at the same levels as for Fall, with the exception of felt base goods, which were advanced 1 cent a square yard.

Spokesmen for New York's independent motion picture theatre operators and representatives of the major circuits yesterday assured Mayor La Guardia of their cooperation in his campaign to provide safeguards for minor's attending the cinema.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 6. -- With the arrest of Harry Berger, said to have entered Brazil on a United States passport, the political police here claim to have captured the resident director of Soviet activities in South America. The United States embassy is investigating the validity of the passport, as the holder had not registered at the embassy.

Relinquishing the editorial chair to our readers, we submit first a note from S. G. PI. (could this pos-[ sibly be that reformed worm fisher, r Sparse Gray I-Iackle?) anent the I wisdom of devoting so'he time these Winter nights to looking over your !fishing tackle.

Dr. Illo Hein, WPA project supervisor, who recently held that graduates of five colleges and universities here were unqualified for two chemists' jobs for which requisitions had been made, has been dismissed, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator.

A four-year high school average of 80 per cent instead of the present 178 per cent will be required, beginning next month, for admission to the day session of City College, it was disclosed yesterday by Recorder John K. Ackley. Provision also has been made to admit students graduated from religious and parochial schools in New York State.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Today's decision by the Supreme Court in the AAA case came with dramatic suddenness.

With wonder and bewilderment will be read the plan as published in yesterday's TIMES, to provide for the expatriation from Germany of 100,000 to 250,000 Jewish citizens. It is proposed that the laws now restricting the flight of capital from the land be relaxed and that these emigrants be permitted to take with them some of the wealth which during years of toil they have accumulated.

Charging that the Queens Midtown Tunnel Authority had "carefully and deliberately neglected to tell me" of its plan to use part of St. Gabriel's Park on the East Side as an approach plaza for the tunnel, Park Commissioner Robert Moses angrily warned the authority yesterday that under no circumstances would he permit such use of the park.

The will of Jessie Robbins Belmont, wife of Perry Belmont, who died in Paris on Oct. 20 last, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday disposed of her estate, which consisted solely of her jewels. The petition for probate valued the estate at less than $10,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 31 shows a decrease for the week of $44,000,000 in total loans and investments and increases of $131,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $103,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $61,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

On the eve of the golden anniversary of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, A.W. Robertson, chairman of its board, announced yesterday that the company's gross business in 1935 amounted to $122,000,000 and that the net earnings would amount to $12,000,000, or about $4.50 a share of common stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The united front Bonus Bill sponsored by the American Legion, the Veterans of Foreign Wars and the disabled veterans' organization was approved late this afternoon by the House Ways and Means Committee and there are indications that the bill will pass the House by an overwhelming majority probably early next week.

The Vinson Bonus Bill, supported by the American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars and Disabled American Veterans of the World War, was characterized as "larceny" yesterday by Major Knowlton Durham, commander of the New York Chapter of the American Veterans Association, with headquarters at 420 Lexington Avenue.
Dr. Charles Reiser, in 235 E. 22d St., from J. H. Taylor Construction Co.; Warren L. .Marks Co., brolers.

Mrs. Ethel Burkhardt Arnold and Miss Jane Sharp of California and Berkeley Bell of New York and Texas were officially welcomed into the professional tennis ranks last night at a dinner given at the Hotel Astor by Bill O'Brien, promoter of the matches to be held at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6. -- Dr. Tilton E. Tillman acknowledged today that he had advised, and been a party to, the operation through which Ann Cooper Hewitt was deprived of the privilege of motherhood,

MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (Canadian Press). -- The rapid rise of Larry Northcott of the Maroons, Marty Barry of Detroit and Sweeney Schriner and Art Chapman of the Americans to the first flight of point-makers in the National Hockey League featured statistics released tonight.

Wide and irregular fluctuations occurred on the Cotton Exchange yesterday immediately succeeding the decision of the Supreme Court invalidating the Agricultural Adjustment Act. The first reaction to the removal of a tax of more than $10 a bale on cotton consumed by domestic mills was a wave of buying by consumers and prices moved up more than a quarter of a cent.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- Comment of farm leaders on the Supreme Court decision invalidating the Agricultural Adjustment Act varied widely tonight.

BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- Trading on the Boerse was mixed today, with a slight tendency to strength at the close. Activity, as usual, was limited. Heavy industrials were somewhat weaker at the opening, but recovered their losses. Machines were slightly stronger, Schubert Salzer gaining 1/4 point.

While thousands of out-of-town visitors wandered about the Sunken Plaza in Rockefeller Center at 11:10 A.M. yesterday, four armed robbers held up a jewelry store on the north side of the promenade in Rockefeller Plaza, Fifth Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, and escaped with jewelry valued at from $100,000 to $150,000.

The Columbia Club squash tennis players gained undisputed possession of first place among rival Class C teams in the Metropolitan League last night by defeating the Short Hills Club, 4 to 1, while their chief rivals, the City A.C., were sustaining their first loss of the season.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- Henry P. Fletcher, Republican National Chairman, speaking at a luncheon meeting of the Union League today, declared the nullification of the Agricultural Adjustment Act indicated that "constitutional government still lives in Washington."

BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- The Admiral Graf Spee, third and last of the 10,000-ton "vestpocket" battleships built by Germany within the Versailles Treaty specifications, was put into service at Wilhelmshaven today. The next two German battleships, however, which are already being built under the Anglo-German naval agreement, will be of 26,000 tons each, and Chancellor Hitler is determined in the future to built ships as large as those of any other nation.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6. -- Miss Lillian M. Feitner was hostess to twelve for dinner tonight at her home, taking her guests later to the wrestling matches at Lake Worth and returning to join Mrs. Wanamaker Munn's large supper dance at her patio.
Records of the office of the United States Marshal dating back to 1812 were moved yesterday in four van loads from the old Postoffice Building at Park Row to the new Federal Building on Foley Square.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6. -- Reviewing the past year's results in the nation's business and industry in a speech before the Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce tonight, Grover A. Whalen of New York declared that conditions had been immeasurably better in almost every line of production but warned of certain "dark spots."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The rejection of the Agricultural Adjustment Act by the Supreme Court today constituted the fifth defeat out of six suits affecting New Deal cases brought before the court so far for settlement. The sole victory the government achieved was in the gold-clause cases, and then only by the narrow margin of 5 to 4.

Active trading, with some impressive gains and some wide declines, divided the commodity futures markets yesterday. Sugar futures fell on the AAA decision by the Supreme Court. Rubber and silk were strong. On the cash markets, cotton, corn, oats, cocoa and rubber gained, while rye, eggs and tin declined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The government won an important victory in its legal battle with the utility holding companies today when Justice Jennings Bailey in the District of Columbia Supreme Court signed an order staying proceedings in suits filed here to restrain the Securities and Exchange Commission from enforcing the provisions of Title I of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- S. Davis Wilson, taking office today as this city's 113th Mayor, assailed New Deal policies locally and nationally and promised to devote himself to "bringing Philadelphia and its people back within the fold of representative government."

The announcement of the opening of the joint campaign tonight for the raising of $600,000 to meet the current expenses of the Young Women's and the Young Men's Christian Associations of this city speaks of depression as "striking hardest at youth -- like war."

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday announced several staff promotions that had been approved by the bank's board of directors at their annual meeting last Thursday. John H. Williams, formerly economist of the bank, and Allan Sproul, formerly assistant to the governor and secretary of the bank, have been appointed deputy governors, the bank here made known.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- While organized labor is hopeful that the Supreme Court's AAA decision will not affect social justice legislation, it believes that it makes an amendment to the Constitution necessary.

Mayor La Guardia marked the half-way point in his four-year term yesterday by reviewing sixteen of the city's major problems before the new Board of Aldermen. which met for the first time at City Hall.

Federal, State and city employes have contributed $46,000 to aid the voluntary hospitals of the city, it was announced yesterday by the United Hospital Campaign Committee, which is seeking $2,000,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 7. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann was told today that the date for his execution had been set for Friday, Jan. 17, at 8 P.M. He smiled and shrugged at Warden Mark O. Kimberling, who conveyed the information to him, and later expressed to other visitors his continuing conviction that he will not die.
Slightly over "even 4s" for fifty- five rounds, Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., captured low scoring honors among America's professional golfers in 1935.

Former Mayor Walker went over to Brooklyn yesterday for a personal call on Supreme Court Justice George E. Brower, but before he returned he visited Peter J. McGuinness, Sheriff of Kings County, and was almost mobbed as he left the Greenpoint Democratic leader's official quarters.

The production of steel ingots in the United States last year amounted to 33,425,576 gross tons, the highest for any year since 1930, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. This compared with an output of 25,599,118 tons in 1934.

The retirement of Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., commandant of the Third Naval District, will take place early in the Spring, it was revealed yesterday at the district's headquarters in the navy yard in Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The Court of Appeals practically nullified the Brownell "Public Enemy" Law in a six-to-one decision today in which it reversed the convictions of Salvatore Spitale and eleven others. The court, in effect, held that the statute was not unconstitutional, but added that "the proof, however, is another matter."

Life insurance companies should refrain from taking sides in any political controversies over governmental policies designed to promote social welfare, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, told members of the Life Underwriters Association last night at a dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Yesterday was Christmas for thousands of Eastern Orthodox Russians and Syrians, whose church calendars adhere to the old Julian formula. Syrians observed the holy day with services around midnight, while those of the Russian faith stood before gayly decorated ikonostas for three hours yesterday morning.

Sailing tonight for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania are Senator A.C. Hardy of Montreal, with Mrs. Hardy and their daughter Dorothy; Sir Robert Peel, son of Beatrice Lillie, English actress, and:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- In addition to the conference of farm leaders called by Secretary Wallace another farm meeting has been...

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7. -- Three policemen and two civilians were killed as strikers burned thirty auto buses and several street cars and tore up railroad tracks in the course of a one-day general strike that began in the Argentine capital at 5 o'clock this morning. Police announced tonight that order had been completely restored with the cooperation of Federal troops.

Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a large increase over the preceding week, the total was well below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals were 911 as against 297 in the previous week and 1,246 in the same period last year.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- Going into action immediately after receiving the Governor's message on anti-crime legislation, the Senate advanced today a series of twelve measures designed to carry out proposals of the Executive.

Six persons, including a physician and a former insurance agent, were arrested and booked at Brooklyn police headquarters yesterday in connection with an alleged attempt to defraud insurance companies of about $55,000. District Attorney Geoghan charged all six of them with cooperating in a scheme whereby forty-three insurance policies were fraudulently placed on the life of a man who died last Jan. 24 after a long illness.

A tea and fashion show for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association drew a large attendance yesterday to the King Cole Room of the St. Regis. Mrs. C. Frank Reavis spoke briefly on the work of the association and announced the manikins as they appeared, wearing Southern resort clothes.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 7. -- Count von Rosen, the young Swedish airman who flew gasoline and supplies to Noghelli, where a Swedish Red Cross unit was bombed, saw Mr. Junot, the International Red Cross representative here, start yesterday on his 190-mile night truck drive to the ruined Swedish camp with a Red Cross photographer.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7. -- Miss Anne Page of Merion, the defending titleholder, won two matches in the opening rounds of the women's Philadelphia and district squash racquets championship at the Penn A.C. today.

Determined to end as quickly as possible the market confusion caused by invalidation of the AAA by the Supreme Court, both manufacturers and distributors of cotton goods yesterday plunged into the task of restoring order to the merchandising of their products.

The long delays and discomforts suffered by hundreds of passengers on the Long Island Railroad during the blizzard of Jan. 23, 1935, were an act of God and not caused by negligence on the part of the railroad, a jury in First Municipal Court of Queens decided yesterday.

The authority of Secretary Wallace to make further payments to farmers under AAA contracts for reduction of acreage and production was questioned yesterday by Nelson Littell, a member of the Lawyers' Committee of the American Liberty League, as a result of the Supreme Court decision declaring the AAA unconstitutional.

BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- Yesterday for the first time since the Ethiopian conflict has threatened to become a European crisis, German political opinion gave indication of becoming apprehensive of its implications. A section of the press reflected this concern in commenting on what it now believes to be Italy's avowed aspirations.

The William H. Nichols Medal of the New York section of the American Chemical Society, a highly prized honor, has been awarded for 1936 to Dr. William Mansfield Clark, Professor of Physiological Chemistry at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, "for researches of incalculable value to human welfare," it was announced yesterday.

Waiting in Germany to escape the "humiliation and indignities" of the Hitler regime are 10,000 Jewish adolescents who need the aid of sympathizers to maintain them in a land of refuge, according to Miss Henrietta Szold, organizer and leader of Youth Aliyah, the movement for the transference of German-Jewish youth to Palestine.
For the third time since the season opened the Squash Club Class B team gained a victory in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association without having to swing a racquet.
Thirty-two contributors added $478.50 yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund. The fund's total is now $248,374.82.
Several food manufacturers who have paid millions of dollars in AAA processing taxes to the government since 1933 plan suits within the next month to recover this money.

An announcement regarding the Spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House may be made late this afternoon. A meeting of directors of the Opera Association was held yesterday at the Opera House when a number of proposals concerning the name, incorporation, personnel and price scale of the supplementary season were considered.
ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The State's highest court ruled today that confidential information obtained by a newspaper reporter was not privileged and could not be withheld when demanded by a court.

Facing a possible rejection of the Wagner Labor Relations Law by the United States Supreme Court, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that he had prepared a "baby Wagner bill" for submission to the Municipal Assembly.
Flanked by Commissioner Bill Brown and Chief Deputy Joe McOwen, Brig. Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, announced yesterday that:
The prospect of another sell-out at Madison Square Garden loomed yesterday as the seat sale for the professional tennis matches to be held there Saturday night passed the mark of $13,000.

The four armed robbers who on Monday held up three men in the Greenleaf Crosby jewelry store at 620 Fifth Avenue, in Rockefeller Center, obtained sixty-two pieces of jewelry valued at $132,810, an inventory disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- The banks of the United States will be forced to support the Federal Government's credit, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Data filed by corporations as confidential and made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, received in 1934 remuneration of $161,671; W.A. Irvin, president, $102,161, and W.J. Filbert, chairman of the finance committee $87,941.

IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Jan. 7. -- Rescue of twenty snow-trapped coal miners and their families, marooned on an isolated Wyoming ranch by the section's worst snowstorm in thirty years, was believed near tonight.

Several hundred persons, including 150 children from the Professional Children's School, which occupies part of the Campion Building at 1,860 Broadway, were forced to leave the building shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday when a fire destroyed the assembly room of the school.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The necessity of regulating the over-the-counter markets and the prospective increased activity on the Stock Exchanges of the country have been cited by James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in urging increased appropriations for his body.

Sales last year of department, dry goods and specialty stores throughout the country showed a rise of 7.1 per cent over 1934, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Created in May, 1933, to restore to its pre-war parity with industrial products the purchasing power of farm commodities, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration had still some distance to travel when declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Narrowly divided decisions of the Supreme Court, such as the five-to-four opinions for which the court has become famous, are great evils which Senator Borah would like to correct, but for which he has as yet found no solution, he said tonight.

Armour Co. of Illinois and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 2 a net income of $9,377,849 after expenses, depreciation, provision for Federal income taxes and other charges. The earnings are equivalent, after dividend requirements on the preferred stocks of the Illinois and Delaware companies, to 57 cents a share on 4,065,418 common shares outstanding.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The Legislature passed today a bill creating a New York City Tunnel Authority, empowered not only to build the $59,000,000 vehicular tunnel connecting Manhattan and Queens but, if and when the city can obtain the necessary funds, a similar vehicular tube, to cost between $55,000,000 and $60,000,000, between the Battery and Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, as well.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Beginning an investigation of the wartime financing activities of J.P. Morgan Co. and other banking institutions, the Senate Munitions Investigation Committee undertook at hearings opened today to prove that the bankers of the nation were largely responsible for the entry of this country into the World War in 1917.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Daily average production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,802,750 barrels, compared with 2,810,800 in the preceding week, a decline of 8,050, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 14,050 barrels in Oklahoma was the most important change.

The question whether newspaper reporters, like priests, physicians and lawyers, may claim legal privilege in refusing to divulge the source of confidential information when demanded by courts or in criminal investigations, has never been passed upon by the United States Supreme Court.

PARIS, Jan. 7. -- After having recovered to 15.13 francs to the dollar, the French currency in the last week has slipped back again toward the gold-export point. Today it touched 15.17 francs. Sterling was at 74.77 francs to the pound. The franc's downward movement was accompanied by a somewhat depressing session of the Bourse, rentes again sagging and virtually all French securities showing losses.

In an interview yesterday Charles W. Burkett, vice president of the Farmers Independence Council of America, said that 4,000,000 farmers in the country regarded the defunct Agricultural Adjustment Act as one that had been "hateful to them" and that his constituents "opposed its principles of bureaucracy and regimentation."

The joint campaign to raise $600,000 for the 1936 expenses of the Young Men's and Young Women's Christian Associations opened last night at a reception and dinner at the Commodore Hotel. The campaign slogan will be "Youth Marches On."

Douglas Fairbanks, motion picture star, returned last night on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, after spending six months in Europe, with the announcement that he would not appear again as an actor in the movies but would become a producer.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- The University of Toronto hockey team overwhelmed the St. Nicholas sextet of New York by 12 -- 2 before a crowd of 1,000 persons at the Playland Casino tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- "United action" by organized labor and organized farmers for a constitutional amendment will be the goal sought by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in forthcoming conferences with the heads of the principal agrarian groups, it was announced today.

Three men were arrested yesterday morning in a raid ordered by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County, on charges of operating policy games. Detectives estimated that the group had an income of $500,000 a year.

Estimates of trading losses on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange attained seven figures yesterday as the prices advanced the permitted limit of 25 points in the space of a few minutes after tickers quoted Secretary Wallace to the effect that the sugar quotas were not affected by the Supreme Court's decision on the AAA.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is seeking unjustified lengthening of working hours and reduction in wages, according to the conclusions of a fact-finding board appointed by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, who made public the board's report today.

The dissenting opinion of Mr. Justice STONE, concurred in by Judges BRANDEIS and CARDOZO, is a strong and able argument for the right of Congress to levy taxes and spend them as it pleases. This doctrine may some day become, in part at least, the view of the majority of the Supreme Court.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 7. -- Sparkling Lady, a $93.20-for-$2 shot, electrified the crowd at Tropical Park today by outrunning nine other maiden 3-year-old fillies in the first race.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The important retail price-fixing section No. 2 of the Fair Trade Law adopted by the Legislature last year was declared unconstitutional today by the Court of Appeals in an opinion written by Chief Judge Frederick J. Crane.

Floor coverings prices, named by additional mills yesterday on Spring lines, continued in general unchanged, with minor revisions both up and down to bring certain types into line with competition. Buying interest was again confined to the wholesale trade and in general was disappointing.

PEIPING, Jan. 7. -- "We established this independent government in East Hopei in order to break away from Nanking's domination and the Kuomintang's misrule," the official spokesman of Yin Jukeng, head of the East Hopei Autonomous Council, asserted in an interview today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 7. -- Mayor Charles R. Erdman Jr., who appointed last week a "municipal brain trust," announced tonight the formation of a citizens' safety advisory committee, comprising eleven prominent residents of the community, to cooperate with the Mayor and council of the borough of Princeton in carrying out the new administration's program of increased efficiency in local government.

Coach Adolph Rupp arrived in New York yesterday with his University of Kentucky basketball squad, which lost to N.Y.U. in the final seconds of play a year ago by one point. Tonight they will meet in a return engagement at Madison Square Garden in the feature game of the fourth of the college court double-headers.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 7. -- A bold attempt by a seaman to rob the cash till of the Pacific Fleet's flagship singlehanded on a stormy night at sea is related by The Baltimore Evening Sun.

The United States Supreme Court decision brought heavy selling orders from European, Oriental and domestic sources, and prices on the Cotton Exchange declined about $2 a bale yesterday to close at losses of 25 to 36 points.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 7. -- Representatives of United States exporters met last night at the American Chamber of Commerce here to discuss the agreement between the two countries for the thawing of frozen credits and voted in favor of accepting paper of the Banco do Brazil rather than government paper because of its greater negotiability.
BERLIN, Jan. 7. -- The Boerse was slightly firmer today, but about as inactive as it has been for many months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The Republic Steel Corporation of Cleveland has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, under the Securities Act of 1933, an application for the issuance of $45,000,000 of general mortgage bonds, Series B, due on Feb. 1, 1961, to be used chiefly for refunding purposes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Mae West received salary checks totaling $339,166.65 during 1934, the Treasury report on salaries paid to all corporation employes in the country receiving $15,000 or more a year disclosed today. The report was made to Congress under the Revenue Act of 1934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP). -Filing of an application by the Paramount Broadcasting Corporation, operating radio station WVFW at Brooklyn, to transfer control of the corporation to the Brooklyn Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, was announced today by the Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- A statement that unless some substitute for processing taxes and acreage control is devised a return to 1932 farming conditions may follow was issued today by Secretary Wallace.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7. -- Thirteen of the twenty-eight trustees of Westminster Theological Seminary, the Presbyterian fundamentalist institution established here in 1929 in protest against what its founders described as the modernistic trends of Princeton Seminary, resigned at a board meeting here today.

Organization of the National Federation of Sales Executives has been completed by charter members, it was announced last night. The primary aims of the organization are to provide the sales side of business with a national voice and to develop a wider and more influential fraternalism among those engaged in the managerial phases of selling and marketing.

Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, mother of Gloria Laura Vanderbilt, will apply to Surrogate James A. Foley this morning for a show-cause order, it was ascertained yesterday. The order will be to compel George W. Wickersham and Thomas B. Gilchrist, general guardians of the child's property, to pay an additional $6,000 incurred for the child's maintenance during the last year.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 7. -- The United States Consul General here, Charles M. Hathaway Jr., issued a strong protest to the Bavarian Government today against the forty days' imprisonment incomunicado of Captain Paul Herberger, an American citizen.

With little clarification of the situation now faced as a result of the voiding of the AAA, coming yesterday from official sources, puzzlement on the part of followers of the markets continued. The matter is far too complex to be readily understood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Facing the worst crisis in cotton since it undertook control of its production and price level in 1933, Agricultural Adjustment officials conceded today that they were powerless to deal with the problem and that 1936 would witness a reversion to unrestricted production throughout the South, with possible unfortunate consequences on prices.
Making a brilliant comeback after its defeat by N.Y.U., Fordham's basketball team crushed the Upsala quintet of South Orange, N.J., 81 to 30, last night in the Maroon gymnasium.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Playing four against three, the Boston Bruins registered two goals in a 14-second interval to gain a 2 -- 0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 13,000 persons tonight at the Boston Garden.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 7. -- Thomas H. Webb, president of the American Cotton manufacturers Association, expressed the hope before leaving Charlotte today for New York to attend a cotton conference that no mill in the South would cut prices following the Supreme Court's adverse decision on the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

While retail and wholesale failures showed an increase in the five business days ended Jan. 2, compared with the previous short week, there was a decline in the manufacturing division, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

New York Hanseatic Corporation in its statement of condition for Dec. 31, reports cash in banks of $1,549,806, compared with $1,296,910 on June 29, 1935. Bankers' acceptances including those pledged as collateral, stood at $5,309,786, against $3,516,972 and United States Government securities, including those pledged as collateral, amounted to $14,833,063, compared with $14,841,394 at the end of June.

The promotion of sixty-one members of the teaching staff in eighteen departments at Brooklyn College to higher ranking in the faculty was announced yesterday by Dr. William A. Boylan, president of the college. Dr. Boylan said that thirty-one instructors had been designated assistant professors.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 8. -- Naval opinion here throws out the suggestion that the wisest policy would be to break off the naval conference in London and seek a fresh start in the future. It believes there is no use in struggling to reach some face-saving agreement, such as a compromise between the British and French formulas for announcement of building plans might provide.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The lengthening of work hours in 1935 as compared with 1934 cut down the number of jobs available for the unemployed, according to the annual review of business made public by the American Federation of Labor.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Jan. 8. -- Disturbances in North China far more serious than those of December and last June are expected at an early date, for it is learned that Major Gen. Kenji Doihara of the Japanese Army has sent to General Sung Cheh-yuan, chairman of the Hopei-Chahar Political Council, secret demands constituting a virtual ultimatum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Even those who consider it a sacrilege to question whether the framers of the government intended a majority of the Supreme Court to attain its present power over legislation and executive action must be aware, after reading the two emanations from the court yesterday in the Hoosac Mills case, that a great national debate of the issue, with possible action by the people, is drawing near.
Mrs. John Hubbard gave a reception with music last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. The Manhattan String Quartet, which has just returned from an extended tour of sixteen European cities, played.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Farm leaders from every section of the United States were called today by Secretary Wallace to meet in Washington Friday and Saturday to see what, if anything, can be devised in the way of an agricultural program to offset the Supreme Court decision which yesterday outlawed the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 7. -- An ambulance driver was killed and four persons were injured, one critically, when a private ambulance was in collision with a truck at 12:30 P.M. today at Jericho Turnpike and Guinea Wood Road here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Cooperation by investment bankers in seeking to work out problems on the over-the-counter markets and in handling security flotations to provide capital for the recovery movement was indicated today in a statement by B. Howell Griswold, chairman of the Investment Bankers Conference Committee, in which he praised the Securities and Exchange Commission for avoiding "radical" recommendations in its recent report to Congress on unlisted trading.

The apprehension expressed some months ago by Charles R. Gay, president of the Stock Exchange, that the stock market might again get beyond control apparently is shared by James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mrs. Charles Ashby Penn of Reidsville, N.C., gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Katherine Gray and Edrington S. Penn, son of the hostess, who will be married Saturday in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

Last season's Pulitzer Prize winner -- the name is Zoe Akins -- has provided this evening's first-night fare. "O Evening Star!" is the play; and once again, as with "The Old Maid" a year ago, the theatre is the Empire and the producer is Harry Moses.

Word comes from London that many countries are making preparations to observe the total eclipse of the sun which is to take place on June 19 of this year. It will be total, according to The Observer "along a belt of the "earth from the Mediterranean to the "Pacific Ocean, passing over Greece, "through Siberia and on to Japan."

A calm, often smiling young gunman on the witness stand in Bronx County Court described yesterday how he and eight others kidnapped and got $9,000 in ransom money from an alleged policy banker. Three of the eight confederates he named have been murdered, a fourth committed suicide and another was wounded; the others are in jail, like himself.

Price movements on the local commodity futures market were highly mixed yesterday. Sugar futures advanced the limit as the Cuban duty remained at .9 cent. Coffee and cottonseed oil were weak. Wheat, corn, oats and rubber gained on the cash markets and cotton, rye, lard, cocoa and flour declined.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- Speaker Ives asserted tonight that all was harmonious among the Assembly Republicans after appointment of committees, featured by the selection of Abbot L. Moffat as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

Ten thousand relief workers on WPA rolls will be dropped within the next two weeks as the first step in the WPA retrenchment program, which contemplates a reduction of 20,000 in its rolls, it was announced last night by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator.

St. John's University's undefeated freshman basketball team registered its ninth straight triumph, beating City College's junior varsity five, 31 to 28, in an overtime contest at the De Gray gymnasium yesterday. In another game the Long Island University cubs downed the New Utrecht quintet, 35 to 25, on the loser's court.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7. -- Rioters in the streets and highways in today's general strike, a survey showed tonight, had burned three milk wagons, five street cars, several railway cars, three municipal garbage wagons and four food carts.

The financial markets were rapidly adjusting themselves yesterday to the scrapping of the AAA. Stocks rallied sharply from the decline that followed the Supreme Court's decision and the primary commodity markets fluctuated widely, but gave evidence of approaching stability.

A program fortunately chosen, and music well within the capacities of a new instrumental organization, distinguished the third concert of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 7. -- Enactment of "such constitutional legislation" as may be needed to "place agriculture on an equal basis with other industries" was recommended tonight in a resolution adopted by the Kansas Agricultural Council in session here.

For several reasons it is difficult to accept at face value the pessimistic forecasts of those members of Congress and those spokesmen of farm organizations who predict that the Supreme Court's decision in the case of AAA will be followed by a major collapse of farm prices and a loss of farm purchasing power.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP). -- Two seeded entries, one of them Marcel Rainville, Canadian champion, tasted defeat today as eight others advanced into the third round of the Miami Biltmore tennis tournament.

Two men were shot dead by the same band of hold-up men in two Brooklyn saloons yesterday morning, and three suspects, arrested for the murder a few hours later, were identified by half a dozen witnesses.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 7. -- Affidavits in support of the suit of Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21-year-old heiress, demanding an accounting from her mother, Mrs. Maryon Hewitt McCarter, of her father's estate, reached here from the Pacific coast by air mail today and were filed before Vice Chancellor Vivian M. Lewis.

A warning that judicial interference with legislative acts may result in the long run in constitutional amendments far more radical than the legislation was sounded last night by Donald R. Richberg in an address before the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at its building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

The London Madrigal Group of seven singers, whose director is T.B. Lawrence, gave their first concert of a two weeks' American tour yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. This organization has come highly commended by noted musical authorities of England.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The following leaders of farm organizations and prominent agriculturists had been invited, up to tonight, to attend the conference called by Secretary Wallace for Friday and Saturday:

For her second recital this season Sarah Osnath-Halevy, Palestinian singer-pantomimist, whose American debut at the Town Hall last month disclosed her as a most unusual personality, appeared last night at the Majestic Theatre. Her second recital was more than sufficient proof that Miss Osnath-Halevy is an artist of magnitude.

TRENTON, Jan. 7. -- Methods by which $27,857,121 may be made available to finance unemployment relief during the current year were set out in a report submitted by the legislative Budget Advisory Committee to Governor Hoffman today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Adapting to their arguments some of the same reasoning employed by the Supreme Court yesterday in its AAA decision, 135 railroads joined today in a suit filed in the District of Columbia Supreme Court challenging the constitutionality of the revised Railroad Retirement Act and its taxation vehicle.

A veteran diver, working from a police launch, groped along the murky bottom of the East River around Pier 36, at the foot of Jefferson Street, for more than six hours yesterday in a fruitless search for the body of 10-month-old Jackie Horowitz, who disappeared in his carriage on Sunday from in front of 45 Gouverneur Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien entertained twenty-one for dinner tonight at Villa del Sarmineo, where Mrs. Richard F. Hoyt and Mrs. Joshua S. Cosden are visiting. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer, Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas, Countess Elie de Ganay, Charles A. Munn, Emilio Alduo, Captain Cecil Boyd-Rochfort and Milton W. Holden.

THOMAS MANN voluntarily quit his native Germany when Hitler became "the leader." But Thomas Mann refused in any active sense to join the Opposition; his first duty, he implied, was to his art, which, as every one knows, is timeless, a matter of probing into philosophical first causes. His son Klaus, however, has gone over completely to the Opposition.

Simon Schuster have been having what they call "statistical orgy" and emerge with the news that their ten best sellers for 1935 provided a total sale of 410,000 copies. Four titles sold more than 25,000 copies each: "I Write As I Please," by Walter Duranty; "Now in November," by Josephine Johnson; "Inflation Ahead," by Willard Kiplinger and Frederick Shelton; "Sudden Death and How to Avoid It," by J.C. Furnas and Ernest N. Smith.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- Declaring the crime situation "fraught with grave and continuing danger, not only to the people of the State but to the body politic itself," Governor Lehman in a special message of 16,000 words to the Legislature today recommended drastic revision of the criminal law.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 7 (AP). -- The Wisconsin Recovery Law of 1935, patterned after the NRA, was held valid today by the State Supreme Court.

James Hagan's heart is a better organ than his head. In "Mid-West," which was acted at the Booth last evening, he is writing of plain folks who are holding their own against adversity; and, as in the instance of "One Sunday Afternoon," which was Mr. Hagan's second Broadway play, his respect for simple decency and his wholesome sentiment are most attractive.

A brand new suit, with long trousers and a pleated-back coat, awaits Raphael Pagano, 15-year-old high school pupil, who ran away from his home, 108 Mulberry Street, on Nov. 10 because he was "ashamed to go to school in his ragged clothes." The offer, made by a detective of the Missing Persons Bureau and spread among Raphael's friends, stipulates that the boy can select his own color, too.

The city of Detroit awarded yesterday to a banking syndicate headed by the First National Bank and Halsey, Stuart Co. an issue of $5,108,000 of refunding bonds that are dated Jan. 1, 1936, and will mature from 1937 to 1963. The group paid 100,002 for $1,988,000 due from 1937 to 1950, as 4s, and $3,120,000 due from 1951 to 1963, as 3 3/4s, making the interest cost to the city 3.80426 per cent.
LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Twenty-seven persons were known dead tonight in shipwrecks at sea and accidents in Northern Europe since Sunday. France was ravaged by floods.

A police squad bearing a subpoena from the newly impaneled Drukman grand jury visited the Brooklyn headquarters of the Luckman trucking concern yesterday and took away a truckload of records and three prisoners, including two more members of the Luckman family.

The injunction not to let your left hand know what your right hand doeth is scrupulously obeyed by this administration, which has as many hands as Briareus. Some of the resultant contradictions are merely funny, but one now beginning to operate seems stupid politics.

Central Building gained undisputed possession of first place in the vocational school swimming league, conducted under the auspices of the P.S.A.L., by defeating Brooklyn Boys, 28 to 26, at the James Madison High pool in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Path for debate on the Veterans Bonus Bill in the House on Thursday and a vote on Friday or Saturday was cleared today through parliamentary manoeuvres by its advocates. The Vinson-Patman-McCormack bill, which has the support of the united veterans' organizations, was reintroduced with only one important revision.

MADRID, Jan. 8. -- A decree dissolving Spain's second republican Parliament and convoking a general election Feb. 16 was signed today by President Niceto Alcala Zamora. The new Parliament will meet March 16.
Resuming competition after the holidays, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club won its third successive victory in Group 2 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association last night.

LONDON, Jan. 7. -- For the first time today, and with the Naval Conference not in session at that, there is visible the sole type of naval agreement with which it seems possible to replace the Washington and London treaties in the matter of limitation.
ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- Following are excerpts from Governor Lehman's message on crime prevention:

For almost two-score years travelers in the Bronx have noticed a life-size statue of a Civil War soldier standing in the middle of the Bronx River just south of the Gunhill Road Bridge, and, upon inquiry, have been unable to learn its origin and the reason for its being in the river.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Two of the smartest members of Rio de Janeiro's fashionable foreign circles, known as Mr. and Mrs. Harry Berger, were held incomunicado today while the police investigated their alleged communistic activities.

Railroads in all parts of the country reported a sharp upturn in net operating income in November, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. The increase in the East was 52.9 per cent, in the South 25.4 and in the West 121.9 per cent.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The decline in the price of silver in the London market was checked, at least temporarily, yesterday when the quotation moved up to 20 3/4d an ounce, a gain of 1/4d over the previous day. This was equal to approximately 46.09 cents an ounce. Here the price was unchanged at 49 3/4 cents an ounce, the pegged quotation since Dec. 23.

TOKYO, Jan. 7. -- The Foreign Office spokesman intimated tonight that Japan was ready to negotiate on all outstanding questions affecting the relations between Japan and the British Empire, but that the Japanese would not discuss the China question alone.

Julien Levy's gallery at 602 Madison Avenue bubbles over into the new year with a quantity of surrealist art that has never before been shown here. By this time it would truly seem that we must have seen everything produced to date along that line.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Evidence is now available that Postmaster General Farley personally solicited party contributions from at least five Federal employes in issuing invitations to the Jackson Day dinner here tomorrow night, thus violating a Federal statute, the American Liberty League charged today.

The Horace Mann School for Boys began the defense of its Eastern Private Schools Basketball League crown yesterday with a victory over Poly Prep of Brooklyn, 20 -- 17, in a game which stood out on a busy card arranged by metropolitan scholastic quintets.
