TOWNSEND'S INLET, N.J., Jan. 7. -- While a group of police and Coast Guardsmen looked on and a few gulls circled overhead, Adam Ambrose, a South Philadelphia butcher, seized a shovel this afternoon and dug up the body of a man buried in the sand dunes near this little Cape May County resort.

The Soldiers and Sailors Club owns a building at 283 Lexington Avenue and is the only peace-time agency in the city providing a safe welcome and wholesome entertainment for the enlisted men of the army and navy. During the past year, more than 83,000 visits were made to the club, by soldiers representing 111 army posts throughout the world, and sailors and marines who came from 140 ships and stations.
Rambling around the outdoor circuit:

The Secretary of the Treasury's annual report gives the statistical details of Government finances up to the closing of the last fiscal year, but carries the summary no further. It contains no review of the country's economic situation and no discussion of the Government's financial plans.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7. -- Setting all the pace, Mose Goldblatt's Gilbert Elston chalked up his first victory in seven starts at the Fair Grounds today, winning the Emerald Handicap of one and one-sixteenth miles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Establishment of an Appellate Division inside the Interstate Commerce Commission to be composed of five commissioners and to have full power to act on applications for rehearings was recommended to Congress today in the annual report of the I.C.C. for the period from Nov. 1, 1934, to Oct. 31, 1935.

Although the death of Charles A. Stoneham served for a short time to revive reports -- heard off and on for many years -- that the Giants would now be surely sold, opinion in local baseball circles yesterday seemed almost unanimous that not only will there be no sale but no serious change in the club's policy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 (AP). -- District Attorney Matthew Brady said tonight that the sterilization plot charge of Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21-year-old heiress, against her mother, will in all probability be presented to the grand jury.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7. -- The conflict in the Socialist party, accentuated with the suspension of the New York State organization's charter, drew into the fight today James H. Maurer of Reading, Pa., running mate of Norman Thomas in the last two Presidential campaigns.

Leaders in the various sections of the cotton textile industry are making rapid progress toward adjustments required by the AAA decision and, according to Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, normal activities in yarn and cloth markets should be resumed within a few years.

Mrs. Jane Norman Smith, in a letter on minimum wage legislation published in THE TIMES, made two serious charges against the New York State Minimum Wage Law and its administration. No proof for either statement was given. Mrs. Smith said:
The Detroit Red Wings beat off the New York Rangers' threat to dislodge them from first place in the American Division by defeating the Blue Shirts at Madison Square Garden last night, 2 to 1.

Some 4,000 specially selected members of the Dressmakers Union have been called to meet at the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, this evening at 6 o'clock "for final tuning up of the general strike machinery" affecting 105,000 workers, it was announced yesterday by Julius Hochman, general manager of the Joint Board of the Dressmakers Union.

George Robinson's accommodating nature cost him $556 yesterday. Robinson, who lives at 4,314 Fifteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, is the bluff, hearty and obliging concessionaire of the restaurant in the Administration Building at Floyd Bennett Airport.

Sarah Bernhardt scored another triumph last night when her motion picture "Queen Elizabeth," made in 1911, was shown at the Museum of Modern Art in a program of six early films illustrating the development of the cinema.

ROME, Jan. 7. -- Newspapers announce that the regular army's crack Val Pusteria Division of Alpine troops is on its way to reinforce the Italian armies in East Africa. The divisional general staff and the first contingent of 4,000 men left Naples yesterday aboard the troopship Conte Grande, followed by 2,500 artillery men today aboard the Conte Rosso.

LONDON, Jan. 7. -- Transactions on the London Stock Exchange today were restricted as a result of the United States Supreme Court decision in the AAA, although the international list was little changed. It is thought here than Wall Street may enter a temporary period of uncertainty, but confidence is felt in the continuance of American industrial recovery.

Two works of the nineteenth century, unknown to the public here until recently, one by Cherubini and the other by Verdi, will be introduced by Arturo Toscanini when he conducts the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on Jan. 23 in the first of a series of concerts.

We believe the threat of a general taxicab strike, held over the trade by the Taxi Chauffeurs Union, A.F. of L. affiliate, is to be deplored by every individual interested in the welfare of the taxicab industry.

Conservative leaders of maritime labor on the Atlantic Coast will form a maritime federation similar in organization to that which functions on the Pacific Coast under the leadership of Harry Bridges if Bridges attempts to carry out his threat to organize the Atlantic Coast men, it was said yesterday.
Thirty-eight of the star 2-year-old trotters of 1935 remain eligible for the Hambletonian Stake of 1936, it was announced yesterday by the Hambletonian Society.
ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- Following is the text of the Court of Appeals decision on the Fair Trade Practice Act:

The registration of automobiles for 1936 took a spurt yesterday, when thousands thronged the headquarters of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, 155 Worth Street, to obtain new plates. I. James Brody deputy commissioner in charge, reported that the number of mailed applications also showed a large increase.

Rules for the city's anthem competition have been laid down by a Mayor's committee. Among other things it is stipulated that the hymn must breathe the spirit of the city as a whole. Borough sectionalism will not be tolerated.

Amid the crowing of several thousand roosters, the fourth annual New York Poultry Show opened yesterday morning in the 244th Coast Defense Armory in West Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue. Philip M. Plant, sportsman, and Stark Young, author, are among the exhibitors, Mr. Plant being one of the largest and Mr. Young, with one bird, a Foxhurst rainbow cockerel, being one of the smallest.

With the arrival in this country yesterday of Jean Dupuy aboard the United States liner Washington it became known that the 1936 Gold Cup Regatta at Lake George on July 25 may take on an international flavor for the first time since 1904, when the first regatta was held at the Columbia Yacht Club in New York.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- The most intense siege of the Winter lifted slowly in the prairie States tonight as the cold wave pushed across the Mississippi River.

Reflecting the year-end improvement in business caused by the holiday trade, sales by chain stores in December showed considerable improvement. Of the seventeen chain store and mail order companies that to date have reported sales for that month the only decrease shown was one of 0.5 per cent.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP). -- The drama of 500,000,000 years ago, when life began leaving the oceans and populating dry land, has been reenacted on a small scale at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography here.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- Theresa Mayer, 14 years old, of 36 Harding Avenue, this city, was arrested as a juvenile delinquent today by the police, who charged her with beating her mother, Mrs. Hermina Mayer, 40, on the head with a heavy iron furnace shaker.

The seventieth annual meeting of the Society of the Home for Incurables was held yesterday afternoon in the Kent Pavilion of the institution, Third Avenue and 183d Street, the Bronx. Ogden L. Mills, president of the society, presented the annual report of the board of managers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Evidence that J.P. Morgan Co. invited the British Government to purchase control of an American munitions concern in 1916 and that the Morgan firm obtained commissions of $30,000,000 through handling purchases of American munitions for the Allies during the war was produced at today's hearing before the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 8. -- Reports from South Tyrolese sources assert that there were mutinous scenes in Merano recently on the occasion of the moving of the Fifth Italian Alpine Regiment from the Untermais barracks there for service in Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Skelly Oil Company of Tulsa, Okla., has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a statement covering $12,000,000 in securities, of which $9,241,500 is to be used to refund outstanding debentures. The rest of the net proceeds will be applied to such capital expenditures as the management believes desirable.

Encouraged by a communication from Park Commissioner Robert Moses which indicated that the Central Park Casino may soon be among the park memories, the parliament of the Community Councils of the City of New York adopted a resolution last night calling for the demolition of the casino and the establishment on the site of a playground as a memorial to the late Mrs. Charles Cary Rumsey.

HSINKING, Manchukuo, Jan. 8. -- An explanation of the recent sudden check on the Japanese military's aggressive attitude in North China was made today by General Jiro Minami, ranking general of the Japanese Army as well as commander of the Kwantung Army and Tokyo's Ambassador to Manchukuo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- An administration decision to continue the Agricultural Adjustment program, or its equivalent, with cash benefits to farmers under a new method of production control and rewards, was reported tonight to have been reached after two days of almost continuous conferences between President Roosevelt, Secretary Wallace and other officials.

As reported in THE TIMES, Jerusalem has begun to receive a new water supply, ending two thousand years of water shortage. The little land in the midst of which Jerusalem stands has an annual rainfall of thirty inches or thereabout, but every drop of this rain falls within less than one-half of the year.

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- The Court of Appeals has ruled in favor of the Eastman Kodak Company in a suit brought by John Marsich. He asked for $30,000 damages from the company, which, he asserted, established a list price at which all photographic supplies should be sold to the consumer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Neutrality shared attention with the soldiers' bonus today in both branches of Congress. Committees on both sides of the Capitol held executive sessions to discuss the various proposals and to consider means of expediting their legislative progress.

Captain Hans Kieff, master of the Hapag Lloyd liner Deutschland, was on the liner Europa as a passenger last night en route to New York, with the nature of his next four months' employment depending upon the ability of the Europa to make up the time she has lost by reason of storms in the last four days.

ROME, Jan. 8. -- Full figures of the number of workmen brought home from East Africa because of ill health were made public today. Of 11,338 repatriated 11,182 came from Eritrea and only 1,269 were ill. Seventy-six of 156 from Somaliland were ill.
The concert given by Sir Thomas Beecham and the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall began stodgily and ended in a very brilliant and amusing manner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- With the rallying cry of President Roosevelt at the Jackson Day dinner still ringing in their ears, members of the Democratic National Committee will meet here tomorrow to take one of the chief steps in the 1936 campaign by fixing the date and choosing a city for the national convention.

Larry MacPhail, bustling business manager of the Cincinnati Reds, who last Winter stampeded even the most conservative element in the National League to permit the staging of night baseball for the first time in the history of the major circuits, arrived in New York yesterday and immediately sprang another innovation right out from under his hat.

PARIS, Jan. 8. -- Although the forthcoming cruise of the French Atlantic Fleet is not unusual, it is in accord with the preparedness measures that the French Government is taking in agreement with the British Government in case of any incident in the Mediterranean.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, disclosed yesterday that plans for a gradual and progressive reduction in the army of 240,000 workers now on WPA rolls will be worked out within the next fortnight.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- Stockholders of the St. Regis Paper Company at the annual meeting here today acted favorably on the proposal to lower the par value of the common stock from $10 to $5 a share and thereby reduce the common capital stock by $20,625,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- In helping his fellow-Democrats to celebrate tonight the memory of Andrew Jackson, the President could not fail to draw certain similarities in his own mind between his problems and those of Old Hickory. Every Democratic President who has publicly discussed Jackson since the shades were pulled down at The Hermitage has done the same.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The test of President Roosevelt's Jackson Day address was as follows:

A meeting of union dressmakers and cutters called for 6 P.M. yesterday at the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, to plan for a strike, brought out the active membership, While 4,000 jammed the large auditorium and others listened to the speakers through amplifiers in other rooms, an overflow crowd, estimated by the police at 3,000, milled about the doors.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 8. -- Edward Metelski, 26-year-old hold-up man and gunman, was convicted this evening in the Middlesex County Court of Oyer and Terminer here of first-degree murder in connection with the fatal shooting of State Trooper Warren C. Yenser, near Woodbridge, N.J., last Nov. 9.

Displaying more confidence than had been manifest at any time since Monday noon, when the United States Supreme Court upset the Agricultural Adjustment Act, the share market moved higher yesterday in active trading. The closing was strong (petroleum issues featured the late dealings), but down somewhat from the day's best level.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- The deadlock that has been threatening the naval conference from the outset became real today. Unless it can be remedied before the next session Friday, it is difficult to see on what basis the discussions can continue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Sentiment was divided among members of Congress today on a proposal to hang a "none-of-your-business" sign on corporation salary lists submitted under the 1934 Revenue Act.

One of the most remarkable young teams in recent polo history, the national interscholastic champion indoor trio of Lawrenceville School, is to make an appearance at Squadron A Armory in a special match Saturday night.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- Examination of J.P. Morgan by the Senate munitions committee is regarded by the German press as an "international event of great significance." German editors assert that the cross-examination and evidence offered demonstrate the accuracy of the classic German explanation of America's entry into the war -- that she went in solely for business reasons.

All friends of friendship are very well pleased to hear from Speaker IVES that Chairman EATON "is very "well pleased with the way things have "turned out" in the distribution of honors in the Assembly. Over the telephone, an easy means of discord, Mr. IVES and Mr. EATON have succeeded in keeping or getting into general accord.

Probably Zoe Akins should have been an actress. She is all emotion. In "O Evening Star!" which was appreciatively acted at the Empire last evening, she transforms the Marie Dressler legend into a vast, heaving, purple sea of warm emotion.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- Mrs. John Van Ryn, first ranking tennis player in the Middle Atlantic district, caused an upset in the women's Philadelphia and district squash racquets championship by defeating Miss Muriel Pierpoint of Cynwyd in a third-round match at the Penn A.C. today.

Frequent and more moderate feeding is more beneficial to the human family than "the age-old" consumption of three meals a day, according to Dr. Howard W. Haggard, head of the Department of Applied Physiology at Yale University.

Net operating earnings of the Manufacturers Trust Company in 1935 were $6,645,992, equal to $4.04 a share, against $5,163,600, or $3.13 a share, in 1934 and $4,000,154, or $2.43 a share, in 1933, Harvey D. Gibson, president of the bank, told stockholders at their annual meeting at 4 P.M. yesterday in the main office of the bank.

" I am not recommending legislation at this session for higher license fees and the Conservation Department is not preparing to introduce such a bill," Commissioner Lithgow Osborne told 700 members of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association at a meeting in White Plains Tuesday night.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 8. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman has no present intention of granting Bruno Richard Hauptmann a reprieve, he said today in revealing the contents of a letter Hauptmann wrote to him asking that the Court of Pardons give him a hearing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Of the internal revenue taxes of $3,299,435,572 paid during the last fiscal year, New York State furnished $672,473,493, or 20.38 per cent of the total, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, disclosed today in his report for the period ended June 30, 1935.

Formidable Kentucky was reduced to the status of just another opponent and just another victim last night as the all-conquering New York University five strode unimpeded on its way along the victory road.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Possibility of renewal of the interunion warfare which split the American Federation of Labor Building Trades Department into two rival groups was discussed in building circles today when it was learned that J.W. Williams of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners is about to become president of the reorganized building department.

Pig iron production in December, as reported by The Iron Age, totaled 2,106,453 tons, or 67,950 tons a day, as compared with 2,065,913 tons, or 68,864 tons daily, in November. In terms of daily rate, output declined 1.3 per cent. Furnaces in blast Jan. 1, numbered 119, as against 122 on Dec. 1, a loss of three.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Secretary Swanson today appointed Vice Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn, now commanding the Scouting Force of the fleet, to be commander-in-chief of the fleet. At the same time a general shift in the navy high command was announced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Mrs. Roosevelt, Mrs. Woodrow Wilson and Mrs. William Howard Taft attended the concert given by Helen Jepson and Richard Crooks at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's eighty-fourth musical morning at the Mayflower, heading a distinguished audience which included representatives of all ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society.
The text of Governor Lehman's address last night at the National Democratic Committee Jackson Day dinner at the Hotel Commodore follows:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 8. --The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company with $14,971,000 and the Prudential Life Insurance Company with $11,781,000 were reported as the principal holders of bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad in a list filed in Federal court today in connection with the railroad's petition for reorganization under the amended Bankruptcy Act.

The name of President Roosevelt was linked with those of Louis of Bourbon and George of Hanover as exponents of the "monarchical theory" of government in an address here yesterday by Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune.

Despite the probable disapproval of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Stock Exchange continues to attract active issues from the nation's smaller Exchanges. Among six companies whose issues were admitted yesterday to listing on the big board, the securities of two had been traded previously on the Curb Exchange and those of a third on the Detroit Stock Exchange.

The franc dipped once more to the point at which gold shipments to this country from Paris are profitable, 6.59 cents, and closed at 6.59 3/8 cents, off 1/4 point, in yesterday's dealings in the foreign exchange market.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- Charges that foreign agents of the Vickers armaments interests tried to "promote war" by urging countries to buy munitions brought to a climax a day of cross-fire between the Royal Commission on Private Manufacture of Arms and British manufacturers.

BABYLON, L.I., Jan. 8. -- The United States Army Board of Engineers, who conducted a hearing at Town Hall here today on the development of the Long Island Southern Inland Waterway, announced it would report on the matter to the Army Engineer Corps in Washington, D.C., in a month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- While Senate leaders were working desperately today to evolve some method of paying the veterans' bonus without adding to the burden of the Treasury, a "united front" bonus measure was reported to the House and booked for passage before the week ends.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 9. -- The newspaper Asahi's London correspondent cables the following message:

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- Edwin F. Jaeckle, belligerent leader of the Republican organization in Erie County, and Irving M. Ives, the more pacific new Speaker of the Assembly, after a conference here of more than an hour's duration behind closed doors, sent for the newspaper correspondents at the Capitol and shook hands in their presence in a solemn pact of peace.

The State of South Dakota will entertain bids on Saturday for a new issue of $5,696,000 of rural credit refunding bonds. They will be dated Feb. 1, and will mature on Feb. 1, 1943 to 1947. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 1/2 per cent.

Claims against debtors in Brazil amounting to approximately $30,000,000 have been filed by American exporters with the National Foreign Trade Council, which has been designated as a clearing house to carry on negotiations to collect on frozen credits, it was announced here yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8. -- The Bristol Stable's Believer, longest-priced horse in the field of five, raced to an easy triumph in the six furlongs of the featured fifth race today at Tropical Park. Closing at 10 to 1, with Apprentice Clayton Phillips doing the piloting, the 5-year-old gelded son of Omar Khayyam greeted the judges two lengths clear in 1:12 flat.
The critical position of many automobile dealers throughout the country, at present overstocked with used cars, was considered at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday morning.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP). -- A Miami boy, Gardner Mulloy, out-manoeuvred Ricardo Morales, Cuba's amateur champion, in three sets today to dispose of the chief remaining foreign threat in the Miami Biltmore tennis tournament.

The stork finally made its long-awaited visit to the Grazzianni household last month and deposited an heir to the Italian vendor's frankfurter stand. The Grazzianni family greeted the bambino with celebrations which carried over from the old year to the new.
ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- William R. White of New York City was named today State Superintendent of Banks by Governor Lehman, who transmitted the nomination to the Senate.

HAVANA, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Political observers believe Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, twice Mayor of Havana, will defeat General Mario G. Menocal, twice President of Cuba, in the Presidential elections Friday. Carlos Manuel de Cespedes, Provisional President after Former President Gerardo Machado fled in 1933, has made no campaign and has little chance of success.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- President Roosevelt addressed the Jackson Day dinner of the Democratic National Committee. Earlier in the day he conferred with Secretary Wallace regarding the situation created by the Supreme Court's AAA decision. Mrs. Roosevelt was a speaker at the Jackson Day dinner of the Young Democrats.

The Ornamental Pheasant Society of America, the first organization in its highly specialized field in this country, held its first meeting and election of officers yesterday afternoon at the fourth annual New York Poultry Show in the 244th Coast Defense Armory in West Fourteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Temple W. Seay, an attorney for the Board of Tax Appeals, told the Securities Commission today that a customer's man for a brokerage firm had advised him. M.J. Meehan, Wall Street operator, would make good any loss he suffered in Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock, which Mr. Meehan is accused of rigging.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8. -- Toronto's four-goal rally in the third period overcame a Yale lead and produced a 6 -- 5 hockey victory for the Canadian collegians in the New Haven Arena before 1,000 spectators tonight. Toronto defeated Yale, 7 -- 3, in Canada two weeks ago.

Xavier High School's undefeated basketball team registered its seventh straight triumph by downing Manhattan Prep, 27 to 16, in the Xavier gymnasium in one of the non-league scholastic games contested in New York City. At half time the winners led, 15 to 11.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Democratic leaders tonight predicted harmony for the meeting of the national committee tomorrow. The plan is to wind up all business in one session and then adjourn. Whether fireworks will develop on the floor, however, is a matter of some conjecture.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 8. -- The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company today celebrated its golden jubilee. Employes in the Pittsburgh district observed the anniversary tonight with a program in Syria Mosque, which was carried by short wave to simultaneous gatherings of Westinghouse workers in 100 American cities and eighty nations where the company maintains branch offices.

The Pennsylvania Railroad declared yesterday a dividend of $1, to be charged to earnings in 1935, thus maintaining the ratio of distribution to stockholders established in 1934. The action maintained also the company's record of continuous cash dividends since 1847.

A suitor, who was apparently more ardent than discreet, piqued at the refusal of the object of his affections to change her name from Swenson to Swensen, found himself held in $25,000 bail in Flatbush Court, yesterday, charged with arson.

The Governor's special message to the Legislature on law enforcement is another example of the Lehman method. First, get the facts. Second, have them reviewed by experts. Third, formulate a program. The message is a logical sequel to the labors of the Attorney General, the Judicial Council, the Law Revision Commission, the Commission on the Administration of Justice and the Governor's recent crime conference.

The last important "distress" block of public utility shares, constituting working control of the $575,000,000 United Light and Power Company of Chicago, is being sold for an unstated amount by the Chase National Bank to a group of investment trusts identified with the Harrison Williams, J. and W. Seligman Co. and Field, Glore Co. interests.

Regardless of the decision of the Court of Appeals holding Section 2 of the New York State Fair Trade Law invalid, retail drug interests here announced their intention yesterday of carrying on the fight to curb predatory price cutting, which has been widespread throughout the industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Owen D. Young of New York has accepted membership on the American Youth Commission of the American Council of Education, but will be unable because of illness to attend the two-day meeting called by Dr. Homer P. Rainey, director of the commission, to open here tomorrow.
ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- Bus lines now operating in Queens may continue for the present, the Court of Appeals ruled in effect today.

Prices of crude oil will be advanced 7 to 15 cents a barrel today throughout Texas and New Mexico. The increase was announced first yesterday by the Sun Oil Company in several fields of Texas where it is a purchaser, and later was extended throughout the State and New Mexico by the Humble Oil and Refining Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the largest purchaser of oil in Texas.

Postponed from last Monday, the premiere of "Truly Valiant," by Irving Stone, is announced for tonight at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre. Gustav Blum, in association with Ernest W. Mandeville, presents it. Ian Maclaren, Martha, Mayo, Margot Stevenson and Alan Handley comprise its entire cast, and Mr. Blum has directed. Curtain at 8:45 P.M.

Mike Belloise, Bronx featherweight, stopped Claude Yarner, Californian, in the thirteenth session of their scheduled fifteen-round bout at the Star Casino last night and advanced in the State Athletic Commission's eliminations to develop a champion.
Donald Richberg's criticism of the Supreme Court and of the Federal judiciary generally in his address before the City Bar Association was, in my opinion, wholly unwarranted.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Governor Lehman and the Legislature were asked tonight by the State Mayors Conference to authorize complete local administration of home relief, "subject only to such State supervision as is necessary to insure that the State's share of the cost is properly spent."

The American Arbitration Association announced yesterday that Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, would head a special committee in charge of a series of twelve meetings to be held in observance of the association's ten years of activity.

The soldiers' bonus is scheduled to come before the House of Representatives today, as debate begins on the most expensive plan for paying it that has ever received the endorsement of the Ways and Means Committee. President ROOSEVELT estimated last year that an expenditure of more than $2,200,000,000 would be required.

New York will escape a cold wave that has sent temperatures down toward zero in the last few days as it moved eastward across the Mississippi River, according to the forecast of the Weather Bureau last night. With the cold area turning northeastward toward Canada, rain, with not much change in temperature, is expected here today.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- Operations on the Boerse today were unstable at the opening but showed some signs of strength later. AEG dropped 2 1/4 points at the start, and the effect was depressing on the general market, which, as usual, was very limited, however.

Determined efforts to have the State Athletic Commission's temporary ban on Hank Bath, heavyweight protege of Jack Kearns, recalled were unsuccessful yesterday and the situation remained as it was on Tuesday, when Chairman John J. Phelan, with the concurrence of Commissioner Bill Brown, announced action on the applications of Bath and Kearns for licenses would be held in abeyance.

Although selling pressure on the Cotton Exchange lightened somewhat yesterday, enabling the market to recover about 15 points at one time, fluctuations were irregular and a dip in the last hour left the list 4 points lower to 12 higher than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission told Congress inferentially today that coal, oil and other interests had choked off the supply of natural gas to the great New York and Philadelphia manufacturing areas.

INDIO, Calif., Jan. 8. -- Officers and volunteers searched tonight in lonely Painted Canyon and adjacent barren desert wastelands for 12-year-old Alfred Altman, son of an official of a Brooklyn dress manufacturing concern, who has been missing since late yesterday.

The present national administration, by its failure to live up to "a single item of its national platform," has lost the confidence of the nation and is retarding economic recovery, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared last night.

In Edwin L. James's Jan. 5 article he refers to Section 8 of the Neutrality Bill of 1936 as capable of abetting League sanctions. Some of us believe that this will not be neutrality; that it will be taking sides.

TOPEKA, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Alf M. Landon, Republican Governor of Kansas, predicted tonight that "some new basis" would be found to supplant the invalidated AAA, and urged the government to "fulfill its existing contractual obligations with the nation's farmers."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Is the Lambs Club of New York a social, athletic or sporting organization within the meaning of the Internal Revenue laws, the Supreme Court was asked today in a brief presented by Harvey L. Rabbitt of Washington, protesting a tax of $101,121.

With Sales of General Motors cars to dealers in the United States and Canada together with overseas shipments in December, setting a new high mark for that month, sales for 1935 reached the highest level since 1929, the company reported yesterday.

A new super-detector, which physically separates the tweedledees from the tweedledums of the atomic world, was described last night by Dr. W.F.G. Swann, director of the Bartol Research Foundation of the Franklin Institute, Swarthmore, Pa., before the Science Forum of the New York Electrical Society, held at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Bowing on its home courts to the Harvard Club in last night's match, the Princeton Club's Class C squash racquets team dropped out of a tie for first place among the Group 1 teams in the Metropolitan League.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Seeking another approach to the crime problem, Attorney General Cummings announced today a nationwide survey of the parole system and administration.

Tentative plans for coordination of rapid transit facilities to serve the proposed World's Fair to be held in Flushing in 1939 were discussed yesterday at a conference in the offices of the Board of Transportation, 250 Hudson Street.

Omaha, 3-year-old champion of last year, which carried the colors of William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, to victory is most of the important stakes for his age group and emerged the season's biggest money winner, was shipped to England last night aboard the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

Price movements continued mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Trading was in fairly heavy volume. On the cash markets cotton, tin, rubber and cocoa advanced, while all the grains, butter, lard, printcloths and raw sugar declined.

Among the passengers sailing tonight for a 40,000-mile voyage around the Cape of Good Hope on the Hamburg-American liner Reliance are Ferdinand Roy, Chief Magistrate of the Province of Quebec, with Mrs. Roy; Mr. and Mrs. Alvan T. Simonds, Mr. and Mrs. Lester N. Stockard and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stearns.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 8. -- A communique issued from Emperor Haile Selassie's headquarters at Dessye this morning stated that the forces of Ras Seyoum completed yesterday their occupation of the whole Province of Tembien from the Takkaze River to Abaro Pass on the Adowa Road and northwestward to Makale.

A large model showing the East River Drive from Grand to Sixtieth Street was on display yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's reception room at City Hall, where it had been assembled by engineers under Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan.

It is a thoroughly enjoyable exhibition of prints that Fitzroy Carrington has arranged (for a brief stay, until Jan. 18) at Knoedler's; one that, besides constituting a rare delight for all lovers of work in the graphic mediums, recommends itself likewise to a general public that may feel the need of a moment's surcease in the midst of art's occasionally deafening roll of contemporary drums to right and left.

Mayor La Guardia's arbitrary reduction of the bankers' reserve in the 1936 budget from $17,000,000 to $10,500,000 last October had its repercussion yesterday when the bankers notified the city that they expected the full amount of reserve to be restored.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- The trials of Catholic monks and nuns on charges of exchange law violations were resumed today. About half the Catholic clergymen and lay members of monastic orders who had been arrested have already been tried.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The amount of money in circulation -- outside of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Banks -- in the United States on Dec. 31, 1935, was $5,881,710,819, compared with $5,535,671,557 one year earlier, according to the Treasury's monthly circulation statement issued today.

About 100 persons out of 3,000 holding administrative and supervisory jobs under the WPA here have refused to take the loyalty oath prescribed for them under the law and may, as a consequence, lose their jobs or be demoted to positions not requiring the oath and paying less money.

The vital need for a greater interest in the opera by the young professional and business men of New York vas stressed yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Mrs. Belmont addressed members of the men's committee of the guild at a meeting at the home of Mr. and Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, 10 East Sixty-eighth Street.

PEIPING, Jan. 8. -- A sharply worded protest charging anti-Japanese activities by the army of General Sung Cheh-yuan was presented at Tientsin today by Shigeru Kawagoe, the Japanese Consul General. The protest was served on subordinates of General Sung in the Hopei-Chahar Political Council.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 9. -- In an editorial today The London Times accuses American business leaders of forgetting that President Roosevelt "rescued them from disaster" less than three years ago. The editorial is typical of others in British newspapers, even the most conservative expressing amazement at the Supreme Court's decision and sympathy for the President.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- Building construction in this city and in the near-by town of Greenburgh increased markedly in 1935 over 1934, according to reports made public today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 (AP). -- A battle of alienists appeared likely tonight in Ann Cooper Hewitt's $500,000 sterilization suit against her mother, Mrs. Maryon Hewitt McCarter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- After paying a courtesy call on President Roosevelt as part of a hurried visit here today, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit radio priest, announced that he intended to bring suit immediately to test the constitutionality of the Federal Reserve Act.

The governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the application of six companies to list an aggregate of $70,000,000 of bonds and 2,986,030 shares of stock. They also received details of a new compensation contract between H.L. Green and the H.L. Green Company, Inc., whereby Mr. Green is to get 11,000 shares of the company's stock in the next two years.

The Columbia University Club's Class A squash tennis team moved into a tie with the New York Athletic Club for the lead in the Metropolitan League last night, administering the first defeat of the season to the Winged Foot players by a score of 4 to 1.

Before leaving Hollywood to serve a contempt of court sentence here imposed for failure to reveal his sources of information on racketeering, Martin Mooney sold the screen rights of his non-fiction "Crime Incorporated," published by Whittlesey House, to Fox Films.

The third engagement between men and women squash racquets players originated by the Metropolitan Women's Squash Racquets Association and played on the Junior League courts last evening ended far less favorably for the sponsors than the first two experiments.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- A rapid readjustment is being made between the price of fresh pork and hogs. A drop of 2 to 3 cents a pound in the dressed article in leading markets, compared with the quotation early on Monday, had some effect on the price of hogs today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Jan. 8. -- The M.I.T. varsity basketball team handed Harvard a surprise 30-to-27 defeat at the Indoor Athletic Building tonight.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan Jr. were hosts tonight at dinner at Villa Oheka for their house guests, Major and Mrs. John C.O. Marriott, Miss Louise M. Iselin, Rodman Arturo de Hereen; also Mr. and Mrs. Grover Loening, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer, Miss Grace Munn Amory, Milton W. Holden and the Earl of Carnarvon.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 8. -- A sealed command from Emperor Haile Selassie to all his chieftains ordering them to refrain from attacking the enemy "in a body" was disclosed today. The document ordered a continuation of guerrilla warfare and also outlined the procedure for collecting and transporting grains to troops.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- While the echoes of Monday's AAA decision still rumbled through the corridors of the Supreme Court today, it was announced that the court had decided to hear arguments in March on two other New Deal issues.

An adjourned hearing on the Long Island Railroad's application for an increase in commutation rates had hardly got under way yesterday morning when Joseph L. Weiner, an Assistant Corporation Counsel for the city, arose and demanded that the entire proceeding be dismissed because George Le Boutillier, operating vice president of the railroad, and not the company directors, had been responsible for the application.

A sharp recovery in steel production has followed the holiday interval, with ingot production now at 51 per cent of capacity, a gain of 3 1/2 per cent over the preceding week, according to the weekly summary issued by The Iron Age.

Senator NYE may be an amiable and sincere gentleman, but he is a little on the credulous order. He swallows scandalous rumors greedily, and puts the plate of evidence away untouched. In several addresses during the past Summer and Autumn he recited charges against J.P. Morgan Co.

The governors of the New York Stock Exchange rewrote yesterday the rule regarding the handling of customers' discretionary accounts, giving full authority over such trading to the new committee on customers' men.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- McGill University maintained its supremacy over American college hockey teams when it blanked the Harvard varsity sextet, 3 to 0, in the Garden tonight before more than 3,000 spectators.

The results of a study of the reading habits and purchasing power of nearly 1,000,000 American families, compiled to show the importance of this information to advertisers, were made public yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

At the annual meeting of shareholders of the New York Trust Company yesterday Mortimer N. Buckner, chairman, reported that net profit before adjustments and charge-offs for 1935 was $4,060,205, equal to $8.12 a share, compared with $5,146,751, or $10.29 a share, in 1934, and an average for 1929 to 1934 inclusive of $5,194,400, or $10.39 a share.

HACKENSACK, Jan. 8. -- Two conflicting statements were made here today, further complicating the relationship of Ann Cooper Hewitt and her mother, Mrs. Maryon McCarter. One was made by William V. Breslin of Englewood, counsel for Mrs. Hewitt, at her request.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 (AP). -- A committee representing sixty-eight labor organizations voted tonight to end their general strike immediately after two days of scattered disorders in which five persons were killed. The strikers had walked out in sympathy with stone masons who had been striking in orderly fashion for three months.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, yesterday obtained from Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler an order authorizing his department to take over for rehabilitation the Equitable Mortgage and Title Guarantee Company, 21 East Fortieth Street.

Harry Bache Smith, librettist, who died at the Marlborough-Blenheim Hotel in Atlantic City on Jan. 1 in his seventy-fifth year, named his widow, Irene Bentley Smith of 319 West 107th Street, chief beneficiary of his estate, it was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

The only way for the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas Company system to defeat the plan for a municipal "yardstick" plant is to reduce their rates by 30 or 40 per cent, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE Detroit Red Wings snatched a hockey victory from the Rangers and flew off before Manager Jack Adams could be apprehended and questioned on the use of what might be called the "stall gait" in the ice sport. A couple of weeks ago the stout Mr. Adams wailed that the "stall gait" was hurting hockey and, strangely enough, the other managers agreed with him for a change.

Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn will become the principal base of the Coast Guard on this section of the Atlantic Coast, it was disclosed yesterday when the Sinking Fund Commission voted conditional approval of a fifty-year lease for part of the field.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 8. -- At the close of the discussion this morning on the report of the application of the international labor conventions, Luis Yepez, Colombian workers' delegate, warned other members of his group that if they permitted themselves to be carried away "by the desire to attack capitalism and the curse of imperialism" without effectively tackling the problems confronting the conference they would fail in their duty.

The State Legislature will be requested to authorize a $200,000,000 bond issue for buildings to relieve "intolerable" conditions of overcrowding in the public schools, unless funds are made available immediately by the city or Federal Government, Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, disclosed last night.

The annual Wagner matinee cycle, including the uncut "Ring des Nibelungen," will be presented this season at the Metropolitan Opera House, beginning Thursday, Feb. 6, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.

Divide up the Supreme Court judges on the AAA geographically and we get an amusing paradox to play with. Of the six judges who voted "against" the farmer by outlawing the AAA, four judges come from the agricultural States of Tennessee, Minnesota, Wyoming and Utah, and only two judges come from New York and Pennsylvania.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP). -- Marv and Lady Bowman finished in a dead heat today to divide honors in the Oceanside Handicap for a $1,200 purse at Santa Anita.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8. -- Bob Kiphuth, Yale swimming coach, is going in for the "fish's eye view" in his search for natatorial perfection.

The Federal Government's most ambitious effort to restore the morale of depression-bound youth got under way here yesterday with the placement of the first group of 200 young men and women in National Youth Administration jobs. Mark A. McCloskey, NYA director for the New York area, promised that by the end of the month 2,600 other jobless young persons would be placed in part-time posts at wages ranging from $19 to $25 a month.
MANILA, Jan. 8. -- Cessation of sugar benefit payments has tied up about $4,000,000 which was ready for distribution here.

With only immediate members of the family and officials of the New York ball club present, funeral services will be held today for Charles A. Stoneham, owner of the Giants, who died Monday night in Hot Springs, Ark.

Initial buying operations of retailers for the Spring season confirm the stronger trend toward better-grade merchandise. Reports yesterday indicated that budgets in the upper medium and higher price brackets will probably be expended from 10 to 20 per cent over the same period last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Jackson Day Dinner at the Mayflower Hotel tonight crowded the ballroom floor, filled the balconies and overflowed into the the broad main lobby and adjoining private rooms.

Your Mr. Krock's Washington letter of today adds another to his list of public services -- he calls for a "clarifying debate," saying "it is open to discussion whether our laws are what a mathematical majority of nine Supreme Court Justices say they are." Democracies normally decide questions by a "mathematical majority," so of course Mr. Krock is not criticizing that test of the court's opinion.

Processors throughout the United States who deposited more than $150,000,000 in Federal Courts pending disposition of suits to invalidate the Agricultural Adjustment Act may be required to surrender some of the deposited money to their customers, now that the Supreme Court has declared that act to be unconstitutional.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- The tone cheerful on the London Stock Exchange today as a result of the overnight Wall Street news. A general rally in prices marked British funds on the resumption of investment demand.

Two armed and discriminating Negroes who rejected silverware and trinkets and searched vainly for almost half an hour for money held four women and an ill child prisoners yesterday in a home in the Midwood section of Flatbush, Brooklyn.

At least half the population of New York City depends on the city hospitals for medical care and ambulance service, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday in his report on his department's activities during 1935.

At tonight's meeting of the Bar Association a question will be brought up of great interest to it and to the public. Through its Committee on the Judiciary the association has charged itself with the duty of opposing the selection of unfit judges and of officials having to do with the administration of justice.
Radio engineers in charge of the Saturday afternoon broadcasts at the Metropolitan Opera believe they have discovered a "phantom of the opera" in that venerable New York institution.

State and municipal financing in December amounted to $120,353,034, the largest total for that month since 1933. The total in December, 1934, was $114,183,124. The revised total for November, last year, was $136,123,534. The total for 1935 was $1,188,494,586, the largest for any year since 1931.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- The chairman, managing director and other high officials of the Vickers interests, the great British armaments manufacturers, spent four hours today testifying before the Royal Commission inquiring into the private manufacture of arms in Britain.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, speaking as a former business man last night at the Jackson Day dinner in the Hotel Commodore, urged that the New Deal be judged by its accomplishments rather than by such "catch phrases" of politics as "regimentation," "constitutional safeguards" and "rugged individualism."

A gain of nearly 10 per cent in attendance at indoor and outdoor sport events under the direction of Madison Square Garden for the period of June 1-Dec. 31, 1935, is claimed over the corresponding period for 1934 in figures released yesterday by Colonel J. Reed Kilpatrick, Garden president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- President Roosevelt made a bid for non-partisan support of administration policies from "all those, regardless of party, who believe in retaining progress and ideals" in an address here tonight at the principal dinner arranged by the Democratic party in observance of Jackson Day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- With Mrs. Roosevelt as their honor guest and speaker, more than 2,000 Young Democrats, from 17 to 70 years of age, celebrated Jackson Day tonight at the Willard Hotel, while the major celebration, attended by President Roosevelt, was in progress at the Mayflower.

A woman whose identity was kept secret testified for two hours yesterday afternoon before the extraordinary grand jury in Brooklyn which is investigating the murder of Samuel Drukman and the allied charges of bribery and police brutality in the case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Echoes of the collapse of the Insull utility empire were aired today at the hearing before Robert P. Reeder, examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, on the application of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., for exemption as a holding company under Section 3(a)(4) of Title I of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- President Roosevelt has made one pledge based on the possibility of his re-election. If he returns to the White House as victor in the elections next November he will invite Senator Borah to join him on his deep-sea fishing cruises.
The Neediest Cases Fund was increased to a total of $248,673.38 yesterday by thirty contributions totaling $298.56.
The Intercollegiate Democratic League of New York held its Jackson Day dinner and a rally at the Hotel Astor last night.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 8. -- The Maryland Racing Commission, in session today, approved dates requested by the State's four major tracks for the 1936 season and in addition granted dates to three of the four minor courses. The Hagerstown Fair Association, headed so far as racing is concerned by Harold (Deke) Bester, has not yet asked for dates.

Secondary railroad and public utility issues were lifted to new high levels yesterday in the most active trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange since March 6, last year. Activity in the domestic corporate bonds was the heaviest since Feb. 6, 1934.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 8. -- Trailing 16-9 at the half, Columbia's basketball team put on a powerful drive to defeat Princeton, 32 -- 22, in its first Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball game of the season in the university gymnasium tonight.
TOPEKA, Ken., Jan. 9. -- L.J. Taber, master of the National Grange, voiced vigorous opposition today to a constitutional amendment for validating the outlawed AAA.

Plans for the acquisition of the Chase National Bank's holdings of 42 per cent of the voting shares of the United Light and Power Company by a group of investment trusts had not been consummated at the close of business yesterday, but negotiations were nearer completion of the deal.

A few minutes before flames raged through a dormitory of the New York Foundling Hospital, Staten Island, at 4 A.M. yesterday, a night nurse who had detected the fire roused twenty-four children from sleep and assembled them in fire-drill fashion for a march to safety.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- What will probably be a crucial session for the five-power naval conference will be held Monday afternoon, the session scheduled for tomorrow having been postponed at the joint request of the British and Japanese delegations.

Harold R. Cronin, 42 years old, of Bronxville, N.Y., president of the defunct Concord Casualty and Surety Company, which, up to its collapse in 1934, conducted the largest bail bond business in the city, went on trial in General Sessions yesterday on a third-degree forgery indictment growing out of the company's alleged mismanagement.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- The resignation of Raymond B. Fosdick of New York from the board of trustees of Princeton University was announced here today at the Winter meeting of the board. Mr. Fosdick is a member of the Princeton class of '05.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange ended irregular today because of profit-taking. Some British funds were higher, although investment demand was small. Japanese issues weakened in the foreign section of the market, while the Brazilian list was better.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Several alternative plans to continue temporarily at least the basic philosophy of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, but within the limits set up by the Supreme Court in its decision of Monday, will be submitted by the administration to farm leaders from all parts of the country gathering here tomorrow to help plan a new agricultural program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, who has been temporary chairman of the Youth Commission of the American Council on Education, was elected permanent chairman and Oven D. Young of New York permanent vice chairman at the opening of the second of the commission's four annual meetings here today.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, for more than fifty years a feminist, peace worker and woman suffragist leader, was the guest of honor let a surprise luncheon given yesterday at the Women's University Club, 106 East Fifty-second Street, to celebrate her seventy-seventh birthday.

The 1,463 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $42,893,198,741 par value on Jan. 1, had a total market value of $39,398,759,628, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. On Dec. 1 there were 1,467 issues, aggregating $42,232,388,273 par value, which had a total market value of $38,464,704,863.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 9. -- General Plutarco Elias Calles, former President of Mexico, who for many years was virtual dictator of this Republic, played a most unusual role this morning when he was summoned by the judge of the First City Court to give evidence in a case dating from 1915.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., were the highest bidder for $30,800,000 of Pennsylvania Railroad Company secure 4 per cent serial bonds, maturing $1,100,000 on Jan. 1 of each year from 1937 to 1964, inclusive, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21-year-old heiress, who charged that her mother duped her into a sterilization operation, tonight sharply answered an affidavit picturing her as easily infatuated by men in uniform.

The Union League Club, at its annual meeting last night, adopted a report of its committee on public affairs accepting President Roosevelt's challenge for those opposed to the New Deal to state what they would offer instead.

With seven of the fifteen members of the three 1935 All-America teams on hand to lend color and prestige to the event, the Middle Atlantic States skeet championship will get under way on the Loantaka Club field at Morristown, N.J., tomorrow.

ON BOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Jan. 9 (By Wireless). -- The Wyatt Earp is now about 700 miles in a direct line from Little America and well within range of even the weakest of Lincoln Ellsworth's radio sets, and still there is no signal from him. The sustained silence is apprehensively disturbing.

The country will not be displeased with the President for refraining from comment on the Supreme Court decision killing the Agricultural Act. His sole reference to it at the Jackson Dinner was to say that he was carefully studying the judicial opinions, and exhorted everybody to do the same thing.

No one but Johnny Gottselig scored for the Chicago Black Hawks in their game against the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night. But Johnny blasted the puck past Roy Worters four times to give his team a much-needed 4-to-1 triumph.

The right of skilled workers to hold WPA jobs while doing part-time work for private employers became an acute issue yesterday when Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, dismissed seven men from the WPA rolls.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP). -- A charge that Commander Sir Charles Craven, high official of the Vickers munitions interests, took an attitude that "the more munitions in the world, the merrier for the world" was made today at the British munitions investigation.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Twenty additional contributions, totaling $129.74, were received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the total for this appeal to $248,803.12.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- The part played by science in the art of music, especially through the medium of recorded and transmitted sound, is constantly growing in importance, according to Leopold Stokowski, who gave his first interview today since his rejection a week ago of a three-year extension of his service as conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Jan. 9.-- Ellis H. Parker, chief of the Burlington County detectives, who has been ,making a private investigation into the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., said today that J.J. Faulkner may be an important link in the case and may prove the guilt or innocence of Bruno Richard Hauptmann.

Unification of the air express service of the country, following several months of negotiation, was announced yesterday by L.O. Head, president of the Railway Express Agency. Beginning Feb. 1, the agency will act as coordinator of air and air-rail shipments over twenty of the twenty-three domestic air lines in the United States and the lines of Pan American Airways leading to Latin America and to the Orient.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- In his address before the Democratic National Committee here today Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman, charged that the forthcoming campaign would not be waged around conflicting policies of government but would be "a campaign of defamation" financed by "greedy, selfish interests" which dominated the government during the post-war Republican administrations.

Bank clearings for the first week of the year were the largest since Dec. 17, 1931, with the single exception of the week ended on July 3, 1935. The total for the twenty-two leading cities of the United States for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., amounted to $6,720,840,000, compared with $5,376,940,000 a year before.

England offers the best market for exports of American motor cars and automotive equipment, C.M. Peter, former president of the Overseas Automotive Club, told members of the group at a meeting at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday. Mr. Peter, who returned recently from a four months' business trip to the Continent, led the discussion during a symposium on Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Disbursements made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in December for activities of the corporation other than advances made to governmental agencies and for relief totaled only $96,867,589, while repayments made on earlier loans in the same categories were $117,586,191, according to an accounting of its operations since its establishment merit on Feb. 2, 1932, made today by the corporation.

A movement is under way among the important composers and lyric writers in New York to gain a "freedom of outlet" for their melodies on the radio, or in whatever medium they choose to grant performance rights.

Replying yesterday to the request of the city's bankers for a $6,500,000 increase in their reserve fund in the 1936 budget, Mayor La Guardia said he would take the first steps in the Board of Estimate this morning to end the agreement completely.

In behalf of the many children and mothers under the care of the State Charities Aid Association who are facing this year with renewed hope and opportunity, I wish to express the deepest appreciation to those who contributed to the One Hundred Neediest Cases published by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The cases selected this year for the appeal were unusually compelling in their tragedy and need.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- An additional list of applications for registration by brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission included M.J. Meehan Co. of 30 Broad Street, New York, a partnership. The application, filed on Dec. 16, has become effective.
More than 100 feline blue bloods and about a dozen alley cats snoozed in small wire cages yesterday at the Hotel Taft and waited to be judged in the annual show of the Atlantic Cat Show.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Wholesale prices advanced slightly last week, bringing the index, based on the 1926 average, to 80.9, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. This compared with 80.6 on Dec. 28 and 77.9 a year before. Last week the index for all commodities other than farm products and foods was 78.8.

The ending by the Supreme Court of the Government's agricultural experiment will at least serve as a test for the reality of the country's industrial recovery. Much the same thing was said when the court outlawed the NRA on May 27 last year. There were many honest observers who apprehended at the time that the decision might mean industrial reaction and confusion.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 10. -- The attempted kidnapping of a Soviet citizen by two Japanese army aviators who landed a military plane in Soviet territory within 100 miles of Vladivostok at 7 o'clock last night was reported today in a communique issued by the Soviet Foreign Office.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 9. -- Dedjasmatch Bayenna Mared, Governor of Bale, who for three months has been at Imi on the Webbe Shibeli River with his small camel corps and a Bale levy, today reported an encounter with a force of Italians and Somalis in the Karanle district, immediately south of his headquarters.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP). -- One unranked entry, Weston Painter of Minneapolis, tonight found himself with seven seeded stars in the quarter-finals of the fourth annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament.

COPENHAGEN, Jan. 9. -- The suicide of Kurt Tucholsky, former co-editor with Carl von Ossietzky of the famed German satirical periodical Weltbuehne, at Hindaas, near Gothenburg, Sweden, on Dee. 20 has just been revealed here.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 9. -- Minister of Finance Eduardo Suarez arrived today by plane from Washington after a series of conferences with Secretary Morgenthau on the United States and Mexican silver problem.

THE TIMES in its editorial "Demoracy in 1935" says: "The past year has seen here a marked revival of what we had always regarded as democratic aspiration and practice." Instances are given in support, but no mention is made, of certain American phenomena which seem to make the quoted observation unwarrantedly optimistic.

GENEVA, Jan. 9. -- The League of Nations published today the report of its expert committee on reorganizing world refugee work, both as regards refugees from Germany and previous ones under the Nansen Office.

The younger generation had its innings in last night's weak-kneed performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan. With Josephine Antoine and Charles Kullmann as the lovers, Helen Oelheim in the role of Maddalena and Thelma Votipka cast for Giovanna, the newly acquired youthful members of the company received a splendid chance to prove their capabilities.
Leases of office, showroom and store space in buildings over a wide area were announced by brokers yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Jan. 9. -- Complimenting Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer, who today celebrated their forty-first wedding anniversary, Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West entertained tonight with a dinner at Villa Tramonto for twelve.

The increase in quotations on crude oil that was started by the Sun Oil Company on Wednesday, when it announced advances of 10 to 15 cents a barrel in the price that it would pay to producers in some of the important Texas oil fields, was extended yesterday throughout the Greater Mid-Continent area.

HAVANA, Jan. 9. -- Cuba was preparing tonight to go to the polls tomorrow in the first general elections since 1924. The last obstacle was removed this afternoon by a ruling of the Supreme Court denying a petition of Dr. Manuel de la Cruz, ousted Liberal Presidential candidate, who asked suspension of the elections until a decision had been given on a pending unconstitutionality plea against the electoral laws.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- A letter asking the Court of Pardons to grant clemency to Bruno Richard Hauptmann on the ground that he is not guilty has been partly identified as in the handwriting of the J.J. Faulkner who turned in $2,980 in ransom gold certificates in New York on May 1, 1923.

Richard C. Kerwick, a Jamaica lawyer, announced yesterday that he had helped C. Lloyd Fisher, chief counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, take an affidavit from Oscar J. Bruchman, a New York taxicab driver, for use in the effort to save Hauptmann from the electric chair.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Representative B.W. Gearhart, Republican, of California, asked Congress today to take steps to end alleged racketeering in New York auction markets for fresh fruits and vegetables.

Even at $50 a plate no one would think a public dinner could abound in so many iniquities as Representative FISH has discovered. The Congressman from Dutchess County says the Jackson Day dinner in Washington was a Lucullan display and a gala social event.

Leonard Weisman, described by Postoffice inspectors who arrested him last August as the "super confidence man of America," received a prison sentence of fifteen years after his conviction yesterday of mail fraud.
The gathering of the large professional tennis clan appearing at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night was completed yesterday with the arrival in town of Ellsworth Vines, the world's champion.

Cardinal Hayes praised the efforts of workers for Catholic Charities Land affiliated organizations yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral where he celebrated a pontifical mass at which 275 aides in the charity work received holy communion before attending their annual communion breakfast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,480,000,000, a decrease of $8,000,000 compared With preceding week and an increase of $16,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 9. -- Rather than "bail out" and allow their large bombing plane to crash on houses or motor cars below, three army fliers stuck to the craft when it developed engine trouble 3,500 feet above this village this morning.

Staging a brilliant comeback in the second half, the St. John's University five conquered Georgetown University, 41 to 27, before a capacity crowd in the De Gray Gymnasium last night. It was the ninth triumph in a row for the unbeaten Redmen.

Joseph Bentonelli, 33-year-old American tenor, walked into the office of Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Company, yesterday afternoon and several minutes later -- much to his surprise -- walked out again with a contract to sing the leading tenor role, that of Des Grieux, in Massenet's opera "Manon" tonight.

MONTREAL, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons moved a point nearer the Toronto Maple Leafs, leaders of the National Hockey League's International Group, as they played. a 1-1 tie with their local rivals, the Canadiens, tonight. The draw enabled the Canadiens, beaten in two out of three previous encounters, to retain a chance of winning the city championship for the season.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Ambassador Straus today presented the new officers of the American Club of Paris to the members at the first club luncheon of the new year. In doing so he characterized the club as one of the most useful institutions in Paris for bringing cordiality into Franco-American relations.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9. -- Mrs. Robert H. Montgomery of Greenwich, Conn., entertained fifty guests today at Elanar, the Montgomery estate here. Among those who attended the swimming party, luncheon and bridge were Baroness Frederick van Hogendorp, Mrs. Gilbert Grosvenor, wife of the editor of the National Geographic magazine, and her sister, Mrs. David Fairchild; Mrs. George P. Brett of New York and Mrs. Hugh McKenzie of Washington.
LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Noel Coward's repertory of short plays featuring himself and Gertrude Lawrence began the season at the Phoenix Theatre tonight under the title "Tonight at 8:30."

The dollar weakened suddenly to the foreign exchange market yesterday as rumors circulated here and abroad that plans for further, devaluation of the currency were being considered by the administration. Sterling rose to $4.96, the best price in more than four months; the franc advanced almost to par and other foreign currencies moved strongly against the dollar.

The share market had to contend with further profit-taking yesterday, particularly in the late trading. Price movements, during most of the day, were narrow; the closing was irregular. Trading on the Stock Exchange aggregated 2,995,000 shares, the smallest total thus far this week.

MUNICH, Jan. 9. -- Between 1,200 and 1,500 German-speaking refugees from Italian Tyrol are now in Germany, having arrived by twos and threes since the Italo-Ethio pian War began. Most of them are being housed and fed in refugee camps at Bad Aibling and other places in Bavaria.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Millers and flour buyers appear to have outguessed professional speculators in the wheat market. The pits in the Chicago Board of Trade failed to receive the heavy buying orders the trade had expected from the elimination of the AAA processing tax, causing speculative holders of May to liquidate.

Declaring that "a little American courage of the Spartan variety" would soon put an end to racketeering, Supreme Court Justice Black denied yesterday an application for a writ of habeas corpus for a witness who gave evasive testimony before the extraordinary grand jury investigating rackets in New York County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The House all but passed the united front bonus measure early tonight, after the bill was manoeuvred within one hour and 15 minutes into a position where only two record roll calls on its final passage will be permissible tomorrow.

The city is attempting to collect $14,000,000 from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for payments it declares should be made in compliance with the Utility Tax Law, which has been in force for about two years as a relief fund measure, it was revealed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- The market for hogs rallied sharply today as buyers competed for the largest offerings since December, 1934. A wild scramble developed following the opening sales at 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight decline. At the close prices were steady to 10 cents higher, compared with Wednesday's and generally 25 to 35 cents above the early low point.

The wool textile industry continued to operate at a very high rate during November, with total unfilled orders in the last week of the month at the year's peak, according to the monthly statistical bulletin issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The President conferred with Secretaries Wallace, Morgenthau and other officials in a prolonged discussion of all phases of the farm situation resulting from the Supreme Court's AAA decision. The President and Mrs. Roosevelt were hosts tonight at the annual reception to the judiciary.

BERLIN, Jan. 9 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Nazi agents deprived Boris Smolar, chief European correspondent of The Jewish Telegraphic Agency and an American citizen, of his passport tonight. He was ordered to report to secret police tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Jan. 9. -- When a fog hanging over Moscow prevented astronomers from observing last night's eclipse of the moon and frosts in a temperature of 20 below zero made an airplane ascent impossible, the civil air force was called upon and E.N. Floria, an astronomer, went up four and one-tenth miles in a balloon.
LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

At Philadelphia, June 23, Mr. ROOSEVELT will be renominated, however much to his surprise. In the contest between that city and Chicago financial considerations may have had their part, but the choice must have been determined by the President. The West is his own country. In Chicago Democrats are so multitudinous that traffic is unreasonably congested.

Captain Hans Kieff, newly named staff captain of the Hapag Lloyd liner Reliance, a job which is eluding him like a will o' the wisp, will have time only to catch his breath after his race for his new berth from Bremen to New York, for the race must go on, officials of the line decided last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Willie Hoppe tonight took a 28-point lead over Welker Cochran, the champion, for the first two blocks of their challenge match for the world's three-cushion billiard title in the grand ball room of the Sherman Hotel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Sales are running 25 to 30 per cent ahead and attendance about 35 per cent ahead at the two January furniture and house furnishings exhibitions here. Buyer registrations at both the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart passed the 5,000 mark for each this afternoon, as against 3,900 and 2,731, respectively, for the first four in January, 1984.

After a long and heated debate, in which the city's most eminent lawyers matched eloquence with one another, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York placed itself on record last night as opposed to the appointment of Lamar Hardy as United States Attorney here.

A drop of 0.4 point in The Annalist weekly wholesale price index resulted from the Supreme Court decision on the AAA, the figure declining to 129.0 on Tuesday from 129.4 the Tuesday previous. Hogs rose 72 cents on the removal of the processing tax and the grains were generally higher.

A banking group headed by Edward B. Smith Co. and including the Anglo-California National Bank, the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, the Bankamerica Company, Heller, Bruce Co., Burr Co., Inc., and the First National Bank and Trust Company of Minneapolis obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $4,000, 000 city of Los Angeles, Calif., school bonds.

The De Witt Clinton High School basketball tear downed the Erasmus Hall quintet, 44 to 12, yesterday on the victor's court. From start to finish the Clinton team led, holding a 22--4 advantage at the half.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 9. -- The Pan -- American Labor Conference today approved three of the fifteen resolutions which have been offered for its consideration.
Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford gave a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mrs. James Roosevelt, Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly and Mrs. William Hoffman.

Net profit of the J.K. Mosser Leather Corporation and subsidiaries, controlled by Armour Co. of Delaware, for the fifty-three weeks ended on Nov. 2 amounted to $2,339,713 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $3.94 share on 592,857 no-par shares of capital stock.

An aviation edition, each copy-bound in paper and weighing fifteen ounces, of "Sky Gypsy," by Claudia Cranston, will be published soon by Lippincott. It is designed for use in the libraries of air liners. It is the story of a 25,000-mile air journey over South America.

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- Prices on the Boerse today were mixed and unstable. Heavy industrial shares were inactive, Vereingtestahl losing 1/8 point. Machine issues were somewhat more active, Orenstein Koppel advancing 1 1/4 points.

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, yesterday canceled the entire card of boxing bouts scheduled for the Eighth Avenue arena tonight. The refusal of the State Athletic Commission to issue a license to Hank Bath, young California heavyweight who was listed to fight Clarence (Red) Burman of Baltimore in the main bout, was given as the reason for the action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Philadelphia was designed by William Penn and his followers in the Society of Friends as a haven for the persecuted who asked that conscience be permitted to be their only guide.
