According to the President, the Democratic party, which has chosen Philadelphia for its 1936 national convention city, is the refuge of the oppressed.

BELGRADE, Jan. 9. -- Owing to the steady increase in the number of fugitives from army service in Italy, the Yugoslav authorities are preparing a big concentration camp for their reception at Tuzia, in Bosnia.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Minister of Education Mario Roustan tonight ordered the Paris Law School closed indefinitely following disorders attending the attempt by Professor Gaston Jeze, Ethiopian adviser at Geneva, to resume his law courses.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- A steady increase in the winning percentage of Princeton athletic teams, which has prevailed since 1931, when it stood at .572 until 1934 when the mark had risen to .660, was broken last year with a drop to .631, figures released today by the university athletic association reveal.

A telegram to Ray Murphy, national commander of the American Legion, urging him to reaffirm publicly the Legion's stand, taken at the fourth national convention in 1922, against the adoption of a general pension system for World War veterans was sent yesterday afternoon by the New York Chapter of the American Veterans Association, following their fifth annual meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the premiere performance of "The Eternal Road," a new play by Franz Werfel, which will take place the week of Jan. 27 at the Manhattan Opera House for the benefit of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work.

A verdict of guilty against Battisto Salvo, accused of obstructing justice by refusing information in connection with his disappearance last Aug. 19, was returned at 9:45 o'clock last night by a jury in Bronx County Court. Judge James M. Barrett will sentence Salvo on Jan. 23.
INDIO, Calif., Jan. 9. -- Twelve-year-old Alfred Altman, whose "joke" caused a search by scores in the lonely Painted Desert, was found today near the spot where he disappeared Tuesday.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a rise of 5 per cent for the week ended Jan. 4, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figures are interpreted as indicating a favorable start for local trade in the first few days of this month.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Plans for a Chicago showing of the Boston-banned play, "The Children's Hour," were uncertain tonight as conflicting statements came from the Theatre Guild and the City Hall.

Mrs. Jane Norman Smith, who is chairman of the Committee on Equal Economic Opportunity of the National Woman's Party, claims in a letter to THE TIMES that this organization represents a large number of wage-earning members, and further speaks of "organizations of industrial women" which opposed the Minimum Wage Bill when it was before the New York Legislature.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 9 (AP). -- Ann Cooper Hewitt, the 21-year-old heiress who is suing her mother for $500,000 damages in California on the grounds that she had her unlawfully sterilized, was portrayed in an affidavit on file here today as a girl easily infatuated by men in uniform.
ROME, Jan. 9. -- French fleet movements, following closely corresponding British moves, claim full measure of Italian attention.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Four youths convicted of the murder of a policeman during a hold-up in New York a year ago were put to death together tonight in Sing Sing prison. Up to the last they hoped for a reprieve or commutation from Governor Lehman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Harry L. Hopkins reiterated his demand today that States and communities care for unemployables.

A former national tennis champion, John H. Doeg, was among those to score triumphs in the second round yesterday in the annual squash racquets invitation tourney at the Union League for Class B players.

Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title of actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30, 1934.
Two apartment house corners in Astoria were among the Queens purchases reported yesterday.

It is a pity that Mayor LA GUARDIA should allow his dislike for bankers occasionally to impel him to rash proposals. According to announcement from City Hall, he will offer in the Board of Estimate today a resolution seeking the abrogation of the Bankers' Agreement of 1933. Presumably his object is to bring to an early end what he likes to describe as "banker domination.''

Net operating earnings of the Bankers Trust Company in 1935 were $8,136,267, equal to $3.25 a share, compared with $11,452,111, or $4.58 a share earned in 1934, S. Sloan Colt, president, informed shareholders of the bank at their annual meeting yesterday.

With the signing by Governor Lehman in Albany yesterday of the Hendel-Brownell bill creating the New York City Tunnel Authority, the way was cleared for the drawing up of a contract between the Authority and the Public Works Administration for a $59,000,000 loan and grant for construction of the Queens Midtown tunnel under the East River.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Official correspondence leading up to the financing of the Allies by American bankers before the United States entered the World War was revealed today by the Senate Munitions Committee as follows:
Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke sharply yesterday under the heaviest selling pressure of the week and closed at losses of 8 to 85 points.

Bidding for a first folio edition of the plays of Shakespeare reached what is Believed to be a new high auction record for this country last night when a copy of this literary landmark brought $28,000 at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.
To next month's schedule add a Broadway production of "Love on the Dole," the London hit which opened on Jan. 30, 1935, and closed in London last Saturday night. Maurice Barber will present it here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The text of the Democratic National Committee's resolution today endorsing the Roosevelt administration was as follows:

OTTAWA, Jan. 9 (Canadian Press). -- Manufacturers interested in, or allied with, the automobile industry will establish a committee to attempt to reach an agreement on what plant machinery and equipment may or should be made in Canada.

The Pacific Western Oil Company and Getty interests, representing about 40 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Mission Corporation, have notified the management of the latter concern their stock will be voted at the meeting on Monday only for directors who will agree not to dispose of Mission's holdings of either Skelly Oil Company or Tide Water Associated Oil Company.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9. -- Laughing Sun, in the blue and orange silk's of Mrs. W. Plunkett Stewart of New York, won the featured Aucilla Purse of six furlongs by the tip of his nose today at Tropical Park. Great Haste, representing Miss A. Doris, was the loser in a bitterly fought stretch drive, with the Wheatley Stable's Bellum a length behind the pair. Colonel Ed and Warren Jr. completed the small field as named.

Foreclosed real estate consisting principally of flats and dwellings in Manhattan was taken over at foreclosure sales by plaintiffs yesterday. Seven properties were disposed of in this manner and two sales were adjourned to next week.

Women's garment manufacturers producing 86 per cent of the total output of coats and suits in the country are participating in the activities of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, it was reported yesterday by Alexander Printz, chairman, at the semi-annual meeting of the executive council at its offices, 132 West Thirty-second Street.

IT turns out that James J. Braddock, heavyweight champion of the world, has been practicing something more than card tricks since he climbed to the pugilistic throne. His manager, Joe Gould, was telling about it, with gestures. Jersey James sat near by, nodding agreement and tossing in a few comments in a low and husky voice now and then.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- A resolution calling for a Senate investigation of the Federal Government's machinery with a view to complete reorganization in the interest of economy was introduced today by Senator Byrd. He asked that a committee of five be set to make the survey.
A drastic realignment of the country's first ten in the men's 1935 list has been made by the national ranking committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, it was announced yesterday.

HONOLULU, Jan. 9. -- Continuing the researches for future Pacific airways the Coast Guard cutter Itasca sailed this afternoon for Baker, Howland and Jarvis Islands, carrying relief personnel for the aerological observation stations that have been maintained on those islands since March, 1935.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Fiat Company of Torino, Italy, (Fiat, Societa Anonima), has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the permanent registration of $6,149,000 of twenty-year sinking fund 7 per cent gold debenture bonds, due on July 1, 1946, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Commencing Jan. 1 the payroll of every employer throughout the country, with certain limited exceptions, is being taxed 1 per cent by the Federal Government. The moneys thus raised, which will be increased by the imposition of a 2 per cent tax next year and then continued on a 3 per cent basis, will be used for unemployment insurance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Democratic National Convention was "knocked down" today to Philadelphia, the highest bidder, in a session of the Democratic National Committee which resembled now an auction and now a poker game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Fiat Company of Torino, Italy, (Fiat, Societa Anonima), has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the permanent registration of $6,149,000 of twenty-year sinking fund 7 per cent gold debenture bonds, due on July 1, 1946, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Under the influence of the seasonal return flow of currency from circulation and the disbursement by the Treasury of funds collected last month, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $150,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve's weekly report, issued yesterday.

VIENNA, Jan. 9. -- Two young Englishmen, Gerald Plunkett and Robert Burtram, Cambridge undergraduates, have arrived in Vienna after an unpleasant experience such as tourists may encounter who take the risk in search of Winter sports of visiting a country like Austria, which is under a police dictatorship.

Differences between student leaders and Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men, and the hissing of Edward N. Kinney, ranking officer of the R.O.T.C., one of the speakers, marred an otherwise peaceful assembly in the Great Hall of City College, where about 850 undergraduates convened yesterday afternoon for a forum on the American Student Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- This country and Switzerland ended today a serious rupture in trade relations dating from the passage of the Tariff Act of 1930 with the signing of a reciprocal trade agreement which will become effective Feb. 15, 1936.

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- The German Foreign Ministry, through its semi-official organ, the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, draws today an expected German conclusion from the Morgan investigation in Washington.

Mrs. Henry Wise Miller gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 450 East Fifty-second Street, for Miss Virginia C. Gildersleeve, who will complete her twenty-fifth year as dean of Barnard College next month. The hostess, a trustee of the college and a classmate of Miss Gildersleeve, was assisted at the tea tables by Mrs. Joseph R. Swan.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Lord Lee of Fareham said tonight that the allegation that he had suggested the British fleet might guard the Atlantic, leaving the United States free to concentrate in the Pacific, was entirely without foundation. Lord Lee added:

Joseph Pitman, proprietor of a large trucking business in downtown Manhattan, several of his employes and a quantity of his business records were subpoenaed yesterday by investigators on the staff of Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor investigating the murder of Samuel Drukman in Brooklyn last March.

A racing season of 172 days, six more than last year, to start at Jamaica April 15 and close at Empire City Oct. 31 is practically assured for metropolitan racegoers. This was learned from a reliable source yesterday following the adoption by the stewards of the Jockey Club at their annual meeting of a schedule of dates which was submitted to the State Racing Commission for approval.
BERLIN, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

Commencing Jan. 1 the payroll of every employer throughout the country, with certain limited exceptions, is being taxed 1 per cent by the Federal Government. The moneys thus raised, which will be increased by the imposition of a 2 per cent tax next year and then continued on a 3 per cent basis, will be used for unemployment insurance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Democratic National Convention was "knocked down" today to Philadelphia, the highest bidder, in a session of the Democratic National Committee which resembled now an auction and now a poker game.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Five United States sportsmen challenged for the Grand National Steeplechase classic today. They nominated six horses, one of them American bred, for the world's most trying jumping test, which will be renewed at Aintree March 27.

GENEVA, Jan. 9. -- Jewish and refugee circles here take seriously the London reports connecting Sir Herbert Samuel with a plan for the financing of the transfer of property of Jewish refugees from Germany with a fund advanced by non-German Jews and repaid through German exports.

TOKYO, Jan. 9. -- Memoranda from the papers of the late Adolph S. Ochs, contained in Chapter III of a forthcoming book by Eugene J. Young, excerpts from which were cabled from New York to the Asahi, have made an intense impression in official circles here.

Miss Henrietta Szold, veteran Zionist leader, received New York's official greeting yesterday from Mayor La Guardia and the acclaim of 2,000 members of Hadassah for her work in the transference of German-Jewish youth to Palestine. The program was a part also of the celebration of Miss Szold's seventy-fifth birthday on Dec. 21.
LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Nine persons were known to be dead and many were injured tonight as the second violent storm of the week in the British Isles caused wide-spread damage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The secret lockers of the White House, the State Department, the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Board were opened wide today by the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee to reveal a sudden change in neutrality policy by President Wilson to permit allied financing in this country before the United States entered the World War.

TWENTY years ago F. Scott Fitzgerald's Rosalinds and Amory Blaines were dancing to the tune of "Poor Butterfly," and it probably meant something to them, at least in their more sentimental moments. But it is unlikely that it meant anything to the occasional Japanese who may have put the record on his scratchy phonograph, for its theme -- that of romantic love -- is something out of European literature, not out of Japanese.
PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Somewhat to general surprise, the Bank of France further reduced today the discount rate from 5 to 4 per cent, following the reduction from 6 to 5 per cent ten days ago.
Apartment houses and dwellings in scattered sections of Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn passed to new control in transactions announced yesterday. Some of the buildings will be altered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Cash receipts from United States savings (baby) bonds from March, 1, 1935, to the close of the year amounted to $202,500,000, with 997.000 individual securities having been transferred to investors, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

The long-awaited Regulation U of the Federal Reserve Board, to govern the extension of credit by banks on security collateral, will not be whipped into tentative form and submitted to bankers for criticism for at least another month, according to the best available information in Wall Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP). -- William A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, pleaded today for a cessation of regulatory legislation on business and warned that labor's high wages depended on maintenance of the protective tariff.

Daily newspaper advertising has the confidence of the American public, according to a survey made public yesterday by Charles A. Stech, consumer and advertising research specialist. The survey canvassed more than 5,000 persons in twenty-one States and 122 occupations.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed transfer of the membership in the Exchange of the late Arthur C. Crunden to Allen A. Pierce, who, if elected to membership, will become a floor broker. Mr. Pierce is a nephew of E.A. Pierce, with whose firm, the largest wire house in the country, he has been associated several years.

Weakness prevailed in all the commodity futures markets yesterday in varying degrees of activity. Coffee futures advanced in some months and lost ground in others. On the cash markets declines occurred in all the gains, cotton, lard and rubber.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- John Van A. MacMurray was appointed by President Roosevelt today as Ambassador to Turkey, succeeding Robert P. Skinner. He has been Minister to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
ROME, Jan. 9. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's million-man army was shown today to be at full strength.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Members of the Social Security Act Board have been told that employers in industrial States are requesting their employes to fill out detailed questionnaires concerning their personal lives, including religion, union affiliation, "racial color" and education on the ground that Federal agents will soon call for the replies in conformity with the provisions of the Social Security Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- With the first shock of the Supreme Court's invalidation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act beginning to wear off, several Senators today began to move toward various proposed solutions of the situation thus created.

Two suits seeking the recovery for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway of more than $11,500,000, alleged to have been lost by the road through the purchase of two blocks of stock, one in 1926 and the other in 1930, were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman.

ST. THOMAS, V.I., Jan. 9. -- Virgin Islanders lined the dock here tonight to welcome Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, who arrived in a United States army plane piloted by Colonel Moore, a World War veteran, while a military guard of honor, the first since the withdrawal of United States military forces from the islands, stood at attention.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Far from being frosted by minority Supreme Court attendance, the White House reception to the judiciary tonight turned out to have a six-to-three decision for a very good time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- A statement that the administration neutrality bill was an "amateurish attempt to change the rules of international law" was made by Edwin M. Borchard, Professor of International Law at Yale, at the opening of hearings by the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 9. -- Ethiopia claimed a smashing victory on the southern front today to add to a major success in the north.

If you are looking for the source of the title of Irving Stone's "Truly Valiant," which was put on at the Forty-ninth Street last evening, you will find it in a quotation from Shakespeare in the program -- He's truly valiant, that can wisely suffer.

The first sound made last night by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, playing in Carnegie Hall, emphasized the fact of the peerlessness of this band, which Dr. Koussevitzky, its conductor, has so admirably developed. The tone speaks for itself, in its balance, euphony and brilliance and in the excellence of solo passages.

In your issue of Jan. 5 there are references in dispatches and in your editorial to a matter of importance which has engaged my attention for some years, and which needs to be seriously studied by Congress as it debates the neutrality legislation. This is the meaning of the word "belligerent" in the new international situation of today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- A new farm-aid program based upon the idea of soil conservation as sponsored by President Roosevelt, and supplemented by a scheme of crop insurance for basic agricultural production, began taking shape here today as farm leaders from every section of the country met with administration officials in an effort to find a substitute for the outlawed Agricultural Adjustment Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- With the exception of 1919 and 1920, last year was the most active in the history of the United States mint service in the production of domestic coinage, Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, director of the mint, announced today.

Plugging away quietly in the confusion that is Washington, Secretary HULL has succeeded in negotiating his tenth tariff treaty -- a reciprocal trade agreement with Switzerland. It represents an exchange of concessions on products which are largely noncompetitive.

Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, considered the foremost Christian leader in Japan, will speak in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens at seventeen separate meetings Jan. 24, 25, 26 and 27. His schedule has been arranged by the Rev. J. Henry Carpenter, Eastern States director of the American itinerary for Dr. Kagawa.

Sheriff Peter J. McGuinness, whose staff of about sixty deputies usually is concerned with serving writs and attending to court routines, announced yesterday that he would swear in 5,000 special deputies for his war on crime. Before the new deputies are sworn in, Mr. McGuinness must go to Albany to get special legislation to permit them to carry pistols.

Colgate's swimming team inaugurated its season by conquering New York University, 40 -- 31, last night at the Park Central Pool. The setback was the second in as many meets for the Violet, which captured two individual first places and the relay of the eight events contested.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Democratic leaders, following yesterday's meeting of the National Committee, began making plans for a vigorous campaign in the Eastern States, to be started immediately after the National Convention in Philadelphia on June 23.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- A proposed survey of social welfare agencies to determine the degree and extent of their usefulness to young people headed the list of five projects considered today by the Youth Commission of the American Council of Education at the last of its two-day sessions here.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 10. -- An earthquake, followed by landslides which swallowed up villages, killed between 200 and 300 persons in Southern Colombia, dispatches said tonight.

The bonus lobby had its day yesterday in the House of Representatives. By an overwhelming vote, even larger than the vote on the Patman bill last March, the Vinson bill was approved and sent to the Senate. The test came at the end of only a few hours of debate. But that was time enough.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company reported yesterday for 1935 net earnings of $23,896,398 after deducting taxes, depreciation and all charges. This was equivalent to $2.38 a share on the combined 10,000,000 shares of common and Class B common stock outstanding. In 1934, the company earned $21,536,894, or $2.15 a share.

Governors Island, headquarters of the Second Corps Area, will be thoroughly renovated to give it an aspect commensurate with its rating as prize post of the army. Other near-by military reservations also will be improved. A WPA appropriation of $1,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday, has been made to carry out the modernization program, which will give work to 5,000 men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Robert G. Page, regional administrator of the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has submitted his resignation, to be effective on Jan. 31. He will become a member of the law firm of Debevoise, Stevenson, Plimpton Page of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Elimination of a phrase from the administration's neutrality bill which some Senators feared might mean a link with the League of Nations, was accepted by Secretary Hull as he sat today with the Foreign Relations Committee behind closed doors.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10. -- Philadelphia today started intensive preparations for the Democratic National Convention, to open here June 23.

The recent crude oil price advances in Texas and New Mexico were extended yesterday to the Rocky Mountain, Illinois and Kentucky fields by the Ohio Oil Company, which increased prices in these areas by about 10 cents a barrel, bringing prices in these areas in line with those of the Mid-Continent field.

I am writing this letter in memory of a boy who no longer needs our aid. Fifteen when I met him, he looked barely 10 -- so bent and twisted and crippled he was -- but gnarled and tough with the old, old stuff of which the fighters for life are made.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The value of United States exports to all major geographical divisions of the world increased markedly in November over the corresponding month the year before, the Department of Commerce reported today. Imports also increased, but in lesser degree and, in the case of Southern North America, a decline was noted.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- J.P. Morgan did his best today to make peace with newspaper men who had heard testimony that in 1915 he called some of their writings "idiocy."

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- Informal exchanges between the five delegations of the naval conference today have seemed to leave it more certain than ever, if that is possible, that the Japanese will leave the conference soon after it is resumed next week.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 10. -- A merger of the Sharon Steel Hoop Company and the Pittsburgh Steel Company was indicated today, in the view of some observers, when an officer of Sharon Steel confirmed a report of the purchase of a block of Pittsburgh Steel common and preferred shares by his company.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 (AP). -- Indictments were returned today charging Cornelius Van Schaak Roosevelt, 20 years old, a grandson of former President Theodore Roosevelt,' and a college classmate with assault with a dangerous weapon in what the pair said was a bit of "relaxation."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP). -- Two tennis players undaunted by national rankings or high seedings marched into the semi-final round of the fourth annual Miami Biltmore tournament with straight-set victories today.

Baron Robert de Nexon, captain of the French bridge team that competed with the Four Aces here, will sail today for Paris on the French liner Ile de France. He will be accompanied by the other members of the team -- Pierre Albarran, Emmanuel Tulumaris and Sophocle Venizelos.

VIENNA, Jan. 10. -- In connection with Austria's sounding the ground in Czechoslovakia, presumably in search of a new protector in the Little Entente to replace Italy during her absorption in the conflict with Ethiopia and the League of Nations, it is learned with interest here that the Czechoslovak Premier, Dr. Milan Hodza, stopped in Vienna unannounced yesterday afternoon en route from the Italian Riviera to Prague.

Despite the inevitable slackening off of business in the nocturnal joy-haunts since New Year's, an event of major proportions is on the calendar for next week -- the reopening of the erstwhile Casino de Paree under the name of the Palladium Music Hall and the management of Angelo Palange.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area made favorable progress during the week. Consumer demand for seasonal merchandise was well maintained and expanding interest was shown in between-seasons offerings of style apparel. Because of the fact that adverse weather conditions curbed trade during the early part of the corresponding week last year, a number of establishments here showed sharp gains for the period.

Supreme Court Justice John L. Walsh refused yesterday to grant an injunction sought by the Harlem Market Company, Ltd., against Mayor La Guardia and "practically all of the officials of the City of New York charged with the enforcement of law."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 10. -- Many dinner parties marked tonight's formal opening of the Beach Club for the season. Mrs. Henry R. Rea entertained for Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Replogle, Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Harris, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shearson, Mrs. E.H.G. Slater and Mrs. Annie F. Breniser; Mrs. Margaret Emerson had twelve guests, including Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C.P. Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. John C. King and Major Richard Cooper.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Neverfade, a veteran campaigner from P.T. Catalano's Stable, staged a great finish today to chalk up his first victory of the year in accounting for the mile and seventy-yard feature at the Fair Grounds.

Ten truckmen were questioned yesterday by the special grand jury in Brooklyn as it ended its first week of investigating the murder last March 3 of Sam Drukman in a garage at 225 Moore Street. Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor, intimated indictments would be ready the middle of next week.
Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in 1935 aggregated $297,177,288,516, a gain of 13.7 per cent from 1934, and the largest total for a twelve-month since 1931.

TRENTON, Jan. 10. -- Francis D. Murphy and Truman H. Luhrman, both of New York City, are listed among 161 candidates who were successful in the October examinations for admission to the New Jersey bar. The tests were taken by a class of 434. Examinations were held at the same time for attorneys seeking to become counselors, but the names of those qualifying for the latter have not been made public.

Who could guess, merely from reading the reports of the Senate committee inquiring into the Morgan firm, what was the object of the hearings? Professedly, and under the authority of the Senate, the investigation was intended to help to frame and perfect the Neutrality Act.

The sale by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $30,800,000 of Pennsylvania Railroad Company 4 per cent serial bonds by competitive bidding on Thursday and the subsequent reoffering of the bonds by the purchasing bankers swelled the new bond financing this week to $56,879,000, compared with $11,650,000 last week and $55,634,000 a year ago this week.

ROME, Jan. 10. -- Casualty lists made public Jan. 5 gave the number of Italian officers and men who lost their lives in the East African campaign from its beginning up to Jan. 1 as 390, to which must be added fourteen unaccounted for, making the total 404. Eighty-six lost their lives in actual combat.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10. -- Miss Anne Page of Merion, defending champion, and Miss Cecile Bowes of Cynwyd reached the final round in the women's Philadelphia and district squash racquets championship tournament today by winning their semi-final matches on the Penn A.C. courts.

This is the season for colds and accompanying illnesses. The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross wishes to draw attention to its free classes in home hygiene and care of the sick, where simple nursing procedures in caring for the ill are taught.

The gradual improvement in stock prices yesterday suggested that the recovery in business since the turn of the year had reasserted itself as a market factor, even at a time when such compelling subjects existed as the soldiers' bonus, extension for one year by Presidential proclamation of the stabilization fund and the power to devalue the dollar, and the absence of an announced program of substitutes for the voided AAA.

Net income of the American Gas and Electric Company for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30 amounted to $10,417,619, equal after preferred dividends to $1.84 a share on 4,482,737 common shares, comparing with $9,443,156, or $1.63 a share the year before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Representative John H. Hoeppel, Democrat, of California, and his son, Charles J. Hoeppel, who were convicted by a District Supreme Court jury several weeks ago for conspiring to sell a West Point appointment, were sentenced today by Justice W. O'Donoghue to serve jail sentences of from four months to one year.

Two clubs are at present hosts to large group exhibitions -- the National Arts with the Members Annual of Painting and Sculpture, and the Union League with an exhibition styled "Paintings by Eminent American Artists." A number of the artists are represented in both places.

Koe-Ishyo of Edgewood, an eighteen-pound silver Persian tomcat, who has won 250 ribbons, was judged the "best cat" at the second and last session of the annual show of the Atlantic Cat Club at the Hotel Taft yesterday. This grand champion tom and aristocrat of catdom, who has sired about 200 offspring in his eleven years, is owned by Mrs. Bertha Costello of Springfield, Mass.

Textile High's sextet lost an excellent opportunity to assure itself of at least a tie for the city P.S.A.L. ice hockey championship last night when it was held to a 1-all tie by New Utrecht in the feature contest of a schoolboy triple-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Legal protests against application of the Securities Act of 1933 were taken to the Supreme Court today by residents of New York and Boston, demanding a review of a decision against them by the Second Circuit Court of Appeals. The validity of the SEC act is not involved.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Receipts of hogs here today were the second largest for a Friday since December, 1934, but aggressive buying lifted prices around 25 cents a hundredweight in the early trading and some sales as high as $10.25 were recorded, or 20 cents above yesterday's best quotation.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 10. -- Details were announced today from Emperor Haile Selassie's headquarters at Dessye of the recent victory of Dedjasmatch Bayenna Mared south of Imi on the Webbe Shibeli River about 200 miles south of Harar.

A proposal to link Newark Bay with the upper Hudson by an inland waterway between the town of Piermont, on the Hudson, and Hackensack, N.J., met strong opposition yesterday when Colonel E.D. Ardery of the army engineers conducted a hearing at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

Samuel Goldwyn's second batch of pictures for this season will include Sinclair Lewis's "Dodsworth"; "Come and Get It," from the novel by Edna Ferber; "Hurricane," by Charles Nordhoff and James Norman Hall, authors of "Mutiny on the Bounty"; "Perfectly Good Women," by Rachel Crothers, and "Pony Boy," which will star Eddie Cantor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- One week from the day that Congress convened the House passed today and sent to the Senate the "united front" bonus bill calling for immediate and full cash payment of the adjusted service certificates of those veterans who wish payment at this time.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The New York Edison Company, Inc., yesterday applied to the Public Service Commission for permission to issue $55,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent Series D first lien and refunding mortgage bonds, due in 1966. The issue would be put out at not less than 99 per cent of face value, to yield proceeds of not less than $54,450,000.

PARIS, Jan. 10. -- What may possibly be a new start in Premier Pierre Laval's efforts to reach a settlement between Italy and Ethiopia was made today when the Premier had a long interview with Ambassador Charles de Chambrun, France's representative in Rome had come to Paris "on a vacation" at the same time that his British colleague, Sir Eric Drummond, was in London.

Flashing a powerful offensive in the second half, the Brunswick School of Greenwich, Conn., routed Fieldston, 29 -- 13, on the latter's court in one of the outstanding basketball games involving Metropolitan private schools yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Stocks of grain on farms Jan. 1 were reported today by the Department of Agriculture as follows:

ARMONK, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Jack L. Warner, motion-picture producer, and Mrs. Ann Page Alvarado of Los Angeles, the former wife of Don Alvarado, the screen actor, were married at 6 o'clock this evening at the residence of Justice of the Peace Julius A. Raven.

On the eve of the hearing today by the New Jersey Court of Pardons, which will decide upon Bruno Richard Hauptmann's plea for a commutation of the death sentence facing him for the kidnap-murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., Dr. John F. Condon, the "Jafsie" who paid the $50,000 for the infant's release, sailed on the Grace liner Santa Rita from Brooklyn on a South American cruise.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Tightening of its code to safeguard 250,000 youthful gridiron athletes was undertaken today by the football rules committee of the National Federation of High School Athletic Associations.

A committee which includes William Lyon Phelps, Thornton Wilder, Helen Wills Moody and Frederick Hand Rogers is selecting nine works, verse, prose or drama, dealing with sport and less than 20,000 words in length, which will "worthily represent the United States in competition with other nations" in the Olympic Fine Arts Competition.

Injuries incurred in the war in Ethiopia may result in a disability award under the Workmen's Compensation Law in this State if a case now before the State Department of Labor is decided in favor of the injured employe, it became known yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10. -- Asserting that Germany and Japan are armed camps rapidly preparing devastating wars, Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff said tonight it was essential that the Soviet Union make marked increases in this year's military budget and put its defenses on the highest plane.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Willie Hoppe of New York increased his lead over Welker Cochran of San Francisco, the champion, to 240 to 177 tonight in the fourth block of their challenge match for the world's three-cushion billiard title.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The consideration by Congress of legislation for the regulation of the $2,500,000,000 natural gas and natural gas pipe-line industry was recommended in a report transmitted to the Senate today by the Federal Trade Commission.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 10. -- Rutgers defeated City College of New York in the first Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet of the season tonight, 58 to 13. The Scarlet swimmers took first place in every event and all seconds except in the quarter mile and 200-yard breast-stroke.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Representative Patman made the following estimate today of the number of veterans by States who hold certificates, and the amount which would be paid to them under the House Cash Payment Bill:

The United Hospital Campaign Committee, which began on Nov. 18 a drive to aid the voluntary hospitals in the city, has raised a total of $1,852,821 in cash, pledges and reported pledges, it was announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the committee, at the final report luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore.

OTTAWA, Jan. 10 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended Wednesday increased $9,553,279 and deposits in chartered banks declined $3,119,672, the bank's weekly statement said today. The statement follows:
READING, Pa., Jan. 10. -- Francis J. Bettinger of Reading won the twentieth Great Eastern Handicap, symbolic of the wing-shooting championship of the East, today.

The already tangled affairs of the nation's radio broadcasters and the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers were further complicated last night when ASCAP notified 390 independent radio stations that they must sign a new five-year license agreement by Jan. 15 or be held accountable financially for the broadcasting of ASCAP's music since Jan. 1.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- Ramsay MacDonald's candidacy for a seat in Parliament as a National Laborite for the vacancy in the Scottish Universities was hotly criticized by the conference of the Union of University Liberal Societies at Manchester yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Prince Splendor, carrying the maroon and white silks of Thomas C. Worden and making his first Santa Anita start of the season, today won the Glendale Purse in the feature race of six furlongs. The time was 1:11 2-5.

Real estate owners represented by the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations turned down flatly yesterday the demands of James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union, on proposed new contracts starting Feb. 1 and March 1.

The New York University women's basketball team won its first game in two starts yesterday when it defeated the Connecticut State College girls, 22 to 18, on the court of the School of Education at Washington Square. Leading the attack for the victors was Miss Helen Locus, left forward, who caged four field goals and five foul shots for 13 points.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Here is what the Bonus Bill passed by the House today may mean to the holder of a $1,000 bonus certificate:

PARIS, Jan. 10. -- The Law Faculty of the Sorbonne remained closed today because of the student disturbances in the classes of Professor Gaston Jeze, Ethiopian adviser at Genvea. The authorities stated the classes would be resumed when the students were ready to insure order.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Jan. 10. -- Intense activity by patrols and reconnoitering columns continues in the Tembien region. Several minor skirmishes occurred yesterday just south of Makale. In every case the enemy, presumably simply using their customary harassing tactics, were repulsed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Because of the increasing House favor for the Frazier-Lemke Farm Refinancing Bill, the administration leadership is considering dropping the attempts to keep the bill off the floor as futile and allowing the $3,000,000,000 inflationary measure to come to a vote, and likely passage.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 10. -- The resolution which Jose Antuna, Uruguayan Government delegate, submitted to the Pan-American Labor Conference last week and which called for setting up a Pan-American Labor Institute, as proposed at the Seventh Pan-American Conference at Montevideo, was withdrawn in the steering committee today.

Captain Hans Kieff, former master of the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, who has been running a losing race to join the world cruise liner Reliance as staff captain, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. nearly nine hours after the Reliance sailed.

A letter denying that it had rejected the franchise proposals made by the city's special committee on Queens buses was filed with the Board of Estimate yesterday by the New York and Queens Transit Corporation through Harold J. Cloutman, its counsel.

PARIS, Jan. 10. -- Yesterday's recovery of the franc and of government bonds, which was coincident with the lowering of the bank rate, has proved short lived. This morning when the Bourse opened some buying orders from the country kept the market for the moment in an optimistic mood, but soon the tide turned and swept away all of yesterday's gains and more.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- The right of a State to tax Federal property was argued today before the United States Supreme Court, which recently has heard many arguments on the question whether the Federal Government was encroaching on State power.

The city's embattled organ grinders disclosed last night that they will take to the radio on Monday in an effort to persuade Mayor La Guardia to remove his ban on them. Dassizzi Donati, Caesar Borsotti and Anthony Negri will use part of NBC's time at 10:30 Monday morning for an appeal for the organ grinders.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 10 (AP). -- Seeking to create an atmosphere suitable to college boxing and to control the crowd better, Rear Admiral David Foote Sellers, superintendent of the Naval Academy, today issued regulations providing for the wearing of formal dress at future boxing meets at the institution.

AMERICAN writers who concentrate on the dark side of the new Russia commonly don't do very well. Even persons tending to agree with them spot their books as exaggeration rather than realism and resent the attempt to put something over.

A month of close police surveillance of an apartment at 109 West Eighty-eighth Street culminated yesterday in two raids in which the police seized nine men, a quantity of policy slips, money stolen from a Fort Lee bank and a number of weapons.

Senator Copeland of New York is said to favor repeal of that section of the Income Tax Law requiring the publication of the names of those enjoying incomes over a stated sum. An examination of the list of names published in the newspapers fails to disclose any individuals holding public office possessed of an income in excess of the fixed limit.

Back in New York after accompanying the body of his late employer, Charlres A. Stoneham, from Hot Springs, Ark., to its final resting place in Jersey City, Manager Bill Terry bobbed up in the offices of the Giants yesterday and put in a busy twelve-hour stretch.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The mail of Supreme Court Justices has bulged due to the opinions that killed AAA.

With the announcement of the opening games of the 1936 pennant races, Ford C. Frick and Will Harridge, presidents, respectively, of the National and American Leagues, concluded their schedule meeting yesterday by revealing some startling innovations for the coming baseball campaign.

Mrs. Murray Whiting Ferris gave a luncheon yesterday in the terrace garden of the Plaza for Mrs. William S. Nelson of East Orange, N.J., who celebrated her seventy-third birthday. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Raphael Diaz, Mrs. James S. Alexander, Mrs. Fred T. Kelsey, Mrs. Charles Hathaway, Miss Maria Iturbi, Miss Antoinette Scudder, the Rev, Jerome Harris, Etienne Jalenque, Frank Carrington and Roman Totenberg.

Returning from a year's campaigning abroad, Jose R. Capablanca, Cuban chess master and former world's champion, paused in New York yesterday on his way to his home in Havana to further his plans for a chance at regaining his title, but admitting rather candidly that he seemed to be stuck for the next move.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- In a press conference President Roosevelt discussed the farm problem and intimated the administration expected to develop a successful new program before the 1936 crops are planted, but refrained from mentioning the Supreme Court's decision on the AAA.

Joseph C. Jacobson, 48 years old, president of F. Jacobson and Sons of 1,115 Broadway, shirt manufacturers, jumped or fell to his death shortly before 7 A.M. yesterday from the window of his room on the twenty-first floor of the Hotel Navarro, 112 Central Park South. His body landed on the roof of an adjoining two-story building.

BERLIN, Jan. 10. -- Is the American Olympic bobsledding team, which arrives at Hamburg tomorrow, too fat? This question was raised today by Hans Killian, German bobsledding champion and favorite to win the Olympic gold medal this year.

The undefeated La Salle Academy five scored its eighth consecutive victory of the season by halting Cathedral Prep of New York, 34 -- 25, at the Goddard Gymnasium yesterday. St. Ann's registered its fifth consecutive triumph, turning back the All Hallows quintet, 27 -- 19, on the victors' court.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- London dramatic critics with but several exceptions shared the first-nighters' enthusiasm for Noel Coward's first bill of three short plays presented at the Phoenix Theatre last night under the title "Tonight at Eight Thirty."

Trading quieted down on the local commodity futures market yesterday and price changes were smaller in consequence. Gains and losses were about evenly divided. On the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, lard, cotton, crude oil, tin and raw sugar advanced, the latter 5 points to 3.15 cents a pound, while corn, coffee and silk declined.

The will of the late Charles A. Stoneham, president of the New York National League Baseball Club, who died at Hot Springs, Ark. on Jan. 6, filed in Surrogate Court yesterday bequeathed his estate in trust in equal shares to his widow, Johanna Stoneham of 55 Central Park West; Mary E. Feeney, a daughter, of East Orange, N.J., and Horace C. Stoneham, a son, of 104 East Forty-second Street.

PEIPING, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Chinese reports reaching here today said Manchukuoan-Mongolian forces had entered Eastern Suiyuan Province from Chahar, gaining control of the important railway point of Fengchen and proclaiming an autonomous regime. The occupation was bloodless, the report said.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on exhibition this morning in its room of recent accessions the valuable collection, totaling 202 objects, bequeathed by Mrs. Mary Strong Shattuck, widow of Albert R. Shattuck, New York banker, and daughter of the late Mayor William L. Strong.

WARSAW, Jan. 10. -- The complaint of the League of Poles in Germany against the persecution of the Polish national minority in the Reich and the decision to send a delegation to Chancellor Hitler with a request to respect the cultural, religious and economic rights of the Polish-speaking citizens of Germany have reminded Warsaw of the existence of 1,500,000 Poles under Nazi rule facing the danger of extermination.

Discarding its cloak of mystery, the State Athletic Commission yesterday revealed why it had held in abeyance action on the applications for a boxer's license for Hank Bath and renewal of a manager's license for Jack Kearns. Advices that two of Bath's fights on the Coast were considered "questionable" by the California State Athletic Commission resulted in the New York board's move.

Two men were seized early yesterday morning in Brooklyn as they were about to drive away with a business man on "his last ride," according to the police, after he had failed to make demanded payments on a loan he insisted he had repaid in full.
Plans and specifications for the $11,000,000 West Side improvement from Seventy-second to 125th Street were filed with the Board of Estimate yesterday by the Park Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, with Secretary Hull's approval, today eliminated from the administration Neutrality Bill part of the section relating to bans on exports of commodities to belligerents which some contend tied the United States too close to League of Nations sanctions.

BERLIN, Jan. 10. -- The Propaganda Ministry said tonight, without explanation, that Chancellor Adolf Hitler's voice, which rallied Germany to the Nazi standard, would be heard less frequently in the future than it has been in the past.

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Constitutionality of the amended Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Moratorium Act was upheld today by Judge Elwood Hamilton of the Federal district court in an opinion terming the act not "essentially different from the Minnesota Moratorium Law," which the Supreme Court sustained.

The Columbia Club's Class B squash tennis team moved into the Metropolitan League lead last night when it turned back the visiting Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club squad with the loss of a single contest. Harvard, which had been at the top, dropped a tight struggle on the City A.C. courts by 3 to 2.

The forthcoming retrenchment program of the local Works Progress Administration, which will begin with the dropping of 10,000 workers from the WPA rolls within the next ten days, will also affect the WPA Industrial Re-employment Bureau, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, local administrator.
The biggest tennis show put on by the professionals in this city moves into Madison Square Garden tonight.

HAVANA, Saturday, Jan. 11. -- Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez y Arias, the coalition candidate of the Republican, Nationalista and Liberal parties, was unofficially conceded last night to have won the Presidency yesterday in one of the most orderly general elections ever held in Cuba.

Using airplanes and fast steamers and working at top speed to create several new varieties of double nasturtiums, David Burpee, president of W. Atlee Burpee Company, stumbled upon a mutation, a super-double hybrid nasturtium which has as many as sixty-five petals.
An increasing majority against the New Deal is shown in the eighth report on the Literary Digest's poll, published in the current issue of that magazine and made public yesterday.
TOKYO, Jan. 10. -- "If the United States is interested only in defense, why should she demand a navy superior to Japan's?" asked Eiji Amau, spokesman of the Japanese Foreign Office, today.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- Wholesale rejection of bids on supplies by the State Division of Standards and Purchases has followed the decision of the Federal Supreme Court invalidating the AAA Law and its processing taxes.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 10. -- Running to fast recent works and the good form he displayed during the New York season, the veteran sprinter, Quel Jeu, carried the Arden Farms' silks to a well-earned victory in the Withlacoochee Purse, six-furlong headliner on today's card at Tropical Park.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Common stock of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company was placed today on a $2 basis after a lapse of three years in dividend payments.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Methods of treating diabetes with a new kind of insulin were described by Dr. Elliott P. Joslin, Clinical Professor of Medicine at Harvard University, in an address here tonight at the Strong Memorial Hospital.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 10. -- A postseason, but none the less, gleeful vision of Santa Claus surrounded by an array of dolls, toys and candy, led 5-year-old Thomas Nevins Jr. and his "girl friend," Lena Senior, also 5, both of Newark, on a seven-mile walk through three towns today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The administration seemed determined tonight to throw back into the courts the fundamental constitutionality of Federal control of agricultural production that might be made possible by cash inducements to farmers within the limits laid down by the Supreme Court in its decision invalidating the AAA, the government's first attempt in that direction.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 10. -- The Estonian Cabinet has resolved to hold a plebiscite Feb. 23 on the Cabinet's recent project to introduce a new constitutional regime in place of the present dictatorial rule.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10. -- The rose and north gardens of the Bellevue Stratford tonight were banked with greenery and great pink blooms as a background for the December Ball, one of the noteworthy social events of the post-holiday season.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 10. -- An important "joker" seems to be concealed in the third one of the points presented by Foreign Minister Koki Hirota of Japan for China's acceptance, this point providing for a formal agreement for joint Chino-Japanese-Manchukuoan military action against communism.
The Long Island University five routed Alfred University, 56-20, last night at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court.

Extra-game matches were the order of the day, only one contest being settled in three straight games yesterday, in the third round of the Union League Club's squash racquets tournament for Class B players.

George H. (Pete) Bostwick, one of the best-known amateur riders in this country who has recently been devoting his time largely to polo, will return to the turf this season. He is coming back in the dual capacity of trainer and rider and expects to acquire a large stable of jumpers which he will train and ride.

With pistols pointing at them, fifteen women employes of the Adelson Dress Manufacturing Company, 183 East 107th Street, stood facing a wall in the company offices yesterday while three robbers took a $475 payroll from Samuel Adelson, the head of the concern.

For the first week of 1936 Cincinnati had to get along without a Mayor. No Mayor existed, for the simple reason that the Council, which has this responsibility in Cincinnati, could not bring itself to elect one. And thereby hangs a tale which may be of interest to other cities, even including New York -- and especially to those engaged in rewriting this city's Charter.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 10. -- Bernard M. Baruch warned here tonight that neutrality could drag us into war and declared that it made preparedness for war all the more essential if the nation was to retain peace.
I should like to present a few thoughts on the subject of character building in our schools in reply to the letter of W. Jerold O'Neil.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- In response to complaints of Oregon lumber mill owners. Senator McNary began inquiries today at the Labor Department concerning the tie-up of steam schooners carrying lumber from Pacific Coast ports.

Twelve-year-old Alan S. Glendening should remain in the custody of his father, Harold S. Glendening, New York lawyer, despite the boy's preference for "the more elaborate home his mother is able to provide," Official Referee Edward J. Gavegan reported yesterday to the Supreme Court.

The sale of $25,000,000 of corporate stock by New York City next Thursday will bring to $41,336,561 the State and municipal financing scheduled for next week, represented by 122 loans. This compares with a revised total of $27,140,847 for this week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10. -A charge that New York City is wasting $6,000,000 a year in the "miseducation" of 50,000 high school students not fitted for the kind of training they receive was made here tonight by Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of Schools of New York City.
" Don't let this bunch fool you," whispered the dignified, gray-haired banker who occupied the next seat. "We're just a lot of grown-up boys who still like to play Indian."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- At the hearing today before Robert P. Reeder, trial examiner, of the Securities and Exchange Commission, on the application of the Texas Utilities Company to acquire the assets of the New Mexico Utilities Company, Senator Carl R. Hatch of New Mexico protested against giving the permission unless the people of Clovis, N.M., voted approval of the proposal.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 10 (AP). -- Ann Cooper Hewitt's attorney, Russell P. Tyler, in an affidavit on file in Chancery Court today, said the girl's mother offered to be generous in payment for services he was requested to give in her behalf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- The Communications Commission announced today that it had denied a rehearing on its decision to bar three Brooklyn radio stations from the air and to grant The Brooklyn Daily Eagle Broadcasting Company, Inc., a new station.

The Federal social security program was characterized as "a test of public confidence in government administration" yesterday at the closing session of the annual conference of the Personnel Research Federation held in the Hotel Commodore.

Lamar Hardy, whose ad interim appointment by President Roosevelt as United States Attorney was disapproved Thursday night by a vote of 321 to 247 at a meeting of he membership of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, announced yesterday that he had no intention of retiring from office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- In the Senatorial munitions investigation today Senator Clark picked up a cablegram dispatched on Aug. 26, 1915, from Morgan's in New York to Morgan's in London. Negotiations for the coming $500,000,000 Anglo-French loan were in progress.

Enchanted by the orphic strains of the electron tubes, Dr. STOKOWSKI drops his expressive hands -- no baton for him -- and for the moment leaves the concert stage for the laboratory. As a musical counselor of broadcasting organizations and phonograph companies, his ears are opened.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP). -- General publicity of corporation salaries of $15,000 or more a year was stopped today by Representative Doughton, Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

The International Righteous Government Convention of Father Divine's Peace Mission opened a three-day convention yesterday at Rockland Palace, formerly the old Manhattan Casino, at 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, in Harlem, Speakers, both white and Negro, insisted that the time had come for the self-styled Rev. M.J. Divine to organize his claimed "20,000,000 followers" into a politico-spiritual force for good government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The Supreme Court was asked today if one unnamed Attorney General of the United States was legally correct in endorsing the organization of the Sugar Institute, an association of refiners, and in helping to work out a code of ethics to "remedy recognized evils without violation of the anti-trust laws," or whether a later Attorney General, also undesignated, was justified in trying to prosecute the institute for its efforts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- For hours today the Senate Munitions Committee hammered away in an effort to prove its contention that the slump in the British pound exchange rate in August, 1915, was a manoeuvre to force President Wilson to alter materially in favor of the Allies the neutrality policies of the United States before it entered the World War.

The United States and Great Britain, working side by side in friendly understanding, can exercise an "influence of unparalleled potency" upon the course of world history, the Archbishop of York, the Most Rev. and Right Hon. William Temple, declared last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Talk of inflation of the currency became a factor in the wheat market again today, and passage of the Bonus Bill brought in sufficient scattered buying to lift prices around 1/2 cent from yesterday's finish, with the close around the top.

The home of Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt at 49 East Seventy-second Street will cease to be a haven for Mrs. Vanderbilt's servants after Jan. 15 unless Mrs. Vanderbilt chooses to pay for its upkeep at her own expense. Surrogate James A. Foley ruled yesterday that the running expenses could not be charged to the estate of Mrs. Vanderbilt's 12 year old daughter, Gloria, after that day.

Emil Puhl and Dr. Hans Hartenstein, two leading figures of German financial officialdom, came to New York early yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. But if either of them journeyed to the United States to discuss financial matters with American officials or to sound out the possibilities of enlarging upon German credit in this country, nothing they said on the liner would give any indication of this purpose.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Smashing par by four strokes, Vic Ghezzi, the defending champion from Deal, N.J.; Harry Cooper, Chicago veteran, and Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., gained a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the Los Angeles open golf tournament. The pace-setters posted 66s for the first eighteen holes of the well-trapped course.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The Federal Communications Commission had action under way today to lay definitely rumors, already investigated and discounted by the Department of Justice, that one of its members was susceptible to undue influence.

The Federal social security program was characterized as "a test of public confidence in government administration" yesterday at the closing session of the annual conference of the Personnel Research Federation held in the Hotel Commodore.

Lamar Hardy, whose ad interim appointment by President Roosevelt as United States Attorney was disapproved Thursday night by a vote of 321 to 247 at a meeting of he membership of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, announced yesterday that he had no intention of retiring from office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- In the Senatorial munitions investigation today Senator Clark picked up a cablegram dispatched on Aug. 26, 1915, from Morgan's in New York to Morgan's in London. Negotiations for the coming $500,000,000 Anglo-French loan were in progress.

Enchanted by the orphic strains of the electron tubes, Dr. STOKOWSKI drops his expressive hands -- no baton for him -- and for the moment leaves the concert stage for the laboratory. As a musical counselor of broadcasting organizations and phonograph companies, his ears are opened.

BERLIN, Jan. 10. -- A public protest charging violation by German authorities of the national, cultural and religious rights of the Polish minority in Germany was issued today by the League of Poles in Germany, an organization which claims to represent the interests of 1,500,000 Poles living in Germany.

Zoe Akins's play, "O Evening Star!" which Harry Moses set upon the stage of the Empire Theatre only Wednesday night, will close after this evening's performance. Miss Akins's preceding play, "The Old Maid," also started badly and was nursed along to the Pulitzer Prize, but apparently the authorities simply felt it easier to let "O Evening Star" set as soon as possible. . . .

A two years' extension of the Adolescent Court in Brooklyn, established on Jan. 7, 1935, as a "social experiment" for delinquents between the ages of 16 and 18, was recommended by Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill, in a personal report to Mayor La Guardia, made public yesterday.

IT comes as something of a shock to note that the program for the professional tennis soiree at Madison Square Garden has Big Bill Tilden pushed somewhat into the background. Eheu! Eheu! Tempus fugit and all that sort of thing. The one-time monarch of a world-wide court is now a spear-carrier or a merry villager adding local color to the big scene.

The United Hospital Fund minimum has been so nearly attained that the community cannot let it fall short of that goal. There must still be thousands of persons who have intended to give to this fund but have not yet come to the point of sending a contribution or pledge -- and thousands of others who had not so purposed will now feel that they must help in this emergency.

After having broken $5 a bale in new-crop contracts as a result of Monday's decision by the United States Supreme Court, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday recovered more than 30 points to end with gains of 7 to 25 points on the day.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in December amounted to 661,515 tons, compared with 681,820 in November, a decrease of 20,305 tons. In December, 1934, shipments were 418,630 tons; in December, 1933, 600,639 tons, and in December, 1932, 227,576 tons.

Two potentates are rejoicing in heavy showers. Seldom can unseasonable weather have been more gladly welcomed than the unseasonable rains in Ethiopia. They have washed out the roads along which the Italians must advance.

The issuance yesterday of a Presidential proclamation declaring a continued state of emergency in matters of international commerce and finance and in foreign exchange was merely a formality required to extend for a year the existence of the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund and the authority of the President to alter the gold content of the dollar within the limits of 50 to 60 per cent of its gold content.
Mayor La Guardia's plan to end the city's agreement with its bankers was scrapped yesterday by the Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Stock transactions to create fictitious losses, and thus reduce income taxes in 1929, were charged to Pierre S. du Pont of Wilmington before the Board of Tax Appeals today.

Aroused by statements of lawyers seeking to take advantage of the circumstances surrounding guaranteed mortgages, the State Mortgage Commission, it became known yesterday, has sent to the 200,000 holders of certificated mortgages under its jurisdiction a circular letter advising them of its willingness to act as trustee in mortgage reorganizations and charging that the statements in question are false.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (AP). -- August Fourtner, Assistant District Attorney, announced tonight that mayhem complaints would be issued against Mrs. Maryon Hewitt McCarter and two physicians if her daughter, Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21-year-old heiress, would sign them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (AP). -- August Fourtner, Assistant District Attorney, announced tonight that mayhem complaints would be issued against Mrs. Maryon Hewitt McCarter and two physicians if her daughter, Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21-year-old heiress, would sign them.

Former President Herbert Hoover challenged yesterday a recent statement of Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes that Congress had passed laws which were held to be unconstitutional during the Hoover administration and called on Mr. Ickes for an apology to the public. A telegram to Secretary Ickes at Washington, made public by Lawrence Richey, secretary to Mr. Hoover, at the latter's suite in the Waldorf-Astoria, read:

" The average age of prison inmates," Governor Lehman said in his crime message to the Legislature, "is twenty-three years, but the largest group is composed of those 19 years old. Moreover, the tragic truth is that the first offender in the legal sense is frequently an old offender in the eyes of the parent, the neighborhood, the attendance officer, the police officer, the social worker and the church."

While 1,200 of his aristocratic rivals strutted jealously in their cages a lordly white Wyandotte cock owned by John B. Greenan Son of Saginaw, Mich., yesterday was named by a committee of thirty-one experts the champion large fowl of the New York Poultry Show at the 244th Coast Defense Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Smiling Freddie Lindstrom, center fielder with the 1935 Cubs, National League champions, was cast adrift today.

Holders of $249,456,000 of dollar bonds of the Government of Chile, the Mortgage Bank of Chile and Chilean municipalities were urged yesterday by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., not to accept the service on those obligations offered by the Chilean Government. The offer is $4.75 a $1,000 bond for two coupons, or less than one-half of 1 per cent of the contractual service.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
The total for this season's appeal for the Neediest Cases Fund reached $250,038.12 yesterday when eleven additional contributions, amounting to $1,235, were received.

The city ban on pin games, better known as bagatelle, became a fact yesterday when License Commissioner Paul Moss announced the suspension of all licenses for the various "Sportsland" and "Playland" establishments in the city featuring the games.

Preliminary trials in the annual Brooklyn Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's individual swimming championships were held in the pool of the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus Building, Brooklyn, yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 10. -- The proposed American permanent neutrality legislation, as viewed from Geneva, appears to be a question of primary, immediate and far-reaching political and economic importance for the League of Nations and all its members.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- A heavy fall of snow and cold weather in the Poconos continue to draw visitors to this Winter sports area of Pennsylvania, and the hotels report the liveliest Winter patronage in a number of years.

BARCELONA begins to look like the Marseilles of a new Riviera. The pines, the red rocks and the golden sandy coves of its "Costa Brava," or wild coast, have long been one of the most famous Summer playgrounds below the Pyrenees.

Mrs. Rogers Dunn Jr. of New York and Miss Edith Drury of Boston are the two new players to win a place on the American women's squash racquets team which will meet Great Britain's representatives in the fourth annual Wolfe-Noel Cup matches in London on March 9.

WITH more Winter carnivals and Winter sports events scheduled than in previous years, with vastly improved sports facilities, with plowed highways and numerous week-end and Sunday snow trains, skiers and other Winter sports fans are assured of an exciting season in New Egland this year, recent reports to the New England Council indicate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Proceeds from Jackson Day dinners throughout the country will total nearly $250,000 and will wipe out the party's deficit, W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the national committee, announced tonight.

Hamilton House Settlement at 72 Market Street will be aided by a pre-opening performance of the "Illustrators' Show" on Tuesday night at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The funds realized will further the work of the organization, which is affiliated with the Henry Street Settlement, and which provides recreational and educational advantages for about 7,000 Italians in a crowded district of the city.

The machine-gun speed of strokes that leveled all before him as amateur and professional carried Ellsworth Vines to a crushing triumph over Lester Stoefen of Los Angeles last night in the professional tennis matches at Madison Square Garden.

THE question of when and how children shall attend motion picture theatres caused a stir in parental, educational and social science circles last week in view of Mayor La Guardia's plan for liberalizing the law governing the admission of minors to the portals of screenland.

LUCREZIA BORI, Nino Martini and John Charles Thomas will head the cast of Verdi's "La Traviata," which opens the twenty-eighth season of the Metropolitan Opera, Tuesday evening, Jan. 21, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
WASHINGTONG, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Wholesale resumption of child labor since collapse of the NRA was reported today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

Two benefits have been arranged for the near future to aid the educational, vocational and recreational program of the Madison Square Boys Club. The first of these will be a beefsteak dinner to be held by the club at Jack Dempsey's Restaurant on Feb. 11. The following day, Lincoln's Birthday, a committee representing the club will open at the Hotel Lincoln an exhibition on the life and time of the Great Emancipator.

Running a front race all the way Jimmy McPoland, Georgetown freshman, took the measure of a strong field in the 500-yard special, the only invitation event on the program of the Sixty-ninth Regiment A.A. indoor track meet on the armory floor last night.

In a tiny court room of London there was recently revived the history of last February's pepper crash. A dozen firms of excellent reputation found themselves involved in that crisis. The windows of Downing Street rattled under the reverberations.

MIAMI. -- With ten major stakes, a total purse award of $349,400 -- or $26,300 more than that of the 1935 meet -- and the prospect of a record opening-day attendance, the 1936 season of horse racing at Hialeah Park will start next Thursday, to continue through forty-six days.

CHICAGO, Jan. ll. -- Willie Hoppe of New York tonight wrested the world's three-cushion billiard championship from Welker Cochran of San Francisco, taking the sixth and final block of their three-day challenge match by 60 to 38 in fifty innings. This was the one title that heretofore slipped through Hoppe's gifted fingers in his thirty-five years of billard playing.

FEARS of a new world war have not dimmed interest in the battlefields of the last one, for more than 250,000 persons a year still are visiting the scenes of conflict in France. About 70 per cent of the visitors are French, many of them being relatives of soldiers who gave their lives on Flanders fields. Belgium comes second with 10 per cent, while Germany is third with 6 per cent.

BOGOTA. -- Colombia is not in position to resume service of $22,000,000 annually on its foreign debt of $206,500,000, according to Joaquin Angel, financial expert, writing in a recent issue of the newspaper El Tiempo.

Mrs. Courtlandt Nicoll and other members of the Diocesan Auxiliary to the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine have arranged an illustrated lecture by John Angel, distinguished sculptor, for the night of Jan. 29 in the ballroom of the New York Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

The slashing of primary cotton goods prices last week, following destruction of the AAA by the Supreme Court, to levels far below those which mills had expected, may jeopardize the industry's entire program of maintaining former code hours and wages, according to opinions expressed in the local market yesterday.

The ten-year fight of the Armand Company, cosmetic manufacturer, to maintain resale prices of its products was reopened yesterday in Washington when the company, through Henry Ward Beer, counsel, served court notice on the Federal Trade Commission to show cause in the Circuit Court of Appeals here on Feb. 10 why its cease and desist order against the Armand Company: should not be vacated or modified.

THIS novel is based on the impressions received during a visit of about six weeks to Russia and it follows the same lines as the author's "Soviet Side- lights," published in The Saturday Evening Post in December and January, 1934-35.

Captain George Gibbons, master of the Cunard White Star liner Majestic, will make one more voyage on the ship and then leave to join the Queen Mary as second captain under Captain Sir Edgar T. Britten, the master of the new de luxe liner.

Prices of food bought by hotels in December rose 3.41 per cent from November, and established a new high average for the year, according to R.M. Grinstead Co. For the year prices averaged 9.82 per cent above those in 1934.

Townsendites may find that in the absence of a constitutional amendment all their efforts to promote their plan may prove vain. It would seem that the Hoosac-AAA case, which doomed Federal payments to farmers who agreed not to hoe their own row, may likewise foredoom the hopes of those who advocate that life begins at 60.
SO LONG as used car stocks remain at current high levels, automobile dealers and manufacturers will watch closely the effect of every step employed in sales operations.

The First National Bank and Trust Company of Minneapolis had net operating earnings of $1,218,526 in 1935, according to the annual report made to shareholders by L.E. Wakefield, president. This compares with $1,327,721 in 1934. After various adjustments net income for the year was $1,170,926.

AN ancient and oddly named British public post -- that of Master of the Rolls, whose first incumbent was appointed in 1275 -- has recently changed hands. It is now held by Lord Wright, successor to Lord Hanworth, who was forced to resign because of ill health.
Play was inaugurated yesterday in one of the season's blue ribbon squash tennis tournaments, the Clyde Martin Memorial, at the Yale Club.

Seventeen out of thirty-six major departments in local stores showed increased use of advertising linage during December, according to the analysis issued yesterday by Media Records. The total advertising space used by these stores comprised 3,933,323 lines, against 3,708,629 in the corresponding month of 1934.

IN centers dependent largely upon farm trade, retail sales last week were affected by the AAA decision invalidating control funds. In others, the weather played a dominant part in holding down volume. The result in them aggregate was probably a total barely over a year ago.
