WITHIN a mile or two of the largest automobile factory in the world men are busy setting up a very old windmill. In a short time the eight silvery smoke stacks of the Ford plant on the River Rouge will look down upon the revolving arms of this relic of a time when men traveled slowly in stage coaches, when mass production was unheard of and steam was still unharnessed.

Although the United Hospital Campaign Committee has closed its public solicitation in the drive to obtain $2,000,000 for the support of New York's hospitals with the goal not quite reached, additional gifts of $81,000 have been received. Many came from persons who had previously given to the fund but did not want to see it close short of its goal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- When J.P. Morgan corrected Thomas W. Lamont's biblical quotation on the relationship of money and evil at the Senate Munitions Committee's hearing last week, he gave his final answer to his Senatorial inquisitors' only slightly veiled charges that the Morgan firm's financing of the Allies led directly to American participation in the World War.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Conditions were spotty this week, but improving. Sales with the larger department stores were about 2 per cent below those of a year ago, due in part to the snowy weather during the first half of the week.

These elegies cover a writing period of twenty years and a variety of subjects: love, death, cities, countries, voyages, races, religion and literature; and they sometimes commemorate specific happenings, as the achievement of Edison and the loss of the airship R 101.

It was with great pleasure to read from your "Mail Pouch" the article written by an Elizabeth Wismer Ring with reference to Rosa Ponselle's rendition of the opera "Carmen." I too have felt exactly the same toward Mr. Downes for such an unfair review upon such an artist.

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- In unofficial trading in the foreign exchange market here today the dollar dropped from 15.12 1/2 francs to 15.06 1/2. This is the lowest point for the dollar in considerable time. It is traced principally to uncertainty in Europe as concerns events in the United States.

ONCE in a while radio electrifies a song, spreads it across the country and overnight the haunting melody begins to whirl round and round in the minds of millions. It is hummed, whistled, sung and strummed from coast to coast and before long is in the front rank of song hits.

NEWCASTLE, Ind. WESTWARD over the rolling midlands of Henry County, Ind., an airplane drones, winging its way through the late afternoon at more than 180 miles an hour. The passengers lie back relaxed or reading in the spacious cabin.

Poultry fanciers from thirty-five States and their aristocratic fowl started for home last night as the eighty-first annual exhibit of the New York Poultry Show, Inc., closed. The five-day event at the 244th Coast Defense Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street, was attended by a record crowd of about 10,000 poultry enthusiasts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Prosecutors today sought a final conference with counsel for Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21-year-old heiress, before deciding whether to initiate criminal proceedings as a result of her sterilization.

Activity in the wholesale markets here began well last week, with many out-of-town buyers here seeking Spring merchandise, according' to the market report prepared especially by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Early indications that an extremely good season was in prospect for suits was confirmed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Representative Wesley E. Disney of Oklahoma will be an honor guest and speaker, and his bill introduced at the last session of Congress, providing for the establishment in Washington of a National Academy of Public Affairs, will be the subject of discussion at several of the business sessions of the directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, who will open on Wednesday a four-day mid-Winter meeting here.

Andre Sennwald, motion-picture critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was killed shortly after 1 o'clock this morning when an explosion of undetermined origin believed at first to be caused by gas wrecked his terrace apartment on the top floor of the seventeen-story apartment building at 670 West End Avenue. Mr. Sennwald, who was 28 years old, became motion-picutre critic of the Times in October, 1934.

In a recent editorial you stated, fairly, albeit none too sympathetically, some grievances of Scotland against her too egotistical partner beyond the Tweed. May I mention some other irritants which an exiled Scot yearns to hear and see no more? The radio is probably my chief affliction.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 11 -- The insufficiency of available funds for the Princeton University Library and the crowded conditions caused by steadily mounting circulation figures, which reached the highest point in the history of the institution in the year ending June 30, 1935, were stressed in the annual report of James Thayer Gerould, University Librarian, which was published here today.

Last week will go down in history as AAA week. News of the Supreme Court's decision upsetting the Agricultural Adjustment Act at midday on Monday immediately plunged the security and commodity markets into a state of confusion reminiscent of the date late in May when the NRA was overthrown.

AMERICAN tulip and daffodil enthusiasts are stirred by curiosity these days as to the effect the recently signed United States-Netherlands Reciprocal Trade Agreement may have on the importation of "Dutch" bulbs. Domestic growers meanwhile are concerned over the possible reactions of the treaty on their industry.

A series of Wednesday morning lectures on flower arrangements has been arranged for the benefit of the Hudson River Community Music School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., the first of which will take place this week at the Colony Club. The speaker will be Mrs. Yoneo Arai of the Japanese Women's Club.

Two games of polo last night at Squadron A Armory made no change in the metropolitan league standing but left in their wake the firm feeling that Winston Guest's Optimists are alone in their class and that Lawrenceville School has one of the finest young polo teams that has even ridden out on horse- back.

THE American painter Max Weber is one of a group of well-known artists who have just joined the American Artists Congress, it is announced by Stuart Davis, secretary of the Congress. Others are Peppino Mangravite, Harry Hering, Alexander Calder, Paul Manship and Bernice Abbot.

PARIS, Dec. 15. TWO productions by the Dullin and Gaston Baty managements and a new play by Marcel Achard have been the theatrical events of this week. Dullin, who had had a run of bad luck and was even on the point of giving up his theatre, has now won a distinct success with a revised and concentrated version of a piece originally written in five acts by Balzac.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The statement of the new farm relief plan as adopted today by the conference of farm representatives was as follows:

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 11. -- The Dartmouth College athletic council announced today that Head Coach Earl H. Blaik had been given a new three-year contract. His assistant varsity coaching staff received similar contracts.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP). -- Apparently in the best health he has experienced in months, 96-year-old John D. Rockefeller Sr. enjoyed a forty-five-mile automobile ride today, the second such trip in as many days.

Organized relief workers and their sympathizers staged one of the largest demonstrations in recent weeks at local WPA headquarters in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, yesterday. Some 2,500 men marched around the building protesting among other things the contemplated reduction of WPA rolls by 20,000, recently announced by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- The Chamber Music Society of America will present two concerts this week in Westchester. On Friday evening Georges Barrere, flutist; Carlos Salzedo, harpist, and Horace Britt, 'cellist, will appear at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Debry here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Although industrial activity slackened in the two weeks ended on Jan. 4 because of holiday influences, there is no present indication of a reversal of the general upward trend, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business survey.

May I add my congratulations to those undoubtedly piling up on the desks of the members of the New York Film Critics after the publication of their awards. I have lived in New York for seven years and had about despaired of ever seeing really discerning awards in the cinema.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 10. -- While the Jews in Palestine remain unanimously adamant in rejecting High Commissioner Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope's proposed Legislative Council, the Arabs are still bickering among themselves as to what attitude to adopt.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 11. -- Reorganization of Sweden's national defense was foreshadowed by King Gustaf today in a speech from the throne opening the new session of the Riksdag.

When the Black-McKellar Air Mail Law was enacted in 1934 certain corporations were obliged to divest themselves of the ownership and control of subsidiary corporations in order to make them eligible to bid for air-mail contracts.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area made a good showing last week. Increases in sales over the same period a year ago were noted by most merchants, with active consumer demand reported for seasonal merchandise.

Paul Popenoe, in his very interesting and significant article on "Is There a Scarcity of Good Husbands?" in THE TIMES of Dec. 29, did me the honor of quoting me to the effect that the educated woman's chances of marriage are less favorable than those of women in the general population.

VERY light, very glib, very inconsequential, this novel is destined for not quite adult readers. It is the story of a young English girl, Philippa March, who was unhappily the child of rich and notorious parents. After her mother, a beautiful divorcee, was killed in a train wreck with her South American lover, Phil left the fetid atmosphere of Monte Carlo to live in London with her older sister, Angy.

TO most people the euonymus is "just another vine," but as one becomes acquainted with this extraordinary family of plants he finds new places and new functions for each of its many members. They are extraordinary in their adaptability to garden uses.

In the various accounts of the past opera experience of the young American singers appearing for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House, I have noticed that the Chautauqua Opera Association is conspicuous by its absence.

In so far as the Senate Munitions Committee's inquiry has confined itself to information regarding this country's munitions exports during our period of neutrality in 1915 and 1916, it has morely presented familiar history. Every one knew the facts twenty years ago.

Senator BYRD, who as Governor of Virginia brought about so fruitful a reorganization of the State government, has introduced a resolution for an investigation of the Federal Government for the purpose of reducing its cost. His object is praiseworthy, however ironical his reference to the patter of the Democratic platform of 1932 on the subject.

RAWALPINDI, India, Dec. 15. -- The extension of our geological and prehistorical studies from the Himalayan foothills to the lower Indus Valley in Sind and to the Narbadda Valley in Central India has resulted in discoveries that have an important bearing on the history of early man in India.

While his mother worked in another room, preparing for a party that was to have been held last night for two older sons, Ruben Slavin, 9 years old, was hanged just before 7 P.M. yesterday in a bedroom of his home at 2,021 La Fontaine Avenue, the Bronx.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica. -- Former President Julio Acosta is not satisfied with Costa Rica's army of 500 men, of which 285 are officers, and in a recent statement to the press warned that the possible invasion of Costa Rica cannot be ignored with impunity.
ATLANTA, Jan. 11. -- Retail trade in the Sixth Federal Reserve District showed a slight pick-up this week, although rains continued a chief factor in reducing buying demands.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With the opening recently of the new Pine Needles Inn, owned by George T. Dunlap, New York publisher, and his associates, Southern Pines now has four eighteen-hole golf courses and three country clubs, at which a number of tournaments have been arranged.

GALESBURG, Ill., Jan. 11. -- Mrs. Philip Sidney Post of Chicago, Knox trustee and chairman of the Knox Centennial Committee, announced this week preliminary plans for the celebration in 1937 which will mark the 100th anniversary of the chartering of Knox College and the beginning of Knox and Galesburg.

IT is an established army principle that, during field operations, aviation gasoline will be supplied in fifty-gallon drums and five-gallon tins. Tank cars on sidings at rail-heads are deemed most vulnerable, as are field-servicing trucks.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11. -- A suit was filed in the Federal District Court here today seeking to restrain President Roosevelt, Secretary Morgenthau and Chester C. Davis, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator, from stopping the operation of the AAA, which was outlawed this week by the Supreme Court.

EDGAR STILLMAN-KELLEY will attend the third American composers' concert of the season to be given by the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, under Howard Hanson, Thursday evening, in Rochester, N.Y. The program will be headed by Mr. Kelley's "New England" symphony.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- An impression is gaining ground on Capitol Hill that Governor Lehman's recent demand on the lawmakers for the enactment of a sixty-point program to insure better enforcement of the criminal law was, by design, more than a mere message to the Legislature.
The St. John's University quintet was upset, 40 to 37, last night by a fighting Niagara University five before a capacity crowd in the De Gray Gymnasium, Brooklyn.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 10. -- Denial of a defense motion for the transfer of the Scottsboro case to the Federal court has put a temporary, and perhaps a permanent, end to the only remaining hope for a change of venue to some less prejudiced locale than Morgan County.

BRILLIANT blues, crimsons and electric greens are some of the strong colors that are beginning to appear in accessories for late Winter and Spring. The traditional dullness that settles over late Winter ensembles is bound to vanish before his blaze of color.

One hundred and twenty-three individual dogs, with a total entry of more than 160, will be benched tomorrow at the thirty-seventh specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America, to be given in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The New York State Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Will be dedicated next Sunday afternoon at 2 o'clock, it was announced yesterday by George N. Pindar, secretary of the Memorial Commission.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 11 -- Dr. Frank H. Hankins, Professor of Economics and Sociology at Smith College and internationally known writer in that field, has been elected editor of a new publication, the "American Sociological Review," which will be the official organ of the American Sociological Society, it has been announced.

CHICAGO, Jan 11. -- Any infraction that looks like unnecessary roughness will be called without fear or favor by football officials at games in the fourteen States which play under the National Federation of High School Athletic Association code from next season on.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 11. -- Conferences between police and officials of the General Electric Company next week will determine whether arrests are to be made in a series of thefts in which trusted employes, in connivance with shippers and truckers, have stolen thousands of dollars of merchandise from the plant for their personal use over a period of a year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- To keep peace among the wives of the American diplomatic corps, President Roosevelt has issued an order deciding a dispute of long standing.

AFTER a prolonged period of observing works of art it becomes very interesting to note at what point an artist achieves fullest expression of his theme and also whether he has enough self-control and vision to stop at that point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Senator Borah, before making his public appeal for the Eastern vote in his contest for the Republican nomination for President, decided today to extend his primary activities into Pennsylvania, South Dakota and West Virginia.

Four vehicular under-water tunnels are now in New York City's traffic picture. One is already in prosperous operation; the second will be ready in two years; a large Federal loan and grant have been arranged for a third, on which work will begin soon; the fourth has been proposed and first official action taken concerning it.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10. -- It has not been unusual for politics to enter into the appointment of court employes in this city, nor has it been unusual for these employes, better known as "officers of the court," to continue their political activities after appointment.

AN interested welcome ought to await this handsomely made book, so packed is it with information concerning a service that comes intimately into the lives and welfare of Americans and by its heroic performance of perilous duties has always appealed thrillingly to their appreciation.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 11. -- Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, tonight warned the banks of the country that the government would continue private lending until the banks themselves provided a "free flow of credit" with reasonable interest rates to the "small fellow" as well as to the "big fellow."

THE cost of living has risen for the parrot. A few weeks ago two pounds of sunflower seed -- "parrot food" is its popular name -- could be bought in the city for a quarter; today the price is thirty-five cents. Nor is Polly alone affected.

MRS. BORDEN has chosen, for this romantic Catholic novel, a period that would be hard to beat for picturesqueness, startling contrasts and controversial interest. Joanna I (or, to give her Mrs. Borden's preferred spelling, Johanna ) was queening it at Naples .

MOSCOW, Jan. 11. -- One day last Summer Joseph Vissarionovich Stalin beamed from the front page of Pravda with his 11-year-old daughter, Svetlana, in his arms. And millions of Soviet citizens who saw the picture over their breakfast tea must have wondered what it was all about, for it was the first time the nation's leader has ever appeared smiling in the role of a doting father.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Tristan und Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles, the afternoon of Jan. 31 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to augment the scholarship fund of the Vassar Club.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 11. -- Dr. Ernest Martin Hopkins, president of Dartmouth College, announced today important changes in the freshman curriculum, effective next Fall. They are as follows:
THERE'S a lot of Greek drapery floating around this town.
Former Mayor John F. Hylan died of a heart attack about 1:15 o'clock this morning in his residence at 2 Olive Place, Forest Hills, Queens. He was in his sixty-eighth year.
ROME, Jan. 11. -- Rumors were heard in Rome this evening that another attempt to solve the Italo-Ethiopian conflict is about to be made.
Six teams, paced by Abraham Lincoln High School, gained the final bracket of the annual P.S.A.L. rifle team championship as a result of the qualifying round tests held at three ranges yesterday.

ONCE more the United States leads the world in the air, if records of various sorts can be taken as an indication. This state of affairs exists in spite of frantic testimony before "fact-finding" Congressional committees that everything that can be wrong is wrong with out aviation, both commercial and military.

Dr. SWANN'S announcement that Dr. L.H. RUMBAUGH of his Bartol research staff has managed to separate the two kinds of lithium and to obtain somewhat more than a milligram of the lighter has implications that impress physicists. The lithium twins are isotopes, a word coined by Sir FREDERICK SODDY to designate elements which are chemically identical and which differ only in their weights.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Although Governor Harold G. Hoffman announced this morning that he intended to have Attorney General David T. Wilentz bring Dr. John F. (Jafsie) Condon back from a Southern cruise for questioning, he had taken no action tonight looking to that end.
ORGANIZED college youth of both middle-of-the-road and leftist tendencies seems just now to be united in two causes -- opposition to war and militarism and to all curbs on freedom of speech.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- Amid acclaim from the German intelligentsia but also amid marked frowns from the National Socialist rank and file the Kaiser Wilhelm Society for the Advancement of Science celebrated today the silver jubilee of its foundation by the then German Emperor and the present exile of Doorn twenty-five years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11. -- Retail trade was quiet during the past week, especially among the larger stores, as the seasonal lull of the after-Christmas weeks became felt, during the time when this area must expect at least two weeks of rainy weather.

Control of the Axton Fisher Tobacco Company has been acquired by the Standard Commercial Tobacco Company, Inc., through the purchase of 80,000 common B shares of the former company, it was announced yesterday. There are outstanding 112,012 B shares.

COLOGNE, Jan. 11. -- The Chamber of Industry and Commerce and spokesmen for the Rhineland industry have called the attention of Dr. Hans Ernst Posse of the Ministry of Economics and various party functionaries to the Rhineland's failure to keep up with the economic improvement of the rest of the Reich.

The Industrial Re-employment Bureau, set up to swing Federal WPA employes back to jobs in private industry, is meeting with serious difficulty from an unexpected quarter. Many WPA workers to whom opportunity to get such jobs has been offered have turned it down, expressing their strong preference for continuing to work for Uncle Sam.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- A strongbox containing negotiable securities valued at $10,000 was found buried in woods near buildings of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society here today. Later the New York State police issued a five-State alarm for two wards of the institution who disappeared yesterday at about the time the strongbox and its contents were stolen from the bedroom of Mrs. Mary Thompson, a teacher.

Activity in the market for new securities will be resumed this week, following the usual holiday curtailment of operations around the turn of the year. Important bond issues, representing four major classifications, are scheduled for offering to the public by investment banking groups, with the total likely to reach $150,000,000.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York has issued a report urging the defeat of the Vinson bill calling for the immediate payment of the veterans' bonus.

This is a book for those who like difficult and intricate puzzles. It begins with a cryptogram that is brought to Philip Tolefree by Ronald Hudson, a man who is known to Tolefree by reputation but not personally. Hudson wants the cryptogram decoded, but he refuses to give any further information about it.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

There has been going on for some time in your column a discussion on Art as Propaganda. I believe that this matter needs some further clarification. One aspect of art is propaganda; just as color, line, subject-matter, , is of painting. The Passion Play, the Greek comedies, , are propaganda plays

THE plot of Mr. Oppenheim's latest novel -- accounted his 98th and the 134th volume of his published works -- is drawn in part from the sensational disclosures of political and financial corruption which a year or two ago shook France to her foundations.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11. -- Temple University's quintet took undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference tonight by beating West Virginia in the second part of the double-header at the Arena, 42 to 34.

HATRED, violence, murder, madness, revenge and true love afloat in a sea of psychology and animal magnetism form the nucleus of this dark tale which trails its way from Louis Golding's Doomington to London, thence to the Mediterranean coast line of Africa and Europe, to wind up in Berlin.

Arrested in his apartment at 1,085 Park Avenue, Austin Phelps Palmer, a wealthy retired mechanical engineer, was held in bail yesterday on a charge of sending two threatening letters to President Roosevelt.

" BE gay! Our life is jollier and merrier today, and it is due to your efforts -- our heroes of labor." Thus Joseph Stalin spoke, smilingly, to a recent audience of Soviet workers and thereby expressed a lighter philosophy of living under the dictatorship of the proletariat.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- The Yale varsity swimming team won its initial meet tonight, defeating an alumni aggregation, 54 -- 12, in the Payne Whitney Pool. The Eli freshmen conquered junior varsity rivals, 41 -- 25.

TO a fishing camp in the Province of Quebec comes Mr. Treadgold of New York, but it is not the prospect of good fishing that has lured him from his prosperous tailoring business. He is an ardent philatelist, and he has heard that the storekeeper in the village nearest the camp has some rare stamps to sell.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Princeton beat Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight when the Tigers' superior passing game brought a 38-to victory. The game was not as close at the score indicated.

THE recent opening of the Hayden Planetarium has served at once to emphasize and to accentuate the popularity of amateur astronomy as a hobby. In its first month the "all-star show" at the Museum of Natural History was visited by 120,000 persons and, in addition, it gave some thirty-five special performances for a variety of organizations, including a group of clergymen and another of business men.

WEST POINT, Jan. ll. -- Displaying a powerful attack, the Army basketball team routed Lehigh, 52 -- 21, today in a contest dedicating the Cadets' new gymnasium. The Army indoor polo team, using the same men who won the indoor intercollegiate title last season, also scored a triumph, turning back the Squadron A riders, 11 -- 4, in its first game of the year.

Debutantes of this and recent sea sons wearing ruffled lace gowns of the period of 1860 and their escorts in the smart cutaways of the same era will dance a stately quadrille, which will be one of the outstanding features of the Lace Ball to be held on Feb. 11 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

Continuing its program of replacing obsolete units with modern plants, the United States Steel Corporation dismantled seventy-six mills or furnaces of its subsidiaries last year. Its annual pamphlet report, which will appear in March, will show the extent to which these outmoded units were displaced by new equipment.

THERE have been half a dozen important books written about Gluck, but modern student have added to the knowledge of his life and Works and put into a clearer relation his development from a conventional Italian operatic composer to a reformer of the musical drama and cleared up the tangled story of his turbulent days in Paris, when he was the subject of a war waged by eighteenth-century intellectuals.

The financial district last week viewed the rising trend in public utility stocks as reflecting a widespread belief that the Tennessee Valley Authority Act will be declared unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court in a decision expected tomorrow.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 11 (AP). -- J. H. Cooper of New York, owner of thirty theatres in the Middle west, announced today the formation of the Cooper Foundation, a $1,000,000 organization "to establish homes, to maintain and to provide education for destitute deserving youngsters."

Debutantes headed by Miss Lucy Saunders are taking an active interest in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Die Walkuere" with Kirsten Flagstad, Gertrude Kappel, Lauritz Melchior, Friedrich Schorr and Emanuel List in the leading roles, the afternoon of Jan. 22 at the Metropolitan Opera for the benefit of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission in Labrador.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- For the first time in his administration, President Roosevelt has sent to Congress a budget which is significant because of its "ordinary" items rather than because of its "emergency" supplement. Commentators have to go back to the war era to find tax revenues as high and regular expenditures as large as those contemplated by the budget for the 1937 fiscal year which the President sent to Congress last Monday.

THE night that Congress opened, four Americans sat up in Rome until 3 o'clock in the morning listening to the President's address over the short-wave radio. The inimitable Roosevelt voice, charged with unusual feeling, rang clearly through the dark silence of the Roman night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Len Small, twice elected State Treasurer of Illinois, and twice elected Governor, has announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination to a third term as Chief Executive. This is the same Len Small who, in his second term as Governor, was sued by the State to recover over $1,000,000 interest on State funds alleged to have been collected but unaccounted for during his service as Treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP). -- An application was filed today with Secretary Roper and the United States Shipping Board Bureau by a group of New Englanders, asking the establishment of immediate steamship service from Portland, Me., Boston and Providence, R.I., to London and Hamburg.

Heavy trading continued in the share market during yesterday's half-day period, rounding out the busiest week in seven weeks. Stocks opened steady, advanced briskly during the first hour, but met substantial profit-taking during the second and closed irregular.

Several hundred members and guests of the Carroll Club are expected to participate in the sixteenth annual corporate communion of the club this morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral at the 9 o'clock mass, at which Patrick Cardinal Hayes will be the celebrant.

The decline in average annual 1931-35 revenues suffered by the railroads, compared with the average in the corresponding period, was almost offset "by means of the most drastic retrenchments in all history," the magazine Railway Age says.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Dr. C.W. Scranton of the Roseland Community Gun Club, who was named recently on the second all-America skeet team, paced a field of thirty-one top-flight shooters to win the Middle Atlantic States .410-gauge championship on the Loantaka Skeet Club field today.

Mr. Day Lewis's poetry is a rising tide of gleaming and exultant energy through which the hard rocks of intellect are plainly to be seen. It mounts in ardor and certainty from the dubious introspection on "Transitional Poem" through the coming of age in "From Feathers to Iron" (the birth of a child: the beginning of new life) to "The Magnetic Mountain," where he welcomes the positive force of a revolutionary movement, arduous and exhilarating.
THREE men made modern Italy. The first was Mazzini, the idealist. The second was Cavour, the statesman. The third was Garibaldi, whose contribution to the cause was achievement.

DESPITE the fact that no State highway contracts were completed during 1935 on Long Island, cities, townships and villages continued to improve the network of roadways which comprise the Long Island Highway system.

Mayor La Guardia swore in yesterday as members of the newly created New York City Tunnel Authority the three members of the Queens Midtown Tunnel Authority, which the new official body supersedes. The three members are Albert B. Jones, chairman; Albert T. Johnson and William H. Friedman.

Constantine Liadis, 37 years old, a leper who had been brought here from a Louisiana hospital for deportation to Greece, shot and seriously wounded himself in the head yesterday morning while confined in an isolated room of the hospital on the Vulcania of the Italian Line.

The celebrated London pie with its filling of singing birds may have been a dainty dish to set before a king, but here in America pie is still essentially a dessert, as has been proved by the entries in recent pie-baking contests in and around New York.

Under the chandelier in the Blue Room of the White House last Thursday evening Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes, the guest of honor at a state reception, bowed over the hand of the President and uttered the usual courteous good wishes. Roosevelt smilingly responded.

Deputy Clerk Herbert Charlson accepted a final document for filing one minute before noon yesterday in the United States District Court as the gloomy corridors of the ancient postoffice building echoed the rumbles of dozens of handcarts moving the Federal departments to the new Federal Building in Foley Square.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Sailing and speed boating will attract unusual interest this season at Sea Island, where the surrounding serpentine waterways afford picturesque courses safe for small pleasure craft.

HAMBURG, Germany, Jan. ll. -- The main body of the American Olympic Winter sports team, composed of fifteen skiers, thirteen bobsledders and five speed skaters, arrived today aboard the United States liner Manhattan. A storm was met in the North Sea, but the athletes seemed to have suffered no ill effects from it.

A.L. Burns broke 100 straight targets at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. It was the first time this season that a perfect score has been returned at the Winged Foot Club. The performance was outstanding as the final fifty targets were trapped in driving snow.

VIENNA, Dec. 28, 1935. THE first real novelty which the Staatsoper has put out in a blue moon is a 100 per cent domestic product. Franz Salmhofer, the composer of the three-act opera "Dame im Traum" -- most conveniently Englished as "Dreaming Lady" -- is a 35-year-old Viennese who, besides exuding numerous orchestral and chamber works that nobody hears, furnishes music for the plays at the Burgtheater and for an occasional ballet.

Stell Andersen, pianist, who has made many appearances, both in solo recitals and as a member of the highly commendable team of Scionti and Andersen, gave her first recital of the season yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall before a large and approving audience.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The judicial branch of the Federal Government which last May razed the NRA has demolished another superstructure which the legislative and executive branches had erected -- because it was held to be out of plumb with the foundation.

Recovery of any part of the invalidated AAA processing taxes, either those paid directly to the Federal Government or those impounded by the courts, will be a long and difficult task, according to reports of leading manufacturers made last week to Fitch Investors Service.

Big red motor vans clustered about the new Federal Building in Foley Square to advertise the fact that New York's so-called Civic Center has taken over the job of handling the national as well as the State, county and municipal agencies of government for our citizens.

The main ballroom of the Plaza was the setting last night for the thirty-seventh annual dinner and dance of the Maryland Society of New York. The event had been arranged by a committee of which James H. Turner was chairman and including Dr. Benjamin M. Cissel, Franz Euler Jr., Charles J. Schaefer Jr. and J. Frank Graham.

Harold H. Funk of Brooklyn, owner of the remarkable little Wheeler cruiser Sound Wave, which carries on board such instruments as a radio compass, has been renominated to the post of chief commander of the Uitned States Power Squadrons, according to a report submitted this week by the committee consisting of Harold Dudley Greeley, Frank H. Holland and Wilbur A. Smith.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- A tentative draft of regulations for margins covering bank loans for the purpose of purchasing or carrying equity securities registered on national security Exchanges, transmitted today by the Federal Reserve Board to its agents, provides for equal margin requirements on bank and brokers' loans.
UNIVERSITY, Va., Jan. 11. -- Harvard's boxing team sprang a surprise tonight by conquering Virginia, 4 1/2 to 3 1/2. It was the first defeat sustained by a Cavalier ring squad in several years.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Robert H. Cunningham, counsel for the Investors Title and Mortgage Guarantee Company of Paterson, was today named president of the New Jersey Title Association at the group's fourteenth annual convention here.

DR. COMPTON begins his thesis by pointing out the various fallacies of the mechanistic theories of the past and by describing, in the light of modern scientific discoveries, the general erratic character of nature. One aspect of this part of his work which deserves special notice is his limitation of the principle of uncertainty in the physical realm to the "motions of the very small things" generally excluding "the ordinary large-scale events."
Reductions in most classes of crime in cities where the police employ radio extensively is indicated in a survey by The Municipal Index of 174 such municipalities.

An increase in the prices of both sugar and cocoa was a feature in the short session in the commodity futures markets here yesterday. In the cash market, all the grains were lower, while cocoa, cotton and rubber worked higher.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. DEEP-SEA diving will be continued during January and February at the Bermuda Government Aquarium, according to Louis Mowbray, the aquarium's curator, and the midwinter tourist may visit Davy Jones's locker and see the highly colored fishes and the weird coral formations for which Bermuda's sea floor is famous, on any day when the ocean is not rough.
PARIS, Jan. 11 (AP). -- The United States Olympic hockey team played a 4-4 tie with the French Volants tonight in its first game after arriving in Europe.

A PAIR match was held in Minneapolis last week between a Mr. and Mrs. Stanley and a Mr. and Mrs. Thatcher. Because neither the Stanleys nor the Thatchers ever made a name for themselves in national tournaments, their match attracted the attention of no more than a handful of people.

I HAVE no ideas," said Van Gogh, "except that a field of corn or a cypress is worth looking at, close up." And I might say that I have none about playwriting except that certain natures attract me -- and certain phases of life -- which I think are worth looking at, close to.

CHICAGO, Jan, 11. -- Strength in the wheat market in Liverpool, increased talk of inflation here and the best milling demand for cash wheat in some time fell flat today as influences on grain futures on the Board of Trade. Scattered buying at the opening lifted wheat futures fractionally, but thereafter the market sagged under scattered selling by longs, who evened up for the possible Supreme Court decision on Monday.

THOSE who were moved and impressed by Mme. Tchernavin's "Escape From the Soviets" -- and they were many -- will want to read her second book. The story of her flight with her husband and son across the northern forests into Finland belongs among the finest annals of human fortitude.

A provocative program superbly delivered, was offered by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Serge Koussevitzky at its second afternoon concert of the season yesterday in Carnegie Hall. The first half of the schedule was given over to the initial New York performance of Albert Roussel's Fourth Symphony, Opus 53, and the symphonic fantasia, "Pohjola's Daughter," by Sibelius, which had not been heard here since 1924.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, Jan. 11. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener, in an article published here, admits that the possibility of maintaining a Zeppelin service on regular schedule over the North Atlantic must first be tested. He is, however, optimistic.

" Theory of Flight" is the most decided achievement in this series of younger poets, not only in its abundance and relatively mature substance, but in the vigorous direction of its thought. It follows a pattern familiar by now, the development from childhood introspection to an outward direction toward revolution, and it uses the accepted technique in contemporary verse (Miss Rukeyser adds a clever semi-colon), but both are personally felt and developed.

Women who long have been interested in the philanthropic enterprises of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of the Jooss European Ballet to be held the night of Jan. 21 at the Metropolitan Opera House to raise funds for the institute.

MUSIC being the recognized backbone of broadcasting, radio has had several vertebrae jolted out of place in its spinal column since the first of the year, when copyright owners stopped the microphoning of thousands of songs.

With the publishing of Miss Ring's letter it is fairly safe to predict that the Carmen controversy will heap your desk with violent recriminations and diatribes of every species known to the great American public.

Bequests of about $100,000, including $26,000 to Brooklyn philanthropic institutions, were made by the late Simon Frank Rothschild, former department store head, whose will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

CONGRESS is back again; the representatives of the people, both Senators and members of the House, have gathered from the Middle-Western plains the mountains and forests of the Northwest, the Cotton Belt of the South and the industrial centers of the smoke-filled North to wrestle with such problems as the bonus and neutrality, and possibly to reconstruct the New Deal now that the Supreme Court has smashed some of its machinery.

Describing the beneficial effects on heavy industries of the Federal Government's recovery program, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, told members of the Harmonic Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street, yesterday afternoon that more than 450,000,000 man-hours of work had been created up to last Oct. 15 in the mining, fabricating and transportation of iron and steel products and in the production and transportation of cement alone.

A day of many important musical performances, a Saturday night edition which goes early to press, makes it impossible to review in any complete or thorough fashion the concert given by the League of Composers last night at Town Hall. It was an imposing program and it gathered the large, interesting and variegated assembly of modern music lovers who only appear in force when the league gives its concerts.

PROSPECTS on American campuses seem relatively bright as administrators from various parts of the country gather in New York for the annual meeting of the Association of American Colleges beginning next Thursday.

Obviously, defenders of Mussolini's war can find no moral arguments to support their stand. They fall back on distorted reasoning and flounder in emotional and passionate irrelevancies. Typical of this sort of thing is M. Greco's letter to THE TIMES.

TO London comes the world and it is London's task to make the way easy. She has tried to keep up with the times in the quality of her transportation facilities, adopting new and better methods as they are introduced to the world.

The Greenwich House Workshops, a neighborhood project where boys are trained in the crafts, will be turned over to the Board of Education next month, giving an opportunity for gifted students in the city's industrial and vocational schools to become experts in cabinet making, stone cutting, wood carving and bronze casting.

Lou Lubin's field goal on a lay-up shot in the three-minute overtime period broke a 24-all tie and enabled the James Madison High five to conquer Textile High, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, 26 -- 24, on the winners' floor in Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- What permanent course shall the President pursue, now that a Supreme Court majority has blocked the path of reform and recovery which he was blazing? He stands at a delta of the roads of choice. Upon his decision his political fate and the type of the development of the nation may well depend.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- During New Year's week many new styles were noted in the popular Crillon bar at the lunch hour. Among them was a mink coat cut and seamed like a man's shirt; it was made with large revers.

Nine men arrested Friday in policy racket raids on two apartments, some of them suspected of bank robberies and other hold-ups, were arraigned yesterday in West Side Court. Two, accused of being fugitives from justice, were alleged to have been among five men who, on Dec. 20, held up and robbed the First National Bank of Fort Lee, N.J., of $15,851.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Restoration to banks of the right to underwrite long-term issues for commerce and industry would do much to clear up the jam in private financing and would enable the government to withdraw more rapidly from the lending field, Edward E. Brown, president of the First National Bank of Chicago, said today.

BOSTON, Jan. 11, -- Led by Beekman Poole, a former national champion, the New York Squash Racquets team got off to a flying start in the Lockett Trophy intercity tournament with a 5-to-2 victory over Philadelphia on the Harvard Club courts today.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 10. -- All along the Pacific seaboard the No. 1 political issue is Dr. Townsend's Old-Age Revolving Pension Plan. Every officeholder in the West, from Senator William E. Borah down to the humblest town constable, is alarmed by the size and aggressiveness of the throng demanding enactment of the $200-a- month retirement program.

THE Middle American Research Department of Tulane University in New Orleans has won for itself, in the ten years of its existence, a very distinguished position in the field of archaeology. That this department has far outstripped the rest of the university in achievement is due, in great measure, to the enterprise and intelligence of its director, Franz Blom.
The title poem is as fine as anything Mr. Masters has written, and one of the few modern poems to reveal the enduring strength of the landscape:

IN this pleasant little volume Milton H. Stansbury presents a series of thirteen informal essays on living French novelists. If the subjects are selected rather haphazardly, and if their treatment is something less than comprehensive, it is without pretense to the contrary.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 11. -- R. Marano led a field of twenty-two gunners in the skeet shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He took the high scratch honors by breaking 49 out of 50 targets.

HENRY HOBSON RICHARDSON died fifty years ago at the early age of 48, enjoying the highest prestige among contemporary American architects. Today the architects who call themselves modern hail him as the greatest of all American architects. notwithstanding that the invention of the steel skeleton has so far transformed practical architecture in the interval that Richardson is by his admirers listed as last of the master masons.

The New York Herald Tribune announced last night that it will sponsor a charity football game early next season between the New York Giants, Eastern division champions of the National Professional League, and an all-star team of college graduates recruited from all parts of the country.

THE greatest work of fiction, said Cecil Roberts in a recent address, is the story, as published in the press from time to time, of what authors make. He believes there are somewhere around 4,000 novelists today -- presumably in Great Britain -- but 3,500 of them are not making more than 200 a year out of their novels.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 11. -- Adoption by presidents of six Southern Conference colleges of a program calling for stringent regulation of scholarships and other aids to athletes appeared today to project explosive issues into the conference meeting here Feb. 6-7.

Through a program reviving memories of its infancy in the upper stretches of Manhattan Island, the Haarlem Philharmonic Society will celebrate its forty-fifth anniversary on Thursday with a breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. A musicale, with Lotte Lehmann of the Metropolitan Opera and Poldi Mildner, pianist, as the artists, will follow the function, for which more than 1,400 reservations have been made to date.

L0S ANGELES, Jan. 11. -- Jimmy Hines, the Garden City, L.I., pro who won the recent Riverside tournament, continued his sub-par golf today to tie Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., with a card of 137 for the lead in the second round of the $5,000 Los Angeles open tournament.

The State committee of the Socialist party of New York, elected by the Utica convention, has voted unanimously to accept the decision of the National Executive Committee of the party suspending the New York organization's charter and setting up a temporary State committee, according to Max Delson, chairman of the committee.

What may prove a major phase of the conflict between the chains and the wholesalers was seen here yesterday as the outcome of the possible adoption of the plan suggested by John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, that the company turn wholesaler to some degree and sell out its units to store managers in States where discriminatory anti-chain taxes have been enacted.
HAVANA, Sunday, Jan. 12. -- Official figures at midnight showed Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez leading General Mario G. Menocal by more than 25,000 votes in the race for the Presidency.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 1 Major changes will be made in the journalism curriculum of Rutgers University next year so that the course may more adequately meet the needs of daily and weekly newspapers, President Robert C. Clothier announced today.

Charles J. Werner, who was lodged in alimony jail the day before Thanksgiving because he owed $150,000 alimony to his former wife, Mrs. Leonora H. Werner, lost yesterday his application for immediate release. In dismissing the motion Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin referred the matter of the $1,000 monthly alimony to an official referee for a report on whether Mr. Werner is able to pay "such heavy alimony."
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Convening of State Legislatures in 1936 already has signaled the return of women's organizations to one of their most popular objectives-ratification of the Child Labor Amendment. Favorable action is needed in twelve more States to secure abolition of the employment of children, which has increased materially since the Supreme Court's decision declaring the NRA unconstitutional

A SPORT which of recent years has caught the imagination of far more than the few privileged to enjoy it is that of ocean racing in small yachts. There is an annual Bermuda race, with every now and again a race across the Atlantic.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Ernest Schelling, opened its thirteenth season of concerts for children and young people yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. Youngsters attended in droves, listened with rapt attention to the interesting and diversified program arranged for them, and indicated their strong approval with rounds of excited applause.

TWO Literary Fellowships, similar to the two awarded last year by the same firm, are being offered this year by Houghton Mifflin Company. The purpose of these awards is to help writers of promise to secure the financial independence essential to their development.

PANTS AND PREACHERS: "Any woman who can manage a well-organized home has executive ability. It is only within the church that a definite prejudice against women exists. I intend to wage a fight to break this down."

The five-power naval parley in London took up its work last week after a Christmas recess; immediately the old differences flared up and the conference postponed its sessions until early this week. London is not hopeful about the outcome of the discussions. All reports from the conference contain the gloomy prophecy: "Failure expected."

FOR the garden in the house a few annual florists' plants are highly desirable to give seasonal brilliance. For this purpose the Persian cyclamen is particularly suitable. The light and dark rose shades are suited for window gardens containing purple African violets and paperwhite narcissus.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11. -- Two hundred persons attended the dinner dance given in the ballroom of the Hotel Warwick tonight by the Saturdays at Nine Committee.

" Illinois," says Mr. Dresbach, "has produced more nationally known poets * * * than any other State in the Union." He enumerates them, and fails to mention Lindsay. There are sixty-four poets here, "nobody" ( Mr. Dresbach writing) "as bad as the Sweet Singer of Michigan."

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 11 (AP). -- The first definite schism within New York State Young Republican ranks was brought into the open tonight on the eve of their campaign for a "fair share" of delegates to the State and nations conventions.

DALLAS, Jan. 11. -- Momentum gained by business in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during the holiday buying season continues to sustain the upward curve. Retail trade continues in volume larger than merchants had expected, and other lines of industry reflect satisfactory improvement.
The stymie, which has been a thorn to many United States Golf Association administrations, bobbed up at yesterday's annual meeting held at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Although many persons believe the decision of the United States Supreme Court last week invalidating the AAA probably means the end of the Federal Government's control of cotton production and also the eventual return of a free cotton market, the government still has a controlling interest in some 6,000,000 bales of cotton, 900,000 of which are futures contracts.

MADRID, Jan. 11. -- Spain today appears just as ripe for a coup d'etat resulting in a military dictatorship as it was in 1923 when Primo de Rivera took charge of the government. This time, however, a civilian Premier, Manuel Portela, instead of a military man, looms as the possible dictator.

WHEN Dave Bullis announced to his family that he had sold the Dan'l Webster and that they were all going West to homestead in Minnesota, the delight of his three small sons was equaled only by their amazement at the newly discovered strain of adventure in their father.

Metropolitan areas in the next war will face a far greater danger from enemy planes that drop small incendiary bombs than from gas attacks, according to Professor J. Enrique Zanetti of the Department of Chemistry in Columbia University.

EARLY Colonial weavers, who had brought many of their designs with them to the new country, looked to Europe for inspiration as a matter of course. Our native originality in the weaving art is still supplemented by European ideas, stimulated by the revival, overseas, of peasant arts and crafts.

The Stony Wold Sanatorium will benefit from net proceeds of the annual Yankee Doodle Ball to be held on Saturday at the Park Lane. The entertainment has been arranged by the institution's Auxiliary No. 6, of which Mrs. H. Thurston W. Huntting is chairman.
It cannot be denied that general world advancement makes a change in the calendar advisable, but it ought to be general and not piecemeal.

MONTREAL, Que. -- Skiing in the Laurentians now is attracting many Montrealers and the railways are running weekend "ski specials" to accommodate the crowds. The clubhouse of the St. Margaret's Ski Club opens for the season today, when the club championships will be settled in down-hill and jumping competitions.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- With the arrival of Helen Hicks, former national women's golf champion and present Canadian titleholder, for an exhibition match today, and the annual dinner and dance of the Augusta Rotary Club, Augusta's Winter social and sports program is being formally launched.

On the great waterways of China the river people still live as independently as have their ancestors, ever since certain noblemen refused allegiance to the Manchu conquerors and were forbidden with their descendants ever to own land or live under the roofs.

Your ten-best list on Sunday surprised me greatly. In the first place I was rather taken aback about your decision of including only English-speaking photoplays among the ten best. But I was especially surprised about the fact that you did not even list "La Maternelle" among the ten best foreign films, giving the preference to such average works as "Liliom" and "Le Dernier Milliardiare."

INCIDENTS and mysteries associated with the Andrew Jackson figurehead of the historic frigate Constitution are recalled by a display opening Wednesday at the Marine Gallery of the Museum of the City of New York, of the wooden effigy of "Old Hickory," lent by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

ITIAN, Tintoretto and Veronese are the names that greet those who visit the galleries of Arnold Seligmann, Rey Co., Inc., this month. It is announced that none of the present canvases has ever before been shown in New York.

THAT there may be life on Mars is no longer denied by advanced astronomers. Still, the known facts about the planet are not in favor of anything higher than vegetation -- something scrubby, something that can survive intense cold and drought and flourish, after a fashion, in an atmosphere which contains very little oxygen and in which, only recently, some water vapor has been discovered.
Under active buying by trade and commission house interests prices on the Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at net gains of 3 to 19 points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Federal registration of pistols is sought as the next step in the national government's war against crime. Legislation along such lines has been strongly recommended by Attorney General Cummings in his annual report.

Economic and cultural foundations for a democratic bulwark against Fascist or Communist dictatorship are already emerging in Eastern Nova Scotia, although the cooperative movement built there by St. Francis Xavier University of Antigonish is only five years old, a progress report just issued by the institution reveals.

LONDON. -- An Empire Settlement Board to advise the government on the best methods of restarting the flow of emigrants from Britain to the Dominions is to be established, according to present plans, under the presidency of Douglas Hacking, Under-Secretary for the Dominions.

AIKEN, S.C. -- The Aiken drag hunts are now on regular schedule for the season. Meets have been announced by Mrs. Averell Clark, M.F.H., for Tuesday morning at Willie Barton's in the Hitchcock Woods, for Thursday morning at the brickyard field, and for Saturday morning at the Berry Hill, opposite the C.W. Dolan Winter home.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11. -- A dinner followed by a moving picture show was given this evening by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer at their villa.

Criticizing the disposition of drunken driving cases in the magistrates courts as "most unsatisfactory," Mayor La Guardia called upon Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman yesterday to see to it that the magistrates give better cooperation to the police in such cases.

IN a letter to the Drama Editor, published three weeks ago in an adjoining column, Arthur Robinson said: "Propaganda, as such, ceases to be propaganda when it becomes good drama." Although he has been cordially denounced for his impertinence, I think his distinction is a sound one: I have sometimes made a similar observation about folk plays.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. ll. -- The Hobey Baker Rink was the scene of one of the most exciting and well-played hockey games of recent years tonight as Princeton s six staved off a desperate third-period Harvard attack to win its opening quadrangular league contest, 4 -- 3.

FLORIDA is not all roof-gardens and yacht trips, white satin gowns and tuxedos, long black cars and surf boards. Far from the night clubs is another Florida, a land of simple folk and fields of swishing sugar cane.

CAMDEN, S.C. -- Golfers are here this season in greater numbers than they have been in years, attracted by the fine condition of the two Walter ft. Travis courses at the Kirkwood Hotel and the course at the Court Inn. The hotels report more guests than usual, with hundreds of reservations.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in an annual statement issued yesterday, reports net earnings of $4,336,000 in 1935, compared with $8,307,000 in 1934. After payment of $3,411,000 in dividends, and the transfer of $64,000 to the United States Treasury, under Section 13b of the Federal Reserve Act, there remained $861,000 to be added to the surplus.

The new motorship Batory, second transatlantic liner built by the Gdynia America Line since Poland recovered her independence in the World War, will leave Gdynia on May 18 on her maiden voyage to New York, it was announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A. Thompson gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center. Their guests included: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Raffalovich of Paris, Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mr. and Mrs. John A. McVickar Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Sickles, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Johnston, Mrs. Harry Brown, Mrs. Morris de Peyster, Princess Dolly Obolensky, F. Frazier Jelke, Griswold Tasker, Lawrence Smith Butler and Harold Tasker.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- In upward of 700 ways the New Deal has set out to learn what makes America tick.
ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's address at the joint dinner at the Albany Chamber of Commerce and the Albany Society of New York tonight:

Deposits in leading Wall Street banks rose 13.8 per cent and their resources increased 11.6 per cent in 1935, it is shown by a comparison of the aggregate figures of seventeen clearing house banks as of Dec. 31 with the figures at the close of 1934. In the final quarter of the year the banks gained 4.4 per cent in deposits and 4.2 per cent in resources.

RENO, Nev., Jan. 10. -- First feelings of fear, anger, exasperation and resentment, with which the silver States greeted the news that the price of white metal had collapsed in the world market last month, have given way now to one of bewilderment.

THIS year Texas is celebrating the centennial of its achievement of freedom from the Mexican Government, its memorable battle of the Alamo, its declaration of independence, its adoption of the Constitution of the Republic of Texas, its heroic battle of San Jacinto and its entrance upon the world stage as a sovereign nation.

A REPORT on the inauguration of what is called "the most powerful radio station in South America," located at Buenos Aires, has been received at the United States Commerce Department. The station, known as "Radio el Mundo," is said to be second only to Radio City, being modern in every respect.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11. -- Racing over a sloppy track and through a driving rain. Brown Feathers, 4-year-old daughter of Brown Bud, carried the silks of Mrs. Emil Denamark of Chicago to an easy victory in the Gulf Stream Grade B Handicap today.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- To the informal matches and preliminary play which comprised the early sports schedule, will be added this week the first of the major golf events, signalizing the arrival of this resort's swift, mid-Winter pace.

Halevy's "La Juive" was performed last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time in five seasons. The New York Chapter of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, and the American Jewish Physicians Committee benefited.

One thinks with mixed feelings of the performance of "Goetterdaemmerung" given yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House. First there is the memory, still very vivid, of the magnificent opera, and the torrent of Wagnerian inspiration which floods the score.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Howie Willie, Princeton swimming captain, shattered his own pool record for the 150-yard back-stroke as the Tiger mermen conquered Lehigh University, 55 -- 16, in their opening meet today in the Brokaw Pool.

HAVANA, Jan. 11. -- The Cuban public tonight awaited the final results of the general elections yesterday with some impatience as the government failed to make an official announcement of the victorious candidates because of the slowness with which the returns were being compiled.

EDDIE CANTOR was back in New York only a few hours, after a long stay in Hollywood, before he confessed that "Major Bowes is the hottest thing in radio today," and that is why he stepped aside from the 8 o'clock spot Sunday night.

DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH is composing a ballet based on Cervantes's "Don Quixote," with a scenario by I.I. Solertinski of Leningrad, an authority on Spanish language and literature. Incidentally, two new orchestral scores by this composer have just been issued by the State Music Publishing House in Moscow.

RELIABLE old stand-bys of grandmother's day, the once humble and unpretentious garden marigold and calendula have been taking on class and distinction within recent years. Modern miracles, in a sense, have been performed.
