And he has need for all of his strength before the tale is done, for he is up against a cold-blooded villain known as the Doctor, who has a small army of ruthless killers at his beck and call.

SIR BASIL ZAHAROFF is probably the most famous living symbol of death. His fortune -- based on selling arms to any or all sides of wars -- has been estimated in hundreds of millions of dollars. Herr Neumann himself does not know how much he is worth. But interest in him is world-wide and unflagging.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- From time to time observers of the exceedingly dull and hitherto futile proceedings of the London Naval Conference have been stirred up this week by reports from the United States that along side the naval conversations, although not a part of them, there are going on political talks between the British and the Japanese, the object of which is the adjustment of their interests in the Far East.

Active cooperation between New York City and the State of California to eliminate food racketeers and to protect both consumers here and producers in California was agreed upon yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and C.J. Carey, chief of the Division of Market Enforcement of the California Department of Agriculture.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Governor Hoffman made public today letters from Bruno Richard Hauptmann's mother, Mrs. Pauline Vern Hauptmann, and from his spiritual adviser, the Rev. James Matthiesen, urging clemency. Both expressed faith in his innocence.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Clemency was denied here today to Bruno Richard Hauptmann by the New Jersey Court of Pardons at the end of one of the longest sessions of the court on record. The vote was kept secret, but it was reported that it had been unanimous.

Columbia gambled with rough, driving play to check the invincible sweep of the N.Y.U. quintet in the University Heights gymnasium last night, but these tactics bounded back with boomerang force. For one half Lion aggressiveness held the Violet at bay, but when the lads in blue started paying the penalty in the second period for their overzealousness, New York won, going away, 39 to 27.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- With the return of warm weather, visitors to St. Petersburg this week will enjoy deep sea fishing parties, golf tournaments and a gay round of social festivities.

AMORDEN Santo Domingo, risen from the debris of the disastrous hurricane which swept the Dominican Republic in 1930 is making its bid this Winter for a share of the West Indian cruise business, which has largely been passing by the ancient "Cradle of the New World."

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- A telegram protesting against being "barred" from the conference of farm leaders at Washington was sent tonight to President Roosevelt by the Farmers Independence Council of America, over the signature of Dan D. Casement of Manhattan, Kan., president.
The women's auxiliary of the Holy Name Mission at 319 Bowery, near Bleecker Street, had its first visit yesterday from Patrick Cardinal Hayes.

From the moment that icy water dripping from the ceiling of the igloo wakened Tuktu until dreams of the Arctic Summer time sealed his eyes at night, this Eskimo boy's day was filled with action. Armstrong Sperry has chosen to tell the story of that eventful day in every boy's life when he first proves himself to be a man of courage and authority.

IT seemed a pretty silly thing to do, this being January and going down the bay in the cutter being one way of risking pneumonia. Still, as the apologetic fellow from United Artists remarked, it was a case of going out into the night or not getting any world-shattering interview with Douglas Fairbanks Sr. and Erich Pommer.

CAIRO, Jan. 11. -- British military preparations still go on in Egypt. The 30,000 British troops now here are expected by Feb. 15 to be increased to 50,000 including army, Royal Air Force and Marine Corps men.
I wish to correct the statement in THE TIMES recently that Mark Twain's poem on the Ornithorhynchus is "the only poem known to have been written by the eminent American man of letters.''

CHARLES B. COCHRAN'S new revue, "Follow the Sun," has not yet reached London. Since Dec. 23 it has been trying out in Manchester, but there its success has been so great, and Mr. Cochran is so sure of a hit, that he is taking London for granted and planning transatlantic steps.

CASTING a last backward glance over the film year that is ended, it occurs to me that one of its most interesting trends has been scarcely noticed and may be of considerable significance to the social philosopher. I refer to the increasing emphasis the cinema is placing on the shocking details of physical torture and brutality.

All is peaceful in the Whitehall Club. Mr. Morrison is asleep in the most comfortable chair in the club library and Mr. Pargiter, who is Morrison's chief rival for the dubious honor of being the club's greatest nuisance, is not, at the moment, in evidence.

PARIS, Jan. 1. -- Preceding the New Year's Eve feasting here a number of eggnog parties were given in the American colony, one of the most largely attended being that of McCeney Werlich of the embassy and his wife, and most of the embassy staff and their wives came in.

FORT LEE, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Ralph E. Hacker, son-in-law of Dr. John F. Condon, this afternoon described as "utterly absurd" allegations that the doctor had not been willing to testify again before the authorities concerning any points in the Hauptmann case.

The conversion of many American industrial holding companies into operating units, through the liquidation of subsidiaries, has been gaining momentum steadily, and promises to become one of the most interesting developments of 1936, according to executives of industrial companies.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 (AP). -- The Detroit Symphony Orchestra weathered the depression only to lose the services of its conductor, Ossip Gabrilowitsch, but it was well on the road today to a successful season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- President Roosevelt's outline of a new agricultural program based on soil conservation and incidental crop control was translated today by about 100 farm leaders into a plan of their own to carry forward the major objectives of the outlawed Agricultural Adjustment Act.

ANEW year that ushers in a new Wodehouse book bids fair to be a happy one, at least so long as the reader is absorbed in the cavortings of Wodehouse characters. The new novel combines English merriment with Hollywood hilarity.

With the beginning of 1936 about a quarter of a million employers of approximately 2,500,000 workers in the State of New York became subject to taxation, under Federal and State laws, as part of the new plan of national unemployment insurance.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11. -- After a year's trial, Harvard's new plan for awarding large scholarships to students in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences has been declared a success by college authorities and has been made an essential part of Harvard's 300th anniversary fund program.

Bernt Balchen, the Norwegian-American aviator who has flown on notable flights and expeditions with Admiral Byrd and Lincoln Ellsworth, arrived Friday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for a brief visit here to discuss Atlantic air service plans with Pan American Airways officials and talk with the Sikorsky people about the purchase of some large transport planes.

While Southern cities continued to register gains in retail sales over a year ago last week, extremely cold weather and the influence of the AAA decision combined to retard activity in other sections, particularly in the Midwest. Locally, stores showed some increase over last year.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- With the Stock Exchange closed, a sudden slump in the dollar monopolized attention in the financial markets here today. Early in the day, the rate touched $4.96 1/4 to the pound, but the dollar steadied later and closed at $4.96 3-16. Other foreign exchanges were quiet, the francs closing at 74 25-32 to the pound.
Basic constitutional questions are raised by the provisions of the Neutrality Bill introduced on Jan. 3 by Senator Key Pittman and Representative Sam D. McReynolds.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Five cases of scarlet fever here and two of smallpox at Palmer caused authorities to order strict quarantines in the little cities and bottle up Matanuska colonists in their new valley settlement today.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 11. -- Dartmouth's basketball team was on the defensive throughout a blistering second half tonight, but managed to shade Pennsylvania, 34 -- 33, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game before 2,200 spectators.

THE publishers and editors of this reprint of a famous history of music must be men of optimistic views and invincible courage; for its publication would seem to be a work rather of piety than of business acumen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Virtually certain of early passage of the soldiers' bonus measure, which was passed by the House and sent to the Senate on Friday, two of the major groups of ex-service men are preparing for a combined drive for more liberal pensions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP). -- J.C. Nichols of Kansas City, vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, asserted today that the Federal slum clearance program had retarded recovery of the building industry.

THAT the University of California Press should have turned its attention to the publication of a book on modern dancing is an indication not only of the growing interest in this frequently misunderstood branch of the arts but also of the recognition of its potentialities in the field of education.

WINTER-TIME spraying, which has become a regular and indispensable part of the practice of commercial fruit growers, is being extended more and more to the home garden. Many insects, especially the scales that attack lilacs, euonymus and other plants, can be most conveniently and most effectively controlled by so-called "dormant" sprays.

Mr. and Mrs. Courtland Kelsey gave a dinner dance last night at the Ritz-Carlton for their niece, Miss Margaret Louise Kelsey, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Tomlinson Kelsey. Miss Kelsey, who received with her mother and aunt, wore an ivory crepe gown made on Grecian lines and girdled in gold and pearl embroidery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- After receiving a brief list of callers in the private library of the White House, President Roosevelt spent two hours this afternoon witnessing a pageant and riding show at Fort Myer, Va. The event is held annually for the benefit of the Army Posts Fund.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 10. -- Refusal of Josephus Daniels, Ambassador to Mexico, to comment on reports that he may run for the Senate against Senator Josiah W. Bailey has given rise to speculation in North Carolina, where the Senatorial campaign is warming up.

MR. DOOB, a member of the faculty of Yale who has a comprehensive knowledge of psychology that includes both its academic and practical applications, in this book brings his varied knowledge to bear on that symptomatic social phenomenon that has bloomed out so flauntingly in recent years.

Festooned outside the Lexington Avenue entrance with streamers and halyards of nautical code flags and ablaze indoors with flood lights focusing on pleasure craft of every description and almost every size, the Grand Central Palace will serve as a gay reminder, for nine days beginning on Friday, that another Summer is not far off.
More than 2,000 persons attended a pre-birthday celebration for B. Charney Vladeck, long an authority on the lower East Side and member of the Municipal Housing Authority, at Carnegie Hall.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11. -- The Court of Pardons which heard Bruno Richard Hauptmann's plea for clemency extended through his lawyers today consists of five lawyers, a newspaper publisher, a business man and the Governor of the State.

THE recent rise and more recent reduction in war-risk insurance on vessels sailing the Mediterranean Sea bring Lloyd's back into the news. Anything that affects the world's risks affects Lloyd's, for all the big losses, wherever they occur, eventually work back to Lloyd's.

On May 20, 1935, President Roosevelt followed the practice of his Republican predecessors by vetoing a bonus bill; in the matter of vetoes he did something altogether new by presenting his message to Congress in person that he might be heard not only by those who voted on the bill but, via radio, by the veterans and the taxpayers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Terming the self-investigation of the Federal Communications Commission by a committee of five of its members "an attempt to cleanse the commission before Congress takes action." Chairman Connery of the House Labor Committee announced today that a Congressional investigation into all activities of the FCC would be asked.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 -- There are indications that James MacDonald's indictment of the National Socialist "persecution" of Jews, together with President Roosevelt's denunciation of autocratic regimes generally, and the imminence of the Olympic games are beginning to have at least one effect: the "cold pogrom" which now is concentrated to drive Jews from business will be conducted in the immediate future less spectacularly and more under cover than has been the rule heretofore.

GEOMETRICAL axioms to the contrary, a straight line is not always the shortest distance between two theatrical points. Indeed, quite as often as not, that comparatively simple solution of a generally complex problem may prove to be the most delusive in theatrical mathematics.

The Rev. Edgar R. Hyde, 65-year-old pastor of the Creston Avenue Baptist Church, 114 East 188th Street, the Bronx, unfolded yesterday before Magistrate Frank Oliver in the Bronx Magistrates' Court the story of his struggle by which, on Friday, he held a man of superior strength in his home until the police arrived.

Convinced that the University in Exile has become a "great American institution of higher learning, staffed with the best minds the universe has been able to produce," the board of trustees will consider plans for its permanent financing at a dinner Wednesday evening at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON Dec. 20. AN actor, whose eminence must certainly command for him the theatrical resources of London, told me that, having occasion not long ago to appear for charity in the costume of King Henry VIII, he was unable to obtain such a thing until he hit upon the happy idea of borrowing it from an amateur.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Jan. 11. -- Engagements in the past few days in Tembien in which artillery has been effectively used seem to herald an important new development in the Italian war tactics.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The naval conference suddenly won a new lease of life tonight at a time when its chances of survival had appeared hopeless to all except the most confirmed optimists among the five delegations.

Stella Gibbons, who is best known for an uproarious burlesque of the novel of the soil for adults, here proves her versatility with a whimsical fairy story, warranted to capture the imagination of younger children and to send their parents dreaming back to the Grimm brothers.

GENERAL GARIBALDI is the grandson and name-sake of that great leader of Italian patriots, who earned for himself the title of the Liberator. In simple, soldierly words he has given us an account of that part of his life which has been devoted to the pursuit of arms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A freedom-of-the-seas bloc within the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was reported holding out tonight against any abandonment of traditional American trading rights under the pending neutrality legislation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- That the Illinois relief crisis is an acute phase of a nation-wide problem is indicated by responses of eleven executives of national organizations, made public today, to a survey conducted by Survey Magazine. Specimen sentences follow:

Hope Farm, which offers homelike surroundings, care and training for underprivileged children, will be the beneficiary of a Spring fashion revue, entertainment and tea dance on Jan. 23 at the Ritz-Carlton. Miss Beatrice Butler heads a group of younger members of society aiding in the plans for the benefit.

Fordham's basketball team set back St. Francis College last night, 20 -- 18, in the Maroon gymnasium. But the mere figures fail to tell the heights to which both teams rose in the final two minutes of play before the thrilling game was decided.

ROME, Jan. 10. -- Unusual diplomatic activity in London, Paris and Brussels and to a lesser degree in Rome lead many to believe that European Chancelleries are again at work to break the Italo-Ethiopian deadlock and smooth out the European complications to which it has given rise.

IF Gene Tunney is sent to Congress, becomes a race horse owner and wins both the Derby and the Preakness in the same year, becomes the parent of twenty-four children and lives to be 79 years old, his record will yet remain a cut leas impressive, when seen from a distance, than the record of John Gully.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11. -- There was much speculation in shipping circles here today on what effect the temporary truce agreed upon in New York last night would have upon San Francisco arrivals and departures of the Panama Pacific Company's intercostal liners which have been meeting with delays caused by labor disputes with their crews.
You can't eat your trout and have them, too.

Apropos of the action of the New York film critics in designating the Hecht-MacArthur film, "The Scoundrel," as the most readable script of the year, and your own inclusion of the film among the best ten of the year, permit me to make the following comment:

PARIS, Jan. 4. -- A plan to bring about a better understanding of France in the United States is to be put into effect at the end of this month. A bureau of information will be opened in Paris that will be equipped to answer all questions concerning France and a similar bureau will function in the French Building of the Rockefeller Center in New York.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- New England, the section of the country which benefited the least by the New Deal's agricultural adjustment program and which, in its own opinion at least, suffered the most from it, is still gloating over the Supreme Court's decision of last Monday.

ON that day in February, 1861, when Abraham Lincoln in simple words but with deep emotion bade good-bye to his friends and neighbors in Springfield he began: "To this place and the kindness of these people I owe everything.

Ray Murphy, National Commander of the American Legion, has promised to make a statement regarding general service pensions for World War veterans. He said that the matter of general pensions had been raised at this time for the purpose of defeating the present payment of adjusted service certificates.

THE name of Sir William Rothenstein is so intimately bound up with British art and letters of the last half century that his son perforce enters the arena under a paternal handicap. The work of Michael Rothenstein, currently on exhibition at the Carl Fischer Gallery, is, however, quite distinct from that of his father and is likely to lead to decided differences of opinion among visitors to the exhibition.

AS a scientific essay this probably will take rank with the celebrated opus of Mr. Pickwick entitled (approximately): "On the Origin of the Hempstead Ponds, with Some Observations on the Theory of Tittlebats." But the bats that may be mentioned herein are not of the Pickwickian or Tittling variety, nor do they belong in the same class with the flutter-winged "Vespertilio Murinus" that gobbles up insects in erratic flight at dusk.

FOR the 1,010,506 men and boys now actively engaged in scouting there are 6,000,000 who no longer take part but have had training in the movement. These graduates, or veterans, have become a growing concern of Scout leaders; within the past year various Senior Scout programs have been devised to re-establish or further their contacts with scouting and its ideals.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 11 (AP). -- F. Brandon Smith Jr. received an award of $12,600 today in his case against Joseph F. Cannon, his former father-in-law, and tonight prepared to defend his gain from renewed attacks by the defense.

JUST A GIGOLO: When Marie Delphine Baele, known in Monte Carlo as Mme. Leroy, died in 1932 at the age of 77, she left a $1,000,000 estate to Luis Baese de la Cuadra, Chilean gigolo. Last week the Appeals Court of Monaco declared that the dancer had exerted "undue influence" on his elderly benefactor; he was deprived of his legacy, which went to Belgian relatives of the deceased.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 11 (AP). There have been thirty-one deaths in Oklahoma from spinal meningitis in about a month, but health authorities insist there was no danger of an epidemic.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Still protesting his innocence, Bruno Richard Hauptmann heard the news in his cell at the New Jersey State prison tonight that his plea for clemency had been denied and that he must go to the electric chair next Friday night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- For the first time a complete collection of the bookplates engraved by the late William F. Hopson, known among bibliophiles as "the dean of American bookplate artists," has been assembled in the exhibition room of the Sterling Memorial Library of Yale University.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 11. -- Thirty-one per cent of the membership of last June's graduating class at Bryn Mawr College is employed in paid jobs, according to a survey by the bureau of recommendations.

When I first read your account of best films, directors, actors, , last Sunday, I was rather furious because I thought you had not given credit to Victor McLaglen. On re-reading the account I see that you do give his name second among actors for fine performances, on account of his work in "The Informer."

The Ives Teachers' Oath Law was assailed as "futile" and a requirement that "promotes disloyalty" by Charles H. Strong, secretary of the Bar Association of the City of New York, at the annual luncheon yesterday of the Teachers Guild Associates at the Hotel Astor.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 11. -- The question of rationalization of and reduction in the work hours in the textile industry, which is on the agenda of the Pan-American Labor Conference at the suggestion of the United States, came up for discussion this morning and met strong opposition from employers' delegates of Chile and Brazil.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 11. -- In defeating Dartmouth, 7 -- 3, tonight, Yale not only won its first hockey game of the season in six attempts, but scored an Intercollegiate League victory. It was Dartmouth's first defeat in eight games.

HOLLYWOOD.WITH the change of the title of Sinclair Lewis's "Main Street" to "I Married a Doctor," one of the cinema's most flourishing industries and appalling liabilities again has been brought to the fore.

MURDER, as reputedly practiced by the Borgias, was a glass phial cinch when compared with what a writer has to endure when presenting that art upon the stage. Murder in private is simply a matter of individual taste and its technique rarely annoys any one other than the victim.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Winter finally relented this week-end and the Berkshires are blanketed with eight inches of snow. This is the first substantial snowstorm of the season. Flurries starting on Dec. 1 made skiing possible on several of the Berkshire mountain trails, but the thinness of the surface made the runs too fast and treacherous for any but competent runners.

An extensive program for broadening the scope of Federal and local relief for the unemployed was outlined in a four-page resolution adopted yesterday afternoon by 125 accredited delegates to the Citizens Conference on Unemployment who met in a three-hour session at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street.

One of the most prolific sources of statements denouncing the New Deal and all its works is Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee of New York. Last week he issued a statement in which he gave some advice to Republicans.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- The British Colonial amateur tennis championship will get under way Tuesday on the palm-surrounded courts of the hotel and will continue through Saturday, with J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J. defending the title.

WHATEVER else may be said about the three American painters whose one-man shows are here bracketed -- and however vehemently disagreement may rage -- I think we shall prove unanimous in conceding that each of them brings to his task an abundant fund of creative imagination.

OMAHA, Jan. 10. -- Of course, there is a great deal of disappointment in the farm States and some genuine dismay over the AAA decision. There is also some hardly disguised satisfaction over seeing Mr. Roosevelt "slapped" again, but not out on the farm.

TORONTO. THIS winter promises to be a bumper season, for the freighting business in Canada's new gold-mining area north of the transcontinental railway line. Aerial transport operators report the best year yet and now tractor trains are running across the frozen lakes, freighting in thousands of tons of mining machinery.

WARRENTON, Va. -- After being weather bound for three weeks by snow, rain and frost, the Warrenton Hunt had its first meet for the year on Tuesday with a good field out eager to resume the sport. The Hounds will meet during January, weather permitting, on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, at places and hours to be designated by the secretary, Captain Kirkpatrick.

WASHINGTON, Jan. ll. -- President Roosevelt was credited personally today with having evolved a plan whereby Treasury officials reviewed the facts which led up to the tax claim for more than $617,000 filed yesterday against Pierre S. du Pont, although they did not know the name of the principal concerned when the President suggested the procedure.

Since the Supreme Court decided against the Agricultural Adjustment Act, arousing doubts about its attitude toward other New Deal recovery measures, there has been introduced in Congress a bill to deny to the court its "assumed power" to declare laws unconstitutional.

DETROIT, Jan. 11. -- Such diverse enterprises as a distillery, a pickle factory, a university, a big manufacturing concern, numerous hotels and apartments and two hot-dog stands are being operated by the Federal court here, and the judges are enjoying the experience.

Certainly no one will pretend that the military situation in Ethiopia is today what Mussolini had hoped for. For ten weeks there has been no notable advance on the northern front, and there is every evidence that for what were perhaps good military reasons Marshal Badoglio has withdrawn his lines in the Tembien region. On the southern front it is plain that the Italian forces are behind the positions occupied by them two months ago.

My attention has been drawn to a letter from John Stuart Thompson of Jersey City in which he suggests that Nansen the explorer formerly owned the Samoyede dog Antarctic Buck. A team of Samoyede dogs was collected by Ivanovitch Trontheim for Nansen, but Antarctic Buck was not one of them, because he came from the team used by the explorer Borchgrevink when he went to the Antarctic for Sir George Newnes.

Twenty-two Brooklyn high school football players, selected as the outstanding performers in the borough during the last season, were honored at the tenth annual Abraham Straus football luncheon which was held in the store's dining room yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 11. -- An attempt to murder Rumania's chief rabbi, Dr. Jacob Isaac Niemerower, who is also a Senator, was made this morning when Aurel Jonescu, an alleged lunatic, fired three revolver shots at him, wounding him slightly in the hip.

Tom McDermott, 17-year-old swimming ace of George Washington High School, increased his record-breaking achievements yesterday by bettering the Public Schools Athletic League standard for the 50-yard back-stroke at the twelfth series of dual meets for the senior high school team championship of the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond division, conducted in the 75-foot pool of De Witt Clinton High.
A thrilling victory in the 400-yard relay, the final event of the meet, enabled Colgate to defeat Columbia's swimmers, 39 -- 32, last night in the loser's pool.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (AP) -- After trailing in the early running, Mrs. J. Chesney's Cristate came through with a great rush in the stretch to take the one and one-eighth miles Martin Behrman Memorial Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Although the plan which the government may eventually evolve to replace the Agricultural Adjustment Administration is still in a tentative form, President Roosevelt has ruled out two possible alternatives for the system which last Monday was held unconstitutional.

WINTER quarters, well stocked with the provender of mendicancy, are now occupied by the city's squirrels, who learned to live happily on relief long before the depression. These town-bred animals have developed a mode of life entirely unknown to their country cousins.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State and delegate to the London Naval Conference, will sail for home on the steamer Manhattan next Thursday. In announcing this fact today Secretary of State Cordell Hull said it was in accordance with previous plans and had no relation to reports of the impending collapse of the conference.

A long-range goal in the final ten seconds by Augustus Cutler enabled the Blind Brook team to start its Metropolitan Indoor Polo League campaign with an 8-to-7 victory over the First Division last night at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson, who never seemed much disposed to run away from trouble during his service in the City Controller's office, came face to face with it this week soon after becoming Philadelphia's 113th Mayor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP). -- A way to curtail the powers of the Supreme Court without resorting to a constitutional amendment was considered today at a meeting of a small bloc of House members.

VIENNA, Jan. 2, 1936. NEXT Summer's Salzburg Festival will open on July 25 with -- Beethoven's "Fidelio" under the direction of Arturo Toscanini, according to an official announcement made by the Salzburg Festival committee. Toscanini will repeat his sensationally successful "Falstaff," and will add to his Salzburg repertoire Wagner's "Die Meistersinger," the stage direction of which has been entrusted to Dr. Herbert Graf.
The City College basketball team scored an easy 40-15 victory over Yale in the Lavender gymnasium last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11. -- Leopold Stokowski, conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra at his final Saturday concert until he returns here in the Spring, thanked a large audience at the Academy of Music tonight for not applauding between the five Bach numbers that made up the first half of the program.

THERE are two boats in New York Harbor that fly the red flag. Daily they cross the busy shipping lanes of the port, and such capitalist-owned craft as transatlantic liners, tugboats and freighters give them wide berth.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Jan. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Deep in Guianan jungleland searching for Paul Redfern, Art Williams will lose all chance of renewing his license to operate an air taxi service for some time unless he returns here by tomorrow.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 11. -- Advocate of a "free American business," Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, issued a "hands off" warning to the government in an address today before the Rochester City Club.

BOSTON, Jan. 11. -- Retail trade in the First Federal Reserve District is seasonally quiet. Most merchants report sales at approximately the same level as this time a year ago. Last week department store sales in Boston were 3 per cent over a year ago.

New York University has received more than $42,000 in the last two months of the current semester from the National Youth Administration, the largest allotment of any institution of higher education in the country, Dr. H. Harold Axworthy, the university's Youth Director, announced yesterday in a report to Provost Rufus D. Smith.

MORE cats are basking these days close to family firesides and radiators than have appeared since the depression, according to experts in feline lore. The popularity of all breeds was evidenced this week-end at the thirty-fourth annual show in New York of the Atlantic Cat Club, one of the oldest organizations of its kind in the country, which drew a large attendance.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the Silver Bassinet Ball in behalf of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, which will be held the night of Jan. 31 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The occasion will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the nursery by Mrs. Henry Dwight Chapin.

TURIN, Dec. 24, 1935. AN event of exceptional importance for Italian music was the was the first performance (outside of England, Germany and France), after a century of silence, of Muzio Clementi's C major symphony, reconstructed from scattered manuscripts by Alfredo Casella and conducted by him some days ago at the second concert of the "E.I.A.R." public symphonic season in the Teatro di Torino of this city.

The end of the first week of the new session of Congress finds the fiscal plans of the Government temporarily in a state of confusion. Three great uncertainties overshadow the budget submitted by the President at the beginning of the week. First, there is the soldiers' bonus.

HERALDING the Presidential year, the Kleenmann Galleries are devoting space this week to a large group of cartoon attacks on the New Deal and its proponents. These papers are by Henry Ires Cobb, and he leaves no doubt of his thoroughgoing disapproval.

CONSIDERABLE interest this week centers in exhibitions that have to do with artists affiliated with the Ecole de Paris. At the Valentine Gallery, for example, we find a group of canvases by Matisse, Picasso, Henri Rousseau, Derain and Modigliani.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11. -- The blasting of the AAA has produced rather serious results in the Eighth Federal Reserve District.

Lord BRYCE said that public opinion is the real ruler of the United States. Granting that, it is still difficult to detect and utilize its flow and force. Nothing is harder than to find out what the mass of the people are thinking, or how they will vote. No census taker can tabulate such information accurately.
MADISON, Wis. -- Pasture research is being pushed at the University of Wisconsin Agricultural College here as part of a program to provide dairy farmers with better forage crops.

GROUNDSMEN at Lord's -- that famous cricket field almost in the heart of London -- recently won a strenuous battle against an insect horde, the daddy longlegs. Not only are these creatures a nuisance in themselves, but they are also the parents of the leather-jacket, a larva that is dreaded by every gardener and lawnsman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP). -- The Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether the Missouri or California State courts have control of $65,000 in New York City, part of the estate of Katharyn Oglesby Cornell, who died June 4, 1933, in Kansas City.
Drawings by Helene Sardeau are on view until Jan. 29 at the Boyer Galleries. Miss Sardeau, the wife of George Biddle, is well known as a sculptor.

WITH the departure of the Ethiopian troops, this recently panicky place has begun to resume more or less its normal aspect as the most picturesque city in Ethiopia. If one can ignore the smells and the squalor which fill its brown-walled rabbit warrens, one may even call Harar beautiful.

Mr. Stevens writes a very intelligent poetry with a gay rhythm and a sad undertone, relieved by irony: "harmonious skeptic * * * in a skeptical music." Mozart ("lucid souvenir of the past") and Claude Lorrain "(In a world that was resting on pillars)" come into his poems with their sense of order, and Ramon Fernandez ("Messages") with his ideas of order.

ATLANTA, Jan. 10. -- The South's reaction to the abolition of the AAA, which, it is assumed, will carry down with it the Bankhead Cotton Control Act, is as varied as the diverse elements in the economic structure of the section.

THIS novel, by the author of "The Furys," is another story of the Liverpool waterfront which James Hanley knows so thoroughly that he sets nerves atingle with the vividness of his successive portrayals. It is a district that breeds sharp passions and cruel encounters.

PARIS, Jan. 10. -- With French elections at most three months distant, every party has started counting heads and votes, and out of such a count as can be made at present the most striking fact that emerges is that "fascism," if it ever really existed in France, may now be considered dead, for any practical purposes.

President Roosevelt's recent address to Congress was one of strife, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., grandson of the late Senator of that name, from Massachusetts, declared yesterday. Mr. Lodge, a member of the Massachusetts House of Representatives and a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator, spoke at the Saturday luncheon discussion at the National Republican Club.

RECALLING one of the starkest incidents in America's history of the eventually successful efforts of white settlers to conquer the Indians, Floridians recently observed at Dade Memorial Park, near Bushnell, the 100th anniversary of the Dade massacre, which cost the lives of Major Francis L. Dade and his company of 103 men.

LET this morning's discourse begin with the ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House. The American Ballet and George Balanchine, maitre de ballet, are responsible for the dance on Thirty-ninth Street, and there is eagerness on the part of both the ballet and the opera management to undertake a full evening's production before the season is over.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Congress, in all probability, will soon enact for the United States a neutrality policy as permanent as any creation of that biennially elected organization can be. The halls of the Capitol these days resound with argument over such terms as "mandatory" and "discretionary," but the speakers are really discussing the same thing -- a legally directed course to keep the United States out of any war that may arise.
Hunter College's Dance Group will give recitals on Feb. 7 and 8, in which original dances in the modern idiom will be featured.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Expenditures of $330,801,713 on maintenance and improvement of existing river and harbor works in the fiscal year 1937 were recommended by Major Gen. E.M. Markham, Chief of Army Engineers, in his annual report for the fiscal year 1935, which ended last June 30.

CONSIDERING actual and estimated results of past, present and future months, motor companies continue to report a rising tide of business. . . . With 1936 retail sales continuing at what is described as a record-breaking rate, Chevrolet has announced the maintenance of peak production, 110,000 units, throughout this month, with heavy output continued through February and probably well into the Spring.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- A girl was killed and four women were injured tonight when their automobile was in a head-on collision with a tow truck on King Street, near the Connecticut boundary. Rye police said the truck had been pushing an automobile when it suddenly lurched from behind the small car and moved dizzily into the wrong side of the highway.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Ann Cooper Hewitt had a dozen evening gowns, forty pairs of shoes and thirty hats and twice made trips in special railroad cars to insure privacy for her pet dog, her stepbrother, Richard Brugiere, 31, of New York, has attested in an affidavit filed in Chancery Court here, it was disclosed today.

QUEENS BOULEVARD is at last being made into an adequate modern highway between Elmhurst and Jamaica. Already a large section of new pavement has been completed and opened to traffic, including the Woodhaven underpass which permits traffic on the center lanes of the boulevard to pass under the crossroad.

Because today is the first Sunday after the Epiphany there will be Epiphany pageants, candle services and oratorios in some of the churches this afternoon or evening, and this morning pastors will preach on lessons to be drawn from the story of the Magi from the East coming to bring their gifts to the new-born Christ.

SO scarce has water become in the goldfield district of Central Australia that it is being used as a popular and precious currency. Workmen often seek payment for their labor in water; a carpenter of Tenant's Creek, for instance, was recently paid eighty gallons for a piece of work.

MONTREAL, Jan. ll. -- The Montreal Maroons took first place in the National Hockey League's international group tonight with a 3-2 triumph over the New York Americans, in which Hooley Smith starred with two fine solo goals. The game, which started tamely, ended in rugged, hard-checking play that threatened to get out of control of the referees.
WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 10. -- President Roosevelt's attack on the aggressiveness of autocracies was read in Poland with understanding and approval.

THE formal town season is still in full swing. Nightly opera boxes are filled with women in rich gowns and dazzling jewels. In spite of all this it is too late to buy an important gown, unless one is fortunate enough to find a bargain.

H.G. WELLS had set the stage for a close-up interview. It was a starlike arrangement. The setting on the fourth floor of the Ambassador, facing the avenue; brocade-covered furniture against olive green walls; dim lights from an outside world, hardly penetrating the dignity of solitude, throwing a slight reflex on the golden content of a whisky bottle.

WE know more about the causes of accidents and how to prevent them than ever before; we know that communities and entire States can greatly reduce their traffic accidents if they really went to, and we know that the press, officials and the public are stirred intensely over the yearly sacrifice of 36,000 lives, more than a million injuries, and many millions of dollars through motor vehicle accidents.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. THE legitimate theatre of this city came to life briskly two weeks ago with a wave of first-class productions. Six openings called out the first-nighters within a space of eleven days, and the town suddenly became drama-conscious.

Eighty-one per cent of the 1,500,000 persons living on relief in this city, or 1,215,000, received medical care from the medical and nursing service of the Emergency Relief Bureau in the last eight months of 1935, Dr. C.F. McCarthy, director of the service, told a luncheon of the American Association for Social Security at the Astor yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11. -- Merchandise stocks were so greatly reduced during the holidays that clearing sales have been of less importance than usual, causing something of a lull in trade. Bank clearings, however, are maintained at a high level, due largely to the activity in the stock market, payments of interest and customary settlements in January.

LAKE PLACID, N Y. -- There will be an unusual variety of events to participate in and witness at Lake Placid this week, culminating next weekend in the sixteenth annual Lake Placid Club figure skating tournament and the National A.A.U. junior two and four man bobsled championships.

Athletes of Evander Childs High School of the Bronx carried off the principal honors in the annual Manual Training High School interscholastic meet, opening event of the schoolboy indoor track and field campaign, at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Representatives of five major airlines are reported near an agreement on a cooperative program of research and development of improved equipment which would save them millions of dollars annually.

THE main interest of 1936 in radio history undoubtedly will be the establishment of the first high-definition television service, according to a discussion of the prospects by the British Broadcasting Corporation in its official program journal, The Radio-Times.

The unbeaten Long Island Hockey Club regained first place in the Brooklyn-Long Island League by subduing the Manual Hockey Club, 4 -- 1, in the first game of a league double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Catholic philosophy was held by speakers at the annual communion breakfast of the Carroll Club yesterday to be the foundation of the United States Constitution and as the bulwark of "that security for which the world is clamoring today."

Your editorial on cheese was rather favorable on the general qualities of English cheeses. It was somewhat misleading when you mentioned Blue Dorset -- skim-milk cheese, slightly moldy, made in Dorset County -- a product not known outside of England in the same company with the internationally known Stilton, a fat, whole-milk cheese, made in Stilton, Huntingdon County, as well as in Leicestershire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Approval was given today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to an application of the Irving Trust Company of New York, in its capacities as trustee in bankruptcy of the National Electric Power Company,

Yenching University, a co-educational American-sponsored institution in the environs of Peiping, with a student body of nearly a thousand and more than a hundred teachers, two-thirds of whom are Chinese, has, through its American trustees, announced that it will remain where it is and carry on, "come what may."

Events in the art world this week include the reopening of the Whitney Museum of American Art with Section I of its Second Biennial Exhibition of Contemporary American Sculpture, Drawings and Prints. (Part II, devoted to watercolors and pastels, will follow, from Feb. 18 to March 18.) There are more than 150 artists represented and the exhibition will include sixty-five pieces of sculpture, thirty-eight drawings and 105 prints. It will open to the public tomorrow.

The tentative transit unification plan developed by Mayor La Guardia's advisers, Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., will not be acceptable to representatives of the B.M.T. unless modified in several important respects, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Conditions under which persons on WPA projects will be required to take private employment when offered were laid down today by Harry L. Hopkins, administrator, in terms which seek to protect labor employed on WPA projects from "the chiseling type of employer" and to safeguard existing wage standards.

Domestic markets for cotton futures were completely dominated last week by the invalidation of the AAA program, and prices fluctuated over a wide range. Near-by contracts held relatively firm, but the more distant months declined. At the close of trading on Saturday, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 11 points higher to 47 points lower than at the end of the preceding week.

Rating the candidates on the basis of points scored in the last two national championships, the American Olympic fencing committee yesterday named thirty-nine swordsmen as members of the squad from which the team will be picked to represent the United States in the games at Berlin next Summer.

Eugenia Buxton, young pianist from Memphis, Tenn., made a successful New York debut yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall in a recital for which she had arranged an exacting program featuring the Beethoven sonata in C minor, Op. 111.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 12. -- W.W. Swan in Sore Knees and Egbert Moxham Jr. in Stingaree led their respective divisions in the Frostbite dinghy races conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today. With perfect sailing weather prevailing a fleet of thirteen boats turned out.

I always fully shared the indignation of Theodore Roosevelt against persons who claim all the rights and privileges of American citizenship at the same time that they give the major part of their loyalty to the foreign country from which they came.

The most progressive and prosperous year New York racing has enjoyed in a quarter of a century was reflected yesterday in the annual report of the State Racing Commission, an outline of which was released for publication.
PARIS, Jan. 11. -- Money has not become much more abundant in the market here but the rate of call money has fallen simultaneously with the Bank of France's rate to 4 per cent and even slightly less.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Action to prevent repetition of the "flagrant offenses" at the trial of Bruno Hauptmann and "shocking incidents" preceding Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's departure for England was demanded today by William L. Ransom, president of the American Bar Association.

Some of the ship lines operating in the intercoastal trade are considering the abandonment of San Francisco as a port of call until they can obtain assurance of protection of their crews during their stay in port, it was learned yesterday. They have considered using Los Angeles as their only California terminal.
The annual report of the Commonwealth Fund, a philanthropic endowment with assets of $40,000,000, was made public yesterday at the office of the fund, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The AAA decision of the Supreme Court overshadowed all other news in the commodity futures markets here last week and caused erratic price movements. Cocoa, wool tops, rubber and crude oil moved up in the cash markets with all other staples declining.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 12. -Frank R. Kelly and Edward E. Garland, partners in many a victorious march to two-man team honors and collaborators in a series of record achievements as members of the crack Roseland Community Gun Club squad, were arrayed against each other today in a dramatic shoot-off for the Middle Atlantic States individual skeet championship.

Back in the late nineties Maud Allan shocked the courts of Europe and New York with her interpretation of "Salome" and the dance of "The Seven Veils." In those years and later she vied with Isadora Duncan in that "abomination" then described as "barefoot dancing." Miss Allan called it esthetic.

Commissioner MOSES' latest and in some respects most ambitious plan for park and parkway development in New York City was submitted to the Board of Estimate last week. It brings up to date, complete with landscaping and engineering details and cost estimates, the project for the improvement of the Manhattan waterfront from Seventy-second Street north to 125th Street.

A united front of religious leaders and Communists in this country can only prove harmful to religion, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Neither Neil Burkinshaw nor Nugent Dodds, the Washington attorneys retained by the defense in the Hauptmann case, could be reached tonight and some mystery surrounded their whereabouts.

Mrs. Lee A. Reid will give a tea tomorrow at her home, 158 East Sixty-third Street, for a group of women active in behalf of the Duchesne Placement Bureau, which will be opened this month at the headquarters of the Carroll Club. The bureau, which will be maintained by the alumnae of the Sacred Heart Convent, will aid young women, former students of the convent, in obtaining employment.

Distribution of the forms, on which some 1,200 cotton mills will be asked to pledge individual voluntary maintenance of fundamental provisions of the industry's former codes, has been started, Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, announced yesterday.

Attorneys for Bruno Richard Hauptmann prepared yesterday for a last-ditch fight in the Federal courts to save his life as Governor Harold G. Hoffman, attending a frolic at the Lambs Club here, declared he had not decided whether to postpone the execution of the convicted slayer of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son.
BERLIN, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Germany's capital last night and in the early hours of today witnessed the most imposing and brilliant social event since the heyday of the Kaisers.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12. -- Urging that the Soviet Union's military budget for this year be increased by 6,000,000,000 rubles over last year because of increasing war danger, one of the commanders of White Russia's military forces took up today the keynote of Premier Molotoff at the congress of the Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Union.

Offering will be made to the public today of an issue of $1,340,000 Fort Worth, Texas, Independent School District 4 per cent bonds by a banking group consisting of the Chase National Bank, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company and Frazier Moss Co. of Fort Worth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Some leaders of the Democratic party who temper their enthusiasm about President Roosevelt's chances of re-election with a study of the political possibilities this year, have begun urging State chairmen to pay careful attention to the selection of Presidential electors.

BOSTON, Jan. 12. -- Asserting that they regard the Teachers' Oath Law as the beginning of an attempt to regiment the teaching profession, educators and teachers from twenty-four colleges, universities, preparatory and public schools have formed the Massachusetts Society for Freedom in Teaching, the group announced today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- The first bobsled race of the current season, a novice event from the half-mile mark, was captured by a girl driver, Miss Katheryn Dewey of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds, in both the two and the four man divisions on the Mount Van Hoevenberg bob run today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- An attack on President Roosevelt's budget message and a plea for a Congressional investigation of "the entire governmental structure" with a view to attaining objectives pledged in the Democratic national platform and Mr. Roosevelt's campaign speeches in 1932 were made by the American Liberty League in a statement today.

Securities of several domestic welfare institutions and foreign governments were a feature in a diversified list of announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity. Proposals looking to several large refundings, pending completion of new financing,

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- The reaction in the markets here to the heavy blow to President Roosevelt's ambitious reform plans seems to have been slight. Commodities were unsettled by doubts concerning the President's future policy in this field.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 12. -- Four Italian prisoners at Dessye told today of the Italian defeat at Enda Selassie which resulted in disaster to an entire column of 1,600 infantry. The action occurred twenty miles north of Enda Selassie after an Ethiopian advance which routed the Italian garrison there.

In 1911 some 200 German philanthropists subscribed fifteen million marks to create a research organization in the spirit of a proposal made a century before by WILHELM VON HUMBOLDT. Under the leadership of the theologian ADOLF VON HARNACK the Kaiser Wilhelm Gesellschaft was born.

HSINKING, Manchukuo, Jan. 12. -- For the first time since the establishment of Manchukuo four years ago the highest official assurance was given today to American and other foreign business concerns that their rights and interests would be safeguarded.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP). -- A change in the "little Supreme Court," making Richard W. Hogue Jr. the right hand man of Chief Justice Hughes was "confirmed" today.

All redemption or relief which comes to mankind, broken by economic and political situations beyond its control, has as its root a religious impulse, the Rev. Worcester Perkins, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

With nearly half of January behind us, market indices have pointed to continuing business recovery. Last week's nation-wide bank exchanges ran 25 per cent above 1935, whereas average commodity prices were up less than 4 per cent. The week's steel output rose from 47 1/2 per cent of capacity to 51 and, while this was still below the 57 per cent high point of December, it compared with 44 last January.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- John J. Raskob, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee and active supporter of the American Liberty League, declared today that Pierre S. du Pont and himself, who were charged on Friday before the Board of Tax Appeals with creating "fictitious losses" in order to reduce Mr. du Pont's income taxes in 1929, were the victims of bureaucratic tyranny.

Although the AAA was a strong factor in stimulating sales of agricultural implements and automobiles in the rural areas, the United States Supreme Court's decision invalidating the law has had comparatively little effect on the demand for steel, according to the magazine Steel.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- Grain futures quotations here last week, with comparisons, follow:
Viking claims the first "dark-horse hit" among the 1936 books. It is "The Wooden Pillow," by Carl Fallas, which has sold almost 3,000 copies in four days, the Publishers say.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- A success which justifies President Roosevelt's plans to make it permanent has attended the operation of the Civilian Conservation Corps, Robert Fechner, director of emergency conservation work, declared today in his first annual report to the President.

Charging that there are from 2,000 to 3,000 pseudo-decorators in the metropolitan area who work hand in hand with so-called furniture wholesalers in deceiving the public, the American Institute of Decorators, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, joined yesterday with the Furniture Trade Committee in its war on fake wholesalers.

The names of 376 members of the Police Department cited for bravery or for other distinguished service in 1935 are listed by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in general orders made public yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings outplayed a tired band of Montreal Maroons tonight, handing the Stanley Cup winners a 6 -- 0 beating before 12,000 spectators, the largest crowd of the season.
MOSCOW, Jan. 12. -- The authoritative Soviet writer, Karl Radek, today accused American Fascist sympathizers of plotting to wreck Soviet-United States friendship.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (Canadian Press) . -- The government today faced an uphill struggle in its efforts to find seats for Ramsay MacDonald and his son, Malcolm, Cabinet ministers defeated in the general election.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Jan. 12. -- The distribution of $5,716,886 in cash, securities and chattels of the $8,580,107.22 estate of Brig. Gen. H.C. Trexler has been authorized by Judge Ethan A. Gearhart of the Lehigh County Orphans Court. The trustees still hold $2,863,220.38 in bonds, mortgages, obligations and real estate for future distribution.

DETROIT, Jan. 12. -- An experimental model of a new type "flivver" plane, powered with a newly developed Ford V-8 engine and built behind the closed doors of the Ford Motor Company's airplane division in Dearborn, has been licensed by the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce.

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, L.F. Sanman won the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The second trophy went to E.B. Horwath with 95. In the handicap contest F.B. Jacobus took the first and R. Walsh the second prize.
Viola Mitchell, violinist, will appear in a recital under the auspices of the American Woman's Association tonight at 8:15 o'clock in the American Woman's Club.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 11. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84.4, which compares with 84 the week before, 84.1 two weeks before, 84.4 three weeks before and 84 four weeks before.

TOKYO, Jan. 12. -- Before the Cabinet considered today the new instructions sent to Admiral Osamu Nagano, chief Japanese delegate at the London Naval Conference, naval members of the Supreme War Council heard them explained by Navy Minister Mineo Osumi.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- With due allowances for forthcoming decisions of the Supreme Court, the bonus issue, neutrality, and the drive for a new farm program to supplant the invalidated Agricultural Adjustment Act promise to dominate the Washington scene during the coming week, probably in the order named.

HERE is a travel-adventure book which is as masculine as an old mackinaw or a plug of chewing tobacco. The title is "Desolate Marches" (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50), and L.M. Nesbitt, author of "Hell-Hole of Creation," wrote it. It is a throw-back to the old days when adventure and exploration books, like what were once called "smoking-room stories," were meant exclusively for men.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP). -- At a cost of $5,000 Cornell University has a machine capable of making artificial radium as a substitute for the real stuff, which costs $40,000 a gram.

N.Y.U. and L.I.U. again performed impressively during the past week in intercollegiate basketball circles as St. John's was dropped from the ranks of the unbeaten. Manhattan kept pace with the leaders and is also undefeated.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Shirley Tapp, 17-year-old daughter of an automobile factory worker, remained unconscious tonight for the fourth consecutive day, "slain," as her father explained her condition, "by the power of God."

For the purpose of adjusting the vision of Eastern Republicans to the calm contemplation of one of their rising hopes or fears in the Middle West, we read eagerly all surveys of Governor LANDON and anthologies of his opinion. Some of the latter, taken by themselves and wrenched from the main body of his thought, seem at first sight ill calculated for these Republican latitudes.

BOSTON, Jan. 12. -- Arthur Barker's five-game victory over Richard V. Wakeman gave the New York squash racpets team the first leg on the third Lockett Trophy, the New Yorkers defeating Boston, 4 to 3, in the concluding match tonight at the Harvard Club.

More than 1,000 delegates from the eight States comprising the Northeast Region of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations gathered yesterday at the Community House of Congregation Emanuel, 3 East Sixty-fifth Street. During the annual convention, which lasted all day, representative rabbis, lay and youth leaders discussed the subject "If the Synagogue Could Speak."

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- Although the Atlantic conference that fixes fares has not yet decided when it will discuss the Cunard-White Star Line's notice of withdrawal over the rating of the Queen Mary, "the fantastic situation" of allowing the largest and probably the fastest British liner to sail on her maiden voyage as an inferior "cabin ship" is being widely discussed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 12. -- A special exhibition of nearly 1,000 volumes of the poetry of Horace, ranging in publication dates from the fifteenth to the twentieth century and in size from vest-pocket editions to volumes nearly two feet high, has been opened in the treasure room of the Princeton University library in connection with the bimillennial anniversary of the great poet's birth.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12. -- King Carol of Rumania, accompanied by Prince Michael and his suite, arrived at 9 o'clock this morning at Topchider, the private royal railway station, where they were awaited by King Peter of Yugoslavia, Dowager Queen Marie, Regent Prince Paul and Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch.

The Boston Bruins served notice last night that they are still very much in the running for a play-off berth in the American division of the National Hockey League. The Beantown skaters, last in the group, handed the New York Rangers a 6-to-3 defeat at Madison Square Garden and drew too close to the blue-jerseyed sextet for comfort.

One of the ironies of time concerns WILLIAM J. BRYAN. As a statesman who tried hard to keep the United States out of war twenty years ago, Mr. BRYAN has acquired stature and popularity in quarters hitherto severely critical of his ideas and his policies.

A plan to reduce payroll hold-ups by making it mandatory to list the serial numbers of all paper currency used in large weekly salary payments, was suggested by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in a statement released yesterday.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 12. -- The financial report of the Dartmouth College Athletic Council showed an operating loss of $36,609 for the past academic year, according to figures disclosed today.

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- Domestic politics continue as the predominant factor on the Bourse as on the foreign exchange market. This is ascribed to the current opinion that the franc is destined to be the real stake to be played for soon in Parliament and, later, during the elections.
PARIS, Jan. 11. -- The French index of wholesale prices in December, compiled by the Statistique Generale, was 357, compared with 353 in November and 344 in December, 1934.

Your editorials so often reflect true understanding of American principles, unbiased by partisanship, I am encouraged to suggest that you enlighten The Times of London and other British newspapers on the significance of our Supreme Court's ruling against the AAA.

The two-year reign of the St. Francis Prep as holder of the Brooklyn Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's individual swimming championship honors was brought to an end yesterday when the defending titleholders were outscored by a strong Brooklyn Prep contingent, 32 to 30.

Because their plans for a new home for the Museum of Modern Art were of such excellent quality, sixteen students of the Columbia University School of Architecture will have their work placed on exhibition outside of academic circles for the first time in the history of the school.

On Jan. 20 the Nearly New Shop, 913 Eighth Avenue, the second oldest permanent rummage shop in the city, will hold a special sale of women's apparel and accessories for the benefit of the Berkshire Industrial Farm, at Canaan, N.Y.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- Country holders of hogs who held them back in anticipation of the United States Supreme Court's decision on the AAA, which virtually removes the processing tax on pork products, received 65 cents a 100 pounds more on Friday in the livestock market here than they would have obtained on Monday.

For almost five hours yesterday afternoon the snowclad hills around Pittsfield, Mass., resounded to the shouts and thuds of skiers who had taken the first Sunday snow train excursion of the season from New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Three more important New Deal measures will be before the Supreme Court when it meets tomorrow for its second opinion day in January, and Washington speculated tonight on the possibility of their meeting the fate that befell the AAA in last Monday's six-to-three decision.

The highest percentage of suicides today is not among the persons living in the slums, nor is it among the crippled, the blind or the sick, but instead is among the well-to-do, the Rev. Dr. Jean S. Milner said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Declaring that their chief activities "are increasingly becoming a kind of political gangsterism," the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, criticized the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars in a sermon last night at his church.

There should be recognition on this side of the Canadian border of the distinguished public service of the Hon. CHARLES A. MAGRATH, who has just resigned his post as chairman of the Canadian section of the International Joint Commission, of which he has been a member since the adoption of the treaty under which it was established.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 12. -- The Montclair Athletic Club completed its schedule in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Class B Squash Racquets League in first place today, receiving a default from the Morristown Squash Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Legislation to carry out a new and more ingenious plan of farm relief that would go further in the direction of crop control than any heretofore conceived was being whipped into shape tonight by Agricultural Adjustment officials preparatory to its submission to the National Council of Farm Organizations on Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- After flying to Trenton and back this afternoon, Captain George R. Dickens, a veteran pilot of the 103d Observation Squadron, Pennsylvania National Guard, went to the locker room of the squadron's armory at the Philadelphia airport and shot himself fatally with a revolver.

Tina Flade made what was virtually her second New York debut at the Guild Theatre last night in a program of nine new dances. When she gave her first performance here three years ago she was a charming airy young person who apparently had nothing to say of any great moment.

It is sometimes as hard to chain a word as to put a hook in the nose of a leviathan. But there are occasions when the effort ought to be made, lest it fly apart and dissipate its force. The latest word to suffer that fate is the most useful and timely "racket." Originally, it meant a disturbance, or "excessive social excitement."

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- Riverdale, Ardsley's first rink and Caledonia's third rink came through with victories today in the first round of the annual interclub curling matches at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

Dan O'Mahoney will engage in another defense of his world's heavyweight wrestling championship when he engages Chief Little Wolf of Albuquerque, N.M., in a finish contest at Madison Square Garden tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Notwithstanding the conflicting views which have been cabled from America as to the future of wheat and cotton as the result of the extinction of the AAA, these are having but little influence on opinion here, and the keener observers have not the slightest disposition to take a tragic view of the outlook.

With disclaimers frequently voiced by those who spoke for him of any intention of organizing a new political party, the first political platform of the International Righteous Government Convention of Father Divine's Peace Mission was read yesterday to 5,000 Negroes and whites who jammed St. Nicholas Palace, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 51 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the rate of the preceding week.

The question just what brought the United States into the World War, on which debate has recently been reopened, will probably never be answered to the satisfaction of every one. Those who want to believe that President Wilson succumbed to the pressure of the international bankers in their desire to protect loans made to the Allies will not be dissuaded by present-day testimony.

Works new to the Sunday afternoon audiences of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra were played under Sir Thomas Beecham's direction yesterday in Carnegie Hall. They included the "Symphony No. 1," which is actually in form a "concerto grosso," by William Boyce,

The Skillman Homes Corporation, Queens builders, have purchased a plot 60 by 100 feet on the east side of 159th Street, 300 feet south of Thirty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, from George Sisbower of Yonkers. H. Albert Johntra negotiated the sale of the land, which will be improved with a dwelling of brick and stone construction containing eight rooms and two baths.

Details of the agreement entered into by the American Superpower Corporation on Nov. 22 with the Bankers Trust Company whereby 1,500,000 shares of common stock of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation were transferred to the trust company are given in the annual report of the investment company to be issued today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP). -- Adam Mann, policeman, is again riding to work with Vice President and Mrs. Garner in their long black government automobile, instead of going down by street car.

The government received an "overwhelming mandate" to stay out of war in the final returns of a national peace poll conducted by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches of America, it was announced yesterday.

A man cannot have been for eight years Mayor of New York without displaying qualities which helped him to gain that office, and which go far to explain what he did while in it. As we now look back to the time when Mr. HYLAN was in the City Hall, we see certain traits of his stand out more clearly perhaps than they did at the time.

Because of a realization that "for some time to come it will be necessary to provide care for the destitute," thus transforming the administration of relief from an emergency to a permanent function, Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, announced last night plans for complete reorganization of the Bureau designed to attain maximum economy and efficiency.

America, the only country that Hitler respects, should have refused to send its athletes to the Olympic Games in Berlin, it was declared by Heinz Liepmann, German author, formerly in a Nazi concentration camp, who addressed the congregation of the Free Synagogue, worshiping in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning.

ATHENS, Jan. 12. -- In response to an invitation by the British Admiralty, the Greek general staff of the navy comprising thirty officers and headed by Prince Paul will take part in the manoeuvres of a destroyer flotilla off Athens tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- The action of the corn market on the Board of Trade last week was a great disappointment to interests on both sides. Bulges have drawn selling orders on futures and a certain volume by interior cash holders, while on the breaks there has been no appreciable rush to buy the distant options which would cause more than moderate price changes.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the recital by Jascha Heifetz, violinist, which will take place tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Women's Trade Union League of New York. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is honorary chairman of the benefit committee and Mrs. Myron I. Borg is active chairman.
The following earnings of subsidiaries of the Standard Gas and Electric Company for the year ended on Nov. 30 have been reported:

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 12. -- Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, new sensation of the clay courts, today upset Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, the nation's third ranking player, in the semi-finals of the fourth annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament. The score was 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

ASTORIA, Ore., Jan. 12. -- Thirty-four men, the intercoastal freighter Iowa's entire crew, apparently perished today when a southeast hurricane dashed the 410-foot vessel onto treacherous Peacock Spit.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Jan. 12. -- At a meeting of the board of directors of the Pittsburgh Steel Company tomorrow, Henry A. Roemer, chairman of the board and president of the Sharon Steel Hoop Company, is expected to be elected to succeed Homer D. Williams, who has been president of Pittsburgh Steel for ten years.

BERLIN, Jan. 12. -- Leaders of the independent Protestant clergy in a declaration read from hundreds of pulpits throughout Prussia today charged the officially inspired press with deliberately misinforming the public regarding developments in the church struggle and the government with suppressing all reports indicating the true situation.

Some parts of the neutrality legislation now under consideration in Congress are approved, while others are rejected in a report submitted to the Council of Foreign Relations by Allen W. Dulles and Hamilton Fish Armstrong. The report was made public by the council yesterday.
BERLIN, Jan. 12. -- The vanguard of the American Olympic Winter sports team, which arrived today, brought with it the long and earnestly desired snowfall.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week developed the heaviest turnover and the widest price range in many months. The narrow and routine character of recent markets was broken and orders in the large, round amounts typical of the trading last year featured.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Confronted by "a momentous opportunity'' when it meets in Miami on Jan. 15, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor should take favorable and speedy action to promote union organization on an industrial basis in at least four basic industries, it was stated today by the Committee for Industrial Organization of which John L. Lewis is chairman.

The records of the Police Department on automobile accidents in 1935 showed a decrease in the number of accidents of 7,653, in deaths of 65 and 9,212 in the number of injured, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

A program of ten projects to provide new and improved access to the World's Fair in Flushing Meadows Park will be submitted to Mayor La Guardia and other officials of the metropolitan area today by the Regional Plan Association.

The coming Presidential election and the economic situation were discussed in many New York City pulpits yesterday. Several clergymen praised President Roosevelt, but at least one charged that he sought to "set class against class."

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- Action of the grain markets last week was extremely disappointing to both the longs and the shorts. The volume of business was not large, although fluctuations were rapid at times. There seemed to be nothing to attract new buying or selling in sufficient volume to give prices a sufficient range to create confidence on either side

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,817,627,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- While Governor Lehman has guarded closely the recommendations contained in his annual budget message, which will go to the Legislature at the session tomorrow night, there is good reason for believing that due to the upward trend in business, reflected in the receipt of greatly increased revenues, the Governor may be spared the necessity of calling for new taxes or an increase in existing levies.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
The purchase of a group of tenement houses on a First Avenue corner for modernizing featured realty transactions reported in the city over the week-end.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP). -- A methodical plot to extort $5,000 from John W. Behr, widely known boxing authority, under threat of kidnapping his co-ed daughter was disclosed today.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J. Jan. 12. -- Norman Armitage, the national indoor and outdoor saber champion, gained his third victory in the Olympic tryout series at the Commonwealth Club today.

The St. Mark's Ladles Emergency Society will give a luncheon, bridge and musicale on Jan. 30 at the Astor to celebrate the fifth anniversary of the founding of the organization. Mrs. Mary Breckinridge, volunteer director of the Frontier Nursing Service, will speak.
