" Granite," the Clemence Dane play produced ten years ago in London, will be offered professionally for the first time in this country tonight at the Vanderbilt Theatre. Heading the cast will be Mary Morris, supported by Byron McGrath, Robert H. Gordon, Phyllis Welch, Len D. Hollister and Jack Soanes, and what they are up to is a story of dark doings off the coast of ngland.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- The ambitious ski jumping program arranged for the metropolitan area this season by the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association was inaugurated today at Bear Mountain Park under a setting that was more befitting a Spring sport than a Winter activity.

I am a young man of 21. This November I intend to vote for the first time. I am in a dilemma. I want to vote, but I do not know for whom. As far as the Republican party is concerned, I see no candidate worth voting for.

NUTLEY, N.J., Jan. 12. -- Members of the Nutley Consumers Club will reap the first benefit of their cooperative buying movement Tuesday night when Allston Pulsford, club treasurer, will distribute the first dividends. Although the dividends total only about $15, the members believe the occasion marks a real start toward local consumer cooperation.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- The money market again is experiencing pronounced ease, now that the disturbance normally experienced at the year-end has lifted. Daily accommodation is abundant at one-half per cent, at which rate the big banks once again are buying bills freely from the discount market.

The Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets had an opportunity yesterday to tie for first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League for the first time this season, but the redoubtable New York Rovers, primed for the occasion, stood in their way.

While the AAA decision brought to a complete standstill trading in cotton goods, other divisions of the local wholesale markets enjoyed a fair amount of activity last week on Spring goods. Some buyers scheduled to come here for purchases of cotton items delayed their trips.
Although it will do little to assuage the anguish of all those disappointed wing shots who vainly searched for woodcock last Fall, the mystery of what became of the birds has at last been solved.

Eide Norena, Metropolitan Opera soprano, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, seems to have a following which believes she can do no wrong. At any rate a large audience congregated for her concert and gave her a reception that waxed in enthusiasm as the evening progressed.

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- While Providence and the weather are to some degree moderating the urgency of the Ethiopian problem which Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, will face when he goes to Geneva a week hence there is a minor yet scarcely less difficult question before the League of Nations Council with which he is intimately concerned that is coming into the foreground.

VIENNA, Jan. 12. -- The permanent head of the Czechoslovak Foreign Office, Dr. Kamil Krofta, contributes a significant article to to morrow's Reichspost entitled "The Republic and Austria." It urges the desirability of a rapprochement and close cooperation in the future between Czechoslovakia and Austria.

Characterizing Senator William E. Borah as the ablest of the aspirants for the Republican nomination for President, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday that the Idaho Senator was unavailable for the nomination because of his opposition to participation of the United States in the World Court, his support of New Deal measures in Congress and his advocacy of the prohibition amendment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP). -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will resume tomorrow an effort to reach a compromise with a bloc which reportedly is holding out against any surrender of traditional American trading rights under the pending neutrality legislation.

LARCPIMONT, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- Fair skies and a moderate westerly breeze brought out a record fleet of thirteen frostbite dinghies in the regular regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Leroy Clark's Skeets led the Class B boats by a margin of three points, while Walter Rowe in Liza was an easy victor in Class X.

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- News from Tokyo this evening that the Japanese Cabinet had confirmed an agreement between its Foreign Office and its Navy Department to remain in the London Naval Conference as long as any agreement toward limitation was possible was received with utmost gratification by the other delegations.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 12. -- Enforcement of the 35-year-old law limiting corporate land ownership on the island to 500 acres is a matter of administration policy, Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, who started for Washington today, emphasized to sugar representatives here.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 12. -- Dripping skies came to the aid of Ethiopia's fighting men today, far ahead of time. The "little" rainy season has returned.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12. -- Jimmy Hines of Garden City, L.I., won the Los Angeles $5,000 open golf championship today with a seventy-two-hole total of 280.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- The decision of the United States Supreme Court invalidating the AAA is considered here as an advantage to President Roosevelt in the election campaign, it being held that the ruling will rally farmers to unconditional support of the Democrats.

Eight societies, each with a more than passing regard for the works of William Shakespeare, convened last night at the Hotel Astor in Twelfth Night revel and supper. Heretofore they have paid their homage separately, but last night it was a joint celebration -- the first of its kind, it was said, ever to have been held in New York.

The Silver Purchase Act of 1934 has accomplished none of the purposes that it was supposed to accomplish and should be revised or repealed, according to Handy Harman, bullion brokers, whose annual review of the silver market is published today.

The death of former Mayor John F. Hylan at 1:15 o'clock yesterday morning brought tributes and expressions of regret yesterday from many who had been associated with him during his eight years as Mayor and from many present-day officials as well.

Abraham Kaplan, former president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and manager of John P. O'Brien's unsuccessful campaign for re-election as Mayor, charged yesterday that the Fusion city administration, in the light of its campaign promises, had been a complete failure.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 12. -- Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, 38 years old, a Baldwin housewife, and Everett R. Appelgate, 36, Nassau County Legionnaire, will be placed on trial here tomorrow morning before County Judge Cortland A. Johnson and a jury, charged with the murder of Appelgate's wife, Ada C. Appelgate, at her home, 12 Bryant Place, Baldwin, on Sept. 27, last.

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- The United States Supreme Court's decision against the AAA stirred considerable interest here by reason of the principle it affirms, in that leaders in French financial circles are not among the advocates of planned economy.

Robert Underwood Johnson, poet, celebrated his eighty-third birthday yesterday with an afternoon of chamber music, a birthday cake and the company of a score of intimate friends yesterday at his home, 327 Lexington Avenue.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Action has been begun to test the validity of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law, it was learned here today.

Dan O'Mahoney, a former member of the Irish Guards, retained his world's heavyweight wrestling championship last night, defeating Chief Little Wolf, Trinidad, Colo., challenger, in a business-like manner before about 5,000 devotees of the mat sport in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- An appropriation of $2,340,000,000 for the WPA to provide relief jobs for 3,000,000 persons in the fiscal year 1937 was requested of Congress today by the United States Conference of Mayors.

Dissatisfied with the playing of his squad in their recent games, Manager Red Dutton yesterday announced a wholesale shake-up of the New York Americans' hockey, six on the eve of their struggle tonight in Madison Square Garden with the Canadiens.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP). -- The fifteen-year-old "ideal marriage" of Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks was formally dissolved today while they sat together at a movie business conference.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP). -- In connection with a secret ballot among alumni on the question of retaining the veteran Gilmour Dobie as head football coach at Cornell University, James Lynah, the director of athletics at the Ithaca (N.Y.) institution, today obtained the views of the Cornell Club of Chicago.

Women of all nations were urged to stand together for peace by three speakers at the international dinner of the New York League of Business and Professional Women at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- John W. Keogh, a well-to-do realty owner with an obsession on the subject of legislative reapportionment in Illinois, drew a pistol this morning during a hearing before Circuit Judge John Prystalski, shot and killed Major Christopher G. Kinney, a lawyer. He also fired three bullets at the judge.
The advance of a veteran competitor through the second round of the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tourney at the Yale Club was one of the highlights of yesterday's play.

Seventeen former officers and directors of the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company, which is being liquidated by the State Insurance Department, were restrained permanently yesterday from dealing in securities of the company under a consent injunction obtained from Supreme Court Justice Lydon by Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall, in charge of the Bureau of Securities of the Attorney General's office.

The Panama Pacific liner California, which arrived yesterday at San Pedro, Calif., was ordered by officials of the line to remain there until next Sunday, when she is scheduled to start back to New York. Her scheduled trip to San Francisco was canceled.

The potency of the names of Serge Rachmaninoff, Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra was manifested at the concert given by these parties last night in Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Philadelphia Orchestra Pension Fund and the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery.

Clad in the somber habiliments of monks, with Paul Henkel of the Hotel Ansonia wearing the more striking costume of the abbot, the Society of Restaurateurs dined last night in more or less medieval fashion in the winery of B. Cribari Sons at 601 West Twenty-sixth Street.

BASLE, Switzerland, Jan. 13. -- The dollar has ousted the Italian war situation from the position it has held as Public Worry No. 1 among the big European bank governors at their last three monthly meetings here as members of the board of the Bank for International Settlements.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Leaders of the Republican majority and Democratic minority completed preparations tonight for convening of the 1936 Legislature tomorrow noon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 13. -- With a dazzling late rally, the University of Pennsylvania won its first game in two starts in defense of its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League crown when it whipped Harvard, 26 to 24, in a thrilling encounter at the Indoor Athletic Building tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The text of the Harrison-Byrnes-Clark-Steiwer Bonus Bill, introduced in the Senate today, reads as follows:

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- Plans of the Soviet Union for a vast increase in military expenditures, revealed yesterday by Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff in Moscow, aroused great interest in Berlin. Although official quarters were rather reticent in their comments, the view the Hitler regime wants to impress on the German people and the world was voiced emphatically in the officially inspired press.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- An absent-minded professor escaped a disbarment action in the Supreme Court today, but the justices "reprimanded" him.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- J.P. Morgan today described the sales of treasures from his vast art collections as an attempt "to protect my heirs from buying them back from the government" after he dies.

Business along Broadway, considered a barometer of general trade conditions, is looking up and the recent holiday trading exceeded that of a year ago, according to reports made yesterday at the annual meeting of the Broadway Association in the Hotel Astor.

At the concert given by the Beethoven Association last night in Town Hall -- the third concert of the eighteenth season of the organization-the artists were Enid Szantho, the contralto of the Vienna Opera who came over here last month to assist in Otto Klemperer's perI formance of Mahler's Second Symphony, and Guy Maier and Lee Pattison, again performing in public, to the pleasure of their audiences throughout the country, on two pianos.

A step toward reviving national interest in the legitimate theatre, a primary objective of the Federal Theatre Project, was seen yesterday in the announcement that arrangements had been made for a WPA company which will visit forty-four cities in the Southeastern States.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors adopted this afternoon a resolution protesting against "discriminatory treatment" of this county by the WPA for failure to provide 100 per cent cost allotments for Westchester projects.

The Whitney Museum of American Art has two biennials, held in alternate years. One is devoted to oils, the other to sculpture, watercolors, pastels, drawings and prints. The second biennial, which opened with a preview yesterday afternoon, has been divided, this year, into two parts, the present group being confined to sculpture, drawings and prints.

The possibility that Freddie Lindstrom, one-time star infielder-outfielder of the Giants who was unconditionally released by the Cubs last Friday, might come back to New York this year, but in a Yankee uniform, loomed yesterday. Ed Barrow, business manager of the local American League club, admitted such a move might come up for consideration.
An ankle injury has forced John H. Doeg, former national tennis champion, out of the Union League squash racquets invitation tournament for Class B players.
Abandonment of the WPA music project in this city was threatened yesterday by Federal officials in reply to another threat of a strike against the project by the American Federation of Musicians.

An action for triple damages amounting to $54,000,000 was begun in the United States District Court here yesterday by the Mills Novelty Company, manufacturers of ice cream freezers, slot machines and other devices, alleging unfair trade practices against forty-two defendants, including leading ice cream companies.

The Inland Steel Company has undertaken a construction program calling for installation of four new open-hearth steel furnaces, it was announced yesterday. This is the first work to be undertaken in more than three years by any company in the steel industry on new plants for producing steel ingots.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- A split in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that put three veteran members together in favor of outright "freedom of the seas" in opposition to Secretary Hull today grew out of renewed discussion of the administration Neutrality Bill.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Following the refusal of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System to accept for presentation over their circuits a series of political skits prepared by the Republican National Committee, Western Republican leaders announced tonight that they had arranged with WGN, a unit of the Mutual Broadcasting Company, to send out the first of the proposed programs tomorrow night at 9 o'clock, Eastern standard time.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Jan. 13. --The four months' strike at the Consumers Research plant in Washington, N.J., ended today. An official statement issued by the Technical, Editorial and Office Assistants Union, No. 20055, of which the striking employes were members, outlined the reasons for discontinuing the strike and the further activities they would follow.

Two unanimous decisions bearing on the Administration's farm program were handed down yesterday by the Supreme Court. The background of one of them is to be found in the long legal battle over AAA. The other is the court's first word on the Bankhead act, under which the Government has exercised compulsory control over the marketing of cotton.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale ices in New York:

Manhattan's basketball team, undefeated but more or less unsung in its early-season campaign, last night definitely indicated its quality as a contender for metropolitan court honors by overwhelming the Niagara University quintet, which had dropped St. John's from the ranks of the unbeaten.

Comparatively few persons knew the name SAMUEL LIONEL ROTHAFEL. As ROXY, who in the United States didn't know of him? He spread the name upon the air. The palace-cathedral-theatres where his genius expressed itself proclaimed and echoed it. The master showman, the artist in grandiose and "gorgeous" effects, must have had to smile sometimes for pride in fame.

Failure of the United States Supreme Court to announce yesterday a decision with respect to the Tennessee Valley Authority and that tribunal's dismissal of the first test case on the Bankhead Cotton Control Act, disappointed followers of the markets.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Scotland's lame duck parliamentary campaign moved another peg today when Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin gave his blessing to the candidature of Malcolm MacDonald as National Labor nominee in a bye-election to choose a member of the House of Commons for Ross and Cromarty.

An attractive brown-haired woman who had carefully stripped her meager belongings of every clue to her identity, and a 5-year-old child thought to be her daughter were found dead by gas asphyxiation at 8 o'clock yesterday morning when police broke into a furnished flat on the second floor of 346 Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Retention of the Bankhead Cotton Control Act on the statute books through dismissal of the Moor case brought speculation tonight on the effect on the 1936 cotton crop.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 13. -- Glory Greenock, a recent winner for Curtis King, today came right back to carry the black and white dotted silks of the Memphis sportsman to an easy victory in the Pensacola Purse as the final three days of a successful meeting at Tropical Park got under way.

A new nominating committee of seven members, which will prepare the slate of candidates for the annual election of the New York Stock Exchange, to be held in May, was elected yesterday. It was the first time, since the constitution of the Exchange was amended last year, that members of the Exchange had the opportunity to vote directly for candidates for the nominating committee.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Two young children, daughters of Hugh Grant Straus, son of the late Nathan Straus and an executive of Abraham Straus, were among four persons injured near here today when an automobile skidded on an icy road and crashed into a following car, in which the Straus children were riding.

Present-day colleges fail to provide spiritual and character development that will help students to face and adjust themselves to life with a healthy attitude, Dr. Henry W.A. Hanson, president of Gettysburg College, declared at the opening of the twenty-third annual meeting of the National Lutheran Educational Council at the Hotel Roosevelt.
PARIS, Jan. 13. -- Another parliamentary session begins in France tomorrow. Whether it will be calm or extremely stormy is unpredictable.
LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Noel Coward and Gertrude Lawrence achieved another joint triumph in Mr. Coward's second and equally varied bill of three short plays presented at the Phoenix Theatre tonight.

Will, Wallace and Inez Haynes Irwin all have books scheduled for publication -- by different publishers -- within two weeks of each other. Will Irwin's "Propaganda and the News" will be published by Whittlesey House on Jan. 27 and Mrs. Irwin's detective story, "The Poison Cross Mystery," will come from Smith Haas that same day.
In the Jan. 5 issue of THE TIMES Senator Copeland urged a ship subsidy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Irving Wexler, beer racketeer, also known as "Waxey Gordon," must serve his ten-year sentence for evading income taxes, the Supreme Court ruled today through denial of his petition for review.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- After two minutes of discussion, Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick denied today a petition for a temporary order enjoining President Roosevelt and others from ending the Agricultural Adjustment Administration because of the Supreme Court's decision of last week.

Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, head coach of New York University's football team for the past two seasons, has been reappointed and given a five-year contract, it was announced yesterday by Professor Philip O. Badger, chairman of the board of athletic control.

Operators of pin ball game amusement centers went to court yesterday in an effort to prevent the city from putting their "playland" and "sportsland" centers out of business by suspending their licenses. The operators obtained from Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon an order bringing the question into court, but were unsuccessful in their application for an immediate injunction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Dominion of Canada filed an amendment today to its registration, under the Securities Act of 1933, covering the $48,000,000 issue of twenty-five-year 3 1/4 per cent bonds due on Jan. 15, 1961, fixing the offering date as tomorrow.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PARIS, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Defense of France's African colony of Tunisia in the event of possible Italian attack was reported discussed by Marcel Peyrouton, Governor General of Colonies, in a call today on Navy Minister Francois Pietri.

TIENTSIN, Jan. 13. -- The second Russo-Japanese war will begin with a Russian offensive at the completion of the second Soviet five-year plan, General Hayao Tada, commander of the Japanese garrison in North China, predicted today.

ATHENS, Jan. 13. -- Thirty Greek officers, including the general staff and the leading technicians of the navy, attended manoeuvres today of seven British destroyers in Greek waters. The five-hour demonstration included high-speed steaming, drills in anti-aircraft work, torpedo and submarine defense and a mimic battle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The text of the Supreme Court's unanimous decisions in two cases today were:

Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler was convicted Dec. 1, 1933. As United States Attorney, Thomas E. Dewey, who is now special rackets prosecutor, conducted the prosecution. Gordon was arrested May 21 by Federal agents and State troopers while hiding in a rented hunting lodge at White Lake, in the Catskills.

Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, made a tour of inspection through Queens yesterday morning to point out slums or potential slum areas on which the borough office of his department was directed to concentrate slum clearance activities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Revelation that the two chief broadcasting chains had barred Republican political dramatizations came today when Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, made public letters he had written to the heads of the chains.
The orchestra and chorus of theI Federal Music School at the JacobI H. Schiff Center in the Bronx will1 present a program this evening at/ the center.

It is a long time since William C. de Mille, playwright and film director, has been represented on the Broadway stage, and what brings him back now is "Hallowe'en," a play by Henry Myers. Mr. de Mille will produce and stage it, with Mary Hone in the leading role.

TOKYO, Jan. 13. -- Although "no rupture, no concession," is a succint description of the Japanese Government's instruction to Admiral Osamu Nagano in London, some qualified foreign observers see signs of an important modification of Japan's attitude toward the naval problem.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 13. -- Three jurors were chosen today at the opening of the trial of Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, 30 years old, and Everett R. Applegate, 36, both of Baldwin, who are charged jointly with murder in the first degree in connection with the death by poison of Applegate's wife, Ada, last Sept. 27.
BERLIN, Jan. 13. --M Ernst Popper, Czechoslovak citizen of Jewish antecedents and Berlin correspondent of the Prager Tageblatt, was expelled from Germany today.

NEWARK, N.J., Tuesday, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Howard Hughes, Hollywood film director, landed at Newark Airport at 12:42:10 A.M. today, completing non-stop flight from Los Angeles in 9 hours 27 minutes 10 seconds. Airport officials said this was a new transcontinental record.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 (AP). -- District Attorney Matthew Brady announced today that his office would not initiate criminal proceedings against the persons responsible for the sterilization operation performed on Miss Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21-year-old heiress.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Senator John J. McNaboe, Tammany Democrat, introduced a concurrent resolution tonight calling for a legislative investigation of activities of Communists in the schools and colleges of the State.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The assertion that not more than 15 per cent of the AAA was destroyed by the Supreme Court was made here today by Dr. E.G. Nourse of the Brookings Institution of Washington, in addressing the Rutgers Institute of Rural Economics.

Proposed construction of a nine-story building on a leasehold in Hudson Street for the General Dyestuff Corporation, now at 230 Fifth Avenue, was announced yesterday. The site, assessed at $697,000, takes in the blockfront on the west side of the street between Leroy and Morton Streets.

Opening a limited number of trout streams for a thirty-day period last Fall was a worth-while innovation, in the opinion of the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game, which has just released some interesting statistics relating to the Autumn fishing.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- A man charged with drunken driving cannot obtain a fair jury trial in Peekskill, and when a Peekskill jury recently acquitted a man charged with this offense, the jurors were held up to public ridicule, James Dempsey Jr., former Peekskill Mayor, told Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close here today.

Lester Patrick, in an effort to stem the string of reverses recently suffered by the New York Rangers, yesterday announced the breaking up of the veteran forward line of Bill Cook, Frank Boucher and Bun Cook.
When an aviator is lost in the Bay of Bengal, the Antarctic regions or elsewhere everything possible is done regardless of expense for his rescue. That is civilization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Bonds issued to World War veterans under the Bonus Bill introduced to day by Senator Harrison would represent a charge against the public debt, which was $30,557,000,000 Dec. 31.

Chin Clair Sun Star, owned by the Chin Clair Kennels of Mrs. William C. Smith of Stratford, Conn., last night won best in show at the thirty-seventh specialty exhibition of the Pekingese Club of America, held in the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Jan. 13. -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, speaking here today at the State convention of Young Republican Clubs, assailed the policies of his kinsman, President Roosevelt, on the ground that they tended to lower the American standard of living.

Formal offering will be made today of a new issue of $5,696,000 State of South Dakota rural credit refunding bonds by a banking group headed by Lehman Brothers. The placement will consist of $3,500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due from 1943 to 1946, at prices to yield from 3 to 3.15 per cent, and $Z2,196,000 of 3 per cent bonds, due 1947, and priced at 99.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee, who voted to sustain President Roosevelt's veto last session of the inflationary Patman Soldiers' Bonus Bill, said today that the measure he introduced in the Senate had the support of the Democratic leader, Senator Robinson, who also has voted in the past to support the President's stand.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Heavy receipts of hogs here today, the third largest for a Monday since last February, failed to have a depressing effect and, while prices were about in line with those of Friday, sales showed 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight advance compared with Saturday's levels.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- By employing a new geodetic or "spider web" construction of wings for monoplanes a noted British aircraft construction company claims to be able to supply the Royal Air Force with a bombing plane that can fly 8,000 miles, not allowing for wind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- A new Bonus Bill, providing for payment of adjusted compensation certificates with an issue of non-transferable baby bonds in denominations of $50 and $100, but which could be cashed by World War veterans at any postoffice, was introduced in the Senate today by Senators Harrison, Byrnes, Steiwer and Clark.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 14. -- Rudyard Kipling, who was taken suddenly ill at a London hotel yesterday morning, was in a grave condition in Middlesex Hospital, London, early today after an urgent operation.
I recommend no new tax. I recommend no increase in any existing tax. I ask merely the continuance of existing emergency taxes for another year. -- Governor LEHMAN'S Budget Message.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Evidence that President Wilson was distrustful of the sincerity of Count von Bernstorff, German Ambassador to the United States during the early days of the World War, slipped into the record of the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry today before members of the committee realized its significance diplomatically and made a futile effort to recall it.

A total of $185,500,000 was spent in this city for home relief during the year just past, according to a report made public yesterday by Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

Kirsten Flagstad sang the role of Elsa in the season's third "Lohengrin" at the Metropolitan Opera House as the fifth week began last night. The company is indeed fortunate that it can alter casts with each performance of an opera, retaining always a high individual and ensemble level.

IT was the confession of Ching Johnson, the Bald Eagle of the ice, that once he was cracked so hard over the sconce with a hockey shillelah that smoke got in his eyes. But Ching the Chinaman still goes skating along in the hockey riots with no cover for his denuded dome. He refuses to be bothered by a helmet.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- Hearings before Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick were interrupted today by the Supreme Court's decision in the Louisiana rice milling case, and a group of 120 concerns, which had deposited more than $2,000,000 of processing tax money with ten local banks pending outcome of the AAA case, petitioned for return of this money.

Your editorial "After AAA" fails to take cognizance of a very important phase of the Agricultural Adjustment Act -- marketing agreements entered into voluntarily and executed without benefit of bounty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Jan. 8 shows a decrease for the week of $61,000,000 in total loans and investments, an increase of $110,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, a decrease of $240,000,000 in demand deposits, adjusted, and an increase of $194,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- The United States Supreme Court's decision today in the rice-milling case, which released impounded processing taxes, caused a brief flurry in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here, but at no time was the May delivery above Saturday's finish and all minor upturns brought in liquidation by tired longs.

Some six or eight responsible business groups are prepared to organize within thirty days to launch a program providing for the construction of 8,000,000 new low-cost houses, as proposed by the Committee for Economic Recovery, it was announced yesterday by Allie S. Freed, president of Paramount Motors Corporation, who heads the committee sponsoring the plan.

Preceding the opening of the annual conference of the educational associations of the three American Methodist churches, a group of executives and delegates met yesterday afternoon in the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street, to draw up plans for the unification of the churches -- the Methodist Protestant Church, the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, and the Methodist Episcopal Church.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- Germany celebrated today the first anniversary of the Saar plebiscite which astounded the world with a sweeping victory for the Reich. By government order, the entire country was bedecked with swastika flags.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 13 (AP). -- Charges of assault and battery by means of dangerous weapons against Cornelius Van Schaak Roosevelt, 20, grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt, and Peter de Florez, 21, a classmate, were nol prossed today by District Attorney Warren L. Bishop.

Despite the city's exceptionally low accident rate in 1935, as compared with that of 1934, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine exhorted his men and the public to further efforts yesterday when he released a favorable tabulated report covering last week and the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Testimony about orders that might have stabilized the market in Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock was recorded in the Securities Commission hearing today into alleged manipulations by Michael J. Meehan.

TRENTON, Jan. 13. -- The defense attorneys for Bruno Richard Hauptmann had a secret conference today on their plans, which resulted in a cryptic statement by C. Lloyd Fisher that the next "logical place to go would seem to be a court room."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Despite statements of seven physicians, two of whom were appointed by the government, that John Cooke Grayson, indicted former chief clerk in the office of the National Bank Examiner, is physically and mentally incapable of standing trial on charges of conspiring to defraud the government, Justice Daniel W. O'Donoghue of the District of Columbia Supreme Court forfeited his bond today and ordered his arrest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The filing of four additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 covering issues aggregating $9,738,596.90, and of prospectuses for small issues exempt from registration under the act, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- A foretaste of the fight which may develop in Congress over the administration-sponsored substitute for the invalidated AAA came today when influential farm organizations decided to press for remedies which the administration would not sanction and on some of which the farm leaders themselves are in disagreement.

Mrs. M. Rice Varlet gave a luncheon yesterday in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis. Her guests were Mrs. Gilbert S.B. Darlington, Mrs. Euclid Covington, Mrs. Herman S. Murray, Mrs. William L. Rich, Mrs. Addison Van Tine, Mrs. Alfred H. Ehrenclou, Mrs. William E. Chambers, Mrs. Hans C. Stricker, Mrs. Harold Banks, Mrs. Spencer Waters and the Misses Harriet Shelden, Alice W. Lawrence and Janet Coleman.

Speeding up its attack after holding only a 5-4 lead at the end of the first quarter, the strong McBurney School quintet conquered Collegiate School, 41 to 17, in the McBurney gymnasium yesterday. The victory was the fourth in as many starts this season for the winners.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 14. -- Physicians attending Rudyard Kipling reported early today that his condition was "still very grave."

A shift in the attitude of the Japanese delegates at the London Naval Conference reveals what is now a fixed element in international psychology. For a few days they threatened to bolt the conference because their demand for naval parity had been rejected. But before they could shake off the dust of London from their feet orders came from Tokyo that they were not to leave incontinently.
Collections for last year from the 2 per cent city sales tax were estimated at more than $42,000,000 last night by Controller Frank J. Taylor.

Earnings of the Brooklyn Trust Company for 1935 amounted to $879,141, compared with $974,101 the year before, George V. McLaughlin, president, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. These earnings were after providing reserves of about $181,000 for depreciation of bank building and other real estate.

ASTORIA, Ore., Jan. 13 (AP). -- While air and sea craft scanned the wind-whipped waters for bodies, emergency aid was ordered tonight for the families of the 34-man crew of the freighter Iowa, lost when seas battered the craft ashore.

Continuance of activity on Lexington Avenue and an operator's deal in Brooklyn were included in the urban realty trading reported yesterday. Various properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 13 (AP). -- Federal Judge John P. Nields today set Feb. 17 for argument on the suits of seven utility companies seeking injunctions to restrain the Securities and Exchange Commission from carrying out the holding-company provisions of the Public Utility Act.

MONTREAL, Jan. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Dave (Sweeney) Schriner, New York American left-winger, has advanced to a tie with Charlie Conacher of the Toronto Maple Leafs for scoring honors in the National Hockey League, according to official statistics announced tonight.

A member of the additional January grand jury, who had devoted the morning to passing judgment on the crimes of his fellow-citizens, was himself placed under arrest yesterday afternoon charged with grand larceny.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- That a German conductor who earns his bread and butter in the Third Reich must watch his step regarding Mendelssohn, came home rather disconcertingly to Wilhelm Furtwaengler when he conducted a concert of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra in Budapest last week.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 13. -- Measuring the "spin" of light, the twisting force of which its rays exert on anything solid, a scientific feat never done before, was announced today in a report to the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Richard A. Beth of the Worcester Polytechnic Institute.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- A budget calling for an aggregate of $308,667,248 for the fiscal year beginning July 1 was presented to the Legislature today by Governor Lehman. This is an increase of $10,203,568 over the present year's budget.

I think the President did well to eulogize Andrew Jackson. I hope that the electorate will take up the President's recommendation, that every one who expects to take part in the next election will constitute himself a committee of one to obtain the facts and get at the truth of the life and policies of Andrew Jackson.

Count de Castellane is among the passengers due today from England and Ireland on the Cunard White Star liner Laconia. Others aboard are Antonio Lardizabal, Consul General for Honduras, and Mrs. Lardizahal, Carlos Arrarte, Ecuadorian Consul at Liverpool; Mrs. Enid Shaw, Alec Miller, Mr. and Mrs. J. Randall Dunn, T.E. Cottier, W.H. Davies. R.D.R. Sinclair, A.E. Penfold, Miss Katherine Shepard and Miss F. W. Woodward.

" CAN We Be Neutral?" by Allen W. Dulles and Hamilton Fish Armstrong (Harpers, $1.50), is, within its limits, the most sensible word that has been spoken to date on a perplexing and ominous question. The answer which the Messrs. Dulles and Armstrong return is tentative and conditional; they are not at all certain that there can be peace for any great nation should two or more of the important powers go to war.

The Presbytery of New York voted at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, to refuse to obey a command of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, of which it is a lower court.

Commodity futures were generally mixed in moderate trading yesterday, but sugar futures forged ahead in an active market and coffee contracts were strong. In the cash markets prices of all the grains, lard, pork and beef eased, while tin, silk and rubber advanced.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- A strong possibility that the sanctions ring around Italy will be drawn tighter was indicated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- J.P. Morgan's speech to bond dealers on the eve of flotation of the $500,000,000 Anglo-French loan of 1915, introduced before the Senate Munitions Committee today, was as follows:

WARSAW, Jan. 13. -- Death sentences were passed today in the Warsaw District Court on three of the twelve Ukrainian terrorists who were tried for participation in the assassination of Interior Minister Bronislaw Pieracki in June, 1934. Under the recent general amnesty the sentences were commuted to life imprisonment.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 13. -- Dartmouth tonight defeated Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball game, 27 to 23. The Hanoverians took the lead after the first eight minutes of play and at the end of the half were ahead, 19 to 14.

Staving off a great closing rally by his opponent, Ralph (Indian) Hurtado, fast-stepping lightweight from Panama, remained in the unbeaten ranks as he captured a ten-round decision over Al Roth of the Bronx at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Buyers' arrivals were heavy in the market here yesterday, indicating that the week will be among the most active of the early Spring season. The arrivals included a number of store representatives who were scheduled to be here last week but deferred their visit owing to the AAA decision.

In throwing out yesterday the suit filed against the Bankhead Act without passing on the merits of the law, the United States Supreme Court prolonged the existing taxes on all cotton produced in excess of the quota. Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered 30 points.

More than eighty varieties of hardy, seedless grapes, suitable for culture in the Eastern part of the United States, have been developed by Dr. A.B. Stout, director of the laboratories of the New York Botanical Garden, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York Botanical Garden.

A total of $178,632 has been raised by the joint campaign committee of the Y.W.C.A. and the Y.M.C.A. toward $600,000 sought for the 1936 current expense funds of the organizations, it was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the committee, at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

A plan by which accumulations amounting to $6,564,162 on the preferred stocks of the Pure Oil Company will be disposed of, is being offered holders, according to Henry M. Dawes, president. The proposal involves the exchange of the present preferred stocks, of which three classes are outstanding, for shares of a new 6 per cent preferred stock.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The Judicial Council, headed by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals, came to the support of several major items in Governor Lehman's anti-crime program in his annual report submitted to the Legislature tonight.

Opening Spring and Summer lines of draperies, curtains and drapery hardware at prices substantially unchanged from the preceding season, more than 100 manufacturers were represented yesterday at the ninth semi-annual Curtain and Drapery Show being held this week at the Hotel New Yorker.

A revolution in school architecture, with "fads and frills" giving way to severe simplicity of design, was proposed yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, Fusion member of the Board of Education and chairman of its sub-committee on overcrowding.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Governor Lehman's budget message to the Legiture covering the fiscal year beginning next July 1 was as follows:

The lecture by Dr. TILDSLEY in the notable Inglis series deserves wide public attention. His experience in the public school service as teacher, principal, assistant superintendent, gives him not only the right but the obligation to speak. No one does it with greater authority on the American secondary school and no one is more outspoken than he in touching upon its shortcomings as well as in reciting its achievements.
ATCHISON, Kan., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Chaloner B. Schley, 24 years old, of Baltimore, died early today of injuries received when his 18-year-old wife was killed Saturday in a car-train collision here.

A Shakespearean Theatre modeled after that of Stratford-on-Avon and supported by members of the many Shakespearean societies in this country is being planned for New York, according to Miss Mona Morgan of Philadelphia, founder of the Shakespearean League of America.

Donald A. Hobart, National Commander of the American Veterans Association, which is opposed to prepayment of the soldiers' bonus, announced last night receipt of a telegram from Senator Pat Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, denying the request of the association for a public hearing on the bonus question.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 13. -- Speaking at this afternoon's session of the Pan-American Labor Conference in support of the United States Government's proposal to establish a 16-year-old minimum for child labor, Miss Frieda Miller of the United States delegation said a suggestion that such a step would help relieve unemployment was not the basic ground for urging it.

Attacking representatives of banking and "big business" as "unprincipled brigands," Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, put forth last night what is likely to be the Democratic slogan in the coming Presidential campaign -- "Keep Roosevelt in, and keep the gang out."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 13. -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks today simplified and hastened the reorganization plans of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad by ordering the payment of interest on underlying bonds of the railroad aggregating $23,000,000 and on notes held by the Railroad Credit Corporation and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation amounting to $32,000,000.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The franc was stronger here today with respect to the dollar and weaker with respect to sterling. Despite denials of further devaluation of the United States currency, importance seems still to be attached here to the re ports circulated last week.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The franc was stronger here today with respect to the dollar and weaker with respect to sterling. Despite denials of further devaluation of the United States currency, importance seems still to be attached here to the re ports circulated last week.
Three men arrested on Sullivan law charges in the investigation of the slaying of Samuel Drukman were released yesterday on writs of habeas corpus by Supreme Court Justice Smith in Brooklyn.

THEODORE A. METZ'S "A Hot Time in the Old Town Tonight" may have been the hit of the Spanish-American War for the brass bands and the soldiers at the front. But for the civilians at home the song of the war years was in softer and sadder key.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- As the convention of the International Seamen's Union of America was opened here today by Andrew Furuseth, president, drastic action was indicated against Pacific Coast union officials aligned with Harry Bridges, the radical longshoremen's leader.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- In an atmosphere again tense with expectancy the Supreme Court today, by a unanimous decision, ordered $200,000,000 of impounded AAA taxes returned to processors, and left in doubt the status of $1,000,000,000 other farm taxes already levied on processors.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 13. -- The Public Utilities Holding Act was denounced as "vicious" today by John W. Davis in a vigorous assault on its constitutionality in argument in the American States Public Service Company case before the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, with Senior Judge John J. Parker, Judges Elliott Northcott and Morris A. Soper on the bench.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 13. -- Conversion of Provincial debts, at lower interest rates backed by a Dominion guarantee, and a system of separate Provincial loan councils to control the future debt and loan policies of the Canadian Provinces was proposed today to Provincial Finance Ministers at a conference here by the Dominion's Minister of Finance, Charles Dunning.

Contrary to plans previously announced by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator, assurance that no reduction in the number of WPA employes now at work in this city would be undertaken, was received yesterday from Washington.

The players of the New Jersey women's secondary league squash racquets team scored a 4-3 victory over the New York squad yesterday afternoon on the Cosmopolitan Club court to win the Class B intersectional title. New York had previously defeated Westchester, 6 -- 1, in a morning encounter.

ROME, Jan. 13. -- It is unfortunate for Marshal Pietro Badoglio that he should be obliged to interrupt his preparations just now when the Italian people are beginning to show increasing signs of impatience at the long inactivity of his troops in East Africa and when a resumption of the Italian advance is eagerly looked forward to.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- President Roosevelt spent a quiet day attending to routine matters.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Forces of nature have combined in throwing up an effective bulwark against an advance of Italy's southern army, an impartial European observer said today.

A Russian New Year's Eve celebration was held last night in the Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Russian Children's Welfare Society. The customs of Russian people dating back to the time of Peter the Great were followed in the celebration, and at midnight Russian marches and Christmas and New Year carols were played.

The Columbia University Club strengthened its lead in the Class C section of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League yesterday by defeating the City A.C., 4 to 1. The setback sent City from second place and a chance for a tie to a deadlock for fourth with the New York A.C.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals refused yesterday to allow the extradition of Bertrand Cole Neidecker and his brothers, George W. and Aubrey, for trial in Paris for alleged embezzlement of funds of the Travelers Bank of Paris and Neidecker et Cie., on the ground that for 150 years France has refused extradition to this country of any of her citizens.

Today is national bank meeting day, the most important of the bank-meeting season, with all national hanks having their annual assemblages of stockholders. In addition, annual sessions are scheduled here for the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, the Empire Trust Company and the Fifth Avenue Bank.

About ten years ago Clemence Dane's "Granite" was produced in a reformed beer garden on the East Side. Encouraged by a respectful notice or two it presently moved down to the Mayfair Theatre, which was a reformed restaurant in Forty-fourth Street.

Carl Snyder, statistician of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, told the American Farm Association that "high profits, concentrated ownership and industry reinvesting in industry" are responsible for America's growth.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 (AP). -Sound Advice, after trailing at the start, finished fast today to win the Coronado Handicap at Santa Anita. The time for the seven furlongs was 1:23 1-5.

Still somewhat deafened from the roar of his powerful engine, Howard Hughes, oil man and motion picture producer, was more interested yesterday in the implications for air transport of the coast-to-coast record of 9 hours 27 minutes 10 seconds which he had just set than in the record itself.

According to The Economist, joyously sniffing its Christmas dinner, there was a real renascence "of English culture in 1935." A great revival, at least the foundation of one, is being built up in the drama, literature, music, all sciences, all arts, even "the cult of the open air."

Insuranshares Certificates, Inc. reported yesterday that the asset value of its stock on Dec. 31 was $7.95 a share, compared with $5.44 at the close of 1934, a gain of 46.13 per cent. Investments held are all in fire, life and casualty insurance companies, and were valued at bid prices at the year-end.

At the end of the opening day of play in the second annual women's metropolitan secondary squash racquets championship at the Colony Club the field of fifty players had been brought down to fifteen last night under the able direction of Mrs. A.W. Paine.

Jascha Heifetz gave his second Carnegie Hall recital of the season last night for the benefit of the educational department of the New York Women's Trade Union League. A capacity audience was on hand and greeted the violinist with unmitigated enthusiasm.

A gas explosion in the cellar of 441 East Sixteenth Street, that shook a six-story tenement housing thirty-six families, caused the death yesterday of a butcher. Five other persons were shocked, including an infant and a 12-year-old girl who was ill.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Assertions that Congress may be unable to escape consideration of additional tax legislation at this session produced a widening rift of opinion upon this point.

When the history of these shifting years is written, at least a footnote's worth of space will be accorded to the picketing of City Hall by members of the staff of the Emergency Relief Bureau in protest against the dismissal of some of their fellow-employes. The idea apparently is that these workers have some sort of a vested interest in their jobs even after the work for which they have been recruited has been completed.

The floating supply of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation, as indicated by holdings in brokers' names, was 1,876,618 shares, or 21.56 per cent of the total outstanding on Dec. 31, an increase of 101,122 shares compared with Sept. 30 last, when brokers held 1,775,496 shares, or 20.4 per cent of the total. On Dec. 31, 1934, brokers held 1,691,456 shares, or 19.44 per cent of the total.

In a few days they will be celebrating the 200th birthday of the man who is responsible for most of the world's present troubles. He is JAMES WATT, who may be said to have made the steam engine what it is today.

Using a machine gun and carrying out their plans with the thor oughness of a large bank robbery, six men held up a small wholesale candy and cigar company in the basement of an East Side tenement at about 6 o'clock last night and escaped with less than $500 in cash.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- A Supreme Court test of the constitutionality of the Securities Act of 1933, a New Deal law, seemed certain when the government agreed today to a review demanded by J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties.

BUFFALO, Jan. 14. -- Two new vice presidents were elected and seven executives were promoted at the annual meeting of the Marine Trust Company, a Marine-Midland affiliate, here today. The two new vice presidents will be in charge of the Bank of Batavia and the Bank of East Aurora, Marine-Midland banks which have become branches of the Marine Trust Company.

The Musical Art Quartet, playing last night in Town Hall, made a refreshing departure from convention in the arrangement of the program. It began with the quartet, still unfamiliar, of Jean Sibelius, "Voces intimae," and offered the first performance of the amusing "Mosaic quartet" by the American, Henry Cowell.
The explanation of the difference between the majority and minority opinions of the Supreme Court and the AAA is clearly revealed by the methods of their respective approaches to the issue.

Merchant ships under construction in the yards of the world at the start of the year totaled 1,543,153 tons, according to the quarterly report issued yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping. This represents a gain of 345,184 tons over the aggregate reported the previous quarter.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- Edward T. Davis, 60 years old, only brother of Lee Parsons Davis, former Westchester District Attorney, died at White Plains Hospital at 5:03 this afternoon a few minutes after stabbing himself while in Olie's Bar and Grill, 30 Grand Street, here.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- Several changes in administrative personnel were made today at annual meetings of stockholders and directors of banks in Glens Falls and vicinity.

In your editorial of Jan. 11, "'P.R.' in Cincinnati," you outline as if damaging to the case for proportioned representation the present situation in Cincinnati in which the Council is split 4 -- 4 -- 1 and in which the lone independent was able to secure the acceptance of his terms by the City Charter Committee group in return for his vote to re-elect Mayor Russell Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The Pacific Lighting Corporation of California and its subsidiaries were granted exemption today by the Securities and Exchange Commission from all provisions of Title I of the Public Utility Act of 1935, otherwise applicable to the parent corporation as a holding company and to its subsidiary companies as subsidiaries of such holding company.

Phil Siriani defeated Jimmy Hughes in the six-round main bout last night at the New York Coliseum. The Bronx battlers, each of whom weighed 128, threw plenty of blows at each other but Siriani was more accurate and he began building up an advantage in the second session.

Thanks to a goal by Aurel Joliat of the Canadiens the New York Americans find themselves in last place in the international division of the National Hockey League. Joliet's tally was the only one registered in the game between the rivals at Madison Square Garden last night as the flying Frenchmen turned back the recently revamped spangled sextet before a crowd of 8,000 fans.

Charles S. Lefcourt, brother of the late Abraham E. Lefcourt, builder, left an estate of $119,889 gross and $106,969 net when he died on March 4, 1935, it was shown in the transfer tax appraisal yesterday. The estate goes to the widow, Mrs. Rae Lefcourt of 16 West Seventy-seventh Street, except for a $25,000 trust fund for the son, Charles Ray Lefcourt.

The campaign for funds to wipe out a deficit of $2,636,000 of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies has been successful, Samuel D. Leidesdorf, president, announced last night. Thus the federation's budget of $4,050,000 for the maintenance of ninety-one affiliated welfare societies has been balanced.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton, University of Chicago physicist, announced tonight the starting of a world-wide scientific effort to penetrate the mystery of the cosmic ray.

The task of a college president as an educator is "largely that of educating his trustees," Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York area of the Methodist Episcopal Church said yesterday morning. He spoke before representatives of colleges and universities from twenty States at the forty-first annual meeting of the Educational Association of the Methodist Episcopal Church at the Hotel Prince George, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.
TRENTON, Jan. 14. -- The text of Judge J. Warren Davis's decision on the Hauptmann petition for a writ of habeas corpus follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes of the Interior Department awarded today a contract for the sale of government "royalty" oil from the Salt Creek Field in Wyoming, adjoining the Teapot Dome preserve, one of the largest in the Rocky Mountain area, to the Sinclair Wyoming Oil Company, controlled by Harry F. Sinclair, and the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill passed last night changing the date of the Spring primary from April 7 to April 2. Under the original law the date of the primary would have fallen on the Jewish Passover. The measure was sponsored by Assemblyman Streit, New York Democrat.

Reflecting the recent rise in crude oil prices east of the Rocky Mountains, the leading gasoline-marketing companies announced yesterday generally higher prices for gasoline and refined products along the Atlantic Coast. The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of Ohio were included in the list.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 14. -Duke's basketball team won its twelfth straight game of the season tonight, staging a powerful last-half drive to down the Princeton five, 40 -- 26.

Miss Maud Allan protested to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that she had been misdated in a story printed on Monday morning. The time was erroneously set as "the late Nineties" when she danced before the crowned heads of Europe.

Two complete, prefabricated hotels of forty-five rooms each were among the 6,000-ton cargo of the Pan American chartered supply ship North Haven, it was disclosed yesterday, when she sailed from San Francisco on Monday night for the island bases of the airline across the Pacific Ocean.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- In voting a favorable report today on Chairman Harrison's "solution" of the bonus, the Senate Finance Committee went the way of all politicians in a re-election year. The committee members are trustees of the public debt and budget, and Secretary Morgenthau gave them a sufficient picture of what the bonus would do to these to have startled a group of trustees in business.

BERLIN, Jan. 14. -- The National Synod, highest authority of the original opposition movement against the National Socialist dominance over the German Protestant Church, has been called to meet early in February to decide the fate of that movement.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 14 (AP). -- One thousand smell-less cabbages are under guard at Cornell University, each of them a descendant of a cabbage with no odor discovered at Cornell a few months ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Behind closed doors today government attorneys planned moves to combat an expected flood of suits to recover $1,000,000,000 paid by processors under the AAA.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- An agreement on reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway, despite the fight among various factions of security holders, virtually has been completed, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- The fiscal "follies" of the New Deal, as interpreted by the Republican National Committee, were dramatized for popular consumption tonight in the first of a series of anti-administration skits broadcast from Radio Station WGN.

The extent to which oil and some of the packing stocks are dominating the market at present is shown by the activity of these groups. Of the twelve most active issues on the Stock Exchange yesterday, two were packing issues and six were oil issues.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 14 (AP). -- Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota was announced today the winner of the Cardinal Newman award for 1935 for his "courage and insight" in exposing "the hidden factors which make for war."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Alex Yokel, who offered "Three Men on a Horse" to the Washington public about a year ago, came back tonight with "Julie the Great" by John Taintor Foote, based on a Saturday Evening Post short story by the same author.

MEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 14 (AP). -- Resignations of two heads of departments at Tufts College, who refused to comply with the Massachusetts Teachers' Oath Law, were accepted "with regret" by the Tufts board of trustees today.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Jan. 14. -- Because of the danger of avalanches in the Mount Zugspize area, where the American ski team has been practicing, the training will take place further down the mountain tomorrow. Two competitors for Olympic honors in the slalom and downhill events must be eliminated from the American team in tomorrow's trials.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Mrs. Thomas D. Schall, widow of the Senator from Minnesota, announced today she would be a candidate for the seat left vacant by her husband's death.

Two one-story business buildings on a plot 100 by 98 feet at 229-01 to 229-13 Merrick Road, northeast corner of 229th Street, Laurelton, Queens, have been sold for the Roclave Realty Corporation by Byrne Bowman to an investing client of Eppstein Hirshfield.

A social planning commission to chart the course of the city's public and private agencies in a coordinated, long-range program to stamp out juvenile delinquency was projected yesterday at a luncheon of the Civitan Club in the clubrooms of the Building Trades Employers Association.

The possibility of consolidating the musical departments of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New York Public Library is being considered by officials of both institutions, it was learned yesterday.
[ The State Athletic Commission will open an investigation Friday i into charges that one of its officials iis associated with gamblers at local boxing clubs.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 14. -- The Swedish Government today protested to Italy through its Minister in Rome against the bombing of a Swedish ambulance unit at Noghelli, Ethiopia.
Business and housing properties were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- A government attempt to obtain a rehearing from the United States Supreme Court of the rice millers' processing tax case which the court yesterday decided against the government, was forecast in the Federal court here tonight.

The Jackson Heights Squash Club turned in the most convincing victory last night in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association, beating Block Hall on the Jackson Heights courts, 5 -- 0, with three matches decided in straight games.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Formation of the new Air Transport Association of America, which includes in its membership every scheduled airline in the United States, was announced today by W.A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, in his capacity as chairman of the organization committee

With a preview yesterday afternoon the Museum of Modern Art opened three exhibitions that together fill all the available gallery space: Photographs, drawings and plans illustrating the achievements of H.H. Richardson, American architect, the fiftieth anniversary of whose death is being commemorated this year; posters by Cassandre, and a miscellaneous selection of pictures in various mediums from the collection of contemporary art recently presented to the museum by Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr.
The national champion, Harry F. Wolf, made a noteworthy entry into the ranks of competitors in the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tourney at the Yale Club yesterday.

Two winning streaks will be endangered tonight when the fifth college basketball double-header of the season is staged in Madison Square Garden. New York University will seek its nineteenth victory in a row against North Carolina, Southern Conference champion, in one game, while Manhattan will attempt to run its string to ten at the expense of St. John's.

The undefeated Long Island University quintet registered its fourteenth victory by defeating Niagara University, 48 -- 25, last night before an overflow crowd at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court.

With the formal casting of a single ballot, William A. Dalton was re-elected as president of the New York Athletic Club last night. Returned to office with him were Orie R. Kelly as vice president and M.F. Loughman as captain.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday to end at a gain of 12 to a loss of 3 points on the day.

National banks here and throughout the country yesterday held their annual meetings, in accordance with their charter provisions which, in almost all cases, specify the second Tuesday in January for such gatherings. In addition to the national banks several important State banks and trust companies held annual meetings.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 14. -- William G. Moore of Haddonfield, head of the Moore Securities Company, and Joseph Beck Tyler, a lawyer here, were elected directors of the Camden Safe Deposit and Trust Company today. All the other directors, except Dr. George M. Dorrance, who resigned, were re-elected.

John Drewen, former Prosecutor of Hudson County and a law partner of Representative Randolph Perkins, was one of two new directors elected yesterday by the Trust Company of New Jersey, in Jersey City. The other new director is Arthur L. Fagan, treasurer of the Jersey Publishing Company of Hoboken, publishers of The Jersey Observer.

Declaring that the electrical manufacturing industry has registered a 50 per cent increase in sales of electric ranges for each of the last two years, Reese Mills, manager of the range and water heater department of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, yesterday predicted that 1936 will bring another 50 per cent increase in sales and give the industry a unit volume of 350,000 ranges for the current year.
Various apartment and dwelling parcels in Brooklyn were reported sold yesterday. A large part of the turnover was made up of holdings by a savings bank.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 14. -- The war has returned to the air with two Italian reconnaissance flights, one over the Ethiopian northern headquarters at Dessye and the other over Ennis, sixty-five miles southwest of Harar. Both were carried out by single machines, which circled without dropping any bombs and returned toward Assab, Eritrea.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- The Senate today approved three major anti-crime measures sought by Governor Lehman and then, after a sharp debate, agreed that more consideration of other measures proposed by the Governor was necessary. As a result, a joint hearing on all crime bills has been set for Jan. 28.

A further program of developments and improvements in Manhattan, Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey, with particular concern as to the world's fair opening in 1939 at Flushing Meadows Park, was put forward yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of December: Total imports 74,480,000; exports of British products 34,910,000; re-exports 5,430,000; total exports 40,340,000; excess of imports 34,140,000.

The Squash Club and the Downtown Athletic Club increased their leads in Groups 1 and 2 in the Class B competition of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday when each achieved its fourth victory to remain undefeated since the season's start.
The America's Cup class sloop Yankee will not remain abroad for another season to race against the large British yachts, but will come home in the Spring.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Jan. 14. -- Unsuccessful in his search for Paul Redfern, American flier missing since 1927 on a flight from the United States to Rio de Janeiro, Art Williams left his base at Wanatoba Junction by plane today and headed for Georgetown.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Charges and denials that a Louisiana Legislature dominated by Senator Long sought to restrict the freedom of the press through a law imposing a 2 per cent tax upon the gross advertising revenues of thirteen newspapers in that State with circulations above 20,000 were heard by the Supreme Court today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- A substantial gain in cotton exports in December and for the last five months of 1935 was reported today by the Commerce Department.
Reports of annual meetings of banks, held yesterday here and in other places, at which important changes were made, follow:

The assertion of Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in a letter to William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, that he could not free himself of an impression that the attitude of CBS in rejecting dramatized political issues "is affected and perhaps voluntarily controlled by the political party in power" was answered by Mr. Paley yesterday.

About this time, as the Old Farmers Almanac would say, expect a few mystery plays. Rufus King, who has written mysteries in book form, and Milton Lazarus, who wrote Ernest Truex's recent skit, have turned out a routine job under the alluring caption of "I Want a Policeman!"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- President Roosevelt discussed at luncheon with Senator Robinson proposed legislation to remedy the agricultural situation created by the adverse decision of the Supreme Court on the AAA. At his press conference he announced plans for a new conference of Federal housing agencies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- President Roosevelt plans to call within two weeks a new conference on housing, at which heads of the government agencies concerned with this question will again take up the unsolved problem of modern homes for the low-income group.

Lexington Avenue started going nautical yesterday although today at 8 A. M. is the official hour when the marine industry formally takes possession of Grand Central Palace in preparation for the National Motor Boat Show which opens Friday night.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- King George and Queen Mary are becoming inveterate movie fans. In just over a fortnight they have seen nineteen pictures -- eleven British, seven American and one Viennese, besides numerous Walt Disney shorts -- in private at Sandringham.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 14. -- The first Pan-American Labor Conference adjourned at 7 o'clock this evening after holding two sessions today.

ALBANY, Jan 14. -- A sweeping investigation by a legislative committee of the conduct of boxing by the State Athletic Commission was demanded today by Assemblyman Robert R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican, in a resolution offered in the Lower House.
WARSAW, Jan. 14. -- Yesterday's heavy sentences in the Ukrainian terrorists case closed the first of a series of trials of members of the Ukrainian nationalist organization.

Representatives of motion picture companies and theatres and fellow-critics from other newspapers attended the funeral service yesterday for Andre David Sennwald Jr., motion picture critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at the Funeral Church, Broadway at Sixty - sixth Street.

An appeal to President Roosevelt to use his influence to defeat the veterans' bonus in the Senate or, if it passes Congress, to veto it, was made by the New York Board of Trade in a letter sent to the President on Monday.

GOODWIN, Ark., Jan. 14. -- In one of the worst disasters of its kind in the history of commercial aviation in this country, fourteen passengers and the pilot, co-pilot and stewardess were killed when a twin-motored American Airlines plane crashed into a swamp two and a half miles northeast of this village shortly after 8 o'clock tonight.

I wondered after I had read your editorial "Dr. Riddle on Life" if Professors Donnan, Stanley and Carr, Dr. Riddle and others as notable in this question, with opinions at variance, could ever discuss this profound topic with each other.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14. -- Tommy Goodwin, 22-year-old New York star, who won the tournament last year and yesterday carried off the qualifying medal, scored an easy victory in the first round of match play for the Lake Worth championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State and delegate to the London Naval Conference, has been authorized by Secretary of State Cordell Hull to delay his departure for the United States, scheduled for Thursday, if he considers it advisable in view of the critical status of the conference.

The new Soldiers' Bonus Bill introduced with the support of Senators who usually speak for the Administration, and approved yesterday by the Senate Finance Committee, is a complete surrender to the veterans' lobby. Only in one important respect does it differ from the plan already adopted by the House.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14. -- At their new home here Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Blair tonight gave a small dinner. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio, Mrs. Quentin F. Feitner, Mrs. Chalmers Wood and Paul Moore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Despite an opinion expressed today by Senator Norris that no law regulating agricultural production could be worked out within the limits of the Supreme Court decision outlawing the AAA, President Roosevelt expressed a hope at his press conference that Senator Norris had been overly pessimistic and said that a bill embodying a substitute program would be introduced in Congress.

Wednesday, Jan. 29, will bring the "Follies" to the Winter Garden or so runs the latest bulletin. To give the show and the house plenty of time to prepare for the event, the Winter Garden's current tenant, "At Home Abroad," will move next Monday to the Majestic.

Manager Joe McCarthy of the Yankees swept into New York yesterday, brushed some of the up-State snows from his hair and almost immediately set at rest a number of fears which seemed to have gained considerable headway recently in local baseball circles.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- The arrival of 32,000 hogs here today not only ran far ahead of trade estimates, but the receipts were the largest for a Tuesday since December, 1934. Prices dropped 20 to 30 cents a hundredweight at the start on the heavy receipts, but there was a keen demand for all classes and at the last sales showed 5 to 10 cents above the opening levels.

Conquering Textile, 36 to 34, in a keenly contested meet yesterday, the De Witt Clinton High School swimmers regained a tie with George Washington for the lead in the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond division of the Public Schools Athletic League championship tourney.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- The bicentenary of the birth of James Watt, Scottish engineer and inventor of the modern condensing steam engine, was commemorated today by a special exhibition at the Science Museum in South Kensington. Watt was born at Greenock on Jan. 19, 1736.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 14 (AP). -- The captain and other officers of the Chilean liner Cautin held their positions tonight aboard the 4,316-ton steamer, battered by heavy seas off the coast of Peru, after all the passengers and most of the crew had been removed safely.

GUANAJAY, Cuba, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Cuban Army agents, whose fingers are trigger-loose in dealing with kidnappers, shot dead three suspected abductors today and all but cleaned up the latest in a wave of kidnappings in the island republic.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn handed down yesterday a ten-page opinion informing S.W. Straus Co. bondholders of the progress of the company's receivership and advising them how to proceed to realize the best recovery on their holdings.

ABOARD THE S.S. WYATT EARP, in the Antarctic, Jan. 14. -- Nosing heavy lumps of ice aside the Wyatt Earp, supply ship of Lincoln Ellsworth's Antarctic flight expedition, is wriggling her way on a more or less direct course for the Bay of Whales, which lies about 500 miles south of our noon position.

Several large apartments in the Park Avenue section were among those reported leased by brokers yesterday. These included a twelve-room suite to Mrs. Catherine A. Hard at 521 Park Avenue, a large apartment at 535 Park Avenue to Mrs. Louise Shipman Hubbard and a furnished apartment at 480 Park Avenue to Jack Curley.
