The problems of financing the city's share of relief for the first six months of this year are materially eased, city fiscal officers said yesterday, by the expectation that the local relief taxes for 1935 will yield at least $3,000,000 above expenses.

ROME, Jan. 14. -- The possibility is beginning to be lamented that Italy may refuse to be represented at the League of Nations Council meeting Jan. 20. Well-informed circles believe this question is being studied by the government, which is expected to make known its decision within a few days.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14. -- In the Key Largo purse, a mile and a sixteenth affair for $2,000 platers, which featured the program at Tropical Park, the 4-year-old Ariel filly. Sleek, which won her last start here when entered for $1,300, triumphed even more easily today, taking the lead at once and holding it to register by three lengths in 1:45 flat.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14. -- After repeated charges that aggressive neighbors were threatening the Soviet Union with war on the east and the west, the government announced tonight that its military budget for 1936 would be more than double that of last year.

S.K. Farrington Jr., a big-game angler of wide experience, has just returned from a trip to Bermuda, where he spent two days fishing with Captains Harold Driscoll and Charles Christianson. Despite the briefness of his visit, he said yesterday that as a result of his observations and conversations with Bermudians he was convinced the island possessed tremendous potentialities as a resort for rod and reel enthusiasts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Outside interest in grains was unusually small today and the turnover on the Chicago Board of Trade was estimated as the lightest in some time. Price changes were confined to small fractions. Wheat's maximum range was 5/8 to 3/4 cent and corn's 1/4 to 3/8 cent.

Starting in 1937 New York City's public high school football schedules will be limited to seven games, according to a new ruling passed by the members of the High Schools Games Committee of the P.S.A.L. at their January meeting yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

James L. Kilpatrick, president of the New York Telephone Company, has advised stockholders that total telephone revenues of the company were $172,266,339 for the first eleven months of 1935, against $170,157,780 in the same period of 1934.

BERLIN, Jan. 14. -- The Boerse opened today with the trend undecided, and then turned weaker after a display of strength by the dollar, which mitigated the fears of inflation that have prevailed. The turnover, however, remained small.

Net operating earnings of the National City Bank in 1935 were $13,048,191, or $1.82 a share, on the bank's 6,200,000 shares of common stock outstanding, against $14,623,463, or $2.03 a share, in 1934, James H. Perkins, chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange in a letter to presidents of corporations having securities registered on the Exchange yesterday summarized the requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding annual reports to be filed on Form 10-K.

Bank earnings have been steadily decreasing the last two years, as a result of the low money rates. Jackson E. Reynolds, president of the First National Bank of New York told about forty stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

A 320-carat sapphire, called the Star of Artaban, said to be the largest and most beautiful stone of its kind ever brought into this country, was released by the customs yesterday to N. Zaidens, Inc., a jewelry house at 62 West Forty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The rivalry of two American companies in the field of international radiotelegraphic communications came before the Federal Communications Commission today.

Price movements of commodity futures were quite irregular in the trading here yesterday. Losses and gains were about evenly divided in light trading. On the cash markets corn, rye and rubber advanced, while wheat, eggs, silk and raw sugar declined.

Some weeks ago Senator of NORRIS Nebraska, who is nominally a Republican, stated that he intended to support President ROOSEVELT for re-election this year. This did not mean, he explained, that he approved of everything the Administration had done. Least of all could he, as an honest believer in civil service reform, approve of the great extension by the New Deal of the spoils system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Both Italy and Ethiopia should be specifically exempted from the effect of the administration neutrality bill, a group of Italian-Americans urged before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

In the letter of Roscoe Steffen it is in effect stated that the majority opinion in the AAA case recognized the right of Congress to provide for the general welfare but held that the act constituted an invasion of rights reserved to the States, "although it could point to no provision in the Constitution requiring that the broad grant of power to Congress to spend in the general welfare must be so crippled."

Another group of members of the United States Olympic Winter sports team is leaving today for Germany on the Washington of the United States Lines. Among them are Miss Maribel Y. Vinson of Boston, American women's figure skating champion; Robin Lee of Minneapolis, men's figure skating champion; George E.B. Hill of Boston, and Erle Reiter of Minneapolis.

John J. Kemp, 51 years old, life insurance agent for stage folk, formerly at 551 Fifth Avenue, who stole in the last fourteen years more than $96,000 he had received as premiums, was sentenced in General Sessions yesterday to two and one-half to five years in Sing Sing.

Off to an 18-7 lead in the first half, the Irving School of Tarrytown opened its Eastern Private Schools Basketball League schedule with a 34-15 victory over Trinity School in the latter's gymnasium in one of the many schoolboy court contests played yesterday.

Invention of a "super-alarm' clock apparatus to awaken heavy sleepers and persons who turn over for an extra wink in the morning was disclosed yesterday by Edward O. Ross, a senior in Columbia University.

The city of San Francisco has awarded an issue of $3,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes to the First Boston Corporation on a 0.13 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $11.50. The notes are payable on May 15.

Public offering, by means of a prospectus, of a new issue of $27,000,000 of West Penn Power first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series I, will be made today by a banking group headed by W.C. Langley Co. The bonds, which mature on Jan. 1, 1966, are priced at 103 and interest.

A BAND from the cultured region of Chapel Hill, N.C., has come to town to see what can be done about cutting the string of victories of the Ultra-Violet array on the basketball floor. They call themselves the Tar Heels and the Phantoms of the hard floor. If any one wishes to refer to them as the Chapel Hill Billy Band, they have no objections as long as it is done with a smile.

TRENTON, Jan. 14. -- The 160th New Jersey Legislature convened here today to face what is believed will be one of the stormiest sessions in its history. As both houses set to work, legislators sounded a call for economy and Governor Hoffman in his budget message suggested cutting $3,387,774 from State governmental expenditures for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Action based upon a study of the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann and intended as the basis of a code of ethics for lawyers, the press and the public at future criminal trials was taken today by the Executive Committee of the American Bar Association.

Loew's, Inc., reports for the twelve weeks ended on Nov. 21 a net profit of $1,811,396 after expenses, depreciation, taxes and other deductions. The earnings equal, after preferred dividend requirements, $1.08 a share on 1,464,205 common shares outstanding.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 14. -- At the hangar of the American Airlines at Newark Airport tonight it was said that the Southerner left the Newark Airport at 1:20 P.M. today, bound for Fort Worth, Texas, which is a division headquarters of the airline.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday exceeded the thousand mark. For the week the arrivals were 1,269, the highest listed in THE TIMES since the same period of 1934, when 1,278 were recorded, and compared with 991 listed in the preceding week and 1,257 in the corresponding week last year.
Several large parcels were among the eighteen holdings taken over by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auction sales yesterday.

Chain store and mail order concerns last month showed a gain of approximately 10 per cent in sales over the corresponding month of 1934, which gave them the best Christmas trade in almost five years, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc. and Hammons Co., Inc.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 14 (AP). -- A man, believed to be Roland Patterson Heatly of 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, New York City, was missing from the steamer Concord of the Colonial Line when that vessel docked here this morning after a trip from New York.

Consumer expenditures for general merchandise in department stores, mail order organizations and general and variety chain stores last year amounted to $5,121,694,000, a gain of 7.3 per cent over the 1934 figure of $4,772,469,000, according to A.W. Zelomek, economist of the International Statistical Bureau, yesterday.

Directors of Best Co. declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents in addition to a dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, payable on Feb. 15 to holders of record of Jan. 25. The regular semiannual dividend of 3 per cent on the preferred stock also was voted, payable out of net earnings on Jan. 31 to stock of record of that date.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet today, but prices held firm. Outstanding in the trading was the further rise of oil shares as a result of the better overnight news from the United States, which aroused expectations of an early upturn in prices of petroleum issues here.

The Metropolitan Opera's sixth week will open next Monday with the first subscription performance of "La Juive." The week will also witness the return of Gertrud Kappel in "Die Walkuere," and the second performance of "La Rondine."

The need for early action to halt the exodus of manufacturing concerns from New York and to bring back those plants which already have left the city was emphasized at a luncheon meeting of the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

Is the proposal to raise the educational requirements for admission to civil service examinations undemocratic? It would seem impossible that any responsible person could think so, were it not that certain reports in the press of a recent hearing before the New York Civil Service Commission indicate that they do.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Continental Steel Corporation has filed an amendment to its registration statement for the issuance of $1,500,000 of ten-year 4 1/4 per cent sinking fund debentures, due on Jan. 1, 1946, fixing tomorrow as the offering date.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Partisan strife on Capitol Hill is just around the corner and may flare up when the Senate and Assembly consider Governor Lehman's executive budget bills. The first rumblings of the approaching storm were heard today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14. -- Twelve alumni were named tonight as candidates for the five vacancies on the Harvard Board of Overseers which will come by normal retirement in June. The selection was made by the committee on nominations of the Harvard Alumni Association, and the five new Overseers will be elected by a postal ballot to Harvard graduates.

MONTREAL, Jan. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Lester Patrick's New York Rangers sped to a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Maroons in a National Hockey League game tonight with a patched-up line-up made necessary by the absence of Bun Cook, Vernon Ayres and Harold Start. A crowd of 6,000 witnessed the contest in the Forum.

If one wishes to obtain convincing proof of the futility and mischievous results of our Silver Purchase legislation, it may be found in the Annual Review of the Silver Market for 1935, just issued by the leading New York bullion house, Handy Harman. The firm's yearly retrospects are necessarily dispassionate and non-political.

Price movements in stocks continued indecisive again yesterday. The closing was irregularly higher, a few of the leaders gaining a point or more on the day to give the market a generally firm appearance. Perhaps the most charitable observation that could be made is that the market exhibits a "tired" appearance.

St. John's University junior varsity and freshman quintets scored over the Long Island University jayvees and cubs in a double-header in the DeGray gymnasium last night. The jayvee score was 43 to 32. The St. John's freshmen annexed their twelfth consecutive victory of the season by 37 to 31.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- The five-power naval conference is now coming to an end as such. It will enter its second phase as a four-power conference next week, with Japan absent, proceeding to deal with questions hitherto untouched, particularly of qualitative limitation, which Japan's departure will have left open.
It seems to me that Roscoe Steffen in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 13 has missed the force of the majority opinion in the AAA decision and has in a measure answered his own arguments.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14. -- Members of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor gathered here today apparently still at odds on the question of preparing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States and then moving to have it presented to Congress at the present session.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,810,150 barrels, compared with 2,802,750 in the preceding week, a gain of 7,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 36,250 barrels in the daily average output of Texas and an increase of 24,150 in Oklahoma were the important changes.

The Great Northern, Great Northern Railway earned a net income of about $7,000,000 in 1935, in contrast with a ]net loss of $1,074,480 in 1934, according to an estimate by W. 1m. Kenney, president. Gross revenues in the first week of thi year ran about 10 per cent ahead of those in the same period last year.

Sentences of five years each in Sing Sing were imposed by Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions yesterday on five ex-convicts, trapped by detectives on Nov. 24 when they were about to loot some of the 100 or more safes in the six-story Manhattan Diamond Center, Inc., at 82 Bowery.

" King of Burlesque," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical film featuring Warner Baxter, Alice Faye and Jack Oakie, opens this morning at the Center Theatre. Also on the program will be the new issue of "The March of Time."

TRENTON, Jan. 14. -- A motion by Bruno Richard Hauptmann's attorneys for a writ of habeas corpus was denied here today by Judge J. Warren Davis of the Federal Circuit Court, who held that any other action by him would "in effect be overruling the Supreme Court of the United States." He also refused to grant a stay to give time for an appeal.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday in his recent action granting a summary judgment in behalf of a foreign corporation that brought suit to collect interest on bonds of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company at the old rate of exchange.

PELHAM, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- The Men's Club of Pelham, which, its members contend, is intellectually superior, was considerably humbled here tonight by the senior class of Pelham Memorial High School, who defeated club members in a "childish" spelling contest.

Hotels throughout the city are fingerprinting their employes, from executives down to bus boys and chambermaids, it was learned yesterday. The movement, it was said, followed the urgings recently of Governor Lehman and Federal authorities for the adoption of fingerprinting as a general means of identification.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- In his campaign to bring about a reduction in interest rates for corporate financing, as well as a better deal from the banks for the "average man," Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, reached an agreement today with W.P. Kenney, president of the Great Northern Railway.

Daniel Webster Mead, nationally known hydraulic, power and valuation engineer of Madison, Wis., has been elected president of the American Society of Civil Engineers, it was announced yesterday on the eve of the opening this morning of the eighty-third annual meeting of the society at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, returned from Washington yesterday, where he had conferred with Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA chief, and issued an order rescinding instructions of last week to drop 10,000 workers from the WPA rolls here.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 15. -- According to a communique issued at Dessye today the Italians are continuing airplane raids on open towns and villages to terrorize the civilian population. It said the fliers were using explosive and gas bombs.
LONDON, Jan. 15. -- Cynthia Stockley, the novelist, was found dead in her Bayswater flat by a charwoman today. Near her mouth was a tube attached to a gas jet which had been turned on.

Two New Yorkers, Charles Altschul, 22-year-old son of Frank Altschul, partner in the banking firm of Lazard Freres of 120 Broadway and a member of the governing committee of the Stock Exchange, and Frank C. Hart, president of the Hartol Products Corporation of 630 Fifth Avenue, were victims of the airplane crash which took seventeen lives near Goodwin, Ark., Tuesday night.

The power trouble that threw the greater part of northern Manhattan into darkness at 4:16 P.M. yesterday, crippled the Eighth Avenue line from Fifty-ninth Street north one minute later, causing home-going workers to throng to the B.M.T. and I.R.T. lines, taxing the facilities of the two privately operated lines.
First, there must be an exposition that will give the world at large a new conception of America, its traditions and its ideals, its unity and its might;

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 15. -- Using a heavy iron pinch bar, Mrs. Sara Oberle, wife of Joseph S. Oberle, Chester County agent for the State Agricultural Extension Society, killed her three children early today while they lay asleep in their beds.

A statue of Andrew Jackson that once served as the figurehead of the historic frigate Constitution was unveiled yesterday afternoon in the Marine Museum of the City of New York. Although housed in the Museum of the City of New York, on Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, the Marine Museum is a separate institution.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- A stenographic record of a conversation in 1916 between Secretary Lansing and Ambassador Von Bernstorff, made public today by the Senate Munitions Committee, was as follows:

Judge CARDOZO held that the powers granted to the President by NRA were too "wide and vagrant." Still wider and more vagrant are the powers of a Senate committee of investigation. This was never better illustrated than by the proceedings of Senator NYE'S committee.

The prize-winning fish caught in Long Island waters during the 1935 season compared quite favorably, from the standpoint of size, with those taken in the few years immediately preceding, judging from the awards made recently by the East End Surf Fishing Club.

Many New Yorkers are concerned about the proposed World's Fair because they feel keenly the possibility of failure and are not overconfident of a great success. Financial success, however measured, will not be enough. It must be such an artistic success that New York itself will feel proud of the accomplishment and content in the result.

Two smooth-functioning Bronx teams, representing DeWitt Clinton and James Monroe High Schools, impressively turned back two Manhattan squads in the non-league scholastic basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

TEANECK, N.J., Jan. 15. -- A mother and child were killed instantly tonight when the automobile in which they were riding was in head-on collision in the fog with a crowded bus on Route 4 near Queen Anne Road here. The driver of the car was injured seriously, and two bus passengers were slightly hurt.

PARIS, Jan. 15. -- Premier Pierre Laval today conferred with several foreign diplomats regarding matters to come before the League of Nations Council Monday. Dr. Augusto de Vasconcellos of Portugal, chairman of the Committee of Eighteen on sanctions; Vittorio Cerutti, the Italian Ambassador, and Bosidor Pouritch, the Yugoslav Minister, discussed the Italo-Ethiopian question.
GOODWIN, Ark., Jan. 15. -- Lake Littlejohn, Commerce Department attache, said informally today that he believed the cause of the crash could not be established.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 15. -- Yale conquered Boston University tonight by 7 to 2 in the New Haven arena. Bob Cooke's goal shooting featured the Yale victory. Al Carvelli's clever passing made both the visitors' goals possible.
John Jacob Astor 3d has quit the job he got with the International Mercantile Marine Company March 20 last year at an initial salary of $25 a week.

The Savings Banks Trust Company, which acts as a central institution for savings banks in New York State, reported yesterday that its deposits increased $18,000,000 in 1935 to $89,779,232. The deposits of the 131 member banks in the company increased $16,000,000 to $59,922,657.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- The emerald necklace of the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick has been sold to an unnamed foreign buyer for $480,000 in cash. This was disclosed today when Probate Judge John F. O'Connell authorized the Chicago Title and Trust Company, executor of Mrs. McCormick's will, to complete the sale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- A proposal by the Maine Central Railroad to sell part of a refunding bond issue carrying 4 per cent interest to a group of bankers headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. at 1 1/2 per cent below par to cover distributing expenses was approved today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Mrs. Andrew S. White gave a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for Mrs. Edward J. Pearson. Her other guests were Mrs. Alton B. Parker, Mrs. Finley T. Shepard, Mrs. Frederick H. Ecker, Mrs. Frank N.B. Close, Mrs. George Hunting Hartford 2d, Mrs. Harry E. Byram, Mrs. Solomon R. Guggenheim, Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell and Mrs. Harlow S. Pearson.

GOODWIN, Ark., Jan. l5. -- The worst disaster in the history of American commercial aviation, resulting last night in the death of seventeen persons on an American Airlines plane which crashed into a swamp near here, remained a mystery tonight to investigators for the line, the Bureau of Air Commerce and the Senate Commerce Committee.

Effective steps to bring about a reduction of excess bank reserves would facilitate control of credit and disturb business less than if such action should be postponed until credit inflation is definitely under way, Harry E. Ward and Lewis E. Pierson, president and chairman, respectively, of the Irving Trust Company, told stockholders of that institution at their annual meeting here yesterday morning.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The British Cabinet met today for the first time since Christmas and discussed the line Foreign Minister Anthony Eden should take at next week's session of the League of Nations Council. It may be said with assurance now that he will do and say nothing definite.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP). -- A new treatment for diabetes by use of a heretofore unknown compound of insulin was announced today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Japan's withdrawal from the London Naval Conference brought authoritative indications today that the United States Navy might soon ask Congress for new funds with which to bolster its capital ship strength.
GLASGOW, Jan. 15. -- The building of a sister ship to the giant Cunarder Queen Mary now approaching completion here already is being envisaged before the Queen Mary herself has started her career.

WARSAW, Jan. 15. -- An admonition in connection with the recently concluded Ukrainian terrorist trial was given to the Lithuanian Government today by Foreign Minister Joseph Beck in his speech before the Sejm's foreign affairs committee.
ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today urging action by the State Government to cooperate in making the world's fair of 1939 a success.

The Medical Society of the State of New York is starting a State-wide organized attack on pneumonia. In its long campaign during the Winter months it is to have the cooperation of the New York State Department of Health, the Commonwealth Fund, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the New York State Association of Public Health Laboratories.
LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The text of Japan's letter of withdrawal from the London naval conference, sent to Viscount Monsell, the chairman, by Admiral Osami Nagano today, follows:

The marked upturn in business cannot continue or last long without a balanced Federal budget and a stabilized currency, Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, told shareholders of the bank at their annual meeting yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 15. -- In a speech delivered at the new aircraft hangars at Detmold on the third anniversary of the National Socialist election victory in the principality of Lippe, which paved the way for Chancellor Adolf Hitler's accession to power fifteen days later, Hitler warned the German people tonight that they must be prepared to make sacrifices if they are to win.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- Japan turned her back on naval limitation and withdrew from the London conference today, with ultimate results to the peace of the world which nobody can even faintly foresee at the present time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- All ranks of official and diplomatic society were represented in the large audience which turned out today to welcome and applaud Ernest Schelling and members of the Musical Art Quartet at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's eighty-fifth musical morning at the Mayflower Hotel.

The Chicago North Western Railway, which entered bankruptcy last June, is to file a plan of reorganization in the Federal court in Chicago on Feb. 27, Fred W. Sargent, president, announced yesterday. The court has ruled that reorganization must be completed by April 1.

One of the rarest issues of all the United States gold coins, the quarter-eagle ($2.50) of 1863 was sold for $510 yesterday at the auction offering of a collection of United States and foreign gold coins held at the J.C. Morgenthau Galleries, 1 West Forty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP). -- The government today ordered six aviation experts to investigate the American Airlines crash near Goodwin, Ark.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15. -- One long table adorned with yellow and mauve sweet peas, blue and yellow iris and vari-colored gerbera in black tripods on mirror plateaux, illumined by yellow tapers, was arranged for the dinner which Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Gale gave tonight in the north lounge of the Breakers. Later the guests danced in the central loggia.

HELSINGFORS, Jan. 15. -- Finland's preparations for the Olympic Winter Games at Garmisch-Partenkirchen will be completed after thorough trials in distance skiing which are taking place in the northern districts where snow conditions are favorable.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP). -- Racing Commissioners from seventeen States today voiced approval of Walter H. Donovan's leadership in the campaign to elevate turf standards, re-electing the Floridian president of their national association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- A resolution calling for an investigation of the Federal Communications Commission by a special House committee was introduced today by Representative Connery, Democrat, of Massachusetts. The resolution will have the active support of Republicans, Representative Snell of New York, the minority leader, stated.

Horace C. Stoneham, son of the late Charles A. Stoneham, yesterday became the youngest baseball magnate in the history of the major leagues when, at a special meeting of the board of directors, he was elected president of the New York Giants to succeed his father.
John K. Weeks of the Princeton Club and Val Ely of Apawamis gained the final round of the Union League invitation squash racquets tournament for Class B players at the club's courts yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15. -- The thirty-hour work week bill will top organized labor's legislative program at the present session of Congress, it was indicated today as the executive council of the American Federation of Labor ended the first meeting of its quarterly session.

The United Corporation, in its report to stockholders for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1935, shows a decline in consolidated cash income to 89,471,100, compared with $10,784,362 a year before. This was the result, George H. Howard, president, said in his letter to stockholders, of a net reduction in the amount of dividends received from the corporation's holdings.

The controller of the United Fruit Company announced yesterday that net earnings of the company in 1935 were estimated at $10,359,222, subject to verification and final audit upon receipt of year-end cables and statements of accounts from the various offices of the company.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 15. -- Clarkson's strong hockey team defeared the Princeton sextet, 5 to 3, in the Hobey Baker rink tonight. Gary Donihee, spare wing, led the victors' attack with two goals and one assist.

Yesterday's trust company meetings virtually completed the season of annual gatherings of banks' stockholders. In retrospect several common characteristics emerge from the individual gatherings. Most important and most obvious was the better spirit displayed as between management and shareholder.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation has deposited $5,464,408 with the Chase National Bank for the redemption at $110 a share plus accrued dividends of all of its 8 per cent preferred stock which was called for redemption, the company announced yesterday.

An exhibition showing details in the planning and making of Dard Hunter's book, "A Papermaking Pilgrimage to Japan, Korea and China," will open on Monday in the rooms of the Pynson Printers, 229 West Forty-third Street. The book has been in preparation more than a year by Elmer Adler of the Pynson Printers and will be issued shortly.

COLFAX, Calif., Jan. 15. -- A snowslide 150 feet wide buried three coaches of the Southern Pacific's westbound transcontinental train, the Pacific Limited, tonight near Donner Summit in the high Sierra Mountains. Eleven passengers were reported injured.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Chairman Anning S. Prall said today the Communications Commission regards orders by the Federal Trade Commission affecting radio programs as an "important consideration" in applications for renewals of broadcasting licenses.

TIENTSIN, China, Jan. 15. -- Japanese consular authorities here do not see any chance of formal recognition by Japan or Manchukuo of either of the North China autonomous regimes. They declare, however, that Japan and Manchukuo will probably negotiate with the local authorities on any problems that arise and will ignore Nanking in most cases, "just as has been done in other parts of China."

VIENNA, Jan. 15. -- The Austrian revolutionary Socialists have now passed from whispered jokes about the regime to elaborately printed hoaxes and are reducing the bewildered officials of the Austrian Fascist movement to a state in which they do not know what documents are official and what they should hand over to the police.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15, -- Wheat made a firm start and a tame finish today on the Chicago Board of Trade, closing around the low point at net losses of 1/4 to 3/4 cents.

The mastery of New York University's artists of the court was never more dearly etched than last night. While a crowd of 15,000 marveled at their shot-making and passing, the Violets rolled their winning basketball streak to nineteen games by routing North Caroline, champion of the Southern Conference, in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Woodrow Wilson and Robert Lansing, who was his wartime Secretary of State, were pictured today before the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee as givers of false testimony.

One of the lessons taught book publishers by the depression years is the necessity and the desirability of closer cooperation in all branches of the industry, Stanley Rinehart declared yesterday. Mr. Rinehart was elected president of the National Association of Book Publishers at the annual meeting at the Hotel St. Regis.

BERLIN, Jan. 15. -- The Boerse, which continues to suffer from creeping paralysis, opened rather firmer today under the leadership of specialties, but prices soon turned soft because of weakness developing in government loans.

About 80,000 men, women and children patrons of neighborhood motion picture theatres were left in darkness yesterday afternoon when their favorite stars of the screen suddenly lapsed into silence and obscurity as lack of power caused the projection machines in the northern part of the city to slow down and stop.

MONTREAL, Jan. 15. -- Production of newsprint by Canadian mills in 1935 amounted to 2,753,289 tons, the largest on record and comparing with 2,725,000 in 1929, the previous peak, and 2,599,244 in 1934. The increase over 1934 was 5.9 per cent.

The Tri-Continental Corporation and its three affiliated investment companies issued yesterday reports for 1935, showing an increase in net assets as a result of the rise in the value of investments. The affiliated companies are Selected Industries, Inc.; Capital Administration Company, Ltd., and Broad Street Investing Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- When Mark Antony reminded the citizens of Rome that the good men do is oft interred with their bones, he did not dwell upon another fact -- well known to him as a Roman politician -- that these bones are oft disinterred to probe for even more evil than has lived after them.

Following last night's matches, the Class A squash tennis teams of the New York Athletic Club and the Columbia University Club still maintained their places at the head of the Metropolitan League standing. Both turned in triumphs which left them tied with eight victories and one loss for the season to date.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 15 (AP). -- Seven persons, including three members of the crew, were killed when a tri-motored army plane crashed yesterday between Puerto Boy, a military post on the Caqueta River, 150 miles south of Bogota, and Tesesquinas in the wild southern region of Colombia, belated reports from the Department of Caqueta declared tonight.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The Chicago North Western Railway's gross income in 1935, before fixed charges, was about $6,000,000, or about $2,500,000 less than in 1934, according to Fred W. Sargent, president. The figures for November showed a net loss of $569,996, against $1,053,805 a year before.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15. -- The Soviet Union has been forced to increase its standing army to 1,300,000 men and has been compelled to more than double its military budget because of increasing menaces on its Far Eastern and western borders, Marshal Mikhail Tukhachevsky, Assistant Commissar for Defense, told delegates to the seventh congress of the Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Union tonight.

Fordham's basketball team gave its best performance of the season last night in defeating Columbia by 26 -- 19 on its home court. The victory was the eighth in nine starts for the Maroon. Except for about a minute near the end of the first half the Rams were always in the lead.

Four more members of the American Olympic Winter sports team sailed for Europe yesterday, but two of them came perilously close to missing the boat. Robin Lee and Erle Reiter, winner and runner-up for the men's national figure skating championship, were aboard the United States liner Washington bright and early.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters elected Dr. Walter Damrosch president last night to succeed Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut, chose seven new members and voted to award the organization's gold medal for sculpture to George Grey Bernard.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- Robert Kay, who with a few quietly spoken words over the telephone from the Bank of England controlled the government's 375,000,000 exchange equalization fund, dropped dead on the street while en route to his office this morning. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Agreement to place qualifications above party, to encourage the candidacy of women and as between a qualified man and qualified woman to support the candidacy of the woman, regardless of party affiliation, was voted today by the directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at the opening of their mid-Winter meeting here.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15. -- A company of 1,500 guests attending the annual Junior League party passed a "novel day" in an atmosphere of tropical cruising at the Arcadia International today.

Charge account and installment sales at retail continue to expand, emphasizing the trend which was markedly evident in the Fall of last year, retail executives here reported yesterday. Further strong impetus to this type of selling will be given by the furniture and home furnishings events to be staged shortly by the stores.

When the New York Rangers square off against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight a face familiar to local hockey fans will be missing from the Blue Shirts' line-up. Earl Seibert, the husky defense man who has played with the New Yorkers for the past four years, is no longer a member of the team.

"AMERICA MUST ACT," by Assistant Secretary of State Francis Bowes Sayre (World Peace Foundation, 75 cents), is, one supposes, the answer of one of Cordell Hull's men to Professor Charles A. Beard's relatively "isolationist" work on "the national interest," published in two volumes by Macmillan. Considered purely as dialectics, Mr. Sayre's arguments for the loosening of trade restrictions on a worldwide basis are irrefutable.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15. -- British troops are being brought here in great haste. Three more battalions arrived today, more are coming Friday and additional contingents will reach here next week.

Extending its realty holdings in the financial district, the Trinity Church Corporation yesterday purchased from the Horn Hardart Company the building at 68 Trinity Place, running through to 103-07 Greenwich Street. The buyers are said to have paid $1,000,000 for the property, which gives them control of a combined frontage of about 132 feet on Trinity Place and 109 feet on Greenwich Street.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15. -- Florida's horse racing scene shifted across town tonight, leaving Tropical Park temporarily closed after a prosperous meet and Hialeah Park opening tomorrow a forty-six-day season of exceptional promise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The administration moved today to give foreign countries notice that the United States would not waive any of its rights under international law, especially regarding freedom of the seas, in adopting the permanent neutrality measure which it has placed before Congress.
LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The text of the Japanese naval delegation's statement presented today by Admiral Osami Nagano follows:

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 15. -- Following a statement from witnesses at today's hearing in the case against Colonel Damian Veltcheff and other prominent Bulgarian officers and politicians that they had been involved in a plot to overthrow the government in 1934, military police arrested Colonel Kaum Koleff, former Minister of the Interior and Colonel Michael Kalendaroff.

The absence of aggressive leadership in the share market was evident yesterday. Various groups showed considerable activity but movements were confusing, so that the market, as a whole, failed to make much progress. Indicative of the lack of sponsorship, many of the most active issues of the list composed an odd assortment of low-priced stocks.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- Baron Forster of Lepe, British cricketer, politician and one of the most popular Governors General that Australia ever had, died here today at the age of 69. As a sportsman he had been president of the Marylebone Cricket Club (ruling cricket authority), captain of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club and also a member of the Royal Yacht Squadron.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., today will add 2 cents a gallon to the retail price of gasoline in Manhattan, the Bronx, Kings and the remainder of Long Island. The new price for the regular grade of gasoline at service stations will be 18.5 cents a gallon, including Federal and State taxes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- A sharp reduction in receipts of hogs here today lifted prices 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight in the early trading, but as soon as urgent orders had been filled, a reactionary tendency developed. Sales at the close were around steady to only 10 cents higher than yesterday.

ROME, Jan 15. -- General Rodolfo Graziani took immediate advantage of the end of the "little rains" in Italian Somaliland to resume operations against the Ethiopians. It was announced here today that on Sunday he had launched an offensive against Ras Desta Demtu's forces north of Dolo, which is on the River Juba in the extreme southwestern corner of Italian Somaliland.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 15. -- Upon their own application four mortgage companies in this city were placed today under the supervision of Carl K. Withers, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, by Vice Chancellor Vivian M. Lewis in Chancery Court here.
Reports of annual meetings of banks, held yesterday here and in other places, at which important changes were made, follow:
The State Liquor Authority announced yesterday plans for broadening its temperance campaign by means of a State-wide speaking program.
Steel operations this week will remain unchanged at 51 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by The Iron Age.

Almost complete paralysis of the normal life of Manhattan north of Fifty-ninth Street, in the Bronx and in Westchester, and indirect repercussions affecting other sections of the metropolitan area resulted late yesterday afternoon and last night from a breakdown of the New York Edison Company's alternating current system.

Further activity by the special grand jury investigating racketeering in Manhattan was disclosed yesterday by a raid on the headquarters of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paper Hangers of America, Council No. 9, at 244 West Fourteenth Street.

Is it too much to hope that before the Senate votes on the soldiers' bonus it will consider seriously the enormous problems which confront the Treasury? Secretary MORGENTHAU has given the Finance Committee an outline of them. He submitted this estimate of the borrowing that will be forced upon the Treasury during the next eighteen months if payment of the bonus is now added to the other heavy responsibilities of the Government:

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 15. -- The American Olympic bobsledding team's need for funds to transport sixteen men from Bavaria to St. Moritz was a leading topic today. It had become the talk of the town that the team could not afford to train in the Swiss resort, where a majority of the European Olympic teams already are assembled.

I have read with interest your editorial "Chancing Constitutionality." It seems to me that the admonition of Justice Stone was never so greatly needed as at the present time. It was the thought of Chief Justice Marshall, as expressed in Fletcher v. Peck, decided in 1809, that the Supreme Court would never pronounce an act of Congress to be unconstitutional unless its incompatibility with the Constitution was absolutely clear.

The President, following the decision voiding the AAA, told us that some means must be found to carry out the moral obligation of the government the farmers with whom contracts had been made under that law. He made no reference to the fact that these contracts had been made after several Federal courts had decided that the act was invalid, and the overwhelming weight of legal opinion was that the Supreme Court would similarly rule.

About 100 Japanese figure prints from the last quarter of the eighteenth century will be exhibited, beginning today, in the Print Gallery of the New York Public Library, at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue. The subject and period indicated stand for the most important section of the collection formed by Captain F. Brinkley and presented to the library by the late Charles Stewart Smith.
New York City went candle-conscious last night.

August Heckscher, real estate man and philanthropist, is "deliberately attempting to starve Frieda Hempel into submission," it was charged yesterday in Supreme Court in affidavits submitted in the former opera star's suit to collect a payment due last Dec. 1 on a $15,000 annuity paid to her by Mr. Heckscher since 1928.

After leaving his taxicab to lead a blind man across a street, George Winnick, 35 years old, of 952 Utica Avenue, Brooklyn, was fatally injured yesterday morning when struck by another taxicab as he returned to his stand. He died in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Jan. 15. -- The fate of Bruno Richard Hauptmann became an active topic of editorial comment with a part of the Berlin press today, but it is chiefly concerned with the argument that his conviction was obtained through what is alleged to be purely circumstantial evidence.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- Apart from British funds being overshadowed by coming new issues, prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm today and the tone was cheerful. German issues were better in the foreign section and the Far Eastern list was dull.

PARIS. Jan. 15. -- Rentes weakened again today on the Bourse and the 3 per cents fell to the low level of 70.65. For this situation the blame is being placed on the uncertainty prevalent regarding the future of Premier Pierre Laval's government.

Charles Pascal Franchot, general counsel and director of half a dozen important corporations, was informed by the police last week that he had been swindled out of $5,000 in two stud poker games at the Metropolitan Club.
A board of directors for the Spring season of the Metropolitan Opera House to be known as the Metropolitan Spring season has been named, it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- Great Britain's exports of hard liquor to the United States in 1935 amounted to about 17 per cent less than in 1934, when the long thirsty spell of prohibition had just been ended.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Leaders of the Republican legislators decided today to assume the offensive, go after the New Deal and lay a foundation for their State and national campaigns while the legislative session is still in progress.

Austin Phelps Palmer, wealthy retired engineer of 1,085 Park Avenue, who was arrested last Saturday for sending threatening letters to President Roosevelt, unexpectedly pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Patterson in Federal court. He will be sentenced on Jan. 24.

Samuel Lionel Rothafel, known to millions of motion picture and radio enthusiasts as "Roxy," was buried yesterday after about 2,000 persons had attended a simple, impressive funeral service for him at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Construction awards of all types in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains last year totaled $1,844,544,900, a gain of almost 20 per cent over the 1934 aggregate of $1,543,108,400, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

Twenty-four detectives and twenty-six uniformed policemen, commanded by Inspector John E. Copeland, were rushed to the Hall of Records behind City Hall about 9:30 o'clock last night after a hold-up in which two watchmen were robbed of $12.50.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Sensing Congressional indifference, and with signs of divided views among farm organization leaders developing, Agricultural Adjustment officials virtually decided tonight on a new course of action which, if approved by President Roosevelt tomorrow, could continue the New Deal farm program in force without the enactment of new enabling legislation.

The more one studies the plot of that radio tragedy produced and directed by the Republican National Committee the more incredible it seems. The play shows John Smith and Mary Jones applying for a marriage license and being frightened out of their wits and their wedding by the clerk of the marriage bureau.

Eddie Cantor's new musical film, "Strike Me Pink," will have its premiere this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Besides Mr. Cantor, the players include Ethel Merman, Sally Eilers and Brian Donlevy.

Artur Schnabel last night in Carnegie Hall returned to his large New York public when he gave the first of a series of seven programs which will offer all the thirty-two Beethoven piano recitals, on consecutive Wednesday evenings. Mr. Schnabel's public is not only a substantial but a distinguished one.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Four billion dollars expenditures, made up of a $2,000,000,000 deficit and $2,000,000,000 in receipts for the fiscal year from July 1 to date, were reported by the government today. All figures were new high marks for the year.

Supporters of the bonus for World War veterans were assailed as "tin cup veterans" yesterday by Major Henry H. Curran, a director of the National Economy League, speaking at a luncheon meeting of the Reserve Officers Association of the United States, Manhattan Chapter, at the Princeton Club.

Shareholders of several important trust companies held their annual meeetings yesterday, receiving reports from the banks' chief executive officers which detailed the operating results of the last year, emplasizing, in almost all cases, the reduction in earnings due to low interest rates and small demand for bank credit, and the mounting expenses resulting from taxes and costs of Federal deposit insurance.

Newport Harbor, Calif., was deprived of the 1936 world's championship Star Class sailing championship, team tactics in individual racing were condemned and the rule governing the location of the event was amended to provide more frequent change of scene at a special meeting of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association yesterday at 160 Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15. -- A plan disclosed by Leopold Stokowski whereby the Philadelphia Orchestra would tour four continents during the next four years caused lively discussion among members of the orchestra today, but was without confirmation from officials of the Orchestra Association, most of whom expressed surprise.

STOCKY DAN FERRIS, secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U., was queried about the indoor track and field campaign. For the past two seasons the lure that brought out the big throngs for the races under a roof was the Bonthron-Cunningham rivalry. The latest report was that Bounding Bill, late of Princeton, was wearing running shoes again but had no intention of treading the boards.
LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The address of Viscount Monsell, First Lord of the British Admiralty, at the naval conference session here today was as follows:

Trading in futures in the commodity markets here continued active yesterday, but price trends were mixed. In the cash markets corn, rye, cocoa and rubber were higher, while wheat, dairy products, tin, cotton and silk moved lower.

In a contest that was productive of keen play throughout, the Horace Mann School basketball team conquered the Columbia freshmen, 19 -- 16, yesterday in the Blue and White gymnasium in one of the feature contests involving private school quintets in the metropolitan area.
TRENTON, Jan. 15. -- Dr. Albert Einstein took out his first papers for citizenship in the United States at the postoffice here today. At his home in Princeton later, he refused to comment.

Colonel Edward M. House, declining yesterday to comment on the delving by the Nye-Clark Senate munitions committee into the World War neutrality policy of Woodrow Wilson, said he was satisfied to let the written record of his relations with the war President "speak for itself."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 15. -- Rutgers conquered Fordham in a dual swimming meet tonight, 49 -- 22. The Scarlet took five of the seven individual events, Jimmy Reilly, sophomore ace, accounting for first places in the furlong and quarter mile.

Inconveniences ranging from the complete paralysis of the elevator system in the forty-three-story Hotel Pierre, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-first Street, to the failure of the doorbells to ring in the Mayflower, just across the park from the Pierre, were cheerfully endured yesterday in the many hotels and apartments north of Fifty-ninth Street as a result of the power line breakdown.

Sales tax collections yesterday, the final day for payment without penalty of the last installment of the relief levy for 1935, totaled $6,910,399.81, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night. This brought the total collections to date for the year to $36,978,776.90.

Two circus managements have made attractive offers to Billy Rose to tour "Jumbo" when the time comes, Mr. Rose disclosed last evening. They are the Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Enterprises and the Cole Brothers-Beatty Combined Shows.

ATHENS, Jan. 15. -- Diplomatic negotiations concerning naval power in the Aegean Sea continue here. It was announced today that the British Minister, Sydney Philip Waterlow, had a long interview with King George at the palace following the banquet given to the Greek general naval staff at the British Legation Monday night.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday he would make eighty-eight promotions in his department this morning at police headquarters.

Using the corner shot with telling effect and mixing up her game in guileful fashion, Mrs. Watson Wyckoff, an unseeded player, defeated Miss Susan Guion, third ranking favorite, in the women's metropolitan secondary squash racquets championship yesterday at the Colony Club.

The Board of Estimate notified the city's bankers yesterday that the amount of the tax delinquency reserve in the 1936 budget was $17,000,000, in response to the request of the bankers for definite assurance that the full amount of reserve was set aside.

TRENTON, Jan. 15. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann's attorneys began an effort today to interest the United States Supreme Court in their attempts to stave off the execution decreed for him on Friday night.

An emergency administration of oxygen, performed principally by the light of matches, and an emergency operation performed soon afterward with the aid of a plumber's flashlight and candles took place yesterday at Parkway Hospital, 123 West 110th Street, during the failure of lighting current in that neighborhood.

PARIS, Jan. 15. -- A round-trip flight between Paris and New York in forty-eight hours, with a five-hour stop in New York for refueling, is planned for next Summer by Captain Maurice Rossi, famous French aviator. He will make the attempt in a new plane with an automatic pilot of such improved design that, it is declared, the flier will be able to sleep en route.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Interest in trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday continued to be centered in the January position in which houses doing government business again released contracts. It was estimated that 30,000 to 40,000 bales of January have been sold by a few houses so far this week, part of the sales being replaced with May and the rest liquidated outright.

If, as this department was informed, last night's performance of Valentin Katayev's "A Million Torments" at the Heckscher Theatre was the world premiere of this play by Soviet Russia's leading satirist, there must be some explanation for it.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15. -- Fragments of ancient Phoenician temple records, which, Russian scientists say, cast new light on biblical stories, were made public here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Secretary Roper appointed eighteen new members of his Business Advisory and Planning Council today. They will serve through 1936. At the same time George Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Progress, reported that his Council for Industrial Progress had completed organization of committees to undertake studies approved at the meeting Jan. 6.

The definite statement that Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas is a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination was made here yesterday by Albert Ottinger, former Attorney General and Republican candidate for Governor of New York in 1928.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 15. -- Samuel Schwartz, 48, one of the victims of the plane crash near Goodwin, Ark., was the owner of the Apollo Hotel on the Boardwalk at New York Avenue, and was one of the leading amateur pilots and aviation enthusiasts here.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15. -- Hueu, a consistent 6-year-old plater from Clyde Troutt's barns, upheld the confidence of his followers today when he defeated five other older horses at six furlongs in the feature at the Fair Grounds.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, having come into possession of a remarkable album of drawings by Goya, is completing arrangements for an exhibition of work in several media by that great Spanish artist. It will open with a private view for members on Monday, Jan. 27, and to the public on the following day, remaining current through March 8.

Thousands of shoppers in department stores throughout upper Manhattan and the Bronx had their usual afternoon shopping hours abruptly discontinued shortly after 4 o'clock, when the stores were plunged into darkness. In no case, however, was any disturbance reported, and employes, armed with flashlights and candles supplied from the store stocks, quickly helped the customers leave the darkened buildings.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 16. -- Japan's departure from the London naval conference -- having been well prepared -- is calmly received in this country. Beneath this fatalistic mood, owing to the knowledge that no political force in Japan is strong enough to resist the fighting services at present, certain fears persist and are gaining expression.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- The prediction that if President Roosevelt is re-elected this year the trend of governments will continue toward dictatorship was made by James P. Warburg, New York banker, in an address today before the Chicago Association of Commerce.

The consolidated net earnings of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company applicable to the capital stock in 1935 were about $7 a share, compared with $5.96 a share in 1934, Walter S. Gifford, president, revealed in a letter to stockholders yesterday.

President Roosevelt expressed hope last night for a "brilliant future" for the "University in Exile," formally known as the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science. He characterized it as symbolic of American intellectual, religious and racial freedom.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Following is the text of Norman H. Davis's statement to the London Naval Conference today, as given out here:

John F. Hylan received full official honors from the city he had served as Mayor for eight years at his funeral yesterday morning. Mayor La Guardia, Controller Frank J. Taylor and detachments from the Police, Fire and Sanitation Departments joined with hundreds of political and neighborhood friends in paying a final tribute to the Children's Court judge who died suddenly Sunday morning.

The restrictive policies of the Interstate Commerce Commission with respect to railroad operations were attacked by Charles S. Belsterling, vice president of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday in an address before the Traffic Club of New York.

Arturo Toscanini, the orchestra conductor, is arriving today from Paris on the French liner Lafayette to begin a ten-week season as conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. He is accompanied by Mme. Toscanini. Others arriving on the ship include Laurence Stallings, author; Robert Casadesus, French pianist, with Mrs. Casadesus; Kurt Jooss and members of his European ballet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- A statement that it was a "good bet" that the President would veto any bill proposing prepayment of the face value of the World War veterans' adjusted service certificates was made today by a person who frequently sees President Roosevelt.
Registering three field goals and a foul in the three-minute extra period, the Haaren High School five conquered Theodore Roosevelt, 41 -- 38, yesterday on the latter's floor.

More than 2,500 physicians, nurses, social workers and public health officials met yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania to consider the toll of social diseases and to map a unified social hygiene program for the city and State. Twenty-eight organizations, constituting the Social Hygiene Council of Greater New York, cooperated in the deliberations.

Closer relationships with manufacturers, a reduction in operating costs and a broadening of their program of aiding independent retailers were urged upon more than 200 dry goods wholesalers by speakers yesterday at the opening session of the ninth annual convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at the Hotel New Yorker.

Illinois politics of both parties and all factions is full of instruction for the sociologist. There are already six Republican aspirants to the Governorship, including the irrepressible LEN SMALL, Governor for two terms and aching for a third. A man of character and intellect and independent judgment, Governor HORNER has earned the dislike of many Democratic politicians.
ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- A bill under which voters would decide next year whether there should be a constitutional convention in 1938 was reported today by the Assembly Judiciary Committee.

Thirteen well-paid officials of the building departments of the various boroughs are to be dropped from their jobs today, James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, announced last night.

What was described as the most important meeting of railroad managements since the conference that resulted in a 10 per cent wage cut in 1932 is to be held in Chicago today, when the Association of American Railroads is to consider a proposal to negotiate with railroad unions an agreement to provide for employes displaced through the elimination of superfluous facilities.

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house the property measuring 100 by 100 feet at 2,263-2,269 University Avenue, just south of Fordham Road, was purchased by a builder from the 2,263 University Avenue Corporation. There are two dwellings on the property, which was sold through Armstrong Brothers, brokers.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- Miss Carol Thorne-Smith, 19 years old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sky-ring Thorne-Smith of 24 Willow Avenue, this village, has been reported missing by her parents and is being sought by police in eight States.

Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title of actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 20, 1934.

MANILA, Jan. 16. -- President Manuel Quezon's campaign to save Philippine natural resources from "exploitation" got under way today when thirty-one of a total of sixty-three oil exploration permits were canceled. Included among those canceled were ten previously granted to the Standard Vacuum Company and twenty-one granted to twelve local companies.

Carmen Salzarulo, 3 years old, of 201 East Tenth Street, was judged the most beautiful brunette and acclaimed queen at the annual Little Sister Beauty Contest at the Boys Club of New York, Avenue A and Tenth Street, yesterday afternoon.

GOODWIN, Ark., Jan. 16 (AP). -- Shattered remnants of the airliner which plunged seventeen persons to death Tuesday night in a nearby swamp were ordered assembled today for a public inquiry by Federal investigators seeking the cause of the accident.
LONDON, Jan. 16. -- Admiral of the Fleet Earl Beatty, Great Britain's greatest living hero of the seas, who will be 65 years old tomorrow, will be placed on the retired list.
The shippers' conference of Greater New York yesterday approved the program of operation of motor trucks which was drafted recently to meet the provisions of the new Federal Motor Vehicle Act.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 16. -- Vigorously attacking President Roosevelt's farm policies in the fourth of his recent speeches against the New Deal, former President Hoover tonight outlined a new farm program of his own, which he said would change the present "economy of scarcity" to one of plenty, and restore our "lost" foreign markets.

The United States Treasury notified yesterday depositary banks throughout the country that on Monday it would withdraw from them $63,720,000 of its balances, of which amount $26,928,400 would be called from banks in the New York Federal Reserve District.
ROME, Jan. 16. -- Rain ceased on the Northern Ethiopian front, and the sun shone brightly. Roads are drying up, and heavy traffic of motor trucks carrying war supplies to the front lines was resumed.

The annual report of the Adams Express Company for 1935, issued yesterday, shows net assets applicable to outstanding securities increased from $25,794,059 to $37,159,894 in the year, after deducting $432,967 preferred and common dividends and giving effect to the retirement of preferred stock at a cost of $488,465.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- After conferring with Congressional leaders and Cabinet aides, President Roosevelt approved the Soil Conservation Act of 1935 as a vehicle to be used, in an amended form, to supersede the AAA.

One of the major obstacles to setting up work relief projects is the "needlessly involved" regulations and procedures of Federal officials, it was said in a report made yesterday before the annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers by Harold M. Lewis, planning consultant of the Regional Plan Association of New York.

HAVANA, Jan. 16. -- Openly charging a fraud in the elections, the newspaper Discusion, Democratic organ, published today an appeal to registered voters who failed to vote in the general elections Jan. 10 to appear at party headquarters all over the island in order to "verify frauds in the voting precincts, since the list of voters carries the names of many who did not vote."

In criticizing Senator Copeland for advocating a subsidy for the shipping industry, A.H. DeGraff in his letter to you failed to take cognizance of one of the first principles for maintaining a merchant marine.

To meet the problem created by increased Federal taxation on holding companies, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, with assets of more than $600,000,000, is merging four of its subsidiaries, and is taking steps to convert its status to that of an operating company, according to an announcement yesterday by Eugene G. Grace, president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP). -- Secretary Roper's business advisory council was reorganized today under the chairmanship of George H. Mead of Dayton, Ohio, president of the Mead Corporation.

May I, as a member of the medical profession for over twenty years, answer the attacks on our profession in THE TIMES as having been made at a luncheon of the American Association for Social Security on Jan. 11? A. Epstein was "bitterly critical" of the opposition of "professional agitation groups" in the medical field to health insurance.

After declaring that he had "never heard of a case tried like this by anybody," Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag dismissed yesterday the city's suit to collect $44.15 for damages to a lamp-post in an automobile accident. Justice Shientag expressed astonishment that the city had failed to have its key witnesses present for the trial, which it was estimated would cost the taxpayers more than $150.

There will be an exhibition and contest in flower arrangements, including miniature gardens and floral displays in antique vases, the afternoon of Jan. 21 at the clubhouse of the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- Heavy snow storms in parts of the West curtailed the receipts of hogs here today, but the effect of the smaller offerings was offset by further weakness in the prices for fresh pork loins. Loins in the local market dropped 1/2 cent to 15 to 17 1/2 cents a pound wholesale, and it was reported the business was the largest in more than a year.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 16. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey has employed Lieutenant Robert W. Hicks, Washington criminologist, to investigate the Lindbergh kidnap-murder case to aid him in deciding the extent of Bruno Richard Hauptmann's guilt, it was learned today by The Baltimore News Post.

A short circuit and fire in the Hell Gate power plant cripples subway trains at the peak of the traffic and plunges New York into darkness from Sixtieth Street to the Harlem River for some six hours. Similar accidents occur at rare intervals in central stations all over the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Bids received on forty-two issues of 4 per cent bonds taken over from the Public Works Administration by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and now offered for public sale, were announced late tonight.

Assailing the spending program of the national and various State administrations, Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin declared last night that a "pay as you go" policy was the only solution to present-day financial and economic problems.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- Federal Judge John P. Barnes today ordered returned to a group of packers and millers more than $7,500,000 of processing taxes, under the Supreme Court decision in the Louisiana Rice Millers case, following invalidation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

The Outdoor Cleanliness Association held its fifth annual meeting and election of officers and directors yesterday afternoon at the Barclay. Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, who presided, was re-elected president for the second year. Reports of the association's work were read by chairmen of sectional committees.

A labor union, two of its officials and five members of a committee appointed to enforce its demands, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for violation of the Anti-Trust Laws in what John Harlan Amen, Special Assistant Attorney General, described as a package-delivery racket that yielded $300,000 a year.
More than three out of five voters in The Literary Digest poll are opposed to the Roosevelt New Deal, according to the final compilation, announced in the current issue of that magazine.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- Charles S. Gelbert, one-time University of Pennsylvania football star and father of "Charley" Gelbert, St. Louis Cardinal shortstop, committed suicide this afternoon in Hahnemann Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Silver acquired by the Treasury Department through Dec. 27 amounted to 835,112,000 ounces, Secretary Morgenthau announced today. These acquisitions dated from the executive proclamation of Dec. 21, 1933, providing for the purchase of newly mined silver in the United States, the Silver Purchase Act of June 19, 1934, and the transfer under the nationalization order of Aug. 9, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- President Roosevelt today nominated William O. Douglas, Sterling Professor of Law at Yale University, as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission to serve out the unexpired term of former Chairman Joseph P. Kennedy, expiring on June 5, 1939.

Except in the case of five passengers who were escorted to lifeboats on his direct command, William F. Warms, master of the ill-fated Morro Castle, issued no order directing any subordinate to see that 313 other passengers were placed in the boats, Warms admitted yesterday in Federal court.
With the coming of Freddie Lindstrom to Brooklyn local baseball critics yesterday were inclined to view the Dodgers' 1936 prospects as having received a considerable boost.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- On the eve of his scheduled fifteen-round bout with Charley Retzlaff tomorrow night in the Chicago Stadium, which is expected to make indoor boxing history, Joe Louis was looking forward to what is to him just another ring encounter with an inevitable result -- another knockout victim.

American women look alike because the average American woman has a horror of looking "different," Miss Ruth Hutton of the Cooper Union Art faculty said yesterday. French women, she continued, avoid "popular" styles, striving for originality even in details.

Bert Connolly stepped into a hero's role last night. The tall Ranger forward made good on a penalty shot against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden to give the revamped New York sextet a 1-to-0 triumph over the Canadian team.

A tacit admission of the existence of an unwritten and unspoken agreement among certain Eastern colleges on athletic relations was made last night at the Biltmore Hotel during the course of the dinner given by the Cornell Club of New York in honor of James Lynah, Cornell, '05, new director of athletics at the Ithaca college.

Frieda Hempel, former Metropolitan Opera star, herself broke the agreement under which August Heckscher, real estate man and philanthropist, was to pay her $15,000 annually, counsel for Mr. Heckscher declared yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.

WISE, Va., Jan. 16 (AP). -- Judge H.A.W. Skeen denied a new trial today to Edith Maxwell, 21-year-old mountain school teacher under a twenty-five-year penitentiary sentence for the first-degree murder of her father.

Cleto Locatelli, Italian welterweight, will box Bobby Pacho, hard-punching Mexican, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Both battlers are eager for a bout with Barney Ross, holder of the world's welterweight title, and the winner will likely get the call to oppose the champion this Summer.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 16. -- Although the government here is suspicious of peace proposals it believes are in preparation, fearing that these proposals may he used to obtain further postponement of consideration of an oil embargo, it remains ready to discuss peace on a reasonable basis.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 16. -- The Catholic Church, making its most outspoken attack upon the government's socialistic education program, in a pastoral letter today forbade members to allow their children to attend socialistic schools.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 17. -- Across 13,000 miles of ocean word reached London by radio last night that Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, might still be alive in the Antarctic wastes of Little America.

Although Lynn Riggs has a good many ideas about the muddle that we have all drifted into, he has not lost his sense of humor and he has not forgotten to write a comedy. He calls it "Russet Mantle" and it was gorgeously acted last evening at the Masque, where it ought to hang its hat for a long time if New Yorkers relish original work.

A committee of the Real Estate Board of New York which is studying the exodus of business firms from this city yesterday informed Charles E. Murphy, who is studying the same problem for the city, that more than a million square feet in buildings in the area from Canal to Fifty-ninth Streets was vacated last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Secretary Morgenthau of late months has declined to express to Congressional committees his views as to the wisdom of fiscal legislation proposed by them or to give an opinion whether the Treasury could stand the strain of suggested appropriations.

WARSAW, Jan. 16. -- Foreign Minister Josef Beck, replying to questions put to him in the course of the debate following his speech before the Foreign Relations Committee of the Sejm declared tonight that the Polish Government was determined to guard Poland's rights and privileges in the Free City of Danzig.

Longmans, Green announce the early publication of a biography of Senator William E. Borah, written by Claudius O. Johnson. Senator Borah cooperated with the author and gave him the use of private papers. The title will be "Borah of Idaho."

In THE TIMES editorial "Imagination Vindicated," there is an error in your reference to the year in which Dr. William Prout made his suggestion of the fundamental part which hydrogen probably plays in the make-up of the other chemical elements. Dr. Prout was born in 1785 and died in 1850; he made the suggestion mentioned in your editorial in 1815, and not in 1915.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- The Danzig Senate's press department announced today that Air Minister Hermann Goering entertained at his hunting lodge, Karin Hall, near Berlin, yesterday both Arthur Greiset, President of the Danzig Senate, and Josef Lipski, Polish Ambassador to Berlin.

I read with great interest Solomon Altman's letter in THE TIMES. Like Mr. Altman, I find myself confronted with the task of selecting a target real and tangible enough to shoot my vote at this coming November. Although I am four years Mr. Altman's senior, and have voted in previous years, I too have realized his feeling of despair.

Preliminary to a proposed Statewide study of flood control, the New York State Planning Council at a meeting here yesterday authorized a survey of the water supply, pollution and soil erosion in the Mohawk Valley drainage basin.

Receipts from the city's 2 per cent sales tax, the main support of its pay-as-you-spend relief policy, were increased to $41,275,068.08 for 1935 yesterday with the tabulation of last-minute mail payments which totaled $4,173,881.07.
ROME, Jan. 16. -- An Italian communique said today the army on the Somaliland border achieved "complete success" in an advance of more than forty miles along the entire front.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP). -- Racing commissioners from seventeen States today closed turf employment to all persons ever convicted of possessing or using narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Support of women for this country's merchant marine, particularly through direct subsidy for competition with foreign craft on equal terms, as proposed in pending legislation, was urged tonight upon the board of directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

TIENTSIN, China, Jan. 16 (AP). -- North China's dominant war lords were told by Japanese militarists today that they must stop teaching their soldiers anti-Japanese doctrines or suffer the consequences.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, announced today a gift of $1,000,000 to the university from the Spelman Fund of New York, for the erection and maintenance of a national headquarters for the seventeen public administration organizations which have been operating here for five years.
