George Washington High School's last-minute 19-17 victory over the Manhattan College freshmen and the 39-15 triumph of the undefeated St. John's freshmen over St. Michael's High of Brooklyn featured the basketball contests involving New York City scholastic quintets yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The new proposal of agricultural experts to make the relatively obscure Soil Conservation Act of 1935 the vehicle for carrying forward, at least for the present, the principles of the invalidated Agricultural Adjustment Act was approved today by President Roosevelt and Congressional leaders at a White House conference.

Noteworthy among the addresses at the dinner in honor of the "University in Exile" Wednesday night was that of Mr. HAMILTON FISH ARMSTRONG. Editor of Foreign Affairs and for years a close student of international subjects, he confessed himself hampered and almost baffled by recent changes in the political life of Europe.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- Prices of wheat moved erratically within a range of about a cent today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Scattered selling caused a moderate recession soon after the opening, but the close was at the top at net gains of 3/8 to 5/8 cent.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- A report that has appeared in the press abroad that the Rev. Martin Niemoeller and his associates in the Reich Brotherhood Council, the Confessional Protestant Church's central organization, expelled Bishop August Marahrens from his post as head of the so-called temporary Reich church government is not correct.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- France has warned Germany in an informal fashion against any attempt to disregard her obligations under the Locarno Treaty, which guarantees the territorial status quo in the west, including the existence of the demilitarized zone in the Rhineland established in the Treaty of Versailles.
ANOTHER fearless fellow is about to hop into a ring with Shufflin' Joe Louis, the dealer in dynamite. This time it is Charley Retzlaff, who is strong of hand and weak of chin.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Albert Fish, 65 years old, of 55 East 128th Street, Manhattan, a housepainter who murdered Grace Budd, 6, after attacking her in a Westchester farmhouse in 1928, was put to death tonight in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 16 (AP). -- The Ethiopian Government said today a Red Cross unit led by a Briton was destroyed in an Italian air raid and fourteen natives were killed.

The appointment yesterday by Mr. Roosevelt of William O. Douglas to fill the vacant fifth position on the Securities and Exchange Commission came somewhat as a surprise to Wall Street where the former Yale professor is relatively unknown.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- Emperor Hallie Selassie of Ethiopia in an interview with a correspondent of the official German news agency, published here, asserts that the Italians will be unable to make any major advances on the northern front for several months because of the destruction of their roads by the rains.

A dozen New York women, who are the holders of political offices in various divisions of either the city or State government, spoke last night at the Women's City Club of New York, 22 Park Avenue, on two questions relating to the success of women in government.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16. -- The racing season at Hialeah Park opened this afternoon, attracting colonists from many Florida resorts. With Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club, at the races were Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d, Captain Cecil Boyd Rochfort of Newmarket, England, and Frank Carter of Chantilly, France.
With twenty teams in the draw, the fifth annual doubles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association got under way yesterday on the courts of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

DUBLIN, Jan. 16. -- The Irish Free State Senate concluded what will probably be its last sitting late tonight, when by 30 to 20 votes it refused to pass the Senate Abolition Bill unless the government introduced proposals for a new second chamber.

The Salle d'Armes Vince team retained the national junior saber championship by winning the annual competition for the Stoll Cup last night at the New York A. C. In the final round the champions turned back the New York A.C., 5 to 3.

Leading savings banks and insurance companies are arranging to confer soon to decide on action to be taken as a result of the announcement of a plan of reorganization for the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway made on Monday by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Proposals made by the Van Sweringen interests are largely followed in the new project.

Mayor La Guardia, in an address yesterday at the opening of the new magistrates' felony court in the Criminal Courts Building, in which felony prisoners in Manhattan henceforth will get their first arraignment, announced that the police had shifted the old "deadline" for crooks from the south side of Fulton Street to the borderline of the entire city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Creation of a Roosevelt organization to prevent the sudden calling of a Presidential primary in Georgia was agreed upon in a conference at the White House today between members of the State delegation and President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Defenders of the memory of Woodrow Wilson today hurled charges of animus and prejudice against members of the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee, with sharp criticism of Senator Nye, committee chairman, resounding on the floor of the Senate as well as in the committee hearing room.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- The New York State Aviation Association opened its program at a meeting here today to "promote and encourage" aviation in the State, after electing Max J. Pollet of Albany its first president.

Twenty-five years ago possession of live game birds in captivity was illegal in every State in the Union. The felony was compounded if a man attempted to breed birds for commercial purposes. Any one so inclined ran the risk of a long sojourn in the local bastille.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 16. -- Ras Seyoum, Ethiopian northern commander, has reported by radio to the Emperor that his troops had moved out of Tembien Province, the whole of which they had reoccupied, into Gheralta, a wild region immediately north of Makale.

The newspapers of the country were called one of the most powerful forces combating crime yesterday by H.B. LeQuatte, president of the Advertising Club of New York, in an address before the eighth annual meeting of the Federal Grand Jury Association at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Proof of the precocity of New York City's public school children and their progressive development over a period of years was given yesterday in the first installment of the annual report of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
LINCOLN, Jan. 16. -- Ex-President Hoover's address on the agricultural policies of the New Deal here tonight was as follows:

Directors of the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday declared an extra dividend of 25 cents and the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share. In the preceding quarter a similar extra dividend was declared.

The presidents and chancellors of 400 American colleges assembled yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel, with "loyalty oath bills as the most important matter on their minds today," according to Dr. Henry M. Wriston.

TOKYO, Jan. 16. -- An unexpected note in official statements today on Japanese naval policy was the comment by War Minister Koshiyuki Kawashima that the end of restrictions on Pacific fortifications would increase the army's responsibilities for national defense.

Detailed proposals for changes in the football rules, including abolishment of the point after touchdown, substitution of a scoring system allowing one point for each first down and an overtime period to break ties, were put forward yesterday on behalf of the Eastern Association of Football Officials.

With final trading in the January position a week from today, houses doing government business continued yesterday to release contracts on the Cotton Exchange here and the list ended with losses of 5 to 8 points.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- The withdrawal of Japan from the London naval parley surprises neither German official quarters nor naval observers, and present comment is confined to speculating on whether the incident presages a race in armaments among the three big naval powers.

Seven yachtsmen will build into the new one-design class of racing and cruising boats which the New York Yacht Club is sponsoring, it was announced last night by Robert N. Bavier following a meeting at the New York Yacht Club.
TOKYO, Jan. 16. -- The United States and Great Britain were pictured today in Japanese newspaper editorials on the naval conference as villains in an international melodrama.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Wholesale prices declined slightly during the week ended on Jan. 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average, declined to 80.5 from 80.9 on Jan. 4. A year ago it was 78.6.

Further losses in the commodities affected by the Supreme Court decision invalidating the AAA caused a loss of 0.8 point in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices, the index declining to 128.2 on Tuesday, from 129 the Tuesday before.

Sir Thomas Beecham began his third and final week as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night. The composers were a trio of British contemporaries and Mozart. The English works were Vaughan Williams's "Norfolk Rhapsody" No. 1, in E minor, Arnold Bax's Third symphony and the suite from Lord Berners's "Triumph of Neptune," and Mozart was represented by the E flat major symphony (K. 543).

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Jan. 16 (AP). -- All objections to indictments found against eighty-six defendants in New York State's inquiry into alleged fake racetrack tipster services were overruled today by Supreme Court Justice O. Byron Brewster, who held the indictments valid and declared that dates for the trials would be set Feb. 3.

Initial steps toward the organization of a city-wide "taxpayers' party" for the protection of the interests of property owners throughout the city were taken last night at a meeting at the Paramount Hotel of delegates from twenty-two taxpayers' organizations banded together as the Council of Real Estate Associations of Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP). -- Former President Herbert Hoover told friends over the telephone tonight that the Columbia Broadcasting System's handling of his speech from Lincoln, Neb., was entirely satisfactory.

The broadening interest in real estate on Long Island which has been fostered by plans for the World's Fair on the Flushing meadows site was emphasized yesterday in reports of several sales of lots and acreage to operators and builders.

With price levels reported "identical or slightly lower" and costs 15 to 20 per cent higher, the operating margins remaining for manufacturers of coats and suits serving catalogue houses are smaller than those of last Spring, it was declared at a meeting yesterday at the Garment Center Capitol Club.
Three alleged loan sharks were arrested at 7 o'clock yesterday morning at their homes by detectives acting on orders of Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Lincoln Day will be made the occasion for the real opening of the Republican campaign, with speeches by former President Hoover and other leaders of the party in the major cities. Dinners will be held in the smaller cities and it is estimated by Chairman Fletcher that at least 3,000 gatherings of Republicans will meet on Feb. 12 to honor Lincoln and to discuss the issues of today.

Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities throughout the nation for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., amounted to $5,661,717,000, against $5,696,360,000 a year ago. This represents a decrease of 0.6 per cent and compares with a gain of 25.0 per cent in the preceding week.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- Creation of privately owned and publicly regulated mortgage banks in an effort to curb the evils that caused losses of millions of dollars in guaranteed mortgage certificates was recommended today by the State Mortgage Commission in a report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- A cheerful air prevailed today on the London Stock Exchange, with interest confined to the speculative sections, principally to oil, rubber and industrial issues. British funds were dull as a result of the Australian loan.

MIAMI, Jan. 16. -- When the quarterly meeting here of the Executive Council of the A.F. of L. adjourns organized labor will ask Congress to enact a resolution providing for a thorough investigation and analysis of "technological unemployment," President Green said today.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- Prices on the Boerse closed today unchanged or slightly weaker after having shown firmness at the opening. No real tendency developed and the market was as usual more or less inactive.

The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland, arriving today from Hamburg and channel ports, has among her passengers Gertrude Kappel and Karin Branzell, opera singers, who are returning for the season of the Metropolitan Opera. Others on the liner are Colonel W. Stewart-Roddie, Lew Burston, N. Sabatino, Mrs. Johanna Brown, Mrs. Barbara Narr and Mr. and Mrs. Adam Vogel.

Member-bank reserve balances rose $114,000,000 to $5,859,000,000 and the excess of these reserves over legal requirements increased $90,000,000 to $3,090,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve reports issued yesterday.

Gertrud Wettergren took the role of Carmen for the first time in America last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. She gave the part exceptional distinction. She sang like a true musician, and she conveyed what the composer and librettist intended by means of finesse rather than the exaggerations which have been practiced by nearly all prima donnas who have taken this role of late years.

TRENTON, Jan. 16. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman granted today to Bruno Richard Hauptmann a reprieve until Feb. 15, after a last-minute effort to obtain a confession from the convicted murderer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. through his wife.
Investment buying of multi-family buildings featured realty activity in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday.

This week's issue of The Literary Digest contains a final summary of the answers to its questions about the New Deal. That they were fair questions cannot be disputed. The same ones were asked of nearly the same people about a year and a half ago, and then their vote was 61 per cent in favor of the New Deal.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- An official messenger delivered tonight to Admiral Osami Nagano of Japan a letter from Viscount Monsell, chairman of the first committee of the Naval Conference, expressing "real regret" that Japan had decided to withdraw from the conference.

PARIS, Jan. 16. -- Premier Pierre Laval emerged victorious today from one of those titanic teapot tempests that have become almost as regular as rain. All last night and all this morning the tempest raged -- among the Radical Socialists.

MONTREAL, Jan. 16. -- The Montreal Canadiens tumbled back into the cellar of the National Hockey League's international group tonight under the weight of a crushing 8-3 defeat by the New York Americans in the biggest scoring outburst seen here this season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Secretary Ickes admitted today that he was under a "false impression" when he said in a speech at Rochester that three laws signed by President Hoover were invalidated by the Supreme Court.

There will be no first-night conflict, after all, between the premieres of "The Puritan" and "The Illustrators' Show," both of which had been scheduled to open next Monday evening. "The Puritan" will have that night to itself, Mr. Weatherly having decided yesterday to postpone his "Illustrators' Show" to Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 15, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,485,000,000, an increase of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $21,000,00 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

ABOARD THE WYATT EARP, in the Antarctic, Friday, Jan. 17. -- That Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, are alive and well at Little America was the heart-quickening message flashed from the wireless of the Royal Research Society ship Discovery II to the Wyatt Earp, Ellsworth's supply ship, today.

This city made a creditable record in street and highway safety last year. Deaths dropped 6 per cent, injuries 21 per cent. It would be difficult to distribute exactly the praise for this improvement. The police are entitled to a large share of it for their persistent safety campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP). -- The administration balked today at a move in the House Foreign Affairs Committee to exempt Italy and Ethiopia from operations of the proposed permanent neutrality law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Senator Connally stirred the Senate today with a defense of Woodrow Wilson as the result of published accounts of Senator Nye's remarks at the Munitions Committee hearing yesterday that referred to President Wilson.

AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 16. -- One of the most radical changes in the policy of Amherst College since the inauguration of President Stanley King was announced today, when Dean C. Scott Porter stated that all requirements regarding student attendance at classes would be withdrawn beginning Feb. 10 and that each undergraduate would be placed on a system of unlimited cuts.
Auctioneers offered five properties in Manhattan and three in the Bronx at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. All eight parcels were bought in by the plaintiffs. One scheduled sale was adjourned.

MEDFIELD, Mass., Jan. 16. -- Failure of an all-day searching party of more than 1,000 to find a trace of Dale Tibbetts, 3 years old, within an area of two square miles around his home here, led the State police tonight to broadcast his description as the possible victim of a kidnapping.

Behind Grand Central Palace doors that will remain closed until 7 o'clock tonight, a flotilla of motor-driven pleasure yachts for three days has been getting into formation and reaching the dry-land moorings for the official preview.

PIRAEUS, Greece, Jan. 16. -- Despite Communist disapproval of the Italian war against Ethiopia as Fascist imperialism, Russian Governmental monopolies continue to sell Italy secondary supplies of war, virtually no change having been made by sanctions in Soviet-Italian trade through the Black Sea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained tonight in honor of the diplomatic corps with a State dinner to which were invited the chiefs of mission of the fifty-four countries represented in Washington. A musicale afterward in the East Room was attended by 300 additional guests.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16. -- Hal Price Headley's giant 4-year-old, the aptly named Whopper, today carried his tremendous frame and 122 pounds through the stretch with sweeping strides to win the Hialeah Park Inaugural Handicap. A colorful crowd of more than 15,000 fans attended as the Miami Jockey Club's forty-six-day meeting opened.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the formation of a new member firm, the transfer of a membership in the Exchange and the proposed transfer of others.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- Anthony Eden will make his first speech since becoming Foreign Secretary tomorrow night in his parliamentary constituency in Warwick. Colleagues who know what he is going to say remark that it will be a good speech but not epoch-making.

Asserting that opponents of the New Deal policies include many who believe that President Roosevelt has not gone far enough, Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, warned business men last night that they must produce a "definite and understandable plan for mass prosperity," to make the people forget about Father Coughlin and the Townsend plan.

A new method for preparing vaccine against deadly bacteria, which promises to open up an entirely new field in immunity against diseases for which so far no vaccine exists, is announced in a preliminary report in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (AP). -- The seeded list failed to get by the first round of the national professional squash racquets championships intact today as young Al Ramsay of Cleveland provided the initial fireworks by upsetting Tom Iannicelli, national pro squash tennis titleholder from Newark, N.J.

Final assurance that there will be no drastic cuts in the WPA program in this city was given yesterday when Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, announced that the Federal Government has allotted another $40,000,000 to the WPA in New York. This will make possible continuance of the work without curtailment of forces until the end of April.

More than 1,000 members of the Socialist party met last night at Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, and with only five dissenting votes approved a resolution repudiating the action of the National Executive Committee of the party suspending the charter of the New York State organization.

The Elizabeth Town and Country Club, winner in the New Jersey division, defeated Bronxville, champion of Westchester, yesterday in the women's metropolitan intermediate squash racquets interclub tournament on the courts of the Junior League.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Dramatically today the Supreme Court refused the plea of Bruno Richard Hauptmann to save him from the electric chair.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 16. -- Criticizing Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, for his recent attack upon American newspapers, Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, tonight denied that newspapers were "usually owned and controlled" by "special interests."

Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana declared on his return from the Orient yesterday that the power of the Supreme Court might have to be curtailed, and urged that immediate steps be taken to settle the question one way or another.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- Indications are piling up that British rearmament will be on a much wider scale than was intimated by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and his Cabinet colleagues in their recent electoral campaign speeches.
PARIS, Jan. 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Reports of re-acquired stock filed monthly with the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that in December S.S. Kresge, chairman of the board of the S.S. Kresge Company, paid the company $2,000,000 for the release of 87,500 shares of its stock carried in his name but covered by an assignment to the company.

As the city's electric light and power system was gradually restored almost to normal yesterday, five investigations were begun into the failure Wednesday of the New York Edison Company's alternating current system in Manhattan north of Fifty-ninth Street, in the Bronx and in Westchester.

The share market displayed a steadier tone yesterday than on the day before, but aside from sporadic speculative flurries trading was comparatively uninteresting. The turnover was still above 3,000,000 shares on the Stock Exchange but was about 500,000 smaller than on Wednesday.

Obviously, it is to be a campaign of slogans. Mr. FARLEY has provided the Democratic leitmotif in Keep Out the Gangsters, upon which we must be prepared for numerous variations. Republicans are evidently going to do a great deal with Liberty at the Crossroads.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a sharp rise for the week ended Jan. 11, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase was 10 per cent over the same week of 1935, as compared with a gain of 5 per cent for the week ended Jan. 4.

The Gulf States Steel Company reported yesterday for the final quarter of 1935 a net profit of $119,350 after interest, depreciation, taxes and other charges. This is equal after quarterly dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock on which there is an accumulation of unpaid dividends to 43 cents a share on 197,500 no-par shares of common stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- A bill to establish a select House committee to study the subject of housing was introduced today by Representative Maverick of Texas.

Former Attorney General OTTINGER went to Kansas, saw Governor LANDON, conquered him. He persuaded or forced the Governor to confess that he would take the Republican nomination for President if it should be offered to him. Thus the doubt that must have been gnawing millions of anxious bosoms torments no more.

After promising an announcement concerning crime yesterday that would "shock the town," Mayor La Guardia disclosed that he had found fifty-four telephones with false listings in this city, which were used by racing bettors to place bets in New Jersey, Westchester and Nassau County.

Ten days have passed since AAA was declared by the Supreme Court to be unconstitutional, and the debate over a substitute for it is still in progress. From Washington it is reported that a decision was reached yesterday at a White House conference to use the existing Soil Conservation Act as the basis for a temporary program.
Another match between two famous squash tennis rivals will be staged this evening as a semi-final contest in the Clyde Martin Memorial tourney at the Yale Club.
The Elizabeth Town and Country Club won the secondary league intersectional tournament of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday.

Clarence Hathaway, editor of The Daily Worker, official publication of the Communist party in this city, was questioned yesterday in the District Attorney's office in an investigation of charges that the Criminal Anarchy Law had been violated in pamphlets issued by the Workers Library, an alleged adjunct of the newspaper.

Referring to your editorial "A Manifest Injustice," there are further inequitable provisions of unemployment insurance enactments that will tend to discredit the aims of social security legislation if they are not remedied by amendments.
BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- The Boerse was very quiet today, but showed scattered evidence of increased firmness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The Kingdom of Italy has filed an application on Form 18 of the Securities and Exchange Commission for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $79,275,400 of its external loan sinking fund 7 per cent gold bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1925, and due on Dec. 1, 1951.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 17. -- Dr. Alexander O. Gettler, toxicologist in the office of the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, testified today in the trial of Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, 38 years old, and Everett R. Applegate, 36, both of Baldwin, L.I., who are charged jointly with the poison murder last September of Applegate's wife, Ada.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Thirty-eight issues of bonds offered for sale yesterday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were awarded today to the highest bidders. The high bidders were listed in THE NEW TORE TIMES today.

In his message to the Legislature, Governor Lehman said that "recent events have destroyed public confidence" in title insurance and that "the Torrens System which was created by the Legislature more than twenty-five years ago has not served the purpose of its sponsors, but to make it attractive the statute must be made less cumbersome and more workable."

Firmness in United States Government bonds and highly selective buying in the domestic corporation list were features in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The market for Federal obligations, while not particularly active, completely ignored the announcement of important changes in the personnel of the Treasury Department, and a good demand carried prices up from 1-32 to 8-32 point on the day.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 17. -- One man was killed and four women injured when an automobile plowed through a crowd of pedestrians at Kentucky and Atlantic Avenues, in the heart of a business district here, this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP). -- Formal approval of the administration's farm program plans was voiced unanimously tonight by the National Agricultural Conference as leaders studied the possibility of impounding tariff receipts for necessary revenues.

Henry E. Cabaud, executive vice president of the Ward Line, operator of the Morro Castle which burned off Asbury Park Sept. 8, 1934, with a loss of 134 lives, testified yesterday in Federal Court at his trial for criminal negligence.

Because a properly worded resolution had been inadvertently omitted from its calendar the Board of Estimate found itself blocked yesterday from making several long-awaited changes to seven Brooklyn Bus Corporation routes in Brooklyn.

To prevent undue land speculation and irregular building construction in the Flushing Meadows area which the city proposes to use as the site for the 1939 World's Fair, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens laid before the Board of Estimate yesterday a resolution designed to restrict the zoning of land adjacent to the site.

Those upon whose youth young Mr. KIPLING'S Tales, published here in pirated paper editions, shone like a sudden, splendid star can hardly write of him dispassionately. They have followed the star too long. The spell of the enchanter still holds them; nor do they wish to be released.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Four Italian airmen whose bombing plane was forced down in Anglo-Egyptian Sudan Wednesday were interned yesterday under the neutrality rules of The Hague convention of 1923, it was officially announced here today.
PARIS, Jan. 17. -- The need for a Franco-American trade treaty is greater than ever, says a report made tonight to the annual meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce by its importation committee.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 18.--Rudyard Kipling, one of Britain's greatest men of letters, died at 12:10 o'clock this morning, five days after he had undergone an emergency operation for a perforated stomach ulcer. He was 70 years old.

The Continental Steel Corporation reports for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30 a net income of $1,003,577. This equals $5 a share on 200,590 shares of common stock after present financing and allowing for estimated dividend requirements on the preferred shares. Gross sales were $14,518,085.

Twenty thousand New Yorkers had an out-of-season Summertime thrill for three and one-half hours last night. A sample panorama of their June, July and August vacationing, five months before it is due, was unfolded for them on three exhibition floors of the Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The question whether control of world-wide radio-telegraph service would pass out of the hands of the United States if the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, Inc., were permitted to duplicate in many instances the foreign services of RCA Communications, Inc., was brought before the Federal Communications Commission today by RCA.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The ad ministration will wage a vigorous fight to prevent Governor Talmadge, who is heading a movement in the South against the renomination of President Roosevelt, from winning for himself the Georgia delegates to the Democratic National Convention.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 18. -- Major Gen. Lionel Charles Dunsterville, original of Rudyard Kipling's character "Stalky," eulogized the author today at Crowborough, Sussex.

The President's statement yesterday that only slight changes in the Soil Conservation Act passed by the last Congress would be necessary to continue crop control stimulated prices on the Cotton Exchange, quotations advancing 7 to 15 points, the greatest gain being in the distant months, in which selling pressure had been most severe recently.

Two men, believed by the police to be members of a syndicate of bookmakers with headquarters in New Jersey, were arrested with thirty-nine other men shortly after 3 P.M. yesterday in a raid on the sixth floor of 35 West Thirty-first Street.
The 129th anniversary of the birth of Robert E. Lee was celebrated by thirty-one Southern societies of New York City and vicinity at the Hotel Pierre last night.

The future of American shipping lies in the development of commerce between the United States and the republics and islands lying to the south, according to Charles H.C. Pearsall, president of the Propeller Club of the United States and vice president of the Colombian Steamship Company.
Miss Edythe Pearson of Short Hills, won the secondary league championship of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday.

Women were urged last night by State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton to help in the campaign for the election of a Republican President. Mr. Eaton spoke at the annual dinner of the State Republican Educational League at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. He outlined ways in which women could aid in the election of a Republican President.

Ten religious, charitable, educational and social institutions will receive bequests totaling $145,000 in the will of Dr. George Dewar Cochran, artist and Colonial descendant, which was filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday. The will also provided trusts and cash bequests for a number of employes and bequeathed the residuary estate among grandnieces and grandnephews.

Limiting the opposition to three field goals, the undefeated Long Island University five crushed La Salle College, 49 -- 9, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court last night. It was the fifteenth straight triumph this season for the Blackbirds, who have won twenty-two in a row, including last year's closing run.

Swinging sharply back into action just when it looked as though his rival pilots had him definitely blocked in the baseball trading mart, Manager Joe McCarthy bobbed up with a broad smile late yesterday afternoon as he announced the completion of a four-player deal with the Washington Senators.

Sweeping through all matches in straight games, the Harvard Club team last night shut out the visiting Princeton players, 5 -- 0, and moved into a tie for first place with the Columbia University club in the Class B division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

Marshall MacLeod of the Princeton Club and Donald J. Nightingale of the University Club, fourth seeded team, reached the quarter-final round of the doubles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night on the courts of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

The price of silver in New York, which is controlled by the United States Treasury, was reduced 3 cents further yesterday to 45 3/4 cents an ounce, the lowest quotation since July 20, 1934. The decline followed a drop of 7/8d in London to 19d an ounce, the lowest London quotation since May 5, 1934, and equivalent, in terms of New York silver, to about 42.43 cents an ounce.

Magistrate Nathan D. Perlman, presiding for the second day in the new magistrates' felony court in the Criminal Courts Building, tabooed yesterday the favorite police form of "short affidavits" as complaints in felony cases.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- One of the bitterest personal attacks heard in the Senate in recent years was loosed today by Senator Glass against Senator Nye, chairman of the Munitions Investigation Committee, for his recent assertion, repeated today on the floor, that President Wilson and former Secretary of State Lansing "falsified" as to their knowledge of wartime secret treaties.

Superseding indictments were returned yesterday by the special grand jury in Brooklyn against three of the four men whom the regular November grand jury accused of murder in the first degree in connection with the beating and strangling of Samuel Drukman in a garage at 225 Moore Street the night of March 3 last.

A meeting of the Teachers Union on "How to Meet the Challenge of Fascism" attracted so many school teachers to Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Sixteenth Street, at 8 o'clock last night, that after a few minutes the auditorium and galleries were filled and policemen had to be posted at the doors to prevent more persons from entering.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (AP). -- John Masefield, Poet Laureate of England, paid tribute to the memory of Rudyard Kipling tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- With Mrs. Roosevelt as honor guest and the wives of half a dozen diplomatic representatives of foreign countries present as bearers of messages from their homelands, the directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs tonight celebrated with an "international dinner" the determined "will to peace" of club women the world over.

Application for membership in the American Retail Federation has been made by the Massachusetts Council of Retail Merchants, following a unanimous vote of its board of directors, it was announced yesterday. In a letter to Colonel C.O. Sherrill, president of the federation, by Richard M. Thompson, head of the council, the membership of the latter body was given as 1,500 merchants in all lines of retailing, a majority of whom operate small stores.

Six members of the socially prominent younger set joined with professional models yesterday in a display of the latest wardrobe for Southern climes, and staged a tricycle race in which a debutante was declared the winner at a Bermuda fashion show in the store of Oppenheim Collins, 33 West Thirty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- A year ago a marine ambulance crashed into a jinrikisha in Shanghai and as a result President Roosevelt asked the House today to pay a $500 claim.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- Wheat fluctuated slowly within a range of around 5/8 cent on the Chicago Board of Trade today, with May contracts somewhat firmer, while more snow over parts of the West and Southwest led to a little preessure on new-crop months.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 17 (AP). -- Governor Preston Delano of the Home Loan Bank System said today that "it is not at all certain" that protection can be provided "against a repetition of the debacle of 1929."

Denying Senator Nye's statement on the floor of the Senate yesterday that members of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co. passed notes among themselves predicting an answer attacking the munitions committee, the firm sent the following telegram to the North Dakota Senator:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- High praise of President Wilson was offered today by Secretary Hull and Joseph P. Tumulty, who was secretary to the late President, in connection with the controversy over his attitude before we entered the World War.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- Nine persons were convicted and eleven acquitted when after two years of political discord which have shaken the foundations of the French Republic a verdict finally was delivered today in the Stavisky case.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- A prediction that the forces of recovery would continue "at least during the year 1936, in ascendancy over the offsetting depressing influence of political action," was made tonight by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation.
New financing scheduled for next week by sixty-two municipalities and one State totals only $11,071,715. The revised total for this week was $44,836,561.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- T. Jefferson Coolidge, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, sent his resignation to President Roosevelt today, because, his friends said, he felt that he could not give 100 per cent support to the administration, and disapproved the continuation of an emergency spending policy by the government at a time when business was showing signs of improvement.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 18.--A bulletin regarding the health of King George V caused anxiety here last night when it was broadcast. It was issued from Sandringham, the King's present residence, as follows:...

Three additional arrests in the State's drive on alleged fake racetrack tipster services were made yesterday by detectives assigned to the Anti-Racket Bureau of the Attorney General's office. Of eighty-six persons indicted last Fall in Saratoga County, twent-three have now been apprehended, Chief Investigator Thomas F. Ward Jr. said.

Prices generally were firmer in the local commodity futures markets yesterday. The trading was active. Losses appeared in hides, rubber and the minor metals. On the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, lard, cotton and wool tops were firm, while eggs, tin and rubber eased.

While there was a continuance of the gain in retail sales this week, it was superseded by the surge in wholesale distribution, as buyers assembled Spring requirements and released a steady flow of reorders to freshen current stocks, according to the survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Martin Mooney, the newspaper reporter who last Spring refused to reveal to the New York County grand jury the source of articles he had written on the policy racket for The New York American, yesterday began to serve the thirty-day jail term imposed in General Sessions for contempt of court.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- The memory of Benjamin Franklin was honored today, his anniversary, by a series of events in Philadelphia, including a service in Old Christ Church, where Colonel C.R. Day, chief of staff of the Seventy-ninth Division, read a message from President Roosevelt declaring that Franklin's life was "an inspiration to every American citizen."

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- The Reichs-bank statement for the week ended Jan. 15 revealed today that during that period Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the bank, used 6,000,000 marks of Germany's slender gold supply to buy foreign foodstuffs, especially fats, in order to ease the food shortage in Germany.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The tenure of control by the Midamerica Corporation of the Cleveland Railways Company has been extended for at least three years as a result of an agreement effected with stockholders of the railways.

Rudyard Kipling was beyond question one of the most fabulous figures of his generation. In a field for which he was uniquely and opulently endowed. Kipling produced an amazing series of masterpieces in both poetry and prose.

An old question of policy is raised in the current discussion of plans for the 1939 World's Fair. These plans will involve the reclamation of a considerable area in the Flushing and Astoria sections, a part of which at least will be used for residential and business purposes.

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, disclaimed yesterday knowledge of the details of the transaction whereby S.W. Straus Co., Inc., deposited securities now valued at $200,000 with his bank as additional collateral on a defaulted loan of $5,146,351, which the bank was carrying for the Straus Investing Corporation.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17. -- Secession from the American Federation of Labor was threatened today by twenty-one local unions comprising 30,000 radio workers if the federation does not grant them a charter to form a national union on an industrial basis.
LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were irregular today as a result of profit-taking. British funds were weaker again.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the United Stales District Court, Brooklyn, yesterday reserved decision on an application of Charles H. Tuttle, counsel for the trustees in reorganization proceedings of the defunct Nassau-Suffolk Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, for permission to pay $220,827 to holders of bonds and mortgage-participation certificates issued by the company.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- The Republicans in the Legislature made a formal declaration of war against Governor Lehman and the Democrats today as they fixed the dates for their own public hearings on the budget and the Lehman tax program.

ITHACA, Jan. 17. -- A fear that despotism would displace the Constitution was shown by Benjamin Franklin in the draft of his last speech at the Constitutional Convention of 1787, the manuscript of which is part of the Jared Sparks collection in Cornell University library.

Among the most popular of the scores of phrases by Rudyard Kipling that became familiar in every-day conversation -- often without the speakers knowing who had originated them ana often in corrupted form -- were the following:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The Department of Justice has never approved the code drawn up by the Sugar Institute, the government asserted today in replying to the institute's recent charge that whereas one Attorney General sanctioned the proposal, the organization was haled into court by a later Attorney General for having adopted the scheme.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Following a prediction of Senator Harrison that whether the Bond Bonus Bill was signed by the President or not, it would become law, the Senate tonight unanimously agreed to limit debate of each Senator to fifteen minutes after 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, in the hope of passing the measure before adjournment.

Channing Lefebvre and his Golden Hill Chorus -- of approximately 150 female voices -- made their second annual appearance last night in a recital at Carnegie Hall. It was a large and delighted audience which greeted conductor, chorus and soloist, who gave a well-balanced program.

Seven Manhattan properties and two in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The Manhattan parcels included an eleven-story building at 11-13 West Thirty-second Street and an adjoining five-story structure. The results were as follows:

The bad impression created by Governor HOFFMAN in reprieving HAUPTMANN is largely due to the fact that it seems to be an act done in the dark. At least the Governor has left the public in the dark. He has given no good and sufficient reasons for delaying the execution of a man convicted of murder.
Bobby Pacho, busy Mexican welterweight from California, scored an eight-round knockout victory over Cleto Locatelli of Italy in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Here is a transcript of Senator Glass's Speech in the Senate today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The United States will not intervene in one "European" war in which millions have died, even though it is being fought here. The war involved is one against termites at the Finnish legation.

Federal Judge William Bondy reserved decision yesterday on the application of The Associated Press for a declaratory judgment holding the National Labor Relations Act unconstitutional, and for a preliminary injunction restraining Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, New York director of the National Labor Relations Board, and the American Newspaper Guild from interfering with its business.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
The Associated Dry Goods Corporation has declared a dividend of $3 a share on the $6 first preferred stock. Dividends on this stock are in arrears. The company paid a similar dividend on Dec. 2.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Anthony Eden's maiden speech as Foreign Secretary, delivered tonight at a dinner of the Engineering Employers Association in his constituency of Warwick, contains not a single syllable that will disturb Paris or Rome or bring any ray of hope to Addis Ababa.
Apartment house and loft deals featured the realty trading in Manhattan and the Bronx reported yesterday.

The Metropolitan laid aside its customary preoccupation with grim lyric tragedy for opera in a lighter vein last night when Puccini's "La Rondine" was restored to the repertoire. It was a change that did the dignified house no harm; the audience, in fact, responded to the revival with evident pleasure and the company behaved as if it were out on a lark.

The pulse quickened, cares vanished, as the eye fell on headlines which announced that LINCOLN ELLSWORTH and his pilot, HERBERT HOLLICK-KENYON, unheard of since Nov. 23, when they left Dundee Island for a flight across the south polar regions, were safe in Little America.

I was very much interested in Mr. Lyons's statement as published on Jan. 2 in regard to "leeches" in the Home Relief Bureau. I agree with Mr. Lyons that leeches should be eliminated from all branches of our city service. What I take issue with is Mr. Lyons's definition.

John L. Sundean, 61 years old, a retired lawyer of 291 West Fourth Street, pleaded not guilty yesterday in the new magistrate's felony court to the theft last Monday night of $300 collected at a mass meeting organized for the defense of Bruno Richard Hauptmann.

The Brooklyn Cathedral Prep quintet gained a firmer hold on first place in the race for the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. title by routing St. Francis Prep, defending champion, 34 -- 18, at home yesterday. The victory was the sixth in six tourney starts for Cathedral.

Since there are those today who would have us believe that Woodrow Wilson, achieved a long-nourished ambition when he led this country to war against Germany, it may be useful to recall a few of the things that were said of him during the 1916 campaign and earlier.

Plans for two large apartment houses, one to go up on upper Broadway, Manhattan, and the other on Walton Avenue, in the Bronx, were filed yesterday. The combined estimated cost of the two buildings was $710,000.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 17. -Complimenting Mr. and Mrs. David K.E. Bruce, their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan Jr. entertained this afternoon with a party at Oheka.
SO that's why Bill Crowley wore that red band across his cap when he was steaming about the Autumn gridirons in pursuit of his umpirical duties! Came the Revolution! Comrade Crowley in the van!

I have just received a clipping from your paper describing an amusing incident as related to a painting of mine, "Picture Upside Down for Eighteen Days at Exhibit." "The blunder was noticed by one of the trustees of the New Jersey Museum Association, and only then when it was seen that Mr. Nichols's signature was upside down and in the wrong corner."

A suit claiming damages against the trustees of the $25,000,000 American issue of Austrian bonds due in 1935, for their failure to insist on payment of the bonds at the old gold value, was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer on the ground that the New York State courts had no jurisdiction.

New bond financing this week amounted to $148,366,000, making the period the most active so far this year. The amount compares with $56,879,000 marketed last week, and with only $19,479,000 offered a year ago.

For the first time in the ten years that the championship has been at stake, a Manhattan school won the P.S.A.L. ice hockey title last night when Textile beat Jamaica High, 2 -- 1, in one of the three clashes that concluded the regular league campaign at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17. -- The Miami Jockey Club's long meeting settled into routine stride at Hialeah Park today, with the Bradenton purse, a one-mile test for veteran campaigners, topping a well-filled seven-race program. Sablin, which won so impressively in his one Tropical Park outing, carried on to his second straight triumph in the black and yellow banner of the Canadian distiller, Edward F. Seagram.

In a letter printed elsewhere on this page, Mr. MATHEWS makes a point too often ignored by those in a position to influence the city's growth. Until now expansion has been the accepted watchword, and there has been a constant effort to develop new areas for residence and trade.

ABOARD THE DISCOVERY II, in the Bay of Whales, Antarctica, Jan. 17.--At last the transantarctic flight has been accomplished, but not without some difficulty. We were forced to land four times on the way and we were held up once for seven days, for three days of which a blizzard raged.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- A bill to enable voters in any Assembly or Senatorial district to express themselves on a public question in an official poll for the guidance of their representatives in the Legislature, was introduced today by Senator Desmond, Republican, of Orange.

Mayor La Guardia's program for immediate condemnation and removal of the Sixth Avenue elevated line, without waiting for transit unification to be realized, struck a serious snag in the Board of Estimate yesterday when Controller Frank J. Taylor served notice that he would press for substantial amendments to the condemnation resolution adopted last November.
Dr. Roy C. Flickinger of the University of Iowa has written me to point out an injustice which occurs in an article of mine on the Horace bimillenary celebrations.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, in a fiery address in the new Deutschland Hall tonight thunderously applauded by 18,000 of the National Socialist party rank and file, declared uncompromisingly that the time was coming when Germany must demand colonies.

Unofficial trade estimates place the volume of unfilled orders for wool goods at mills at about 53,000,000 linear yards, or the equivalent of thirteen weeks' production at the present rate of output, according to the weekly survey issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Stanley Reed, Solicitor General, informed Chief Justice Hughes in the Supreme Court today that the government might ask reconsideration of the case in which the court decided last Monday that $200,000,000 of impounded taxes should be refunded to processors.

Governor Lehman was commended yesterday by the Civil Service Reform Association for his stand on civil service in his annual message to the Legislature. The commendation was sent in a letter by H. Eliot Kaplan, the association's secretary. This action brought to a close the association observance of National Civil Service Week, commemorating the fifty-third anniversary of the adoption of Federal and New York State civil service laws.
Apropos your editorial on Dr. Tildsley's Harvard lecture, may I contribute one fact?

Ghaffer Khan Djalal, Minister from Iran [Persia] to Washington, whose recall came after he had protested his arrest for a violation of traffic laws in Maryland, will sail for his home today on the French liner Lafayette accompanied by his wife.

New York, at present a laggard among the States in aid to aviation, will better its position if legislation urged in the annual report of the State Aviation Commission is adopted. Last year the commission's proposals to set up a permanent State body to control aviation were coupled with recommendations for taxes which hit nearly every phase of flying.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area made a good showing during the week. Increases over a year ago were larger than in the preceding week and were general among the leading stores here. Volume in the case of some of the Fifth Avenue stores ran heavily ahead of last year at this time, with the average increase for the week ranging around 10 per cent.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 17. -- It was announced today that the government will proceed with a partial resumption of foreign debt obligations in accordance with plans previously made public, despite the lack of approval on the part of many foreign bondholders.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:...

The third national convention of the Holy Name Society of the United States and Canada will be held here Sept. 17, 18, 19 and 20. This will be "the greatest religious convocation ever to be attempted in this city," said the announcement made yesterday by the Very Rev. Thomas F. Conlon, national director of the Holy Name Societies, at the national headquarters, 141 East Sixty-fifth Street.

" Mr. Ramshaw," of the species "Aquila chrysaetus," huddled dejectedly in a wooden "cell" at the East Thirty-fifth Street police station yesterday afternoon and bitterly contemplated the hazards confronting a stranger bound on an innocent sight-seeing tour of the city.

President Roosevelt emphasizes the "necessity to guard and perpetuate" the contributions of the country's founders to "the American tradition of civil and religious liberty for all," in a letter to the National Conference of Jews and Christians, endorsing the third annual observance of Brotherhood Day throughout the country, Feb. 22 and 23.

Tonight's arrival on the shore of Broadway will be Roy Hargrave's play, "A Room in Red and White," which at the hour of 8:30 will start its career on the stage of the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. In the company are Chrystal Herne, Leslie Adams, Richard Kendrick, William Saunders, Ivy Troutman and Joshua Logan. . . .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Assuming personal leadership of the new program to substitute the half-forgotten Soil Conservation Act of 1935 for the Agricultural Adjustment Act, President Roosevelt today not only endorsed such a course but went to some lengths in a White House press conference to explain that the shift in method of crop adjustments necessitated by a Supreme Court decision follows a program he laid down on Oct. 25.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 8. -- Senator Rosendo Naulo, workers' delegate of Ecuador, asserted in an address to the Pan-American Labor Conference yesterday that New York's unemployment insurance was not the result of the altruism of employers but was the result of "the heroic struggle of the laboring classes."
The Board of Estimate ratified yesterday the 2 per cent interest rate recently obtained by Controller Frank J. Taylor on revenue bills to be issued this year and a 3 per cent rate on revenue notes.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- Tomorrow or the next day Edouard Herriot, Minister of State in Premier Pierre Laval's Cabinet, will send his resignation to the Premier. Between now and then he is hoping to persuade his Radical Socialist colleagues in the Cabinet to remain so as to avoid provoking a governmental crisis.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- Problems involved in effecting economies through consolidation and joint use of facilities, elimination of unnecessary facilities, and provision for employes displaced by such action were discussed here today by directors of the Association of American Railroads.

Despite an announcement that the government was intending to seek a re-argument of the Supreme Court's decision ordering the return of impounded AAA processing taxes, Judge William Bondy of the Federal District Court yesterday granted a motion for the refund of $73,000 of such taxes in two cases, that of the American Thread Company, with $45,000 due, and that of the Consolidated Cigar Corporation, which asked the return of about $28,000.

A marked increase in stocking of Pennsylvania trout waters with rainbows is in prospect this year, following the taking of more than 600,000 rainbow eggs last Autumn from brood stock held at the Bellefonte hatchery.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 17. -- Valentim F. Boucas left today by plane for the United States to represent the Brazilian Government in a semiofficial capacity. It is understood he has been instructed by the government to lend his technical help to the Brazilian Embassy in Washington to end the impasse in the Brazilian-American thawing agreement tentatively signed in Washington on Feb. 12 last year, but not yet ratified.
BERLIN, Jan. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP). -- The three top-seeded performers and the upsetting young Al Ramsay of Cleveland survived two rounds of play to reach the semi-finals of the national professional squash racquets championships today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- Release of about $10,000,000 of bonds and cash in AAA processing taxes impounded in his court was refused today by Judge James H. Wilkerson of the Federal District Court. He ruled that packers and other processors who posted it must await a final mandate in the Supreme Court's Agricultural Adjustment Act cases.
EWINGS LANDING, B.C., Jan. 17. -- Marylea and Timothy Hollick-Kenyon, the daughter and son of Lincoln Ellsworth's pilot, had a holiday from school today.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 17. -- Apparently determined to catch Emperor Haile Selassie if he was traveling north by road, the Italians with four Savoia planes yesterday again bombed the town of Quoram and the roadhead south of Lake Ashangi, about midway between Dessye and Lake Makale.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Great Britain, as the guarantor of the treaty of Locarno, which in turn guarantees the inviolability of the borders between Germany, France and Belgium and which particularly provides for continued demilitarization of the Rhineland zone, has informed the German Government of her determination to hold that pact inviolate.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 17. -Many large parties have been formed by members of the Surf Club for the Satin Ball, first in the series of ten Saturday gala dinner dances arranged for this season, which will be at the clubhouse tomorrow night. Many luncheon parties will feature opening tomorrow of the new Caribbean Beach Cafe at the Surf Club.
Once more the superior play of Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C. carried him through to the final round of the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club yesterday.

Mrs. J. Lee Wyatt gave a dinner last night in the Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza for Mrs. Egbert G. Leigh. Her other guests were Mrs. Cortlandt Schuyler Van Rensselaer, Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell, Mrs. George Fritz Chandler, Mrs. Harmon H. Kelley, Mrs. Henry F. Jeffress and Mrs. Charles Griswold.

The story of how Sinclair Lewis rejected James Branch Cabell's "The Cream of the Jest," when Mr. Lewis was an editor for George H. Doran in 1915, is told for the first time in Mr. Cabell's new book, "Preface to the Past," which McBride will publish next month.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Jan. 17. -- Figures to prove that the health of Italian soldiers and workmen in Africa is remarkably good were given out today by Senator Aldo Castellani, High Commissioner for Sanitation, who has just completed his third medical inspection here.

The early return of prohibition because "it is right and right will prevail" was predicted yesterday by dry leaders speaking before 500 members of the State W.C.T.U. at their annual "national temperance education day" luncheon.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, his co-pilot on his successful flight across the Antarctic continent, were safe aboard the Royal Research Society ship Discovery II in the Bay of Whales tonight.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, granted a preliminary injunction yesterday to the Koppers Company of Delaware and the Koppers Gas Coke Co., Inc., of Brooklyn, restraining the Koppers Fuel Service Corporation of Brooklyn from in any way representing that it was selling the product of the complainant company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP). -- The Treasury refused to comment on the drop today in the price of bar silver in New York. One official said:

GREENOCK, Scotland, Jan. 17. -- Lord Rutherford paid generous tribute today to the work of James Watt, the bicentenary of whose birth will be commemorated Sunday, in the Watt lecture delivered in Watt Hall in the great engineer's native town.

Advances in both the truth and fairness of advertising, particularly in the sale of furniture, radios and other home furnishings, marked the past year, according to the annual review of the merchandise section of the Better Business Bureau of New York, Inc., made public yesterday by H.J. Kenner, general manager.

ROME, Jan. 17 (AP). -- Four thousand Ethiopians have died in the raging battle on the Southern Ethiopian front, with the Italians still pursuing the fleeing enemy, Marshal Pietro Badoglio, commander-in-chief of the Italian armies in East Africa, reported today.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17. -- Declaring that he doubted some parts of the State's case against Bruno Richard Hauptmann, Governor Harold G. Hoffman defended himself today against critics who had demanded his impeachment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Bernard Garfinkel of Stanton Preparatory Academy at Cornwall, N.Y., was designated by the War Department today, on nomination of President Roosevelt, for the entrance examination on March 3, with a view to admission to West Point at the term beginning July 1.

PHIL STONG seems to have missed reading Sinclair Lewis's "Main Street." He is still sentimental about life in a small Midwestern town. He likes the food they eat out there in Summer time, ripe, fresh-picked tomatoes still warm from the hot sunlight, corn newly stripped from the stalk and tender as the rich butter that covers it, and the berry pies.

Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer of the 107th Infantry, N.Y.N.G., the old Seventh Regiment, last night commissioned 116 men in his unit as second lieutenants in the National Guard, a class which is reputed to be the largest from any single regiment since the World War.

A conditional gift of $1,500,000 to Fisk University, Negro college in Nashville, Tenn., by the General Education Board, through which John D. Rockefeller Jr. has made many gifts to education, was announced last night by Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the Fisk University board of trustees, in a radio program broadcast over the N.B. C. network and Station WEAF.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- Despite smaller receipts of hogs here today and heavy snow in the West there was no snap to the demand for hogs. While the early market was steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher, the finish was weak with the general trade averaging steady, although there were some sales which appeared to be slightly lower.

Officiating yesterday at a hearing on the proposed reorganization of the American Encaustic Tiling Company, whose common shares recently have been churned upward on the Stock Exchange, Federal Judge John C. Knox remarked that he thought "we should know who is engaging in this activity on the Exchange."
Elaborate police arrangements for the visit of President Roosevelt here today were completed yesterday by the authorities of this city and Newark.

With an appropriation of $100,000 approved by Washington, the local Works Progress Administration announced yesterday that it had initiated a new project to assist the Department of Health in its campaign to control venereal diseases.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 17. -- Ernie Nevers, the former Stanford all-America fullback, takes over the football coaching reins at Lafayette College in March with what shapes up as the best Maroon squad in five years.

The resignation yesterday of Mr. THOMAS JEFFERSON COOLIDGE as Under- Secretary of the Treasury is greatly to be regretted. To a position of large responsibility he brought practical banking experience, a level head and a deep sense of loyalty which has no doubt been put to the test by some of the Administration's policies.
From San Francisco an opera lover has sent a check for $15 to Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, with the accompanying letter:

With an appropriation of $100,000 approved by Washington, the local Works Progress Administration announced yesterday that it had initiated a new project to assist the Department of Health in its campaign to control venereal diseases.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 17. -- Ernie Nevers, the former Stanford all-America fullback, takes over the football coaching reins at Lafayette College in March with what shapes up as the best Maroon squad in five years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Personal sponsorship of the plan to carry on the work of the AAA under the provisions of the already enacted Soil Conservation Act of 1935, was announced by President Roosevelt at his press conference, and at the same time he warned that his remarks on the program were not to be construed as replying to former President Hoover's speech yesterday.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, reversing a decision handed down by Federal Judge John M. Woolsey in 1934, decided yesterday that the motion picture "Lettie Lynton" had been based on the play "Dishonored Lady," written by Mrs. Margaret Ayer Barnes and Edward Sheldon.

With its original Gallic intimations pretty well pre-empted in the local entertainment field by the eye-filling French Casino, the erstwhile Casino de Paree -- now called the Palladium -- turned a page in the geography book and went English variety hall at its premiere on Thursday evening.

Famous wartime aviators and noted fliers of the present day, including a large delegation of pilots from Mitchel Field, attended the annual dinner and ball of the First Reserve Aero Squadron Association, Inc., held last night in the Lorenzo Ballroom of the Delmonico.

SACRAMENTO, Jan. 17 (AP). -Wild Bill Mehlhorn clipped a stroke from par on the wind-swept Municipal course today to gain the lead as the $3,000 Sacramento open golf tournament started. The Louisville (Ky.) professional carded a 71 to top a field of 113 amateurs and money players by a stroke.

The New York Stock Exchange sent out yesterday a letter to 215 listed companies which have not heretofore published data on sales and cost of sales in their listing applications and annual reports, requesting that they supply this information if its disclosure is required by the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration of their securities.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- The naval conference of four powers, meeting in committee today, agreed upon the principles that should be embodied in an arrangement for exchange of shipbuilding programs, and it appointed a technical sub-committee to work out the details of such an arrangement and submit it to the full committee.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN. Germany, Jan. 17. -- Several Italian bobsledders, entered in the Winter Olympics here Feb. 6-16, have been disqualified on grounds of professionalism, it became known today as the German Olympic committee pored over the list of 1,200 contesants -- by far the largest in the history of the Winter games.

ROME, Jan. 17. -- Premier Benito Mussolini today struck back hard at the Ethiopians for making international issues of the bombing of foreign Red Cross units to arouse world public opinion against Italy. In a copiously documented protest sent to the League of Nations he accused the Ethiopians of mutilating captives and enemy dead and reiterated charges of the wide use of dumdum bullets.

SANDRINGHAM, Saturday, Jan. 18. -Sir Maurice Cassidy, noted heart specialist, was in London early today when he was summoned to reinforce the physicians already in attendance at the bedside of King George in Sandringham, 100 miles northeast of London.

ABOARD THE WYATT EARP, in the Antarctic, Jan. 17 -- At 2:30 P.M. Greenwich mean time (9:30 A.M. Friday in New York) the Wyatt Earp at last broke through the ice barrier bordering the Ross Sea. She is now heading directly for the Bay of Whales, where she expects to meet Lincoln Ellsworth some time Sunday morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- A demand that the joint Senate and House committee considering the Clark amendment to the Social Security Act should postpone action until the Supreme Court rules on the constitutionality of the entire act was made before the committee today by Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee.

FOREST CITY, Ark., Jan. 17 (AP). -- A farmer's testimony that the motors of the airliner Southerner were functioning normally a moment before it crashed in an Arkansas swamp was heard today by Federal investigators, who concluded the plane was not attempting a forced landing.

The Association of American Colleges, attended by more than 400 college presidents and chancellors, at the closing session of a two-day annual meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday voted down a resolution to appoint a commission to make "a comprehensive survey of the athletic situation."

A rousing chorus of "noes" yesterday greeted the proposal for a new football scoring system involving the abolishment of the try for extra point, the award of a point for each first down and a five-minute overtime period to break ties.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- Joe Louis made Charley Retzlaff, gangling Duluth heavyweight, the victim of his twenty-seventh straight victory and his twenty-third knockout in the Chicago Stadium tonight in what is believed to be the shortest bout in the Brown Bomber's amazing career.
Piling up a 21-1 margin at the intermission, the strong Horace Mann quintet crushed Trinity School, 30 -- 7, in an Eastern Private Schools League contest on the latter's court yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Admiral Sir William Goodenough, past president of the Royal Geographical Society, expressed delight today with the news that Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon were safe.

Whether it may be said that the stock market appears hesitant, confused, nervous, or tired, matters little. The fact is that the showing this week has been disappointing. Buying which might be termed "important" has been lacking ("important" selling, too, was lacking, for that matter); the "public" has purchased a great many low-priced stocks, and speculative flurries in many of the better-grade issues have enlivened trading from time to time.

Professor EINSTEIN has taken out his first citizenship papers and seems to have encountered no special difficulty in figuring out the right amount of his fee at the Naturalization Bureau, which was $2.50. Inasmuch as Dr. EINSTEIN has been more than two years in the country, he becomes eligible for full citizenship in 1938.
LIKE the River Thames, the Strand is flowing along evenly, the cable reports, with these matters listed for immediate attention:
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 18. -A jury today found Mrs. Dorothy Sherwood guilty of first-degree murder for drowning her 2-year-old son Jimmy Aug. 20, but recommended mercy.

In a recent article anent the possible Spring tour of the Philharmonic under Toscanini you dwell upon the unique privilege which will be Chicago's if within one season its musical population is privileged to hear both the famous New York orchestra and the Philadelphians, whose tour is already certain.

A WILDLY improbable adventure novel, "The House of the Spaniard" is told, paradoxically, in a fascinatingly veracious manner. The hero and narrator, young David Grey, has a straightforward, effective way of recounting the simplest and the most outrageous happenings.

CAMDEN, S.C. -- The second polo game in the annual match for the John Devine Cup between the Town and Country Camden teams is expected to be attended by an unusually large gallery this afternoon as a result of the spectacular battle last Sunday in which Charlie Little of the Town team had his left leg broken at the knee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The ancient doctrine of freedom of the seas, to which the United States has clung since the days of George Washington, is the basic principle around which current discussion here is waged regarding the proposed enactment of a permanent neutrality policy designed to keep this country out of wars between foreign powers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The status of a score of persons and companies not registered with the government under the terms of the neutrality resolution as manufacturers, exporters or importers of arms, ammunition and implements of war is being examined by the Department of Justice at the request of Secretary Hull, it was announced today.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company placed in service yesterday its new entrance and exit facilities at the Times Square station of its Broadway-Seventh Avenue line. The new entrances, designed on modernistic lines, replace those formerly in use at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The Holland-America Line has announced to all agents that effective immediately three of the company's fleet of first-class liners would be designated as cabin ships. The fourth, the flagship Statendam, will be reclassified in May after it leaves a cruise schedule to return to her transatlantic run between New York and Rotterdam.

Fifteen executives of metropolitan department stores have been added to the faculty of the New York University School of Retailing for evening courses for the Spring term which will begin Feb. 5, Dean Norris A. Brisco announced yesterday.

MIXING business and -- to a certain extent -- sentiment, the Plaza Theatre will celebrate its sixth anniversary by presenting a ten-day repertoire of the "ten best" photoplays of 1935 as selected in Film Daily's recent annual poll of the nation's motion picture critics.

Late in 1934 Rupert D'Oyly Carte sent the D Oyly Carte Opera Company to America. The engagement opened in New York under the aegis of Martin Beck. From every point of view it was a triumph. Followers of Gilbert and Sullivan gratefully made acknowledgment to the performers to Mr. D'Oyly Carte and to Mr. Beck.

WHEN there are five boys and a girl in the family, even though they be of the gentle Quaker persuasion and the time is the sedate period of the Seventies, any child worth his salt knows there must have been lively doings afoot, particularly when the clan is supplemented by one small but very active black girl.

One of the most interesting sidelights on yachting during the past year is the increased interest in cruising. Statistics, based on the thousands of letters received at my office, show that boat owners have taken cruises to a far greater extent than in previous years.

The text of the address delivered by President Roosevelt last night over the telephone from his home to a meeting of the National Committee for the Birthday Ball for the President at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel follows:

A pretty and attractive girl who was terrified of marriage is the heroine of Miss Marshall's latest novel. Iris Irving's parents were a horrible example of casual philandering, divorce and remarriage. Her work in a New York settlement house brought her into direct contact with many miserable marriages.
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- The stock markets here were closed today, as usual on Saturday. The price of gold was lower at 140s 10d an ounce, with 152,000 of the metal sold. There were no dealings in silver.

NASSAU, B.W.I. -- Race meets at Montague Park will he held twice a week from now through February, with perhaps three meets a week in March. The track will close in the middle of April. Sixty-four horses have been entered for the season, including fifteen thoroughbreds.

NINETY musicians are playing on the stage of the largest studio in Radio City -- without a leader, creditably performing a difficult Bach fugue. Suddenly a yellowish mop of hair pops up before a control-room microphone and a voice calls from a studio loudspeaker:

MATTHEW CALBRAITH PERRY had the misfortune to be the younger brother of a hero, Oliver Hazard Perry, the man who "met the enemy and made them ours" on Lake Erie in the War of 1812.
