Staid and plodding, but thorough, he had little of Oliver's dash and glamour, and so, for years, long after the hero of the Battle of Lake Erie had died, Matthew Calbraith lived under the handicap of his brother's fame.

Another of the infant prodigies of the new track and field season came slamming through to victory in a middle distance feature last night when 21year-old Eddie Brown of the New York A.C. triumphed in the 600-yard invitation run at the Seventh Regiment Armory before a capacity crowd of 4,000.

THERE was a time when Canada was sensitive about its Winter -- one might almost say ashamed of it. It was this feeling which made Kipling's intende tribute to "Our Lady of the Snows" one of those things that might have been better expressed and which led to the discouragement of ice palaces on the ground that they might be mistaken for the normal, not merely the gala, habitation of Canadians in January.

The extension of the campaign to raise $2,000,000 for the volunteer hospitals of the city beyond the scheduled closing date on Jan. 10, is bringing additional contributions, it was announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign.

Few persons, until they have actually experienced the thrill for themselves, realize the quite unsuspected world of romance and adventure which lies only a few miles away when they become the owner of a family cruiser. One of the greatest rewards we in the boating business get is the opportunity of talking with enthusiastic owners who have made this discovery, each in his own way.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, submitting his annual report to the Legislature in Albany yesterday, recommended trial of a properly safeguarded system of mortgage banks, a thorough revision of the title insurance business and continuation of the general mortgage moratorium for another year with the courts permitted to foreclose in special cases.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18. -- Mild weather throughout the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week has been a potent factor in holding trade at excellent levels. Retail sales are reported exceptionally good and the usual let-down after the holidays has been eliminated.

A PRESIDENT of the United States will, this afternoon, pay tribute to his kinsman who held the same high office. The occasion is the dedication of the New York State Roosevelt Memorial, adjacent to the American Museum of Natural History on Central Park West -- a memorial, to quote from the inscription above the main entrance, to "A great leader of the youth of America."

OMAHA. Jan. 17. -- Farmers have been little affected as yet by the difficulties and doubts raised at Washington over the ability of Congress to legislate both constitutionally and effectively in the matter of farm relief. They are confident, rather, that the thing can and will be done, soon or late.

A CAREFULLY selected exhibition of paintings by Adolphe Borie, the Philadelphia artist who died about two years ago, is being held (until Jan. 25) at Marie Sterner's. It is an exhibition which well deserves attention, for it is the largest group of the artist's paintings to be shown in New York thus far and it should go far to enhance his posthumous reputation.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN. A DESIRE to avoid pitfalls that technicians at the Zeppelin Works here believe caused disaster to the Macon last February is among the reasons, The Associated Press has learned, why the new airship LZ-129 may be kept on the ground later than was at first expected.

The family cruiser is the backbone of the entire sport of motor boating. While racing of speed boats creates quick public interest and attracts big headlines in newspapers, only about one-third of 1 per cent of the estimated 1,500,000 American motor-boat owners actually participate in racing events.

It was raining a cold, penetrating rain Wednesday afternoon, which made it doubly inconvenient when uptown New York suddenly found itself without electric power. Because of the rain, lights were on early and more people than ordinarily wanted to use the street cars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Cumulative proof of an increasingly practical disposition on the part of American club women to translate into action the ideals to which they have long been dedicated is reflected in the legislative program tentatively adopted by the board of directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at its annual midwinter meeting here this week.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Jan. 17. -The proposed abolition of State lines by Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico and Colorado for fighting crime, through an interstate compact, is expected to mean the end of the Southwest as a hiding place for criminals.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18. -- Sudden fame has come to half a hundred Soviet workers, taken from factories, farms and mines to be pacemakers for the Stakhanoffite speed-up movement.

WITH ever-increasing additions to the number of types and varieties of the wilt-resistant strains of the Chinese or annual aster, many gardeners who had discontinued growing it -- because of the pernicious "wilt" disease -- are again taking it up.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18. -- Heavier freight shipments and more passengers from Germany to the Pacific Coast are indicated by the Hamburg-American motor liner Portland, now in port.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- Miss Ellen Bailly of the Rye Country Day School today was awarded the championship for girl riders at the Winter equestrian competition of the Kenilworth Riding Club, with the reserve ribbon going to is Bettie Horgan of the same school.

A BIT more of a "kick" in the sun's rays and a little later lingering of the afternoon light -- not much, to be sure, but enough to be perceptible -- help to cheer the gardener in his long wait for Spring and planting time.

I note in today's papers the death of Charles Henry Meltzer. He was a man of many uncommon qualities and, in his way, very gifted. Toward the end of the Nineties his translation of Daudet's "L'Arlesienne" -- and a most poetic job it was -- was produced at the old Broadway Theatre.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 18. -- Wild Bill Mehlhorn of Louisville held his lead in the $3,000 Sacramento open tournament at the thirty-six-hole point today.
PANAMA. -- After a quarter of a century of suppression, the people of Venezuela are not likely to accept another dictator to succeed the late General Juan Vicente Gomez.

An administration committed in 1932 and 1933 to "a complete and honest balance of the Federal budget and reduction of expenditures as the greatest possible present contribution to recovery" has presented a Federal budget for 1937 that is confused and open on both ends.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- Yale defeated Princeton, 2 to 1, tonight before 1,500 spectators in the New Haven Arena, taking the lead in the Quadrangular Hockey League with its second straight triumph. Two overtime periods were necessary to decide.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Augusta's Winter social and sports program will be enlivened this week by a bridge party, a polo game, a golf tournament and the weekly meeting of the Cross Country Riding Club.

Often we meet some misguided soul who has an ingrowing peeve on the subject of boat speeds. Invariably cited is some particular case of an individual boat which apparently failed in the hands of its owner to realize its rated speed by a margin of several miles per hour.

THE gentleman who plays the choleric and pungent lawyer for the defense in Gilbert Miller's current production of "Libel!" at Henry Miller's Theatre is Wilfrid Lawson, and his purple-faced performance as Foxley is his first American appearance.

THE Japanese Embassy in Washington, D.C., has installed a short-wave receiver so that the diplomatic representatives of that country may tune in broadcasts from their native land at tea time on Mondays and Thursdays. They may also eavesdrop on Tokyo if the atmospherics permit after midnight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 17. -- Egyptians are busily engaged in preparing for parliamentary elections at the beginning of March. Thus a new Parliament will convene at the end of that month or at the beginning of April and then, the Egyptians hope, Britain will agree to conclude a treaty of alliance based on the Henderson-Nahas draft of 1930.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- More than 1,000 cases of alleged racketeering involving the WPA are under investigation throughout the country and the staff of the Works Progress Division of Investigation has been doubled and now numbers 100 men.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- In a meet undecided until the final bout, Yale varsity wrestlers today defeated the Brown University team, 17 to 13.

HOLLYWOOD awoke one morning last Summer to the realization that it had become an art center. That was when the Museum of Modern Art pronounced the cinema the only new art form of modern times, admitted it to parity with painting, sculpture and architecture and, aided by private subscription and a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, established the motion picture's first true museum.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 19. -Again after seven years the people of the British Empire are anxiously awaiting news from the sick room of their King. That news from Sandringham yesterday was increasingly grave.

Holders of nearly 25 per cent of the allowable claims against General Theatres Equipment, Inc., have failed to deposit their securities and claims under the plan of reorganization approved by the Court of Chancery in Wilmington, Del., and will not be entitled to its benefits unless they do, counsel of the reorganization committee said last week.

Six thousand buyers, the majority with 5 to 20 per cent more money to spend than they had a year ago, will invade the wholesale home-furnishings markets this week to purchase upward of $8,500,000 worth of homewares.

Parental education among foreign-born groups is a possible solution to the problems of truancy, juvenile delinquency and crime, in the opinion of evening elementary school directors who are seeking to lift the program of the Board of Education out the experimental stage and extend it throughout the city.

Sentiment for peace among organizations of women in Westchester will result in an audience of several hundred, it is predicted, for the appearance of Miss Kathleen Courtney of England before the Contemporary of White Plains tomorrow afternoon.
It is doubtful if any other passage in the Scriptures has been so many times misquoted as Paul's warning concerning the "love of money," contained in his first letter to his friend Timothy.

SIDNEY FAIRWAY, they say, is the pseudonym "of a well-known London medical man" and the author of "The Doctor's Defense," "A Cuckoo in Harley Street" and "Reluctant Sinners," all three of which titles might have served the present pseudo-detective story.

WHEN the memorial to Theodore Roosevelt is dedicated today at the American Museum of Natural History eighty-five Boy Scouts will serve as a guard of honor. Their presence has been requested by the New York State Roosevelt Memorial Association, for in T.R.'s manner of living, in his ideals and in his active encouragement of the movement during its early days there was much that was congenial to the teaching and the aims of scouting.

ANN BROCKMAN -- her work already familiar to the public through the instrumentality of group appearances -- is having her first one-man show at the Kleemann Gallery. It will continue until the end of the month.

IT is natural to think of the unemployment problem as that of men and women who once had jobs and have now lost them. The bulk of unemployment is of that kind. The picture is not complete, however, unless we paint in the situation of the boys and girls who have reached working age since 1929 and who have not been employed at all or have been employed only intermittently and in dead-end occupations.

An appeal has just come out from Nashville, Tenn., East and West, North and South, in behalf of Fisk University, the first institution to claim "the ne-"cessity of a college education for the "development of the Negro." For a half century it has developed and maintained this leadership and stands today the first college for Negroes to be approved by the Association of American Universities, the leading national accrediting institution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Senator Clark disclosed on the floor of the Senate today that his father, Champ Clark, always believed that William Jennings Bryan "betrayed" him at the Baltimore convention of the Democratic party in 1912, and that members of Mr. Clark's family felt "animosity" toward Mr. Bryan for his part in preventing Speaker Clark from obtaining the Presidential nomination in place of Woodrow Wilson.

DALLAS, Jan. 18. -- The upward swing in business throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District continued for the week, with stronger evidence that the recovery is of a lasting nature. Retail trade showed a gain of approximately 12 per cent over a year ago.

WHEN I was playing at the Radio City Music Hall last Spring, Alexander Basy, Russian impresario, came to see me and offered me a contract to play in the music halls, vaudeville and revue theatres in Soviet Russia for a period of three months.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 17. -- Within the last year Canada has been outranked in gold production and now rates fourth in the list of the world's gold producers, according to preliminary estimates of world gold production released from authoritative statistical sources.
BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- Coast Guard air and steamer patrols fought today to bring two disabled men to shore hospitals from trawlers riding rough seas more than 125 miles off Boston Light.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- International cooperation in the cause of world peace will be practiced as well as preached at the eleventh Conference on the Cause and Cure of War, which will meet here this week at the call of Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, founder, and Miss Josephine Schain, conference chairman.

The game's leading amateur, Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club, again proved his invincibility yesterday when he won the final of the Clyde Memorial squash tennis tourney at the Yale Club in forty-five minutes of play.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 18. -- It was stated in Chaco peace conference circles tonight that a definite agreement was reached today for the exchange of war prisoners, the establishment of guarantees against a renewal of hostilities and the renewal of diplomatic relations.

ESCANABA, Mich. -- With only an act of Congress needed to give Isle Royale a national park status, detailed plans for developing the island in Lake Superior have been announced by the National Park Service.

A committee headed by Mrs. Davenport West representing the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association has taken over the matinee performance of "Aida" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Feb. 12 to aid the service in maintaining five health stations where physicians, nurses and other workers conduct a welfare program for underprivileged infants.

MUSICIANS, scientists and laymen who are fascinated by infant prodigies may find a fertile field for their studies in two outstanding musicians of the present day -- Yehudi Menuhin, the boy violinist who now stands at the threshold of young manhood with his talents undimmed, and Ruth Slenczynski, the pianist, who celebrated last Wednesday her eleventh birthday -- a medial point in the prodigy's career -- with her brilliance and popularity on the increase.

In connection with recent discussions of the problem of the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, bankers here have been giving increased attention to the large volume of foreign funds that have come to this country in the last year. The influx has been ascribed to seeking safety for these funds that the dollar and for profit in the stock markets.

The preceding installment (Vol. V) in Professor Post's exhaustive account of early Spanish painting traversed Hispano-Flemish work in Andalusia (at Seville and Cordova), taking up thereafter the life and achievements of Bermejo. The present volume, which for convenience has been bound in two parts, deals with the Valencian school of the late Middle Ages and early Renaissance.
JANUARY is certain to go down in the chronicle of the current art season in New York as a month well provided with stimulating events.

L AST Summer I read a brief notice somewhere to the effect that a New York producer was planning to send a tent-show through Florida this Winter. Since then I haven't heard anything of the project, and so far only the canvas of revivalists, holy rollers and medicine shows has been erected down here.

In an exciting game that hung in the balance until the last moments of play, the Governors Island team took a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League game from Evergreen Farms last night by 8 1/2 to 8 in the Squadron Armory. The match, full of fast, exciting and good polo, was by far the most closely contested of the season, with neither team yielding ground and the lead swinging back and forth.
MOREHEAD CITY, N.C., Jan. 18. -German steel is being driven in American waters here for construction of the PWA-sponsored Morehead City port terminal.

THE hazardous nature of the retail automobile business in the past six or seven years is illustrated by figures placed in the hands of industrial leaders here showing that, since 1929, more than half the dealers then in operation in the United States have disappeared as dealers from the economic scene.

With the Saint in the cast one is always assured of lively entertainment in the form of thrilling melodrama with a goodly seasoning of comedy. Technically the Saint is a crook, but he is hardly a member in good standing of the underworld, since he prefers to prey on other malefactors, whether they are operating within or without the law.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- Very seldom has any French Legislature, in this Third Republic, at least, come toward the end of its term in such confusion and disarray as this one, which is due to disband in May.

At the age of 70 Rudyard Kipling, writer of imperishable tales about India, soldiers, steamships and sailing men, died yesterday morning in London after an operation for a perforated stomach ulcer which resulted in peritonitis.

The New York Concert Division of the Federal Music Project yesterday announced a general reorganization of units in its division. The principal change involved is the disbanding of two small symphony orchestras and the establishment of one orchestra of eighty men to be known as the Federal Symphony Orchestra.

Two auctions were held at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries yesterday afternoon. The first one, consisting of less than fifty pieces of precious stone jewelry realized $73,992.50 in an hour. The other, which was made up of period furniture and decorative objects, the property of Mrs. Robert Maclay, brought $21,295.

Frank Carbo, 31 years old, a fight manager of 52-36 Sixty-second Street, Maspeth, L.I., who was arrested Friday night at Madison Square Garden on a charge that he was a fugitive from justice in Union County, N.J., was held without bail in West Side Court yesterday for examination next Tuesday.

A regular sixteen-hour schedule over the 1,039-mile Chicago-Denver route will be instituted by the Burlington Lines early in June with two new Zephyr streamlined trains, according to an announcement yesterday by Ralph Budd, president of the lines.

HENRY FORD is putting out a new flivver plane and he is placing upon it the serial number "1." However, this is neither the first plane nor the first flivver plane that the automobile manufacturer has built. Aviation appealed to him for a number of reasons.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 19. -- Although all knew that King George lay ill at Sandringham, 100 miles from London, many men and women went to Buckingham Palace last night and stood silently beside the gates as a token of respect and devotion.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 (AP) -- John L. Lewis, labor leader, opened an organization drive for industrial unionism in the automotive industry tonight with a fiery attack upon major automobile companies and the craft union structure championed by William Green, President of the American Federation of Labor.

The annual Octave of Prayer for Church Unity or the union of Christendom will begin today. Because of the issuance a few weeks ago of a letter to 1,500 Episcopal clergymen by twenty-seven "high" church clergymen and laymen of that communion asking for its union with the Roman Catholic Church an interest more widespread than for many years has been created.

These ungrammatical but highly picturesque letters from Eddie, the groom, retailing the progress in the sporting life of his three young charges, add a new and gayer note to juvenile sporting literature.

BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- Dr. Robert M. Gay, director of the School of English, Simmons College, cites employment of graduates which show that literary ambition does not always mean hitching one's wagon to a star.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- The regular pound loaf of bread is being sold in Chicago for 5 cents. It has been long months since that was true, and many executives of retail and chain stores hold that return of the 5-cent loaf is the precursor of a general downward trend in food prices.

A recommendation that all commitments of prisoners be made to the Department of Correction, where appropriate confinement would be determined, is made to the Legislature by the Prison Association of New York in its ninetysecond annual report.

Readers of Mr. Rhode's stories are well aware by now that when Superintendent Hanslet tackles a case he is going to muddle it up so completely that it will be necessary for Dr. Priestley to step in and do his stuff if the mystery is to be solved.

UP in West Fifty-fourth Street at Tenth Avenue, not far from Waterfront Sound No. K-20, is the hangout for as reckless and hardy a gang of adventurers as ever stirred the heart of any red-blooded or even slightly anemic male.

Now that the emergency legislation called the AAA has been called unconstitutional, it might be a good idea to sit down calmly and to consider what legislation, if any, should be undertaken. The act was passed as an emergency law to curtail the production of certain so-called basic crops and animals.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 18 (AP). -- Major Gen. John Biddle, retired, died today in the station hospital, Fort Sam Houston, after a lingering illness. He was 75 years old.

SCHOOL histories, when we were young, were mostly of the factual kind -- long, dry, dreary catalogues of dates and events that made learning a feat of mnemonics rather than an exercise of the intelligence -- and gave no hint of the romance and human drama which hid behind them.

Continuing his program of putting his vast holdings in "more manageable shape," J.P. Morgan has placed on the market about 200 acres of historic land in Westchester County, which he holds jointly with E.T. Stotesbury in a trust which will be liquidated.

CONTINUING the review of last year's lists, we reach this outstanding domestic product -- the perennial Minneapolis Symphony series. Where Ormandy has maintained such a consistently high all-round level it is almost unfair to pick outstanding items, but Schoenberg's "Verklaerte Nacht" and Beethoven's Fourth symphony occur as having made the most lasting impressions.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The American Legion charity ball, one of the leading social events of the tourist season in St. Petersburg, will feature activities here this week. The ball will be held on Friday night at the Vinoy Park Hotel, with guests from the resort hotels and neighboring cities attending.
QUEBEC, Que. -- International snowshoe races and an eight-mile relay ski race are the Winter sport events offered for the entertainment of New York visitors to Quebec during the course of next week.

THE merit of this book is that while it will give unusual delight to the scholar and the antiquarian, it also provides no little entertainment for the casual reader. Within the field in which it is set this history of the fool, the jester, is an authentic and definitive piece of work.

GAG COMES TO LIFE: The absentminded professor joke was revived last week. Ralph J. Baker, Harvard University professor and a member of the bar of the Supreme Court of the United States, had mislaid a check for $15.45 mailed to him by a court clerk as part of a fee for his appearance before the tribunal back in 1934.

ALL those who gave themselves the pleasure of reading "The Russian Journals of Martha and Catherine Wilmot," which appeared a year or so ago, will chuckle with anticipation of renewed acquaintance with the vivacious, intelligent and ebullient Martha.

ANNISTON, Ala., Jan. 18. -- Colonel Harry M. Ayers, publisher of The Anniston Star, made public here tonight two old letters from Newton D. Baker and Josephus Daniels, War and Navy Secretaries respectively in Woodrow Wilson's Cabinet, that have an interesting bearing on the controversy now raging around the heads of the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee.

A steady supply of electricity is almost as necessary to life in a twentieth-century city as a steady supply of food, drink and ready cash. Several hundred thousands of New Yorkers living north of Fifty-ninth Street made that discovery last Wednesday evening when something went wrong at the Hell Gate power plant of the New York Edison Company -- something with thunderbolt destructiveness, paralyzing the upper part of town and the Westchester suburbs for hours.

TWO volumes on the same theme have come to the reviewer's attention within the year, the other being Professor Arthur Gardner's "Handbook of English Medieval Sculpture." Although it is not indicated in her title, Miss Anderson's account also confines itself to the early sculpture of England -- naturally embracing, however, as does Professor Gardner's book, frequent background reference to medieval work on the Continent.

"VERY nice, this ride," said the passenger on a new Ninth Avenue bus. "But what in the world was done with the old trolley cars?" It is a question many New Yorkers are asking these days. Rolling stock has been removed from more than seventy-five miles of trolley track in the last few years, and seventy-eight miles more are likely to be abandoned within the next twelve months.

The St. John's University five rallied to defeat the Crescent-Hamilton Athletic Club team, 32 to 24, in a hard-fought game in the De Gray Gymnasium last night. The New Mooners led at the half, 14 to 12. It was the eleventh victory in twelve games for St. John's this season.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Jan. 18 (AP). -- Two of Emperor Haile Selassie's generals have been rushed to northwest Gojjam Province to put down a serious revolt, it was learned today from reliable sources in Addis Ababa.

THE hero, who is also the narrator, of this story is Jerry Spence, a young newspaper owner and publisher in the boss-ridden city of Midland. Along with his newspaper, The Gazette, Jerry has inherited from his father a long-standing political feud with the Robinson family, consisting of "Boss" Andrew Robinson, his brother the judge, and the judge's daughter Ellen. But the feud does not extend to Ellen.

THE tendency of the Japanese mind to live, work and think in an almost deceptively ornate fashion is well known; Westerners usually accept it under the general heading of Customs, Jap., or, thinking of those poor Chinese, sigh over dark ways that are very peculiar.

The most amusing part of this story deals with the efforts of an English girl and her brother to brighten up the social life and the finances of an old-fashioned hotel in Cornwall. When Gillian and Ronnie found that their father's fortune had been dissipated in gambling, they were in luck to find a post as host and hostess at Trevennan Towers, where their talents for dancing, golf, tennis, bridge and swimming were business assets.

Not so many years ago, a cruise of a couple of hundred miles seemed like a vast undertaking. Cruisers were slow, facilities for service were very poor or non-existent, and for one to undertake a cruise, say, from New York to Montreal he had to be engine mechanic, pilot, locker-tender and possibly a dozen personalities all in one.

The factional fight in the Socialist party in this State widened yesterday when delegates from six States and two affiliated foreign-language federations, representing approximately half the national party membership, met at the Hotel Pennsylvania and condemned the conduct and policies of the national executive committee under the leadership of Norman Thomas.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 (AP). -- Catherine D. Boyle of Woburn, Mass., filed suit in Common Pleas Court today to recover for the benefit of all stockholders $4,450,000 from six officers of the Glidden Company, maker of paints and varnishes. She reported that she owned 300 shares of the company's common stock.

Having just emerged from Odets's Paradise I feel compelled -- as who isn't these days -- to offer a few words of advice to everybody's darling of the theatre and to "everybody." Were Clifford Odets not regarded as a Wunderkind his latest opus, "Paradise Lost," would not have been permitted the dignity or indignity -- depending on your state of mind -- of a professional production.

ROME, Jan. 18. -- Today's war communique said 5,000 Ethiopians had been killed in the running battle in the south. Yesterday's estimate was 4,000. Fascist newspapers estimated 3,000 prisoners had been taken.

OLIVER GOLDSMITH had the virtue, rare among writers, of being a singularly lovable character, interesting as a human being. He was a great writer, to boot. There was an intimate connection between the man and his writings, which gave form to the distilled essences of a spirit so shy as in our own day to receive credit for an inferiority complex with -- to use Mr. Gwynn's phrase -- "fantastic manifestations."

THE BALCONY" is a reverie, a reverie in its mood and its apparently artless manner. It summons the life of the child, Roland, from the time he first becomes aware of the world through the bars of a London balcony until the end of his first year at boarding school.

An alluring picture of what Riverside Park will -- or may -- look like in a couple of years is presented in the plans and specifications submitted to the Board of Estimate by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, and presumably due for approval next Saturday, since what is so graphically set forth is the architects' and engineers' embodiment of the compromise entered into last June between Mr. Moses and Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan.

In addition to presenting its new 56-foot cruising yacht, the largest craft at the thirty-first annual National Motor Boat Show at the Grand Central Palace, the Wheeler Shipyard, Inc., of Brooklyn, is exhibiting eight other boats incorporating the important trends in design.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18. -- Azucar, winner of the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap last season, showed today he was far from "through," as some track observers claimed, by winning the $2,500 added San Felipe Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at the Santa Anita track. The time for the mile was 1:36.

OSLO, Jan. 18. -- Allan Ports of Brooklyn, veteran member of America's Olympic speed skating team, turned in the finest performance of his career today as he cracked Clas Thunberg's 5-year-old record for 500 meters.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 18. -- Dividend checks totaling $20,000 were returned to undergraduates, alumni and faculty of Princeton University, members of the Princeton University cooperative store, on Jan. 1, according to the announcement here today by B. Franklin Bunn, manager of the store.

A selection committee to choose the American eight, six and monotype class representatives in the Olympic sailing races off Kiel, Germany, has been named and preparations for the elimination series are moving forward.
From all appearances the 1936 season will be one of the best that motor boating has seen in some years. It will be the best for a number of reasons.

The political activity of "Father Divine," Negro cult leader, worshipped throughout the United States by thousands of ecstatic black and white followers designated as "angels" or "children," has politicians disturbed and puzzled.
HERE is a charming book, intimate and profoundly revealing at the same time, of an aspect of Bergson accessible even to the reader who has not specialized in metaphysical studies.

WITH contracts let last week for work on the Merritt Highway in Connecticut and progress made in the extension of the Hutchinson River Parkway through Westchester to connect with it at the State line, the long nourished project of a broad boulevard from New York City to the principal points of coastal New England appears to be approaching reality.

Judging by yesterday's crowds at the National Motor Boat Show, New Yorkers are divided two ways. There are those who already have yachts and those with a persistent ambition to wear nautical white caps in Summer and spin the spokes of their own steering wheels on Long Island Sound.

While higher woolen and worsted goods prices for Fall are again creating some resistance from men's clothing manufacturers and reviving the use of substitutes, the industry's problem will not be as severe as it was in 1933 and 1934, when the sharp advance in quotations brought about a collapse in the market, mill executives and others agreed here yesterday.

Although yacht clubhouses may be quiet during the Winter lull except over week-ends, members of the organizations are convening at this time of the year for at least one night to schedule events, elect flag officers and hold annual meetings.

GENEVA, Jan. 17. -- Next week Premier Mussolini's conflict with the League of Nations and Ethiopia will again be focused in Geneva. Row do things look here on the eve of the sessions of the Council's Committee of Eighteen?

At Albany this week a move will be made to liberalize New York State's divorce statute through the introduction of a bill now being drafted, which will be introduced by Assemblywoman Jane Todd of Westchester County. Correspondence already received preliminary to the formal presentation of the measure indicates wide interest in the subject, Miss Todd said yesterday, on the part of both individuals and organizations.

Porter Butts's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine does an injustice to the undergraduate of today. Mr. Butts views the average college man as a moronic jellyfish, unintelligent, placid, even scornful, in the face of educational opportunity and stupid in choice and use of leisure activities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Troubles multiply for the President as the year of the national election begins. His political enemies have never been so confident as now that the campaign can be waged on the line they set down aforetime more in hope than in expectation.

FOR several reasons Eugene Cunningham is one of the best three or four writers of Western thrillers now writing. He always has a story worth the telling. He tells it expertly, convincingly and with a considerate economy of words.

Reports to be made by Miss Marjorie Smith of Syracuse on membership and by Miss Kathryn Starbuck of Saratoga Springs on international relations will be prominent on the order of business of the State board of the New York Federation of Business and Professional Women, to be held on Saturday in the Franklin Arms Hotel in Brooklyn.

FIFTEEN years ago the United States spent $278,000,000 on high schools, or $2.50 per head of population. Today we spend at least $660,000,000, or more than $5 per head. The cost of high schools has more than doubled and it is still increasing.

Small boats, particularly of the sailing type, have been bought eagerly during the last two seasons and very few are available, even at prices higher than during the boom years. This accounts for the fact that the stock boat builders are experiencing great increases in their sales, as many buyers feel that they might as well have a new article rather than pay a high price for a boat built five to seven years ago.

FOR what seems in retrospect a very long time the pictures representing modern schools of painting flocked by themselves in exhibition rooms, the idea being that there could be no community between old and new; but now that the "new" are beginning to seem a little -- quite a little -- old, a light sprinkling of earlier favorites is often introduced, and the moderns look positively grateful for the diversion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- A sharp rise in the printing of money orders, held to be one of the most dependable of economic indices, heralds further recovery for the country.

AS previously announced, the current exhibition of Nantucket Island material at the headquarters of the National Committee on Folk Art of the United States, 673 Fifth Avenue (entrance on East Fifty-third Street) has been extended to Feb. 1.

THE mysterious "Two-Twenty" spread got a foothold in No Woman Valley by purchase, and went on buying out the small ranchers one by one until at the end of five years it sought to dominate the range and drive out its biggest rancher, old Donald Mac-alpine, who for forty years had loved the valley and worked there and built up his property.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 18. -- Dr. Isaiah Bowman, director of the American Geographical Society and president of Johns Hopkins University, declared tonight that Lincoln Ellsworth's story of his flight indicated that the data he gathered would make possible the construction of the first physiographical map of the hitherto unknown interior of the Antarctic Continent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Railroads serving an area comprising about a third of the Continental United States in the West and Southwest were authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to begin pick-up and delivery service of less-than-carload traffic throughout their entire systems.

THE National Symphony Orchestra at its concert Thursday in Washington D.C., will feature Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, the duo pianists, in an arrangement for two pianos and orchestra of the "Carnival of the Animals" of Saint-Saens, in commemoration of the one hundredth birthday of that composer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18. -Batting in three rebounds during the final two minutes of play, the last of which went through the net as the final gun sounded, Bill Gray gave Harvard its first Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball triumph of the season with a 32-31 decision over Princeton at Harvard's indoor athletic building tonight.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 18. -- Mrs. Lyttleton Fox of New York, who is a guest of Mrs. Charles Lewis larding at Chiora, was honored today by Dr. and Mrs. Hobart Endicott Warren at a party at their apartment.

Assailing President Roosevelt for "willfully misleading" the nation on fundamental economic problems, Robert A. Taft, son of President Taft, predicted yesterday afternoon that the continuance of the New Deal for the next four years would result in the adoption of a system of complete socialism for the country.

ROME, Jan. 18. -- News from the Somaliland front continues to take precedence over everything else in the Italian press. Public opinion is in a high state of elation over the extraordinary success of General Rodolfo Graziani's offensive.

MANILA, Jan. 18. -- With the surrender of Kulas Encallado, the last of the bandit chieftains who have been terrorizing the Philippines, President Quezon has carried out the pledge given at the inauguration of the new Philippine Commonwealth to make substantial improvement in domestic order.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP). -- A restraining order against the California "Little AAA" was issued to day by Superior Court Judge Emmet H. Wilson.
The tendency toward shorter hours and shorter weeks in industry has given people more time to enjoy the outdoors. It is sometimes rather surprising how many millions of them like to fish.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- Extensive contributions toward the development of community life in New Haven have been made by drama students at Yale recently Miss Lucille Newman, a playwright, is directing the Amalgamated Shirt and Clothing Workers Union, Local 125, which presents labor plays for workers as part of its recreational activity.

WHEN a production called "Recruits" last season took violent hold of people who had until then imagined they were doing pretty well by a thrilling play if they visited it two or three times and made them undertake at least half a dozen pilgrimages to the tiny Artef Theatre in West Forty-eighth Street it became evident that something pretty remarkable was on exhibit.

Outboard drivers who captured sectional titles in the four divisions of the National Outboard. Association during 1935 are, as in past years, to receive prizes or their accomplishments. The Champion Spark Plug Company, which has been making a habit of presenting silver trophies, will award prizes of a more utilitarian nature to the leading scorers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The administration's substitute farm program was formulated this week to replace the AAA with a system based upon the Soil Conservation Act of 1935. The proposal is ostensibly to supplant the outright acreage reduction provision of the AAA with a scheme for soil conservation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- A board, approved for the most part by the conservative Senator, Carter Glass, was reported to have been selected today by President Roosevelt to run the Federal Reserve System after Feb. 1.

MIAMI, Jan. 18. -- Progress toward settlement of the tong-standing jurisdictional controversy between the brewery worker and the teamster unions was made at a conference held here today in connection with the meeting of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.

Plans for the development of Flushing Bay as part of the World's Fair project in Flushing Meadow Park have been delayed because of the failure of the State to appropriate $5,000,000 required for highways, bridges, yacht basin and docks.

With the continued and rapid improvement of marine motive power, both in the gasoline and Diesel type of engine, there is a growing recognition of the need of improved lubrication. This especially is true of the lighter power plants used in the small family cruisers which are increasing in popularity each year.

NOT only are wide wings these days bringing the sun and blue waters of America's Winter playground close to the colder cities of the North in point of time but they are linking the varied elements of that playground as never before.

Webster Aitken, the California pianist, who aroused great interest at his debut recital recently by his remarkable playing of the Diabelli variations by Beethoven, again proved himself one of the most gifted of the younger generation of American keyboard artists by his outstanding performance of Ravel's "Gaspard de la nuit" at his second Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon.
A CLERGYMAN up in Vermont, the Rev. A.R.E. Greer, writes in that he is greatly puzzled by Georgia O'Keeffe's painting reproduced in the art page last Sunday. His querying letter follows:

NOBODY has ever thought of Tuesday as being anything extraordinary at the box office and so when it recently started to be, a few experts began to wonder why. Apparently the most plausible reason, as furnished by the Shubert office's Elias Weinstock, is the fact that "Victoria Regina" and "Jumbo" pause every Tuesday night in favor of the radio -- Helen Hayes to broadcast a serial, "Jumbo" to broadcast itself.

DURING the Palestine day the sun burns into the Holy Land and keeps hot the tempers of its tripartite population. But at night racial and political antagonisms fade out under the cooling influence of the moon and the movies.
Precipitation during the first eighteen days of the month measured 4.44 inches, the Weather Bureau reported last night. The amount of precipitation for the same period last year was 1.58 inches.

THERE is extant a letter from Beethoven to Therese Malfatti in which he asks her, "Have you read Goethe's Wilhelm Meister?" and also refers to an improvisation he had made for her one evening, subsequently written down and sent to her for comparison with the original.

ALTHOUGH the Paper-White Narcissus is the most favored bulb for forcing in pebbles and water, the early French Roman Hyacinths are certainly to be recommended as alternates, if not as substitutes. They, too, are delightfully fragrant and have the additional value of staying in bloom a longer period.

KALGAN, China, Jan. 18 (AP). -Proclaiming restoration of the vanished glory of the Mongol Khans, whose armies once swept over most of the known world, troops from Inner Mongolia marched today into Changpei, capital of the North Chahar territory recently seized by a Manchukuoan army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Reasserting that critics of the Democrats were wrong in saying that legislation enacted in the Hoover administration was ruled unconstitutional by the Supreme Court, Charles Michelson, Director of Publicity of the Democratic National Committee, today declared that Mr. Hoover had bestowed upon his cautious predecessor "the honor of bad guessing on the highest tribunal's view of the Constitution."
LONDON. -- Lawrence of Arabia's cottage in Dorset, where he spent his spare time during the last ten years of his life, is to be kept as a memorial shrine, exactly as it was in his lifetime.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- Richer in purse and distinction, Joe Louis has laid aside his fighting gloves for a well-earned rest. The Brown Bomber from Detroit made plans today for a trip which will carry him to California and far-off Honolulu before he turns his attention to the serious business of training for his June meeting with Max Schmeling in New York.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- The progressive disintegration of the naval conference notwithstanding all efforts to present in a favorable light its shiftings, its subterfuges and its constantly lessening objectives is one more development in the crumbling of the solid shore of peace into the rising whirlpool of warlike preparation.

The National Youth Administration ended its first full week of job-giving yesterday with 1,800 young men and women enrolled in out-of-school posts. Mark A. McCloskey, district NYA director, announced that placement was proceeding at the rate of 300 persons a day and estimated that the 3,500 positions provided by projects now approved would be filled by Jan. 28.

NORMAN THOMAS, Socialist leader, who recently aligned himself with the Left Wing forces of his party, recapitulates in the pages of this book his views and opinions of warfare. The title is significant and gives the meat of the volume. Unlike many present-day supporters of a world-peace program.

THIS is assuredly a monumental work -- one which not only corrects and refines ali previous scholarship in the field but which also seems to render future scholarship unnecessary. The efforts of the present two editors have been as careful as they have been extensive.

The National Civic Federation will soon publish a 100,000-word report on Germany's alleged subversive activities in this country during the World War, it was disclosed yesterday by Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the federation.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. -- An innovation in tennis tournaments is that recently inaugurated at the Sea Breeze Bath and Tennis Club. The winners at the season's close will be crowned king and queen.

NOW that less than five months intervene before the two great political parties will assemble in convention to choose candidates for the job of ruling the United States for four years, the time has come for a discussion of how one wins a Presidential nomination.

Boating activity in the past year indicates clearly that 1936 should be a banner period for boating enthusiasts. In particular, we who have fostered outboard motor boating feel that the coming season will see a return to the popularity enjoyed by this type of sport which was so evident in the years 1926-30.

ABOARD THE ROYAL RESEARCH SOCIETY SHIP DISCOVERY II, in the Bay of Whales, Antarctica, Jan. 18. -- The greatest contribution to our successful trans-antarctic flight was the wonderful performance of my Northrop airplane, the Polar Star, and the Texaco fuel and oil which has served us so splendidly throughout a great variety of conditions.

For some reason there appears to be a present quickening of interest in the art of the great Italian painter, sculptor and architect. At hand are two volumes devoted to the same subject; covering in general the same ground, yet differing considerably in the approach and often, as well, in the conclusions reached.

LONG-GOWNED, round-shouldered youngsters, male and female, march in ragged ranks, awkwardly waving banners and crying shrill slogans. They are students and China's only defense forces. For though China is, technically speaking, the most militaristic country in the world, with the largest standing army, that army lolls in garrisons while adolescent students summon the nation to defend its birthright.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Business activity in the first half of January was well above that for the same period a year ago, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.
BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- Harvard's varsity hockey team defeated a strong and rugged Dartmouth aggregation on the Arena ice tonight, 3 to 2, in a Quadrangular Hockey League clash.

THE old Mauretania is a rapidly dwindling hulk in the ship-breakers' yard at Rosyth and the Olympic approaches a similar condition at Jarrow. Neither the Majestic nor the Homeric figures in next Summer's sailing lists, and anybody who cares to draw his own conclusions is presumably at liberty to do so.

CLERGYMEN are no longer as fashionable in fiction as they used to be in the last century. Doctors, scientists and school teachers have usurped the role of God (or Devil) in the modern novel. Yet Mr. Cozzens has risked his popularity to give the clergyman his due and has done it with characteristic energy and candor.

THIS book is not a clear, orderly, comprehensive comment on the Agricultural Cooperative Movement in Ireland, of which Sir Horace Plunkett was the founder. As economic history it is not valuable, but as a contribution to the Comedie Humaine of the Irish Cooperative Movement, of which George Moore made so much in his "Hail and Farewell," it makes very interesting reading.
PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Palm Beach is now fully launched upon its midseason activity, with honors evenly divided between sports and cultural affairs.

I believe most of us would agree with Dr. Beard that until we can resolve the confusion of thought in our present situation we cannot hope to resolve the confusion in the realm of action -- confusion which leads inevitably to war.

AS Walt Whitman once "started from fish-shape Paumanok," James Rorty, who is also a poet, "started West from Easton," and with much the same intent, to see, if possible to sing, America. But the America that Rorty found is not, unhappily, the one that Whitman sang about:

An attendance of several thousand persons, including leaders in the Polish colony here and in many cities throughout the country, as well as many members of society, is expected at the "Night in Poland Ball" to be held at the Astor on Feb. 1 under the auspices of the Kosciuszko Foundation for memorial exchange scholarships between the United States and Poland.

At carefully selected points throughout the United States the chief of engineers has established United States Engineer Offices, each in charge of an officer designated as district engineer. A division engineer supervises the activities of each of several groups of district offices.
Christopher Columbus Smith, founder of the Chris-Craft Corporation, is not going to attend the Motor Boat Show, neither is he going to Florida this Winter.

When President Roosevelt decided to use radio to transmit his Congressional message to the people, he stirred up a hornet's nest which not only indicated how bitter the coming campaign may be, but also revealed the difficult position in which radio broadcasting companies find themselves when the political pot begins to boil.
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- King George V's chances of recovery were described as touch and go late tonight by a medical authority who has been familiar with the King's condition for several years.

THE year 1936 will be the centenary year of "The Pickwick Papers." In honor of the occasion the B.B.C. is to broadcast a special feature program entitled "Mr. Pickwick's a Hundred Years Old." In preparation for this event The Radio Times has invited that enthusiastic Dickensian, G.K. Chesterton, to discuss the universal and enduring popularity of this famous character.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 (AP). -- Coming from off the pace with a well-timed drive, S.J. Molay's Fire Advance, a 4-year-old son of General Lee, scored an unexpected victory in the one mile of the Chalcedony Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

WITH each passing week the snow piles deeper in the mountains to the north, and the infectious enthusiasm of the skiers is soaring to hitherto unknown heights in New York City. Speeding over glistening woodland trails in the keen, cold air is a sport that warms the blood of the Winter sportsman.

PARIS, Jan. 3. SIMON GANTILLON, the author of "Maya," is one of the dozen playwrights whose work counts artistically, and he has a sense of poetry which gives him a very individual place in this selected group. So any new play of his deserves serious attention.

Swimmers of George Washington High captured the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the Public Schools Athletic League by downing De Witt Clinton's defending titleholders, 37 to 34, in the concluding series of dual meets for triborough honors yesterday.
IN addition to two elaborate museum openings, the week has been marked by no little activity in the galleries about town.

Although his ambitious program of furnishing each of the five boroughs of the city with yacht basins has struck a snag for lack of WPA funds, Commissioner of Parks Robert Moses has added two proposed basins to his list, both of which are to be located in the upper region of Manhattan, making a total of seven.

METRO'S defeat of the British censors in the controversy over "Ah, Wilderness!" apparently has had a salutary effect on local producers and, it was predicted on several lots this week, may provoke a change in the industry's obsequious attitude toward foreign demands which have become a major problem of late.

Checking the results of their campaign to prevent the attendance of unescorted children at motion picture shows, the police of the juvenile aid bureau visited theatres in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday, and at fourteen of them served a total of thirty-four summonses.

When Pierre Loti was admitted to the French Academy Anatole France said: "The only one among us who has genius ha no brains." There was a great deal of justice to this quip, for the French Academy, originally founded in 1637 to establish standard French forms and diction, has never quite forgotten its lexicographical function.
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- All of the King's doctors have previously attended him. Sir Maurice Cassidy, who was summoned today, is one of the greatest living authorities on heart disease.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17. -- While wintry snowstorms fold the towers and citadels of Moscow's ancient Kremlin under a white cloak of peace war talk thunders down the long former throne room of the great palace, where the seventh congress of the Soviet Central Executive Committee is in session.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 18. -- President and fellows of Harvard College, Cambridge, Mass., are bequeathed $10,000 in trust by the will of Benjamin Welles of Manhattan and Islip, who died in Manhattan on Dec. 26. The instrument provides that the money shall be used for a scholarship, to be known as the Benjamin Welles Scholarship, the income to be paid to any deserving undergraduate descendant of Benjamin Welles of the class of 1800.

SCENES of international importance arising out of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict and involving the outstanding personalities in world affairs will be brought to life before an American audience as the world premiere of the Federal Theatre's "Living Newspaper" unfolds on the stage of the Biltmore Theatre on Wednesday night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The Democratic National Committee today announced that it now expected Jackson Day Dinner receipts to exceed $275,000, instead of the $225,000 estimate of a week ago.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- It is only natural to assume that President Roosevelt's home State, with the biggest block of votes in the electoral college, will be, perhaps, the most hotly contested battleground in the Presidential campaign this year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- Appointment of a committee with broad powers to negotiate with labor officials on rules to protect employes displaced by railroad abandonments, or unifications, was announced today by John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, at the conclusion of a two-day closed conference.

RADIO as an educator is soon to have a new Federal Government tryout. In one of five "white-collar" educational projects, for which in all WPA has allotted $1,983,000, the Office of Education will conduct over a national hook-up a program designed for reception by the halfmillion men of the Civilian Conservation. Corps.

Carrying on his campaign against drunken drivers, Mayor La Guardia yesterday announced the appointment of a commission of medical and legal experts to study the situation with a view to making it more difficult for guilty motorists to escape the penalties of the law.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- The Bronxville League for Service has completed plans for the presentation of "The Drama of a Clown" on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1 in the auditorium of the Bronxville School. The cast will include seventy-five men, all residents of Bronxville and active in the community life.

ASMARA, Eritrea -- The military police during the World War were never particularly popular with the rank and file of the armies. Theirs was a thankless job, well performed. Here in Eritrea the Royal Carabinieri perform a similar though much more extensive task, just as they have done for 121 years through all the wars of Italian independence, through the World War and all colonial campaigns.

LEVY of a license fee on broadcasting stations is being considered by the Federal Communications Commission, according to a report to a House sub-committee on appropriations. It was indicated, however, that the commission does not look with favor upon issuing permits to operate broadcast transmitters more than six months at a time without renewal.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 (AP). -- Warships aggregating 110,500 tons are under construction in German shipyards, the naval monthly Marine Rundschau said today in a survey of Reich fleet building progress at the beginning of 1936.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons are active in behalf of the fashion show for the benefit of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Osteopathic Clinic which will be held during the luncheon hour on Wednesday in the Louis XVI restaurant of the Park Lane.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (Canadian Press). -- Recovering from an attack of nerves that brought about its unceremonious exit from the English Cup by Port Vale, the powerful Sunderland team resolutely set about winning the Football League championship for the first time since 1913.

THIS season, because of the increasing interest in the great group of succulents, city flower shops and specialty nurserymen are offering a wider selection than ever of cacti and related plants. They range in size from the diminutive to the large and luxuriant; and in diversity from the usual varieties to the bizarre products of the hybridizer.

A saying of the sententious Bishop BUTLER is often quoted. It is, in effect: "The facts are what they are, and their "consequences will be what they will "be. So why should we try to deceive "ourselves?" The practical truth implied in this is today being ruefully discovered by several different nations.
More than 5,800 undergraduates at the three buildings of Hunter College will take their final examinations next week. Almost 500 seniors already have finished their tests.

United States Treasury accumulations of silver at the first of the year are estimated to have been above a billion and a half ounces. This means that the Treasury has acquired the equivalent of all the silver the world produces in more than seven years.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels assigned yesterday Philip W. Haberman Jr., an assistant, to head the condemnation trial section of the real estate division of the city's law department. The move was part of his campaign to clear up all pending condemnation proceedings in which the city is involved by the end of the year and thus effect substantial savings in interest.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Finishing with three birdies, climaxed by a twenty-five-foot putt on the final hole, Densmore Shute of Chicago, former British open champion, won the thirty-six-hole Tropic Open golf tournament at the Miami County Club today with an aggregate of 138 strokes. He led the field of notable performers by three strokes to win $200.

Numerous innovations that are certain to enhance the interest of spectators and attract exhibitors are presented in the premium list for the twenty-fourth annual show of the Eastern Dog Club, which is to he held in Mechanics Building, Boston, on Friday and Saturday, Feb. 21 and 22.

FOLLOWING the post-holiday slackening, retail trade picked up in the week and most centers reported comfortable gains over a year ago. The increases ran to 12 per cent in the Midwest. Some stores here found similar improvement and it was estimated that the half-month's figures would be 7 per cent ahead of a year ago.

Regarding the neutrality legislation pending in Washington with serious misgivings, exporters last week sought ways of having the bill modified without running the risk of being accused of fighting the measure because it might interfere with profits in event of war.

Support for the government policy of spending to maintain consumer purchasing power is vital to the country, and particularly to retailers, and retail executives should not be "on the fence" but should oppose a "contracting economy at this time which would throw the country back to the conditions of 1932," according to Harry W. Schacter, president of the Kaufman-Straus Company, Louisville, Ky.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- Despite the departure of the Japanese delegation from the London naval conference, the conversations must continue, Francois Pietri, Minister of Marine, declared in an interview today.

The opening chapters of this story deal with the loss at sea of a freight steamer plying between England and South America. No lives are lost, but the ship, with its cargo, goes to the bottom. There is the usual Board of Trade inquiry, but the cause of the disaster remains unexplained.

May we, under the Constitution without amendment, regulate agriculture and industry on a national scale without the sacrifice of State rights? If we want some of the things that NRA gave us, can we bring them back with the Supreme Court blessing and Schechter only a memory of our early pioneering on the New Deal frontier?

THIS book is badly named. The great Tudors are here, to be sure: but the general reader will be sadly mistaken if he turns away from this somewhat heavy-looking volume with the idea that it is simply something more about Henry VIII and Elizabeth

A REVIVED interest in a little-known art is marked by two current displays. One is the exhibit of a distinguished collection of rare and lovely old fans recently acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art through the bequest of Mary Strong Shattuck.

BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- General industrial conditions in New England have shown practically no change from December. Reports from a wide variety of manufacturing companies covering many different industries indicate that operations are at practically the same rate as a month ago.

If this season's big exhibition of the Society of American Artists at the National Arts Club in New York be a reliable indication (and it should be) of the present trend, we are emphatically justified in deciding that the graphic medium known as aquatint has come into signal popularity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP). -- The Supreme Court held a secret conference today and thereby stirred speculation as to whether it had completed a final draft of its Tennessee Valley Act opinion.

Kostanty Kempisty, holder of the P.S.A.L. half-mile outdoor championship, followed his brilliant victory in the Manual games last week with an even more scintillating performance in the 440-yard dash last night at the 102d Regiment Armory, where the thirty-first annual Stuysvant meet was held.
President Roosevelt enjoyed a smoke at the National Emergency Council meeting in Newark yesterday, and so did the delegates to the conference.

FORT PAYNE, Ala., Jan. 18 (AP). -- A tornado dipped at three points on the populous slope of Sand Mountain near here early today, killing four persons, injuring several others, and inflicting extensive property loss.

Out of the perpetual darkness in which they walk -- with groping hands, careful footsteps and faces forever lifted a little toward the sun -- members of the Blind Woman's Club of Manhattan have erected over the last three decades a prideful record of service to their own.
Neutral Inquiry Methods. The White Rabbit put down his morning paper with every sign of satisfaction.

The New York Banks' Glee Club, with Frank Kasschau as conductor, gave the Winter concert of its fifty-seventh season, last evening at the Town Hall before a large and responsive audience. Rose Dirmann, soprano, was the assisting artist, and William J. Falk, the accompanist.

HOW many bands are there in the United States? Has a census ever been taken of these pulse-stirring organizations? If so, whoever has the figures should stand up and make them known; and if not, isn't it about time for the bands to march by and be counted?

THE busy man of affairs, tied to his desk during the day, is becoming in increasing numbers an enthusiastic practitioner of the woodworking hobby. Acting sometimes on the orders of the doctor, who recommends it for unused muscles or overwrought nerves, and sometimes in response to an inner urge to fashion things with his own hands, he is turning more and more to the saw, the hammer, the plane and the paint pot.

The death of Rudyard Kipling early yesterday morning, just past 70 years of age, removed from the world's stage not a mere poet and teller of tales but a monumental figure of the late nineteenth century with a powerful projection into the twentieth -- in a very real sense the last of the Victorians and the first of the moderns among Englishmen.
PRAGUE, Jan. 18. -- Austrian Social Democrats are circulating a document in which precise charges of ill treatment of Socialists confined in the concentration camp at Woellersdorf are formulated.

IN eleven months of 1935 there was a gain of 62,932 in the registration of motor vehicles in New York State, according to Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. The registration of passenger cars in 1935, up to Dec. 1, was 1,991,013, a gain of 49569 over the same period of 1934, and the registration of commercial cars in eleven months of 1935 was 312,470, a gain of 7,673.

Prayers will be said in the New York churches at the services today for the recovery of King George V of England. In the Protestant Episcopal churches the King will be remembered at the altar at virtually every service, particularly that of the holy communion.

A few days ago an Italian engineering commission announced from Eritrea that if oil in abundance is found in the eastern Aussa region of Ethiopia a canal would be dug to let the Indian Ocean flow into the dry Danakil basin, some 500 feet below sea level. Thus, a lake 200 miles long and 100 miles wide would be formed and the problem of shipping out the oil solved at one bold engineering stroke.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Discovery of a treatment for allergic patients has been "practically verified" by a group of staff doctors at Abington Memorial Hospital in suburban Abington, it was announced tonight by Dr. Harry B. Wilmer, the hospital's medical director.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, charged here tonight that the Roosevelt administration's financial policies had laid the foundation for "an immense credit inflation'' and, at the same time, had "deprived us of our means of arresting it."

RAWHIDE was the Arizona town midway between Phoenix and Springer toward which those rival contractors Minard Moss and old Geronimo Garland were rushing the new telephone line that would connect the two larger towns.

Several operatic performances at the Metropolitan Opera House in the near future have been taken over to raise funds for various philanthropic enterprises. An encouraging subscription has been reported for the special performance of "Die Walkuere," with Kirsten Flagstad, Gertrude Kappel, Lauritz Melchior, Friedrich Schorr and Emanuel List in the leading roles, Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's mission in Labrador.

STOCKINGS are an unobtrusive note in one's costume, yet in their quiet way they can make or break it -- particularly with skirts getting shorter. It is as important to have the subtle color of the stockings just right as it is to put a picture in a properly blending frame.

SINCE Miss Akins's "O Evening Star!" has already dropped below the Broadway horizon, it is perhaps an act of supererogation to go on talking about it. But her success story, based on the Hollywood career of Marie Dressler, suggests several topics that are pertinent to an artist's relation to his material.

THE Professor of Protozoology in Johns Hopkins University and Mrs. Hegner have provided in this sturdy volume a very charming and most informing book about animals of representative species from the amoeba to the gorilla.

Price movements in the security and commodity markets were indecisive during the week just completed. Stocks moved irregularly, unrelieved except by speculative flurries, especially in the lowerpriced issues; trading was slower, 15,554,000 shares for the week on the Stock Exchange, against 18,248,000 the week before. Treasury and corporate bonds pointed higher as foreign issues declined; grains advanced a little and cotton was easier.

Most markets for commodity futures were strong yesterday. Although rubber, hides and copper eased, the quotations on sugar and coffee advanced in unexpectedly heavy trading. In the cash markets, corn, rye, oats, lard and eggs gained, while rubber fell back.

Uncertainty over tomorrow's Supreme Court decisions, with selling against increased receipts of India's new crop reported in Liverpool, caused declines of three to ten points in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson's announcement of an administration labor policy which would permit mass picketing without police molestation during strikes is accepted as further evidence that he feels the support of labor is worth having.

TRAFFIC courts in New York City handled nearly 1,400 motor-law violators daily during 1935. The total for the year was 506,979 -- a number approximately equivalent to one out of every two persons who drive motor vehicles in this city.

Corporation officers, aware of the success attending the record-breaking refunding of bonds in 1935 which substantially reduced fixed charges, are looking to their next senior issues, preferred stocks, in furtherance of the policy inaugurated last year of reducing charges against their capital structures.

The emergence of Brookwood, pioneer resident school for workers at Katonah, N.Y., as a permanent arm of the American labor movement was hailed by speakers yesterday at a luncheon marking the institution's fifteenth anniversary.

CHICAGO. -- Cities and towns rimming Lake Michigan from Kenosha, Wis., to Michigan City, Ind., are considering plans to follow Chicago in the adoption of Eastern standard or permanent daylight-saving time, a survey indicates.

THE present season of the Metropolitan Opera Association has proved of great in- interest to the public. A few letters from a sheaf much too large to be printed in full, and most of these pertaining to a single performance, have been printed in these columns.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- Trading in wheat was slow today on the Chicago Board of Trade, and not until near the close did the market break out of a range of 1/8 to 3/8 cent. A small buying spurt lifted prices fractionally, but the upturn was quickly lost and final trades were unchanged to 1/8 cent higher than yesterday's closing.

Share prices drifted lower yesterday in the slowest trading since mid-December; the turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to but 1,072,000 shares, compared with 1,641,000 the Saturday before. WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP). -- Legislation to increase the Federal Trade Commission's powers to halt unfair and deceptive trade practices will be introduced Monday by Chairman Rayburn of the House Interstate Commerce Committee.

Miguel A. de Capriles, New York University's fencing Professor of Economics, captured first place in the third of the series of Olympic epee tryouts staged at the New York Athletic Club yesterday under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18. -- The Montreal Canadiens went back into third place in the National Hockey League's international group tonight as they sped to a 3-to-1 triumph over the New York Rangers in a game that marked the Canadiens' first home triumph since Nov. 23.

A plea for "debate without bitterness and a settlement without strife" of all problems here and abroad was made yesterday afternoon by William Guggenheim, honorary president of the International Benjamin Franklin Society. He spoke before 200 persons at the society's thirteenth annual meeting and luncheon at the Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

The second performance of the season of Gounod's "Faust" was the Metropolitan offering last night at the Broadway house. But unlike the first presentation, last night witnessed a notable change of principals in the cast. Frederick Jagel was Faust, Susanne Fisher was Marguerite and Irra Petina was Siebel.

Twenty-two years ago a volume called "Medieval Figure Sculpture in England" made its appearance. The collaborating authors were Dr. Gardner and the late Edward S. Prior. It is now out of print and Dr. Gardner has written this textbook -- based to a large extent, he explains, upon the research that went into the earlier survey, though the volume we are now considering is, the author adds, essentially a new work rather than an abridgment.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- Columbia's basketball team scored its second successive victory in Eastern Intercollegiate League competition tonight, turning back the Yale quintet, 25 to 24. The victory advanced the Lions to first place in the standing, ahead of Dartmouth, which was handed its first setback by Cornell in a game at Hanover.

My sudden urge to race motor boats just "happened." It was one of those things where you leap suddenly and without premeditation when you discover something you've been missing. It took place a little over a year ago during a vacation down South.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- Bronxville residents, whose public school system is known throughout the country as a leading example of progressive education, adopted a plan this week to assure the nonpartisan election of school trustees.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- The creation of an advisory group of 100 prominent persons to increase Temple University's sensitivity to current educational trends was proposed tonight by Dr. Charles E. Beury, president, at a "ten-year progress" dinner.
GRETCHEN GREEN'S book defies classification. It is not like any other book and because it is distinctively itself and nothing else it does not submit easily to description.

A SMELL society has recently been formed England with the avowed purpose of making time nation smell-conscious. Its leaders realize that the movement may provoke ridicule at first, but they are determined to carry on. Not only will they combat the obnoxious smells that civilization has created but they will seek to develop an appreciation of pleasant smells.

ONE of England's most celebrated trees -- Latimer's elm in Hadley Woods, Middlesex -- was recently chopped down. The old tree marked the spot where Henry VIII first heard Hugh Latimer, the preacher, one of the leaders of the Protestant Reformation in England, later martyred at the stake.

Veteran steamship agents in this city said yesterday that the decision of the Cunard White Star management to bring out the Queen Mary as a cabin liner indicated that the term "first class" gradually would be abandoned.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- It is now certain that Sir Samuel Hoare, after his return from his holiday in Switzerland and not later than the end of the naval conference, is destined to be reinstated as a member of the British Cabinet. Pacifists in London are alarmed by reliable information that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin intends to appoint him as First Lord of the Admiralty in succession to Viscount Monsell, who is due to retire.

More favorable weather conditions annd an easing of the tension, following invalidation of the AAA, started retail trade in many sections of the country on a new upward surge last week. While a few districts reported volume only equal to that of last year, in other areas increases ranged from 1 to 12 per cent, the Middle and Southwest enjoying the maximum rise.

On the first day of this month the gross debt of the United States stood at $30,557,000,000. Whether this figure accurately measured the obligations and the responsibilities of the Government was a question sharply debated last week in Washington, when Secretary MORGENTHAU appeared before the Senate Finance Committee to testify on the soldiers' bonus.

Net income of Remington Rand, Inc., for the nine months ended on Dec. 31 amounted to $1,869,466 after all charges, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday. The income is equal, after allowing for preferred dividend requirements, to 66 cents a share on 1,378,684 common shares outstanding.

Featured by military ceremonials and decorative effects, a brisk floor show and many other divertissements, the Military and Naval Ball -- one of the largest dances of the Winter -- will be held on Thursday night in the Grand Ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A capacity attendance is assured for the annual dinner of champions of the American Power Boat Association to be held Wednesday night at the Hotel Montclair. The affair was originally scheduled for the Lexington, but because of the many reservations the scene was changed late last week.

TONIGHT as usual 10-year-old Johnny Jones of Davenport, Iowa, will exercise his freedom of the air. Twirling the radio dials through programs from Bach to ballyhoo, he will pick up his favorite "bedtime story."
