Astor the First had erected his monopoly, crushing the free traders who sought to pursue their dealings with the friendly Indian trappers independent of the great company's influence and employ.

Since the first of the year, automobile owners have continued to renew their car licenses in larger numbers than in previous years, Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, said yesterday. At the close of business on Friday 15,395 more sets of plates had been issued in Manhattan than at the same date last year.

Etchings and engravings from the collections of Mrs. Robert Maclay and Miss Elisabeth Achelis of this city, E.R. Ferriss of Chicago and other private owners will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries on Wednesday evening.

Music lovers in New York are delighted to welcome the great conductor from England, Sir Thomas Beecham, as he gallantly leads our Philharmonic men in a characteristic program. And I for one take off my hat to Sir Thomas not only for his musicianship, but also for his straightforward loyalty to the composers of his country.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 18. -- In a thrilling game tonight Cornell's basketball team ousted Dartmouth from the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by a single basket, the Red team winning, 36 -- 34. The Green squad now is in second place behind Columbia.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- Competing in a heavy snowstorm that made visibility poor, eight teams of bobsledders raced this morning at the Mount Van Hoevenberg slide for the national A.A.U. junior two-man bobsled championship.
OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 17. -- Issues of unique importance to Canada's economic and political future were discussed, and in one case decided, in Ottawa during this past week.

AN entirely new type of bid has been introduced into his bidding system by Ely Culbertson, who declares that ever since the start of contract bridge the proper theory of slam bidding has been overlooked by the best players.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Pennsylvania opened its Intercollegiate Swimming Association season today by winning from Columbia in a keenly fought meet before a large gallery at the Hutchinson Pool, 36-35.

LAKE PLACID. -- With the January program of Winter sports getting well under way at this snow-covered mountain resort, sportsmen are turning their thoughts toward spectacular events scheduled for February.

PIKILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- The United States needs "men who are specifically trained to serve in the government of a democracy such as ours," Dr. James Madison Stifler of Chicago declared today, in speaking at the University of Pennsylvania's first Founder's Day exercises in honor of Benjamin Franklin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Thousands of samples of all types of building materials produced have been installed in a display gallery by the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department to assist architects in the designing of Federal buildings and in selecting satisfactory materials indigenous to the localities for such buildings.

President Roosevelt returned to his home here again last night for a one-day visit after stopping at Newark to "sit in" for two hours at a meeting of the State heads of Federal relief organizations in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Amendments to immigration laws which would make possible the deportation "of certain criminal classes now immune" were recommended today by D.W. MacCormack, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, in a report to Secretary Perkins.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The two-thirds rule now required by the Democrats for the nomination of President and Vice President will be abrogated by the party's national convention in Philadelphia, if the present plans of leaders in Northern States are fulfilled.

RAGGED clouds were drifting across Central Italy" is the first brief sentence of this 812-page novel by Johan Fabricius; and in some mysterious manner known only to the romantic reader the simple words set the tone, dispense the atmosphere of the whole vast volume.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 18. -- The Intercollegiate Model Senate will discuss bills concerning pure food, neutrality and constitutional amendments when it meets at the New Jersey College for Women Feb. 13, 14 and 15. The group met at Vassar College last Winter.

THERE it goes again. One more victim for Shufflin' Joe Louis. The Dark Destroyer, annoyed by a swinging right that sent him against the ropes, came stalking out to crash a lightning left into Retzlaff's face and Chin-chin Charley became, as the old song has it, "one more for the undertaker, just a little job for the cemetery man."

DUSTY spinning wheels have been dragged down from the attics of New Hampshire farmhouses; once more shepherds are herding their sheep on the slopes of the White Mountains; smoke pours forth as in the days of an almost forgotten generation from many a village smithy as the smith, who had lost hope of ever following his natural bent again, pounds away once more at his anvil.

Juridical opinion on the effectiveness of the adolescent court in salvaging first offenders will be heard Tuesday night at the Beckman Tower at a dinner sponsored by the Panhellenic House Association. Four magistrates especially selected to conduct the new court in Brooklyn during its first year -- Jeanette Brill, Bernard A. Kozicke, John D. Mason and William O'Dwyer -- will be guests of honor and speakers.

Business is partly responsible for crime in the United States, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. declared last night in an address at the thirty-first annual dinner of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. In some cases business has openly flaunted its alliance, through trade associations and the like, with underworld characters, Mr. Bennett said.

MR. SILCOCK dedicates his book to that distinguished Orientalist, Laurence Binyon, who fired him "with his own enthusiasm for the art of China," and talks with whom were largely responsible for Mr. Silcock's having undertaken, at the true sources themselves, the study that has here been brought to completion between covers.

"The buffaloes are the life of the Sioux," said old Newah to the young men of the tribe, and in his tales of epic hunts on the Western Plains the reader senses the close, almost mystic relationship between a primitive people and the game by which it lives.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- A new theatre being evolved in China, composed of persistent filterings from native tradition, liberal borrowings from the modern Occidental stage and original ideas of the Dramatic Club of Yale-in-China.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- Edouard Herriot, Minister of State, has deferred his resignation from the Cabinet until after Premier Pierre Laval's return from Geneva next week and for the next few days everybody and everything will be in a state of suspense.

FORMATION of the Air Transport Association of America with Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, former chief of staff of the air services of the A.E.F., as its "czar," marks a further hopeful step toward coordination and progress on the part of the operators.

An unusual lot of United States and foreign coins, including the collections of the late Charles W. Sloane, Frank Lenz and E.D. Smith of this city, will be sold at auction by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street beginning next Wednesday afternoon and continuing through Saturday.

PROBABLY the most amazing thing about Rene Clair's first English film, "The Ghost Goes West," is that there were so few cries of disappointment from his followers. Conversely, that there were those few is one of the highest tributes to his genius.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -With a full calendar of sport events scheduled for the next few weeks, golf takes the lead in the field of outdoor sports at Southern Pines. Two major tournaments of national importance are scheduled for Spring.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17. -- Members of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor, gathered here for their quarterly session, fear that before long organized labor may find itself in a predicament similar to that of 1922, when the Supreme Court dealt a severe blow to labor and social welfare legislation for which the trade unions had worked for many years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Scholars of the future will be saved many research trips abroad because of the photographic exploration of foreign libraries and archives by the Library of Congress.
BERLIN, Jan. 18. -- Trading on the Boerse was mixed today, showing exceptional strength in certain specialties, yet generally almost completely stagnant.

ROME, Jan. 17. -- The unexpected rains on the Ethiopian high plateau in the middle of what is normally a dry season and their equally sudden cessation have raised the question here whether the "little rains," usually lasting from a fortnight to a month, have come and gone or whether they are still ahead.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 18. -- In an attack on many New Deal policies, Albert C. Ritchie, four times Governor of MaryLand, appealed today in an address before the Ohio Bar Association to the "American lawyer" to "protect the kind of government we call American."

INTO a scene of virulent antagonism, economic and political and soon to become personal also as the Presidential election approaches, of bitterness of opinion to find whose like it is necessary to go back to the Eighteen Fifties, and of resounding battle-cries and hot-tongued insults, Henry Wickham Steed's earnest little discussion of some economic matters that are fundamental to our own situation sounds like a gentle voice exclaiming, "Peace! Be still!"

TO make a distinguished collection of furniture requires not only unusual ability to recognize quality but also patient and extensive research, which may occupy a lifetime. On rare occasions the privilege of seeing the result of such discerning labor is offered, as when a museum acquires a collection or a special display is held.
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- News from Somaliland bears out the expectation that their state of embarrassment in the north indicated the probability of a renewed move by the Italians in the south of Ethiopia.
A REPORT at hand reveals that in London the year 1935 witnessed some improvement over 1934, although "only in the auction room, where prices were generally higher."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 17. -- After a month of "atmospheric" conferences by candlelight and minutes recorded with quills, "The Company for the Restoration of Colonial Annapolis, Inc.," completed its organization this week and issued its first commission, the drafting of an authentic map of the pre-Revolutionary capital of Maryland, locating all landmarks of the days when it was a center of wealthy Colonial culture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Three of the cartoon stamps issued by the National Republican Council of New York were held unmailable in a decision given to Postmaster General Farley today by Karl A. Crowley, solicitor of the Postoffice Department.

THE practice of dying was developed into a fine art during the Middle Ages. Its moral support and encouragement were derived from the species of block-book known as the "Ars Moriendi." It was here that block printing reached the highest point of its artistic and literary merit.

IT was a lucky day both for archaeology and for the reader when Count Byron de Prorok wearied of following what he calls the staid side of archaeology and became a kind of explorer-archaeologist. Again and again, it is true, he was unable to follow up his discoveries; other men reaped the fruits of several of them, while some must await the advance of civilization before they can be properly investigated.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Jan. 18. -- A report from an American source at Addis Ababa said that the United States military attache, Captain John Meade, had narrowly escaped with his life in a recent encounter with shiftas (bandits) during a recent journey by mule in the interior of Ethiopia.

SIMON BLUMENFELD'S first novel has triple significance. It is the outcome, he says, of his belief that it is time some one portrayed the Jews of Whitechapel as they are and not as exotically picturesque aliens. He is a Jew himself, born and bred in the district of which he writes, and the Jews who figure in the book are convincingly alive and, indubitably, of their day and city.

Instead of being purely national in character, as has been the case for the past eight years, the grueling Albany-to-New York motor boat marathon down the Hudson will take on an international flavor this year.

LONDON, Dec. 27. THIS morning, in announcing the death of Paul Bourget and giving an account of his life, The Times drew an illuminating distinction between criticism in England and criticism in France.

Improving upon their mark set in the qualifying round, the Abraham Lincoln High School sharpshooters of Brooklyn carried off the P.S.A.L. rifle championship by scoring 1,046 points at the Richmond Hill High School range yesterday. Six survivors of the fifteen squads which started in the elimination round last week competed for the title and the Harry Payne Whitney trophy.

AN observation was printed in this space recently to the effect that, while many motorvehicle drivers inexcusably endangered the lives of pedestrians, it was also true that many pedestrians just as inexcusably exposed themselves to danger in the streets.

THIS collection of fifteen essays touches on a large variety of subjects, including metaphysics, psychology, ethics, economics, anthropology, biology and history. None is dull and in all Professor McDougall proves to be master of the subject with a very definite message to present.

What is meant by the term "standard of living"? As Malthus used the term it meant that income which a given class in society would have to have before it would marry and reproduce. A class which, because of changing economic circumstances, failed to receive an income equal to its standard of living would decline in numbers.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- The National Socialists, who have clothed Nazi aims in an entirely new vocabulary that is often intranslatable and therefore just as often escapes foreign notice and understanding, have invented a new word to conjure within the Third Reich.

THE Hoosac Mills case will live to torment the defenders of judicial supremacy long after the issue of farmers' relief has become a historical episode. It my ultimately have more profound effect upon American institutional development than all of the New Deal experiments rolled into one.

As a corollary to the mounting interest in art in recent years there has been a greatly increased popularity for reproductions of works of art. At present at least two New York galleries are entirely devoted to the display and sale of reproductions; and a growing number of bookshops and galleries find this field a profitable sideline.

BISBEE, Ariz., Jan. 18 (AP). -- A small boot protruding from under a rocky ledge led to the finding late today of the frozen body of 4-year-old Roy Rogers. The discovery ended a four-day hunt that in its final stages had the aid of 300 volunteers and six airplanes.

LONDON. -- Tension between Great Britain and Italy in the Mediterranean has produced results which will endure. Among these will be the enhanced importance of Palestine in the structure of the British Empire -- an importance which may equal that of any one of the great dominions.
With a 48-foot motor yacht as its largest contribution, the Elco Works of Bayonne, N.J., is offering a fleet of six boats at the show.

Improving retail trade, coupled with rising activity in the major wholesale markets, featured business developments in the metropolitan area last week. The increase in retail trade over a year ago was larger than in the preceding week. An average increase of 7 per cent or more is anticipated for the first half of the month.

PARIS, Jan. 16. -- The big Renoir exposition, to be held at Tuilleries this Spring, is giving a new impetus to the mode. Opal-tinted pastels, which are characteristic of his technique, are prominent in the new textile collections.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- A newly discovered portrait of Edgar Allan Poe, which shows the author without the signs of illness marking his features in most pictures, will be placed on exhibition here tomorrow at the Poe House, 530 North Seventh Street. The day is the 127th anniversary of Poe's birth.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- Although many Germans had to tighten their belts and go without butter, eggs and other food at times, nevertheless Germany was able last year to import enough raw materials for rearmament and in addition roll up a surplus in foreign trade amounting to 124,200,000 marks.

The Beaux-Arts cruise to Nassau, B.W.I., on the Volendam, which is being arranged as a benefit by the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects, has aroused much interest among members and friends of the society, many of whom have made advance bookings.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 18 (AP). -- As Federal investigators studied the "human element" in the crash of the transcontinental plane Southerner in Arkansas, American Airline pilots were ordered to keep doors between their compartment and passenger cabins locked during flight.

IT is sometimes a little difficult to cope with Celtic charm. So much has been said about it, its manifestations bear such a strong family resemblance, that beyond murmuring a few plati tudes about poetic beauty and sly wit there is little one can do in the way of appropriate homage.

MR. JACKSON has translated here in some sixty pages the body of medieval Irish and Welsh nature poetry which has come to be commonly spoken of as early Celtic nature poetry. IN a recent booklet, "International Conciliation," John B. Whitton writes: "Our international society owes its existence to a vast network of treaties, and their maxim pacta sunt servanda -- pacts must be executed in good faith -- is nothing less than the keystone of the arch of international society."

PERHAPS it is the briefness of Perry's career which has served to discourage biographers. Mr. Dutton's well-defined work is the first life of Perry to appear since 1840. At 28 Perry had won the Battle of Lake Erie. On his thirty-fourth birthday he died at sea.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- The subcommittee of the naval conference which is drafting an agreement for exchange of building information on the basis of various plans already submitted continued its work today and made substantial progress, aided by a new plan presented by the Italian delegation.

The eighth annual Russian Students Ball in aid of the Russian Student Fund and the Russian Alumni and Student Association will be held on Friday at the Ritz-Carlton. A gala entertainment is planned for the occasion, which this year marks the fifteenth anniversary of the founding of the fund and of the Russian Student Christian Association and the tenth anniversary of the alumni association.
Mrs. James Roosevelt is chairman of the committee on arrangements for the Birthday Ball for the President, her son, which takes place Jan. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 18. -The Englewood Field Club scored a sweep over the Plainfield Country Club on the latter's courts today and resumed its first-place tie with the Montclair Athletic Club in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Class C Squash Racquets League.

HAVING chalked up a reduction in automobile accidents, injuries and fatalities in the year just ended, New York City's Police Department is broadening and intensifying its attack on traffic evils. Through its Safety Bureau it is carrying out a program which has for goal the making of New York, in the words of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, "the safest city in the world."

For your pains you will take out a product not unlike the current Tarkington offering.
Sea Scouts from all parts of the metropolitan area are functioning this year at the thirty-first annual Motor Boat Show, units of the various sections being assigned definite days to hold forth.

A resolution requesting all citizens to urge their State Legislators to call a Constitutional Convention, as provided for under Article V of the Constitution, was unanimously adopted by members of the Women's National Democratic Club at their monthly luncheon meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Iroquois.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 18. -- Enrollment in the College of Agriculture of Rutgers University has been reflecting a "back-to-the-farm" trend in recent years, Professor Frank G. Helyar, Director of Resident Instruction, said today. Freshmen choosing the agricultural curriculum this year number 82, as compared with only 64 last year.

THE Federated Garden Clubs of New York, of which Mrs. Ralph Pratt Hirschman is president, has announced its final schedule for the International Flower Show, March 16 to 21. The "keynote", for exhibits in the artistic classes of the Federated Clubs will be the Dutch and Flemish influence. The flower arrangements, as usual, will be changed daily.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The Treasury Department was reported tonight to have decided on a definite plan for seeking to prevent recovery of $200,000,000 of impounded AAA processing taxes which, under the Supreme Court's decision in the rice millers' case, appeared destined to be turned over to processors.

A committee headed by Mrs. Henry C. Taylor is arranging the annual benefit for St. Johnland, a resident home in Kings Park, L.I., for children and homeless elderly persons. The committee has taken over the hockey match to be played on the night of Feb. 4 in Madison Square Garden by the New York Rangers and the Detroit team.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College, asked college women yesterday afternoon to do their utmost to establish reason rather than force as a rule for the settlement of International disputes. The request was made before about 105 members of the Alumnae Association of Wilson College at the Woman's University Club, 106 East Fifty-second Street.

BERLIN, Jan. 18. -- The National Socialist State has continually stated that one of its chief aims is to preserve the racial purity of the German people. It came to adopt this view upon realizing that the future of the German people can be secured only on the assumption that it is racially healthy and of pure stock.

While uncertainty prevails as to the quantity of merchandise to be put into work, there has been no lull in the designing activities of dress firms due to the threat of a strike, according to statements by officials of the various dress associations.

VIENNA, Jan. 18. -- Prince Ernst von Starhemberg in newspaper men's parlance "killed" tonight the story of tomorrow's first general assembly of Fatherland Front officials by convoking the Austrian foreign press in order to assert that no sensation need be expected.

Preservation of the medieval culture guarded for more than 400 years as the heritage of the Sephardic Jews who were expelled from Spain in 1492, is the aim of a research program organized by the Department of Hispanic Languages at Columbia University.

HOUSTON, Texas, Jan. 18 (AP). -- John Henry Kirby, veteran of the political wars and wealthy Texas lumberman, predicted today that 10,000 "good Democrats" would gather at Macon Jan. 29 for a South-wide convention of anti-Roosevelt Democrats. Mr. Kirby and Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia called the convention.

A decision by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, that prizes awarded by spinning a wheel in motion picture houses and other places of amusement are a violation of the State Lottery Law, was announced yesterday, after being handed down late Friday.

CLAUDE KENDALL and Willoughby Sharp report that they have received from John Clayton the complete manuscript of his new novel, "Anger of the North," the concluding volume in the trilogy which began with "Dew in April" and was continued in "Gold of Toulouse."

The Tennessee Society in New York, an organization composed of native Tennesseans now residing here, held its thirty-first annual Jackson Day dinner dance last night in the main restaurant at Sherry's.

The annual Yankee Doodle Ball in aid of Stony Wold Sanatorium was held last night at the Park Lane under the auspices of the sanatorium's Auxiliary 6, of which Mrs. H. Thurston W. Huntting is chairman.

As a general rule a corporate taxpayer need not be concerned with the calculation of its tax liability until the close of the taxable period for which the return is required to be filed. The Federal capital stock tax, an exception to this rule, has given rise to much confusion.

TO stimulate non-professional musicians to form chamber-music groups MacDowell Club is starting its second annual chamber music competition for amateurs. Competitors will receive from the judges of the contest constructive criticism based rather on their musical understanding of the work performed than on technical proficiency.

HOLLYWOOD. THE long-threatened conflict between cinema and radio is in progress. The controversy has not taken the form that was anticipated, nor was it inspired by a rivalry for audiences. Music, for which studios pay song writers anywhere from $8,000 to $15,000 a week, has precipitated it.

For twenty-one years a studious friend of long life, with the name, unmusical to the Volscians' ears, of GABB, has reported to The Times of London the number of deaths of persons 90 or more recorded on its front page. His whole exhibition of nonagenarians or better numbers 7,776.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 18. -Colgate's basketball team, featuring a stout defense which Army had difficulty in breaking through, conquered the Cadets, 32 to 23, today.

The Long Island Southern Inland Waterway, extending from East Rockaway (Debs) Inlet at Atlantic Beach to Great Peconic Bay at Shinnecock Canal, has been in the process of development for many years. It is now beginning to take shape as through waterway for shallow-draft boats -- four feet is the controlling depth between the Patchogue River and the Shinnecock Canal.

Winning seven of its division's nine events and compiling 20 points more than its nearest rival, P.S. 9 of Brooklyn, represented by a well-balanced squad, won its twelfth straight city P.S.A.L. indoor track title in the annual elementary school championship met yesterday at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Notre Dame, in a sensational second half rally, defeated Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 37 to 27, before a crowd of 8,000 basketball fans.

The North American Wildlife Conference will be held in Washington Feb. 3 to 7. Called by President Roosevelt and arranged under Federal auspices, the conference will be faced with the opportunity of writing a new and vital chapter in the history of the nation's battle to restore its waning natural resources.

In accordance with plans approved by the Superintendent of Schools and the Police Commissioner, a course in safety education will be offered to high school teachers in fifteen sessions, to be held on Fridays from 4:15 to 5:50 P.M. at the Twenty-third Street building of City College beginning Feb. 7. Supplemental work will be done in the schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Weary of debate on the "baby bond" Bonus Bill, and eager to get away to attend the annual Alfalfa Club dinner, the Senate suddenly stopped work at 5:15 o'clock this evening while only thirty minutes of further talk seemed likely before a final vote.

Queens Sea Scouts will receive an opportunity over the coming weekend to put into actual practice many of the theories they studied during the recent courses held at the Jamaica Normal School, according to Sea Scout Director Joseph H. Brinton.

Two new white-collar projects, one providing for a study of railroad organization and the other designed to cross-index and bring up to date the records of the Chief Medical Examiner's office, have been approved by the WPA policy board and work on them will start immediately, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator.
ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- The Republicans in the Legislature have completed charting a course which they hope will provide an opportunity for a double-barreled attack on the New Deal and Governor Lehman.

EMPEROR HAILE SELASSIE ought to derive considerable patriotic satisfaction from the classic studies of grains made by the distinguished Soviet geneticist, N.I. Vavilov, chief adornment of the All-Union Plant Institute of the Lenin Agricultural Academy.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- The development of student unions at colleges and universities of the country since before the turn of the century is being studied with satisfaction at the University of Pennsylvania, which is observing this month the fortieth anniversary of the dedication of Houston Hall, the first student union building in the United States.

When a family of children is deliberately nourished on false values the effect on their characters makes an interesting study. Olive Wadsley sets out to show how a pretty, insipid, unscrupulous woman, striving for a higher social and financial standing than she actually rated, tried to model the lives of her three children.

Principles for the guidance of certified public accountants in corporate reporting and in public accounting practice are embodied in a booklet which has been published by the American Institute of Accountants. The booklet, titled "Examination of Financial Statements by Independent Public Accountants," is being distributed among accountants by the institute to help them in preparing annual corporate reports for shareholders, Stock Exchanges and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

GIRLS at four large universities and one college in the past two years have been relieved of all required courses in physical education. Unless they wish to do so, they need never wield a tennis racquet or a hockey stick. Gymnasium and sports instruction is at their disposal in elective courses, but it is no longer a hard-and-fast prerequisite for a degree.

Due to poor weather conditions, only eighteen gunners reported at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. O. Agathon led with a card of 97 -- 4 -- 100. It was excellent shooting considering the driving rain. Agathon took the scratch prize, the handicap trophy going to S. Milligan, who had 89 -- 10 -- 99.

THE Jooss Ballet, which established a record with its run of fifty performances at Forrest Theatre in the Fall of 1933, will return to New York for the first time since then with a single performance at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday evening.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- The body of Rudyard Kipling, poet laureate of the British Empire by popular acclaim, lies tonight in the chapel of Middlesex Hospital, where he passed away, while from every place where the English language is spoken or read there pour in to the family, to newspapers and to public institutions tributes of his greatness, his inspiration and his skill as a master craftsman in literature.

STEAMSHIP men of New York and London are vigorously debating the question, "What is a cabin ship?" in view of the fact that the giant Queen Mary has been placed in that category. Some experts hold that the Queen Mary, a de luxe ship larger than any now afloat and much faster than any vessel hitherto assigned to the cabin class, should not be so designated.

Failing in two attempts to see Mayor La Guardia, members of the July, 1934, grand jury, through C.A. Richards, secretary, made public yesterday a letter urging the Mayor to support the request of District Attorney Dodge for an appropriation of $50,000 for the employment of a special prosecutor in the trial of the remaining mortgage cases.

The Emergency Relief Bureau, having turned over half its home relief clients to the Works Progress Administration, is now paring its personnel in line with its decreased burden. Miss Charlotte Carr, ERB Administrator, has announced that by Feb. 1 her staff will have been reduced from 18,000 to 13,000.
NORRIS, Tenn., Jan. 18 (AP) -Evicted from his Tennessee Valley farm as the backwaters from a TVA dam crept around his cabin, James Randolph today found a new home for his wife and seven children.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- Even conservative Pennsylvania is undergoing a change in its attitude toward the public utility issue, if the decision of the Public Service Commission in the Myerstown case a few days ago can be accepted as a criterion.
The text of President Roosevelt's address in Newark yesterday follows:

WHILE it is true that broadcasting is growing up, it is growing stale in some spots, Luella S. Laudin, executive secretary of the Women's National Radio Committee, told the radio audience in a recent interview over WMCA.

The year 1936 looks like a boom one for the boating business. Chris-Craft fourth-quarter sales in units were larger than those of any previous corresponding period. The addition of the Chris-Craft Clipper, to sell in the $1,300 cruiser price group, further adds to the favorable outlook for 1936.

Judge Mack declined to rule yesterday at a hearing before him in the Federal Building whether it was mandatory or discretionary with the court to permit petitioners to intervene in the case of the Associated Gas and Electric Company whose reorganization is sought by certain creditors under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

With a record-breaking attendance of close to 6,000 merchants expected and with its program designed to reflect the advances made in retailing during the last quarter century, the silver jubilee convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will open tomorrow night at the Hotel Pennsylvania and continue until Friday noon.

IN this work an attempt is made to bring together recent discoveries and conclusions of biology, psychology and clinical medicine so as to give a prospective of psychosomatic interrelationships. The author maintains that the phrase psychosomatic interrelations conveys "an emphasis we are outgrowing: it is inadequate to express the conviction that psyche and soma are not entities which interact but actually two aspects of a fundamental unity."

AT any moment, day or night, President Roosevelt can select any one of 150 telephones in the White House and talk with friends, official emissaries of the government -- in fact, to any of the 30,000,000 telephone subscribers in the sixty nations linked by telephone service.

ADDING to the attractions of an already well-filled week, four of New York's elder and more staid clubs held exhibitions of works of art last week. At the Century Club, French masterpieces of the nineteenth century, lent by members, are on view (until Feb. 10) with eight of the great names of French painting represented.

Nearly all branches of the Roosevelt family, including the President and Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., will participate this afternoon in the dedication of New York State's $3,500,000 Theodore Roosevelt Memorial.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 18. -- Rutgers University's quintet team upset Fordham, 50 to 49, tonight, staving off a desperate fourth period rally which almost brought victory to the Rams.

Another display of impressive team work and effective all-round play was given by Squadron C's first-string riders as they routed Fort Hamilton, 17 1/2 to 7, last night at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn for their fourth success in as many Metropolitan Indoor Polo League matches.

BERLIN, Jan. 18. -- With that "iron discipline" which Chancellor Adolf Hitler recently lauded as his outstanding achievement, the German press opened a barrage today against Seen Lester, the Irish League of Nations High Commissioner for Danzig, who has submitted a report to the League censuring the National Socialist regime there and attacking the validity of the last election.

High-ranking army and navy officials and others of prominence in patriotic societies compose an honorary executive committee for the annual military ball of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Department of New York, which will be held on Feb. 28 at the Manhattan Ballrooms, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

This admirable survey, which covers significant Italian plastic work of the fifteenth, sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, is composed of material constituting the nine Charles Eliot Norton Lectures for 1927-28, delivered at Harvard University.

A Summer on the Maine Coast is alluring enough for any girl of 12, but when there is a legend of Colonial treasure, buried practically in one's front-door yard, and an authentic treasure map to guide the search, one's vacation is an assured success.

MADRID, Jan. 18. -- Spanish women are expected to vote for conservative candidates, as they did in 1933, when the Second Republic elects its second Parliament next month. They were a deciding factor at the previous general election and there is much more reason now for them to cast their ballots the same way as they did then.

Radio censorship problems can be cured only through Congressional action, the American Civil Liberties Union declared in announcing that copies of "freedom of the air" bills, introduced last Summer by Representative Byron Scott of California, had been submitted to Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, for his support of the measures.

The La Salle Military Academy hockey team defeated New Utrecht High by 5 to 1 at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night as Henry McMullen scored three goals and John Grimes two. The Oakdale sextet is undefeated in twenty-four straight contests since midway in the 1933 season, although twice held to a tie during that period.

PARIS. LITTLE things indicate most clearly the direction the mode is taking this year, just as the leaves of the tree show which way the wind blows. A tiny lace "carriage-shade" better evokes the Second Empire than any long, dull treatise on that epoch.

That America's sportsmen are turning to deep-sea angling in droves is a very evident fact-judging by the increasing number of Matthews 38 Sport Cruisers and other models adapted to fishing that are being sold and rushed to Southern fishing spots these days.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 18. -Captain Howard Willey set a new Princeton and new pool record of 1:40 in the 150-yard back stroke to lead his team to a 62-9 victory over Lafayette in the Brokaw Pool today. The Tigers captured every first and all but one second place.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The high spot in sports attractions here during the coming week is the seventh annual Atlantic Coast men's squash racquets championships to be held on the courts of Chalfonte-Haddon Hall on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
"PARADISE LOST," an oratorio by the young Franco-Russian composer, Igor Markievich, was given its premiere, under the composer's direction, at a recent concert of the B.B.C.

All four seeded teams were left in the running last night as play in the doubles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association came down to the quarter-final round at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

The tax burden on owners of real estate in American cities was just a shade lighter last year than the year before, according to Mr. C.E. RIGHTOR'S annual compilation in the National Municipal Review. The average adjusted rate for each $1,000 of assessed valuation in the 236 cities for which information is available was $25.84 as compared with $26.03 -- a drop of 19 cents.

Leaders of the Young Women's Christian Association and of the Young Men's Christian Association, at their first joint leadership conference yesterday, were advised to be gay and blithe and were warned against priggishness. The conference was at the West Side Y.W.C.A., Fiftieth Street and Tenth Avenue, and the adviser was Dr. Ordway Tead, lecturer on personnel and administration at Columbia University.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Traders who are favorable to the buying side of corn and are picking up futures on all weak spots base their operations on a report that there is 41 per cent more cattle on feed in the Corn Belt States than last year, which means a greatly increased consumption.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Wholesale activity at the close of the calendar year 1935 was at the highest level since 1931, Dr. N.H. Engle, acting director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today. Estimated sales for 1935 were valued at $16,287,000,000, as compared with $14,710,000,000 in 1934.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 19. -- Two veteran campaigners, Wild Bill Mehlhorn of Louisville, Ky., and Willy Cox of Bethesda, Md., tied for first place in the seventy-two hole Sacramento golf tournament today with 286 strokes each.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Jan. 19. -- A Statewide alarm was sent out this morning by the Bay Shore and Babylon headquarters of the State police for the Rev. Walter A. Ralls, 38 years old, of 110 Hiawatha Drive, Brightwaters, who has been missing since Thursday morning when he took his mother, Mrs. A. E. Ralls, to the Post Graduate Hospital in Manhattan for treatment.

The Missing Persons Bureau of the Police Department conducted 29,287 investigations in 1935 and solved 98.09 per cent of them, according to a report submitted yesterday to Commissioner Valentine by Asting Captain John G. Stein, in command of the bureau.

The battle for control of the national convention in May, which will determine the outcome of the struggle in the Socialist party between the "Old Guard" and the left wing group headed by Norman Thomas, was launched yesterday at the conference of representatives of Eastern organizations of the party, before it adjourned after a two-day session here.

A plea for unity within the Protestant churches was made by the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, minister of the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Broadway at 174th Street, in his sermon, "The Good Fight," there yesterday morning.
SANDRINGHAM, England, Jan. 19. -- All day they came in twos and threes to ask: "How is the King?"

The whole history of the Catholic Church is "the history of one great mission," with Christ the first missionary, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathdral, declared yesterday at high mass.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP). -- Indiana's Hoosiers, hearing all the responsibility of upholding State prestige in Big Ten basketball while Purdue's Boilermakers battle midsemester examinations, were still riding high tonight, although showing signs of wabbling.

If the average American voter wants to see just what a politician up for reelection looks like he should make a study of the recent genuflections of Pat Harrison, senior Senator from Mississippi, chairman of the Finance Committee of the upper house.
The address of President Roosevelt, delivered yesterday at the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial dedication ceremonies at the American Museum of Natural History, follows:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19. -- Touring the course in 35, 34 -- 69, one stroke over par, Elmer Rich of Chicago won the low gross award in the eighteen-hole medal play handicap today, the first event on the program of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests, which is holding its twenty-eighth annual championship here.

Fish and game associations, sportsmen's clubs and bird societies in the metropolitan area played the role of good Samaritan to wild life yesterday. With the heavy snow adding to the hazards created by the thin glaze of ice that resulted from Saturday's rain and sleet, game species and small birds were confronted with the most critical conditions of the Winter.

Rudyard Kipling's "L'Envoi," which opens with the words, "When earth's last picture is painted," and describes the time when we shall "lie down for an aeon or two," was quoted by Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island yesterday morning in a tribute to the author.
LONDON, Jan. 19. -- George Lansbury, former leader of the British Labor party, made the following comment on the King's illness tonight:
DETROIT, Jan. 19 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings, counting in every period, shut out the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 0, tonight before more than 13,000 fans, the largest crowd of the season.

In his address on Saturday to members of the Emergency Council at Newark, the President laid down correct principles regarding the work of relief. He said that it required smooth-running cooperation between Federal, State and county and municipal governments. He added that the chief function of the Washington authorities was to give information to local bodies doing the actual administration of projects for work relief, and so on.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71.5 on Jan. 15, against 71.4 a fortnight before, 71.4 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Miss Kitty Cheatham gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the Great Northern Hotel in honor of Asgeir Asgeirsson, former Prime Minister of Iceland, now Minister of Education and Finance, who has just finished a brief lecture tour in this country and will sail on Wednesday for home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Defining the New Deal as the American expression of "a new world movement" exemplified in Germany by the Nazis, in Italy by the Fascists and in Russia by the Communists, Ogden Mills, in an address here tonight, called for dealing with the issue as a "formidable challenge" to this country's traditional "liberalism."

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Considerable comment has been stirred in the security markets by the partial failure of the Australian Commonwealth Government's 21,000,000 conversion loan, half of which has been left with the underwriters.

The Merchants Association of New York favors an extensive revision of the Federal Government's taxation and fiscal program. Its opinion was expressed in a referendum conducted by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States in which business and commercial organizations were asked to answer a number of questions regarding tax policies.

Sheila Jackson, 10 years old, of 2,170 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, and her 6-year-old brother, William Jr., were "mushing" northward on their sled yesterday afternoon while relatives and two police cars searched for them and all police precincts in the borough were on the lookout.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 19. -- The Arab Youth Federation and the Palestine Arab party, two principal Arab bodies, have submitted to High Commissioner Wauchope a memorandum listing their objections to the proposed Legislative Council and giving amendments that would make it acceptable to the Arabs.

Leading from start to finish, Miss Dorothea Dickinson of the Women's Swimming Association successfully defended her Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 500-yard free-style indoor crown at the championship A.A.U. swimming meet staged in the W.S.A. pool yesterday. The time was 6:34.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- Foreign trade showed a remarkably healthy expansion in 1935, the December increase of 11,241,000 in imports bringing the year's expansion to 25,522,000, or 3.4 per cent, while the December rise of 617,000 in exports made the total increase for the year 33,958,000, or 7.5 per cent.

The program of individualized instruction in the city's public schools, though yet in an experimental stage, has proved successful, as manifested by an eagerness on the part of children to work out problems on their own initiative, according to the annual report of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, the second installment of which is made public today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19.--The Democratic platform in June will not contain a plank calling for enactment of a constitutional amendment, it was reported today in influential labor circles close to the Roosevelt administration.

How many people know of the nerve-racking experience awaiting any person under 25 years of age who applies for a reference work at the central building of the New York Public Library? All youthful persons are subjected to an inquisition commendable only in a detective dealing with a criminal.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Indications here at present are that the most serious problem for the Nazis in the coming months will be the rise in prices. In the last few days there have occurred irregular and sharp advances in the prices of certain foodstuffs and many luxury articles, particularly foreign, and also in store prices and those of manufactured goods.

World industrial production increased for the fourth consecutive month during November, according to the monthly report yesterday of the National Industrial Conference Board. Substantial improvement was reported in the United States, Canada, Great Britain, Belgium, Denmark and Australia.

While New York landlords were repeating their expressions of fear yesterday that enforcement of recent amendments to the Multiple Dwelling Law would bring many foreclosures and property losses, several housing and welfare organizations announced plans for concerted drives to improve tenement conditions or to effect changes in the dwelling statute.

Seamen who are provided with necessities as well as an educational and recreational program at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York will be the beneficiaries of a performance of the Jooss European Ballet tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

VIENNA, Jan. 19. -- Whatever doubt Prince Ernst von Starhemberg may have left in his declarations last night on the plans of the present regime were filled out today at the assembly of Fatherland Front leaders in speeches by Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and himself.

Developments in Washington were the controlling factors in the cotton futures markets last week. The January delivery lost 16 points of its premium over the distant December. Net changes for the week on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from a decline of 10 points to an advance of 21.

Through snow and sleet Ruth Draper's public went last night to the Booth Theatre to sit before the first of five Sunday evening programs with which -- after threatening not to pay New York any visit at all this season -- she has consented to favor this town.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 (AP). -- A substantial revival in the building construction industry in the State was noted in 1935, with estimates calling for an expenditure of about $74,543,000 more than in 1934, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, said tonight.
Madeleine Carroll is due to arrive from England tomorrow on the Majestic. She recently completed the leading feminine role in a Gaumont British film of W. Somerset Maugham's "Secret Agent."

Sir Thomas Beecham concluded his three weeks' visit as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The musicians stood as Sir Thomas walked to the podium at the beginning of the concert and joined the audience in prolonged applause at the end.

The Metropolitan Opera Association's first attempt at opera translated into English, under the new management headed by Edward Johnson, will be made next week with a revival of Puccini's one-act comic opera, "Gianni Schicchi." The work will open the seventh week of the season on Monday evening as part of a double bill with the same composer's "La Boheme."

The lower income group is not, as John D. Colgan in a recent letter to THE TIMES would seem to believe, merely a phrase to designate a nebulous section of the citizenry. When the final applications were accepted for First Houses, it was found that income among the applicants averaged a little over $23 a week.

Use of terror, force, violence and intimidation against workers and unemployed increased and civil liberties in this country reached a low ebb in the last year, it was reported yesterday by the Methodist Federation for Social Service on the basis of a survey of country-wide conditions.

By now it seems clear that Chairman FLETCHER of the Republican National Committee has thought better of it. He will not ask the courts for a writ of mandamus against the broadcasting companies, compelling them to give the Republicans as much time as they give the Roosevelt Administration.

Foreign exchanges declined sharply last week. The recovery in the dollar was noteworthy in view of the rumors of further devaluation and the flight of capital, but bankers said that little fear of these possibilities was held in foreign financial circles. The volume of business fell with the recession in values, the turnover being substantially under that in the preceding week.

Economic conditions in this country would improve with wider foreign trade and prosperity based on peace rather than war would be more lasting and genuine, in the opinion of business leaders who replied to a questionnaire sent out by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP). -- Putting together three swift scoring drives in the opening quarter, the Green Bay Packers, runners-up for the 1935 National Football League championship, defeated a team of Pacific Coast stars, 24 to 14, today before 20,000 persons.

Statements in my letter to THE TIMES concerning opposition of the National Woman's Party and other women's organizations to minimum-wage legislation applying to women but not to men have been challenged by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, vice president of the Consumers League of New York; Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, and Miss Rose Schneiderman, president of the New York Women's Trade Union League.
CORNING, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- A new type of glass from which can be made skillets, frying pans and other kinds of pots to be used over the kitchen fire was announced today by the Corning Glass Works.

PARIS, Jan. 19. -- Edouard Daladier was elected today president of the Radical Socialist party of France and a new phase of French political history was begun which promises to be, both in the immediate future and perhaps for some time to come, extremely active and perhaps agitated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The Senate is expected to make quick work tomorrow of passage of the "baby bond" Bonus Bill, and the House is counted upon by its leaders to fall in line, to put up quickly to President Roosevelt this novel plan for prepayment of the World War adjusted service certificates.
The overflow "crowd" at the dedication ceremonies of New York State's Roosevelt Memorial had hard going yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The Foreign Policy Association attacked in a statement today the administration's Neutrality Bill and suggested more flexible powers for the President.

Massachusetts Investors Trust, an open-end general management investment company, reported yesterday that the asset value of its stock increased from $18.80 a share on Dec. 31, 1934, to $24.03 on Dec. 31, 1935.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 20. -- Although there was still almost blank uncertainty and the gravest anxiety during last night concerning the condition of King George, the weight of opinion in the best-informed quarters was to the effect that death was not yet imminent.

BERLIN, Jan. 19. -- The secret political police have resumed their role in the settlement of the German Protestant Church struggle. The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, a leading opponent of the government's church policy, declared from the pulpit of his church this morning that they had again raided the homes of several prominent Protestant clergymen yesterday in search of a pamphlet on the church situation which he issued last week.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,817,657,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 50 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the preceding week, and comparing with an average of 57 per cent in the four weeks through Dec. 21.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 19. -- Outscoring the United States by a wide margin on the second day of an international speed skating meet, Norway easily defeated America's Olympic skaters today, 49 points to 95.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- Westminster Abbey was thronged all today, not only by those who came for services and formal prayers for King George but by hundreds who went there to various chapels to pray by themselves and in their own ways for blessings on the stricken monarch.

HONGKONG, Jan. 19. -- Hu Han-min, Cantonese leader, arrived here today on his return from voluntary exile in France and received an elaborate welcome by deputations from both Nanking and Canton, who appear to be competing for his aid in seeking unity of North and South China.

Domestic stocks of cotton at the end of December, including government-financed cotton and private holdings, were 11,854,000 bales, compared with 12,665,000 on Dec. 31, 1934, and 14,208,000 two years before, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Choice of Frank W. Caldwell, engineering manager of the Hamilton Standard propeller division of the United Aircraft Manufacturing Corporation of East Hartford, Conn., as recipient for 1935 of the Sylvanus Albert Reed Award, was made public yesterday by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP). -- Creation of a "geographically and economically integrated power system" in the United States was visioned today by the Federal Power Commission.

The Maroons of Montreal prevented the New York Americans from lifting themselves out of last place in the International Group of the National Hockey League last night. The Canadian sextet handed Red Button's team a 2-to-1 defeat in a bitterly contested battle at Madison Square Garden while a crowd of 11,000 persons looked on.

Philip Crandall being the sort of chap he is, his wife and son have to murder him, and Roy Hargrave, actor and author, has made eight elegant scenes of it, "A Room in Red and White," which was put on at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre on Saturday evening.

In the debate last week on the soldiers' bonus, Senator HARRISON expressed his hope that the President will sign the new bill when it reaches him, and gave as a reason for this hope his belief that "there is a great difference between this bill and the one he "vetoed." How wide is this difference?

President Franklin D. Roosevelt emphasized the fight for social justice and progress in government carried on by his cousin and predecessor. Theodore Roosevelt, in an address yesterday afternoon at the dedication of the New York State Theodore Roosevelt Memorial at the American Museum of Natural History.
Mayor La Guardia spoke in part as follows at the dedication yesterday of the New York State Theodore Roosevelt Memorial at the American Museum of Natural History:

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Selling of May wheat on all bulges and purchases of July furnished a large part of the speculative business in the wheat market here last week, May furnishing the greater part of the business. Price ranges were small, mostly lower except on oats, which finished 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel above the previous week.

GENEVA, Jan. 19. -- A full Italian delegation, including not only Baron Pompeo Aloisi, chief delegate, but also Dr. Guido Rocco, was among the first to arrive hero today for the ninetieth session of the League of Nations Council beginning tomorrow.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 19. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman was "surprised" to learn today that his own State police had been checking his clues in Bruno Hauptmann's case.

Frequent peals of thunder were heard distinctly yesterday afternoon in various parts of Manhattan. The first reported was at about 2:30 in the afternoon and it was followed by others at short intervals all afternoon.

The attitude of 642 college students and 220 parents on the matter of choosing a marriage partner is revealed in a six-year survey of the problem just completed by Dr. Ray Erwin Baber, Professor of Sociology, New York University.

It must be a joy these days to be a member of almost any of the various quasi-public organizations which, mediating between citizens and their officials, seek the improvement of this city's government. Civil service reformers have no cause for anxiety in an administration as utterly free from spoils-mongering as Mayor LA GUARDIA'S.

" The Puritan," scheduled to relight the Belmont tonight, instead will wait until Thursday to celebrate that event. "Construction difficulties" in rebuilding the house was the explanation given yesterday for the postponement.

Senator Robert F. Wagner yesterday defended government interference in business as a means to attaining better wages and working standards and fairer competitive practices. Measures along this line are necessary, he said, to "safeguard the majority of fair-minded people from the destructive tactics of the unruly few."

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Lawyers involved in the reorganization of Middle West Utilities Company valued their time at $21 to $100 an hour, examination of the requests for fees aggregating more than $1,600,000 indicates.

CHIPLEY, Fla., Jan. 19. -- A weekend toll of seventeen deaths was caused by off-season tornadoes which struck three Southern States, leaving extensive property damage and two-score rural residents injured.

BOMBAY, Jan. 19. -- The picturesque ceremony of weighing the Aga Khan against gold was the principal feature of the opening of the celebration of his fiftieth year as head of the Ismailian sect of Mohammedans here today. He receives from his followers each year his weight in gold.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- Millions of King George's subjects spent an anxious morning at their radio sets today, listening at fifteen-minute intervals to bulletins telling of the Sovereign's fight for life.

The transatlantic passenger traffic between ports of the United States and Canada and Europe last year totaled 594,698, an increase of 23,654 over the 1934 total of 571,044, according to reports prepared by the Atlantic Passenger Conference. The United States ports had 506,541 of this total and the Canadian ports 88,157.

Several sales of business and residential properties in various parts of Long Island were announced yesterday. Among the deals was one involving the three-story commercial building at 166-13 Jamaica Avenue, in the business section of Jamaica, which was acquired by Gross Lemmerman, a client of Brunswick, Praver Nassof, Inc.
Although fewer than in the preceding week, announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity included more substantial blocks.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 19. -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, predicted tonight the complete unionization of automobile workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The administration is understood to be preparing to rush through Congress amendments to the Federal Housing Act which would send increased funds into the building industry and stimulate what already is being termed a "boom" in the construction field.

Argument on a motion to discontinue the suit brought by twenty-eight members against the Building Service Employes International Union will be heard this morning by Justice Samuel I. Rosenman in Supreme Court.

Net operating profit of $1,258,359 after all charges, including interest, amortization and depreciation but before Federal income taxes, was reported yesterday by Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., for the thirteen weeks ended on Nov. 30 last.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 19. -- A sort of "haven for homeless hounds," the nearest thing to a dog heaven that architects could conceive, will be complete and ready for occupancy here within a few weeks.

T.H. Lawrence broke 96 out of a possible 100 targets to win the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. It was, an exceptionally fine score considering the poor shooting conditions. The handicap prize was taken by J.P. Hennessy, who finished with a card of 86-1399.

The Roosevelt Memorial dedication exercises yesterday were an extraordinary tribute to the memory of that great American and world citizen THEODORE ROOSEVELT. The addresses were discerning and eloquent of the rare diversity of his gifts, his amazing energy and his genius in understanding his fellow-mortals.
Only once did the disk find the net in seventy minutes of the most hectic sort of hockey, but that gave Hershey a 1-to-0 triumph over the New York Rovers yesterday afternoon.

Mr. OGDEN MILLS is by knowledge and experience the most competent among Republican leaders to discuss the fiscal aspects of the Administration's program. It is a reasonable guess that he will have an important hand in formulating, in the Republican platform, criticisms of the legislation since March 4, 1933.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- Among all the expressions of sympathy that poured into London and Sandringham today none touched the British people more than a personal message from King Victor Emmanuel of Italy.

More than three hundred and fifty years ago the first sermon in what is now the United States was preached to a group of French Huguenot colonists standing on the banks of a river in the wilderness of South Carolina under a blue banner on which was embroidered three golden fleurs-de-lis.

Leases of commercial space along Broadway featured the business renting activity as reported by realty brokers yesterday. Several novelty firms took sales space in that district and a dance studio rented the entire second floor of the new taxpayer at the northeast corner of Broadway and Fifty-third Street, completing the occupancy of that structure.

A storm that continued all day yesterday covered New York City with an eight-inch mixture of snow and sleet, making walking and automobile traffic difficult, but failing to interfere greatly with railroads and ferries.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $2,102,000 of Houston (Texas) Independent School District 3 per cent bonds by a banking group headed by Edward B. Smith Co. and including Goldman, Sachs Co., F.S. Moseley Co. The Boatmen's National Bank, St. Louis; the Equitable Securities Corporation, McDonald-Coolidge Co., Garret Co., John B. Carroll Co. and Moroney Co., Houston.

MANILA, Jan. 19. -- President Quezon's release yesterday of the bandit Kulas Encallado, who triumphantly returned to his home town in the President's car accompanied by high officials, was severely criticized both privately and publicly today.

Purchasing of the new Spring apparel lines got under way in the local wholesale markets last week and a fairly substantial volume of business was placed. Tailored suits and the casual type sport coats received the bulk of the orders, with the former fulfilling earlier predictions of their popularity.

Emmanuel Feuermann gave a 'cello recital last night in Town Hall. In spite of bad weather outside, he gathered an audience which, if it did not fill the auditorium, showed its appreciation of the art of an extraordinary master of his instrument.

The Giuditta Guild of the Cenacle of the St. Regis will be aided by a supper dance and entertainment to be known as a "Shipboard Gala Night," next Saturday in the Louis XVI ballroom of the Park Lane. The occasion will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of Mother Ferri's work at the Cenacle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Professors were matched against professors by the American Liberty League today to demonstrate that many educators throughout the country do not subscribe to the views of their colleagues of the "Brain Trust" on policies of the New Deal.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- Geoffrey Toye today announced his resignation as managing director of the Covent Garden Opera Company owing to "differences of opinion between the directors and myself with regard to questions of policy, management and financial control."
Governor Herbert H. Lehman, at the dedication yesterday of the New York State Theodore Roosevelt Memorial at the American Museum of Natural History, said in part:

Democracy may be superseded in every country throughout the world, but the Christian spirit will remain steadfast regardless of what the social order may be, the Rev. Dr. Charles J. Smith, president of Roanoke College, Salem, Va., said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Sixty-fifth Street and Central Park West. Dr. Smith was for many years the pastor of the church.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (AP). -- The official Soviet News Agency, in a dispatch from Ulan Bator (Urga), Outer Mongolia, said tonight that Manchukuoan soldiers had made a new penetration of Monoglian territory.

Many card parties in behalf of organizations that carry on extensive educational and recreational programs for the relief of the needy and handicapped have been arranged for the near future. Under the auspices of the Junior League of the Walter Scott Free Industrial School for Crippled Children, a card party will be held Tuesday afternoon in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis.

Recreational activities for youth conducted by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will be reorganized in part into a new Catholic Youth Association, it was announced yesterday by Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, as a part of its study of investment trusts and investment companies, has addressed a comprehensive questionnaire to virtually all such trusts and companies of the management type.

With the season past the half way mark, New York University and Long Island University continued their unbeaten paths in a week which proved disastrous for most other leading Eastern college of the basketball teams.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 19. -- In the same court room setting, but in an atmosphere somewhat changed, the Scottsboro case, cause celebre of the South, will go to trial again tomorrow before County Judge William Washington Callahan and a jury on which, for the first time in half a century, Negroes have a chance, though a small one, of being included.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP). -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, frequently mentioned as a Republican Presidential possibility, presented today his plan for solving the farm problem -- a two-price system.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Prices of hogs here fluctuated sharply over a fairly wide range last week. The top price, $10.20 a hundredweight, was made at the beginning of the week. It compared with $9.75 in the preceding week. On Friday the top was $10.05.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 19.--Governor O.K. Allen defied the Federal Government today to send agents into the State for Tuesday's Democratic primary, and told election commissioners they could "kick President Roosevelt out if you want to."

William Coyle Jr. and Conway Hoffman of the Montelair A.C. came through with the first major upset in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association doubles championship yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn when they defeated the third seeded pair, G.H. Walker Jr. of the Field Club and P.W. Bunnell of the Yale Club.

BEACON, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- A young woman, seriously injured in an automobile accident, was carried more than a mile on a stretcher through the snow near here late today when an ambulance was unable to get through a traffic jam caused by the storm.

An alliance between Communists and religious organizations would be disastrous, the Rev. John Sutherland Bonnell of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning on "Atheism in Russia."

TOKYO, Jan. 19.--Incidents along the borders of Manchukuo have recently taken on a significantly changed form, with Soviet and Outer Mongolian forces offering active and even aggressive resistance. Russia in its military power along the border is superior to Japan and, finding diplomatic protests ineffective, is adopting a new policy of reprisal.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Compared with those of other countries, British commodity prices have been relatively stable for the past three years, but in recent months there has been an increase in the rate of advance and the underlying tone of almost all commodities is much stronger.

Notwithstanding multiplying signs that Congress will override even a veto of the Soldiers' Bonus Bill, with all of that measure's implications in regard to Federal budgeting, business recovery pursued its course last week. On the Stock Exchange the rise of prices halted, though without reaction; the week's steel production did the same.

People even tried to get into the National Motor Boat Show yesterday, blizzard and all. Or, perhaps the be-mufflered gentleman who in the late afternoon mistook the front entrance watchman for a ticket seller and proffered him 55 cents was merely trying to find a warm haven out of the storm.

TOKYO, Jan. 19.--Incidents along the borders of Manchukuo have recently taken on a significantly changed form, with Soviet and Outer Mongolian forces offering active and even aggressive resistance. Russia in its military power along the border is superior to Japan and, finding diplomatic protests ineffective, is adopting a new policy of reprisal.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Compared with those of other countries, British commodity prices have been relatively stable for the past three years, but in recent months there has been an increase in the rate of advance and the underlying tone of almost all commodities is much stronger.

Contrary to some reports heard in construction circles, the cost of various basic building materials today generally is less than for any mid-January period since 1926, according to Myron L. Matthews, writing in the Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 19 (AP). -- With the prosecution hinting at "startling disclosures," more than 115 witnesses were marshaled today for the trial of Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld on charges of slaying Walter W. Liggett, publisher.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- The Eastern States senior speed skating title went to Jack Shannon of Troy today as he triumphed in the 220-yard dash and half mile and took second in the 440 to run up 80 points. Second place went to Joseph Barton of Albany, with George Wallace, Dartmouth College sophomore, third.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Gold imports in December were reported today as amounting to 15,921,000 and exports to 8,000,000, making the total imports for the year 244,091,000, compared with 262,483,000 in 1934. Exports of the metal were 174,020,000, against 128,713,000 in 1934.

Another week of thickly crowding new exhibitions opens in the local galleries. If there are no large museum shows, such as those at the Whitney and the Museum of Modern Art last week, there nevertheless are a sufficient number of unusual attractions among the thirty or more initiated over the week-end or to be given during the next few days to insure the gallery goer against any possibility of doldrums.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Jan. 19. -- Miss Margaret Winner, an artist, said today that her granduncle, William E. Winner, probably was the painter of the portrait of Edgar Allan Poe which was found about two months ago in a second-hand store and placed on exhibition at the Poe House today, the 127th anniversary of the author's birth.

It was certainly both a unique and enlightening experience for one, after driving for nine years in the city without once having received a summons, to find himself behind the bars sentenced to a two-day imprisonment for passing a red light.

FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- A raging snowstorm that obscured visibility caused the indefinite postponement of the second annual Dutchess County ski jump scheduled for today on the renovated hill of the Norway Ski Club. The calling off of the tournament marked the first time in the thirteen-year history of the sport in the metropolitan area that it was necessary to do so because of a snowstorm.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP). -- Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, the nation's third ranking tennis player, won the annual Dixie championship by turning back Martin Buxby of Miami, in straight sets today, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- Steps taken by the State Department of Health to control pneumonia are outlined in the weekly bulletin of the department which will be released tomorrow. The lines along which the campaign is being conducted are as follows:
PARIS, Jan. 18. -- The money market is still narrow here, and the rates do not deviate from the official rate excepting for call money, which at times costs 3 1/2 per cent.

Incorporation of the Risk Research Institute, the first national organization of insurance buyers and self-insurers in the United States, was announced yesterday by the Insurance Buyers of New York. A.A. Schmidt of the Johns-Manville Corporation is president of the institute, which will establish headquarters at 30 Church Street.

Strength was the rule in the commodity future markets here last week, with trading in general proceeding at an active pace. The metals, silk and hides did not share in the improvement, easing moderately in the week. On the cash markets, corn, rye, oats, lard, wool tops, raw sugar, coffee, rubber and gasoline were higher, while wheat cotton, dairy products, pork, beef, cocoa, silk and antimony were lower.

The audience which braved the weather last night to attend the performance of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their concert company at the Guild Theatre was generously rewarded by an evening not only delightful in content but also novel in form and significant in direction.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- Robert (Bob) Linney drove the Lyon Mountain Miners to first place in the National A.A.U. junior four-man bobsled championship on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run this morning with a total time for the four heats of 4 minutes 42.06 seconds.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- Imports in 1935 amounted to 20,945,000,000 francs, a decrease of 2,152,000,000 francs, compared with the total for 1934. Imports of foodstuffs amounted to 6,230,000,000 francs, a decline of 1,253,000,000 francs. Raw materials were 11,182,000,000 francs, a decline of 190,000,000 francs.

Apartment houses in Manhattan and varied types of property in the Bronx figured in the active realty transactions reported by brokers over the week-end. Several West Side apartment properties were involved in the trading.

SANDRINGHAM, England, Jan. 19. -- Several hundred persons were waiting in the snow outside the royal grounds of Sandringham House this morning when the bulletin telling of King George's restless night was posted on the newly finished Jubilee Gate.

HANDLED by almost any one other than Booth Tarkington "The Lorenzo Bunch" (Doubleday, Doran, $2) would have developed into a depressing, but obviously effective, study of the futile viciousness of which bored little people can sometimes be capable.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in December showed a net reduction of $260,000,000. This was due to temporary influences such as a net withdrawal of $450,000,000 from the market through Treasury transactions, but the effect on excess reserves was in part offset by a further increase of $200,000,000 in the monetary gold stock, according to the monthly Federal Reserve bulletin issued today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP). -- The Black Hawks strengthened their hold on third place in the American division of the National Hockey League tonight by conquering the Boston Bruins, 2 to 1, in a lively battle before 13,500 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.
