NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19. -- Trading on the Cotton Exchange here last week was somewhat more active than it had been, although uncertainties as to the effect of recent decisions by the United States Supreme Court and also as to what Congress might do to offset the setbacks received by the New Deal caused periods of comparative quiet.

Man cannot simplify his life "by surrendering religion and trying to live the good life," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, said in his sermon yesterday morning. "As soon as any one takes goodness seriously," he declared, "he begins to face, in his goodness itself, all the central problems of religion."

The Detroit Edison Company has reported for 1935 a consolidated net income of $9,677,957 after all deductions, equal to $7.61 a share on 1,272,260 capital shares, compared with $5,448,331, or $4.28 a share, reported for 1934.

Although marked progress has been made in the acquisition of park areas in the last two years, there still is need for more playgrounds and parks in or near congested sections of the city, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger declared yesterday in her annual report as president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 20. -- The Diet, which reassembles tomorrow, will be dissolved as soon as the customary official speeches have been made. A general election will follow next month.

Many reservations have been made for the fashion revue, entertainment and tea for the benefit of Hope Farm on Thursday at the Ritz-Carlton. Younger members of society headed by Miss Beatrice Butler are aiding in the plans for the entertainment and have announced that stars of the theatre, motion pictures and radio are to appear.

Pounding along to what now appears to be an almost certain championship in the metropolitan league, the Columbia University Class C squash tennis team administered a one-sided defeat to the Princeton Club on the letter's courts last night.

The Transit Commission is scheduled to approve today the abandonment by the New York Railways system of trolley service on all of its remaining routes and the purchase by the company of buses to be run instead of the old Green Line trolley cars.

LONDON. -- Although King George earned the title of "The Sailor King," comparatively few of his subjects now living are aware how he earned it, except that they know that at one time or other he served in the navy.

Some interest has been expressed in the term "horsing" and its meaning among printers. The accepted definition in the trade, as applied to proofreading, is the reading of proof without consulting (holding) the copy.

Works Progress Administration officials in Washington ordered yesterday a slight modification in rules which will make it possible for some persons who have not been on the relief rolls before Nov. 1 to obtain jobs on WPA projects here.

It will be interesting to see whether the publication this morning of news that $56,000,000 has been refunded in taxes by the Federal Government, mostly to large taxpayers, causes a stir in Congress. When the Democrats were the "out" party, rather than the "in," they seldom let an event of this kind pass without a display of oratory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- By a vote of 74 to 16 the Senate today passed after about three hours' further consideration the "baby bond" Soldiers' Bonus Bill, whose total cost in outlays soon and eventually is estimated at from $2,491,000,000 to $2,864,000,000.

The Board of Estimate appropriated $1,000,000 yesterday for snow removal, while the Department of Sanitation estimated that it would take a week to clear all the streets, despite the progress made by 50,000 men already put to work with shovels and mechanical equipment.

In the twenty years or more since the proposing by various students of education that children be classified on the basis of "mental ability" into two or three streams, each given a curriculum supposedly adapted to the ability of those in that stream, there have been put into action in many school systems quite thorough applications of this plan.
The midwinter meeting of the Federal Wholesale Druggists As-i soeiatton will be held at the Hotel loosevelt on Feb, 25 to 27.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Part of the fight for the airwaves as a vehicle for political oratory was tossed into the lap of the Federal Communications Commission today.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- Lou Brouillard's bid for the world's middleweight boxing championship failed tonight when the Worcester, Mass., veteran was disqualified in the fourth round of his scheduled 15-round bout with Marcel Thil of France, generally recognized as king of the division.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Pressing a program which would almost double its present air fighting strength by 1942, the navy placed an order today for 114 torpedo-bombers to be used on two new aircraft carriers scheduled for completion next year.

Hobart D. Betts, electrical engineer, who died in a ten-story fall on Oct. 28, 1934, left an estate appraised yesterday at $492,956 gross and $467,091 net. Delia McGovern, family employe, received the income from $25,000, while a fund of $49,944 was left to Margaret B. Mason, the fund consisting of Mr. Betts' interest in the estate of his mother.

Fake charitable organizations, run by an organized gang of offenders and chartered under the law of the State as religious corporations, have been duping persons in New York out of thousands of dollars a year in "contributions" solicited by "telephone salesmen" impersonating accredited persons, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, revealed yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20. -- Putting aside his perfect fool's cap, Ed Wynn entered a new phase of his career as a theatrical producer at Ford's Theatre tonight with the first performance on any stage of a serious drama called "The Light Behind the Shadow."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP). -- Wiffy Cox of Bethesda, Md., registered an eagle 3 on the thirteenth green today to defeat Bill Mehlhorn of Louisville, Ky., in an eighteen-hole play-off for first prize in the $3,000 Sacramento open golf championship.

The Townsend plan, if adopted, would surely bring about a collapse in our commercial and financial structure equal to, if not exceeding, any we have seen, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The future of the Tennessee Valley Authority, a major element in the Roosevelt administration's New Deal program, was left hanging in the balance until Feb. 3 at the earliest when the Supreme Court adjourned today until that date without handing down an opinion on the constitutionality of the act creating the Authority.

Democracy in many parts of the world is imperiled, and in this country democracy never needed more a "rebirth of flaming, violent, stirring, passionate" defenders than it does today, speakers at a birthday dinner in honor of Mrs. Harriot Stanton Blatch said last night.

With the death of King George the whole world, and more especially that quarter of the earth's surface over which floats the Union Jack, turns its eyes toward the slight wiry figure upon whose head must rest the imperial diadem that symbolizes the commonweal of Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- A capacity house opened its heart to "Call It a Day," the Theatre Guild-Lee Ephraim production which opened at the National Theatre tonight, with Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper starring.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20. -- The California State Railroad Commission approved today the absorption of five power companies by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, but only after it had whittled valuations by approximately $11,000,000. Unless protested by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, an order of the commission to that effect will become operative within twenty days.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- The Boerse was quiet today. Heavy industrials were slightly stronger, Mannesmann gaining one point. Machines were firm, Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 1 1/2 points. Chemicals were firm, I.G. Farben gaining 1/2 point. Electricals were firmer.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 21. -- Within a few minutes of the King's death almost every corner of the earth had heard the news.

Queen Mary, widow of King George, who became Dowager Queen on his death, is the daughter of Francis Paul Charles Louis Alexander, Duke of Teck. She was born at Kensington Palace on May 26, 1867, and was christened Victoria Mary Augusta Louise Olga Pauline Claudine Agnes.

Establishing a new record for first day attendance at a January furniture opening here, the New York Furniture Exchange yesterday launched its seasonal showing of Spring and Summer furniture lines with 1,100 buyers in attendance.
Public officials and leaders in many walks of life expressed regret last night at the death of King George V and praised him as a monarch and a man. Some of the tributes follow:

GENEVA, Tuesday, Jan. 21. -- Discussion in the committee of thirteen yesterday made it fairly certain that the League of Nations' action on oil sanctions would be limited for the present to naming a committee of experts to consider how existing sanctions are working, whether others such as that on oil are needed and under what conditions they would be effective.

The first railroad to report for 1935, the Texas Pacific Railway, showed yesterday a net income of $1,382,278, or 51 cents a share, on the common stock for the year. This compared with $1,031,944, or $4.35 a share, on the 5 per cent preferred in 1934. The preliminary statement for 1935 follows:

IN Bella and Samuel Spewack's play about Hollywood, "Boy Meets Girl," a movie writer is effervescing about his imminent release from the job of grinding out innocent dialogue for the Shirley Temples of this world. "I've chartered a plane," Be bubbles, "right for Vermont. . . . . I'm going to bare my soul. I'm going to write life in the raw.

A year ago St. John's had a pretty good basketball team, but it lacked spark and drive. When its scoring twins, Rip Kaplinsky and Java Gotkin, had "on" nights, the Redmen looked like a great combination. But when they couldn't find the hoop, or bewildered their teammates more than the opposition with their tricky ball-handling, then Buck Freeman's young men were very ordinary indeed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20.--Twenty hearings, at which twenty-six companies seeking exemption from the provisions of Title I of the Public Utility Act of 1935 will have an opportunity to place their arguments before examiners, were set today by the Securities Exchange Commission.

The condition of the city's streets yesterday kept down the number of persons who renewed their automobile licenses, but several thousands applied at the main offices as well as at the twelve temporary branches opened for the first time in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- King George's last official act was to appoint today Queen Mary and their four sons -- the Prince of Wales and the Dukes of York, Gloucester and Kent -- as a Council of State to act for him during his illness in such public matters as could be delegated and normally would require the personal attention of the monarch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- A bill to permit teachers in District of Columbia schools to "give the facts" about communism to their pupils as a means of combating it was introduced today by Representative Fred J. Sisson, Democrat, of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- A compilation of rules under the Securities Act of 1933, rearranged for purposes of clarification and containing amendments which have been adopted from time to time, was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, to become effective on March 15.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 21.--George V, King and Emperor, passed peacefully last night in the twenty-sixth year of his reign and the seventy-first year of his life out of a world in which he had faced manfully much tribulation.

An increase of 19,030,000 passengers on the city's transportation facilities for the quarter ended Sept. 30, 1935, as compared with the same quarter of 1934, was noted in a report issued yesterday by the Transit Commission, summarizing rapid transit operations for that period.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20. -- John Masefield, Poet Laureate of England, said tonight there was "no subject of all King George's 500,000,000 subjects who will not mourn for the great, good and gentle ruler now gone to his rest."

Prices on the commodity futures markets yesterday were generally lower. Sugar futures gained slightly and coffee, which has been advancing steadily recently, lost ground. In the cash markets, raw sugar and dairy products were higher, while wheat, corn, rye, tin and silk were lower.

With the financial community generally expecting that the United States Supreme Court would announce a decision yesterday on the Tennessee Valley Authority, the news at midday that the court would issue no important rulings caused the share market to revert to the irregularity of last week.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Foreign Minister Koki Hirota, speaking before the reconvened Japanese Diet, reiterated today a three-point program for the "readjustment of relationships between Japan, Manchukuo and China."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be the chief speaker tomorrow night at a dinner which will open the eleventh conference on the Cause and Cure of War. More than 700 women delegates will be in attendance.

King George V was trained to be a sailor, not a King. His youth was spent amid the rigor and discipline of the British Navy, and he was destined to follow in the footsteps of his uncle, the Duke of Edinburgh, and ultimately obtain an important naval command.

The General Public Service Corporation reported yesterday that the market value of its assets was $8,772,293 at the close of 1935, after giving effect to the redemption on Jan. 1, 1936, of $1,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent debentures. This was equivalent to $151.38 a share of preferred stock and to $1.02 a share on common stock after allowing $100 a share and accumulated dividends on the preferred shares.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved irregularly over a range of about 15 points yesterday, influenced in the early dealings by a decline in Liverpool. There was a strenthening in the last hour on the Supreme Court's order for the release of processing tax payments in escrow.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 20 (AP).--Discovery of an automatic pistol and a piece of twisted metal through which an object about the size of a bullet had been driven resulted in fresh speculation tonight concerning the cause for the crash of the passenger plane Southerner near Goodwin, Ark., last Tuesday.

Decision as to whether supporters of President Roosevelt under the leadership of Postmaster General James A. Farley will start a fight to oust James J. Pooling as leader of Tammany may depend upon the extent to which former Governor Alfred E. Smith goes in attacking the President and the New Deal.

In the Atlantic for February a Washington correspondent, Mr. LAWRENCE SULLIVAN, sets forth in merciless detail the impairment of the merit system under the present Administration and the enthronement of political spoils. The percentage of officeholders appointed or promoted after examination has steadily declined.
Syracuse, N.Y., will open bids today for a new issue of $2,000,000 of short-term notes. They will be dated Jan. 23 and become payable on Oct. 23.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Lieutenant Robert K. Giovannoli of Lexington, Ky., on duty with the Army Air Corps at Dayton, was selected today to receive the Cheney Award for 1935, in recognition of his "extreme bravery" in the rescue of two men from a burning plane at Dayton on Oct. 30.

The French liner Paris, which was withdrawn from the transatlantic service last May to make way for the new liner Normandie, will return to the service March as a cabin-class ship, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- With the farm situation created by the rulings of the Supreme Court in the various AAA cases still unsettled, President Roosevelt summoned a conference of farm and Congressional leaders to meet tomorrow to discuss the problem.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Douglas Fairbanks Jr. revealed himself a true son of his father in a swashbuckling film, "The Amateur Gentleman," his first venture with his recently formed Criterion Film Productions, Ltd., which had a charity premiere at the London Pavilion tonight.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 21. -- The hand of death lay upon London last night. It was a stunned and silent crowd of several hundreds that stood outside Buckingham Palace just after midnight when the notice announcing that the King had died was posted on the railing.
LONDON, Jan. 20. -- "A reign of great deeds, great sufferings, great perils and great splendor is ended."

LONDON. -- The era of Queen Victoria was marked by monumental literary figures and products that stamped it as a remarkable and advanced age of letters. Though her grandson's reign was within narrower boundaries in terms of years, his period, too, was one of prolific literary output.

Buyers' arrivals from all sections of the country were heavy yesterday, with every indication being that this week will see peak activity in preparation for the early part of the Spring season. Practically all store divisions were represented in the gathering of buyers here, with particular emphasis on women's apparel and home furnishings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Jan. 15 shows increases for the week of $79,000,000 in total loans and investments, $71,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, $97,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $109,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

Hints that the Metropolitan Museum of Art may not be able to continue its policy of lending works of art to European and American institutions for special exhibitions are contained in the annual report of the museum's trustees.

Warning the municipal authorities against saddling the city with too heavy a burden of relief projects, the Citizens Budget Commission revealed in its annual report yesterday that PWA construction contracts entered into by the city as of Jan. 1 amounted to $126,871,351, of which the municipality is pledged to pay $85,462,313.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 (Canadian Press). -- On behalf of the government and people of Canada, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King cabled tonight to the new sovereign a message of loyalty and affection, and expressions of sympathy in his bereavement.

It may be confidently predicted that when LINCOLN ELLSWORTH gets back to New York at least three things will happen to him. (1) He will catch a heavy cold which most likely will confine him to his home for several days, but which he will succeed in throwing off nicely, provided he takes care not to expose himself to drafts.

The good faith of the Republican party was at stake in the Senate of the United States when the veterans' bonus was brought to a vote. Opportunity was afforded to show whether the party of HAMILTON and COOLIDGE was really opposed to spending when funds were not available, or whether it merely opposed that form of spending for which credit was to go to the other political party.

ROME, Jan. 20. -- Today's official war bulletin confirms the sweeping nature of General Rodolfo Graziani's victory on the Somaliland front. His forces on Saturday advanced 140 miles along the main road from Dolo to Allata and are now believed very near Noghelli, formerly Ras Desta Demtu's headquarters and main base.

With only twelve days remaining in a joint drive of the Y.M.C.A. and the Y.W.C.A. to raise $600,000, workers reported yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore that $247,250, or 41 per cent of the total sought, had been contributed. The total reported for last week was $68,361.
As an American citizen, member of the Federal electorate and a taxpayer wish to endorse your analytical review and editorial policy of opposition to the payment of the double bonus with "baby bonds."

Marian Anderson, the Negro contralto, a born singer and a very sincere and thoughtful musician, gave her second New York recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. She has returned to this country this Winter after remarkable achievements and recognition in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Friends of Senator Borah were planning an open appeal today to the Negro voters of the country in an effort to offset any opposition against his candidacy for the Presidency because of his views against Federal anti-lynching laws.

Concurrently with an offering by Allen Industries, Inc., to its common stockholders of 39,600 shares of common stock, F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., will offer to the public today suck of these shares as are not taken by the stockholders, at $19 a share, subject to allotment upon determination of the number of shares brought by stockholders.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 21. -- Edward VIII, who at the age of 41 became King at the moment of his father's death just before midnight, will be publicly proclaimed as sovereign today.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20. -- Points came rapidly to Dave (Sweeney) Schriner last week as the star left winger set the pace for the New York Americans in their fight for a higher berth in the standings. The New York player opened a lead of three points over all pointmakers in the National Hockey League.

On the motion of Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor, Supreme Court Justice Rogers in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday a murder indictment filed by the November grand jury against Morris Luckman in the death of Samuel Drukman. The defendant was released after the extraordinary grand jury had informed the court that its investigation gave no cause for his indictment by the new body.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 20. -- Troops were called out in Clarke and Floyd counties today, where labor disorders broke out at the New Albany and Jeffersonville plants of M. Fine Sons, shirt makers.
Donald A. Hobart, commander of the American Veterans Association,expressed his disappointment yesterday over the Senate's action on the Bonus Bill.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- Active use of the British equalization fund held the franc today at 75 to the pound for-sterling with, of course, the probable consequence that francs bought will be converted into gold for export to London. The dollar recovered all that it had lost last week when there were rumors of further devaluation, and closed once more at 15.16 francs.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20. -- The Wheatley Stable's 4-year-old colt Bellum, a son of Pompey that began his racing career at Tropical Park on Christmas Day, drove home a victor in the Arcardia Claiming Handicap as the first full week of the Miami Jockey Club's meeting began at Hialeah Park today.

Tonight's opening is, of course, "Ethan Frome," derived from Edith Wharton's novel by a series of dramatists starting with Lowell Barrington and ending with the Davises, father and son, Owen and Donald. The National is the theatre and the company includes Pauline Lord, Ruth Gordon and Raymond Massey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20.--With sudden swiftness breaking a precedent of years, the Supreme Court today issued mandates making immediately effective its recent decisions declaring the Agricultural Adjustment Act unconstitutional and ordering $200,000,000 of impounded AAA taxes returned to processors.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 20. -- The opening of Haywood Patterson's fourth trial here today for an attack on Victoria Price, five years ago, was marked by an innovation in the selection of a jury to try him for his life.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 12. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman challenged the constitutionality of the Federal Security Act program tonight in regard to the plans for unemployment insurance and the taxation of employers.
Strengthening of the State minimum wage laws through adequate appropriations for their enforcement was urged yesterday at a meeting called by the Consumers League of New York at 99 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- Cold weather, with heavy snow and icy roads in the West, curtailed the receipts of hogs here today and stimulated the demand for fresh pork. This resulted in aggressive buying of hogs. Prices were lifted 15 to 25 cents a hundred weight with the top of $10.20, showing 15 cents above Friday's level and within 5 cents of the best level since Oct. 17.

The estate of James E. O'Neill, who died as an expatriate in France in 1931 following his defiance of a summons to testify in the Teapot Dome lease inquiry, returned $750,000 to the Continental Trading Company on instructions he gave just before his death, it was asserted yesterday.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, lacks "the human qualities necessary to achieve the widespread confidence of his faculty and his student body and to provide genuinely inspired, resourceful and socially imaginative leadership," in the opinion of a special committee of the Associate Alumni of the college.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 20. -- John Creighton, husband of Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, who is on trial here with Everett R. Applegate, charged jointly with the poison murder last September of Applegate's wife, Ada, testified today that he did not "believe" his wife had anything to do with the death of Mrs. Applegate.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 20. -- In an effort to clarify for the colleges what industry wants in college graduates it places in jobs, the opening session of the Watt bicentenary program at Lehigh University today was devoted to a panel discussion of "The College Graduate in Industry."

Twenty-seven of the 200 largest commercial banks and trust companies in the United States are in this city. The Chase National Bank is still the leader, followed by the National City Bank and the Guaranty Trust Company, according to the copyrighted annual roll-call of The American Banker for 1935.

The premiere of "The Living Newspaper," first of the Federal Theatre Project shows scheduled for a Broadway house, is postponed from tomorrow night to Jan. 29 at the Biltmore Theatre, it was announced yesterday.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate reported favorably yesterday on the application of District Attorney William C. Dodge for a $50,000 appropriation to prosecute bond and mortgage cases now pending.
The memory of Lenin was honored again last night by 18,000 Communists, who packed Madison Square Garden on the eve of the twelfth anniversary of the Soviet leader's death.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The Sparks-Withington Company, manufacturer of electric and radio accessories, reported a profit of $46,219 for the six months ended on Dec. 31, after ordinary taxes and depreciation but before Federal income taxes. In the corresponding period of the preceding year the company had a net loss of $148,977.

Now that boat building and boat racing affairs in America seem to be on a surging wave of progress for 1936 and the next few years, the solons and moguls and ordinary folk who are swarming into Grand Central Palace this week spent yesterday looking overseas and pondering about foreign affairs.

IT has been a hard Winter and it seems to be getting harder all the time for some of the stick-swingers on skates. Red Dutton's star-spangled Americans were tucked away on the lowest shelf in the icebox the other evening.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S description of Dr. FRANKLIN as "an inspiration to every American citizen" must be taken as gracious general approval of an illustrious and a varied career. It should not be thought approval of certain blemishes that enlightened citizens of today have to pass over or forgive.

For the first time in nearly two centuries a bachelor King now rules over England. He is the fifth unmarried ruler since William the Conqueror was proclaimed King in 1066. Three other Kings, William II, Edward V and Edward VI never married, and there was one unmarried Queen, Elizabeth.

Educators were the guests of honor last night at the thirty-seventh annual dinner of the Society of the Genesee at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The dinner, "dedicated to higher education," was also a tribute to the society's founder, the late Louis Wiley, who last February planned this year's dinner and suggested the list of honor guests.

The new King is the thirty-eighth sovereign of England from the time of and including William the Conqueror, who as Duke of Normandy in. 1066 defeated the Saxon King Harold at the battle of Hastings and was crowned King of England by the Archbishop of York at Westminster Abbey in December of that year.

Decrying the lack of suitable boat basins for metropolitan yachtsmen, Arthur E. Barton last night at a meeting of the Waterway League of America presented a definite plan for a proposed municipal basin to be constructed on the land of the Dock Department along the Hudson River, between 145th and 154th Streets.
The announcement that the British Government is no longer averse to the "big ship," heavily gunned, represents a significant about-face in British naval policy.

Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper told the National Retail Dry Goods Association last night that a constructive basis had been laid for a better cooperative relationship between business and government.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 20. -- Despite rain and cold weather, Arthur F. Lynch of Mamaroneck, N.Y., the 1935 winner, turned in a fine card of 35, 39 -- 74 to lead the field in the qualifying round of the annual Miami Biltmore amateur golf tournament today.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- It was announced tonight that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, Sir James Barrie and Admiral Sir Roger Keyes would be among the pallbearers at Kipling's funeral in Westminster Abbey on Thursday. Mr. Baldwin's mother and Mr. Kipling's were sisters.

Joseph Weinstein, 33 years old, a "slugger" in strike disturbances, was sentenced to Sing Sing for seven to fifteen years yesterday by Judge James G. Wallace in General Sessions. He had pleaded guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the death of Philip Paone, 23, a non-union cobbler, in West Thirty-fourth Street, near Broadway.

The schedule makers of the National Hockey League have inadvertently produced an odd situation for those hockey fans who attend tonight's skirmish in Madison Square Garden between the Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks.
" Dangerous Waters," featuring Jack Holt, Robert Armstrong and Grace Bradley, opens with a preview tonight at the Rialto after the last screening of "The Crime of Dr. Crespi."

Arturo Toscanini will conduct one American work this season in New York with the Philharmonic-Symphony. This will be Emerson Whithorne's Second symphony. Mr. Whithorne will be the fifth American composer to be so honored by the maestro at these concerts.

With French leaders striving to avert a financial crisis due to the impending resignation of the Laval government, the franc wavered yesterday in the foreign exchange market and at one time approached the gold-export mark. With the official exchange control in London, however, absorbing the offerings of francs, the decline was held to a fraction, the franc closing at 6.59 3/4 cents.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- The Assembly adopted tonight a resolution expressing its sorrow on the death of King George. The resolution, offered by Majority Leader Oswald D. Heck, was directed to the Governor General of Canada. It follows
The United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company reported yesterday that its surplus increased by $2,190,552 last year, and that the profit from operations amounted to $1,526,821.

SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Whisking, 7-year-old gelding owned by J.H. Tate, equaled the Alamo Downs track record for 6 1/2 furlongs of 1:17 2-5 today in winning the $700 Castroville Purse, feature for 3-year-olds and up. The mark was set by Pharatime.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Notre Dame withstood a Syracuse drive in the final minutes of their basketball game tonight and the South Benders won, 46 to 43.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP). -Led by $3,366,666 for Swift Co., Chicago packers, a list of Federal tax refunds showed today that the Treasury handed $56,122,153 back to taxpayers in the last fiscal year.

Hal Valan of the St. Anselm's A.C. outpointed Joe Wall of the Salem-Crescent A.C. in the 115-pound special that featured the regular amateur boxing card at the New York Athletic Club last night before a gathering of 1,000. The fast Valan, essentially a boxer, parried Wall's hard-driven punches to squeeze through to victory.

A moderate decline developed yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. A downward readjustment was not unexpected in trading circles in view of the persistent advance in all classes in the last month. High-grade, as well as the more speculative bonds, were subjected to profit-taking and declines ranging from fractions to about a point ruled over a broad list of issues at the end of the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Internal revenue collections gained $59,794,173 during the six months ending Dec. 31 constituting the first half of the 1936 fiscal year as compared with the corresponding period of 1934, despite a reduction of $200,957,022 in the processing taxes which recently were invalidated by the Supreme Court, the Treasury announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- The British Government made a sharp upward revision tonight of its views on the maximum sizes of battleships, other types of warships and gun calibers. This development, reported by authoritative naval circles, apparently was a result both of Japan's withdrawal from the international naval conference and of the Italo-Ethiopian War.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 20. -- Regular graduate courses on automobile traffic control will be started next Fall by Harvard University's Bureau for Street Traffic Research in a scientific attack on automobile accidents. This is said to be the first move along this line by any university.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Some well-meaning friends tried to tender Big Bill Tilden a farewell luncheon today, but when the lanky veteran refused to say good-bye to his Boston public they hastily toned the title down to "fare-thee-well."

TOKYO, Jan. 20. -- The Japanese War Office and Foreign Office and the German Embassy denied today reports that Germany and Japan had signed a treaty of mutual military assistance. Each pointed out that similar reports had appeared during the past two years and each suggested that they originated in Moscow.

A vehicular tunnel piercing the rock hill in Mount Morris Park, which blocks Fifth Avenue from 120th to 124th Street, will be proposed soon to the Board of Estimate by Borough President Levy, it became known yesterday.

Jewel thieves, protected somewhat in their operations by snowdrifts that virtually had eliminated pedestrian traffic along Fifth Avenue, shattered one of the "invisible glass" show windows of Marcus Co., jewelers, at 671 Fifth Avenue a little before midnight Sunday and extracted three diamond rings valued at $1,200 each.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Makale and the holy city of Aksum, for weeks in the hands of Italian invaders, were said by high government sources today to be practically ringed with thousands of Ethiopian warriors.

Philip Wylie, author, entertains the utmost respect for Ernest Hemingway both as a contemporary literary figure and as a fisherman. He reads Hemingway's angling yarns avidly, but he has always felt that Ernest's stories about big-game angling contained entirely too much of what he chooses to call "hurrah."

The verb "individuate" has come into frequent use in the vocabulary of the teacher, though it is not new to the lexicon. Two hundred years ago Bishop BERKELEY ventured, though rather apologetically, to employ it in the passive voice in the passage.

The city can carry out its plan to demolish the Sixth Avenue elevated structure without breaking its contract with the I.R.T., in the opinion of Harold J. Cloutman, counsel to the Sixth Avenue Association, which has been urging the early razing of the line.

A conference of representatives of various city departments was held yesterday afternoon in Police Commissioner Valentine's office to formulate plans for meeting another emergency such as that created last Wednesday by the power breakdown.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 20. -- The Central Bank of Argentina reported today a net profit of 3,689,789 pesos from operations for the eight months from May 1, when it started operations, to Dec. 1, last.

The questionnaire sent by the Securities and Exchange Commission to investment trusts in connection with the investigation of them that is to be undertaken in accordance with a provision of the Public Utility Act of 1934 caused concern yesterday among executives of the trusts chiefly because of its voluminous nature.

LONDON. -- Whatever stories are being told today of King George are stories of a conventional English country gentleman, a man of warm heart, wide sympathy and, to all those who met him, straight, simple, sincere and kind.
King George's last address to all the people of his realm was broadcast Christmas afternoon from his study at Sandringham House. It follows:
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 20. -- Mrs. Charles Lewis Harding gave a tea for nearly 100 persons today at Chiora in honor of her house guest, Mrs. Lyttleton Fox of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- The House passed the Walsh-Tobey bill today, giving Congressional approval to the minimum-wage compact ratified by the Massachusetts and New Hampshire Legislatures and signed by Representatives of Connecticut, Rhode Island, Maine, New York and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20.--The death of King George caused deep sorrow and brought many expressions of grief here tonight. Official messages of condolence were sent to London by President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 20. -- The Owens-Illinois Glass Company's directors declared today a dividend of $1.25 a share on the company's stock and announced the organization of a new subsidiary, the Owens-Illinois Can Company. Fred A. Prahl, who has been with the Continental Can Company, will be president of the new concern.

Members of the Textile Converters Association of America, Inc., at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, decided to vigorously oppose efforts of dyers and printers to collect 1 1/2 per cent additional on the finishing or processing of goods to cover the social security tax on payrolls.

The Panama Pacific Line will resume its passenger and freight service to San Francisco this week, it was announced yesterday by Basil Harris, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, owner of the line.

SANDRINGHAM, England, Jan. 20. -- News of the death of their beloved King and master was made known tonight throughout his great estate here and in the surrounding villages inhabited almost wholly by his dependents as quickly as the sad tidings reached London.

Jimmy Fantini, rugged young welterweight, pulled himself from the brink of defeat last night to a glorious victory over Ray Miller, Chicago veteran, in a savagely fought eight-round bout before 3,000 fans at the St. Nicholas Palace.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20. -- After the executive council of the American Federation of Labor ended today's session of its quarterly meeting it was strongly intimated that on reconvening tomorrow the majority members would subscribe to a severe condemnation of the eight international unions which have formed the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The new Metropolitan management, in its search for a repertoire that will draw the public, has revived "La Juive" this season. Last night it was performed for the first time in one of the subscription series, the initial presentation having taken place as a Saturday evening benefit ten days ago.

The campaign for the reduction of traffic accidents showed to exceptional advantage yesterday with the announcement of the previous week and the last week-end accident tables, compiled by the traffic division of the Police Department.

With Nebraska as their destination, two 9-year-old girls, dressed in skiing suits and carrying alternately a valise weighing twenty-eight pounds, ended the first and last leg of their journey last night in Hoboken, where they had walked from their home at 92 Grove Street.

A full year of operation of the sales tax in this city has proved its detrimental effect upon retail trade, particularly from the standpoint of driving business into communities where there is no levy, Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday at the opening session of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Drastic revisions of the design and function of governmental units in Westchester County were outlined to the Board of Supervisors in a report made today by the county's Commission on Government after two years of study.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Lenore Ulric scored a hit with the audience in her new play "Name Your Poison," which opened at the Shubert Theatre here tonight. Presented by A.H. Woods, the melodramatic comedy is the work of two former New York newspaper men, Louis Weitzenkorn and Herbert C. Lewis.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman hopes to get "the final story" of the Lindbergh kidnap-murder before Bruno Richard Hauptmann goes to the electric chair, and to that end is willing to visit Hauptmann in his death-house cell again.
LONDON. -- The reign of King George V will go down in history as one during which the historic British Empire in its evolution became a "commonwealth of nations."

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- Four masked robbers raided the apartment of Eugene Ford, vice president of the Household Finance Company, at 2,350 Lincoln Park West, early today. They imprisoned eight persons, including Townsend Netcher, son of Mrs. Molly Netcher Newbury, head of the Boston Store.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The confidential State Department papers on which Senator Nye based his charge before the Munitions Investigating Committee, of which he is chairman, that Woodrow Wilson and Robert Lansing had "falsified" when they testified they had no knowledge of the existence of secret treaties prior to the Versailles conference, are being returned.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- Chicago packers and other processors will be told to come and get some $47,000,000 in contested AAA processing taxes as a result of action taken by the Supreme Court today in denying the government a rehearing and in issuing a mandate covering its decision in the rice millers case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- It would seem in conformity with the temper, not to speak of the budgetary necessities, of the present government if it should resort to every legislative measure that ingenuity can devise to prevent the return of the 979 millions collected in AAA processing taxes, and take legal steps to recover what the courts order returned.

With Glenn Cunningham heading the parade, crack athletes of the country will gather at the Boston Garden on Saturday for the fifteenth annual Prout Memorial indoor games of the Massachusetts K. of C., it was announced by Chairman William F. Kenney yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- The accession of the Prince of Wales to the throne brings his younger brother, the Duke of York, to the eminence of heir to the throne and brings a woman not of royal blood within sight of becoming Queen of England for the first time in more than 250 years.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Possible economic repercussions from King George's death were indicated in the London insurance market during the day, when prevailing rates for insurance against his passing rose from 25 to 60 per cent.

It is a long while since New Yorkers have had the privilege of attending an exhibition devoted entirely to work by the great American artist, Winslow Homer, who died in 1910. Unusual interest, therefore, attaches to the Homer show that opened yesterday at Knoedler's, to remain through Feb. 8.

The New York Giants, who have made it a practice in recent years to bring their athletes into the fold with as little delay as possible, got off with a rush yesterday when Secretary Jim Tierney, wearing his very best smile, announced that the signed 1936 contract of Carl O. Hubbell of Meeker, Okla., had just been received.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 20 (AP). -- The condition of Lloyd Waner, Pirate outfielder, ill of pneumonia, was described tonight as "very good, considering the nature of the illness."
The text of the address of Foreign Minister Koki Hirota before the Japanese Diet at Tokyo today, as given out by the Japanese Consulate General in New York, follows:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 20. -- Five former winners of the title were listed for the first division after the qualifying round of the twenty-eighth annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests, played today over the course of the Palm Beach Country Club.

LONDON. -- Persons who knew King George as a friend, who have been shooting with him on the Scottish moors, yachting at Cowes aboard the royal yacht Britannia or have been entertained by him at Sandringham, say that genial good humor was his outstanding characteristic.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 20. -- Six scantily clad persons fled into sub-freezing weather this morning when a fire at the Longshore Beach and Country Club caused $50,000 damage and reduced the interior of the luxurious clubhouse to a mass of charred beams and broken walls.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- It is generally predicted in Paris tonight that the Radical Socialist Ministers will present their resignations to Premier Laval Wednesday and that the Premier will thereupon present his own resignation and those of the entire Cabinet to the President.
The text of the address of Foreign Minister Koki Hirota before the Japanese Diet at Tokyo today, as given out by the Japanese Consulate General in New York, follows:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 20. -- Five former winners of the title were listed for the first division after the qualifying round of the twenty-eighth annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests, played today over the course of the Palm Beach Country Club.

LONDON. -- Persons who knew King George as a friend, who have been shooting with him on the Scottish moors, yachting at Cowes aboard the royal yacht Britannia or have been entertained by him at Sandringham, say that genial good humor was his outstanding characteristic.

GEORGE V was pre-eminently a constitutional monarch. He ruled but did not govern. In law-making, he recognized the supremacy of Parliament, and ever was ready to give the assent of the Crown to measures backed by the Government of the day. He even went further.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Close scrutiny of the executive budget with a view to possible cuts in the appropriations recommended by Governor Lehman will occupy the fiscal leaders of the Assembly, controlled by the Republicans, in advance of public hearings on the budget before the Ways and Means Committee, scheduled for Feb. 4.

Despite the fact that almost forty matches were contested yesterday, there was nothing approaching a major upset as play started in the sixth annual invitation squash racquets tourney on the Junior League courts.

The reign of King George V of Great Britain was characterized as an example of the "finest traditions of monarchy," blended ve/th the "best instincts of democracy," in a special memorial program broadcast over Station WOR at 11:15 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- As the first step toward Federal control of the movement of electric energy in interstate commerce, copies of rate schedules, contracts or agreements in effect on Jan. 1, affecting more than 200 electric public utility companies, have been filed with the Federal Power Commission under the provisions of Title II of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

MANCHESTER, Ky., Jan. 21 (AP). -- Clay County's court house, overlooking a street which has been the scene of spectacular assassinations, was destroyed by fire here today. It was feared all the county records were lost.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- Until investigators know what happened in the cockpit of the American Airlines' luxury airplane, The Southerner, during the sixty seconds before the big Douglas DC-2 destroyed herself and the seventeen persons aboard by ploughing into the scrub oaks of an Arkansas bog last Tuesday, no real explanation for the crash will be forthcoming.

VIENNA, Jan. 21. -- Central and Southeastern Europe marked the death of King George by flying flags at half-staff on public buildings. Newspapers appeared with mourning borders. At all British legations there was a stream of Premiers, Cabinet members, diplomats and members of the British colonies.

By means of government loans in the form of HOLC bonds, the State Mortgage Commission has refinanced 209 mortgages and paid nearly $1,000,000 in principal on 8,767 certificates, the commission reported yesterday.

Disagreement as to the best means for reorganizing the Western Pacific Railroad are expected to be adjusted at a conference between the management and the company's bondholders, which is planned for tomorrow or Friday.
Eleven Manhattan properties and five in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. One scheduled Bronx offering was withdrawn.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Captain-Eddie Shore's first goal of the season, registered less than three minutes before the final bell, gave the Bruins a 1-0 triumph over the Montreal Maroons tonight before a near-capacity crowd of 14,000 at the Boston Garden.

Elmer Rice, regional director of the WPA Theatre Project, announced yesterday that persons on home relief would be able to see the project's shows on Monday nights. There had been a question as to whether the government could charge admission to such persons; that has been settled by turning over to them one performance each week.

Secretary ICKES continues to administer oil to all comers His gracious suavity never fails. His kind words never die. He pours unction upon all comers. His urbane apology to Mr. HOOVER had hardly been pasted in the scrapbooks of earnest students and seekers of deportment when he made a loving and a fair reply to Governor TALMADGE, the Georgian Chesterfield with whom from time to time he has exchanged sympathetic messages:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21. -- Four of five former holders of the title survived the first match round in the twenty-eighth annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Country Club today. One of these was a New York member, Merrill M. Lord, the 1929 champion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Convinced that railroads and other transportation agencies are either unable or unwilling to promote the greatest possible operating economy and efficiency, Coordinator Joseph B. Eastman said in a report to President Roosevelt and Congress today that it was his intention to apply "increasing pressure" to bring it about and asked for a five-year extension of his office to that end.

Increased retail sales volume, together with an advance in prices, resulting from the expected soldier bonus and other inflationary measures and from demand deposits topping the record for 1929, was forecast yesterday by speakers at the silver jubilee convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Trading on the local commodity futures markets was listless yesterday, in sympathy with the inaction in Great Britain, where the markets were closed. Coffee was active and strong. On the cash markets rye and lard were higher and corn and rubber eased.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The filing of seven additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of securities involving $5,327,953 was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Of the total, $4,403,958 was in five issues registered by commercial and industrial enterprises, $173,995 by an investment trust and $750,000 for voting trust certificates.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- King Edward on his accession sent messages today to the three defense services -- the navy, the army and the air force -- recalling their loyal and gallant services to the nation in the World War and the associations of the late King George and other members of the royal family with them.

Net profit of the Paraffine Companies, Inc., and subsidiaries for the six months ended on Dec. 31, was reported yesterday as $1,138,490, after depreciation, taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to $2.39 a share on 476,009 no par shares of capital stock.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- This was a city without theatres tonight and without films, concerts, night clubs or amusements of any kind. What has recently been the gayest capital in Europe has suddenly become a city of mourning.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- King Edward probably will be much wealthier than his father was because, in addition to the usual perquisites of the crown, he will continue until he has a son to draw the revenues of the Duchy of Cornwall which he has received as heir to the throne.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The American Association of Railroads will apply to the Interstate Commerce Commission within a few days for authority to make permanent present emergency freight surcharges which the I.C.C. said in March, 1935, would raise an additional $85,000,000 in carrier revenues. These rates now are due to expire on June 30.

As the city continued yesterday to dig itself out of last Sunday's snowstorm, New York's residents noticed that the Sanitation Department was having its efforts facilitated by 110 new, trim and efficient-looking trucks and plows.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, has made several visits to the Zoological Gardens observing the rhythmic actions of animals, and the result is that these actions are to be the basis for a serious musical score.

The London Economist has prepared a table showing for the principal commercial countries the course of staple prices during 1935. Evidently with a view to measuring the effect on prices of England's suspension of gold payments and its sequel elsewhere, all the "index numbers" are converted into averages based on September, 1931, as 100.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Today the House of Representatives, as a tribute to the late monarch of Great Britain, adjourned as soon as it assembled. Had the Senate been in session the same wreath would in all likelihood have been laid on the bier of George V.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- King George's death was not only an emotional blow to the British public but will cause financial losses. For some trades the effect will be exactly the same as contraction of the currency or raising the bank rate, although London is overflowing with idle funds awaiting a chance for investment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- As a climax to the first day of discussion of international problems 750 delegates to the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War tonight heard Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt join with Carrie Chapman Catt, veteran suffrage and peace leader, and Kathleen Courtney, leader of the British Women's Peace Crusade, in a plea that women have faith in the instrumentalities of peace.

BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 21. -- Major Robert R. Neyland's retirement from the United States Army became effective today, and he announced his acceptance of the post of head football coach at the University of Tennessee. Major Neyland has been on duty here for almost two years. He plans to sail on Saturday for New Orleans.

Melvin T. Ott, boy veteran of the Giants, yesterday became the second of Colonel Bill Terry's performers to fall in line for the 1936 campaign by filing his signed contract with Secretary Jim Tierney.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- A demand from Representative Rich of Pennsylvania for investigation of contemplated mergers in the steel industry" was under consideration today in the Justice Department's anti-trust division.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,833,600 barrels, as compared with 2,810,150 in the preceding week, an increase of 23,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 19,200 barrels daily in the output of Oklahoma was the most important change.

COLOGNE, Jan. 21. -- The Rev. Josef Spiker, a Jesuit priest, was sentenced in the Cologne district court today to fifteen months' imprisonment for misusing the pulpit for attacking the National Socialist party and the State.

Rumors are getting around town that something like a palace revolution is impending in Tammany Hall. Loyalty of the present management to the Washington Administration has not been all that is desired. Opposition of the leaders to Chairman FARLEY has been but thinly concealed.

" The Illustrators' Show," more benign now than when it had a slight tournament with the police, will open this evening at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The greater part of the material has been captured from that one-night engagement of a few weeks ago, and in the professional company arriving tonight are Helen Lynd, Earl Oxford, Neila Goodelie, Otto Soglow, Fred Cooper and Gomez and Winona. Settings are by the illustrators themselves.

The present state of railway construction serves to explain the moderate demand for rail, compared with conditions in previous years. This work, which has been diminishing since 1931, is described as almost at a standstill. Stimulated by government grants, elimination of grade crossings has provided most of the constructional work undertaken on railroads in recent months.

Learned Englishmen do not consider American speech "dreadful," according to Dr. A. Lloyd James, linguistic adviser to the British Broadcasting Company and Professor of Phonetics at the University of London. Professor James arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic as the guest of the Rockefeller Institute, and while here he will confer with American authorities on radio enunciation in both countries.

Cooperation in solving the administrative problems of the Social Security Act, the enactment of new legislation to check predatory price-cutting and continued efforts to curb rising taxation were urged yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The automobile industry opened yesterday "the most comprehensive cooperative educational program for greater safety on streets and highways" yet attempted by the industry.

New life insurance last year was 2.5 per cent greater than in 1934, while for December it was 6 per cent less than a year before, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents. The figures are for new business, excluding revivals, increases and dividend additions, of forty-two member companies having 83 per cent of all life insurance outstanding in United States legal reserve companies.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- In monarchies it is a delicate problem always to decide who profits more from the association, the ruler or the subjects. But in the case of Great Britain, so far as world politics is concerned, the answer can unhesitatingly be given that the nation takes all the profit from the existence of the British Crown.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company had a net operating income of $270,418 in 1935, George McAneny, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting. After deducting increased carrying costs of outstanding debentures and other charges, there was a net loss of $244,253, compared with one of $8,897 in 1934.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- Owen B. Hunt, State Insurance Commissioner, has threatened official action against group medical practice in Eastern Pennsylvania.

Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N.Y., one of the leading contenders for the lightweight title held by Tony Canzoneri, knocked out Tony Herrera of Pittsburgh in the ninth round of their scheduled ten-round bout, at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

HAVANA, Jan. 21. -- Cuba has again embarked on a program for government control of the sugar crop for the next six years, somewhat similar to the five-year Chadbourne sugar restriction plan, which ended on Dec. 19, 1935.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- How widely and deeply King George is being mourned in the British Empire is revealed in reports from all parts of the world. In all foreign countries, too, there have been remarkable expressions of sympathy and sorrow.
LONDON, Jan. 21. -- King Edward VIII flew from Sandringham to London this morning to meet the Privy Council, which was waiting to proclaim his accession.

The Jooss European Ballet made its first New York appearance in something over two years at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute. An enormous audience expressed its approval of the performance and the evening can be fairly considered a success.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- King Edward VIII, first British monarch to fly, and who by his flight today gave renewed emphasis to his interest in aviation, has not only been aloft often during the last seven years but has kept his own fleet of planes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Data filed by several companies as confidential and made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that the Balaban and Katz Corporation paid $78,000 as remuneration in 1934 to Barney Balaban, its president, and to John Balaban, its secretary and treasurer. Walter Immerman, vice president, received $15,080.
Your valedictory to Mr. Coolidge as Under-Secretary of the Treasury moves me to a somewhat different point of view.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System reports a consolidated net income of $2,462,916 after all deductions for the six months ended on Dec. 31, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.33 a share on 735,664 no-par common shares, compared with $2,778,532, or $2.76 a share in the 1934 period.

Members of the Curb Exchange were interested to note yesterday that James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was conferring with Representative Sam Rayburn, chairman of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, on the SEC's proposal to extend unlisted trading privileges beyond June 30 by amendment of the Securities Exchange Act.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- Arrivals of hogs here today exceeded trade estimates because of the receipt of some stormbound shipments from the West. Early sales were 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than on Monday, but the demand became aggressive and part of the loss was recovered.

TOKYO, Jan. 21. -- In his address to the Diet today Foreign Minister Koki Hirota envisaged a new Far East, in which Japan, China and Manchukuo will constitute a solid East Asian bloc against Communist penetration and Western imperialism.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler signed an order yesterday directing the liquidation of the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company, by Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance. The company is the fourth largest of the guaranteed mortgage companies taken over by the Insurance Department for rehabilitation, and is the nineteenth company to be put into liquidation, with seven remaining in rehabilitation.

A banking syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. will offer today a new issue of $35,000,000 of first-mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, Series D, due on Feb. 1, 1961, of Inland Steel Company. The bonds are priced at 101 1/2, to yield about 3.66 per cent.

A formula whereby a patient may sit in a dentist's chair without squirming in pain while the dentist drills at his teeth was given free to the world last night by its discoverer, Dr. LeRoy L. Hartman, Professor of Dentistry in the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Fourteen offering sheets of various oil interests were received by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the week ended on Jan. 18. The commission stated that in no case does the act of filing give to any security its approval or indicate that it has passed on the merits of the issue or that the material filed itself is correct.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 21. -- Bolivia and Paraguay signed today a pact providing for the release of all war prisoners and the renewal of diplomatic relations. The pact reestablished peace, which was broken by the outbreak of the Chaco war on June 19, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Comprehensive disclosures must be made to stockholders by corporations soliciting proxies under the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to an opinion by John J. Burns, general counsel of the commission, which was made public today.

Aliens living in this city who have not declared their intention of becoming citizens would be required to register with the Police Department under a local law introduced yesterday by Alderman Charles E. Keegan, Bronx Democrat, in the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly.

When the sportsman reads that migratory waterfowl use four main flyways in their travels to and from the nesting grounds; that a duck follows the same route used by its ancestors and rarely any of the others; that certain species wander as much as 5,000 miles in the trip from the breeding area in Winter quarters, and other interesting bits on the subject of migration, he no doubt wonders how such information is obtained.
With interest heightened because it is an Olympic year, the board of stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association yesterday fixed Monday, June 22, for the 1936 Poughkeepsie regatta.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- With the introduction in the Senate and Assembly today of twenty-eight additional bills for the better enforcement of the criminal law, the bulk of Governor Lehman's anti-crime program is now before the Legislature.

The screams of a cashier and pursuit by three other women employes of the Automat cafeteria in the basement of 1,441 Broadway, near Forty-first Street, frustrated an attempted holdup at 7:03 A.M. yesterday and led to the capture of a suspect.

Julius J. Gans, the Democratic candidate, was elected to the Assembly from the Fifth district of the Bronx in a special election yesterday to fill the vacancy caused by the death on Dec. 13 of Benjamin Gladstone, who had been re-elected. The Communist candidate, Moissaye J. Olgin, ran second, ahead of both the Socialist and the Republican candidates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- President Roosevelt took direct issue today with the Supreme Court on its mandate ordering the return of nearly $200,000,000 of impounded AAA processing taxes. He said the court apparently had reversed its position of fourteen years ago, when it ruled that although taxes under the Child Labor Law were unconstitutional, a law of 1867 prevented any injunction against collection.
" Liberty at the Cross Roads," the Republican National Committee's "dramatization of the country's current problems," came to New York last night, with variations.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Jan. 21.--A modern dairy farm will be developed on property to be added to President Roosevelt's estate near here, if present plans are carried out.

Irving School of Tarrytown, N.Y., assumed the lead in the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League by turning back the Horace Mann quintet, 37 to 18, on the victors' court yesterday. It was the third straight league triumph for Irving School and the first setback in four starts for Horace Mann.

Samuel Lionel Rothafel, known to motion picture and radio audiences as "Roxy," who died on Jan. 13, left an estate valued at less than $5,000, according to the petition of his widow, Rosa R. Rothafel, who yesterday asked Surrogate James A. Foley to grant her letters of administration on his estate.
Commodity markets in many parts of the United States and Security and Commodity Exchanges in Canada curtailed their activities yesterday out of respect to the late King George.
THE TIMES is to be congratulated for its editorial "The Poll Completed." Assuredly, as you say, The Literary Digest poll is far from being a sure word of prophecy for election day.
ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Jan. 21. -- I am once more on board the Wyatt Earp. How good it was to see her again!

Economic planning was defended, government regimentation opposed and a sound-money policy advocated by speakers last night at a dinner meeting of the New York Unit of the Executives League of America at the Hotel Roosevelt, where eighty-five business leaders attended.

Mr. and Mrs. Aymar Johnson gave a large reception yesterday afternoon at Sherry's to introduce to New York society their niece, Miss Adelaide Grima Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bradish G. Johnson of this city and Paris. Miss Johnson, a granddaughter of the late Bradish Johnson, was introduced in Paris last Spring and has been passing the Winter in New York.

The entry of Glenn Cunningham for the Wanamaker Mile, feature of the annual Millrose A.A. indoor track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 1, was received yesterday by Director Fred Schmertz. It will be the fourth start in this board-track fixture for the Kansas flier, and another victory will bring him his second Wanamaker Trophy.

Dealings in foreign exchange here yesterday were quiet in view of the closing of the London markets in observance of the death of King George V. The French franc, while declining 1/8 point to 6.59 5/8 cents, again displayed unusual steadiness in the face of the French Cabinet crisis and the renewed talk in Paris of a possible devaluation.

The text of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's tribute on the radio to King George v. which was broadcast in this country by the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, follows:

The annual meeting of delegates of the United States Polo Association, held yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club, was marked by retirement from the chairmanship of Louis E. Stoddard, who had held that position continuously since 1922, and by long debate over contemplated revisions in the constitution.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Sorrow over the death of King George was manifested here today in many ways.

MADRID, Jan. 21. -- Republican Spain remembered today that her deposed Queen is related to the British royal family and Madrid newspapers reflecting all shades of opinion unanimously paid tributes to King George's personal virtues and his official qualities as a ruler.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- All Britain was a land of tolling bells today. The demonstrations of sorrow in London were repeated on a smaller scale in every city and town of the kingdom. Flags flew at half staff, cinemas and theatres were closed and people went about their tasks with a sense of loss as if one of their own family circle had been taken from them.

In your issue of Jan. 12 John Temple Graves 2d writes from Birmingham, Ala., concerning the Scottsboro cases being in great prejudice as long as the defense is in charge of national organizations with "Socialist and Communist groups" on the defense committee and with outside counsel.

A decrease in the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the preceding week. However, the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

The empire over which GEORGE V presided and of which RUDYARD KIPLING sang comprises one-quarter of the earth's population. Half a billion souls have already transferred allegiance from GEORGE R. to EDWARD R.
With all of the talk and worry now going around as to how the United States can most easily find the cash to pay the soldiers' bonus, I offer the following:
Leasing of a Greenwich Village Landmark for replacement with a taxpayer, together with several housing sales and leases, constructing the Manhattan real estate actually reported yesterday.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French frano on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The current exhibition in the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, consists of work by teachers. A note in the catalogue explains: "The art teachers of the WPA Federal Art Project instruct children in fine and applied arts in the schools of the Board of Education and in settlement houses.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21. -- Heart Break, a 6-year-old mare which finished second her last time out after taking three straight races, carried Mrs. H. Torriente's silks to victory over six rivals in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

Miss Elizabeth Pearson of Philadelphia furnished the first major reversal of the women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Junior League yesterday as seven of the eight seeded players, including all five members of the Wolfe-Noel International cup team, reached the quarter-final round.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21. -- The rules committee of the American Football Coaches Association decided today to meet in Pittsburgh Feb. 1, with apparently little possibility that many important changes will be up for consideration.

Winifred Christie, exponent of the Moor double keyboard piano, made her first appearance of the season last night at the Town Hall. A large following, decidedly warm in its applause, greeted Miss Christie, who was the wife of the late Dr. Emanuel Moor, composer and inventor of the piano.

In discussing some of the features of the forthcoming report of the New York State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws, of which he is chairman, Senator MASTICK declares that the commission is unanimously opposed to the over-all constitutional real property tax-limit proposals advanced by the real estate interests.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- King George V rests tonight in a plain coffin made by a carpenter of his own estate, in the chancel of the Sandringham Parish Church, where each Sunday he worshiped during his brief respites from the cares of state.

Women headed by Mrs. Ernest P. Davies are active in arrangements for a luncheon in behalf of Stony Wold Sanatorium, to be held on Jan. 30 at the Ambassador under the auspices of the board of directors. Serving with Mrs. Davies are Mrs. Myron I. Borg, Mrs. William C. Breed, Miss Margaret Clark-MacMillan, Mrs. William R. Biggs, Mrs. Alexander Johnson, Mrs. William B. Given Jr. and Mrs. Hiter King.

The New York Athletic Club defeated the Mitchel Field Aviators, 3 to 2, on the Winged Foot courts yesterday in an Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group 2 team match. Victories in the last three matches won for the clubmen.

The Squash Club team won the Class B championship in the Group I division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League last night when it wound up the season with a victory over the University Club. Playing on their home courts, the Squash Club stars captured the final match on their schedule, 4 to 1, to complete the season without a single defeat to mar their record.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- The new British King, Edward VIII, made his first public utterance as sovereign today when he declared to his Privy Council that he was determined to follow in his father's footsteps and to work for the happiness and welfare of all classes of his subjects.

The Chicago Black Hawks scored a goal in the first period of their game with the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. And they nursed this sole counter so carefully in the ensuing chapters that the New Yorkers, despite their most carefully planned assaults, could not retrieve it, with the result that Lester Patrick's skaters left the ice on the short end of the 1-to-0 score.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 21. -- An enthusiastic audience, in which were many persons prominent in New Jersey's social and civic life, turned out tonight to hear Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," presented at the Mosque Theatre here by the Metropolitan Opera Association.

A limited edition, signed by the author of Ogden Nash's new book of poems, "A Bad Parent's Garden of Verse," will be sold by Simon Schuster for a price 50 cents lower than that charged for the regular, unsigned edition. Only 100 copies will be sacrificed for the joke.
LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin disclosed over the radio tonight that in the last hours of his life King George's thoughts were for his empire.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- A near-record low volume of business was transacted today on the Board of Trade as a result of a general lack of outside interest and the closing of the markets in Liverpool and Winnipeg because of the death of King George.

PARIS, Jan. 21. -- Premier Laval returned to Paris from Geneva today to face the intricate political situation that has developed, and after consultations tonight it appeared probable that he would resign after a Cabinet meeting tomorrow and would also decline to accept the task of forming a new government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21. -- Open revolt against the stern discipline at Alcatraz penitentiary today put 100 of the 259 Federal prisoners in solitary confinement. No violence occurred, but a strike started in the laundry and spread to other parts of the prison.

Menus selected by nutrition experts of Teachers College, Columbia University, for their value as low-cost diets have been placed on view in Grace Dodge Hall of the college. They include menus for women who want to reduce, for those who want to gain weight, for high school children, for three-year-olds and for nursing mothers.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (AP). -- The Brookmeade Stables' Black Gift, the favorite in the betting, won the Mount Wilson Handicap for 3-year-olds and upward at Santa Anita for a purse of $1,200 today. The time for the mile and a sixteenth was 1:44 1-5.

Miss Lucy T. Saunders heads a group of debutantes who will distribute programs at the performance of "Die Walkuere," with Kirsten Flagstad, Gertrude Kappel, Lauritz Melchior, Friedrich Schorr and Emanuel List in the leading roles, to be held this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's mission in Labrador.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 -- J.C. Palmer's Rosselli, keyed to his best form with two promising efforts at Tropical Park, received a heady ride from Nick Wall to capture top honors in the first division of the Delray purse, a one-mile feature that was split into two sections today at Hialeah Park.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 21 (AP). -- Twenty passengers on a New York to Springfield and Haverhill bus were injured early today, seven of them seriously, when the vehicle crashed into a loaded coal truck at a street intersection.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- A supplemental appropriation bill, designed principally to speed the Social Security Act into active operation during the current fiscal year, was reported to the House today by its Appropriations Committee.

BERLIN, Jan. 21. -- Germany will be represented at King George's funeral by a delegation headed by Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath and including an army general, an air force general and a navy admiral, according to official quarters.
The depression naturally has changed the course of many careers, but when one turns from sculpture in wood to bartending, as Frank Reele was forced to do, it presents a unique situation.
