Society staged its own fashion show (and luncheon) yesterday afternoon with men and women manikins from its own ranks before an audience of 250 persons at the Hotel Weylin, Madison Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street. The models walked down the brightly illumined red plush platform in pairs, exhibiting attire for men and women.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- William Adger Law had attained na-

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Wheth er this session of Congress is to consider new taxes, including taxes to replace the agricultural processing levies outlawed by the Supreme Court, was said by Congressional leaders today to be strictly up to President Roosevelt and his advisers.

Sharps gains in the income and the volume of traffic using the interstate facilities of the Port of New York Authority were made last year, according to the annual report issued yesterday by the commissioners.

GENEVA, Jan. 21. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Great Britain decided today not to return to London immediately as a result of King George's death. He will remain here till Thursday night, by which time he hopes the League of Nations Council session will have ended.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 21. -- Less than five hours after a jury of white farmers had been chosen to try Haywood Patterson, a Negro, for rape of a white woman, his lawyers moved for a mistrial today, accusing Judge William W. Callahan of infecting the jurors with the same bias and prejudice which they charged him with showing.
STEELE CITY, Neb., Jan. 21. -- Conflicting love affairs were blamed today by his young wife for terminating the army career of a West Point honor student.

Stockholders of the Northern New York Utilities, Inc., approved yesterday a plan of reorganization and consolidation of the company with eight other operating subsidiaries of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and with the Old Forge Electric Corporation, subject to the approval of the New York Public Service Commission.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP). -- "Profitless prosperity" got a lambasting today at the annual convention of the National American Wholesale Grocers.

The American International Corporation announced yesterday that its net assets on Dec. 31, 1935, were $25,961,313, equivalent, after providing for the $13,821,000 face value of debentures, to $12.04 a share on 1,007,973 shares of common stock. This represents an increase of $6,524,191 over the net assets on Dec. 31, 1934, which were $19,437, 122.
The Morgenthau-Seixas Co. has arranged for an increase and the replacement of a $30,000 first mortgage on 551-3 1st Av. and 356 E. 32d St., the southwest corner. The property is being modernized.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Georgia Congress members today called on their State Democratic Executive Committee, controlled by Governor Talmadge, foe of Roosevelt, to provide a primary to instruct the State's delegation to the National Democratic Convention.

Severe criticism of the city's policy toward homeless persons was expressed yesterday by Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein in Yorkville court when Ambrose Sweeney, 21 year old and without a home, was arraigned on a vagrancy charge. The magistrate charged that no provision was made for the homeless except to have the police lock them up and have them committed to the workhouse.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 21.--Neither confirming nor denying that one of several Japanese demands in North China includes the appointment of Yin Ju-keng, leader of the East Hopei independent regime, as Mayor of Tientsin, a high Chinese authority disclosed today that the Japanese Army has given Sung Cheh-yuan, chairman of the Hopei-Chahar Political Council, two weeks to agree to all Japanese stipulations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders and agricultural advisers on the projected farm program, talked with Senator Glass concerning the new Federal Reserve Board which he will appoint within a few days, discussed neutrality legislation with Chairman Pittman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and said at his press conference that the Supreme Court had reversed its position of fourteen years ago in ordering repayment of impounded processing taxes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21. -- The Yale University five scored its first victory in eleven starts this season by turning back Penn, 33 -- 28, in a hard-fought Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League battle tonight. It marked the second setback in three circuit games for the visitors, who are the defending champions.

The assertion that he was firmly convinced that his policies as president of City College had conformed to the "highest ideals of public education" was Dr. Frederick B. Robinson's reply yesterday to the report of a special committee of the Associate Alumni of the college criticizing his relations with the faculty and undergraduate body.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 21 (AP). -- Frank Watson, Housing Research Director for Purdue University, declared today that residential construction in the United States would slump badly in 1936 if the building industry did not pare costs to fit the average family's pocketbook.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21. -- At Beaurivage Mrs. Bernard Henry Kroger was hostess today at a luncheon and contract for Mrs. Herbert E. Gale, Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Mrs. James H. Kennedy, Mrs. McKay Le Roy, Mrs. Frank B. McQuesten, Mrs. William R. Sweatt, Mrs. Elden C. De Witt, Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff, Mrs. Zenas Sears, Mrs. George H. Nicolai and Mrs. Nathan D. Bill.

IT might be laying it on a little thick to say that a golf match between the Emperor Jones and his Majesty Edward VIII of Great Britain and Ireland would be a battle royal all the way, but as Prince of Wales, Baron of Renfrew, Lord of the Isles, , , the new monarch was better than a fair golfer in recent years.

An alleged insurance swindle uncovered two weeks ago in Brooklyn, which was thought then to have involved only one case, was viewed yesterday by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan as part of an extensive fraud, possibly involving murder, which may have cost insurance companies "hundreds of thousands of dollars."
Let not the people of the City of New York be misled by the report sent out to the members of the City College Alumni Association by a divided committee.
The Union Jack and the Stars and Stripes were at half-staff on British ships and buildings here yesterday as plans were completed for official and informal services in memory of King George.

Thousands of cummuters from the four communities served by the Rockaway Beach division of the Long Island Railroad were considerably delayed getting to their Manhattan and Brooklyn destinations yesterday morning when the derailment of an equipment train caused suspension of service on the division from 7:42 to 9:10 o'clock.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 21.--William A. Law of Philadelphia, president of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company, died in a hospital here early tonight of a wound he suffered when a shotgun in the hands of S. Clay Williams, chairman of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, was accidentally discharged.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

These must be the palmy days of acting. In order to tell the gaunt story of "Ethan Frome," which arrived at the National last evening, the management has hired Ruth Gordon, Pauline Lord and Raymond Massey, who are hereby nominated for immortality.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Jan. 21. -- Art Williams, former United States Army pilot, said today his jungle expedition had found "definite traces" of Paul Redfern, American flier missing since 1927 on a flight from Georgia to Rio de Janeiro.

By dint of a magnificent rally that carried off the last three games, William C. (Billy) Coyle Jr. and Conway Hoffman of the Montclair A.C. yesterday won the metropolitan squash racquets doubles championship at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music was sold out last evening for the opening of the Metropolitan Opera Association's twenty-eighth Brooklyn season. Verdi's "La Traviata" was presented with Edith Mason singing the leading role, replacing Lucrezia Bori, who was unable to appear owing to a cold.

ROME, Jan. 21. -- It was with deep, sincere regret that Italians learned this morning of King George's death. Even the East African campaign was crowded from the most prominent position in many newspapers by detailed accounts of the King's last hours and long laudatory articles reviewing the principal events of his reign and the important part he played in it.
Oswald W. Knauth has been elected a director of Lord Taylor to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Leroy Palmer.

Joseph Castaldo, said to have succeeded Ciro Terranova as New York's "artichoke king," and four other officials and "salesmen" of the Union Pacific Produce Company, which used to do business at 203 West Street before Mayor La Guardia placed an embargo on small artichokes, went on trial yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack as violators of the antitrust law.

The number of automobiles in the city registered for 1936 passed the 200,000 mark on Monday, it was revealed yesterday at the Bureau of Motor Vehicles' headquarters, 155 Worth Street, when the previous day's figures were compiled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- A struggle in Congress between advocates of privately financed low-cost housing and the government subsidy method appeared imminent today after Secretary Ickes declared that private builders could not provide for the lowest income groups unless they did so without profit.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Westminster Hall, where the body of King George will lie in state from Thursday until his burial Tuesday, is a great chamber with a cedar roof where Guy Fawkes, King Charles I and Warren Hastings stood trial.

The second exhibition at the temporary galleries of the Mayor's Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street, opened yesterday and will be current until Feb. 1. Like the first exhibition, which served for the opening event in these galleries a fortnight ago, this one offers much of interest and maintains a commendable "average."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during December at 103.8 per cent of capacity, compared with 101.1 per cent in November and 87.1 in December a year ago.
LONDON, Jan. 21. -- The text of the proclamation issued by the Privy Council on the accession of the Prince of Wales as King Edward VIII, follows:

Payment of the veterans' bonus with an issue of $2,250,000,000 in government bonds at this time "might easily prove to be only slightly less inflationary than the issue of greenbacks," the executive committee of the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy, 70 Fifth Avenue, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Paced by the speedy action and overwhelming vote in the Senate yesterday in favor of the "baby bond" Veterans Bonus Bill, House leaders planned today to rush the measure through in short order tomorrow. The prospects were that the bill would be sent to the White House for President Roosevelt's approval or veto by tomorrow night.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21. -- Fear that the work of the committee for industrial organization may lead to a split within the unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor was expressed today by President William Green at a session of the executive council which considered the recent action of eight international unions in forming a bloc within the federation to advance the cause of industrial unionism in the mass-production fields.

Directors of the Eagle-Picher Lead Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on the preferred stock covering the period from Oct. 1 to Dec. 31, 1935. This payment clears up all arrears on the exchanged stock.

If the return of confidential papers placed in the hands of Senator NYE's committee is now demanded by the State Department, as Washington reports indicate, Secretary HULL is thoroughly within his rights in insisting upon such action. He points out in an explanatory statement that among the important documents in his files are confidential communications from other Governments which contain "subject-matter of vital concern to third governments."

BEIRUT, Syria, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Violent street fighting, in which two French soldiers were wounded and street ears were stoned, broke out in Damascus today. The fighting was a result of a French campaign to suppress the Nationalist bloc.
The Liverpool Cotton Exchange adjourned trading at 11 A.M. yesterday as a measure of respect to the late King George, and similar action was taken by the New York Cotton Exchange at midday.
The Building Service Employes Union called yesterday a strike of elevator operators and other service workers in 200 buildings to go into effect this morning.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21. -- Dr. Herbert Lockyer of Liverpool, England; Francis Harmon of New York and Frank E. Gannett of Rochester, N.Y., were speakers tonight on "The World Outlook" before the Committee of One Hundred.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- James M. Beck, former United States Solicitor General, revealed today that King George V once told him a "chestnut," or old joke.

Because of the illness of one of its leading sopranos, the Metropolitan Opera Association for the second time this season announced last night a change of opera. Verdi's "Aida" will be given Saturday afternoon instead of "La Rondine," because of the indisposition of Miss Lucrezia Bori.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- The dispute over whether President Wilson was a "falsifier," coupled with a division of opinion as to the best method of keeping America out of war, threatened today to upset administration plans for immediate enactment of broad neutrality legislation.

Business failures declined in the retail and two other groups in the week ended Jan. 16, compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:
LONDON, Jan. 21 (By wireless). -- What are the qualities that the new King brings to the fulfillment of his destiny?

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 21. -- Ras Desta Demtu reports that during the past fifteen days there have been frequent skirmishes between his advance guard and Italian Somalis near Dolo and along the Ganale Doria River on the southern front.

The ten-year drive for the substitution of buses for trolley cars on the principal streets of Manhattan came to an end yesterday when William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission, closed hearings on all of the New York railways' applications pending before the commission.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Governor O.K. Allen late tonight claimed a "stupendous victory" for the Huey P. Long candidates in Louisiana's Democratic primary and called it a "positive disapproval of the Roosevelt New Deal and its alphabetical slush fund."

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 9.9 per cent for the thirteen shopping days from Jan. 2 to 16, in comparison with the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The French liner Champlain arrives today from Havre and Southampton. Among those on board are Countess van der Straten-Ponthoz, wife of the Belgian Ambassador to the United States; the Countess Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, wife of the French Consul General in New York, Blaise Cendrars, French author; Lucien Wolf, professor at the University of Rennes; Rene Maison, Belgian tenor who will sing with the Metropolitan Opera this season, and Miss Dora Duby, American dancer.

The General American Life Insurance Company of St. Louis yesterday reported that its total resources at the end of 1935 were $124,392,387, an increase of $1,131,541 from 1934. The surplus account was $1,828,718, an increase of $168,492.
Boat dealers began hitting their stride yesterday at the National Show, and by the closing hour of 10:30 last night salesmen, especially those on commission, were wearing smiles understandably broad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- President Roosevelt plans to send to the Senate within two days the nominations of members of the reconstructed Federal Reserve Board who will take office on Feb. 1 with the coming into operation of the new Federal Reserve Act.

BERLIN, Jan. 21. -- The Boerse opened firm today, but showed weakness at the close. There had been somewhat more activity recently than in the preceding weeks, but the market was relatively quiet today. The slight depression at the close was reported to be a result of rumors regarding the possibility of increased taxes or a reorganization in part of the tax system in view of the Reich's somewhat strained financial situation.
As one of the 100,000 or million "rulers'' you praise in your editorial "When the Lights Go Out" allow me to thank you for this recognition of the engineer's importance in the life of the community.

TRENTON, Jan. 21. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman revealed today that before he reprieved Bruno Richard Hauptmann he had received an opinion from former Governor George S. Silzer that a reprieve would be legal.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21. -- The twelfth anniversary of Nicolai Lenin's death was marked here today and the observance will continue tomorrow, with some 40,000 Muscovites winding over the snow-packed Red Square to the mausoleum where the body of the leader lies -- a slight figure in khaki tunic without decorations and draped with a scarlet coverlet.

Sir Herbert Samuel, Viscount Bearsted and Simon Marks arrived here yesterday on the Majestic as "a delegation from the leaders of the Jewish community of England to confer with the Jewish leaders of the United States on the situation that has arisen from the intensified persecution of the Jews in Germany."

Plans for apartment houses in three boroughs of the city, to cost a total of $1,127,000, were filed yesterday. The aggregate took in a $400,000 house for Hillside Avenue, Manhattan; a $225,000 structure for 167th Street, the Bronx, and two buildings for Jackson Heights, Queens.

SANDRINGHAM, Jan. 21. -- The body of King George V was carried this evening from his home to the parish church of St. Mary Magdalene. There it will remain until Thursday so that the people of his estate may bid him a last farewell before he is taken to London for the empire obsequies now being arranged.

BERLIN, Jan. 22. -- The creeping paralysis from which the Boerse here has been suffering was evident again today. No tendency of any significance developed. Heavy industrial shares had rather heavy losses, however, Rheinstahl dropping 2 1/4 ponts. Electrical issues also weakened somewhat, Siemens Halske losing 1 3/4. Chemical stocks showed more resistance, I.G. Farbenindustrie losing only 1/4 point.

Miss Maria Iturbi, 18-year-old daughter of Jose Iturbi, Spanish pianist and orchestra conductor, and Stephen Hero, 20-year-old violinist, were married on Tuesday evening in Bedford Hills, N.Y., it was disclosed yesterday.

Prices on the local commodity futures markets yesterday were generally higher and the trading was more active. Coffee, hides and tin met setbacks. On the cash markets, all the grains, cotton, lard and rubber advanced, while tin lost ground.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22. -- The Soviet Union is loyal to the League of Nations and is carrying out faithfully all the sanctions imposed against Italy, a Foreign Office spokesman asserted today. His statement was in reply to charges that Russia was shipping to Italy timber, coal, wheat and coal tar.

The first glimpse of Eulace Peacock racing across the Madison Square Garden runway since the Temple Negro won the national 100-meter sprint championship will be had at the Millrose indoor track and field carnival on Feb. 1, it was revealed yesterday when his signed entry blank reached Director Fred Schmertz.
Mayor La Guardia informed Henry Morgenthau, Secretary of the Treasury, yesterday that the Sinking Fund Commission had approved a fifty-year lease for the Coast Guard at Floyd Bennett Field.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- The charter plan of the Westchester Commission on Government can never be adopted in its present form, Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley told the Woman's Club of Mamaroneck at a meeting this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP). -- A hearing on the connections of the Midamerica Corporation, holding company formed by the Van Sweringen interests to regain control of their railroad system, was announced today by a spokesman for the Interstate Commerce Commission.

DUBLIN, Jan. 22. -- King Edward VIII was not publicly proclaimed in Dublin today and when inquiries were made in official circles on the Irish Free State Government's intentions in the matter no information was forthcoming.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale Prices in New York:

Let me tell Sue Falk that not only persons under 25 years of age have trouble getting books at the New York Public Library. Persons of any age have a distinct tendency to weep softly on the stone lions after an earnest effort to do a little serious reading.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 22. -- An entirely new method of weather forecasting, utilizing the strength of short wave radio signals as an indicator of conditions aloft, was described tonight by Professor Charles F. Brooks, director of the Blue Hill Meteorological Observatory of Harvard University, speaking on "The New Three-Dimensional Weather Forecasting," at the Institute of Geographical Exploration free public lectures.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- Chicago continued to be the food capital of the country today as more than 20,000 persons engaged in the food and allied businesses filled the hotels to capacity. The largest group centered about the annual convention of the National Canners' Association.

Influenced by a belief that the proposed method of meeting bonus payments will have an inflationary effect on prices, and by increased activity on the part of domestic spinners, cotton prices rose quite sharply yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Some months improved nearly a dollar a bale and closing prices showed gains of 3 to 13 points.

The second in a series of informal Celebrity Dinners will be given tonight at the Cafe des Artistes, 1 West Sixty-seventh Street, by the women's committee of the New York City Cancer Committee, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Samuel dams Clark.

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, yesterday announced that "Carmen" will be the opera for the Saturday matinee, Feb. 1, at the Broadway house. This will mark the fifth presentation of "Carmen" for the season.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22. -- Mrs. Emil Denemark's Higher Cloud, a smart performer at Churchill Downs last Fall, got off to a successful 3-year-old debut in the rain and slop at Hialeah Park today. The colt, receiving a well-judged ride from Joe Renick, captured the featured Grade A Handicap by three-quarters of a length over Mrs. A.W. Abbott's Dancing Doll.
Theodore W. Stemmler of Stemmler Co. has been elected to membership in the New York Security Dealers Association.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 22. -- Financial statements for last year announced here today at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Travelers Insurance Company showed substantial gains in assets, surplus, special reserve and volume of business.

Long Island and Westchester will be the principal battlegrounds for metropolitan district amateurs this year, according to the schedule of 1936 events released yesterday by the Metropolitan Golf Association.

Surrogate James A. Foley in a decision yesterday fixed allowances of the temporary administrators in the estate of Ella Virginia Von E. Wendel. The Surrogate approved a total allowance of $392,378.73, of which George Stanley Shirk receives $132,633.03 for his services, Isabel Koss Murray a similar amount and the estate of Charles G. Koss $127,112.67.

Chairman FLETCHER of the Republican National Committee has had a stroke of genius. Republicans who have grumbled at him must hold their tongues henceforth. His astuteness in complaining that two great broadcasting systems wouldn't give the Republicans the same amount of time over the same stations, to answer Mr. ROOSEVELT'S annual message, that was put at the disposal of the President, is now doubly evident.

Daylight seemed to puzzle Walter Brannon yesterday as he toured through the Flatbush and Midwood districts of Brooklyn with detectives trying to find more than 200 homes he is alleged to have robbed between August and December.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- Republicans, controlling a majority in the Assembly, opened fire on the New Deal today when a bill sponsored by Assemblyman Wheeler Milmoe of Madison County, providing for the repeal of laws adjusting State statutes to the defunct NRA, came up for final passage.

Two important business properties in midtown Manhattan passed to new control yesterday when contracts were arranged for the sale of a Madison Avenue building and the leasing of a tall structure on Ninth Avenue.
The bitterest cold wave in years gripped the entire midcontinent yesterday, causing nineteen deaths in thirteen States, many accidents and widespread suffering among human beings and livestock.

The strike movement launched by the Building Service Employes Union went into effect yesterday with a walkout of elevator operators and other service workers in 175 buildings in the garment and fur area and a tie-up of more than 50 buildings in Harlem.
White marlin landed this morning."

Barbara Stanwyck will have the principal feminine role in RKO Radio's screen translation of Sean O'Casey's play. "The Plough and the Stars." It will be directed by John Ford, who transformed Liam O'Flaherty's "The Informer" into a film.

Municipal administration has become a specialized task calling for men with scientific training and a "politician can no longer bluff it through," Mayor La Guardia told members of the Municipal Engineers of New York City at their annual meeting at the Hotel Astor last night.

President FOX of Union College undertook in his Genesee Society dinner address to answer this difficult question. The difficulty is increased by the confusion with which no other State has to deal -- due to the accident that city and State share the same name. His contention is that New York City does not belong "peculiarly" to New York State.

ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Jan. 22. -- We had planned to make the 2,200-mile transantarctic flight in fourteen hours if the weather held good throughout the journey, but, as you will see, it took us twenty-two days to go from Dundee Island at the head of the Weddell Sea across the continent to the Bay of Whales in Ross Sea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- In the face of circumstances that made impossible the sending to London of a special delegation to represent the United States Government at the funeral of King George, President Roosevelt tonight named Norman H. Davis, chief of the American delegation to the naval conference, as Special Ambassador for that occasion.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports. Her passengers include Lord Terence Conyngham Plunket, accompanied by Lady Plunket and the latter's mother, Mrs. J.W. Dean, known here as Fanny Ward.
Purchases of tracts for housing development in Whitestone and East Williston, L.I., and West Orange, N.J. were reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- A firmer undertone developed today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade as a result of strength in Liverpool, reports of a better foreign demand for overseas grain and the sub-zero temperatures sweeping over the Winter Wheat Belt, but there was no increase of consquence in outside speculative interest.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 22. -- Nearly 1,600 athletes from twenty-eight nations were certified today by the Olympic Committee as competitors in Winter sports. The total, 1,593, exceeded by 400 the estimate made when the entry lists closed Jan. 15.

MIAMI, Jan. 22. -- By a vote of 11 to 6 the members of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor today condemned the committee for industrial organization, formed in December to organize unions further on an industrial basis in mass production industries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Although substantially less than for the preceding month, exports in December, valued at $223,737,000, carried the total value of foreign shipments for 1935 to $2,283,023,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A new "Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act" vesting in the Secretary of Agriculture more discretionary powers to influence basic agricultural adjustments than under the old AAA, was started through Congress today in the face of warnings on both sides of the Capitol that the stop-gap measure might be held unconstitutional if it ever reached the courts.

The opening of a $2,000,000,000 buying market for electric appliances through reduction in electric rates and a nation-wide home-building program to release frozen billions of dollars were among the suggestions for recovery and reduction of unemployment made by speakers yesterday at the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A score of naval officers of command rank received new assignments today, effective about June 10. The Navy Department thus completed a list of changes begun on Jan. 9, when it was announced that Vice Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn would succeed Admiral Joseph M. Reeves as Commander of the Battle Fleet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The House today voted in quick time to concur in the Senate amendments to the Bonus Bill, and by a ballot of 346 to 59 sent the measure to the White House for the approval or disapproval of President Roosevelt. The overwhelming majority, however, left little hope for the President if he plans to return the bill to Congress without his approval.

America's foremost motor boat racing authority, Commodore Charles F. Chapman of New York, the man who had the audacity soon after the war to cajole Gar Wood into racing a speed boat against an express train from Miami to New York and to go along with him as navigator, was hailed, cheered and adulated until an early hour this morning by several hundred boat show officials and visitors.
With characteristic unobtrusiveness, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody slipped unheralded into New York yesterday, took up quarters at the Colony Club, and settled herself for a stay of four or five days.

LENIN'S death twelve years ago was commemorated by a great mass meeting in Madison Square Garden. The chief speaker of the evening demanded, among other things, a continuation of the Nye munitions inquiry, and that is something not so easy to understand.

Riverdale Country School and St. Nicholas of Tolentine High scored victories in scholastic basketball games played in New York City yesterday. Undefeated Riverdale won in its home gymnasium from Fieldston School, 21 -- 8, for its fourth success.

Resumption of trading in the British markets and of full-time schedules in the North American commodity exchanges accounted for the heavier dealings in our security and commodity markets generally, but the explanation for the substantial rise in stock prices and the decline in the dollar yesterday was not as clear.

Postponed from last Monday, "The Puritan" will open at the Belmont Theatre tonight, restoring that house to the fold of the legitimate. The play's producer, director and adapter (from Liam O'Flaherty's novel) is Chester Erskin, who, however, has stopped short of acting it.

The publishing firm of Coward-McCann will join offices with G.P. Putnam's Sons, and Minton, Balch Co., on Feb. 1. For some time Putnam's has taken care of billing, shipping and collecting for Coward-McCann and it now will take over the Coward-McCann manufacturing arrangements as well.

Railroad financing at the most favorable coupon rate in three decades, or since the period of low money rates prevailing about the turn of the century, will be announced today in the offering by Kuhn, Loeb Co. of $40,000,000 of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company general mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, Series C, due on April 1, 1970.

A brilliant breast-stroke leg by the veteran Walter Spence enabled the New York A.C. to regain the metropolitan 300-yard medley relay championship last night in the Winged Foot pool. Joe Ruddy's charges dethroned the strong Dragon Club trio from Brooklyn.

Lord and Lady Duveen gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. H. Bartow Farr, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Newton, Mrs. Howard Page and Count Mario di Zoppola.

Tom McDermott, 17-year-old swimming ace of George Washington High School, and Alan Lemlein, a virtually unconsidered springboard artist of Flushing High School, were the winners yesterday of qualifying trials for senior high school championships of the Public Schools Athletic League, conducted in the 75-foot pool of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A letter charging that the Senate Munitions Committee had invaded privacy and disregarded the wishes of the Lansing family through circulating among some Senators excerpts from the private diaries of Robert Lansing, Secretary of State under Wilson, has been written to Senator Nye, chairman of the committee, by Allen W. Dulles, New York lawyer, who is a nephew of Mr. Lansing.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22. -- Clarkson Tech tonight defeated Yale by 4 -- 2 for the fifth straight year in their annual hockey series at the New Haven Arena. Each of the previous four victories was scored by a one-goal margin.

The principals of the Atlantic Passenger Conference are scheduled to meet next Tuesday in London to discuss the situation created by the withdrawal of the Cunard White Star Line from conference membership and the proposed reclassification of ships owned by other members of the conference.

Local banks, acting in concert, yesterday raised from one-quarter of 1 per cent to one-half of 1 per cent their rate on demand loans secured by bankers' bills and government securities. The advance, which was agreed upon by the banks late on Tuesday, was applied yesterday morning to both new and outstanding loans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- President Roosevelt received Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt and congratulated her on fifty years of service in the interest of feminine causes, presented the Schiff Trophy to Lieutenant Haynes and appointed Norman H. Davis to represent the United States at the funeral of King George.

THE TIMES publishes this morning the text of the Administration's new Farm Bill, devised as a temporary substitute for AAA. It consists of a series of amendments to a comparatively obscure law known as the Soil Conservation Act, adopted without much fanfare in April of last year.

H. Biddle Fitler, member of a socially prominent Pennsylvania family, plunged seven stories to his death early yesterday morning from his room on the tenth floor of the Hotel Lexington, Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Members of several Canadian organizations, including the Canadian Society of New York, will pay tribute to the memory of King George at a service at 11 A.M. in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street. The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the church, a Canadian by birth, will preach.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The Senate Munitions Investigating Committee is now expected to complete its inquiry and it is probable that J.P. Morgan, Thomas W. Lamont and George Whitney of J.P. Morgan Co. will be recalled as witnesses early next week.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- King Carol of Rumania, whom the late King George refused to receive at Buckingham Palace, is one of four Kings who have already announced that they are coming to England for the funeral at Windsor Tuesday.

HAVANA, Thursday, Jan. 23. -- The government early this morning amended the Constitution with retroactive effect, increasing the number of Senators from each province from four to six in order to give minority representation to the Democratic party, considered as defeated in the recent elections.

In one of the greatest lightweight ring battles seen at a small club since the night nineteen years ago when Benny Leonard lifted the title from Freddie Welsh in Harlem, Tony Canzoneri, holder of the 135-pound crown, last night knocked out Brescia Garcia, rugged, stout-hearted little Mexican, at the Star Casino.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 22. -- More than 400 attended the dinner dance with which the Colony Club inaugurated tonight its eighth season. Lavish flower decorations, colorded lights, two orchestras and special entertainment enhanced the brilliance of the occasion.

The Pilgrims of the United States paid tribute to the memory of King George V at the society's annual meeting yesterday in the Bankers Club. The program was simple with the president of the group, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, making the only address.

Two goals from the stick of Carl Wahnquist enabled the Curb Exchange Tickers to turn back the pace-setting Van Cortlandt Broncos last night in the feature contest of an amateur hockey triple-header at Madison Square Garden before 3,000 persons. The score was 2 to 1.

Premier LAVAL evidently chose to resign rather than be thrown out. His defeat was certain if he had gone again before the Chamber of Deputies and demanded a vote of confidence. His Cabinet was disintegrating in full view. The party "truce" was over, with all groups preparing for the coming election of a new Parliament, and the temporary coalitions in the Chamber which had saved LAVAL again and again could no longer be held together.
GENEVA, Jan. 22. -- The text of a statement by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Great Britain on mutual assistance by five powers in case of an Italian attack was made public here today as follows:

ATHENS, Jan. 22. -- A setback for Italian arms in Africa or a checkmate for Italy in the Mediterranean through League of Nations sanctions may cause Turkey to attempt the seizure of the Dodecanese Islands, which she lost to Italy in 1912, it is believed in international diplomatic circles here.

Unique divertissements have been planned for the gala fashion revue and tea which will take place this afternoon in the Oval Room and the Palm Court of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of Hope Farm. A number of theatrical, motion picture and radio performers have volunteered their services and together with women of society will act as manikins in the style parade.

The Class A squash tennis teams of the New York Athletic Club and the Columbia University Club remained in a deadlock for the lead in the Metropolitan League by winning their matches yesterday. Each has now registered nine victories against a single defeat.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 22. -- Laura Bohusczucz, 20 years old, of Union City, N.J., confined aboard the Monarch of Bermuda since she was discovered stowed away in the ladies room of the ship Sunday en route from New York to Bermuda leaped from the vessel's deck into Hamilton Harbor at 11 A.M. today, determined to set foot on Bermuda soil.

Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. received a clean bill yesterday when he appeared before the State Athletic Commission at a hearing on a protest from the Havana Boxing Commission over cancellation of the Joe Louis-Isadoro Gastanaga heavyweight bout scheduled there last Dec. 29.
PRAGUE, Jan. 22. -- Edmund L. Goodman, New York merchant, was injured in a motor accident near Lobositz tonight.

Artur Schnabel gave the second of his series of Beethoven sonata recitals at Carnegie Hall last night before an audience which listens to him, excepting the few who come to scoff, as if he were the high priest of Beethoven revelation. The program touched more varied points in the great Ludwig's progress as a composer than last week's.

I was surprised to read in THE TIMES that Dr. James H. Kimball of the local Weather Bureau had never heard of thunder and lightning in a snowstorm. I do not know how old Dr. Kimball is, but if he had been attached to the local Weather Bureau in December, 1916, he surely would have seen the lightning and heard the thunder, at least if he had lived in Brooklyn.

Wagner's "Walkuere" was performed yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Grenfell Association. The occasion was one for congratulation, since an immense audience packed the house to overflowing, an audience which Sir Wilfred T. Grenfell thanked handsomely during an intermission for its support and assistance in the noble task to which he has dedicated his career.

ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio, Jan. 22. -- Sheriff's deputies on horseback rescued 100 school children tonight from buses buried in sixteen-foot snowdrifts in this hilly, sparsely settled section on the West Virginia boundary.

Retail credit collections in December showed an increase of 0.22 per cent, according to the index of twenty local "key" stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The gain is the thirty-second monthly increase in the past thirty-three months.

The appointment of fourteen army reserve officers to be members of the advisory board for the Second Corps Area was announced yesterday, after the appointments had been made by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding at Governors Island.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- With the pomp and ceremony that have clothed the monarchy in this country throughout 1,000 years Edward VIII was proclaimed King and Emperor today in his capital city of London and in cities throughout his realm.
Dr. and Mrs. Hubert A. Newton of 149 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, gave a reception last night at their home for Mrs. Ethelbert Nevin, widow of the composer.

Acquisition of a fleet of more than 700 tank cars from an undisclosed corporation was reported yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange by the General American Transportation Corporation in its application to list 10,000 additional shares of its $5 par common stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP). -- A House committee investigating charges of wholesale death of workmen from silica dust today heard Senator Holt, Democrat of West Virginia, term the Hawk's Nest power project tunnel in Southern West Virginia "one of the most barbaric examples of industrial construction" in history.

Stockholders of the Atlantic Refining Company have been called to vote on March 24 on a proposal to authorize $25,000,000 par value of preferred stock. The letter calling the meeting states that if the proposal is approved the new shares will be offered first to the stockholders on a pro-rata basis for subscription.

The number of firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange increased by twenty-three in 1935, while the number of partners in the firms showed a gain of 125, it was shown yesterday upon publication by the Exchange's public relations committee of the Stock Exchange Year Book for 1936. Branch offices, which are located in forty-four States and six foreign countries, declined by two in the year.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- The Archbishop of Canterbury, who was with King George at Sandringham at the time of the monarch's death and gave him the last blessing, told of that final moment today at the Convocation of Canterbury.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- President Roosevelt today received Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, escorted by a delegation from the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War, and presented to her a letter congratulating her on the completion of half a century of public service and the leadership she has given to the cause of peace and the prevention of war.

On Jan. 18 you published a letter from Philip Becker with reference to the conflict between the Federal and State unemployment insurance laws. The need for ironing out these differences and for uniformity in the State and Federal provisions cannot be overemphasized.

Of course it may be that illustrators are easily entertained. What is known as "The Illustrators' Show" arrived at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last evening with a squadron of lean models in parsimonious costumes and a stageful of intelligible innuendoes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- John Hay Whitney of New York City, Fritz Kreisler, violinist, and Roy A. Hunt, president of the Aluminum Company of America, today petitioned the Board of Tax Appeals for relief from additional assessments.

The Harvard Club strengthened its hold on first place in Group 1 while the Dartmouth Club moved past the Downtown A.C. for the leadership in Group 2 in Metropolitan Class C squash racquets play yesterday. The Crimson clubmen registered their fifth straight triumph of the campaign by conquering the Squash Club combination while Dartmouth won from the Columbia Club as the Downtown A.C. was being beaten by the Cornell Club.

Former Mayor John F. Hylan, who died Jan. 12, left an estate of less than $5,000 in personal property and no real property, it was revealed yesterday when his will was filed for probate. The testament directs that all of his estate go to his widow, Mrs. Miriam L. Hylan, of 2 Olive Place, Forest Hills, who is named executrix.

To the distinction of her victory over Mrs. H. Stuart Green of Ardsley on Tuesday, Miss Elizabeth Pearson of Philadelphia added another meritorious performance yesterday when she carried Miss Anne Page of Wayne, Pa., to the limit of five games in the invitation squash racquets tournament at the Junior League.
In her letter to THE TIMES Sue Falk recounts her "nerve-racking" experience when applying for some reference works in the Central Building of the New York Public Library.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- There must be planning if there is to be progress. Therefore it was natural for the President to have made every effort to arrange in advance a brief and uneventful session of Congress in the year of the national elections.

The dollar weakened in foreign exchange yesterday as a result of the combined influence of adverse sentiment created by the passage of the bonus legislation, strong commercial demand for sterling and steadfast support of the franc in terms of the pound by the British and French financial authorities.

GENEVA, Jan. 22. -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, put on public record here today, apparently for the benefit of both Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler, that Great Britain had received guarantees of armed support from France, Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey in the event of an attack by Italy and had given such guarantees in return specifically to Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey and implicitly to France.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- Declaring that a "tremendous gamble" had been forced on scores of industries by the necessity of operating under unconstitutional measures of the New Deal before those measures were invalidated by the Supreme Court, Gilbert H. Montague, New York attorney, advised food and grocery trade associations today to go slow on seeking legislative enforcement of fair-trade-practice codes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The implied promise in the administration neutrality bill that this country might cooperate in a collective effort to stop a war has been stricken out in a Senate Foreign Relations Committee which is sharply divided on features of the measure. At least two weeks is expected to be needed to report the measure.
LONDON, Jan. 22. -- Except for a few stray absentees, all Members of the House of Commons and many peers had sworn allegiance to Edward VIII when the two houses of Parliament adjourned tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- The stock markets resumed trading quietly today. Business was on a small scale but prices gained in firmness as the day progressed. British funds strengthened on Continental support. French bonds weakened in the foreign market, while Brazilian issues were firm.

Anxious to avert primary fights over delegates to the Republican National Convention, Republican leaders in New York County and in the State as well have been actively conferring in the preparation of lists, even though the last day for filing designating petitions is still a month and a half away.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 22. -- Union College has decided to take over complete financial control of athletics, President Fox announced today in reporting the transactions of a meeting of the board of trustees held last week. The decision put the department of physical training and athletics on the same basis as other educational activities of the college, since it centers responsibility and gives full recognition to athletics as education.

Admitting that the Long Island Railroad might move to increase its commutation rates 40 to 50 per cent, Hobart Rawson, railroad statistician, whose study was responsible for the application to increase rates 15 and 20 per cent revealed yesterday that he had been on the Pennsylvania Railroad payroll since he started the survey.

BERLIN, Jan. 22. -- Political opposition to the National Socialist regime will become reason for com pulsory divorce in Germany, according to the draft of new divorce laws prepared by the Academy for German Law and made public today.

A special session of the handicap committee of the United States Polo Association, held in conjunction with Tuesday's annual meeting of the delegates at the Racquet and Tennis Club, announced its findings yesterday. In none of the major brackets of the game was anything done to change the actions of the regular meeting which was held last December, when Thomas Hitchcock Jr. was returned to the top of the game with a ten-goal rating.

Britons in New York, their American friends and the general public continued yesterday by messages, cablegrams and statements to express their sympathy to the British royal family and to the people of Britain at the death of King George.

The Board of Education at a meeting last night approved 410 appointments of teachers and other members of the school staff and transferred more than 700 others in the system in preparation for the Spring term opening Feb. 3.

The walnut grand piano in the rear of the city's only barbering classroom deep in the lower East Side is not just an irrelevance. An adult music class uses the same space; besides, the closed top is a perfect table for tonsorial sketching.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has purchased the painting "Abandoned," by George Elmer Browne from the first exhibition at the temporary galleries of the Municipal Art Committee at 62 West Fifty-third Street. This is the second sale made from the exhibition, which was closed last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A portrayal of the late Senator Huey P. Long as a constructive benefactor of Louisiana, a champion of the common people, an outspoken and effective fighter and a man gifted with "control of circumstances" was given to the Senate today by Senator Overton, his colleague from Louisiana, and Senator Caraway, whom he helped to re-election in Arkansas in 1932.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 22. -- Ras Desta Demtu communicated to the authorities here last night the information that he was moving his headquarters northward into the Sidamo foothills, where he believes Italian tanks and trucks will not be able to operate.

The city of Fitchburg, Mass., awarded yesterday a new issue of $776,000 of high school bonds to a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at 100.55 for 2s. The bonds are to be dated Jan. 1, 1936, and mature serially from Jan. 1, 1937 to 1956.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The hurdy-gurdy delivered a posthumous cry for recognition in New York yesterday morning. But, far from being sad, it was a festive occasion for the sixty children at the Virginia Day Nursery, 632 East Fifth Street, for whom Mary Lewis, former Metropolitan Opera soprano, arranged a special recital of favorite old songs, which she sang to the accompaniment of a hand organ.

An old rink favorite will be missing from the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight when the New York Americans clash with the Toronto Maple Leafs in their fourth struggle of the National Hockey League season.

With the details received yesterday from LINCOLN ELLSWORTH of his 2,000-mile flight in five stages across the Antarctic, the true proportions of that hazardous journey with HERBERT HOLLICK-KENYON at the controls become apparent. Apart from the importance of this looking down with the eye of the eagle on vast areas heretofore unknown to man, the airplane flight takes rank as a great feat of aviation.

ROME, Jan. 22. -- Today's official war bulletin, which finally tells definitely of a sweeping victory won by General Rodolfo Graziani in Southern Ethiopia and gives news of the resumption of operations on the northern front, may well mark the turning point of the Italo-Ethiopian war, it is believed here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The text of the amendments to the Soil Conservation Act of 1935 (printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 16), as introduced today by Senator Bankhead, is as follows:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 22. -- A United Air Lines passenger plane, ending its run from Chicago with eight persons aboard, was landed safely at the airport at 10:30 o'clock tonight after circling above the field for almost an hour with a frozen stabilizer until fire apparatus and ambulances had assembled in readiness for a crash below.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 22. -- Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, Baldwin (L.I.) housewife on trial with Everett Applegate, former American Legion official, for the murder of his wife by poison, sought on the witness stand today to place all blame for the killing on the codefendant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- At the request of WPA, a study of the relative number of World War veterans on relief in twelve major cities has been completed by the Veterans' Administration and turned over to Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

The report of the Liggett and Myers Tobacco Company for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $16,856,543 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after dividends on the 7 per cent preferred stock, to $4.91 a share on 3,136,939 shares of combined common and common B shares. It compares with a net income of $20,086,690, or $5.92 a share on the stock, for 1934.

Armed with newspaper reports that Dr. LeRoy L. Hartman had given to the world the formula for his dental pain-killing solution, patients who called upon their dentists yesterday demanded an immediate try-out.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- Hailing a broad rise in New York farm prices, Governor Lehman, in an address to the State Agricultural Society tonight declared, however, that they were short of the general price rises and asserted that for further improvement this spread must be reduced.

IT was nice of M'sieu Lestairre Patrick to let the Chicago Black Hawks practice on the Garden rink yesterday after what they did to his Rangers the night before. An ill-natured gent would have told Clem Loughlin and his fast-flying Hawks to get out and stay out and never darken his doorstep again.

GENEVA, Jan. 22. -- Unusually strong pressure was marshaled by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in the League Council this morning and continued tonight in private talks to persuade Danzig's Nazi Government to respect its democratic Constitution and the League's authority as a guarantor of that Constitution, but Arthur Greiser, president of the Danzig Senate, was still balking tonight.

Educational leaders, social workers and representatives of other professional groups proposed various methods for improving the economic and social condition of residents in the mountain sections of the South and other rural areas at a meeting held yesterday under the auspices of the Save the Children Fund at the Hotel McAlpin.

The Transit Commission approved yesterday the group of applications submitted by the New York City Omnibus Corporation and designed to make possible the substitution of buses for surface cars on the entire New York Railways Corporation network in Manhattan some time this Summer.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- Employment in 7,903 retail stores in New York City rose 1.5 per cent from October to November and payrolls increased 1.1 per cent, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported today. For the same period of 1934 the corresponding figures increased 3.2 to 1.4 per cent, respectively.

The second trial of William H. Rabell, former investigator for the Securities Exchange Commission, ended abruptly yesterday afternoon when Federal Judge Patterson dismissed all six counts of an indictment charging him with impersonating a Federal officer and accepting a bribe from J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A movement to restrict the Supreme Court's power to invalidate acts of Congress took shape today in the Senate and the House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Lawsuits involving more than $8,000,000 in claims against the government as a result of the devaluation of the dollar, outlawry of payment in gold and other gold-restriction policies have been filed in the Court of Claims, it was ascertained today.
Construction of a Jamaica-Ocean Skyway which would bring Manhattan within a half-hour's ride of the Long Island beaches was proposed yesterday by the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce.

J. Howard Shoemaker of New York, sixteen-time winner of the title, defeated Louis Brookes of Philadelphia, 125 to 109, in forty innings as play in the national amateur pocket billiard championship started last night at the Strand Academy.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- With the introduction of more anti-crime bills, some carrying out recommendations made by Governor Lehman in his recent special message, nearly two score of measures sharpening the State's penal law to provide better protection from organized criminals are now pending before the Legislature.

John F. O'Ryan, former Police Commissioner, announced last night that he had agreed to serve as special counsel for the pin game industry on the understanding that the industry would exclude unlawful use of the machines.

Asserting that witnesses in the Drukman murder case have been "terrorized," Hiram C. Todd, special Assistant Attorney General now investigating the murder and allied charges of bribery and police brutality, issued a statement last night, defending his action in opening headquarters for the investigation in the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22. -- Eulace Peacock, Temple University sprinter, making his first indoor start in Philadelphia, won the 40-yard dash, feature of an A.A.U. meet tonight.

For the third successive day the youthful Horace Stoneham, new president of the Giants, had occasion to feel that this business of being a club owner is perhaps not as difficult as it has been cracked up to be when Secretary Jim Tierney announced yesterday that another member of the cast had come into the fold for 1936.

Steel output continues unchanged this week at 51 per cent of capacity for the third week, with demand still spotty but the market for scrap buoyant, according to the summary by The Iron Age. The composite price for heavy melting steel, however, is up to $13.58 a ton, which is 16 cents a ton higher than the peak for 1935, reached in December.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 22. -- A radio "check-valve" to eliminate man-made interference and cut down static, has been perfected by the development and experimental short-wave engineers of the American Radio Relay League.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- Receipts of hogs here today fell below the trade's expectations as a result of the cold wave, and with a larger demand prices advanced 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight. Numerous lots of selected 185 to 225 pound averages reached the top of $10.25 or 15 cents above the best price on Tuesday and only 15 cents under the highest sale since Oct. 21.
Plans for a new court house on the westerly side of Foley Square were disclosed yesterday by Samuel Levy. Borough President of Manhattan, after he had discussed them with Mayor La Guardia.

The prevention and control of chronic disease is today the "outstanding public health problem" of the nation, Dr. Hugh S. Cumming, surgeon general of the United States, told members of the Welfare Council last night at a symposium arranged by the council's committee on chronic illness.

In Town Hall last night Andres Segovia, the Spanish guitarist, returned to a grateful public for his first American appearance of the season. The concert was one of the Town Hall Endowment Series. On the stage, when the audience gathered, was only the diminutive rest which is his sole apparatus.

Reports of increasing cooperation from the medical profession were given by the chairmen of twelve affiliated committees of the New York State Birth Control Federation at the annual meeting held in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday morning, attended by 125 delegates and members from all parts of the State.

PARIS, Jan. 22. -- Once more, and for the eleventh time since this Parliament was elected less than four years ago, President Lebrun was looking tonight for some one who would form a government, for Premier Laval and his Cabinet resigned today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22. -- The Cabinet of Premier Tewfik Nessim Pasha resigned today after fourteen months in office, as an outcome of Great Britain's reply to the demand of the United Front of all parties for negotiations for an Anglo-Egyptian treaty of alliance.

SANDRINGHAM, Jan. 22. -- A simple country gentleman who was also the ruler of a mighty empire lay today in the parish church of Sandringham while an unending line of villagers and tenants from his estate filed slowly past his coffin.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 22. -- Haywood Patterson's fourth trial for his life on a charge of rape ended today, as have all the other trials in the famous Scottsboro case, with an appeal to the passions of the jury.

TRENTON, Jan. 22. -- Within a week of Governor Hoffman's plea to the Legislature that it take steps to remedy conditions responsible for railroads withholding each year a part of their State taxes, it was disclosed today that Republican members of the Assembly had voted themselves six annual railroad passes each for distribution among their political supporters.

An indication of the vigor with which members of the New York Yacht Club are taking up their new one-design class of cruising-racing sloops was given yesterday when Vice Commodore E. Townsend Irvin of the class committee said that the number of orders placed thus far has reached fifteen.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22. -- Richard Leche, the Huey Long candidate for Governor, had a majority of 109,980 tonight over his "Home Rule" opponent, Representative Cleveland Dear, on late returns from yesterday's Democratic primary.

In a memorandum handed down yesterday Judge Robert A. Inch, in the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, served notice on the Bush Terminal Company that unless a plan of reorganization is presented to him within thirty days he will terminate the proceedings under Section 77b now before him and return the company to the possession of equity receivers.

Things looked dark indeed for the New York Americans when they were trailing the Toronto Maple Leafs by two goals in the third period of their game at Madison Square Garden last night. The 10,000 fans on hand were resigned to a defeat for the spangled forces and remained in their seats only to postpone their venture into the freezing outdoors.

Organization of the Consumer Distribution Corporation, having a capital of $1,000,000, to serve as the central buying and service unit for a large chain of cooperative department stores and other types of retail business was announced yesterday by Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 23. -- President Jose Luis Tejada delivered a manifesto to the nation today officially announcing the signature of the protocol of Buenos Aires liberating the prisoners taken during the recent Chaco war. The agreement is subject to the approval of Congress.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 23 (AP). -- A.B. Gochenour of Sycamore, Ill., filed suit in Common Pleas Court here today asking for a receiver for the Cleveland Terminals Building Company, a Van Sweringen property, and for judgments of approximately $15,000,000 from three defendants.
Several thousand industrial plants have moved out of New York City to near-by States in the last six or seven years, Controller Frank T. Taylor reported last night.

DETROIT, Jan. 23.--The Detroit Red Wings, serving notice they intend to be very much in the National Hockey League play-offs, handed the New York Rangers a 4-2 trimming tonight in a thrill-packed match before 9,000 fans. The victory widened the Wings' first-place lead in the American Division.

From LINCOLN ELLSWORTH'S dispatch of yesterday we must infer that the remarkable flight from Weddell Sea to the Bay of Whales is one of the great scientific achievements in the history of exploration. The time has not yet come to evaluate the discoveries that have been made, yet it is already evident that some of the more hotly disputed issues of Antarctic geography have been settled.

Obviously fearing that freedom would mean his death as an informer at the hands of a gang, Martin Loonan, 51 years old, halted his trial in General Sessions yesterday and pleaded guilty as a fourth offender to an indictment charging him with attempted robbery.

Only 179 buildings, most of them small apartment houses in the Bronx, remained affected by the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes yesterday as the bitter cold forced many owners to meet the union's demands while the union itself curbed it strike activities.

MIAMI, Jan. 23. -- Taking the ground that the activities of the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, constitute "a challenge to the supremacy of the American Federation of Labor," the federation's executive council today requested the committee to dissolve and cease its operations.

W.R.K. Mitchell, vice president of the Provident Trust Company of Philadelphia, announced yesterday that he had filed an alternative plan of reorganization for the Peoples Light and Power Corporation on behalf of the protective committee for first-lien bond-holders with the Federal District Court in Wilmington.

Bank clearings of twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., amounted to $5,820,632,000, against $5,076,403,000 a year ago. The increase of 14.7 per cent contrasted with a decline of 0.6 per cent in the previous week.
LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Only four of the five stanzas of Rudyard Kipling's "Recessional" were sung at his funeral today. The stanza beginning "If, drunk with sight of power, we loose" was omitted.

J. Howard Shoemaker, defending national amateur pocket billiard champion, scored his second victory in as many starts in the current tourney at the Strand Academy last night by administering a third straight setback to Hayden W. Brown of New Haven, 125 to 33, in 19 innings.

Eleanor Powell, tap dancer and featured performer in "At Home Abroad," has left the show for an indefinite period. She last appeared in the cast Tuesday night. Suffering from what her physician described yesterday as exhaustion resulting from overwork, Miss Powell was taken yesterday to the Westchester Medical Center, a private sanatorium in Yonkers.
LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The following is the text of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's remarks on the monarchy before the House of Commons today:
PARIS, Friday, Jan. 24. -- No government has yet been found to take the place of that of Pierre Laval, which resigned Wednesday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 23. -- The Wagner Labor Relations Act was held constitutional by Federal Judge Martin today in denying an injunction sought by Bemis Brothers Bag Company, Bemis, Tenn., against Charles N. Feigelson, chairman, and the National Labor Relations Board of the Tenth Region.

Miss Anne Page of Wayne, Pa., and Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Rye will be rivals this afternoon in the final round of the annual invitation squash racquets tournament of the Junior League. They are meeting for the fourth year in succession in this event on the courts of the clubhouse in East Seventy-first Street, Miss Page having won the past two years. The match is to start at 3 o'clock.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Outside and professional interest in the wheat market on the Board of Trade showed no evidence of expanding today, although there was sufficient buying early, based on strong cables from Liverpool, talk of inflation and strength in stocks, to lift prices around 1/2 cent a bushel, with the May selling at the highest level since Jan. 11.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (AP). -West Main, C.A. Peck's 6-year-old gelding, won the featured $1,200 Del Mar Handicap at Santa Anita today, running seven furlongs in 1:23 3-5.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23. -- The horses had to plow through one of the heaviest tracks in Florida's racing history at Hialeah Park today. Two features, the Fort Myers and the Gainesville Purses, were offered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- An additional list of applications for registration of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market, including those of several New York firms, filed between Dec. 30 and Jan. 4, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- A million sorrowing subjects are expected to look upon their late King for the last time while passing in solemn lines past his catafalque when he lies in state, beginning tomorrow.

As a writer of murder plays Liam O'Flaherty has the virtue of imagination and the vice of introspection, and "The Puritan," which was dramatized at the Belmont last evening, travels the full range. Chester Erskin has turned the novel into a play and ingeniously set it on a diminutive stage with Denis O'Dea in the part.
Travis Jackson, gallant captain and venerable warhorse of the New York Giants, yesterday became the fourth straight player in as many days to return his signed contract for 1936.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith is understood to have completed the speech he will deliver in Washington tomorrow night at the dinner of the American Liberty League.

In the fourth week of decline The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices dropped to 127.4 on Tuesday from 128.2 on the Tuesday previous. Petroleum, gasoline, rubber, coffee and eggs were higher, but obacco, cattle and beef, refined sugar and the textiles were lower.

Floyd Y. Keeler of Orvis Bros. Co. was elected yesterday president of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., to succeed Jerome Lewine, who served in that post two years. Martin H. Wehncke was elected treasurer to succeed Mr. Keeler. Douglas Walker became a vice president to succeed Charles Muller, and William E. Bruyn was elected vice president to succeed Charles Slaughter.
Development, estate and business property deals were included in the Westchester transactions reported yesterday.

To meet the pressing financial needs of the city's voluntary hospitals, the first $500,000 raised in the campaign for the United Hospital Fund will be distributed tomorrow to the seventy-five institutions participating in the fund, it was announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the distribution committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The speedy course of the "baby bond" Soldier Bonus Bill was temporarily halted today when President Roosevelt followed his customary procedure by referring it for study to the Veterans Administration, Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau and to the Director of the Bureau of the Budget.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 23. -Charles E. Whitehead of South River, N.J., and Howard A. Tryon of Elmira, N.Y., will meet tomorrow in the final of the annual Miami Biltmore amateur golf tournament as a result of double victories today.

The New York Stock Exchange instructed all member firms yesterday by letter to file before Feb. 1 accounts of expenses incurred since July 25, 1935, in the entertainment of employes of the Exchange and of several organizations with which members transact business.
The cold wave from the Middle West hit New York early yesterday and sent the mercury to 2 degrees below zero, the coldest Jan. 23 in seven years. It caused three deaths.

The Long Island Railroad's method of attempting to show need for an increase in commutation rates was sharply attacked yesterday by Joseph L. Weiner, assistant corporation counsel, at the joint hearing of the Public Service and Transit Commissions on the application for the increase.
Beginning of the subscription sale for the Wagner matinee cycle at the Metropolitan Opera House was signalized yesterday morning by a near sellout. Only a few scattered seats remained.
PARIS, Jan. 23. -- Belieing all forecasts that disaster would fol low the resignation of the Laval government, the Bourse today was active and firm.

The Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council approved yesterday a draft of a bill amending the Unemployment Insurance Law to meet certain objections to the present law and to provide for minor corrections.

The special grand jury to succeed the one that has been investigating rackets in New York County for the last six months will be selected and sworn in this morning by Justice Philip J. McCook at a new extraordinary term of the Supreme Court.

ROME, Jan. 23. -- Anthony Eden's memorandum of yesterday to the Committee of Eighteen at Geneva, revealing a five-power military pact against Italy, is deemed here to have strengthened rather than weakened the Italian case. It is regarded as evidence of arbitrary methods hitherto followed by Great Britain in dealing with the Ethiopian crisis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Governor Davey of Ohio, whose opposition to the administration once reached the point of an open break, bore an olive branch to the White House today, where he was accompanied by a delegation of Democratic leaders to swear his allegiance and give newspaper correspondents an emphatic prediction of a Democratic victory in Ohio in November.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23. -- Higher education in the United States in the next 100 years must necessarily be radically different from that of the past century, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, declared in his annual report to the Harvard Board of Overseers, made public tonight.

OTTAWA, Jan. 23 (Canadian Press).--The attack of Canadian liquor firms to recover $4,000,000 paid to the government on liquor shipments to the United States from 1923 to 1926 under the Volstead Act began today in the Exchequer Court with hearing of the suit of the Dominion Distillery Products, Ltd., of Montreal.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 (AP). -- Ann Cooper Hewitt said on the witness stand today that she was duped into a sterilization operation by her mother, Mrs. Maryon Hewitt McCarter.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23. -- California's Democratic party squabbles were appealed to President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley again today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP). -Quantity production of airmen and airplanes to keep pace with aviation defense programs of foreign powers was urged upon Congress today by Eugene L. Vidal, head of the Air Commerce Bureau.
LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The first authoritative account of the King's last illness appeared simultaneously today in The Lancet and The British Medical Journal.

A fundamental clash over the question whether this nation should be governed by men elected by the people or by legal machinery -- a controversy which today seems almost certain to involve President Franklin D. Rosevelt -- is indicated as the reason for the famous "break" between Taft and Theodore Roosevelt in the latest volume of the Dictionary of American Biography.

The dollar continued to fall in the foreign exchange market yesterday to the accompaniment of a further batch of devaluation rumors, fresh silver manipulations, new resignations from the Treasury and other reports of impending developments that might affect the value of the United States currency unit.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Parliament received today its first message from King Edward VIII. It was very brief and was written in the King's own hand to inform the House of Lords and House of Commons of the death of his father and to assure them he was resolved to follow the example set by the late sovereign.

A syndicate headed by R.W. Pressprich Co. has purchased a new issue of $778,500 of city of Fort Worth, Texas, 3 1/2 per cent bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1936, and due serially from Jan. 1, 1937 to 1966. Other members of the syndicate are, Elredge Co., Illinois Company of Chicago, Stern Bros. Co. and the State Investment Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Government plans for raising billions of dollars to meet burdens imposed on the Treasury by the soldiers' bonus, the agricultural relief problem, the deficit and other budgetary requirements were taking shape, Secretary Morgenthau said today, and would be clarified within a few weeks.
LONDON, Jan. 23. -- A note of anxiety crept into the speech in which William Favill Tuke, chairman of Barclays Bank, attempted to forecast the future to his shareholders today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23. -- Asserting that bankers were better equipped than ever before to give "adequate and constructive service" to the American people, Robert V. Fleming, president of the American Bankers Association, said here today that there had been "too much dependence upon legislation as a cure-all for our troubles."

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a rise of 9 per cent for the week ended Jan. 18, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure is slightly under that for the previous week, when a gain of 10 per cent in deliveries was reported.

GENEVA, Jan. 23.--Flatly defying Uruguay to prove her charges that the Soviet Legation abused its diplomatic privileges by helping Brazilian revolutionists with checks, Foreign Commissar Litvinoff of Soviet Russia vainly offered today to authorize Uruguayan banks to divulge all his legation's financial transactions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The Supreme Court of the United States has invaded the rights of Congress in recent decisions, Senator Logan, who was formerly Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Kentucky, asserted in the Senate today while speaking in favor of a proposed amendment to the Constitution which he introduced a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The marketing today by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company of $40,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent mortgage bonds priced to yield 3.84 per cent to maturity in 1970, was accepted by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, as a development backing up his campaign to obtain lower interest rates for railroad financing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Angered because the Senate adopted an amendment by Senator Bailey to the bill changing the measurement of vessels for purposes of assessing Panama Canal tolls, Senator Gore, charging that the amendment emasculated the measure, today moved to withdraw the bill from further consideration.

There are intimations in some quarters at Washington that President ROOSEVELT may decide to sign the Bonus Bill. If not that, its backers hope that he may let it become a law without his signature. Either course is unthinkable for the President. It is a reflection upon his character, almost an insult to him, even to suppose that he is capable of repudiating his own recent stand and stultifying himself in any such fashion.
