An all-heavyweight boxing card will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight, with Andre Lenglet of France opposing Hans Birkie, German veteran, in the feature bout of ten rounds.

Price movements were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with activity moderate. On the cash markets dairy products, wool tops, rubber and silk advanced, while rye and oats declined.

With Ray Sears of Butler, credited with the fastest two miles ever run by an American, heading the field, thirteen of the nation's leading distance stars will toe the mark in the two-mile invitation race, one of the feature events of the twenty-ninth annual Millrose meet at Madison Square Garden, Feb. 1.

On a day described by government weather scientists as the coldest Jan. 23 in New York in seven years, it must have been the warming vision of a Summer in gay cruisers on alluring inland waterways that filled the National Motor Boat Show yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The Republic Steel Corporation has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $45,000,000 of general mortgage bonds, giving the names of the underwriters: The interest price and the date of offerings are to be supplied later.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- No traffic moved through the heart of London this afternoon. The streets had been cleared and fresh sand had been spread over them in accordance with London's age-long custom whenever a state procession is expected.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- George V made his last journey today to the capital of the empire whose greatness and dignity his reign had done so much to enhance. It was less than a month since he had left it with his Queen to spend Christmas at Sandringham, to which of all his homes he had been most attached because it embodied the healthful country life he had loved.

Preparations for a strike of 105,000 dressmakers in this city and near-by States were completed last night by leaders of the Dressmakers Union and the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, parent organization, at a meeting in the Hotel Delano, 108 West Forty-third Street.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- During King George's reign nearly 7,000 new stamps were created throughout the British Empire. All these are believed to be included in his big collection, valued at an estimated 400,000, and at present housed in Buckingham Palace.

OTTAWA, Jan. 23 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada yesterday showed a decrease of $5,529,825 in the week, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. At the same time an increase of $5,970,861 was recorded in deposits by chartered banks.

An increasing flow of investment funds to savings and loan institutions and a greater real estate activity than for several years was seen in 1935, George L. Bliss, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders of the bank, held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Stock prices vigorously pursued the advantage gained the day before, closing strong yesterday, at or near the day's best levels. Many of the market leaders on the Stock Exchange were up 1 to 3 points, some of the preferred stocks even more, in total trading of nearly 3,000,000 shares.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange again advanced yesterday on buying activity in distant deliveries, particularly from foreign sources, and the list closed with net changes ranging from a gain of 12 points to a loss of 5 points.

When Charles F. Tillinghast Jr. of Providence brought the crippled ketch Hamrah safely into port with two young companions over 900 miles of storm-torn ocean last June after three of her company had drowned, he had performed the finest feat of seamanship accomplished by an amateur yachtsman during 1935.

Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, promoted two members of his staff yesterday and in doing so, he announced, brought to completion a self-imposed task of reorganizing the supervisory personnel of the department "along modern public health lines."
While Professor McBain's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine on the AAA Supreme Court decision is most clear and explicit, he seems to fall into the pit he dug for others.

Supreme Court Justice Rosenman reserved decision yesterday on the application by the Times Amusement Corporation, operator of a pin-ball "Sportland" at 1,661 Broad way, and thirty similar establishments, to restrain License Commissioner Paul Moss from revoking their licenses.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
PARIS, Jan. 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
The city can borrow $351,484,376.38 and remain within its constitutional debt limit, Controller Taylor announced yesterday.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning President Roosevelt is reported as viewing the recent action of the Supreme Court in ordering the return of impounded processing taxes as a reversal of that court's position in Bailey v. George (1921), 259 U.S. 16, 66 L. Ed., 816, and as viewing that case as authorizing the retention by the government of illegally collected taxes.

An exhibition comprising some 300 foreign travel posters, including designs by A.M. Cassandre, Pierre Masseau, Rene Martin, Ludwig Holwein, J. van den Bergh, Fred Taylor and Warwick Goble, has been arranged at the offices of Thomas Cook Son, 587 Fifth Avenue.

Declaring that the verdict of guilty against Haywood Patterson was a "challenge to the conscience of the nation," the Scottsboro defense committee, representing six organizations, declared last night that it will continue to aid the defense in a "fight to the finish."

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Trial of the suit of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to collect approximately $10,000,000 from about 3,000 stockholders in Illinois of the old Central Republic Bank and Trust Company on stockholders' double liability was started today before Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP). -Chairman Nye of the Senate Munitions Committee made public today a letter to Allen W. Dulles of New York, nephew of Secretary of State Lansing, denying that he had violated a trust in showing fellow-Senators a section of the Lansing diary.

A minimum price of $29,656,510 for the properties of the Richfield Oil Company and Pan American Petroleum Corporation was fixed yesterday by Federal Judge William P. Jones, sitting in Los Angeles, according to an announcement made here yesterday on behalf of the companies.
SANDRINGHAM, England, Jan. 23. -- King George passed for the last time today through the peaceful Norfolk countryside where he had spent the happiest days of his life as an English squire.
The North German Lloyd liner Bremen, which arrived late yesterday, will sail again tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- After sitting for five years the commission appointed by the Archbishops of Canterbury and York to inquire into the relations between church and State issued a report tonight urging a round-table conference of churchmen.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- Declaring that fire truck trails in the State forests "presaged a demand to make them passable to automobiles," Governor Lehman's special committee, by a majority of four to one, reported today to Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, against further construction of such trails.

ALBANY, Jan. 23.--Reorganization of series of guaranteed-mortgage certificates amounting to $93,270,081 was effected in the first seven months of actual operation of the State Mortgage Commission, the annual report of that body to Governor Lehman disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The Bonus Bill was started by President Roosevelt through the departmental routine customary with such legislation, making it certain his decision as to veto or approval of the bill will not be made known until next week.

CAIRO, Friday, Jan. 24. -- At 1 A.M. Ismail Sidky Pasha and Mohammed Mahmoud Pasha, both former Premiers, left Adbin palace, where they conferred for more than two hours with Ali Maher Pasha, chief of the Royal Cabinet. But it is still uncertain who will form the new Ministry.

BERLIN, Jan. 23. -- The usually omnipresent Nazi party uniforms have been banned from the Olympic Winter Games beginning Feb. 6 at Garmisch-Partenkirchen. With perhaps unexpected tact, Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, and Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the Nazi party, today issued a request that sports clothes, instead of uniforms, be worn by spectators at the Winter Olympic events.
Arrangements were made yesterday for the transfer of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange for $173,000, an advance of $1,000 over the last previous transaction a week ago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Only 4,000 hogs were received here today because of the cold weather, and prices advanced 15 to 25 cents a hundred-weight to the highest level since last October. The top soared 25 cents to $10.50, while the day's average was up 25 cents at $10.35.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company and sixteen affiliated companies were named defendants yesterday in an action begun by State Attorney General Bennett to prevent the sale of securities to their employes in lieu of wages and to recover for the benefit of employes the proceeds of securities sold since October, 1931, by allegedly fraudulent means.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- With a demand for an accounting of the operations of the secret exchange stabilization fund, Representative Fish of New York said today that at least $1,000,000,000 of the Treasury's gold reserve should be lent abroad to act as a revolving fund for the purchase of American agricultural products.

Serious practical objections to the tentative draft of regulation "U," the Federal Reserve Board's rules governing loans by banks for the purpose of purchasing or carrying equity securities registered on a national securities exchange, have been disclosed in a study of the regulation now being carried out by an informal committee of five vice presidents of clearing house banks, it was learned yesterday.

Colonel Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, "Black Eagle of Harlem" and former pilot in the Ethiopian Army, was barred from the United States yesterday after a special inquiry board on Ellis Island had studied his case and found that he did not have proper papers.

Net income of the Freeport Texas Company for 1935 was $1,492,108 after Federal taxes, depreciation and other charges, according to the preliminary statement, issued yesterday. The earnings are equivalent, after allowing for dividends on the 6 per cent preferred stock, to $1.78 a share on 796,380 common shares.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Stock markets here generally were firm today, with the industrials particularly active. British funds gained on further investment buying. Brazilian issues again strengthened in the foreign market; Japanese securities were firm and the Europeans uncertain.

The notion seems to be gaining credence that the United States was drawn into the World War by some combination of occult and sinister influences, instead of by the acts of hostility, some threatened and some perpetrated, by the power against which war was declared.

Brokers' loans fell $17,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $954,000,000, according to the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, published yesterday. The decline followed an increase of $4,000,000 the week before and a drop of $47,000,000 two weeks ago.

In accordance with an order of the Federal Court in St. Louis, the receivers of the Wabash Railway Company have entered into an agreement with the principal holders of about $9,500,000 of its equipment trust certificates whereby the payment of certain installments will be deferred.

Representative Emanuel Celler and Gomer Smith, newly elected president of Old Age Revolving Pensions, debated last night the merits of the Townsend plan before a visible audience of about 1,500 persons at the Town Hall. The debate, held under the auspices of the League for Political Education in "America's Town Meeting" series, was broadcast over the National Broadcasting Company chain.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 23 (AP). -- It was the same old story today when Norway's ski jumpers in general and Birger Ruud in particular dominated formal Olympic practice competition in which representatives from the United States, Canada, Japan, Italy and Germany also participated.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The Senate bill files received the first measures for the session today, which provides for major changes in the Public Service Law, recommended by Governor Lehman in his annual message.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 24.--The war of frontier posts between Manchukuo and Outer Mongolia was renewed yesterday Then 100 Outer Mongolian troops attacked a Manchukuoan patrol force near Heilmuto.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- A sharp Democratic attack upon the American Liberty League, whose members will gather here Saturday night to hear former Governor Alfred E. Smith, was made today in the Senate, where Senator Schwellenbach assailed the organization and the "leeches, rascals, crooks and bloodsucking lawyers" who, he said, controlled its policies.

Robert Worth Bingham, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, returned from London last night on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, for a belated Christmas vacation and a rest at his home in Kentucky. He planned to come home for the holidays, but was forced to cancel several bookings on steamers because of the pressure of business at the embassy, including the naval conference.

Elmer Rice resigned last evening as the regional director of the Federal Theatre Project In this city. He did so in a dispute over the subject-matter in what was to be the project's first play -- "The Living Newspaper." The WPA authorities felt that the government's shows could not rightly picture the heads of other nations -- as was to be done in a sketch called "Ethiopia" -- but Mr. Rice apparently felt otherwise.

Despite wide publicity given to the meeting, only thirty members of the Salt Water Anglers of America turned out for the session at the Hotel Gramercy Park last Wednesday evening. Officers of the association made no effort to hide their disappointment. They were frankly puzzled at this evidence of lack of public support.

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 23. -- The first break in the succession of death verdicts returned against Haywood Patterson, one of nine Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case, came today when a Morgan County jury found him "guilty as charged," and fixed his punishment at seventy-five years in the penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP). -Cotton of last year's growth, ginned prior to Jan. 16, was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 10,249,688 running bales, counting 281,007 round bales as half bales, and including 16,284 bales of American-Egyptian.

Dr. Albert Harrison Brundage, now in the twilight of a career devoted to the study of toxicology and public health service, will lose his home in Queens under foreclosure Feb. 1 and will probably spend remainder of his days in a home for the aged.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--Sub-zero temperatures were again allotted to Chicago today, but the main fury ...

Stockholders of the Virginia Bridge and Iron Company ratified yesterday the sale of its plants at Roanoke, Va.; Memphis, Tenn., and Birmingham, Ala., to the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, Southern subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

Frank Presbrey, advertising executive, made public yesterday his resignation from the National Advisory Board of the Council for Moderation, Inc. According to Mr. Presbrey, the resignation was tendered three months ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP). -The International Seamen's Union convention ordered its Pacific Coast locals today to leave the Maritime Federation of the Pacific.

The mystery of our enormous gold imports, in a twelvemonth when combined imports of merchandise and silver exceeded exports, is deepened by Wednesday's full report on our foreign trade in 1935. Briefly summarized, the year's excess of merchandise exports was $234,226,000 (smallest, except for 1933, of any year since 1895), whereas excess of silver imports was $335,730,000.

BERLIN, Jan. 23. -- The Boerse was definitely weaker today as a result of reports regarding the Krupp report, due on Saturday, and in response to the depressing effect of the now evident fact that industry will have to carry the new increase in freight rates.

The fashion show and tea for the benefit of the children of Hope Farm in Dutchess County, N.Y., was held yesterday in the Oval Room and Palm Court of the Ritz-Carlton. Among those who entertained at the tea were Mrs. Alfred Seton, who had as her guests her daughter, the Duchesse de Feltre, Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler and Mrs. Marc Peter, wife of the Swiss Minister at Washington.

A 40-year-old woman died in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday from burns and other injuries suffered when, her clothing aflame, she leaped five stories from her burning apartment on the top floor of 347 West Twenty-third Street. The fire, which was discovered about 11 A.M., drove thirty-five persons into the icy streets.

The position of the Eastern railroads in the contest which the Port of New Orleans is waging before the Interstate Commerce Commission to win export motor car traffic, is attacked in a new brief filed with the commission by the New Orleans Port Commissioners.

The probability of the reorganization of the Lawyers Mortgage Company in behalf of its creditors was announced yesterday in a decision by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler. The court granted an application for the reorganization proceeding made by a creditors' committee, and will appoint a referee to conduct hearings upon the plan proposed by the committee or any other plan that may be submitted.

One great merit in LINCOLN ELLSWORTH'S beautifully told story of his historic flight is the frank statement that science was not the only thing that drew him on. No doubt a remote continent of five million square miles, almost twice as big as the United States, holds many a problem for the scientist. "

As the late King George V was the head of a commonwealth of nations in which many religions are professed, an "all faiths memorial service" will be held by the World Fellowship of Faiths Wednesday at 4 P.M. in the Hotel New Yorker, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

FRANK SIMONDS'S death will be deplored by all who knew him, and regretted by the wide circle of readers that his articles and books informed, stimulated and sometimes irritated, as clear and firmly held opinions, often on matters sharply controversial, could not fail to do.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP). -- The Senate spent $236,000 for its investigations in the last fiscal year.

Negotiations have been virtually completed by Loew's, Inc., for the offering of a new issue of $15,000,000 of ten-year debentures, bearing interest at 3 1/2 per cent. The proceeds will be devoted, in part, to the retirement of the $7,717,500 6 per cent sinking fund debentures of 1941, and to the retirement of mortgages and subsidiary funded debt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Securities having a total face value of $2,677,692,920 and registered under the Securities Act of 1933 were released for sale in 1935, and of these $1,047,800,208, or 39.1 per cent, was by electric and gas utility companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

OSAKA, Japan, Jan. 23 (AP). -- Vice Admiral Sankichi Takahashi, Commander-in-Chief of the combined Japanese fleets, pictured tonight a prospect of rivalry between America and Japanese commerce, backed by navies, in the island territories of the Southeastern Pacific.

The Bank of Montreal says in its monthly survey that 1936 has opened under favorable economic auspices and that Canada is benefiting from a slow but steady upward movement in business, some industrial expansion and an increasing volume of external trade, and that agriculture is in a generally more prosperous condition than at any other time in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 22, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,485,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week and $17,000,000 above the average for the corresponding week in 1935.
The board of directors of the U.S. Pipe and Foundry Company declared yesterday a dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share on the common stock as against 12 1/2 cents a share paid in the preceding quarter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Liberalization of this country's immigration laws to permit admission of Jewish refugees from Germany was a problem which Congress must soon face, Senator William H. King of Utah told the Senate today. He said that 600,000 Jews were today subject to "ruthless persecution under decrees of the present German regime."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 23. -- Following stormy debate today, the Assembly eliminated all reference to the Church of England from the new Tax Collection Bill, designed to facilitate collection of colonial, municipal and parochial taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Attorney General Cummings said today that plans for new taxes to finance a farm program replacing the AAA are in process of formation by the Justice Department and the Treasury.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The ashes of Rudyard Kipling were buried today between the graves of Charles Dickens and Thomas Hardy in the quiet transept of Westminster Abbey that is known as the Poets' Corner.

Majestic and beautiful New York certainly is, but life here for most of us is pretty grim. It seems to me we need just such funny, gay, lowbrow entertainers in the streets as the hurdy-gurdies. Many times I have started home with aching feet and depressed spirits to find myself stepping out to the tune of a Souse march or a popular song, my pain forgotten, my courage renewed.

Dean Young B. Smith of Columbia Law School urged members of the bar yesterday at the fifty-ninth annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association to support the work of the Law Revision Commission, of which he is a member. The meeting will continue today and tomorrow, with proposed amendments to the Federal Constitution featured as topics for discussion at today's meetings.

Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, appealed to the country's retailers last night to "oppose all price-raising and volume-restricting measures of every character" and made a plea for their support of public education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- In an international radio conversation broadcast for delegates to the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War here today, Lady Astor, who has held a Parliament seat longer than any other woman in the world, and Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, who has celebrated her fiftieth anniversary in work for woman suffrage and feminism, compared notes on prospects of war and peace.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Speaking today before the House of Lords, the Archbishop of Canterbury again told of King George's last hours, adding one incident to which he did not refer in his address yesterday before the Convocation of Canterbury.

MINEOLA, L.I, Jan. 23.--The poison murder trial of Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, Baldwin, L.I., housewife, reached a dramatic climax today with the admission by Mrs. Creighton under cross-examination that she had given arsenic to Mrs. Ada Applegate, wife of a former American Legion official.

TRENTON, Jan. 23. -- Dr. William Moulton Marston came here today with his lie-detector and conferred with Governor Harold G. Hoffman, who was impressed by the psychologist's claims for his mechanical contrivance to bring out the truth.

THIS is coming it strong. Much too strong. In sending out general information and vital statistics on the fighters who are due to appear at the heavyweight Garden party this evening, somebody in the office of the dulcet-voiced James J. Johnston listed the proposed opponent of Senor Jorge Brescia, the South American slugger, as "the Boston Strong Boy, Frankie Connelly."

BUFFALO, Jan. 23. -- The National Lutheran Council adjourned today without acting on the four reports of the Committee on Social Trends. Approval of the incomplete documents, it was said, might lead to misrepresentation of their contents. The Rev. Dr. J.A. Aasgaard of Minneapolis, president of the Norwegian Lutheran Synod, explained that the reports were drawn up primarily for consideration by the clergymen.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 23. -- An Ethiopian communique given out at Dessye this morning announced a great battle had opened Monday near Makale and was still progressing.

Developments of the last several days have furnished further indications of the intention of the old-time Republican organizations in the city and State to be firmly in control of the State delegation to the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in June.
LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The biggest gathering of crowned heads seen in London since the World War will attend King George's funeral on Tuesday. There will be five Kings besides Edward.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23. -- After the first budget conference of the City Commission today, Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein announced that salary reductions of all city employes, numbering about 8,000, would be restored July 1.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 23 (AP). -- Seven cosmic ray meters set up in the same room show that every time it rains man gets a radium bath, and that half an hour afterward there is laid down on the earth an imperceptible film of radio-active lead.

Upon her arrival in New York on Wednesday Mrs. Helen Wills Moody vouchsafed the opinion that her game was a little stronger than a year ago. Yesterday the world-famous Californian worked out on the beautiful tennis court at the Court House, 206 East Sixty-fifth Street, and the consensus of those present was that Mrs. Moody was much too conservative in her analysis.

Toscanini stepped on the stage of Carnegie Hall last night to lead the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in his first New York concert of the season. The audience gave him a royal welcome. Impatient of preliminaries, however flattering to him, he was soon at his miracles.

Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, in discussing employer-employe relations yesterday before the personnel group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania, declared "there are few fundamental differences among capital, labor and the consumer, but there are many misunderstandings."

Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title of actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 20, 1934.

A statistical summary made public yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, disclosed that from Aug. 1 to Dec. 31, 1935, the WPA expended more than $93,800,000 on work relief in this city.

Letters were sent yesterday to more than 1,500 alumni of City College by Jacob Holman, president of the class of 1904, urging rejection of the majority report of a special committee of the Associate Alumni of the college which criticized Dr. Frederick B. Robinson's administration as president of the college.

In accepting the presidency of the American Birth Control League, Dr. Clarence Cook Little, the biologist, managing director of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, wrote from Bar Harbor, Me., that "the league faces an immense amount of hard work due to the ill-advised and unsound policies of economic relief employed in this country."

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, whose congregation dates back more than a century, will vacate within a few days its edifice at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street as the first step in its plan to sell the property and build a new church on the upper East Side.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, yesterday resold the five-story apartment house at 190 Claremont Avenue to Alexander Tretiak through Arthur L. Shaw as broker. The building is on a plot 40 by 100 feet, between La Salle Street and Tieman Place and was acquired by the sellers last Monday through Pease Elliman.

Books and magazines, with a gain of 26 per cent over the preceding year, led in the sales gains of department stores here during December, according to the analysis of departmental showings issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. Candy with 20.9 per cent and musical instruments with 20.6 per cent followed.

As measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks, the stock market yesterday not only established a new high mark for the year but also reached the highest level since the Summer of 1931. The index touched a high for the day at 117.01, thus exceeding the previous top for the month, 116.80, established on Jan. 15, as well as the November peak, 116.74.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Despite many outward appearances of a serious breach between the administration and some Senate agricultural leaders over the substitute farm relief program, they were in thorough agreement after a meeting of the Senate agriculture subcommittee today on the course to be pursued in circumventing the Supreme Court's decision on the AAA.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23. -Charles H. Jennings of Miami Beach, the defending titleholder, and George Hartman of Chicago, winner in 1925, advanced to the final in the twenty-eighth annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests as the result of two triumphs at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System were reduced $60,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, through the action of the Treasury in withdrawing some of its deposits from the banks, it was disclosed in the weekly Federal Reserve report, published yesterday.

Reasonable adjustment of trade barriers in all parts of the world would remove the strongest motive which is driving nations to war at the present time, John E. Holt, European manager of International Business Machines Corporation, told members of the Czechoslovakian Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon meeting in the Lobster, Oyster and Chop House yesterday.
MONTREAL, Jan. 23 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks and the Montreal Canadiens battled to a 1-1 tie in a National Hockey League game tonight.

Somewhat indirectly, Joe Cook would seem to be headed for Broadway again. In Providence he opened yesterday in an elaborate vaudeville act, which he will take to Boston next week and later to other cities, the idea being to test out material for a potential Broadway musical in the Spring.

I have seldom come across a more blatant instance of legal sophistry than the piece on the Supreme Court by Professor McBain in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Jan. 19. It would take pages to point out all the perversions of logic in this article. Perhaps one will suffice.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- American housewives bought more canned foods in 1935 than in any other year on record, Carlos Campbell, statistician of the National Canners Association, said today in a speech before the organization's convention here.
In his address last night before the State Bar Association John W. Davis said in part:

" Partisan politics" was charged to the Federal Government yesterday by Elmer Rice at a press showing in the Biltmore Theatre of what was to have been the first production of the WPA theatre program in New York. Mr. Rice resigned Thursday night as Regional Director of the Federal Theatre Project in a dispute over the subject-matter of the play, "The Living Newspaper."

In a survey of registration laws for three professions we have come upon facts that should be very gratifying to those residents of New York who believe that public safety is involved in standards of professional training. Considering all three professions, New York has the highest standards of professional training for physicians, lawyers and engineers of any of the forty-eight States.

Aroused by charges in Congress that 476 men are dead and 1,500 more are dying of silicosis incurred at a West Virginia power project, a meeting was held yesterday at the City Club to organize public support for the relief of the victims of what was termed "America's worst industrial disaster."

NANKING, Jan. 24. -- Japan's future policy toward China, a high official of the Japanese Foreign Office said here, would be one of patience and forbearance while waiting for the present unsettled condition in this country to culminate in forcing Nanking into decisive action.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- While the grain trade talked a great deal today about inflation, there was nothing in the action of the wheat market on the Board of Trade to suggest it had become a material factor in shaping the trend of values. Prices held within a range of 1/2 to 5/8 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- President Roosevelt today vetoed the $2,491,000,000 "baby bond" Bonus Bill. Exactly forty-five minutes after his message had been delivered to the House, the veto had been overridden by a vote of 324 to 61.
MIAMI, Jan. 24. -- Organized labor's proposal to amend the Constitution will not be ready until the next session of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor in April.

ITHACA, Mich., Jan. 24 (AP). -- Sheriff William Nestle arrested George Blank, farmer and Sunday school superintendent, today on a charge of murdering his wife by setting fire to a chair in which she lay unconscious from an anesthetic. The arrest climaxed a three-week investigation of Mrs. Blank's death.

It is apparent from statements by President Roosevelt, Attorney General Cummings and Secretary of Agriculture Wallace that the administration is determined to rid itself of all possible checks provided by the Constitution in order to impose upon the American people a form of government entirely alien to that to which our people are accustomed.

A fire that wrecked the two upper floors of a four-story rooming house at 200 East Forty-ninth Street, at Third Avenue, caused the death yesterday of a middle-aged couple and serious injury to a man who leaped from the roof. Eight of the other thirty-two occupants required treatment for shock and exposure.

While the intense cold and snow which swept across most of the country this week retarded retail distribution, with the exception of some classes of merchandise, the adverse weather did not affect buying at wholesale to any extent, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A supplementary poll conducted by the Literary Digest among its subscribers, made public yesterday, showed approximately the same majority against the New Deal that was shown in its general poll. Out of a total of 229,248 subscribers participating in the poll, 144,270 were recorded against the New Deal and 84,969 for it.

This may be a Winter of discontent to those who hug the fireside, but it is joy for the growing army that seeks each week-end the realms of Winter sports, especially skiing. The business of running "snow trains" for these enthusiasts has developed specialists in our local railroad offices.

The special grand jury selected from a blue-ribbon panel of 100 to continue the investigation of racketeering in New York was sworn in yesterday and charged by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook to enforce the law against the type of criminal who up to now has escaped punishment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP). -- With money provisions for the social security program left in and fund for the controverted potato control act taken out, the deficiency bill today passed the House.
Four of the six buildings offered at auctioneers' stands in Manhattan yesterday were foreclosed by savings banks. All six structures went to the plaintiffs.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24. -- Mixing politics with banking was criticized today by George W. Norris, Governor of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank, in an address to more than 750 bankers attending the Eastern conference of banking service of the American Bankers Association at the Bellevue-Stratford.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Authority to continue collecting present emergency freight rate surcharges calculated to yield about $100,000,000 a year more than the basic rate structure, was requested by Class 1 railroads today in an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The event of the coming week -- indeed, the event of the Winter, perchance -- will be the resumption of activities on Wednesday evening at the French Casino with the premiere of the "Folies de Femmes" revue. (Or might it be "Folies des Femmes," garcon?)

Six pastors have been appointed to serve in Roman Catholic churches in the Brooklyn Diocese and eighteen assistant pastors have been transferred to new churches, the Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Brooklyn Bishop, announced yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 24. -- Italian press dispatches from Asmara, Eritrea, tonight said 8,000 Ethiopians had been killed and 4,000 taken prisoner in a fierce battle on the northern front. Previous dispatches had described the Ethiopian losses as "several thousand."

New York City needs "a cooperative agency" to check the trade exodus which has occurred here during the last few years, according to railroad officials who conferred with representatives of Controller Frank J. Taylor yesterday at a luncheon in the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

Once more a white Alabama jury has brought in a verdict of guilty in the case of the Negro youth HAYWOOD PATTERSON, charged with attacking a white woman. But this time something -- a lingering doubt regarding the evidence, a twinge of conscience, fear of an irrevocable act -- impelled the jury to fix a sentence, not of death, but of imprisonment for seventy-five years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Mississippi's two Senators came to open warfare today. The split may mean a harder contest in this year's primaries for the senior Senator, Pat Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and one of the administration leaders in Congress.

An extraordinary violinistic talent was displayed by Erno Valasek at his recital last night in the Town Hall. The 16-year-old youth, who was born in Hungary and brought to Cleveland at the age of 6, was first heard in New York two years ago and appeared here again last season.

Mr. OLMSTEAD in his address before the Persian Institute tells of 10,000 documents in clay which, with the aid of the Assyrian dictionary, have taken the world behind the scenes of some centuries B.C. Here one comes upon the father of the BELSHAZZAR with whom we became acquainted in our Sunday school days.

After failing to kill himself with a pistol shot, Louis Carroll, 45 years old, said to be a former well-to-do stock broker, walked three blocks to a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday and plunged to his death from a fourth-floor fire escape landing.

William W. Hall, an elder in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street, will be honored at a special service there tomorrow evening in celebration of his fortieth anniversary as a volunteer worker in the church organizations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Representative Curley of New York introduced a bill today to designate the churchyard of St. Ann's Church in the Bronx, New York City, as an honorary national shrine in memorial of founders of the nation buried there, and to erect a $50,000 monument to Gouverneur Morris.

The longest winning streak in the East, perhaps in the entire country, will be put to the acid test tonight when Long Island University brings its twenty-two-game string into Madison Square Garden against St. John's in the sixth of the college basketball double-headers.

Joaquin Nin-Culmell, pianist, a pupil of Manuel de Falla, made his first American appearance yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. Mr. Nin-Culmell, a program note disclosed, is a native of Berlin and is of Cuban-Franco-Danish descent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The Conference on the Cause and Cure of War split today on the question of neutrality legislation. The problem of how this country should cooperate with other nations in collective efforts to maintain peace, and at the same time keep free from international commitments, proved a stumbling block in the adoption of a program for the coming year by the conference, which adjourned its eleventh annual meeting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Jan. 24. -- A Congressional investigation of the Pacific Coast maritime labor situation, asked by the San Francisco unit of the Maritime Federation of the Pacific, would be welcomed by shipowners, Thomas G. Plant, president of the Waterfront Employers Association, announced today. He denied that a lockout was contemplated, as charged.

BERLIN, Jan. 24. -- Bernhard Rust, Minister of Education, has issued an order forbidding public schools to cooperate with religious libraries. Referring to Protestant and Catholic libraries as "confessional" [the Confessional Synods constitute the Protestant opposition to the Nazi-established church], the Minister declares that the ordinary public libraries "serve the whole people," while the confessional libraries serve confessional interests.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24. -Finishing with par on the last three holes, George Hartman of Chicago, won the twenty-eighth annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests today at the Palm Beach Country Club.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The stock markets here were generally firm and cheerful today, the feature being strength in the home rails on the decision of the House of Lords in favor of the Southern in the rating test case. Argentine rails were dull on profit-taking; Canadian Pacific as firm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Senator Borah will formally announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination for President early next month, said Representative Hamilton Fish today. He added that he could speak authoritatively. Mr. Fish is Eastern manager of Senator Borah's campaign, which is being waged actively in many States despite the lack of a formal declaration by the Senator.

Directors of the Radio Corporation of America yesterday received Joseph P. Kennedy's report of his study of the company's capital structure, together with his recommendations as to what should be done, it was announced by David Sarnoff, president of the corporation, after the meeting.
The Class B squash tennis teams of the Columbia University Club and the Harvard Club are still tied for the Metropolitan League leadership in their group.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Sixteen stockholders of the Continental Distillers and Importers Corporation brought suits today in District Supreme Court against the corporation and five of its officers under provisions of the false registration section of the Securities Act to recover the amount of their stock investments.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Jan. 24. -- Battered by high seas, the disabled forty-five-foot auxiliary yawl Nahama was picked up by Coast Guardsmen today as it drifted off Town Bank in Delaware Bay. In the cabin was the frozen body of Charles Carlson, a rigger.

ATHENS, Jan. 24. -- In an openly rebellious declaration defying King George and Premier Constantine Demerdjis which threatened a revolt throughout Greece, Field Marshal George Kondylis, former dictator, today explicitly announced that he would overthrow the government should the voters return Eleutherios Venizelos's Liberal party in Sunday's election.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- The Democrats and the Republicans are to hold rival hearings on Governor Lehman's budget. The hearings will begin on the same day, Feb. 4, and it is possible that competing hearings, even also to the dates, will be held on the Governor's tax program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Following is the text of the Bonus Bill as passed by both houses of Congress:

Joseph Lockman of Textile was the only winner to break a record in the Public Schools Athletic League's annual swimming championships in Columbia University's 75-foot pool last night. Lockman set the new standard in the 75-yard breast-stroke at 0:51.5.

Mayor La Guardia stepped in yesterday in an effort to avert the threatened strike of 105,000 dressmakers, and invited representatives of the union and the manufacturers to a conference at City Hall on Monday morning. The union and the five manufacturers' associations promptly accepted the invitation.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24. -- Mrs. John H. Strongman of New York will give one of the larger parties for the dinner dance at the Surf Club, Miami Beach, tomorrow night for which there will be a colorful "Land of the Midnight Sun" setting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- President Roosevelt today put aside a report originating in New York that the administration contemplated revaluation of the silver dollar with the statement that he had never heard of it and that it was "just another of those things."

The Salvation Army will hold a memorial service for King George V at every center throughout the Eastern territory tomorrow at 8 P.M., Commissioner Alexander M. Damon, commander of the Eastern territory, announced yesterday.

Slowly rising temperatures gave New York temporary relief yesterday from the two-day cold wave. Bitter winds out of the West which swept the city in the early morning hours, however, drove the mercury to one degree above zero and caused one death.

BOSTON, Jan. 24. -- Dmitri Mitropoulos, conductor of the orchestra of the Athens Conservatory, made his first appearance in Boston, and his second in America, as the guest of Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra this afternoon in Symphony Hall.
HONOLULU, Jan. 24. -- Six army fliers were killed tonight when two big bombing planes collided 1,000 feet over Luke Field and plunged to the ground in flames.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 24. - The long fight of Fairfield County lawyers to bar New York lawyers from practice in Connecticut without entrance examinations was ended today when the Fairfield County Bar Association, by a vote of 36 to 12, admitted six New Yorkers to practice in the State.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 24 (AP). -- A coalition of the forces of Huey P. Long with those of Governor Talmadge to fight renomination of President Roosevelt was announced today by the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, national organizer of Share-Our-Wealth Clubs.

Trade agreements have been an important factor in increasing employment in port cities of this State and in other parts of the country, B.C. Budd, chairman of the New York section of the National Committee for Reciprocal Trade, said yesterday in a statement issued following a meeting of the executive board of the State organization.

Sharp price advances were made by several staples in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Silk and cottonseed oil declined. The trading volume was heavy. On the cash markets, gains appeared in raw sugar, rye, tin and rubber, while cotton, corn and silk declined.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24. -- It is a dull day, indeed, for Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago when one of her horses does not win a feature event at the Miami Jockey Club's track. When Nectarine, 4-year-old daughter of Bull Dog, captured top honors in the one-mile Hollywood Purse today it marked the third straight afternoon the canary and blue silks flashed victoriously in a banner attraction at Hialeah Park.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 24. -- Relief from an order of the New York Supreme Court to build a bridge costing $250,000 in Upper New York City was sought today before Judge Carroll C. Hincks in the United States District Court here by the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad.

Memories of the lavish court entertainments of imperial Russia were revived last night at the annual Russian Students' Ball, held in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. Always one of the popular philanthropic entertainments of the Winter in this city, the event last night drew a capacity throng of persons prominent in society, including many dignitaries of the former Russian nobility.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Maximum interest rate regulations of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, affecting about 7,800 insured banks which are not members of the Federal Reserve System, were promulgated today, effective on Feb. 1.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

MINEOLA, L.I., Saturday, Jan. 25. -- Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton and Everett Applegate, both of Baldwin, L.I., were convicted of first-degree murder early this morning. They were found guilty of poisoning Applegate's wife, Ada, last Sept. 27. Sentence of death in the electric chair is mandatory for both.

It is not precisely the kind of weather to make one think of Spring, robins and hurdy-gurdies, but two TIMES readers yesterday did raise their voice in protest against Mayor LA GUARDIA'S ban on organ-grinders.

The final curtains will descend on just two of the local shows after tonight's performances -- "Porgy and Bess" and "Mid-West." The former, leaving the Alvin, goes on tour with what is probably a record for a continuous run of an opera; the latter, departing the Booth, was a briefer matter altogether.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- An increase of 323,000 in December in the number of workers employed in the manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries, reported today by Secretary of Labor Perkins, stimulated administration hopes that the relief appropriation for the fiscal year 1937 can be appreciably reduced.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 24. -- After deliberating less than three hours a Federal court jury late this afternoon found three men guilty of conspiracy in the $200,000 kidnapping of Edward G. Bremer, St. Paul banker.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- A belief that a return to normal temperatures for this season would result in much larger receipts of hogs within a few days resulted in erratic price movements today. Light kinds advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight on buying by shippers and city butchers, but weights over 220 pounds, after being slightly higher early, declined sharply and at the close showed losses of 10 to 25 cents.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Because present Olympic rules forbid leaps of more than 213.36 feet, the German Olympic Committee has been forced to change the big ski jump which will be used next month by international stars.

Few words are needed to tell the truth. Still fewer are required by President ROOSEVELT to repel the suggestion that he might have altered his deep and voiced convictions on demand. Hence he could make his veto message of the bonus yesterday a model of terse directness.
Only twelve hours more, from 10:30 this morning until 10:30 tonight, remain before the most successful National Motor Boat Show in years, if not in history, comes to its close.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 24. -- The battle raging since Monday near Makale is continuing, according to the Ethiopian Government. It was stated today that full details would be given out at its conclusion.
Fiery breaths of dragons rode the chill winds that swept through Chinatown yesterday as more than 5,000 Chinese thronged the narrow streets in a new year celebration that ushered in the year 4640.

The Most Rev. William D. O'Brien, Auxiliary Bishop of Chicago, will sail today for Rome on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia on a special mission to the Pope for Cardinal Mundelein. Others sailing include Princess Civitelli Cesi Torlonia, Professor Attilio Lavagna, Countless Ortensia P. di Mignano, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Spiegal, S.R. Cragg, Dr. Oreste Villa, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Fuller Jr. and Dr. Jose X.B. Rodrigues.

Under the auspices of the Guiditta Guild of the Cenacle of St. Regis an entertainment to be known as a "Shipboard Gala Night" will take place tonight in the Louis XVI Ballroom of the Park Lane to mark the Twenty-fifth anniversary of Mother Ferri's work at the cenacle.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses issued a statement yesterday indirectly accusing the sponsors of the 1939 World's Fair of delay in getting under way. Last month he warned that the preliminary work of preparing the site in the Flushing Meadows must be progressed rapidly and that delay would be "fatal."

A large exhibition of paintings, drawings and prints by the great Spanish artist Francisco Goya (1746-1828) has been installed in Gallery D6 at the Metropolitan Museum, where it will open with a private view on Monday and to the public Tuesday.

After being withheld from publication for several years by order of the British Foreign Office, "Sawdust Caesar," by George Seldes, has been published in England, but only after undergoing censorship imposed by printers. According to Arthur Barker, the London publisher, two printing houses refused to print the book, and the third set up the manuscript only after insisting on a right to censor it.

Harold R. Cronin, 42 years old, president of the defunct Concord Casualty and Surety Company, which for years furnished 80 per cent of the bail bonds for offenders here, including the Dutch Schultz gang, was found guilty of third degree forgery yesterday by a General Sessions jury.

PUTTING on a basketball soiree in these parts without N.Y.U. seems a bit like trying to play Hamlet without including the Melancholy Dane in the cast of characters, but the basket party in the Garden this evening will go on just the same. Probably the other characters will be, as the dramatic critics put it, adequate.

GENEVA, Jan. 24. -- Spain reaffirmed generally her military obligations under Article XVI of the covenant of the League of Nations today but held that preparations to meet the specific case that Great Britain has raised of an Italian attack should be worked out in committees here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Raising of margin requirements applicable to members of national security Exchanges and brokers from a current range of 25 to 45 per cent to 25 to 55 per cent was ordered today by the Federal Reserve Board as an amendment to former regulations, to be effective on Feb. 1.

Under the pressure of widespread rumors of an impending currency move by the Roosevelt administration, and reinforced by alarms stirred up by passage of the Bonus Bill, the dollar fell heavily yesterday in the foreign exchange market.

" Ninety-nine per cent of the intellectuals of Japan are against war," and labor groups there, through demonstrations, express dissatisfaction with the war spirit, Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian labor leader and sponsor in Japan of cooperative buying and selling, said on his arrival here yesterday.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

DECATUR, Ala., Jan. 24. -- Ozie Powell, one of the nine Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case, was shot in the head and critically wounded this afternoon in an apparent attempt to escape, after Judge W.W. Callahan had sentenced Haywood Patterson to seventy-five years' imprisonment and adjourned the rest of the trials indefinitely.
The Council for Moderation, Inc., organized almost a year ago to deal with liquor problems has suspended operations, according to Everett Colby, chairman of its advisory council.

ROE, Jan. 24. -- In a memorandum addressed to all sanctionist powers and to non-sanctionist members of the League of Nations for their information, Italy replied today to the memorandum presented Wednesday by the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, to the Committee of Eighteen at Geneva.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Retail trade in the metropolitan area made fair headway during the week. Reports here yesterday indicated a gain over the corresponding period last year, but the comparison was with rather poor figures then due to the blizzard at that time.
LONDON, Jan. 24. -- King Edward VIII settled down to work today, coping with a vast amount of correspondence and official business that has accumulated since his father's death.

John W. Davis delivered a sweeping attack against the whole New Deal theory and practice of government last night as tending toward the establishment of autocracy in the United States similar to the Fascist and Communist dictatorships in Germany, Italy and Russia.
PORTSMOUTH, England, Jan. 24. -- T.O.M. Sopwith apparently intends to maintain as much secrecy as possible in connection with his prospective new America's Cup challenger, Endeavour II.
New financing scheduled for next week by fifty-nine municipalities amounts to only $9,896,391. This compares with a revised total for this week of $15,619,715.
Feeling they were being a trifle distanced in the general scramble to line up players for the 1936 campaign, the Yankees announced three signers yesterday.

The failure yesterday of negotiations between realty owners and union officials brought to New York City the prospect of three successive strikes on Feb. 1, Feb. 10 and March 1 threatening to tie up elevator, porter, furnace and other building services.

A vital change in the "up and down" clauses used in cotton, gray and brown, goods contracts through elimination of a phrase was made by many gray cloth mills yesterday and threw the market into confusion.

Over the objection of Park Commissioner Moses, the Board of Estimate adopted a policy yesterday of voting individual amounts rather than making a blanket appropriation for the work of covering the New York Central tracks from Seventy-ninth to 129th Street in connection with the West Side improvement.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- This has been the people's own day of homage to the memory of their dead King and it was made to mean more to them than any one had expected because they shared it for fifteen tense, dramatic minutes with their new sovereign and Queen Mary.

Apart from the questions of free speech involved in the withdrawal of "Ethiopia," let us attempt to look at it dispassionately as a play. It was put on yesterday noon at the Biltmore Theatre as a rehearsal before an audience of WPA workers and newspaper men.

Rolling up a commanding margin at the close of the first half, Barnard School conquered Lincoln School, 31 -- 22, yesterday at the winners' gymnasium in one of the outstanding private school basketball games in the metropolitan area.

Extending from the downtown area to Washington Heights, real estate activity was unusually brisk in Manhattan yesterday. Included in the day's transactions were contracts involving dwellings, apartment houses, lofts and factories and an apartment hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- President Roosevelt sent to the House a veto message on the Bonus Bill, penned in his own hand, to which the House responded in the quickest possible time by over-riding the veto, 324 to 61. The Senate is expected to follow the lead of the House when it reconvenes on Monday.

The gates to the churchyard of St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, just off Broadway at Vesey and Fulton Streets, were opened at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon after having been closed for forty-eight hours to show its ownership to the property.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- A potential demand for $65,000,000,000 worth of new housing in the next ten years was pictured tonight by Senator Wagner in an address before the National Public Housing Conference.

Reversing the result of their meeting in the final of this tournament a year ago, as well as the final of the Pennsylvania State championship last week, Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Rye defeated Miss Anne Page of Wayne, Pa., yesterday to win the sixth annual invitation squash racquets tournament of the Junior League.

The Jamaica Water Supply Company, which serves Eastern Queens County and part of the western end of Nassau County, has been ordered by the Public Service Commission to reduce its water rates, effective March 1. The reduction represents a saving of $50,000 annually, of which $19,000 will be saved by domestic consumers and the remainder in hydrant rentals.

Women artists in various parts of the country won prizes at the forty-fifth annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, which was opened with a reception last night at the American Fine Arts Society Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Complete representation by the United States in track and field, backbone of the Olympic Games, as well as in all other major sports, was forecast by Avery Brundage of Chicago yesterday as the president of the American Olympic Committee made ready to sail last night on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen together with one of the final detachments of members of the Winter team.

The marketing of $40,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent bonds of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company swelled the total of new bond financing this week to $93,803,000. This compares with $148,366,000 in new bonds placed on the market last week and with only $8,665,000 in the corresponding period of last year.

The officers and crew of the Ward liner Morro Castle, which burned off Asbury Park on the morning of Sept. 8, 1934, with a loss of 134 lives, did everything within their power to save lives, but the vessel itself was so constructed that their efforts were futile, George Z. Medalie, attorney for defendants accused of criminal negligence, argued yesterday.

Share prices turned irregular yesterday, commodities were easier, Treasury bonds weakened again, and the dollar continued its downward course, with "inflation" remaining the principal topic of the day. Ideas and theories on the general subject of "inflation" were present in great abundance, but if the tenor of such discussion in stock market circles counted for anything, it was notable that the tone was a bit subdued.

The late Robert E. Simon, philanthropist and realty operator, was eulogized yesterday at exercises dedicating the Robert E. Simon Junior High School, formerly known as Junior High School 165, Manhattan, in the school auditorium at 234 West 109th Street.

The depression is a thing of the past, and the country is moving toward its greatest prosperity, the National Retail Dry Goods Association was told by its retiring president, David Ovens, president of J.B. Ivey Co., Charlotte, N.C., at the closing session of its silver jubilee convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

The National Committee on Safety at Sea, which was created by the recent national conference on accident prevention to study conditions on American ships, submitted its program to a group of steamship operators yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the Port Authority Commerce Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

BERLIN, Jan. 24. -- Miss Sonja Henie, who has threatened to retire almost annually for the last four years, again has announced her intention of hanging up her skates as far as active competition is concerned.

J. Howard Shoemaker, holder of the crown on sixteen occasions, and Edward C. Rogers of Glen Cove continued in a first-place tie in the national amateur pocket billiard tournament as a result of matches played at the Strand Academy yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- President Roosevelt today set Monday as the probable time of his sending to the Senate the nominations of most of the members of the new Federal Reserve Board who, on Feb. 1, will supersede the incumbent board and begin operations under a new law involving definite machinery for the control of credits.

La Salle Academy's quintet strengthened its lead in the Manhattan-Richmond division of the C.H.S.A.A. race by turning back St. Ann's Academy, 39 -- 18, at Goddard gymnasium yesterday. The victory was the fourth in a row for La Salle in the tourney.

The Acme Steel Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the final quarter of 1935 a net profit of $438,156 after interest, depreciation. Federal taxes and other charges. The profit is equal to $1.33 a share on 328,108 shares of $25-par capital stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- World War veterans of New York State will share in a "windfall" estimated at $221,373,427.96 if the Soldiers Bonus Bill veto is overridden in the Senate.

The Hon. SOL BLOOM of the Nineteenth New York Congress District and the rest of the universe has entered a new field of activity. As director of the United States George Washington Bicentennial Commission, he made the Father of his Country as famous everywhere as Mr. BLOOM is in Manhattan.
The American debut of Andre Lenglet, 6-foot 3-inch, 208-pound French fighter, was a success as far as results go. But artistically it was a downright failure, viewed from any angle.

ROME, Jan. 24. -- Following is the text of the memorandum sent by Premier Benito Mussolini to sanctionist powers and non-sanctionist members of the League of Nations replying to the five-power military alliance announced at Geneva Wednesday by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary.

For a standard with which to compare the Williamsburg (Ten Eyck) housing project I would refer Frank Maher to the 1932 report of the State Housing Board. On Page 69 is shown the total cost of all the units theretofore completed under State Housing auspices.
A parachute spinnaker, probably the first ever cut for a fifteen-foot boat, made its appearance at the International Snipe Class's dinner at the Hotel Shelton last night.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Cavalcade, the Brookmeade Stable's champion money winner in 1934, apparently proved his shape today, running the mile in a workout at Santa Anita Park in 1:36 2-5.

Mayor La Guardia received yesterday from Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. a copy of their "definitive" plan for unification of rapid transit lines. He failed, however, to get immediate action by the Board of Estimate on his resolution to authorize its submission to the Transit Commission as a basis for public hearings before that body.

Action of a subcommittee of the Senate in agreeing on a bill framed as a substitute for former crop-control legislation, had an unsettling effect on sentiment in foreign cotton circles yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange broke a quarter cent in the early trading.
The text of the new margin requirements announced by the Federal Reserve Board follows:

PARIS, Jan. 24. -- Although there was some irregularity, the Bourse continued today to show the same resistance to the effect of the political crisis as yesterday. Rentes were firm, although they failed to close at the highest figures of the day.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24. -- Blame for the fall of the Baltimore Trust Company, with a loss of more than $29,000,000, was placed today principally on the shoulders of Eugene I Norton and Donald Symington, its first two presidents, by Simon E. Sobeloff, in a report to Judge Eugene O'Dunne in Circuit Court No. 2. "Gross folly" and "profligacy" were his descriptions of some practices.
ATLANTA, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Development of a process for manufacturing a new product closely resembling woolens from rayon waste was disclosed today by the Georgia School of Technology.

While it is impossible to predict what effect the new margin requirements, announced last night by the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, will have on security quotations, the consensus is that it will be dampening. In view of the fact that the regulations do not apply to stocks already purchased on margin, the new regulations should not result in heavy disposal of stocks now.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt"s message as delivered in person to Congress when he vetoed the former Bonus Bill on May 22:

Lea Luboshutz, Russian violinist and instructor at the Curtis School of Music in Philadelphia, gave her only recital of the season in Carnegie Hall last night before a large audience which tendered her generous tribute for a distinguished program.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 24. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman wants to determine whether public clamor for a victim in the Lindbergh case caused any part of the evidence against Bruno Richard Hauptmann to be framed.

In a suit involving the State Insurance Law, Supreme Court Justice Levy ruled yesterday that a widow may be compelled to pay her debts from her husband's life insurance. The court directed the Dry Dock Savings Bank to pay the State Banking Department an assessment of $1,382 levied against Mrs. Ada May's share of Bank of United States stock.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody worked out again at the Court House yesterday and a gallery that taxed the seating capacity of the club on East Sixty-first Street turned out to see the holder of the British tennis championship unleash her famed forehand drive against Vincent Richards.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Fingerprinting of every resident of the State over 18 years of age is proposed in a bill introduced today by Senator Coughlin, Brooklyn Democrat. The measure would compel all persons who have reached that age to register their fingerprints in their local county clerk's office and pay a filing fee of 50 cents.

GENEVA, Jan. 24. -- The League of Nations Council session adjourned tonight after getting the Danzig Nazi Government to give in on every issue, after deciding to leave the Soviet-Uruguayan dispute to public opinion and after making provisional refugee arrangements on the lines that experts recently recommended.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- After several days of negotiations and compromises by agricultural spokesmen in the executive and legislative branches of the government, the administration-sponsored Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Bill, with further slight refinements agreed on today, will be laid formally before the House and Senate Committees on Agriculture tomorrow as a substitute for the AAA, under circumstances favorable to early enactment.
WASHINGTON Jan. 24. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to the House vetoing the new Bonus Bill [shown in facsimile above]:

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Frederick H. Prince of Boston, chairman of the board of Armour Co., will sail for England soon to complete a financing operation with British interests which will permit the retirement of the $57,782,600 of outstanding 7 per cent preferred stock of Armour Co. of Delaware.

BERLIN, Jan. 24. -- The ]Eoese was quiet but exceptionally :ir'zn: today, after yesterday's weakness, i Electricals advanced markedly, Schuckert gaining 3 points and Siemens Halske 3 on reports of coming dividends of about 8 per i cent.

The four-story building containing stores and apartments at 1,285 Madison Avenue, between Ninety-first and Ninety-second Streets, has been purchased by an investor from the Euripedes Realty Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The house is on a plot 20 by 62 feet and was sold for cash over a $30,000 mortgage held by the Franklin Savings Bank.

Sounding the keynote of a national campaign for relief of oppressed and impoverished Jews of Poland, Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, called upon American Jews and Christians yesterday to support the $1,000,000 rehabilitation fund being raised by the Federation of Polish Jews in America.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 24. -- Sven Utterstrom, Swedish star who won the 18-kilometer ski race at the 1932 Olympics, will arrive here tomorrow to train the United States cross-country skiers.

PARIS, Jan. 24. -- Albert Sarraut succeeded within forty-eight hours after Premier Pierre Laval's resignation in setting up a Cabinet which seems solidly constructed and with a sufficient majority to carry it until the elections.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- While thousands paid their last respects to King George in Westminster Hall today, London began transforming itself into a city of mourning for the somber funeral pageant which will pass through the streets Tuesday.

The Board of Standards and Appeals, which has just submitted its annual report to the Mayor, is one of those comparatively obscure agencies of municipal government whose function, like that of the half-hidden ductless glands in the human body, is to control growth.

While the Prout Memorial K. of C. meet at Boston holds the spotlight tonight, metropolitan track enthusiasts received welcome news with the announcement yesterday that Edward T. O'Brien of Syracuse, premier quarter-miler of the nation, has filed his entry for the twenty-ninth annual Millrose A.A. games at Madison Square Garden next Saturday night.

VIENNA, Jan. 25 (AP). -- A proposal for an association of Middle European States with the thinly concealed purpose of forestalling the spread of German influence southward gained ground in Austria and Czechoslovakia this week.
Robert Gordon Anderson, author and newspaper man, will make the baccalaureate address in Carnegie Hall at Hunter College Wednesday morning at 10:30 o'clock.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 25 Governor Harold G. Hoffman told Republican State leaders with whom he conferred today that he would welcome a legislative inquiry into his conduct in the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann.

Mr. Roosevelt is a great one for the unusual. He set a precedent for out-of-ordinary behavior when he flew to Chicago in 1932 to address the Democratic National Convention that had nominated him for the Presidency. He has followed it many times since; for example, there was his personal appearance before Congress May 22, 1935, to read his veto of the Bonus Bill.

TRENTON, Jan. 24. -- New Jersey will refuse to place itself in conformity with all provisions of the Federal Social Security Act, sometimes viewed as the keystone of the New Deal, if the State follows the recommendations of its Republican Governor, Harold G. Hoffman.

The announcement from England last week that the British Navy is no longer opposed to the big ship, heavily gunned, again focuses attention on the naval race which is slowly gathering momentum, while the London naval conference -- floundering since the withdrawal of Japan -- tries to find some way of checking it.

BOSTON, Jan. 25. -- Virtually pushed into the tape by Joe Mangan of the New York A.C., Glenn Cunningham raced to victory in the K. of C. mile for the Governor Curley Trophy tonight. Some 10,000 excited spectators changed the Boston Garden into something resembling a madhouse as the pair stormed across the line in as thrilling a mile race finish as has ever been witnessed here.

Endowed secondary schools and colleges throughout the country will be forced to close if taxes on their property are increased by the national and State administrations, Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University, declared last night.

Stanley Reed, Solicitor General of the United States, expressed the hope in an address before the New York State Bar Association yesterday that existing Federal powers under the Constitution would be sufficient to solve the new social and economic problems of the country without the necessity of constitutional amendments.

MUSIC by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms will comprise the program to be given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Thursday evening. Arturo Toscanini will conduct, and Robert Casadesus, the French pianist, will be soloist in the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25. -- Grog, a Wheatley Stable cast-off now racing for J.U. Gratton of Canada, befuddled the Florida Derby calculations still more today when he turned in an unexpected victory over ten other 3-year-olds in the $3,500 Hialeah Stakes at Hialeah Park.

A proposal to oust the management of the Fourth National Investors Corporation was made public yesterday by Thomas E. Brittingham Jr., a trustee and vice president of the Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation; William Ferguson, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Moors Cabot, and Sanford Griffith, a partner in Thomas Griffith, another Stock Exchange firm.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies is entitled to bequests of more than $500,000 to date from the estate of William B. Kaufman, financier, according to a decision announced yesterday by Surrogate James A. Delehanty in an accounting proceeding brought by heirs to determine their shares in the estate.

SOMEWHAT camouflaged by its alliterative title, here is the story of that young giant, the chemical industry, which is growing so like Jack's bean-stalk that it behooves every one who wants to keep on speaking terms with the times he lives in to be informed on its history and its developments.

BOOKS concerned with the so-called Modern Movement (which we conveniently speak of as beginning with Cezanne) have been legion. But of course this movement is fluid, still going through startling and significant change, almost from day to day.

MRS. PERKINS, who continues to add to her long list of Twin books without losing the freshness and naturalness that have characterized her writing from the beginning, has now written for 9 and 10 year olds a story of a brother and sister who lived in a remote village of China.

To raise funds for the community service supplied by the Neighborhood Guilds in furnishing clothing to needy families in the East Side district of the city from Fifty-second to Eighty-sixth Street, a dinner dance will be given on Feb. 6 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador under the auspices of a committee headed by Mrs. George G. Walker.

A CROWDED bill is promised this week in the two sales provided by New York auction houses. Two sessions at the Rains Galleries, on the 27th and 28th, will witness the dispersal of books and autographs, including selections from the library of Mortimer G. Merritt.

It has been shown many times in our political history that a national candidate for office has little to fear from "group" opposition. Scattered over many States it has little effect on a Presidential election. This was true even of "the Irish vote," which was so long a terror to timid American politicians, or the "labor vote."

If it is conceded that mechanical advantages and material gains axe as nothing compared with the spiritual, the character and personality forming qualities in life, then all the apparent and real advantages of calendar reform must be disregarded if acquired at their expense.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 24. -- Something of a furor has risen in North Carolina over the strong anti-Roosevelt views accredited to C.L. Shuping, Greensboro lawyer and member of the Democratic National Committee. The opinion has been expressed by many Democrats that he should resign as committeeman.

THIS novel was the winner in a contest sponsored by The New Masses and the John Day Company, in which the award was to be made for the best novel on an American proletarian theme. More often than not literary prize awards are a disappointment, and "Marching! Marching!" follows the rule.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Few events other than national conventions staged by the two major parties have aroused keener political interest -- and concern -- than the American Liberty League dinner here tonight which Alfred E. Smith will address.

The light had failed outside the ninth-floor window, so William Henry Jackson began to "clean up." He corked the India ink, rearranged a series of brushes, flecked dust from the worn, blue sleeve of a wide lapeled work jacket. On the slightly tilted pine drawing board lay a black-and-white picture.
