LIMA, Jan. 25.--It is reported from Pimentel, where the steamship Cautin, insured by Lloyd's for 175,000 and belonging to the Compania Sud America de Vapores, went aground Jan. 14, that she is a total loss.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24. -- Less than a month ago the Sinclair EPIC Democrats of California were announcing in loud tones that their endorsement of the Roosevelt candidacy would be contingent upon a production-for-use plank in the Democratic platform.
The Chinese Government may propose, but even in China the people sometimes dispose. China may still find itself resisting Japanese aggression almost in spite of itself.

THE naval conference brings the once familiar name of Beatty back into the news. Only a few weeks ago London saw him walking in the funeral procession which conveyed Lord Jellicoe to his last resting place in the crypt of St. Paul's Cathedral, not far from Nelson's tomb.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 25. -- A series of lectures by representatives of prominent industrial firms and by members of the faculty of Rutgers University constituting a "placement seminar" will be offered seniors this year, Edward H. Heyd, director of the Bureau of Personnel and Placement at the university, announced today.
THE weekly London cable rushes forward darkly to submit the following as the current theatrical news over there:

A DEMONSTRATION of what drinking means in the driving of an automobile was staged at the sessions of the Street and Highway Traffic Section of the Safety Congress recently held in Louisville, Ky. It was reported in Public Safety, National Safety Council publication, as follows:

Floyd Y. Keeler, new president of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., said yesterday that the public's purchases of finished goods has so depleted raw materials in factories and plants that manufacturers must replenish supplies, and that this should mean increasing activity in the commodity markets.

A tribute to Arturo Toscanini, the conductor, as the "foremost living interpreter of the great masters," was broadcast yesterday afternoon by Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association. Mr. Cravath's address was delivered over WJZ and WEAF, NBC networks, from the Metropolitan Opera House during an intermission of Verdi's "Aida," the Metropolitan's fourth presentation of this opera for the season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- A mixed movement in current business is indicated in the weekly summary of the Department of Commerce, made public today. Although a seasonal improvement has occurred in numerous industries, aggregate industrial output so far this month has apparently not recorded the expansion usually experienced at this period of the year.

EVERYWHERE we go, everywhere we turn, we hear suits, suits, suits. Suits for the morning, suits for the afternoon, suits for the evening -- the morning ones tailored to a T; the afternoon ones fitted yet feminine; the evening ones trim as a tuxedo.

The Association for the Aid of Crippled Children has taken over a pre-opening performance of the play "Fresh Fields," by Ivor Novello, on the night of Feb. 6 at the Empire Theatre to raise funds for the organization's welfare work among young cripples.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- An appeal to German housewives to use less fat and thereby to free foreign exchange for the purchase of raw materials needed for armament was voiced today by Agriculture Minister Richard Walter Darre at the opening of "Green Week," the national agricultural exhibit in Berlin.

S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, authorized yesterday the following statement relative to a speech made on Thursday in the United States Senate by Senator Schwellenbach of Washington and reported in newspapers on Friday, in which the Senator named the Bankers Trust Company and John J. Raskob:

THE aim of the four-volume series of which this is the first installment is "to give a clearer understanding of the fundamentals upon which the law of neutral rights and duties has been based and of the factors -- largely economic -- which have conditioned its development."

The Cunard White Star Line is scheduled to withdraw from the North Atlantic Passenger Conference on Wednesday at the expiration of the six weeks' notice given to the conference by the steamship line. The hope was expressed by experienced steamship men in the North Atlantic passenger business that a rate war would not result.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Earl February will see the first of the series of really serious golf tournaments -- a series which lasts until the middle of April and reaches a climax in the thirty-sixth annual North and South invitation amateur championship.

INTO this noble and very beautiful two-volume George Shiras 3d, internationally known for his lifetime of enthusiastic study of wild life and work for its conservation, has gathered some of the most important things he has done with pen and camera toward that end.

Major B.H. Namm, head of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, in a statement issued yesterday, declared it "unfair to imply that the entire lag in retail trade in this city has been due to the imposition of the 2 per cent sales tax." Other factors, he said, have played an important role, although he held the sales levy partly responsible for the unfavorable showing.

J. Ricard Leonard and Malcolm Kirkbride, national champions, went down to defeat yesterday as New York beat Philadelphia, 4 to 3, in the annual intercity racquets doubles matches at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

OUT of profound depths of cynicism deriving from a keen understanding of human nature, Johan Bojer, already well known through English translations of his novels, presents an intensely dramatic conflict in "Day and Night," and so timely, so universal is the theme that this novel ought to capture attention from thoughtful readers in whatever country it may be introduced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Justices of the Supreme Court have agreed in 95 per cent of their voting and in 84 per cent of the cases they have decided this term. This was shown today in a tabulation of ninety-nine decisions announced since the court went into session last October.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Three days of subzero weather played havoc with retail activities and cut store sales sharply below those of the like 1935 period. Wholesale dry goods houses reported good road orders, but the number of out-of-town buyers in the local field was subnormal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- An atmosphere of pessimism marked the round-table discussions of the National Public Housing conference here today when a dark outlook was forecast for the immediate future of the housing movement.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 25. -- With ceremonies attended by many church dignitaries and several hundred laymen, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Russell Ludlow, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, South Orange, was consecrated as Suffragan Bishop of the Newark Diocese of the Episcopal Church here today.
The spirited advance in sugar continued yesterday as the feature of trading in the commodity futures markets here. In the cash markets all the grains, cotton, rubber and wool tops moved up.

The first of the major indoor track meets of this Olympic year will take place in Madison Square Garden on Saturday, when the Millrose A.A. stages its twenty-ninth games with all the panoply and showmanship that this affair annually unfolds.

Proposals introduced in Congress for revision of American neutrality legislation represent "vicious, cowardly and un-American" policies, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo declared yesterday in making public a fifty-six-page brief on neutrality legislation sent by him to every member of Congress.

Nine of the less familiar French folk tales are translated in this book. The versions are undistinguished and the stories as they are given here lack the liveliness of those in such collections as "Picture Tales From the French," by Simone Chamoud, and other volumes in the same series.
AGUSTA, Ga. -- Social interest of both Augustans and Winter visitors here this week centers on three Roosevelt birthday bars to be held Thursday night.

The first arrests resulting from the struggle of householders in Sunnyside Gardens, Queens, against surrendering their homes in foreclosure proceedings were recorded yesterday when three men and three women were booked at Hunters Point police station on charges of disorderly conduct.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- New York artists won the lion's share of prizes in painting and sculpture awarded in connection with the opening of the 131st annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. A private view was given tonight, and the show will be open to the public from tomorrow until March 1, inclusive.

Their associates in the National Federation of Business and Professional Women will pay tribute Thursday night to Miss Emily Kneubuhl, formerly executive secretary of the federation, and to her successor, Miss Louise Bache, at a dinner at the A.W.A. clubhouse.

Dr. Charles Francis Horne, Senior Professor of English at City College, has been appointed head of the English Department by the Board of Higher Education, it was announced yesterday by President Frederick B. Robinson. Dr. Horne succeeds the late Professor Harry C. Krowl, who died Dec. 1 of last year.

We first meet Penny Adams struggling along a gray cement road, an ungainly puppy with a bandaged leg hanging over one arm, in the other a bundle tied up in cotton cloth printed with faded roses. For Penny, "13, going on 14," was running away from the orphan asylum.

HOLLYWOOD. PROTESTING their love for, and devotion to, studios and producers, the while circulating among the prospective membership one of the most rigid and stern plans of action yet to confront the industry, the Screen Directors Guild held its first organization meeting last Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Senator McAdoo called upon California Democrats today to "repudiate those warring chieftains who are dominated by selfish ambitions, and who would rule or ruin the party."

SOMEWHAT infrequent the occasions on which decorators have a chance to show their work to the public. The rooms in private houses which they decorate are not available for public inspection, and photographs of them suggest little of' the color and texture of the furnishings.

SPECIAL General Motors exhibits of cars and other products will be held in forty-five cities between Feb. 1 and May 2, it is announced by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president. The dates have been advanced from previous years because of the earlier holding of the national automobile shows

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25. -- With organization campaigns in the mass production industries being discussed by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, but no decision to be made until next week, it appeared today that the United Automobile Workers International Union would probably be permitted to hold a convention soon to elect officers and terminate the provisional government set up for it by the federation.

Civil War veterans of the North and of the South will be honored at the Blue and Gray Ball to be held on Friday night at the Commodore. The 110th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York will be featured by a midnight military parade and other ceremonies traditional to the function since the first ball was held in 1826.

WHEN King Edward VIII of England goes on the air his voice will not be strange to the American radio audience. As the Prince of Wales he has been heard no less than eleven times on the networks since 1930, according to the statistics of the National Broadcasting Company.

Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, praised last night the speed with which various groups within the medical profession are getting under way the general program for the examination and certification of all medical specialists.

IN the death of King George V the philatelic world has lost not only one of its most ardent stamp collectors but also a recognized student of the various factors "behind" the stamp, such as the occasion of its issue, the reason for the design, the artist, engraver of the dies and other information included in the realm of philately.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 25. -- The Symmes Gate in memory of the three Williams seniors and a professor who were lost in the Mohawk disaster off the coast of New Jersey while on a field trip to Yucatan just a year ago was dedicated at noon today with a brief, simple ceremony.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Two field goals by William (Tippy) Dye in the closing minute gave Ohio State University a sensational victory over Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 41 to 37, before 4,500 spectators.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- The Geneva compromise regarding Danzig, which avoids any drastic action and, as seen here, permits the National Socialist regime to continue its "coordination" of the Danzigers without serious hindrance, is accepted in German quarters with quiet satisfaction that mere moral condemnation of Nazi practices in the Free City cannot dampen.

WHILE it is a bit early for starting most seeds indoors or in a frame -- to grow plants for setting out in the open later -- it is none too early to get everything ready for the task. Where supplies of one sort or another are needed, gardeners are ordering them now, that they may be adequately prepared for the day when seeds are planted.

Bizet's "Carmen" had its fourth performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with Rosa Ponselle appearing for the third time in the title role. This special presentation was staged as a benefit for the French Hospital of New York.

NASSAU, B.W.I. -- A wide program of social activities is being arranged here for participants in the third annual Miami-to-Nassau international race for sailing yachts, which starts from Miami on Feb. 11, under the joint sponsorship of the Miami and the Nassau Yacht Clubs.

Winter sports devotees will have an opportunity to test their ability, at skiing, ski-jumping, ice-skating and bobsledding and at the same time to subscribe to a noteworthy charity on Feb. 12 at a Winter sports party now being arranged for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery.

Allen Hardgrove, Detroit cue star, provided a major upset by defeating the defending champion, J. Howard Shoemaker, last night in the national amateur pocket billiard tournament at the Strand Academy. Making a brilliant comeback in the late sessions, Hardgrove won by 125 -- 118 in thirty-seven innings.

VANCOUVER, B.C. A FINE tract of giant Douglas fir, towering up to 250 and 300 feet, is falling under the lumberman's axe on Vancouver Island because an ardent conservationist who planned to make this strip of forest a preserve for posterity failed to make his will.

WHO should it turn out to be but Lee Shubert who has a financial interest in the Theatre Guild-Lee Ephraim production, "Call It a Day"? To latter-day observers this may mean nothing one way or the other.

WINSLOWHOMER is quoted as venturing upon this item of prophecy: "You will see, in the future I shall live by my water-colors." Artists, like all the rest of us, are not infallible prophets, and it has become, whether with justice or otherwise, axiomatic that as a general thing an artist's critical evaluation of his own work is not to be considered sacrosanct.

OUR youngest and most vigorous agency of the national defense is the army's General Headquarters Air Force. I say youngest because as an organized unit the Air Force will not be a year old until March 1 of this year.

Homeless waifs who are cared for until suitable foster parents are found for them by the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery will be aided by the Silver Bassinet Ball on Friday night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. During the evening there will be divertissements by professional entertainers.

THAT first glimpse of Dr. Shih I. Hsiung, standing upon the naked stage under the white glare of a 1,000-watt work lamp, did not immediately endow him in the visitor's eyes with the stature of an irresistible force. He was a very small man with a thin, alabaster face, which was, at the moment, puckered into a contemplative frown, and his slight body was clothed in a straight and simple Chinese robe.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- Rallying behind the spirited play of Larry Kelley, Yale, won its second Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight with a 39-to-27 victory over Cornell.

ROME, Jan. 25. -- The results of heavy fighting occurring the first half of this week in the Tembien region of Northern Ethiopia are given in a rather unsatisfactory official war bulletin today which leaves the greatest confusion in the mind of the reader as to exactly what happened.

TWENTY-SIX years ago -- on Feb. 8, 1910 -- the Boy Scouts organization was officially founded in this country. Each season when the anniversary rolls around there is a special celebration; this year the stress will be on the movement's early history, its pioneer Troops, and the theme "Carrying On the Traditions of Scouting."

Dr. Ralph Modjeski, one of the best-known engineers in the country, will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday tomorrow and in observance of that anniversary his friends and associates here are sending him a handsomely bound volume containing more than 2,000 congratulatory letters.

The dollar declined further on the foreign exchange market yesterday, but the pace of its fall was much slower than on previous days. The pound sterling rose to $5.01 and closed at $5.00 1/2, up 1/4 cent, and the franc gained 1 1/4 points to 6.67, 3/4 cents.

WITH traffic jams costing 25,000,000 yearly in London alone through the immobilization of material, it has been decided to spend 100,000,000 in five years on the reconstruction of Britain's roads. Apart from new and harder surfaces, many of them are in much the same condition as they were left by their Roman builders.

With the peak of buyers' arrivals for the early part of the Spring season reached last week, purchasing activity in women's apparel, accessories and home furnishings maintained a fast pace, according to a survey of the wholesale markets here. An exception was cotton goods, which, due to the processing tax situation, did not share in the activity.

A scramble to reverse straddles between near and distant deliveries developed yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and upset differences, and final quotations showed net gains of 4 to 23 points in the heaviest volume of business in some time. While positions recently selling at abnormal discounts were moving rapidly into new high ground, the March contract virtually stood still.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- Underlying all the homage to the memory of King George and the acclaim for Edward VIII in which the British Empire has been steeped since last Monday night there has been a note of anxiety, at least here in England, concerning the course the new sovereign will pursue.

About 300 members of the Women's Civic Organization celebrated the tenth anniversary of their association yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore. Miss Ella T. Sullivan, president, was the toastmaster and she received almost as many congratulations on her leadership as the organization did on its anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP). -- The International Seamen's Union joined Harry Bridges, San Francisco waterfront labor leader, tonight in a request for a Federal investigation of the maritime labor situation.

The markets last week were very definitely under the spell of inflation psychology. What with Congress in a spending mood and the Treasury's large holdings of gold and silver offering temptation for currency manipulation, stocks rose, commodities edged higher, government bonds declined, and the dollar dropped sharply.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Delighting a huge crowd on its London ground, Tottenham Hotspur, second division soccer team, eliminated Huddersfield Town, 1 -- 0, from the English Cup competition. The match was the highlight of fourth-round games, of which three were postponed on account of fog and one abandoned after seventy-five minutes' play.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Chairman McReynolds of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said he learned at the White House today that President Roosevelt was eager for Congressional approval of a permanent neutrality law before expiration of the present temporary act Feb. 29.

TOP HATS, white ties, tails; ermine and velvets; limousines and taxies plying their way through the East Fifties and Sixties and westward, too, especially in Fifty-second Street; people in less festive raiment, on foot, in buses, in street cars and their own modest vehicles.

Robert Francis Weatherbee is an awful example! He would Not go to school, with the result that not only could he never grow up to be President of the United States but he found himself beset with all kinds of difficulties in his daily life.
Alfred E. Smith was first nominated as the Democratic candidate for President at San Francisco in 1920. Franklin D. Roosevelt seconded the nomination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- A flood of telegrams which poured into the Senate Office Building urging that the recipients vote to sustain the President's veto today confused Senate and administration leaders who are expected, in view of recent utterances, to vote Monday to override President Roosevelt's veto of the $2,491,000,000 "baby bond" Soldier Bonus Bill.

IN the Gulf of Aden recently a giant swordfish rammed an Arabian dhow and sent it, with its cargo, to the bottom. Fortunately, the fifteen men aboard were all saved. Although rarely seen, the monster fish -- often fifteen feet long and 300 pounds in weight -- is known and feared by the seamen of these waters.

By encouraging more semi-annual health examinations and by sponsoring a program of lectures on anatomy, physiology, pathology and hygiene, the Union Health Center of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union purposes to intensify its efforts to promote better health.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Heart Break, a 6-year-old mare which has been clicking with regularity for Mrs. H. Torriente, hung up her fifth victory in six starts today in accounting for the six-furlong Jefferson Park Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The President is now serving the last year of the term to which he was elected. It began on Jan. 20, though he bad been in office about six weeks less than three years on that date. This is because of the Norris Amendment which provides that his successor, and all following Presidents, shall begin their terms on Jan. 20 of the year following their elections.

WHEN Hollywood needs a beard or two for a motion picture, it has only to go to the beaver colony and holler. There is a group of men out there whose whiskers are their bread and butter, to mix a metaphor or so. They manage to keep in food and raiment because of those beards.

MRS. HENRY BRECKENRIDGE was quoted the other day as remarking, apropos of the new Municipal Galleries at 62 West Fifty-third Street, that "it is entirely up to the artists" to make this venture a success.

ISLANDS have aroused the poetic imaginations of men and appealed to their romantic instincts ever since Ulysses wandered among them on his devious and Circe-strewn way. They have been the homes of one-eyed giants, of fallen angels and Kingsley's water babies, of lost peoples like the Atlanteans, and the queer vanished folk of Christmas Island. Across the Pacific many races used them for stepping stones, and left traces over which archaeologists have puzzled.

ONE of the most regrettable elements which can be associated with an airplane accident is mystery. Where a clear cause can be ascertained, as has been the case in several crashes during the past year, airline operators can address themselves to its correction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The administration moved on several fronts last week to repair the damage done to its program by the Supreme Court decisions wrecking the Agricultural Adjustment Act. It agreed with Congressional leaders on a system of Federal-State cooperation to achieve the farm relief which the court had declared was beyond the unaided power of the Federal Government.

Hunger and her luck in meeting good Samaritans led yesterday to the finding of chubby Marjorie Richards, 13-year-old daughter of District Attorney Karl E. Richards of Harrisburg, Pa., for whom Federal agents and Pennsylvania State police had made an intensive search since her disappearance from home last Tuesday night.

WITH the op era season reaching a midway point at the end of this weeks, the thoughts of certain members of the company are turning to plans for the annual "surprise party." The date this year will probably be March 22, the last Sunday night of the season.

PAINTINGS by a group of young American artists currently at the Montross Gallery (till Feb. 1) are distinguished primarily by a great diversity of methods and approach. Revington Arthur's peculiarly titled "Mormon Lady" shows gathering powers and rich color.

AN attractive book of sixty-two pages, called "Judging the Amateur Flower Show," has been issued by the National Council of State Garden Clubs. This practical manual is just what the harassed members of hundreds of local flower show committees have long needed as a source of authoritative answers to the many questions arising in connection with planning, staging and judging flower shows, for its contents cover much more than the subject of judging alone.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- The New Rochelle High School hockey team defeated Greenwich High School in a Westchester Interscholastic League game at the Playland Ice Casino tonight, 5 to 1.

WASHINGTON. -- Government committees report a marked increase in volume and sales of useless public documents -- an increase attributed to the "taking of pen in hand" by depression letter writers to the government and to the multiplicity of surveys by government bureaus.

SULLEN and shuttered since "The Drunkard" staggered down its steps after a forty-week carouse a year back, the American Music Hall, once a stained-glass haven for the faithful in East Fifty-fifth Street, will endure a lethal renaissance Saturday night, when there will erupt within its walls as ruby a play as ever iced the spine of a taxpayer.

THOSE who read "Blood of the Conquerors," fifteen years ago; "Footloose McGarnigal," six years ago, or "Rio Grande," going on three years ago, might not expect their author to set up shop as a philosopher, but he has done so, and the result is a singularly satisfying performance.

We have with us today none other than Aurelius Smith, than whom no man is more completely master of himself and of any situation that may confront him. Smith is a private detective whose staff consists of a Hindu cook and handy man named Langa Doonh, a secretary named Bernice and a boy named Jimmie.

Squadron A and Blind Brook were the victorious polo teams in the Metropolitan League matches at Squadron A Armory last night. The cavalrymen defeated a reorganized First Division side, 15 1/2 to 10 1/2, and Blind Brook downed Governors Island, 8 1/2 to 5.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- More and more as the days pass since the fifth George to reign over Britain closed his eyes forever and Edward VIII reigned in his stead has it become manifest how much a change in the throne that links the British Commonwealth of Nations means to the world at large, as well as the empire and the nation itself.

Utah was seen as "easily safe" for the New Deal by United States Senator William H. King and other speakers at a national Utah dinner and reception given last night at the Hotel McAlpin by the Utah Club of New York in honor of members of President Roosevelt's official family who are natives of the State.

With the aid of a grant from the Carnegie Foundation a distinguished committee of the American Neurological Association has made a scientifically objective study of sterilization and its social effects with particular reference to mental diseases and feeble-mindedness.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25. -- With strikes and rumors of more strikes, San Francisco shipping interests had a bad case of "jitters" as the week ended. The coastwise lumber fleet, which has been practically inoperative for a month, is likely to remain that way for some time to come, observers say.
AMES, Iowa, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Iowa land economists today viewed the sharp increase in farm tenancy over a wide area of the Corn Belt as a serious barrier to the progress of a long-time farm program.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- In a day-long drizzle of rain that never reached a downpour and under a cold gray mist that veiled Parliament Tower and almost hid the face of its big clock, a long queue of plain people of Great Britain again moved through Westminster Hall today to bid farewell to their dead King.

LONDON, Jan. 3. THIS is the moment in the year during which the theatre pauses for breath. There is still a week before Noel Coward's first night. Meanwhile we may consider what has happened in the theatre during the past year and what indications there are of the future.

IN The American Magazine of Art Gertrude R. Benson emphasizes the sound and carefully planned side of Van Gogh's art as opposed to the too widespread conception of the artist as a madman. And her conclusion is well worth pondering:
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 25. -- Ethiopia claimed victory in "the biggest battle of the war" today and said Makale, the advance point of the Italian Northern front, was surrounded.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 25. -- The Montclair Athletic Club and the Englewood Field Club completed the regular schedule of the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Class C Squash Racquets League today in a tie for first place.

When Nikita Magaloff, Russian pianist, appeared recently at Carnegie Hall as accompanist for Josef Szigeti, the violin virtuoso, his playing aroused such favorable comment that as a result he came forward yesterday afternoon to make his New York debut as recitalist at the Town Hall.

TO the accompaniment of the heaviest trading for a Saturday since Nov. 23, the share market shook off yesterday the restraining hand of the Federal Reserve Board just as it did in 1929 when the board endeavored to halt the sharp rise in Security prices by forcing money rates higher.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25. -- Emphasis on intelligent participation in the social order is the aim of the revised curriculum at Pennsylvania College of Women, effective next Fall. The new curriculum, planned by the faculty and approved by the board of trustees, divides the college program into two parts.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Richard Gimbel of this city, who was displaced last year as an officer of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., but remained on the board of directors, made public today a letter dated Jan. 21 which he is mailing to preferred stockholders of the corporation.

Philip Barber, who had served as assistant to Elmer Rice prior to the latter's resignation on Thursday as Regional Director of the Federal Theatre Project in New York City, was appointed yesterday to succeed Mr. Rice, for the present, at least. The appointment was made here by Jacob Baker, Assistant WPA Administrator, with the approval of Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, National Director of the Theatre Project.
ANDOVER, Mass., Jan. 25. -- Breaking a world's interscholastic, three school and two pool records, the Andover swimming team routed the Gardner High natators, 48 -- 17, today.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- With both the leading parties opposed to the holding of a constitutional convention in 1938, the question of whether one shall be held is now before the Legislature. A bill submitting the question for a vote at the general election this year has already passed the Assembly and should come up in the Senate for concurrence this week.

IN the three decades between 1890 and 1920 Henry van Dyke was eminently known both nationally and internationally. Few men of his time achieved prominence in so many different fields. As pastor of Brick Church, the Presbyterian house of worship at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, Henry van Dyke was hailed, both within his own denomination and without, as a profound theologian and an illustrious preacher.

INTENDED for general reading and interestingly presented, this book gives a full, well rounded and scientifically accurate and dependable account of its subject. Dr. Harris, an Englishman who has long been an experimental student in vitamin theory, is director of the Nutritional Laboratory of the University of Cambridge and a member of the Medical Research Council.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- Germany's great pre-war armament firm of Krupp at Essen, which remains one of the largest industrial concerns in the world, closed its business year with a very optimistic annual report for the period ended Oct. 1.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 25.--Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, who was convicted early this morning with Everett C. Applegate of first degree murder for the arsenic poisoning of Applegate's wife, was visited today by her husband for the first time since her imprisonment in October. He said he would stand by her.

By the largest score recorded thus far this season at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn, the Fort Hamilton team trounced the Boulder Brook trio of Westchester, 22 to 6 1/2, in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League contest last night.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 25 (AP). -- Governor Alf M. Landon is expected to outline his views on national issues Wednesday night for the first time since mention of his name as a Presidential possibility.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- Students of Vassar College have organized a chapter of the American Student Union, hailing it as a means of emphasizing the undergraduate insistence upon peace, freedom of thought and speech and the necessity of defending the country from subversive political activities.

MR. RAMSEY is not the first historian to say a good word for that son of Oliver Cromwell who, for eight months, held together the disintegrating Commonwealth that owed its existence, in such large part, to his father; but he is the first to build up a formidable body of authenticated evidence into such an unassailable vindication of Richard's position and character as to produce a definitive biography.

DURING 1934 and 1935 Mr. de Leeuw made an extensive journey through the Spanish Main and the islands of the Caribbean. Finding that he could not do justice to the vast amount of material in the scope of one volume he wisely decided to confine himself in this book to his experience in only a few of the countries visited, reserving many of the Windward and Leeward Island groups for subsequent treatment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- As the eleventh annual session of the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War closed here after a week of debate on international problems, more than 750 delegates from national organizations endorsed international cooperation and public opinion as being effectual instruments of peace.

ENID, Okla., Jan. 25 (AP). -- William H. (Alfalfa Bill) Murray said here last night that he had renounced political ambition this year in favor of his own plan to "save this old Republic from the wreck to which it is hastening."

George W. Wickersham, Attorney General of the United States during the Taft administration and chairman of President Hoover's National Commission on Law Observance and Law Enforcement, died at 1:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon while riding in a taxicab. He was 77 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25. -- Ky Laffoon, sharp-shooting linksman from Chicago, and Jimmy Thomson of Ridgewood, N.J., one of the longest hitters in the business, tied for medal honors today in the San Francisco match play open championship.

Lincoln Ellsworth's flight of 2,100 miles across Antarctica has revealed some suspected but nevertheless highly interesting facts as to the mountain-pierced land over which he traveled, and, taken in connection with the flights of the last Byrd expedition, pretty well cleans up the mystery of this hitherto unknown section of the continent.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area made a fair showing last week. Sales were reported as showing a gain over the corresponding week last year, but the comparison was with a period of poor trade in 1935 owing to the blizzard which adversely affected business.
HAVANA, Cuba. -- Attention of yachting enthusiasts is centered on the tenth annual International Star Class Regatta being run off this week along the Havana waterfront.

CONFLICTS at the College of the City of New York between the president, Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, and the students led the Associate Alumni of the institution to appoint a committee of investigation. Tomorrow evening the Associated Alumni will meet to hear the reports.

As we turn the pages of "Merry-Go-Round" it is almost impossible to believe that the author's first volume of verses, "Sketches and Scraps, by Laura E. Richards, With Pictures by Henry Richards," was published in 1881 and that Mrs. Richards has recently celebrated her eighty-sixth birthday.

It is as old as Aeschylus that only when a man's life comes to its end in well-being dare we pronounce him happy. So with poignant lament over the sudden going of GEORGE W. WICKERSHAM, we as a community, as a State, as a nation and as friends pronounce him among the happiest to have gone in the height of his well-being.

The fourth Leap Year Assembly in a series inaugurated in 1924 will be held on the night of Feb. 29 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. A counterpart of the Junior Assemblies, Knickerbocker Assemblies and Friday Assemblies, which are arranged each season for debutantes of the current Winter and of former years, and for young matrons, the Leap Year party will reverse the traditional customs followed at regular subscription dances.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 25. -- A new world's interscholastic record for the 150-yard medley relay was established by a powerful Blair Academy trio as their team scored a 43-to-32 triumph over the Student Varsity Swimming Club of the Montclair Y.M.C.A. today.

IF we judge by the prints should shown in the second biennial exhibition of the Whitney Museum we should assume a definite rise of lithography in the world of graphic art, and we should not be so far wrong at that. In numbers the lithographs in this exhibition are practically two to one over etchings and woodcuts combined and their interest is unusually varied and sustained.

MR. HUGH ROSS, conductor of the Schola Cantorum, is not a routine musician. He is in the habit of constructing interesting and provocative, programs. For the Schola Cantorum's concert in Carnegie Hall Feb. 4, he has arranged an event which might have the subtitle "One Hundred Years of Russian Music.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 25. -- Although Bryn Mawr College from its inception has led in suffrage movements and encouraged its students and alumnae to take an active part in civic affairs, undergraduates have shown increased interest in this direction in the last few years, according to the results of a survey disclosed during midyear examinations this week.

Whether an individual's attitude toward life is that of a conservative, radical or liberal soon may be determined scientifically as a result of the development of a new type of intelligence test by Dr. Julius B. Maller of Teachers College, Columbia University, and Dr. Harold S. Tuttle of City College.

ATHENS, Jan. 25. -- Seven major and nine minor parties, with 1,668 candidates, will contest in tomorrow's election the 300 seats in the monarchy's first National Assembly. This evening troops occupied the Ministry buildings and telephone and telegraph offices in order to uphold freedom in the election.

GENEVA, Jan. 24. -- This week's sessions of those confusingly interlocked bodies of the League Council, the committees of thirteen and eighteen, seem, as was foreseen, to leave the issue between the League and Italy pretty much where they found it, but with what movement there was directed toward stronger sanctions.

ATHENS, Jan. 24. -- Greece's first election under the restored monarchy to be held Sunday exactly two months after the return of King George II, promises to be characterized by the scrupulous honesty with which non-partisan cabinets are always chosen in order to tidy up after Greece's political upsets and replace the engine of democracy upon the rails for another run.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Governor George H. Earle 3d of Pennsylvania attacked the "Morgans, Fricks, Carnegies and Raskobs" as "reactionary capitalists" in a speech tonight at the eleventh annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Society of New Jersey in the Robert Treat Hotel.

THIS is on many counts a welcome book. Of Professor Shellabarger's distinct merits as a biographer I shall speak later; it is enough at the outset to commend his choice of a subject. There have naturally been other biographies of Chesterfield, but fewer than you might suppose, and this is perhaps the first which from a modern angle relates the man to his writings, and the two together to their age.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 25. -- Roger Shepard of the Yale Alumni Hockey team scored three goals as the graduates beat the Eli varsity, 4 to 3, in two-overtime periods tonight in the New Haven Arena.

COLUMBIA is making what promise to be two of the year's more interesting pictures and is about to begin a third. In 1924 the studio attained distinction because of two or three outstanding films, but its product last year was regarded as mild at best.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--Highlight of Alfred E. Smith's Speech tonight at the American Liberty League dinner:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- Army teams conquered rivals from Amherst in two sports today, the Cadet varsity quintet turning back the Lord Jeffs, 35 to 30, in a hard-fought battle that was decided in a five-minute overtime period, while the West Point swimmers won in a dual meet, 49 to 22.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- In its own view the Lambs Club of New York City is an "employment agency" with "minor social features," rather than a "social club," and its famous "gambols" are "deadly serious work," "not for the purpose of entertainment."

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- Xrith the' Stock Exchange closed today, weakness in the dollar monopolid the attention of the financial district. Fear of inflationary moves by the United States caused further heavy sales of the dollar and the dollar rate moved off at one time to SS.01-_. to the pound.

George McMahon, a freshman at St. John's University, who was running his first race in competition, broke the tape as victor in the 60-yard novice dash at the Pre-Olympic Games held in conjunction with the Seventy-first Regiment meet at the armory last night.

A NATIONAL Academy of Public Affairs, to be set up by the United States Government along the lines of the military and naval academies at West Point and Annapolis, "for the training and education of men and women for public service in administrative service in national and international affairs" is proposed in a bill (H.R. 10105) introduced in Congress recently by Representative Wesley E. Disney of Oklahoma.

PRODUCING Shakespeare on the radio is a monumental task described as "a ticklish job" by Charles Warburton, director of the current cycle of the bard's "king" plays being presented by the Radio Guild. Mr. Warburton, who has played and produced Shakespeare here and abroad for many years, finds the clock the big bugaboo in staging a Shakespearean play for the microphone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Sharp argument over possibility of new taxes or of inflation spread in Congress today as a prelude to the apparently certain Senate overthrow of President Roosevelt's bonus veto.

THE juvenile delinquent is in the spotlight. He is a leading figure today not only on the stage and in the movies, where the evolution of the gangster is the theme, but on the program, seemingly, of every organization concerned with the welfare of human beings, from the churches and the women's clubs to the Lions and the Rotarians.

THE NEW YORK TIMES announces today a series of Constitution contests for teachers and students in the high schools and preparatory schools of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, to be conducted this year and next year. Prizes will be awarded for the best teaching plans, articles and essays submitted on the Constitution of the United States as a living document.

Chairmen of thirty committees were named by Avery Brundage, president of the Amateur Athletic Union, just prior to his sailing early yesterday morning for the Olympic Winter Games. The list was released through Secretary-Treasurer Daniel J. Ferris. These committees will have supervision over the various sports under A.A.U. jurisdiction for the current year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Democracy's "happy warrior" tonight sounded the bugle call for revolt.

THOMAS ROURKE takes his major impulse from those who still follow the mode of hard-boiled simplicity. And yet, as the somewhat warmish title indicates, he is not free from the plague of the nightingale. What he actually does is to combine the most literal realism with the mood of romance.

There ought to be a law about maps in detective stories. Either they should be useful in helping the reader to visualize the movements of the characters at the time when the crime is committed or they should be left out. The map in "The String Glove Mystery" is worse than useless, for it causes the reader to waste time in trying to extract from it information that is not there.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Storm signals are out for the Democratic party in Illinois. The rejection of Governor Horner's candidacy for renomination by the State committee of the party and the endorsement of Dr. H.N. Bundesen, medical health officer of Chicago, to replace the Governor at the head of the ticket have stirred up dissension down-State.

In behalf of the Protestant Episcopal Church schools for Negroes in the South a recital will be given by Roland Hayes the afternoon of Feb. 5 at the home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond, 9 East Ninety-first Street, under the auspices of the Woman's Auxiliary to the National Council of the Diocese of New York Committee for Work Among Negroes.

Behind all the neutrality bills lies one common purpose. It is to keep the United States from becoming involved in war. But Congress is planning to do it by enacting an inflexible law. Increasing doubt has been cast on the wisdom of this method.

Secretary of War Dern disclosed last night that improvement of Hawaiian fortifications was being studied by the War Department. Mr. Dern was in New York to attend a dinner given by the Utah Club of New York to him and other natives of Utah in the Federal Government.

CHARGING that there is a vagueness about airline traffic regulations, Dean Smith, veteran pilot for American Airlines who flew the night mail across the Alleghanies before the days of radio beacons and last week received the Harmon Trophy for his eighteen years of safe piloting, is of the opinion that neither pilots nor some others realize the seriousness of the traffic situation and the necessity for regulations and cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- A prediction that outlays by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, excluding allocations to other government agencies and those for direct relief, would be liquidated without loss to the taxpayer if all crop loans made through the Commodity Credit Corporation were repaid, was made today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the corporation, in his annual report to President Roosevelt and to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- With the Senate expected to act finally Monday on the Bonus Bill which the House passed over President Roosevelt's veto, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States warned today that the government's financial plight is a matter of "increasing concern" and declared flatly that there is a "menace of inflation."

HONOLULU, Jan. 25. -- As two boards of army officers began today an investigation of the air collision that last night cost the lives of six members of the air corps at Luke Field indications were that the actual cause of the accident would never be fully clarified.

Elevator operators, porters, firemen and other service employes in more than 1,000 buildings not covered by contracts may be called out this week, it was asserted yesterday at the headquarters of the Building Service Employes' International Union, 570 Seventh Avenue.

Legislative intent is sometimes obscured by the employment in statutes of words which have varied meanings. In the interpretation of taxing statutes, a doubt is generally resolved in favor of the taxpayer and against the government, particularly where the doubt pertains to the meaning of words.

Sub-zero weather in many sections of the country last week served effectively to check the rising trend of retail sales, with the result that in several instances volume dipped under that of last year. New York City was an exception, with gains of 8 to 9 per cent, while the South and the Pacific Coast, escaping the severe cold, also registered increases.

These true stories of the United States Coast Guard have a thrill of danger and daring that will please not only boys but also their fathers, Mr. Chaffee has visited shore stations, watched activities and talked with men who have been heroes of some of the hazardous exploits he describes.

IN this story, as in "The Cadaver of Gideon Wyck," Thomas Painter and Alexander Laing are, nominally, merely the editors of a narrative produced by another, in this case a reporter named Jack Martin. It may be that Thomas Painter, Alexander Laing and Jack Martin are three names for the same person, but what does it matter?

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- All indications point to the fact that the period of unlimited borrowing with which the National Socialist government has been financing its rearmament and labor creation programs is coming to a close.

THERE are few hotter places on the world's main highways than the Red Sea, where Italian transports are pouring men and munitions into the Eritrean port of Massaua. The heat is always bad enough. It is worse in Summer, when the blaze in the sky fills all the sleepy Red Sea ports with its scorching glare and there is never any relief from the torment.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Signs that the Federal Government may try to collect incomes taxes on processing levies paid before the AAA was declared unconstitutional threatened a new fight today between processors and the New Deal.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- Anxiety is being felt in diplomatic circles in Paris regarding the fate of Charles Robert Pusta, formerly Estonian Minister in Paris and later in Stockholm. Mr. Pusta had just been accredited as Minister to Sweden, Norway and Denmark when, on Dec. 9, 1935, an attempted revolution was thwarted in Estonia.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 25 (AP). -- Cletus Stone, escaped Southern Illinois prison convict, his brother, Carl, and Mrs. Mae Banghart, wife of Basil Banghart, Touhy gangster, were convicted today of kidnapping Mr. and Mrs. Rufus Costner of Knoxville last October.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- In the same banquet hall where on Jackson Day administration Democrats paid $50 a plate to hear President Roosevelt liken himself and his problems to Andrew Jackson, conservative Democrats and Republicans tonight paid $5 a plate to hear the President, his policies and his advisers and aides denounced as experimenters in government at the first dinner of the American Liberty League.

PAINTINGS by John Young-Hunter are on view, through Feb. 3, at Wildenstein's. Best known here as a fashionable portrait painter, the English artist offers, besides a large group of canvases of the type that may be called "expected," an equally generous assortment of picturesque scenes from New Mexico, among them the enormous romantic spectacle called "Old Santa Fe Trail."

A letter from Mayor La Guardia, stating the reasons for the city's refusal to renew the licenses of organ grinders, was made public yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company. The communication was in reply to a request by May Singi Breen and Peter De Rose, radio entertainers, for an appointment to present a petition, signed by nearly 5,000 persons, asking the Mayor to again allow the organ grinders on the streets.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25. -- Sub-zero weather has had the to-be-expected results on retail sales and other lines of business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week, but the underlying conditions continue satisfactory. Payments of WPA workers, with old-age pensions in Missouri, have increased buying power materially and have been reflected in sales exceeding last year at this time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Sharp criticism from administration Democrats, but an outpouring of praise from those critical of its activities, tonight greeted the speech of Alfred E. Smith before the American Liberty League.

MONTREAL. THE grizzled "sourdough" of the old West, whose best friend was his six-shooter and whose favorite sports were rum and faro, is nowhere to be found in the new mining camps now going up in the wilder and remoter regions to the north of the Abitibi gold fields in Western Quebec.

Former Mayor James J. Walker, who appointed Jonah J. Goldstein a magistrate, spoke in his honor last night at a dinner at the Grand Street Boys Clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street. Magistrate Goldstein is president of the Grand Street Boys Association.

Three hundred hounds, representing twenty-seven hunt clubs, will be in competition at the eleventh annual Riding Club hound show to be given next Friday in the ring of the Riding Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street. The exhibition is under the joint auspices of the Masters of Foxhounds Association of America and the National Beagle Club, the proceeds to go to the A.S.P.C.A.

CALLING attention to "certain grave problems in radio broadcasting that deeply affect the present and future of our democracy," Sayre M. Ramsdell, vice president of Philco Radio and Television Corporation, is conducting a symposium among leaders of the radio industry to help find thoughtful solutions.

MR. WINTRINGHAM is a thoroughgoing Marxist, and therefore he is adept in the spinning of theories and has such implicit belief in their truth that he thinks arguments founded on their assumptions are impregnable.

Pierre Laval, Premier of France, has joined Sir Samuel Hoare, British co-author of the rejected Hoare-Laval plan for the pacification of Ethiopia, in temporary exile from public life. He resigned last Wednesday.
MANILA. -- Functioning under some difficulties, the office of the American High Commissioner in the Philippines, former Governor General Frank Murphy, is already in operation.

The United States should not and cannot follow a course of absolute neutrality in time of war, members of the Foreign Relations Association were told yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Astor. Speakers replying to the question "Can America Be Neutral?" warned that we cannot consider ourselves a nation apart from the world.

DURING its first tour of the season recently the St. Louis Symphony played at Purdue University, the University of Michigan and in Toledo, Ohio. The second tour will open in Chicago Feb. 16, where the orchestra will appear for the first time in some twenty years.

BUTTON TROUBLE: As the hands of the clock were nearing 12 last Monday in the chamber of the United States Supreme Court, Thomas E. Waggaman, crier, banged his gavel and every one in the room arose, expecting the nine justices to enter. But they did not, and Mr. Waggaman, resuming his seat, announced in bass and impressive tones: "Somebody pushed the wrong button."
THE automobile industry is ready to mark up the current month as the best January in its history.

Warning against any compromise with the New Deal, Senator J.J. Dickinson of Iowa, declared yesterday that the Republican party could not "pussyfoot its way to victory" in the coming Presidential election. Senator Dickinson, a potential though not an avowed candidate for the Presidential nomination, spoke at the Saturday luncheon discussion of the National Republican Club to an audience of about 200.

A red "badge" to "humiliate" drivers who figure in automobile accidents was one of dozens of proposals for highway safety put before legislators and traffic officials, representing nine States, at a conference here yesterday under the auspices of the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

The death of Dr. V.K. Ting, the eminent Chinese geologist, which was reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently, deserves, more than passing notice, for he was one of a select group, none too numerous in any nation, who combine high intelligence and unusual qualifications in their chosen fields with broad culture and exceptional vigor.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 25. -- A grant has been made by the Carnegie Foundation to the New Jersey College for Women to be used to establish a Social Information Center, Dean Margaret T. Corwin announced today. Information and guidance along civic and welfare lines will be made available to the public through the new center.
A special study of the best methods of teaching the art of writing to students who wish to take up that profession has been made at Barnard College, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday.

With the announcement yesterday that Frankie Frisch, dynamic pilot of the Cardinals, and Hank Greenberg, slugging first baseman of the world champion Tigers, would be their guests of honor, the New York baseball writers have practically completed arrangements for their thirteenth annual dinner and frolic which will be held next Sunday night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

Mrs. Herbert Shipman will preside at a tea to be given on Feb. 12 at the Hotel Lincoln to open the exhibition there on "The Life and Time of Abraham Lincoln." Miss Ida Tarbell, author of a wellknown biography of the Great Emancipator, will be guest of honor.

KING GEORGE V -- greatly beloved of his generation -- rest with his ancestors. The Prince of Wales, as King Edward VIII, has ascended a throne that is a landmark in history; he is the thirty-ninth sovereign to reign over England since William the Conqueror, the fifty-fourth in succession to Alfred the Great.
WARSAW, Jan. 25. -- Poland has good reason to be satisfied with the settlement of the Danzig dispute just arrived at by the League of Nations Council.

Rapid alterations in the New Deal administration's methods of combating the depression have produced "spiritual shell shock" throughout the country, declares Bruce Bliven in an article in February Current History.

In the most exciting interscholastic basketball game seen at Madison Square Garden this season, New Utrecht High School of Brooklyn rallied in the second half to defeat James Monroe of the Bronx, 24 -- 22, yesterday afternoon before a crowd of 4,000.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Three seeded players moved into the semi-final round of the seventh annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship today on the Haddon Hall courts.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25. -- Extension of the Yale Peabody Museum research into Alaska, India, South America and Russia has given the work a world-wide range. The completion of the third of a series of Alaskan ethnological field studies by Dr. Cornelius Osgood, curator of anthropology, who has devoted his studies to the Far North, was announced today in a report of the research projects of the museum.

FROZEN lakes and ponds are luring skaters from their firesides these wintry days. The parks and skating rinks of the city are prepared to accommodate thousands of men, women and youngsters, for skating is becoming as popular a hobby as stamp collecting, photography or automobiling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Rapid changes are taking place on the Washington front of the Townsend Old Age Revolving Pension Plan movement. Since Congress assembled, the movement itself has altered both its strategy and its objectives.

IN issuing its annual census or the number of books published, in Great Britain during the last twelve months. The Publishers' Circular has this year the satisfaction of recording the highest total yet reached. The total for 1935, amounting to 16,110, is made up of 9,687 new books. 442 translations. 1,110 pamphlets (i.e., publications not exceeding forty-eight pages). and 4,871 new editions.

THE Harvard Glee Club and the Radcliffe Choral Society will join forces in a concert March 29 at the Town Hall. The program will have among its numbers two choruses from Handel's "L'Allegro," excerpts from Pergolesi's "Stabat Mater," Bach's "Singet dem Herrn ein neues Lied," from Cantata No. 190; the Nanino motet, "Diffusa est gratia," and Gastoldi's villanella, "Tutti venite armati."

The Giants yesterday brought their total of signed players for 1936 to eight when Secretary Jim Tierney announced receiving three more accepted contracts to add to the five already tucked safely away in the Stoneham vaults.

PARIS, Jan. 24. -- Behind the temporary solution of the Cabinet crisis in France there lies a situation much like that which existed in Great Britain and later in the United States some years ago, when, owing to the tremendous difference between the prices of raw materials and the prices of retail products, burdened as they are by taxation, there is no longer any profit for producer or even for merchant.

Of the thousands of Birthday Balls for the President being held simultaneously throughout this country and its colonial possessions on Thursday night, one of the largest will be the gala party here in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 25. -- While in Geneva Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, and Dr. Alberto Guani, Uruguayan League delegate, were defending their viewpoints, Brazil was swearing in a special committee, recently appointed by President Vargas, to investigate the November revolt and the extent to which Communists were involved.
