They ask many foolish questions, such as: Why aren't all laws before they go into effect tested for constitutionality in the Supreme Court?

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Inflation talk and apprehension of damage to the new Winter wheat crop in Western Kansas as the result of the forecast for a severe cold wave in that growing area injected sufficient life today into the market on the Board of Trade to lift prices around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish to the highest level since Jan. 11.

I have read with interest the letter of Miss Marion Bauer in THE TIMES of Jan. 12, relative to the many young singers of the Metropolitan Opera Company who for several Summers have been members of the Chautauqua Opera Association at Chautauqua on Chautauqua Lake, N.Y.

With a field of forty candidates, the first Eastern New York amateur badminton championships opened yesterday at the Tudor City Tennis Club in the 165th Regiment Infantry Armory. Henry T. Slocum of Boston, seeded ninth, easily defeated H.A. Montandon of the home club, 15 -- 0, 15 -- 1.

BOOKS were to Charles Lamb his greatest solace. Harassed by the family fear of dementia, torn by the tragedy of a mother murdered, wracked by financial anxiety and worn by the daily plod of a clerkship in East India House, books and friends were his only alleviation.

WHEN Mrs. Bill speaks of the conquest of death as being an imminent step in evolution, she means just that. Man has but to clear up past misunderstandings, discard inherited prejudices and the bereavement of death will no longer intervene between him and his loved ones.

CHICAGO. -- It is overwork that makes professors absent-minded, according to the faculty of Northwestern University. Instead of the life of leisure the professional class is popularily supposed to lead, Northwestern's professors say they are so busy they scarcely have time for sleep.

WITHIN a few months the traveler with his eye to the Orient will be able to buy a ticket which will take him by air 8,900 miles across the Pacific from California to China. So smoothly have the shake- down and exploratory flights of the Pan American Airways clipper ships merged into the mail-carrying schedule that the whole program of passenger-carrying has been advanced to a much earlier date than was originally planned.

The collection of American and European paintings, English and American period furniture, tapestries and art objects formed by the late Robert W. de Forest, former president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will be sold at auction at the de Forest residence, 7 Washington Square North, by order of Mrs. de Forest, on Wednesday and Thursday mornings and afternoons.

The action of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System on Friday in raising margin requirements, effective on Feb. 1, was designed primarily to cheek the spread of inflationary psychology, in the opinion of bankers and brokers as expressed yesterday.

MORE ways than ever to entertain passengers on Winter cruises appear this season on programs devised to while away their time both afloat and on their excursions ashore. The advance bookings made thus far this month exceed those of last January from 25 to 50 per cent.
NOGALES, Ariz., Jan. 25 (AP). -- The Seri Indians, last warring tribe in North America, are facing extinction through one of the strangest pacts with death in the history of the red man.

PARIS, Jan. 23.--Erik, the youngest of newly arrived Paris hat makers, shows a daring collection for Spring featuring the largest hats ever seen. These are made of specially woven panama, baku or leghorn and are shallow, posed on bandeaux, sometimes tilted up in front.
ROME, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Italy rejoiced tonight over what she called her second great victory in Africa within ten days.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 25. -- The two Negroes riding with Ozie Powell when that colored defendant in the Scottsboro case was shot in the head by a deputy sheriff denied today that there had been any attempt at an escape and Samuel S. Leibowitz of New York, chief of defense counsel, scoffed at attempts to link Northern white sympathizers with an intimated "plot."

A temporary lull in industrial activity, to be followed by a favorable trend in succeeding months, was forecast yesterday in the report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

WITH THE SOUTHERN ITALIAN ARMY AT NOGHELLI, Ethiopia, Jan. 21 (Delayed).-- The Italian victory at Deidei broke the backbone of Ras Desta Demtu's army and the capture of Noghelli broke Desta Demtu's heart, an Ethiopian chieftain who surrendered said today.

Professor McBains article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine is devoted to two main objects: First, to show that the AAA decision is likely to cause widespread and perhaps successful attack on the power of the Supreme Court to invalidate Congressional legislation, and, secondly, to stigmatize the court's action, and the opinion in support of it handed down by Justice Roberts, as manifestly animated by political and not judicial considerations.

Acquisition of virtual control of the United Light and Power Company by six trusts identified with the Harrison Williams, Seligman and Field-Glore interests marks the turning of this group of investment companies to a broad field of activity, and also the resumption of Mr. Williams's work as a builder of utility systems.

THE brothers Warner -- there are three of them, Harry, Albert and Jack -- always have impressed us as being a bit less predictable than the other Hollywood families and firms, Normally you know what to expect of a Metro version of Dickens, of a Paramount adaptation of Kipling, a Universal abridgment of Edgar Allan Poe, a Columbia recording of Puccini or an RKO-Radio improvisation for Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire.

Buying has been consistently active this week on Spring merchandise, despite the extremely cold weather, with out-of-town buyers continuing to arrive in large numbers, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Women's apparel, accessories, men's and boys' wear and home furnishings items were sought.

William Hodson, Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare, announced yesterday that hot coffee and doughnuts were being served daily to about 9,000 needy men and women. Coincidentally the Emergency Relief Bureau reported that 104 public and private shelters were caring for 11,400 local homeless people, including 168 women.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico. -- A statement attributed to Secretary Ickes since his recent brief visit here has occasioned much criticism in Puerto Rico. The Secretary was declared to have said that the island Legislature is sugar-controlled and therefore opposed to proper enforcement of the law passed by Congress thirty-five years ago forbidding corporations to own more than 500 acres of Puerto Rican land.

A YEAR of practice in handling typical problems of an architect's office is to be given to students of architecture at Syracuse University, N.Y., in a wholly new curriculum which goes into effect immediately. As part of the requirement for graduation the student must have completed contract drawings which he can defend before a jury of faculty members and visiting architects.

AIKEN, S.C. -- Meetings of the Aiken Drag Hounds for the coming week are scheduled for Tuesday morning at the Ridge race track, for Thursday morning at the Gamekeeper's Lodge in the Hitchcock "Woods and for Saturday morning at the Play Cottage below the Hitchcock residence.

ALTHOUGH Lynn Riggs is a serious fellow, it is pleasant to know that he can write a comedy when he wants to. Collaborating with one of the subtlest casts the town has recently assembled, he has put together whole evening of chuckles in "Russet Mantle," which slipped quietly into the Masque about ten days ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Congress, which now proposes to add by bonus legislation more than $2,000,000,000 to the vast sums spent on World War veterans, has already athorized expenditures which have brought the annual veterans' bill to a point where it approximates the amount expended by all other major combatants combined.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Taking two matches this evening, Harry F. Wolf of Montclair led the field into the fourth round of the New Jersey State squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club. The national champion and New York A.C. star is seeking his fifth State crown.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Return to the possession of Illinois of some 600 legal documents said to be in Abraham Lincoln's handwriting and valued as high as $75,000 is being sought by Governor Horner and by Attorney General Kerner.

THE name of Tyrone Guthrie appears for the first time in a New York playbill Tuesday night. The occasion is the premiere of "Call It a Day," the new Dodie Smith play, which the Theatre Guild, in association with Lee Ephraim, will present at the Morosco Theatre, with Gladys Cooper and Philip Merivale in the leading roles.

IN this interesting and forceful argument Mr. Young, who for many years has followed foreign news from a newspaper desk, and who is now cable editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, pleads for the establishment of a Pax Americana in cooperation with Great Britain.

At noon on Monday George V held his last Privy Council. There was submitted to him an order establishing a Council of State to serve in his stead during the twelve hours that were to remain of his life. In clear tones he said of that order: "Approved," and tried to sign it, but strength was gone from him, and all that he could accomplish was an undecipherable mark.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Only a thorough Congressional investigation can end the increasingly threatening Pacific Coast maritime dispute, both sides agreed today. They declared that a suggested round-table conference would be useless.

Brokers attributed yesterday's buying of stocks principally to the belief among traders that the Federal Reserve Board, by advancing margin demands from 45 to 55 per cent, had publicly recognized as a genuine or potential bull market the rise in stock prices that began last April.

Scant progress was made yesterday in clearing the thick coating of ice from the city streets, a slippery and corrugated surface which has made motoring hazardous since the cold wave set in early in the week.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- "Book Night," one of the annual institutions sponsored by the Committee of One Hundred, will be observed at the clubhouse in Michigan Avenue on Tuesday night.

By breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets, A.L. Burns led in a field of twenty-three gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. J.J. Van Gonsic, with 94 -- 4 -- 98, and J.F. Gagliardi, with 73 -- 25 -- 98, tied for the handicap honors, Van Gonsic scoring in the shoot-off.

Many reservations have been made for the luncheon in behalf of Stony Wold Sanatorium on Thursday at the Ambassador. Mrs. Ernest P. Davies heads the group in charge of arrangements. Her associates are Mrs. Myron I. Borg, Mrs. Hiter King, Mrs. William C. Breed Jr., Mrs. Alexander Johnson, Mrs. William B. Given Jr., Miss Margaret Clark MacMillin and Mrs. William R. Biggs.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 25. -- Robert Lowry of Shamokin, Pa., was the leader at the end of the first eighteen holes in the 36-hole medal play handicap golf competition on the St. Augustine links today with a net score of 69. This event annually precedes the national championship of golf club champions which will commence on Monday.

THIS book should be a blow to that school of psychoanalysis which takes a gloomy attitude toward the relations of parents and children. Briefly, it is an affectionate, informal account of the home life of the Popes -- father, who is a newspaper man; mother, who rules him quietly; and Nancy, the author, who has a delighted appreciation of her parents' peculiarities.

AT a time when Westchester legislators are fighting at Albany for the credit of passing a bill to make the State assume a large portion of the county's $68,000,000 park debt, it is regarded as encouraging here that the State and City of New York, the Tri-borough Bridge Authority and the State of Connecticut have recently recognized the Westchester parkways as serving State highway functions.

SEVERAL enlivening issues are closely fused into the plot of highly entertaining story of rum-running and love, hatred and revenge, business promotion and financial stress, whose setting is a British Columbia city in the fateful year of 1929.

A better management and merchandising job this year will continue to keep retail trade in the van of business recovery, despite the threats on the horizon of increased expenses, inflationary trends and higher taxes, according to individual expressions of large and small merchants who attended the silver jubilee convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association last week.

GEORGE V, King and Emperor, was the first British ruler to be known by the sound of his voice throughout the Dominions beyond the seas. During his reign radio knit Britain's far-flung empire with invisible wave lengths of sound.

A total of 6,847 contributions, amounting to $247,251, has been received in the city Y.W.C.A.-Y.M.C.A. joint campaign for $600,000 for 1936 current expense funds, it was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the campaign.
BERLIN, Jan. 24. -- The problem of resolving Franco-German relations into some constructive factor in a larger scheme for European pacification seems to be no nearer solution than it was in 1931.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Prominent Democrats, including some who served early in the present administration, Republican members of Congress, nationally known business men and socialite's mingled tonight in the crowd of 2,000 at the Liberty League dinner.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Jockey Harry Caperton scored his eighteenth victory of the Alamo Downs race meet today when he booted home Fredrick, the Hamrick and Massey Stable entry., in the featured fifth race.

BUFFALO, Jan. 25 (AP). -- In preparation to fight the regular Republican organization, if necessary, for a share of the delegates to national and State conventions, the Association of Young Republican Clubs of the State of New York is "going to organize the girls of the State," its president, Walter Mahoney, said today.
The far-flung realm over which Edward VIII as King-Emperor has been granted the sovereignty is without precedent in history.

THE heavy snow and sleet of last week have served to bring into prominence one of the most humane of all hobbies -- the Winter feeding and taming of wild birds. In the city, in the suburbs and in the open spaces beyond, amateur ornithologists may be seen daily ministering to the needs of their feathered friends, whose normal sources of food supply have been buried by the snow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- An order banning letters from the mails which have stickers on them lampooning President Roosevelt has focused attention on the laws governing the United States mails.

With the word that Van Lingle Mungo, speed-ball star of their hurling corps, is not regarded as a holdout and that Emil (Dutch) Leonard, another starting pitcher, has signed his contract, the Dodgers made progress yesterday in lining up their players for Manager Stengel.

Fleet of Falcon Hill, American-bred English springer spaniel owned by Henry L. Ferguson of Fishers Island, N.Y., was the outstanding field-trial spaniel of 1935 in the opinion of nine judges who officiated in the five spaniel meetings during the season just closed.

IN these massive volumes a Bishop achieves the biography of an Archbishop. It is a great achievement, invaluable to the historian of a rapid transition, social and religious, The narrative is decorous but by no means dull. It is well authenticated, admirable in proportion and enlivened, here and there, with a subdued but genuine humor.

In addition to preparing arguments against the proposed Ellenbogen bill for control of the textile industry, hearings on which start tomorrow, leading cotton goods interests yesterday started a widespread campaign to arouse sentiment throughout all divisions of the industry against enactment by Congress of retroactive taxes to finance farm relief.

WE live in a machine age but seldom realize it except when the technocrats speak to us about it -- or when all man's tools quit because their motive force disappears, as they did recently in upper New York City. Then he cannot move quickly over any great distance, night is darkened for him, his safety is diminished, and the turnstiles of all his activities stop clicking.

BALTIMORE newspapers hail him affectionately as "Uncle Dan." Railroaders along 6,000 miles of line speak of him as "D.W." The rest of the land knows him as Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, dean of his profession, a man who has progressed from the bottom to the top of the business.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- A survey of recorded instruments covering the spurt of real estate construction last Fall in Westchester County reveals that the place formerly occupied by the title and mortgage companies in the home-loan field has been taken by the building and loan associations, according to a report made public today by Louis B. Joyce, executive secretary of the Westchester Real Estate Conference.

Although three new units of the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education will be fully established soon after the opening of the Spring term, the facilities of the bureau are still inadequate to serve all maladjusted children in the city's school system.

Members of the Vassar Club of New York will give a reception on Tuesday afternoon at their clubhouse, 43 East Fiftieth Street, for the patronesses and women active in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Tristan and Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles, next Friday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Scholarship Fund.

The privilege of the accused against self-incrimination in a criminal action "is of value only to the professional criminal and is a menace to the safety of the community," Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County, said yesterday in an address at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor of the District Attorneys Association of New York State.

Reversing a trend which has disturbed economists since the middle 1920s, the reciprocal trade policy of the administration has curbed the establishment of American branch factories abroad, leaders in foreign trade agreed here yesterday.

Building inspectors under the direction of Building Commissioner Samuel Fassler will start tomorrow the work of selecting the first 200 structures belonging to charitable institutions which are to be rehabilitated with WPA funds under the supervision of Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator for New York, and Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan.

Robes and Buggies Silk robes are the latest example of how words can be made to sound sweet or sour, according to convenience. The reference is to black silk robes of the kind that judges wear, including members of the United States Supreme Court.

Homemakers whose thumb and finger tests have taught them how durable a linen cloth or percale sheet will probably prove to be will go into session on Thursday afternoon at the Hotel Astor with the men who sell them. In a conference on "Quality Standards" arranged by the division of economic adjustment of the City Federation of Women's Clubs they will hear spokesmen from the industries describe the more scientific tests evolved for their protection.
The international troubles precipitated by the fighting in Ethiopia had their repercussion last week in the WPA theatre project for the relief of unemployed actors.

THEY have brought a back to the front in polo. The new grand mogul of the happy horsemen in this country is Robert Early Strawbridge Jr., former Philadelphian, now a denizen of Wall Street. As chairman of the executive committee of the United States Polo Association, he becomes the front man in polo council although he was always a back on the polo field.

PARIS. PARIS stylists play tricks with geography according to the changing taste of the day. For example, on the mid-season's map of the chic world mountains occupied all the foreground, while the Riviera was diminished to the merest speck.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Democrats joined Republicans today in denouncing the proposed soil conservation subsidies of the administration's stop-gap farm relief measure as the completed bill was laid before the Senate Agriculture Committee.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25.--Inaugurating the first of seven successive exhibits, a loan collection of old masters from private homes, directors of the newly organized Society of the Four Arts give a tea and private showing today for officers and members at its gallery here. From tomorrow until mid-April the show will be open to the public.

The New York State Bankers Association will hold its annual mid-Winter meeting tomorrow at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. About 500 members from all parts of the State will attend. Industrialists, financiers and public officials outside the State organization also are expected to be present.

The spread of the cooperative movement since its inception in Rochdale, England, in 1844 by twenty-eight unemployed weavers until its present membership of 100,000,000 families in forty countries was described yesterday by Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian labor leader, in addresses at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street, and at Cooper Union Hall, Eighth Street and Fourth Avenue.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- The first of the season's shoots for the second annual handicap skeet tournament for the Cloister Handicap Trophy will be held at 3 o'clock Thursday at the Gun Club, Sea Island. Numerous skeet enthusiasts at the Cloister and in the Sea Island residence colony will assemble for this tournament.

"I have read with considerable interest Mr. Edward R. Hewitt's remarks on the trout problem as reported in your column," writes J.R. de la Torre Bueno Jr. of this city. "I am very glad you gave so much space to this important matter, as the whole problem of the rearing, stocking and taking of trout is a very tangled one, and of vital interest to so many people in this and other States.

IT is unfortunate that one must speak of L.M. Nesbitt in the past tense. His untimely death in an airplane crash over the Alps brought to an end a promising literary career. What might have accrued from a longer tenure of life may only be surmised from two published books, "Hell Hole of Creation," which made a timely appearance with the Italo-Ethiopian war, and this new volume on his observations and experiences in Venezuela.

IN a recent speech saying that Germany should "rely upon guns" instead of upon the League for the settlement of her problems, Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, emphasized, above all, Germany's lack of colonies and raw materials, and added that the time must come when she would demand her former colonies back.

MR. IRWIN'S book makes interesting propaganda against propaganda. In carrying this out he has a lucid plan. It is to show how people get ideas favorable to themselves -- and confounding to their enemies -- into other people's heads.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 25. -- Orrin G. Wood, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, said today that present-day factors indicated a favorable and active year in the investment banking business.

This is not a book for those who upon a murder in the first chapter and swift, relentless sleuthing in the ensuing ones. Mrs. Irwin prefers to give her readers ample opportunity to become acquainted with all her characters before the tragedy.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 25. -- The Union College Outing Club is completing arrangements at "Skiihabn," its cabin at North Creek, for more than sixty delegates of the Intercollegiate Outing Club Association expected next week-end, when they will celebrate a three-day intercollegiate ski week-end.

MARY GRAHAM BONNER, who is well known for her stories for children, has written her first book for adults, a novel entitled "Rainbow at Night." It will be published about the middle of February by Lee Furman.
An article entitled "New Airship Is Modified" published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 19 gives the first real insight into the new LZ-129 now being finished in Germany.
Police Commissioner Valentine credited Mayor La Guardia's noise abatement campaign yesterday with playing an important part in the success of the Police Department's traffic safety drive.

Fire swept an oil barge and damaged the pier of the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company, near Shore Road and Twenty-first Avenue, Astoria, Queens, last night following an explosion of undetermined origin.

HIS WEIGHT IN GOLD: In purple robes and a green turban, Sir Mohammed Shah, the Aga Khan, spiritual head of 100,000,000 Ismailian Mo hammedans opened the golden jubilee of his leadership last week in Bombay. He sat on one side of a huge scale; on the other side gold bars, the gift of this followers, were placed until a balance was struck.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 24. -- Aroused finally to the gravity of the Talmadge menace and the opportunity the Georgia Governor will have to make trouble in the Democratic National Convention unless his grip on the State party machinery is pried loose, Roosevelt leaders in the State and nation began this week a belated move to establish an effective organization in Georgia.
THE Atlantic National, first large tournament of the new year, begins on Tuesday night at the Park Central Hotel. It is run by the United States Bridge Association.

Captain Ralph E. Fleischer, Q.M.C., who has been on duty at Fort Slocum as commissary officer and as director of the school for army bakers and cooks there, is under arrest on Governors Island and awaiting trial by general court-martial on "serious charges," it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the Army Second Corps Area.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Sleet II, the new Class B ice boat owned and handled by Jesse Howland Jr. of Seabright, today won the Commodore's Race, the first official point event of the season of the Monmouth Ice Yacht Club over the North Shrewsbury River here.

OMAHA, Jan. 24. -- While Herbert Hoover did not precisely conquer the Corn Belt with his speech in Lincoln, he did surprise it with the disclosure of the length to which he is willing to go to further farm recovery. He mightily pleased his friends and he made it much easier for the well-disposed to be better disposed without embarrassment.

After deliberating more than nine hours, a jury in the United States District Court returned a verdict of guilty against Acting Captain William F. Warms and three co-defendants in the criminal negligence trial resulting from the disastrous fire that swept the Morro Castle off Asbury Park Sept. 8, 1934, taking a toll of 134 lives.

Conflicting influences brought irregularity yesterday into the bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Week-end profit-taking in evidence among many of the lower-priced speculative issues while, in contrast, high-grade loans maintained a firm undertone.

ROME, Sunday, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Reliable sources reported today that Lieut. Gen. Giuseppe Pavone, commander of the Italian Twenty-ninth or Peloritana Division in Ethiopia, was gravely ill with a tropical disease.

Dentistry had one of its big moments last Tuesday evening, when Dr. LeRoy L. Hartman of the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery gave the world his formula for desensitizing the dentine for painless drilling of teeth.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25. -- A plan to get as many Jews out of Germany as possible was outlined publicly here tonight by Sir Herbert Samuel, the first British High Commissioner for Palestine, and Felix M. Warburg, partner in the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co.

ON Wednesday afternoon last Miss Madeleine Carroll, who had Just arrived from England on the steamship Majestic the night before, was poking around among her numerous effects in her Ritz Tower apartment, getting ready to leave for Hollywood early that evening.

IN the Summer of 1914, when the vast gray waves of the German Army were ruthlessly slogging across Belgium and an amazed and shocked world was voicing its anger and its sympathy, some one dubbed the outraged little nation "the international baby."

AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 25. -- An increase in cultural emphasis was the outstanding event of the past year at Massachusetts State College, President Baker said today in connection with the preparation of his annual report to the trustees.
BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler declared in an interview that, so far as Germany was concerned, pacifism could be based only on the theory that every nation had a right to live.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With more horses stabled here this season than in any year since 1929, the hunting season with the private pack of James and Jackson Boyd will reach its height during February.

Swimmers of Henry P. O'Neil Junior High School, interborough team champions of the Public Schools Athletic League, dominated that organization's annual individual title tests, decided in the seventy-five-foot pool of Seward Park High School yesterday.

The New York City dress industry's union and employer representatives, who have been called to confer at City Hall tomorrow at 10:45 A.M. by Mayor La Guardia, acting as a mediator in an effort to avert the threatened strike of 105,000 workers, were in conference yesterday and will meet again today at the Hotel Pennsylvania to discuss their differences.

CARLOS CHAVEZ speaks for the youth of Mexico. He is l one of the guiding spirits in a musical movement that is seeking to mine the rich musical resources of his country, a movement which has enlisted the support and enthusiasm of most of Mexico's young musicians and composers.

ADVANCE programs of the "American Hour" from station 2RO, Rome, will be announced each week during the broadcasts at 6 P.M., Eastern standard time, on the preceding Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, Count Guerino Roberti, secretary of the Italian Embassy in Washington, has been advised.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Housing has become one of the major issues before Congress as government agencies prepare to present two different sets of proposals to encourage home building, each one of them including elements which are certain to promote controversy.

THAT eighteenth century, so luminous and crystal-clear in the retrospect of historians, conceals a mystery. In 1700, as M. Fay puts it cogently in the preface to his book on the relations between Freemasonry and Revolution, "heredity, inequality, the divine right of kings, dogmatic Christianity were accepted throughout Europe as the essential principles on which the established order rested.

MANY books have been written about California, and quite a number of them have been usable as guidebooks, but Mr. Drury is sure that his is so different from the others that it will fill a distinct niche of its own. In many ways it is.

A plea for elimination of "the spoils system" from the administration and enforcement of the criminal law was made yesterday by Raymond V. Ingersoll, Borough President of Brooklyn, at a "citizenship" meeting under the auspices of the Women's Press Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Senator Harrison said today that he would submit to the arbitration of the electorate of Mississippi the charges hurled at him by his colleague, Senator Bilbo, in connection with Mr. Harrison's efforts to obtain confirmation of the appointment of Judge Edwin R. Holmes to the Circuit Court.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons, displaying plenty of scoring punch and a sound defense, tonight defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game played before 9,000 persons, the biggest Montreal crowd of the season.

Plans for the Blue Ridge Ball to be given on Friday at the Plaza will he discussed at a tea to be given by Miss Mary Cole, chairman of the junior committee, tomorrow at her home, 730 Park Avenue. The ball, sponsored by Senator and Mrs. Harry Flood Byrd of Virginia, is given annually in behalf of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Greene County, Va.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Sixty-six naval officers were selected for promotion today by President Roosevelt in approving lists recommended to him by Navy Department boards. They included fifty-nine officers of the line, two of whom were designated for engineering duty only, to be promoted from lieutenant commander to commander, and seven dental officers chosen for promotion from commander to captain.

WITH the revising, re-editing and reissuing of the "Master Musicians" series, first published a generation ago, it was found that a few books were, for one reason or another, beyond revision, and that a new writing was desirable.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The American Liberty League heard President Roosevelt pilloried by its speakers tonight as a "betrayer" of his oath of office and country. Count on count in their indictment led to an appeal for the voting millions to rise against the New Deal in the Presidential campaign.

The verdict of a Jury that 490 station agents employed by the Independent Subway system are entitled to $6 daily wages was set aside by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church yesterday and a new trial was ordered.

Manual Training High School's hockey team held La Salle Military Academy to a 2-all tie in a non-league game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. In another contest the Astoria Americans blanked the Bronx Tigers, 5 -- 0.

DANVILLE, Va., Jan. 25. -- All restrictions on the sale of surplus tobacco in the bright belt in this area were lifted today on orders from Washington annulling the tax of 4 cents a pound that has been levied on all tobacco sold in excess of the farm allotments provided under the Kerr-Smith Tobacco Control Act.

The city's public education system has received a total of $34,500,000 from the PWA in the form of new plant construction and equipment during the depression years, it is noted by Arthur S. Tuttle, Acting State Director of the PWA, in an announcement yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Charles D. McLaughlin signed yesterday an order returnable Feb. 10, temporarily restraining Alex E. Muhleman of 152 West Forty-second Street and George H. Proctor of Los Angeles, living at the Murray Hill Hotel, from dealing in securities in violation of the provisions of the Martin Act.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- Although in composition and political complexion the new French Cabinet under Premier Albert Sarraut is the logical outcome of the Radical Socialist revolt against the Laval government and is considered certain to obtain a good majority in the Chamber of Deputies, passionate opposition to it is expressed in today's Rightist press.

The retirement of Captain Thompson H. Lyon as marine superintendent of the International Mercantile Marine Company was announced yesterday by officials of the company. Captain Lyon plans to leave the Chelsea piers Feb. 1, thus closing a maritime career that has extended over forty-four years and embraced years in sail and steam and in the directing of ships coming to and from their berths in the North River.

For the first time in New York's history, skyscrapers may rise above the auditoriums of theatres under the revised building code, which will come up for its first general hearing before the committee on buildings of the new Board of Aldermen on Thursday.

AFTER the impressive appearance of Clark Gable on the cinematic horizon the Hollywood marts were flooded with a spate of beetle-browed muscular basso-profundos, each of whom was hailed with a great to-do as another Gable. Again, with the arrival of George Raft to screen prominence, hordes of individuals dug up their jars of vaseline and set out for the Coast with well-lubricated hair and a variety of menacing facial gestures.

Despite the apparent lag in employment last year behind manufacturing output, a return to the 1929 level of production and services on the basis of a 1936 or 1937 population should absorb the bulk of the economically unemployed, according to opinions expressed yesterday by business statisticians and economists.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24. -- A storm may have ripped over Japan when the Bolsheviki boldly told the world they were more than doubling last year's military budget in the figures for this year -- from 6,500,000,000 rubles last year to 14,700,000,000 this year -- but the Soviet press, which usually delights to engage in polemics with the Japanese, has taken a new tack, silence.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 25. -- General Rafael Chazaro Perez, Director of Military Education, was killed this afternoon when a plane in which he was riding crashed at the military aviation field because of engine trouble. Clinton E. Warner, an American, who was piloting it, was seriously injured but is not expected to die.

IT is in the Middle West, according to political observers, that the decisive battle of the 1936 national election will be fought. There, by present signs, the fate of the New Deal will be determined. The signs, it is true, are confusing. The political effects of the overturn of the AAA by the Supreme Court are still to be demonstrated.

DALLAS, Jan. 25. -- Business generally continued its upward swing during the week throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, with increasing retail sales and enlarged construction programs. Unemployment registers improvement as more of the unemployed are absorbed into industry and by the construction work now well under way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The American Liberty League will participate aggressively in the Presidential campaign in support of the Republican nominee if he and the platform agree with the league's policies, according to the dominant opinion of those who shape these policies.

BOSTON, Jan. 24.--The Rhode Island Democracy is looking forward to the complete consummation of its avowed purpose to "modernize" the government of that State. A constitutional convention at last is in sight.

There is a real need for a book about the Presidents of the United States. Of course, biographies of the Presidents have been published, but I refer to a book that within the compass of one volume, say of 500 to 600 pages, will give brief, succinct facts in a kind of catalogue fashion of all that is actually known about all the Presidents.

SINCE Robin Lampson calls his "Laughter Out of the Ground" a "novel in cadence" rather than a novel in verse, or a narrative poem, a reviewer had best do the same, for it is clear that Mr. Lampson, when he chose his words, perceived a definite shade of difference.

MRS. MARGARET SANGER, American advocate of birth control, is now in India, lecturing on family limitation. She has spoken in Bombay, Calcutta and Delhi, and the newspapers have opened their columns to a debate on birth control, a subject heretofore neglected because it was not regarded as important to the welfare of the Indian people.

Convinced that the invalidation by the Court of Appeals of Section 2 has seriously curtailed the effectiveness of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Law, efforts will be pushed this week for new State legislation here to ban predatory price cutting and eliminate "racketeering" in all divisions of retail business.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- German Catholic clerics will read from Catholic pulpits throughout the Reich tomorrow a pastoral letter from German Bishops which indicates a subtle yet firm basis upon which the Catholic Church is willing to compromise with the Nazi regime.

TORONTO, Jan. 25 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs returned to their best form of the National Hockey League season tonight as they trounced the Detroit Red Wings, 6 to 1, in a wide-open game. The Wings, off to a bad start as the Leafs attacked persistently in the early part of the game, never recovered.
ROME, Jan. 24.--General Rodolfo Graziani's offensive in Southern Ethiopia, whose success exceeded all expectations, is believed to have ushered in a new phase of Italian military operations.

THE humanities have come into their own again, and this as the result of relativity and the thinking that has been done by the modernists in atomic physics. Philosophy has been pre-empted by the Einsteins, Eddingtons, Schroedingers and Paulis of our time.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Prophetic of the rush of activities which will mark the next eight weeks are the many planned for this. So varied are they that every resident should find among them one, or many, appealing to his fancy.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 24. -- Peace was re-established in South America Tuesday when Bolivia and Paraguay signed an agreement to release all prisoners of war and renew diplomatic relations. The agreement definitely terminated the Chaco war, which began in June, 1932, cost the lives of 100,000 young men and brought permanent disability to many thousands of others.

The Irish-American stock in America is the natural defender of liberty, because of long training in fighting for freedom, Attorney General John J. Bennett said last night at the thirty-eighth annual dinner of the American-Irish Historical Society at the Hotel Astor.

The progressive withering of political superstitions, plus the twenty-one amendments to the Federal Constitution, have gradually made our government vastly more democratic than its founders intended it to be. In fact, all the real democracy in our government is to be found in the amendments rather than in the original document.
A tour of nine States by a United States Field Hockey Association team will carry the principles and influence of field hockey into the south during the next two months.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan 25 (AP). -- State Senator Perley A. Pitcher, author of the bill which created the State Milk Control Board and chairman of the joint legislative commission which investigated the milk industry before that law, declared today in favor of continuing State control.

Alumnae of Wellesley will flock to the Hotel Biltmore on Saturday for what is expected to be the last official visit in New York of Dr. Ellen Fitz Pendleton, president of the college. Dr. Pendleton, who has announced her retirement at the end of this school year, will be one of the speakers at the annual luncheon of the New York Wellesley Club, as will Robert Gray Dodge, president of the board of trustees.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Several records fell today as the Yale swimmers gained their 144th consecutive dual-meet victory by defeating Penn in the Hutchinson Pool before a big crowd, 52 to 19.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Several records fell today as the Yale swimmers gained their 144th consecutive dual-meet victory by defeating Penn in the Hutchinson Pool before a big crowd, 52 to 19.

YOUTH'S present job worries are by no means due wholly to the depression. Many of them even today are due to a vast ignorance of the occupational field and a tremulous uncertainty as to which vocation to choose.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25. -- The Iuyamtorg Corporation, Soviet trading agency in Montevideo, has begun definite liquidation preparatory to going out of business and leaving South America, it is announced in the Uruguayan capital.

OREGON, Ill., Jan. 25. -- A proposal looking toward a permanent farm program within the framework of the Constitution was advanced today by one of the nation's ranking agricultural authorities, Frank O. Lowden.

THIS story of young Jimmy Golden is a plea for peace and an indictment of war as the destroyer of much more human life than appears on the casualty list. They gave little Jimmy Golden a gun and lived to repent it. The war and its aftermath changed Jimmy from a timid undersized bookkeeper in a small town to a killer and fugitive.

Of course, biographies of the Presidents have been published, but I refer to a book that within the compass of one volume, say of 500 to 600 pages, will give brief, succinct facts in a kind of catalogue fashion of all that is actually known about all the Presidents.

MRS. MARGARET SANGER, American advocate of birth control, is now in India, lecturing on family limitation. She has spoken in Bombay, Calcutta and Delhi, and the newspapers have opened their columns to a debate on birth control, a subject heretofore neglected because it was not regarded as important to the welfare of the Indian people.

Convinced that the invalidation by the Court of Appeals of Section 2 has seriously curtailed the effectiveness of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Law, efforts will be pushed this week for new State legislation here to ban predatory price cutting and eliminate "racketeering" in all divisions of retail business.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- German Catholic clerics will read from Catholic pulpits throughout the Reich tomorrow a pastoral letter from German Bishops which indicates a subtle yet firm basis upon which the Catholic Church is willing to compromise with the Nazi regime.

MOST women who use cosmetics powder their noses from six to a dozen times a day. And it is usually the same shade of powder, from day to day, no matter what color dress is worn. Experts say that the powder which looks well when one wears a scarlet dress can hardly be expected to be becoming when one is gowned in gray.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 25. -- Displaying some good basketball during the first ten minutes of play, the Naval Academy team ran up 16 points before Oglethorpe tallied and then went on to win today by 44 to 22. The home quintet made many changes in its line-up, using a total of seventeen players.

HOLLYWOOD. THE auditoriums of 4,000-odd American theatres presented a strange sight yesterday afternoon. In fact, they do every Saturday afternoon. More than a million youngsters, ranging in age from 5 to 17, undeterred by the line on the marquee which read "Special Kiddies' Matinee," thronged the neighborhood cinema temples to scream and shout.

HANDICAPPED by the severest cold wave in years over many sections of the country, retail trade slumped in the week. The weather brought forth a call for heavy Winter apparel but the coal and oil business and certain hardware lines enjoyed the only real sales spurts.

If the per capita production and consumption of light wines in the United States could be brought up to one-half that of France or Italy there would be -- nationally speaking -- no more drink problem and no more farm problem in this country. This assertion may sound like mere panacea mongering, but it will stand examination.

THE automotive industry, which gives employment to 12 per cent of the country's workers, has swung solidly to the support of the nation-wide campaign for safer highways. Through direct subsidies to many existing agencies the industry plans to underwrite a large part of the campaign to reduce automobile accidents.

HAVANA, Jan. 25. -- The American boat Ace, sailed by Adrian Iselin 2d and representing the Western Long Island Sound fleet, today took the first two races of the tenth international Star Class series for the Bacardi Cup. Nutmeg, skippered by Paul Hurlburt Smart of the Central Long Island Sound fleet, finished second in both contests.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 24 (AP). -- Wisconsin, cradle of progressivism in legislation, has what State officials believe to be the only operative "recovery" law in the country for the regulation of intrastate business through codes of fair competition.

A COURSE in gardening will be presented again this Spring by the Junior League of New York. Last year's course -- the first -- attracted not only league members but many non-members. The general topic selected for the current course is "New Gardens for 1936.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25. -- James J. Westwood, justice of the peace and Republican boss of McKees Rocks, was found guilty today of first degree murder in the death of his wife, Martha.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Homer Seider's Swordfish easily outclassed the fleet of the Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club's Class B boats today in winning the Commodore's Pennant.

THE Abutilon or "Flowering Maple," though rarely seen in window gardens, is an ideal plant for display there as well as for bedding out in Summer. It is almost a continuous bloomer, where there is sufficient sunlight, and for that reason often rivals the geranium in homes where it is once given trial as a house plant.

A MUSIC festival, hereafter to be an annual event, is being prepared by the esoteric group, the Friends and Enemies of Modern Music, to be held in Hartford, Conn., the week-ends of Feb. 8 and 15. It was this same organization which two seasons ago put on the opera.

The largest list of entries received in recent years, a total of 126 boxers, is announced for the Metropolitan A.A.U.'s championship boxing tournament which is to be held in Madison Square Garden tomorrow and Wednesday nights. Preliminary bouts will be conducted in the eight standard ring divisions from flyweight to heavyweight tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Plans for increasing considerably the size of the Federal police force to insure more effective law enforcement have been completed by the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, and will be put in force as soon as the departmental budget is acted upon by Congress.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25. -- Time Supply's 1936 debut at Santa Anita today was a winning one.

LAKE PLACLID. -- This resort is buried in the deepest snows of the season. More than twenty inches of flakes cover the main streets of the village and near-by hillsides, while the mountain trails and passes are blanketed with a two and three foot coat.

The Atlantic national bridge championships, the first of four new tournaments planned by the United States Bridge Association, will be held at the Park Central Hotel beginning next Tuesday and continuing through the following Sunday.

ARTHUR CARLES of Philadelphia is the present exhibitor at the Marie Harriman Gallery, where his retrospective show will remain until Feb. 8. Many New Yorkers are sure to welcome this chance to become better acquainted with the work of a gifted abstractionist.

A story of an inflation in ancient Babylonia caused by high taxation and the hoarding of precious metals has been worked out from a study of 10,000 ancient clay tablets at the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, Dr. Albert Ten Eyck Olmstead, Oriental Institute Professor of Oriental History at the University of Chicago, said last week at the annual dinner of the American Institute for Persian Art and Archaeology at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The text of Alfred E. Smith's speech before the American Liberty League, as taken down by stenographers was as follows:

To weave a network across the country that will emphasize the interstate character of its drive for adequately trained government office holders, the National League of Women Voters will celebrate "Public Personnel Day" on Wednesday with a coast-to-coast broadcast.

HISTORIANS have too frequently left unsung the heroic work of the few American inventors and engineers in the post-Revolutionary period. Oliver Evans, the first complete study of whose life and work is now presented, is no exception.

IT is comforting, in this agitated life of ours, to come across some one whose entire interest seems to be the study of birds. Frances Pitt will pack up and drive across the English Midlands to an island off the coast of Wales in answer to a telegram saying that the weather conditions are ideal for the shearwaters.

With only five days remaining during which automobile owners may use their 1935 license plates, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Charles A. Harnett issued an appeal yesterday to tardy applicants for renewals to avoid a last-minute rush and congestion by obtaining their 1936 plates immediately.

Delegates and visitors to the number of 2,500 will gather on Thursday at the Hotel Astor, it is expected, for the sixteenth annual convention and luncheon of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations. A total of 250 constituent groups, each devoted to some phase of social service or religious activities, are entitled to representation.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 25. -- America's Olympic speed skaters were unable to keep pace with the Norwegians today as the European championships got away to a slow start.

FRANCES FROST, in her poetry, has captured with sharpness and beauty the special quality of New England landscape and New England character. Now, hazarding a new dimension, she has done much the same thing in terms of fiction.
PHILADELPHIA. -- The citation by the State Insurance Department of a local medical clinic to prove that it is not subject to the insurance laws revived the question of group medicine in Pennsylvania.
BUCHAREST, Jan. 24. -- Germany is displacing France as a seller of goods to the Balkan States with a rapidity which is arousing keen interest among diplomats stationed in this region.

RECENT developments in the WPA project are of a most encouraging character. Instead of being an aggregation of three small projects which together form one of thirteen units in the Municipal Theatre project, (itself a subdivision of the Federal Theatre plan), the dance now has a project of its own under the direct supervision of the Federal Theatre directors.

Joseph B. Weaver, director of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection Service, is on his way to the Pacific Coast to investigate labor conditions in the shipping industry. The influence of the Maritime Association of the Pacific on longshoremen and on the crews of ships operating to and from Pacific Coast ports is the major item on his program.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24. -- The political machine built by the late Senator Huey P. Long in Louisiana carries on, after his death, with undiminished power. That is the conclusion to be drawn from Tuesday's primary election in which every plan laid by the Senator before his assassination on Sept. 8 was borne to fruition and the Long machine won a record victory that shattered opposition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Professor Jean Piccard, who with his brother, Auguste, formerly held the stratosphere balloon record, will make another attempt to recapture the record now held by Captain Albert Vg. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- A "President's Birthday Ball" will be held on Thursday evening at the County Center here. All communities of the county are taking part in the event except Mount Vernon, Peekskill, Yonkers, Ossining and Port Chester, where separate balls will take place.

SANTO DOMINGO, reputed to be the oldest existing settlement of white men in the New World, has changed its name to Ciudad Trujillo (Trujillo City) in honor of President and Dictator General Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.

I fondly believed that the question of propaganda plays versus art had long been laid to rest. I am wrong. Your discussion reopens the question in so far as you have misread the intentions and purposes of the left-wing playwright and critic. If these people have failed to make their position clear it is not because they have not stated their propositions often enough but not widely enough.

Japan's withdrawal from the London Naval Conference, the controversies provoked by the sensational but abortive Senatorial Munitions Committee investigations, and the present Congressional discussion to determine a definite national policy of neutrality, have brought many controversial and historical events into the foreground.

Japan's withdrawal from the London Naval Conference, the controversies provoked by the sensational but abortive Senatorial Munitions Committee investigations, and the present Congressional discussion to determine a definite national policy of neutrality, have brought many controversial and historical events into the foreground.

DETROIT, Jan. 24. -- The war of divided unions waxed hotter this week when John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, speaking as chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, addressed first rubber workers at Akron and later automotive plant employees at Cleveland, urging a campaign to organize automotive workers into industrial unions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The President's birthday ball holds the center of the social stage in Atlantic City this week. Scheduled for Thursday evening, along with those in other sections of the country, the local ball will be held in the Hotel Traymore.

I fondly believed that the question of propaganda plays versus art had long been laid to rest. I am wrong. Your discussion reopens the question in so far as you have misread the intentions and purposes of the left-wing playwright and critic. If these people have failed to make their position clear it is not because they have not stated their propositions often enough but not widely enough.

London's quiet hit, "Lady Precious Stream," arrives tonight at the Booth. As all must know by now, it is an ancient Chinese classic done into English by Dr. S.I. Hsiung, who has also staged it, with these players, among others: Helen Chandler (in the title role), Bramwell Fletcher, Clarence Derwent, Molly Pearson, Helen Kim, Marcella Abels, Henry Morrell, Detmar Poppen, Natalie Schafer and Miss Yuen Tsung Sze.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 27. -- "I am a very ordinary sort of fellow," was the way in which King George described himself recently to the Archbishop of Canterbury, who repeated the story yesterday in the course of his sermon on the dead King in Westminster Abbey.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 26. -- Defense attorneys in the Scottsboro case said today that their clients had told them that Ozie Powell, one of the nine Negro prisoners who was shot in the head after an attack with a knife upon a deputy sheriff of Morgan County, was goaded into his rash act by threats intended to frighten them into repudiating their present lawyers.

PEIPING, Jan. 26. -- Japan is evidently intent upon crowding China into a corner where there will be only two courses open -- armed conflict or submission to Japanese dictation to the extent of virtual national slavery. This fact is revealed here by Chinese sources of undoubted responsibility and veracity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Jouett Shouse, American Liberty League president, said today that more than 1,000 telegrams concerning Mr. Smith's address last night condemning the New Deal had been received up to early afternoon.

ATHENS, Jan. 26. -- On a platform of toleration of King George II, the Venizelists defeated Field Marshal George Kondylis today in a perfectly orderly and honestly conducted election, thereby making probable an early return of Eleutherios Venizelos to Greece.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The passage of the Soldiers' Bonus Bill has thrust the United States dollar into the speculative limelight again with disconcerting precipitancy. Whatever individual opinions may be regarding the effect of this measure, there is no doubt that a fear of inflation in the United States is leading to the withdrawal of European capital from the United States and causing a weakness in the dollar against the pound sterling.

The annual report of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, noted "two specific gains upon patronage" in the last year. One was the taking out of the exempt class the clerks of municipal courts and the ruling that employes formerly exempt whose positions became competitive must prove by special examination that they have abilities equal to the standards set for the competitive positions.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--Kings, Princes, Premiers or foreign Ministers from every country in Europe are arriving here daily for the royal funeral. In the aggregate they constitute a political gathering that even Geneva cannot duplicate.

Cotton futures prices last week fluctuated narrowly until Saturday, when there was a sharp run-up in new crop deliveries attributed to reports from Washington on new farm legislation. Closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange at the end of the week showed net gains from 9 to 35 points.

Contracts for the leasing of business and housing properties comprised the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan over the week-end. Investors and operators were active in deals involving Bronx properties.

MIAMI, Jan. 26. -- An early "head-on collision" between industrial and craft union forces in the American Federation of Labor was regarded as certain in labor circles today when it became known that the executive council, controlled by craft union representatives, has refused the two-year plea of the National Radio and Allied Trades for a national industrial union charter.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Jan. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Art Williams, former United States Army air pilot, left here today by plane for the interior to renew his search for Paul Redfern, missing since 1927 when he attempted a flight from Georgia to Rio de Janeiro.

Since tradition sets aside one Sunday night each year to do honor to Daniel Frohman and his Actors Fund, Broadway responded opulently on both sides of the Forty-fourth Street Theatre's footlights last evening. A star-studded and resounding festival, it took its place as No. 54 in the long line of tributes to Mr. Frohman and his kindly charity.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Outrushed and outshot, the New York Rangers dropped a 2 to 1 decision to the Chicago Black Hawks tonight in a rousing National League hockey match played before 11,000 spectators in the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Dr. Hugh S. Cumming, surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service for the past sixteen years, will retire next Friday from that post and from the service, which he entered on May 25, 1894, as an assistant surgeon.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Sing Sing's ancient stone cell-block was denounced as damp, insanitary and vermin-breeding and the old dormitory inside the walls, where some of the keepers are housed, was called a firetrap in a report of the State Commission of Correction made public today.

Cotton is selling in world markets at far below the average pre-depression relationship with all other commodities, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. This is attributed in part to the above-normal stock of the staple and the stimulation of foreign production of cotton in recent years.

PANAMA, R.P., Jan. 26. -- The partly completed mural by a Mexican artist, Fernando Leal, in the National Institute was destroyed yesterday by orders of the government, according to The Panama American. It is reported Dr. Octavio Mendez Periera felt that the mural commissioned by the government reflected on the country unfavorably.

A luncheon and bridge will be held today in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Catholic Boys Brigade. Mrs. Thomas J. O'Neill heads the group in charge of the benefit, which is sponsored by the Association for Catholic Action Among Boys.

If accepted by Governor LEHMAN and Commissioner OSBORNE, as they probably will be, the recommendations of the Governor's committee on "truck trails" in the Adirondacks will bring to a close an issue which has stirred sharp controversy in conservation circles.
PARIS, Jan. 26. -- Premier Albert Sarraut's Cabinet held its first meeting this evening to debate its joint policy and will hold another before it appears before the Chamber of Deputies Thursday.

Seventy-eight members of the faculty of City College, all graduates of other institutions, have sent to the Associate Alumni of the college an emphatic assertion of their admiration for the "enlightened leadership" of Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the institution.

LAKE LUZERNE, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Mary J. Dillon, owned by Watson Shippee of Hadley and driven by Walter H. Andrews, also of Hadley, won the first trotting race on today's ice harness card after having run four heats. The third was a dead heat with Calumet Ebblis, owned and driven by W. Ellis Gilmour of Schenectady.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Orders that an election be held by secret ballot in the plants of the Chrysler Corporation at Highland Park, Detroit, and Hamtramck, Mich., have been issued by the National Labor Relations Board. The election will take place to select representatives for collective bargaining between the designing engineers and the company.

Representatives of 600 Jewish groups at an all-day meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday backed increased reconstruction activity in Palestine to facilitate the absorption of refugees from Germany and other European countries.

The second annual women's chess championship tournament opened yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club, 23 West Tenth Street, with sixteen players entered in the two sections which will contest the preliminary rounds.

A conference to avert the threatened strike of 105,000 dressmakers in this city and vicinity will be held at City Hall this morning, when Mayor La Guardia will seek to prevail upon representatives of employers and employes to agree on a compromise.

The Rev. Gordon Wadhams, the new rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, Seventy-fourth Street east of Park Avenue, set forth a "course of action" for his new congregation and himself in his first sermon yesterday morning.

Your editorial "Need for the Fair" was most interesting and practical. Adequate traffic and transportation facilities and the most modern provisions for the comfort of the millions of expected visitors are primary needs, but, as the words you quote from George McAneny so inspiringly point out: "First, there must be an exposition that will give the world at large a new concept of America, its traditions and its ideals, its unity and its might."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26. -- Fighting a great uphill battle after being 3 down, Willie Hunter of Los Angeles defeated Craig Wood, New York, on the nineteenth hole today to enter the final of the San Francisco match play open golf tournament.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 51 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the preceding week and equal to the rate in the week before that.
The School Art League will award eight art scholarships and seventy-five medals to high school students tomorrow in the auditorium of Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

The United States, until recently a land of comedy, is undergoing tragedy through depression, Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian labor leader, declared in one of a series of sermons preached here yesterday.

Warning that the next decade would determine whether the world would plunge headlong into war and revolution, the Rev. Dr. Frederick Brown Harris of the Foundry Methodist Episcopal Church, Washington, D.C., declared yesterday, in his sermon as guest preacher at the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, that a new social order would come not through "tin soldiers with wooden leaders," but through a belief in the teachings of Christ.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- Although Lew Babiak of the Newark A.C. quintet scored 20 points, the Penn A.C. came through with its sixth straight victory in the Eastern Athletic Club League by beating the Jerseymen today, 47 -- 38.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- The official Institute for Trade Research declares that prices of raw materials in 1936 will be determined largely by measures taken in Washington to replace the regulation of agricultural output as prescribed in the revoked Agricultural Adjustment Act.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- The return of the Bank of France, dated Jan. 17, shows a decrease of 355,000,000 francs in loans against securities and treasury bonds. Circulation decreased by 806,000,000 francs and private deposits were 46,000,000 less. The gold reserve rose 149,000,000 francs, with the ratio of gold coverage at 72.39 per cent, against 71.52 a week before.

The retirement of Samuel Seabury as special counsel for the Board of Estimate in rapid transit matters, including unification, may follow soon after the tentative plan negotiated by him and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. is submitted to the Transit Commission, it was indicated yesterday.

It was a characteristic speech that Secretary ICKES delivered last night in defense of public works. He began by paying his respects to the "uninformed and hypercritical people" who have doubted their efficacy. It is absurd, he thinks, to say that the public works theory has failed, because "it has never really been tried."
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 26. -- Official Ethiopian sources disclosed today the retreating Southern armies of Ras Desta Demtu had fallen back to Wadara, 268 miles northwest of Dolo.

Forty members of the Park Department Band, a WPA unit, appeared at the Fifty-ninth Street Lake in Central Park yesterday afternoon and complained about the cold. Playing their instruments in such a low temperature, they said, would place them in great danger of being frostbitten, and so they would be unable to fill their assignment to provide music for the department's annual Winter Carnival.

Shirley Peknay is a chubby little girl, 8 years old, with dark brown hair in curls down her back and a ready smile. Moreover, she is, to her great astonishment, chairman of the Brooklyn committee of the Birthday Ball for the President, to be held Thursday in the Hotel St. George.

THE night was dark and the going was rough as a couple of military gentlemen rolled away from the last fight gathering at Madison Square Garden. The military gentlemen were General John J. Phelan and ex-Private Bill Brown, who were discussing the battles of the evening as the car bumped northward over the icebound streets.

The Roman Catholic Church is the greatest international obstacle to communism today, the Rev. Edmund A. Walsh, regent of the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University, declared yesterday at a symposium on "The Catholic Answer to Communism."
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
Christians who believe some tenets of their faith and reject others were rebuked by the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge in his sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

Ralph Metcalfe's domination of the sprints on the All-America track and field team came to an abrupt termination yesterday when the 1935 selections of Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, were made known in Spalding's Athletic Almanac just off the press.

Foreign exchanges jumped sharply higher last week with a vigor not witnessed in months. The major currencies reached their highest levels in several years, while the gold bloc in some instances ran above and in others approximated the point at which gold could be shipped abroad.

The need for private welfare agencies to continue their work, regardless of national, State or municipal social service work, was stressed at the annual meeting of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies yesterday afternoon at the Community House of Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith's Liberty League speech in Washington Saturday night was interpreted here yesterday as meaning that he is ready to lead a bolt from the Democratic National Convention at Philadelphia in June if, as seems inevitable, President Roosevelt is renominated and his administration is approved in the party platform.

Senator BORAH would make a very acceptable nominee for President if only because of the precedents and contrasts one might bring up. In that sense Mr. BORAH is very much of a New Deal candidate himself.

When the Tapay Realty Holding Corp. sold to Horatio Isaac and Alexander Lockhon the residence at 702 St. Nicholas Av.. for a consideration shown as $3,000 over the first mortgage for $10,500, the buyers gavo back a purchase money mortgage for $1,500 at 5 per cent.

It is reported from Washington that an unexampled flood of telegrams has descended upon Senators urging them to vote today to uphold the President's veto of the bonus. These appeals come from organizations and citizens known to the Senators to whom they are individually sent.

The heaviest blow which the New Deal and the Administration have suffered was delivered by ex-Governor SMITH Saturday evening. He is the hardest-hitting political speaker of his time. He also has a marvelous gift for showmanship. Wit and ridicule flow easily from him, and make old subjects seem fresh and vivid.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- A few speculators who have been long in corn against sales of wheat and lard, the latter being a most unusual spread, took advantage last week of hard spots in the corn market to get out of their lines and, at times, put enough corn on the market to prevent prices advancing to any extent.

A new 15,000-ton floating drydock, which is under construction for the Todd Shipyards Corporation in Seattle will be placed in commission within two weeks, it was announced yesterday. John D. Reilly, president of the corporation, left last night for the Pacific Coast to be present at the exercises.

Edna St. Vincent Millay has written a 15,000-word biographical sketch of Charles Baudelaire which will be published in "Flowers of Evil," a translation from the French of Baudelaire, by Miss Millay and George Dillon. About seventy poems are translated, the French text facing the English. Mr. Dillon and Miss Millay are both Pulitzer Prize winners in poetry.

The Federal Government expects to complete the Hightstown (N.J.) agro-industrial community project for garment workers by Sept. 1, it was said yesterday by Boris Drasin, chairman of the Workers Aim Association. The association is composed of about 200 persons who have been selected for the project.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Subzero weather was responsible last week for most irregular markets for livestock here and at Western points. The top price for hogs here on Friday was $10.70 a hundredweight, an advance of 70 cents in the week and the highest price since Oct. 17, 1935.

The New York Association of Community and Settlement Music Schools, in which for more than fifteen years eight member organizations and two associate members have banded themselves together in an informal central organization, has now been incorporated with a directorate of representatives of each of the schools and members at large.

Glenn Cunningham's close call in the K. of C. Mile in the Prout Games at Boston Saturday night, in which the Kansan triumphed by a step as Joe Mangan bumped him over the line in a nerve-tingling finish, was one of the most unpopular victories ever registered by the world's indoor and outdoor record-holder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Al Smith knows the ways of politics completely and he is an honest man. Therefore his public prediction last night that "millions of Jefferson and Cleveland Democrats," among whom he enumerated himself, will "take a walk" if the Philadelphia convention heartily endorses the record of President ROOSEVELT must be taken as advance notice of the most important party bolt since 1896.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26. -- Leaders representing the organized philanthropic effort of American Jewry voted unanimous endorsement today of the proposal outlined last night by Sir Herbert Samuel and Felix M. Warburg to finance the emigration of the younger generation of Jews from Germany, together with as many of the older generation as might be able to exist elsewhere.

Violin playing of decided excellence was put forth by Inez Lauritano last night at the Town Hall. Her recital, the first she had given here since 1932, was a pronounced success with her large audience, occasioning many strenuous demonstrations of approval, which were richly deserved.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- The arrival of President Lebrun of France today produced a curious incident. There appeared at the French Embassy two Paris firemen in shining helmets and brass-bound uniforms that make Paris firemen objects of civic pride.

HAVANA, Jan. 26. -- Ace of the Western Long Island Sound fleet, owned and sailed by Adrian Iselin 2d, today captured the Bacardi Cup for international Star Class yachts, finishing the series of three races with a total of 37 points.

Nearly 300 residents of Sunnyside Gardens, nearly all of whom face loss of their homes under foreclosure because they refused to keep up payments on mortgages, met last night at the Community Park Cabin in Sunnyside and drafted telegrams appealing to Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens to arrange a conference at which they and the mortgagees could settle their differences.

The Metropolitan A.A.U. championship boxing tournament will get under way at Madison Square Garden tonight, when preliminary bouts in all standard divisions from the flyweight to heavyweight will be contested. The semi-finals and finals will be contested in the Garden on Wednesday night.

Described as a "Parade of Progress," a caravan of twenty-eight motor vehicles will start early in February on a 20,000-mile tour of the country to demonstrate "the contributions of a new age of scientific progress to the comfort, happiness and welfare of 126,000,000 Americans," it was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation.

Unless the policy of the government is changed or some of the recent legislation is declared unconstitutional, business faces a further permanent increase in taxation, the Guaranty Trust Company says in its current issue of the Guaranty Survey, published today.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 26. -- Hopeful that a higher court will vindicate him, William F. Warms, acting captain of the Morro Castle, who was convicted of criminal negligence by a jury in the United States District Court of New York yesterday, will continue his fight for freedom and justification of his seamanship the night the liner burned off Asbury Park with the loss of many lives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Speedy passage of Federal legislation to establish a permanent Federal housing agency and appropriation of funds to permit assistance to State and local agencies in low-rent projects was urged at the closing session of the National Public Housing Conference today.

Last week's vote for the Soldiers' Bonus Bill by both houses of Congress (356 to 59 in the House, 74 to 16 in the Senate), the instantaneous House vote of 324 to 61 to override the President's veto, and the expectation of similar action by the Senate, shaped in a somewhat peculiar way last week's later incidents.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 26. -- Norway's speed skaters, paced by the brilliant Ivar Ballangrud, won the European speed skating championships today, outscoring the United States and Japanese Olympic representatives by a wide margin, as well as the pick of Europe's bladesmen.

With five goals scored in the final period and the constant possibility that either team might emerge the victor, the New York Rovers battled the Baltimore Orioles down to the last minute and finally triumphed, 5 to 4, yesterday afternoon in Madison Square Garden.

Memorial services for King George V were held yesterday in many churches in the metropolitan area. Thousands of worshipers, regardless of denomination, joined in offering prayers for the dead monarch and his successor, Edward VIII.
