ON BOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Jan. 26. -- A tractor party that had set out to save the airplane Polar Star, which was abandoned by Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon at a point about twenty miles south of Little America, has returned to this ship after having narrowly escaped disaster.

A spirited defense of the bankers' agreement, which Mayor La Guardia announced recently that he wanted to abrograte, was contained in a statement issued yesterday by the Department of Finance. It predicted a surplus in the city treasury in the not distant future as a result of the agreement.

The break between two old friends and political associates, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Alfred E. Smith, threatened first in 1930 by their conflicting Presidential ambitions, became definite and irremediable as a result of Mr. Smith's Saturday night speech, it was said here yesterday.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 26. -- Three seeded players were eliminated today in the New Jersey squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club. The biggest surprise was the defeat of Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia University Club, seeded second and runner-up here two years ago, by a club-mate, Frank V. Brodil.

Mrs. Margaret H. Sprague, principal of Public School 141, was critically burned yesterday morning in a fire which demolished her three-room apartment on the ninth floor of 801 West End Avenue, on the northwest corner of Ninety-ninth Street.

The unbalanced growth of parts of the population, including defectives and diseased persons, demands the wider practice of birth control, Algernon D. Black said yesterday at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street. He urged education for "the new responsibility."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 26. -- Two men are dead and a woman in critical condition as the result of an explosion, caused by leaking illuminating gas, which wrecked a double frame house today at 225-227 Houston Avenue.

Doubt that a neutrality which is based on isolation and the repudiation of a universal duty toward mankind will assist in the realization of the Kingdom of God was expressed by the Rev. Dr. William F. Peirce, president of Kenyon College, Gambler, Ohio, in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A dollar a word is the rate that figures out for the 2,500,000-word description of the United States that is being done for Harry L. Hopkins by a corps of writers who hadn't been able to find jobs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Delegates to the international convention of the United Mine Workers of America, starting here Tuesday, are expected to ratify the demand of John L. Lewis, president of the organization, for industrialization of all unions connected with the American Federation of Labor.
Foy and Duke and other four-legged veterans of New York State's last horse-drawn regiment of field artillery will pull the caissons no more.

A new snow began falling shortly after midnight last night, after 28,000 workmen, who had been called out during the rising temperatures yesterday, had worked all day Sunday to clear away the ice and snow left in the city's streets by the storm of a week ago.

Teams from two British universities will visit this country during the Spring for a series of rugby games, according to an announcement made yesterday by Albert Woodley, secretary of the Eastern Rugby Union, at a meeting in the George Washington Hotel.

A team of three students of the Department of Architecture of Cornell University won the first prize of $300 in a competitive exhibit of plans for a "community recreation center for a town of about twelve thousand people," sponsored by the Association of the Alumni of the American Academy in Rome, it was announced yesterday by Francis S. Bradford, chairman of the committee of judges.

During the week's rest which Arturo Toscanini is to take following his first fortnight's activities with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Hans Lange will conduct. His first program, Thursday evening, Feb. 6, and Friday afternoon, Feb. 7, will feature the world premiere of "Three Shadows," a poem for orchestra by Lazare Saminsky, and Vaughan Williams's symphony in F minor, No. 3, which will be given its first New York presentation.

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, L. F. Sanman took the high scratch prize at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. In the handicap test J. Mercadante and J. Nida each had full cards, the first-named gunner winning the shoot-off.

Ezio Pinza, one of the leading bassos of the Metropolitan Opera for the last ten years, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. It is a pity he has not done so sooner, for his is a genuine basso cantante, admirably suited to the concert hall.

The fine performance given by Long Island University in beating St. John's at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night was easily the outstanding feature of a basketball week which saw many teams idle because of examinations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- The hardening of foreign exchange against the dollar and the rise of securities have created a belief among speculative interests that there will be general inflation in the prices of grains and that the trend is to be irregularly upward from now on unless unforeseen factors develop.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Indifference of the speculative public to the grain markets was indicated by the narrow fluctuations here last week, with bulges running into selling, and brakes developing buying support from speculative interest. The range on wheat futures was 1 1/2 to 2 1/8 cents a bushel, with the close at nearly the highest of the week.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 26.--Further orders have been given to the Ethiopian southern armies to close the gap in the line caused by the withdrawal of Ras Desta Demtu's army into Southern Sidamo.

Obligations of the United Statek Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,835,634,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- Benito Mussolini's mechanized armies pushed through Southern and Southwestern Ethiopia at an unprecedented pace today. Reports received here from Rome said Italy's southern "hell on wheels" column rumbled onward past Noghelli, aiming seemingly at Allata, major city of Sidamo Province, hundreds of miles from the starting point of the column, at Dolo.

While declining to comment on the attack by former Governor Alfred E. Smith against the policies of the Roosevelt administration at the Liberty League dinner in Washington, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, declared yesterday that the principles affecting the rights of the individual were in no way in contradiction with the principle of cooperation necessary to national progress.

The Metropolitan will give an evening cycle of Wagner's "The Nibelungen Ring" on four Saturday nights. General Manager Edward Johnson announced yesterday. This decision was occasioned by the fact that the afternoon Wagner cycle already is sold out except for standing room.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- The official view here is that the quantity of Germany's exports is likely to continue to increase in 1936, but that indications are that foreigners still are inclined to buy lower-priced wares, as in 1935. Against this situation is the expected rise in the world market for manufactured wares, soon to begin following the advance in prices of raw materials.
The sixty-second anniversary of the founding of the Young Men's Hebrew Association was commemorated last night at a dinner at the "Y," Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue.

Placing second in the final heat, Charley Winter of the Bronx compiled thirteen points to win the twenty-mile international motor-paced bike race last night at the New York Coliseum. A crowd of 5,000 watched the program of six events.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The passage by Congress of the bill for payment of the bonus will be followed by a demand for pension legislation with an ultimate cost of more than $100,000,000,000, Donald A. Hobart, national commander of the American Veterans Association, predicted today in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The heavy boots of policemen and detectives echoed in the marble corridors of the Woolworth Building all yesterday afternoon and last night in futile search for a burglar who had looted five offices and wounded a building watchmen.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- An excellent performance by Francis Boardman, skip of the Riverdale rink, enabled his outfit to defeat Ardsley's first team, 14 to 13, today in a second-round match of the interclub competition at the St. Andrew Curling Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The open threat of former Governor Alfred E. Smith to bolt the leadership of President Roosevelt in the coming campaign, made last night at the first annual dinner of the American Liberty League, resounded with baffling effect today throughout the quarters of those who feel they must carry the New Deal torch in that contest.

About 1,500 Winter sports enthusiasts spent more than twelve hours last night and early this morning trying to get back to New York after a freight train wreck between Haverstraw and West Haverstraw, N.Y., had marooned them up-State, leaving 350 of them on the unsheltered platform of the Bear Mountain station for almost four hours.

BERLIN, Jan. 26. -- Miss Sonja Henie, world's champion woman figure skater, again won the European title tonight at the Sport Palast. She was opposed by a field made up almost exclusively of girls in their teens. The youngest of all was Yetsuko Inada, Japanese miss, who is only 11 years old. She finished ninth in the field of seventeen skaters.

Thirty-six cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy Will receive their diplomas and licenses at the semi-annual graduation exercises this afternoon on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. Nineteen of the cadets have studied two years in the deck department and seventeen in the engineering department of the academy aboard the training ship Empire Ship.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Harald Sorensen of the Norfolk (Conn.) Winter Sports Association, rated among the top-notch fliers of the country for the past eight years, gave his customary excellent performances today to carry off the Class A honors in the annual Palisades ski jumping competition held over the Bear Mountain Park hill.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 26. -- A new high record in membership, surpassing even that of the boom days, has been reached by the Investment Bankers Association of America.

The French Players, a newly organized company which aims to present the best in the classic and modern French theatre, offered yesterday at the Heckscher Theatre, 104th Street and Fifth Avenue, as its first production Alfred Savoir's "La Huitieme Femme de Barbe-Bleue."

If a father wishes to "rate" well with his children he must talk, read and play with them, but all a mother need do to receive the children's highest approval is to cook well and be a good housekeeper, according to a survey of 800 high school students by Dr. Marian J. Fitz-Simmons of Teachers College, Columbia University.

A large group of Norwegian paintings, assembled by the National Gallery in Oslo under the direction of Johan H. Langaard, has been placed on view at the International Art Center, 310 Riverside Drive, where it will be shown until the end of February. The exhibition was opened yesterday afternoon with a reception.

Joseph Bree of Tuckahoe, N.Y., carried off the metropolitan senior speed skating championship yesterday on the ice of Central Park's Fifty-ninth Street lake. In an exhibition of stamina as well as speed the new champion earned his laurels by taking both the quarter and one mile tests in addition to placing third in the two-mile event.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -In the present bewildering state of French politics the City is finding difficulty in forecasting the effects of the probable outcome of the downfall of the i Laval administration. Financial London has made up its mind, however. that no government which might be formed between now and the elections could be strong enough to devalue the franc and that, therefore, no immediate change in French monetary policy is likely.
The Boston Bruins skated through to a surprise triumph over the New York Americans last night by the score of 2 to 1.
In comment on former Governor Smith's speech, telephoned last night from Lake Placid, Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Secretary Ickes and Senator Albert W. Barkley of Kentucky joined tonight in the first reply of administration spokesman to the speech of Alfred E. Smith before the American Liberty League dinner last night attacking the New Deal policies of the Roosevelt administration.

Refunding of railroad debts, which was inconspicuous in 1935, was a feature of last week's announcements of plans to retire bonds before their dates of maturity. In addition, several entire issues of public utility and industrial bonds, together with some small amounts of municipal liens, also were called.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan. 26. -- The Volunteer Firemen of Bloomfield refuse to be abolished. For a half century the Volunteers have been running to fires and although in recent years there has been a professional department in the town, the Volunteers have turned out on the second alarm -- and have been paid for that service.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- Upon the shoulders of the 27-year-old Duke of Norfolk has fallen the task of arranging all the ceremonials of King George's burial and the assumption of sovereignty by King Edward.

Commodity futures prices were generally higher last week, probably influenced in part by the increased number of inflation rumors that were current. In the cash markets, corn, rye, oats, cocoa, raw sugar, dairy products, lard, quicksilver, cotton, wool tops and rubber advanced, while tin and silk were lower.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- This has been a week of subdued activity in the financial and commercial markets here, which have been manifesting their appreciation of the fact that a great loss has been sustained by the country in the death of King George.

A $12,000,000 financing operation for the Skelly Oil Company, to provide for refunding and additional working capital, will be carried out today with the offering to the public of $3,000,000 serial notes, due from 1937 to 1941, and $9,000,000 4 per cent debentures, due in 1951 through an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co.

The Sleepy Hollow Country Club and Round Hill Club teams scored victories in Westchester squash racquets club matches contested yesterday. Playing on their home courts, the Sleepy Hollow representatives defeated the Bronxville Field Club, 6 to 1, and at the Greenwich Country Club the Round Hill squad downed the Greenwich Country Club men, 4 to 3.

Associates of George W. Wickersham in his many public and official activities will act as honorary pallbearers at the funeral tomorrow noon in St. George's Church, Sixteenth Street and Stuyvesant Square, for the former United States Attorney General, who died Saturday while riding in a taxi at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street.

The Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, to whom fell the mantle of Huey Long as leader of the "share-the-wealth" movement in Louisiana, arrived in New York City yesterday with a declaration of war against President Roosevelt. The Rev. Mr. Smith is here to confer today with leaders, as yet unnamed, in the share-the-wealth movement on the Eastern seaboard, and to make plans for the organization.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 26. -- Don Strachan, national title-holder, retained his Atlantic Coast men's squash racquets championship in the seventh annual tournament on the courts of Haddon Hall today, conquering Neil Sullivan, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 14.

TOKYO, Jan. 26. -- With 1,436 candidates in the field for 466 seats the election campaign is now fairly under way. Its chief interest is the answer it will give to the question of whether the political parties can recover sufficient power and prestige to check the excessive influence of the fighting services.

As the site for a theatre and store building, a plot fronting 225 feet on Cedar Lane Road and having a depth of 140 feet, adjoining the Grand Union store taxpayer, Teaneck, N.J., has been purchased by Murray M. Rosenberg, president of Miles Shoes, Inc., chain-store operators.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Captain A.A. Frierson of the West Point horse show team today won the individual jumping championship of the annual Winter indoor exhibition of the West Point Horse Show Association held in the huge riding hall of the United States Military Academy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- An indication of the light volume of trading in oats for future delivery, as shown by brokers who report lean earnings, suggests the condition of the speculative trade in this grain. Some reports, however, have gone out that oats is regarded as indicating the real speculative condition, but the majority of traders fail to take it in that light.

Aggressive evangelism "by Bible-believing Christians" is the only remedy for present-day lawlessness, the Rev. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.9, which compares with 83.8 the week before, 84.4 two weeks before, 84 three weeks before and 84.1 four weeks before.

Use of prison labor on State highway construction, compensation for injured prisoners, abolition of the "third degree," also of the antiquated cells at Sing Sing, extension of finger-printing and the parole system are among the recommendations made by the Prison Association of New York yesterday in its ninety-first annual report the Legislature.

Inclusion in high school curricula of courses in safe driving was urged yesterday by legislators and traffic officials, representing nine States, at the concluding session of the conference on highway safety called by the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 26 (AP). -- A weird mystery of sudden death with beautiful "Miss Rumania" as the victim and a toothbrush as the suspected lethal weapon left Bucharest police up against a dead end tonight.

Mrs. Whitney North Seymour heads a group of women who have arranged for two special showings for children of the motion picture "Once in a Blue Moon" on the mornings of Feb. 1 and 8 at the Plaza Theatre for the benefit of Metropolitan Junior Achievements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- With increases in the output of durable manufactures largely responsible, industrial production as indicated by the Federal Reserve Board's adjusted index advanced in December to the highest point since the Spring of 1930.
BERLIN, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Miss Sonja Henie, who has been rated as the world's leading woman figure skater for nearly a decade, faced the closest competition of her career today.

The action of the Consolidated Sportsmen of New Jersey in calling the State's first farmer-sportsman convention on Feb. 5 is indicative of the new trend toward cementing a closer harmony between landowner and hunter.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- With wide fluctuations in the prices of hogs, the market for lard futures here was unsettled last week, experiencing sharp declines in prices, followed by moderate rallies and by periods of dullness. Shorts and investors bought futures on the weak spots, while packing interests were credited with being the best sellers of lard against their purchases of hogs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The Soldier Bonus Bill tonight was only a few hours away from the statute books, according to all indications, and before the Senate stops work for the day tomorrow the measure is expected to be sent to the State Department, there to be filed away in the archives.

The Electric Bond and Share Company in its annual report for 1935, to be made public today, shows net losses, after expenses and taxes but before preferred dividends, of $9,299,895, which compares with $9,534,373 for 1934. The surplus income after preferred dividends amounted to $865,965, against $1,100,443, and gross income was $13,636,624, against $13,952,702.

The greatest task facing Christianity today is that of effecting a "reconciliation" between God and man, and between nations that, after brief periods of peace, again turn to war, the Rev. Dr. Harold C. Phillips, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Cleveland, said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

A protest against the "enforced resignation" of Elmer Rice as regional director of the WPA theatre project, and alleged administration censorship of "The Living Newspaper," will be made by members of the City Projects Council at a mass meeting at 8:15 P.M. tomorrow at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Deaths in industry in New York State rose in 1935, the industrial Commissioner, Elmer F. Andrews, reported today, stating that 1,372 death claims were filed with the Division of Workmen's Compensation.
VIENNA, Jan. 26. -- Preparations for the first mass trial of alleged revolutionary Socialists has just been completed and the charges published.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- It is "practical to design, construct and operate" airships of the size of the ill-fated Akron and Macon "with a reasonable assurance of safety and with a presumptive life which should serve to permit of a demonstration of their capacity for useful service."

Demand for Spring merchandise continued to broaden last week and large orders were placed in the local markets. Dress orders were rushed in order to beat the strike scheduled for Feb. 1. While tailored styles continued to dominate the suit requests, purchases of more casual types were also made to round out stocks.

Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their groups gave the second of their pair of performances at the Guild Theatre last night, with the program again devoted to the presentation of works in more or less extended forms. As last week's performance was chiefly Miss Humphrey's, last night's was to the same extent Mr. Weidman's.

The Brooklyn mass meeting for Senator William E. Borah tomorrow evening will serve as the formal opening of the Idaho Senator's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination and will be followed in New York State by a drive for Borah delegates to the Republican national convention, William Ziegler Jr. said last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Sales on all registered securities Exchanges in December amounted to $2,293,246,599, it was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which noted that this represented a decrease of 10 per cent from the value of sales in November, 1935, and an increase of 98.7 per cent over those of December, 1934.

The first in a series of entertainments in behalf of the 1936 budget campaign for funds to further the work of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association will take place this afternoon, when Mrs. Wilton Lloyd-Smith will give a reception at her home, 10 Gracie Square, for Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, chairman of the committee, and a large group of women interested in the success of the drive.

The speech of former Governor Smith before the American Liberty League was the subject of so much advance publicity and conjecture that anti-climax seemed inevitable. None came. To the contrary in his masterly summary of the case against the New Deal, in the homely eloquence of his plea that his party return to the principles enunciated in its platform, he fulfilled all expectations.

Armour Ferguson, 44 years old, of Norwalk, Conn., tentatively identified by documents found in his pockets as a grandson of the late H.O. Armour, founder of the Chicago meat-packing concern, was taken to Bellevue Hospital last night suffering from poisoning after he had swallowed several tablets while sitting in the lobby of the Hotel Tudor, 307 East Forty-first Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Condemning the Townsend old-age pension plan as a "delusion," twenty-one experts have issued a warning that its adoption would curtail business, depress wages, raise living costs, deepen the depression and probably ruin the monetary standard.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Miss Katharine Dewey, driving a Sno Birds' sled, captured first place today in the Adirondack Bob Sled Club's annual four-man race for the Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne Perpetual Challenge Trophy.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Miss Katharine Dewey, driving a Sno Birds' sled, captured first place today in the Adirondack Bob Sled Club's annual four-man race for the Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne Perpetual Challenge Trophy.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- An exodus of the wealthier part of the Jewish population in Germany with a certain proportion of its capital is already in progress, according to information that has reached THE NEW YORK TIMES here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- Hogs met with an active demand here today, while early sales were about in line with Saturday's market; later trading showed an advance of 10 to 15 cents a hundred weight. The top price was unchanged compared with Saturday at $10.25 and showed 45 cents under Friday's extreme top, while the day's average of $10.10 was 10 cents better than on Saturday and 25 cents lower than on Friday.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- The Reich Air Ministry announced today that a delegation representing it, the Reich Post Ministry and Lufthansa, the Reich's international air service, would leave for Washington within a few days to discuss with American authorities the establishment of airlines between Germany and the United States.

DOORN, Jan. 27. -- Because of the death of King George, his cousin, former Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany passed his seventy-seventh birthday quietly today. The only visitor at Doorn Castle was the Duchess of Brunswick, his daughter, who has been there for a fort-night.

Application of economic sanctions against a warring nation under a system of international Christian cooperation in business would eventually prove the most effective method of halting a military invasion, Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian labor leader, declared yesterday.

Share prices continued higher yesterday, Treasury bonds pursued their current decline, commodities moved narrowly, and the dollar closed a trifle higher after early weakness, as followers of the markets continued to grope in the "inflation" fog.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that its preliminary statement for 1935 showed a net profit of $167,226,000, equivalent to $3.69 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding during the year.

By a vote of 519 to 217 the Associate Alumni of City College endorsed and sent to the Board of Higher Education last night the finding of a special alumni committee that Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college, lacked the "human qualities necessary to achieve the widespread confidence of his faculty and his student body."

A pigmy of the pigmies, but a hippopotamus nevertheless, is the latest arrival at the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx. Dr. W. Reid Blair, director of the park, announced with evident satisfaction last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- Creation of a State commission to coordinate with the Federal Government in expediting a long-range flood control system for New York State was urged tonight by Governor Lehman in a special message to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- President Roosevelt named today six of the seven members of the new board of governors of the Federal Reserve System which on Feb. 1 will displace the present board under a new law which will vest strong control over credits in the board.

Good response to Spring home furnishings promotions, particularly of furniture, was reported yesterday by leading retailers here. Some establishments launched their sales events last week, with the showings yesterday completing the local promotional events.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 27. -- Leaders in the Republican party, headed by Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, here today to perfect arrangements for the convention on June 9, were told by Ohio Borah leaders that the Idaho Senator would not submit his candidacy for the Presidency to the primary election in this State.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 27. -- Although it was expected the general strike here which began as a protest against the action of the French authorities in closing the offices of the Nationalist clubs in Damascus and Aleppo would quickly subside, it seems, on the contrary, to be gaining momentum.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 27. -- Declaring that "a state of religious persecution exists in Mexico," the Catholic Episcopate of Mexico, in an open letter to President Lazaro Cardenas made public today, asked for the restoration of certain church liberties.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 27. -- America's skiers and skaters have settled down to hard practice for the Winter Olympics either here or at other points in Europe, but her bobsledders are suffering from inactivity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- A resolution providing for an appropriation of $7,369 to complete hearings and pay for the preparation and printing of a report was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Nye, chairman of the Munitions Investigating Committee.

Several railroads in the Pocahontas coal regions refrained from joining other lines in the petition filed last week with the Interstate Commerce Commission for an indefinite continuance of the surcharges that are to end on June 30, examination of the petition disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- The stock markets here were quiet but firm today. British funds improved, although business still was restricted. Foreign issues were idle except Brazilians, which were higher on reports of better South American trade.

DUBLIN, Jan. 27. -- The government of the Irish Free State will be represented at the funeral of King George by its High Commissioner, John W. Dulanty. Several Irishmen, including the Lord Mayor of Dublin, Alfred Bryne, are in London to attend the funeral, but no member of the government will be present.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The $2,491,000,000 "baby bond" Bonus Bill became law at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon when the Senate voted 76 to 19 to override President Roosevelt's veto. Every member voted.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- There are more signs now than at any previous time since Adolf Hitler came to power that the Catholic and Protestant churches are both on the way to an understanding with the Nazi State.

Standardized financial statements for all branches of retailing, including department stores, specialty shops, installment selling and chain stores, was urged by Herman Herwood, of Herwood Herwood, public accountants, last night. Mr. Herwood was one of the speakers at a meeting of the New York Credit Men's Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania, at which the question of the evaluation of statements by retailers was discussed.
Housing and business property deals in Greenwich Village, the upper East Side and the lower West Side were among the Manhattan realty items listed yesterday.

One hundred and fifty industrial executives, editors and chemists had the experience yesterday of mixing chemicals and creating synthetic rubber on the linen of their own dining tables. Gathered at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore, they pushed aside their dishes and silverware and under the direction of the inventor of the product tried their hands at amateur chemistry.

The death of the pivot play, like the story of Mark Twain's demise, is "slightly exaggerated." That point was brought forth very forcibly last Saturday at the Garden double-header as Long Island University, Temple and St. John's resurrected the bucket play and set it up all over the court.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 28. -- The body of King George will be borne across his capital today in a cavalcade more solemn than any London has known in a quartercentury and more gorgeous than any this democratic age is likely to see again.

Funeral services will be held at l noon today for George W. Wickersham, former Attorney General of the United States, at St. George's Church, Sixteenth Street and Stuyvesant Square. Bishop William T. Manning, assisted by Dr. Karl Reiland, rector of St. George's, will conduct the service.

ATLANTA, Jan. 27. -- Ten thousand Democrats are expected to gather in Macon on Wednesday to hear Governor Eugene Talmadge and others denounce the New Deal as communistic and help map a campaign by which the leaders hope to block President Roosevelt's renomination.

Two elementary school seniors who conquered physical and economic handicaps to win the respect of their classmates and teachers were selected yesterday as recipients of the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Prizes of $150 each. They will receive the awards Thursday morning from Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
MIAMI, Jan. 27. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor made several important decisions today concerning the future status of affiliated automobile workers. The council decided:
ALBANY, Jan. 27 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, up-State WPA administrator, announced today approval of forty-four work relief projects with allocations of $1,206,697.28.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP). -- Sectional differences were shown today as hearings opened on the Ellenbogen bill for Federal regulation of the textile industry.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 27. -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors unanimously adopted today the resolution calling on the State Legislature to approve a new county charter plan submitted by the Committee on Governmental Revision and drawn under the terms of the Fearon amendment for the improvement of county government systems.

Four city displays showing New York's progress in recent years are featured in the fifth Building Modernization Exposition which opened yesterday afternoon at the Lincoln Building. The interior of an old tenement flat torn down two years ago and reassembled, a part of the exhibit of the New York City Housing Authority, attracted considerable attention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP). -- A showdown fight between young left-wing leaders and old line unions for control of the nation's maritime labor appeared certain tonight after revocation of the charter of the Sailors' Union of the Pacific by the International Seamen's Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- A mysterious memorandum which now is regarded to have been the cause of the decline of the dollar on the international exchange market last week, and of countless rumors of devaluation and other monetary manipulations, has been traced by Secretary Morgenthau to an unidentified author, with the result that the Treasury has "stopped worrying."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 27. -- That the Left Liberal government of Colombia is alarmed at the rise of communism here is shown by a message from the Minister of Government to the Governor of the State of Antioquia with reference to the outlaw textile workers' strike at Envigado.
Joey Ferrando, Jersey City lightweight, outpointed Fritzie Zivic of Pittsburgh last night in the feature bout of eight rounds before a crowd of 2,500 at the St. Nicholas Palace.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 28. -- In a last tribute of love and affection to their father, King Edward VIII and his three brothers, in full dress uniform, took up guard over his coffin in Westminster Hall at midnight for a brief period.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 27. -- Charles Whitehead of South River, N.J., representing the Forsgate Country Club of Jamesburg, N.J., aided by an eagle 3 on the eighth hole, won the qualifying medal today in the ninth annual national championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine links.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -The Boerse opened the week firm but at the i close there were some signs of softness. Heavy industrials rose, Vereinigtestahl gaining 1 points, with a fairly heavy turnover for the Berlin market. Aachines were firmer, Berlin Kar]sruhe gaining 1 points.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 27 (AP). -- The behavior of officers when Ozie Powell, one of the Scottsboro case Negroes, was shot after a knife attack on a deputy sheriff aiding in the transfer of the Negroes to jail here was commended today by Governor Bibb Graves.

The value of internationalists among American seamen was emphasized yesterday by speakers who addressed a class of thirty-six cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at the semi-annual commencement exercises on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- Soviet history textbooks are too dry and the teaching of history in Soviet schools, instead of being interesting and lively, with the historical characters made real and all important facts and events presented in chronological order, has been a series of abstract definitions of social and economic phenomena, says a decree from the Kremlin today.

WINSTED, Conn., Jan. 27. -- Pheasants purchased from Newton and Burnett, Hartford, by John Lavieri, proprietor Old North Road Inn near Winsted, revived today by warm sun while hanging by foot in front of inn Stop Pheasant escaped although fired upon by Deputy Game Warden William Lowe, a witness Stop One remaining bird struck on head as precaution against coming to life Stop Both birds cold on arrival Stop -- A.L. Chapman.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt submitted yesterday to Surrogate James A. Foley her final household bills, totaling $4,477.42, incurred in the keeping of her home at 49 East Seventy-second Street during 1935. Thomas B. Gilchrist, as guardian of her daughter's estate, had refused to pay the sum unless itemized bills were rendered.

Net profit of the American Hide and Leather Company in the last six months of 1935 amounted to $313,688 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent, after six months' dividend requirements on 100,000 shares of $50-par new 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, to 32 cents a share on 512,741 shares of $1-par common stock, excluding 2,259 shares in the treasury.

The blue-denimed phantom burglar who slipped through 200 policemen after looting five offices and shooting Tony Petrone, a watchman, in the Woolworth Building on Sunday, completed his escape yesterday.

ATHENS, Jan. 27. -- The National Assembly, in which Venizelists are deadlocked with anti-Venizelists after yesterday's election, each being within a score of votes from mastery, was presented to King George II by Premier Constantine Demerdjis today as the stuff from which the monarchy's first popularly elected Cabinet must be formed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- Prices for wheat held within a range of 1/2 cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade. There was an absence of the Eastern buying which was so much in evidence on Saturday, and there also was a lack of aggressive selling, the latter being held in check by inflation talk, the strength in stocks and reports of a better shipping demand for cash grain.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Pierre-Etienne Flandin, former Premier of France and now Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Sarraut government, has arrived in London, ostensibly to accompany President Lebrun to the funeral of King George, but in reality with the object of discussing problems of great importance with the British Government.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27. -- R.A. Coward's Sir Michael, winner of his last two starts in a breeze, came through with another easy triumph today in accounting for the mile and seventy yard feature at the Fair Grounds.

More than 23,000 veterans here and 300,000 throughout the country who are on home relief or work relief may be dropped from the relief rolls in June when they receive "baby bonds" in accordance with the Bonus Bill enacted yesterday by Congress.

Etienne Amyot, South African pianist, made his American debut at the Town Hall last night, presenting a program of music by Brahms and Schumann. The visiting artist disclosed a talent that was at its best in intimate music, which be communicated with warmth and poetry.

Competition in the tenth annual De Witt Clinton High School invitation indoor interscholastic tennis tournament started on the courts of the 369th Regiment Armory yesterday with an entry of ninety-two players, the largest in the history of the event.

A total of thirty-three players will report to Manager Joe McCarthy when the Yankees get their complete squad working at St. Petersburg in the Spring, according to the club's official roster distributed yesterday.

WINDSOR, England, Jan. 27. --Thousands of persons standing outside Windsor Castle today watched 150 bluejackets of the fleet drag the historic gun carriage from the station to St. George's Chapel, as they will tomorrow when it bears King George's body on its last journey, and saw a detachment of the sovereign's company of Grenadier Guards carry a dummy coffin up the steps to the chancel.

Saturday's advance on the Cotton Exchange not only failed to attract new business yesterday but ran the market into an increased supply of contracts. As a result the list was set back 3 to 11 points. Uncertainty over the proposal for a start on distribution of government holdings influenced near months, while delay on measures for continuance of crop control reduced new crop support.

Sufferers from the current neutrality neurosis overlook the fact that it is as imprudent for people in glass houses to throw stones as it is for a nation dependent on imported raw materials to lay down the precedent of embargoing raw materials as a neutrality principle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP). -- Fingerprints will identify veterans on the application blanks for their bonus bonds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- A Supreme Court review was asked today by Mallory H. Taylor Jr. and Curtis J. Hazlerigs of their convictions arising from allegations that they sought to capitalize the name of Warm Springs, health resort sponsored by President Roosevelt, in shipping Glauber's Salts as "Warm Springs Crystal Compound."

The first New York performance of Rimsky-Korsakoff's opera, "The Invisible City of Kitezh" will be presented by the Art of Musical Russia Company and the Philadelphia Orchestra on March 3 at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Through Chester C. Davis, Farm Administrator, the Roosevelt administration today gave word of its intention to rely entirely on the principle of States' rights in carrying out its permanent program of agricultural recovery.

In an opinion that traced the Hebraic law back to Moses, Supreme Court Justice McCook handed down a decision yesterday upholding the right of the Kashruth Association of New York, a semi-official organization of laymen and orthodox Jewish rabbis, to declare a ban against all poultry not killed under the supervision of the organization and not bearing leg-bands or seals sold by it.

VIENNA, Jan. 27. -- Hans Knappertsbusch, for thirteen years general music director of the Munich State Opera, has been deprived of his passport and thus prevented from leaving Germany, according to a statement published in the Vienna Sonn und Montag Zeitung, which says its information comes from trustworthy Munich circles.

District Attorney William C. Dodge, at the request of the Furniture Trade Committee, representing legitimate retail furniture dealers in the metropolitan area, ordered yesterday an extensive investigation of a furniture racket in this city.
Sales of several apartment houses in the Bronx were included in the list of transactions reported for that borough yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- A revised Neutrality Bill, imposing on the President the duty of laying embargoes on all war materials in accordance with the terms of existent trade treaties, was reported out today by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Indeterminate penitentiary sentences not to exceed three years each were imposed yesterday by Justices Hackenburg, Flood and Gresser in Special Sessions upon eight principals in the United Relief Association for defrauding hundreds of persons in a "charity racket."
Money market was dull and except for renewals little new business was involved. Quotations continued unchanged.

Final arrangements for a strike of 20,000 elevator operators and other building service employes in more than 1,200 buildings in the garment and fur district were completed yesterday at a meeting of the strike committee of the Building Service Employes Union at the union's office, 570 Seventh Avenue.

Voluntary health insurance for workers of restricted income and the liberalization of laws relating to birth control and abortion were advocated last night at a meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New York, at the New York Academy of Medicine, by Dr. Charles Everett Farr, in his inaugural address as incoming president of the county society.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, who heads the executive committee for the Birthday Ball for the President, to be held Thursday in the main ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria, will give a tea tomorrow in her home, 47 East Sixty-fifth Street, for members of the women's press committee.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 27. -- Heralding a vigorous campaign in Pennsylvania for the renomination and re-election of President Roosevelt, the Democratic State Committee today endorsed the President's official acts and bound sixteen nominees for delegates-at-large to the national convention to enter the primary pledged to the Roosevelt-Garner ticket.

Gains and losses were about evenly divided on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with sugar, cocoa, rubber and cottonseed oil among the firmer staples. Coffee and hides eased and others were irregular. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, cocoa and rubber advanced. Cotton, silk, pork and beef declined.

Mariette Lydis, Viennese by birth and education but now a resident of Paris, is having her first American one-man show, which opened yesterday at the Marie Sterner Galleries, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until Feb. 8.
Eight Manhattan parcels were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The results were as follows:

Philip W. Barber, acting regional director of the Federal Theatre Project, announced yesterday that, he would continue the policies, personnel and production plans introduced by Elmer Rice, who resigned as regional director Thursday night.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Darby Co., Inc., and the Baum, Bernheimer Company, won yesterday the award of two new bond issues of Kansas City, Mo., aggregating $1,500,000.

HONOLULU, Jan. 27. -- Aboard an army airplane the remains of Father Damien de Veuster, priest of Molokai, who gave his life for the sufferers in the leper settlement at Kalupapa reached Honolulu at 3 P.M. today on the first stage of their journey to Belgium, the priest's homeland.

Tammany will send former Governor Alfred E. Smith as a Congressional district delegate to the Democratic National Convention if he wishes to go, it became known yesterday from an authoritative source.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27. -- Willie Hunter of Los Angeles blasted the heavily trapped Lake Merced course with sub-par golf on the last round and defeated Willie Goggin, San Francisco, 4 and 2, today for the San Francisco match play open title.

The consolidated balance sheet of the New York Stock Exchange, New York Stock Exchange Building Company, New York Quotation Company, Stock Clearing Corporation, New York Stock Exchange Safe Deposit Company and 39 Broad Street Corporation follows:

Dr. Hsiung, the diminutive poet from China, has found Western pundits so belligerently ignorant of Oriental drama that we must be doubly careful what we say about "Lady Precious Stream," which opened at the Booth last evening. This is Dr. Hsiung's translation of a venerable Chinese drama with which he captivated London audiences a year ago and which Morris Gest has persuaded him to bring to America.

Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society and the State Chamber of Commerce, urged business men yesterday to use their power and influence with their employes to counteract the "demagogic and foolish doctrines" of the present administration.

MONTREAL, Jan. 27. -- Change of his wingmen seems in no way to have dimmed the luster of Frank Boucher, veteran center of the New York Rangers, who scored two goals and an assist last week to take over scoring leadership of the National Hockey League's American group.

Ball players, some of whom become embroiled in spirited salary disputes at this time of the season, found themselves with a strange ally yesterday when Albert D. (Dolly) Stark, the umpire, declared in unequivocal terms that for the present he is to be considered a holdout.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Jan. 22 shows increases for the week of $56,000,000 in total loans and investments and $66,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and a decrease of $88,000,000 in government deposits.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 27. -- Grand Circuit stewards pointed tonight to a thirteen-week racing schedule for 1936, compared with nine weeks last year, as evidence of the increased popularity of harness events.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 (AP). -- The steamship Amapala, cruise !ship of the Standard Fruit and Steamship Company, was severely damaged today when it was rammed by the oil tanker Camden in the :Mississippi River about sixty miles below New Orleans.

ROME, Jan. 27. -- Today's official war bulletin again shifts interest to the Somaliland front, where General Rodolfo Graziani's smashing victory last week is assuming ever greater proportions. One index of the damage inflicted by the Italians is given by the Ethiopian casualties, which are now stated to total 10,000 killed.

Press comments on the enactment of the veterans' bonus was considerably concerned with the source of the money to pay for it, some warning of inflation and one reminding the ex-service men of the taxpayers' "self-denial." Several declared that the law did not end the problem, but only opened the way for pension drives in the future.

The decision of Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler to take jurisdiction over the reorganization of the Lawyers Mortgage Company and to appoint a referee to hold hearings on the fairness of the plan of reorganization required by the creditors' committee of the mortgage company was praised yesterday by Mortimer N. Buckner, chairman of the committee, who said the decision was "most constructive and in consequence will help the whole mortgage situation."

HAVANA, Jan. 27. -- Adrian Iselin 2d today piloted his Western Long Island Sound boat Ace to victory in two races and captured the Cup of Cuba for international Star Class yachts for the second consecutive year.

One of the arguments said to have influenced members of Congress to vote for the Bonus Bill was that it must be "taken out of politics." For more than ten years it had been deeply in politics, troubling Representatives and Senators at Washington and filling them with fears of what might happen when they came up for re-election.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 27. -- Serious disorders broke out today among students at Damanhour and Mansorah, resulting in clashes with the police. In the former town five students were wounded, one dying tonight. In the latter village three were hurt, while in both places many policemen suffered severe injuries.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27. -- "Sportier" clothing, with "more extreme" cuts, was predicted for men's wear next Spring as members of the International Association of Clothing Designers began a four-day session here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- Governor Martin L. Davey's football joke became officially known as such today.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- King Edward followed his father's precedent tonight by giving a dinner at Buckingham Palace for five Kings, Haakon of Norway, Christian of Denmark, Leopold of the Belgians, Boris of Bulgaria and Carol of Rumania, who have come to London for tomorrow's funeral of King George V.

GOETEBORG, Sweden, Jan. 27. -- The decision of the Council of the League of Nations to appoint a committee of experts to inquire into the probable effectiveness of an embargo on oil against Italy has caused concern in the Scandinavian countries.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- Management by the trustees of properties underlying $35,195,204 invested in the certificates of the two largest mortgage companies in Westchester County resulted last year in $865,000 being made available to certificate holders, the trustees announced today.

At the first of this month 35,319 white-collar employes were engaged on 200 service projects under the WPA here, and the work they do is not "boondoggling," according to a report submitted yesterday to Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator by Walter M. Langsdorf, assistant administrator in charge of services.

The writer who signs herself "A Sister in Sorrow" is most decidedly in the wrong about the service of the New York Public Library. I have used that really great institution for twenty-five years and I have never known a body of public employes anywhere, in this country or Europe, more responsive, more capable, or more willing to go out of their way to aid readers pursuing a legitimate purpose.

Hope of averting the threatened strike of 105,000 dressmakers, scheduled for Feb. 1, rose yesterday after Mayor La Guardia had prevailed upon the employers and employes to resume the deadlocked negotiations.

The Columbia Club continued its advance toward the Class C championship of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association yesterday by winning its eighth straight match and thus moving within a step of clinching the title. However, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, in second place, followed right along, so that the encounter between the two next week will settle the issue.

The New York Stock Exchange reduced its operating loss from $1,060,890 in 1934 to $209,325 in 1935 and at the same time improved its balance sheet cash position by $448,616, it was shown yesterday in the Exchange's second annual pamphlet report to its members.

Coming from behind after trailing by 45 -- 5 in the early stages of his match, Edward C. Rogers of Glen Cove, L.I., conquered Herbert Courtney of New York, 125 to 82, to gain undisputed ossession of first place in the national amateur pocket billiard championship at the Strand Academy last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- President Roosevelt named six of the seven members of the new Federal Reserve Board who will take office on Feb. 1. Following overturn of his veto of the Bonus Bill by the Senate he held conferences with officials of veterans' organizations to expedite issuance of the bonus bonds and urge veterans who do not need the money to hold them as investments.

LAST year John Steinbeck wrote "Tortilla Flat," a sunny book about some amoral, wine-guzzling vagabonds who lived, philandered and roistered without benefit of money or clergy in the more poverty-stricken section of Monterey, Calif. Reviewers promptly compared Mr. Steinbeck with Victoria Lincoln and Robert Nathan, and the best-seller lists each week have continued to testify to Mr. Steinbeck's hold on the capacious American heart.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27. -- The trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, which is under a reorganization process in court, today petitioned the Federal district court here for permission to buy ten Diesel engines at a cost of $65,000 each for use in switching in the Boston, Providence, Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport yards.

Democrats in Congress seem to be trying to do all they can to magnify the importance of Governor SMITH'S speech. If the blow he struck wasn't a hard one, why get so hot about it? It is natural that the Republicans should crow loudly, but they are only translating their wishes into predictions.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

A word of sorrowful farewell must be spoken when one who notably served THE TIMES for forty years passes from this mortal scene. An account of the life and career of Mr. MORTIMER, who died yesterday, is printed elsewhere in this issue. Here there is room and occasion only for a brief tribute to his personality by his associates in this office.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 27 (AP). -- A group of nearly 200 peasant women seized the Santa Barbara ranch of former President Plutarco Elias Calles yesterday but abandoned it tonight in the face of a threatened attack by employes of the ranch.

Not only can man fly an airplane "blind" by the use of visual instruments in the cockpit, but he can fly safely when actually blindfolded, using the sense of hearing alone. This has been demonstrated in flight, it was ascertained yesterday.

Of the six seeded players who were scheduled to play in the opening matches of the Class A singles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association two had short careers in the annual event which began yesterday at the University Club.

Competition in the small artichoke trade ended and fear spread among merchants when the Union Pacific Produce Company began business at 203 West Street early in 1930, it was testified yesterday in Federal court.

With New York showing the way with a total outlay of $143,350,992, forty key cities throughout the country showed substantial increases last year in building permits over the totals for 1934 and 1933, according to a study of construction activity by E.M. Craig, executive secretary of the National Association of Building Trades Employers.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27. -- Columbiana, bay daughter of Petee-Wrack, essayed a mile for the first time in the Key Largo Purse at Hialeah Park today and emerged a handy winner over seven other 3-year-olds. The W.J. Hirscl, color-bearer, recent winner here at six furlongs, ran one of her characteristic races, closing powerfully from a sluggish beginning and scoring by a length and a half.

Six Sunnyside Gardens home owners who were arrested Saturday for trying to halt the eviction of Mr. and Mrs. William Thal from their foreclosed home at 39-26 Forty-fourth Street were paroled for hearings Feb. 14 when they pleaded not guilty before Magistrate O'Brien in Long Island City Court to charges of disorderly conduct.

Lord and Lady Trent, Colonel F.P. and Lady Victoria Braithwaite, Mary Boot and J.H. Jarrett, Colonial Secretary of the Bahamas, are among the passengers due from England today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.
New York City will pay tribute today to King George, whose funeral will take place this morning in London.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The greatest dangers to the nation come from those within its borders who are "resorting to a conspiracy to nullify the Constitution," Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, declared here tonight. He called nullification "a fraudulent device, a swindler's resource, a weak man's expedient."

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27. -- The National Conference of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds concluded its annual assembly here today in the understanding that American and British Jews were already committed to the withdrawal of the younger generation of Jews from Germany.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 28. -- The collapse of China's controlled-currency plan, with a financial panic in April, is predicted by the newspaper Nichi Nichi, which asserts its statements are based on reports reaching reliable quarters in Tokyo from all parts of China.

Mr. JONES'S account of the activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, over the whole period of its operations since early 1932, is the record of a useful and successfully managed institution. During the four years of its existence RFC has loaned a grand total of eight billion dollars, of which two billions went to other governmental agencies and to relief.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 27. -- The Passaic police announced this afternoon that they had obtained a confession from Mrs. Elizabeth Fiederer, 38 years old, of 201 Parker Avenue, that she turned on the gas that took the lives of her husband and their three small children in their flat last Tuesday.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 27. -- Ethiopian Ambulance Unit 3, stationed near Makale and staffed by two Irishmen, Captain Brophil and Dr. Hickey; a British Indian, Dr. Ahmed, and an Austrian, Dr. Schuppler, was bombed twice on Jan. 18 by Italians, according to telegrams from these three doctors, received at northern headquarters at Dessye yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Philadelphia will get back manifold the money it raised for the Democratic National Convention, including the extra $50,000 which quenched the hopes of Chicago in a Danaean shower. Since Al Smith made his "take-a-walk" speech Saturday night, the Republican show at Cleveland went into the suburban circuit.
ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- Sale of $75,000,000 in short-term notes of the State of New York was announced today by State Controller Morris S. Tremaine.

During 1935 the Young Men's Christian Association of the City of New York found jobs for 16,537 young men, according to the annual statement presented yesterday afternoon to the association's board of directors.

Activity in the financial section and on the securities and commodity markets throughout the country generally will be one hour late in getting under way this morning as a mark of respect to King George. Trading on the New York Stock and the New York Curb Exchanges will not commence until 11 o'clock, and all local commodity markets will likewise delay their openings.
Gleanings from notebook and mailbag:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Invocation of the Corrupt Practices Act, with its heavy fines and jail sentences, against the leaders of the Townsend old-age pension movement, is being considered in Congress.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27. -- Several thousand persons were delayed for more than an hour in reaching New York, and New Jersey communities, during the rush hour tonight when a Pennsylvania Railroad electric engine was stalled on the tracks used by the Hudson Manhattan railroad tube trains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The payment of the veterans' bonus is probably the most tremendous task ever given to the Treasury Department, Secretary Morgenthau said today. He was referring chiefly to the job of distributing the bonds to veterans and to the subsequent problem of paying cash to those holders who present the securities at postoffices or other places designated for payment.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The United States guide book now being compiled by 5,000 WPA writers will be very nearly 2,700,000 words long and will cost almost exactly that number of dollars. But it is not the expense that first leaps to the mind.

Following his sudden trade of Glenn Brydson for Howie Morenz, star forward of the Chicago Black Hawks, announced on Sunday before the Ranger sextet left Chicago with a 2-1 defeat, Lester Patrick made public another drastic change in the line-up of the Blue Shirts when he arrived here with his team last night.

The action of W. Earle Andrews, general superintendent of the Parks Department, who discharged a WPA band after its members had refused to play in Central Park Sunday because of the cold weather, drew comment yesterday approving Mr. Andrews's stand but denying that he had the right to discharge WPA workers.

A crowd of about 3,000 flocked to Madison Square Garden last night for the opening bouts in the annual championship boxing tournament of the Metropolitan A.A.U. This renewal of the annual fixture attracted the largest entry in several years and the competition ran true to tradition, with boxing that was good, bad, indifferent and funny.

As the first step toward the introduction of a new service rating plan for the city's 80,000 civil service employes, James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, wrote yesterday to the Borough Presidents, the Controller and the President of the Board of Aldermen requesting them to attend a conference Feb. 4 to consider the new system.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 27. -- Governor Hoffman sent a special message to the Legislature tonight asking passage of accompanying bills to create a Palisades Interstate Park Commission by interstate compact with New York. Similar legislation must be enacted by New York and the compact ratified by Congress before it becomes effective.

It was possible, prior to the performance of "Gianni Sehicchi" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, to hear the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conductor, play in Carnegie Hall, with Shuts Cherkassky, then making his first public appearance in this city since his recent European tour, in the performance of Tchaikovsky's B-flat minor piano concerto.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Alfred E. Smith's speech before the American Liberty League stirred up a caustic debate in the House today, and an attack on the New Yorker by Representative Woodrum of Virginia for his threat to "take a walk" from the Philadelphia convention brought the Democratic members to their feet in a noisy ovation.

Following a new cold wave that struck the city yesterday and was expected to drive the mercury to zero or lower early this morning, the weather will moderate somewhat later in the day, according to the official forecast last night. Continued rising temperatures were predicted for tomorrow, with light snow probable tomorrow night.
Plaintive whimperings in a freshly dug den at the Central Park Zoo disclosed yesterday that some time since last Friday one of the zoo's two female black bears had given birth to cubs.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- Republicans in the home State of President Roosevelt and Alfred E. Smith are preparing to take the utmost party advantage of the lead furnished by Mr. Smith's Liberty League address for their own attack on the New Deal policies.

The preamble of a bill introduced into the House by Representative VITO MARCANTONIO presents a harrowing picture of the ravages wrought by silicosis among laborers who drove the power tunnel of the Hawks Nest hydroelectric project in West Virginia and of the cruelty of the contracting firm -- too harrowing indeed for acceptance at its face value.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 27. -- Only three New Jersey players remained in the sixth annual New Jersey women's open squash racquets championship today at the close of the first day's play at the Short Hills Club. Philadelphia had three players among the eight surviving, New York one and Boston one.

Long an important figure in Congregational Church circles, Dr. Stocking was elected national moderator of the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches of the United States on June 26, 1934, at Oberlin, Ohio. Before that he had served as chairman of the commission on missions of the council, which has national headquarters at 287 Fourth Avenue.

Three corporations and four individuals were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury for running machine guns to Bolivia during the war between that country and Paraguay growing out of the Gran Chaco boundary dispute.

The obvious amusement and interest shown by a large audience in the Metropolitan Opera Association's performance last night of Puccini's "Giant Schicchi" was proof that there are occasions and there are operas which do very well when sung in English.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The Irish Free State has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $30,773,830 of its external loan sinking fund 5 per cent gold bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1960.

The children were clearly in charge, although none were present, at a "luncheon in honor of parents" at the Commodore Hotel yesterday under the auspices of the Child Study Association of America. Some 800 fathers and mothers who were told by the speakers that they were representatives of a precarious, if not a vanishing, social entity.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 27. -- Memphis members of the Jackson Society of Tennessee in an open letter to Alfred E. Smith today sharply challenged his "insinuations" that Jackson and Jefferson were different "in policy and creed" from President Roosevelt.

THEY couldn't have picked a better time for it. Meaning the trading of Glenn Brydson for Howie Morenz on the hockey front. Here comes Howie just in time to drape himself in a Ranger uniform and take the ice against his old comrades of years ago, Le Club de Hockey Canadien.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP). -- The House today received an $81,221,330 Interior Department Supply Bill from the Appropriations Committee.

The annual report of the Central States Electric Corporation for 1935 puts the year-end market value of the company's assets at $37,364,239, compared with $17,569,193 at the end of 1934, a gain of almost 113 per cent. The book value was set at $49,200,103 compared with $67,934,033 the year before.

Latin America is substantially out of the depression and business there will be normal or better in 1936, according to S.G. Wharin of Argentina, manager in South America for the International Business Machines Corporation. Mr. Wharin was one of the speakers yesterday at the annual business congress of the corporation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Pursuing his determination to find out if any of the evidence against Bruno Richard Hauptmann was framed, Governor Harold G. Hoffman declared today that Dr. John F. Condon, -- Jafsie of the Lindbergh ransom payment -- should be questioned vigorously when he returns to the United States.

On the eve of his eviction from his foreclosed home at 93-12 Ninety-first Street, Woodhaven, Queens, friends in Providence, R.I., indicated that they would provide funds to aid Dr. Albert Harrison Brundage, authority on toxicology and public health service.
ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- Liberalization of the State's divorce law to permit a decree after three years' desertion was proposed today in a bill introduced by Miss Jane Todd, Westchester Republican.

While business failures declined in the retail and wholesale divisions in the week ended Jan. 23, compared with the previous week, there was an increase in the manufacturing group, according to the survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 28. -- The Yale University basketball team scored its third straight triumph by conquering a hard-fighting Georgetown five, 44 to 38, tonight. The home forces, after rolling up the commanding lead of 31 -- 17 in the initial period, had to check a thrilling last-half drive by the visitors before winning.

Plans are being made by the governors of the New York Stock Exchange to remodel the entire eleventh floor of the Exchange tower at 11 Wall Street and to consolidate there offices of five standing committees which now are on the sixth floor of the building at 18 Broad Street.

It is now just twenty years since the public became familiar with the slogan "Sing Sing Must Go." Even before that the old cells, built in 1825, were publicly condemned as unsanitary and inhumane. It was thought that they were all doomed when, in 1916, the Legislature provided for the rebuilding of the prison.

Registrations of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday were considerable less than tin he preceding week. The total, however, was slightly above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much moved by the two articles in this morning's TIMES about Fred Mortimer Such articles are not called forth by statesmen or generals or scientists or anybody but a friend, a comrade, a very remarkable man. And I think Fred Mortimer was the most remarkable man I ever knew or knew of.

An action to set aside the will of Miss Mary G. Thompson, 91-year-old philanthropist, descendant of Lord Gardiner and a member of one of America's oldest families, was started yesterday by her grandnephew, Robert David Lion Gardiner of 812 Park Avenue, on the ground that undue influence was exerted on her when the will disposing of $18,000,000 was drawn.

A program of Hungarian folk music, a sound film and addresses on current issues in Hungary was presented last night in the McMillin Academic Theatre of Columbia University under the auspices of the university's Institute of Arts and Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The thousands of World War veterans who have never claimed their adjusted service compensation certificates and may wish to do so now that Congress has voted full and immediate payment in "baby bonds" may obtain the certificates by a simple procedure.

During the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1935, the average family supported by a wage-earner in the income-tax paying group paid more than thirty taxes to the Federal Government, according to an analysis of internal revenue collections by Laurence Arnold Tanzer that the Merchants Association of New York released yesterday.

Nineteen cases of epidemic meningitis and five deaths from this disease were reported to the Department of Health last week, it was disclosed yesterday. In the same week last year four cases and no deaths were reported, while in 1934 there was one case and one death during the third week of January.
Eleven contributions totaling $1,062 were received for the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the Fund's total to $252,672.87.

When the "superstitious faith" now placed in the economic power of the government is abandoned, "Wall Street" is likely to be blamed for whatever the government has not done, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, predicted last night in urging business men to cooperate in a movement to counteract popular prejudices against the Stock Exchange and Wall Street.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Dispatches to London tonight indicate this was the greatest day of mourning in the history of the world. In capitals of the British Dominions, in the chief towns of colonies and in imperial fortresses like Malta and Gibraltar churches were packed, guns boomed their salutes and the whole life of the empire paused for two minutes of silence.

Fingerprinting of civil service candidates for laborers' jobs has resulted in the discovery that thirty men were obtaining city pay checks twice a month by pretending to be men appointed to such jobs who actually had died or disappeared, James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Unequivocal support of President Roosevelt and the New Deal, coupled with a sharp attack on former Governor Smith as "a gibbering political jackanapes," marked the keynote speech of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, at the opening of the constitutional convention of the miners' union in Constitution Hail today.
Exports and imports from and the United States by classified into groups of merchandise during 1935, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with those in 1934 and 1933.

Final efforts to avert the threatened strike of 105,000 dressmakers in this city and vicinity were under way yesterday as a result of the intervention of Mayor La Guardia on Monday and his appeal to employers and employes to do everything in their power to avoid the walkout.

John Kirkpatrick, a tall young American pianist, has an all-embracing sympathy for the works of American composers. It was an enthusiastic audience that greeted Mr. Kirkpatrick, a pupil of Isidor Philipp, in his debut at the Town Hall last night and rendered more than ample approval for his strong propensity for the modern school of music.

A point system for the selection of tenants for Harlem River Houses, the $4,700,000 PWA low-rental housing project at 151st Street and the Harlem River, was recommended to the New York City Housing Authority in a report submitted yesterday to the Harlem Housing Committee, composed of Negro welfare and civic workers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The text of Senator Robinson's reply to the recent Liberty League address by Alfred E. Smith was as follows:

The bonus rush started yesterday. About 35,000 application blanks for settlement of the veterans' adjusted service certificates were distributed from the New York regional office of the Veterans Administration and about 5,000 veterans applied in person for the blanks at the offices, Ninth Avenue and Thirtieth Street.

Increased activity in the midtown garment, millinery and fur sections was reported by brokers yesterday. Among other business lessees was the National Association of Gardeners, which, after twenty-five years in 522 Fifth Avenue, has taken quarters in the RKO Building, Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Giuseppe M. Bellanca, airplane manufacturer, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that L. Sherman Adams, a broker of Boston and New York, represented M.J. Meehan in a fight for control of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation's policies early in 1930.

The last-minute entry of Norman Bright of the Olympic Club, San Francisco, in the classic Wanamaker Mile, traditional feature of the twenty-ninth annual Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night, was announced yesterday by Fred Schmertz, director of the meet.

The first forty-four railroads to report showed net operating income of $29,146,000 in December, against $23,101,000 in December, 1934, an increase of 26.2 per cent, and against $18,820,000 in December, 1933, a rise of 54.8 per cent. These companies had net operating income of $29,967,000 in November, up 54.3 per cent from November, 1934.
For many years I have been an admirer of ex-Governor Smith. I must withdraw my allegiance after his performance of last Saturday night.

The Actors Equity Association on Monday ordered suspended the rehearsals of its members in "The Eternal Road," which Max Reinhardt has been directing. It was said that money due the chorus had not been paid, nor could rehearsal expense money be given to the other members of the cast when it falls due today.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 28. -- Governor Oscar Kelly Allen, who inherited the leadership of Senator Huey P. Long's forces after the Senator died from a gunshot wound Sept. 10, died suddenly in the Executive Mansion today of cerebral hemorrhage.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (by Wireless). -- Among the host of princes and personalities who came to London to attend the funeral of King George V, Crown Prince Humbert of Italy stands out in the public interest and occupies much of such public attention as the Britons can spare from their dead King.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
The field in the Class A championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association was reduced to sixteen last night as six more players advanced to the third round at the University Club.

Charles Shankroff, Brooklyn resident, who sued Mayor La Guardia when the Mayor called him a "bum" and a "faker" but lost his case, was ordered yesterday to pay $10,000 for damages he is alleged to have caused Samuel Henis, an attorney.
