WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The entire PWA loan to the New York Port Authority for construction of the midtown tunnel, linking Manhattan and New Jersey, which originally had been set at $37,500,000, has been changed to an outright Federal grant of $4,780,000, Secretary Ickes announced today.

Marvin Kantrowitz, last year's winner and top-seeded star, representing Clinton, made his debut in the tenth annual De Witt Clinton High School invitation indoor interscholastic tennis tournament yesterday and defeated Morris Kaufman of New Utrecht in a second-round test.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- The Right Rev. William Procter Remington, Bishop of the Eastern Oregon Missionary District of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was unanimously elected dean of the Philadelphia Divinity School today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Testimony describing as "ridiculous" the Van Sweringen plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad was received today at a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission. It was given by James H. McIntosh of New York, who was seeking the commission's approval of a $75,000 fee for legal services of himself and associate counsel in one of the gold clause suits.

The Brooklyn Cathedral Prep and St. John's Prep quintets triumphed and remained in a deadlock for first place in the race for the Brooklyn Division C.H.S.A.A. crown yesterday. Cathedral repulsed Bishop Loughlin Memorial High, 24 -- 17, in the afternoon at Loughlin, and St. John's beat St. Augustine's by virtue of a gallant second-half rally, 28 -- 27, at St. John's at night.
LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Amid a popular outpouring such as London had never known, King George was borne through the streets of his capital for the last time today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The navy "took a walk" in almost wholesale fashion today from the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense in protest against an attack on the Roosevelt administration delivered last night by Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State.

Mrs. Mary Breckinridge, volunteer director of the Frontier Nursing Service, which cares for the Kentucky mountaineers in a district of 1,000 square miles, making her annual report to the New York committee yesterday afternoon at the home of Miss Anne Morgan, 3 Sutton Place, said that work was progressing satisfactorily and that during the organization's ten years of existence it had received more than $1,000,000 in contributions.

Six persons were injured, four of them seriously enough to require hospital treatment, in a three-alarm fire, which started yesterday at 1:45 P.M. in a two-story frame building at 922 Putnam Avenue, near Ralph Avenue, Brooklyn, and spread to six adjoining three-story frame and brick houses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- President Roosevelt's increasing interest in politics was marked today as he talked with many prominent officials and then ended his day with a press conference.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Never did the American people more greatly need an intelligent and searching discussion of the issues before them for settlement at the polls. But if the beginning of the campaign is any criterion of what is to follow, they are not going to get it.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Completion of negotiations for the purchase of 200 acres of land for the future expansion of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton was announced here today by Dr. Abraham Flexner, director of the institute.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- Walter Cole, engineer of the West Shore Railroad's Weehawken-Albany "newspaper train," was killed this morning in a derailment of the train north of Haverstraw. It was the fourth railroad derailment in Rockland County within two days.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Secretary Ickes urged Progressive Republicans today to support President Roosevelt in the coming campaign.

Mr. and Mrs. Claude Oliver Brown gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Dorothy Nelson, a debutante. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marvin Nelson, parents of the debutante; Miss Ellen Fales, Walker Buchner, Ned Wilson, Ernest Hand and Wendel Palmer.

Dates were agreed upon, subject to possible minor adjustment, a tournament committee was appointed and a start was made toward this year's indoor polo championships by the executive committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America at a meeting held yesterday at the Lunch Club, 63 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The administration's $1,000,000,000 stop-gap farm-relief program, designed to replace the invalidated AAA and pave the way for a more permanent system of Federal grants in aid to States, will be ordered reported tomorrow by the Senate Committee on Agriculture, according to members.

ATHENS, Jan. 28. -- Marshal George Kondylis brought the negotiations between Themistocles Sophoulis, Venizelist leader, and former Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris for the formation of an anti-Kondylis Cabinet to a sharp halt today when he announced he would oppose vigorously any coalition attempting to reinstate rebel officers or refusing to recognize the full legality of King George's restoration during the Kondylis regency.
ROME, Jan. 28. -- General Rodolfo Graziani's southern army, fresh from a 290-mile drive northwest in Ethiopia, swung to the east today, Italian press reports said, in a new offensive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The administration Neutrality Bill was drafted with the dual purpose of keeping us out of wars and leaving unhampered our efforts to prevent future wars, the formal report of the bill by the House Foreign Affairs Committee stated today.

A denunciation of the planned economy of the New Deal was sounded last night by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, in an address before the Ivy Republican Club, 1,300 First Avenue, at Seventieth Street. Goodhue Livingstone Jr., president of the club, presided.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Curiosity was aroused in London tonight when it was learned that after the royal funeral services Sir John Simon, Secretary for Home Affairs, had broadcast a tribute to the late King to France, where it was relayed over the entire wireless system of that country.

ROME, Jan. 28. -- Usually well-informed Italian circles particularly emphasized in today's official war bulletin the statement that twenty-seven cases of munitions had been found in Swedish ambulance trucks captured by General Rodolfo Graziani near Wadara.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- The market for hogs was strong at the start but finished tamely. The early advance of 10 to 15 cents a hundred-weight was lost at the close, and the undertone was easier with a top of $10.25 which was hard to obtain, although early sales had been made as high as $10.40.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Miss Eileen Beresford of Short Hills, New Jersey's ranking women's player, who was seeded second, and Miss Charlotte Darling of Philadelphia, seeded third, gained the final of the sixth annual women's New Jersey squash racquets championship at the Short Hills Club today.

PUNTA GORDA, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP). -- Favorites advanced today in the championship of women's champions golf tournament. Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of Miami, veteran national competitor, ousted the 1935 winner, Mrs. Mark McGarry of St. Petersburg, 4 and 2, and Miss Lucille Robinson of Des Moines, Iowa, defeated Mrs. G.C. Blaisdell of Waterville, Me., by the same score.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- President Roosevelt today added his tribute to the many other honors conferred upon Surgeon General Hugh S. Cumming as he authorized the veteran chief of the United States Public Health Service to step from active service on Feb. 1. Dr. Cumming has held his present position since 1920, and has been an officer of the Public Health Service since 1894.

The press of the world is slowly regaining some of its lost liberties and journalistic standards generally are being raised, according to Carl W. Ackerman, Dean of the Columbia University School of Journalism, who returned on the Dollar liner President Harrison yesterday after a 31,000-mile journey around the world.

After weeks of friction resulting from the bureau's failure to produce satisfactory results in its task of obtaining jobs in private industry for WPA workers, Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, forced the resignation yesterday of Major Wilfred E. Boughton, head of the industrial re-employment bureau of the WPA.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today to recommend the confirmation of six members of the new Federal Reserve Board who were appointed by President Roosevelt yesterday to take office under the Banking Act of 1935, on Feb. 1.

J. Howard Shoemaker, defending champion, and Edward C. Rogers, Glen Cove, L.I., will meet tonight at the Strand Academy in the final match for the national amateur pocket billiard title. The titleholder won his way to the final by a decisive triumph over Herbert Courtney last night, 125 to 48.

What is left of the depression will disappear when foreign trade and the building construction activity get back to 1926 levels of activity, Karl L. Rankin, United States commercial attache at Athens, Greece, assured the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., yesterday at the regular luncheon meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

" Professional Soldier," based on a story by Damon Runyon and produced by Twentieth Century-Fox, opens today at the Center Theatre. Victor McLaglen, Freddie Bartholomew and Gloria Stuart head its cast.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 28. -- Charles Whitehead, representing the Forsgate Country Club of Jamesburg, N.J., the defending titleholder, was eliminated today in the first match round of the ninth annual National Championship of Golf Club Champions on the St. Augustine links.
In your editorial of Jan. 27 you state: "The heaviest blow which the New Deal and the administration have suffered was delivered by ex-Governor Smith Saturday evening."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The temporary exemption from provisions of Title I of the Public Utility Act of 1935, except in the cause of holding companies and their subsidiaries whose operations are predominantly intrastate in character, will not be extended after Feb. 2, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

With the Liverpool Exchange closed and the uncertainty over proposed crop legislation again an active factor, trading on the Cotton Exchange contracted further yesterday and the list ended with losses of 2 to 7 points. Houses doing government business released March contracts, while unsettled mill and wholesale cotton goods conditions restricted the demand for the near month, which reflected more or lass selling pressure throughout.

After sixty-five years of marriage, the anniversary of which they celebrate tomorrow, Mr. and Mrs. Owen Haggerty of 302 Convent Avenue agree on the right and the wrong things in married life. But on the question of mothers-in-law they are a house divided.

Stockholders of Fourth National Investors, an investment trust, were notified yesterday by Fred Y. Presley, president, that they would be asked to act at the annual meeting on March 3 on a proposal to reestablish the management contract with the National Investors Corporation, which lapsed on Dec. 31, 1934.

Progress is being made in the work of federating all groups and individuals interested in wildlife restoration into a nation-wide organization, according to Charles E. Clarke Jr., chairman of the committee on conservation of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce.

THE swirling finish of the mile run in the Boston garden last Saturday night will add a little sauce to the Millrose meet. It seemed to the bystanders that Joe Mangan, the law student on the lope, was about to breeze by Galloping Glenn of the Kansas Cunninghams when the world's record-holder swerved out in the stretch and received a push from Mangan that practically shoved him over the line a winner.

With the markets closed yesterday throughout the British Empire and with the security and many of the commodity exchanges here opening an hour late, activity was necessarily diminished. The stock market plainly showed the effects of dissipation of the "inflation" impulse, closing irregular.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- A bill to modernize Nassau County's government was introduced today by Assemblyman Herman, Nassau Republican. It is the first measure filed under the Fearon constitutional amendment approved last Fall.

JOLIET, Ill., Jan. 28. -- Richard Loeb, who with Nathan Leopold killed 14-year-old Bobby Franks nearly twelve years ago in one of the country's most sensational crimes, was slashed to death today by a fellow-convict in the Stateville penitentiary near here.

Members of the Stock Exchange seemed pleased yesterday upon reading the Exchange's second annual pamphlet report showing a reduction in operating loss from $1,060,890 in 1934 to $209,325 last year. In their opinion, Warren B. Nash, treasurer during the first half of the year, and Benjamin Brinton, who succeeded him, were entitled to credit for the decrease in expenses by almost $750,000.

Striking contrast is never far to seek with a New York art season in full swing. An example that may be recommended to readers this morning concerns a couple of newly opened one-man shows, devoted to Maurice de Vlaminck at the Lilienfeld Galleries, 21 East Fifty-seventh Street, and, just round the corner Massimo Campigli at the Julien Levy, 602 Madison Avenue.
A new result of the continued cold in the metropolitan area was reported yesterday when harbor traffic was impeded throughout the morning by ice floes from the upper reaches of the Hudson River.
Greater New York's three major league ball clubs put in another spirited stretch yesterday getting things in order for the dash to Southern training camps, now less than a month away.

A thorough canvass by the Board of Higher Education of the relations existing among the administration, faculty and student body of City College appeared certain yesterday as the Associate Alumni of the college prepared to transmit to the board a report holding Dr. Frederick B. Robinson lacking in the personal qualities required for his position as president of the institution.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- While the grain markets were relatively inactive today there was scattered pressure in evidence on the Board of Trade from the start while support was limited. Houses with Southwestern and Eastern connections were moderate sellers of wheat, with the main pressure on the May, which closed 1 cent a bushel lower while the new crop months were off 3/8 to 1/2 cent.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- For those British millions who could not see the procession at King George's funeral, nor even approach near enough to hear the slow marches and dirges of the military bands, there was at least the great benediction of a two-minute silence for all. It was not the least in its impressiveness, solemnity and universality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked by the New York Central Railroad today to extend from various dates in 1936 and 1937 the maturity dates of $11,899,000 of loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation until July 1, 1941.

TOKYO, Jan. 28. -- Expecting revelations concerning the dissensions that have racked the army in recent years, the Japanese public is absorbed in the trial of Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa for the murder of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, director of the Military Affairs Bureau, in the War Office on Aug. 12, 1935.

Governor BRANN of Maine, now serving his second term, has declined to be a candidate for a third. He gives no reasons for his decision. He contents himself with saying that he "will not be a candidate" again. A Democrat elected and re-elected with the aid of Republican voters in a State still Republican on national issues, his conduct in office has had cordial and general approval.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 28. -- Disposing of an estate with an estimated value of $1,000,000, of which upward of $800,000 was in securities, the will of William D. Guthrie, lawyer and writer, who died at Lattingtown on Dec. 8, 1935, was filed here today for probate with Surrogate Leone D. Howell.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 28. -- Governor Landon will formally make his debut tomorrow as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President. At the celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the admission of Kansas as a State and in the city where four years ago he asked the Republicans to choose him as a candidate for Governor, he will speak on all the vital questions of the day, including currency, economics and the farm problem.

Manhattan's foreclosure auction list yesterday comprised seventeen parcels taken over by plaintiffs. The properties included apartment houses, loft buildings and taxpayers. Ten banks were named as plaintiffs. The largest parcel was composed of two eight and ten story structures at 111-31 West Nineteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- President Roosevelt showed increasing interest in the political situation, discussing that topic with at least six callers. He commended Surgeon General Cumming, who is retiring, and was dinner host this evening to six of nine Supreme Court justices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Seven additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 involving $2,555,438 have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Of the total, five were by commercial and industrial corporations for $2,115,491.

BERLIN, Jan. 28. -- Baldur von Schirach, Reich Youth leader, tonight answered the recent Catholic pastoral letter attacking anti-Christian propaganda in the Nazi ranks with the declaration, "To be a nation is the religion of our epoch."

Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip gave a luncheon yesterday in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for members of the women's reception committee for the opening of the New York Museum of Science and Industry. Later the group inspected the museum, which will be opened to the public Feb. 12 and will occupy the space in the R.C.A. Building, Rockefeller Center, formerly known as the Forum.

Situation Was Delicate Governor GRAVES of Alabama finds that in the Ozie Powell affray the Sheriff's officers deserve commendation. They handled "a most delicate and deplorable situation in an efficient manner." The police report on which the Governor's verdict is based declares that the Scottsboro defendant POWELL did more than slash the deputy sheriff with a knife.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Catcher Leo (Gabby) Hartnett of the champion Cubs, who was voted the National League's most valuable player in 1935, effectively silenced rumors that he was a hold-out today by signing his contract.
The board of managers of the American Bureau of Shipping elected J. Lewis Luckenbach to his fifth term as its president yesterday afternoon at its annual meeting at the bureau building, 24 Old Slip.

On Saturday of this week the important changes made last year by Congress in the organization of the Federal Reserve System become effective. Yesterday's newspapers reported the names of six of the seven members to be appointed by the President to the new and reconstituted Board of Governors.
" The House in Paris," by Elizabeth Bowen, will be the Book-of-the-Month Club choice in March. It will be published on March 2 by Knopf.

WINDSOR, England, Jan. 28. -- George V, most powerful and most modest of present-day monarchs, ended his last journey here today and was laid to rest amid the tombs of his predecessors after such scenes of splendid mourning and his people's grief as England had never seen before.

Eighty-eight players began play last night in the first session of the open-pair contract bridge event of the Atlantic National Bridge tournament being held at the Park Central Hotel by the United States Bridge Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Renewing his attack today on "injustices resulting from legal decisions" of the Supreme Court, Secretary Wallace characterized the mandatory refund of $200,000,000 of processing taxes under the rice millers' decision as "probably the greatest legalized steal in American history."

Activity in business during 1935 was greater than for any of the preceding recovery years, according to an analysis of reports of production and distribution by the National Industrial Conference Board. Although complete figures for December are not available, the board reported yesterday that it is apparent that industrial production during the last quarter reached the highest level since the second quarter of 1930.
A special dividend of $1 was declared yesterday on the stock of the Ainsworth Manufacturing Company. On Dec. 28 a similar dividend was paid.
The bill for the last half of next week, the eighth of the season at the Metropolitan Opera, was announced yesterday.

As evidence of the widespread interest in the funeral services of King George, broadcasting companies reported that thousands of listeners over the country rose before dawn yesterday to tune in the ceremonies radioed across the Atlantic and broadcast over nationwide hook-ups.
Apartment, dwelling and garage properties were included in the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.
Continued improvement in the operations of the United States Steel Corporation resulted last year in its first net profit since 1931, it was announced yesterday.

William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union; Sir Thomas Beecham, composer and orchestra conductor, and William H. Beck, United States Consul General at Oslo are among the notables leaving today for the Channel ports on the Manhattan of the United States Lines.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 28. -- John McCann of 45 West End Avenue, Newark, was fined $50 and sentenced to thirty days in jail by the Juvenile Court here yesterday for his refusal to allow his 6-year-old son to be immunized against diphtheria, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Moving swiftly to meet the rush of veterans over the country, government officials put into the malls today 3,000,000 bonus payment application forms and at the same time gave assurance that there would be no wholesale discharge of ex-soldiers from relief rolls.

Mitchel Field, L.I., was designated yesterday as the target to be "attacked" by bombardment aviation, based at Concord, N.H., in the first phase of the Winter manoeuvres of the General Headquarters Air Force that will open on Saturday and continue through Monday.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins turned back a furious Detroit Red Wing attack tonight and scored a 2-0 shutout before a packed crowd of 14,000 at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- The Stock Exchange and the bullion and foreign exchange markets were closed today because of the King's funeral. Only the banks and houses in Lombard Street were open, but business in the money market was practically at a standstill.

Consumers Research, Inc., of Washington, N.J., violated the National Labor Relations Act when it discharged three employes last August for unionization activities and refused to bargain collectively with a group of its organized employes after they called a strike on Sept. 4, 1935, according to an intermediate report filed on the case by Charles A. Wood, trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, who heard the complaint.

A $200,000 apartment house plan for Bennett Avenue in upper Manhattan was filed yesterday. Bronx projects included a $260,000 park recreation building for Reservoir Oval for a $225,000 apartment structure for the northwest corner of 232d Street and Riverdale Avenue.

A goal in the overtime period last night kept the New York Rangers from dropping into last place in the American division of the National Hockey League. The tally, scored by Cecil Dillon, enabled the Blue Shirts to break a tie with the Canadiens of Montreal and skate off the ice the winners by a score of 3 to 2 at Madison Square Garden.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Hunt Tilford Wagstaff, who are visiting Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford at Oceanic Cottage, were guests of honor of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred V. Leaman today at Casa Banyan.

Ed Wynn yesterday exercised his prerogative as a producer and set back the premiere of "Alice Takat" from next Monday to Feb. 10 at the Golden. The attraction began its out-of-town engagements in Baltimore last week and is currently on view in Newark.
WARSAW, Jan. 28. -- Poland is in the grip of a seemingly nation-wide wave of anti-Semitism that is assuming an increasingly serious character.

The annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers opened here yesterday morning at the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street, with a registration of 1,300 electrical authorities, coming from every State in the Union and from Canada.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- Acting on the demand of Governor Lehman, the Democratic-controlled Senate Finance Committee overrode today objections of Tammany members and voted to confirm the nomination of William R. White as Superintendent of Banks.

HAVANA, Jan. 28. -- The National Democratic party issued a public statement asserting it would accept the minority representation legislation recently approved by the Barnet government only after the Supreme Court had declared the measure constitutional.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $45,000,000 of Republic Steel Corporation general mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series B, due on Feb. 1, 1961, by a banking syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Field, Glore Co.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 28. -- Delegates invited to the "grass roots convention," called by Governor Eugene Talmadge and John H. Kirby, Texas constitutionalist, were wondering today what kind of a political pow-wow they had been invited to attend.

EUGENE J. YOUNG, as news and foreign editor of The New York World and, later, as cable editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has seen thousands of words about "disarmament," "collective security," the "Locarno spirit," the "renunciation of war as an instrument of policy," the need for an "internationalist" outlook, and so on, pass under his blue pencil during the past decade and a half.

A man identified as Private Joseph Minsky, 20 years old, who was absent without leave from the army post at Fort Wadsworth, S.I., committed suicide yesterday morning on the steps leading to the altar rail at St. Joseph's Maronite Roman Catholic Church, 57 Washington Street, between Morris and Rector Streets. He fired a single shot into the right side of his head with a pistol he had smuggled from the fort.

BOSTON, Jan. 28. -- Dr. Heinrich Bruening, former German Chancellor and leader of the outlawed Catholic Center party, declared in his first interview on American soil at the Algonquin Club this afternoon that he would always be in opposition to the Nazi form of government "as long as the principles of justice and equality in law are disregarded" by it and "liberty of conscience is endangered."

With activity in the foreign exchange markets both here and in Europe reduced materially because of the closing of the London markets for the funeral of King George V, the United States dollar reduced further its losses of the last week.

Eben S. Abbott, schooled for years in the traditions of the sea, sat dazed and trembling more than a year ago on the thwart of a lifeboat, which bore him and twenty-nine seamen toward the shore of Asbury Park, leaving 134 passengers and seamen to perish on the burning Ward liner Morro Castle.

The Board of Estimate, after an executive session yesterday afternoon, voted approval of the $6,040,000 contract for the construction of the first section of the Sixth Avenue subway from Fortieth to Forty-seventh Street, and in so doing committed itself to construct the subway without tearing down the present elevated structure.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- The killing of Bobby Franks shocked the country in 1924.

NORTHERN ITALIAN ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Amba Jesus, South of Makale, Jan. 27 (delayed) (AP). -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio, commander of the northern Italian forces, predicted today his troops would push forward deeper into Ethiopian territory during the coming rainy season.

Declines were numerous in active trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Cottonseed oil was strong because of the improvement in the spot price of lard. Tin and silk were higher on the cash markets, but wheat, corn, oats, cotton, rubber, dairy products and refined sugar declined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Official Washington paid its last tribute to King George at a memorial service held today in the Washington Cathedral, where last May the twenty-fifth anniversary of his accession was celebrated.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (AP). -Pancoast, 6-year-old gelding from O. Viau's barn, upheld the confidence of the public today when he defeated seven other platers in the six-furlong feature race at the Fair Grounds.

Colonel KNOX, Republican aspirant or at least possibility, for the Presidential nomination thinks that the Smith speech makes success for his own party certain. He perceives accession to it of a perfect "sea of votes" by anti-Roosevelt Democrats. Lake Michigan must seem to him fairly dotted with them as he looks out from his watch-tower in Chicago.

A suspect in the hold-up of forty members of the Forton Club at 219 Second Avenue, near Fourteenth Street, at 10:30 o'clock last night, was captured a few minutes later by a policeman, assisted by the club members. At the Fifth Street station the prisoner said he was David Lerner, 21 years old, of 296 East Second Street, a dishwasher at Beth Israel Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- More than half of the $3,359,229,745 internal revenue collected in 1935 originated in New York, Illinois, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and California, the Treasury announced today. The five States paid approximately $1,738,700,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- Net income of the Inland Steel Company and its subsidiaries for 1935 amounted to $9,417,818, which was the best showing for the company since 1929, the company reported today. Last year's total, however, does not include the profit made in the first nine months of the year by Joseph T. Ryerson Son, Inc., which was acquired on Oct. 1, last.

Two bills designed to strengthen and extend the enforcement powers of the Tenement House Department relating to old tenements have been approved by the department and by Mayor La Guardia and have been sent to Albany for introduction in the State Legislature, it was learned yesterday.

Senator William E. Borah of Idaho opened last night his Eastern campaign for the Republican nomination for President with a denunciation of the Old Guard leadership of the party and a declaration that the nominee of the national convention at Cleveland must not be determined in secret with "selfish interests pulling the strings."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28. -- Edward F. Seagram, Canadian distiller and sportsman, arrived at Hialeah Park today in time to see his consistent 4-year-old gelding Sablin capture the featured fifth race, a one-mile event that attracted a half dozen smart members of the older division to the post.
Frederick T. Mayer will manage the new downtown office, at 39 Broadway, of the Raw Products Corporation, members of the Commodity Exchange, Inc.
AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 28 (AP). -- Arthur Page was free of an Auburn Prison term today and $25,000 richer than when he entered the prison gates.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28. -- A "West Point" of Soviet Industry, where workers from the ranks may be trained for responsible positions, was created today by order of G.K. Ordjonokidze, Commissar for Heavy Industry. He directed that special industrial courses be given for 1,500,000 men and women now employed in heavy industries.

At a recent meeting of the New York Women's League for Animals held at the home of Mrs. Orme Wilson, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street, Mrs. J. Dyneley Prince was re-elected president of the organization. Other officers re-elected included Mrs. Orme Wilson, Miss Rosa Anne Grosvenor, Mrs. Phillips Allen Clark, Miss Ruth Stillman, Mrs. William M. Polk, Mrs. Edith Wharton, James Speyer, Henry C. Holt and Robert G. Mead.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,820,500 barrels, compared with 2,833,600 in the preceding week, a decline of 13,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 14,250 barrels in the daily average output of the Eastern area was the most important change.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 28. -- Rolf Monsen, American skier, who is a veteran of two Olympic competitions, is definitely out of action for this year, due to a foot injury.

Eight of twenty employes of the Selfast Hat Company, Inc., on the seventh floor of 11 East Twenty-second Street, were taken to Ballevue Hospital yesterday after they had been overcome, evidently by odorless poison fumes.
The text of Senator Borah's address in Brooklyn last night follows:

Satisfied that he has thrown a monkey wrench of some size into the machinery of the Roosevelt political organization by his Liberty League speech, former Governor Alfred E. Smith will leave tomorrow for a short vacation at Palm Beach.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To write the customary words of sympathy on the death of Frederick Mortimer would be inadequate and foolish, for a great man has left the earth, the greatest this writer has ever known. He had the hardest handicaps and met them without bitterness. It was the writer's good luck to share an office with him.

The total number of unemployed workers in the nation in December was estimated at 8,979,000 in the monthly survey made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. This represents a decrease of 218,000, or 2.4 per cent, from the preceding month, and a decrease of 916,000, or 9.3 per cent, below December 1934.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Jan. 28 (By Wireless). -- The claims of great Italian victories in the north around Makale and in the south around Noghelli are evidently inspired by the necessity of reconstituting the morale of the Italian people, suffering badly from admitted checks and enforced retreats in the north and in Ogaden.

With only three days remaining before the 1935 automobile license plates expire, about 3,000 car owners applied yesterday at the headquarters of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles for the new tags. These must be on all vehicles in operation in this State after midnight Friday.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club team scored a decisive victory over Block Hall in last night's matches among the teams in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association. The Half-Mooners won on their home courts by the score of 4 to 1, Block Hall's only point coming when E.W. Butler, No. 1 on the Crescents, was forced to default in his match with I.A. Powell.
Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, will confer degrees upon 472 graduates of the institution at midyear commencement exercises at 10:30 A.M. today at Carnegie Hall.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- Alfred E. Smith's attack on the Roosevelt administration in his speech before the American Liberty League Saturday night was criticized by speakers at the closing sessions today of the Catholic Conference on Social Problems.

Although the average account on deposit in the mutual savings banks throughout the country receded slightly in the last half of 1935, the total of deposits on Dec. 31 was near the peak of Jan. 1, 1932.

Donald C. Vaughan Jr. of the Garden City Casino, ranked fifth on the seeded list, upset Gilbert B. Carpenter of Westport, who had been ranked just ahead of him, to enter the men's singles semi-final round yesterday in the Eastern New York badminton championships being staged on the courts of the Tudor City Tennis Club in the 165th Infantry Armory.

In memory of King George V of England, the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall last night, Sir Thomas Beecham conducting, opened with a special performance of Grieg's "Elegy." Grieg's piece, short and simple, was well chosen for the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Six of the nine Justices of the Supreme Court sat down to dinner at the White House tonight, as the President and Mrs. Roosevelt tendered the annual dinner to the members of the court. Justices Brandeis, McReynolds and Van Devanter were unable to be present.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- Several bills included in the series introduced to carry out Governor Lehman's program for better enforcement of the criminal law were opposed today by spokesmen for labor organizations, Communists and lawyers at a joint hearing before the Senate and Assembly Code and Judiciary Committees.

The city of Rochester, N.Y., will consider bids for a new issue of $2,000,000 of public welfare bonds, award of which will be made on Feb. 4. The bonds will be dated Feb. 1, 1936, and mature from Feb. 1, 1937 to 1941. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.

The Anglo-Chilean Nitrate Corporation, incorporated in Chile, has formulated a plan for the readjustment of capital structure after extended negotiations with representatives of British and American security owners, it was announced yesterday.

More than 2,000 men and women, including some of the most distinguished figures in American public life and hundreds of British or Canadian birth or descent, gathered yesterday at 10 A.M. in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine for a simple service in memory of King George V.

A statement by Lambert Fairchild, head of the National Republican Council, that it had not yet decided to take legal action against the Postofftce Department's ban on its anti-Roosevelt cartoon poster stamps, "as there is little involved except a question of principle," was challenged yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union.

Elmer Rice, who resigned last week as Regional Director of the Federal Theatre Project in New York because of "censorship" of one of the project's productions, revealed last night that he had requested Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, to tell him who was the real authority for the action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- A record drawn from Alfred E. Smith's utterances as Governor of New York, candidate for President and private citizen, intended to demonstrate that Mr. Smith has specifically endorsed many of the acts and principles of the New Deal which he attacked last Saturday in his American Liberty League speech, was broadcast to the country tonight by Senator Robinson as the Democratic party's official answer.

The financial statement of the Y. M. C.A. of New York for 1935, as reported in yesterday's TIMES, shows a budget so nearly balanced that there must be hundreds of persons interested in the work of this organization any one of whom would have gladly met the deficit, which was only $139.

The unanimous vote of about 600 of the most influential Jews within reach of New York imposed one restriction last night on the plan being elaborated here by British and American Jewish leaders to finance a migration of Jews from Germany.
The oration delivered by John W. Davis is highly interesting as a perfect example of antagonistic criticism devoid of any constructive suggestion.

SEATTLE, Jan. 29 (AP). -- The body of Delmar Fadden, mountain climber missing since Jan. 13, was sighted late today at the 13,000-foot elevation on Mount Rainier. He had attempted to scale the 14,408-foot peak in January, a feat never accomplished.

Two evidences that the improved business at the Metropolitan Opera House is likely to continue through the rest of the season were disclosed yesterday. One was the announcement that a new box office is being installed in the lobby of the opera house.
LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Fred Perry is not through with competitive tennis, temporarily or otherwise.
The city of Syracuse, N.Y., will enter the market on Feb. 10 for bids on an issue of $5,110,000 of relief and refunding bonds. Details in connection with the financing will be announced soon.

At Topeka last night Governor LANDON refrained from that partisan bitterness that sets the crowd yelling and disgusts the thoughtful reader. He was temperate and fair. He impresses you as a man of sound judgment and moderate opinions, clothed, as a rule, in simple, homely words.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Doubts as to the constitutionality of the administration's stop-gap soil conservation program were resolved in the Senate Committee on Agriculture today in favor of immediate farm relief when, by a vote of 15 to 2, the measure was ordered favorably reported to the Senate.
Work of students in the Fall term art classes of the New School for Social Research is on exhibition at that institution.

CAIRO, Jan. 29. -- The Italian Minister presented today an Italian note replying to the Egyptian Government's arguments justifying the application of sanctions. Retorting to Egypt's invoking the Kellogg pact, which was signed by both governments and which, according to Egypt, justifies her application of sanctions, Italy asserts there is nothing in the treaty restraining the right of legitimate defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Federal Government of Austria has joined the growing list of foreign nations that have filed applications with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permanent registration of bonds on the Stock Exchanges, and similar applications are being received in considerable numbers from political subdivisions and other foreign issuers.

City officials conferred with the heads of the World's Fair Committee at City Hall yesterday on the contribution they think New York State should make to the Fair, to be held on the Flushing Meadows in 1939.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Arguments over proprietary rights to the old party labels will go on in this country until the growing groups of deserters from both, passing each other on their restless travels, force the professional politicians to admit that their herds have more mavericks than brands.

National steel interests are opening a campaign to encourage building with steel to the detriment of lumber, while manufacturers of materials that compete with lumber are directing a subtle propaganda which sometimes takes the form of a direct attack, Theodore K. Quinn, president of Maxon, Inc., and merchandising counsel of the General Electric Company, told 400 members of the Northeastern Retail Lunbermen's Association at a session of their convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it was expanding its interest in the air-conditioning industry through the organization of a new company, the Delco-Frigidaire Conditioning Corporation, for the marketing of year-around air conditioning and automatic heating products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Cooperation between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the investment bankers in a fight against fraudulent transactions and in moves to promote fair practices in over-the-counter markets was discussed today at a conference between the SEC and representatives of the Investment Bankers Conference Committee, at which details of a permanent voluntary organization to be set up by the bankers were considered.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- A conference next Wednesday on legislation for the "transfer in an orderly fashion" of the duties now performed by the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration to the State Department of Social Welfare was called today by Governor Lehman, who invited the Republican leaders of the Legislature, Senator Fearon and Speaker Ives, and those of his own party, Senator Dunnigan and Assemblyman Steingut.

The estate of Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, daughter of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, increased from $2,948,743.90 on Jan. 1, 1935, to $3,667,814.79 on last Dec. 27, according to an annual accounting by Thomas B. Gilchrist, surviving guardian of the child's estate, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Great Britain finally abandoned today the "smaller warship" policy which her admirals and politicians have been urging with varying emphasis but with less and less success ever since the end of the Washington Naval Conference fourteen years ago.

Mayor La Guardia conferred yesterday with the commission he named recently to make a scientific study of methods used to determine whether automobile drivers arrested for traffic violations are intoxicated.

Net profit of the F.W. Woolworth Company last year amounted to $31,247,230, after provision for depreciation, amortization expenses, taxes and other deductions. It was equal to $3.20 a share on 9,750,000 shares of $10-par capital stock outstanding and compared with a profit of $32,142,363, or $3.30 a share, the year before.

More than 6,000 parties throughout the nation and its colonial possessions -- parties encompassing the range of entertainment from barn dances and fiestas in rural communities to formal balls in large cities -- will be held tonight in celebration of President Roosevelt's fifty-fourth birthday.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 29. -- Apparently with the object of paving the way for eventual resumption of the private export sale of Canadian grain, the Canadian Government has invited representatives of the grain growers, dealers, exporters and millers to confer in Winnipeg on Feb. 25.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- A demand that Secretary Wallace be impeached for his statement that the Supreme Court's decision in regard to the return of the processing taxes was a "legalized steal" was made on the floor of the House today by Representative Treadway of Massachusetts.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 29. -- Yale defeated the New York Athletic Club at hockey, 5 to 3, tonight, with Andy Gagarin, a spare, leading the attack, in the New Haven Arena. He assisted in two goals and shot a third.

Squash tennis history was made on the courts of the City A.C. last night when Milton Baron, playing No. 1 on the City team, defeated Harry Wolf, the game's outstanding star and metropolitan as well as national champion.
The cold wave moderated somewhat yesterday and the city enjoyed temperatures that averaged 22 degrees, the highest since Jan. 22.

A bequest amounting to at least $500,000 was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences, which opened a three-clay session in the Pupin Physics Laboratories at Columbia University.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- Amendments to the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law were submitted to the Legislature today by Senator A. Spencer Feld, Manhattan Democrat. One amendment would prohibit Sunday sales between 1 A.M. and 1 P.M., instead of from 3 A.M. to 1 P.M. as now, except in hotels having fifty or more rooms, where the closed time would be from 4 A.M. to 8 A.M.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Responsibility for raising $2,249,178,375 to pay the cost of the bonus was put up to Congress by President Roosevelt in a letter to Speaker Byrns.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- An early ending of Great Britain's phenomenal building boom was foreseen today by Rupert Beckett, chairman of Westminster Bank, in his annual address to his shareholders. Owing to the King's funeral two of the "Big Five" banks held their meetings today, with the result that Mr. Beckett's speech had to compete for public attention with that of Reginald McKenna, the Midland Bank's chairman.

PORTSMOUTH, England, Jan. 29. -- The keel of T.O.M. Sopwith's new yacht, Endeavour II, was cast today at Camper Nicholson's yard at Gosport. Fifty feet long and weighing ninety tons, the keel is made of the purest lead, and the work of casting it occupied eighty men for five hours.

William W. Bodine, president of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company, has advised holders of its preferred and common stocks that counsel for the company are preparing claims, which must be filed by April 1, against the Connecticut Company and by May 1 against the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company.

New regulations restricting the uses to which ASKI marks may be put in the purchase of German products were made public here yesterday by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., for the information of companies doing business with Germany.

The residence of the late Robert W. De Forest, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Mrs. De Forest at 7 Washington Square North was turned into an improvised auction gallery yesterday when paintings, furniture, rugs, objects of art and other furnishings of the old red-brick house were offered to the highest bidders.

Paul Di Bari, 52 years old, father of five, fatally beat his wife, Rose, 49, with a hammer after an argument over money in their flat on the top floor of a four-story tenement at 413 Monroe Street, Hoboken, yesterday afternoon and then jumped to a rear yard, killing himself.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- The Cabinet met today to discuss the government's legislative program for Parliament, which will resume its session next Tuesday after a ten-week holiday broken only by the emergency meeting last week to enable members to swear allegiance to the new King.

BERLIN, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Germany served notice today that she would continue her unrelenting drive against Jews in a strong restatement of Nazi principles on the eve of the third anniversary of Adolf Hitler's dictatorship.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince, Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Norman and Captain de Corvette Bonnot are among the persons sailing today for Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Ile de France.

It can be said that the performance of Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was commensurate, as no previous performance given here this season, to the contents of the work. It is not a small compliment.

The crest of the wave of applicants for bonus blanks at the Veterans Administration Office, Ninth Avenue between Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets, passed on Monday, and the flood diminished yesterday to a small but steady stream. Speedy handling of applicants, the widespread distribution of the blanks to veterans' organizations and business houses accounted for the slackening of the rush.

James G.K. Lawrence, 41 years old, whose father, also James G.K. Lawrence, was one of the country's best-known racing men until his death in 1895, killed himself at 1:45 P.M. yesterday by firing one barrel of a shotgun into his head, according to a police report.

Seamen employed on ships operating from Atlantic Coast ports have indicated their unwillingness to renew their wage contract with their employers for the current year. A poll of the men taken by the leaders of their unions has shown sentiment overwhelmingly in favor of a new contract that would provide higher wages and better working hours. The poll is to end tomorrow.

Grace Leslie, contralto, gave her first recital in three years at the Town Hall last night before an enthusiastic audience of good size. It was in the same auditorium that the singer made her New York bow twelve years ago, and she has often been heard here since in oratorio and concert.

Long Island University's basketball team continued unbeaten last night, but only after a hard-fought contest with the surprising St. Francis squad at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium. The Blackbirds triumphed, 31 -- 23, before a crowd that overflowed on the court, but the score does not give a true indication of the fight they had.

Harry Balsamo, 160 3/4, undefeated Harlem middleweight, knocked out Frankie Slevin, 155 3/4, West Side, in the third round of the featured six-round bout at the Star Casino last night. A crowd of about 2,500 persons saw the loser counted out after 2:51 of the session.

The stock market moved cautiously yesterday forenoon and, when no important profit-taking developed as the aftermath of the recent "inflation"-inspired activity, gained confidence and moved to a generally higher closing. The oil, motor, aviation and railway shares, and a scattering of issues in various other groups, led the afternoon advance that carried THE NEW YORK TIMES railway, industrial and combined averages to new high levels for the year.

Decision to call a strike of elevator operators and other service workers in the Empire State Building was announced yesterday by James J. Bambrick, president of the Building Service Employes Union. Mr. Bambrick would not reveal the date but it was learned that the strike would probably go into effect on Monday, when the walkout called by the union in more than 1,200 buildings in the garment and fur area is to begin.

The number of boats to be built into the New York Yacht Club's new class of 32-foot-waterline cruising and racing sloops has reached twenty and the class is closed at that figure, it was announced yesterday by Vice Commodore E. Townsend Irvin of the class committee.

Last year the city adminstration's rapid transit advisers suggested that it be given wider responsibility for the development of unification plans, and a bill to effect that change was sent to Albany. But the Transit Commission objected and the suggestion was dropped.

MONTREAL, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press). -- Canadian pulp and paper companies are paying an "enormous tribute" to foreign country specialists for the solution of their problems, and it is high time the Dominion had a corps of trained investigators "on the spot," Major Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton, president of the National Research Council, told the annual convention of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association today.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- On the eve of the first encounter of the new French Cabinet with the Chamber of Deputies, the Bourse today was weak and irregular. Although it is conceded that Premier Sarraut will obtain a majority, there seems to be a persistent uncertainty regarding the monetary outlook.

A controversy between the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway and the Southern Pacific Company concerning methods to be followed in obtaining rights to operate omnibuses was disclosed yesterday in correspondence made public by the Santa Fe. The situation, an unusual one, marked an extension of railroad rivalry to the highways.

While the market for stocks in general was strong yesterday, weakness cropped out in one or two groups. The can stocks, which have been soft recently, continued to move lower, presumably in the expectation that increased competition, resulting from the entrance of Owens-Illinois Glass into this field, would reduce profit margins.

A "coat-pocket" radio transmitter weighing less than a pound, said to be the result of two years of research conducted by engineers of the National Broadcasting Company to enable "footloose" announcers to carry a microphone to any desired location to broadcast an event, was announced yesterday by O.B. Hanson, chief engineer of the N.B.C.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 29. -- Ras Kassa telephoned yesterday to Ethiopia's northern headquarters at Dessye to report that Italian efforts to recapture the positions lost in the fighting near Makale from Jan. 21 to 23 were continuing and that heavy artillery had been employed against him for the first time.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29. -- The text of Governor Alfred M. Landon's address here tonight was as follows:

A large addition to the song-and-dance business comes tonight to the Winter Garden, by name the "Ziegfeld Follies," being "Billie Burke's 1936 edition" thereof. At the head of the carnival is Fannie Brice, assisted by Bob Hope, Gertrude Niesen, Josephine Baker, Hugh O'Connell, Harriet Hoctor, Eve Arden, Judy Canova, Cherry and June Preisser, John Hoysradt and a lot of others.

In the brief time which this department finds at its disposal this morning, it would strongly advise the gentlemen who purvey the musical revues to Broadway's legitimate stage to have one look at the new "Folies de Femmes," which opened last night at the French Casino -- and then to look to their laurels.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Secretary and Mrs. Hull gave their first official diplomatic dinner of the season tonight at the Carlton Hotel, where they make their home.

Members of the Committee of Management of the Studio Club of the Young Women's Christian Association, in conjunction with the members council of the organization, have arranged a program of Russian music for tomorrow night at the clubhouse, 210 East Seventy-seventh Street, for the benefit of the 1936 joint campaign for their current expense funds.

The elimination of Bernard Jacobowitz of Evander Childs High School, fourth seeded, by George McColl of Scarborough School, an unranked competitor, featured yesterday's play in the tenth annual DeWitt Clinton High School invitation indoor interscholatsic tennis tournament being staged on the courts of the 369th Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- An appropriation of $2,249,178,375 to finance the veterans' bonus was requested today by President Roosevelt of Congress, which so recently rushed the "baby bond" Bonus Bill to enactment over his veto.

AKRON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- While 1,000 workers of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company remained idle in a "sit down" protest, the company refused tonight to reinstate a union worker whose suspension caused the "passive resistance."

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- Tomorrow, which is the anniversary of the day on which the late President Paul yon Hindenburg placed the destiny of Germany in Adolf Hitler's hands three years ago and the swastika banner was first raised above the Chancellor's palace, is for the National Socialists the most solemn holiday of the year.

THE door opened and the silver-thatched cupola of M'sieu Lestairre Patrick was poked through the gap. His spectacles were resting away down on the end of his nose, something in the Ichabod Crane manner.

Granted a Feb. 7 deadline by which to raise $200,000 or see "The Eternal Road" indefinitely postponed, Meyer W. Weisgal, its producer, said yesterday that $125,000 of this sum had been promised on the condition that he raise $75,000 more.

ON BOARD MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Jan. 29. -- The airplane Polar Star, in which Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, pilot, flew across the Antarctic, is now safe aboard this ship, which will leave the Bay of Whales tomorrow.

The publishing firms of Random House and Smith Haas will merge on April 1, it was announced yesterday, the new firm to be called Random House, Inc. The Modern Library, a distinct enterprise controlled by the owners of Random House, is included in the merger.

A dinner was given last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, by Mrs. Howard J. Pullumi of the Pierre and Louisville, Ky., for her niece, Miss Virginia Wathen, and Dr. Roberto Gutierrez, who will he married SaturdayI in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- A bill to write into State law the main features of the Federal Wagner Labor Relations Act was introduced today by Assemblyman Irving D. Neustein, New York City Democrat.

ATHENS, Jan. 29. -- Premier Constantine Demerdjis resigned today after the general election in accordance with his promises. King George, who has enjoined all the members of the royal entourage to keep aloof from party negotiations, caused Themistocles Sophoulis, Venizeliet leader, to be notified that he would be invited to form a Cabinet, and there will probably be a conference at the palace tomorrow.

The revised draft of the Neutrality Bill, now favorably reported to the House of Representatives by its Committee on Foreign Affairs, is an incomplete and unsatisfactory measure. It bristles with embargoes and restrictions, and with jail sentences and fines for infractions of the rules of conduct it prescribes for individual Americans in time of war.

The thirty-seventh annual report of the Superintendent of Schools appeared yesterday in entirely new format, following the style of a modern magazine in print and in numerous illustrations of "the largest school system in the world."

By a vote of 3,923 to 1,495 members of the Musicians Union, Local 802, defeated yesterday a rank and file proposal for a division of work among the union members which was opposed by the officers and executive board of the union. The proposal was designed to so readjust working rules as to furnish jobs for the unemployed members of the union, of whom there are said to be more than 9,000.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Mrs. James P. Donahue gave a dinner tonight for twenty on board her yacht Freedom, where she will pass the season.

Under every street is a sewer with manholes at frequent intervals. To convert them into sluiceways, the most efficient of all means for removal of substance like snow, it is only necessary to make water connections to provide the necessary motive power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Department of Justice announced tonight, as a major victory in its anti-trust litigation, the signing late today before Judge John P. Nields in the Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., of a consent decree by which the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation surrendered control of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Liquidation by tired holders of May wheat and selling of that delivery to close spreads with the July future carried prices off readily today on the Board of Trade and the close was at the bottom, with a net loss of 1 3/8 cents a bushel.

A request for a declaratory judgment holding the Public Utility Act of 1935 unconstitutional was filed yesterday in the Federal court in Manhattan by several public-utility companies as their answer to the suit of the Securities and Exchange Commission demanding that the companies comply with the provisions of the act, which requires listing of assets on the basis of actual cost on the date they were acquired for actual use.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (AP). -- The official Soviet news agency, Tass, reported from Khabarovsk tonight that a detachment of 109 Manchukuoan soldiers, rebelling against Japanese occupation of Manchuria, crossed into Soviet territory after killing four Japanese officers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Representative Martin L. Sweeney of Ohio today justified his opposition to the adjournment of the House on Jan. 21 out of respect to the memory of King George V by asserting that he "did not believe it was consistent with a democracy to pay a lavish tribute by adjourning out of memory to a foreign power."

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- For the eleventh time since the present Parliament was elected less than four years ago, a new Cabinet will present its program to the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow and ask for majority with which to govern.

ROME, Jan. 29. -- General Rodolfo Graziani's drive toward Harar was halted today at Wadara because of his need for supplies before he can resume operations. He may not be ready to resume the advance for several weeks.
MACON, Ga., Jan. 29.--Following is the text of the platform on which Governer Talmadge was asked by the convention here today to oppose the renomination of President Roosevelt:
Jimmy Howell, Salem-Crescent A.C. boxer, won the Metropolitan A.A.U. heavyweight title for the second successive year in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The WPA made it possible today for Philadelphia to spruce up both the city and the Convention Hall for the Democratic National Convention in June. To show that no partisanship was involved, officials made clear that when Cleveland makes formal application for reconditioning its Public Auditorium for the Republicans Federal aid will be given.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- A definite hint that funds for modernizing a pair of battleships or building a new one might be worked into the Navy appropriation bill was given today by members of the House Appropriations Subcommittee.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 29. -- The discovery of the earliest written psalm was announced tonight by Dr. Julian J. Oberman, Professor of Semitic Languages at Yale University, who told the Semitic and Biblical Club that a cuneiform inscription of about 1500 B.C., which has puzzled scientists since it was found several years ago at Ras Shamra in Northern Syria, is now known to establish the source of Hebrew psalmody of a thousand years later.

After all the outcries over Japanese trade competition it is refreshing to have the balanced and authoritative study by the United States Tariff Commission. Its report concedes that in the last few years Japan has begun to send to our market many classes of articles which she had not sold here previously.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Many members of the Surf Club will have guests tomorrow night for the first time in a series of informal Thursday evenings, to be featured by an informal dinner-dance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Consumer resistance to high prices for fresh pork has become a strong factor in the hog market, and with the best loins off 1/2 cent in the local market at 18 1/2 cents a pound, buyers of hogs reduced their bids 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight in the face of the smallest arrivals for a Wednesday since Nov. 27.

AT ITATLAIN HEADQUARTERS IN NORTHERN ETHIOPIA, Jan. 28 (Delayed). -- The strength of the Italian positions around Makale was impressed upon this correspondent today after a prolonged visit to the front line artillery positions.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Joe Gould, manager of Heavyweight Champion James J. Braddock, took a hand in the business of keeping fight fans interested in a Fall meeting between Braddock and Joe Louis when he let fly With a steaming retort today to intimations that the Brown Bomber was not interested in fighting for the title this year.

Restoration of part or all of the pay cuts imposed on city employes by July 1 was requested yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx in a letter to his colleagues on the Board of Estimate.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 29 (AP). -- Deputy Sheriff Dewitt Truss of Jefferson County today quoted Josephine Powell, mother of Ozie Powell, wounded Scottsboro defendant, as sating she would seek to displace Samuel S. Leibowitz of New York as her son's counsel.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith reiterated yesterday his demand that the answer to his Liberty League speech come from President Roosevelt himself. He did so in replying to the attack made on his speech on Tuesday night by Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, majority leader of the United States Senate.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- An anniversary of the utmost importance to Europe occurs tomorrow. The third year of Adolf Hitler's absolute control of Germany comes to an end and the Year IV of the National Socialist Third Reich begins.

Further reports on consumer response to home furnishings events indicate that results here thus far are fully meeting expectations. The sales are steadily gathering momentum and the turnover is expected to play a big part in swelling February volume above the same month a year ago.

After years of litigation, more than 1,000 claims for damages arising out of the sinking of the Lamport Holt liner Vestris off the Virginia Capes in 1928 were settled yesterday by approval of Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- The Atlantic Passenger Conference met in London today in an attempt to settle the dispute that has arisen as a result of the Cunard White Star Company's designation of the new liner Queen Mary as a cabin ship and its threat to withdraw from the conference because of dissatisfaction with the higher rates accorded the ship in that category by the conference.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- The Securities Commission was told today that M.J. Meehan, Wall Street operator, suggested bankruptcy for the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation last year, just before the commission cited him for alleged manipuation of Bellanca stock.

In its Gallery for Living Artists the Brooklyn Museum is holding, until March 15, an exhibition called "The Dance in Art," featuring dancers as subject matter and illustrating varied treatment of this theme in several mediums -- oil, drawing and sculpture.

Supplementing a brilliant program of special features at the twenty-ninth annual Millrose games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night will be twelve one-mile and two two-mile relay races, bringing together a total of fifty-three selected college, club and school quartets.
John Steinbeck's new novel, "In Dubious Battle," started off its publication day yesterday with a sale of 1,000 copies, Covici, Friede report, and the first edition is now exhausted.

By accident I happened to listen to the speaker of the Farmers Union program broadcast this afternoon. I have been studying economics for fifteen years, but if this speaker told the truth I will have to start all over again.

Dr. Albert Harrison Brundage, 74-year-old toxicologist, who faced eviction by foreclosure from his home at 93-12 Ninety-first Avenue, Woodhaven, Queens, was taken yesterday to the Queens General Hospital to be treated for an ailment said by his son to be due in part to the excitement of leaving the home in which he has lived for the last ten years.

J.W. Thayer of this city agrees with the opinion voiced by other correspondents that if we are to have better trout fishing in New York State, anglers must take more interest in trout conservation than they do now. He believes that if the fish supplied by the commission could be distributed and planted more effectively, the sport could be improved 50 per cent with no additional cost to the license holders.

Neil Petree, head of James McCreery Co., was re-elected president of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York at the annual meeting of the organization, it was announced yesterday. The meeting, held on Tuesday night at the Ritz-Carlton, completed the fortieth year of the association, which is the oldest retail organization in the country.

Many reservations have been made for the luncheon in behalf of Stony Wold Sanatorium which will take place today in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador. The sanatorium on Lake Kushaqua in the Adirondacks was established in 1901 to provide care and treatment for young women suffering from pulmonary tuberculosis.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Mrs. A.M. Creech's brown 4-year-old gelding, Crete, found a muddy track to his liking today, and won the $1,200 Venice Handicap for 4-year-olds and upward at the Santa Anita track. The time for the one mile and a sixteenth was 1:46 2-5.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 29.--Holding that a mother may lose her children if she rears them as Communists and atheists, Robert Grosman, Advisory Master in Chancery, denied to Mrs. Mabel Eaton today the custody of her son and daughter, and awarded them to their father.

A new king of the national amateur pocket billiard world was crowned last night when Edward Charles Rogers, 24-year-old Glen Cove (L.I.) player, ended the long reign of J. Howard Shoemaker in the final at the Strand Academy. The new champion turned in a brilliant display of shot-making to triumph, 125 to 41, in eighteen innings.

WHEN the arguments start flying about e "destiny" of America, of its "rights" and "duties" which must be upheld, even to the point of going to war about them, this column sighs and wishes it were a Swede. And when the class-war-addicts begin foretelling the day of barricades and the "final conflict," this column again sighs and again wishes it were a Swede.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Passage of permanent neutrality legislation at this session of Congress, it became plain today, may become impossible unless differences of opinion within the Senate Foreign Relations Committee can be reconciled, and Senator Pittman, chairman of the committee, said he was prepared to ask Congress to extend the life of the existing neutrality resolution for a year if necessary.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sent yesterday to all banking institutions in this Federal Reserve district a circular reminding them of the facilities set up under Section 136 of the Federal Reserve Act for providing loans to industry for working capital and asking their cooperation in bringing these facilities to the attention of those who might be interested.

ROME, Jan. 29. -- Commenting on the effect of sanctions on Italy so far, well-informed Italian circles made the extraordinary statement today that the gold exodus in 1935 was less than that of the preceding year.

Mrs. Roy Bergman of the Westport Badminton Club and Mrs. Frank R. Ford Jr., New York star, the two top-ranking players, moved into the final round in the women's singles division of the Eastern New York badminton championships yesterday on the Tudor City Tennis Club's courts in the 165th Infantry Armory.

After easing early in sympathy with a decline in Liverpool, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied and the execution of trade buying orders in the final dealings left the list with net gains of 2 to 14 points. Sentiment was influenced by the advance on the Stock Exchange and reports that the Senate Agricultural Committee had voted 14 to 2 in favor of the proposed substitute for the Agricultural Act.

Counsel for the B.M.T. and the various groups of holders of Interborough and Manhattan Railway securities notified the Transit Commission yesterday that they were not satisfied with the "working draft" of a rapid-transit unification plan as prepared by Samuel Seabury and A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, transit advisers to Mayor La Guardia.

Six representatives from as many organizations qualified for the women's national junior foils fencing championship tournament by surviving the preliminary bouts last night at the Fencers Club. The finals also will take place at the Fencers Club on Feb. 12.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- Details of the reports of the Glens Falls Insurance Company and its subsidiaries follow:

Argentina had a favorable balance of trade of 367,400,000 pesos $121,242,000 at the official rate of exchange) in 1935, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. This compared with a favorable balance of 358,5000,000 pesos ($108,405,000) in 1934.

VIENNA, Jan. 29. -- A great deal of mystery covers the future movements of Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor. It is believed he left London after the funeral of King George to meet former Empress Zita and Archduke Otto, but the meeting place has not been revealed.
Value of Dollar in Exchange. The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- The Boerse was stronger today but activity was relatively limited, as usual. There is no evidence of the market becoming again a genuine barometer of financial or commercial conditions. Most transactions of any importance continue to be arranged privately.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Naval delegates were disturbed tonight by the report from Rome of the special Cabinet meeting called for tomorrow morning to draft new instructions for Dino Grandi and his colleagues at the London conference.
PARIS, Jan. 29. -- Incidents that indicate a movement toward a revival of factional agitation that resulted in the February riots of two years ago over the Stavisky scandal occurred here today.

Leaders of various employer and employe groups in the men's and boys' outer clothing industry went on record yesterday as favoring an order prohibiting home work in the industry at a hearing in the State office building called by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- The merit system in public appointments was upheld as an essential of good government by President Roosevelt tonight in a letter read in a radio broadcast sponsored by the League of Women Voters.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 29. -- Edgar H. Hunter Jr. of the American Olympic skiing team plunged into a rock during the trials today and cut his leg to the bone. He will be laid up for a week and is not expected to compete for the United States in the games.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29. -- The Soviet Academy of Scientists announced today that insects and a small variety of lobsters born thousands of years ago had been revived and were pursuing a normal existence. They were found buried fifteen to twenty feet under the surface of a region of eternal frost in Siberian peat fields, the statement said.

Mayor La Guardia made a vigorous argument for the extension of the merit principle in civil service last night, in a radio speech over WJZ, which opened a nation-wide drive by the National League of Women Voters.
Walter Spence of the New York A.C. successfully defended his title in the senior metropolitan A.A.U. 220-yard free-style event at the London Terrace pool yesterday. The victor's time was 2:18.6.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- A bill which would grant the consent of the United States to construction of an airport on the Red Hook Flats off Bay Ridge was introduced in the House today by Representative James A. O'Leary, New York, Democrat.

A meeting of the holders of the $20,000,000 of twenty-year 5 1/2 per cent Series A debentures of Remington Rand, Inc., has been called for Feb. 21 to consider exchanging those securities for an equal amount of 4 1/4 per cent debentures dated March 2, 1936, and maturing on March 1, 1956.

Now that GEORGE V has been laid to rest, there is one thing which Senator NYE might do for the success of his neutrality inquiry. To the mass of oral and written testimony adduced before his committee the Senator might add all the dispatches, feature stories and pictures that have appeared in the American press about GEORGE V and his successor.
Margaret Sullavan returns today to the screen of the Radio City Music Hall in "Next Time We Love," which Universal adapted from Ursula Parrott's novel, "Next Time We Live."

The St. John's University five returned to winning form after its defeat by L.I.U. and conquered the La Salle College quintet of Philadelphia, 40 to 26, in the De-Gray gymnasium last night. The Redmen led at the half, 20 to 13. It was the team's twelfth victory of the season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- By unanimous vote, 1,716 delegates to the United Mine Workers of America convention pledged the more than 500,000 members today to support legislation that would curb the power of the Supreme Court.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- The stock markets resumed operations cheerfully today. British funds rose on good revenue returns. Foreign bonds were quiet, although Brazilian issues continued to gain on trade reports. Canadian Pacific was strong on transatlantic buying.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- "Over-all" constitutional limitation on the tax on real estate is considered as "unsound in principle as well as impracticable of administration in New York State" in a report filed with the Legislature today by the State Tax Commission, of which former State Senator Seabury C. Mastick of Westchester is chairman.

Price movements were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Most staples were active. Coffee and cocoa were firmer, while rubber and hides lost ground. On the cash markets cocoa, tin and cotton advanced, while wheat, corn, rye and oats, dairy products, silk and rubber declined.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 29. -- Here in the heart of the "Solid South," a mass meeting of 3,500 Southern Democrats, united in a common opposition to Negroes, the New Deal and the teachings of Karl Marx, adopted a platform today repudiating President Franklin D. Roosevelt as their party leader, and called upon Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia to lead them in a holy war to drive the "Communists" from Washington.

While the leaders in Group I retained their relative positions, the Cornell Club and Downtown A.C. joined the Dartmouth Club in a triple tie for first place in Group II as a result of yesterday's play in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C tournament.
