WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- An investigation of the Townsend movement by a House committee was made virtually certain today.

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- The number of prisoners in Germany has nearly tripled under the National Socialist regime, according to reliable figures obtained today, and more than one-third of these prisoners are being held for political offenses.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Trainer George Odom and the veteran jockey, Tommy Malley, basked in the spotlight at Hialeah Park today. After winning the fifth race, the combination clicked again in the next number, the featured Grade A handicap.
PARIS, Jan. 29. -- Robert Piquet's opening today introduced the first significant collection of the coming season. Youthful touches characterized a number of the costumes displayed.

The old-age pension and social security plan used by Senator William E. Borah of Idaho as the basis of his declaration for an old-age pension of $50 to $60 a month, was outlined yesterday by its author, Dr. Henry E. Jackson, head of the Social Engineering Institute, Inc., 230 Park Avenue.
The man-of-war Erie, classed as a gunboat but having many of the characteristics of a small cruiser, was launched with simple ceremonies in the navy yard in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

Dr. Walter Damrosch confessed yesterday not only that today would be his seventy-fourth birthday but that he had composed a new symphonic work, which he will conduct in his last public appearance on Friday, April 3, at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The bondholders' protective committee for Bush Terminal Company consolidated mortgage 5 per cent bonds due in 1955 has advised holders of certificates of deposit that it has applied to Judge Inch of the Eastern District Federal Court of New York for the payment of $994,350 interest in arrears on the $6,629,000 bonds outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Establishment of the first free foreign trade zone in the United States was provided for today when Secretary Roper announced that the privilege had been granted to New York City to establish, operate and maintain a free area at Stapleton, S.I., for the transshipment of goods to and from foreign countries.
TOPEKA, Jan. 29. -- Defining himself as a "constitutional liberal," Governor Landon outlined tonight in concise terms his views on vital issues of the day.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
Liquidation and dissolution of the Sun Investing Company has been recommended by the directors, and will be voted upon by the stockholders at a meeting on Feb. 21.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- Georgetown's speedy quintet, with keen shooting and a hard-fighting defense, defeated Army today, 43 to 31.

LONDON, Jan. 29.--Men who served with Colonel T.E. Lawrence in Arabia and friends of his undergraduate days at Oxford and of his later years in the Royal Air Force were among a congregation that crowded St. Paul's Cathedral this afternoon for a service following the unveiling in the crypt of a memorial bust of Lawrence executed by Eric Kennington, illustrator of his "Seven Pillars of Wisdom."

Despite the restrictive effects of the recent severe weather, steel operations have held virtually unchanged at 50 1/2 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Iron Age. The movement of iron and steel has been retarded by the weather, according to the magazine, but new orders have remained steady.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 29. -- Runner-up for the last two years, Miss Charlotte Darling of the Germantown Cricket Club, Philadelphia, captured the New Jersey women's squash racquets championship at the Short Hills Club today, defeating Miss Eileen Beresford, a local girl, in a closely contested five-game final, 15 -- 5, 17 -- 18, 16 -- 18, 18 -- 15, 15 -- 6.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 29. -- Although the two recent student demonstrations in Shanghai were classed by International Settlement police and other official foreign observers as important only in the possibilities of large-scale rioting, the official spokesman of the Japanese Embassy in Shanghai views this evidence of the resumption of student activities in a more serious light.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- A total of 14,540 women entered the military and naval service of the United States between April 6, 1917, and Nov. 11, 1918, or in a time that would entitle them to bonus payments under the Adjusted Service Certificate legislation, records of the War and Navy Departments revealed today.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Some details were revealed today concerning the various diplomatic conversations that resulted inevitably from the presence in London this week of so many representatives of continental governments, who had come to attend King George's funeral.

CAIRO, Jan. 29. -- Fifty-six students and twenty policemen were injured today in a new outbreak of rioting, in which the students attacked with bricks and the policemen replied with shotguns and a new weapon -- an "ink pump" that sprays indelible ink on demonstrators. The idea is to facilitate later identification of rioters.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29. -- Another device of bourgeois countries -- advertising -- has suddenly been embraced with enthusiasm in Communist Russia.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Queen Mary in a simple message to "My dear people," which bears every imprint of having been written by her own hand, tonight returned thanks for the sympathy shown during her bereavement.

The team that defeated the national champions in the intercity matches on Saturday was eliminated in the opening round of the national racquets doubles tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday and a former pair of titleholders escaped a similar fate by a single point.
ROME, Jan. 29. -- Leaders of Italian industry are eager to revive a trade mission to the United States which failed last year, according to informed persons.

Six contract bridge teams-of-four started play yesterday afternoon at the Park Central Hotel for the Douglas W. Paige Trophy of the new Atlantic National Bridge Championships. The United States Bridge Association, which is sponsoring the week's program of events, had expected an entry list of more than twenty teams.
Ray Murphy, national commander of the American Legion, gave assurance yesterday that his organization would not seek general service pensions for World War veterans at this session of Congress.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Playing with a badly swollen finger on his right hand, due to infection from a cut, Tommy Goodwin, youthful star of the Winged Foot Golf Club at Mamaroneck, N.Y., won his second-round match today in the ninth annual national championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine links.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 29. -- Sir Arthur Wauchope, the High Commissioner, today met with the leaders of all the Arab political parties in Palestine and read to them the British Government's reply to the Arab memorandum submitted last November demanding the establishment of a democratic government, the complete stoppage of Jewish immigration and prohibition of the sale of land to Jews.
MACON, Ga., Jan. 29. -- The text of the address by Governor Talmadge prepared before the convention of anti-Roosevelt Democrats here today was as follows:

When the team of the United States Polo Association rides out at Hurlingham, London, next June to defend the Westchester Cup in the resumption of the international series with England, it will be without the services of Thomas Hitchcock Jr., the only ten-goal polo player in the world.

No extension or leniency will be granted to motorists of the city who fail to display the 1936 license plates on their automobiles after midnight tomorrow, the Police Department and the Bureau of Motor Vehicles warned yesterday.

Senator BORAH began his appeal to Republican voters in New York by commiserating them on having for years been "disfranchised." What he meant was that they have no part in the selection of delegates to the National Convention of their party. The question of his fitness to be President been raised.

Artur Schnabel's third recital in his Beethoven sonata series, like the first two, was cannily arranged to provide fruitful contrasts and similarities in the development of the composer's mind and style. The program at Carnegie Hall last night began with the Sonata in A, Op. 2, No. 2.

HELSINGFORS, Jan. 29. -- Thirteen Finnish shipowners claiming about $1,600,000 damages from the United States for the alleged unwarranted detention of Finnish ships in American ports during the World War have appealed to the Finnish Cabinet for official support of their efforts to collect.

The estate of Colonel James A. Blair Jr., corporation official and art collector, who died on Aug. 14, 1934, was appraised yesterday at $1,063,657 gross and $955,030 net. He had securities worth $953,380, notes valued at $18,805, cash amounting to $44,582 and personal: effects, including art objects, worth $16,463.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- A dozen Democratic Senators were informed at a private conference with Harry L. Hopkins today that almost as many persons are on the dole or work relief as a year ago.

The insignificant speck in the sky which was identified recently by Harvard astronomers as a "celestial Haroun-al-Raschid parading through the heavens in the raiment of a beggar, was shown last night in photograph, for the first time in New York, by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The battle of the navy versus the woman patriots grew into a major engagement on all fronts today as Capitol Hill and the Republican National Committee took up the cry of "politics" following the withdrawal of naval officers from the program of the conference on national defense as a protest against Bainbridge Colby's speech attacking the New Deal and the Roosevelt administration.

William Ziegler Jr., chairman of the New York Borah-for-President Committee, yesterday urged friends of the Idaho Senator to present candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention in each of the forty-five Congressional districts of the State.

Directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock and the regular quarterly dividend of 87 1/2 cents on the preferred. On Aug. 30 and Nov. 30, 1935, 50 cents was paid on the common.

Colonel Bill Terry's pennant hopes for 1936 rest upon a squad of thirty-three players, it was revealed yesterday as copies of the Giant roster for the coming campaign were distributed by Secretary Jim Tierney. The roster itself is something of an artistic triumph, an elegant plush-covered brochure and containing on the first page, in memoriam, a picture of the club's late owner, Charles A. Stoneham.

Despite selective admissions the privately controlled colleges have no monopoly in the business of providing the country with an intellectual aristocracy, according to Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, who spoke yesterday at the midyear commencement of Hunter College in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- If Finland deducts from future war debt payments sums she considers due to meet her diplomatic claim for damages because of the detention for several months of thirteen of her auxliary sailing vessels in New York Harbor in 1918, she will become a defaulter, unless President Roosevelt should decide not to press the issue and accept partial installments of token payments.

Sixteen of the country's outstanding chess experts will be admitted to the forthcoming tournament for the United States championship to be held in this city, beginning on March 28. This decision was reached at a meeting of the tournament committee of the National Chess Federation, U.S.A., held yesterday at the offices of its chairman, Harold M. Phillips, president of the Manhattan Chess Club.

Three A.S.P.C.A. agents, all experts at rescuing exhausted pigeons from steeples and extracting curious cats from crevices, received an assignment yesterday morning to recover a black duck from the murky, ice-caked Hudson River, where, so reported, the duck for two days had been marooned with an ice-crusted, injured wing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Secret documents of the State Department disclosed today how Woodrow Wilson personally charted the nation's neutrality policy in the stirring days prior to American entrance into the World War.

More than 30,000 automobile owners in the city, it was estimated, obtained new license plates yesterday for their cars at the seventeen offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles. The bureau's headquarters, 155 Worth Street, were jammed all day with registrants, but no disorder was reported.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 30. -- Finishing with a birdie deuce on the 130-yard sixteenth hole, Tommy Goodwin of the Winged Foot Club of Mamaroneck, N.Y., winner of the event in 1934, defeated Jack Ryerson, former Yale team member, in the quarter-finals of the ninth annual national championship of golf club champions on St. Augustine links today. The 22-year-old star triumphed by 4 and 2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Within two minutes today the Senate confirmed the appointment of six members of the new Federal Reserve Board which will take office, under the Banking Act of 1935, on Saturday. President Roosevelt's recommendations for appointment were ratified as a whole and without a dissenting vote.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 30. -- The Olympic bob run was opened today, but the American representatives refused to go down it, declaring that the run was unfit for use. Teams from several other nations tried the slide but gave up when the going proved so soft that the sleds constantly overturned.
So far it has been so good for the defending champion, little Robert Grant 3d, in the annual metropolitan squash racquets singles championship now being decided on the courts of the University Club.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 30. -- Basing their predictions on telephone calls and telegrams from the conservative East, managers of Governor Alf M. Landon declared today that he would enter the Republican convention as the leading candidate for the Presidential nomination.
MOSCOW, Jan. 30. -- There is still no mercy for those whom the Soviet Union considers profiteers and wreckers.

Though one party will doubtless defer to another before the time comes, a three-play conflict is in prospect for Monday, Feb. 17. "Mainly for Lovers" announced itself yesterday for that date, already claimed by S.N. Behrman's "End of Summer" and James M. Cain's "The Postman Always Rings Twice."

Net operating income of the Class I railroads in December was $47,000,000, according to an estimate based on returns to date, compared with $38,729,833 in December, 1934, an increase of 21.3 per cent. The roads' net operating income was $37,726,339 in December, 1933.

Announcement that the National Foreign Trade Council has been incorporated in order to cope with the wider range of its activities was made by E.P. Thomas, president, at the council's annual meeting and dinner in the Metropolitan Club.

Renewal by Senator Clark of the old charge that William Jennings Bryan betrayed his father, the late Champ Clark, in the Baltimore convention seems to be a rather belated performance. The accusation rests on a delicate question of political ethics.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30. -- A new slate of coaches will handle the football destinies of Tulane University.

Lady Thornton gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. S. Proctor Brady, Mrs. Jerome Hill and Mrs. Henry McComb Bangs. Another luncheon there was given by Mrs. Willard S. Brown for Mrs. Duncan Sterling, Mrs. Thompson Drexel, Mrs. Arthur Ryle, Mrs. Montaigu La Montagne and Mrs. Morris de Peyster.

Philip A.S. Franklin, for more than thirty years a leading figure in the American shipping world, relinquished yesterday his duties as president of the International Mercantile Marine Company on the eve of his sixty-fifth birthday. His son, John M. Franklin, was elected his successor at a meeting of the board of directors at the company's offices, 1 Broadway.

Increases of 4.3 per cent in sales of chain store systems and of 8.9 per cent by wholesalers during December were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank noted that total sales of department stores in the metropolitan area during the first half of January were 10.7 per cent higher, following a rise of 4.3 per cent for January and of 1.7 per cent for the entire year of 1935.

AVALON, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP). -- Fred Morrison of Pasadena, Calif., and Ted Longworth, Portland, Ore., led in the first round of play today in the Santa Catalina Island $5,000 open golf tournament with 60, six under par.

The Sterling Securities Corporation, an investment company controlled by the Atlas Corporation, reported yesterday that its total net assets on Dec. 31, 1935, after a reserve of $691,000 for Federal income tax on unrealized appreciation, were $18,782,530, equivalent to $79.73 a share on the 235,573 shares of first-preferred stock outstanding on that date.

With more than 32,000 certiorari cases arising from disputes between owners and the city over assessed valuations of properties, plans are being laid to speed up action on these cases, it was learned yesterday.

Two $50-a-week "salesmen" for the Union Pacific Produce Company received "bonuses" totaling more than $10,000 during the artichoke season of 1931, Joseph Frieden, bookkeeper for the company, testified yesterday in Federal court at the trial of five men accused of constituting an artichoke racket.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The Senate voted $7,369 to the Nye Munitions Investigating Committee late today and the investigation probably will be resumed Monday with J.P. Morgan, Thomas W. Lamont and George Whitney of J. P. Morgan Co., as the witnesses.

Commonwealth The of Massachusetts will enter the market on Feb. 14 with an issue of $4,000,000 of serial bonds authorized under the Public Works Loan Act of 1935. Dated Feb. 15, 1936, the bonds will mature from 1937 to 1941. Bidders are to name the rate of interest to apply on the entire issue in multiples of one-quarter of 1 per cent.

With the deadline two weeks distant, only sixty-two of the 167 foreign governments and corporations whose securities are listed on the New York Stock Exchange have applied or have signified their intention of applying for permanent registration of their issues under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

The Trinity Church Corporation continued to play a leading part in lower Manhattan real estate activity yesterday when it disposed of a tall structure in the City Hall Park area. The deal affects the fourteen-story Postal Building at 253 Broadway, northwest corner of Murray Street, which has been purchased by the Junior Leasing Corporation, John C. Penrose president.

Cardinal Hayes, in a letter yesterday to the pastors of the 370 parishes in the Archdiocese of New York, designated the week of April 16 to May 4 for the annual appeal for funds to support the 1936 work of the Catholic Charities of New York.

Arturo Toscanini devoted his efforts to the interpretation of compositions by the three great B's of music -- Bach, Beethoven and Brahms -- at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. The Leipzig cantor was represented by his "Brandenburg" concerto, No. 2, in F major, and Beethoven by two works of his second period, the overture to "Coriolanus" and the Fourth Symphony.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 29, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,488,000,000, an increase of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $22,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
Mrs. Prudence Patterson, 37, Has Average of 92.5% -- Plays Bridge, Swims and Dances.

S. Bayard Colgate, president of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, Jersey City, was elected president of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., at the organization's annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore, yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The price of victory came high to two former winners of the Grand National Steeplechase, today when Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller, victor in 1934, and Major Noel Furlong's Reynoldstown, surprise victor last year, were assigned top weights for the ninety-seventh running of the jumping classic at Aintree March 27.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 30. -- After nine days without a Ministry, Egypt saw a settlement of her political crisis today with the formation of a new Cabinet. Aly Maher Pasha, Chief of the Royal Cabinet, was charged with forming a Ministry.

Two men accused of being members of an interstate bankruptcy ring that swindled creditors of thousands of dollars during its operation between 1934 and 1935 were held yesterday by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, for removal to Philadelphia, where three other men are on trial on similar charges in Federal court.

At the risk of setting up class against class, it must be pointed out that the 250,000 Winter sportsmen who have invaded New England are divided into two classes. There are the skee-ers and the she-ers. No doubt the plain people for whom President Roosevelt has done so much pronounce it skee in their own blunt native fashion.

ISTANBUL, Jan. 30. -- Turkey has answered the Italian note in which the Turkish Government was asked whether the affirmative reply to Great Britain's query about security in the Mediterranean was irreconcilable with the Turko-Italian treaty of friendship signed in 1928.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -Senator Vandenberg of Michigan called today for a "legislative formula" to guide the government in making contributions for relief in the States.

The latest improved model of the "Biway" system of continuously moving, endless electric platforms, first proposed in May, 1932, as a means for improving transit in the congested areas of large cities, was described yesterday before the annual Winter meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- The North Garden of the Bellevue Stratford tonight was the scene of the dinner dance given by the Pennsylvania Society of Mayflower Descendants. The 155 guests were received by Governor General and Mrs. Burnham Standish Colburn, Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Stoddard and Mr. and Mrs. Laurence H. Eldredge.

Congress having overriden the veto of the Bonus Bill by the President, he naturally requests it to provide the money for carrying out the law which it had made. The usual form of a special appropriation bill, such as Mr. ROOSEVELT asked Congress to pass, is that the money shall be paid out of funds in the Treasury "not otherwise appropriated."
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

The New York Junior League Glee Club and the Yale University Glee Club will give a joint concert tonight at Rosemary Hall in Greenwich under the direction of Marshall Bartholomew, director of both clubs. This will be the Junior League Glee Club's first program of the season.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 30. -- The recent Supreme Court decision holding the AAA unconstitutional will have a wholesome economic, social and political effect, but has left agriculture in the United States with the same problems that it faced before enactment of the farm legislation, Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank of New York, told farm, business and industrial leaders of Indiana here today.

The annual report of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation for 1935, made public yesterday, shows net income of $15,867,591, a new high record, excluding any income from the company's investment in its own securities. This is equal, after preference dividends, to $6.25 a share on the outstanding common stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- President Roosevelt observed his fifty-fourth birthday. He visited Louis Howe, his Chief Secretary, who is ill, dined at the White House with a group of old associates, and spoke on the radio, thanking those who contributed to the success of the birthday balls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- While an estimated 5,000,000 persons danced tonight at balls held in 6,000 cities and towns as benefits to finance the fight against infantile paralysis in celebration of President Roosevelt's fifty-fourth birthday anniversary, the object of this tribute presided at a quiet dinner at the White House.

Only four or five places on the New York County delegation to the Republican National Convention remain open, it was indicated yesterday as the tentative assignment of the twenty-one posts became known.

With the women's garment manufacturing industry concentrating on the production of mannish suits, stocks of men's wear suitings became acutely scarce in the wool goods market this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.
Members of the Aldermanic Committeee on Buildings divided sharply yesterday on voting approval of the new Building Code, after a stormy public hearing at City Hall.

ATLANTA, Jan. 30. -- Governor Eugene Talmadge said today that he was ready to campaign from "Coast to Coast" for the declaration of principles adopted yesterday at Macon by a "grass roots convention," which asked him to lead the fight to drive New Deal "Communists" out of office.

A glittering pageant called "Health, Wealth and Happiness" featured the President's Birthday Ball at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night. The ball, attended by more than 3,500 persons, was one of the largest parties among the thousands held throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Remington Rand, Inc., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $20,000,000 of twenty-year 4 1/4 per cent debentures, due on March 1, 1956, with stock-purchase warrants attached.

TRENTON, Jan. 30. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman ordered the New Jersey State police today to renew their investigation of the Lindbergh kidnapping murder and to find the accomplices of Bruno Richard Hauptmann.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa will arrive today from Bremen and channel ports, a day behind schedule as a result of Winter storms on the Atlantic. She is due to reach her dock in the late afternoon and sail out again shortly after midnight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Two members of President Roosevelt's official family made new attacks on Governor Talmadge today. They were Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and PWA administrator, and Harry L. Hopkins, WPA head. Mr. Hopkins has turned over to the Federal Attorney at Atlanta charges that Mr. Talmadge's political aides have used WPA workers and funds to distribute campaign propaganda.

Aristophanes would be delighted. So would John James Audubon. For the Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street, has been turned into an aviary. It is not an aviary in the strict sense, since some of the birds date back to 1785, and all of them are fashioned in stone, wood, metal, papier-mache, alabaster, chalkware and ceramic, as the case may be.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Transfer of $2,000,000,000 in gold certificates from the Treasury to the New York Federal Reserve Bank may be followed by action of other Reserve Banks in withdrawing a part of their holdings now maintained at the Treasury, it was learned today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30. -- Soviet Russia has found a way to give an unmistakable hint to Japan that the Soviet Union's eastern defenses are strong and her people are united against any plans for expansion at the expense of their territory.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The Boston Braves became the Boston Bees today after a committee of twenty-five baseball writers and one cartoonist listened to the 1,327 nicknames submitted by thousands of widely scattered fans.

The third anniversary of Hitler's accession to power was celebrated here last night by an audience of more than 3,000 persons of German origin in Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, by invitation of the German Consul General. Dr. Hans Borchers, who called it "the Fourth of July of Germany."

The 110th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York -- oldest veterans' organization in the country -- will take place tonight at the Commodore. With a blue and gray motif, the event will honor the Civil War veterans of both the North and the South.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
War veterans should not be refused city relief upon payment of their bonus, Mayor La Guardia and Controller Frank J. Taylor declared yesterday in a joint statement.

Puccini's "Tosca" was the opera last night at the Metropolitan Opera House -- the first "Tosca" of the season. The audience had opportunity to glory in the robust tones of Mr. Tibbett as Scarpia, and the moving though not subtle or Italianate Tosca of Mme.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- The report of Governor Jean Tannery of the Bank of France, delivered under dramatic circumstances at the annual meeting of the bank this afternoon, assumed the nature of an ardent appeal to the French people to defend the franc until such time as international monetary stabilization became possible.

The second in a series of teas was given yesterday at 124 East Seventy-ninth Street, the home of the Misses Miriam and Dorothea Tooley, for the group arranging the dinner dance to be given Feb. 24 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Barat Settlement House, Houston and Chrystie Streets.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The Atlantic Passenger Conference made such progress today that by tomorrow night, when the six weeks' notice of resignation from the group of the Cunard White Star Line expires, the problem caused by the company's designation of the new liner Queen Mary as a cabin ship not only will be settled but the whole schedule of Atlantic fares will be amicably recast.

On his way to Pittsburgh for a conference with fellow-coaches on the gridiron rules, D.O. (Tuss) McLaughry of Brown, president of the American Football Coaches' Association, yesterday suggested the rulemakers ban all "hard protective equipment."

While still above the totals for the comparative week of last year, bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday did not show so large a percentage increase as in the week before. The total for twenty-two leading cities in the United States, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,272,618,000, compared with $5,119,085,000 a year ago.

Following short-lived strength in the first hour of trading, the share market turned irregular yesterday and in the final hour easier to close slightly lower on the day. The overnight news that President Roosevelt had asked Congress to appropriate $2,250,000,000 to finance the bonus set the "inflationists" in Congress in motion, but as the "views" of these advocates of currency-tinkering came over the financial news tickers, followers of the market were not unduly impressed.

Every member of the police force was asked yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine to contribute $1 to the Police Band Fund, which is used to buy uniforms and instruments for the Police Band and to pay the salary of its musical instructor.

Although no public information has thus far been made available on the proposed plan of recapitalization of the Radio Corporation of America that was delivered to the directors by Joseph P. Kennedy last Friday, a heavy influx of overnight buying orders delayed the opening of the Class B preferred stock on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday until sufficient selling orders could be found.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- Declaring that large sections of the British people are still undernourished, the head of one of Britain's "big five" banks called on his government today to push the consumption of foodstuffs and to give its people more to eat.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30. -- A private showing today marked the opening of the Palm Beach Art Center for its fourth season under the direction of Junzio Vayana. On the walls of the gallery, formerly the Oasis Club, are works by 170 contemporary artists, more than half National Academy members.

While more than 30,000 workers continued the gigantic task of clearing the streets of frozen snow and ice left by the storm of twelve days ago, the Board of Estimate at a special meeting yesterday appropriated an additional $1,500,000 to carry on the work.

Charles Yanowsky, 29 years old, described by the Department of Justice as "one of the most dangerous criminals in this part of the country," was shot and seriously wounded about 10:30 o'clock last night in Hoboken by Federal men who had been led to him by the tip of an accomplice.

Declaring that there is no assurance whatever that future depressions can be avoided, T.K. Quinn, president of Maxon, Inc., advertising counselors, said last night that the reasonable assumption is that the present upward trend in business will continue for perhaps five or six years and then the curve will bend downward again.

DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The Black Hawks, behind the brilliant goal-tending of Mike Karakas, beat the Red Wings, 4 to 3, tonight in a wild, rough game to take undisputed leadership in the American division of the National Hockey League.

Behind the facade of National Socialism in Germany, on the anniversary of HITLER'S rise to power, lies an economic problem which cannot be put aside as easily as the rights of a minority or the obligations of a treaty. This problem is the inevitable consequence of the method used thus far to promote that recovery of business and that increase of employment on which the Government's authority so largely depends.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- No German response was made here today to the Polish threat to limit railway traffic through the Polish corridor if Germany does not do something about paying her debt to the Polish railway.

Denial that any contracts in March cotton held by the government had been liquidated this week and that the pool's outstanding long interest in the near month aggregated 178,000 bales exerted a steadying influence on all 1935 crop positions on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Already conceded small chance against their rivals from the north countries, America's Olympic skiers found themselves beset by an injury jinx today.
Although the City Hall Park area provided the outstanding realty deal of the day, houses in Harlem and the Morningside Heights section proved attractive to investors yesterday.

Governor TALMADGE predicted that his convention of anti-Roosevelt Democrats "from seventeen Southern and border States" would bring an audience of 10,000. If 6,500 of the expected enthusiasts didn't turn up he blames the cold weather. Possibly the generous hand that would have paid the fares was frozen.

ROME, Jan. 30. -- The conviction that has been gaining ground in Italy recently that another Winter of war will be necessary to force the Ethiopians to capitulate received confirmation from Premier Benito Mussolini today.

Whether or not the showing forecasts a reversal of the unfavorable trend in local retail trade during much of last year, merchants yesterday expressed satisfaction with sales volume during the month which closes today. Practically all of the large establishments here will show increases for the period, with the average gain for the district expected to be comfortably above 10 per cent.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 30. -- On behalf of the International Olympic Committee the Norwegian representative, Thomas Faernley, has proposed to the Norwegian Nobel Committee the award of the peace prize to Baron Pierre de Coubertin, founder of the modern Olympic Games.

Nothing so clearly and depressingly illustrates the moral, intellectual and ethical decadence of our Congressional representatives as the vindictive personal attacks made from the floor of both houses against a long line of Democratic standard-bearers, a national party treasurer, a convention leader and many political and platform technicians.
THIS is the way it was once explained to me by Van Wyck Brooks or some one else of the sort:

A collection of thirty-nine autograph letters by the late Colonel T.E. Lawrence, written between 1931 and 1935, were sold at auction yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., for $3,800. The buyer was an agent for a private collector.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- The Boerse was firm again today. Several security issues responded buoyantly to dividend announcements. Heavy industrials were relatively quiet, but Vereinigtestahl gained 3/8 point. Potashes were virtually inactive. Machines were mixed, with a tendency to strength, Berlin Karlsruhe, dominant in the list, gaining 1/2
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Consumer resistance to high prices for hog products continued to depress the market for hogs here today. While early sales were 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower, the demand was not aggressive and late in the day sales were reported at losses of 20 to 25 cents.

The article in THE TIMES last Sunday by Joseph H. Choate Jr., formerly director of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, advocating a "shift to wines" is a counsel of perfection. As such it tends to divert attention and effort in a direction which experience has demonstrated to be quite ineffective.

Sixteen prominent men, one of whom was former Governor Alfred E. Smith, have been upheld by the United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue in their protest against an attempt by the government to tax them on "dues" to the Oakland Golf Club at Bayside, L.I., of which they were honorary members paying no dues, James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue, said yesterday.

Brokers announced contracts for the leasing of various store, office and showroom units in the city yesterday. While most of the space was taken in buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan, the renting activity extended to other areas.

Roger N. Baldwin, chairman of the International Committee for Political Prisoners, made public yesterday an appeal to the Soviet Government of Russia for information about the fate of Sergei Trotsky, 27-year-old son of Leon Trotsky and of Mrs. Sergei Trotsky.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 30. -- The battle in Ras Kassa Sebat's sector of the northern front is continuing. The Italians appear to be concentrating on the recapture of a fort named Shum Aberra in Tembien, commanding the Adowa road, which was captured Jan. 21.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to borrow an additional $5,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and to postpone payment to that agency of other loans totaling $5,500,000 from January-April, 1936, until Aug. 1, 1939.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The Soviet Government delivered a formal protest tonight to the Japanese Ambassador, Tamekichi Ota, against the alleged invasion of Soviet Far Eastern territory today by a force of Japanese and Manchukuoan soldiers.

A light-polarizing "glass" that transforms motion pictures into a fairyland of substance and reality, appears adequately to solve the problem of automobile headlight glare, clarifies problems of facial beauty treatment hitherto unfathomable, and aids human vision in many other ways was shown in New York yesterday for the first time.

Cotton textile mills yesterday made plans for quick payment of processing-tax refunds to their customers, in line with the decision reached by mill executives in conference in Washington on the previous day, and expectations were that checks would be sent out shortly.
Oscar, the pet pigeon of Rockefeller Center, who had been missing for two days, was found dead yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The stock markets here were quieter today and irregular, with end-account profit-taking, but the undertone remained firm. British funds at first weakened, under the influence of the new railway finance loan, but later improved.

E.H. Campbell, formerly advertising and sales promotion manager of Rex Cole, Inc., has been appointed manager of the newly created retail sales agents department of Remington portable typewriter division of Remington-Rand, Inc., with headquarters at 205 West Forty-second Street.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The fourth month of Premier Benito Mussolini's venture in Ethiopia drew toward a close today with Italy's swift push in the southwest sector holding the spotlight while the armies in the north and southeast were at a standstill.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, appealed yesterday to Secretary of Commerce Roper to assume an "aggressive leadership" of the newly inaugurated campaign to obtain Federal legislation that will improve conditions on American merchant ships.

In New Jersey a man has been granted a divorce from his wife on the ground of extreme cruelty and awarded the custody of their two children. Both decisions of the court may conceivably have been warranted; it is the reasons that the court gives, particularly for depriving the mother of custody of her children, that arouse misgivings.

ATHENS, Jan. 30. -- To the anti-Venizelists' annoyance the publication today of the official election figures revealed that the Venizelists and Democrats had received 144 seats in Parliament and the anti-Venizelists only 141.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Speaker Ives of the Assembly and Senator Fearon, Republican leaders of the Legislature, accepted tonight the invitation of Governor Lehman to participate in a conference next Wednesday on ways and means to establish a permanent system for administering unemployment relief.

The Montreal Maroons trailed the New York Americans going into the last five minutes of their game at Madison Square Garden last night but a spirited surge enabled the Canadian skaters to win. A goal by Hooley Smith gave the Maroons a tie and, with less than two minutes remaining, Russ Blinco blasted a shot past Roy Worters that gave the Maroons a 8-to-2 triumph.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30. -- For the first time in the history of the new Hialeah Park, a race over the turf course held the honored position on a Miami Jockey Club program today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Pierre S. du Pont was represented to the Senate today as one of the largest income-tax contributors in 1929, as the donor of nearly $1,000,000 to charity in that year, and as one "of the finest characters this or any other generation has produced in America."

Three new films are listed on today's schedule. They are "Rose Marie," featuring Nelson Eddy and Jeanette MacDonald, at the Capitol; "King of the Damned," with Noah Beery, Conrad Veidt and Helen Vinson, at the Roxy, and "Two in the Dark," with Margot Graham and Walter Abel, at the Palace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Steadying after a sharp decline in the two preceding weeks, the general wholesale price level remained unchanged in the week ended on Jan. 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index remained at 80.2, compared with 79 a year ago, based on the 1926 average as 100.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 30. -- Everett R. Appelgate, former Nassau County American Legion official, and Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, both of Baldwin, L.I., were sentenced today by County Judge Cortland A. Johnson here to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison the week of March 9 for the poison murder of Appelgate's wife, Ada, last Sept. 27.

Tenement houses formed the bulk of realty offered by auctioneers at foreclosure sales in Manhattan yesterday when nine properties were put up for bidding at stands in the auction exchange at 18 Vesey Street. All nine parcels were bought in by the plaintiffs.

After a day of aerodynamic discussion at the Pupin Physics Laboratories at Columbia University, at which improved control for airplanes and the possibilities of much heavier armaments for military aircraft were revealed, the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences held its annual dinner last night at the Faculty Club.

The auction sale of paintings, furniture, rugs and objects of art collected by the late Robert W. de Forest, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Mrs. de Forest was completed yesterday at their residence, 7 Washington Square North.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- With a program that was cheered on the Left and coldly received on the Right the new French Cabinet, presided over by Premier Albert Sarraut, went today before the Chamber of Deputies and tomorrow will put its fortunes to a vote.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- A bill to carry out the farm relief views of Governor Landon of Kansas, Republican aspirant for the Presidential nomination, was introduced in the House today by Representative Hope, ranking minority member of the Agriculture Committee, just as the Senate received a favorable report from its own farm committee on the administration's stop-gap soil conservation program.

The annual report of the City Superintendent of Schools has set a precedent that is alluring and in a sense perilous, for it seems difficult to live up to it. It is a striking departure from its thirty-six predecessors in that it has not a forbidding aspect. Citizens who have not been inside school rooms will be surprised to know what attractive places some of them are.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 30. -- A strike was begun yesterday by workers of the Huasteca Petroleum Company in the Ebano section of the State of Vera Cruz. Although it involves no more than 600 men, the strike is considered most important from the viewpoint of foreign investment, for the labor demands are greater than any recorded in the long and frequent troubles between Mexican labor and foreign oil operators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The Italian Superpower Corporation, a Delaware corporation, half of whose voting stock is owned by the Instituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, a semi-governmental institution formed under the laws of Italy, and half by American interests, was exempted today, as a holding company, from the provisions of Title I of the Public Utility Act of 1935 by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Economically it is good for women to have their clothes fit well. Psychologically it is even better, members of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs were informed yesterday at a conference at the Hotel Astor. Because well-fitted frocks not only increase women's chic and self-confidence, but add to their attractiveness and therefore promote romance.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 30. -- Wesley Andersch, a salesman, identified Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld today as the occupant of the gunner's seat of the car from which the shots that killed Walter W. Liggett were fired.

J. Richard Leonard and Malcolm Kirkbride, the defending title holders, and Huntington D. Sheldon and Joseph W. Brooks, winners of the crown in 1934, reached the final round of the national racquets doubles championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

" This Simian World," by the late Clarence Day, will be a co-selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club for March. It will be offered along with "The House in Paris," by Elizabeth Bowen. This is the third book by Clarence Day to be sent out by the Book-of-the-Month Club in the last twelve months, two of his books, "God and My Father" and "Life With Father," having been the club choices in ,ugust.

Life insurance in force in the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company at the end of 1935 was the greatest on record for the company at $20,269,349,576, a gain of $779,544,101 in the year, Frederick H. Ecker, president, stated yesterday at the opening session here of the three-day convention of the company's managers.

A drive for funds to help alleviate the increased hardships suffered by needy families during the recent cold spell was started yesterday by the Heckscher Foundation for Children, 1 East 104th Street.

TOKYO, Jan. 30. -- The reading of a letter written in blood and the weeping of the prisoner and his defender in an abandonment of patriotic emotion were the highlights today in the trial of Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa for the murder of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, director of the Military Affairs Bureau, in the War Office on Aug. 12, 1935.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- President Roosevelt turned away larger matters today to recommend in a message to Congress that consideration be given to procedure for conservation of "little rivers."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Facts of the migratory movement of Negroes in the United States are told in a new study by the Census Bureau. This shows that in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Washington, Detroit, Memphis, St. Louis, Cleveland and Pittsburgh 50 per cent or more of the Negro population was born in some other State.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Five optional forms of government for up-State counties under which useless offices and governmental functions would be abolished in the interest of economy and efficiency are provided in a bill introduced today in the Legislature at the request of the State Tax Revision Commission, headed by former Senator Seabury C. Mastick, Westchester Republican.

Establishment of a free foreign trade zone at Stapleton, S.I., was hailed by Mayor La Guardia and city officials yesterday as a great spur to business, while opposition to the free zone was expressed by the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and the American Jewelers Protective Association.

An interesting experiment in "planting" food on barren ocean bottoms to attract bottom-feeding game fish will be launched here next Spring, providing approval of the project is obtained from Federal authorities.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Stavka, 4-year-old gelding, won the $1,000 Ocean Park Handicap today at Santa Anita. The time for the six furlongs, on a damp track, was 1:13 1-5.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Increased liquidation in May wheat by tired longs depressed prices 3/8 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, the price dropping to the lowest level since Dec. 28. However, at 99 cents aggressive buying appeared.

The dollar declined yesterday on the foreign exchange market to the lowest price since March 6, 1935, as Representative Patman of Texas and Senator Thomas of Oklahoma gave notice in Washington of a drive to force the Treasury to issue additional amounts of currency.
THE esteemed president of the National League, Ford Christopher Frick, was speaking about baseball, which is something he will do on the slightest provocation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 30. -- The ancient curse of money is the chief fiber of "End of Summer," an arresting and interesting, albeit involved play by S.N. Behrman, which had its premiere here this evening at the Bushnell Memorial before an audience of 3,000 persons.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- Many persons of wealth and title who were among the 1,200 guests at the now-famous all-night card party in aid of charity given at Sunderland House in December, 1934, crowded Judge Finlay's court today to hear Keith Hugh Williams, a promoter, tell how he had lost 12,000 in a few hours.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Brig. Gen. Stanley H. Ford, commanding the First Infantry Brigade of the First Division in New York, and Colonel George R. Spalding, division engineer at New York, were among a dozen army officers designated for promotion today in nominations sent to the Senate.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- How the French center of information, which will open spacious offices in New York and Paris March 1, has been created from the voluntary cooperation of French and American business firms was described here today by Count Rene de Chambrun speaking to the American Club.

The timid Sisters Ready, who were pink-cheeked schoolma'ms at Old 44 on the site of the Dominie Bogardus Farm in North Moore Street back in the Eighties, were found dead of exposure yesterday in their three-room flat on the ground floor of 82 Morgan Avenue in the Greenpoint district of Brooklyn.

The United Aircraft Corporation expects to realize between $5,000,000 and $6,000,000 from the sale of stock in accordance with measures to be voted upon by stockholders on March 6, according to a notice of the meeting issued yesterday. When the proposal to increase the company's authorized stock was announced recently, it was reported that Brown, Harriman Co., Inc., would underwrite an offering.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- A wildly enthusiastic convention, by the unanimous action of more than 1,700 delegates, today authorized the officers of the United Mine Workers of America to take the first step that would sever the union from its affiliation with the American Federation of Labor.

At the close of the market yesterday prices of stocks showed an average gain of a little more than 3 per cent for January. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks stood at 116.85, against 112.95 at the end of December. It seems unlikely that a sufficiently large decline will occur today to cancel the advance of the first thirty days of the month.
At a special meeting in City Hall yesterday the Board of Estimate authorized the expenditure of $9,563,000 for relief during February.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30. -- The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and wholly owned subsidiaries, in the annual report for 1935 filed today with the State Public Service Commission, stated that net income amounted to $6,288,203 and the balance available for the common stock, after allowing $1,144,764 for preferred dividends, amounted to $5,143,439.50, equivalent to $4.41 a share on 1,167,397 shares of common stock.

Following the consent decree terminating the Department of Justice's anti-trust suit against the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and others late on Wednesday, announcement was made yesterday by Philip G. Gossler, president of the corporation, of plans to finance the construction of a 300-mile natural gas pipe-line system at a cost of $18,000,000 to connect the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company's gas transmission lines with the Detroit Gas Company's system.

WARSAW, Jan. 30. -- German railroad traffic through the Polish Corridor will be restricted Feb. 7 unless Germany begins to pay frozen dues now amounting to 68,000,000 zlotys, the semi-official Iskra Agency announced today.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- How the French center of information, which will open spacious offices in New York and Paris March 1, has been created from the voluntary cooperation of French and American business firms was described here today by Count Rene de Chambrun speaking to the American Club.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation issued yesterday its preliminary report for 1935, showing a net profit of $4,291,253, after charges equivalent to $4.59 a share on the 933,887 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock. This is the largest profit for any year since 1930. In 1934 the profit was $550,571, or 59 cents a share, on the preferred stock.
Prices in the commodity-futures markets were irregular yesterday in generally quiet trading. In the cash markets, corn, rye, and lard were higher, while wheat, hides and rubber were lower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Plans for perhaps the largest tax program since President Roosevelt took office, needed to finance the new farm program, liquidate the old AAA and pay the veterans' bonus enacted over a Presidential veto, were discussed at the White House today by President Roosevelt, with Secretaries Morgenthau and Wallace, Attorney General Cummings and Daniel W. Bell, Acting Director of the Budget.

Following the consent decree terminating the Department of Justice's anti-trust suit against the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and others late on Wednesday, announcement was made yesterday by Philip G. Gossler, president of the corporation, of plans to finance the construction of a 300-mile natural gas pipe-line system at a cost of $18,000,000 to connect the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company's gas transmission lines with the Detroit Gas Company's system.

WARSAW, Jan. 30. -- German railroad traffic through the Polish Corridor will be restricted Feb. 7 unless Germany begins to pay frozen dues now amounting to 68,000,000 zlotys, the semi-official Iskra Agency announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 30. -- Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, which is undergoing reorganization, asked the Federal court today to relieve them from a 22-year-old personal injury settlement made with a woman which has cost the road thus far $193,000.
Conferences were continued yesterday between representatives of employers and employes in the dress and fur industries in last-minute efforts to avert strikes scheduled to go into effect tomorrow.

The three teams that will represent the metropolitan district in the women's intercity squash racquets matches at Merion, Pa., next week were named yesterday by Mrs. A.J. Lamme Jr., chairman of the selection committee.

The two top seeded players, Kenneth R. Davidson and Kenneth J. Ridgway, ranked in that order, advanced to the final round of the Eastern New York badminton championships yesterday on the courts of the Tudor City Tennis Club in the 165th Infantry Armory.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- National Socialist Germany celebrated today the Third Reich's third birthday and the beginning of the year IV of Adolf Hitler's rule with all the spectacular display both of pomp and power that has become traditional under the new regime.

Complete fields were announced yesterday by the Millrose A.A. for its twenty-ninth annual indoor athletic carnival at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, and the announcement brought in its wake a wealth of statistical data.

DOGHEA PASS, Near Makale, Northern Ethiopia, Jan. 29 (delayed). -- The Ethiopian positions on Amba Aradam, across the no man's land separating the contending forces, were severely bombed by the Italian artillery positions in this vicinity today.

Herman Axel, Clinton representative, whose stellar play has been one of the highlights of the competition, scored a noteworthy triumph as play reached the quarterfinal round in the tenth annual De Witt Clinton High School invitation indoor interscholastic tennis tournament yesterday at the 369th Infantry Armory.

SUNBURY, Pa., Friday, Jan. 31. -- Three persons were killed and thirty-seven injured at 11:40 o'clock last night when the crack Reading Railroad express, the Williams-porter, was derailed as it approached the Susquehanna River Bridge at Clement Station, across the river from here.

James P. Warburg, vice chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, and opponent of President Roosevelt's monetary policies, told "America's Town Meeting" last night at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, that the whole currency and banking system of the United States needs reform today even more than it did when the New Deal went into effect.

A four-point long-range program emphasizing youth training, international relations, rights of minorities and women's place in civic life was placed yesterday before the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations at its sixteenth annual convention in the Hotel Astor.

Six contract bridge teams-of-four survived the second session of round robin elimination yesterday in the contest for four semi-final places for the team-of-four title of the Atlantic National bridge championships at the Park Central Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- Foreign Minister Anthony Eden had still further talks today with Foreign Ministers who had come to England for King George's funeral, but with the exception of Maxim Litvinoff of Russia, Prince Paul, Regent of Yugoslavia, and Prince von Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor of Austria, his callers represented smaller States unlikely ever to be vital factors in international politics.

Other public bodies may well envy the New York Port Authority. Although it has been engaged for some years on an immense program of bridge building and tunnel digging, it has managed -- thanks largely to the Holland tube gold mine -- to take the whole thing in its stride.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 30. -- A proposal to barter Australian wool for German automobile parts, worth 612,000, to be built in Australia into chassis, was killed today when Sir Henry Gullett, Minister in Charge of Trade Treaties, declared the plan impracticable.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, warned today against submission to employes of questionnaires seeking data under the Unemployment Insurance Law which called for answers about church, fraternal or union affiliations and other personal affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Full administration support for comprehensive legislation designed to enable the government to encourage an amplified privately financed housing program is assured, and the government will turn its back upon further federally subsidized slum clearance and low-cost housing, either eliminating it or reducing it to a relatively negligible quantity.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, total bills discounted and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while the reserve note circulation was at the lowest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Neither durable nor general prosperity is possible, said the president of the Banque de France in his annual report today, until the principal moneys of the world are stabilized. He meant the dollar, the pound sterling and the franc, each of which for years has severally played the part of villain in the great international drama that might be called "What Price Recovery?"
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Treasury officials figured today that payment of the soldier bonus will bring the cost of the World War to the American Government to about $45,200,000,000.
The North German Lloyd liner Europa arrived yesterday from Europe thirty hours late because of a succession of storms from Cherbourg to Sandy Hook. She had six inches of ice on her bow.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in January was the heaviest of any month since July, 1933, when 120,300,463 shares were sold, and was with one exception the largest on record for January, the exception being January, 1929, when the turnover was 110,803,940 shares.

Representative Emanuel Celler announced yesterday that he intended to lay all the facts in New York's "gyp" furniture business before the Federal Trade Commission in Washington on behalf of a group of manufacturers and wholesalers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Four large trade associations urged the Supreme Court today to construe the anti-trust laws in such a way that industries could frame their own agreements to protect themselves against cut-throat competition and harmful trade practices.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Unless some ghost nips them at the plate with a miracle throw from center field, Buck Ewing, Pop Anson, Willie Keeler and Cy Young will have their unforgettable names inscribed on plaques in baseball's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y., birthplace of the national game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Cloaked with the most powerful centralized control over banking in the history of this country, the newly organized Federal Reserve Board will assume office officially tomorrow. The Banking Act of 1935 provided that it take office on Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Senator Borah virtually abandoned hope today of making any headway in Pennsylvania with his campaign to "liberalize the Republican party."

OTTAWA, Jan. 31, (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada increased $1,331,771 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. At the same time deposits by chartered banks increased $2,453,454.

Herta Glueckmann, German contralto, made her New York debut last night in a recital at the Town Hall, being well received by a large audience. The artist, who began her career as a soprano, has sung with many orchestras and oratorio societies abroad.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- Sir Josiah Stamp told the Bankers Institute in Liverpool tonight that America had lost the opportunity of becoming the world's financial center which she once appeared to have before Great Britain resumed the gold standard in 1925.

John J. Raskob, who was chairman of the Democratic National Committee during the campaign of Alfred E. Smith for President, has sent out letters to men and women urging them to join the American Liberty League as a rallying point "to root out the vicious radical element that threatens the destruction of our government," it was learned yesterday.

The French Line started yesterday to remove its operating and victualling departments from its North River Pier at Fifteenth Street, which it has occupied twenty-six years, to the new Pier 88, at the foot of West Forty-eighth Street.

While retail distribution improved this week, the general pace of wholesale buying was slower than a week earlier, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail sales for the country as a whole were estimated at 5 to 10 per cent above the total for the corresponding 1935 week, but the agency says that the resumption in the improvement was not uniform.

Caspar Holstein, 50 years old, deposed Negro head of the Harlem policy racket, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions by Justices Hackenburg, Flood and Gresser of operating a small policy game in his old bailiwick.

Mrs. William N. Haskell gave a dinner last night at Mayfair House for Mrs. Dennis E. Nolan, Mrs. Junius Spencer Morgan, Mrs. Walter G. Robinson, Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, Mrs. Lewis Nixon, Mrs. Frank B. Mason, Mrs. David Sarnoff, Mrs. William M. Benjamin, Mrs. Richard C. Colt, Mrs. Morgan J. O'Brien and Mrs. Joseph F. Haskell.

In an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES: Magazine of Jan. 19 Dr. McBain considers the AAA decision in the Supreme Court. Hits severe censure of the logic and his sinister reflections on the motives and purposes of the six justices uniting in the decision demand the careful examination of the thoughtful citizen.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stock from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- The Boerse continued firm today. The basis of the present buoyant mood apparently is the armament boom resulting in favorable reports and dividend announcements by various companies that received heavy government orders last year.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Two bank robbery suspects were killed and another was arrested today after a bank was held up one block from the Sheriff's department pistol range in suburban El Monte.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Increased buying power was apparent today in the wheat market, and while the business was not up to normal, fairly persistent purchases of May on the Board of Trade here and in Minneapolis, credited to mills and cash interests, resulted in a much better feeling.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 31. -- The investigation of Puerto Rican affairs ordered by Senator Tydings's Committee on Insular Affairs, to be conducted by Colonel William C. Rigby, retired army judge advocate, was hailed today by coalition majority leaders.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- An increase from 1,000,000 to 1,500,000 in the subsidy for air routes to develop transatlantic and empire air services is proposed in the Air Navigation Bill, whose text was issued today.

While the Building Service Employes International Union mapped plans to call out, probably Monday, elevator operators, attendants, janitors, porters and other service employes in some 1,200 buildings covered by contracts that expired yesterday, strike violence was reported by elevator operators in at least two buildings.

At Harlow's, in the British Empire Building, the countenances of British and American statesmen and other public figures look out from the walls. William Rollinson's stipple engraving of Alexander Hamilton, a mezzotint (after Copley) of John Hancock, a line engraving of Thomas Paine (1793) by W. Sharp, and amusing silhouettes of Henry Clay and William Henry Harrison are among the unusual material assembled.
An appeal to all citizens to join the authorities in the concerted drive to curb the turning in of false alarms of fire was issued yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman reserved decision yesterday on an application in behalf of Nicholas Roerich, founder of the Roerich Museum, and two others to restrain Louis L. Horch, leader of the anti-Roerich group, from taking control of the museum and its activities.

Two men on a coal truck recognized yesterday the license numbers on a passing automobile and notified a police radio car, with the result that two robber suspects were seized in Flatbush after a chase of almost a mile.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31. -- Foreigners whose incomes were derived from abroad became the new poor of Soviet Russia today as changes in the currency system went into effect, accompanied by the closing of the Torgsin stores and the closing out of accounts in foreign currencies by the State Bank.

Operations of the American Chicle Company in 1935 resulted in a net profit of $2,642,327 after expenses, income taxes, depreciation and other deductions. This is equivalent to $5.94 a share on 445,000 shares of no-par common stock outstanding.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Approval of forty-seven work relief projects, for which $1,022,720.79 has been allocated, was announced today by Lester W. Herzog, up-State WPA administrator.

He was one of the ablest and most popular public men of his time; he had done great things and won great honors; but somehow he never attained the dominant position to which he aspired, and so he found himself suddenly shoved into the background, unoccupied and disappointed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- F.G. Awalt, First Deputy Controller of the Currency, who was Acting Controller during the banking crisis of 1933, has resigned, effective Feb. 15, to re-enter the private practice of law, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.
Frank Ward, world's open squash tennis champion from 1926 through 1934, is returning to the courts after an absence of two years.

The United States Steel Corporation's report for the quarter ending last December is particularly interesting for its reflection, in earnings and profits, of the period covered by the statement and, by comparison, of the depression period which preceded. This large and conservatively managed company, operating in what is perhaps our "key industry," had its ups and downs before 1930.

Large offerings of industrial and railroad bonds, unequaled for a month since July, raised the total of securities offered publicly here last month well above the amounts for either December or January, 1935. The new flotations aggregated $377,649,000, consisting of $371,756,000 for sixty-two bond issues and $5,893,000 for six stock issues, compared with $343,193,716 for offerings in December, when bonds totaled $308,263,750, representing seventy-four issues, and $34,929,966 for eight stock offerings.

Dates for thirty-six hunts meets to be held in various parts of the country during the coming season were granted and action was deferred on three other applications, it was announced yesterday following the annual meeting of the hunt committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.
LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The Russian steamer Pravda, 2,513 tons, and the Italian steamer Fedora, 5,016 tons, collided in a fog off Dungeness in the English Channel early today.

The third for this season of the Caprice Dinner Dances was held last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Subscribers to the series include young married couples, former debutantes and single men.

In his speech Governor LANDON remarked that the goods the farmer has to buy are increased about 25 per cent in cost by the operation of the tariff. As the farmer is forced to sell on the world market, the Governor asked, is he not entitled to some compensating equivalent?

I have just completed a journey through Central and South America. At Colon a German freighter had tied to its decks two locomotives and two passenger cars. An officer of the steamship company informed me that they constituted part of an order for fifty- five locomotives and several hundred railroad cars for a South American country.

Broad questions of policy and operating problems will form the background of discussion at the midwinter conference here next month under the auspices of the trust division of the American Bankers Association. The sessions will be held on Feb. 11, 12 and 13 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Needle trades unions of New York City, representing hundreds of thousands of workers, rallied yesterday to the support of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, in his fight for industrial as against craft unionism.

The city's law department was confronted yesterday with the problem of whether to appeal Magistrate Thomas F. Boyle's ruling that the nineteen-year-old tax on garages within fire zones was "illegal, discriminatory and unconstitutional" to the Court of Special Sessions, or whether to seek to appeal it at once to the Court of Appeals on a question of constitutionality.

For the third consecutive month, both call and time money rates were stationary in January. On the New York Stock Exchange three-quarters of 1 per cent for call loans was the lowest January rate in more than ten years. It compared with 1 per cent the year before.

An appraisal of the holdings of the Alleghany Corporation, once the top company in the Van Sweringen railroad holding structure, to be made today by the Guaranty Trust Company is expected to show that for the first time in three years Alleghany is in a position to pay interest on all its senior obligations.

Payment of 35 per cent of the coupons maturing today of the Greek Government 6 per cent Stabilization and Refugee Loan of 1928 will be made by Speyer Co. or the National City Bank, according to announcement made by the Greek Minister of Finance, G. Mantzavinos.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31. -- A new sensation developed at Tropical Park today with the running of the featured Carol Gables Purse. Steel Cutter, a 4-year-old gelded son of Sir Greysteel-Marie Rose, with only ninety-three pounds on his back, ran the one-mile distance in the smashing time of 1:35 1-5.

Colorful pack competitions, resulting in victories for representatives of the Cheshire Hounds, Millbrook Hunt, Meadow Brook Hounds and Vernon Somerset Beagles, brought the Riding Club's eleventh annual hound show to a spectacular conclusion yesterday.

President ROOSEVELT made it clear at his press conference yesterday that he will ask Congress to enact a tax bill at this session. Its primary purpose will be to supplant revenues lost through the collapse of AAA and to raise about $500,000,000 for the support of a new farm program during the next fiscal year.

With the consent of the government, represented by Assistant United States Attorney Vine H. Smith, Judge Dyers in the Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday voided claims by the government of $195,074 in processing taxes against Adolf Gobel, Inc., meat processors, of Brooklyn.

Free ports are nothing new. Europe has had many of them: Genoa, Leghorn, Trieste. Copenhagen, Danzig, Hamburg. Even in this country they have not been unknown. Perth Amboy, in New Jersey, was a free port for a time in early Colonial days. Radio City has the rudiments of a free port today, under special Federal legislation permitting the import of articles free of duty for exhibition purposes there.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 31 (AP). -- What threatened to be the first serious row of the Winter Olympics was averted, at least temporarily, today with a half-hearted promise to America's bob-sledders that they will be permitted to use their own sleds both in practice and during the international Winter games starting next Thursday.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The stock markets here, after a quiet opening, became more active and prices, which at first sagged under the influence of end of account and profit-taking, all rallied. British funds gained on investment support.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 31. -- After playing eleven holes of a scheduled thirty-six-hole match under the severe handicap of a badly swollen right finger, due to infection from a cut, Tommy Goodwin of the Winged Foot Club of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was forced to default to Claude Harmon of Orlando, Fla., in the semi-finals of the ninth annual national championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine links today.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Auctioneers held foreclosure sales of seven properties in Manhattan yesterday when they put up for bidding various buildings and a vacant plot. All the properties were bought in by the plaintiffs.

Railway passenger revenues in 1935 rose to the highest level since 1932, it is indicated in figures issued yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission. This would make 1935 the third successive year in which these revenues have increased.

Samuel Abelow, a clerk employed by the Curtiss-Wright Export Corporation, who was indicted last Monday with three other persons and three corporations for violation of Congress's neutrality resolution forbidding shipment of arms to Bolivia or Paraguay during the Gran Chaco War, was indicted again yesterday for perjury.

Melodrama of the beery age will raise its gory head this evening at the American Music Hall over on Fifty-fifth Street, East. The occasion is the revival by Harry Bannister and John Krimsky -- and with Lucius Beebe lurking in the voluble background -- of "The Murder in the Old Red Barn."

As filled-in bonus applications began yesterday to flood the local Veterans Administration offices in such numbers that no tally could be kept, relief officials said that no immediate decision would be made on whether veterans receiving bonus payments should be permitted to remain on relief rolls.

Boston awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,000,000 of notes to a banking group composed of Jackson Curtis, Hallgarten Co., Wilmerding Co. and Bond, Goodwin in a sale marked by unusually close bidding. The successful bid was for 0.68 per cent notes, plus a premium of $33. The notes will be dated Feb. 3 and become payable on Nov. 3.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the dissolution of the firm of Morrill, Rich Wilson and the formation today of Morrill, Wilson Co. by Stanley Morrill, John Taylor Wilson, Casimir de Rham, Lauren J. Drake, William L. Underwood, Claire A. Dunham and Robert Lewis Ames.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31. -- The conviction of the Soviet Government that Germany and Japan have a secret military understanding was shown once more today with the publication under a two-column headline on the front page of Pravda of a dispatch to the Paris newspaper Liberte from its Berlin correspondent, asserting that such an agreement was signed in Berlin Jan. 4.
