Men who fought on opposite sides during the Civil War occupied the same box, as guests of honor, at the 110th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York at the Hotel Commodore last night. Colonel Martin H. Meaney represented Mayor La Guardia.

More dividends for stockholders were voted last month than in any previous January since 1931. Special declarations, particularly in the forms of extra payments and payments against accumulated arrearages, accounted for the larger disbursements.

Federal Judge John C. Knox approved yesterday, subject to certain modifications, a plan for reorganization of the American Encaustic Tiling Company, Ltd., as proposed by the reorganization managers, Robinson, Miller Co., Inc. The changes must be filed on Feb. 7.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 31. -- The State Board of Affairs laid out the blueprints today for "The World's Most Beautiful Oil Field."

To gain still greater speed from the advantages of the thin air of the upper levels, airplane designers and operators have turned their attention to the substratosphere and the stratosphere itself. The question was discussed at the closing sessions yesterday of the annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at the Pupin Physics Laboratory, Columbia University.

The main reason for the foundation of the League of Nations was to provide a super-diplomatic machine for the maintenance of peace in substitution for the old-style method of treaty negotiations between individual nations. The old-style treaties brought about many inconsistencies and caused confusion and wars.

A poll of Atlantic Coast seamen which has been under way for the last month to obtain the views of the men concerning a wage and working contract for 1936 will be continued until next Saturday, it was announced yesterday. The poll was to have been completed last night.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week aggregates only $6,715,219, representing forty-five municipalities. This is the smallest amount of bonds of this classification to be offered for sale in any week this year, and compares with a revised total of $15,001,391 for this week.

The directors and president of H.R. Mallinson Co., Inc., stylers of silk, of 299 Fifth Avenue petitioned the United States District Court yesterday for permission to reorganize the company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

ALBANY, Jan. 31 (AP). -- More persons are attending college this year than last year in New York State, 7,180 more, to be exact, counting day and night sessions and extension classes of sixty-one colleges and universities.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31. -- Mrs. Huey P. Long, whom the late Senator courted and married after she won a baking contest which he conducted, will serve out his unexpired term in the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Protests against the objections of Hastings-on-Hudson to the erection of a mental hospital there were presented to the Supreme Court today by the Jewish Mental Health Society, which asked the high court to overturn the findings of the New York State Supreme Court and New York Court of Appeals upholding the validity of a Hastings zoning ordinance.

The Rev. Alexander P. Frenchman will be instituted as rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Edward the Martyr, 12 East 109th Street, tomorrow at 11 A.M. He succeeds the Rev. Dr. Percival H. Pyle, who died March 30.

Additional contributions of $50,033 to the Y.W.C.A.-Y.M.C.A. Joint Campaign Fund were reported yesterday at the fourth campaign luncheon, held at the Hotel Commodore. This brought the total raised to $354,121, with $600,000 needed for 1936 current expenses.

WITH THE ITALIAN NORTHERN ARMY, ENDA JESUS, Ethiopia, Jan. 30 (Delayed) -- Italian artillery and planes again heavily bombarded Amba Aradam, a mountain fifteen miles south of Makale, this afternoon as the writer watched from a combined observation and shooting post dominating that part of the Babat Valley.

Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, yesterday announced the detailed program of the North American Wildlife Conference, which opens in Washington on Monday and continues through Friday.
Several expansion leases and other rentals resulting in complete occupancy of buildings were among the business items reported by brokers yesterday, as follows:
SCOTTSBORO, Ala., Jan. 31. -- Trapped behind the locked doors of a motorized cage, twenty Negro convicts were cremated near here today by flames from an accidentally fired gasoline container.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Discovery tops the list of sixty-four entries in the weights assigned for the Metropolitan Handicap to be run during the Spring meeting at Belmont Park, it was announced yesterday by John B. Campbell, official handicapper.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31. -- With a 50 per cent increase in the number of entries, the Maryland Kennel Club today opened its twenty-third annual dog show in the new Fifth Regiment Armory. The proceeds will go to the Will Rogers Memorial Funds.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 31. -- A grand jury here today assailed police "bungling" and refused to charge a nurse with the murder of her patient.
LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The Earl of Derby is leasing the late King George's horses until the end of the racing year, although King Edward VIII is continuing the long royal connection with racing.

Donald Vaughan Jr. and Kenneth J. Ridgway, top-seeded entrants from the Garden City Casino, yesterday gained the final in the men's doubles of the Eastern New York badminton tournament on the Tudor City Tennis Club courts in the 165th Infantry Armory.

Four more players wore signed yesterday by Greater New York's three major league clubs to strengthen further the belief -- if, indeed, there is any doubt of it at all -- that there will be plenty of talent available when the 1936 campaign gets under way some three or four weeks hence.

John T. McNeil yesterday retired as Deputy Commissioner of the New York State Athletic Commission, concluding forty-one years in the service of the Empire State. His successor is Thomas L. Farley, brother of Postmaster General James A. Farley.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Confiscation of old-law tenements will be undertaken only when lack of management permits insanitary conditions and firetraps to exist, Harry N. Prince, First Deputy Tenement House Commissioner, declared last night.

With the new "Folies de Femmes" revue successfully launched at the French Casino on Wednesday night, there can be little doubt of the perpetuity of the aforesaid resort, along with Radio City and the Empire State Building, as one of the compulsory "sights."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- William J. Bennett of Highland Falls. N.Y., was designated by the War Department today, upon recommendation of Senator Copeland, to take the entrance examination March 3 for admission to the United States Military Academy July 1.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- Summoning all their strength and drawing more largely from the Center than had been expected, the Left parties in the Chamber of Deputies this evening gave the new government headed by Albert Sarraut the largest majority any Cabinet has had during the life of this Legislature.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- Disapproval by the State Tax Revision Commission of the proposal for an overall limitation on real estate taxes was assailed roundly today by the New York State Tax Limitation Committee.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- A renewed attack on economic nationalism was made today by J. Beaumont Pease, chairman of Lloyds Bank, in addressing his shareholders at the last of the annual meetings of Great Britain's "Big Five" banks.

ATHENS, Jan. 31. -- Amid monarchist efforts to find a Cabinet capable of government, Marshal George Kondylis, who was responsible for King George's restoration, died at his home today of a heart attack. He was 55. He had long suffered from asthma.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Inclusion by members of Congress of large numbers of private relief bills in single omnibus measures will not prevent vetoes by President Roosevelt if individual items conflict with his rule that no such bills must take away the government's defense rights, he said today.

Direction of the regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission at 120 Broadway will be taken over today by Joseph R. Sheehan, administrative coordinator of the SEC, who will serve until a successor is found for Robert G. Page, who resigned.

In malcontent Massachusetts Governor SMITH'S speech makes most Democrats in or seeking office walk warily -- instead of "out." A candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor goes so far as to say that he is "for harmony and hopes that all groups of Democrats will cooperate for that end.
Two cruise ships are leaving today with capacity bookings. The Carinthia of the Cunard White Star is going to Nassau and the New York of the Hamburg-American Line to the West Indies.

A crowd which filled the auction room of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., yesterday afternoon watched the dispersal of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt's glassware, silver and other effects, removed from her former residence at 49 East Seventy-second Street.

The winning streak of the undefeated St. John's University freshmen was extended to sixteen games at the expense of St. Leonard's Academy, while a high school quintet, James Madison, turned back the Brooklyn College jayvees in two of the leading local school basketball games yesterday.

WHEN a man is up there, the inclination of the bystanders is to root for somebody to come along and pull him down. There have been exceptional cases where the reigning hero was so popular that any threat against his superiority was considered a public danger or a national disgrace. But ordinarily the tendency is to cheer for the underdog and hope that the gent on high will be toppled into the dust.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Secretary Ickes will continue to fight for a large appropriation for federally subsidized housing, despite the fact that the administration has withdrawn its support from any comprehensive plan.

Clergymen of the city will tomorrow refer in their sermons to Edward VIII, the new King of England, and will offer prayers for a blessing upon his reign. In the ritualistic calendar tomorrow is the Feast of the Purification of the Blessed Virgin, or Candlemas, as the day is called.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP). -- The Hotel Huntington Handicap for 3-year-olds and a purse of $1,200 was won at Santa Anita today by He Did, favorite in the betting.
Contracts for the sale of a block front in downtown Manhattan and an old holding in the Madison Square section were announced yesterday.

Weakness of the dollar in the foreign exchange market caused a sharp curtailment in shipments of gold to the United States in January. Imports at New York totaled $34,010,900, the smallest in six months, compared with $177,565,200 in December and $130,987,700 in January, 1935.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 31. -- Mrs. Edith Liggett, widow of Walter W. Liggett, took the witness stand late today in Judge A.W. Selover's court and identified Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld as the machine-gunner who shot the publisher to death Dec. 9 in an alley behind the Liggett apartment.

Marshal George Kondylis, who died yesterday, was pro-Italian and threatened to upset the plans of King George of Greece, who had returned to his throne with the intention to make the British constitutional monarchy his model.

SUNBURY, Pa., Jan. 31. -- A broken rail was blamed today by Reading Company officials for the wreck near here last night of their express train, the Williamsporter, which plunged thirty feet from the Susquehanna River Bridge into an abandoned canal bed, killing three persons and injuring thirty-one.
PARIS, Jan. 31 (AP). -- New prints in silhouette, etching and watercolor effects were launched today as the last word in smart fabrics in midweek fashion openings.

New bond financing this week amounted to $62,265,700, compared with $93,803,000 last week and with $11,620,000 in the week a year ago. This week's financing was featured by the offering of the largest corporate loan so far this year, $45,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent general mortgage bonds of the Republic Steel Corporation, due in 1961.

Walter Malowan and A. Mitchell Barnes of New York won the Joseph E. Ridder Pair Trophy of the Atlantic National Bridge championships at the Park Central Hotel last night with a driving finish which brought them from sixth place to victory in a field of thirty-two pairs.

A demonstration, in protest against the clothing budget which they contended was sufficient to provide enough Winter clothing for only 5 per cent of the needy, was held yesterday by more than 100 persons representing the Unemployed Emergency Council in front of the Home Relief Bureau at 8 Avenue D.

The Blue Ridge Corporation reported yesterday a net asset value of $41,282,961 at the close of 1935, equivalent to $95.66 a share of preference stock, and, after allowing for preference stock on the basis of $55 a share and accrued dividends, to $2.33 a share on the common stock.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- C.R. Fairey, who recently withdrew his challenge for the America's Cup, still reserves the right to issue a fresh challenge after August for 1937. He may do so if T.O.M. Sopwith, who has Endeavour II under construction at Camper Nicholson's Gosport yard, fails to carry through with his plans to challenge again for the famous yachting trophy.

Followers of the share market took the line of least resistance yesterday; "long" positions recently sold out were replaced, "shorts" covered, and new buying was in evidence, responsive to the hue and cry raised by the highly articulate "inflationist" group in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Governor Landon of Kansas discussed farm-aid plans by telephone with Washington today and afterward said that "the appeal" of a bill by Representative Hope, a Kansas Republican, "lies in its simple administrative features."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The appointment of a New York City advisory committee for the National Youth Administration was announced today by Aubrey Williams, NYA administrator, in the $50,000,000 program to assist students in schools of all kinds.

The first of this season's teas for the benefit of the Authors League Fund will be held tomorrow at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Hull Brewster, 350 East Fifty-seventh Street, from 5 to 7 o'clock. The guests of honor will be Jane Cowl, Sigmund Romberg and Elmer Davis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Determination to campaign relentlessly against the New Deal, regardless of party ties, was evidenced anew tonight by the leadership of the American Liberty League.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- The revocation of appointments of three special deputy superintendents of banks was announced today in the department's weekly bulletin. They are W.K. Denton of Tuckahoe, M.L. Masson of Bronxville and R.G. Dorman of Rockville Centre.

" The suffering of the Jews in Germany has brought into focus the necessity for an all-inclusive brotherhood of Jews and Gentiles in the city and nation," the Greater New York Federation of Churches asserted in its report for 1935, which was issued yesterday at its headquarters, 7l West Twenty-third Street.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 31. -- "The Dream of a Clown" was presented here tonight by a cast of eighty men, leaders in the civic affairs here, at the Bronxville School's auditorium, under the auspices of the Bronxville League for Service. The league's philanthropic fund will benefit.

A plan of recapitalization destined to leave the Radio Corporation of America ultimately with only common stock outstanding was explained yesterday by Joseph P. Kennedy, on behalf of the board of directors, in the presence of General James G. Harbord, chairman; David Sarnoff, president, and other officials of the company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP). -- The Senate Munitions Committee decided today to call J.P. Morgan and his partners Tuesday for the renewal of its investigation. They will be asked, among other things, whether the war debt obligations held by this country could be converted into "marketable securities" to replenish the Treasury.

With two victories to his credit already this season, Glenn Cunningham, king of milers, will strive for a third triumph tonight at Madison Square Garden when he faces a crack field in the Wanamaker Mile, feature of the twenty-ninth annual Millrose A.A. track carnival.

Under the sponsorship of Senator Harry Flood Byrd, former Governor of Virginia, and Mrs. Byrd, the annual Blue Ridge Ball was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza, drawing an attendance of more than 500 persons, including many native Southerners, now residing in New York.

A JUNIOR at Harvard walked home with Dean Briggs one snowy night in 1911. The talk turned to George Santayana, then the great man of the academic world. "I remember when he was a freshman here back in the Eighties," Dean Briggs said. "He turned in a theme to me in which he said that Emerson was 'brought up on the sour milk of Puritanism.' The phrase has stuck in my mind."
Edward F. Zimmerman, formerly with Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co., is now manager of the office-renting department of Butler Baldwin.

Home furnishings continued to fare well in retail trade during the week. Despite the weather handicaps, increases over a year ago were recorded for these departments. Further reports have indicated trade during the second half of the month showed a smaller gain than during the first half, which might put the average increase at from 8 to 10 per cent.
A nation-wide essay contest will begin today under the auspices of the National Association of Audubon Societies, 1,775 Broadway.

The subsiding of liquidation due to the AAA invalidation and restriction of livestock shipments by cold weather were partly responsible for the halting of the decline of The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices, which rose to 128.0 on Jan. 28 from 127.4 the Tuesday previous.

The Harvard and Columbia Club squash tennis teams finished their regular season last night in a tie for Class B honors in the metropolitan league, each having won nine matches and lost three during the competition, which began back in October. As a result, a play-off will be necessary to determine which team deserves the honors.

In a running international survey to which I have given my undivided time, I have had to read all serious discussion in the important periodicals of the United States and many in Great Britain and every noteworthy European and American book by representative authorities.
In a whirlwind finish after trailing at half time the Long Island University quintet awakened to trounce Northeastern University, 50-27, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

Events have thrown the Naval Conference at London so much into the shadow that people might be excused for thinking it had ceased to sit. Yesterday, however, came the announcement of what is called the "first major agreement" reached by the conference. It cannot be said to be of earth-shaking importance.

Commodity futures were quiet and in the local markets steady yesterday with cocoa futures active and strong. Wheat, rye, cocoa, lard and rubber were higher in the cash markets, while corn, cotton and silk declined.

The French franc rose yesterday to its gold-export point as continued discussion of large currency issues to finance the bonus and meet other governmental requirements were heard in Washington and Premier Sarraut in Paris received a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies.

TRENTON, Jan. 31. -- The State Judicial Council in its annual report, submitted today to Governor Hoffman, criticized the administration of criminal justice in New Jersey as cumbersome and lacking in uniformity and dispatch. A new set-up of the courts, which would require a constitutional amendment, was recommended.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -- "En Skandinavisk Fest" was presented tonight by the Philadelphia Skating Club and Humane Society at the Arena. The beneficiaries of this annual ice carnival, which will be repeated tomorrow, are the social service department of the University Hospital and the Broomall Convalescent Hospital.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 31. -- Three Italian planes bombed Chilga and two other villages near Gondar, about 140 miles west of Makale, yesterday morning without damage, it has been reported to the Emperor's headquarters.

Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order yesterday for the maintenance and support of 17-year-old Anthony Newton Duke, son of the late Angier B. Duke and Mrs. Cordelia Biddle Robertson of 895 Park Avenue. The order permits the withdrawal of $115,200 from her son's income and covers the years of 1933-34-35 and 1936.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- Challenges from twenty-three nations -- one less than last year -- were announced today by the British Lawn Tennis Association for the 1936 Davis Cup tennis competition. The draw will be made Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Administration leaders in Congress planned swift action today to head off an inflation drive which surged forward in the House following confirmation by President Roosevelt of reports that action on taxes would be demanded to finance the farm program and, probably, to amortize the veterans' bonus.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The lawsuit over the charity card party at Sunderland House, Mayfair, came to a sudden end in the King's Bench division today when Mr. Justice Finlay upheld Sir Patrick Hastings's submission for the defense that there was no case to answer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Wielding his wide powers to require rail consolidation projects for the first time, Joseph B. Eastman, transportation coordinator, said today that he soon would order the unification of terminal facilities in eleven cities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- President Roosevelt's endorsement was given today to a resolution introduced in the Senate yesterday to set up a special committee to investigate campaign expenditures and possible violations of the Corrupt Practices Act by candidates for the Presidency, Vice Presidency and the Senate.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 31. -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz, who prosecuted Bruno Richard Hauptmann, replied today to Governor Harold G. Hoffman's demand for a renewed investigation by declaring that "Hauptmann, and Hauptmann alone," was responsible for the kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP). -- A committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States declared tonight that a continuation of present administration fiscal policies may result in "uncontrolled inflation." The report was released by the chamber's directors, now in session.

Rejecting pleas for leniency, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday sentenced Austin Phelps Palmer, wealthy retired engineer of 1,085 Park Avenue, to serve ninety days in the Federal House of Detention for sending a threatening letter to President Roosevelt.

The bid for additional honors by Donald M. Frame of the Harvard Club in the metropolitan squash racquets singles championship came to an end yesterday in a prolonged semi-final match at the University Club.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP). -- An attempt to sell at public auction the Richfield Oil Company of California and the Pan American Petroleum Company, in receivership for five years, failed today.

More than 35,000 automobile owners in the city yesterday rushed to the seventeen offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles in the five boroughs to obtain the 1936 automobile license plates. The old ones expired last midnight and beginning today no vehicle may be operated in this State unless it displays the new tags.
AVALON, Calif., Jan. 31. -- A sparkling hole-in-one supplied the main interest today as newcomers to golfing fame continued to lead in the $5,000 Santa Catalina Island Open tournament.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Frank J. Raven, formerly of San Jose, Calif., and Honolulu, and J. Warner Brown, formerly of Kansas City and Marshall, Mo., were found guilty in a United States court today of embezzlement in connection with the affairs of the defunct American Oriental Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- A tumultuous demonstration for President Roosevelt and the New Deal labor, social welfare and employment policies was evoked at the convention of the United Mine Workers of America today by Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor.

With traditional military ceremony the 1,070 officers and enlisted men of the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh Regiment) gave a full-dress review last night in honor of General Malin Craig, the new army Chief of Staff, at the 107th Infantry Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Textile employers, fighting the Ellenbogen bill, which would provide Federal control for their industry, told a House labor subcommittee today the Federal Government could aid most by modifying the anti-trust laws. They referred also to "peril" from Japanese competition.

Ambassador Hirosi Saito of Japan defended his country's demand for naval parity and her expansion policies in China last night before 800 persons at the annual dinner of the Japan Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The Ambassador and Mrs. Saito were the guests of honor.

La Salle Academy remained undefeated in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball competition by defeating the Cathedral Boys quintet of New York, 36 to 25, in a Manhattan-Richmond division contest on the victors' court yesterday.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 31. -- The weather jinx that has brought all three previous Winter Olympics to the brink of catastrophe now is seriously jeopardizing the fourth set of games, scheduled to open here Thursday.

The third and final leg on the Alex Taylor Trophy was captured by the Clinton tennis squad yesterday as it clinched team honors in the tenth annual De Witt Clinton High School invitation interscholastic tournament, which will enter its final stages at the 369th Regiment Armory today.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 31. -- Governor Landon of Kansas, prospective Republican candidate for President, finds himself today deluged with words of approval of his first national speech.

The second exhibition at the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, consists entirely of oil paintings. A number of well-known artists are represented among the fourscore canvases, and there is the widest diversity of subject matter, approach and method.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Democratic resentment against the American Liberty League was manifest again in the House today during consideration of the Interior Department Appropriation Bill, and for a few minutes an uproar unequaled at this session prevailed.

JOLIET, Ill., Jan. 81. -- William R. McCabe, State's Attorney of Will County, asserted today that he had received new information to support a theory that Richard Loeb was deliberately murdered Tuesday in a plot by fellow-prisoners at Stateville penitentiary.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31. -- The revival of living organisms that had been frozen for 3,000 to 5,000 years, as announced this week by the Academy of Sciences in Leningrad, will be of great value in the study of genetics and the mysteries of life, your correspondent was told today by Professor Michael Sumgin.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Supplies of hogs fell off abruptly here today and brisk competition between local and Eastern buyers lifted prices 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight with some sales of weights under 170 pounds showing as much as 35 cents higher.

A simpler, cheaper process for extracting Vitamin B-1, the "nerve vitamin," in pure crystalline form, was announced here yesterday by Fordham University through the Rev. Dr. Joseph B. Muenzen, head of the Fordham chemistry department.

The second exhibition at the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, consists entirely of oil paintings. A number of well-known artists are represented among the fourscore canvases, and there is the widest diversity of subject matter, approach and method.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Democratic resentment against the American Liberty League was manifest again in the House today during consideration of the Interior Department Appropriation Bill, and for a few minutes an uproar unequaled at this session prevailed.

JOLIET, Ill., Jan. 81. -- William R. McCabe, State's Attorney of Will County, asserted today that he had received new information to support a theory that Richard Loeb was deliberately murdered Tuesday in a plot by fellow-prisoners at Stateville penitentiary.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31. -- The revival of living organisms that had been frozen for 3,000 to 5,000 years, as announced this week by the Academy of Sciences in Leningrad, will be of great value in the study of genetics and the mysteries of life, your correspondent was told today by Professor Michael Sumgin.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Supplies of hogs fell off abruptly here today and brisk competition between local and Eastern buyers lifted prices 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight with some sales of weights under 170 pounds showing as much as 35 cents higher.

No break in the subfreezing temperatures of the last ten days is forecast by the Weather Bureau for the week-end and today's weather, according to the prediction last night, will be about the same as yesterday's. Increased cloudiness probably followed by snow is forecast for tomorrow.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The machinery of the British Foreign Office has been set in motion to discover the exact measure of truth in the persistent rumors that Japan has concluded a treaty of friendship and mutual defense with Germany.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- The London Naval Conference approved today the plan for an exchange of building programs which had been worked out by a subcommittee during the past fortnight. The work of the conference on the quantitative side is now completed, and the new plan will form part of whatever four-power agreement may emerge in the next few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The Federal Communications Commission directed a study today of the anti-New Deal speech broadcast by Governor Eugene Talmadge on Wednesday to determine whether it violated provisions of the Communications Law.

Charles Stewart Ludlam, member of Haskins Sells and one of the world's leading accountants, who died April 4, 1934, at his Winter home at Miami Beach, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,692,945 gross and $1,501,082 net. His interest in the concern was valued at $766,524. He owned securities worth $515,426.
The Presidential campaign got away last week to a noisy and name-calling start, the like of which hasn't been seen for many years.

In its first thirty years, the motion picture has made more artistic progress than any other medium in its first three hundred. Yet strange to say, this rapid progress has been made in the face of continued opposition from the very men who exploit the movies.

THIS competently done little book is admirably adapted to its purpose, which is to interest in eugenics intelligent people who have little or no scientific knowledge of that science and to give them fundamental information as to its principles, its purposes, its practical importance and the methods by which it can be applied to the betterment of the race.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Feb. 1. -- This army air field, the bulwark for the aerial defense of New York City, was theoretically destroyed tonight at the end of the first day of Winter test manoeuvres of the General Headquarters Air Force. The fireproof hangars and barracks constructed at a cost of nearly $5,000,000 were all theoretically "wiped out."

Two specialists from England, three from Canada, six from the Pacific Coast and ten from the Middle West are included in the board of judges for the tenth annual exhibition of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club to be held at Giralda Farms, Madison, N.J., on Saturday, May 28, it was announced yesterday.

MUNICH, Feb. 1. -- The efficacy of the National Socialist principle of government which allows the Hitler party to muzzle opponents of its policies while itself employing all modern propaganda methods will be tested here again tomorrow, when free and open registration of children for the confessional or secular schools will take place.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- A cooperative research project by specialists in separate branches of science is under way at Duke University at Durham. Ten scientists -- botanists, zoologists and foresters -- have laid out three plots of ground in the heart of the university's near-by 5,000-acre forest, and for five ten, and possibly twenty years every conceivable feature of the plant and animal life, and the properties of the soil will be recorded and analyzed.

Philip A.S. Franklin passed part of his sixty-fifth birthday yesterday discussing the development of shipping as he has observed it the last forty years and as he believes it should be continued. Mr. Franklin on Thursday turned over to his son, John M. Franklin, the duties of president of the International Mercantile Marine Company and assumed the office of chairman of the board.

President ROOSEVELT sent to Congress last week a message expressing his solicitude for America's "little rivers." It is his contention -- and that of the National Resources Board -- that in our zeal to harness the larger rivers, such as the Mississippi, the St. Law rence, the Columbia, the Colorado, the Tennessee, we have sometimes overlooked the lesser streams out of which they grow.

Shura Cherkassky, the young pianist known in past years in New York as an exceptional talent, who has ripened this talent by a long concert tour in Europe and the East, played in recital before a large audience yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

A village midway offering a diverting variety of games and carnival attractions will be a feature of the Lace Ball to be held on Feb. 11 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

AS yet no really noteworthy novel on the college scene has been written. The postwar mood accounted for "The Plastic Age," "Flaming Youth," "Glitter," and similar shockers designed to represent the new generation as unmoored and as undisciplined as the times could make them.

THE really modern interior is not considered complete without its share of accessories in aluminum, chromium or rustless steel. These contemporary metals supplement or replace the traditional wrought iron, bronze and silver, and because of their usefulness are entering even period rooms in the form of pieces for the hearth and other articles.

THE broad-leaved evergreens hold a very definite and important place in the landscaping of home grounds and are especially desirable for use on lots of moderate size, or in little gardens where most conifers, if used, would soon grow out of bounds.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 1. -- A move to strengthen and perpetuate fraternities at Rutgers University was made this week when Dean Fraser Metzger announced that the Interfraternity Council and the office of the dean of men would cooperate in conducting a training seminar for fraternity officers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- As the Senate Munitions Committee made plans today to complete its investigation by Feb. 20, the progress of the administration Neutrality Bill appeared to be slowing down because of a general loss of enthusiasm on the part Of leaders in both houses of Congress.

A new newspaper chain, limited as to potential circulation and advertising but unlimited as to the ambition of the publishers, is now being planned by John and Thomas Donahue, both 15 years old, who for three Summers have edited, written and published The Falls News at Northfield Falls, Vt. They also founded the paper.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Congress was called upon by the United States Conference of Mayors today to enact legislation providing for a permanent Federal-city low-cost housing program as outlined in the Wagner bill.

FINAL schedules for the International Flower Show, to be held March 16 to 21, have been issued by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York and by the Garden Club of New Jersey. Copies of the New York schedule may be obtained from Mrs. Ralph Pratt Hinchman, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, New York; and of the New Jersey schedule from Mrs. Cyrus N. Vail, 86 South Clinton Street, Orange. N.J.

THE tragedy of the Ward liner Morro Castle, which burned off Asbury Park in September, 1934, with a death toll of 134 persons, and the subsequent sinking of the same line's Mohawk with a loss of eighty-four persons, have provided lessons which promise to contribute measurably during the coming year to the age-long problem of achieving greater safety at sea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Formal orders for the railroads to carry out coordination plans worked out by Joseph B. Eastman may bring an early climax to the work of the Federal Coordinator of Transportation.

WHEN the North American Wild Life Conference meets in Washington, D.C., tomorrow -- at the call of President Roosevelt to consider means of conserving the wild life on this continent -- among its participants will be numerous leaders in Scouting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The United Mine Workers of America, with more than 500,000 members in thousands of coal camps and mining communities in twenty-eight States, endorsed today by unanimous approval of 1,700 delegates the administration of President Roosevelt and authorized the executive board to contribute to the campaign to re-elect the President, as well as to solicit contributions from several thousand local unions.

While official censorship is a constant evil, it occasionally bursts forth with increased virulent activity as at the present time. The current dramatic victims reported by the press are "The Children's Hour" and "Tobacco Road," involving Boston, St. Paul and Chicago.

DIETITIANS and scientific investigators of food values are constantly emphasizing the necessity of including a variety of vegetables in the well-balanced diet. They often advance new reasons why certain vegetables should be consumed in greater quantities.

TEN years of successful experience with a unique plan of group cooperation among small colleges will be celebrated this week by the Claremont Colleges of California. Herbert Hoover and half a dozen college presidents will be among the participants in the special anniversary convocation on Feb. 7.

Again the financial position of the Federal Government dominates the scene in Washington. A series of events maturing with great speed has overturned the President's budget, involved the Treasury in new obligations, raised the problem of new taxes, revived the currency question and set Wall Street talking of inflation.

One hundred women and ten men were arrested last night in seven disorderly houses in Brooklyn and thirty-four in Manhattan in a series of raids that were carried out in the greatest secrecy, it was announced at 3:45 o'clock this morning at the office of Thomas E. Dewey, Special Deputy Assistant District Attorney investigating vice and racketeering in the city.

Beckman Pool of the Harvard Club yesterday regained the metropolitan squash racquets singles title by defeating his clubmate, the defending champion Robert Grant 3d, after twenty-five minutes of play at the University Club.

Short of demonstrating how two can live as cheaply as one, the National Institute of Family Living has provided the most practical solution for the problem of engaged couples eager, to have a home on a minimum amount of money. Thousands of them -- some blissful, some bashful -- have wandered through the especially designed "Economy House" on the third floor of 469 Fifth Avenue, for its object lessons in artful shopping.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- A harder fight than ever, on more fundamental issues, with a closer working alliance, is being planned by the group of thirty-odd Progressive Congressmen, nicknamed the House "mavericks," who last year pooled their forces on a number of issues.

With examinations a thing of the past, intercollegiate basketball activities in the metropolitan district will pick up considerably during the coming week. All the leading local teams, with the exception of Fordham, are scheduled to see action.
LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Robert Williams, 54 years old, a former labor leader, was found dead today in his gas-filled room.
IN an article dealing with the New York City Traffic Courts, recently printed in this section of THE TIMES, Victor H. Bernstein wrote:

Japan's approaching general election cannot be expected to bring momentous changes in foreign or domestic policy. The Diet which has just been dissolved came to an end by expiration of its legal term of life and not because of any perceptible change in public sentiment.

YOU may remember "Tortilla Flat," Mr. Steinbeck's last novel, which described with genial gusto and gentle irony the picaresque adventures of a small group of Latin-American vagabonds in a California suburban slum. That was a gay, melancholy and charming book.

Joseph Fishbach, second seeded star, representing Clinton, captured the honors in the tenth annual De Witt Clinton High School invitation interscholastic tennis tournament yesterday when he defeated George MacCall, unranked entry from Scarborough School, in the final at the 369th Regiment Armory. The score was 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 4.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With the new steeplechase course on Midland Road rapidly being put in shape for the second annual races over brush and timber to be held on Saturday, March 14, the Sand Hills Steeplechase and Racing Association has announced that five races will feature the program at the new $50,000 layout.

Officials of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs will go into session on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Hotel McAlpin for their midwinter meeting. Mrs. Almeron W. Smith of Plandome, L.I., president of the organization, will be in the chair.

THIS anthology of English poetry from the fourteenth century to the close of the nineteenth is called "new" because of the principle adopted by the editors in determining selection. And one can but admit the principle has considerable novelty, for it is nothing less than a determination that the book shall include no poem already available through either "The Golden Treasury" or "The Oxford Book of English Verse."

PHILADELPIA, Jan. 31. -- With employe-stockholders of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company threatening revolt against the present management by court-appointed trustees, an already involved situation has become more confused.

Proceeds of a cruise ball to be held Saturday evening by the New York City Panhellenic Club, of which Miss Mary Theye Worthen is president, will go to the scholarship fund and the philanthropic fund of the Panhellenic groups. Mrs. Kenneth Har of Staten Island is chairman of the event, which will take place in the Beekman Tower, headquarters of the club.

For a week past it seemed as if of the making of speeches, like the making of books, there was no end. First came Governor SMITH'S address at Washington. Whatever its merits or defects, it had the effect of setting all tongues wagging. It broke the ice and precipitated an amount and intensity of discussion seldom following a single political utterance.

Among the most popular indoor recreations of America today is what we may not inappropriately call radio razzing. Cursing the sponsored programs has become almost a habit except among those naive persons who constitute what is known as that imponderable element, the "fan mail."

TOKYO, Feb. 1. -- More petitions written in blood, more tears and more attacks on bureaucrats and senior statesmen marked today's session of the trial of Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa for the murder of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, director of the Military Affairs Bureau of the War Office, last August.
ALONG the North Temperate Zone there are four distinctive populations. The first is Europe, the second America, the third Japan. Also there is China.

Prominent men and women interested actively in the relief work of the Neighborhood Guilds are subscribing to the dinner dance arranged for the benefit of the guilds to be held on Thursday in the Trianor Room of the Ambassador. An entertainment will be presented during the evening.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Midwestern States are not so strongly pro-administration as the prospects for inflation or excessive taxes impend to provide for bonus payments and for the fulfillment of contracts to farmers made under the invalidated AAA.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- President Roosevelt rode in an open car for more than an hour this afternoon to inspect a proposed site for a monumental building for the War Department to cost $20,000,000.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 31. -- Governor Alf M. Landon appears to be still strong in Kansas despite the fact that he did not present a specific agricultural aid program in his Kansas Day banquet speech here this week, in which he outlined the policies and principles on which he will stand if chosen as the Republican Presidential nominee.
CAMBRIDGE, Feb. 1. -- Revival of the old-time public water pump in Harvard Yard was advocated by two graduates in an appeal printed in the current Harvard Alumni Bulletin.

BALI, according to Hickman Powell in "Bali, the Last Paradise," which Dodd, Mead Co. have just reissued in revised form at $3, is one of the few countries left whose people really understand the use of leisure.

BROADWAY and the Rivoli Theatre are preparing for the world premiere of Charlie Chaplin's new film, "Modern Times," which is scheduled to take place on Wednesday night. Since this is the comedian's first photo-play in almost five years (his last being "City Lights" in 1931), United Artists promises to transform night into day around the vicinity of Forty-ninth Street with powerful flood lights.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf assigned his two outstanding detectives today to take charge of the renewed investigation of the Lindbergh kidnap-murder ordered by Governor Harold G. Hoffman. They were Captain John J. Lamb and Lieutenant Arthur Keaton.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor of Austria, was highly amused when he learned at breakfast in a London hotel today that he was reported to have conferred with Archduke Otto in Belgium yesterday.

ON the recent day when Theatre Arts Monthly published its twentieth anniversary number letters from a dozen countries were on the desk of its editor, Mrs. Edith J.R. Isaacs, and that is almost the story of Theatre Arts.

WINTER sports are now in full swing throughout the United States. From New England's snowy hills to Western mountain peaks, experts intent on making new records and amateurs seeking fun and healthful exercise, are foregathering in some 140 resorts and playfields.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- A basin for testing ship models -- long advocated by Navy Department officials -- will be built soon at Cabin John Md., at a cost of $3,500,000 if Congress approves a bill introduced by Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Senator Bankhead and some of his colleagues asserted today that thirty-five to forty Senators wanted the President to use his powers to increase currency in circulation, with the backing of the Treasury's gold and silver stocks.

More than 1,500 managers and agents of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, attending their annual dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, heard Frederick H. Ecker, president of the company, report a general upward trend in business conditions in 1935, and its continuance through January.

A NEW high fidelity short-wave station, W8XWJ, operated by The Detroit News, opened for service on Jan. 29. The channel is 30,100 kilocycles; power 100 watts. It is said to be the first "ultramodern installation of its type in Michigan."

Legislators and newspapers, as well as many others, are warned by Mr. CHARLES L. CHUTE, executive director of the National Probation Association, that the terms "probation" and "parole" are not interchangeable. Their purposes and methods of dealing with offenders are the same --" none "other than those of good family case "work," or at any rate should be.

THE recent pair of performances of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman were remarkable not only for their positive accomplishments but also for their uncovering of the difficulties that beset the modern dancer as he ventures away from the familiar paths of the recital program into the field of extended forms in more or less theatrical dimensions.

GENEVA, Feb. 1. -- Only the Committee of Experts gives a sign of life in Geneva while Marshal Pietro Badoglio's communiques seem daily to proclaim triumphs in Ethiopia by the Italian armies. The League of Nations appears to be asleep just when the first really heavy fighting begins.

I read with much interest Theodore Pratt's "Lament From the Keys" sent in to THE TIMES from Lake Worth, Fla. As manager of the only legitimate troupe, as Mr. Pratt puts it, in Florida, I can offer from experience several reasons why Florida has no legitimate theatre -- hasn't much legitimate anything but climate.

The ingenious Chinese of 6,000 years ago who made the very first motion pictures from buffalo hide and cast their shadows on parchment, would stand aghast and bewildered within the great film studios of today; but Mr. Floherty knows his way around the movie lot, within the sound studios, in the vast collections of the property departments, on location, and in the stacks of the scenario and research departments.

USING well-worn material and one of the most familiar of plots, Marian Sims has succeeded in writing an interesting novel. This Mrs. Sims has accomplished partly through her gift for writing easy, natural dialogue, but mainly through the character of her heroine.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 1. -- Sinking a thirty-foot putt on the last green for a birdie, Claude Harmon of Orlando, Fla., won the ninth annual national championship of golf club champions on St. Augustine links today, defeating Robert N. Wilkinson of the Locust Grove Country Club, Westfield, N.J., 1 up, in the thirty-sixth-hole final.

Despite the absence of definite information regarding plans for the possible distribution of government-financed cotton, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated nervously in yesterday's short session and ended with net changes ranging from a loss of 12 to a gain of 2 points after a liberal volume of business.

Two events -- an exhibition of costumes of the late Marcella Sembrich, operatic star, and "A Late Comers' Party," to be held on Sunday afternoon, Feb. 16, at the Metropolitan Opera House -- have been announced by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1. -- Girl textile weavers who are now earning more than 1,000 rubles a month under the Stakhanoff system have volunteered to take a cut in their own wages so that their auxiliary workers can receive more. The new wage scales will be promulgated shortly.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 31. -- The wounds of Deputy Sheriff Edgar Blalock seem to prove, in the judgment of most Alabamians, that there is nothing to the inevitable suspicion from outside that the shooting of Ozie Powell last Friday by Sheriff J. Street Sanderlin was a "put-up job."

Leading all the way, the Boulder Brook team of Donald McDonald, Billy Sullivan and Ed Ford upset Squadron C, 9 to 6 1/2, last night at Squadron a Armory in Brooklyn to hand the home forces their first setback in five Metropolitan Indoor Polo League matches this season.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The Earl of Derby will not be able attend the sixty-second running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs, May 2, because of his new responsibilities for maintaining King Edward VIII's racing stable, it was learned today.

The Citizens Union Committee on Legislation announced yesterday that it had approved the hill of State Senator McNaboe providing that newspaper owners and employes should not be compelled to disclose the source of confidential information.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- An automobile speed governor -- believed the first to be made mandatory by a public official -- was installed here today on a car owned by a man who has been convicted several times for speeding in New Jersey.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- Very little change took place in the trend of business on the Pacific Coast during the past week. Light rains caused a slight decline in downtown shopping activity, although some merchants running clearing sales reported satisfactory volume.

LONGMIRE, Mount Rainier National Park, Wash., Feb. 1 (AP). -- Reinforcements hurried today to aid five mountaineers struggling down the icy slopes of Mount Rainier with the body of Delmar Fadden, youthful "thrill climber."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Secretary Morgenthau has declared that the job of distributing the bonus payments available to World War veterans under the terms of the new Adjusted Compensation Payment Act is the most difficult and technical problem that ever has confronted the Treasury Department.
The opening of the Spring term in the city's public schools tomorrow will be marked by the establishment of two new projects in progressive and experimental education.

IF you walked around Beekman Place asking the natives what they knew about Nathan Hale --who gave his one life in those parts -- you might get as much precise response as Mr. Franck did when he questioned Mexican villagers about Cortes. He was following the march of the Conquistadores.

WITHIN a few days, weather permitting, the bobsled teams of many nations will race down the mountainside to contend for honors in the fourth Olympic Winter Games at Garmisch-Partenkirchen in the Bavarian Alps.

ANNAPOLIS, Mid., Feb. 1. -- A boxing match under the new conditions at the Naval Academy -- with spectators attired in evening dress -- resulted in a series of good bouts between representatives of Navy and Western Maryland, and a tie score, each taking four contests.

FOR the first time a competition for a symphonic work has been instituted by the players of a great orchestra, in the nation-wide contest for the best overture or suite for orchestra just announced by the men of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

ROME, Sunday, Feb. 2. -- The Grand Council of Fascism met again last night to consider the military and political situations that have been maturing in the past few months and to discuss Italy's future course of action in the light of recent events in East Africa and Europe.

OF the two ambitious group "regulars" here to be reported, the 131st annual in Philadelphia is a bit the larger, with 444 entries (oil and sculpture), as against 341 (including miniacures) in the forty-fifth annual of he National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors at the American Fine Arts Building in this ity.

HE was born in an old chateau like a wreck sunk in the trackless forests of Auvergne, where, according to his latest and Austrian biographer, Mr. Latzko, "the tenant farmers extracted from the sweat and blood of their serfs the sums which the landowners dissipated at Versailles or Paris."

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Miss Kit Klein, America's No. 1 woman speed skater, came through with two victories today to take a commanding lead over rivals from six other nations at the opening of the women's world speed skating championships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A major drive for currency inflation was determined upon today by the expansionist high command in the House who, at the same time, perfected plans for setting off the drive in both Congressional branches if and when President Roosevelt submits a demand for taxes to pay the veterans' bonus.

WASHINGTON, Feb.1 -- In an address made tonight upon assuming the presidency and directorship of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the oldest engineering school in the English-speaking world, Dr. William O. Hotchkiss predicted the development of greater efficiency in industry and all other forms of endeavor, and said that the end of technological improvements was not yet in sight.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1. -- Discovery, the 1935 handicap champion of the American turf, made his 1936 debut at Santa Anita today by winning the $5,000 added San Carlos Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth. The big horse of Alfred G. Vanderbilt's stable started fifteen lengths behind his five rivals and finished in front by five lengths.

Mitty, aged six and a half, was friends with nearly every one in the little village of Greenfield, Wis. She was a friend of Mrs. Johnson, the Norwegian dressmaker, who gave Mitty scraps of materials to make dresses for Sarah Ann, the beloved doll.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- More about an incident of proposed "secret diplomacy" which Woodrow Wilson refused to countenance during the World War was disclosed today in heretofore unpublished State Department records.

Leaders in scientific thought and achievement, including four Nobel Prize winners, will take part in the dedication of the new, permanent home of the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center, on the evening of Feb. 11. The museum will be opened to the public the following day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Asserting that American farmers willingly would endorse any sound move to protect the nation's neutrality, Chairman Nye of the Senate Munitions Committee said tonight that he would seek the addition of foodstuffs to any embargo list.

Between emergent prosperity and the full tide of the Winter season New York is attracting a new quality of attention as an art center of international distinction. Shows run the gamut of the centuries, from the medieval intricacy of illuminated manuscripts to the last canvas prepared for a post-office
COMES the cable to say that London's theatre goes on in spite of everything. This week, for instance:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1. -- Pennsylvania, in a second-half rally, dealt Yale a 23-18 defeat before 4,500 basketball fans at the Palestra tonight and broke the Elis' streak of three straight. The Red and Blue, Eastern Intercollegiate League champions for the last two seasons, went into a third-place tie with Cornell, the Bulldogs dropping to fifth position.

A variety of special trade promotions, originating from the determination of home furnishings manufacturers to capitalize on the reviving consumer interest in these lines, are under discussion in the industry at the present time.

WATCHING Lionel Barrymore perform before the microphone, it is apparent that he is a dynamo of human energy, who brings an enormous gusto and an amazing vitality to his work. Even when the actor had no lines to speak, his eyes, peering over tilted spectacles, darted from one face to another, hanging on every word spoken by the various player.
TAIYUAN, Shansi Province, China -- Chino-Japanese tension in North China is having startling results in Shansi Province -- results which promise to become of great moment for the future of all China.

Ten thousand child-study groups, spread throughout the country, have been formed by women's organizations as part of their programs for improving their communities and educating themselves as homemakers and parents. Of these groups, 5,000 have been formed by the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, and 3,000 by college women under the direction of the American Association of University Women.
Following along the lines of a plan used by the Philadelphia association, the women's New York Field Hockey Association will promote what will be known as a Spring Play Day.

SPECIALIZATION is the keynote of present-day activities among model engineers, just as it is in the industrial world which provides the prototypes for the realistic miniature locomotives, airplanes, power boats and other products of the model-maker's workshop.

The United States Leather Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31, a net profit of $313,537 after depreciation, depletion, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges. This is equal to $4.31 a share on 72,705 shares of 7 per cent cumulative prior preference stock, exclusive of 10,612 shares in the company's treasury, on which dividends in arrears on Oct. 31 amounted to $17.25 a share.

Kenneth R. Davidson, Yorkshire's exponent of badminton, who has been giving American players lessons in the game for the past week, routed the metropolitan singles champion, Kenneth J. Ridgway of the Garden City Casino, in their final round match to win the first Eastern New York tournament yesterday on the courts of the Tudor City Tennis Club in the 165th Infantry Armory.

FEBRUARY is the last active month of the theater's season. After that the drama's roving eye begins to examine the Summer, or Old Barn, situation, and to look over the plans for Fall. As is usual, the current month gives promise of being a busy one, the managers' schemes being lavish and energetic.

Prices were steady to firm in all commodity futures markets in exceedingly light trading yesterday, with no outstanding developments. On the cash markets wheat, corn, oats, lard, wooltops and rubber quotations were higher.

NOT the least of the miracles wrought by the bantam sorcerer, Billy Rose, in his tussles with acrobat and beast has been the apparent regeneration of William Morrissey, sometime civil engineer, actor, master of ceremonies, vagabond minstrel and flighty impresario.

WHEN Daniel L. Marsh became president of Boston University in 1926 his inauguration was the fourth in the fifty-seven years of the university's history. He was 45 years old and one of the youngest university president in the country.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 1. -- With nearly 300 guests from the campuses of Bennington, Smith, Vassar, Wellesley and other colleges, the 1936 Williams College Winter carnival officially opened with a dance in the Lasell Gymnasium under the sponsorship of the Musical Clubs here tonight.

A baseball off season that already has been a rather notable one will swing gayly into its closing numbers this week with two events on the calendar which have come to be accepted as a certain sign that another Southern Spring training campaign is just a short jump away.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- Trading on the Boerse was mixed today, but essentially friendly, with activity strictly limited. Heavy industrials were quiet and steady. Potashes also remained at yesterday's levels. Machines were somewhat more active and firm, Orenstein Koppel gaining 1 point and Maug 1/2.

Public response to the national broadcast and numerous features arranged by the League of Women Voters last Wednesday to further its drive for trained personnel in government service has been gratifyingly active, according to officials in the State and city headquarters, at 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

FROM writing books about the big top, circus animals, white elephants and "Ten Thousand Public Enemies," Courtney Ryley Cooper has returned to his earlier field of adventure and romance in the Far North and has now produced a fresh, breezy tale of a gold rush into Northern Canada.

A general movement in the heavy industries, particularly in construction, to reduce prices will do more to turn the tide of the depression and to reduce the national deficit than inflation or other monetary experiments, Professor O.M.W. Sprague of Harvard University declared yesterday.

PARIS. THE first act of the big Spring-and-Summer fashion show is played by the new textiles. They set the stage, as it were, prepare the spectators and furnish the material for the style drama that is worked out in detail by Paris couturiers.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1. -- The remarkable good fortune attending the campaign of Mrs. Emil Denemark's horses at Hialeah Park reached a new peak today when the Chicago sportswoman's Nectarine, a 10-to-1 shot, led a high-class field in the eighth running of the Miami Beach Handicap at one mile.

Mr. and Mrs. Archbold van Beuren gave a supper last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. G. Bogart Blakeley, Mr. and Mrs. John O'Donnell, Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Easby of Philadelphia, Mrs. McCauley McIlhenny and Miss Emily Thomas.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- Gilmour Dobie ended his 16-year tenure as Cornell football coach today for "the best interests of all concerned."

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Coal miners in four States gave up their Saturday holiday today and kept the pits in operation in an effort to relieve coal shortages brought about by eleven days of unprecedented cold, the longest in a generation.

NASSAU, B.W.I. -- More than twenty yachts are expected to enter the Miami-to-Nassau international race starting from Miami on Feb. 11. The race is sponsored by the Miami and the Nassau Yacht Clubs. A perpetual challenge trophy is offered by the Nassau Club.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 1. -- Barely recovered from an attack of influenza, Delbert Lamb, 21-year-old landscape artist from Milwaukee, defeated the premier speed skaters of twelve nations at 500 meters today and gave the United States an even break with Norway for the first two individual titles of the world championships.

Buckle in his "History of Civilization" states that "Every great reform which has been effected has consisted not in doing something new but in undoing something old. The most valuable additions made to legislation have been enactments destructive of previous legislation; and the best laws which have been passed have been those by which some former laws have been repealed."

AN extraordinary adventure, intellectually and psychologically, is that which Sir Arthur Willert records. Conscripted in 1921 from a notable journalistic career to help the British Foreign Office in its rela-those with the world's press, he broke away last year from the enforced repressions of that career "to look at it all from the outside, from different angles and from greater distances."

THE school teacher, in her vulnerable position as guardian of the nation's youth, has always been a center of controversy. Once she was criticized as a "blue stoking," a paragon of forbiddingly angular rectitudes who carried her classroom didacticism too frequently into the parlor.

George Washington, Commander-in-Chief of the Continental Army, first President of the United States and first Commander-in-Chief of the United States Army, never held the rank of general in that army, a recent study by the War Department shows.

MOST cheerful item of the week: Edward Johnson, manager, may yet present Edward Johnson, tenor, at the Metropolitan Opera House this season. There has been intensive demand for a farewell performance by Mr. Johnson; he did not give one last season.

TOWNSEND INQUIRY: A resolution was introduced in Congress last week by Representative Bell of Missouri, with the backing of the Democratic leadership, calling for an investigation of the Townsend movement. The resolution said: "Several groups of fraudulent promoters are enriching themselves by working the so-called pension plan racket.

SHANGHAI, China, Jan. 3. -- The aftermath of Shanghai's most terrible financial debacle in many years is to be marked by the trial, opening today, of Frank J. Raven, president of the great combination of companies known as the "Raven group." The charge is embezzlement.

The Weather Bureau prediction last night of partly cloudy and continued cold weather left it doubtful whether the proverbial ground hog would see his shadow today. If he sees it when he emerges, the tradition is that he will duck back into his burrow for six weeks more, during which wintry weather will continue.

A NUMBER of young British film directors have broken away from the big companies to form a concern of their own, the Associated Realist Film producers. Their object is to provide "screen journalism," instead of "screen fiction," and to that end they are to make real-life films, whose stars will be ordinary men and women going about their daily tasks.

TOKYO, Feb. 1. -- Headquarters of the Kwantung army at Hsinking officially confirms reports previously received from a Russian source that a Manchukuoan detachment stationed at Mishan mutinied Thursday and killed three Japanese officers.

A committee of younger members of society, including several debutantes, has been formed to assist with details of the second and last of this season's Yorkville dinner dances, which will take place on Tuesday in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- Gustavus T. Kirby, treasurer of the American Olympic Committee, today warned the German Olympic authorities against allowing propaganda for the Nazi regime to creep into the Winter and Summer Olympics.

After his concert this afternoon at Carnegie Hall, Arturo Toscanini will take a week's rest and will not direct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra again until Feb. 13. During that period Hans Lange will conduct.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 1. -- Ralph W. Morrison of San Antonio, personal friend of President Roosevelt and appointed by him to the Federal Reserve Board, has been an outstanding figure in Southwestern finance for several years.

A total of 2,920 dogs will be benched in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 10, 11 and 12 in the sixtieth annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club. This is the largest entry ever accepted in the history of this famous exhibition, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Samuel Milbank, chairman of the bench show committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- All through the week the President read and heard much in blame of himself and his administration, and little in praise. The 1936 pre-convention oratory began to resound in earnest. His only reply was to concentrate on the tremendous budgetary problems raised in the repassage by Congress over his veto of the bond bonus, and the decision of the Supreme Court in the Hoosac Mills case.

A JOURNEY through the Third Reich as the fourth year of National Socialist rule opens must convince any observer that Hitler still reigns supreme because he has achieved for Germany the one right all Germans value and desire more than all the rights they have lost. This is the right of independence vis-a-vis the outside world.

Nominally hired to keep an eye on Kip Shannon, a ne'er-do-well if there ever was one, Hank Hyer is suspicious, but then, he has a suspicious nature, as becomes a private detective. Hyer already knows a great deal about Shannon and nothing that is good.

Noted French artists will participate in a concert at Carnegie Hall on the night of Feb. 16 for the endowment fund of the Lycee Francais de New York. The concert will be given under the auspices of Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General here.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Clyde Troutt's good luck at the Fair Grounds continued today when he sent out Lady Federal to defeat six rivals in the one and one-sixteenth miles of the Fairmount Handicap.
Five patrolmen were dismissed from the department yesterday by Commissioner Valentine on a variety of charges of violating regulations. Each, in addition, had been found guilty of intoxication.

Retail trade in many sections of the country continued last week to reflect the adverse effects of the recent storms and abnormally low temperatures, according to the market report prepared by Kirby, Block Co. The gains piled up during the early part of the month were substantially reduced.

ONE of the most significant activities initiated by the national administration, and one of the least publicized or understood, is the creation of green-belt town The impression has got around that they are in some vague way radical. Actually, the greenbelt town is not a new venture.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- The establishment of an Institute of the Arts in the Theatre, to be conducted from June 27 to Aug. 22 at Triuna Island, Lake George, was announced here today by the Corporation of Yaddo. Thomas H. Dickinson, former director of the Summer Institute of the Theatre at Union College, has been named director of the institute.

School supervisors, with their attention riveted on theoretical "will o' the wisps" rather than the needs of the children, are just "playing at" being educators, Professor Rudolph D. Lindquist of Ohio State University told 500 superintendents, principals and department heads at a conference yesterday under the auspices of the department of supervisors of the National Education Association.

ROME, Sunday, Feb. 2. -- The meeting of the Fascist Grand Council last night came after Italians had read in Premier Benito Mussolini's newspaper a warning that "Italy will defend herself with teeth and nails" and that "she has long been prepared for any eventuality." It was asserted an oil embargo against Italy might extend the African war to Europe.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 31. -- It is not an easy task to assay the political value of the "grass-roots convention'' at Macon, where the New Deal of Franklin D. Roosevelt was condemned and Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia was asked to lead a crusade for "the old-time religion" and the economic doctrines of Thomas Jefferson against the heresies of Washington.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- Permanent friendship between Great Britain and Germany is the goal hotly claimed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler and its pursuit and conservation have become the keystone of German foreign policy.
THE dream of every enthusiastic gardener is to possess, some time, a small greenhouse, a place where he can be independent of the weather, and start seeds and grow plants at his own sweet will.
AIKEN, S.C. -- The Highland Park Golf Club has announced that its championship tournament will be held March 7, 8, 14 and 15. It has also arranged for several other important tourneys.

An entertainment by members of the Madison Square Boys' Club will feature the dinner dance to be given on Feb. ll at Jack Dempsey's Restaurant in behalf of the club's work among under-privileged boys living in the neighborhood from Nineteenth to Forty-second Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1. -- The Virginia of the Panama Pacific Line, which left here at noon today for New York, has an exceptionally good passenger list for an East-bound Winter sailing, with a total of 300. She also took out a heavy express cargo of California products. Many persons of note in various walks of life were aboard.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 1. -- The five-year campaign of business interests, led by the chamber of commerce, for a central postoffice for this city to abolish the 3-cent postage rate between business centers a mile apart became a political issue today when opponents of the Roosevelt administration joined in criticism of a plan for construction of two first-class postoffices.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 1. -- The Union Steamship Company's proposal that the Australian, New Zealand, Canadian, Fijian and, possibly, the British Governments combine to subsidize British shipping in the Pacific to meet competition from the heavily subsidized Matson Line was brought to the attention of A.C. Dieriox, Matson Line vice president, who arrived today on the Monterey.

ALTHOUGH this volume is, strictly speaking, little more than a monograph on the influence of Virgil's Georgics on English poetry during the eighteenth century, it has been developed into a discussion of the origin and contents of the nature poetry of Wordsworth and his predecessors.

IF half the motorists of America avoided nine common driving practices they would save $90,000,000 a year in gas and oil, according to B.H. Anibal, vice president and chief engineer of the Pontiac Motor Company. Mr. Anibal based his assertion on results obtained at the General Motors proving grounds from tests with eight makes of cars priced below $850 each.

It would be difficult to discover more solid ground for confidence in the future of American aeronautics than was afforded by the fourth annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences which closed at Columbia University last Friday evening. For three days some 300 leaders in the field gave absorbed attention to technical papers presented by a score of their number and participated widely in the ensuing discussion.

Past, present and future development of the Y.W.C.A.'s international program will concern the delegates to the annual meeting of the foreign division of the association at the national board headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue, on Wednesday and Thursday.

GREENWICH. Conn., Feb. 1. -- The annual junior riding competition will be held at the indoor ring of the Round Hill Club Stables next Saturday. Students of private schools of Greenwich will compete. There will be twelve classes, featuring the best pair of riders, side saddle, novice, open jumping over eight fences for boys and girls, and teams of three riders from the same school, judged as hunt team over four jumps.

"I have read with interest Mr. de la Torre Bueno's excellent letter and would like to reply to some of the comments he made on the interview with me published in your column," writes Edward R. Hewitt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Although industrial output in January was considerably higher than a year ago, current statistics show little significant change from December, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.
A resolution vigorously opposing the neutrality bills now before Congress has been drafted by the special committee on national defense of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

SEVERAL thousand carefree travelers, without hotel or apartment problems, arrive in Florida every Winter, bringing their homes with them. Practically all the streamlined automobile trailers or sturdy housecars in which they travel display the emblem of the Tin Can Tourists of the World, an organization of some 36,000 registered members whose name was first bestowed in fun by stay-at-home Floridians.

New plans for a Manhattan-Bronx express highway from Ninety-sixth Street and Park Avenue, Manhattan, to 153d Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, were announced yesterday by Borough Presidents Samuel Levy of Manhattan and James J. Lyons of the Bronx.

The National Board of Review of Motion Pictures will open its twelfth annual conference on Wednesday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The first session will be devoted to a symposium on different types of motion picture review, in which critics from representative publications will take part.

THERE is a very pretty problem for the habitual gallery-goer: whether the discovery of hitherto unknown talent gives greater delight than the discovery of a veteran artist who has not settled into complete routine but has chosen rather to extend his subject-matter and keep his mind open to new impressions.

MURDER continues to fascinate the intelligent reading public. And Mr. Edmund Pearson continues, happily, to meet that public's taste for the recital of piquant tales of crime. It is essentially a "refined" taste, a taste sophisticated but not decadent, a taste for inexplicable strangenesses in human behavior, for the unraveling of curious puzzles and the presentation of queer characters, for odd stories well told.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1. -- The latest in airplanes, commercial, sport and military, went on display here today with the opening of the National Pacific Aircraft and Boat Show.
