CONSIDERING that it is primarily a delicate, witty story of tension within a family, there is a curious amount of melodrama in "I'll Mourn You Later." It starts with a funeral; it goes on to include suicide and sudden death in its roster of tragedy.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 1. -- A squadron of six of the army's most modern fighting airplanes demonstrated their striking power today when they "tactically" destroyed Mitchel Field in a mission that required less than three hours.

SUNBURY, Pa., Feb. 1. -- For the next ninety days the Reading Railroad will use the Pennsylvania Railroad's trackage between Sunbury and Shamokin during the rebuilding of the Reading overpass leading to the west end of the bridge. Signing of the agreement was announced today.

TRADE showed some Improvement in the week, but in many sections was still hampered by weather conditions. As a general thing, retail volume was ahead in the industrial centers and slightly off in the farming areas of the county.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The high spot in the Winter social season here, will be reached Friday night when the Charity League presents its "circus" at the Traymore, with members of the younger set appearing as cowgirls, Indians, clowns and dancers in the various musical numbers that enliven the program.

President Frederick B. Robinson's promised appearance at the House Plan Center of City College Thursday as speaker at a reception and tea to be tendered incoming freshmen will mark the final step in the House Plan's efforts to obtain complete support from the college administration.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- During this past week one more French Government has announced and has confirmed its determination to "defend the stability of the franc," that is to say, to maintain the gold standard in the midst of a world that has largely abandoned it.

Thirty-one men were seized early yesterday in two raids on gambling games in Harlem by plainclothesmen attached to the squad of Inspector John J. Martino, over whose head detectives from Commissioner Valentine's office had conducted a gambling raid in the same area Friday that netted fifty-five prisoners and $20,000 in cash.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 1. -- With Captain Paul Guibord of Dartmouth scoring the winning tally in an overtime period, the Green defeated Yale, 5 to 4, in a Quadrangular Hockey League game tonight.

THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine account of the issue of de Tocqueville's "Democracy in America" 100 years ago is an interesting review of the Frenchman's observations, but it does not tell the whole story.

THIS book, Mr. Sinclair tells us, is his fifty-fourth; and he adds, "That is a long time to have let God wait." God might have waited even longer, it seems had the people of California looked more approvingly on Mr. Sinclair's Gubernatorial aspirations.

BERLIN. IN view of the severe restrictions placed upon foreign films through contingent regulations, which admit not an inch more of the celluloid strip than is absolutely necessary to fill the gap left open by the realm's own industry, Minister Goebbels's praise of the American film, in his recent speech before Germany's collective film organizations, is particularly significant.

THE sister of Friedrich Nietzsche died on Nov. 8, shortly before her ninetieth birthday. Not long before her death she had undergone an operation for a cataract, so that her last days were brightened by the restoral of her sight after a period of almost total blindness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Registration by the Securities and Exchange Commission of $15,000,000 of its 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures due on Feb. 15, 1946, was sought today by Loew's, Inc., of New York City. The bonds would be redeemable in whole or in part after thirty days' notice at 103 and interest if redeemed by Feb. 15, 1941, and at smaller premiums thereafter.

The Hospital and Music Committees of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Add Association will be the beneficiaries of a special performance of "Parsifal," with Kirsten Flag-stad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles, the night of April 8 at the Metropolitan Opera House.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- A threat to kidnap the 12-year-old son of Governor Curley of Massachusetts had both postoffice inspectors and the Justice Department men in action today.

A Democratic district captain and a man on relief were convicted yesterday by a jury before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard of conspiracy to use the mails for an attempted extortion in a case taken over by the Department of Justice after the Police Department had recorded it as closed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A State advisory committee of the National Youth Administration for New York State was announced today by Aubrey Williams, executive director.

Apropos of Mr. Downes's recent article on a celebrated Russian composer, let me say that the best compliment that could have been paid Alexander Glazunoff was done in an appropriate way by the distinguished critic Montague-Nathan, comparing him to a large tree, rooted deep in the soil of music, spreading its branches in every direction.

With 3,000 young men and women at work and 100 others being placed in part-time jobs each day, the National Youth Administration began yesterday a statistical picture of the ways in which the depression has kept the young people of this city from following the professions and trades for which they studied.

FOR students interested in old English carols, this book offers a mine of information. Preceded by a voluminous introduction and supplemented with an extensive bibliography and notes, it presents a collection of nearly five hundred carols, virtually all of them newly edited from the original manuscripts and printed sources.

Tom, Dick and Harry, three singing, dancing and talking birds from Africa, spent most of yesterday warming up for contests to be held during the week at the second international bird show at the Hotel Breslin, Twenty-ninth Street and Broadway, under the supervision of the National Federation of Canary Breeders.

The Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland and subsidiary companies reported yesterday that their net assets on Dec. 31 were equivalent to $3,273 for each $1,000 debenture, compared with $2,291 at the close of the preceding year; $860 for each share of Class A preferred stock, compared with $504, and $15.34 for each share of Class B common stock, compared with $8.15.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31. -- San Francisco gets a breathing spell and the hitherto victorious maritime unions of the Pacific Coast staggering blow as a result of the action of the International Seamen's Union in convention at the national capital this week in revoking the charter of the Sailors Union of the Pacific and tying up its funds through an injunction suit filed in Federal court here.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 1. -- Bucknell University will stage a nationwide observance of Charter Day Wednesday evening, exactly ninety years after the granting of the original charter by Governor Francis Shunk at Harrisburg in 1846.

ATHENS, Feb. 1. -- A group of anti-Venizelist generals influential in the army and the air force today addressed to King George an oral manifesto in which they defined the nature and power of the Cabinet that they would consider could take over the government, according to newspaper statements confirmed by military circles.

SPENCER TRACY joined the G-men in "Whipsaw" exactly ten day ago. Three days later J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, told one of THE TIMES Washington correspondents that his Federal police force was undermanned and that -- Congress and the Budget Director being willing -- he intended to add 288 more G-chaps to his staff.

It is not only in Soviet Russia that the history textbooks are dry and colorless. American history, too, was much more fun when it consisted of CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS, GEORGE WASHINGTON and ABRAHAM LINCOLN. But today American history in the schools consists chiefly of climate, river valleys and the Profit Motive, with an occasional ghost named WASHINGTON or LINCOLN flitting across the scene.

The hockey match between the New York Rangers and the Detroit team on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden will mark the annual benefit for the St. Johnland Society. The committee representing the women's auxiliary of St. Johnland, which has arranged the benefit, has announced that virtually all the boxes and arena seats taken over by the auxiliary have been sold.

Motorless flights of several hundred miles, perhaps breaking the world records, held in Germany, were predicted for glider pilots in this country yesterday at the annual meeting of the Soaring Society of America.

EDINBURGH, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Wales took the lead in the international rugby series today by defeating Scotland, 13-3, before 50,000 at Murrayfield. In the first of the international encounters England and Wales battled to a scoreless draw at Swansea.

RICHMOND, Jan. 31. -- North Carolina's new lethal gas chamber failed to function in accordance with expectations when Allen Foster, the first person executed by this method east of the Mississippi, was put to death there last Friday, and a storm of indignation has arisen over what witnesses say were the sufferings of the victim.

IT is an interesting group of canvases by Maurice de Vlaminck that has been assembled in the Lilienfeld Galleries, to remain through Feb. 17; interesting, for one thing, because nearly all of these canvases are recent and may, therefore, be considered representative of the artist's present outlook.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Although there has been no discussion of a British loan or credits to Russia between Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, in the several intimate talks they have had within the last week, it is understood that the Foreign Office believes such a financial overture to the Soviet at the present time would be good politics.

In a high scoring game in which neither team paid any particular attention to defense, Fordham's basketball team defeated Army, 60 -- 40, at the Maroon gymnasium last night. It was the tenth victory of the season for the Rams, who are unbeaten on their home court, and the third defeat for the West Pointers.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 1 (Reuters). -- A determined struggle has begun for possession of the seventy-five-mile road between Makale and Adowa in Northern Ethiopia. The Italian main force is believed to have concentrated southwest of Hauzien, but Blackshirt forces, seriously engaged for the first time since the outbreak of the war, are reported to have been badly shaken.

TURIN'S Winter lyric season was opened early this month at the Teatro Regio with Franco Alfano's "Resurrezione," which confirmed here, as elsewhere, its vibrant humanity and strong popular appeal. "Turandot" with Gina Cigna and "Traviata" with Mercedes Capsir followed suit.

A supper dance was held last night at the Plaza by the young men's division of the Sons of the American Revolution, who were assisted by members of the Daughters of the American Revolution and other patriotic societies. Curtis C. Shears was chairman of the dance committee.
Your editorial "Perils of Rock Dust" merits comment.

JOLIET, Ill., Feb. 1 (AP). -- Nathan Leopold Jr. denied today to the head of the Illinois penal system that he was withholding any information which could throw light on the prison slaying of his crime partner, Richard Loeb.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, Public Works Superintendent, started today a new drive to obtain legislative authority to construct an elevator and shelter house at the end of the nine-mile memorial highway leading to the top of Whiteface Mountain in the Adirondacks.

THE most important event of the closing season in 1935 was the special performance of Purcell's "King Arthur," conducted by Adrian Boult at the last B.B. concert of the year; the most important event of the new year, up to the present, has been the performance of Shostakovich's Concerto No. 1 for pianoforte, trumpet and strings.

In the Jan. 12 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review there appears a review of O'Connor's "Steel -- Dictator," by R.L. Duffus, which contains statements by the reviewer so seriously in error and so misleading that I am taking this occasion to call your attention to them.

Use of the new free port facilities to obtain the release of millions of dollars tied up by exchange restrictions in South America and other foreign markets was considered a distinct possibility by exporters here yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Memories of the days when motoring to Miami from principal points in the North and West was more a matter of grim determination than pleasure will be vividly recalled on Feb. 22 in a celebration to take place on the arrival from Detroit of Colonel W.S. Gilbreath of that city, known as the "father" of the Dixie Highway, and Claude Nolan, veteran Florida motorist.

The revamped Rangers are ready for their encounter with the world champion Montreal Maroons in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Lester Patrick's charges, faced with elimination in the race for a play-off berth in the American Division of the league, need a triumph over the Northerners if they hope to retain their precarious hold on the third rung in their group.
The youngest team to win the national racquets doubles championship since Clarence Pell and Stanley Mortimer launched their long reign in 1915 extended its tenure to a second year yesterday.

PRODUCTION plans are beginning to take form at RKO-Radio. Samuel Briskin, credited by the industry with having elevated Columbia from the ranks of the independent and the lowly "quickie" to a formidable spot among the majors, has been in charge a month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- A plan to dispose of the government's large cotton holdings through a sales agent at a rate not to exceed 20,000 bales a week was proposed today by a group of Southern Senators. It will be incorporated in a resolution to be introduced Monday by Senator Smith, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

AMERICANS have begun to realize that they have in the United States health spas -- now modernized and refurbished by Federal recovery funds -- which equal or surpass the long celebrated watering places abroad. Hot Springs, Ark., and Excelsior Springs, Mo., have been enabled to offer to those seeking health and pleasure seekers, facilities equal to those of Vichy, Baden-Baden, Bad Homburg or other European hygienic centers.

Aviators Post 732 of the American Legion is sponsoring the seventeenth annual aviators' ball, which will take place on Feb. 21 at the Pierre. Charles S. (Casey) Jones, commander of the post, heads the arrangements committee.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 2. -- "The loss of national revenue from the northern provinces is the main reason the Chinese Government has been forced to refund domestic bonds, reducing the interest rate and lengthening the amortization period," a Nanking official spokesman said here today as a plan was announced for funding the nation's whole bonded debt.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- Enzel's Spring shoe collection seeks inspiration from the heights. Peasant shoes from European mountainous regions, the Scotch highlands, the Tyrol or Norway are made light and dainty for street wear.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Francis Williams, financial editor of The London Daily Herald, contributes an article to his newspaper today on loopholes in the sanction decrees in which he asserts that British companies and individuals, by repeatedly chartering Italian tramp steamers, are "actively assisting Italy to obtain the foreign exchange she so urgently needs to purchase raw materials."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Two large cotton trading firms were named in a report before the Senate Agriculture Committee today as having exercised influence over price movements in cotton by futures sales greatly in excess of their spot operations.
BARCELONA. -- The question of adequate exchange facilities is the snag holding up the commercial treaty which for some two years has been under negotiation between Spain and the United States.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine issued detailed orders early today to put the department in a position to handle any emergency that might arise from the threatened strike of elevator operators, attendants, porters, janitors and other service employes expected this week and possibly tomorrow.

ROME fell in 476, as we all know, and the Dark Ages began. But was it so simple? Did the Roman Empire really "fall" at that moment of barbarian triumph in the Imperial City, and was a new era ushered in, thus, by overturn?

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. GEORGE M. COHAN is showing us this week at the Garrick "Dear Old Darling," his latest, while Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess" comes to the Forrest and William Gillette and colleagues continue at the Chestnut Street Opera House in "Three Wise Fools."

PEIPING, Feb. 1. -- While the Japanese policy of attrition in North China continues to intensify there are signs aplenty that a certain degree of cooperation by Nanking will be forced by Japan's continual implied readiness to use military pressure in case of opposition.

YUMA, Ariz. WITHIN a few hundred yards of the once-towering pile that was "Beau Geste," now swallowed by the surging waves of sand until but the uppermost two feet of the walls are visible, still waging a valiant though losing fight against the desert's ceaseless wind and dust, another transitory drama is being concocted.
TWO works new to New York will be performed on the Thursday night program of the Philharmonic-Symphony concert, conducted by Hans Lange.

IN connection with the National Pacific Aircraft and Boat Show which opened yesterday in Los Angeles, the giant 24,000-pound transport, Douglas DC-3, has been put on public view. This is the first of a series of sleeper planes which will ply the air lanes of the United States this year and next and bring a new phase to the rapidly developing industry of air transport.

HOW does a healthy, young bean plant begin its day's work? What does it do when it "wakes up" in the morning; how does it combat the blistering heat of the midday Summer's sun, or prepare for a comfortable night's "sleep"?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Adoption by the Securities and Exchange Commission of amendments to rules governing registration of securities of issuing concerns emerging from bankruptcy or receivership and of companies created to acquire assets of other issuers was announced today.

LONDON, Ont., Feb. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Russell Knowles of Detroit was found guilty today on all four charges made against him in connection with the kidnapping of John S. Labatt, London brewer, in the Summer of 1934.

IN planning for the effective use of color in the garden most amateurs -- and not a few professionals! -- overlook the fact that contrast and background are quite as essential as the brighter colors themselves. But more and more are gardeners coming to recognize that the neutral tones have an important place; and this is particularly true of gray.

P. Hal Sims and Mrs. Prentice Cromwell led one section of play for the mixed pair title in the new Atlantic national bridge championship matches at the Park Central Hotel last night, while Mrs. Sims and M.D. Maier led the other.

LET this morning's gentle reminder be on the harrowing details of Winter. Once again sleet is toying with the tempers of the commuters, and winds howl like critics through the side streets off Broadway. The sun is cold and the shadows are colder, and night workers shake their gaunt fists at the dismal predictions of the Weather Bureau.

LONDON, Jan. 10. AFTER a tour of the provinces, Noel Coward has reappeared in London with no less than six new plays, of which as yet three only, "Family Album," "Astonished Heart" and "Red Peppers" have been seen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- A decision on the legality of the New Deal's power program is strongly expected to be one of the first rulings to come from the Supreme Court when it enters the second half of its term Monday.

The majority of representatives of producer, distributor and consumer groups, who attended an all-day milk-control conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, agreed that some form of control was still necessary for the handling and sale of interstate milk.

JEREMIAH DUMMER was one of the earliest of a long line of craftsmen who set the torch of art alight in the New England colonies. He left products so fine that after many generations we still find them worthy of our admiration.

VAUDEVILLE is dead, and there is some question whether the torch it flung was caught by the stage-show firm of Fanchon and Marco. It is sad but true that the firm's merchandise, although it certainly lives and breathes, is no longer an end in itself -- the way the "Four Malones" et al used to be -- but is merely a prelude to the more vital entertainment exposed upon the screen.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 1. -- In the beautiful Palacio de Bellas Artes the Mexican Commission of Military Studies paid tribute this evening to the United States Army for its courtesies to Mexican officers on their good-will visits in the United States.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1. -- The first "Stakhanoff ten-day period," in which Soviet heavy industry by an intensive application of the principles of the new efficiency movement endeavored to increase production all along the line as an earnest of its ability to complete the second Five-Year Plan in four years, has ended.

THE Constitution in the Twentieth Century" is the topic of a new WEAF series to open Feb. 4 at 7:45 P.M. The fifteen-minute broadcasts, presented by the Committee on Civic Education by Radio in cooperation with the American Political Science Association, are scheduled to be on the air Tuesday nights at the same time until June 9.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Looming large on the February calendar at Sea Island will be the series of tournaments at the Sea Island Golf Club. Today marks the beginning of play in the men's and women's ringer tournaments, which extend through the month for the best composite scores for ten or less rounds.

CAIRO, Jan. 31. -- With the subject of the independence of small nations very much in the limelight these days, both Great Britain and France are finding themselves confronted by the problem of settling difficult situations which have arisen as a result of persistent nationalistic demands made through demonstrations and disturbances in Egypt and Syria respectively.

A SLING in which oxen are placed for shoeing is now in its 176th year of use at West Buxton in Maine. Built of hand-hewn timbers, it weighs about a ton and a half, and although badly worn is still serviceable. It is longed in a smithy, the first brick building erected in the town.

TORONTO, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs played inspired hockey tonight to earn a 3-2 overtime triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks and again cut the Montreal Maroons' lead in the international division of the National Hockey League to a single point.

Twenty-six gunners took part in the weekly shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Peter Garino was the leading performer. He annexed the High-Over-All Cup by breaking 95 out of 100 targets, then took the scratch trophy in the shoot at 155 targets with a total of 140.

For the second time this season, a large and delighted audience -- mainly comprised of youngsters -- greeted Ernest Schelling and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday morning in the second concert for children and young people at Carnegie Hall.

NO police being at hand, for the very good reason that Winatchee Island is isolated by a flood that has torn away the bridges to the mainland, Peter Kerrigan undertakes to find out who murdered Mr. Pierdeck, head of the Pierdeck family and owner of the greater part of the island.

This is an amusing fable for children of the picture-book age in which five mischievous bear cubs discover some white paint and forthwith go masquerading as polar bears. Their prank took on a serious aspect when the zoo keeper thought he recognized them as escaped charges and, regardless of their plaints, hurried them off to the polar bear cage.

Slightly lower merchandise stocks as compared with a year ago were quite generally shown in retail inventories last week, which marked the end of the fiscal year for about 80 per cent of department and dry goods stores throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- An effort to take food to ice-bound Tangier Island on a small privately owned dirigible was planned tonight after a survey had shown it was impossible to land a plane close by.

ROME, Feb. 1. -- Losses of guns, machine guns and other war material in a battle in the Tembien area of Northern Ethiopia between Jan. 20 and 24, hitherto unrevealed, were admitted in well-informed Italian quarters today. The statement was in reply to an Ethiopian claim that the fighting resulted in a complete victory for the Ethiopian forces.

THE clipping of the hours between distant centers of the United States has been a recent spectacular achievement of the railroads. Running time has been reduced north, east, south and west. The busy New Yorker can close his desk on a completed day's work, catch a train at 5:30 P.M. and arrive in Chicago at 9 o'clock next morning for another full business day, after sixteen and one-half hours of comfortable travel.

The resignation of Gilmour Dobie at Cornell marks the end of the longest tenure enjoyed by any football coach in service at a major college in the East. In spite of the fact that his teams fared rather poorly of late years and that Cornell's stock on the gridiron has dropped steadily since he turned out his unbeaten and untied combinations of 1921, 1922 and 1923, "Gloomy Gil" appeared to be a fixture at Ithaca.

Three outstanding violin concertos of the first half of the nineteenth century were performed by Mischa Elman, as soloist with the National Orchestral Association, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall at the second of the special series of five concerts intended to demonstrate the development of violin literature.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- Capturing the 400-yard relay, the closing event of the meet, the Army varsity swimmers defeated Colgate, 36 to 35, today. The encounter, which was among the features of an extensive sports program, was marked by the record-breaking performances of Cadets Lemmon and Hill of the visitors.

AS part of the campaign to check crime the Department of Justice has undertaken a survey of the parole system and its administration in the various States with the ultimate purpose of determining the effectiveness of the measures applied in different jurisdictions.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 23. -- When the advance guard of the American figure-skating team arrived today for a quiet period of intensive pre-Olympic practice on the high-altitude rinks of this famous Engadine resort we were greeted, much to our surprise, by the members of the American Olympic women's ski team, in training a mile away at Dares-Doff.

You print on page 14 of your issue for Jan. 12 the statement that the British Library of Information informs you "there is nothing in the records of the British Foreign Office to substantiate a statement made in this column Nov. 24, 1935, concerning George Seldes's 'Sawdust Caesar,'" which statement referred to the suppression of the book in England.

Making his third extended trip since his election last May to the presidency of the New York Stock Exchange, Charles R. Gay will visit the South and Southwest early next month. Accompanying him on this good-will tour to Tennessee, Oklahoma, Texas and Louisiana as part of the Exchange's public-relations program will be governors and members of the Exchange.

Because of limited accommodations at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, the museum's film library has announced that its second series of motion pictures, under the general title of "The Rise of the American Film," featuring four early examples of film-making technique, will be held in the auditorium of the Dalton School, 108 East Eighty-ninth Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings.

The brilliant amateur who solves the mystery of the killing of Hugo Fassler in this story is Sidney Meyers, a young writer of detective stories, who is also a music lover. Since Fassler is shot while conducting a performance of Wagner's "Gotterdammerung," a knowledge of music does not come amiss.

More than 300 pickets, representing the City Projects Council and the Federation of Professional and White Collar Unemployed Workers, demanding work instead of home relief, held a demonstration yesterday morning at the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, where the WPA has its headquarters.

THIS is a first rate, virile piece of story-telling. It moves dramatically but in a restrained and effective manner toward its ultimate goal. Each link is securely fastened in the chain of events and, by allowing fate rather than human initiative to decide the final outcome, it retains plausibility.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Since the three Roosevelt birthday dances held here Thursday night, interest of Augustans and Winter visitors has turned temporarily from social activities to sports events.

East Orange High School's band of foilsmen came from behind to defeat Flushing's favored trio, 5 to 4, yesterday on the strips of the Green Room of the East Building at Washington Square. Trailing, 4 to 2, the Blue and Red fencers smashed through to a brilliant triumph in the third annual preparatory school tourney staged by N.Y.U. for the Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Trophy.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- Republican and Democratic leaders were putting the finishing touches tonight on plans for their rival public hearings on the executive budget next Tuesday. The Republicans will control the hearing before the Assembly Committee on Ways and Means, while the Democrats will rule at the hearing before the Finance Committee of the Upper House.

AVALON, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP). -- Cracking par by a dozen strokes in seventy-two holes of medal play, Willie Hunter of Culver City, Calif., won the Santa Catalina Island $5,000 open golf meet today with a total score of 252.

As a constant supporter of Al Smith during his campaigns for Governor and President, for which activity I received his written thanks, I would like to mention a few impressions of his Liberty League speech.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 1. -- Champion Ambroise of Misty Isles, an upstanding black poodle, owned and shown in the ring by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of the Blakeen Kennels of Katonah, N.Y., and New York City, tonight was awarded the highest honors of the twenty-third annual dog show of the Maryland Kennel Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- With nineteen injunction suits pending against enforcement of the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act, the National Labor Relations Board revealed today that it is aiming for a Supreme Court test of the statute this Spring.

AS ANNOUNCED in this department a few weeks ago, there is to be a new worldwide survey of cosmic radiation with seven new instruments designed by Professor Ralph D. Bennett of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on the basis of suggestions made by Professor Arthur D. Compton of the University of Chicago.
MINNEAPOLIS Feb. 1 (AP). -- An investigation into conditions alleged by the recently assassinated Walter W. Liggett was pushed today by the grand jury.

St. John's University won its thirteenth basketball game of the season by conquering its borough rival, St. Francis College, 41 -- 18, before 1,200 fans at the De Gray Gymnasium in Brooklyn last night.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1. -- Yale tonight defeated the New York Boys Club, 47 to 33, in a swimming meet in which two Payne Whitney pool records were broken.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 1. -- A strong agitation has been set under way here for drastic action by the government to stop what is called "water play" in the coming carnival. It is the practice of throwing water on celebrants. It originated in the lower quarters of towns but has spread to the better streets in recent celebrations.
Bits of good news:

Governor LANDON'S plea for common sense in Government seems to have made a good impression, as it ought, upon Republicans generally. Friends of other candidates or aspirants can hardly be expected at this stage of the game to telegraph their approval. Technically, every expectant is regarded in public as "a good man."

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 1. -- Consternation is felt in local oil circles -- especially those of foreign interests -- by the most recent decision of the Federal Labor Board which has ruled that 44 per cent of the Huasteca Petroleum Company employees in the Ebano field must be retained as watchmen during the period of the prevailing strike.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Assurances that Georgia would send a delegation to the Democratic National Convention pledged to the nomination of President Roosevelt were given to him today by a group from that State which had met here earlier in the day to plan their campaign.

ON Jan. 19 we printed a letter from Rev. A.R.E. Greer, in which this Vermont clergyman confessed extreme bewilderment as to the meaning and significance of a painting by Georgia O'Keeffe, "Ram's Horn, Hollyhock, Hills," included in the artist's current show at An American Place and reproduced on the art page Jan. 12.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- Some 500 years ago a King of England who had been a lively lad as Prince of Wales sent purses of gold to his boon companions on his succeeding to the throne as Henry V, along with a message that their jolly companionship had come to an end.

AT the Brooklyn Museum for the whole of this month and half of the next an exhibition of "The Dance in Art" will occupy the Gallery for Living Artists. The exhibition is given a partly professional aspect by the presence of a number of items that are manifestly studies of different phases of dances and different moments in the work of the dancers caught in action with no attempt at making a "picture."

LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Bound for the "last great adventure on earth," the first members of the 1936 Mount Everest Expedition left here today en route to Darjeeling, India, for a new assault on the world's highest mountain.

THEIR guns and pistols oiled and primed, sights tested and adjusted, marksmen representing nearly 600 teams began yesterday another competitive season in indoor target shooting. The competition, held under the direction of the National Rifle Association, will continue for ten weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The question of industrial versus craft unionism has become the dominant issue in the American labor movement. Scarcely a week goes by without some development to stress the cleavage that has developed between those holding divergent ideas as to the best method of labor organization in modern industry.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 1 (AP). -- On a treacherous, muddy track, Whisking, 7-year-old gelding owned by J.H. Tate, captured the feature race today at Alamo Downs, running the six furlongs in l:15 3-5.

EVIDENCE is increasing from day to day that eventually an international conference will be necessary to avert a snarl in short-wave broadcasting. More and more as many foreign stations boost power outputs their "voices" become stronger far beyond their own frontiers.

IT is time for a new dress -- one of those in-between-season affairs which some one once called a pick-up dress. You'll want one with all the latest wrinkles the style experts write about; one that is fresh as paint and not too expensive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A national maritime labor council was formed here today for the ultimate purpose of uniting all marine unions in the nation into a large, powerful organization. This would confer with the national representatives of marine and shipping interests in the hope of effecting a national agreement on wages, hours, and working conditions.

ATHENS, Feb. 1. -- When death took General George Kondylis, Greece's free-style artist in military government, King George lost a resolute leader who virtually alone created the monarchy he was pledged to defend. The King is now shadowed by the approaching return of a rival of General Kondylis -- Eleutherios Venizelos, sixteen years older, cannier and without the attachments to the throne which cramped the close of Kondylis's career.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Hundreds of conservation experts headed toward the capital tonight to work out a program for making certain that fish and game shall not be exterminated.

Floating ice in the Hudson and East Rivers has added a toll to the cost of ship operation that affects travelers as well as ship lines. The difficulty of getting a ship to and from her pier, the delay to arriving passengers who are in a hurry to catch trains or keep appointments, and the confusion in arranging for longshore staffs to handle arriving freight result in financial losses.

QUEBEC. -- More skiing championships for Quebec city and district titles are scheduled for next Sunday at Lake Beauport, with the pick of ski artists from Quebec and surrounding territory within a radius of twenty-five miles testing their skill over the jumps and across country.

THAT the upswing in travel in the United States is being accompanied by increased competition among the various States for the attention of tourists is revealed by a recent survey of travel advertising expenditures and activities.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1. -- Striving for uniformity in football, the rules committee of the American Footbal Coaches Association tonight recommended six sweeping changes, including abolition of both the "slow whistle" and the first down penalty for interference with a kicker.

If the recent impressive dedication of the State of New York's imposing memorial to Theodore Roosevelt was notable in any other way than honoring in the highest degree that any State or nation can do it, it was in showing how such State or nation can rise to really noble heights and display super-qualities in evaluating the character, attainments and achievements of its sons.

The re-election of Miss Anna E. Lawson, retiring principal of Public School 119, to the Teachers' Retirement Board when the election is held in May, was urged by Justice Agnes M. Craig yesterday afternoon. She spoke at a luncheon given in Miss Lawson's honor by the staff of Public School 119 at the Hotel Astor.
BOSTON, Jan. 31. -- All New England listened in on "Al" Smith's Liberty League speech, and half of New England heard "Joe" Robinson's reply.

Uncle Robert is arranging an ambitious program for the ninth annual observance of Parents Day on the Mall in Central Park on Sunday afternoon, May 10. He expects an attendance of more than 25,000 children and parents.

Formation of a committee of educators to study the cases of teachers who contend that they have been dismissed because of their political, social or economic beliefs, and to lend financial and legal aid to these teachers, if the committee decides it is merited, was announced yesterday by Frederick L. Redefer, secretary of the Progressive Education Association.

HAVANA, Feb. 1. -- Provisional President Jose A. Barnet today signed a decree fixing the 1936 sugar crop at 2,515,000 long tons, in accordance with the six-year restriction plan, enacted recently by the Cuban Government.

In behalf of its endowment fund, the Adventure Society is arranging a gala dinner and entertainment to be held on the night of Feb. 19 at the Ritz-Carlton. Features of the program for the evening will be a pre-opening showing of the new Gaumont-British film, "Rhodes -- The Diamond Master, The Empire Builder, The Jungle Conqueror," and an exhibition of precious stones including the world-famous diamond, the Star of Kimberley.

Joe Mangan came rocketing off the banked turn forty yards from the finish of the Wanamaker Mile last night as a crowd of 15,000 turned Madison Square Garden into bedlam with its frenzied cheers. And the ancient sport of footracing was handed another hero and other sensation.

Tomorrow marks the formal opening of the series of Constitution Contests which THE NEW YORK TIMES will conduct this year and next year for teachers and students in the high schools and preparatory schools of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

ONE would like to say that this is a thoroughly American book about a typical American frontiersman. Superficially, its characters, who are chiefly Indians, soldiers and Indian agents, and its color, which is adventure against a flaming background of mountains and deserts, would seem to place it in the customary category of the heroic Western yarn.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Jacob Loevenhart, 67 years old, walked into the office of his business associate, Herbert Phillip Grossman, 44years old, on the thirteenth floor of the First National Bank Building, just before noon today and shot him four times, killing him instantly.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The Junior League's annual cruise ball at the Vinoy Park Hotel on Friday night, Feb. 7, heads the calendar of social events here this week. The cruise motif will be carried out in cabaret numbers depicting various foreign ports.

IN this book Paul Pigors, Assistant Professor of Sociology, University of Rochester, has made an adventurous and impressive effort to demonstrate the difference between leadership and domination, to describe the technique by which each one works and to set forth at least some of the means and methods, the national, group or community characteristics and desires which determine the outcome.

THE history of Dover Wilson's "Hamlet" goes back to 1917 and is racily told in the epistle dedicatory (to W.W. Greg) of "What Happens in 'HAMLET.'" It was then, while simultaneously inspecting government schools and munitions factories, that Wilson found time to read Greg's article on "Hamlet" in The Modern Language Review and was excited enough to write an immediate postcard:

FROST-BITING is the sport of sailing little open racing boats in the Winter. Every Sunday now, days with howling northeast blizzards only excepted, hundreds of men and women (and boys and girls) are embarking in tiny craft from the shores of a score of bays and harbors from New York City northward along the coast and sailing forth for fun and rivalry on the cold, green waters of the North Atlantic.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 1. -- The Scarsdale Golf Club was the scene tonight of a "snow ball" for the benefit of the philanthropic fund of the Scarsdale Junior Service League.

Share prices closed irregular yesterday following early strength. Trading was active throughout the two-hour period, amounting to 1,758,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, compared with 1,656,000 on the Saturday before, and ranking as the busiest half-day session since Nov. 23.
Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, will submit his resignation to Mayor La Guardia this week, it was learned yesterday at City Hall.

AN interesting book for any one, young or otherwise, who finds fascination in the myriad forms of life that populate either land or sea. Mr. Boulenger's new volume will be especially excellent to put into the hands of young people who expect to spend a Summer at the seashore.

A BRIDGE week is being planned for the Pacific Coast States between May 30 and June 7, with tournaments being held simultaneously at Los Angeles and San Francisco. The Los Angeles players will decide their champions early in the week and will then be transported by special train to San Francisco, where other bridge events will be held.

Pending the completion of plans for a complete revision of the New York State Insurance Law in 1937, the State Insurance Department will confine its requests for new legislation this year to two major statutory changes and several minor modifications, Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, says in his department's seventy-seventh annual report, to be sent to the Legislature tomorrow.

LAKE PLACID. -- Bob-sledders are polishing their steel runners and skiers are waxing their long wooden blades for the two major competitions on the sports program at Lake Placid in the next ten days. The spiral ice slide down the side of Mt. Van Hoevenberg is in fine running condition.

MR. CHILDS says in more than one place that one of the strongest traits in the Swedish character is jealousy or envy. Far from being ashamed of it as a weakness, people refer to it with distinct pride. They refer to it as "the royal Swedish jealousy," apparently in the same spirit that at the other end of Europe animates the Spaniard in his insistence on the pundonor.

Many people are today forced to admit that Mussolini established in Europe a focal point from which the infection of dictatorship spread to other lands, and that should his technique prove successful in his Ethiopian gamble the last hope for peace in Europe would vanish.

Ever since the Fusion administration took hold in January, 1934, Mayor La Guardia has been agitating for a free port in New York Harbor. He got Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn to introduce enabling legislation in Congress; he made trips to the capital to argue for his project.

THE prefatory note to this scholarly volume tells us that the studies which led to it were begun in 1929 "when Dr. Gayer assisted Dr. Leo Wolman in preparing a report for a committee of the President's Conference on Unemployment upon the 'Planning and Control of Public Works.'"

THE recent arrests here of several prominent persons charged with violation of the speed law were not just unlucky accidents for them. They occurred in course of a campaign by District of Columbia authorities to stop fast driving on its broad avenues and boulevards.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The Metropolitan Edison Company has taken to the Superior Court its fight to prevent the borough of Myerstown, Lebanon County, from constructing a municipal electrical plant.

UNFORGIVEN: With the rank of brigadier general, a record as A.E.F. air commander, and a chip on his shoulder, William Mitchell came out of the World War to become Director of Military Aviation. The chip was a belief that old-timers of the army and navy were neglecting the air services.

An appraisal ordered by the Guaranty Trust Company of collateral behind the Alleghany Corporation's three bond issues showed yesterday that the market value of the collateral was less than the 150 per cent of the par value of the bonds required by the indentures.

A near collision of two buses traveling in opposite directions on Ninth Avenue, between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, caused injuries to at least six persons shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon when the buses crashed head-on into pillars of the Ninth Avenue elevated. The accident tied up traffic for a half-hour.

OTTAWA, Jan. 31. -- Canada's Constitution, the British North America Act, which in 1867 united its then four Provinces into a federal whole, has been under fire from two angles and before two tribunals in Ottawa this week.

IT was away back in the Eighteen Eighties that Mr. Eisdell went to Australia, where a great, many unusual experiences awaited him, and right entertainingly he tells about them in this little book. An undergraduate at Oxford and planning to enter the ministry of the church, in his early twenties he was threatened with tuberculosis and ordered by his physician to go to Australia and live in the open until he recovered.

NOT always in a strict sense "contemporary" is the exhibition of paintings by Norwegian artists now installed at the International Art Center of the Master Institute of United Arts, scheduled to remain current for several weeks (the closing date, Feb. 26).

In his preface Mr. Oursler explains how this book came to be written. In the course of a discussion of mystery stories Mr. Roosevelt, at that time Governor of New York, told Mr. Oursler of a plot he had long had in mind for a mystery story.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The Atlantic conference, which has been sitting in London for four days, adjourned again tonight without reaching a decision on the question of passenger rates. The conference will be resumed at Paris on Thursday.

Development of a silk industry from the production of the raw silk to the manufacture of the finished cloth is going forward rapidly in Venezuela at the present time, August Haefner, president of the August Haefner Associates, Long Island City silk-mill operators, said here yesterday.

Having had its foretaste of "inflation" discussion some days earlier, Wall Street listened to the speechmaking of Congressional "inflationists" last week with comparative calm; not that the inflation influence was not disturbing, but rather that it was less so than could easily have been supposed in the circumstances.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 31. -- Pursuant to Harry L. Hopkins's edict that States must support their unemployables from now on, and also reflecting last year's bitter attack by Governor Davey upon the administrative costs of Federal relief, the Ohio Legislature this week sliced at the Gordian knot with a law providing for State relief maintenance, exclusive of WPA, from State funds, and demanding monthly relief budgeting.

With the attention of manufacturers and retailers centered on hearings which start tomorrow on the Utterback bill, designed to control trade practices in distribution, the fight to wipe out loss-leader selling opened on another front last week when wholesale food interests began a drive for the enactment of State legislation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Behind a battle for commercial supremacy waged by two corporations at a hearing which ended this week is being reared a structure of fact upon which future national policies with regard to international communication may be based.
The Transit Commission will renew this week its efforts, first begun in 1921, to prepare a plan for the unification of all rapid transit lines within the city's limits.
PINEHURST, N.C. -- The week just opening, really the first of the "high season" in the Sand Hills, will see two competitions of major importance in Pinehurst -- in the fields of bridge and golf.

IN comparison with certain of her contemporaries the life of Mary I of England has been neglected by the biographers. Hardly a year passes by without the publication of one more volume dealing with the career of Henry VIII, Elizabeth, or Mary Stuart, Queen of Scots.

MANKATO, Minn., Feb. 1 (AP). -- Minnesota opened the Farm Belt's Democratic drive for renomination of President Roosevelt today when Democrats, assembled in State convention, elected national convention delegates pledged to the President. Convention officials said some 2,000 attended the meeting.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- Through the brilliant performance of its skip, Francis Boardman, Riverdale, today subdued Yonkers, 14 -- 10, in a semi-final round match of the interclub curling tournament for the Utica Cup at the St. Andrews Golf Club indoor rink.

Here is another episode in the life of Jane Amanda Edwards, the spinster detective who figured in "Murder in the Old Stone House." The background is a political campaign, and Jane is in the thick of it because her brother Arthur is a member of the campaign committee.

THE burial of one British King and the accession of another call forth the elaborate pageantry of an ancient monarchy and absorb the attention of the nation and the empire. But foreigners may wonder whether a change of Kings in the twentieth century is really such a momentous event as it appears, whether it will have any profound effect upon the government or the life of the British nation.

There is no official team championship at stake in any Olympic games, whether they be Winter or Summer meets, but a team title always is awarded, nevertheless, even though it has no official status. The pressure of public opinion has been such that the press has kept tabulation of team standings according to a system that now is world-wide and uniform.

Mrs. William Foster Rowland, president of the New York City Federation of Womens Clubs, will officiate on Friday at the ninety-ninth convention of the organization at the Hotel Astor. In view of the fact that this session is also the annual meeting of the federation, at which reports will be given by the president and other officials and the election of borough directors will take place, an unusually large attendance is predicted.

WASHINGTON. -- A small group of advisers representing many fields of learning is ready to assist visiting scholars and students at the Library of Congress. An endowment sufficient to enlarge this group to fifteen, according to Dr. Herbert Putnam, is now an important need of the library as an "institution of learning."

Governor NOE'S appointment of Senator LONG'S widow to fill his unexpired term is only technically an instance of what has come to be something of a custom. Something like a "right" of survivorship has grown up when a member of either branch of Congress dies in office.

GENEVA, Feb. 1. -- The League of Nations committee studying the application of sanctions against Italy ended a four-day session tonight by recommending that the Committee of Eighteen arrange to supply monthly statistics on Italian trade and to tighten the existing sanctions in a few minor ways.

Senator Royal S. Copeland told members of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., at their annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night, that he favored a manufacturers' sales tax, "provided there is devised some plan of close cooperation between the Federal Government and the States in the uses to which such revenue would be applied."

IN his introduction to "A History of American Biography" Mr. O'Neill explains the insidious tricks employed by biographers, critical, psychoanalytical, dramatic, debunkist, dull and stupid. Then he delves into the essence of American biography 1800-60, which was "usually poorer both in form and in content" than that of the period 1860-1900.

NOT untarnished by the grime and dinginess of the Machine Age, the very name of gypsy still has the power to quicken us with a sense of unexpected adventure, and in this story of a daughter of modern gypsies, for boys and girls in their early teens, Chesley Kahmann proves its spell anew.

SPECIFICALLY, this novel concerns the insurrection of Negro slaves, led by one Gabriel, around Richmond, Va., in 1800. The incidents are historically true, but the romance of Gabriel and his brethren is neither history nor pageantry in any restricted sense.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands. -- Congress is to be asked at the present session to make the Virgin Islands nearly self-governing. It is deemed complementary to the attempt to make them economically self-sufficient through reviving the rum industry.

The Junior League of New York will hold a gala jubilee in its clubhouse on the night of April 17 to raise funds for the Junior League Welfare Fund, which supports the Housekeeper Service, the Clothing Center and the Occupational Therapy Department at City Hospital.

THIS book, full of ironic wisdom and poetic tenderness, of long views and exact pictorial details, offers a peculiar problem to the critic. "The Last Puritan" is a first novel, and yet can scarcely be treated as such, for it is a first novel written in the still active fullness of years by a writer distinguished for nearly half a century as a poet, an essayist and as the most imaginative and humane of philosophers.

ON their way to the football conference at Pittsburgh, Tuss McLaughry and Bill Cowell paused to look in on Lou Little up at the Medical Center where the Columbia coach, with some difficulty, is being confined to a cot while recovering from his recent operation.

With weather conditions playing a major role, retail trade in the metropolitan area last week showed a smaller increase than that which marked the first half of the month. The dip, however, was not large enough to make a sharp reduction in the gain for the entire month of January, which is estimated at from 8 to 10 per cent.

WITH THE ITALIAN NORTHERN ARMY, Enda Jesus, Ethiopia, Jan. 31 (Delayed) -- It seems possible now to answer with fair assurance the world-wide speculation about the effect of the Ethiopian rains on the Italian lines of communication on the northern front.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- The fate of Governor Lehman's sixty-point legislative program for the better enforcement of the criminal law remains in the balance. Of some eighty anti-crime bills introduced not one has been passed nor has any been defeated.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The battle between the late Senator Huey P. Long and the Federal Government over the administration of Federal relief funds in Louisiana waged anew today with a demand from Governor James A. Noe for a complete reorganization of the Works Progress Administration in this State.
Most of us could forgive President Roosevelt for some of his "experiments," but we cannot forgive his assailing the Constitution.

FIRST, she said, there was that job in "Shuffle Along," at Daly's Sixty-third Street Theatre, and after that there was the old Plantation Club, just above the Winter Garden. A girl was getting along. The year was 1924. And then it was Paris, and they were lowering a huge mirror from above stage at the "Folies Bergeres," and on the mirror was Josephine Baker, dancing a frantic Charleston, in diamonds and a string of bananas.

The Socialist and Communist parties, together with progressive and radical labor organizations throughout the country, were urged yesterday afternoon by the Communist party of the United States (Opposition) to unite their forces for the November elections and form a Labor party headed by Tom Mooney, who has been in a California prison for twenty years, as Presidential candidate.

Creation of the Catholic Bishops' Commission, Inc., for Mexican Relief, with headquarters in the Empire State Building under authorization of the Hierarchy of the United States, was announced yesterday. It is headed by Archbishop Michael J. Curley of Baltimore and is to begin its activities shortly.

The hearings of the Securities and Exchange Commission charges of market manipulation against Michael J. Meehan, which have been in progress in Washington since Dec. 10, are expected to be transferred to this city this week.

THE holiday of good St. Valentine is in the offing, affording sophisticates an opportunity to lapse into sentiment without losing face. Grace may accompany a gift of the heart from man to maid and vice versa. Flowers can be specially arranged to convey a message, and yet remain quaint and charming.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Aids," with Mme. Dusolina Giannini, Giovanni Martinelli and Lawrence Tibbett in the leading roles, which will take place on the afternoon of Feb. 12 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association.

GOVERNMENT has never been and end in itself, but only a means to an end, that end being the highest possible welfare of the people. The government of the United States was organized and is maintained not for the particular and exclusive benefit of any one class, but for self-protection from foes from without and from exploitation from within by the selfish and the ruthless.

MRS. MacGIBBON is one of those few persons whose special job, an interesting and important one, was being shaped and made ready for her by circumstances, while other circumstances, and herself, were making her an exact fit for the position.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- The passage through Paris of a number of rulers and statesmen returning from the funeral of King George V has given occasion for a series of diplomatic conferences on European affairs.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31. -- The sudden death of Governor Oscar Kelly Allen appears to have patched up any differences that existed in the State administration machine following the assassination of Senator Huey P. Long last September.

Miss Virginia Vanderlip and her brother, Frank A. Nanderlip Jr., gave a large reception with dancing yesterday afternoon at The Court IEr-ouse, 206 East S/xtyofifth Street,. for their cousins, Mr. and Mrs, Albert Parker of Pasadena, Calif.

The development of a uniform protective clause in all sales contracts, equitable for both seller and buyer, was regarded as a vital need yesterday by purchasing agents and other buyers of raw and semi-finished materials, if advance orders are to be placed freely and disputes between manufacturers and purchasers reduced.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31. -- The Bolsheviki are not content with writing history; they are rewriting it.
BERMUDA, Feb.1. -- Fine specimens of two kinds of fish previously unknown in Bermuda waters brought their captors prizes in the first annual Bermuda game-fishing tournament, which closed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Many more children were reported today by the Labor Department to have gone to work in factories and stores during the seven months after NRA went out of operation than in the whole year of 1934.

The accession of King Edward VII to the throne in 1901 opened a new era in European affairs. Edward VII disliked Germany, especially her Kaiser; he admired France. In 1903 he visited Paris; he made a warm speech in which he said, "I know of no two countries whose prosperity is more interdependent.

DESPITE inclement weather, the Spring sales campaigns of the automobile companies already are under way. The shift in automobile show dates has revised the entire automobile calendar, with the result that almost all the Detroit sales organizations have started the fireworks usually reserved for late March.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1. -- The New York Athletic Club fencing team today defeated Yale in the opening meet for the Elis, 14 to 11. The victors took the foils bouts 6 to 3, and lost with the epee, 6 to 3, making the score 9 -- 9 when the saber competition began.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- The Reich Government announced today the confiscation of the funds and the compulsory closing of the offices of the former League of Free Corps. This organization, which was suppressed last July, was a union consisting of former members of corps that fought in the Baltic countries, Upper Silesia and the Rhineland after the World War.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 1. -- The fate of seven persons lost in the Matto Grosso wilds and threatened by wild beasts and savages depends solely upon the ability of Bolivian Army sappers to reach them. The lost persons are four passengers and the crew of a Bolivian seaplane forced down in the wilds two weeks ago.

In embarking on unemployment insurance under the Federal Social Security Act we are not merely preparing to dispense cash benefits to the unemployed. We are also introducing legal and administrative relationships wholly foreign to our customs and attitudes.

THE spread of schools and other cultural influences for Negroes in the South apparently has made little headway in combating superstition. Voodoo still flourishes here, and no less than $1,000,000 a year is spent in Louisiana, Mississippi and Southern Alabama for mystic charms, "hoodoo bags," love potions and philters.

WHEN the Music Educators National Conference meets in New York City for its national convention the week beginning March 29, more than 8,000 visitors from all parts of the country are expected to attend, in addition to the several thousand teachers and musicians from the metropolitan area. The convention is announced as the largest of its kind ever held in this community.

TORONTO, Feb. 1. -- Hollinger Consolidated Gold Mines, Ltd., in its preliminary operating statement for 1935, shows net profit of $4,922,929 before surplus adjustment, or approximately $1 a share on the 4,920,000 shares outstanding, and compares with $5,992,444 net, or $1.21 a share for 1934.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- Minister of Education Henri Guernut tonight ordered the summoning of the University of Paris Council Tuesday to discuss measures to end student demonstrations such as again today prevented Professor Gaston Jeze from lecturing in the law school.

Approximately 2,500 persons attended the Night in Poland Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the Kosciuszko Foundation, which is now celebrating its tenth anniversary as a living memorial to General Thaddeus Kosciuszko, Polish patriot and hero of the American Revolution.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 1. -- The Peabody Museum of Harvard University had scientific expeditions last year in Ireland, Siam, the Cameroons, Venezuela, the Tibeto-Indian border, Ecuador, Arizona and Florida, according to its annual report to President Conant.

WITHOUT minimizing the extent of other influences, such as that of his classical training and of his German studies upon Matthew Arnold, Miss Sells traces in this book the influence, upon this English poet, of French literature.
The New York Athletic Club and Blind Brook turned in triumphs in two keenly waged Metropolitan Indoor Polo League battles at the Squadron A Armory last night.
ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 1. -- Ethiopia sent two veteran commanders to the southern front today in an effort to rally warriors reported to have retreated under Italian attacks.

TWICE a week while Congress is in session an attendant puts fresh snuff in the Senate's snuffboxes. This is one of the quaint customs that have survived in the Federal Government, although its usefulness belongs to another day. Similarly, in its palatial new home the Supreme Court must have a regular supply of quill pens which no one uses any more, but without which the sitting of the justices would be almost unthinkable.
SOMERS, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- Ten State troopers raided Venice Gardens, a roadhouse on Granite Springs Road, shortly before dawn today and interrupted what they called a disorderly entertainment.

More than 105,000 workers in the local dress industry who are threatening to strike unless a new agreement is negotiated to take the place of the old contract that expired on Friday will return to work tomorrow morning for the first day without an agreement.

RED WING, Minn., Feb. 1. -- Paul Bietila, just 17, twice cracked the precipitious Charlson Slide record to win the Class C championship in the national ski tournament's first day's performances today.

The season's third performance of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan last night marked the initial appearances of Hilda Burke and Joseph Bentonelli in the principal roles. The broad melodic appeal of the opera and the performances of both Miss Burke and Mr. Bentonelli were of unusual merit, justifying the enthusiasm of the audience, which filled every available seat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The administration-sponsored stop-gap farm relief program, slated for early consideration in the Senate, was attacked today by George N. Peek, former AAA Administrator and foreign trade adviser, as prompted by political expediency, inadequate to meet the problem and "extremely dubious constitutionally."

A survey of the religious affiliations of the freshman classes at Barnard College during the last two years shows that the Episcopalians far outnumber all other denominations. This year 25 per cent of the 211 freshmen are Episcopalians. The Catholic and Jewish groups are the next largest in number and form 15 per cent each of the class.
PARIS, Feb. 1. -- The new couturier collections, now being shown, present novel ideas for day and evening wear.

TO the extraordinary number of this season's superb productions add one more -- "Ethan Frome," which Max Gordon has recently escorted to the stage. No one need worry much about a theatre that regularly finds actors who are gifted, directs them wisely and encloses them in dynamic scenery.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 31. -- If it becomes necessary for the States to participate in a farm-assistance program by furnishing the administrative machinery while the Federal Government puts up the money, the Corn Belt will doubtless do its part. Governor Cochran has promised the cooperation of Nebraska.

THIS is a boom year for public forums. Whether it is due to the approaching Presidential campaign, the neutrality issue or the doom of NRA and AAA, the experts are not sure. But they do know that all over the country all kinds of organizations and people, from the Kiwanis Club to Citizen John Jones of Kalamazoo, are suddenly interested in forming discussion groups.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Practically every golf devotee on the island and numerous visitors from various parts of the State, either as contestants or spectators, will follow the program of three major tournaments scheduled here for this week.

The collection of American and English eighteenth century furniture and decorations of the late Francis Hill Bigelow of Cambridge, Mass., together with early American and English silver belonging to Mrs. Martha D. Johnston of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and other owners, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., Saturday afternoon.

MARKED gains in engine performance during the past year were stressed at last week's sessions of the annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences held at Columbia University. With leaders in the field of aircraft engine development gathered in the Pupin Physics laboratories, sharp differences of opinion in detail appeared.

Fire which started in the third floor ceiling of the six-story Murray Apartments Hotel at 228 West Forty-second Street, about 300 feet west of Seventh Avenue, resulted in the rescue at 5:15 P.M. yesterday of two young women who were trapped in their fifth-floor apartment.
