The book is not intended alone for the use of students and professors but primarily for those business and professional men and, in fact, for all citizens who participate in the control of higher education.
ROME, Jan. 31. -- Recent events in East Africa have again emphasized the difference in the fighting on the southern and northern fronts.

Within two months, if plans approved by the Department of Commerce last week and energetically pushed by Mayor La Guardia and other, officials are carried out, the long-idle municipal piers on Staten Island will be part of America's first free port -- or, in more informal language, its first foreign trade zone.

ST. JOHN ERVINE calls attention, in The Observer, to the significant fact, hitherto unnoticed, that almost all poets are masters of good conversation, even when they practice only the monologue. He draws this conclusion from his own personal experience.
Final real estate assessment figures for 1936 have been set by the Board of Taxes and Assessments at $16,092,747,571, an increase of $140,100,640 over the 1935 total.

THE Quebec Government will keep more than 800 miles of main highways between the United States and the Canadian Province open to traffic during this Winter, according to J.E. Perrault, Quebec Minister of Roads. More than $300,000 will be spent on this work, which seeks to double the mileage kept open last Winter, largely for the benefit of those seeking Winter sports.

BECAUSE The Press of the Pioneers, Inc., has frequently been confused with other publishing houses of similar names, the name of the firm has been changed to Rufus Rockwell Wilson, Inc. The new name does not indicate a change of policy, for Mr. Wilson, founder and director of The Press of the Pioneers, is president of Rufus Rockwell Wilson, Inc., which takes over and carries forward the activities of the old firm.

THE Winter cruise season has more than lived up to its promises. In practically every instance, cruise accommodations have been sold out days or even weeks before scheduled sailings. One of the major long-distance voyages was booked completely seven weeks before the date of departure and a waiting list of several hundred prospective passengers accumulated.

URBANA, Ill., Feb. 1 (AP). -- The most potent death ray yet devised by man was assigned today to go under tests for its possible ability to save human lives. Tests were prepared in the physics laboratory of the University of Illinois.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 1. -- The thaw continued today at the scene of the Olympic Winter Games. It rained steadily all day and the dreaded warm wind, the "foehn," is still blowing.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 1 (AP). -- The University of Michigan School of Dentistry reported today that its clinical tests indicated that a recently announced desensitizer would not prove to be a "panacea for relief from all pain from instrumentation in the dental chair."

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 1. -- The Akron rubber industry's second "sit-down" of the week was in progress today as 100 Goodyear tire and rubber employes in the "pit," where tires are cured, refused to work in protest over a 10 per cent cut in piece rates.

HIALEAH PARK, Fla., Feb. 1. -- The big crowd here today had an unscheduled thrill just after the running of the third race. Western Lad, a 4-year old gelding owned by Mrs. Ed Haughton, got out of control after passing through the paddock gate from the main track, straddled the fence on the grand stand side of the path and fell off.

Joseph A. Broderick was appointed New York State Superintendent of Banks by Governor Roosevelt on March 3, 1929, to succeed Frank H. Warder, who resigned following the collapse of the City Trust Company. Mr. Broderick served as superintendent until Dec. 31, 1934.

ONE of the primary rules laid down in the textbooks of fiction writing is that the hero of a tale should be introduced before the villain, in order that the reader may begin at once that unconscious but vital process of self-identification.

LONDON, Feb 1. -- A new biblical discovery was made in further papyri secured from an Egyptian dealer by A. Chester Beatty, American millionaire collector, who became a British subject, which proved to contain another section of the Pauline Epistles.

In a little valley below the frowning heights of the Bavarian Alps at the Southwest corner of Germany, athletes of twenty-eight nations await the start of the fourth Olympic Winter Games at Garmisch-Partenkirchen on Thursday. From three continents a total of 1,593 competitors, a record entry, have gathered under the neutral banner of the white Olympic flag.
PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP). -- An experiment in alchemy at the California Institute of Technology producing energy surpassing that of pure radium was made public today.

Twelve scholarships and fellowships, totaling $20,000, are being offered by the Advanced School of Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, for the academic year 1936-37, Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the Advance School, announced yesterday.

The great gold-plated bronze doors of the central portal of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the main entrance to the nave on the western facade of the edifice, were dedicated yesterday afternoon by Bishop William T. Manning.

They have thrown together quite a stew of foolishness at the American Music Hall in East Fifty-fifth Street. "The Murder In the Old Red Barn" is the chief prank of the evening in the disconsolate Holy Roller meeting house where "The Drunkard" was reforming the parishioners last year.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- A 17-year-old lad, Merrill Barber, came down from Brattleboro, Vt., to steal the spotlight at the annual metropolitan ski jumping tournament held today on the towering Norsemen Ski Club's hill. A junior at high school, the previously unheard-of flier recorded the longest jump of the day and also carried off the Class B honors to dominate the interesting program.
Twenty thousand workmen celebrated Groundhog Day yesterday by hacking at New York's glacial covering, with no prospect of a break in the weather to help them.

All sorts of strange things happen in an Olympic year, but perhaps nothing in recent history can quite match the astounding resurgence of Joe Mangan, a has-been on his graduation from Cornell two years ago but very much the man of the hour at the moment.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Deere Co., second largest manufacturers of farm machinery and implements in the United States, had a sharp rise in profits in its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, net income amounting to $6,105,452, compared with $379,734 a year before and a loss of $4,335,308 two years before, it was shown in its annual report issued today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Marketing of livestock here in January was disappointingly small, with reductions in all receipts compared with the 1935 month.

Even a ten-minute overtime period which saw both teams reach the net once and which encompassed more action than the preceding three regular chapters failed to break a deadlock, and the New York Rovers and the Pittsburgh yellow Jackets ended hockey hostilities yesterday afternoon tied at 3 -- 3.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Professor John Garstang, British archaeologist, announced today the discovery of vestiges of human habitation in Palestine of 6,000 years ago. The discoveries result from excavations carried on for six years and are presumed to link the Neolithic period with the early bronze age.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 2. -The Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club successfully defended the Class B North American championship challenge pennant against the Musconetcong Club today, then lost the Class C interclub series for the Long Branch Exchange Club Cup to the Monmouth Club of Red Bank. The Class A event for the I.T. Strauss Cup went to B. Price's Snow Flake.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 2. -With the harbor frozen solid far out into Long Island Sound, iceboat racing was held today by the Larchmont Yacht Club for the first time in the organization's existence. The dinghy sailors took to a fleet of craft on runners.

All new Department of Sanitation cars -- both trucks and passenger vehicles -- will be equipped with automatic governors permitting them to be driven at no more than twenty-five miles an hour, W.D. Binger, deputy commissioner, announced yesterday.

John Masefield, poet laureate of England, relaxed last night in the library of Thomas W. Lamont's home, 107 East Seventieth Street, and told of his American visit, which has been saddened by the death of his King.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Unless the Supreme Court should come along tomorrow with an adverse decision on the Tennessee Valley Authority Act and further solidify the executive and legislative branches for a test with the judicial the coming week promises a virtual showdown between President Roosevelt and Congress as to who is master in the immediate fiscal planning for the government.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2. -- A visible symbol of the improved relations between Rumania and Soviet Russia, which for long could not forgive her southwestern neighbor for having taken Bessarabia in the Paris peace settlement, is the newly opened railway route directly linking the two countries.

Business developments in January have added some elements of uncertainty to the outlook, but on the whole, seem to call for no great revision of previous opinions as the 1936 prospects, according to the National City Bank in its current monthly bulletin, published yesterday.

A St. Valentine supper dance will take place Feb. 14 in the main ballroom of the Biltmore under the auspices of the New York State Chapter of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae. Mrs. Richard G. Auspitzer heads the executive committee.
Mercy killings and suicides are justified under certain conditions, Dr. Charles Francis Potter said yesterday in an address at the First Humanist Society of New York, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Revision of the Constitution to give the Federal Government power to regulate the economic life of the nation and pass social legislation without the threat of nullification by the Supreme Court was demanded yesterday by labor leaders at a rally of more than 20,000 trade unionists in the Manhattan Opera House under the auspices of the newly organized Trade Union Institute of the Rand School of Social Science.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Francis Curley, 12-year-old son of Governor Curley, went to church as usual today despite a kidnapping threat. A State trooper, assigned by routine to the Governor's home, accompanied the boy.

A liquor store salesman was held on a charge of homicide by the police of the West Forty-seventh Street station last night after he was said to have admitted that he engaged in a fight in which Odin Fredman, 27 years old, a graduate of Columbia University Law School, was fatally injured at the Alamo Chile restaurant, 139 West Forty-seventh Street.

Baseball's current social season reached its peak if, indeed, it did not soar clear over it last night, when more than 700 guests, including practically all of the game's notables, attended the thirteenth annual dinner and frolic of the New York baseball writers in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- A smouldering House fight over the Tennessee Valley Authority threatened to break into the open tomorrow with the anticipated release of the Authority's annual report.

As a memorial to Theodore Roosevelt and the ideals for which he strove, Doubleday, Doran Co. have established an annual award of $2,500 to be given for the best book manuscript on any political, economic or social phase of contemporary American life or of America's foreign relations by an author whose work has not yet been published in book form.

An impressive list of opening or newly opened art exhibitions faces the gallery-goer as the week begins. Some 300 years of art will be represented, ranging from the eighteenth century French drawings to present day abstractions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 2. -Dr. Herbert E. Gregory, director of the Bernice P. Bishop Museum at Honolulu for fifteen years and Silliman Professor of Geology at Yale University, will retire at the end of the present academic year, it was announced today by Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale.

The majority of the members of Congress, in disposing of the Bonus Bill, indicated throughout that they wanted to get rid of a troublesome matter, and that, in overriding the President's veto, they felt that they were finally closing an account between the Government of the United States and the ex-soldiers, excepting only, of course, the disabled and the dependents of those who were killed or died of illness incurred in the war.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Chicago's Black Hawks blasted a pair of goals during an uproarious third period tonight to conquer the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 0, and regain first place in the American Division of the National Hockey League.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 2. -- Fifteen hundred skiers from New York and Boston came by special trains to the Berkshires today. The weather was ideal and the Thunderbolt Trail at Adams was the center of events with an intercollegiate carnival, in which six colleges participated: Williams, Dartmouth, Yale, Harvard, Middlebury and New Hampshire State.

Communism was discussed in Protestant and Jewish pulpits of the city yesterday. Some of the clergy held that today's youth faced the choice between communism and fascism or Jesus Christ, and others that youths embraced communism not through conviction but through "eviction from the economic life."

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- An attempt to extend the age limit of capital ships from twenty to twenty-six years will be made by the United States members of the second technical subcommittee of the naval conference soon after the committee begins discussions of qualitative limitation tomorrow afternoon.

War, race prejudices and economic injustice will eventually be dispensed with, declared the Rev. Dr. James H. Franklin, president of the Northern Baptist Convention and of Crozier Theological Seminary, in a sermon yesterday morning at Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn.

Mixed price movements were the rule on the commodity futures markets here last week and, outside of weakness in copper, cottonseed oil and hides and moderate strength in coffee and wool tops, price changes were small. On the cash markets corn, rye, coffee, cocoa, lard, tin, wool tops, rubber and gasoline gained, while wheat, cotton, beef, pork, hides, silk and refined sugar eased.

Controller Frank J. Taylor made public yesterday the annual report of the Bureau of Investigation and Statistics of his office, showing that in 1935 it made more than 3,300 field inspections, checking up work on contracts aggregating $18,667,835.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 2. -- Miss Kit Klein, speedy Buffalo (N.Y.) girl, won the world speed skating championship for women today by finishing second in the 5,000-meter race after scoring two victories yesterday in the shorter events.

A decline in the number of new cases in both the Children's Court and the Family Court during 1935, as compared with 1934, was revealed in the annual report of Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court, made public yesterday.

Long Island University's undefeated basketball team continued to perform impressively and added two more victories to its long string of conquests during the week. St. John's was successful in two games and Fordham scored a fine triumph over Army.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Indifference of large traders, as well as the limited small-operator following, has put the speculative grain trade in a position where daily market fluctuations are largely controlled by privilege traders.

Lotte Lehmann's sole recital of this season brought out a host of her fervent admirers who packed the Town Hall to capacity yesterday afternoon and deluged the soprano with sustained volleys of applause after every number on her lengthy list. With the exception of two selections at the close, Miss Lehmann devoted her talents entirely to German lieder by Beethoven, Mozart, Schubert, Schumann, Brahms, Reger and Blech.

" Apathy and indifference" on the part of Catholics toward church news and programs of Catholic action as presented in the Catholic press were deplored by the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, at high mass there yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Secrecy of Senate hearings on the administration neutrality bill was shattered today with disclosure that John Bassett Moore, former World Court member, had characterized the measure as a "curious blend of homicidal with suicidal mania."

Worship and propaganda are the cardinal tasks of the Christian Church, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the James Memorial Chapel, 120th Street and Broadway.

ATHENS, Feb. 2. -- The Military League, composed of Kondylist officers, increased its pressure on King George this afternoon, even while the body of Marshal George Kondylis was being borne on a gun carriage through the streets of the capital in an atmosphere of great tensity.
" But," said Alice, "do you always base your criticism of government on the fundamental principles laid down by Jackson and Jefferson and Cleveland?"

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 2 (AP). -- A Catholic Church spokesman said today it would be "inconvenient" to comment on the creation of the Catholic Bishops' commission for Mexican relief, announced yesterday in New York.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 2. -Aubrey (Buck) Wells piloted the Keene Mountaineers to first place in the Governor Lehman Cup four-man bobsled race at the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run this morning with a total time for the four heats from the mile start at Whiteface Curve of 4 minutes 46.77 seconds.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- The German Zionist Federation opened this afternoon its first national conference since Chancellor Adolf Hitler came into power, with all Zionist leaders attending and agents of the secret State police taking notes on the proceedings.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 2. -- Thirty-one planes from the United States Fleet airplane base at Coco Solo will engage in manoeuvres in the Pacific off Colombia and Ecuador and around the Galapagos Islands under the direction of Rear Admiral F.J. Horne, commander of the air base forces.

The commission appointed by Governor LEHMAN "to make a compre"hensive study and analysis of State "aid to the municipal subdivisions of "the State" is made up of experienced, public-spirited men like GEORGE MCANENY, RALPH JONAS, ex-Governor MILLER and ex-Superintendent VAN SCHAICK, whose conclusions on this highly important subject must carry more than ordinary weight.

Foreign exchanges were strong again last week, continuing the movement which set in several weeks ago. The upturn was a reflection of the efforts of the inflationist group in Congress to force the Treasury to issue additional amounts of currency, at the same time blocking any effort to impose new taxes to cover bonus requirements, farm and relief demands.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- State aid to localities for various purposes which under the budget bills now before the Legislature would aggregate $135,307,000 during the next fiscal year should be continued at the present level, the Commission on State Aid to Municipal Sub-Divisions recommends in a report to be filed with the Senate and Assembly tomorrow evening.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 (AP). -Ty Cobb was "overwhelmed" today on being declared the No. 1 immortal in baseball's hall of fame.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- While a Coast Guard cutter vainly tried to break through the ice to Tangier Island, only ninety miles from Washington, where about 1,500 persons were marooned by cold weather and short of food, a small, privately owned dirigible glided successfully to the ice today and landed sufficient supplies for four or five days.

John Miles Flynn, chairman of the legislative committee of the New York State division of the Izaak Walton League of America, appeals to sportsmen of the State to register their disapproval of bills introduced at Albany recently by Assemblyman Lavery and Senator Garrity.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Lard stocks in Chicago on Feb. 1 aggregated 29,260,935 pounds, an increase for the month of 11,181,531 pounds. A year ago lard stocks were 65,457,507 pounds. Stocks of dry salted clear bellies made since Oct. 1, 1935, aggregate 5,601,418 pounds, compared with 3,097,219 pounds on Dec. 31, 1935, and 4,472,373 pounds Jan. 31, 1935.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 2. -- The stimulation of recovery by legislation designed to free trade rather than to regiment it is to be the keynote of the first session of the post-election Canadian Parliament, which opens this week.

As many persons as the Guild Theatre could hold turned out last night to greet Herald Kreutzberg on his annual return to New York. They found him in characteristic form both as to program and performance, and applauded him with quite indiscriminate enthusiasm.

Christ was the friend or the poor, not only of those poor in material possessions but also of those poor in spirit, in mind, in morals and in achievement, of those who are conscious of not being the kind of men or women they wanted to be, the Rev. James J. Henry, pastor of the Park Avenue Methodist Church, Eighty-sixth Street east of Park Avenue, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Contributions totaling $61,430.34 have been paid into the United Hospital Campaign Committee since the last public announcement, Gates W. McGarrah, chairman, announced yesterday. He said the amount represented gifts which had been pledged at the close of the campaign but not received by the committee.

A dispute over termination of the rotation system of employing workers in the building trades now being carried on between the latter and contractors threatens to disturb the peace of the building construction industry, writes Myron L. Matthews in The Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

MAKALE, Ethiopia, Jan. 27 (Delayed). -- Today is market day here and 10,000 natives from the surrounding neighborhood and from as far away as Gojjam Province have come to sell and buy. Many of these merchants, traveling at night and hiding by day, took from ten days to two weeks to carry their wares through hostile Ethiopian territory.

Under the influence of reports relative to government selling of holdings of cotton in the producers' pool and the loan stocks, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange last week declined 25 to 38 points. Declines were greatest in old-crop deliveries, since it was anticipated that the sale of government-financed cotton would ease the tight spot situation, pending the harvesting of the new crop.

There was a renewed accumulation of funds in the money market last month, due largely to the seasonal return flow of currency from circulation since Christmas, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in its monthly review.

The charge that the Roosevelt Administration has been trying to set "class against class" has usually been dismissed as partisan or exaggerated, but the remarks of the Assistant Secretary of Labor, EDWARD F. MCGRADY, at the convention of the United Mine Workers of America, surely do nothing to discredit that charge.

Of a total of $3,299,435,572 turned in to the Federal Government by the taxpayers in the fiscal year ended last June 30, exclusive of customs payments, 17.45 per cent was collected in New York City and 20.4 per cent in New York State, a survey made public yesterday revealed.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- More than 2,000 employes of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company tonight cheered Mayor S. Davis Wilson's plan for reorganization of the transit system and the discontinuance of the present voting trust for employe-owned stock.

American civil liberties are seriously endangered by the recent growth of "Fascist" forces in this country, according to the report of a survey made public today by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches of America.

Norman Thomas, left wing Socialist leader and former candidate for the Presidency, declared in a radio address yesterday that President Roosevelt and the New Deal were not producing socialism or communism, as charged by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, but a State capitalism that must inevitably lead to a Fascist dictatorship.

TRENTON, Feb. 2. -- The name of a person suspected of being the "stoop-shouldered man" whom Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh saw in the Bronx one night while he and Dr. John F. Condon were carrying on the fruitless ransom negotiations for the return of his kidnapped and murdered son is in the hands of Governor Harold G. Hoffman.

BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- The Boston Bruins put on a blazing finish after 67 minutes of the tamest sort of hockey tonight to gain a 2-1 overtime triumph over the New York Americans before 8,500 in the Boston Garden.

In its final eight performances "Parnell" grossed $14,500. Nevertheless, it closed firmly on Saturday night, though the cast would gladly have taken a cut and kept on playing. One of its producers, Frederick W. Ayer, said last night that the play closed because the management was not making enough money.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Conservationists from all parts of the country will assemble here tomorrow for the North American Wild Life Conference, called by President Roosevelt for the purpose of formulating a definite plan to restore the nation's diminishing wild-life resources.

MUNICH, Feb. 2. -- Catholicism suffered a severe defeat at the hands of the Nazi party here today after a school registration campaign in which the party functionaries employed economic pressure and enjoyed an enforced monopoly of propaganda opportunities.
EASTON, Md., Feb. 2. -- Provisions showered upon them from the air, ice-marooned Tangier Islanders sent word to the outside today that although "food is short," there "is no panic" among them.

Great Britain, too, has its distinguished "walker-outer," except that over there the thing is history instead of conjecture. RAMSAY MACDONALD is believed to have been elected to the House of Commons from the Scottish universities.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 2. -- At a testimonial dinner tendered to Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark here tonight, an annual scholarship fund of $5,000 for Newark boys attending Yeshiva College was established by 500 representatives of Newark Jewry and others.

Several large issues of public utility bonds were called last week for redemption before maturity and the proposed retirement of nine loans by one industrial corporation was reported. The redemption dates, except for one small miscellaneous loan for January, were all for months starting with February.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 2. -- It is believed here the Brazilian-United States agreement for the freeing of frozen credits will be completed this week. Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, has been authorized to sign up.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- For many years past Paris has not seen such an assembly of kings and princes as is just now within her walls. King Carol of Rumania, King Boris of Bulgaria, Prince Regent Paul of Yugoslavia and Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor of Austria, are all here, and much is being written and hinted about the diplomatic importance of their presence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, will "mince no words" when he addresses the convention of the United Mine Workers of America tomorrow afternoon in Constitution Hall.

Title was passed on Saturday whereby Thomas R. Jones, Frank C. Ferguson and Charles L. Carrick, trustees in bankruptcy of the American Type Founders Company, sold to the Arvey Corporation of Chicago the plant of the Type Founders at Communipaw Avenue, Monitor and Garrabrant Streets, Jersey City.

Serious impairment of national credit threatens the United States unless prompt steps are taken to reduce Federal expenditures and balance the budget, the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of New York declared yesterday in a report by Richard W. Lawrence, its chairman.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 2. -- The New Hampshire Winter sports team, favored to retain its championship in the Williams College Carnival, showed up poorly in today's events, while Dartmouth's B delegation piled up a big lead in the ski jumping test to capture the scoring honors for the day.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Roy Mikkelsen's strong showing filled the Americans with renewed hope today. Offsetting this, however, was the unhappy news that Edgar Hunter, who is rated second only to his Dartmouth team-mate, Dick Durrance, among the Americans at downhill racing and slalom, was definitely out of the Olympic competition.

WHITE RIVER ENTRANCE, Mount Rainier National Park, Wash., Feb. 2. -- Spike-shod mountaineers, who dared bitter cold and darkness to recover the body of Delmar Fadden, "thrill climber," from Mount Rainier's treacherous slopes, sometimes wondered if they too, would perish, their leader said today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Tyrus Raymond Cobb, fiery genius of the diamond for twenty-four years, will be the No. 1 immortal in baseball's permanent hall of fame.

The Rev. Arthur P. Frenchman was instituted yesterday as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Edward the Martyr, 12 East 109th Street, amid ceremonies which lasted more than two hours and which were culminated by a solemn high mass.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Apart from sporadic rallies, the weakness of the dollar, which followed adoption of the soldiers' bonus legislation, persists as a market factor. Confidence in the dollar undoubtedly has been undermined by the financial morass into which the United States Treasury has been plunged with somewhat startling suddenness, not only by this particular piece of legislation, but also by the recent legal demolition of almost all the pivotal New Deal price-control machinery.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- In the face of strong, organized revolt against him in his own party, Governor Harold G. Hoffman last night attacked over the radio the economy program of the strongly entrenched clean government group and made an open fight against the "freeze" measure which would divert highway funds to relief.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Donald MacMurray, 21 years old, who was graduated at the age of 10 from P.S. 165 in New York City, where he was a member of the special class for bright children, is establishing a scholastic record under the University of Chicago's "New Plan" of education, whereby a student may progress as rapidly as he is able.

Maurice P. Davidson made public yesterday his letter to Mayor La Guardia, resigning as Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity to resume the practice of law. In his letter, dated Jan. 16, Mr. Davidson suggested that his resignation become effective about Feb. 1, but he will continue in office for a short time at the pleasure of the Mayor or until his successor is selected.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- Three young fawns, apparently deserted by their herd, were being fed and cared for here today by officials of the Palisades Interstate Park. They were found huddled together, hungry and nearly frozen, in a wooded section of the park.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Facing a dismaying record of only one victory out of six New Deal tests in the Supreme Court, the government regarded tonight with some foreboding the possibility that the Tennessee Valley Authority Act might meet the fate of other key projects of the recovery program when the court rules upon its con stitutionality.

BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 2. -Ex-Premier Alejandro Lerroux, who as a militant anti-clerical Republican during the time of the monarchy directed the uprising in Barcelona in 1909, spoke here today as a Conservative candidate for Parliament and vigorously attacked President Niceto Alcala Zamora for having dissolved the Cortes last month instead of having offered the Premiership to the leader of the Clerical party, Jose Maria Gil Robles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Reports that political considerations entered into the purchase of a site for a postoffice at Norwalk, Conn., were denied today by Rear Admiral Christian J. Peoples, in charge of the Treasury Procurement Division, who handled personally the final negotiations.

MUSSOLINI is rapidly taking his place in the first line of pacifists. Last week he issued a moving appeal to the youth of all Europe (outside Italy), urging them to do everything within their power to prevent war. Its horrors and subsequent miseries he pictured in somber colors.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 1. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84, which compares with 83.9 the week before, 83.8 two weeks before, 84.4 three weeks before and 84 four weeks before.

In addition to the regular prizes, C.T. Greene, one of the veterans of the club, offered special scratch and handicap cups at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The scratch winner was A.L. Burns, with 97 out of 100 targets, the handicap prize going to W.A. Pate, who finished with a card of 89 -- 12 -- 100.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 2. -- America's chances in the Olympic ski jumping were decidedly improved today as Roy Mikkelsen placed third in a field of thirty-eight jumpers who competed in this year's first international practice tournament on the big Olympic hill.

TANGIER, Va., Feb. 2 (AP). -- "In but not of America" is a phrase applied to tiny Tangier Island in Chesapeake Bay, about half way between the mainland of Virginia and the Eastern Shore of Maryland, and center of interest since ice-locked waters have cut off its food supplies.

In HUGH RUTTLEDGE'S story of the attack on Everest in 1933, the chapter on "The Third Attempt" ends: "As we turned the corner of "the moraine we had one more look "at Mount Everest. Then the clouds "came down for good. We had done "with it all."

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- It is considered certain here that the political disputes and inflationist tendencies of the United States Congress, featured in the French press as dangerous to the maintenance of the stability of the dollar, will dissuade the French people from sending money to the United States.

Patrolman Thomas Comisky, attached to the Arsenal station in Central Park, and a friend who had accompanied him into a tavern at 353 Amsterdam Avenue, were shot at 12:45 A.M. today by four hold-up men whom the policeman tried to capture.

Machinery has been set in motion to complete the task of refunding the entire funded debt of twenty-one superseded districts of the Chicago Park District. The refunding operation is under the direction of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., as refunding agent and depositary for Chicago Park District, and contemplates the consolidation of the 224 now outstanding issues into a single issue in four series of $99,085,708 refunding bonds.

Two animals whose classification has long puzzled scientists were brought back from West China by the Dean Sage Expedition and are to go on exhibition today, stuffed, in the main lobby of the American Museum of Natural History.

The National Industrial Conference Board turned a statistical searchlight on the Townsend old-age pension plan yesterday and concluded that the burden of financing it would bring about a "general paralysis" of the country's production, trade and finance.

It is attempted to sugar-coat the taxes which the Administration thinks necessary by asserting that they are not "new." We are to think of them merely as "substitute" taxation. The Supreme Court having disallowed one tax, Congress must devise another to take its place.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -Diplomatic circles heard today that Bulgaria had threatened to withdraw her legation from Moscow because of the Soviet Government's newly instituted monetary system.

The annual report of the Brooklyn Catholic Big Sisters, Inc., takes issue with those who believe a college degree is essential to a charity worker. The report, issued yesterday as part of the third Social Service Guide, criticizes professional social workers who are attempting to convert charity into "business."

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, has damaged his reputation in London by repeating, apparently to all and sundry, his version of what he and King Edward discussed in Buckingham Palace last week.
LONDON, Feb. 2. -- Credits of 65,000,000, which France advanced to Great Britain during the crisis of 1931, are now being used by the French as an argument for extracting a similar loan from Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The right of women, even married women, to work outside the home was asserted tonight by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in an address before the Town Hall, a public forum here. Women could be restrained from working in spheres outside their homes only to meet some temporary emergency, she declared.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 2. -- An extraordinary joint session of Congress was opened at 4 P.M. today by President Sorzano Tejada, whose speech stressed the historical importance of the Congress, which must study and approve or reject the peace protocol signed in Buenos Aires Jan. 21 dealing with repatriation of prisoners and renewal of diplomatic relations with Paraguay.

WHEN the old Manassa Mauler, Johnno Demsey, announced some time back that he was sponsoring a "white hope" tournament among the heavyweights he annoyed Jim Braddock and Joe Gould more than a trifle, but he did Postmaster General James A. Farley a good turn.
AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The "sit down" protest held attention of the rubber industry and labor unions today as a novel technique in labor relations.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Lucile Paray in her fashion show presents a completely modern collection, with the exception of one Margot-sleeved evening gown, modeled after the costumes of Yvonne Printemps's new show. She launches an interesting new silhouette for the daytime with a flaring waist-length, shirt-like bolero slip-on, buttoned at the nape of the neck and showing a lowish belt above a slim, straight skirt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Reductions of 31.7 per cent, or $6,491,866, were made between Sept. 1 and Jan. 1 by creditors on debts of 3,661 farmers who owed a total of $20,503,312, according to a statement issued today by the Resettlement Administration.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average for 1927 as 100, stood at 71.3 on Jan. 29, against 71.5 a fortnight before, 71.4 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Debutantes of this season, headed by the Misses Beatrice Kunhardt and Thayer Gibbons, are active in the arrangements for an entertainment to be known as a Star-Gazers Supper Dance, for the benefit of the Convalescent Work Shop of the New York City Visiting Committee, which will take place on Feb. 18 at Le Coq Rouge.

Whether James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, or James J. Hines, head of the group in that organization allied with local supporters of President Roosevelt, will gain an additional vote in the Tammany executive committee may be determined tonight at a meeting of the Democratic County Committee of the Nineteenth Assembly District to elect a leader.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- Richard Werner of the Blue Bird Skating Club, who has been improving with each competition, annexed the interstate speed skating crown today by taking a first and two second places for a total of 70 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- A complete boycott of all Nazi goods and services was approved without a dissenting vote today by the National Conference for Palestine, which also unanimously pledged support to an unprecedented campaign to raise $3,500,000 to promote upbuilding of the National Jewish Home in Palestine and emigration of Jews from Germany.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Discord in the Democratic ranks and the action of the party boss, Patrick A. Nash, and Mayor Kelly in turning down Governor Horner for renomination, together with the militancy of Republican workers in the farm sections, are leading Republican leaders to believe that Illinois will elect their candidates for Governor and President.

Apparently, trade activity slowed down last week; mostly, perhaps, because of the intense cold and snow that has with such unusual persistency gripped the Northern United States, but possibly also because of doubt arising from the fiscal controversy following Washington's "bonus vote."

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- C.C. Pettijohn Jr. was the high-over-all gunner in the scratch shoot over the traps of the Westchester Country Club today. He triumphed by breaking 89 out of 100 targets. Pettijohn, C.L. Sears, Mrs. Lancaster and A. Wright deadlocked for the handicap prize, Sears winning the toss.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- The fall of the dollar against sterling and the franc last week gave rise to all sorts of more or less fanciful comments here. A leading financial paper expressed the opinion that the equalization fund should have sent gold to London to prevent the dollar from declining and even announced that the Bank of France was to confer with the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve.

The Metropolitan Opera debut of Dusolina Giannini, American dramatic soprano, will take place during a special matinee of "Aida" on Wednesday, Feb. 12, it was announced yesterday. The ninth week of the season will see the return to the company of Rose Bampton, American contralto; the beginning of the evening "Ring" cycle and the season's first performance of "Il Trovatore."

About 20,000 millinery workers will join in a tie-up of their industry tomorrow when a stoppage order of the Millinery Workers Union, Locals 24 and 42, goes into effect. The stoppage is designed to enforce what the union termed yesterday "a more effective regulation of the industry and the establishment of enforcement machinery" in the operation of agreements.

ENDA JESUS, Ethiopia, Feb. 1 (delayed). -- The only easy direct route from Tembien southward now seems effectively controlled by the Italian forces. From an artillery observation post at the extreme right of the Makale sector it was easy to see the thoroughness with which the Italian artillery sweeps the wide stretch between Amba Aradam and Tembien.
Mr. and Mrs. Michael T. Gottlieb won the mixed-pair title of the Atlantic National bridge championships at the Park Central Hotel yesterday afternoon in a field of eighteen finalist pairs.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 2. -The award of 401 scholarships with total value of $147,889.51 for the current academic year to undergraduates of Princeton University was announced here today by Dean Robert K. Root, chairman of the university scholarship committee.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Two Americans were sentenced today to imprisonment by a United States court following their conviction Saturday for embezzlement in connection with operations of the defunct American Oriental Finance Corporation.

Opposition to the McNaboe bill giving newspaper reporters the right to withhold the sources of information is expressed in a report of the committee on State legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

GENEVA, Feb. 2. -- Poland, one of about twelve oil-producing countries invited to discuss new war sanctions against Italy, declined today to send a representative to the League of Nations embargo meeting.

WITH THE SOUTHERN ITALIAN FORCES AT NOGHELLI, ETHIOPIA, Jan. 30 -- (Delayed) (AP). -- The swift motorized Italian columns of General Rodolfo Graziani have driven back the forces of Ras Desta Demtu eighty miles further along the Ganale Dorya River toward Allata.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 2. -The National Federation of Jewish Men's Clubs closed its annual convention here today with the re-election of Theodore Charnas, New York attorney, as president for a third term.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- Industry in Germany has been quiet this week. Rumors are continuing that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Reich Minister of Economics, is planning to relax the prohibitions against the opening or expanding of factories. Such restrictions are now in force against twenty-nine lines of industry.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- A record low in the number of cases of diphtheria throughout the State was made in 1935, the Department of Health announced today. Only 384 cases were reported outside of New York City in the year, as compared with 442 in 1934 and 4,370 in 1925.
Contracts for the sale of apartment houses in the Bronx featured realty deals announced in this city over the week-end.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 2. -- In the grip of an ice field six miles wide and of formidable thickness, and facing another night and day of near-zero temperatures, the Island of Nantucket was cut off today from all shipping for the second day, with the menace of a fuel and food shortage growing hourly.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The weakness of the United States dollar and the doubts concerning the franc which were dispelled this week by the efforts of Jean Tannery, governor of the Bank of France, to paint the economic picture in France in more favorable colors than those imagined by outside observers, gave additional point to the references made by British bankers in the last few days as to the prospect for general stabilization of currencies.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The check imposed upon business by the passing of King George V is giving place to more active conditions, although the security markets are not as yet quite back to their normal stride.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 2. -- Francisco Martin Perez, a Spaniard, the first radical ordered deported, appealed to the Boston Circuit Court following a denial of habeas corpus by Judge Robert A. Cooper of the Federal Court of San Juan. The appeal contends that if Martin is sent to Spain with a Communist brand he is certain to be shot.

Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, through an agent, bought $3,067 worth of goods from Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt to give to Mrs. Vanderbilt's child. Gloria, at the sale held Friday and Saturday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

Kenneth F. Simpson, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, announced yesterday the appointment of a Legislative Advisory Committee to advise the county committee on social welfare measures introduced in the Legislature.

Although the impending strike affected dress activity in the local markets last week, a substantial volume of orders was received on various ready-to-wear lines. Many dress manufacturers stopped operations and turned down Spring orders, while silk piece goods prices eased.
RED WING, Minn., Feb. 2 (AP). -George Kotlarek, Duluth veteran, soared from a slide abbreviated to eliminate dangerous landing conditions to win the national ski jumping championship today.
The address by Norman Thomas over the Columbia Broadcasting System from Station WABC last night follows:

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Corn stocks at visible supply points are reported to be 6,187,000 bushels. This compares with 33,947,000 bushels for the same time last year. Chicago received only one car of contract grade of corn in January. This is the first time in years that the run has been so small.

Operations of an organized vice ring said to have taken in at least $12,000,000 a year and to have employed between 1,000 and 2,000 women in some 200 houses in Manhattan and Brooklyn were revealed yesterday as eighty women and seven men were held in $10,000 bail each as material witnesses.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 2. -- By equaling the world's record for 1,500 meters despite a driving snowstorm, Ivar Ballangrud of Norway won the 1936 world speed skating championship today, compiling 194.9 points in the four events.
Functioning as an aggressive unit better than they have in a long time, the New York Rangers triumphed over the world champion Maroons' sextet at Madison Square Garden last night, 4 to 2.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 2. -- The State Law Revision Commission, of which Dean Charles K. Burdick of the Cornell Law School is chairman, has submitted to the Legislature its second annual report, containing a list of the recommendations for law revision which the commission will make during the present session.

There must be the right kind of laws and an adequate method of enforcing them if life and property are to be safeguarded at sea, Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, said last night in a radio address broadcast over Station WOR.

Unless defense counsel succeeds in a motion for delay, the trial of three men for the murder of Samual Drukman will begin at 10 o'clock this morning before Justice Erskine C. Rogers at an extraordinary term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

With interest increased and two additional competitors admitted, the women's championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club made good progress yesterday when second-round games were played in two sections.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- Although the stock market was relatively firm through the week and certain specialties advanced on the expectation of increased dividends, the general tendency was toward restraint and the securities of certain Central and East European nations, which recently enjoyed a boom, were sold.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2. -- The cotton market here was somewhat sluggish but generally steady last week. The dominating influence was the conflict of reports from Washington concerning the movements in Congress for crop and market control to offset the virtual elimination of the operations of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration as a result of the recent decisions of the Supreme Court declaring that feature of the New Deal unconstitutional.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- Although the stock market was relatively firm through the week and certain specialties advanced on the expectation of increased dividends, the general tendency was toward restraint and the securities of certain Central and East European nations, which recently enjoyed a boom, were sold.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2. -- The cotton market here was somewhat sluggish but generally steady last week. The dominating influence was the conflict of reports from Washington concerning the movements in Congress for crop and market control to offset the virtual elimination of the operations of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration as a result of the recent decisions of the Supreme Court declaring that feature of the New Deal unconstitutional.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Control of pollution of waters in and around New York City is assured by the tri-State compact which has just become effective between New York and New Jersey, and is to apply to Connecticut as soon as that State enacts similar legislation. It is believed to be the most comprehensive program ever entered into between two or more States.

Featured by a special literary exhibit at Leningrad, the Russian commemoration of Mark Twain's centennial has been very successful, Mrs. Ida Benfey Judd, president of the Mark Twain Association, reported yesterday at a meeting of the association at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 2. -- Soldmon R. Guggenheim discussed tonight the approaching exhibition here of his collection of modern art, but declined to speak for publication on the controversial subject of economics and politics.

Determined to force acceptance of its demands, the Building Service Employes Union turned down yesterday a eleventh-hour proposal by owners to resume negotiations recently broken off. It reaffirmed its intention to call a strike in the garment and fur area affecting such buildings as have refused to meet the union's conditions.

King George V of Great Britain was a true friend to the people of the United States, and this country mourns the passing of a friend in his death, John W. Davis, former Ambassador to the Court of St. James, declared last evening at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Last year there were no hearings on the State budget. That was a mistake, because many persons wished to be heard. This year, today, there are to be two separate hearings at Albany on the budget. That is also a mistake. One is enough. There is no reason why a joint hearing should not have been held.

Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, sitting in Brooklyn yesterday, granted permission to the trustees of the Prudence Company, Inc., to organize their own insurance brokerage company to saving approximately $45,000 annually for the holders of stock and bonds.

The Westchester Commission on Government is looking rather far into the future of the county when it advocates the consolidation of eighteen townships into two. The way has long been open for governmental simplification, but only Scarsdale has taken any drastic steps in that direction.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 3. -- Hit and Run, a mud-running son of Chance Play from F. and M. Letellier's barn, found the heavy track at the Fair Grounds to his liking today and won the one and one-sixteenth-mile feature.

Miss Muriel Johnson gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for her sister-in-law, Mrs. Warren Johnson, the former Miss Ruth Moffett. The other guests were the Misses Katherine Barker, Rita Holland and Helen Barker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Rebellion within a meeting of young Republicans here was reported tonight following the election of J. Kenneth Bradley of Westport, Conn., as chairman of the executive committee of the Young Republican National Federation.

Notwithstanding all the "bally-hoo" in this country in the last year, there is no munitions industry "worthy of the name" in the United States, A.J. Miranda Jr., president of the American Armaments Corporation, said yesterday in a speech at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Men's Post 209 of the American Legion, held at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

PARIS, Feb. 3. -- Out of the maze of diplomatic conversations going on in Paris it is beginning to become clear that it is to the re-enforcement, if not indeed the reconstruction of the system of collective security among League of Nations members that France's new Foreign Minister, Pierre-Etienne Flandin, is devoting all his efforts.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 3. -- The first synthetic production of a natural form of radium, a landmark in man's conquest of matter, was reported here today by Dr. John J. Livingood, research associate at the radiation laboratories of the University of California.

New York City, through Controller Frank J. Taylor, is expected to call for bids next week, probably on Monday, for an issue of $19,500,000 of Rapid Transit Construction bonds, it developed in financial circles yesterday. It was understood the bonds will be set up in three series, namely, short maturities; medium maturities and long term bonds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The deficit of the Federal Government on Jan. 31, at the end of seven months of the fiscal year, was $2,124,419,129, as compared with $1,965,673,915 on Jan. 31, 1935.

A bill designed to clear titles to a large amount of Manhattan waterfront property along the Hudson, East and Harlem Rivers is now "in committee" in Albany and probably will be ordered out this week with a bright prospect for passage by a two-thirds vote in the State Legislature, Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr. reported yesterday.

The field-glass boys report that bald eagles have been sighted on the Hudson in recent weeks. This is the time of year when the mighty birds pay us their annual visit. They are to be seen floating on the ice cakes in the river, diving occasionally to seize a dead fish, or soaring majestically at great heights.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Mrs. Walter Liggett climaxed a dramatic session of Isadore Blumenfeld's trial for her husband's assassination today with the assertion that Governor Floyd B. Olson and his "gang" "permitted" the slaying.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- Following a Federal court hearing on a phase of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company controversy, which resulted in a victory for Mayor S. Davis Wilson, the Mayor threatened to punch the nose of an opposing attorney during a dispute outside the court room.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Feb. 3. -- A "gang" of five school boys -- the leader and oldest 14 -- who are accused of robbing eight Long Island homes, indulging in gin-drinking "parties" and destroying paintings, art works and furnishings valued at about $25,000, will be arraigned in Nassau County Children's Court in Mineola Friday.

ATHENS, Feb. 3. -- In an issue of a daily newspaper, the Elefteron Gnome, which appeared for the first time on Sunday, there is an interview in the form of a polemic by Premier Benito Mussolini against Britain, followed by warnings to the smaller Balkan powers against associating themselves with that nation and thus angering Italy. Austria, Hungary and Argentina are praised for not doing so.

The Remick Music Corporation, a subsidiary of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., filed a suit for $670,000 yesterday in Federal court against the Columbia Broadcasting System, alleging that the defendant, through its chain of sixty-seven stations, had violated the copyright law by broadcasting two of its songs without permission.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3. -- Lacking three of the necessary thirty-one votes, the House economy bloc-failed tonight in an effort to pass the first of its bills in the program to finance emergency relief by savings and fund diversions rather than by new taxes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Three banks in New York have obtained licenses to export gold to France and a fourth has received permission to ship metal to the Netherlands, the Treasury revealed today, and high officials said movement of gold in and out of the country would be permitted so long as the exchange situation remained as at present.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 3 (AP). -- J. Hubert Stevens, leader of the United States bobsledding contingent, strongly backed by Avery Brundage, newly arrived president of the American Olympic Committee, again went to bat today with the bobsled committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- A bill limiting the granting of trade discounts for quantity purchases, and other practices by which chain stores reduce their merchandising costs, was favorably reported to the Senate today by its Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The people of the United States have suffered incalculable cash losses as a result of their failure to recognize the economic value of wild life, Jay N. Darling declared at the opening session of the North American Wild Life Conference today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The stern face of Andrew Jackson, hero of New Orleans, will grace the soldier bonus baby bonds, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

The names and holdings of principal owners of the stocks of the South American Gold and Platinum Company and the Cuban-American Sugar Company were disclosed yesterday in registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange.

Mrs. Josephine W. Wuppermann, the world's first woman president of a large business corporation, completed plans yesterday to move the Jersey City plant and the Manhattan executive offices of the Angostura-Wuppermann Corporation, which she heads, to Norwalk, Conn., next June.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 3. -- If private industry "persists in its refusal to exploit the possibilities" of building houses within the means of workers and farmers, "the pressure of public opinion may force the government to enter this field on a very wide scale," Rexford G. Tugwell, Administrator of the Resettlement Administration, declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Preferred shares of national bank stock acquired by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in its campaign to rehabilitate the banking structure are subject to taxation by the States, the Supreme Court decided today in a unanimous opinion read by Justice Cardozo.
Moving with unexpected swiftness, the extraordinary grand jury that is investigating rackets returned its first "vice-ring" indictment at a session held last night in the Criminal Courts Building.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- Without debate the Assembly gave unanimous approval tonight to three bills which would establish an eight-hour day for employes in State hospitals, prisons and similar institutions, effective July 1, 1937.
BOSTON, Feb. 3. -- The Boston Chamber of Commerce asked President Roosevelt tonight to order government icebreakers into the Buzzards Bay area to avert "a shortage of fuel."

The "Little World Series," a post-season clash between the International League and the American Association, which was an annual Fall fixture for fifteen years prior to last year, yesterday was revived at the meeting of the International League in the Hotel Commodore.

The threatening weather plus efficient defense "saved" New York City and Mitchel Field, Long Island, from demolition yesterday, according to cameras mounted on machine gun racks and bomb releases of the Army Air Corps planes.

Total advertising spaee used by New York and Brooklyn stores last month comprised 2.791,238 lines, as compared with 2,559,504. lines in January. 1935, according to figures compiled yesterday by Media Records, Inc. The increase was 9.05 per cent and represent one of the largest monthly gains for a considerable period.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The British and French Governments have not given up their efforts to discover a way out of the deadlock over Ethiopia by means of a conciliatory proposal acceptable to both belligerents.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 3. -- A consensus of the Board of Directors of the American Retailers' Association, who are attending their annual convention here, shows the New Deal to be in generally high favor, and the majority anticipate as good or better a year in 1936 than they experienced in 1935.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3. -- With millions of dollars in orders on hand, the aviation industry in California is facing a labor shortage for the first time in a decade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Arguing for the right of a trade association to regulate industrial practices to prevent abuses, counsel for the Sugar Institute, Inc., told the Supreme Court today that the institute, an organization of sugar refiners, had not caused any increase in prices to consumers.

An international convention for the protection of African fauna and flora has just come into force. A score of animals and plants are guaranteed absolute immunity and an equal number receive the benefits of a license system.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Ethiopian officials claimed today that Italy's army of Askaris had been forced back to the plains of Noghelli, ending Ethiopia's critical situation on the southwest front.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 3. -- An amendment to the Westchester County tax act, designed to curb the practices of so-called tax lien sharks, was approved today by the Board of Supervisors and now goes to the State Legislature for enactment.

After resisting seasonal declines in December, wholesale collection and sales conditions in ninety-seven cities revealed an encouraging return toward Fall levels, according to the January survey released yesterday by the National Association of Credit Men.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3. -- The smoldering opposition to Governor Harold G. Hoffman's attitude in the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann broke into the open on the floor of the Assembly here tonight. A member of his own Republican party introduced a bill which, in effect, might extend indefinitely the term of Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, State police superintendent.

An English writer on international affairs, Mr. DOUGLAS JERROLD, recently declared that the League of Nations would not be really alive and forceful until it acquired a "conscience." lie did not stop to consider that it might be the kind of conscience which makes cowards of us all.
The soft hissing of twin kettles in a large, bare room on the twelfth floor of the Appraisers' Stores, 201 Varick Street, rose to a slightly frantic note yesterday morning.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- Critics of Governor Lehman's fiscal program will have their inning tomorrow when his budget bills with a footing of $308,000,000 in recommended appropriations will be discussed at a public hearing before the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, controlled by the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Provisions of a 1932 Louisiana law making retroactive changes in the method of paying off withdrawing members of building and loan associations were held unconstitutional today by the Supreme Court. The opinion was unanimous.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- Inflation talk and strength in stocks failed today to be reflected in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, and wheat at the low point was around 1 cent a bushel under Saturday's closing quotation, as a result of weakness in the markets in Kansas City and Winnipeg and a lack of aggressive support here.

The British Institute of Philosophy, founded in 1925 with the late Lord Balfour as its first president, among other things to consider what the primary standards of right and wrong in the conduct of nations should be, is planning to enlarge its activities and is appealing for support to its friends throughout the world.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May, sitting in Special Term, Jamaica, Queens, reserved decision yesterday on a motion brought by attorneys for the officers, directors and advisory board of the City Housing Corporation seeking dismissal of a suit against the corporate officials for $850,000 by more than 200 owners of homes in the Sunnyside Gardens community of Queens.

The new president of the Rensselaer Polytechnic, WILLIAM O. HOTCHKISS, gave his inaugural address a few nights ago in Washington instead of Troy, the seat of this oldest school of science and engineering in any English-speaking country. This departure from the time-honored custom was a gesture in recognition of the important part, it is explained, that former students of this pioneer institution have had in the development of engineering in Government activities.

With snow falling again in the city yesterday, Thomas W. Hammond, Sanitation Commissioner, announced that the $3,700,000 appropriated last month for clearing the streets was almost exhausted and that he would probably ask the Board of Estimate for additional funds this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Jan. 25 amounted to 313,239,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. This total has been placed on a basis comparable with the bureau's monthly figures and represents a decrease of 1,297,000 barrels from the total of the previous week.

After breaking nearly to 10 3/4 cents a pound for the May delivery last week, prices for cotton on the Cotton Exchange recovered sharply yesterday and ended with net gains of 10 to 22 points. In the morning, new crops gained nearly $1 a bale, while both near months improved only a few points on the undoing of straddles.

Pedro Montanez, sensational Puerto Rican lightweight, moved a step nearer a bout with Tony Canzoneri, the world titleholder, by out-pointing Al Roth of the Bronx in a ten-round bout last night at the St. Nicholas Palace.

The stoppage of 20,000 millinery workers, ordered to take effect this morning in 400 shops of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association, will be effective at 10 A. M., but indications last night were that an early agreement between the Millinery Workers Union and the association was likely.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The cleavage between Supreme Court liberals and conservatives was emphasized again today when a majority of six announced through Justice Butler a decision that the Great Northern Railway Company had been overassessed $10,000,000 by North Dakota through failure to take into account the stock market crash in 1929 and a minority of three, through Justice Stone, criticized the majority's attitude.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell, Boston Red Sox hurler, won the golf championship of the professional baseball leagues today with a seventy-two-hole score of 312.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- President Roosevelt sent a message to Congress recommending repeal of the Bankhead Cotton Act, the Tobacco Act and the Potato Control Act; formally presented commissions to five new members of the Federal Reserve Board and appointed Matthew Abruzzo a Federal judge for the Eastern District of New York.

It is a sentimental gesture that the National Association of Basketball Coaches is making this week for Dr. James A. Naismith, inventor of the sport in a Y.M.C.A. gymnasium in 1891. From Friday to Feb. 15 each college and high school in the country has been asked to set aside one game as the "Naismith game."

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 3. -- The four elimination groups into which the fifteen Olympic ice hockey teams have been divided were announced tonight by the directors of the International Ice Hockey League.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- Cotton and related wash fabrics came into their own as "high style for low budgets" today with the opening, in the Merchandise Mart, of the Women's Children's and Infants' Wear Market, to run to Feb. 15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Bids on fifty-eight issues of securities of counties, municipalities and districts in twenty-seven States, with an aggregate par value of $6,082,400, were invited today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and will be opened here at noon on Feb. 13.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Senator Pope of Idaho introduced a bill today requiring the concurrence of more than two-thirds of the members of the Supreme Court to invalidate a Federal statute. As the Court is now constituted, this would mean that seven justices would have to agree to an opinion holding an Act of Congress unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- No more intimate photographs of President Roosevelt will be taken when he is unaware of them, under strict regulations laid down by Stephen Early, assistant secretary to the President.
A large tea was held yesterday at Willoughby House Settlement, 97 Lawrence Street, Brooklyn, to celebrate the thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the settlement.

There is no reason why the teachers should not take the oath of loyalty. Indeed, they ought to be proud that theirs is recognized as a dedicated profession and that they are sworn as are Presidents. But there is no reason why those who object should be punished. Look at the results of selecting victims this way, and they are bad.

August H. Gehrs, formerly sales manager of Harcourt, Brace, is the new president of the reorganized Womrath Book Shops and Libraries, Inc., it became known yesterday, Mr. Gehrs was elected by stockholders representing a group of publishers that recently refinanced the Womrath chain.

Many parties will be given tonight at the second and last Yorkville dinner dance for this season, which will take place in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Center.

The share market, following early irregularity, gathered strength yesterday in the late dealings after the United States Supreme Court had indicated that it would not decide at this time the question of the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and closed higher.

GENEVA, Feb. 3. -- In the absence of the United States, which controls roughly half the world's oil and a fourth of its tanker tonnage, experts of twelve League of Nations members that are most important in these fields began here today to study cautiously and rather gloomily whether and how Geneva could effectively cut off Italy's oil.

Staging a spectacular rally in the last quarter to score fifteen straight points while holding their opponents scoreless, the Newtown High tossers downed Far Rockaway, 32 -- 24, at Far Rockaway yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Supreme Court, sitting today after a two-week recess, failed to hand down a decision on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority, to the surprise and disappointment of the capital. Interest in the court's consideration of New Deal legislation revived, however, when the justices agreed to a test of the Securities Act of 1933.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Repayments on loans of various types received in December by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation totaled $84,128,106, compared with disbursements of only $36,779,467, according to a report the corporation sent today to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had relinquished control of the Manila Stock Exchange, stating that in the opinion of J.J. Burns, its general counsel, the establishment of the Commonwealth of the Philippine Islands pursuant to the Philippine Independence Act terminated its Jurisdiction over that Exchange.
Operation of buses on the Broadway route of the New York Railways trolley system will begin Feb. 12, it became known yesterday, coincident with the beginning of test operation on the route.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- The Boerse opened the week with fluctuating prices, but a generally firm tone; the turnover remained small. Changes were rarely above fractions of 1 per cent, but Salzdetfurth dropped 3 1/4 points on an accidental larger order.

Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace is reported by the newspapers to have said that the return to the processors of $200,000,000 processing taxes, impounded in the courts, was "the greatest legalized steal in American history."

For over a generation physical geographers, agronomists and geologists have been preaching soil conservation. To wrest 6,500,000 farms from the wilderness it became necessary to hew down about a billion acres of virgin forests -- half the area of the country. There was no other way of building an agricultural and industrial nation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- Receipts of hogs were small here today and aggressive buying by shippers lifted prices generally 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight compared with Friday to a new high level since last October. The demand was especially good for weights under 250 pounds, but an easy undertone prevailed for heavier kinds late in the session, as packers held off because of expectations of larger offerings tomorrow.

Award of the 1935 Chandler Medal of Columbia University to Professor William Francis Giauque of the University of California for his achievements in thermochemistry was announced yesterday afternoon following a meeting of the Columbia board of trustees.

The annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club took place last night in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Robert H. Thayer, daughter of former Representative Ruth Pratt, lead the grand march at midnight. Jesse Markel acted as deputy marshal. Divertissements by well-known Broadway entertainers were given during the evening. Mrs. William Warner Hoppin headed the group in charge of the arrangements.

More than 300 buyers turned out to view a wide range of dress accessories, gift items and household "gadgets" included in the displays of 150 manufacturers participating in the first National Notion and Novelty Exhibit, which opened for a week yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The dollar on the local foreign BELGIUM -- Par 16.95 cents per belga. SHANGHAI, Feb. 3. -- Foreign bankers in Shanghai generally view with mild approval the gigantic refunding scheme of the Chinese Government, even though it brings the domestic bonded indebtedness to a total of $1,800,000,000 and increases the domestic bonded indebtedness nearly 23 per cent.
"Romanticism in Music" was the central theme of the fourth program in the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra series at the Town Hall last night.

Erwin, Wasey Co., Inc., has been appointed to direct the advertising campaign to promote real estate values in the Philadelphia area which is being conducted by the Philadelphia Real Estate Board and other interests.

It became known yesterday that the City Art Museum of St. Louis has purchased Henry Mattson's "Deep Water," which won third prize in the 1935 Carnegie International at Pittsburgh, and "Sulphurous Evening," a well known watercolor by Charles Burchfield, included in the American show at the Worcester Museum a few months ago.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3. -- Polish Beau, a fast gelding, carried his speed the full six furlongs to win the Venetian Handicap from five rival sprinters at Hialeah Park today. The 4-year-old son of Polymelian closed second choice to Mrs. C. Crane's Ladfield and led that veteran to the wire by a half length.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Jan. 29 shows increases for the week of $26,000,000 in total loans and investments, $79,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $181,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $39,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

The first of the sewing shops to be opened in the city by the women's division of the Works Progress Administration was inspected for the first time by officials yesterday afternoon. The shop, on the top floor of the seven-story loft building at 35 West Third Street, employs 266 women as seamstresses, pressers and finishers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- A bill prohibiting the exportation of tinplate scrap from the United States was passed by the House today, 139 to 14, and sent to the Senate, where early approval is expected.

Representatives of railway managements and the heads of twenty-one unions began yesterday a series of conferences on a proposal by labor for the protection of employes displaced by the coordination or unification of facilities undertaken in the interest of economy.

The attitude may be old-fashioned and the statement bromidic; it remains, however, that the popularity of Richard Wagner increases with the New York public year by year. This was proved by the immense audience which listened to Wagner's "Meistersinger" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 4. -- Ten thousand workers in the Central London meat markets at Smithfield, which supply 8,000,000 persons, decided last night to continue their strike, which began at midnight Sunday. Unless a settlement is reached today there will be a serious meat shortage by tomorrow.
Housing and business properties were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Christian statesmen and industrial leaders should receive the aid of the Christian Church in the improvement of social conditions through the creating of a new public consciousness, the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive director of the National Lutheran Council, declared yesterday.

Federal Reserve Banks in New York, Chicago and Boston were kept busy yesterday laying the ghost of a rumor that the Boston bank had issued an opinion stating that margin accounts in existence prior to Jan. 31 were not to be affected by the increase in margin requirements that became effective on last Saturday.

The Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks, trust companies and affiliates reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $3,912,699 for 1935, compared with $4,035,220 in 1934.
