As a part of the profits realized from the purchase and sale of United States Government securities, $219,918 was included, George F. Rand, president, stated in his annual report to stockholders. In the preceding year the amount included was $223,068.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Stamp taxes on bonds of indebtedness, capital stock issues and deeds of conveyance last year amounted to $23,329,405, compared with $17,030,692 in 1934, or a gain of about 36 per cent, the Treasury Department announced today.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 3. -- A party of prospective nudist colonizers who put to sea without a navigator because none would shed his clothes to share their lot were reported aground in their schooner tonight at the mouth of the Hillsborough Bay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Matthew T. Abruzzo of Brooklyn was named by President Roosevelt today to be a judge for the Eastern District of New York to fill a place recently created by Congress on recommendation of the Department of Justice because of the crowded dockets.

MUNICH, Feb. 3. -- The trial of Charles Nisselbeck, held here for more than eight months on accusations of "treasonable activities" and smuggling money out of Germany, was set today for Feb. 17. He will go before the Bavarian State Supreme Court on a charge of high treason.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The Prudence Company, Inc., New York, won a partial victory today in the Supreme Court in its effort to recover $420,000 as expenses it claimed because of delay in completing construction of Essex House, New York City apartment hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The administration's $1,000,000,000 stopgap farm program, substantially revised to bring it more clearly within the limits of the Supreme Court's decision in the Hoosac Mills case, was reported to the House today by a 17 to 6 vote of the Agriculture Committee.

The spontaneous tributes paid to Mr. Mortimer during the past few days cannot but comfort his family and his fellow-workers. As one who also knew him over many years, I want to add a little to the store of comment concerning a truly great man -- one who would have laughed at such an adjective applied to himself.

HOLLYWOOD'S favorite adjective, says Jim Rorty, is "phony." The word doesn't quite apply to "Actor's Blood" (Covici-Friede, $2), which is a collection of short stories by that first citizen of Hollywood, Ben Hecht. For, whatever the depth and intensity of his literary sins, there is always a glittering flair to whatever Ben Hecht turns his hand to.

Two new exhibitions serve to bring to public attention work by several American artists belonging, for the most part, to an earlier generation. One of these is a group show that opened yesterday at Milch's, the other a centennial exhibition of paintings and drawings by Homer D. Martin, who was born Oct. 28, 1836.

Members of the cotton textile industry, acting through a joint meeting of three of their national associations, have petitioned Congress not to impose any retroactive excise levy to recapture impounded processing taxes, and have urged it to finance any substitute farm relief legislation not out of a processing tax, but out of a manufacturers' sales tax.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- Although the Philadelphia women's Class A team defeated Boston's representatives by 4 matches to 1 in the national intercity squash racquets play at the Merion Cricket Club today, Miss Anne Page, Pennsylvania State and Philadelphia singles titleholder, lost to Miss Edith Drury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The number of foreign governments seeking permanent registration of their bonds on national security exchanges was increased to eleven today when Costa Rica filed an application covering $8,000,000 of external sinking fund 7 per cent gold bonds of 1926, due on Nov. 1, 1951.

The preliminary report of the Pacific Lighting Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1935 shows a net income of $8,185,156, equal after preferred dividends to $4.35 a share on the common stock, compared with $5,562,485, or $2.72 a share, in 1934.

In a meeting that was constantly in uproar with charges of illegality from one side and racial discrimination from another, Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of the City Court, was chosen Tammany leader of the Nineteenth Assembly District in Harlem last night by a minority of the county committeemen eligible to vote.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- Continuance of a gradual loss of the metropolitan market by up-State milk producers, unless a program of interstate milk control is effected, was predicted today by Peter G. Ten Eyck, Agricultural Commissioner.

Famous battles and incidents of the Civil War were recalled yesterday by twenty-two members of the Grand Army of the Republic at a luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania given in honor of Commander-in-Chief Oley Nelson by 200 New York representatives of five allied organizations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Endicott Johnson Company of Endicott, N.Y., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of 73,060 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock, 5 per cent series.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Senate munitions investigating committee will begin tomorrow the writing of the final chapter in its long investigation of the munitions and shipbuilding industries and the wartime operations of J.P. Morgan Co. and other financial concerns which helped to finance allied war purchases in the United States during the World War.

The first of the monthly index numbers as of Feb. 1, compiled by Dun's Review, shows increase of six-tenths of 1 per cent during January. This advance brings the Dun index number to the highest of any monthly date since April 1, 1930.
LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The financial editor of The Times of London, commenting on the fall of the dollar, which closed at $5.02 7-16 to the pound here today, says.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- While the League of Nations is considering the addition of oil sanctions to those penalties already in force against Italy, figures which indicate that sales by non-participating nations may impair seriously the effectiveness of such measures were made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The vacant triangular plot at Lafayette and Duane Streets, which was included in the site recently proposed by Borough President Samuel Levy for a new court house for the City Court on the Civic Center at Foley Square, has been transferred by the State Banking Department to a group of private owners including Benjamin Benenson, real estate operator, and Henry Kaufman, builder.

Further laurels were heaped on the shoulders of Joe Mangan, conqueror of Gene Venzke and Glenn Cunningham in 4:11 in the Wanamaker Mile, with the announcement yesterday that the former Cornell ace would receive the Rodman Wanamaker International Trophy, annually presented to the outstanding athlete in the Millrose games.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 3. -- A cryptic notation in an opened German textbook puzzled police tonight as they investigated the mysterious death of Francis O. Grose, an Amherst College freshman.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- If credit is to be controlled effectively, there must be a further concentration of authority in the Federal Reserve Board, Dr. Ray Westerfield, Professor of Economics at Yale University, has written in an article which will appear tomorrow in the Wharton Review of Finance and Commerce.

On Friday the House in Committee of the Whole resumed consideration of the Appropriation Bill for the Department of the Interior. Expenses for the Indian Service were the immediate object of discussion. Inevitably the Liberty League, which the faithful identify with the "good Indian" of the orthodox definition, was lugged in.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The election of Ramsay MacDonald to Parliament from the Scottish Universities will enable Prime Minister Baldwin to face the House of Commons when it resumes sessions tomorrow with his prestige partly recovered from the blow dealt it by the Hoare-Laval Ethiopian peace fiasco just before adjournment in December.

Nine men were arrested in a barber shop at 258 Bleecker Street, near Cornelia Street, soon after 5 P.M. yesterday on charges of counterfeiting after Federal operatives and police detectives uncovered in the basement of the building $2,197 in spurious $20, $10, $5 and $2 notes.

Part of the blame for the decline in the sale of certified milk during the depression may be attributed to the advocates of birth control, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, told 200 scientists, pediatricians and milk company executives yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.
NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 3. -- Youth was crowded out by an aging veteran today when Boston College launched a new football era by engaging Gilmour (Gloomy Gil) Dobie as head coach.

Westchester is believed to be leading the State and the nation in the completion of PWA projects, it was said yesterday in a report issued at the offices of Arthur S. Turtle, Acting State Director of the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3. -- Characterizing as deliberate falsehoods the Japanese versions of recent incidents on the Soviet-Manchukuo border, the staff of the special Far Eastern Red Army has offered to give the fullest aid to an inquiry on the ground by any unbiased commission that may be appointed to investigate.

Consolidated net income of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and subsidiaries for 1935 amounted to $62,085,410. This was equal, after dividends on debenture stock, to $55,527,824. It compared with $46,701,465 and $40,145,831 respectively for 1934.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- Further decisions have been taken by Great Britain concerning the modernization of infantry, and steps toward it are now in progress. Complete mechanization of its first-line transport is involved, horse-limbers being superseded by fifteen-hundredweight trucks with oversize tires or armored carriers, while officers' chargers are being replaced by light autos or autocycles.

Five passengers on a Webster Avenue trolley car were injured soon after 7 o'clock last night at Webster Avenue and Gunhill Road, the Bronx, when a large steam boiler was dislodged from its moorings on a truck and crashed into the side of the trolley car as the truck skidded.

By defeating the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club team last night the Columbia University Club Class C team clinched the championship in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League, although the schedule has another week to go.

Two major advances in the effort of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to "make the largest school system in the world the smallest" were recorded with the opening of the Spring term yesterday.

In a carnival setting that thrilled an overflow crowd of 18,000 persons with its glittering pageantry, Silver Skates champions in all divisions were crowned at Madison Square Garden last night, with Joe Bree of Tuckahoe, N.Y.; Cliff Spelman of Deer Park, L.I., and Miss Alice Burnham of Brooklyn annexing the major crowns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The incident of the Marine Band's walkout from the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense passed into history today, as the House received a letter from Henry L. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, taking full responsibility.

The collection of 175 American historical portraits assembled by the late Thomas Benedict Clarke and appraised for tax purposes last year at $1,024,800, has been bought by M. Knoedler Co., art dealers, of 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Total assets of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York on Dec. 31 were $1,239,039,565, an increase of $78,529,913, in 1935, David F. Houston, president, stated in his annual letter to policy holders made public yesterday. The company paid $138,591,009 to policy holders and their beneficiaries last year, he said, and since 1843 had paid or accumulated for them $4,818,922,566, which was $580,565,543 more than had been received in premiums.

The navies of Japan and the United States will never be used against each other, Ambassador Hirosi Saito of Japan predicted last night at a dinner at the Hotel Pierre given by the American Council of St. Luke's International Medical Center, Tokyo.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 3. -- The Van Sweringen Company and its six subsidiaries, all real estate operating companies, today were granted authority by Federal Judge Paul Jones to file a reorganization plan under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Apparently unaware that the Palladium, a night club, had closed a week ago because of financial difficulties, a well-dressed gunman, his features hidden by a blue woolen muffler, entered the cabaret's second-floor offices at 254 West Fifty-fourth Street yesterday morning and demanded the week-end receipts.

Arrangements have been concluded for the formation of an independent agency to devote itself exclusively to the investigation and prevention of fraudulent practices in the fur trade, it was announced yesterday by Vladimir Eitingon, president of the American Fur Merchants Association.

Reports received at Republican State headquarters up to yesterday indicated that the party organizations in up-State Congressional districts had designated for the most part conservative condidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Overcrowding in the city's high schools reached its peak yesterday when 259,173 pupils presented themselves for the opening of the Spring term. A grand total of 1,131,400 children were registered in all public school divisions.
BERLIN, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today postponed until Feb. 10 the study of the Mid-America Corporation, principal Van Sweringen holding company. The hearing was scheduled to begin today.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Overcrowding in the city's high schools reached its peak yesterday when 259,173 pupils presented themselves for the opening of the Spring term. A grand total of 1,131,400 children were registered in all public school divisions.
BERLIN, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Reports received at Republican State headquarters up to yesterday indicated that the party organizations in up-State Congressional districts had designated for the most part conservative condidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today postponed until Feb. 10 the study of the Mid-America Corporation, principal Van Sweringen holding company. The hearing was scheduled to begin today.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The stock markets here were cheerful today, with Wall Street active over the week-end and the international outlook better. British funds and foreign issues were quiet, although Brazilians received fresh support.
Thirty-one persons were injured last night in Jersey City when a Pennsylvania Railroad train skidded on icy rails and crashed into a bumper in the Exchange Place Terminal.

THERE were 226 registered voters who went to the polls in the recent baseball balloting to select candidates for inclusion in the modern sector of the proposed Baseball Hall of Fame. A glance at the returns produces a swift shock.

Roy S. Durstine, vice president and general manager of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., has been elected president of the advertising organization, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds William H. Johns, who was elected chairman of the executive committee by the board of directors.

This is the night a Federal Theatre Project show actually opens in Manhattan. The honor falls to "Walk Together Chillun," written and directed by Frank Wilson and produced by the Negro Theatre unit at the Lafayette Theatre in Harlem. Sundry dignitaries have been invited, among them Jacob Baker, assistant Federal WPA administrator, who just the other day was concerned in that turmoil over "The Living Newspaper.

The status of the indenture securing $24,532,000 of 5 per cent bonds due in 1950 of the Alleghany Corporation was said by Wall Street counsel yesterday to offer the possibility of an action by bondholders of the company to change a reorganization plan under which prior preferred stock was to be issued in lieu of interest on the bonds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- In a fervid oratorical effort which left him exhausted and all but voiceless, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, warned delegates to the United Mine Workers of America convention today that their possible secession would leave the federation "supreme" and that it would not "tolerate" the formation within itself of an organization "challenging its supremacy."

The Long Island Railroad commuters using Pennsylvania Station have paid an extra $10,000,000 in the last ten years for the privilege of riding through the East River tunnel and using the Pennsylvania Station. Hobart Rawson, railroad statistician, told Public Service Commissioner George R. Lunn and Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley at yesterday's hearing on the railroad's application for an increase in commutation rates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- While refusing to engage in a controversy with the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Treasury officials today took exception to his statement yesterday about the nation's gold supply. Father Coughlin's statement was:

The members of the Seven O'Klockers Klub, that group of 125 Philadelphians who commute to New York daily and like it, held their annual election yesterday morning in one of their two private cars of a Reading express train as it sped along the tracks between Jenkintown, Pa., and the Delaware River.

The creation of a national maritime labor council with a view to uniting all maritime unions of the nation was studied yesterday by local leaders in marine labor circles. The plan was announced Saturday in Washington to the national delegates of the Seamen's Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- A warning that the exemption provided by Section 3 (a) (9) of the Securities Act of 1933 should not be relied upon for exemption of transactions not plainly within the scope of that section was given today in two opinions by John J. Burns, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Plants with abnormal growths and a new technique that makes possible the cultivation of fresh vegetables anywhere, even at the Poles, were among the "plant miracles" at the exhibition that opened yesterday in Rockefeller Center. The exhibition, in Horticultural Hall of the RCA building, will continue through Feb. 15.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The United States and Mexico, which met in the final of the North American Zone competition a year ago, were matched against each other today in the first round of the 1936 Davis Cup tennis play.

MONTREAL, Feb. 3. -- The Chicago Black Hawks' drive to the top of the American group and the brilliant fight made by the New York Rangers to stay out of the cellar were fully reflected tonight in weekly statistics issued by President Frank Calder of the National Hockey League.

The clinical faculty of the New York Homeopathic Medical College, which visits the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, will also serve the Metropolitan Hospital, Welfare Island, it was announced yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 3 (AP). -- Sixteen men were invited by Governor Horner tonight to serve on a board empowered to examine the entire State penal system as a result of charges against it following the razor slaying of Richard Loeb at Stateville penitentiary last Tuesday.

Could there be a more perfect illustration of the fallacy of "protection" than that furnished by Governor Landon? He said: "I am advised from reliable sources that the cost of about two hundred items the farmer has to buy is increased about one-fourth by the operation of the tariff.

The Supreme Court was silent yesterday on the question of TVA, but President ROOSEVELT handed down an important legal decision of his own. This was to recommend "the prompt repeal" of three farm measures which seem plainly to be unconstitutional in the light of the court's verdict invalidating AAA.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- The Republican ticket this year will be Landon and Wadsworth, if the plans of some Eastern Republican leaders who met here last week in secret conference are fulfilled.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Tennessee Valley Authority's annual report was released today after having been held up since the opening of the present session of Congress.
LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The Anglo-German naval pact of last Summer suddenly arose today to plague its British authors and to involve the naval conference in a new and dangerous crisis.

Bills designed to minimize fire hazards by restoring control over combustible materials to the Fire Department soon will be introduced in both branches of the Legislature, Fire Commissioner McElligott said yesterday.

An ammonia tank, seven feet long and a foot in diameter, slipped from the hands of a truck driver while he was unloading it yesterday morning in front of 559 West Thirty-third Street, struck the pavement and exploded. The driver and five other persons in the vicinity were burned or injured by the escaping gas and flying pieces of metal.

Bills designed to minimize fire hazards by restoring control over combustible materials to the Fire Department soon will be introduced in both branches of the Legislature, Fire Commissioner McElligott said yesterday.

An ammonia tank, seven feet long and a foot in diameter, slipped from the hands of a truck driver while he was unloading it yesterday morning in front of 559 West Thirty-third Street, struck the pavement and exploded. The driver and five other persons in the vicinity were burned or injured by the escaping gas and flying pieces of metal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The Treasury today authorized four banks in New York to arrange shipments of $8,500,000 of gold to France and $1,120,000 to Holland as weakness of the dollar continued in the foreign exchange markets. The consignments were in addition to $5,603,000 engaged for shipment yesterday to these two countries.
The sixteen contract bridge hands making up the fifth annual World Bridge Olympic competition were officially opened and played in New York homes, hotels and bridge clubs at 8:01 o'clock last night.
The sale of merchandise items retailing up to 40 cents is being extended by the F.W. Woolworth Company to its more than 1,900 stores in this country, officials of the company said here yesterday.

ATHENS, Feb. 4. -- Great Britain will send military aviators and fighting planes to Greece if war with Italy results from the alliance concluded with her by King George shortly after his enthronement, it was learned today in informed quarters here.
Housing properties in three boroughs were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

Genuine low cost housing cannot be erected in connection with slum clearance projects, and when it is attempted the losses are borne by other sections of the community, Charles R. Ward, Commissioner of Public Works in Brooklyn, told a group of Brooklyn real estate men at a luncheon at the Hotel St. George yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- The rival budget hearings before the fiscal committees of the Democratic Senate and the Republican Assembly were held today and the Assembly committee "stole the show."

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- The feature of the stock markets today was heavy buying of international shares following yesterday's sharp recovery in Wall Street. All issues were higher except International Nickel, which weakened when the dividend was not changed.
Three more jurors, making a total of four, were chosen yesterday at the second session of the trial of three men for the murder of Samuel Drukman in Brooklyn on last March 3.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Senator Borah definitely announced today his candidacy for the Republican nomination for the Presidency. This had been expected, but his exact intentions have been a matter for speculation for several months.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- Following an announcement from Buckingham Palace of the King's wish that entertaining proceed as usual during the coming season, despite court mourning, the banqueting managers of the leading London hotels are being inundated with reservations.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 4. -- America's chances in the Olympic ice hockey competition probably will be decided tomorrow at a meeting of representatives of the International Ice Hockey Federation, called to examine the plethora of Canadians scheduled to appear on Olympic rinks as representatives of many nations, including the British mother country.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4. -- George Bernard Shaw arrived here today, twirled the Shavian quarterstaff over the heads of welcomers and interviewers and blithely advised the United States to "chuck its Constitution into the ocean, bag and baggage, and appoint a Prime Minister."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Continued domination of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway by the Van Sweringen interests, despite an order from the Interstate Commerce Commission in 1929 that they divest themselves of influence over the road's affairs, was charged today by the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway in a petition to the Federal agency.

After a week of study, the Transit Commission informed Mayor La Guardia yesterday that the Seabury-Berle definitive plan for unification submitted to it by the Board of Estimate was not an agreement at all and represented only the views of its authors, Samuel Seabury and A.A. Berle Jr., the City Chamberlain.
John H. Owen has been appointed vice president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., and will direct the liquor activities.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4. -- The depression of 1877 sent the Newark Savings Institution into receivership, but by 1892 the receiver had realized enough on assets to pay off all depositors in full. Up to this time, however, 9,553 depositors have not bothered to claim the remaining deposits of $26,640.92, and with ample money on hand to meet all claims, the bank still is in the hands of the Chancery Court.

Salvatore J. Rizzo, a patrolman attached to Poplar Street police station in Brooklyn was fined thirty days' pay yesterday on a departmental charge of committing fraud in obtaining a Mexican divorce by mall, and for contracting a bigamous marriage in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Some of the anglers and hunters here for the North American Wild Life Conference are strolling about the lobbies and corridors of the Mayflower Hotel in a bit of a daze. They cannot quite grasp the unprecedented scope of this gathering. In some respects it resembles the old American Game Conference and yet it is totally different.

President ROOSEVELT may no longer be snapped by the camera men without his knowledge and consent. Rules to that effect have been issued at the White House. The cause is a recent informal photograph of Mr. ROOSEVELT with his hand before his eyes.

The annual report of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $8,089,052 after all deductions, equal to $6.07 a share on 1,333,458 shares of capital stock, compared with $8,011,199, or $6.01 a share in 1934.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 4. -- Resolutions favoring the Costigan-Wagner Anti-Lynching Bill and the constitutional amendment abolishing child labor were passed today by the executive board of the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods in session here.
ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- The Legislature swung into action today on Governor Lehman's bills for a war on the gangster, the gunman and the racketeer.

Close friends of former Governor Alfred E. Smith expressed doubt yesterday of the accuracy of the published report that he intended to be a candidate for election as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in the Eleventh Congressional District, in which he was born and for many years made his home.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 4. -- Princess Wilhelm von Wied, wife of the former Albanian ruler, died today at her estate, Fontaneli, in Rumania.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- The Gordon National Medal, one of the most coveted awards in curling circles, was won today by the Utica Curling Club's rink, skippered by Robert L. Davies.

A three months' investigation by two of Commissioner of Accounts Blanshard's aides, police and Federal agents resulted in the solution, the Commissioner said yesterday, of what appeared at first to be a perfect crime and the arrest of the alleged criminal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- A Greek offer of partial war debt payments today marked the first break in the impasse resulting from wholesale default by a dozen other European nations two years ago.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs shut out the Bruins, 3 -- 0, before a capacity crowd of 16,000 tonight at the Boston Garden. It was the Leafs' last visit of the regular season here, and they outplayed and outskated the Bruins from start to finish.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Some Democrats commented freely on Senator Borah's announcement of his candidacy, but Representative Fish of New York, who has supported him from the start, was the only Republican to offer his views at once.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The hearings of the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee, in recess since Jan. 16, were resumed today and brought evidence in denial of old reports that the $400,000,000 British demand loan held by J.P. Morgan Co. when the United States entered the World War had been paid out of the United States Treasury.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4. -- The State and Federal Governments and many social welfare organizations were represented this afternoon at the funeral of J. Prentice Murphy, executive secretary of the Children's Bureau of Philadelphia, which was held at the First Unitarian Church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- In response to President Roosevelt's message of yesterday, the Senate adopted a resolution today repealing the Bankhead Cotton Control Act, the Kerr-Smith Tobacco Act and the Potato Control Act. The House is expected to take similar action tomorrow, and then the three principal experiments in compulsory crop control will become economic history.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- Reduced supplies of hogs and prospects that the severe storm and low temperatures in the West would further curtail the movement resulted in price gains of 10 to 25 cents a hundred- weight today. The top of $10.65 was 15 cents better than on Monday and within 5 cents of the best level since Oct. 17, while the day's average advanced 20 cents to $10.40, the highest since Oct. 9.
Paramount's screen version of "Anything Goes" begins this morning at the Paramount. Bing Crosby, Ethel Merman and Charles Ruggles are featured.

George W. Wickersham, former Attorney General of the United States and chairman of President Hoover's National Commission on Law Observance and Law Enforcement, who died on Jan. 25, left virtually all of his estate to his widow, Mildred Wendell Wickersham of 125 East Seventy-fourth Street, who was named residuary legatee.

" We must have a traitor," so it was said, used to be a cry of angry French Deputies. Members of our Congress do not use that idiom, but they do insist upon the existence of some evildoer, some conspirator, some enemy of the people, who blocks their plans for beneficent legislation.

A group of four early American trims, the second in a series designed to trace the evolution of the motion picture art, was presented last night by the Museum of Modern Art Film Library. Because of limited accommodations in the museum's own building, at 11 West Fifty-third Street, the second showing was given in the auditorium of the Dalton School, at 108 East Eighty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Moves aimed at bolstering the strength of the Army Air Corps and the navy were started today in both houses of Congress.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back more than $1 a bale yesterday on the announcement that 25,000 bales of pool cotton would be offered to the trade immediately, with 50,000 more available on Feb. 12. As the market in Liverpool is feeling the weight of increased offerings of Indian cotton, a combination of foreign and domestic selling carried March back around the 11-cent level before meeting sufficient trade price fixing to create resistance.

TRENTON, Feb. 4. -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf today asked the cooperation of the Federal Government and the New York police in the renewed investigation of the Lindbergh case aimed at finding Bruno Richard Hauptmann's accomplices.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4. -- Nearly 500 members of the Everglades Club and their guests attended the Victory Dinner Dance tonight in the Orange Gardens, celebrating the recent purchase of the club from bondholders by twenty-two residents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Senator Vandenberg produced before the Senate Commerce Committee today several letters from steamship operators saying that they would not use the proposed Florida ship canal even if no tolls were charged. The Commerce Committee has under consideration a resolution by Mr. Vandenberg to appoint a special Senate committee to investigate the economic necessity of the project.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Mrs. Asher Carter Baker, who took part in relief work in France in 1917 and 1918, died here today at the Morristown Memorial Hospital at the age of 77. She was the widow of Captain Baker of the United States Navy.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith visited City Hall yesterday as an official of the Meenan Coal Company to assure Mayor La Guardia that the company would continue to supply coal to city institutions despite delays caused by the weather.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- A two-sentence memorandum by President Roosevelt was acclaimed by leaders of the North American Wild Life Conference today as one of the most vital contributions ever made toward restoration of the nation's natural resources.

Gladys Conboy, a 13-year-old public school student who lived at 37-56 Fifty-ninth Street, Woodside, Queens, was killed instantly about 7:45 o'clock last night when the sled on which she was riding slid into a west-bound Long Island Railroad train on Thirty-ninth Avenue between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Street, Woodside.
Seven scholarships, totaling more than $1,300, have been awarded to honor students in the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, Dean Carl W. Ackerman announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Ann Cooper Hewitt's mother and two physicians were charged with mayhem today in a police complaint based on the 21-year-old heiress's claim that she was tricked into a sterilization operation.

The Kolisch Quartet made its second appearance of the season last night in a recital at the Town Hall. This ensemble again delighted a capacity audience not only by its amazing feat of playing some of the most difficult of chamber-music works by memory, but also by their technical virtuosity.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Marriage and sex information beginning in grammar school and the establishment of State departments to administer marriage and family affairs and set up advice centers were suggested as important needs today by speakers before the New Jersey Institute of Family Relations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- O.P. Van Sweringen watched with interest today as the Interstate Commerce Commission began its examination of his intricate plans for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

Italy has contracted for enormous oil supplies from Russia, according to New York authorities, in her rush to nullify the effect of the proposed League of Nations oil sanction. In addition, thirteen tankers have been chartered to carry oil from Gulf of Mexico ports to Italy this month.

Alec J. Edley, formerly a bookkeeper for Mineral Products, Inc., testified yesterday before a trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission that Fred H. Korff, president of the company, had compelled him to alter its books "because he didn't want the SEC to see that he had jacked up the value of the properties 300 or 400 per cent."

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 4. -- Wilhelm Gustloff, 41-year-old militant leader of Nazis in Switzerland, was shot to death in his apartment today by a medical student who said that he wanted to strike a blow at the regime of Adolf Hitler.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin told the House of Commons today that he would disclose details of the government's plans for rearmament "at an early date.' He said a White Paper on the program for augmenting Britain's defenses would be issued, but expressed the belief that there would be no parliamentary debate on the subject "in the immediate future."

TOKYO, Feb. 4. -- Russia is driving at a terrific speed her work on a new railway of greatest strategic importance from north of Lake Baikal to the Siberian coast, high Japanese War Office authorities told this writer today. They declared 100,000 workmen were employed constructing a line eastward from Taishet, which is east of Krasnoyarsk, and westward from Komsomolsk, with work going on at various points along the 2,000-mile route.

THETFORD, Vt., Feb. 4. -- Jerome Nathan Straus, 18 years old, a freshman at Dartmouth College, was found dead beside a railroad about a mile from here early this morning. Apparently he had been struck by a freight train and instantly killed.

Extraction in a highly concentrated form of vitamin H, believed to be a necessary factor in the prevention of pellagra, was announced here yesterday by Dr. Lela E. Booher of the department of chemistry, Columbia University.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4. -- It is exactly two weeks today since the followers of Senator Long delivered one of the most crushing defeats in Louisiana's stormy political history to a slate of opposition candidates who had the backing of the national administration, and already there are signs of a rapprochement between Washington and Baton Rouge.

Brooklyn Cathedral Prep's powerful quintet went back into a first-place deadlock with St. John's Prep in the Brooklyn Division C.H.S. A.A. tournament by conquering St. Michael's High, 32 -- 14, yesterday at Cathedral Prep. The victory was Cathedral's eighth in nine league engagements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- In the midst of testimony concerning America's course in the World War, J.P. Morgan thrust at the Senate Munitions Committee today an assertion that if the leisure class is destroyed, civilization will perish.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 4 (AP). -- The violent death of Francis Grose, Amherst freshman whose body was found yesterday beneath a railroad trestle, remained a mystery today, despite a verdict of "probably accidental."
The second offensive in the city's war on food racketeers, the projected drive on illegal distributing methods in the grape industry, will be launched next October, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday.

Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, Bronx member of the Board of Education, charged yesterday that school officials were actively seeking to discourage pupils from studying the foreign languages used in their homes. His charge brought an emphatic denial from Lawrence A. Wilkins, the board's director of foreign languages.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 4. -- The State closed its case today in the trial of Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld for the murder of Walter W. Liggett and the defense opened with the revelation that Cann would take the stand in support of his alibi that he was in a downtown barber shop at the moment the publisher was slain a score of blocks away on Dec. 9.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, charged last night that "well oiled lobbies operating for the express purpose of quietly burying any inconvenient legislation" were largely responsible for the failure of the government to get improved conditions on passenger ships in recent years.

TRENTON, Feb. 4. -- With this week the last for introduction of bills in either House without unanimous consent, a veritable flood of measures is pouring into the Senate and Assembly hoppers. All received before Saturday midnight will be accepted for reference to committees.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- Germany's rising young battle fleet cast its shadow over the naval conference today while the British and French Governments continued their dispute over whether to invite a German delegation to London.

Harold R. Cronin, 42 years old, a certified public accountant who was considered an authority on the surety business in this country, was sentenced by Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday to eighteen months to three years in prison. He had been convicted by a jury Jan. 24 of third-degree forgery.

Many corporations, it is shown by examination of the proxy forms now being sent out for annual meetings, are failing to comply fully with the regulations laid down last Summer by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This was expected by lawyers, who, when the rules were promulgated, pointed out that they were less specific in their requirements for information than had been hoped.
ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 4. -- Makale is said now to be surrounded as a result of the Ethiopian victory in Tembien Province. Its water supply is reported seriously threatened.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 4. -- Commander N.S. Haugen of the United States Coast Guard cutter Mendota said last night that the purpose of the cutter's visit to Bermuda was to watch the movements of the eighty-nine-ton British motor vessel Isabel H., which arrived at St. George's Jan. 27 to land a sick member of the crew.
" Who's Who of Commerce and Industry" will make its appearance today, it was announced yesterday by the Institute for Research in Biography, Inc., publishers of the volume.

Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx introduced a resolution at yesterday's Board of Aldermen meeting calling upon Victor Ridder, local WPA administrator, to list the number of aliens now receiving relief from the city.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4. -- Benares, winner of the first race at $25.60 for $2, and the $78.40 shot Absconder in the third event combined to pay the longest-priced dally double of the Hialeah Park meeting today. Seven tickets were sold on the combination, which paid $1,459.20 for $2. Six men and one woman composed the fortunate group.

MONTREAL, Feb. 4. -- A driving New York American attack was turned back for two periods tonight by Goalie Billy Beveridge and the Montreal Maroons gained a 1-1 tie in their National Hockey League match after being outplayed for most of the game.

The resignation of Archibald R. Graustein as president and a director of both the International Paper Company and the International Paper and Power Company was announced at the offices of the companies here yesterday morning.

For the first time since the days of the American Revolution a silver oar, which was the emblem of the Colonial Admiralty Court, memorializing man's efforts to conquer the sea before sailing vessels came into use, lay yesterday on the bench of an Admiralty Court in New York.

Michael Capra of 2,134 First Avenue, a Democratic district captain in Harlem's Eighteenth Assembly District and a former supervisor in the Department of Sanitation, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Goddard to two years in prison for conspiracy to extort through the mails.

THE tension in basketball continues. But some night that N.Y.U. string of successes is going to snap. It was about this time last Winter that the Ultra-Violet array received a shock in the way of a Mexican stand-off. The players passed their examinations but were stopped cold by Yale.

Prices of stocks continued to advance yesterday in trading that exceeded 3,000,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, compared with 2,321,000 the day before. On the Curb Exchange, dealings of 1,297,425 shares made the biggest day's business since July 21, 1933.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 5. -- Thousands of suburbanites spent last night in Tokyo theatres and picture houses, kept from their homes by the worst blizzard in fifty-four years, and thousands more sought chilly sleep in electric cars delayed en route to the suburbs by snowdrifts or collapse of their power cables.

SUGAR LAND, Texas, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Jack Cooper, 43, who escaped from Texas prison farms so many times that he lost count, finally will depart next month with the consent of officials, thanks to his perfection of a cotton-dusting machine which saved the 1935 crop on the Central Farm here.

More than 105,000 dressmakers in 3,800 shops in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and other States producing for the New York City market were ordered last night by their union leaders to stop work Friday at 2:30 P.M., at which time a meeting to be held at Madison Square Garden to take a vote on a general strike.

Registrations of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday were less than in the preceding week and in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings of THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 860 as against 940 in the previous week and 958 in the same period last year.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 4. -- Two men attempted to hold up Thomas Griffin, superintendent of the estate of Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, in his cottage at the entrance to the estate here last night, but were frightened away when a daughter of Griffin screamed, it was learned here today.
VATICAN CITY, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Pope Pius today named Mgr. Joseph A. Breslin, vice rector of the American College, a domestic prelate. Mgr. Breslin is a member of the archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The convention of the United Mine Workers of America pledged its support today to the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union in its efforts to obtain a satisfactory agreement for more than 100,000 New York dressmakers.

The New York Life Insurance Company yesterday reported that assets on Dec. 31 amounted to $2,243,587,752, as compared with $2,109,505,224 at the end of 1934, an increase of $134,082,528. The surplus reserved for general contingencies was $116,706,871 after deducting liabilities of $2,126,880,881, which include reserves to meet all contractual obligations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Participating in today's inventory-taking conference with President Roosevelt were Secretaries Morgenthau, Wallace and Ickes; Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC; Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator; Chester Davis, Farm Administrator, and Cyril B. Upham, secretary of the Inter-Department Lending Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Customs Collections of $199,908,917 for the first six months of the current fiscal year compared with $181,623,865 for the same period in the previous year, an increase of 10 per cent, the Treasury announced today.

ROME, Feb. 4. -- The echoes reaching Rome of the negotiations that have been going on in Paris are so various and often so conflicting that they have bewildered Italian public opinion, but they have nevertheless served the purpose of emphasizing the state of virtual isolation in which Italy at present finds herself.
The New York A.C. and the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club teams maintained their tie for first place in Group 2 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association team race last night.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 4. -- Monterrey, the principal industrial center of Mexico, will be without commercial and other activities for forty-eight hours after daybreak tomorrow due to a general stoppage decreed by workmen as a protest against seditious activity attributed to Communists who recently arrived there from this city.

Crime is more prevalent now in New York State than at any previous time, according to a report of a special law reform committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, made public yesterday. The report endorsed Governor Lehman's criminal law enforcement bills.
The chances seem quite reasonable now that Mr. Anderson's "Winterset" will start a leisurely trip around the country early in March.

Eric Pedley of Los Angeles will be a member of the United States team which plays against England in London next June for the Westchester Cup, international polo trophy for which the two countries have been competing since 1886.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 4. -- William V. Breslin, attorney for Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt, said tonight that Mrs. Hewitt had suffered a nervous breakdown and was under the care of a physician and nurse. He declared that he had spoken with her during the past twenty-four hours.

This week's export of gold from the United States for the first time since the Autumn of 1934 has several points of interest. On Monday, $5,240,000 gold was shipped to France and $365,000 to Holland. Last year we imported altogether $1,741,000,000 gold, of which something over $900,000,000 came from France, and exported in all less than $2,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4. -- Boies Penrose 2d, nephew and namesake of Senator Boies Penrose, is being considered for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Fourth Pennsylvania District. The place is held by Representative J. Burwood Daly, Democrat.

Stirred by revelations of the city's highly organized vice traffic. Police Commissioner Valentine conferred yesterday with Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County, on means of meeting the situation.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- King Edward VIII promised today in his first message to Parliament that the first object of his reign would be to maintain the liberties of his people and "to promote the welfare of all classes of my subjects."

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The magazine Steel said today that the first nine companies of the blast furnace, steel mill and rolling mill category to report their earnings for 1935 showed an aggregate net profit of $32,151,840. The publication said the same companies in 1934 had a deficit of $14,147,710.

In a decision holding that the anti-slot machine laws and other statutes against gambling cover the pin-ball machines, Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman denied yesterday the application by the Times Amusement Corporation of 1,661 Broadway for a temporary injunction restraining License Commissioner Paul Moss from revoking its license and those of several other operators of "sports centers" throughout the city.

BERLIN, Feb. 4. -- The Boerse was dull and irregular and generally weaker today. Encouraging business reports were lacking, the public has withdrawn further from the market and the international situation is regarded as calling for caution all around.
The State Athletic Commission yesterday approved two matches for Tony Canzoneri, world's lightweight champion, under the direction of Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt were guests tonight of Vice President and Mrs. Garner at dinner at the Washington Hotel, followed by a program of entertainment arranged by Gene Buck which provoked much laughter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- An assertion that the Sugar Institute, Inc., in attempting to regulate the refining industry, had "eliminated every competitive practice affecting prices" was made to the Supreme Court today by Angus D. MacLean, special assistant to the Attorney General.

Two Standard Oil companies yesterday announced increased dividend payments. The Standard Oil Company of California declared an extra dividend of 5 cents a share on the capital stock in addition to the regular quarterly 25 cents a share, while Socony-Vacuum declared a dividend of 20 cents a share on its capital stock, compared with its last payment of 15 cents.

A move to midtown offices by an industrial firm in the downtown area featured the business leases reported yesterday. The lessee is the Vanadium Corporation of America, maker of steel alloy and allied products, now in the Equitable Building at 120 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- A lively wrangle took place in the House today when Representative Treadway of Massachusetts renewed his attack on Secretary Wallace, and reiterated his statement that the head of the Department of Agriculture should be impeached for characterizing the Supreme Court's processing tax decision as "the greatest legalized steal in history."

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 4. -- Despite warnings from foreign Olympic committees and their own apparent good intentions, the Nazis here appear incapable of abandoning political propaganda in connection with the Winter Olympics.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,815,550 barrels, compared with 2,820,500 in the preceding week, a decrease of 4,950 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 10,800 and 5,600 barrels, respectively, in Oklahoma and California, and an increase of 9,650 in Louisiana were the important changes.

The firm of F.B. Hallock, Inc., formerly Hallock Brothers, Inc., of East Williston, L. I., has taken offices in the Chamber ofm [ Commerce Building, Jamaica, and will coni tinue in general real estate and insurance business.

A CRACKER-BARREL book called "The Movies on Trial" (Macmillan, $2.50) has been compiled and edited by William J. Perlman. Mr. Perlman asked studio executives to join the symposium, but after a long run around and many promises the book went to press without their chapters. Most of the nineteen contributors who came in before the dead line want movie reform.

Ratifying their 1936 schedule and electing Sam Breadon, owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, vice president, the club owners of the National League concluded their Winter legislative deliberations yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria by announcing their staff of twelve umpires and laying plans for commemorating the sixtieth anniversary of the circuit's existence.

A policeman, off duty and wearing civilian clothes, entered the Park Lane Pharmacy, 1,716 First Avenue, at the southeast corner of Eighty-ninth Street, at 9:30 o'clock last night to buy some cough medicine for one of his four children, unwittingly interrupted a hold-up by two young thugs, shot and killed one of them and raced two blocks in pursuit of the other, who escaped with $6.
BERLIN, Wednesday, Feb. 5. -- The assassination of Wilhelm Gustloff has created a sensation in Germany which has crowded all other events into the background.

The city of Rochester, N.Y., awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,000,000 of public welfare bonds to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at 100.3865 for 1 1/4s. The bonds are dated Feb. 1, 1936, and will mature serially from Feb. 1, 1937 to 1941.

The Yankee Stadium, described as "the house that Ruth built," will be considerably enlarged this year despite the fact that the one-time mighty Babe is no longer about to pack thousands into the famous arena.

The Bijou Theatre was caught last evening in another bit of dalliance with the Drama. "The Sap Runs High" was the name she gave, and comedy her description; but she was no shy offspring of the Barries of this writing world. For H.T. Porter and Alfred Henri White captured their plot from that chapter headed The Swindler Swindled; or, The Stock Manipulator's Defeat.

PARIS, Feb. 4. -- France and Great Britain hope to give League of Nations members a "bigger stick," lest Adolf Hitler profit in Europe as Benito Mussolini is trying to do in Africa, semi-official sources said tonight.

A total of 1,302,080 tons of merchant shipping were launched last year by the shipyards of the world, representing a gain of 334,661 tons, or about 35 per cent, over the 1934 total of 967,419 tons, according to the annual report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday.

Colorful costumes worn by Metropolitan Opera stars in some of their famous roles went on exhibition yesterday afternoon at a special showing arranged by the Metropolitan Opera Guild at the Fifth Avenue Branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, Fifth Avenue land Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- President Roosevelt at his press conference today noted the reversal of the flow of gold to this country. He declined extended comment on this movement, but remarked that the export shipments were doing this country no harm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave a luncheon today for fifty guests, among whom were wives of Ambassadors, Ministers, members of the Cabinet and others in and out of official circles in the capital.

The need for coordination between the various groups engaged in recreational and social activities was emphasized yesterday morning by Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse, national director of Girl Scouts, Inc., who spoke at the eleventh annual meeting of the Girl Scouts Council of Manhattan at its headquarters, 670 Lexington Avenue.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4. -- The Paraguayan Government has formally charged Colonel Rafael Franco, its most prominent Chaco war hero, with being a Communist and has ordered him deported to Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- To understand why Governor Landon of Kansas has, in the opinion of most Republican politicians, quickly taken the lead over all aspirants for his party's Presidential nomination, it is necessary first to recall the extent of the Democratic landslides of 1932 and 1934.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 4. -- This year, for the first time in Yale athletic history, the major Y was awarded to members of the soccer team, it was announced today. The board of control of the athletic association of the university took the action because the team went undefeated and untied throughout the season and won the Intercollegiate League championship.

The Commercial Credit Corporation reported yesterday that the gross volume of its business and its net income in 1935 exceeded those of any previous year in its history. Net income from operations, after deducting Federal and other taxes, was $7,800,133, compared with $5,391,133 for 1934.

Mayor La Guardia intervened again yesterday in the deadlock between the Building Service Employes Union and realty owners and forced resumption of negotiations in his efforts to avert the threatened strike of 20,000 elevator operators and other service workers in 1,200 buildings in the garment and fur area.

An exhibition called "The Textbook of the Future and Its Forerunners" will open tomorrow and continue through Feb. 28 at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. The exhibition was arranged by an executive committee of the American Institute of Graphic Arts, headed by Melbert B. Cary Jr.

The New York University quintet will return to the basketball wars tonight when the unbeaten Violet seeks its twentieth straight victory against rugged St. John's at Madison Square Garden in the feature battle of the seventh of the college court double-headers.

New York skidded and slipped over ice-glazed sidewalks and streets yesterday morning and by lunch time sloshed through a coating of thick brown slush. For the first time in twelve days the temperature rose above freezing point, and streets and sidewalks that had not been cleared were covered with crumbling ice and puddles.

The pre-opening performance of the play "Fresh Fields," by Ivor Novello, tomorrow night at the Empire Theatre will be the annual benefit of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, which in past years has sponsored the Rainbow Ball. Many have subscribed to the performance which has been taken over by a committee, of which Mrs. George S. Steele is chairman.

The State Mortgage Commission announced yesterday that it was preparing to "pay off immediately in cash in full with interest" the holders of $1,367,000 in guaranteed mortgage certificates known as issue No. 205,364, under a mortgage guaranteed by the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 4 (AP). -- Torrential rains and melting snow flooded streams in the South today, adding six deaths to a Winter toll of two score lives.

William L. Ransom, president of the American Bar Association, lamented last night the effect of taxation in tending toward "the cruel destruction of the sources from which private charities and praiseworthy institutions were maintained without the aid of government.''

After displaying patience enough to make Job feel envious, the New York Federal Theatre Project raised the curtain on its first legitimate production last evening, "Walk Together Chillun," which was acted at the Lafayette Theatre in Harlem.

The second and last of the Yorkville dinner dances for this season was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, drawing a large attendance of members of society, many of whom are actively interested in the Yorkville Community Center, beneficiary of the dance.

TORONTO, Feb. 4. -- The combined cost of Federal, State and local governments in the United States now demands so great a proportion of the total national income that it has discouraged business, threatened the security of wages and savings and therefore definitely retarded re-employment, Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared today.
PARIS, Feb. 4. -- As they progress it becomes apparent that the diplomatic conversations now proceeding in Paris will mark an important change in the direction of French international policy.

ROME, Feb. 4. -- The Fascist Grand Council at the end of a two and a half hour session tonight and after listening for more than an hour to a detailed report by Premier Benito Mussolini on Italy's present situation, approved several motions emphatically stating Italy's determination to go straight ahead with her East African war, whatever the consequences may be and despite any measures the League of Nations may adopt to stop her.
Long Island University's undefeated basketball team went on a scoring rampage to crush the East Stroudsburg State Teachers quintet, 69 to 35, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

Richard Boyd Ayer, member of the New York Stock Exchange and son of Dr. and Mrs. James C. Ayer of this city, died yesterday morning at the Doctors Hospital after several days' illness from septicaemia. He was 37 years old.

Five armed men held up Charles Froessel, former First Assistant District Attorney of Queens County, in his law office on the seventh floor of a building at 161-19 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, shortly before midnight last night, and after binding him and a watchman in the basement, they methodically ransacked four offices in the building.

Interest manifested by Old Guard Republicans and Al Smith in the platforms and philosophies of the Socialist party is vastly encouraging to those of us who have been laboring in the vineyard these many years in a sometimes disheartening endeavor to educate the masses.

The audience, of impressive proportions, which attended the concert given by the Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, had the pleasurable experience of a program which did not follow the hackneyed ways of most choral societies and conductors, and which introduced important and, in this city, previously unknown music.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

All the New York Rangers could get out of their game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night was a tie. Despite the herculean efforts of Cecil Dillon, who scored three goals, and the fact that they were never headed, the New Yorkers, nevertheless, had to be content with a 4-to-4 deadlock with the tenacious Detroit sextet.

Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw gave a tea yesterday at her home, 13 East Sixty-ninth Street, for heads of various teams and women working toward the success of the $150,000 campaign to aid the New York Association of Community and Settlement Music Schools.

Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times," the comedian's first picture in almost five years, will have its premiere tonight at the Rivoli Theatre before an audience that will include scores of persons prominent in the screen, theatrical and newspaper worlds.

Ten years ago the artificial production of radium E -- one of a whole family of radiums -- was not only impossible but inconceivable. But in our own day Dr. JOHN J. LIVINGOOD of the University of California hurls a neutron at bismuth, jams it into the nucleus, and the world learns that a natural radioactive element has been created in the laboratory for the first time.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Los Angeles police shut the Southern California border against vagrants today amid criticism from the City Council and jibes from Arizona.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- President Roosevelt ordered a survey of Federal credit agencies with view to canceling at least $1,000,000,000 in authorizations for lending.
BOSTON, Feb. 4. -- Former Governor Ely will seek the election of an anti-Roosevelt Massachusetts delegation to the Democratic National Convention, he declared today.
PORTSMOUTH, England, Feb. 4. -- The next America's Cup challenger may have British naval officers among its crew.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4. -- A strike of mechanical department employes oil the Laclede Gas Light Company last Spring cost the company $334,434, a report to stockholders revealed today. The expenditure, charged against surplus, was made, the report said, for "guarding plants and properties, payments to service agencies, feeding and housing men at plants, "
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Further delay in the enactment of permanent neutrality legislation appeared probable today.

The second of a series of four appeals in verse by August Heckscher for aid in alleviating the hardships of the needy during the cold spell was made public yesterday by the Heckscher Foundation for Children, 1 East 104th Street.

PARIS, Feb. 4. -- Although there were some fluctuations in the prices of French industrial securities, the Bourse today remained firm and active. Rentes rose strongly on receipt of buying orders from the public and not, as often happens, as a result of official intervention.
Three chain-store organizations issued yesterday financial statements for 1935.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Eight additional registration statements for the issue of securities valued at $24,239,471 have been filed under the Securities Act of 1933 with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The increase in margin requirements that became effective on last Saturday under the regulations of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System applies to all margin accounts, but brokers are not required to obtain margin on the new basis on commitments made prior to last Saturday, it was explained yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Your editorial "Penalizing Opinions" exhibits clearly why civil rights are endangered. The thought of a mother being torn from her children makes it easy to overlook the fact that a father has some claim to consideration, and that it will always be possible for constitutional rights of different persons to conflict.

Many of the churches in the United States and the British Isles are celebrating this week the 100th anniversary of the birth of Dwight L. Moody, who was born on Feb. 6, 1836. Moody was unquestionably the greatest evangelist of his generation, and it is doubtful if there ever was a greater in the history of our country.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Mrs. Edith Liggett tonight defied Governor Olson to name "the politicians who incited me to make the statements about him that I did."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The population of the United States in 1935 was officially estimated by the Census Bureau today at 127,521,000. The official count was taken as of July 1.

Three hundred guests attended the tea given by the New York Genealogical and Historical Society yesterday afternoon for members of the Society of Colonial Wars in New York, which shares the society's building at 124 East Fifty-eighth Street.

The Duke and Duchess of Marlborough, Brig. Gen. Dr. G. Crile and Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, are among the passengers due today from England and France on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic. Others on board are:

Samples of tea from Far Eastern countries "passed in review" yesterday before members of the United States Board of Tea Experts, assembled at the Appraisers Stores, 201 Varick Street, to determine the standard quality of imports in that product for a year beginning May 1.

The formation of a symphony orchestra in Palestine, composed mainly of residents or former residents of Germany who are unable to obtain work in that country, was disclosed yesterday afternoon by Bronislaw Huberman, prominent Polish violinist.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP). -- The nudist schooner Fleetwood, bound eventually for the Virgin Islands to set up a colony, put back into port here tonight with the announcement that her early navigatorless wanderings were just a trial trip.

The use of wash dresses for every occasion during the day was impressively demonstrated at a fashion revue staged under the auspices of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 4. -- Coming within a single stroke of equaling the women's course record, Miss Patty Berg, 17-year-old Minneapolis star and runner-up to Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare for the national title last year, annexed the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Miami Biltmore golf championship today.
GENEVA, Feb. 4. -- Italy began accumulating oil reserves in 1934, according to figures brought out at today's meetings of experts who are studying the proposed League of Nations oil sanctions.

The twenty-one labor unions now in conference with the managements on the protection of employes in railway unifications seek the preservation of the safeguards provided in such cases by the present law, George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, said yesterday.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 4. -- An important and intensely interesting loan exhibition dedicated to "Rembrandt and His Circle" opened with a private view this evening in the Worcester Art Museum. Beginning tomorrow, and until March 1, the oils, drawings and prints may be enjoyed by the public.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 4 (AP). -- M. Bransfield's 4-year-old brown filly, Aunt Myrtle, a long shot, won the fifth race, the featured Hotel Lanier event at Alamo Downs today. The time for the five and a half furlongs was 1:042-5 on a track slowed by large clods of mud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- President Roosevelt today ordered a check-up of all Federal credit agencies with a view to canceling at least $1,000,000,000 in unused lending authorizations voted by Congress during his three-year drive for relief and recovery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Adoption by Congress of legislation raising taxation on gifts, effective on Jan. 1 last, resulted in about $85,000,000 of equity securities being distributed as gifts by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations before that date, according to reports on transactions by such persons made to the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public today.

The sharp reductions in direct relief when employables were transferred to WPA rolls has resulted in "shocking examples of suffering and hardships relief families ineligible for WPA assignment throughout the country," it was reported yesterday by the American Association of Social Workers.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- With the Democrats voting solidly in opposition, the Assembly passed today the bill of Assemblyman Moffat, New York Republican, eliminating primary elections in districts where there are no contests. The vote was 80 to 68.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4. -- The road still leads to this city for operatic novelty. While Rimsky-Korsakoff's music is scarcely new to our ears, the opera performed here tonight had never been done in this country, according to available records.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4. -- Mrs. Rogers Dunn of New York was the first to advance to the quarterfinal round of the women's national squash racquets singles championship on the Merion Cricket Club courts today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- Wheat prices on the Board of Trade held within a range of around 5/8 cent a bushel today and while there was scattered selling early on relative weakness in Liverpool, a late rally left prices unchanged to 1/8 cent higher than those of yesterday, the latter on July.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The Works Progress Administration of New York State will spend $100,000 on social rehabilitation of prisoners in five correctional institutions.
PEKIN, Ill., Feb. 4. -- National Guardsmen, ready for riot duty, were massed in near-by Peoria to night after a general strike stopped most union labor activity in this city of 17,000 persons.

Declines were numerous in active trading on local commodity futures markets yesterday. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, eggs and antimony gained, while cotton, rubber, silk, cocoa and tin declined.
While New York was experiencing its first thaw since Jan. 22, with accompanying sleet and slush, yesterday, weather ranging from polar cold to floods and gales gripped other parts of the country.

WASHIHGTON, Feb. 4. -- A plan whereby Great Britain and France could pay to the United States $6,000,000,000 on account of their war debts to help this country finance payments of the veterans' adjusted service compensation and agricultural benefits to the farmers was suggested to the Senate today by Senator J. Hamilton Lewis.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5. -- In a direct attack on the American Liberty League, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, tonight termed that group "the center and soul of the predatory powers."

Throngs of men and women jammed the block in front of the Rivoli Theatre on Broadway last night in a tumultuous first-night demonstration at the return of Charlie Chaplin to the screen after an absence of five years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- A prediction that a recommendation on neutrality legislation would be made to the Senate next week came from Senator Pittman today as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee pressed forward with hearings.

With the strike machinery set for action in the threatened walkout of 105,000 dressmakers, Mayor La Guardia intervened yesterday for the third time in a fortnight in a final effort to avert the tie-up, which would paralyze the entire dress market of New York and vicinity.

Many dinners will be given tonight in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador in connection with the dinner dance for the benefit of the Neighborhood Guilds, an organization which cooperates with the Home Relief and various philanthropic enterprises to aid needy families.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt was ordered yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley to pay for cigarettes, mineral waters and cosmetics, which were "plainly intended for the personal use of the mother and her guests."

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- Apprehension of damage to the Winter wheat crop by continued low temperatures and lack of adequate snow protection over a large area in the Southwest resulted today in a somewhat larger speculative trade in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 5. -- A.R. Graustein, former president of the International Power and Paper Company, today continued negotiations for the Gatineau Power Company with the Ontario Hydroelectric Power Commission in an effort to obtain a new contract for Gatineau.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Following a mass demonstration in protest against the general strike here, Monterrey residents today telegraphed to President Lazaro Cardenas a pledge of "absolute support."
The draw for the annual midwinter indoor polo tournament of the New York Athletic Club, to be played at the 105th Field Artillery Armory starting Saturday night, was announced yesterday.

The contract bridge team of F.D. Kaplan, Harry Fishbein, Irving Epstein and C.C. Vogelhofer won the Douglas W. Paige Trophy of the new Atlantic National bridge championships last night, defeating a team led by Mrs. Ely Culbertson by 340 points in a see-saw final match of sixty-four hands at Crockford's Club, 14 East Sixty-second Street.

Baseball's most unusual training junket will be inaugurated when Manager Charles (Chuck) Dressen of the Cincinnati Reds leads the vanguard of his team up the gangplank of the S.S. Borinquen at Pier 15 at 3 o'clock this afternoon to start the long haul to San Juan, P.R., where the National Leaguers will do their conditioning before going to their regular camp in Tampa, Fla.

The rubber-like flexibility of the New York University winning streak was demonstrated once more last night as the Violet, tested to the limit by St. John's, came through with a rousing rally in the final half to vanquish the Redmen at basketball, 28 to 23.

The evolution of "beautiful" American books from the early days of the Eighteen Nineties, when two pioneer book publishers sought to make commercial editions of best sellers attractive, to the elaborately designed volumes of today, is shown in a public exhibit in the Low Memorial Library of Columbia University.

Thomas McFarland, 38 years old, who was accused of strangling to death his 18-year-old niece and his 60-year-old mother-in-law in their Brooklyn home on March 31 last, was convicted by a jury before County Judge Fitzgerald in Brooklyn yesterday of first-degree murder.

PARIS. Feb. 5. -- French rentes continued to improve today and held the center of interest in the stock market. There were renewed rumors of the possibility of a British loan or credit, and at any rate financial circles seem to be convinced that there will be no further call for long-term money in the near future here.

The French liner Lafayette, arriving late tonight from Havre via Southampton, will be the first of the company's ships to dock at the new pier, 88 North River, since the line vacated its old pier, 57 North River, last Monday. Among her passengers are Mrs. Walter Abell; Marise Querlain, French journalist; Jean Jouanet, Alexander Fisher, Jean Bouchard, Dr. F. Battle, Charles Huard and Mrs. Huard, Charles Schwartz and Wesley Russell Johns, actor.

After almost a year in the courts, Burns Brothers, the New Jersey coal corporation with subsidiaries here, won the approval yesterday of Federal Judge Robert P. Paterson to reorganize its interests under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5. -Inaugurating the series of five weekly talks comprising the program of the current events series was the lecture today on "The European Whirlwind" by Cecil Edric Mornington Roberts, novelist and biographer, in the music room of the Everglades.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- Limited arrivals of hogs today forced buyers to pay as much as 25 cents a hundredweight more than yesterday for desirable weights. The top price rose 20 cents to $10.85. Weights under 230 pounds were in demand, while extremely heavy kinds and sows were disposed to drag with some sales little better than steady.
PEKIN, Ill., Feb. 5. -- Union labor, united in a general strike, took complete command tonight of this paralyzed city of 17,000 persons.

The two have been made by MUSSOLINI to go hand in hand ever since the beginning of his campaign in Ethiopia. While pushing the war in Africa he has steadily sought to strengthen or secure his position in Europe. On the whole, his diplomacy has been fairly successful up to a recent time.
