TOKYO, Feb. 5. -- The general election campaign now in full blast is colorless and devoid of major or clear-cut issues and it gives no promise of an early resuscitation of party government. The parties' weakness is indicated by the fact that though the entire political history of the past four years constitutes a challenge to parliamentary government, neither party dares take up the challenge directly.

IT was some months ago that General Charles H. Sherrill, member of the International Olympic Committee, debarked from an ocean liner and delivered a short speech on the participation of the United States in the Olympic Games of 1936. Detonating replies were not long in coming. Cannon to right of him, cannon to left of him, volleyed and thundered.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy directed the District Attorney yesterday to try Vera Stretz for the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt within thirty days. If this is not done, Justice Levy will entertain an application for her release on bail.

Increased interest in poultry raising as a result of the cooperation of the various groups engaged in this industry was predicted yesterday by James E. Rice, president of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council, whose members are conducting the current poultry exposition in Commerce Hall of the Port Authority Building at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Discovery of a narcotic so powerful that its manufacture has been prohibited was disclosed today in a report of hearings before a House appropriations subcommittee.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Measures for placing the administration of unemployment relief in the State on a permanent basis under the Department of Social Welfare were discussed this evening at a conference at the Executive Mansion between Governor Lehman and leaders of the Legislature and some officials identified with relief work.
EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 5. -- A scientific eye which is blind to everything but the invisible rays that cause sunburn was set on the trail of the common cold tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5. -- Scotch Bun, A.G. Vanderbilt's stablemate of Discovery, finished a nose ahead of Thursday today in the mile and one-sixteenth Magnolia Handicap at Santa Anita for a purse of $1,200. Tick On was third. The time was 1:441-5.

Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, American member of the International Olympic Committee, was the luncheon host to more than a score of sports writers yesterday at the Yale Club on the eve of the opening of the fourth Winter Olympic Games at Garmisch-Partenkirchen.

A racket in the butter and egg industry, which receives $24,000,000 a year from buyers in New York, was charged yesterday in an anti-trust indictment returned by a Federal grand jury against seventeen defendants, including Local 202 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers of America.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Today it was the turn of the Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., a 95,000,000 dye-stuffs and explosives organization, to clear itself of charges that it was an armament firm busily fomenting future wars.

Recognition of the motion picture as an independent art equal to the theatre was the keynote set by critics yesterday as more than 500 men and women delegates from all parts of the country gathered for the twelfth annual conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 5 (AP). -- The danger of strained relations between Switzerland and Germany was believed lessened tonight, with the police here satisfied that David Frankfurter, the confessed assassin of Wilhelm Gustloff, leader of Switzerland's Nazis, was not a Swiss citizen.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5. -- Professor George Lyman Kittredge, since 1894 Gurney Professor of English Literature at Harvard, will resign in September.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The administration's stop-gap farm relief program, based on soil conservation with benefit payments, was "rewritten" by the Senate Committee on Agriculture late today and put in position to be taken up on the floor tomorrow.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- The German Government announced today that Baron von Weizaecker, the German Minister to Switzerland, had called on Giuseppe Motta, vice president of the Swiss Federal Council and head of its Foreign Affairs Department, and had demanded in the name of his government a strict investigation of the assassination of Wilhelm Gustloff, German leader of the Nazis in Switzerland, by a Jewish medical student of Yugoslav nationality at Davos yesterday.

The Belding Heminway Company, silk manufacturers, announced yesterday that its net profit in 1935, after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, was $542,536, equal to $1.16 a share on 465,032 no-par capital shares, compared with $495,984, or $1.06 a share, in 1934. For the quarter ended on Dec. 31 its profit, after similar charges but before Federal taxes, was $202,000, against a profit of $147,410 in the same quarter of the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The District Supreme Court was asked today by the Railroad Retirement Board to dismiss the suit brought by 135 major railroad companies testing the constitutionality of 1935 railroad retirement legislation.

Following an investigation of the recently adopted practice of fingerprinting building service and hotel employes, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday that he would recommend to Governor Lehman and the Legislature consideration of legislation to make fingerprinting and the keeping of fingerprint files an exclusive function of governmental agencies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Percy Tetlow, labor member of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, warned the convention of the United Mine Workers of America today that their present wage structure and working conditions would be endangered in a "crisis" following within ninety days an adverse decision of the Supreme Court on the Guffey Coal and Conservation Act.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 5. -- Miss Patty Berg, 17-year-old Minneapolis star, and Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews, formerly of Englewood, N.J., but now residing in Miami, the two outstanding favorites, scored easy victories in the first round of the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship today.

Governor LEHMAN is fortunate in being able to find so well qualified a man as EDWARD P. MULROONEY to take the place of the late WALTER N. THAYER Jr. as State Commissioner of Correction. Mr. MULROONEY'S experience as Police Commissioner of New York and as chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board will stand him in good stead in his new position.

The National Committee on Safety at Sea will exert its efforts to obtain ratification of the international convention for safety of life at sea by the United States Senate despite the opposition of organized maritime labor, it was announced yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Advisers studying the housing problem for President Roosevelt decided today to recommend a nation-wide, low-cost program based on cheap Federal loans to local communities.

Field goals by Bob Crist and Bob Baumann in the final two and a half minutes gave St. John's Prep of Brooklyn a 21-to-18 victory over La Salle Academy of Manhattan in Madison Square Garden yesterday after St. Francis Prep, another Brooklyn school, had beaten Xavier High, also of Manhattan, by 18 to 12 in the opening game of a non-league scholastic basketball double-header.

ON BOARD THE WYATT EARP, in the Antarctic, Feb. 4. -- Sweeping aside the rough pack ice for the last time this season, the Wyatt Earp, Lincoln Ellsworth's supply ship, at 8 o'clock this morning swung her head toward Valparaiso, Chile.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Evidence that many Italian seamen prefer the shores of the United States to those of their native land -- or perhaps are avoiding the heat of Ethiopia -- was contained in reports of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Large purchases of airplanes, machine guns and bombs, amounting in all to more than $3,000,000, were shown by State Department figures today to have been made in the United States by China during January.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- A new era in wild life conservation dawned today as 1,200 men and women from the forty-eight States forgot past differences and joined forces in a common cause.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Despite recent tremendous increases in the public debt, interest in the next fiscal year will increase only $63,000,000 as a result of Treasury operations, the House Committee on Appropriations revealed today in reporting the Treasury and Postoffice Departments' Appropriation Bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- A suggestion of "fresh negotiations" as the only possible way to "reach an equitable agreement" on war debts of European nations owing the United States was put forward by Thomas W. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co. today at the Senate munitions inquiry into wartime financing.

Sir Herbert Samuel and Viscount Bearsted sailed for England last night on the Majestic, confident that they could rely on the united support of the Jews of this country in financing the emigration from Germany of 100,000 Jews between the ages of 17 and 35.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Four policemen testified today in the defense of Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld, as counsel for the former bootlegger attempted to shatter Mrs. Edith Liggett's identification of Blumenfeld as the slayer of her husband, Walter Liggett.
ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- A program of flood control, based upon the experiences of last year in the southern tier, was pushed ahead today in the Legislature.

Difficulties in dealing with Italy are increasing daily as the stress of wartime conditions makes itself felt in that nation's trade with the United States, exporters said yesterday at the regular round-table conference on foreign trade held at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the foreign interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.
The text of the Seabury-Berle letter replying to the Transit Commission's criticism of the unification plan follows:

The charge that Federal Jobholders from Rockland County, N.Y., appointed by Postmaster General James A. Farley, have been forced to give one month's salary to the Rockland County Democratic campaign fund for use in the coming Presidential election was made yesterday afternoon by Miss Natalie F. Couch of Nyack, former Republican candidate for Representative at Large.

Mayor LA GUARDIA has been accustomed to treat the Transit Commission in cavalier fashion. Early in his administration he prevailed on the Board of Estimate to refuse to honor its requisition for salaries, with the result that its staff had to go for a while without pay.

Charges of politics and neglect of official duty in rapid transit unification were hurled at the Transit Commission yesterday by Samuel Seabury and A.A. Berle Jr., City Chamberlain, whose working draft of a unity plan was recently sent to the State board, without commitment, by the Board of Estimate.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Ten measures designed to aid law enforcement and the prosecution of criminals were hurried through the Senate today and sent on their way to the Assembly. They would make drastic changes in the present Criminal Law.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 5. -- The Dartmouth basketball team was defeated tonight by Syracuse, 40 to 30. The Green trailed throughout the entire game.

Urging a public drive for ratification of the Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution, Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the United States Children's Bureau, said last night that there was a 58 per cent increase in employment certificates issued to children of 14 and 15 years of age in 129 cities in twenty-nine States in the seven months after the Schechter decision voiding the NRA, as compared with the year 1934.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Clear appreciation of the present campaign in Ethiopia has been much retarded because the normal fog of war has been increased both geographically and artificially. That fog has never been more opaque than in the past few weeks.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- The British naval delegation renewed its efforts today to solve the difficulties created by French insistence on a 27,000-ton limit for battleships.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5. -- The Ministry of Agriculture announced today that Argentina's exportable surplus of corn yesterday was 78,062,800 bushels. The statement was issued to refute market estimates that the country still had between 157,000,000 and 177,000,000 bushels on hand.

City College will begin its eighty-eighth academic year as a free institution of higher learning today when more than 8,000 undergraduates will return to classes for the Spring semester. Among the divisions of the college opening are the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, the School of Business and Civic Administration and the School of Technology.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Reports that business was improving and that the banking situation was "excellent" accompanied the appropriation bill for the Treasury and Postoffice Departments when it was ushered into the House today.

Prices of most commodity futures continued to decline on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Coffee, rubber and silk were strong. The volume of trading was about normal. On the cash markets the grains, butter, eggs and rubber advanced, while raw sugar, lard, cotton, tin, silk and cocoa declined.

New York City will sell serial bonds for $19,500,000 on Monday to provide funds for the purchase of 500 additional steel cars for the municipal subway system, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Inflation agitation became of much less concern to Congressional leaders today after new signs from the White House enabled them to regain their former confidence that no special taxes would be demanded at this session for prepayment of the veterans' bonus.

Reports from London indicating that the House of Commons plans passage of a bill providing for the retirement of obsolete textile machinery point the way for a constructive program for the textile industry here, Peter Van Horn, president of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., declared in a statement issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Treasury was concerned over the large imports of gold that had been coming into the United States from foreign countries and would be glad to see some of it going back, because the government had an abundance of gold for all credit purposes, George C. Haas, director of the department's Bureau of Research and Statistics, testified last December before a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee.

The market value of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased $3,218,965,497 in January to a total of $50,164,547,052, the Exchange announced yesterday. At the same time borrowings by members of the Exchange on security collateral declined from 2 to 1.84 per cent, brokers loans totaling $924,704,335 on Jan. 31, compared with $938,441,652 on Dec. 31.

Dr. George W. Crile, one of the foremost American surgeons and investigators of the phenomena of life, returned yesterday on the Majestic after a wild-game hunt in Africa, not for glory but for glands.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5. -- The Philadelphia Award for 1935 was presented tonight to Francis Fisher Kane, attorney, and leader in the Public Defender movement here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Senator Borah's decision to test his strength as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President in the pivotal State of Ohio has upset the calculations of Hoover men and "Old Guard" leaders in that State.
LOUISVILLE, Feb. 5. -- Compulsory military training was denounced today by the executive board of the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods, closing its annual two-day meeting here.
Value of Dollar In Exchange. The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 5. -- Public subsidy is necessary to provide adequate housing, as one-third of the population in this country is not able to pay for "satisfactory" living quarters, Dr. Charles-Edward A. Winslow, Professor of Public Health at Yale School of Medicine, told 600 persons in the Orange High School here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The forthcoming cancellation by the President of probably "more than a billion" in the unused credits of government loaning agencies may be the precursor of an official announcement to Congress at this session that the emergency is ended.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5. -- Soviet foreign trade showed a decline in both exports and imports last year, according to complete figures for 1935 just made public by Custom House authorities.

The State off California will consider bids for a new issue of $5,000,000 of veteran welfare bonds on March 12. The bonds will be payable from 1938 to 1954, and will carry a 2 3/4 per cent interest rate.

The threat of a strike of 20,000 elevator operators and other building service workers in 1,200 buildings in the garment and fur area was definitely removed yesterday as a result of an agreement brought about through the intervention of Mayor La Guardia.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 5 (AP). -- America retained the international Lakes Cup trophy today when a picked team of professionals defeated a group of golfers from Australia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The House Immigration Committee today held its annual hearing on the question of putting a protective embargo on imports of foreign actors and bridegrooms.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Edward P. Mulrooney, former New York City Police Commissioner, was appointed State Commissioner of Correction by Governor Lehman today, filling the vacancy caused by the death of Dr. Walter N. Thayer. The appointment, which came as a surprise, was immediately confirmed by the Senate.

Senator BORAH, a true progressive, subject to occasional turns of walking backward, is going ahead in his war against the monopolists and reactionaries. He has thrown off something of his coyness. To the general surprise, he has declared his willingness to be a candidate in Ohio.

A reunion of all the churches in Christendom, both Catholic and Protestant, is not only needed but is inevitable, because separations and divisions are resulting in spiritual losses, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday afternoon in the last of a series of Epiphany lectures at St. Bartholomew's Church Community House, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Some isolationists are much more likable than others. There are the isolationists who are always washing their hands of everything outside the immediate family circle and simply have no interest in what goes on in the world.

Pig iron production last month, according to The Iron Age, declined 3.8 per cent from December, having averaged 65,351 tons daily. Only 117 stacks were making iron on Feb. 1, compared with 120 one month before; but the difficulty of securing water shipments of coal and coke by river because of ice in the Pittsburgh district may have influenced recent operations.

Columbia's basketball team returned to action last night after a three-week lay-off and defeated Pratt Institute, 39 to 28, on the Morningside Heights court. There were flaws in the Blue's attack but it managed to click for a few minutes at a time and brought to Pratt the first defeat the Brooklyn quintet has suffered in five games.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Feb. 5. -- Fire, believed set by boys in retaliation for school discipline, caused $2,000 damage a little after noon today to St. Boniface's Roman Catholic Church at Glen and Carpenter Avenues here.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- With its official life due to expire in ten days, the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Public Utilities today subjected Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, to three hours of examination chiefly as to the reasons for the long delays in the commission's decision in rate cases.
It would appear that the plan of Governor Landon to help agriculture -- in reality to pay unearned bounties to farmers -- is just another "crackpot" proposal.

One of the three defense lawyers made an unsuccessful attempt to void the Drukman murder trial proceedings yesterday because, he asserted, his hitherto enforced absence from court had deprived his client of constitutional rights.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 6. -- Many rural districts of Japan are still isolated by the heavy snowfall of Tuesday. Reports of loss of life and damage to property are coming in, especially from the northern and northeastern regions, where the full force of the blizzard was felt.

Thirty-three members of the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing were graduated last night at the fifty-third annual commencement exercises in the Blumenthal Auditorium, Ninety-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue. Hugo Blumenthal, president of the Board of School Nursing, presided.

A more sympathetic and scientific approach to the problem of training and placing unadjusted and homeless women in employment was outlined yesterday by speakers at a luncheon at the Girls Service League, 138 East Nineteenth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's government turned a cold shoulder today against a proposal that it should do something definite to abate world friction by giving powers without colonies a fairer portion of raw materials, of which this country has the lion's share through its mandates and possessions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The best minds in the fields of fish and game research are discussing their problems this week at sessions in the Mayflower Hotel, headquarters for the North American Wild Life Conference. Unattended by fanfare, these meetings nevertheless are a vital part of the conference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Mrs. Michael J. Meehan was put on the witness stand today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to testify in the inquiry into alleged "rigging" of Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock by her husband.
][], S. Department of Agriculture. eat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 5. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman declared today that the new investigation of the Lindbergh kidnapping and murder would go on even after the execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann "if and when it takes place."
Business in money market continued quiet, being confined chiefly to routine transactions. Quotations remained unchanged.

The Normandie of the French Line will use the new 1,000-foot pier at the foot of West Forty-eighth Street for the next five years under the terms of a lease approved yesterday by the Sinking Fund Commission.

Mrs. Mae Scheible, who was arrested late Tuesday in an elaborately furnished apartment at 77 Park Avenue and who, according to an Assistant United States Attorney, made $80,000 in 1933 by operating expensive disorderly houses, was locked up last night in the House of Detention for Women, at Sixth and Greenwich Avenues, because she could not raise $6,500 bail.
ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Capitol Hill saw another flare-up today in the warfare between Governor Lehman and Republican leaders in the Legislature over the executive budget.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5. -- Taking the lead at the fifth hole, Grantland Rice of New York defeated Fontaine Fox of Manhasset, L.I., by 7 up and 5 to play in the second round of the ninth annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association today.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 5. -- The Senatorial toga of Huey P. Long was conferred today upon his widow by the State Central Committee, which, at its meeting in the Capitol here, clothed young Richard W. Leche, the Governor-designate, with plenipotentiary powers as the spokesman for Louisiana Democrats in State and national affairs.

A return of below freezing temperatures, after the thaw of Tuesday, left sidewalks and roadways glazed with ice in the city yesterday, with a resulting slowing of traffic and more accidents caused by slipping.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 5. -- Bucknell University observed the ninetieth anniversary tonight of the granting of its original charter with a nation-wide series of charter day dinners, and a coast-to-coast broadcast from a similar affair in New York City.

Conferences between a committee for the managements and the Railway Labor Executives Association on the protection of employes in railway unifications and coordinations were adjourned yesterday for about ten days. In this time it is hoped to lay the ground for an agreement satisfactory to both sides.

The devout assembled, again in large numbers, when Artur Schnabel dispensed the gospel according to Beethoven last night in Carnegie Hall. This was the fourth of the seven programs he will give, on successive Wednesday nights, of the piano sonatas of the master.

Attempting to show the complete domination of the Pennsylvania Railroad over the Long Island Railroad, George H. Stover, chief counsel of the Transit Commission, concentrated his attack yesterday on the valuation of the railroads' joint facilities and the accounting methods of the Long Island, at another hearing on that road's application for an increase in commutation rates.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 5. -- Apparently largely with a view to restricting the competition of trucks with the railroads, the Canadian Customs Department has abolished the bonding of truckloads from the Canadian border to interior customs warehouses in Toronto, Montreal and other large cities.

Aiming at another sharp increase in sales volume for this month, sales agents for electrical appliance manufacturers are soliciting early orders for regular and Spring sales merchandise from retailers and jobbers this week. The month just closed, producers said, was the most satisfactory January experienced in six years on both the low-end and medium-price merchandise.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5 (AP). -- In a bluntly worded address, Joseph B. Eastman charged railroad executives tonight with responsibility for delaying the government's policies for coordination of railroad transportation.

Beginning Monday, Feb. 10, the Cloisters, the branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at 698 Fort Washington Avenue, will be closed to the public preparatory to the removal of the collections to the building being erected for them in Fort Tryon Park, it was announced yesterday by Herbert E. Winlock, director of the museum.
Bat Battalino, former world's featherweight champion, displayed some of his old-time fighting fury last night to defeat Brescia Garcia of Mexico in the ten-round feature bout at the Star Casino.

Perhaps unwisely, but certainly with the best of intentions, I have been training my history class of eighth-grade boys and girls to read and bring in for discussion the governmental and political news as it appears in the daily papers. We devote one day a week to the study of this material instead of the textbook.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- Employers who remember that their workers are individuals and treat with them frankly to adjust grievances need have little fear of having to deal with them collectively as members of a striking union, Whiting Williams, Cleveland industrial consultant, declared today.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- The problem of the so-called Polish Corridor, which separates East Prussia from the rest of Germany, was emphasized anew tonight when the German Government issued detailed instructions designed to meet the drastic reduction of German railway traffic through the Corridor ordered by the Polish State Railways, effective one minute after midnight tomorrow night.

Declaring that it will not discriminate against American jobbers or retailers who sell foreign-made machinery, the Federal Housing Administration has announced the policy of continuing to finance the purchase of foreign machinery under its modernization credit plan, Harry W. Pitt, attorney, said yesterday.

It is to be hoped that "Ding" (otherwise JAY N. DARLING, former chief of the Bureau of Biological Survey) will continue his sounding the bell in every community of the land in warning against the wasteful, wanton, selfish destruction of the wild life of America.

With Captain Robert Hower winning two events, New York University's varsity swimming team conquered Manhattan College yesterday, 49 to 22, in the Park Central pool. This was the first triumph for the Violet in three engagements this season. It was the losers' second setback in four meets.
The St. Francis College basketball team turned back the strong Columbus Council, K. of C., quintet, 29 to 20, on the victor's court last night. The Franciscans trailed at the intermission, 12 -- 10.

About a year ago a new Republican "star" appeared upon the horizon. Until then very few of us had ever heard of Governor Landon of Kansas. Suddenly the great publicity campaign started and it was discovered that we had in our midst a "miracle man," the one and only budget balancer.

Steel production has advanced this week to 52 per cent of capacity, the highest level so far this year, and is largely attributable to the buying of the railroads, which raised ingot output 1 1/2 points, according to the weekly summary by Iron Age.

The second "Manon" of the season was given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House with Richard Crooks appearing for the first time this season as Des Grieux. His presence was the fresh element in a cast which afforded an excellent presentation, and Mr. Crooks's singing constituted one of the finest performances he has given in the famous musical theatre.

A preliminary report of the Engineers Public Service Company for 1935, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $1,293,923, against $1,103,142 in 1934, a gain of $130,781. Annual preferred dividend requirements are $2,323,537.

ATHENS, Feb. 5. -- The fact that the chief Balkan States have been pledged to follow Great Britain in military sanctions against Italy in the name of the League of Nations has filled with apprehensive rumor the peoples of Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey.

An international picture of women, their status in various countries, and the advances they have made in economic fields and political expression was presented by professional Y.W.C.A. workers from the foreign field at the annual meeting of the foreign division of the association yesterday afternoon.

The committee acting for holders of preferred stock of the Pressed Steel Car Company announced yesterday that it had decided to appeal to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for a complete review of the proposed plan of reorganization for the company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretaries Morgenthau and Wallace, Attorney General Cummings and other officials concerning new taxes proposed to finance the farm program.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Farmers of wheat and corn States may take a tip from the invalidated AAA and continue to keep part of their land out of production, a survey indicated today.
UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- Curling competition got under way today in the Allen Medal play with Utica, the Country Club of Brookline, St. Andrews of New York and Schenectady winning first-round matches.

Before leaving for Albany to attend a meeting of the State Welfare Board, of which he is chairman, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator here, said yesterday that David Zwanziger, an engineer, 37 years old, employed by the WPA, would be dropped from the payroll if the facts in his case were as charged in a letter to Mr. Ridder from Pelham St. George Bissell, presiding justice of the municipal court.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- Archduke Otto's arrival in Paris today threw a new element for excited speculation into the involved diplomatic discussions that have attended the presence here of King Carol of Rumania, King Boris of Bulgaria, Prince Paul, chief Regent of Yugoslavia, and Vice Chancellor von Starhemberg of Austria, who are nearly all attended by one of their Ministers.
The credit of our city has been reestablished but the owners of the city have been discredited.

Revelation of President Roosevelt's plan to cancel some $1,000,000,000 of government appropriations authorized but not spent tended yesterday to dissipate "inflation" sentiment, marketwise. At any rate, there was an outcropping of profit-taking sales in the stock market, especially in the late trading, so that the closing was irregular, several important groups finishing lower on the day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Federal Communications Commission today ordered a rehearing of a case involving five Brooklyn radio stations.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- The stock markets today were generally quieter and irregular, with some profit-taking. British funds were supported and firmer and foreign bonds were slightly higher.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 5. -- Two Anglo-Canadian hockey players, James Foster and Alexander Archer, were expelled from the Winter Olympic Games tonight on the ground that they had been suspended from the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association after leaving Canada to play in England without the Canadian association's permission.

Unleashing a powerful offensive in the second half after leading by only 15 to 7 at the intermission, the Poly Prep basketball team crushed Riverdale, 42 to 18, at Poly in one of the outstanding metropolitan schoolboy games yesterday. Robert Jordan, with 14 markers, starred for the home squad.

It seems now that the Piscator-Goldschmidt version of "An American Tragedy" will not be seen on Broadway, though Milton Shubert clings to his option on it and the trade winds continue to whisper of an alliance between Mr. Shubert and the Group Theatre.

The Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers, for the last seven and one-half years pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Utica, N.Y., was installed last evening by the Presbytery of New York as pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

PEARL S. BUCK'S story of her mother, "The Exile" (John Day: Reynal Hitchcock, $2.50), has an infinite sadness about it of which the author herself may be only half-conscious. The book is the biography, done in terms of simple and moving fiction, of an American woman who married a man with a "call" to carry Christianity to the Chinese.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretaries Morgenthau and Wallace, Attorney General Cummings and other officials concerning new taxes proposed to finance the farm program.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Farmers of wheat and corn States may take a tip from the invalidated AAA and continue to keep part of their land out of production, a survey indicated today.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 5 (AP). -- The vote of the International Ice Hockey Federation tonight on the British players was unanimous. Three representatives abstained from voting.
John Masefield, who knew the city as "little old New York, built of brownstone and not quite filling the island on which it stands," left for home on the Majestic last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 5. -- Appointments and reassignments of cadet officers in the Princeton University R.O.T.C. Field Artillery unit for the coming term were issued here today by Lieut. Col. Roger S. Parrott, commander of the Princeton unit. Thirteen men received promotions and six were reassigned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Mrs. Roosevelt attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's musical morning at the Mayflower Hotel for the program given by Grete Stueckgold, soprano, and Charles Kullmann, tenor, of the Metropolitan Opera.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5. -- The one-mile Grade A handicap that headed today's eight-race program at Hialeah resulted in another victory for the silks of Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago, whose Corinto prevailed by three-quarters of a length in a drive with the gray mare, Coequel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- No comment was forthcoming from Democratic circles today on charges of Miss Natalie Couch, former Republican candidate for Representative at Large, that Federal jobholders in Rockland County, N.Y., were being forced to contribute a month's salary to the Democratic campaign fund in that county.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Joseph B. Ely, who put Alfred E. Smith in nomination for the Presidency in 1932, declared tonight that the "brain trusters would destroy Smith's influence with the American people and besmirch his reputation to achieve their own wild purposes."

Par results on the sixteen bridge hands which occupied some 202,000 people throughout sixty-three nations on Tuesday night in Ely Culbertson's World Bridge Olympic, were announced yesterday by the committee of nineteen experts who devised the hands.
Rowing practice at Columbia got under way officially yesterday when thirty-two varsity aspirants and sixteen freshmen reported to Coach Hubert Glendon.

TRENTON, Feb. 5. -- Although using the language of diplomacy to announce its unprecedented action, the Republican State Committee dethroned Governor Harold G. Hoffman today as leader of the party in New Jersey.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Banners Flying, the even-money choice, owned by G.E. Ewins, captured the featured sixth race at the Fair Grounds today.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 5. -- Exponents of Winter sports from all the world -- skaters, skiers, bobsledders and curlers -- are assembled here tonight awaiting tomorrow's opening. With them are sport devotees from lands far and near, for this year's Winter Olympics will be historic.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- J.P. Morgan, his big briar smoking like a small locomotive, and his face beaming good nature, "walked out" on the Senate munitions inquiry this afternoon by agreement.
Rounding into the home stretch of the season, the New York A.C. and Columbia Club teams remained in a tie for the Class A squash tennis leadership in the Metropolitan League race last night.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 5. -- Ray Smith, University of Virginia star, made good on two foul shots in the closing seconds of an extra-period basketball game today to give the Cavaliers a 26-to-25 triumph over the Naval Academy quintet.

Compared, let us say, with Senators, Mr. J.P. MORGAN is popularly regarded as a somewhat mysterious figure. Any remark from him which might seem to reveal his economic philosophy or his general "social attitude" is certain to arouse a great deal of interest. This is especially true of his generalization before the Senate Munitions Committee: "If you destroy the leisure class you destroy civilization."

Thirty-eight years of automobile driving without an accident, without ever receiving a ticket and even without so much as a "bawling out" from a policeman, is the record of Joseph S. Cortelyou of Haworth, Bergen County, N.J.

The advance last month of $3,218,965,497 in the market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange carried the total above $50,000,000,000 for the first time since the Spring of 1931. This was approximately the midway point in the market's long decline that began early in 1930 and continued until the Summer of 1932.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP). -- Fifty million dollars might be a lot of money to some people, but it was not enough to get George Bernard Shaw before a microphone here today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5. -- Orthodox priests in many villages are now masquerading as supporters of Soviet policies in order to lure peasants to church, it is charged by the League of Militant Atheists. The league will celebrate the tenth anniversary of its founding in a big meeting of delegates from many parts of the Soviet Union here Friday.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Great Britain's arms inquiry turned today to relations between the du Pont munitions company in the United States and the Imperial Chemical Industries.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5. -- Miss Eleonora R. Sears of Boston, former titleholder, met with an unexpected setback in the third round of the woman's national squash racquets tournament at the Merion Cricket Club today when Miss Elizabeth Pearson, 19-year-old Philadelphia Cricket Club player, won in four games, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 4, 7 -- 15, 15 -- 9.

President ROOSEVELT has made an important and timely move in ordering a check-up of all Federal credit agencies, with a view to canceling a billion dollars or more in unused lending authorizations voted by Congress during the past three years. As he notes, the result will not be an immediate reduct. ion of budgetary costs.

ROME, Feb. 5. -- Particular importance is attributed to today's official war bulletin, which contains the news that General Rodolfo Graziani has resumed active operations in the southern sector of the Somaliland front.

Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, who returned yesterday from Moscow on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic, declared his belief that the danger of a war in Europe can be averted by concerted action.

President Frederick B. Robinson's address at the House Plan Center yesterday marked the opening of the Spring term at City College. The president spoke to 500 students and members of the faculty at a reception and tea in honor of the incoming freshmen, 250 of whom joined the organization during the day.

Evidence of wholesale faking of accident claims by which insurers have been defrauded of millions of dollars, obtained by an investigation in which twenty-six insurance companies cooperated, was presented yesterday to the Bar Association of the City of New York.

The special Wagner matinee cycle opened yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House with an admirable performance of "Das Rheingold." Seldom has the opera been presented so eloquently in this theatre. It is different from all the other operas of the "Ring."

The New York Americans spotted the Toronto Maple Leafs the lead three times in their battle at Madison Square Garden last night, but the visitors were unable to retain the advantages given them, and after a bruising, hard-checking contest, had to skate off the ice on the short end of a 4-to-3 count.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- President Roosevelt is expected to submit to Congress next week a request for new taxes to raise about $500,000,000 annually, or at least enough to finance the new farm program and, possibly, to cover some smaller deficiencies in the budget.

The United States is confronted by a crisis in her Pacific relations demanding an immediate stocktaking, asserts Sir Frederick Whyte, former political adviser of the national government in China, in a report on a future plan of study for the Institute of Pacific Relations, which was made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- President Roosevelt devoted a considerable part of his day to consideration of the government's tax program. This evening the President and Mrs. Roosevelt were hosts at the third White House reception of the season.

MASSAUA, Feb. 5 (Delayed). -- In a colorful ceremony here at the Governor's Palace this morning Sherifa Alauia El Morgani, a direct descendant of Mohammed and the spiritual head of the Moslems in Eritrea, made an offering of gold collected from her followers.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, which owns the Long Island Railroad completely, has "never been in the red" and always pays a dividend, Hobart Rawson, railroad statistician, admitted to Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley at another hearing on the subsidiary's application for an increase in commutation fares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Italian Embassy took issue today with figures published in THE NEW YORK TIMES that declared the number of seamen's desertions had increased between 1934 and 1935 and that Italian desertions had led those of any other country.

High over Central Park at precisely the "zero hour," 11:40 A.M., yesterday, seven Martin B-10 bombers and eight Curtiss A-12 attack planes swung in from Concord, N.H., 150 miles away, to "attack" New York. At the same time, at higher altitude, eighteen Boeing P26-E single-seater pursuits, warned by radio at Mitchel Field, L.I., of the raid's approach, came into view above them.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 6. -- Mgr. Jose Othon Nunez, Archbishop of Oaxaca, as representative of forty Mexican prelates, has protested telegraphically from the city of Puebla to President Lazaro Cardenas regarding what is said to have been the unjustified expulsion from his residence of the Archbishop of Puebla, Pedro Vera Zuria.

The 158th anniversary of the signing of the first treaty between France and the United States was celebrated last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with a dinner, given by the France-America Society.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- For the second straight day Miss Elizabeth Pearson, 19-year-old Philadelphia Cricket Club player, came through with a surprise victory in the women's national squash racquets championship tournament on the Merion courts this afternoon.

TOKYO, Feb. 6. -- Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa, who has been allowed to take the rostrum during the four preceding sessions of his court-martial, today submitted to a merciless dissection of his political ideals by the prosecutor.

Somewhere in the cellars of the State Capitol at Albany lives a jinx. About this time every year, when politics is brewing upstairs, he slinks out of his lair and bites a Republican. Nobody knows why he always selects a Republican, but the fact is that he never makes a mistake.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 5 per cent for the week ended Feb. 1 over the corresponding period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

ROME, Feb. 6. -- Rumors of the impending recall of Marshal Pietro Badoglio, commander-in-chief of Italian forces in East Africa, were denied here today. It was admitted that his health, which had suffered from the high altitudes in Ethiopia, might necessitate his return before the conclusion of the military campaign, but it was insisted that no change was contemplated at this time.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Johnny Sorrell's goal midway of the second period tonight gave the Detroit Red Wings a 1-to-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks and undisputed possession of first place in the American division of the National Hockey League.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 6. -Howard S. Palmer, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, was today elected president of the Connecticut Company, the consolidated trolley lines of the system. He will succeed John K. Punderford, for ten years the Connecticut's head, who will continue as assistant to the president, and will remain president of the Berkshire Street Railway and the Springfield Street Railway Company of Massachusetts.

HUDSON FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- Frank J. Ahearn, 36 years old, and Henry Margolis, 37, associates of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, surrendered today to David S. Fisk, United States Commissioner, to stand trial under an indictment for income tax evasion.

Declaring that "nothing of any consequence has happened in the Lindbergh case since Hauptmann's arrest," Attorney General Cummings announced yesterday in Washington that the Department of Justice would not re-enter the case.
TRENTON, Feb. 6. -- The State Relief Council announced today that beginning March 1 food orders instead of money will be given to the needy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Justice Department attorneys were reported to have advised the administra tion that any retroactive processing taxes which might be included in a general revenue measure to finance the new farm program must be confined to the current fiscal year, which began last July 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Increases in farm and food prices in the week ended on Feb. 1 caused a rise in the wholesale price index to 80.5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES today appeared a letter signed N.E.M. in which the writer pointed out that he is paying a "tax on a tax." The situation he described was one where he saw a sign "Playing Cards 10 cents; Federal Tax 10 cents," and then had to pay 21 cents, which represented the above items plus a 1-cent New York City sales tax.

Josef Honti, Hungarian pianist and one of the three staff directors of music for the National Broadcasting Company, is working on a book which Covici, Friede expects to publish. The tentative title is "Music and the Radio." It will deal in part with the public's reaction to both classical and popular music.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6. -- Thousands of tons of Pacific Coast commerce, delayed for eight weeks in the controversy of seamen on coastal ships, will begin moving today, following decision of the Ship Owners Association of the Pacific Coast to accept the seamen's decision to return to work.

We must "promote free speech and free assemblage as an educational process" and must "revitalize our educational system" if we are to forestall the development of a dictatorship, Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, said last night in an address at Town Hall.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- Mrs. Wilbur Fribley of Chicago, president of the Housewives League of America, took issue tonight with J.P. Morgan's definition of the leisure class as families "who can afford a maid."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 6. -- Two rounds in the Miami-Biltmore women's golf championship were played today. The survivors in the semi-finals are Miss Patty Berg, 17-year-old Minneapolis star and winner of the qualifying medal; Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of Miami, Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, Mo., and Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky

President ROOSEVELT went over his budget figures yesterday at a White House conference with the heads of the principal "emergency" bureaus of his Administration. Passage of the Soldiers Bonus Bill over his veto has added at least a billion dollars to the probable deficit for the next fiscal year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- Joseph H. Young, 59 years old, secretary of the American Foreign Credit Underwriters of New York, who disappeared last May, is legally alive, according to a jury's sealed verdict opened in Supreme Court here this morning by Justice Close.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- Spreading operations furnished a good part of the trade in grains on the Board of Trade today. There was selling of May wheat against purchases of the new crop months; buying of rye and corn against sales of wheat, and buying of corn against sales of lard.
LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

In commemoration of the opening on Feb. 12 of the new home of the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center, a spectacle entitled "The March of Light" was presented for the first time yesterday on the stage of the Radio City Music Hall.
George Arliss's latest film for Gaumont British, "Mister Hobo," opens this morning at the Roxy. The featured players are Gene Gerrard, Frank Cellier, Patrick Knowles and Viola Keats.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6. -- Harvard's prize fellowship plan has proved to be a success in the Middle West and should be extended to other parts of the country as rapidly as possible, Dean A.C. Hanford of Harvard College says in his annual report to President Conant.

LIKENESSES between William Randolph Hearst and Napoleon, Charlemagne, the Louis of France and the Popes of Rome are noted in Mr. Hearst's official biography, published today. Yet it is possible that Mrs. Fremont Older, the biographer, is amazed at her own moderation. For as she tells the story, "William Randolph Hearst, American" (Appleton-Century, $4), it is apparent to any reader that all history fails to supply complete parallels for the career of Mr. Hearst.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 6. -- The twenty-sixth annual carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club will get under way tomorrow morning when the first competitors in this year's events start at 9 o'clock to risk the icy surface of the downhill course on the face of Balch Hill. This is the first test of the meet, the winner of which will gain the championship of the Intercollegiate Ski Union.

The development of "regional consciousness" is as essential to the poultry industry as to any of the major commodity groups throughout the country, according to T.B. Symons of the University of Maryland, who addressed the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council yesterday at a luncheon held in the Hotel New Yorker.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 6. -- The State should subsidize marriage in early life for young persons unable to afford a home and thus protect the youth of the nation from commercial vice, the Institute of Family Relations was told here this afternoon by Bascom Johnson, legal consultant for the American Social Hygiene Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Senate Munitions Investigation Committee took under consideration today a plan to create a Federal monopoly in all naval construction, other than auxiliary, and put the government into the business of manufacturing its airplanes and airplane engines, explosives, machine guns, rifles and other types of small arms.

Following a decline of more than 30 points in a few days, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and under increased price fixing for mill account made a recovery of 9 to 12 points. As the March delivery got down around 11 cents consumers took cotton and the fact that the producers' pool holds contracts calling for the delivery of 178,000 bales before the end of next month developed even more resistance.
Commodity prices were generally lower last week, and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined to 127.1 on Tuesday from 128.6 (revised) the previous Tuesday.
ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- The Assembly took action today to keep pace with the Senate in the enactment of measures designed to strike at crime.

Under the caption "Consumers' Clubs" THE TIMES published a letter in which the writer drew the conclusion that the objective of consumers' clubs is not worthy of support. The letter, signed "M.E.," obviously refers to the Jackson Heights Consumers Club.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Singing Wood, the favorite, won the feature at Santa Anita track today for a purse of $1,200. The 5-year-old finished the six furlongs in the fast time of 1:102-5.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 6. -- The spread of Monterrey's general stoppage of work throughout Mexico is feared as a result of instructions sent to all members by the General and Regional Confederations of Workers and Peasants.

H.I. Peffer, president of the Seagrams-Distillers Corporation, told The Associated Press yesterday he had sent a letter of apology to President Roosevelt for publication of an advertisement containing a picture of a man some readers mistook for the Chief Executive.

Professor TUGWELL, now the Resettlement Administrator, has come forward with another of those "warnings" to private industry. If it "per"sists in its refusal to exploit the possi"bilities" of building houses within the means of workers and farmers, he tells us, "the pressure of public opinion may "force the Government to enter this "field on a very wide scale."

ALBANY, Feb. 6 (AP). -- William Lester, 29, an American Airlines pilot, lay in a critical condition in a hospital here tonight with severe injuries received when a tri-motored passenger plane crashed on a take-off from Albany airport.

The American Institute's Gold Medal, awarded annually, was presented last night at a dinner at the Hotel Pierre to Dr. John C. Merriam, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, "for his discoveries in palaeontology, his effective promotion of research, and his recognition of the place of science in human affairs."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Impeachment of Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter of the Southern Florida District was recommended today by the House Judiciary Committee.
ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 6. -- An affidavit by a Belgian officer denying Italian claims that a quantity of munitions was found in Swedish Red Cross trucks was published today by the Ethiopian Government.

DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Elmer B. O'Hara, chairman of the Michigan Democratic Central Committee, said that he had neither accepted an invitation to a White House reception tonight nor expressed his regrets that he was unable to attend.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 6. -- Senator Lester J. Dickinson of Iowa, speaking here tonight to the Buckeye Republican Club, on "Lincoln and Liberalism," called for a campaign of extermination, with no compromise, to drive from American government the principles of the New Deal.
Two hard-fought matches featured the opening round of the Class B singles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association that started yesterday at the Harvard Club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Charges of extensive Japanese espionage in Alaska, conducted from vessels ostensibly operated as fishing craft, were sounded today at the Capitol.

A break in the intense cold wave that has enveloped the area east of the Mississippi River for more than a month brought relief from the perils of ice and snow yesterday, but below-freezing temperatures remained and are expected to continue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today recommended confirmation of the appointment of five members of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, set up under the Guffey Act; two members of the Bituminous Coal Labor Board, three members of the Railroad Retirement Board and one member of the National Mediation Board.

Only one favored player failed to survive as thirty-four contestants swung into action in the first Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis championship at the 369th Regiment Armory yesterday, with Long Island University acting as host.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Clark Gable, Charles Laughton, Franchot Tone and Victor McLaglen were nominated tonight for the best actor's performance for the annual awards of merit of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 6. -- The American hockey team's 1-0 victory over the German sextet, with which the program of the fourth Olympic Winter Games opened this afternoon, showed on the part of the Americans that same lack of team play which netted the series of losses during their pro-Olympic European tour.

Edward P. Mulrooney, newly appointed State Commissioner of Correction, indicated yesterday that he would adopt a realistic attitude toward his new job. The retiring chairman of the State Liquor Authority was interviewed in his office at the State Office Building during and after the last meeting of the authority over which he will preside.

John R. Rockart, who had been associated for some years in the architectural enterprises of the late Cass Gilbert, filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against the Gilbert estate, Cass Gilbert Jr., son, and Julia Finch Gilbert, daughter of the noted architect, for an accounting of the work done on the recently completed United States Supreme Court Building In Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Simplification of margin requirements for brokers and dealers to meet complaints of brokers against current regulations, which are held to be too complex and expensive to administer, appeared as a possibility today. It was indicated, too, that certain high Federal Reserve officials would approve the changes.

In The Nation Mr. KRUTCH has become justifiably worried about the reckless rapidity with which we use up our authors nowadays. No phrase seems to fall with more ease from the pen of the contemporary critic than "he belongs to the past." Sometimes this means no more than that the author thus relegated has no significance in relation to certain of the critic's burning convictions, but usually it is broader than that.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt held the third State reception of the White House season tonight in honor of officials of the Treasury, Postoffice, Interior, Agriculture, Commerce and Labor Departments and independent Federal agencies.
ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- Efforts to reach an agreement on ways and means to transfer all relief activities into a single State body on a permanent basis have run into a snag.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Feb. 6. -- Miss Virginia Mallory Peyton, 21 years old, a Wellesley College junior, disclosed today that she had been under State police guard since Jan. 30 in what for a time was believed to be a kidnap plot. The guard was discontinued today when she attended a matinee performance in Boston with her fiance, Charles Winn of Brookline, a former army officer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- By amending their constitution to cover jurisdiction over workmen "in and around coal processing plants," the United Mine Workers of America, in convention today opened an additional point of controversy with the American Federation of Labor.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Feb. 6. -- Three Russian army planes while flying yesterday over Estonian territory were subjected to machinegun fire. One plane was hit, but not brought down. It returned with the others to Soviet territory. The Estonian Government has protested to Moscow against a violation of Estonia's territorial integrity.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System were unchanged in the week ended on Wednesday at $3,090,000,000, according to the weekly report of the system, issued yesterday. Actual reserve balances rose $6,000,000 to $5,869,000,000.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- The custom of "greasing the wheels" in the munitions business was discussed for the first time today before the dignified Royal Commission which is inquiring into the private armaments industry in Great Britain.

In addition to being able to play the Metropolitan open championship this year on one of the country's finest courses, that at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club at Mamaroneck, the professionals will have a still further inducement, for the size of the purse will be increased, according to an announcement yesterday by Max B. Kaesche of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

Protesting against the action of the State Mortgage Commission in taking over the servicing of mortgages from the Lawyers Mortgage Guarantee Corporation, a committee of certificate holders applied yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to restrain the commission.

Six Fencers Club men and two representatives of New York University qualified for the semi-finals of the junior national epee championships to be held later this month as the result of the metropolitan area competition last night at the New York A.C.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 6. -- The North American ice boat championship for 1936 was won today by the North Shrewsbury Ice Boat and Yacht Club of Red Bank. It was defending the title captured five years ago from the South Shrewsbury Club of Long Branch by the modern jib-headed yacht Pirate II, owned by George E. Ruppert and George J. Gillig of New York.

The Hamburg-American liner Hansa will arrive today from Hamburg, Bremen and Channel ports, bringing an official air mission from Germany, the members of which will go to Washington to discuss a projected transatlantic air service.

The latest symphony of Vaughan Williams, who is probably the greatest of living English composers, was performed under the direction of Hans Lange at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 6. -- The fourth Olympic Winter Games began today with an American victory, although it is only a minor victory. In the hockey elimination contests this afternoon the United States defeated Germany, 1 to 0, in a game notable for its slowness.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday decreased $9,701,968, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. At the same time deposits by chartered banks increased $947,587.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- British agricultural laborers are now for the first time to receive government unemployment insurance, which has been at the disposal of industrial workers for a generation. Provision for this is contained in a bill extending the insurance system, which passed the second reading in the House of Commons tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- An unexpected move within the ranks of Senate Democrats for insertion of consumer protective clauses in the administration's broadened soil conservation program gathered momentum late today as the measure was taken up in that body to the accompaniment of partisan debate over the cost and constitutionality of the proposed legislation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that "although the new year has opened with an employment situation more encouraging on the whole than any since the PWA program there is still no prospect of work for more than a mere handful of the 11,400,000 unemployed.

HAVANA, Feb. 6. -- The Count of Covadonga has been in a comatose condition since early this evening, and late tonight he was sinking rapidly. The former Spanish heir was then expected to live only a few hours.

A plan for the use of impounded processing taxes to aid small merchants throughout the country was suggested here yesterday by I. Ginsberg, head of I. Ginsberg Brothers and a former president of the National Association of Dress Manufacturers.

Many dinner parties were given last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador, where a dinner dance was held for the benefit of the Neighborhood Guilds, an organization that ministers to the destitute. During the evening there were divertissements by professional entertainers.
LONDON, Feb. 6. -- The Imperial Conference scheduled for the Summer of 1936 will not be held until 1937, Reuters learned today.

American manufacturers of notions were warned last night by A.J. Donahue, retiring president of the National Notion Association, that importations of Japanese merchandise are seriously threatening the markets of this country. Mr. Donahue spoke at the thirteenth anniversary dinner of the association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- President Roosevelt was urged by Senator Norris, during debate on the system of appointing postmasters on the floor of the Senate today, to ban politics from every postoffice in the country. Failure to do so, he asserted, would cost the President "millions of votes" in the next election.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- Gas and electric companies in this State have padded their valuations by $225,000,000 in an effort to stave off rate reductions, William T. Harris, assistant counsel to the Legislative Utilities Investigating Committee, testified today.
Yesterday's statement of the! twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and total hills discounted for the Systelll a a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

VIENNA, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Professor Eugen Steinach, who has devoted his career to a study of why men grow old, announced today the result of new experiments that he said held out definite hope for effective rejuvenation. His conclusion that "the process of growing old can be reversed" was published by the Vienna Klinische Wohnenschrift.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 6. -- Censuring public officials for employing military force to close an industrial plant, three judges in the Federal District Court today enjoined Governor Olson, Mayor Latimer and Adjutant General Walsh from using troops to close the Minneapolis plant of the Strutwear Knitting Company.

By a vote of the membership the New York State Chamber of Commerce at its monthly meeting yesterday expressed its opposition to the neutrality bills now in Congress, to current Federal spending and deficits and criticized payment of the soldiers' bonus.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 6. -- Two airplanes rammed each other 4,000 feet over Munich today, one falling into the Neunhauserstrasse, one of the city's leading business streets. The four occupants of the planes escaped alive, but three pedestrians were killed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The fight to bar Arthur W. Cutten, Chicago speculator, from the grain markets and to uphold the Grain Futures Act was taken to the Supreme Court today when the government urged the court to review a decision of the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals.

Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared yesterday that the Constitution should be changed only if the American public was willing to admit that adverse conditions were here to stay. Mr. Gay spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 5, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,492,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $29,000,000 compared with the corresponding week of 1935.

THE man in the middle didn't have a chance. He couldn't have put in a small word edgewise. His flankers were Moe Berg and Al Schacht of the Boston Red Box. Mr. Berg speaks seven languages fluently and Mr. Schacht speaks one language persistently.

LANDISBURG, Pa., Feb. 6. -- Farmers working in relays risked life and limb today as they continued to chip away at the stone face of a crevice deep in Tuscarora Mountain, twelve miles from here, in an attempt to free a white terrier.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 6 (AP). -- Modesto Trujillo, 16-year-old Spanish-American houseboy, confessed today, Sheriff Ross Salazar said, that he killed Carl Taylor, magazine writer, in his lonely mountain cabin near here last night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6. -- The double star, "29 Canis Majoris," has been determined by the Harvard College Observatory to be the heaviest star known to astronomy. It is 40,000,000 times as heavy as the earth and seventy times as heavy as the sun. The measurement was made by Dr. Sergei I. Gaposchkin of the Harvard staff, through a study of hundreds of photographs taken at the observatory.

Lou Ambers, the Herkimer Hurricane, who is eager to try conclusions once more with Tony Canzoneri for the world's lightweight championship, will oppose Baby Arizmendi of Mexico in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Women in Geneva at work for peace and disarmament were pictured as the visual symbol that women of the world do care for peace, by Miss Mary A. Dingman, in an address yesterday at the morning session of the annual meeting of the foreign division of the Y.W.C.A. at the national board headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue.

PEKIN, Ill., Feb. 6. -- Pekin's "workers' holiday," which had paralyzed business in this Central Illinois whisky and mining community, was called off abruptly at noon today after merchants had announced that they would defy the workers' orders and after a representative of the American Federation of Labor had intervened to halt the tie-up.

WARSAW, Friday, Feb. 7. -- The passage of six Paris-bound German passenger trains through Polish territory was ordered stopped at one minute past midnight today when the restriction of German railway traffic through Pomorze [the so-called Polish Corridor] came into effect through the refusal of the Polish Government to accept payment in kind of the larger part of $14,000,000 owed by the Reichsbank to the Polish State Railroads.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Governorship of the City of Rome, Italy, has filed for permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange $23,595,200 of external loan of 1927 sinking fund 6 1/2 per cent gold bonds. Capital and interest are payable in United States currency and the bonds have been fully serviced.

Dr. Donald B. Armstrong, vice President of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, was elected yesterday president of the National Health Council, Inc., at its annual meeting at the Hotel Lexington. He succeeded Colonel Theodore Roosevelt.

The share market encountered profit-taking in the late trading yesterday, a characteristic which has been noted in the late dealings on many days recently. Early in the session it appeared as though a broad buying movement had gotten under way, but the advantage was not pursued; the closing was irregularly higher.

The Metropolitan last night offered a twin bill of Puccini's "La Boheme" and "Gianni Schicchi," the one-act comedy in English, before a large and highly responsive audience. The presentation of "Gianni Schicchi" was the second of the season, and that of "La Boheme" was the third, and was also marked by the first appearances in this opera of Susanne Fisher and Nino Martini.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press). -- A legislative program comparatively brief but providing for changes of far-reaching character was forecast in the speech from the throne read at today's opening of Parliament.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6. -- James A. Noe, successor to Oscar K. Allen as Governor of Louisiana, was reported today to have moved to end a practice which Huey P. Long, before his assassination, jokingly described as his own form of "unemployment insurance."

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6. -- With the second and third lines leading the attack, Princeton today. downed a plucky Middlebury College six, 7 -- 0, in the Hobey Baker Rink. Wilkes Covey, second-string wing, led the Tiger attack with three goals.

TRENTON, Feb. 6. -- It was reported today that less than a majority of the membership of the Republican State Committee voted for the resolution that was adopted at a secret meeting here yesterday asserting the committee's intention to relieve Governor Hoffman of leadership of the party in New Jersey.

There has recently been suggested a plan of compulsory automobile insurance and the establishment of a State fund to indemnify those suffering injuries. It is asserted that this would do much to reduce the rapidly increasing number of automobile fatalities. It is too bad that so many individuals believe the easiest way to correct an evil is simply to place additional legislation upon the statute books. Unfortunately, this does not work in actual practice.

Arrangements were made yesterday for the sale of a membership in the New York Curb Exchange for $42,500, an advance of $2,500 over the last previous sale and to the highest level since June, 1933, when a transfer was made for $50,000. Members appear more optimistic than at any time since the Federal regulation of Exchanges became effective in October, 1934.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday rose to the highest level since Jan. 8. The total for the twenty-two leading cities in the United States, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,912,328,000, against $4,905,008,000 for the corresponding period last year.

A tribute to Mrs. August Belmont, president of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, and her co-workers for their aid in obtaining a large number of subscribers and widening the interest in opera this season was adopted yesterday in a resolution by the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., at a meeting held at the Broadway House.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6. -- Walter S. Tower, executive secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute, said in an address today before the State Chamber of Commerce that approximately $200,000,000 will be spent in 1936 by the steel industry for modernizing equipment and new finishing capacity.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- James M. Cain's stage adaptation of his story, "The Postman Always Rings Twice," opened a nine-day engagement at the Chestnut Street Opera House here tonight before an enthusiastic audience.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- The stock markets here were quieter today, weakening on profit-taking, with heavy settlements progressing. British funds were firm on investment demand, following the intimation that the defense program might be financed by Treasury issues instead of a long-term loan.

Clarence W. Hobbs, commenting in THE TIMES on the silicosis hazard, said: "A more direct approach is by the way of physical examination, to weed out those likely to contract the disease and those who have it. There are two difficulties, at least, about this program. It requires a high grade of X-ray technicians, none too common, and a high grade of X-ray apparatus."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6. -- The patio of Casa Marcheta was the setting today for a tea for 150 persons which Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff gave, honoring her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Julius Meyer of New York.

With Miss Janice Lifson and Miss Constance Hanf each capturing two first places for the winners, the New York University women's swimming team launched its campaign by subduing Savage, 32 -- 21, in a dual meet at the American Woman's Association pool last night.

A jury from a special panel of talesmen was chosen in General Sessions yesterday and Frank E. Carstarphen, Assistant District Attorney, made his opening address in the second trial of Mrs. Hilda M. Peterson on a grand larceny indictment growing out of the mythical stock promotion scheme of her fugitive husband, William F. Peterson.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- Paris today observed the second anniversary of the sixth of February riots with unbroken calm. There were scarcely any evidences during a day of many sober ceremonies of that violent factional feeling which two years ago nearly plunged the country into a revolution.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6. -- The Argentine Foreign Office denied today dispatches from Chile saying that South American governments were engaged in diplomatic conversations looking toward uniform legislation to deprive Communists of citizenship.

Colonel Joseph M. Hartfield of the law firm of White Case announced yesterday on behalf of the reorganization managers of National Department Stores, Inc., that the plan of reorganization approved by Judge Nields of the Federal District Court in Delaware had been declared effective as of Feb. 1.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6. -- Jamboree, a son of High Time, running in the famous pink and black silks of Mrs. Payne Whitney's Greentree Stable, displayed marked improvement over his one previous local effort to lead home five other 3-year-olds in the featured mile event at Hialeah Park today.

BOSTON, Feb. 6. -- A finish fight between the Ely and Curley wings of Massachusetts democracy for control of the delegation to the national convention in June was indicated today when Governor Curley telephoned from Palm Beach that he would battle for a Roosevelt pledged delegation.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6. -- Chancellor John G. Bowman, defying Governor Earle's ultimatum to "liberalize" the University of Pittsburgh within twenty-four days or lose its State appropriation, accused the Governor today of trying to drag the school into politics.

The city of Easton, Pa., will be in the market on Feb. 25, with a new issue of $2,750,000 of water works bonds. They will be dated March 15, 1936, and mature serially from March 15, 1937 to 1966, and will carry coupons ranging from 1 1/2 to 3 per cent.

Ten of the eleven principals taken in the raids conducted last Saturday night by the staff of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey were indicted yesterday on charges of compulsory prostitution by the extraordinary grand jury investigating rackets in New York County.

The dollar was marked up for further recovery on the foreign exchange market yesterday and no further engagements of gold for export were reported. The French franc dropped 1/8 point net to 6.69 3/8 cents, which is slightly below the gold export point, and the pound sterling lost 1/8 cent to $5.01 3/4.
