With the selection yesterday of the ninth juror in the Drukman murder trial, Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn ordered a new panel of fifty tales-men summoned today. The original panel of 150 was almost exhausted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- An extensive modernization program topped a list of recommendations given Congress today in a White House-approved drive toward a treaty-strength navy by 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- A plan to teach conservation to the youth of the nation was submitted to the North American Wild Life Conference today by Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- Lucien Lelong, in showing his Summer collection, launches a new "wave" silhouette with the movement constantly surging and subsiding. This is done by panel drapery attached at the neck and low on the skirt and sometimes wound around the figure en route.

With the Giants and Yankees apparently checked in any further efforts to revamp their battle fronts for the 1936 pennant campaigns, it remained for the Dodgers to step into the limelight yesterday with a trade of major proportions.

A drive to force Chinese hand laundries in the city to take out compensation insurance for workers resulted yesterday in the appearance of 340 Chinese at the State office building, 80 Center Street, to answer summonses.

Gradually widening fissures, some more than an inch and a half in width and extending through to the inner walls of the Criminal Court Building, Lafayette and Franklin Streets, caused an official inspection of the 42-year-old structure yesterday after Judge Donnellan of General Sessions had informed Borough President Levy that the building "is in danger of collapsing."

Questions of censorship and propaganda in motion pictures aroused the delegates yesterday at the twelfth annual conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The conference, which began on Wednesday, ends tomorrow.

There is a definite possibility that "The Eternal Road" may not be done until next Fall, according to Meyer W. Weisgal, its producer. He said yesterday that the "major portion" of the $200,000 needed to complete the production is now available, but that the opening date for the spectacle must be governed by the time needed to assemble the physical properties and by Max Reinhardt's Hollywood commitments.

In the vicinity of the Winter Olympics at Garmisch-Partenkirchen in the Bavarian Alps there are some highly conspicuous road signs today. They are the anti-Jewish placards and streamers which correspondents say have been removed for the Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Charges that Edward M. House, adviser to the late President Wilson, "has held in contempt, if not hatred, American traditions, the American Constitution and the American form of government," were made by Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts today in the House.

The Chrysler Corporation in its annual report for 1935, issued yesterday, revealed that last year had been the best in its history, with earnings equivalent to $8.07 a share and the dollar volume of sales 38 per cent higher than the previous peak in 1929.

It cannot be said dogmatically that no general strike anywhere or any time ever succeeded. But it is pretty nearly the exact truth so far as this country is concerned. We have not had, it is admitted, a general strike on the Russian model, meaning a universal strike. Our general strikes have been limited to a given region or city, such as San Francisco, where the failure was complete.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 6. -- Fears that the Olympic bobsled competition would have to be postponed or canceled altogether were expressed today when the run, already the scene of several minor accidents, took a heavier practice toll among the big four-man sleds.

Turning on the critics whose attacks on him have reached a climax since his intervention in the Hauptmann case, Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey angrily launched a counter-attack on the Republican State Committee last night and defied it to dislodge him as head of the party in his State.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Putting on a powerful second-half drive, the Temple basketball team tonight downed Princeton, 45 -- 26, in the university gymnasium.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- Arrival of livestock which had been stormbound swelled receipts of hogs today to 14,000 head, overrunning the trade's estimates by 4,000. This increased supply was largely responsible for declines of 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight in prices.

Expediting the city's school building program, the Board of Education, at a special meeting yesterday, approved contracts totaling $2,263,782 for the construction of three new structures and concurred in the acceptance by the city of a $465,544 Federal grant to aid in the construction of a fourth building.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- The Atlantic Passenger Conference failed to reach an agreement today upon a suggestion by its subcommittee for reclassification of the liners in Atlantic service. The conference did not break up, however, and decided to continue its discussions tomorrow morning.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- The death penalty for David Frankfurter, the Jewish student who killed Wilhelm Gustloff, German leader of the Nazis in Switzerland, was demanded today in an impassioned editorial printed on the front page of the Voelkischer Beobachter, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's own newspaper.

Mayor La Guardia's efforts to avert the threatened strike of 105,000 dressmakers in New York and near-by communities appeared to have collapsed yesterday. The strike is expected to go into effect Monday.

The "professions" not only in this State but throughout the United States are in lasting debt to Dr. AUGUSTUS S. DOWNING for what he did through his labors of a half-century -- first, in the better training of teachers for their profession and then in lifting mere "occupations" into "professions," and helping to prescribe and then maintain sound standards in all professions.

Anent the remarks of Senator Pope of Idaho respecting the Supreme Court and the laws it supports, it may be appropriate to call attention to the circumstance that such laws constitute our Bill of Rights, which concerns largely the economic law, won through centuries of Anglo-Saxon struggle.

Under the patronage of several women of prominence, a dinner will be given for the benefit of the French Benevolent Society of the Ladies of St. Vincent de Paul to mark the opening on Feb. 18 of the Cafe Louis XIV in La Maison Francaise, Rockefeller Center.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 6. -- While the United States hockey team was defeating the German sextet today, Canada, the defending Olympic champion, pushed over five goals in the first period and crushed Poland under an 8-1 score.

Thomas Jefferson and Franklin K. Lane scored yesterday as competition in Section I of the Brooklyn Division of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament opened. Jefferson vanquished Eastern District, 30 to 21, while Lane turned back Boys High, 29 to 23, in games played on the losers' courts.

It was inevitable that the Senate committee delving into our loans to the Allies should raise the question why they have not paid their debts to our Treasury. They have not formally repudiated them, but no longer pay even the interest on them. The debts are thus left, as it were, hanging between heaven and earth.

According to present indications, there will be no interruption in the production of men's wear fabrics for some months, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday. Wool goods markets were active this week and prices continued to show an advancing tendency, the report states.

Domestic consumption of the four leading textile fibers, cotton, wool, silk and rayon, amounted to 3,482,000,000 pounds last year, a gain of 344,000,000 pounds, or 10.9 per cent over the 1934 figure, according to figures made public yesterday by the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

A new theory of relativity, which broadens the foundations of the original special theory of relativity promulgated by Einstein in 1905, and "offers the hope of acquiring a better understanding of the motions occurring in the atom," is presented today in The Physical Review by Professor Leigh Page of Yale University.

On a bid of $1,000,000, the Bowery Savings Bank yesterday bought in twenty-eight lots in West Thirty-Fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, at a foreclosure auction sale conducted in 18 Vesey Street by Henry Brady, auctioneer. The property, part of which is vacant, fronts 230 feet on Thirty-fourth Street and 301 feet on Thirty-fifth Street.

Four embroidery workers were killed and a fifth was on the critical list in North Hudson Hospital yesterday after an explosion destroyed Italo Vittori's two-story combination factory and home at 617 Twenty-fifth Street in North Bergen, N.J.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- A method of measuring the temperature of the electric arc, which is several thousand degrees hotter than the sun and possesses the highest temperature attained by man, has been perfected in Northwestern University's physics laboratory by Professor W.S. Huxford and Dr. William T. Gray, a member of the research staff of the Corning Glass Works.

The report of the Household Finance Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1935, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $4,203,926 after interest, Federal taxes, a charge of $295,000 to provide for contingencies, minority interest in the earnings of its subsidiary company and provision for losses on installment notes receivable in the amount of $550,792 net after deducting recoveries on notes previously written off.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Charges made in Washington by Representative Sirovich that Japanese espionage was being conducted in Alaska from Japanese fishing craft were ridiculed today by the adjutant to Admiral Mineo Osumi, Minister of the Navy.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins climbed into third place in the National Hockey League's American Group tonight by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 3. The victory put the Bruins ahead of the idle New York Rangers.
BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- Radical Nazis demanded today that the Jewish race "stand trial" for the assassination of Wilhelm Gustloff in Switzerland by David Frankfurter, a Jew.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed transfer of the membership of Gus K. Worms to George J. Stockly for $173,000; the sale of the seat of William D. Stevens to William P. Jenkins, that of the late Percy R. Goepel to Arthur B. Treman and that of William S. Fairchild to F. Beverley Eyre Jr.
PARIS, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins climbed into third place in the National Hockey League's American Group tonight by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 3. The victory put the Bruins ahead of the idle New York Rangers.

Municipal bonds are selling on the average at the same levels that prevailed thirty-five years ago, or at the start of February, 1901, according to an analysis made by Darby Co., Inc. Citing The Daily Bond Buyer's index of municipal bond prices for Feb. 1, 1901, as standing at a 3.10 per cent yield basis, the firm points out that its own index average equals that basis on Feb. 1, 1936.

Robert Madden of the University of Pittsburgh, second seeded performer, was eliminated from the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis championship tournament when he lost to Fred Nuebling of C.C.N.Y., 7 -- 5, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 4, in the second round of play at the 369th Regiment Armory yesterday.

The United Fruit Company reported yesterday for 1935 a net income of $10,359,222, or $3.54 a share, on 2,925,000 capital shares, compared with $12,049,300, or $4.11 a share, the year before. After dividends of $3 a share, $1,641,235 was carried to surplus.

With less than two minutes of play remaining, Johnny Heidt tossed in a field goal to give the Lincoln School of Teachers College a 31-30 triumph over Fieldston on the letters' floor in one of the outstanding basketball games on the metropolitan private schools program yesterday.

The New Utrecht High sextet defeated Manual Training, 3 to 2, and Poly Prep played a scoreless tie with Brooklyn Tech in a Metropolitan Interscholastic Hockey League double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Vigorous opposition to the child labor amendment to the Constitution enlivened the ninety-ninth convention of the City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor yesterday. It overshadowed both the emphasis placed in the afternoon session on the declining birth rate in the United States and a less marked objection to a resolution endorsing the principle of foot-printing and fingerprinting for identification.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7. -- The Case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann was revealed as a national political issue here today when it was found that personal observers for President Roosevelt had been quietly checking on the fight between Governor Harold G. Hoffman and the New Jersey Republican State Committee.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 7. -- With a strong showing in the eighteen-kilometer cross-country ski race, the second and last point-scoring event of the day, McGill University of Montreal took the lead tonight in the twenty-sixth annual Winter carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club.

WILMINGTON, Del. Feb. 7 (AP). -- An "autobiography" of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., was read in Federal court today, disclosing a payment of $50,000 to former Ambassador James W. Gerard for the rights to his book, "My Four Years in Germany," and an additional $100,000 as his share of the profits from the filming of the book.

VIENNA, Feb. 7. -- It was stated today that some ten government officials out of thirty-two arrested for suspected Nazi activities had been detained in custody, and that among them was a man attached to the juvenile court's prosecution staff.

Domestic corporate bonds were in good demand at higher levels yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, but United States Government loans turned mildly reactionary, closing off from 1-32 to 4-32 point. The general turnover diminished somewhat, total transactions amounting to $19,298,100, compared with $20,360,400 on Thursday.

Firmer prices were in evidence on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, but the advance tapered off early and the final prices, in many instances, were below the best levels for the day. On the cash markets cotton, butter, standard tin, rubber and cocoa advanced, while the grains, Straits tin, silk and hides declined.
For the first time in 110 years perfect quiet pervaded the dismal cell blocks of the City Penitentiary on Welfare Island yesterday afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7. -- Sir Frederick Gowland Hopkins, British Nobel Prize winner in medicine and a pioneer in the field of vitamin research, has been appointed to the Harvard faculty for the academic year beginning next September. He is now the Sir William Dunn Professor of Biochemistry at the University of Cambridge, where he has been a Professor of Biochemistry since 1914.

An accounting on the $27,900,000 Series F-1 of guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company since its reorganization last Summer, when Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler appointed Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Lawrence M. Martin trustees, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday covering the period ended Dec. 31, 1935.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as particularly suitable for children by the School Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and patents of children in public and private schools:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 7. -- A large audience assembled tonight at the Montclair Theatre, where the Montclair Junior League presented "Double or Nothing," a musical revue, in aid of the league community house.
LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Keen bidding for a copy of the first edition of "Alice in Wonderland," published in 1856, resulted in a final bid of 945 by Maggs Brothers, booksellers, at an auction today.

Thirty miles of waterfront property along the North River and the East River are affected by the conditions of grants running back two hundred years or more. Under the Dongan Charter of 1686, the Montgomery Charter of 1730 and subsequent legislative acts, the city became the owner of a large area of land under water along these shores.

CRISFIELD, Md., Feb. 7 (AP). -- A Maryland State policeman lost his life and three other persons were exhausted tonight in a bold attempt to take food to ice-bound residents of Smith and Tangier Islands.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The question whether Hamlet should be muzzled almost cast Congress and all its problems into the shadow today.

The list of departures from the docks of Times Square is light this week: only two plays have given up the struggle, and will stop after this evening's performances. They are "Paradise Lost," the Clifford Odets drama produced and acted by the Group Theatre, and "A Room in Red and White."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

PEKIN, Ill., Feb. 7. -- Twenty-four hours after the three-day general strike was called off here, representatives of labor and the American Distilling Company today agreed on a program to end the distillery workers' strike. It was this trouble which brought on the paralyzing city-wide walkout of labor.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 7 (AP). -- Four convicts carrying a shotgun and pistols who bluffed and threatened their way out of Frankfort State Reformatory early today were hunted tonight over a wide area in the hills of Eastern Kentucky. The second stolen automobile used by the fugitives was abandoned at Mr. Sterling.
Representing a gain of more than 51 per cent, the Ford Motor Company reported yesterday that world sales in 1935 totaled 1,311,927 units, against 865,101 in 1934.

Alberto (Baby) Arizmendi, stouthearted little Mexican fighter, made an ill-fated decision when he elected to launch his bid for lightweight honors in the ring against the irrepressible Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N.Y., at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Two Presidential candidates took luncheon together in the privacy of the White House executive offices today. Mr. Roosevelt had invited Senator Borah to share with him the meal carried to him daily from the kitchen of the Executive Mansion.

GENEVA, Feb. 7 (AP). -- An investigation to determine the practicability of an oil sanction continues to show that the problem turns very largely on how much oil Italy can procure from the United States, officials of the League of Nations said tonight.

The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation showed yesterday in its report for 1935 net assets of about $36,192,000 on Dec. 31, equal to about $169 a share on the first preferred stock, against $27,250,537, or about $130 a share, a year previously.

Formation of a Junior Park Protective League to assist in preventing vandalism and in enforcing ordinances and regulations in the parks was announced yesterday by the Park Department. Organization meetings of the league will be held this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock in forty-one playground fieldhouses throughout the five boroughs.

Bidding $5,000 over a first mortgage of $235,000, the Warrington Realty Corporation yesterday bought in at auction the eleven-story Warrington Hotel at 161-63 Madison Avenue and the abutting five-story building at 28 East Thirty-third Street, forming an "L" around the southeast corner.

The leading editorial in THE TIMES of Feb. 1 closed with the suggestion that it would be timely to cut the Federal deficit by encouraging local relief through a system of grants-in-aid proportionate to sums raised locally.
UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- The Utica Curling Club made a clean sweep today, winning both the Allen Medal and Mitchell Medal events.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Congressional power to permit States to bar sales on the open market of prison-made goods was argued before the Supreme Court today in a test of the Hawes-Cooper act. The case was based on the shipment of work shirts made by Alabama prisoners to Ohio and sold in that State in violation of an Ohio statute.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7. -For the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough, who arrived today from New York to be their guests, Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan gave a large dinner tonight at their Hypolxo Island estate. Accompanying the Duke and Duchess were their children, Lady Sarah Spencer Churchill, Lady Caroline, Lady Rose Marie and the Marquess of Blandford; also Lord and Lady Montagu of London and Wadsworth R. Lewis of New York.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Elisha Hanson, general counsel for the American Newspaper Publishers Association, tonight said that the United States "is the only country in the world which has a press secured against hostile action by either the legislative or executive branches of the government, or from restraint by judicial injunction."

Marking one of the best monthly gains since the depression began, January sales figures of New York and Brooklyn department stores are expected to show an average increase of 9 to 10 per cent compared with January last year, retail executives here said yesterday.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 7. -- Latest work-relief employment figures showed that WPA, with 2,926,630 jobs, was providing for more than two-thirds of the 3,725,812 employed under the administration's relief program.

A carefully thought-out plan of attack carried through beautifully brought victory to Donald J. Nightingale of the University Club and Marshall MacLeod of the Princeton Club last night over Frederick B. Alexander Jr. and Robert McCormick of the home club in the invitation squash racquets doubles tournament for the Loekett Trophy at the University Club.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7. -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Jan 31 shows the following changes in paper pesos:

Herman C. Pollack, attorney for Mrs. Frances W. King, who sued Bruce Barton, writer and advertising executive, for slander and got a civil order for Mr. Barton's arrest, was disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division on the ground that he tried to blackmail Mr. Barton.
ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Operation and purchase of motor vehicles by the State of New York for the final six months of 1935 cost the State a total of $801,612, Controller Tremaine disclosed today.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, announced yesterday that he would direct the trustees in reorganization proceedings for the Bush Terminal Company to prepare an order to be submitted to him directing all parties in the litigation concerning the company to show cause why the reorganization petition of the concern should not be dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The Securities Commission hearing into alleged manipulations of Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock by Michael J. Meehan, Wall Street broker, was adjourned today until March 2.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Aircraft firms in Great Britain have helped in the rearmament of both Russia and Germany, the British arms inquiry was told today by Charles R. Fairey, head of the aviation company which bears his name.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has amended special rule No. 2 for the use of form A-2 for corporations filing registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933.

Two collegiate prospects with ambitions to soar high in professional baseball came officially into the ranks of the Giants yesterday when Eddie Brannick, assistant secretary, announced receiving accepted contracts from Frank Miller, former N.Y.U. first baseman, and Howard Sipler, star righthander of Swarthmore.

The government's delay in adopting an agricultural program continued yesterday to restrict business on the Cotton Exchange. Prices hovered around previous closing figures to end unchanged to six points higher than on Thursday.

Because Wednesday is the birthday of Abraham Lincoln many of the pastors of the city will preach sermons tomorrow on the martyred President. Some will draw lessons from Civil War times and international conditions today. The Lincoln holiday will be used by a number of religious organizations for annual services.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Persons "in the political structure" were blamed today by a special investigator for what he described as a far-flung vice and crime net in Minneapolis, where two news publishers combating such conditions have been slain in little over a year.

The nine judges of General Sessions, at a meeting yesterday, adopted a resolution urging construction of a new court house to take the place of the Criminal Court Building, erected on the site of the city's old Collect Pond forty-two years ago.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Feb. 7. -Frankie Ahearn and Henry Margolis remained behind the bars of the Warren County jail here tonight held under $75,000 bail on indictments for evasion of the Federal Income Tax Laws. The pair, henchmen of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, made no attempt to raise their bond, set by David S. Fisk of Hudson Falls, United States Commissioner.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Persistent reports of slow demand for flour and refusal of overseas buyers to show much interest in supplies of Canadian cash wheat finally have tired out many traders who bought futures some time ago with the expectation of higher prices.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- How two doctors experimented on themselves with a new vaccine for colds and influenza is described in The British Medical Journal. The vaccine is administered through the mouth and the doctors took repeated doses while fasting to test the results.

An unscheduled landing on one wheel by a big army Martin B-10 bomber marked yesterday's cold weather manoeuvres of the General Headquarters Air Force. Eight bombers had taken off early in the morning from their base at Concord, N.H., for an endurance flight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Another foreign nation sought permanent registration of its bonds on the New York Stock Exchange today when the Royal Hungarian Government filed an application with the Securities and Exchanage Commission covering $6,578,600 State loan of the Kingdom of Hungary of 1924 7 1/2 per cent sinking fund gold bonds.

Playing two-zone basketball for the first time, the New York University women's basketball squad found little trouble with the new system as it defeated the team from New College of Columbia University, 28 to 21, yesterday at the School of Education Building, Washington Square.

The indoor track spotlight will be focussed on Boston again tonight. Joe Mangan and Gene Venzke get the featured billing in the Hunter Mile, but this is only one of a long list of events bringing together the leading lights of the foot-racing world in the annual Boston A.A. games.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Alix sought inspiration in modern Egypt, Ethiopia and Persia for her showing of new styles. Hard, brilliant color combinations for beach and evening are reminiscent of some of Besnard's North African paintings.
J. Prentice Murphy died the other day in Philadelphia, where he had labored for many years in the interests of children and in the promotion of social welfare generally.

Expense accounts submitted by Hiram C. Todd in 1930 in the Healy-Ewald investigation were used by Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan yesterday to cut Mr. Todd's request for funds to finance the Drukman murder investigation from $43,700 to $20,000.

New bond financing this week was the smallest in volume for any week this year, amounting to $11,516,000, compared with $62,265,700 marketed last week, and with $26,879,000 in the corresponding period of last year.

Snow falling on Capitol Hill yesterday forced the Senate to interrupt its debate on the new Farm Bill just as one member was confessing that while he intended to vote for it he had grave doubts of its constitutionality. Most of these doubts attach to the so-called "stop-gap" feature of the bill, designed to cover the period between now and Jan. 1, 1938, when a State-aid farm plan would be put in operation.

It seems a great pity about Mr. J.P. MORGAN. To have done so well all through the Nye committee inquiry and then at the last minute to slip so badly! Actually it was later than the last minute. The inquiry was all over. Senator NYE had shaken hands with Mr. MORGAN and given him a certificate of good character.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The stock markets here, after a quiet opening, became firmer, with outstanding recovery in the international list in active dealings. British funds moved higher on the success of the Coventry Loan. Peruvian and Brazilian issues again rose.
Deals involving apartment houses and a taxpayer featured realty trading in this city yesterday.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Ethiopian forces in the south are being reinforced and organized for action following a short-lived revolt against Ras Desta Demtu, Ethiopian southern commander and son-in-law of Emperor Haile Selassie, it is reliably reported from Addis Ababa.

Final awards for prize poultry and "the best dozen of eggs" were made yesterday at the exposition of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council, which opened earlier in the week at the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 7. -Minute specks on specially sensitized photographic plates sent thirteen and one-half miles above the earth on the stratosphere balloon Explorer II were interpreted today by a University of Rochester science professor as the tracks of a cosmic ray from outer space exhibiting the tremendous energy of 100,000,000 volts.

A strike of elevator operators and other service employes for pay and hour changes in some 210 hotels of New York City was threatened yesterday by the Building Service Employes Union, Local 32-C. The union voted to send an ultimatum to the Hotel Men's Association, giving the owners until Monday to "show some willingness to arbitrate the demands as prescribed" by the union.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 7. -- The flames of a new controversy sputtered at the Olympic Winter Games today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The domestic producers of manganese ore, speaking through J. Carson Adkerson, president of the American Manganese Producing Association, charged before the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee today that the industry is facing ruin, largely as a result of a 50 per cent cut in the tariff provided for in the reciprocal trade treaty recently negotiated with Brazil.

It was not until Dr. KARL LANDSTEINER, a Nobel Prize winner now with the Rockefeller Institute, discovered the four major types into which human blood may be classified by their agglutinative or clumping properties that physicians understood why some transfusions may be fatal.

The National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, holding its twelfth annual conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania, took a stand yesterday against proposals for the extension of legal censorship of movies to include the power to select pictures to be shown to children.

After months of struggle the city bill requiring compulsory city residence for all recipients of public relief and members of the relief staff was passed yesterday by a vote of 11 to 2 in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The remarkable winning streak of N.Y.U.'s basketball team came to an end tonight, broken by an ambitious Georgetown quintet that heretofore had not amazed the basketball world. The final score was 36 -- 34, a narrow but sufficient margin.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7. -- Appointment of a municipal conciliation and arbitration board of fifteen members to mediate industrial labor disputes was announced today by Mayor S. Davis Wilson. He selected Judge William M. Lewis of the Municipal Court as chairman and made M. Herbert Syme, an attorney named as one of the ten labor members of the board, an Assistant District Attorney to deal with labor matters.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7. -- New Jersey National Guardsmen will combine bombing practice and the feeding of wild fowl in the State next Tuesday when they drop more than 1,500 bags of grain over field and wooded areas.

Steel ingot production in the United States in January amounted to 3,049,439 tons, as compared to 3,081,807 in December and 2,871,531 in January, 1935, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 7. -- With a chance to score an upset by winning the relay race, the Dartmouth swimmers missed by four yards today as the Green lost to Princeton by 43 to 28.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Testimony that the Associated Gas Company "rigged" the stock market in 1929, forced up the price of its Class A stock from $35 to as high as $72, and then used the $8,750,000 profits to buy four new operating companies, was given today before the legislative public utility investigating committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7. -- The Federal claim against the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and a group of subsidiaries for $19,654,856.32 of alleged "unconscionable profits" on wartime contracts was dismissed here today in a special master's report, subject to review by the Federal District Court.

A strike of workers in the local dress industry was voted unanimously by 20,000 members of the dressmakers' union yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden. The strike involves 105,000 here and in near-by communities.

Unanimous opposition to the Buckley-Lavery bills, which would consolidate the probation services in the courts of the city, was expressed yesterday in a letter sent to the Legislature by the nine judges of General Sessions. They said passage of the bills "would be destructive to the probation system built in this court through years of effort and progress, a system generally credited throughout the country as a model of probation efficiency."

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 8. -- Extracts from a speech by Senator Pittman on the Chinese situation were printed this morning in Japanese newspapers. They got secondary publicity, however, being overshadowed by the election news.

Robert Garland, Pittsburgh industrialist, who resigned last week as president of that city's Council, and two of his nephews, one of whom was named defendant last November in a $4,500,000 mail-fraud indictment, were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a new charge.

Whatever else may be said of Senator NORRIS, he always stands up like a man for civil service reform and the merit system. Again and again he endeavored, when bills were pending to create vast new staffs under the New Deal, to have the added employes placed under the civil service rules.
ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Governor Lehman will submit the supplementary budget, probably not exceeding $500,000, to the Legislature early next week, it was indicated today.

The League of Nations was defended and praised for its purposes, program and accomplishments last night at the annual dinner at the Hotel Biltmore of the League of Nations Association, although some speakers saw the need for revision of some of the League's aims.

The market value of all bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased $949,102,850 in January to $40,347,862,478, the Exchange announced yesterday, while the average price rose from $91.85 to $93.59. Feb. 1, there were listed 1,459 issues of $43,113,227,076 par value against 1,463 of $42,893,198,741 par value on Jan. 1.

Edward VIII would be elected President if Britain gave up the monarchy, Sir Charles Higham, British advertising man, said yesterday on his arrival in New York aboard the United States liner Washington after his seventy-second crossing of the Atlantic.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Gaining a three-hole advantage in the first half of the match, Rex Beach, New York novelist, won the ninth annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association today, defeating Grant-land Rice, sports authority, in the eighteen-hole final on the Palm Beach Country Club course.

The dream of regular air service on the North Atlantic to reduce the time between the United States and Europe to two days grew closer to realization with the arrival here yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Hansa of an official German delegation to discuss the possibilities with officials in Washington.

Objections to six bills in the proposed anti-crime legislative program at Albany as "inimical to the welfare and rights of organized labor" have been submitted to Governor Lehman by the representative assembly of the Newspaper Guild of New York, it announced yesterday.

Control of the Detroit Gasket and Manufacturing Company has passed from the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., of Baltimore to the directing heads of the company. This was revealed yesterday in an announcement that arrangements have been completed whereby Lloyd H. Diehl, president, and Edward W. Diehl, secretary and treasurer, and their associates are purchasing all of the outstanding and issued stock.

KENILWORTH, N.J., Saturday, Feb. 8. -- After an executive session that lasted more than four and a half hours, the Board of Education here voted soon after last midnight to dismiss Mrs. Ethel S. Prince, 32 years old, teacher who taped the mouths of two 9-year-old girls because they talked in class.

Your editorial "Japanese Competition" seems to be an argument to increase the purchasing power of Japan in permitting Japan to furnish without limitation goods we can and do use, rather than to increase the purchasing power of our American workmen through the consumption of the goods they make.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 7. -Under the State's social security program, which has been approved by the Federal Government, Confederate pensions in Alabama will be paid in part with Federal funds.

PARIS, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Mikhail Tukhachevsky, the youngest Marshal of the Soviet Army, met France's general staff today to draft the first measures of military cooperation between the two nations in the face of the "menace" of Nazi Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7. -- Two Philadelphia entrants, Miss Anne Page of Merion and Miss Cecile Bowes, Cynwyd captain, today reached the final round of the women's national squash racquets championship by winning on the Merion courts.

The first actual construction work on the Sixth Avenue subway will start about March 15 with the sinking of a shaft alongside Bryant Park, between Fortieth and Forty-second Streets, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday.

Many who have pondered Dr. TOWNSEND'S Plan, though fascinated by it, regret that its beneficent purpose is the comfort of a comparatively small class. A thinker in Iowa, Mr. F.H. MCCABE, editor of The Logan Observer, has broadened its scope and has devised a Plan for Perpetual Prosperity.
A Glen Rock dwelling project and two apartment house sales in Jersey City by a trust company were among the New Jersey realty items reported yesterday.

Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator, disclosed yesterday that he had asked Wayne M. Faunce, vice director of the American Museum of Natural History, to call at his offices, 111 Eighth Avenue, to discuss charges of discrimination by the museum against Negro WPA workers.

H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, challenged yesterday statements made before the Senate Munitions Committee to the effect that government-owned shipyards were able to build naval vessels at lower cost than privately owned yards.
The Harvard Club's Class B team won the championship of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night as a result of its conquest of the Columbia Club team on the neutral courts of the Yale Club.
W.K. Rice of the Harvard Club, seeded third, was one of the favorites to advance yesterday in the Class B championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Harvard Club.
The Manhattan approach to the Triborough Bridge was described to members of the Board of Estimate at City Hall yesterday in a scale model completed by the Park Department after three months' work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission's hearing on the Van Sweringen plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad recessed for the week-end today after the taking of technical testimony tracing the methods used in fixing ratios for the exchange of stock.

That the underlying strength of the share market continues was demonstrated yesterday when a fairly steady flow of profit-taking sales was absorbed handily. The potential demand for stocks is strong, so that recessions in prices do not proceed far.

Making his first competitive appearance since 1931, when he retired in favor of his studies, Dr. George Kojac, former Olympic and world's champion, made a brilliant comeback by capturing the 150-yard metropolitan senior backstroke title at the A.A.U. meet last night at the Downtown A.C.

The first public hearing by the Board of Estimate on the proposed "four-zone" bus plan for Queens brought forth charges by civic workers yesterday that the North Shore Bus Company of Flushing, slated to receive one of the four comprehensive grants, was "backed by the old Equitable crowd" and had "political affiliations."

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- The Boerse opened firm today, but part of the gains was lost at the close. Banks led the upward movement because of dividend expectations, Commerce Bank gaining 2 points, although Reichbank declined fractionally. Heavy industrials were quiet and mixed, although the changes were slight and gains predominated.

An appeal to the workers in the 1936 joint campaign of the Y.M.C.A. and Y.W.C.A. to continue their efforts to fulfill quotas was made yesterday at the last scheduled report luncheon of the campaign held at the Hotel Commodore. It was reported that since the opening of the campaign on Jan. 7, 67 per cent of the $600,000 needed for 1936 expense funds had been raised.

TOKYO, Feb. 7. -- The Soviet-Japanese frontier quarrels are tending toward the creation of a state of armed peace between lands that under sincerely pacific governments might enjoy frontier as costless as Canada's.
" Landscapes from the Seventeenth Century to the Twentieth" is the title given to an exhibition that opened yesterday in the Howard Young Galleries, 677 Fifth Avenue. It will continue until Feb. 28.

A substantial increase in new State and municipal financing is indicated for next week, when issues amounting to $52,572,401 will be offered for sale for 118 communities. This compares with a revised total of $7,715,219 for this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Announcement of an agreement between Mexico and the United States for the protection of migratory birds climaxed the closing session of the North American Wild Life Conference tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Random notes gleaned in the closing hours of the North American Wild Life Conference:

The celebration of the golden jubilee of Grace Lutheran Church, 123 West Seventy-first Street, east of Broadway, will begin tomorrow morning. The program has been arranged by the Rev. Edmund A. Bosch, fourth pastor of the church, who has served since July 1, 1934.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7.--Professor and Mrs. Sherley Warner Morgan of Princeton University entertained with a dance this evening at their home in honor of their niece, Miss Grace Virginia Johnston, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cliffe Johnston of New York. Miss Johnston attended the Mount Vernon Academy in Washington and Holmquist School at New Hope.

With most of the reliable night prowlers either relaxing comfortably under the Florida moon or toasting their shins by the stove, activity in the local joy spots is scarcely what one might call hectic these Winter evenings. The weather is right for coasting -- inside as well as out.

Three robbers who made a bluff at sympathy for the workingman, held up the Bus Terminal Restaurant, a lunch counter at 430 East Ninety-second Street, near First Avenue and opposite the main garage and depot of the East Side Omnibus Corporation, and escaped with $1,475 in cash and jewelry at 2 P.M. yesterday.

The dollar weakened again in foreign exchange yesterday and banks here arranged for the shipment of $1,075,000 more gold to Holland. These engagements, following two days in which no gold had moved, brought to $16,678,000 the gold exports of the current outflow, of which $14,139,000 has been sent to France and $2,539,000 to Holland.

A FRIGID trip to the Medical Center revealed the fact that Mr. Lou Little, who was all cut up, is now fairly well gathered together again. He discarded his crutches two days ago and now carries a cane. He says he will discard the cane shortly, and a good idea it is, too. He flourishes it in a dangerous manner when he starts talking.
BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- George Althaus, a former Protestant pastor in Timmerlach, has been sentenced to six months' imprisonment by the Summary Court in Brunswick, charged with having prayed for Jews.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Two rising young golf luminaries won semi-final round matches in the Miami Biltmore women's golf championship today. Miss Patty Berg, 17-year-old Minneapolis star and runner-up to Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare for the national crown last year, will oppose Miss Marion Miley, daughter of a Lexington (Ky.) professional, in the thirty-six-hole final tomorrow.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Governor Floyd B. Olson replied chidingly today to the Federal court which criticized him over the use of troops to close the Strutwear Knitting Company plant.
ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 7. -- Italian troops on the southern front are suffering a serious shortage of supplies. The vulnerability of long lines of communication also is causing them anxiety.

JOHN GUNTHER'S "Inside Europe" (Harper's, $3.50) is aptly titled. For, to a journalist who loves both to speak his mind freely and to keep his visa, the atmosphere of suppression that is palpable everywhere, even in the countries that are still democratic, must suggest a possible coming time when Europe will be virtually forbidden territory, a newspaper man's Tibet.

LANDISBURG, Pa., Feb. 7. -Farmers who had drilled and dynamited for two weeks on Tuscarora Mountain, twelve miles from here, in patient efforts to free a small white terrier from a rocky prison, laid down their tools m failure this afternoon.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Sir Samuel Hoare is still thoroughly unrepentant for the part he played with former Premier Pierre Laval last December in framing the "peace proposals" by which Italy would have been rewarded for her aggression in Ethiopia by receiving about half of that country's territory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that a considerable shift would have to be made in allocations from the $4,000,000,000 work relief fund to carry forward the Works Progress Administration's program of employment until July 1, the beginning of the new fiscal year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- An increase of 32.5 per cent in buyer attendance, sales gains in proportion, and general reports of "more confident" buying marked the first week of the annual February wholesale showing of women's, children's and infants' wear here.

" The Story of Louis Pasteur," a Warner Brothers film biography of the French scientist, begins an engagement this morning at the Strand. The players are Paul Muni Josephine Hutchinson, Anita Louise and Donald Woods.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Plans for prompt passage of the new $500,000,000-a-year Farm Bill, despite renewed objections that it is not constitutional as drafted, were completed by Senate administration leaders today. Senator Robinson, the majority leader, predicted passage on Monday or Tuesday at the latest.

WASRINGTON, Feb. 7. -- As "the Prince of Bourbons," Postmaster General Farley has brought about a "run-down" condition in the Postoffice Department until it is now the "poorest managed" branch of government, functioning "just about 50 per cent of what it was four years ago," Representative Taber of New York, ranking minority member of the Appropriations Committee, charged in debate today on the $989,673,829 Postoffice and Treasury Bill, which passed without a record vote.

A quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock of the G.C. Murphy Company was declared yesterday, comparing with 40 cents previously paid quarterly. The dividend will not apply to the increased stock, as two additional common shares will be distributed on each common share after the record date.

Bank exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country rose last month to the highest level since December, 1931. The total was $27,587,460,144, a gain of 4.6 per cent over the preceding month and an increase of 7.9 per cent over January a year ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7. -The Harvard basketball team, displaying its best game of the year thus far, defeated a strong Williams five on the floor of the new Harvard gymnasium tonight, 35 to 23. Masters of the situation, with one exception, from the opening whistle, the Crimson played brilliantly.

HAVANA, Feb. 7 (AP). -- George Bernard Shaw arrived in Havana today aboard the S.S. Arandora Star and immediately launched into a discussion of President Roosevelt, the Italo-Ethiopian war, Al Capone and communism.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Between 20 and 30 per cent of all employes of business concerns are "mildly crazy," Dr. Robert N. McMurray, head of the Chicago office of the Psychological Corporation, today told executives attending the meeting of the American Management Association.

The Clearing House Committee, of which James H. Perkins, chairman of the National City Bank, is chairman, met yesterday to consider the proposed regulation U of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, governing bank loans for the purpose of buying or carrying registered securities.

The Whitehead Metal Products Company, in an expansion program, has added 5,000 square feet to its former 10,000 square feet of office space in 304-14 Hudson Street. William S. Sussman, Inc., arranged the rental for the Trinity Church Corporation.

A man and a woman, held as material witnesses in the vice campaign directed by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County, made futile efforts yesterday to obtain their freedom on writs of habeas corpus.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP). -Charging the builder of the Hawk's Nest Tunnel in Southern West Virginia with "grave and inhuman disregard" of the lives of workmen, a House labor subcommittee asked today for funds to complete its inquiry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today introduced evidence to show that the Central Republic Trust Company still owed $54,391,396 on Jan. 15 on loans made by the Federal agency in 1932 and which aggregated $90,000,000.

Three musicians of world-wide repute, Artur Schnabel, pianist; Bronislaw Huberman, violinist, and Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist, combined their talents in a recital of trios at the Town Hall last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Prices of hogs dropped 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight early today, but the forecast of another cold wave with snow over the Central West brought in aggressive buying and at the close sales showed a recovery of 5 to 10 cents.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

An increase in cases of measles in the city last week was reported by the Department of Health. A total of 549 cases were recorded, compared to 278 in the preceding week and 194 for the same week last year. There was one death from this disease.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7. -- The first "show trial" in the Soviet Union since the Metropolitan Vickers case in 1933 opened in Leningrad today with thirty-nine defendants, including former members of the nobility and former officers in the Czar's army.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Race fans crossed their fingers and hoped tonight while the respective boards of strategy of Discovery and Cavalcade went into executive session.
LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The United States found itself temporarily isolated at the naval conference today in demanding continuance of the existing 35,000-ton limit for battleships.
ATHENS, Feb. 7. -- By royal decree today all officers and non-commissioned officers sentenced by court-martial after the March revolution have been finally excluded from the army.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation was disclosed by President Roosevelt today as erecting legal defense against a possible decision by the United States Supreme Court that its preferred bank stockholders are taxable by States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The executive officers of the United Mine Workers of America refused today to accept the salary increases voted by the convention during a heated discussion yesterday.

Building plans submitted by architects yesterday included specifications for a two-story meat-storage plant in West Thirteenth Street and numerous alterations to existing structures in Manhattan. Architects also filed for two six-story tenement houses to be erected on sites in the Bronx.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 7. -- Great Britain coupled victory in its eligibility dispute with a triumph on the ice today as the United States and Canada came through with their second straight conquests in the Olympic ice hockey competition.

The Book-of-the-Month Club has made arrangements with La Societe Nouvelle Sequana in Paris to make available immediately to readers of French in this country the outstanding book published each month in France. A new society has been organized called the French Book-of-the-Month Club, with offices at 386 Fourth Avenue.

The resumption of forward quotations in silver in London earlier in the week indicated a recovery of that market from the dislocations that affected it early in December when our Treasury suddenly withdrew as a purchaser of silver and allowed the price to collapse.
LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The Britons are thought to be a solemn people, but sometimes in the most unexpected places they betray humor that is all the richer because it is entirely unconscious.

With the Middle West and the Rocky Mountain States in the grip of a blizzard that shattered records in many sections yesterday, a snowstorm swept over the Middle Atlantic States from Georgia to New Jersey, leaving most of the Atlantic seaboard in a mantle of white before it veered out to sea off the Jersey coast.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7. -- A new piano keyboard that, although essentially the keyboard now in use, provides seventeen intervals in an octave instead of twelve as at present, has been invented by A.S. Ogolevets, a Moscow musician. It has been perfected with the aid of Y.M. Seletski, musical instrument maker, and has just been demonstrated before a gathering of Moscow musicians and scientists.

WARSAW, Feb. 7. -- Germany had a decidedly bad press in Poland today, reminiscent of the days before the Polish-German non-aggression pact was signed in January, 1934, when the Reich was regarded as among this nation's worst enemies.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 7 (AP). -President Arturo Alessandri and General Luis Cabrera, Minister of the Interior, signed a decree tonight declaring a state of siege in all of Chile south of the Province of Aconcagua. The decree, issued in connection with the five-day-old strike on the national railways, will be effective for three months.

Declaring that the "cynical indifference" of the Roosevelt administration has "lowered the morality of the political life of the nation," James M. Beck, former Solicitor General of the United States, appealed yesterday afternoon to the women of the country, regardless of political affiliations, to join with the Republican party in the coming Presidential election and defeat the New Deal for "your children and children's sake."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Senator Borah announced today that he would enter the Oregon primaries on May 15, with the assured support of Senator McNary, Senate minority leader, and his colleague, Senator Steiwer. Ralph H. Williams, vice chairman of the Republican National Committee, who is regarded as a conservative, also will advocate the candidacy of the Idaho Senator, it was understood.

La Salle Academy strengthened its hold on the lead in the Manhattan-Richmond Division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball tournament by overwhelming De La Salle Institute, 36 to 16, at Goodard gymnasium yesterday.

With the arrest of two manufacturers and the seizure of nearly a ton of metal slugs yesterday, authorities made public official figures indicating that the New York Telephone Company suffered a "money value loss" of more than $315,000 in this city last year from the fraudulent use of slugs in coin instruments.

Bernard Gilman, 55 years old, reputedly wealthy paper stock dealer of 131 East Broadway, who conducted his business in candle light and otherwise in the manner of a past generation, was found dead in his shop last night. His body was found on the floor, bound and propped against a barrel.

Mrs. David H. Kincheloe gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 115 East Eighty-sixth Street, for Mrs. Edward C. Shields of Washington, who is visiting the hostess. The other guests were Mrs. Murray Hulbert, Mrs. Walter Annette, Mrs. William Hammack, Mrs. Blaney Mitchell, Mrs. William Field Hackett, Mrs. P.A. Kenna, Mrs. Charles Saunders, Mrs. J.A. Atkinson, Mrs. Bernard Levy, Miss Genevieve Kincheloe and Miss Jean Hulbert.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 7. -- Plunging headlong down sheer mountain slopes and precipitous forest trails on their skis, some hundred competitors from fifteen countries today inaugurated the Alpine sport of downhill racing as an Olympic event.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The New York Edison Company, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $55,000,000 of first lien and refunding mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series D, due on Oct. 1, 1965.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- The legislative Utility Investigating Committee, in concluding its questioning of Public Service Commissioners today, heard two commission members urge additional trial lawyers and hearing deputies to expedite the handling of rate-reduction cases.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Feb. 7 (AP). -- President Lazaro Cardenas, on his arrival here tonight to study conditions that led business men to stage an unprecedented demonstration against communism this week, declared "communism does not exist in Mexico."

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, announced yesterday from his home in Norwich that he would go to the Republican National Convention as a delegate from the Thirty-fourth Congressional District instead of a delegate at large, as his official position would entitle him to.
Value of Dollar in Exchange. The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares a. follows. Quotations are in cents:

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7. -Professor Albert Einstein, who promulgated his theory of relativity in 1905, replied today to criticism of the theory by Dr. Ludwig Silberstein of Toronto in the current issue of The Physical Review.

THE TIMES of Jan. 30 and 31 contained two news items relative to Finland and her debt payments to the United States. It appears that Finnish ship owners who hold certain claims against the United States for damages suffered during the war are attempting to collect by combining their claims with Finland's annual payments to the United States.

Textile High School's quintet got off to a flying start in the defense of its city P.S.A.L. crown by downing Haaren High, 35 -- 19, at Textile, in one of the two games that ushered in the competition in the Manhattan division of the league yesterday.

Despite adverse weather conditions, retail trade in the metropolitan area continued quite active this week. Volume on the first two days was not particularly good, but sales increased toward the close. Home furnishings sales continued to meet with strong consumer interest.

ROME, Feb. 7. -- Today's news from Geneva is regarded as encouraging, as far as an oil embargo is concerned. It is thought that the reports of various subcommittees of the experts' committee have dealt a death blow to the proposal.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- A medley of modes, which failed to establish a definite silhouette, marked the fortnight of Spring fashion shows just ended. They were said to have been attended by fewer American buyers than last season.

Ethiopian forces, having lost the first round of the contest to Italy in a purely military sense, may now be expected to reorganize more sensibly. The King of Kings, having seen that his tremendous efforts at military organization are gone to chaos, cannot but learn the lesson that his infantry will never be able to face the combined arms of Italian power.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Keene Valley crews captured first and second places in the National A.A.U. senior two-man bobsled championships at the Mount Van Hoevenberg run today.

Aroused by a recent increase in poor materials and inferior home-construction methods being used by some builders, the New York State Department of Labor and the Attorney General's office in Albany have enlisted the aid of the Federal Housing Administration to stamp out unscrupulous practices in this field.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Cornell's five moved into a second-place tie in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League today by defeating Penn, 36 -- 31, before a junior week crowd of 3,000 persons in the drill hall.

Secretary ICKES has made himself the champion of those who believe that both national and State parks should retain large areas of primitive wilderness, and should not be laced with too many highways. He does not even believe in the "skyline drives" about which much has been heard lately. "I am a heretic on this subject," he confessed to those assembled at the Wild-life Conference in Washington last week.

THE public of today, much more, I think, than any public of the past, craves to know. Like Budge and Toddy of the long defunct "Helen's Babies," it wants to see the wheels go round. Some one up at the Brooklyn Museum must have a keen sense of the time-spirit, for an exhibition has just been put on there in which information is packed to the running-over point.
I have read with great interest your review of the French film, "Itto," directed by Jean Benoit Levy, that eminent producer of the supreme film, "La Maternelle."

Senator Arthur Meighen, former Prime Minister of Canada, criticized last night this country's policy of "isolated neutrality" at the annual dinner of the Candian Society of New York at the Biltmore Hotel.

The Women's Prison Association of New York and the Isaac T. Hopper Home, 110 Second Avenue, cared for 620 delinquent and potentially delinquent women last year. Of these 483 were correctional cases of women on probation, parole and with suspended sentences. There were eighty-one preventive cases, most of them from the Crime Prevention Bureau, and fifty-six additional cases. The figures were included in the ninety-first annual report of the association.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- A sleigh-ride for 500 is planned as one of the features of a Washington's Birthday Winter carnival being arranged by the Mount Greylock Ski Club for the amusement of skiers and others expected to arrive for Winter sports on the holiday week-end.

Evidence that the lines are being formed in a new trend of competition between the railroads and highway vehicles is afforded by recent moves by both services. An actuating factor has been the placing of commercial highway traffic under the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Picketing was appraised as an ineffective way four labor to express its grievances by Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein in an address yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the labor law committee of the Labor Research Front in the Grand Street Boys Club, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

The relief project carried on in the public schools to conserve the hearing of children, which includes audiometer testing and lip reading, has been recognized as one of the most important services rendered by the WPA, and it is planned to incorporate it in the regular educational program when Federal funds are unavailable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Three men who retired from the Federal Reserve Board will remain in its service, it was announced today. They are Dr. Adolph C. Miller and Charles S. Hamlin, original members of the board and J.J. Thomas. George R. James, who also was not reappointed by the President when the board was reorganized, will resume his business connections in Memphis, Tenn.

DUBLIN, Feb. 7. -- No event in recent times has emphasized more the peculiar paradoxical position the Irish Free State occupies in the British Commonwealth of Nations than the recent accession of Edward VIII to the throne. In the Free State alone among the nations of the Commonwealth the new King was not proclaimed, although courtesy was shown to the royal family in their bereavement.

An increase of 10 per cent in industrial activity, reflected in a greater degree by capital goods than consumption goods, is forecast for 1936 by a Wall Street investment banking firm which last week completed an intensive field survey which was intended to be a check-up on the firm's optimistic outlook at the turn of the year.

LENINGRAD, Feb. 8. -- Kisseleff, a former peasant who is not particularly bright in appearance and who is alleged to have piled up a fortune in a little more than two years, was the chief witness today at the second session of the trial here of thirty-nine alleged speculators and organizers of illegal factories.
A mechanized world of transport is presented in miniature in the offices and laboratories of the New York Society of Model Engineers in the Knickerbocker Building, 152 West Forty-second Street.

Members of the Hollins College Club of New York will hold their annual card party next Saturday afternoon at the Biltmore. During the afternoon there will be an entertainment by Miss Harriet Taylor, character reader, and Charles Wheeler, color cartoonist.

ISTANBUL, Feb. 7. -- In the presence of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk and members of the Cabinet the new school of history, geography and literature recently was opened at Angora. Its immediate purpose is to make the capital the cultural center of the republic and, combined with the law school, it will be the nucleus of a complete university, sister of the one at Istanbul.

PARIS, Jan. 22, 1936. INTERNATIONAL musical performances will have an important part in the fetes of the Paris season this year, according to the program that has already been outlined by the committee.

Class-room work in spelling practice is uneconomical both in time and effort and should be abandoned in the higher schools, Dr. Alice E. Watson of Teachers College, Columbia University, asserted in a report on "Experimental Studies in the Psychology and Pedagogy of Spelling," made public yesterday.

THE anniversary week of the Boy Scouts of America which began yesterday, the twenty-sixth birthday of the movement in this country, will be celebrated today in churches throughout the nation. Ministers will preach sermons of special interest to youth, and with the character-building emphasis of scouting in mind.

Five thousand of the city's brightest school children signed pledges yesterday afternoon to report acts of vandalism in fifty-five parks of the five boroughs as part of their activities in the Junior Park Protective League.

Last week, the Stock Exchange gave out its usual monthly compilation of total market valuation of all stocks listed on the Exchange, and their average price per share. In light of the market's prolonged recovery during 1935, the figures suggest interesting comparisons. Total valuation as of the end of January was the highest since March, 1931.

Led by the national doubles champions, Nell Sullivan and Roy Coffin, three Philadelphia teams gained the semi-final round yesterday in the annual University Club invitation squash racquets tourney for the Lockett Trophy.

IN Proverbs, Chapter 19, the fourteenth verse, it is written that "a prudent wife is from the Lord." Huey P. Long, thumbing his Bible for the texts of his tub-thumping campaign speeches, must have seen the passage many times and given thanks that he, man of destiny that he believed himself to be, was thus blessed of heaven.

PRESIDENTS come and go, but Abraham Lincoln still lives in the community life of the Pueblo Indians of New Mexico. Canes presented by Lincoln to the governors of each pueblo are their official insignia.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- Further profit-taking in the early trading on the Bourse today caused a new decline in prices, but toward the end of the session there was marked recovery, especially in foreign securities like Royal Dutch and gold mines.

COLUMBUS, Feb. 8. -- Backers of Senator Borah for the Republican Presidential nomination made the first definite move today for Ohio's support by obtaining petitions allowing him to enter a full slate of delegates in the May primary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Money in circulation, following the seasonal tendency, decreased $144,173,372 in January and at the end of the month amounted to $5,737,352,474, the Treasury announced today. The month-end peak for 1935 was $5,881,525,846, at the end of December. After that there was the normal flow of currency back to the Treasury.

BRITISH miners recently agreed to accept a wage increase averaging 18 cents a week as a step toward settlement of the problem of coal, which led to the general strike of 1926, and which again has arisen to remind Britain of the areas of depression that still remain, of the limitations of a trade recovery based upon a protected domestic market and upon the acceptance of restrained and shrunken international trade.

ROME, Feb. 8. -- Today's official war bulletin says that General Rodolfo Graziani's advance northward from Dolo up the Webbe Gestro Valley continues. The general opinion here, however, is that the advance is not a major offensive, but merely is a secondary move to make the right flank of the main Italian force in Noghelli secure against surprise attacks.
OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 7. -- Circumstances conspired to make the opening of the eighteenth Parliament of Canada, on Thursday this week, most interesting and unusual.

So quietly that no fanfare has attended its progress, a world-girdling mobilization for peace has been launched in New York within the last few weeks. So effectively has the groundwork been laid by Mrs. Clara Guthrie d'Arcis, representing the peace and disarmament committee of the Women's International Organizations, that an impressive announcement of support from great corporations is anticipated at a luncheon late this month.

There has recently appeared in the press the remarks of Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, analyzing the progressive increase in Federal expenditures. There is much food for thought in this searching analysis.
Employers Warn of City's Loss if Demands Force Flight -- Mayor Awaits Reports.

THE party chieftains have marshaled their lieutenants before the microphone and the oratorical battles of 1936 are under way. To all who twirl the dials of a receiving set come the voices of political figures, praising, blaming, pleading, denouncing. Broadcasting has become a feature of political campaigning, but to what good?

THERE are many varieties of "this business of exploring," with aspects as different as are the depths of the sea from mountain heights, the arid desert from steaming jungles. The particular variety upon which Roy Chapman Andrews, director of the American Museum of Natural History and leader of the Central Asiatic expeditions, has made himself an authority is the northern desert kind, for the greater part of his exploring has been in the Gobi Desert.

THE extent to which specific diseases have affected the course of history and pointed the finger of destiny for man is the interesting theme of this book. Dr. Major, who is Professor of Pathology in the Medical School of the University of Kansas, is the author of several previous books which set forth some of the curious phases of medicine for the provocative Information and entertainment of laymen.

CHILDREN'S theatres as an educational medium to augment the curriculum in the public schools are to be discussed by the triennial conference of the Children's Theatre Department of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, opening tomorrow in Baltimore.

Charges of disorderly conduct were brought against ten women and twenty-three men, members of the City Projects Council, who were arrested shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday while engaged in mass picketing in front of the American Museum of Natural History at Seventy-seventh Street near Central Park West.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- The combined men's and women's national singles championships were awarded again to the West Side Tennis Club of Forest Hills, L.I., today at one of the shortest and most harmonious annual meetings held by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Discussions at Albany last week between Governor Lehman, the party leaders in the Legislature and heads of State agencies marked the beginning of the transition from emergency unemployment relief to a permanent system able to deal with the casualties of the depression and with unemployment as a continuing problem.

DEFENSE against air attack assumes for the continental United States many special features not applicable to countries with a different geographical situation. Measures of defense may be conveniently divide into two categories:

Through a coordinating committee on architecture, New York's World Fair, which is to open in 1939, will have a unified plan of architecture and landscaping, George McAneny, president of the fair, said at a luncheon yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.

MYSTERY, melodrama and romance are the chief ingredients of Miss Martin's new novel The chief interest lies in Dr. Harbold's crafty plan for the death of his wealthy young wife, and in his assistant's efforts to thwart his scheme.

IN spite of its ludicrous title. "The Maker of Heavenly Trousers" is not at all a comical book. It is a sort of combination journal and romance, written in the first person but with delicate detachment by a scholarly recluse who lived in an old house in Peiping far from the legation quarter.

The keen enjoyment I derived from it Christmas gift of Burns Mantle's "The Best Plays" prompts me to suggest a supplement to the tentative plans announced by the New York film critics -- namely, that of publishing in book form the scenario of the year's best film, in this instance "The Informer."

SOME years ago the French put up a memorial to the Norman farmer's wife who discovered Camembert, and now the English are planning similar honors to the Leicestershire woman who discovered Stilton. Sir John Squire, the critic, has formed a Stilton memorial committee, and the memorial is to be put up as soon as the committee is able to decide who is to be commemorated by it and what form it is to take.

A young Harvard Law School graduate, Jack Comerford, craves a bit of excitement, gets himself a job as an unofficial G-Man, and goes out after Mack Shenton, who prides himself on being called "the best known man on Broadway." Jack's job is to prove that Shenton is the man who is flooding the country with illegal liquor.

Sloops, the one-masted craft looked upon by many as feather-weather and millpond creations as far as real racing is concerned, are to strive for honors with schooners, which long have held prominence in deep water, in the newly thought out blue-ocean event of the Larchmont Yacht Club next July.

I have listened with murder in my heart to the announcer in the broadcast of 'Tanhaeuser" while he persistently referred to Elisabeth as "Madame Flachschtad." I have often heard the same pronunciation from people in the audience at the Metropolitan, who probably take their cue from the radio announcers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Formation of a State traffic control commission to correlate highway ordinances was asked today by the Young Men's Republican Clubs of Westchester County, in annual convention at the county Republican headquarters.

AFTER listening to a piano recital by Harold Bauer last Tuesday evening members of the American Woman's Association and their friends went up to the galleries on the third floor of the A.W.A. clubhouse for the opening of the annual exhibition of oils and sculpture by members.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7. -- Unrest flared up this week in three South American countries.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday granted permission to Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard, granddaughter of John D. Rockefeller, to bring before the Court of Appeals her claim for the payment at once of four-sevenths of the principal of a trust fund of $12,000,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8. -- Johnny Higgins, powerful swimmer from the Providence Boys' Club, created a new world's record tonight for the 200-yard breast stroke during a meet in which Yale defeated its Rhode Island rival, 41 -- 30.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8. -- Not only does Soviet Russia possess the largest army in the world -- it is now turning its attention seriously toward rapid upbuilding on a large scale of its navy, in which the country is now admittedly weak in view of its enormous coast line, divided among many separated seas.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- A supper dance will be held on Saturday at the Scarsdale Golf Club to augment the philanthropic fund of the Scarsdale Woman's Club. Mrs. William Leslie is chairman of the committee, and Mrs. William Britton Stitt is general chairman.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- With the Stock Exchange closed today, money was plentiful in Lombard Street. Loans over the week-end were available at one-half of 1 per cent, while the three-month bill rate was unchanged at nine-sixteenths to five-eighths of 1 per cent.

ONE is so accustomed, these days, to thinking of the Southern share-croppers in terms of their economic plight that "Butcher Bird" has an air of strangeness about it. Mr. Davis's cotton field Negroes, who work on Caney Brake Plantation in the Deep South, are not flagrantly the victims of depression.

THIS Freudian nightmare drags one painfully through distorted passions and wild metaphysical speculations. It begins, familiarly enough, with two men on a park bench -- the callow youth who is the author's mask and the strange, older man with the heavy head and sorrowful features whose gestures and mouthings alternately startle and fascinate his unwilling companion.
Hard-fought matches featured the second round of the metropolitan squash racquets Class B singles championship at the Harvard Club yesterday.
