The Lamport Holt Line of Liverpool has just ordered four 10,000-ton motor ships with a speed of 15 knots for the fast freight and passenger business between New York and Buenos Aires, in which it has been engaged for more than seventy years.

The "Interrogation Luncheon" to be held at the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue, on Thursday, is an invention of Mrs. Edgerton Parsons, who will preside. She tried it out first at the 1934 Conference on the Cause and Cure of War, of which she has been treasurer from its very beginning, and again this year, and found it so successful that it is being used increasingly.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- As one by one France's royal visitors take their departure, the public authorities and police are breathing more freely. For the memory of the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia has weighed heavily on the mind of Premier Albert Sarraut, who is again Minister of the Interior, as he was when King Alexander was slain, and on all his subordinates.

Forty youngsters from the neighborhood of Hell's Kitchen are becoming artists with some ideas of their own about perspective, color and detail, but amenable, nevertheless, to instruction on a project of the Catholic Youth Association. They are now preparing for an exhibition of their works next month in the association's building, 410 West Nineteenth Street.

HISTORY may not be past politics, but it is certainly present politics so far as Professor Myers and Mr. Newton are concerned. What they have written is not history; it is a political tract in disguise. What they have done is to establish an arsenal from which the Republican candidate in 1936 can draw ammunition, especially should that candidate be one who feels the need for defending the past.

ARTHUR SCHWIEDER is marshaling his forces for a direct attack on our walls. That becomes patent. And a vigorous, rewarding attack it promises to be. There are two mural designs in his present one-man show at the Montross (current until Feb. 15), both of which demonstrate a real capacity in this popular though so often misunderstood direction.

ANOTHER communication offering a reply to Rev. A.R.E. Greer's comment on a painting by Georgia O'Keeffe in her one-man show at An American Place has come in. E.M. Kusain of this city writes as follows:

FRENCH discussions with government officials in this country in regard to air service by France in the North Atlantic area will be conducted by Jean Schneider, Secretary General of Air France, and Edmond Manier, secretary of the directors committee of the French Line.

The annual report of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for 1935, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $5,949,307 after expenses, depreciation, interest, provision for Federal taxes and other charges. The earnings equal $3.16 a share on 1,882,240 shares outstanding on Dec. 31.

Bernardino Molinari will officiate as guest conductor at the sixth New York concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra, to be given Tuesday evening, Feb. 18, at Carnegie Hall. Alexander Kelberine will be soloist in the New York premiere of Pizzetti's piano concerto, "Canti della Stagione Alta."

Teachers from 115 high schools and preparatory schools in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut last week entered the Constitution Contest for the best teaching-plans or articles which THE NEW YORK TIMES opened last Monday. This is the first in the series of prize contests THE TIMES will conduct, first for teachers and later for students, in 1936 and 1937 as part of the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the Constitution.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons skated rings around their local National Hockey League rivals, the Canadiens, to score a 7-to-2 victory tonight and clinch the Kennedy Cup, emblem of the professional hockey championship of Montreal.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 8. -- A remarkable story of adventure in the jungle is told by passengers of a Bolivian seaplane who have arrived at Puerto Suarez, in the Bolivian Chaco, after awaiting rescue for about two weeks in Matto Grosso.
IN a statement issued last week by the American Petroleum Industries Committee, the tax situation as it affects motorists in New York is presented as follows:

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- The Island of Nantucket was ice bound for the second time within eight days today, and with ice again closing Buz zard's Bay entrance to the Cape Cod Canal, and a forecast of another cold wave over the week-end, a renewal of last week's ice blockade along the New England coast seemed inevitable tonight.

Long Island University's five remained the only unbeaten college basketball team in the metropolitan district by defeating Brooklyn College, 33 -- 21, last night in the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium before an overflow crowd.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica. -- Costa Rica votes for President on Feb. 9 and will choose twenty-two new Congressmen on the same day. A clear majority of the popular vote is required for election of a President. Because of the close race between Leon Cortes and Octavio Beeche, the principal candidates, the Communist candidate, Carlos Saenz, may get enough votes to require a second ballot.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Senate's agreement, however reluctant, permitting the Nye munitions committee to finish its assignment -- probably next week -- furnishes a measure of the public interest stirred by the investigation into the relationship between the profit motive and war.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Valentine parties at nearly all of the hotels and a fashion show at the Don Caesar on Pas-a-Grille Beach dominate activities here this week.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The thunder of heavy guns in the battle over Governor Lehman's executive budget for the fiscal year beginning on July 1 is still some days off. But preliminary skirmishing on Capitol Hill has now progressed far enough to render it an enterprise not too venturesome to forecast the strategy of the Republican offensive against the Governor's big money bill.

A 21-year-old New York University athlete, Milton Aronauer, occupied the spotlight at the second annual Yorkville Athletic League games on the Seventh Regiment Armory track last night. A crowd of 4,000 watched the meet, which was sponsored by the Yorkville Advance and the Yorkville Civic Council.

Election of a successor to Miss Katherine Devereux Blake, widely known educator, as State chairman of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom will be held on Wednesday at 99 Park Avenue during the annual meeting of the organization.

FOR the past few years it has become increasingly difficult to comment on the work of Kay Boyle. Repetition is almost unavoidable. With each new book one is forced to restate the obvious, to say that Miss Boyle's style is as shimmering and fastidious as ever but that her content is dangerously thin.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Elmer B. O'Hara, chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee of Michigan, and fourteen others were convicted of election fraud by a Recorder's Court jury today. Three of four others who chose trial without a jury were convicted by the court.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- In the two weeks period ending Jan. 18, 538 certificates of automobile registration and licenses to drive were revoked or suspended by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- John E. Mack, counsel to the legislative committee investigating the public utilities, warned the utility companies today to eliminate "unfair practices'' and reduce rates, or face the threat of extinction through the rise of public ownership.

LAKE TITICACA, in Bolivia, is to be put to work. The romantic setting of the Inca civilization, the fountain of many legends, is being studied by engineers with a view to tapping it for power. This would provide part of the nation with cheap current for the development of mining, the electrification of railways and the illumination of cities and towns.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa. -- Next week-end will find more than 100 undergraduates, graduates, faculty members of Haverford College and their guests here for the fifth annual Winter sports house party and musical clubs concert. With the Poconos enjoying the largest snowfall in more than a decade, it is predicted that all previous records of attendance for this affair will be broken.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 8. -- Almost 150 members of the north country colonies attended the benefit skating dinner tonight at the Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club at Mill Neck for the Speedwell Unit, an entertainment that had been postponed from time to time during the season on account of the weather.

WITH rail travel heavy to California and Florida, with cruise ships still carrying sun seekers toward the tropics, announcements of Spring and Summer vacation itineraries might appear a bit premature.

THIS book has one compelling merit. It may contain little that is new to the instructed historians of the eighteenth century. It may be a sketch only of the period and its personalities. But, by an undesigned coincidence, it appears at a dramatic moment when it happens to be just what all of us are interested in reading.

WARSAW, Feb. 8. -- Three peasants were killed and several were wounded when the police fired on a mob in the village of Szetlewek, 150 miles from Warsaw, as they were searching for the Nationalist ringleaders who organized anti-Jewish riots in the town of Zagorow.

Legal rights of the crew of an aircraft in international service are among the agenda, it was ascertained yesterday, for a meeting of the Citeja, or International Technical Committee of Aerial Legal Experts, which will be held in Paris during the week of Feb. 24.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 8 (AP). -- A return to "the square deal" of President Theodore Roosevelt was demanded tonight by Senator Vandenberg at a Lincoln Day dinner which opened the 1936 Republican campaign in Michigan.

BY a process of cooperation between the States and their local communities with the Federal Government and its centralized facilities, a thorough guide to the United States is in preparation under the auspices of the Works Progress Administration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Government officials expressed confidence tonight that the Supreme Court would announce on Monday a decision, probably split, in the Tennessee Valley Act case.

THIRTY-THREE years have passed since the first copy of a Kipling book came into the hand that writes these words. It was the eighth printing of "The Seven Seas," then in its fifty-eighth thousand, a buckram crown octavo volume selling at 6 shillings, or about $1, net.

WARSAW, Feb. 7. -- The second anniversary of the Polish-German non-aggression pacts, signed in Berlin at the end of January, 1934, has given the government press of Warsaw and Berlin an opportunity to exchange amiabilities and compliments, but events have contradicted the official editorials.

THE prominent and prolific Peruvian literary critic, Luis Alberto Sanchez, has entitled one of his eighteen published volumes: "America: A Novel Without Novelists." Though more dramatic narrative material is at hand than in most countries, the fiction art has been relatively slighted by South American writers.

SUSPICION of a bar sinister or exotic blood will set most any of us to staring with fascination at a new acquaintance, and Miss Lofts has played upon this romantic falling of ours very adroitly in her first novel. For our delight she has crossed an imaginary English family with gypsy, Negro and noble blood and followed its wanderings down the course of four centuries.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 8. -- At 17 years of age many high school and preparatory school students are sufficiently mature socially and intellectually to enter college and should be encouraged to do so, according to Delmar Leighton, dean of freshmen at Harvard College.

The man who drives a golf ball and the man who drives a car have this in common: both are in control -- or lacking in control -- of fast-moving objects capable of inflicting damage to property and injury to life.

GRAZ, Austria, Feb. 8. -- Richard Strauss's opera, "The Silent Woman," shelved shortly after its premiere in Dresden and prohibited throughout Germany because the librettist, Stefan Zweig, is a Jew, had its first performance outside of Germany tonight in the Graz Municipal Theatre before a large audience, including many musicians from Vienna.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 8. -- State Highway forces on Wednesday morning began parking a mile stretch of the Kings Highway in preparation for the ceremony on l Feb. 22 that will open the Cherry Tree Memorial Boulevard connecting this city with old Washington Family Homestead Farm in Stafford, where, according to historians and tradition, young Washington chopped down his father's valued cherry tree and thus established America's most famous class room story.

Featured by an old-fashioned quadrille, an elaborate fashion promenade of lace gowns, many carnival attractions and a floor show entertainment, the Lace Ball will take place on Tuesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

BROADCASTING in South Africa, after the current year, will be under the direct control of the Union Government, according to a report from the commercial attache of the Department of Commerce at Johannesburg.

The New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association has arranged a subscription benefit for the Washington Cathedral at performances of the motion picture "The Petrified Forest" on Feb. 19 at the Radio City Music Hall. Funds realized through the benefit will be used to commemorate New York under the "Union of States" plan, in which a week of special observances is set aside for the different Commonwealths, in the cathedral in the nation's capital.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 8 (AP). -- Kansans awaited sadly tonight the final return of Charles Curtis to the banks of the Kaw -- his birthplace and always his homing spot during the long years of his rise from reservation Indian to the Vice Presidency of the United States.

Preliminary plans were outlined last week for a continuous program during the next four months of competitive sports, contests and conferences on youth problems, leading to a Boys' Exposition on June 1, 2 and 3, out of which it is hoped a youth planning commission or a regional social plan for boys may be evolved.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8. -- In celebration of the birthday of Milton W. Holden, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer entertained tonight with a dinner for 100, Guests Included:
An ancient Greek masterpiece of sculpture in bronze has been added to the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art through a gift of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Neilson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- A sweeping investigation of the present standard of safety in commercial aviation will be opened on Monday by a subcommittee of the Senate Commerce Commission. All Cabinet members, officials from nearly all government departments, experts in various fields connected with aviation, pilots and airline officials have been invited to testify.

CUBAN Senoras and Senoritas voted in the recent national election for the first time in the island's history -- a right they gained following the Pan-American conference in Montevideo in 1934, when Cuba, Uruguay, Paraguay and Ecuador signed a treaty granting equal rights to women.

ALTHOUGH "Minuet" gives evidence of prodigious scholarship (involving a knowledge of some of the most deadly dull books and plays ever written), it is the work of a man who is something besides scholar. In surveying French and English literary ideas of the eighteenth century, Professor Green is chiefly interested not in cramming us with facts but in presenting us with opinions.

HOMER D. MARTIN (1836-1897) had become all but lost to us in the mist that enshrouds a mood and a manner whence our modern world has raced, in this short space of time, so far. For many of us he exists merely as a name, or little more than that, bracketed with other names attaching to our American landscape tradition.
OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 8 (AP). -- Hopeful physicians increased 15-ounce Nancy Lee Vogt's diet and put her on a "between meals" feeding schedule today.
With Police Commissioner Valentine present at the start, three automobiles left police headquarters yesterday on a month's tour of the city to demonstrate methods of safe driving.

With a total of 533 dogs on the benches, the Associated Terrier Clubs will hold their annual combined specialty shows today in the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue at Forty-sixth Street. It will be one of the largest exhibitions yet held by the organization, nine specialty clubs participating.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 7. -- In these days when a balanced budget puts a State in the front rank and carries with it a badge of honor, Nevada steps forth to answer the roll.

THE polls are closed, the returns are in and Charlie Chaplin has been re-elected king of the clowns. In "Modern Times," which opened Wednesday night at the Rivoli before an audience of his loyal subjects, his comic majesty was restored to the waiting throne which he had abdicated five long years ago.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The Sunday Observer in an interview published today quotes Premier Benito Mussolini as saying that the British "have turned a colonial war into what may yet be a world-wide disaster." The interview was with Sir Arnold Wilson, a member of Parliament.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- Dominating the play from the opening strokes, Miss Anne Page of Merion captured the women's national squash racquets singles championship today by defeating Miss Cecile Bowes of Cynwyd in straight games on the Merion Cricket Club court.

Some of the wizardy of modern methods of communication will be brought into play, it was revealed yesterday, when the New York Museum of Science and Industry dedicates its new home in Rockefeller Center on Tuesday evening.

In the old nursery rhyme riddle from which the title of this book is taken there are, if we remember correctly, forty-nine cats. There is only one cat in this story, but that cat is the cause that lands Miss Belinda Stebbins plump in the middle Of a murder mystery.

J. HOLLAND ROSE writes with singular freshness and charm about man and his conquest of the sea. He has a certain poetical illumination of mind with which he visions man's attitude toward the sea in those long ago centuries when he was first challenging its mysteries, terrors and alluring wonders and with which he studies the developments of later times.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Machinery is a creator of jobs, not a destroyer of employment opportunities, according to a study issued today by the Machinery and Allied Products Institute entitled, "Ten Facts on Technology and Employment." The study, which covers technological advancement, was prepared to dispel the belief that machinery has contributed to unemployment, according to John W. O'Leary, president of the institute.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 8. -- Miss Patty Berg, 17-year-old Minneapolis star, captured her second championship in as many weeks by defeating Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., the Western champion, in the thirty-six-hole final for the Miami Biltmore women's golf crown today, 4 and 3.

IN the history of our continent there is no more heroic nor adventurous period than that of the early exploration and settlement of the West. First came the Spaniards; and, in their conquest of this vast territory, army and church marched together.

The omnibus, once the commonest form of passenger transportation on Broadway, will return to that thoroughfare on Wednesday, replacing the street car. This time it will be a commodious, speedy-gasoline-propelled vehicle, as contrasted with the rattling horse-drawn bus which made its last trip on June 20, 1885, after a generation of public service.

PROMISES made in the columns of this section of the paper are proverbially made to be broken. Will Rogers used to say, "All I know is what I read in the papers," and he might well have added, "except what I read on the theatrical page."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Another of the series of "informals" for undergraduates of Union College and of Skidmore College, sponsored by Mrs. Henry T. Moore and Mrs. Dixon Ryan Fox, took place here today in historic Hanna Hall.

MADISON, Wis. -- One hundred years old this Spring, the Wisconsin State Library is the pioneer book-lending institution of the Northwest. It was created by the act of Congress that established the Wisconsin Territory. The act was approved on April 20, 1836, by President Andrew Jackson.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The army, borrowing an idea from the daredevil's polo automobile, hopes soon to take the jar out of airplane nose-overs, thus saving the necks of its pilots.

IN 1636 Isaac Jogues, a French Jesuit, landed in Canada to become a missionary among the Indians. Ten years later he fell under an Iroquois hatchet, a martyr to his faith. On June 29, 1930, he was elevated to sainthood by Pope Pills XI.

BOTH the Federal Art Project Gallery at 7 East Thirty-eighth Street and the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee at 62 West Fifty-third Street have opened new exhibitions -- the former current until Feb. 19 and the latter through Feb. 15.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- To see -- or not to see -- whether Hamlet bites, twenty men and women offered today to thrust their bare hands into the mouth of Mrs. W. Forbes Morgan's Great Dane.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 8. -- Use of high explosive bombs should be the next step in manoeuvres of the General Headquarters air force, Lieut. Col. Russell Maxwell, ordnance officer at Langley Field, Va., said tonight in commenting upon the success of the recent manoeuvres in Florida which stressed communications and those in progress in New England in which weather has been the big problem.

Several thousand Columbia University alumni of the United States, Canada and Mexico will unite in a "Pan-American" celebration of Lincoln's birthday, Feb. 12, on the Morningside campus, Edmund A. Prentis Jr., president of the Alumni Federation, announced yesterday.

MORE than thirty years of the art of that French poet of blues and grays, Boudin, are represented in the well-selected group of his paintings at the Durand-Ruel Galleries (through Feb. 21). The son of a sea captain, who turned from following the sea to paint it and its craft from the shore, Boudin must have found the impressionists who succeeded him high of key after his beautiful but sober harmonies.

SHANGHAI -- Nation-wide student demonstrations against the granting of autonomy to the northern provinces have again brought to the fore the crippling censorship under which the Chinese press labors. The students themselves are now clamoring to have the government grant real freedom to the press.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- An 18-year-old Ontario County girl with bobbed hair, blue eyes and dimples "baked" herself a trip to New York and Chicago in the State cherry-pie baking contest today.

GEORGE ADE, at 70, after a long retirement from literary production, is turning his hand once more to the fables in slang that made him famous some forty years ago. He calls his newest "The Fable of the Wearisome Business of Repairing and Improving the Whole Works," and he discusses it with enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON. MORE than 36,000 workers, formerly on relief, were employed as the year closed on-320 WPA projects in forty-two States, involving construction of new airports, extension of present airports, and general improvement of the airway system, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, said last week.

THERE is refreshment in turning aside for a little while from the strain and stress under which most of us are now living to contemplate an existence as tranquil, and problems as easily solved as those of the heroine of Frederick Lambeck's very delightful novel.

EVEN by the standards of the moment, "The Rolling years" is a longish novel. But it is not a syllable too long and there are moments, most of them concentrated in the first half of the book, when we devoutly wish there were more of it.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 8. -- The Naval Academy's athletic opponents held the edge in the varsity events today, visiting teams scoring victories over the Midshipmen in three out of five engagements.

THE feeling of a provincial critic after a Week of play-going in New York is that the American theatre never seemed so rich and so remote. As it grows in opulence, it draws further from the hinterland which once fed it.

ON THE NOSE: No one who looks at all those light-year figures on the government's books in Washington would know it, but Daniel W. Bell, Acting Director of the Budget, has a warm spot in his heart for Balanced Budget. Balanced Budget is a horse. Word came from Miami last week that Mr. Bell (there on vacation) recently put $2 on Balanced Budget's nose.

Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci" made its first appearance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera Horse. This tried and true war horse, with its oft-repeated tale of conflicting human emotions, is still undiminished in popular appeal. No further evidence was needed than the capacity house and hundreds more who stood in the Broadway house.

SOFIA, Feb. 7. -- A large number of Bulgarian Communists are about to be tried in the military and civil courts. The Communists have continued active despite repressions decreed since the military coup d'etat in May, 1934.
In the minority opinion of the Supreme Court in the AAA case appears the following:

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Breaking a 4-4 tie in the last three minutes of play, the Princeton sextet gained a 5-4 victory over the St. Nicholas Hockey Club before 2,000 persons at the Hobey Baker Rink tonight.
WARSAW, Feb. 8. -- The Jewish religious communities in Poland are greatly alarmed at an attempt to abolish the Hebrew ritual for cattle slaughter.

TO provide young lawyers with practical knowledge of the kind formerly obtained by serving as a clerk at the side of an experienced attorney, the Practicing Law Courses, an evening school for members of the bar, has just opened its seventh session at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

IN Miller's "Anecdotal History of the Science of Sound" the student of physics, as well as the professional acoustician, at last has available a historical outline of the study of sound from Pythagoras to the present day. Heretofore histories of science have strangely ignored work in this field.

HARTFORD, Feb. 7. -- Connecticut is now engaged in an effort to combine expert knowledge with public sentiment to form a more satisfactory law for the protection of automobile victims. The experts are a judge of the Superior Court, the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles and the Insurance Commissioner, members of a commission created by the 1935 General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Surplus cotton in the hands of the government must be placed on the market in regular known quantities each week in order to avoid price uncertainty, J.E. McDonald, Texas Commissioner of Agriculture, telegraphed today to Chairman Smith and members of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

In Waldemar Kaempffert's recent book review a few observations are made concerning invention that require comment. One of these refers to the Jews as never having "been distinguished as outstanding inventors, although they have been subjected to Western social influence for 1,000 years."

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 8. -- Germany's women skiers presented the fatherland with the first victory for any nation in the fourth Olympic Winter Games today when Miss Christel Cranz, Black Forest girl ski star, won the gold medal for the women's combined downhill and slalom event.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Feb. 8. -- A plan for "brighter week-ends" is being started at Bryn Mawr College, sponsored by the administration but planned and directed to a large extent by undergraduates. The week-end program will be enlarged by more informal events and student activities, scheduled for Saturdays and Sundays.

FEBRUARY, 1861. The inaugural train bearing Abraham Lincoln rolls slowly on toward Washington. In a delirium of enthusiasm the people everywhere swarm out to hail their beloved rail-splitter. A surge of cheering across four States. Lincoln, his big, bony hands clasped on the platform ironwork, nods and smiles his kindly smile.

A tax proceeding in which the findings of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue are reversed by the United States Board of Tax Appeals upon grounds other than those asserted by the taxpayer, and the board is reversed by the Circuit Court of Appeals upon grounds asserted by neither the commissioner nor the board, illustrates the variety of possible findings in income-tax litigation involving capital assets.

Alexander Printz of the Printz Biederman Company, Cleveland, and chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, has written to Joseph E. Helfer, executive director of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association, suggesting joint activities in connection with the recovery program of the two industries.

Through its department of education, which is headed by Mrs. John L. Whitehurst of Baltimore, the General Federation of Women's Clubs this morning announces sponsorship of a radio script contest in conjunction with the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Statue of Liberty.

THE ladies and gentlemen who have handsomely put their hands in their pockets, and who have had the cooperation of a grateful portion of the public in recent years in raising funds to meet the annual deficits of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, find themselves confronted with several major problems as they look forward to the concerts of next season.

BUS lines, rapidly expanding and adopting, one after another, the sales methods of older transportation services, have gone in for personally conducted, all-expense tours. This Winter for the first time a company with a national network of routes will send groups on a series of tours from the North into Florida, the company using its own equipment and supplying trained guides and aides.
Abraham Lincoln's extreme modesty even as a Presidential candidate is revealed in one of his letters which has come to light here.
BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- The end of the week on the Boerse was featured by considerable upward price movements in a small turnover. Gains frequently exceeded 1 point; Vogel Wire even jumped 6 points.

In Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning the Westminster Kennel Club will open its sixtieth annual dog show, with the largest entry in its history on the benches. There will be exactly 2,920 individual specimens of all breeds on exhibition, making up a total entry of 3,434.

THE list of winners in the Atlantic National Tournament, completed Wednesday night when the team-of-four event came to an end at Crockford's Club, produced four names new to tournament championships. Fred Kaplan, Harry Fishbein, Irving Epstein and Charles Vogelhofer, though all have excellent tournament records and have scored victories in minor events, had not won a major tournament before they came through in the team-of-four tournament for the Douglas W. Paige Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Milton LaGattuta, 171 East 115th Street, and Charles Alfano, 403 East 100th Street, have been designated by the War Department as candidates from the Twentieth Congressional District, New York City, to take the examination for admission to the United States Military Academy.

IN miniature rooms the decorator can create as freely as the painter who makes an easel picture. For in them he finds no unlovely interior architecture, no limited budget on furniture and fabrics to impede the play of his ideas.

ON a busy highway vehicles are constantly passing or attempting to pass each other. When there is not sufficient clear space to permit free passing, not only are the chances of collisions multiplied, but the entire stream of traffic is retarded by the slower moving units.

TRENTON, Feb. 8. -- In a week of fast and furious political warfare, Harold G. Hoffman, Republican Governor of New Jersey, failed to outsmart his enemies within his own party, but succeeded in dividing their ranks.

VALPARAISO, Chile, Feb. 8. -- The discovery of Communist inspiration for the railroad strike, which threatened to envelop other public services and industries, has set in motion a series of measures adopted by the government today to break up socialistic activities that have been traced to the Communist headquarters in Montevideo, Uruguay, according to the announcement.

The struggle for raw materials has often been a cause of war. The nations which do not possess them want them; they are frequently prepared to fight for them. The nations which control raw materials want to retain what they have.

Charging the Roosevelt New Deal administration with creating a deficit of $14,500,000,000 of its own making, Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News and an active candidate for the Republican nomination for President, proposed last night a six-point platform.

President ROOSEVELT took three steps last week which must have given encouragement to the more conservative members of his Administration. One was his action in ordering a check-up of all Federal credit agencies, with a view to canceling a billion dollars or more in unused lending authorizations voted by Congress.
Rising temperatures rode into New York yesterday on a wind that shifted from west to southwest, breaking the freezing spell that had continued with but one interruption since Jan. 22.

TORONTO, Feb. 8. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs shut out the New York Americans, 3 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game tonight, despite injuries that kept Red Horner, Pep Kelly and Harvey Jackson out of play.

As a climax to Winter sports activities here, the annual International Skating Carnival will be held in Madison Square Garden on the nights of March 22 and 25 under the auspices of the Skating Club of New York. It will be given for the benefit jointly of the convalescent relief division of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau and the Carroll Club of New York.

SOME people drink water and some drink alcohol. They know no better. But there are others. There are those who drink wine, and who drink wine intelligently; they know good wine from bad, and they know also that wine does them good, that it helps them "remember friends and forgive enemies." to these people a student of wines commends the famous old wines of Madeira from the sunny Portuguese island of that name.

Charles Curtis was the first man of Indian blood to attain a seat in the United States Senate and the first to become Vice President of this country. And all his life he was proud of this part of his heritage.

E.M. DELAFIELD has achieved an unusual combination of qualities in her latest work of fiction. Diving well below the conscious it is subtly analytical as regards characterization, and it has the salty and cynical but good-humored tolerance we expect in a book by "The Provincial Lady."

Federal and State authorities will permit reasonable deductions of city sales tax payments on income tax returns. Where deductions are considered unreasonable, however, the taxpayer will be required to submit proof of payment of the sales tax.

Probably the most important development of last week, marketwise, was the announcement of President Roosevelt's plan to cancel some $1,000,000,000 of unused departmental appropriations. The markets were impressed visibly, although the announcement did not prevent France and Holland from drawing American gold.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- The Columbia five repulsed Army, 26 to 24, today in one of the fastest and hardest fought basketball games played here this season. A crowd of 4,000 taxed the seating capacity of the new gymnasium to witness an extensive sports program of which the court battle was the feature.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- An intensive drive to make automobile drivers "safety conscious" will begin here Feb. 17 under the newly organized Permanent Automobile Safety Council, started last week by the East Side Improvement Association and conducted under the auspices of the Police Department.

THE verse from The Gospel According to Saint John that furnishes the motto and title of Kagawa's famous novel was a great favorite of another religious novelist, Fyodor Dostoevsky. Only the circumstance of a common faith links the two, however, for Dostoevsky's febrile, hardly philanthropic Christianity offers as great a contrast to Kagawa's practical evangelism as could be imagined.

The free employment bureau opened Friday by the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations at 41 West Forty-sixth Street continued yesterday to register applicants for jobs as elevator operators and other building service employes.

OF these six volumes recently published by the Loeb Classical Library under the imprint of the Harvard University Press, only the Livy is a continuation of a work begun, the history of Rome, which is the ninth volume in a series of thirteen.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- The German public has been treated lately to discussion by high State officials and learned men of what is euphemistically called the unwritten constitution of the Third Reich. This discussion would seem to indicate that after three years of revolutionary upheavals there is a growing desire to take stock and arrive at a comparative stabilization of political life within some accepted and generally understood norms.

DRESSING-ROOM ROW in that fenced-in and relatively impregnable part of Hollywood known as the Paramount Studio Is quiet, discreet old English. It has a flat facade, grown over with ivy, the screened doors opening onto the sidewalk, and a file of trim little beeches in front, just as in Pomander Walk, their foliage now being torn by a February wind.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Major honors fell to those two veterans of the game, C.C. Fell and Stanley G. Mortimer, in the first round of the thirtieth annual Gold Racquets tournament at the Tuxedo Park Racquet and Tennis Club today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- In an action planned as an example for other industries the executive committee of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, meeting here today, adopted a resolution that the lumber industry should not urge any Federal legislation that would involve the expenditure of additional funds for its benefit.

THE fire of Goya illuminates our time. Once in an age an artist appears whose work continues to interpret the world to posterities he could not know. Young Goya painted incomparable pictures of Spain's pleasures. The seasoned man dramatized crucial themes and confrontations that still shake civilization.
MIAMI. -- The first annual all-breed dog show sponsored by the Miami Dog Show Association, Inc., and announced for next Saturday and Sunday, is attracting many entries.

Astrological readings will be among the features of the Star-Gazers' supper dance to be held on Feb. 18 at Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the Convalescent Workshop of the New York City Visiting Committee. The readings will be conducted by Mrs. Roxan Locke as part of a diversified program of entertainment arranged by a committee under the direction of Mrs. L. Stuart Wing and Mrs. Dexter Blagden, chairman of the beneficiary.

FIFTY miles of the proposed 500-mile Shenandoah-Great Smoky Mountains National Parkway is now built or under construction. With the cooperation of State authorities, rights of way have recently been obtained by the Federal Government through another strip of North Carolina in a southwesterly direction from the Virginia State line. Financed with PWA funds, the highway was begun early last September.

THE twelfth annual convention of the Association of Highway Officials of North Atlantic States will be held in Atlantic City next Wednesday to Friday. Exhibits of up-to-date developments in the highway industry and discussion of many phases of road building and use will mark the meeting.

Governors Island and the New York Athletic Club rode to victory in Metropolitan Indoor Polo League games at the Squadron A armory last night. Governors Island overcame a three-goal allowance to beat Boulder Brook, 15 1/2 to 5, and the Winged Food riders gave a four-goal handicap and conquered Squadron A, 12 1/2 to 6.

THE demonstration of polarized light reported here two weeks ago, while convincing enough to stir enthusiasm, was only a suggestive preliminary to the real show subsequently staged at the Waldorf-Astoria by the inventor of the polarizing substance used, Edwin H. Land of the Land-Wheelright Laboratories, Boston.

BOSTON, Feb. 7. AFTER a season devoted largely to classics, semi-classics and tryout engagements of musical shows, Boston is rubbing its hands in satisfaction over S.N. Behrman's "End of Summer" as an honest-to-goodness modern play, expertly acted in its principal parts by Ina Claire and Osgood Perkins, and handsomely mounted by the Theatre Guild.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Weekly data on industrial operations have failed to show the seasonal rise usual at this time, but on the other hand there has been no material decline, the Commerce Department said today, adding that business activity was holding "a fairly even pace."

ALWAYS laughing, singing, joking, blustering in his carefree way, Happy Jack Aberdeen was lazier than his fellow-cowpokes and Marshal William Kinney, his employer, avowed that he was no good. To prove it the marshal tricked the boy into a meeting with the great outlaw Charlie Lake who loved violence for its own sake.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Retail sales with the larger stores were About at the levels of the first week of Feb ruary. 1935, with some stores running a little ahead. The showing was regarded as most encouraging, in view of weather conditions, subzero temperatures prevailing part of the week.

Adolph Cotton, 25-year-old student of archaeology and son of the late Dr. Henry A. Cotton, head of the New Jersey State Hospital for the Insane, was reported mysteriously lost at sea off the North German Lloyd liner Bremen in a wireless message received late yesterday by his family.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- High officials and other leaders in public life paid tribute today to Charles Curtis. Among the expressions were:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 8. -- Herbert Wells Fay, custodian of the Abraham Lincoln tomb here, owns the world's largest collection of Lincolniana. Other Lincoln historians have documents and pictures of greater value, but none have as many items.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- For more than a quarter of a century, Charles Curtis was close to the nerve center of American government at the capital and his story that President Warren Harding had selected Charles Dawes of Chicago to succeed him in the White House is permitted to be told today by the death of Mr. Curtis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- John D. Hamilton, general counsel of the Republican National Committee and national committeeman from Kansas, is being pressed by the Landon leaders to resign his activities here and become the primary campaign manager for Governor Landon in the contest for the Republican nomination for President.

More promptly than was anticipated by the various organizations of women interested in their passage, the mandatory woman jury service bills will come before the Assembly at Albany for action tomorrow evening. Since identical measures passed the House last March by the overwhelming vote of 105 to 33 -- being later defeated in the Senate -- there is every indication for favorable action in the lower house this time.

THE mutinies in the British Navy at Spithead and the Nore, which this informative book deals with, occurred 128 years ago. As recently as 1913 Professor Conrad Gill published an account of them. But when Professor Gill wrote his illuminating book the Spencer Papers had not been printed.

Even in this day of innumerable finely illustrated books for children, "Wheels, Ships, Trains, Aircraft" stands out as a beautiful and thrilling volume. It is still better than the author's two preceding volumes, "The Earth's Treasures" and "The Things We Use."

It has been alleged that the United States, by its declaration of war against Germany on April 6, 1917, and the prosecution of the war in cooperation with the Allies, virtually abandoned the position taken in the note of Oct. 21, 1915, to Great Britain contesting the legality of interference with neutral ships and cargoes (For. Rel., 1915, Suppl., 578) and condoned the practices which it protested in that note.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Skeet shooting continues to gain in popularity among Sea Island residents, and in addition to the three weekly shoots at the Sea Island Gun Club on Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday afternoon special shoots are planned almost every day.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- The first week of the Summer fashion openings shows the strong influence of the play "Margot," in a universal crop of high necklines with lingerie, pique or lace ruffs and starched linen Medici collars and plastrons.

MONTREAL. -- The event this week at the curling clubs in Montreal and its district is the annual competition for the Governor General's Trophy. Other clubs in the Province of Quebec and in Eastern Ontario also are competitors for this trophy, which is emblematic of the double-rink irons championship of the Canadian branch of the Royal Caledonian Curling Club.

The annual St. Valentine's Kettledrum in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged will be held in the ballroom suite of the Plaza on Feb. 14. The beneficiary, one of the oldest organizations of its kind in New York, was founded in 1867 and for more than half a century occupied an old-fashioned house in West Twenty-second Street.

PROFESSOR LOVETT points out in his introduction to this account of some of the newer extracurricular activities on (and off) our campuses that foreign students were long surprised "that their contemporaries in American colleges and universities manifested so little interest in public affairs and exerted practically no influence on the conduct of them."

Edward P. Mulrooney, retiring chairman of the State Liquor Authority, announced yesterday that John Sullivan, one of the four remaining members of the Authority, had been elected acting chairman. He will serve until Governor Lehman appoints a permanent head.

The Boy Scouts of America were praised last night by President Roosevelt for their training, which teaches them respect for law and serves as a basis for the building of character and useful habits of life. This training, the President said, leads in later life to "the betterment of conditions affecting community life and will contribute in many ways to the good of the nation as a whole."
A LUSTY echo will resound in the hearts of those who read Old Bill's observation: "I never seed such a complicated place as Europe, never. Why the 'ell can't they all mind their own business?"

ST. PAUL, Minn. Feb. 7. -- Ever since the murder on Dec. 9 of Walter Liggett in Minneapolis in, the midst of his editorial campaign in The Mid-West American Weekly against an alleged illegal liquor syndicate, the case has been on the borderline of State politics.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- An aged man and his wife, snowbound for three weeks in their woodland cottage west of Nyack, were saved from slow starvation today because an alert neighbor noticed that there were no tracks in the snow-filled lane leading to their home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The basis of an agreement for transatlantic heavier-than-air service between the United States and Germany was laid at a conference today between American officials and the German mission which arrived in New York yesterday.

Bonds continued their upward movement in the short session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, and sales amounted to $10,501,800, compared with $11,043,300 on the previous Saturday. Railroad issues continued in demand, and some of them reached the high levels of the present movement.

ADVERSE weather conditions again had a hampering effect upon retail trade throughout the country last week. Some areas fell behind last year in sales, but, on the whole, volume was maintained to an encouraging degree. Moderation of the extreme temperatures which have prevailed will react favorably upon consumer purchasing and pave the way for a good response to the initial Spring merchandise offerings which retailers will soon launch.

By inclination a nautical man, President Roosevelt understands the value of having things shipshape when he is going any place. Shortly he will embark on the election campaign. He attempted last week to get things shipshape in preparation for it. The process involved:

AT this season of the year the indoor gardener often seeks something novel to lend fresh interest to the late Winter and early Spring display in the windows or in the sun-porch garden. The big bulbous plants -- callas, amaryllis and the like -- serve well this purpose.

With the peace of the world at stake, the British Foreign Minister is assassinated just as he is about to depart for Geneva on a secret mission. Fortunately, no one, with the exception of the Prime Minister and his butler, is aware of what has happened.

One sees by the papers that the heavy snowfall will continue and the mercury is expected to drop during the night. There are very few things which one has seen more frequently in the papers this Winter. So the question arises as to what the United States Supreme Court is planning to do about it.

With Manager Casey Stengel struggling with a mass of pleading letters from ambitious youngsters who want a chance for a trial with the Dodgers at Clearwater, the business management of the club yesterday completed arrangements that are expected to toss even more young players into Casey's lap.

District Attorney Geoghan, in Brooklyn, announced yesterday the arrest of a third man in the investigation into the manufacture and sale of slugs by the use of which Mr. Geoghan estimates that public utility companies, restaurants and other places using slot machines have lost more than a million dollars in a little more than a year.

As if held in thrall by a spell of enchantment, the large audience which gathered to hear Andres Segovia, the Spanish guitarist, in his second and final recital of the season at Town Hall yesterday afternoon hung breathlessly upon every sound he summoned forth from the six-stringed instrument.

Additional gold exports of $3,935,000 to Europe were arranged yesterday by local banks as the dollar declined again on the foreign exchange market. The exports consisted of $3,050,000 to France and $885,000 to Holland, thereby lifting to $20,613,000 the total outflow last week. Of the metal thus shipped $17,189,000 is consigned to France and $3,424,000 to Holland.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The revival of the annual dinner to the Governor and the State Legislature of New Jersey is the main item on the social calendar for the coming week. Governor Harold G. Hoffman has assured Mayor C.D. White that he will attend.

F.A. Cauchois was the major winner at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He began his good work by winning the high scratch cup at singles. In this event, both Cauchois and A.L. Burns had 98 out of a possible 100 targets, Cauchois taking the shootoff, 23 to 22.
THE figure-skating championships which will be run off this week at the Olympic Games at GarmischPartenkirchen emphasize the attention that is being given to one of the most graceful of sports.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Feb. 8. -- The popularity of modern dancing has increased to such an extent among women students of Swarthmore College that it is winning recognition from those in charge of the William J. Cooper Foundation, which brings economists, mathematicians, musicians, painters and other persons or groups to the campus for free public entertainment.

THE Interstate Commerce Commission is seriously considering the most revolutionary change in railway passenger traffic since the World War -- the reduction of the passenger "base rate" for the nation to 2 cents a mile.
The garment district of New York, where a vast number of the dresses, coats and hats for American women are produced, reverberated last week with the rumblings of approaching strikes.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 8 (AP). -- A renegade horse almost ended the career of Charles Curtis when he was 15 and gave him scars which he bore the rest of his life.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 7. -- Years ago it was said by a careful observer that Ohio's political situation was like the freight rates in the days before regulation by the Federal and State Commissions -- "subject to change without notice" -- and also like the weather.

Announcement has been made by Columbia University that it has received $51,264 in additional gifts. The sum of $16,200, to be used for research, was given by the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation. The Louis D. Beaumont Trust gave $6,000, of which $5,000 is for the general purposes of the university and $1,000 for research in the Institute of Cancer Research.

This excellent dog story is sure to be popular with boys and girls from 10 to 14. The dog hero is a German shepherd, with the intelligence of the breed and a rare gentleness of disposition. The background of the story is the struggle between the sheep and the cattle owners in the West, that continued for so many years and in some sections is even now not entirely extinct.

The basketball team of St. Joseph's College for Women continued its unbeaten stride by routing an alumnae sextet by a 41-to-7 score yesterday in the school gymnasium. The victory was the third in as many starts for St. Joseph's, who list the Nassau Collegiate Centre and Brooklyn College as their previous victims.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- With a powerful attack that functioned smoothly at all times, Andover's hockey team routed a game but outclassed Exeter sextet today at the Boston Arena and interrupted the latter's long dominance of the series. Swarming all over the ice, the Andover skaters romped to an 8 -- 2 victory, practically clinching the issue in the first period.

A exhibition, arranged as a benefit for the Edgewater Creche, will be held during the luncheon hour on Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Entitled "Waves and Curves of 1936 Preview," the venture is patterned after the usual fashion shows, but will display latest styles in coiffures, facial make-up and contours.

When CHARLES CURTIS began his first term in the House of Representatives the Populists were a majority of the Kansas delegation. The present Secretary of the Navy was a member from Virginia. A whole race of politicians, some of them still famous, has disappeared. Through many changes of opinion Mr. CURTIS remained a regular of reolars.

The newest of the city-owned North River docks, 90, will be completed before its first occupant, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, arrives in May on her maiden transatlantic crossing. The work is about 95 per cent finished, and there is no apparent reason for delay in completing the contract on time, according to Dock Department engineers.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8. -- The desire of thoughtful Russians to widen the cultural basis of the people is reflected in a questionnaire which has been laid before 300 readers by Ogonek, short-story magazine. The questionnaire consists of ten questions for readers to ask themselves and their friends to test whether they are really cultured.

Senator NYE'S committee finished last week its long inquisition of J.P. Morgan Co. It started out with the strongest presumptions and prejudices against that firm. For weeks and even months the committee's agents and inspectors had been combing the files and records of this private banking company.

IT is a bit difficult to discover just what it is in current life that has disgruntled Mr. Erskine so deeply that he had to write a book about it to get it out Of his system. Apparently, he thinks that his disturbance is due to what he believes to be a concerted, mass movement of women to acquire more power and oust men from their time-honored position in the world.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- The pre-Lenten season here will be enlivened this week with a round of varied social affairs and a sports program that includes two golf tournaments.

WITH that instinct for picking up in document and tradition the material for a rousing yarn which they showed in their trilogy based on the Bounty mutiny, Charles Nordhoff and James Norman Hall in "Hurricane" have turned out a romance of South Sea island folk that many will find affecting, and all will vote exciting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- President Roosevelt and his fiscal advisors today canvassed the background for an administration tax bill at a closed conference which coincided with the reported collapse of one wing of the Congressional inflation drive.

TRAVEL posters, striking in color and design, are growing in favor as a means of depicting America's tourist attractions. Railroads, steamship and airplane companies, State tourist bureaus, national parks, resorts and sponsors of expositions and fairs, all are using posters that invite comparison with the best examples of the art to be seen in England, France, Italy or elsewhere in Europe.

THUS runs one of our time-honored proverbs which, strange to observe, no self respecting elderly gentleman with venerable mustache and reverend-looking beard would use to refute the statements of his younger opponent whose chin has not been so luckily endowed.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7. -- If the reader of this article woke up one morning to find that his salary of, say, $100 a week, had been suddenly cut to $25 Or $20 he would feel much the same bewilderment that is enveloping foreign residents of Soviet Russia who derive incomes from abroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Legislation to control and eventually prevent pollution of streams and other waters of the country through establishment of sanitary water boards along watersheds of navigable streams, was introduced today by Senator Lonergan of Connecticut, following its endorsement by the North American Wild Life Conference this week.

RAVEL'S one-act opera "L'Heure Espagnol," and "Joseph and his Brethren," a new ballet by Werner Josten, will be performed by the Juilliard Opera School Monday night, March 9. with repetitions on three consecutive evenings by alternating casts. Both productions will be directed by Albert Stoessel.

TO those whose principal interest is the stage, Allan Noble Monkhouse was best known as a skillful playwright and an accomplished dramatic critic. Among booklovers he had an equal reputation as a novelist, essayist and critic of literature.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Two graduates of Princeton University, James M. Landis, chairman of the Security and Exchange Commission, and Professor William A. Eddy, president-elect of Hobart College, will be the principal speakers at the annual midwinter meeting of the Princeton National Alumni Association, to be held here on Washington's Birthday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8. -- Settlement of the protracted waterfront strike, which had affected coast business activities for several months, was probably the most welcome news received last week by those dependent upon maritime pursuits.

LANDISBURG, Pa., Feb. 8 (AP). -- Three theories were expressed tonight as to what happened to the little terrier trapped for three weeks in a rocky cavern high in snow-bound Blind Gap, but his owner, Roy Dewalt, clung stubbornly to the belief that the dog is alive.

WASHINGTON, Feb.7. -- Events of the last fortnight seem to have confirmed abundantly the general assumption that the budget, and what the Roosevelt administration has done with it and to it, will furnish perhaps the dominating issue in the coming Presidential campaign.
LONDON, Feb.8. -- Lady Rolleston, wife of Sir Humphry Rolleston, re ceived a letter from her son in Zanzibar only this morning. An hour later the Colonial Office told her he was dead.

The extent of the dress industry in New York and the complicated web of its labor and employer organizations are brought forcibly to public attention by the labor difficulties that came to a head last week. Of the country's half-billion dollar annual output of dresses, nearly 90 per cent is produced by 105,000 workers within a fifty-mile circle surrounding its heart and center, the garment district in Manhattan.

THE curtain rises tomorrow on dog-dom's fashion plate for 1936. Advance information from officials of the Westminster Kennel Club's annual show indicates that lines are somewhat lower and more vigorous, fabrics are tending toward the silky, and tassels -- in the form of drooping ears -- have returned to favor.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP). -- When George Ade celebrates his seventieth birthday tomorrow, he will be "rejoicing" over the fullness of his years "instead of bewailing" the brevity of man's biblical span on earth.

Sixteen hundred and fifty gallons of raw milk, condemned as adulterated, cascaded into the East River yesterday as the most dramatic phase of a six-day investigation by Department of Health officials that resulted in the placing of an embargo against the products of the Boiling Springs Creamery, near Harrisburg, Pa.

The future of an area as large as the State of Kentucky, and the power of the Federal Government to plan and carry out far-reaching economic and social reforms for such an area, are involved in the pending suit against the Tennessee Valley Authority.

BAGUIO, Feb. 8. -- Americans and many Filipinos at present are apprehensive over the prospect of High Commissioner Frank Murphy's recall in order to campaign for the Governorship of Michigan. While Mr. Murphy is appreciative of the honor and is grateful for the demonstration of confidence and affection by his American constituency he joins in this apprehension, feeling that American policy would be better served if he remained here.

MADRID, Jan. 12, 1936. THREE Spanish novelties marked recent programs of the Madrid Symphony Orchestra, in continuance of Arbos's hospitality to native moderns. Best the "Suite Sobre Motivos Que Tuvieron Su Epoea" (Suite on Old-Fashioned Airs) by Ramona Usandizaga, brother of the renowned Basque composer, the late Jose Maria.

RECEPTION of programs broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation empire service, already good in this country, is to be improved by stepping up transmitter power and installing new aerials. Sir Noel Ashbridge, chief engineer of the B.B.C., outlined the plans in a recent broadcast.

Commodity futures generally were lower in quiet trading yesterday. The declines, however, were small and in most instances the undertone was firm. In the cash market wheat, corn and eggs were higher, while cocoa, butter and rubber were lower.

PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 7. -- Held in the grip of a general strike for two days and the better part of a third, the little city of Pekin presented a strange contrast to modern-day life with all of the movements of routine existence disrupted. Citizens were thrown upon their own resources to find food, warmth and recreation.

NEW light is thrown on the history of Texas by a book entitled "Viva Tejas," by Ruben Rendon Lozano, which the Southern Literary Institute is preparing for early publication, probably in March. The book tells the story of the native Mexicans who took part in the struggles of Texas for independence.

Stock prices moved within a narrow range during yesterday's brief trading period. The market closed exactly even -- of the 825 issues dealt in, 313 advanced, 313 declined, and 199 were unchanged. The average of prices, however, was a shade lower.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 8 (AP). -- Six convicts fled from the Frankfort Reformatory here today, close upon the escape of four comrades, who drove off in a taxicab yesterday, and the killing of another convict by a fellow prisoner.

The plight of needy families in raising rent to pay for their humble homes is pictured in a poem, written by August Heckscher, chairman of the board of trustees of the Heckscher Foundation for Children, 1 East 104th Street, and made public yesterday as part of the institution's drive to raise funds for needy families who have suffered during the recent cold weather.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- To the scientific collections of the University of Pennsylvania is to be added one of the few remaining duplicate specimens of dried plants propagated by Gregor Mendel while he was determining the laws of inheritance which now bear his name.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., more than 10 per cent of the voting stock of which is owned by the Electric Bond and Share Company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application asking exemption for itself and its subsidiaries, which operate in thirteen foreign countries, from all "obligations, duties, liabilities and disabilities" imposed by Title I of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- In Paris during this past week an effort has been made -- and this time between heads of States as well as their Ministers -- to reach security without treaty revision. Austria, Bulgaria, Rumania and Yugoslavia, to put them alphabetically, were all represented by their Kings, Regents or Chancellors.

BILL DURRANT, ex-skipper of rum-runners, emerges from a two-year term in San Quentin prison just after repeal has been passed. A tough big bruiser down on his luck, he ships to Manila and there gets a job as bouncer in a gambling den whose proprietor, a dumb Italian, is trying to muscle in on the rackets controlled by the city's czar of vice.

IF any one tries to fabricate first editions of Christopher Morley for future generations of collectors he is going to have an uneasy time of it. A challenge to such disorderly printing has just appeared in the form of the long-awaited Morley bibliography by Alfred P. Lee.

The wholesale markets here were generally quiet last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Activity in ready-to-wear lines was limited, as few buyers arrived, due to the uncertainty of the dress strike and the adverse weather conditions,

PEIPING, Jan. 10 (Canadian Press) (By Mail). -- While much attention is centered on expansion of Japanese interests from Manchukuo into Nokth China. Soviet Russia is reported to be extending its influence in a distant part of China vastly larger than Manchuria and Hopei and Charhar combined.

Although the cold weather showed some signs of moderating last week, it continued to act as a check on any expansion in retail activity. Gains up to 10 per cent were registered in some sections of the country, but in most areas volume ran about even with that of a year ago.

As a solution of the problem of the government cotton loans, Robert H. Bean, executive secretary of the American Acceptance Council, proposes in the current issue of the council's Acceptance Bulletin that a syndicate of the leading banks in the country be formed to take over possibly 80 per cent of the Commodity Credit Corporation's loans.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT had a larger radio audience in metropolitan centers than did former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, in their recent broadcasts, according to a morning-after telephone survey conducted among listeners in thirty-three cities by the Cooperative Analysis of Broadcasting.

MOST of the fourteen stories contained in this book belong to the occult variety. It is a genre in which the English excel, and which is but rarely practiced in this country. I have often wondered as to the cause of the occult tale's popularity with the English.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 8. -- Leading Japanese commercial firms have addressed a memorial to President Oscar P. Benairdes requesting the abolition of the quota on imports of cotton goods, declaring that Peru's balance of trade with Japan does not warrant such a restriction.

Censorship of motion pictures, in both the methods used and the extent to which it is carried on, was attacked yesterday at the final meeting of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures by representatives of the board, the industry and the public at large.

HOLLYWOOD AMERICANS are as proud of their pet animals as they are of their children. While the studios are known to be deluged with letters calling attention to the prodigies who can out-Shirley Shirley Temple -- and local parents besiege the casting offices to prove it -- the thousands of letters that are received each year clamoring for recognition for talking dogs and singing cats have gone unchronicled.

The superlative performances of Josef Hofmann have been praised time and again in this city. On no occasion within the memory of this writer has he surpassed, and seldom has he equaled, the beauty, the power, the profound insight of his playing yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

A flat-topped silver tankard, not quite eight inches high, brought $4,850 at auction yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. It was made by Peter Van Dyck, a New York silversmith who lived from 1680 until 1750 and it was once wned by John Pintard who was active in the founding of the New York Historical Society in 1804.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Vincent Astor is president, will be aided by a performance of Rimsky-Korsakoff's "The Invisible City of Kitezh," which will be given the night of March 3 at the Metropolitan Opera House by members of the Art of Musical Russia Company and the Philadelphia Orchestra under the direction of Alexander Smallens.

A new menace has arisen to plague the already harried fishing experts of the New York Conservation Department. The latest source of irritation and concern is the rapid spread of the Asiatic water chestnut, a four-pronged nut that has been hawked at village fairs and bazaars for years as "horned devils" and "mystic ebony shingodas."

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- Facilities to enable him to speed negotiations for a commercial treaty with the United States were asked of the French Cabinet by Commerce Minister Georges Bonnet today. He said France had obtained from Washington prolongation of the most-favored-nation treatment until April 1, and stressed that he was anxious to reach a trade agreement by that date.

Mrs. Adolf Ladenburg gave a supper party last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for her niece, Miss Frances G. Stevens, which followed a theatre party given by Miss Stevens's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis K. Stevens.
A RADICALLY new radio receiver for ultra-short wave reception has been designed by Francis W. Dunmore of the Radio Laboratory, National Bureau of Standards.

JOHN C. WILSON it is who will collaborate with the Theatre Guild in the production of Robert E. Sherwood's "Idiot's Delight," now being rehearsed for a late March opening. Currently aboard the S.S. Champlain and headed this way, Mr. Wilson has various other schemes in his pocket.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- All records for patronage of Winter sports in the Poconos have been broken in the last few weeks. Snow trains have brought thousands of people to the mountains and the influx of sports lovers is expected to continue until the end of the Winter.

STARTLING news came from the University of California last week. Dr. John J. Livingood changed bismuth into radium E -- one of about ten radiums derived from the primal one. Following the Joliots in Paris, the physicists in the University of California have made salt radioactive.

SAN JUAN, P.R., 17 Feb. 8. -- President Roosevelt's appointment of Martin Travieso to the insular Supreme Court to succeed Pedro Aldrey, who retired, has been favorably received, especially by Americans here. In more than thirty years of public life Mr. Travieso has been a consistent advocate of the island's permanent association with the United States, although he has remained a member of the Liberal party, an advocate of independence.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 8. -- American Olympic officials tonight overruled the desire of Donna Fox, star bobsled pilot who was injured in a spill today, to participate tomorrow in the final practice runs for the four-man competition, now scheduled for Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Other comments on the death of Mr. Curtis were:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Congressional leaders abandoned their campaign for immediate enactment of permanent neutrality legislation today in an attempt to bring adjournment of Congress by May 1.

Belief that the vice and racket inquiry directed by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey is driving underworld leaders out of New York was expressed at police headquarters last night when a confidential message from the police of Springfield, Mass., disclosed that "Little Augie" Pisano and members of his gang had established new headquarters in the vicinity of that city.

TUCKED away in a corner of the local WPA is Project 1269, subtitled "Junior Clerks," which seeks to give work to orphans between the ages of 17 and 21. Its ultimate guest is for permanent private employment; meanwhile it provides temporary jobs for needy orphans as junior clerks in the public school system.

Despite adverse weather conditions, retail trade in the metropolitan area was quite active last week. Volume held above a year ago on most days of the week and it is estimated that February trade of New York and Brooklyn department stores is running about 7 per cent ahead of the corresponding period of 1935.

The sixty-sixth anniversary of the opening of Hunter College on St. Valentine's Day, 1870, will be celebrated with an alumnae breakfast on Lincoln's Birthday at the Hotel Astor and a birthday chapel in the main building Friday.
Columbia opened its fencing season yesterday by defeating Hamilton, 17 to 10, in the Morningside gymnasium. The Lions were superior in all three weapons.

LONDON, Jan. 17. DOES our more imperial drama ever reach America? If so, it is as well that you should be prepared for Charles Bennett's "Page From a Diary," in which Nicholas Hannen, Greet Garson and Ernst Deutsch have heroically appeared.

League of Nations experts now figure that an embargo on oil, successfully applied, would paralyze Italy at the end of six months. This estimate is to be sent along to the special commission which is weighing the question of whether there should be an extension of the sanctions now in force against Italy because of the war of conquest she is waging against Ethiopia.

SONG pirates are being driven from city streets in a new campaign, supported by Mayor La Guardia, to curb an old musical racket. The Mayor is cooperating with the publishers whose pockets suffer from copyright infringement. Every time a lyric such as "The Music Goes Round and Around" or "Yes, We Have No Bananas Today" makes a hit, the illicit song peddlers become legion and another effort is made to halt their activities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- In a statement addressed to Ohio voters, Senator Borah today denounced the original plans of the Republican Ohio State Committee to put up a "stalking horse" candidate for President.

THIS is the first hook of Ben Hecht's to appear in four years, a slight but entertaining volume embalming eight short stories in the rough, gaudy and precise language that constitutes the style of the author of "Erik Dorn" and "Gargoyles"

SPRING is already here in the display house in the main conservatory at the New York Botanical Garden. Tulips and hyacinths, yellow and white daffodils, fairy primroses, azaleas, the fragrant butterfly bush and graceful acacias and jasmines await visitors who cannot go South, but who nevertheless yearn for a foretaste of Spring.

Declaring that labor unions in some instances are an instrument of racketeering and that rackets get possibly as much as $15,000,000,000 a year in this country, the executive committee of the New York Board of Trade has adopted a resolution for restrictive legislation.

UNCHARTERED WAYS" is story with a well-made plot and an authentic background of American history; it is also a beautiful and moving book. It has been called a novel for young people, but older readers as well will welcome this thoughtful picture of early New England that presents not only historic events but a spiritual history of the time.

On Dec. 17 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a news item to the effect that a bequest "estimated to be more than $1,000,000" had been offered to Yale University by the late Charles Howard Warren, the beneficiaries of the fund to be "confined to * * * the sons of white Christian parents and Anglo-Saxon, Scandinavian or Teutonic descent, both of whom were citizens of the United States and were born in America."
THE saddest thing in the world is writing jokes for radio. That is the way George Burns looks at it, and Gracie Allen, his devoted partner in life and on the air, says he is absolutely correct.
BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- Three more clergymen were punished by Nazi courts today.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 8. -- The Procter Gamble Company distributed today almost $600,000 in dividends to several thousand workers under its profit-sharing plan. Richard R. Deupree, president, promised each worker a week's vacation with pay.

Establishment by legislative enactment of an official industrial court for the purpose of enforcing fair trade practices in business throughout the country was advocated yesterday by Siegfried F. Hartman, counsel for the National Association of Tobacco Distributors and the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America and a member of Major George L. Berry's National Industrial Council.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8. -- Rates on tanker charters from California to all parts of the world are increasing in unprecedented fashion, with indications that they will continue upward indefinitely.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- Jacques and Roger Worth have opened a new house with a gay evening dance and a private preview of their Summer collection for old friends and favorite clients. This moves the oldest Paris couture landmark, because Worth has been established in a Rue de la Paix house since Second Empire days.

DEPEND on the group in Hartford which calls itself the Friends and Enemies of Modern Music, Inc., throwing the field open to all but those indifferent to it, to provide the season with something different. It will happen next week-end in Hartford.

The most case-hardened listener in the large audience which assembled at Town Hall last night to hear the Roth Quartet must have been stirred profoundly by the unforgettable interpretation of the great Opus 132 of Beethoven put forth by this remarkable group of ensemble players.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Despite the tremendous numbers of unemployed, the uptrend in business has uncovered a serious shortage in skilled labor. This was disclosed here this week at a three-day conference of business leaders. Although hundreds of technical jobs are opening, trained men cannot be found to fill them.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- The reclassification of all North Atlantic passenger ships and their reduction to the democratic designation of cabin ships has resulted from the action of the Cunard White Star Line in so designating the Queen Mary, Henceforth there will be no "first-class" liners on the North Atlantic. They will all be "cabin ships."
