PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- Lightning struck twice on the New York University quintet tonight when the one-time invincible Violets succumbed to their second defeat in two nights, the twenty game winning streak now nothing but a battered memory.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- Reports that the action of the North Atlantic shipping conference was aimed at the big business of the cabin liners Manhattan and Washington of the United States Lines brought a statement from the conference that the rates of those vessels would be little changed.

The committee of twelve appointed by the First District Dental Society of the State of New York to evaluate the dental desensitizer prepared by Dr. LeRoy L. Hartman of the Columbia University School for Dental and Oral Surgery will begin its work tomorrow.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 8. -- The Olympic ice hockey competition was thrown into turmoil today when the highly regarded United States team received an unexpected setback at the hands of the fighting Italian sextet, while Canada, three times wearer of the Olympic crown, was scoring its third straight victory.

The New York Times Company announces the sale of the magazine Current History, which it has published since 1914, to M.E. Tracy, who for many years contributed a daily editorial column to the Scripps-Howard newspapers. The transfer will be effective after the April, 1936, issue.

THE Child Study Association stands pre-eminent among the organizations devoted to the work of discovering why children do so-and-so and what, if anything, should be done about it. It has had a long and vigorous life of almost fifty years and the number of bewildered and distraught parents who in all this time have brought to it their troubles and problems and asked its advice could not be counted.

Children and youths who share in the recreational and health advantages offered by the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will benefit by the hockey match between the New York Americans and Chicago Black Hawks on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7. -- The Los Angeles Police Department has undertaken an interesting experiment involving an original interpretation of the Constitution of the United States which has aroused this State as have few other matters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States reported today that "an excellent basis" has been laid for continued business recovery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Charles Curtis, Vice President in the Hoover administration and a national political figure for many years, 16 of which were spent in the House and 18 in the Senate, died today of heart disease at the home of his sister, Mrs. Edward Everett Gann. He was 76 years old.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 8 (AP). -- A sweeping grand jury crime investigation was promised today as Governor Floyd B. Olson and Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, engaged in a bitter personal exchange over alleged lawlessness here.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Aunt Myrtle, 4-year-old brown filly owned by M. Bransfield, won the Austin Handicap today at Alamo Downs.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 8. -- The construction of two new dormitories in the quadrangle unit at Smith College is nearly finished, completing the unit of ten buildings begun in 1922, and which will house more than 30 per cent of the college's 2,000 students.
Former Mayor James J. Walker received an ovation at the dinner given to Postmaster General James A. Farley at the Hotel Astor last night by more than 3,000 postoffice employes.

THE Princeton undergraduate is rapidly developing a "practical" attitude toward his studies, it is revealed in a survey recently completed at the university. The figures, covering the period from the 1924-25 academic year, when the four-course plan was established, to the present year, show a marked decrease in humanities, while the social and natural science departments have recorded large gains.

GO!" A hand drops above a stop watch. "Go ahead!" A girl's voice rings on the icy air. A girl's slim figure whirls past, in a cloud of snow, behind eight scampering huskies. A cheer from the crowd, a flashing smile, the toss of a curly head above the wind-blown ruff of a fur parka, a wave of the hand, and she's gone -- flying down a white road cut through the eight-foot snow banks.
THEN you say to me:

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 8. -- Before these Winter Olympics are over it is to be hoped that somebody skilled in word picturing and untrammeled with cable tolls will adequately describe the environment in which they are taking place.

CAMDEN, S.C. -- With the Virginians' Horse Show on Saturday next, the Lincoln's Birthday match at the Kirkwood golf course on Wednesday, meets of the Camden Hunt on Tuesday and Friday, polo games today, next Sunday and during the week, and skeet shoots almost daily, Camden's many Winter residents have to move at a fast pace to keep up with events.

The thirty-ninth semester of the Hunter College Evening and Extension Division will begin tomorrow. A total of 454 courses are scheduled for the term, most of them carrying credit toward the degrees of A.B., A.M., B.S. in education or M.S. in education. The courses also meet the alertness requirements of the Board of Education.

THE child actors of Russia's Hollywood may have to observe the same general rules for their physical care in the studios as do our cherubim Shirley and Dickie, even to arithmetic and geography pellets gulped down between "takes."

New York is on a vegetable diet -- relatively. More fruits and vegetables but less meats, poultry, eggs and butter are being eaten, a situation attributed to the continued effects of the 1934 drought. More of the latter-named products will be available next Spring.

MR. PATON'S autobiography (to the age of 33) was published in England under the title of "Proletarian Pilgrimage:" To the wary American bourgeois, who has read about the proletariat in fact and in fiction until he knows all the characters by heart, this might suggest a formula as well worn as little Red Riding Hood herself.

THE subdued spruceness of well-tailored Spring suits will be extended to the new street shoes to be worn with them. Street shoes have withdrawn from the color orgy in which they indulged last Fall and are now to be found almost entirely in navy, black, brown and gray.
ST. PAUL, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Climaxing an unprecedented cold wave, a blizzard isolated scores of cities and towns and brought fuel crises to several localities tonight.

NOW, when seed lists for Summer flowers are being made out, it is well to keep in mind that one of the important things to consider is the length of their blooming seasons. If selections are made on the basis of color, or on the beauty of individual blossoms, the result may be long and annoying gaps in the succession of bloom in the flower borders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- John J. Raskob, chairman of the National Democratic Committee when Alfred E. Smith was the Presidential candidate and a prominent Liberty League member, today was held indebted to the government for an additional $1,026,340 in income taxes for 1929.

THIS English version of "Der Weg der Verheissung," by Franz Werfel, is the one which will be used in the Max Reinhardt production of this biblical drama when it opens in New York. That this production will be a memorable event in stage history no reader of this advance printing of the script can have the least doubt.

Debutantes headed by Miss Barbara Crim are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Parsifal," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles, which will take place the afternoon of March 20 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- The Rutgers basketball team avenged an early season defeat by scoring a 44-to-33 triumph over Princeton tonight. The Scarlet, led by Bus Lepine, forward, who tallied fourteen points, all on field goals, for high-scoring honors, ran up a 13-to-2 lead in the first eight minutes and nursed it throughout the game.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- With several benefit productions added to the sports, cultural and social events of major importance crowding the calendar for the next three weeks, the season's shortest month promises to be one of the liveliest.

DESPITE many setbacks, the persistent fight of Frenchwomen to obtain the vote continues unabated. The leaders of the battle are now concentrating their fire upon the French Senate and are more hopeful than they were of changing the attitude of that body.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Republican Presidential politics, overshadowed by proclaimed and threatened Democratic revolts against Mr. Roosevelt's candidacy, has at last taken its due share of the national spotlight. The responsible person is William Edgar Borah, generally considered a permanent Senator from Idaho.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Lectures on national planning began at Vassar College this week, the second of an annual series of lectures on subjects related to the four major fields of the curriculum. The Social Science Department and the political association arranged this year's program to cover five important aspects of the national planning subject.

A letter from Rudyard Kipling, believed to be the last of his letters mailed to America, in which he criticized the press of the United States for misrepresenting the people, was received yesterday by Charles Tyroler of 1 West Sixty-seventh Street, Mr. Tyroler said.

Declaring that the Wheeler-Rayburn Bill is one of the most complete rewritings of the Federal Trade Commission Act since the Nye and Welsh proposals of 1932, Sol A. Herzog, former counsel to the Congress of Industries and a member of the Consumer Goods Industries Committee, yesterday urged widespread business support of the amendments to control "chiseling, the sweating of labor and exploitation of the consumer."

IF it were possible to label the well-dressed woman of early Spring it would bear the device, "well-groomed." She will have the well-groomed look because she will be turned out on tailored lines, all the details of her costume playing up to them.

Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Tuckerman gave a farewell tea dance yesterday in the Neptune Grill of the Pierre for their debutante daughter, Miss Emily Lamb Tuckerman, who will sail on Wednesday to pass the Spring and early Summer visiting in England and on the Continent.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 8. -- The newspapers report that a strange disease of epidemic intensity has broken out in the Santarem region in the State of Para on the banks of the Amazon River. The territory, which is also called "the gold zone," is perched high upon the river bank and serves as a collecting depot for rubber, Brazil nuts and other produce.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 7. -- There are three outstanding facts in the political situation as it affects the Corn Belt today.

The police and prosecuting authorities of Nassau County were continuing early today a protracted examination of a retired New York City police sergeant in the murder of Mary Ellen O'Connor, 15-year-old schoolgirl, and about other crimes.

KING EDWARD VIII of England having "lent his voice and the spell of his magnetic personality" to the radio in more than fifty broadcasts as the Prince of Wales, is expected, according to London observers, "to recognize in broadcasting an ideal medium for personal appeal from one man to his fellows."

BRONISLAW HUBERMAN, Polish violinist, is authority for the news of the formation of the first symphony orchestra in Palestine. The orchestra numbers sixty-five players and is composed not only of ranking German musicians who have been denied the right to play in their own country but also of other prominent European musicians.

President Roosevelt told 15,000 persons gathered at the annual ball and entertainment of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in Madison Square Garden last night that without law-enforcement "all of our efforts for social and economic betterment rest upon a foundation of sand."

WHEN New York City's three new $1,000,000 ferryboats make their maiden voyages on the Battery-to-Staten Island run this year, they will be entering a steamship service that in two respects is called the most remarkable in the world.

Young Democrats and older ones will be guests on Saturday night of the Democratic Junior League at the Hotel Pierre for its annual supper dance, proceeds of which will be applied to the work of the social service bureau of the league. Five hundred persons are expected to participate in the event, arrangements for which have been directed by Miss Bernadette Dolan as chairman of the committee.

AMONG the unusual hobbies of the present day is that of collecting antique snuff boxes, to which attention is drawn by the current loan exhibition of tiny gold, enameled and jeweled snuff boxes at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- Gene Venzke tonight returned to the heights he enjoyed in 1932, the year he astounded track followers with a 4:10 mile. Over the notoriously slow Boston Garden boards tonight, the popular Penn stylist came through with the fastest mile ever run here to defeat Joe Mangan, his conqueror in the Wanamaker Mile a week ago.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 8. -- Turning in superb performances, Miss Jane Knapp of Greenwich was named the individual champion as she led the Rosemary Hall School to the team title at the eleventh annual mid-Winter junior riding competition of the Round Hill Club in its spacious riding hall today.

A JOINT open hearing before the Education and Labor Committee of the Senate and the Education Committee of the House is expected soon for a bill to provide vocational training and employment for youths between 16 and 25.

Motor vehicles sold by divisions of the General Motors Corporation in January to dealers in the United States and Canada and overseas numbered 158,572, compared with 98,268 in January, 1935, an increase of more than 60,000. In December, last, however, 185,698 passenger and commercial cars were sold.

Over the notoriously slow Boston Garden boards tonight, the popular Penn stylist came through with the fastest mile ever run here to defeat Joe Mangan, his conqueror in the Wanamaker Mile a week ago.

Our President has surrounded himself with some idealists whom the country could very well spare from Washington, and, while I have enough faith in the good sense of the American people to pull us through, some of the things done there give some of us out this way the shivers. However, we also feel considerable good has resulted from the farm program and some other acts.

WHAT with the pre-Christmas activities and the bulky special release of last month, it could hardly be expected that Victor's first list of the year would reach the usual length, but short though it is, its contents have been well selected with an eye to balance.
WITH the passing of King George V there also has passed a twenty-five-year reign of the Georgian stamp -- a stamp bearing the profile or portrait of His Majesty.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Middle Western States, from the Rockies to Illinois, were held in the grip of the worst blizzard in years today as a howling storm and sub-zero temperatures blew out of the frozen Mackenzie River of Western Canada on the way to the Eastern seaboard.

Plans for retailer participation in nation-wide efforts to spur private building of low-cost homes are being developed and a course of action will be mapped at a meeting of the committee on housing of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to be held within the next week or ten days, it was stated yesterday by Saul Cohn, of the City Stores Company, chairman of the committee.

EVEN gardeners who do not make a practice of sowing seeds under glass in order to get an extra early start find that it is decidedly advantageous to sow some varieties before seed can safely be planted in the open. This applies especially to annuals which require a comparatively long season of growth before they flower, and to those which may be wanted to give color effects in the garden at the earliest possible moment.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8. -- In a record-smashing exhibition of speed Time Supply pounded the mighty Discovery and a fine field into crushing defeat today before 45,000 wildly shouting fans at Santa Anita.

A strike in the dress trade will find inventories of piece goods and garments in work the lightest they have been at this period in years, Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday. He estimated that last week scarcely 25 per cent of the quantity of garments ordinarily put into work were cut up.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Fred Welcker, 16, of 714 Abbott Avenue, Ridgefield, died at Englewood Hospital this morning as the result of internal injuries sustained when he was run over by an automobile while coasting near his home late last night.

TRENTON, Feb. 8. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman reaffirmed today his stand in the Bruno Richard Hauptmann case as an answer to critics who have forced a split in the Republican ranks in the State based in part on the Governor's entry into the case.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- A speeding up of Britain's rearmament program on a prodigious scale is likely to be ordered by the Cabinet before the end of this month in consequence of the disturbing reports that continue to come from across the North Sea.

THE markets of New York present, even in the dead of Winter, a most tempting aspect, piled high with fruits and vegetables which, in the course of nature, would appear only in the warmer months. Strawberries, for example, at a price not too painful! Seen, red arid shining, in the grocery window as the snow falls over the city, they seem certain promise that Spring is not far behind.
As a student of the flags of America I was much interested in the news item relative to the fleur-de-lis flag of France which appeared in a recent issue of THE TIMES.

CROWDED to the bursting point with the athletes of twenty-eight nations and with spectators from as many, the picturesque twin Bavarian towns of Garmisch and Partenkirchen have at last come into their own as hosts to the 1936 Olympics.

THE old-fashioned, tear-stained school "report-card," which unequivocally "marked" a child's achievement in spelling at 63 or in reading at 57, appears to be going the way of the old oaken bucket. A survey just made by the United States Office of Education shows only one-fifth of 250 cities in all parts of the country still clinging to reports of this type.

George Barton Cutten, president of Colgate University, replying to President Roosevelt's charge of "entrenched greed," told 1,700 bankers and their friends attending the thirty-fifth annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking, held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, that greed was a classless vice.

SOMETIMES as intrinsically trifling a consideration as size can produce a shock -- pleasurable or painful, as the case may be. After looking at hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of big and often loudly vociferant pictures, it is with a sense of deep refreshment that one steps into the modest 2 by 4 paneled room at the Grand Central Galleries where, last week, the American Society of Miniature Painters opened its thirty-seventh annual.

About 1,000 persons, many of them children, were viewing a motion picture about 4:30 yesterday afternoon in the Rivoli Theatre at 1,374 Myrtle Avenue, near Central Avenue, Ridgewood, Brooklyn, when a man in the audience shouted "Fire!"

Ernest Koslan of New York University, first seeded, swept through two opponents to become one of the semi-finalists in the Eastern Collegiate indoor tennis singles championship at the 369th Regiment Armory yesterday.

Do they mean that private production and trading shall cease and that we shall all live as one family, employed by the government and supplied with goods by the government?

OUR museums seem to grow more and more aware of the great service they can perform in the way of clarifying epochs, personalities and the troublesome art problems of sundry sort that confront us. This awareness, coupled with a sincere wish to take advantage of the opportunity that is theirs, has manifested itself again and again of late.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Discussions looking to an inter-American conference of all the American republics to consider the organization of peace machinery for the Western Hemisphere are being conducted by the State Department on the basis of the policy of the good neighbor.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 8. -- A guardian ad litem was appointed by the Circuit Court today for the forty-four minor defendants in preparation for a hearing of the two-year-old litigation over the estate of the late R.J. Reynolds. The minor defendants seek to establish their rights in trust estates of many millions.

The glee club of the New York Junior League will give its fourteenth annual concert on Friday night in the league clubhouse, at 221 East Seventy-first Street. As in past years, the club will be assisted by a group of singers from the Yale University Glee Club.

At a dinner party in his luxuri ous New York penthouse Edward S. Tilden makes the suggestion that it might not be a bad idea to kill off all the unemployed rather than burden the rest of the community with their support. He probably does not mean that he should be included in the massacre, although he is unemployed from choice, being possessed of sufficient wealth to make work unnecessary.
ED WYNN, abandoning his role of ethereal fire chief, returns to the air on Feb. 13 as "Gulliver the Traveler," electrifying the central figure of the classic written by Dean Swift 200 years ago.

Another athletic carnival, brimful of exciting races and spectacular finishes, is promised for Saturday night when the New York Athletic Club stages the oldest of all American indoor games at Madison Square Garden. The Millrose games of a week ago set the tempo.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8. -- A new threat for the Florida Derby developed at Hialeah Park today when Maeriel, mud-loving son of Ariel, in the silks of DeWitt Page's Maemere Farm, made a show of eight rivals in the Bahama Handicap at seven furlongs.

A friend of mine maintains that the most popular show ever devised -- the one of any sort that has been given the greatest number of performances -- is "The Barber of Seville." I should not wonder if that is true. Although, as a French critic has said, it seems probable that Rossini did not care very much for music, at least he was able to write music that many people have found charming.

NOT a woman screamed on the afternoon last week when William Henry Pratt entered the lobby of the Hotel Algonquin. The taxi driver who brought Mr. Pratt over from the Grand Central Station had not turned pale when he noted (if he did note) just What it was that he had ferried across the ice-choked reaches of Madison and Fifth. Even the room clerk hadn't turned a hair.

CAIRO, Feb. 7. -- Although Egypt has been calm since the Cabinet of Premier Aly Maher Pasha was appointed, there is already slight friction between the Egyptian and British Governments over the question of negotiations for a new treaty of alliance.

EDMONTON, Alta., Feb. 8 (AP). -- The story of a fear-maddened Eskimo youth who fought with a Northern pilot and engineer to escape from the cabin of an airplane about to take off from Coppermine, on the Arctic coast, reached here today in a Canadian Airways flight report.

Mayor F.H. La Guardia will be one of the guest speakers at the dinner to be given at the Biltmore a week from Tuesday, in honor of Miss Virginia C. Gildersleeve, who is celebrating her twenty-fifth year as Dean of Bernard College. Other speakers will represent the trustees of the college, the administrators, Columbia University, alumnae, faculty and undergraduates.

WITH the annual metropolitan team championships at hand, and the opening of the first tournament in recent years for the national championship planned for March 28, chess enthusiasts of New York and its vicinity have plenty of material for discussion.

On one excuse after another attempts are being made to bring into use here a form of the Russian passport system or the Austrian police registration system which have long cumbered the free movements of individuals in Europe. The latest, reported in THE TIMES, is the scheme of identification cards for every resident of the United States, proposed by the chairman of the Unemployment Commission in Massachusetts.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- More than 200 student debaters in some twenty-five New York State colleges are discussing actual bills before the Legislature in preparing their own solutions to problems represented in the legislation, Jasper V. Garland, Colgate debate coach and president of the State Debaters' Conference, announced tonight.

THE outcome of almost a quarter century of steady work and scholarly methods and skill, Mr. Smith's collection of English proverbs makes a reference book of sterling value. It contains over ten thousand proverbs, arranged alphabetically under the first word of each saying, variant versions of the same idea being inserted immediately after what seems to be the oldest form.

With the death yesterday at the age of 76 of Charles Curtis, Vice President under Herbert Hoover, the nation is left with only one former President, Mr. Hoover, and one former Vice President, Charles G. Dawes.

PARIS. LINGERIE styles both follow and lead the way for exterior fashions, so that it is interesting to cast a bird's-eye glance over the foundations upon which Paris is preparing to build its Spring chic.

GENEVA, Feb. 8. -- Among the factors that are causing the League of Nations to hesitate to impose further sanctions are the perils, real and exaggerated, of the European situation now demanding the most attention. Other factors, such as strategical considerations, which remain unchanged, or the uncertainty regarding the American neutrality policy already have been discussed in these columns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- In the United States, east of the Rockies, we have had this Winter some spells of unusually bitter weather. The man in the street describes the season as "old-fashioned," and in using this phrase he no longer evokes a smile of superior knowledge from the professional weatherman, as would have happened up to a decade or so ago.

A gain of a full billion in the number of cigars to be sold this year was forecast by manufacturers yesterday, on the basis of last month's sales reports. Although traditionally a bad month for cigar volume, January this year showed a gain of 10 to 15 per cent, compared with the corresponding month in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- For several days Charles Curtis had been suffering from a cold, but this morning he seemed much improved and his sister, Mrs. Gann, went shopping.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- A disaster was narrowly averted early today when thirty-three members of a theatrical troupe fled from a bus stalled on the Central Railroad of New Jersey tracks at the Middlebrook crossing in the path of a Baltimore Ohio train just before the locomotive wrecked the vehicle.

Low-rental housing for urban slum dwellers requires "substantial" government subsidies and cannot be produced through private initiative and ownership, as is proposed by some realty interests, according to an "economic brief" by Evans Clark, economic adviser to the New York City Housing Authority, and submitted yesterday to President Roosevelt by the National Public Housing Conference.

ALWAYS move in the right set. That's one of the secrets of success. See where the Rangers are on the frozen front? Trailing in their division. They may not make the playoffs simply because they have been skating in the wrong circle, meaning the American sector of the big league. The thirty-two points that make the Rangers poverty-stricken' cellar dwellers in that group would put them "right up there" in the International division.

Manhattan's basketball team, closely pressed in the early stages, unleashed a second-half drive that completely subdued the Seventh Regiment quintet and gave the Green a 40-to-27 victory at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. The triumph was the eleventh in thirteen starts this season for Neil Cohalan's charges.

NO politician in Europe is more active these days than Austria's young Vice Chancellor, Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg. In London, recently, he sought aid for his country from British statesmen. At home and abroad he is constantly on the march, striving to strengthen Austria's independence and his own power.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Devaluation of the franc or the French abandonment of the gold standard, which is looked upon in London as a probability in the near future, will not serve as a compelling cause to bring Britain back to currency stabilization. It will not even be an incentive to the British Treasury to think the time has come to consider that matter.

HERE is another story about Penberthey Island, off Cape Cod, and about Elisha Macomber, the selectman- detective who appeared in Miss Knight's first book, "Death Blew Out the Match." A part of the action takes place on the island of Quontauk, which is separated from Penberthey by only a narrow strait.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8. -- Among those entertaining large parties at the Arabian Nights Ball at the Surf Club tonight were Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Miller, Mrs. Charles I. Corby, Mr. and Mrs. C.A. McGuire, Mrs. Arthur A. Parks, Mrs. W.L. Milner, Mr. and Mrs. E.S. Stackhouse, Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bushnell, Mr. and Mrs. Atherton W. Hobler and Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Smith.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 8 (AP). -- The government struck at former political leaders and opposition journalists today in its efforts to crush a six-day railway strike. The number now under arrest was estimated at 260, following the declaration of a state of siege last night in all Southern Chile.

LOVELY to look at, interesting to read, this handsomely made, large quarto volume offers many satisfactions for readers who are interested in ships, history and the art of the sea. Gregory Robinson is an artist who knows the sea and ships and has done much portrayal of both.

BIRDS have it all their own way just now at the Downtown Gallery. They are done in granite, in marble and in bronze; they are done in alabaster, cast iron, applewood, copper and ceramic; some are done, Mrs. Halpert tells us, in papier-mache.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8. -- Weather played a dominating part in trade and industry in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week and, from present indications, the return to form will be delayed for some time.

Contending that the customs deadlock on liquidation of import entries involving goods formerly subject to compensation taxes is putting an unnecessary financial strain upon them, local importers moved last week to persuade government officials to release well over $1,000,000 "frozen" by the Supreme Court ruling on AAA last month.

THE atmosphere of Europe is becoming heavily charged. Its tenseness inevitably has a reminder of 1914, yet with differences. People everywhere are talking of "war" -- not merely of the war in Ethiopia; this has stimulated their more general apprehensions. It is easier for men to see the ways in which war may come than how it can be avoided.

William C. Durant, pioneer automobile manufacturer and founder of General Motors during a business career in which he built, lost, won back and lost again many-ciphered enterprises as well as fabulous fortunes in security brokerage accounts, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Seven stone tablets, on which the great Persian Emperor Xerxes recorded for posterity the state of his empire some 2,420 years ago, and three of which bear inscriptions new to historians, have been discovered in Iran (Persia) by excavators for the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- In the United States, east of the Rockies, we have had this Winter some spells of unusually bitter weather. The man in the street describes the season as "old-fashioned," and in using this phrase he no longer evokes a smile of superior knowledge from the professional weatherman, as would have happened up to a decade or so ago.

A gain of a full billion in the number of cigars to be sold this year was forecast by manufacturers yesterday, on the basis of last month's sales reports. Although traditionally a bad month for cigar volume, January this year showed a gain of 10 to 15 per cent, compared with the corresponding month in 1935.

Six places in the second round were filled as the first day's play was concluded in the annual invitation tennis tourney at the Heights Casino In Brooklyn yesterday. Three of the qualifiers were seeded players.

William C. Durant, pioneer automobile manufacturer and founder of General Motors during a business career in which he built, lost, won back and lost again many-ciphered enterprises as well as fabulous fortunes in security brokerage accounts, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court.

A memorial ceremony in honor of persons who lost their lives when the Maine was sunk in Havana Harbor in February, 1898, will be held at 8 P.M. Saturday at the 212th Regiment Armory, 120 West Sixty-second Street, it was announced yesterday.

When March contracts for cotton dipped below the level of 11 cents a pound last week mills took a large portion of the floating supply from the market and the result yesterday was that prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied again and gained 2 to 4 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- In the interest of the proposed equal rights treaty, which was considered last September for the first time by the League of Nations Assembly, Alice Paul, founder of the National Woman's party and author of the treaty, and Mrs. John Jay White of New York will sail Wednesday on the George Washington to attend the session of the International Labor Organization at Geneva.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 8. -- Dartmouth's team came through to victory today in its twenty-sixth annual Winter Carnival. The Green has won this event before, but never has there been a finer triumph, for some of her best skiers are in Germany with the American Olympic team.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Seven stone tablets, on which the great Persian Emperor Xerxes recorded for posterity the state of his empire some 2,420 years ago, and three of which bear inscriptions new to historians, have been discovered in Iran (Persia) by excavators for the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago.

LOVELY to look at, interesting to read, this handsomely made, large quarto volume offers many satisfactions for readers who are interested in ships, history and the art of the sea. Gregory Robinson is an artist who knows the sea and ships and has done much portrayal of both.
St. John's University will grant 160 degrees to students who have just completed courses at the School of Law and the School of Commerce, it was announced yesterday at the university.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Dave (Sweeney) Schriner, the league's leading scorer, and Art Chapman led the way tonight as the New York Americans trounced the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, in a ragged National League hockey match.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The stock markets again are experiencing considerable speculative activity, with industrial stocks obtaining by far the greatest share of attention. The government's expenditures for armaments and its fostering of trade in other directions are stimulating interest in companies which directly or indirectly must benefit.
The Manhattan police homicide squad is supposed to inspire terror among evil-doers almost by its name alone.

The successful elementary school teacher does not resort to punishment to meet behavior problems in the class room, but obtains a cooperative response from the children by reasoning, explanations and positive suggestions, according to a survey by Dr. Nellie M. Campbell of Teachers College, Columbia University, the results of which were made public yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- General Andre Niessel, former member of the Supreme War Council, charged today that Germany had moved 40,000 fully armed men into the demilitarized Rhineland zone under the guise of constabulary detachments.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 9. -- The storm in Olympic hockey circles which arose from Canada's suspension of Alex Archer and James Foster, members of the British team, was renewed today as several European nations threatened to protest Britain's victories.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Mrs. Della K. Cotton, widow of Dr. Henry A. Cotton, head of the New Jersey State Hospital for the Insane, will be at the dock in New York tomorrow to meet the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, from which her son, Adolph Cotton, 25 years old, was reported missing at sea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Utopian schemes for a redistribution of wealth threaten destruction of both wealth and income, and "misinformation" on the subject is frequently circulated by demagogues seeking to arouse class prejudices to serve their own political interests, the American Liberty League declared today in a nine-point attack on "share-the-wealth" proposals.

All the nine New York stores that reported their best sellers last week put George Santayana's novel, "The Last Puritan," in first place. This is the first novel since the hey-day of "Anthony Adverse" to be so rated in any one week. Nationally, the Santayana book leads in four of eight other cities reporting.

An outlay of about $10 covering the cost of a single insertion of an advertisement in the Public Notices columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as well as postage and stationery for correspondence, has made possible the mobilization of a symphony orchestra of amateurs.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman was reported today to be planning a second attempt to get Bruno Richard Hauptmann to tell the whole story of his complicity in the Lindbergh kidnapping or ransom payment.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9. -- Argentine editors applaud President Roosevelt's proposal for a Pan-American peace conference.

The Philadelphia monopoly on the Lockett Trophy remained unbroken yesterday, although the national champions were forced to bow in the final of the annual squash racquets invitation doubles tournament at the University Club.

In reviewing the momentous events of the North American Wildlife Conference in Washington last week, three developments stand out as especially significant. Listing them in the order of their importance:

BREWSTER, Mass., Feb. 9. -- Seven youths from the CCC camp at East Brewster were adrift on an ice floe in Cape Cod Bay tonight, their fate uncertain, while the Coast Guard patrol boat Harriet Lane searched for them in an immense field of broken ice.

Under the agreement which calls for offering to the public of a new issue of 10,000 shares of $5 cumulative convertible prior-preference stock without par value at $101 a share plus accrued dividends, Thompson Products, Inc., of Cleveland will redeem its outstanding preferred stock at 110.

The council of the Actors Equity Association has ordered all Equity members to withdraw at once from any other organization whose policies or aims might conflict with those of Equity. More exactly, these would be organizations which claim to represent actors and actresses in their relation to employers or the conditions of their work, an Equity official said yesterday.
PEKIN, Ill., Feb. 9 (AP). -- Clarence Rupp, taxicab company owner who had been wounded during the recent general strike here, was shot again today, this time fatally.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- All of the gold which left the Bank of France this week was withdrawn by the British Equalization Fund. It thus is established that the metal was not taken for hoarding by the French but rather represented the export of French capital to London.

IT takes a billiard player to dig up new angles. Charley Peterson has come up with a strange one. He has been hoping about from one institution of learning to another, stirring up the student clubs and college unions to a greater interest in pocket and non-pocket billiards of various kinds.

Champion Salisbury Sensation, a veteran campaigner and recognized as one of the outstanding toy dogs in the United States, added another noteworthy victory to his already impressive record yesterday when he was named the best of the breed at the twenty-sixth annual specialty show of the American Pomeranian Club staged in the Salle Moderne of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 9. -- A camera which detects and records the first small "explosions" of arteries in the human body, which later may result in death, was announced today by the Cleveland Clinic Foundation.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9. -- The "Hoboes of America" will fight in the courts, if necessary, to preserve their "constitutional rights" against this city's border patrol campaign on indigent transients.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The body of Charles Curtis left tonight for his native Kansas from the national capital which had known him for nearly forty years as a member of the House of Representatives, Senator and Vice President. Mr. Curtis died yesterday at the home of his sister, Mrs. Dolly Gann.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- Attempts to shoot air mail across the State line here into Hewitt, N.J., in two rocket gliders carrying 6,000 postcards and letters specially printed for the event, ended in flame, fizzle and failure today.

LONDON, Feb. 9. -- Apart from the necessity of Britain intervening if Germany attacks France across the Rhine or overruns Belgium, the British Government is now clear upon what point a direct clash between the two countries appears inevitable.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council, assailed yesterday the recommendation of the New York Board of Trade for restrictive legislation to govern labor unions. He denied the board's charge that racketeering was widespread in organized labor, saying that it was not nearly as prevalent in labor unions as in business and industry.

The final report of the Senate munitions inquiry, when it is published about March 15, will not support a conclusion that his committee has given the banking firm of J.P. Morgan Co. a clean bill of health in connection with American entry into the World War, United States Senator Gerald P. Nye said last night in an address at Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9. -- Work has begun on the construction of a great canal to link the Black Sea with the Caspian by way of the Sea of Azov. The canal will make the Caspian Sea accessible to oceangoing ships and will greatly facilitate the shipment, both within the Soviet Union and abroad, of oil from the rich fields of Baku and of other products from the southeastern part of the Soviet Union.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- The London naval parley is being followed here with what is loosely designated in official quarters as "passive interest," and until something concrete in the nature of a formal invitation to participate is extended by the naval powers now involved, the German attitude will not be made known.

Miss Melinda Alexander, writer, lecturer and executive director of the Alexander Forum Foundation, announced last night that she would seek the regular Republican nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District.

We should learn to appreciate our fellowman and to understand their hidden qualities, for every man is unlike any other man, and it is the duty of each to carry out that part of God's plan which has been allotted to him, the Rev. Harry N. Holmes, executive secretary of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches, declared yesterday morning.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 9. -- Germany continued to sweep all before it today in the fourth Olympic Winter Games. Another pair of gold and silver Olympic medals fell to its lot when Franz Pfnuer and Gustav Lantschner finished first and second in the combined down-mountain ski race and the slalom.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 9. -- Today at the Winter Olympics was especially the day of the male figure skaters. They are tall, graceful lads, immaculately clad in close-fitting black skating suits, with their well-developed lower limbs shown off by black woolen tights and high skating boots.

Art Coulter lifted the New York Rangers back into third place in the American Group of the National Hockey League last night. The big defense man, recently acquired from the Chicago Black Hawks, scored one goal and helped Lynn Patrick make another to enable the Blue Shirts to turn back the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden by the score of 2 to 0.

Christian Brevoort Zabriskie, a retired manufacturer, whose first American ancestors came to the Colonies in the seventeenth century, died Saturday at his home, Belle Terre, Port Jefferson, L.I. His daughter, Mrs. Zayda Z. Daniels, and five grandchildren, survive.
Deputy Commissioner Paul J. Kiernan, for many years in the Department of Sanitation, collapsed from overwork yesterday in the lobby of the new Health Department Building, off Foley Square.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The battle of the budget will be renewed on Capitol Hill this week when the Republicans will attack Governor Lehman's tax program at two public hearings.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9. -- The Chilean railroad strike has given President Arturo Alessandri an opportunity to clean up a political situation that had been annoying him for more than two years. Santiago dispatches today announce the railroad and other strikes have been settled and that the situation is again normal.
Was not it Lincoln who said: "But you cannot fool all of the People all of the time"? Certainly many of our men in public life do not believe it today.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 9. -- Franz Pfnuer won the slalom race by a wide margin today. His two times both were faster than the best his nearest rival in the field of thirty-three could do and he received a minimum of penalties for form.

The Rev. Dr. Malcolm J. MacLeod, retired pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Forty-eighth Street at Fifth Avenue, said in his sermon yesterday morning that thinking has an important effect on a person's health and happiness.

While the Dressmakers Union, backed by the International Ladies Garment Workers, parent organization, continued its preparations yesterday for a general strike of 105,000 workers set for Thursday, progress was made in conferences with employers toward a possible settlement.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936 as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Some recent administration pronouncements viewed by him as touching on budget balancing and retrenchment in government expenditures were characterized as a "shallow pretense" today by Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

CRISFIELD, Md., Feb. 9 (AP). -- Six thousand pounds of foodstuffs were sent to ice-locked Tangier Island today as Red Cross, Coast Guard, army and State officials united to continue the rescue efforts which had cost the life of one man.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Renewing his assault as an old-line Republican against the Presidential candidacy of Senator Borah of Idaho, former Senator Fess of Ohio today asserted that the party's nominee must hold a record of having supported "more Republican measures than Democratic measures."

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The incorporation of 1,902 new stock concerns in January was reported today by the division of corporations by the Secretary of the Department of State. This aggregate failed by thirty-four to reach the total for January a year ago, but it was ahead of December's total by 224.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Attempts to find a constitutional method of permitting the Federal Government to make advances to local governments for slum clearance and low-cost housing have held up introduction by Senator Wagner of a public housing bill, it was learned today.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Six bills for drastic revisions of the Motor Vehicle Law, designed to reduce the heavy loss of life in automobile accidents, will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow night by Senator Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, New York Republican.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the following tabulation.

FISHKILL, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- A heavy snowstorm caused the postponement early this afternoon of the Middle Atlantic States ski-jumping competition for the trophy donated by President Roosevelt. The Norway Ski Club, sponsor of the meet, rescheduled the event for March 1 on the tricky Norway hill here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The industrial-craft union controversy within the American Federation of Labor flared up again today when representatives of 30,000 radio workers rejected union with the electrical workers' union.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt, Governor Lehman, Senators Wagner and Copeland, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, and other prominent persons were invited last night to attend the eviction of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Gilleeny and their three children from their home in Sunnyside, Queens.

The Class 1 railroads last year earned their largest net operating income since 1931, according to the Association of American Railroads. A statement by the association, based on reports by 145 companies operating 237,661 miles of line, showed a gain of 7.4 per cent in net for 1935 compared with 1934.

Henry Bernstein, chairman, announced yesterday the organization of a voluntary committee of small furniture retailers to combat the practices of certain self-styled wholesalers who are said to lure customers by professing to charge wholesale prices while actually charging as much or more than retailers.
A wide variety of realty, especially Jersey City property, changed hands in deals announced over the week-end.

At last Senator BORAH'S real purpose is beginning to make itself clear. His Presidential candidacy has never seemed more than tentative and halfhearted. His actual desire to become President has seemed doubtful. But the fight into which, it is now evident, he means to throw himself with vigor and determination is a fight to reform Republican procedure in nominating the President.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9. -- Soviet fliers are battling fogs and blizzards while rescue parties on the ground are fighting their way through mountainous drifts in search of three aviators of a research expedition on the northeast tip of Siberia who vanished on a flight Dec. 19.

Commodity futures prices were generally lower last week in somewhat quiet trading. Crude rubber, however, was an exception, with final prices from 31 to 43 points higher for the week. Cash prices for rye, butter, eggs, antimony, cotton and rubber gained, while the quotations on wheat, oats, flour, raw sugar, lard, pork, tin, silk and hides declined.

The man who can see the future sees nothing but failure for the human race unless there is a return to righteousness, the Rev. M. Joseph Twomey, formerly pastor of the Baptist Temple of Philadelphia, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at Calvary Baptist Church, 23 West Fifty-seventh Street.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Following is a tabulation of how New York City members in the Legislature voted on important roll-calls last week:

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- Within the next six months, according to statements published in Paris newspapers, the French Treasury will have to raise 7,000,000,000 francs and in 1936 its needs will amount to 17,000,000,000 francs.

Housing, taxpayer and garage properties figured in selling and leasing contracts announced by brokers over the week-end. The Bronx was the chief center of trading, the borough furnishing sales of two apartment houses, the purchase of a taxpayer and the leasing of a garage building on Third Avenue.

The New York Chamber Music Society, headed by Carolyn Beebe, founder and pianist, gave its third "Sunday salon" of the season at the Hotel Plaza last night. The guest artists were Bruce Boyce, baritone; Carlos Salzedo, harpist; Lois Phelps, pianist, and Andrew Tietjen, player of the xylophone and glockenspiel.

A luncheon and card party will take place tomorrow at the Dorset for the benefit of the Prosperity Shop, a permanent thrift shop at 1,279 Third Avenue, which is maintained to help various charitable organizations. The event has been arranged by Mrs. Louis B. Higgins with the aid of Mrs. Charles Mattlage and Mrs. William L. Hitzig.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- With their adjournment goal set at May 1, and permanent neutrality legislation, one of the most controversial issues on the original agenda, apparently abandoned, Congressional leaders are expected to agree next week on a very brief list of "must" bills.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 9. -- Zane Grey, the author, who has been fishing in a blaze of publicity since he came to Australia for swordfish, marlin and hammerhead sharks, is the object of unpleasant attention from the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which protests against his playing the fish for long periods.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 9. -- "Lost and Found," a semi-religious motion picture of problems of modern youth, taken for the most part in an abandoned Port Washington gas station and played by local talent, had its first showing here tonight in the parish hall of St. Stephen's Church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The WPA recreational program, which already embraces 10,000,000 persons in thirty States, including New York, is gauged to permit communities to take over the task of providing organized recreation for those on a short week due to technological developments or other causes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Terribly handicapped by frigid winds, the storm-whipped and frozen Middle West tonight was bending every effort to dig itself out after one of the worst blizzards in years, the third major storm in as many weeks.

More than 1,500 Boy Scouts representing seventy-five Catholic councils in nine counties attended a special solemn vesper service and benediction yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral, celebrating annual "Scout Sunday."

Orlando Barera, young Italian violinist, made his first appearance in this country at a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The newcomer arrived without the blasts of publicity affected for too many debutants. He revealed that he has an instinct for the violin, and, making allowance for a few technical and interpretive gaps, he raised hopes for a promising future.

Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General at New York, and Countess de Fontnouvelle will give a reception this afternoon in their apartment at the Pierre for the artists who will take part in the concert in behalf of the Lycee Francaise de New York to be held next Sunday night at Carnegie Hall.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 9. -- Siscoe Gold Mines reports gross production for 1935 of $2,274,583, against $2,116,603 in 1934, an increase of $157,980. A preliminary statement showed net earnings of $1,062,551, or 23.05 cents a share, against $1,186,565, or 25.74 cents a share, in 1934.

A call to members of the Progressive Republican State Committee and others interested in the candidacy of Senator William E. Borah for the Republican nomination for President to circulate petitions for candidates for election as delegates to the Republican National Convention has been issued by William Ziegler Jr., chairman of the committee, he announced yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 9 (AP). -- A five-power Danubian pact for economic and military cooperation will be submitted to French officials by Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia, who arrived here today.

BUFFALO, Feb. 9. -- A call to reformed Judaism of the United States to become a counterpart of the liberal movement in world Jewry, and a plea for more cooperative effort by the 286 reformed congregations of the country were voiced tonight before the executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations by Jacob W. Mack of Cincinnati, chairman.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Feb. 9 (AP). -- President Lazaro Cardenas declared today he found "no reason to believe that a Communist movement exists in Mexico," and then he reviewed a parade of 13,000 workers who sang the "Internationale."

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Export buying of lard, attributed to England and Germany, aggregating around 5,000,000 pounds, stirred the lard trade last week, as the foreign buying was the heaviest in a long time. Some operators in the trade, however, were not disposed to accept the reports of large foreign sales.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 8. -- I am reliably informed that THE NEW YORK TIMES carried a story ridiculing a WPA project of the city of Memphis to provide a dog pound for our city. The city of Memphis takes full responsibility for this project and we deeply resent your biased, partisan and unfair story in regard to this project.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The following public hearings before Congressional committees have been scheduled for this week:

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Heavy snows and intense cold have prevented free marketing of livestock recently in sections of the Middle West, especially in Northwestern Iowa, and resulted in irregularity in market prices of livestock. Quotations have fluctuated over a wide range in the last few weeks, creating an unsettled feeling.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- The press here recently has given considerable publicity to the shipments of gold from the United States and in informed circles it is feared that the public may have acquired a somewhat distorted view of the significance of the movements.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 (AP). -- A Foreign Office spokesman categorically denied tonight the charge by General Andre Niessel in Paris that Germany had sent 40,000 fully armed men into the demilitarized Rhineland disguised as policemen.

Grandma Logan is dead and Greenpoint is in mourning. The friend of all the community and believed to have been Brooklyn's oldest resident, died late Saturday night at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Herman Sloan, 77 Dupont Street, Brooklyn.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- Four great race heats and two broken records enabled Aubrey ("Buck") Wells, pilot for the Keene Mountaineers, to annex the national A.A.U. four-man Bobsled title on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run today.

The investigation by the Senate committee as to the effect of the World War upon American business indicates that the performance of the contracts between the British Government and certain American manufacturers for the sale of British Enfield rifles, instead of proving fabulously profitable, reduced the American manufacturers to a serious financial condition.

DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Father Charles E. Coughlin barred candidates for Congress from membership in his National Union for Social Justice today, and local office holders "or politicians" from holding any office in the union.

GENEVA, Feb. 9 (AP). -- A new campaign for peace in Ethiopia without an oil embargo against Italy was forecast in some League of Nations circles tonight. Reports that Britain was now lukewarm toward an embargo created the impression that oil would not be kept from Italy, because such action would lessen chances for peace through conciliation.

An amendment to the rules governing the One-Ton Cup, the international trophy which has been raced for in Scandinavian waters by six-meter yachts for years, has been made, and the North American Yacht Racing Union has applied to have the trophy competed for in this country, should it be won the coming Summer by an American craft.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- The non-party newspapers, that reflect the German foreign policy, were again today chiefly concerned with the political conversations and diplomatic exchanges in Paris after the funeral of King George in London. The editorials are facetious and do not spare any of the lesser royalty or diplomatic personages who took part in the talks.

Reporting its first net profit for a year since 1931, the Childs Company announced yesterday that it had cleared $117,063 in 1935 after all charges including taxes. The earnings are equal to $3.14 a share on 37,321 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

The Republic of Colombia made the best improvement in its economic position in 1935 for any year since 1928, according to a report of a survey made by the executive committee of Colombia Bondholders Committees and announced yesterday through Lawrence E. de S. Hoover, secretary.

The joint legislative committee headed by Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, that was appointed last April to investigate bondholders' committees, made public yesterday the first of two reports which it will lay before the New York State Legislature.

Louis Waldman, chairman of the Old Guard Socialist State Committee, challenged yesterday the left wing State organization set up by the national executive committee of the party when it suspended the New York party's charter last month to enter the primary contest on April 2 for control of the party in this State.

Gregory Mangin of Newark, the top seeded player, made an auspicious start yesterday in his quest for a leg on the new Governor's Cup in the annual invitation tennis tourney of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

Spokesmen for the Interborough, Manhattan Railway and B.M.T. groups with which Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. negotiated their working draft of a transit unification plan have notified the Transit Commission that they are unwilling at this time to submit to that board in writing their specific objections to the plan.
CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Feb. 9. -- Tommy Rose, British flying officer, landed at 6:03 P.M. Greenwich time [1:03 P.M. New York time] today after a solo flight from Lympne, England.

Regardless of the fact that rain and snow fell long after the scheduled starting hour, nineteen gunners participated in the shoot at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. They decided a full program, with the major victory going to L.F. Sanman.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9. -- Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 51 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week. Production since Jan. 1 has fluctuated merely from 50 to 51 per cent. Output has been about 10 per cent under the daily average in December.

Even the simplified statement of Professor LEIGH PAGE'S modification of relativity will probably be incomprehensible to the non-mathematical in its larger aspect. But they should pick out one plum from its discussion of "frames of reference" and munch that with satisfaction.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 9. -- Two thousand New York and Boston skiers arrived in special trains this noon during a snow storm which disappeared by late afternoon. One thousand went to the Thunderbolt run on Greylock and the others were divided between South Lee and Pittsfield.

Prices in the cotton market moved last week first in one direction and then another, according to the varying interpretations from Washington as to the liquidation of the cotton held by the government. At the close on Saturday prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 1 to 14 points on the week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Cold and snowy weather over the Corn Belt States has increased the consumption of corn to the largest volume in recent years. It also is checking the movement of corn from the country to primary markets, and processors are taking the offerings, so there is almost no accumulation of supplies at leading points.

There will be several luncheons before the performance of "Aida," with Miss Dusolina Giannini, Giovanni Martinelli and Lawrence Tibbett in the leading roles, which will be given on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association.

More than three years after its London premiere, and with a record of extensive American travels, Ivor Novello's "Fresh Fields" comes to Broadway tonight. The final production of the firm of Richard Aldrich and Alfred de Liagre Jr., it opens at the Empire and restores to the local stage Margaret Anglin, last seen here in the season of 1928-29.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 10. -- Buildings and equipment valued at 450,000 were destroyed yesterday in a fire that in less than four hours left five acres in the center of Britain's film industry at Elstree a mass of smoking ruins.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- With a single exception, the favorites in the thirtieth annual gold racquet tournament safely came through their quarter-final tests at the Tuxedo Park Racquet and Tennis Club today. However, the one upset was of the first magnitude.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 9. -- Incomplete returns tonight indicated that Leon Cortes had been chosen President by an overwhelming vote in today's election, one of the bitterest in Costa Rica's history.
With more than a score of new exhibitions on the calendar, and with the Brooklyn Museum opening Chinese, Korean and Indian galleries, the midwinter art season continues at a swift pace.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Holders of May wheat contracts took advantage of all price advances on the Board of Trade last week to sell freely, but the break from the extreme top to the low level was only 2 1/4 cents a bushel, the net loss for the week being 1 5/8 cents.

Total assessments on real estate in New York City have been increased for the first time since the depression set in, the Board of Taxes and Assessments announced yesterday in making public final assessment figures for this year.

The opening performance of the Passion Play, "Veronica's Veil," conducted annually for the last twenty-one years under the auspices of the Holy Family Church of Union City, N.J., was given yesterday at the Passion Play Auditorium in Union City.

Efforts to clear ice and snow from streets over which the funeral cortege of the late Charles W. Rankin, deputy fire chief, is to pass this morning were interrupted when a snowplow burned last evening at Avenue D and East Thirty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, injuring two men.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature this year amount to $4,885,949,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Funeral services for William Marvin Reiber, 94-year-old Civil War veteran, who died Saturday night at the Forty-fourth Street Hotel while attending a Lincoln Day dinner of the G.A.R. Allied Organizations, will be held tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. at the Walter B. Cooke funeral chapel at 117 West Seventy-second Street.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Reduction in the French bank rate has not induced observers here to think that any material change in financial conditions in France has occurred which really justifies the lower money rates. An easier monetary situation is required simply for the needs of the French Treasury and such benefits as French trade may be able to derive therefrom.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 9. -- In his sermon today assailing the Nazis, Cardinal von Faulhaber told his congregation, which included the former Crown Prince Rupprecht of Bavaria, that some Nazis had declared Pope Plus was "against Germany" and that he was "the enemy of German youth."

Nearly 3,000 thoroughbred dogs of 100 varieties will be ready in Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock this morning to extend a noisy greeting to early visitors to the sixtieth annual exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club. They will be on their benches during three days, for morning, afternoon and evening sessions, the great show coming to a close Wednesday night.

The surprising reversal of form by N.Y.U., which fell from the ranks of the unbeaten during the week, left Long Island University as the only local college basketball team which has yet to taste defeat this season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The administration and hundreds of private power companies again awaited tonight the session of the Supreme Court tomorrow in anticipation that the court would hand down its ruling on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- With the public not broadly in the grain markets, local speculative interest lags and price movements on the Board of Trade are confined to narrow ranges, being governed largely by the price of the indemnities that are sold from day to day at only slight differences between the high and the low points.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 9. -- "The untrue attacks against Pope Pius XI and the papacy are so strong in the Nazi press that we can no longer keep quiet," Cardinal von Faulhaber of Munich told 6,000 listeners who packed St. Michael's Church here today.

NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- Jacob Baum, 80 years old, who with his 76-year-old wife was carried from their snowbound home yesterday to Nyack Hospital, died in the hospital today. Death was attributed to a heart ailment aggravated by pneumonia.

Neither "inflation talk" by a handful of Congressmen at Washington, nor the movement of foreign exchange against New York, with the first gold exports in appreciable quantity during sixteen months, gave any sign last week of affecting business sentiment.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 8. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.5, which compares with 84 the week before, 83.9 two weeks before, 83.8 three weeks before and 84.4 four weeks before. The present average is the lowest since Aug. 10.

The dressmakers of Paris continue to register the march of history with their usual infallible touch. New beach styles in Paris draw their inspiration from modern Egypt, Ethiopia and Persia. One house is featuring for the beach "enormously full Bedouin trousers of shantung or wide-striped linen."
A once well-known couplet in The New England Primer ran:

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The Federation of British Industries says in a business forecast for the first quarter of 1936 that the recent increase in the volume of imports of raw materials, contrasted with the stagnation early in 1935, augurs well for a continuation of business activity in the coming months.

To the international champion, "R" Wee Joy, owned by Mrs. Vera Fordham of Detroit and shown by her 11-year-old niece, Mary Jane Newell, went the best-in-show award at the twenty-eighth annual specialty exhibition of the Boston Terrier Club of New York held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Approval of "the actions and leadership" of Governor Harold G. Hoffman and recognition of him as "the titular head of the Republican party in the State of New Jersey" was expressed in a resolution adopted by the executive committee of the Young Republicans of New Jersey, Inc., in a closed session here this afternoon.

As a feature of its tenth week this season, the Metropolitan Opera Association will offer its first triple bill of the Winter. This will consist of "Pagliacci," "Serenade," which will be danced by the American Ballet Ensemble, and "Gianni Schicchi."

American-bred Scottish terriers compare favorably with the best that are benched at the leading British exhibitions, in the opinion of Dr. J.S. Twigg of Crich House, Woodthorpe, Nottingham, England who judged the breed at the annual specialty shows of the Associated Terrier Clubs, held yesterday in Grand Central Palace.

A gold watch that Abraham Lincoln bought for his fiancee and then gave to another girl will be shown for the first time publicly on Lincoln's birthday. It is one of the 250-odd items of the Lincoln exhibit which is being sponsored by the Madison Square Boys Club and which will be opened at the Hotel Lincoln on Wednesday.

Dr. Caroline Ellen Furness, noted woman astronomer who had been a Professor of Astronomy at Vassar College for twenty years, died yesterday after a long illness at the Memorial Hospital, 2 West 106th Street. She was 66 years old.

FROM the far-away island of Tahiti the hardworking authors of "Mutiny on the Bounty" have sent another sure-fire hit to town. In their South Sea remoteness Charles Nordhoff and James Norman Hall write self-confidently along old model lines which have long been deplored and held to be dated. They insist on using heroes and villains.

A goal by Sammy Babcock midway through the final chapter, scored from a melee in front of the Gulls' cage, broke a 2-2 deadlock and proved the winning goal as the New York Rovers triumphed over Atlantic City, 4 to 2, in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
The fourteenth annual pet show of the Madison Square Boys Club last night in the gymnasium of the club at 321 East Thirtieth Street was a howling success.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 9. -- In response to appeals from responsible Italian-Americans, State Commissioner D. Frederick Burnett of the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control will sponsor a bill in the New Jersey Legislature authorizing certain clubs to manufacture wine for consumption by members and their families.

Mrs. Lucie Bigelow Rosen gave an interesting theremin recital at the Town Hall last night before an appreciative audience. She was assisted by a string quartet consisting of Boris Koutzen, first violin; Nikolaia Berezowsky, second violin; Leon Barzin, viola, and Carlo Piscitello, 'cello.

Man's nearest approach to Godliness occurs when he sets himself aside, giving preference to something he believes to be greater than himself, the Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers, newly appointed pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street, said yesterday morning.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise charged yesterday in his sermon at the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall that "thousands of Americans who call themselves 'Liberty Leaguers' would end democracy here tomorrow, though we fought a war to make the world safe for democracy only twenty years ago."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- A manifestation of the personal good-will which most of official Washington, regardless of party divisions, feels toward Postmaster General Farley was given this afternoon when more than 1,000 persons attended a reception given in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Farley at the Mayflower Hotel by Assistant Secretary of the Treasury L.W. Robert Jr. and Mrs. Robert.

Although there were more fires in New York City in 1935 than in 1934, the city's general fire loss and per-capita loss were the lowest in twenty years, it was disclosed yesterday in a report by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

William H. Chandler, traffic manager of the Merchants Association, expressed the opinion yesterday that motor truck operators whose operations are limited to the performance of terminal services for consignors or consignees of freight are not subject to Federal regulation under the new Motor Carrier Act.

BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- Authorities here say that no material increase in the Reichsbank's reserves is likely this year. There is ground indeed for believing that Dr Hjalmar Schacht, Reich Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, does not aim to replenish the bank's reserves as this would bring forth a demand from foreign creditors for a more liberal transfer of funds.

Dwight Huntington Day, retired banker and prominent Presbyterian layman, who retired in 1924 as treasurer and executive officer of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, died at midnight last night, after a long illness, at his home, 114 East Ninetieth Street. He was 59 years old.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Levi E. Folk, a hero of Walter Reed's conquest of yellow fever at the beginning of the century, died last night after a long illness. He was 66 years old last Friday.

The program performed by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Hans Lange at yesterday afternoon's concert was a repetition of the one given by the same forces Saturday night. It brought to the fore three works already presented on Thursday night find Friday afternoon -- namely, the new symphony in F minor by Vaughan Williams; "Three Shadows," by Lazare Saminsky, and "The White Peacock" by Griffes.

Announcements last week of bonds to be redeemed before maturity made little change in the volume previously listed for February. Refundings by public-utility and industrial corporations predominated. Most of the calls were for future months, only one industrial lot and a few small amounts of municipal bonds being added to the schedule for February, which now totals $128,536,000, compared with $267,269,000 a month ago and $165,634,000 for February, 1935, in the corresponding week.

MADRID, Feb. 9. -- The two opposing camps for the general elections to be held next Sunday ended their campaigns today with sixteen meetings in the capital and its suburbs. Speeches here were relayed by telephone wires to the provinces, use of the radio having been prohibited by the government.

MADRID, Monday, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Professor Luis Ulloa, Peruvian historian who stirred up a controversy among scholars with his assertion that Christopher Columbus was not born in Genoa but in Catalonia, Spain, died today. He had lived in Catalonia for many years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Prompt passage of an anti-trust law amendment intended to protect independent merchants was forecast today by its author, Senator Robinson of Arkansas.

Widespread changes in the teaching methods of law schools were advocated yesterday by Dean Young B. Smith of the Columbia University School of Law in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Activity in the local wholesale markets was sharply curtailel last week. The lag in retail trade, caused by the cold weather and the threatened dress strike, prevented buyers from coming to the market and held down mail orders. The chief activity continued to be provided by mannish suits, which sold well in some sections of the country.

It is not news when some special industry asks for a special favor from the Government. It is news when an industry makes a point of declaring that it does not want any special governmental favors for itself and that it thinks it unwise for other industries to ask for them.

" Serenade," a classic ballet in one act, presented by the American Ballet Ensemble, was the special feature of last night's gala concert at the Metropolitan Opera House. The ballet had been seen here previously, when the same troupe of dancers appeared on Broadway last season, but this was its first performance on the Metropolitan boards.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 9. -- After more than twenty-four hours of continuous questioning on two murders, Frederick Hansen, 60 years old, former New York police sergeant, was sent this afternoon to the State Hospital at Kings Park on a voluntary commitment in which he agreed to submit to examination and observation as to his mental condition.

EASTON, Pa., Feb. 9. -- The most striking difference between our colleges today and those of a hundred years ago probably is in religious atmosphere, Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, said in an address tonight at the annual faculty dinner of Lafayette College.
