A return to the old standards when agreements either among men or nations were sacred was called for yesterday by the Rev. Nathan S. Seagle, rector of St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The local social question of the moment, is Mrs. W. Forbes Morgan's great dane Hamlet vicious, reached Capitol Hill today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10. -- Nikolai Bukharin, chief of the editorial board of Izvestia, the principal government newspaper, and one of the foremost if not the foremost of Soviet publicists, has fallen into disfavor with the leadership of the Communist party.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 10. -- A bequest to Harvard College, estimated at between $3,000,000 and $5,000,000, was made in the will of Mrs. Agnes Wahl Nieman, filed for probate today.

BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- Trading on the Boerse opened the week dull and irregular. Changes usually stayed within 1 point and gains and losses balanced each other. There was some fluctuating interest in heavy industrials, among which Hoesch gained 1 point and Stollberg Zinc, 2 3/4.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Efforts of the Navy League to rehabilitate its finances through the solicitation of those who would benefit commercially in a big navy and big merchant marine were detailed today before the Senate Munitions Committee.

Americans digging themselves out of blizzards and raiding the stores for ear muffs simply cannot understand the poor American showing in the Winter Olympics. Citizens who four times a day successfully negotiate the slalom hairpin turns across the Times Square ice hummocks can only wonder what has happened to our boys in the Bavarian Alps.

The first one-man show of paintings by Zolton L. Sepeshy, resident instructor at Cranbrook Academy of Art Bloomfield Hills, Mich., opened yesterday at the Marie Sterner, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street. Sharing the galleries is a group of water-colors by Mary H. Peixotto, wife of the well-known American mural artist, Ernest Peixotto.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Rescue of the "forgotten women" of history and long overdue acknowledgment and just evaluation of their share in and contribution to world civilization by historians, lecturers and others were urged today by Dr. Mary R. Beard, publicist and author.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The Times of London prefaces its annual review of world finance and commerce with the cheerful declaration that progress was made last year in greater or less degree by virtually every country in the world.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

At the annual election yesterday of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange four new board members, Theodore W. Baumfeld, Edward J. Bowler, Frank J. McCormack and George Russhon, were elected. They succeed William F. Philips, Alfred I. Preston Jr., E.J. Muller and Robert L. Stott.
Spokesmen for the State and for smaller milk dealers hailed the Supreme Court's decision in the Borden case as a great victory for the poor people as well as for the independent dealers.

In an open letter addressed "to the press in the United States and Canada," Charles Wakefield Cadman, American composer, has withdrawn from any connection with American participation in the musical aspects of the Olympic Games in Germany.

In spite of all the bluster in administration circles with relation to the Supreme Court decision throwing out the AAA it is a little difficult to believe that the President and his Secretary of Agriculture, Mr. Wallace, did not feel an immense sense of relief when they found that the AAA was knocked out.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 10. -- Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld, on trial here for the murder of Walter W. Liggett, testified today that on the night of the slaying he demanded that police allow him to confront Liggett's widow to deny her charge that he operated the machine gun that poured five bullets into the editor's back in the alley at the rear of the Liggett apartment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Japanese foreign policy, as it affects this country and its relations in the Far East, was sharply criticized on the Senate floor today by Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and by Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois, a member of the committee.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 10. -- America's bobsledders will go out shortly after daybreak tomorrow to begin the defense of their Olympic four-man title and with the hopes of collecting the United States' first championship.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 10. -- Dispatches from Para indicated today that one out of every five persons in the interior village of Santa Rem had been killed by an undiagnosed malady.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 10. -- America will make its strongest bid for Olympic gold medals tomorrow in the 500-meter speed-skating race and in the four-man bob races, which will start at the same time. The results of these events will determine largely whether the United States is to preserve the mythical Winter Olympic championship which it won from Norway four years ago at Lake Placid.

VIENNA, Feb. 10. -- Clemens Kraus, general music director of the Berlin State Opera, denied today reports from Munich that he, in consequence of a desire on the Dart of the Nazi musical dictators to oust him from Berlin, had been appointed to succeed Hans Knappertsbusch as musical director of the Munich Opera, now that Mr. Knappertsbusch has been forbidden to conduct in Germany.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- At least twenty-five Minnesota hamlets, dozens of Wisconsin settlements and others in Michigan, Utah, Illinois and the Dakotas were still cut off by snowdrifts today.

Of all the major industries, perhaps excepting real estate, the railways were hit hardest in the depression after 1929. That was inevitable; because, along with the heavy shrinkage of consumption and production in all other industries, transportation of materials decreased rapidly.

New York City awarded yesterday $19,500,000 of serial bonds at an average interest cost of 3.076 per cent, the lowest on a comparable issue of the city since 1898. One lot of $6,500,000 due on Feb. 1, 1937 to 1946, was awarded to a syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank. The price was 100.789 for 2 1/4s.
CALLANDER, Ont., Feb. 10. -- Ovila Dionne said today the Ontario Government has expropriated seven and a half acres of his land without making an attempt to negotiate with him for its purchase.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 10. -- Commissioner Carl K. Withers of the State Department of Banking and Insurance said today the total assets of State banks, trust companies and savings institutions increased more than $50,000,000 last year.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (AP). -- The Army pursuit plane in which Lieutenant John T. Helms disappeared Dec. 30 was reported found today by a transport pilot who sighted the wreckage of a lost airliner in 1929.
Attorneys for Bruno Richard Hauptmann lost one opportunity yesterday to apply in Federal Court for a writ of habeas corpus at the expiration of Governor Hoffman's reprieve.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 10. -- By a vote of 29 to 28, the Assembly defeated tonight for the second time the Republican economy bloc's bill designed to "freeze" highway funds pending their possible diversion to emergency relief.

A radio car patrolman was shot in the arm at about 10:50 o'clock last night while trying to break into the room in an Eighth Avenue lodging house of a WPA worker who was firing pistol shots in all directions.

SOUTH RIVER, N.J., Feb. 10. -- Chief of Police Charles Eberwein, 53 years old, who had been a member of the Police Department here for thirty years, was shot and killed tonight by an innkeeper who was about to receive a hearing on a charge of selling liquor illegally.

THE mile merry-go-round now has the followers of track athletics in a pleasant dither. Three races, three different winners. With Jack Lovelock pursuing his medical studies in a London hospital and Bill Bonthron refraining from running under a roof, it was expected that Galloping Glenn Cunningham would make a runaway of the indoor miles in which he was a starter.

Visual evidence of the extent to which the wine and spirits industry has grown in the twenty-six months since repeal was presented at the opening yesterday afternoon of a National Wine and Liquor Show, which will continue for six days at Grand Central Palace.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan won his dispute with Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard yesterday over the type of paving to be used on the West Side express highway, when the Board of Estimate sustained his argument for the use of granite block paving.

Postponemen to Feb. 1, 1937, of minimum requirements for old-law tenements, as enacted last year, will only set a precedent for further delays, a joint statement issued by the heads of three welfare organizations declared yesterday.

A service of solemn benediction for the American Guild of Organists was held last evening at its request in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The guild members and their friends were the guests of the cathedral by the courtesy of Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, the rector.

Judith Sidorsky, a winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation Award, made her debut as pianist yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. She has an excellent technical equipment in the form of good wrists, resounding octaves, fleet fingers, a full tone when she does not ask too much of a fortissimo chord.

The sub-freezing temperatures registered yesterday will continue today, according to the United States Weather Bureau. The day's low point was 14 degrees at 7 P.M., and at 10 P.M., the last official reading, the mercury still stood at that point. There were indications that the mercury would continue to drop during the night, reaching 10 degrees by 8 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- A military appropriation bill calling for a record amount for peacetime, was introduced in the House today when the War Department measure for the next fiscal year carrying a total of $572,655,316 for military and non-military activities was presented by the Appropriations Committee and was immediately taken up for debate.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- Following the decision of the Atlantic Passenger Conference, which closed here Saturday with the important ruling that henceforth all Atlantic liners will be classed as cabin ships, it is now learned that the minimum cabin rates that have been fixed will be slightly lower on what formerly were described as first-class ships and slightly higher on former cabin ships.

PARIS, Feb. 10 (AP). -- The work of strengthening Central and Eastern Europe's defenses against a possible Nazi attack went forward today with Pierre-Etienne Flandin, French Foreign Minister, conferring with Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 10. -- Babe Risko successfully defended his world's middleweight title tonight at Laurel Garden by earning a ten-round decision over Tony Fisher of Newark.

The viciousness with which his murderers beat and strangled Samuel Drukman was demonstrated yesterday by the gruesome exhibits presented by the State at the opening of testimony in the trial of Meyer and Harry Luckman and Fred J. Hull.

VALETTA, Malta, Feb. 10. -- Whether the League of Nations imposes oil sanctions or not, the British fleet in these waters is taking no chances. It is making itself ready for any act of retaliation by Italy.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- As Assembly Republicans were preparing for a hearing tomorrow before the Ways and Means Committee on Governor Lehman's revenue measures and for a hearing on Wednesday devoted exclusively to the emergency tax on gasoline which they desire to eliminate, the Governor sent to the Legislature tonight his supplementary budget bill, calling for appropriations of $244,583 in addition to the $308,667,248 provided for in his original budget measures.
SAN JOSE, Feb. 10. -- A menace of possible inflation has arisen to jeopardize endowed educational institutions, former President Hoover testified today as a Superior Court witness.

SALEM, N.J., Feb. 10. -- Mrs. Marguerite Fox Dolbow and her childhood sweetheart, Norman Driscoll, were sentenced to death in the electric chair tonight within ten minutes after a jury had found them guilty of the murder of Mrs. Dolbow's husband, Harry.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 10 (AP). -- A reported split in the Mexican Government over the labor policies of President Lazaro Cardenas was denied today by General Saturnino Cedillo, Secretary of Agriculture and the most conservative member of the Cabinet.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 10. -- Those Olympic visitors who rashly assumed from the weather manifestations of last week that Winter in Bavaria is uniformly mild had a shock today. It is really cold, and it is snowing again to boot.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- A new conference between representatives of eight creditor countries and the committee of German debtors got under way here today to determine future liquidation of approximately 1,400,000,000 marks of short-term credits owned to foreign banks by German banks and commercial industrial concerns included in the so-called standstill agreement.

The Liggett Drug Company, Inc., leased a corner store at Lexington Avenue and Forty-first Street in the Chanin Building, which now has all its ground-floor store space rented. Riker Co. arranged the lease with Chanin Management, Inc.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- Great Britain's beet sugar industry, which has received $250,000,000 of government money in the last twelve years to keep it alive, will continue to enjoy heavy subsidies from the national exchequer by the terms of a bill fathered by the Cabinet that passed second reading in the House of Commons tonight.

Samples of the handwriting of Frederick Hansen, retired police sergeant, are to be compared with writing in letters sent to newspapers by "3-X," the unidentified man who killed a grocer and a salesman at two separate places in Queens in June, 1930, District Attorney Sullivan of Queens announced last night.

The agreement by the United States at the London Naval Conference to limit cruiser construction for the next five or six years to ships of 8,000 tons in size, mounting 6.1-inch guns, represents a concession to the policies of foreign navies which is far more apparent than real.

Net income of the New Jersey Zinc Company for 1935 amounted to $4,666,000 after taxes, depreciation, depletion, contingencies and other charges, equal to $2.37 a share on 1,963,264 shares of $25-par capital stock. The year before the company earned $3,788,380, or $1.93 a share.
BREWSTER, Mass., Feb. 10. -- Seven CCC youths were rescued by Coast Guardsmen today after they had been adrift on the ice in Cape Cod Bay for twenty-three hours.

Prices of most commodity futures were unsettled in the trading on the local markets yesterday. Sugar futures were steady, and silk and cottonseed oil advanced moderately. On the cash markets, cotton, eggs and tin were stronger, but wheat, corn, rye and rubber declined.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 10. -- An oil dilution system which permits starting of airplane engines in four minutes in sub-zero weather, an essential to military missions of the air, was declared by engineers of the material division, G.H.Q., Air Force, to be the "stand-out" result of the army's Winter test manoeuvres in New England.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Opposition to Governor Lehman's program for the better enforcement of the criminal law came to the fore tonight in both the Senate and the Assembly, with the result that two of his more important measures went down to defeat.

The rudely intricate devices of the dawn of the industrial revolution, the delicately powerful developments of modern experimental science and the fundamental forces which link them awed a few hundred guests last night at a preview of the new home of the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- As the Supreme Court failed again today to hand down its decision on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act it was learned that the government was considering a plan to offset the effect of a possible ruling that the act is invalid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Action produces reaction, as more than the physicists know. When politicians are grooming a successor to the man in office, they stress those of his supposed attributes which provide the strongest contrast to the traits of the incumbent, and those of his alleged exploits which do the same.

Squadron A and Silver Brook rode through to the semi-final round of the low-goal division in the tenth annual New York Athletic Club midwinter polo tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx last night. These games completed the first round.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10. -- Five Florida Derby candidates were on display in the mile of the fifth race at Hialeah Park today. Rushaway, a gelded son of Haste, in the scarlet, white and black silks of J.E. Widener, proved thoroughly at home in the heavy going and won by two lengths. Don Meade, completing a double, was looking back through the final sixteenth as he brought his mount home in 1:42 1-5.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Sections of the New York State Milk Control Law allowing companies without well-advertised trade names to sell milk at 1 cent per quart less than other firms were upheld by the Supreme Court today in a five-to-four decision.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Unanimously holding that "a free press stands as one of the great interpreters between the government and the people," the Supreme Court, in an opinion read by Justice Sutherland today, abolished the law driven through the Louisiana Legislature by Huey P. Long to tax the gross advertising revenue of the larger newspapers in that State.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in January reached the highest level since June, 1934, the company reported yesterday. The total for the month was 721,414 tons, compared with 661,515 tons in December and the previous peak of 985,337 tons in June, 1934.

The Great Northern Railway reported yesterday that in 1935 it earned its interest charges for the first time since 1931. The statement was timely in view of the company's plans for the sale of $100,000,000 of 4 per cent convertible bonds.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 10. -- A luncheon meeting that Henry W. Jeffers of Plainsboro, Republican State chairman, had hoped would be a pleasant gathering of the State committee members, the county chairmen and vice chairmen and Governor Hoffman was held here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Still buried under mountainous masses of snow, the Central States today made headway in their fight to open blocked highways and railroads as the sub-zero wave moderated slightly.

The customary championship schedule of forty-two games for the 1936 campaign of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League was announced yesterday by Ellwood W. Kemp Jr., secretary-treasurer of the circuit, through The Associated Press.

Little activity in the urban realty market was reported yesterday. Flats and dwellings comprised the foreclosure auction turnover, mortgagees taking over five parcels in Manhattan and the same number in the Bronx.

The Columbia University Club team, which last week clinched the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League Class C championship for the second straight year, concluded its schedule last night by defeating the Yale Club squad, 3 to 2, on the latter's courts for its tenth victory in as many league matches.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 (AP). -- A warrant charging Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt with mayhem in connection with a sterilization operation on her daughter, Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21, was airmailed today for service on Mrs. Hewitt at New York City.

The revival of Beethoven's only opera, "Fidelio," will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday afternoon, March 7, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Edward Johnson. The work has not been performed at the Thirty-ninth Street House since the season of 1929-30.
Sunday's mixture of snow, sleet and rain did not seem especially conducive to thoughts of baseball and bats, but apparently Robert Goldfarb and Solomon Cohen just don't think the way most people do.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The texts of the majority decisions and minority opinions in the Supreme Court on two New York milk cases were as fallows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Canadian railway companies filed applications for the permanent registration of more than $400,000,000 of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Similar applications for smaller issues have been received from Budapest, the capital of Hungary, and the Lombard Electric Company of Milan, Italy, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Eugene R. Black, a vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York City, son of the late Eugene R. Black, former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, was mentioned in official circles today as a probable successor to Thomas Jefferson Coolidge as Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

Because of delays, the plan of reorganization for the Chicago North Western Railway will not be filed before Feb. 27, Fred W. Sargent, president, said yesterday. He added, however, that it was hoped general principles would be established at a meeting of the board today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 (AP). -- Yale student leaders protested tonight to President James Rowland Angell over the use of "the facilities and prestige" of Yale for raising funds to support United States participation in the Olympic Games.

The Extraordinary Grand Jury investigating vice and racket conditions in New York County heard testimony yesterday from six of the eighty-three men and women who have been held in $10,000 bail each as material witnesses since the raids on disorderly houses conducted under the direction of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, a week ago Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The decision of the Supreme Court on the Louisiana newspaper tax is as follows:

BEIRUT, Syria, Feb. 10 (AP). -- French authorities, seeking to crush the "gray shirt" Syrian Fascist movement, killed five more rioters today as the disorders spread to Deibezor on the Euphrates River.

Already depressed by abnormal trading conditions, members of the Textile Converters Association of America, Inc., last night adopted a resolution appealing to Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia to call upon employers and employes for a speedy termination of the labor issues in the dress industry.

Negotiations between employes and employers in the dress industry, affecting more than 105,000 workers, were continued yesterday with indications persisting that the threatened strike in the industry would be averted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Warning that unless decent and livable quarters were furnished soon Congress would have to abolish the army, Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, commanding the Eighth Corps Area, told a House appropriations subcommittee on Dec. 17 that "when there is a lot of easy money floating around" is the time to take advantage of the opportunity.

The management of "The Eternal Road" yesterday postponed that spectacle until next Fall at the Manhattan Opera House, a move which Meyer W. Weisgal, producer, had indicated last Thursday was quite possible. The date now given ("The Eternal Road" has had a lot of them) is about Sept. 14.

A theory that Adolph Cotton, 25-year-old archaeological student who disappeared from the North German Lloyd liner Bremen Feb. 5, many have walked ashore with visitors at Cherbourg was advanced last night as the Bremen arrived in New York.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Interest in the Illinois primaries of April 14 was intensified today as it was announced that Senator Borah's name would be on the Republican ballot, while a possibility arose that steps would be taken to place the name of President Roosevelt on the Democratic ballot.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The report by the Streit committee to the New York Legislature in connection with its investigation of bondholders' committees attracted considerable interest here, as the Securities and Exchange Commission soon is to make a report to Congress based upon the findings of its Protective Committee Study of which W.O. Douglas, recently appointed a member of the SEC, was director.

Putting on the pressure just enough to win, Ernie Koslan of N.Y.U., the first seeded player, advanced to the final of the Eastern Collegiate indoor tennis championships at the 369th Regiment Armory yesterday. There he was joined by Melvin Lapman, St. John's freshman, and the two will meet today for the crown that the Violet player won a year ago, when it was the New York State title.

Bronze medals of honor of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association were presented to Mrs. August Belmont and Miss Lucrezia Bori of the Metropolitan Opera at a tea given yesterday afternoon by the association at Roosevelt House, the birthplace of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, at 28 East Twentieth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The United States, Great Britain, France and Italy decided today to bind themselves for the next five or six years not to build any more cruisers over 8,000 tons in size or mounting guns heavier than 6.1 inches in caliber.

Depite the fact that many max chants throughout the country are deferring their initial offerings of Spring merchandise, due to weather conditions, the volume ou reorders reeeived here yesterday on suits and coats was better than a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- When the Army Appropriation Bill for the next fiscal year came to the floor of the House today, the committee was found to have disregarded recommendations of the President for appropriations totaling $29,000,000 to finance construction work on non-military projects, including the Passamaquoddy Dam in Maine and the Florida Atlantic-to-Gulf ship canal.
Cleto Locatelli, Italian welterweight, stopped Irish Jimmy Brady of Jersey City in the fifth round of their scheduled eight-round bout before 3,000 spectators at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

SAN JUAN, Feb. 10. -- A recent suggestion by a committee of the New York State Chamber of Commerce that statehood for Puerto Rico be held "in abeyance" because of the low intelligence indicated by a group of children in New York City's Puerto Rican colony in psychological tests has angered political leaders and newspapers here.

The city of Syracuse, N.Y., yesterday awarded a new issue of $5,110,000 of relief and refunding bonds to a banking syndicate headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company at a price of 100.20 for $730,000 as 1 1/2s and $4,380,000 as 2s or at an interest cost to the city of 1.9134 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The breach between the craft and industrial union forces in the American Federation of Labor was widened by yesterday's refusal of 30,000 radio workers now affiliated with the federation in local "federal" unions to comply with the request of the executive council that they affiliate with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

Herbert L. Satterlee, president of the Lifesaving Benevolent Association of New York and formerly Assistant Secretary of the Navy, last night appealed to maritime labor leaders and members of Congress to cooperate in bringing about a greater measure of safety on American commercial ships.

The Broadway Association is looking for the "oldest living merchant" now or formerly engaged in business in the Broadway district. It has named a special committee to find him so that he may be a guest of honor at the association's twenty-fifth anniversary celebration on May 11.

Real estate men professed yesterday to find only scant comfort in the announcement by the Board of Taxes and Assessments that the 1936 basic tax rate might be slightly lower than the $2.65 rate for 1935, and criticized the "unstable" methods used to set the figure.

Three of the six seeded players remaining in the running for the Class B singles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association advanced to the quarterfinal round at the Harvard Club yesterday. They are Willard K. Rice, No. 3; J.K. Weeks, No. 4, and Ivy Lee Jr., No. 6.

There will be twenty sloops in the New York Yacht Club's new one-design class of 32-footers. The fleet list, larger than was even hoped for when it was proposed, was closed yesterday by the committee that arranged it, which was composed of John B. Shethar, Charles F. Havemyer and Junius S. Morgan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Feb. 5 shows an increase for the week of $28,000,000 in total loans and investments, a decrease of $26,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and an increase of $30,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

BASLE, Switzerland, Feb. 10. -- Growing confidence in the dollar was reflected by talks among the governors of the principal European central banks during their monthly meetings here for the last two days as members of the board of the Bank for International Settlements.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 10. -- Argentine editorials continue to praise President Roosevelt's suggestion for a Pan-American peace conference. The Nacion says Roosevelt's good neighbor policy was sure to have led to something practical, such as the proposed conference, and that the entire continent is certain to give cordial support to this attempt to create a method for living together without international disturbances.

MADRID, Feb. 10. -- Juan Ignacio Pombo, Spanish aviator who flew over the South Atlantic on a 7,000-mile journey to see his childhood sweetheart, Maria Elena Rivero, in Mexico, D.F., will marry her tomorrow at San Marco's Church.

Few contracts were pressed for sale on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and purchases for trade account advanced the list 2 to 9 points. Prices closed around the top. March displayed the most strength, rising above 11 1/4 cents to best quotations in ten days.

A new type of "starter" for a heart that has stopped beating, which has already "resurrected" the still hearts of two human beings who could not have been resuscitated by other available methods, was shown last night before a group of physicians at Naval Headquarters, Christopher and Washington Streets.

Lee Shubert filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against Basil Dean, English theatrical producer, and Dorothy Gladys Smith, also known as Dodie Smith, who also uses the name C.L. Anthony, and is the author of "Autumn Crocus" and this season's play "Call It a Day."

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 10. -- The overwhelming vote by which Leon Cortes was elected President of Costa Rica yesterday is seen here as precluding the possibility of his opponents attempting an armed coup d'etat prior to the inauguration May 8, though such a development has been rumored.

The indignity placed upon the members of a police homicide squad early Sunday morning, when a thief stole the crime-detection kit from the squad car while it was parked in front of the West Twentieth Street police station, was partly removed with the recovery of the kit yesterday.

Although observers in the financial section late last week revised upward their estimates of the January shipments of finished products by the United States Steel Corporation, they were hardly prepared for the 59,899-ton increase over December to the best total since June, 1934.

Miss Mary Alice Amory gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for the Misses Jane Rovensky, Mary Schley, Lucy Saunders, Ruth Mary Ruxton, Margaret and Elizabeth Sillcocks, Mary Humphrey, Elsie Lawson, Joan Smith, Marjorie Banks, Doris Terhune, Fanny Jane Smith, Henrietta Wardwell, Susanne Murray and Harriet Arthur.
Being a collection of pertinent remarks by some of the men who led the fight for wild life at the Washington conference last week:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Deprived of their food supply by the heavy snow and ice covering the ground in recent weeks, hundreds of birds have died in Westchester County and many more would have died if the Southern New York Fish and Game Association had not distributed about 15,000 pounds of grain, it was learned today.

A series of spectacular victories, in which idols were toppled from their pedestals, marked the opening sessions yesterday of the sixtieth annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden. Iconoclastic judges, armored against the appeal of popular favor, immune against established reputations, brought from among the younger generation new canine heroes and heroines to receive the public acclaim.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 10. -- Leslie R. Baldwin, 29 years old, of 52 Washington Avenue, this place, a general foreman on a WPA project here, and five other men were held in bail tonight following an investigation of the theft of several hundred bags of cement consigned to the project.

At the request of Mr. Trevor, Dr. C.P. Armstrong, Dr. E.M. Achilles and M.J. Sacks gave psychological examinations last year to 240 Puerto Rican children in Public School 57, 115th Street and Lexington Avenue.
The Federal Theatre Project's schedule of forthcoming shows was announced yesterday by Philip W. Barber, regional director. It follows:

Being uncommonly sensitive to the refinement of manners, Ivor Novello has written a comedy about a raw Australian family and a group of genteel Londoners, "Fresh Fields," which was put on at the Empire last evening. Some two or three years ago it was acted in London.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The British Government expects almost as a matter of course ratification in Paris tomorrow of the Franco-Soviet pact and also awaits the event with considerable equanimity. London has no fear that this new alliance, which goes so much against the grain in Berlin, will cause any immediate German move toward violation of the Locarno agreement or the Versailles treaty by sending troops into the demilitarized Rhineland zone.

The guest artists of last night's Beethoven Association program at the Town Hall bore gifts of rewarding music movingly performed. They were Emanuel Feuermann, 'cellist; Mishel Piastro, violinist Frank Sheridan, pianist, and Lauritz Melchior, tenor.

It is reaching the understanding of some financial writers that much of the gold held by the Treasury does not belong to the United States, but is the property of foreign countries which have lodged it here in safe keeping for one reason or another.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The filing of seven additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, covering issues of approximately $10,000,000, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Emperor Halle Selassie was reliably reported today to have returned to Addis Ababa after many weeks at his field headquarters at Dessye, bombed again Sunday by the Italians.

An opinion by Oswald Ryan, general counsel of the Federal Power Commission, dealing with the meaning of the term "public utility" as defined by Title II of the Public Utility Act of 1935, and discussing the commission's jurisdiction has been received in financial quarters here.

New York is getting dog-conscious these days. The combined terrier show and the annual specialty shows for the Boston Terrier -- which is not technically a terrier at all -- and the Pomeranian are over and the Westminster Kennel Club's sixtieth annual all-breed show opened yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10. -- H. Spears, an apprentice rider from Cleveland, was killed and three others, including F. Polk, one of the leading jockeys of the country, were badly shaken up during the fifth race at the Fair Grounds track today when their mounts went down in a heap on the stretch turn. Spears died before he could be taken to the operating room.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 10. -- A magnificent banquet to all "who in preparation, organization and execution personify the idea of the Olympic Games" was tendered tonight by the German Government in the congress hall of the German Museum.

A pistol battle between a detective and five robbers, who were fleeing in an automobile after having seized a payroll at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue at Thirtieth Street at 3:10 P.M. yesterday, ended five minutes later with the capture of the wounded driver of the car and the escape of his confederates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Relief budget estimates for the fiscal year 1937 are being made upon the assumption that an average of at least 3,000,000 persons will have to be assisted by a Federal program, it was learned in administration circles today.

Plans for the construction of the last of three projects involved in the establishment of a ground base for the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at Fort Schuyler were filed yesterday afternoon with the Bronx Bureau of Buildings. They provide for an expenditure of $800,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Highlights of the Supreme Court's opinion invalidating the Louisiana tax against newspaper, magazine and motion-picture advertising are:

The table that follows shows the cruisers of the five principal sea powers itemized by the classifications set up at the London Naval Conference of 1930. The numbers and tonnages in each column include ships over age according to treaty terms, as well as ships that are on the building ways and ships that are still in blueprint form but for which funds have been appropriated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Light was thrown on the administration's aims for financing the stop-gap farm relief program today with the disclosure that Federal farm and fiscal experts, under Treasury supervision, were working on new schedules of excises covering a broadened list of agricultural commodities.

Board of Education officials wrote the word "resigned" yesterday across the record card of the city's oldest school teacher, Mrs. Dora Esper, 78 years old. Until last week Mrs. Esper taught children of 7 and 8 in the 2A grade at Public School 78 and as far as the law was concerned she could have gone on teaching forever.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- The annual three-day business meeting and exhibition of the Middle Atlantic Shoe Retailers Association got under way today with the largest attendance in the history of the organization. More manufacturers and wholesalers were present than for many years, over 100 having exhibits.

DONALD R. RICHBERG, who helplessly wrung his hands while the Supreme Court was wringing the neck of the Blue Eagle, is apparently still convinced that some such organization as NRA is both desirable and inevitable, that Congress should pass a carefully considered and thoroughly constitutional "enabling act," and that business management throughout the country should also take it upon itself to aid in bringing about the necessary consummation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained tonight in honor of Senators and members of the House of Representatives, holding for them the Congressional reception originally scheduled for Jan. 23 and postponed because of the death of King George of England.

Declaring that 90 per cent of the American people wanted no part in another war, Representative Maury Maverick of Texas told 500 members and guests of the Economic Club of New York at a dinner meeting in the Hotel Astor last night that he could not understand the Federal administration's failure to press for neutrality legislation.
BERLIN, Feb. 10 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The stock markets here were generally quiet but firm today. Outstanding was strong buying of aircraft shares on reports of favorable trading and prospects of increased orders soon in anticipation of rearmament. British funds and foreign bonds were quiet.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
The average pay check for major league ball players is on the upgrade but there is a sharp contrast today with the situation in the "higher brackets" five years ago.

A touch of old New York was presented here yesterday morning. Busy shoppers hurrying along Fifth Avenue between 11 and 12 o'clock paused to witness a brief return to the horse-and-carriage days as twelve young men and women, dressed in costumes of eighty years ago, rode by in six hansom cabs and victorias.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- The first day's visitors at the twenty-ninth annual farm and home week of the Colleges of Agriculture and Home Economics of Cornell University were told by Dean Carl E. Ladd that agriculture "has emerged two-thirds of the way" from the low point of the depression.
Your editorial "Industry's 'Refusal'" deserves commendation. However, I think that even it slipped a bit aside from the real point.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 10. -- The authorities announced this evening that order was being maintained throughout the country with railroads and other public services operating normally except where a few isolated groups still supported the revolutionary strike.

Seldom has warmer approval been given to a public man than was given to Governor HOFFMAN Sunday by the Executive Committee of the Young Republicans of New Jersey, Inc. If the session was not plenary that was in part the fault of the weather and the roads.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10. -- Captain Edgar S. McLellan disappeared from the army transport Republic, of which he was skipper, shortly after 5:15 A.M. today, while the steamer was approaching San Francisco on a voyage from Honolulu.
The 127th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln will be observed here tomorrow by educational, historical and political groups.

John Adams High, champion for the past two years, and Grover Cleveland High remained in a deadlock for the first place in the Queens Division of the P.S.A.L. basketball competition by scoring victories yesterday. The triumphs were the second in as many league starts for both teams.

PALM BEACH. Fla., Feb. 10. -- Complimenting Mr. and Mrs. Andrew B. Graves of Paris and Deauville, her house guests, Airs. Peyton J. Van Rensselaer gave a large tea today at Casa Rosada del Lago, where Princess Dolly Obolensky and Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems are also visiting.

The Shawinigan Water and Power Company of Montreal reported yesterday for 1935 gross earnings of $13,067,800, compared with $12,504,406 for 1934, a gain of 4.5 per cent. Power output established a new high record for the company at 5,315,290,623 kilowatt-hours, a gain of 16 per cent over 1934.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- General Malin Craig, chief of staff of the army, told Congress in a report published today that "evident troublous times in the world" should spur the United States to build up its defense
DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 10. -- Martial law will probably be declared tomorrow as French authorities continue their drive to quell Nationalist rioting in Syria.

Warning that many persons "bent on getting rich quick" are prone to advance food fads for their own enrichment rather than for the betterment of the public, Dr. Howard W. Haggard last night urged greater skepticism toward all specialized diets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- A plan to place partial supervision of the National Youth Administration in the hands of young men and women was furthered by President Roosevelt today when he approved a proposal to select a limited number of members of the advisory councils of the NYA from among winners of an essay contest on national problems.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- W. Kingsland Macy, former Republican State Chairman, tonight made a demand here for legislation to provide for preferential Presidential primaries and the election of delegates at large by State-wide vote at the Spring primary on April 2.

Under the guise of a statute, the late Senator LONG induced the Legislature of Louisiana to pass a bill hitting his newspaper critics. It was, in effect, a tax on gross receipts, so artfully arranged as to place a discriminating and heavy burden upon newspapers that had dared to oppose the Long dictatorship.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 11. -- According to a Daily Mail dispatch from Jibuti, French Somaliland, the Rev. Harold Street, an American member of the Sudan Interior Mission, and his Canadian colleague, John Trewin, lie chained in a fetid windowless cell in Chencha, the capital of the little known Ethiopian Province of Game, south of Wallamo.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick today denied a petition to enjoin the National Labor Relations Board from carrying out the terms and purposes of the Wagner Labor Disputes Act.

The downtown shopping district in Brooklyn was shaken by an explosion that hurled a 350-pound manhole cover fifty feet into the air yesterday in front of 298A Livingston Street near Hanover Place. A short circuit igniting sewer gas is believed to have caused the blast; the police said.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Only 3,000 hogs were received here today because of the severe storms over the West. The receipts were 20,000 head less than the trade anticipated and only a handful were available for sale, as 2,000 went direct to packers.

The Transit Commission, carrying out the suggestion of the Interborough, Manhattan Railway and B.M.T. groups, wrote to Samuel Seabury yesterday proposing conferences to include representatives of the company committees, the commission and the City's negotiators to consider the Seabury-Berle working draft of a unification plan. Mr. Seabury was asked to suggest the date for the first conference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Photographs purporting to show actual liquor running activities have been submitted to the Norwegian and Belgian Governments by the United States to back charges of smuggling involving subjects and ships of those nations.
ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- A bill extending the life of the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration until April 1 was passed tonight by the Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Senator Fletcher of Florida said that the House Appropriations Committee "played into the hands of the Republicans" by striking from the War Appropriations Bill today a $29,000,000 item for the Florida ship canal and four other projects.

Invitations have been extended to American manufacturers and designers in the medium to take part in the Brooklyn Museum's 1936 Exhibition of Glass, which will open on March 20 and continue through April 19. The purpose of the projected showing is to acquaint the public with the best in contemporary design, craftsmanship and quality.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- President Roosevelt signed the bill repealing the cotton, potato and tobacco control laws.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Wheat futures were on the downgrade in all leading markets today. General liquidation developed in the May delivery on the Board of Trade here and in the Northwest and Southwest, and prices dropped nearly 2 cents a bushel, the May selling here at the lowest mark since Dec. 12.
The Emergency Milk Control Act passed by the New York State Legislature in 1933 contained this unusual provision:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The first meeting this year of the Federal Advisory Council, consisting of one representative from each of the twelve Federal Reserve districts, will be held here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- An additional list of registration applications by brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market, including more than sixty from New York City, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 10. -- An iron-man Dartmouth basketball team remained in the thick of the battle for the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship by handing an unsteady Harvard five a 29-22 setback in the Harvard indoor athletic building tonight.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Feb. 10 (AP). -- New Zealand's labor government announced today the first provisions of its "guaranteed prices" policy, a proposed program for stabilization in the wheat, flour and bread industries.

Gregory Mangin and J. Gilbert Hall, seeded in that order, entered the semi-annual round yesterday as a result of straight-set triumphs in the annual invitation tennis tournament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.
WATERVILLE, Me., Feb. 10 (AP). -- Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, said tonight labor and business were on "a rising curve." She attributed the upsurge to administration measures.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 10. -- Karl Schafer, world's premier figure skater, turned in a near-perfect performance today to take a commanding lead over thirty-six challengers for his Olympic title.

MONTREAL, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press). -- Right in the van of drives staged by the New York clubs for berths in the National Hockey League play-offs, Dave Schriner of the Americans and Cecil Dillon of the Rangers continued their consistent scoring last week to lead, respectively, the International and American groups.

When the British Government suddenly made and announced a naval agreement with Germany, it gave two reasons, or excuses. One was that in this way a certain amount of disarmament was automatically effected, since the German fleet was to be kept far inferior to the British, instead of being built up as a rival at sea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Almost the entire membership of the Senate and crowded visitors' galleries saw Airs. Rose McConnell Long take the oath of office today which entitled her to occupy the seat from Louisiana which her husband, Huey Pierce Long, filled for five years.

The dollar recovered strongly yesterday on the foreign exchange market, putting an end to exports of gold. The strengthening of the United States currency unit was ascribed solely to the abatement of inflation alarms, which last week had exerted a depressing influence.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad announced yesterday that it would buy another steam streamlined locomotive from the American Locomotive Company and build 1,500 freight and 37 passenger cars in its own shops at Milwaukee.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 11. -- Favoritism and lenity shown by court officials to automobile offenders were asserted by Governor Cross's commission today to be at the root of accidents which have caused record-breaking death and injury totals in Connecticut. The report ended a searching investigation by the commission, of which Chief Justice William M. Maltbie is chairman.
As an artist, Alexander Iacovleff, who is now exhibiting at Knoedler's, appears to have a triple personality.
Housing and business properties were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 11. -- Great Britain's part-Canadian hockey team, storm-center of the most bitter dispute that so far has disturbed the progress of the Olympic Winter Games, stirred up another major sensation today by upsetting Canada, 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Broader authority to restore the pre-war purchasing power of farmers than was contained in the original Agricultural Adjustment Act would be vested in Secretary Wallace by an amendment offered by Senator Wagner to the pending Farm Relief Bill today with a view to protecting consumers against possible high food costs.

With approximately 300 buyers registered at the close of the day, buying showed a substantial improvement yesterday at the National Domestics and Linen Show at the Hotel New Yorker. The pricing of blankets by several mills attracted chief interest.

The number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the preceding week but was well below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMS. For the week the arrivals were 962 as against 850 in the previous week and 1,143 in the same period last year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11. -- Dr. Henry Reining Jr., Professor of Politics at Princeton University, has been appointed educational director of the National Institute of Public Affairs in Washington, in charge of its internship training, according to word received here today from Frederick M. Davenport, chairman of the institute.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- An early ending of the naval conference in its present form came into sight today after the delegates had failed to follow up their accord of yesterday with an agreement on the size and gun caliber of capital ships.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 11 (AP). -A search by air and sea was under way tonight for the commercial French airliner Ville de Buenos Aires, long overdue on a flight across the South Atlantic.

That Glenn Cunningham will be on hand to run in the classic Baxter Mile, the featured event in the New York A.C. track meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, became a certainty yesterday. Inactive since his defeat in the Wanamaker Mile by Joe Mangan and Gene Venzke, Cunningham, in a telephone conversation with Judge Thomas T. Reilley yesterday, assured the Winged Foot athletic chairman that he was ready for action.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- Contrary to expectations in Republican quarters, little or no protest was voiced against any of the several tax bills in Governor Lehman's revenue program when rival hearings were held today. The hearings were before the Assembly Committees on Ways and Means and Taxation and Retrenchment and the corresponding Senate committees.
Medals for "conspicuous alumni service" will be awarded to six graduates of Columbia University today at the annual Lincoln Day alumni celebration. The medals were first given four years ago.

Joseph de Stefano, 19 years old, of 218 East 103d Street, leader of an East Harlem gang of loan sharks who threatened their victims with pistols and knives to force them to pay usurious rates on loans, was sentenced to Elmira Reformatory yesterday in General Sessions.

Burton J. Hendrick, who has twice received the Pulitzer Prize in biography, is working on the idea for an "epic" or "biography" of the Federal Constitution, in which he will 'treat the Constitution almost like a human thing and always from the biographical point of view."

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 11 (AP). -- An Indian bow and arrows, crossed on his coffin, and floral tributes from President Roosevelt and former President Hoover reviewed strikingly today the career of Charles Curtis at the former Vice President's impressive funeral here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Reports that $9,970,400 of gold marked for an unidentified foreign central bank under special license was destined for China were confirmed here tonight by Treasury officials. They would give no further details.

For the twelve months ended on Jan. 31 Best Co. had a net profit of $1,133,953 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, according to their preliminary statement yesterday. The profit equals $3.73 a share on 300,000 no-par shares of common stock, after dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 11. -- Sunday and yesterday Italian airplanes continued to bomb the Dessye road toward Lake Ashangi. It is believed here these raids and the attack on Dessye Sunday morning were carried out in an attempt to find and destroy Emperor Haile Selassie, for all places mentioned as his next northern headquarters were heavily bombed.

The dispute between the Building Service Employes Union and realty owners in the garment and fur district, which was settled last week through intervention of Mayor La Guardia, threatened to flare up again yesterday as a result of difficulties in formulating in writing the agreement under which the threatened strike of 20,000 elevator operators and other service workers was averted.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 11. -- Two National Guard observation planes dropped 3,000 pounds of grain today over isolated parts of Northern and Western New Jersey, in a program of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission and interested groups to keep wild life in the State from starving to death because of the snow and ice.

MONTREAL, Feb. 11. -- After outplaying the New York Rangers for most of the game, the Canadiens had to be satisfied with a 1-1 tie in their National Hockey League game tonight. Dave Kerr performed in brilliant style in the New York nets and a tight checking band of Blue Shirts protected him well in the pinches.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- Discussion began in the Chamber of Deputies today on France's mutual-assistance treaty with Soviet Russia, which was signed in Moscow last May by Pierre Laval, former Foreign Minister, and which has caused widespread resentment in Germany, where it has been interpreted as a link in a new chain of encirclement. Even here there is strong opposition to the treaty, but on different grounds.

Several leases of large apartments and penthouses were included in the apartment rentals announced yesterday. A client of Douglas Gibbons Co., leased from Vincent Astor a suite of eighteen rooms and seven baths in 903 Park Avenue, and the same brokers rented to James B. Taylor, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co., a duplex apartment of fifteen rooms and seven baths in 770 Park Avenue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. ll. -- Harvard University, which a year ago rejected a proffer of a scholarship fund from Ernst Hanfstaengl, aide to Chancellor Hitler, has acted likewise on another larger proffer made by the German alumnus.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Displaying a stellar brand of stroking, Miss Charlotte Darling, Germantown Cricket Club star, defeated Mrs. Arthur Lewis in four games today to reach the semi-final round as play in the women's New York State squash racquets championship started. The score was 15 -- 5, 15 -- 8, 16 -- 18, 15 -- 13.
LONDON, Feb. 11. -- Profiteers who reaped so rich a harvest from King George's funeral have lost no time in arranging to make money out of King Edward's coronation in May or June next year.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 11. -- Ivar Ballangrud, Norwegian, European and world speed-skating champion, took his revenge today for his defeat by the Americans at Lake Placid in 1932 at the last Winter Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Senator Borah and Colonel Knox, according to the present prospect, are to do most of the Republican pre-convention open fighting. The battle-line has been drawn between them in Illinois, and the colonel is still pondering whether to contest with the Senator in Ohio. If their rivalry is to be expressed in issues, as custom prescribes, will their past political performances be taboo to determine which is the better progressive?

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 11. -- The operating profit of the Richfield Oil Company of California in the last half of 1935 of $660,644 before depreciation and depletion charges compared with $906,380 in the first half and $1,700,971 in the last six months of 1934, according to the eleventh interim report filed today by the receiver, William C. McDuffie, with the Federal court here.

Reports that Paul Redfern, the aviator who disappeared more than eight years ago, is a captive among primitive tribes in the interior of South America received further substantiation yesterday from Dr. Morton C. Kahn of the Cornell University Medical College, who returned Monday night from an expedition into territory near the locality where Redfern is believed to be a prisoner.

Symphonic, operatic and dance music, presented by leading conductors directing as many as 100 musicians, is scheduled to become part of the "bill of fare" soon in leading New York restaurants through a new type of "high-fidelity" recording or "electrical transcription." The recreated tone of the new records is said to rival the quality of the original tone of the players.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial commending Secretary Ickes's disapproval of excessive highways in national and State parks seems to me inconsistent with your editorial treatment several days ago of the truck trails in the Adirondack Park. You accepted the view of the Governor's committee that some truck trails should be maintained, and others completed.

The "little NRA" in the millinery industry, set up after the recent stoppage of work here, began functioning yesterday with an announcement that efforts would be made to introduce the same system of control of trade practices and labor relations in the industry that prevailed under the defunct Millinery Code.

The Chicago North Western Railroad will ask the Federal court in Chicago to defer from Feb. 27 to June 27 the time in which the company must file a reorganization plan, Fred W. Sargent, president, said yesterday following a meeting of the company's directors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- President Roosevelt has sent personal letters to the heads of all the Latin-American governments regarding proposals for the consolidation and reorganization of current peace treaties, it became known today.

" HELL BEYOND THE SEAS" (Vanguard, $2.50) shows the world at its worst. A kind of "journey to the end of the night" in terms of physical rather than mental experience, it is so completely a record of pain, misery and hard luck that it is somewhat remarkable. It is a new mark for the hard-boiled school of artificers to shoot at.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Pope Pius XI, the "peace-loving Pope of the missions," was eulogized today by Bishop Ralph Hayes, rector of the American College in Rome, in a declaration calling attention to the beginning of the fifteenth year of Pius's pontificate tomorrow.

Laurence Housman, author of the play "Victoria Regina," who described himself as the "most censored man in England," arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Ascania on his first visit to this country since 1920.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- A bank vault in Dryden, N.Y., has given up the long-lost manuscript of an address delivered by President Lincoln from a window above the portico of the White House on the evening of Thursday, Nov. 10, 1864, when a celebration of his re-election was staged by Lincoln and Johnson Clubs of the District of Columbia.

The increasing difficulty of conserving wealth and the diminishing incomes of trust accounts occupied the speakers who opened the three-day midwinter conference of the trust division of the American Bankers Association yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Evidence that a European munitions firm sought American aid in scuttling the 1925 conference for the limitation of traffic in war materials was presented today before the Senate Munitions Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was directed today by the Senate Banking Committee to draft legislation embodying the commission's recent recommendations to Congress for an indefinite extension of unlisted stock trading privileges and for clothing the commission with broad discretion for dealing with the problem.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- A better class of speculative buying appeared today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and while there was an early dip to a new low mark for the current downturn, offerings were absorbed quickly and there was a rally of around 1 cent a bushel, and the close was near the day's top.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee reported favorably today the Fletcher-Steagall bill to exempt from State and Federal taxation preferred stocks of banks held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Mrs. Mary Scott-Uda, a sprightly gray-haired woman of 91, arose unexpectedly as a meeting of the Republican Committee of One Hundred was being adjourned yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, and in a surprisingly firm voice appealed to the Republican party to remember the ideals of Lincoln.

Business failures in the manufacturing, retail and construction groups in the week ended Feb. 6 dropped below the average for the first six weeks of 1936, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The number in the commercial service group, in contrast to the lower trend in the previous week, rose above the average, the agency states.

The four-masted schooner Anne R. Heidritter, which left New York thirty-two days ago for Charleston, S.C., with 1,200 tons of coal, was reported last night in tow and on her way to St. John's Light, Fla., after having been battered by storms.

A victory for the City Athletic Club, coupled with a defeat for Jackson Heights, last night sent the former into first place in Group 1 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association, breaking a tie with the latter that had existed last week.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Alfred J. McCarthy was elected vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company yesterday at a meeting of the directors at the company's building, 1 Broadway. Mr. McCarthy succeeds John M. Franklin, who was elected l two weeks ago to succeed his father, P. A. S. Franklin, as president.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Feb. 11. -- Charles J. Margiotti, Attorney General of Pennsylvania, took the witness stand today in his libel suit against The Philadelphia Inquirer and read a four-column story, published Sept. 29, on which his charge is based.

The $1,000 bail posted last November by Otto Fukushima, 64 years old, Japanese art expert, who was accused of the theft of "Snowy Landscape," painted by the Chinese artist Whauwei, was dismissed in General Sessions yesterday.

The suit brought by holders of debentures of the National Electric Power Company, an Insull utility now in bankruptcy, against the Chase National Bank for $10,500,000 damages on the ground that the bank, as trustee of the $10,000,000 issue of debentures, substituted stock of Insull holding companies for operating corporations as security for the issue, will continue on trial before Supreme Court Justice Rosenman several weeks.

Debutantes, headed by Miss Charmion Kineon, will assist Mrs. Herbert Shipman, Mrs. Ripley Hitchcock and Mrs. Henry S. Breckinridge, who will act as hostesses at the opening of the exhibition on "The Life and Time of Abraham Lincoln" this afternoon at the Hotel Lincoln for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club.
Samuel G. Staff, president of Julius Grossman Shoes, yesterday announced the appointment of Gussow, I{ahn Co., Inc., to handle their advertising.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Budgetary studies recently ordered are expected to yield a fairly definite picture of possible savings in previous authorizations or appropriations within a week, President Roosevelt said today at a White House conference.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The noisy fusillade being directed against the administration for breaking the solemn promises made to the people in the Summer of 1932 is intended, no doubt, to convince us by constant reiteration that the Democratic platform of that year was promptly consigned to the ashcan when the party came into power the following Spring.

Five sightless bowlers held a team of opponents who could see to a sixteen-point victory in a unique match last night at the community center of the Community Workers Auxiliary of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, 172 East Ninety-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- President Roosevelt used his veto power today to make short shrift of attempts to collect damages from the government for losses incurred by corporations as a result of the Federal Reserve Board's order of 1919 prohibiting the transfer of Russian rubles and their exchange at that time for American dollars.

The board of directors of Bliss Laughlin, Inc., placed the new capital stock on an annual dividend basis of $1 a share yesterday with the declaration of an initial quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- The long-simmering conflict between the National Socialist State and the Catholic Church, which has as its central issue control over the growing generation, resumed the form of active warfare again today when the secret police struck at the Catholic young men's organizations with wholesale arrests all over Germany.

Textile High's five, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, and Seward Park High remained in a deadlock for the lead in the Manhattan Division of the P.S.A.L. by winning yesterday. Textile downed Commerce, 28 -- 22, at Commerce, and Seward Park routed Benjamin Franklin, 35 -- 12, at Franklin.

For the time being the star-spangled Americans and M'sieu Lestairre Patrick's Rangers are still skating on pretty thin ice. Despite the fact that they have come out of the doldrums in recent competition, they have a rough path ahead of them in the remaining weeks of the season.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, yesterday referred to Edward C. McDonald, referee in bankruptcy, claims of $442,500 for services rendered by trustee and attorneys in the reorganization proceedings of the Prudence Company, Inc. Mr. McDonald will sit as a special master and later report to the court his recommendations as to the fees sought.

Due to an obvious resurgence of speculative buying, the share market moved forward yesterday in the heaviest trading since Jan. 15. From the standpoint of breadth, the number of individual issues dealt in, the market was the broadest since Nov. 4, 1929, with a total of 970.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Andrew W. Mellon won another round today in his fight to avoid paying an additional income tax and fine for 1931, totaling $3,075,103, when the Board of Tax Appeals ruled that all except five of seventeen sets of items obtained from the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh should be barred from evidence.

MADRID, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Juan Ignacio Pombo, Spanish air cavalier who won the heart of a senorita by a transatlantic flight, led her to the altar today in a virtual elopement. The bride's mother refused to give her consent, refused to attend the ceremony and declined to give her blessing afterward.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11. -- Chiang Chin-ko, son of General Chiang Kai-shek, Chinese foe of Communists, has repudiated his father as an exploiter and slayer of Chinese workers and has proclaimed himself a whole-hearted Communist whose intention it is "to walk ahead on the wide road of Chinese revolution.''

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- An era of general prosperity was predicted here today by Dr. F.A. Pearson, Professor of Prices and Statistics of the College of Agriculture of Cornell University. He was one of the speakers at the annual Farm and Home Week.

Data collected so far in the trade exodus survey being conducted for Controller Frank J. Taylor by Charles E. Murphy show that 150 business concerns employing more than 15,000 persons moved from New York City to other communities in 1935.

BOSTON, Feb. 11. -- Harvard's varsity hockey team made a runaway of its deciding game with Dartmouth in the Quadrangular League, scoring a 10-to-1 victory over the Green in the Arena tonight. The victory sent Harvard from last place to a tie with Princeton for second.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Countering allegations that a new efficiency system ordered for the postal service April 1 was an example of an undermining of the civil service by Postmaster General Farley in a campaign year, department officials declared today that the 200,000 field employes would have enhanced opportunities to achieve "promotion and pay" on a strictly merit basis under the new system.

The Andes-Amazon Expedition of the Museum of the American Indian has approached the famous "lost city" of Central Ecuador and discovered an ancient road built for amazing durability, according to members of the expedition who returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Clara.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- One of the danger spots in the European scene was officially removed today when the German Government announced that as a result of the establishment of constitutional government in Memel Territory, in accordance with the recent elections, Germany was willing to discuss with Lithuania an extension of trade between the two countries, and Berlin so informed the Kaun as government.

Queena Mario, Metropolitan Opera soprano, made her first appearance in a Town Hall recital last night. An audience of many singers, including a number of her colleagues from the Opera House, heard the American soprano in a program that covered many centuries, languages and styles.

Mayor La Guardia intervened again yesterday in the negotiations between employers and employes in the dress industry and obtained a delay of another day in the calling of a threatened strike of 105,000 workers.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 11. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann agreed today to a plan by which his wife will seek to replace C. Lloyd Fisher as chief defense counsel with Samuel Leibowitz, New York attorney with a national reputation in murder cases.

Antonia Brico and her New York Women's Symphony Orchestra last night gave their fourth concert of the season at Carnegie Hall before a good-sized audience that rendered approval of an excellent program and also for the talents of Toscha Seidel, the assisting violinist.

Russel L. MacDonald, radio operator who lost his life in the wreck of the Ward liner Mohawk about a year ago, received, posthumously, the gold medal of the Veteran Wireless Operators Association at its annual dinner at the Hotel Montclair last night.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas said today Argentina maintained the viewpoint that the Falkland Islands were part of the Argentine Republic. His statement was made in comment on remarks by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, at London.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The advisability of regulations restricting the extension of credit by banks for the purchase and carrying of securities on national securities exchanges was discussed today at the first meeting of the new board of governors of the Federal Reserve System with its Federal Advisory Council, but no decision was reached.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11. -- Contradicting the theory of Sir James Jeans, British scientist, that the universe in its present form has existed for ten million million years, Dr. Bart J. Bok of the Harvard College Observatory cited today from his researches new evidence that reduces this age estimate to an upper limit of twenty billion years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Seven more foreign countries, France, Finland, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Bulgaria, Australia and Cuba, have filed applications for the permanent registration of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange, the Securities Exchange Commission announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- Decreases were shown in employment and payrolls in 1,643 representative factories in the State from the middle of December to the middle of January, according to a report issued today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner.

Gains and losses were about evenly divided in the markets for commodity futures yesterday. The volume generally was light. In the cash markets gains were made by wheat, corn, rye, cotton, butter, eggs, Santos coffee, tin and rubber.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 11. -- The Ethiopian Government, following diplomatic representations to Addis Ababa, has ordered the fullest investigation into the action of Fitaurari Gizau Shawin, temporary chief of Gamo Province, in arresting an American missionary, the Rev. Harold Street, and his Canadian colleague, John Trewin, and imprisoning them in Chencha, his capital.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 11. -- These Winter Olympics are livening up so that it is a strain to see half that is going on. Beginning soon after daybreak today, there have been bobsledding, speed skating, figure skating and various hockey games, mostly at the same time but in places three to five miles apart.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11. -- With the visitors' goalie making a total of eighty-two saves, the aggressive Princeton hockey team was held to a 1-1 tie by the Boston College sextet in Baker Rink tonight. Tim Ready, guarding the B.C. net, gave an amazing display.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 11. -- One man was killed here today as disturbances marked a strike staged by taxicab drivers and other chauffeurs in protest against alleged unfair distribution of gasoline by the President of the Managua National District, who had established strict control over motor fuel.

More than 1,000 school officials, educators and friends attended the funeral service yesterday for Dr. Nathan Peyser, a member of Governor Lehman's Commission on Crime and Delinquency and for fourteen years principal of Public School 181, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- An administration plan for modernizing fourteen of the navy's fifteen battleships was pressed today on Capitol Hill, dovetailing with demands for vastly augmented land and air defenses.

Racing between America's Cup yachts in this country definitely will be resumed next Summer, without the cup being at stake. Rainbow, successful defender against T.O.M. Sopwith's British challenger Endeavour off Newport in 1934, will be brought out by Harold S. Vanderbilt, who now owns her, being put overboard for the first time since her cup defense.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- A bill that the government is not sponsoring but is greatly interested in as a bit of kite-flying is to be introduced in Parliament Friday to provide for the coordination of all three fighting services under a single Ministry of Defense.

Representatives of transportation interests and communities within the port district drafted plans for a campaign to obtain ample ice-breaking equipment and to increase the efficiency of the Coast Guard's relief activities in this district at a conference yesterday at the Port of New York Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee at an executive meeting scheduled for tomorrow will be asked to recommend to the Senate that the existing neutrality statute be extended, with minor additions, to about May 1, 1937. A substitute proposal was being drafted tonight and it will be sponsored by Senator Key Pittman, chairman of the committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight, in honor of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and Mrs. Byrns, gave the last state dinner on this season's White House schedule.

More than 200 persons, among them many army and National Guard officers, attended funeral services for Howard Morgan Cowperthwait yesterday morning in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Ninetieth Street and Fifth Avenue.
The mystery of 12-year-old Robert Doe, ripening into its third week, just about solved itself yesterday at the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, Fifth Avenue and 105th Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11. -- Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse entertained today with a tea at the Society of the Four Arts for Mr. and Mrs. Albert Herter, her house guests, whose works are included in the show at the society's salon.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- In the debate in the Chamber of Deputies today on the Franco-Soviet treaty Count Charles de Lasteyrie, former Minister of Finance, estimated the amount of France's outstanding Czarist loans at 200,000,000,000 francs.

Led by the New York Central, railroads continued yesterday to announce substantial commitments for rail and equipment. Last week the Bessemer Lake Erie and Union Railroads placed orders for twenty-four locomotives, the largest purchase of the kind since 1932.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,763,750 barrels, compared to 2,815,550 in the preceding week, a decrease of 51,800, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
