A decrease of 50,600 barrels in California, reflecting the recent attempt to get production in that State under control, was the most imporant change.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- The Boerse opened firm today, but turned soft and closed more or less unchanged on the day. Heavy industrials were in demand at the beginning, but yielded most of their gains by closing time. Electrical issues likewise were buoyant at the start, A.E.G. gaining a half point, while Siemens Halske rose three-quarters point, then closed three-quarters lower than yesterday, despite its optimistic business report.

ABOARD UNITED STATES COAST GUARD PATROL BOAT PANDORA, AT SEA, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Out to better her own record, Vadim S. Makaroff's big mahogany ketch Vamarie scurried along in choppy seas today well in the van of nine other boats in the third annual Miami-Nassau sailing race.

Marking another development in the controversy among retailers regarding the style protection program of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, the declarations of cooperation of three stores with the guild have been "canceled," it was stated yesterday at the offices of the guild.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, has revealed that Great Britain still considers the Falkland Islands off the American Continent British territory.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Frank P. Letellier's Pre War, racing in improved form, led all the way to defeat a field of six other platers in the mile and a sixteenth feature race, sixth on the program at the Fair Grounds today.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- The Senate passed today the Ross bill creating a temporary commission of twelve members to cooperate with the Federal Government in expediting a program of flood control for New York State.

The Utility and Industrial Corporation, an investment trust, reported yesterday that on Dec. 31 last the net asset value of its convertible preferred stock was $4.28 a share, based on market or estimated values, compared with $2.11 a share a year before.

Barnard College has purchased the block of land at 120th Street and Riverside Drive which has been under discussion since December, it was announced yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve at the first college assembly of the new semester.
Mayor La Guardia wrote to the State Chamber of Commerce yesterday that preliminary work had been started on the seaplane base at the East River and Twenty-third Street.
ROOSEVELT, L.I., Feb. 11. -- Louis Stancourt, 38 years old, WPA employe who wrote a letter to President Roosevelt and then forgot it, got an answer today.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Roaring down the dangerous course at high speed, Switzerland's daring bobsledders today took the lead in the race for the Olympic four-man championship. America wound up in fifth and tenth places, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- A story that Senator Borah was held up by two women thugs went the rounds of the capital today, and, while the Senator said the tale was all a joke, Mrs. Borah, saying it would "be too bad to spoil such a beautiful, sensational story," gave this version of the affair:

Creation of a "living memorial" to the genius of Thomas Alva Edison, through the endowment of educational and research scholarships designed to give to future generations a "heritage of meritorious accomplishments," is the objective of a national campaign launched yesterday on the eighty-ninth anniversary of the inventor's birth.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11. -- Peter Fick of the New York Athletic Club tonight created a world record by swimming the 100-meter free-style in 56.4 seconds as the feature of a meet held in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium under the auspices of the Yale A.A. to raise funds for the United States Olympic team.

The poor of New York still suffer grievously from overcrowding and lack of heat, especially in such cold waves as the present, but living conditions in the city's old-law tenements are much improved over ten years ago, according to a statement issued yesterday by Bailey B. Burritt, general director of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Senator Borah's managers stated today that his fight for the nomination would be waged against all Republican factions opposed to his candidacy, and would not be confined to a few selected States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Senate Committee on Commerce, now investigating the "crash" problem of aviation, warned the commercial air transport industry today that the committee feels it is not getting the cooperation to which it is entitled from that industry.

Washington dispatches now report that the effort to enact a "permanent" Neutrality Bill at this session of Congress has been abandoned. In place of such legislation the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations is planning to report a resolution merely extending for one year the "temporary" law which is now due to expire on Feb. 29.

Youth again was served at the second day of the sixtieth annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden yesterday. In many a breed youngsters came to the fore, dethroning victors of other years.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- The official German position on the qualitative naval limitations adopted at the London Naval Conference yesterday will not be made known until these have been formally communicated to the Reich.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, stressed the principle of academic freedom and warned against "propaganda organizations which seek some end, usually political," in a welcoming address yesterday to 600 freshmen who assembled in the Great Hall of the college for the first chapel of the Spring semester.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 11. -- Canada's only challenger for the Olympic figure-skating championship held by Miss Sonja Henie of Norway was removed today when Mrs. Constance Wilson Samuel collapsed during the school figure competition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- President Roosevelt announced the sending of letters to heads of Latin-American governments concerning plans for new and more general peace treaties, vetoed a claim bill to reimburse a corporation for $900,000 lost in post-war dealings with Russia, ordered a report within a week on possible savings in authorizations or appropriations and signed the $367,000,000 Deficiency Appropriations Bill.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (AP). -- The government newspaper Izvestia accused the Japanese tonight of having provoked a war scare in the Far East to block ratification by the French Chamber of Deputies of the Franco-Soviet mutual assistance pact, debate on which began in Paris today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Another small run of hogs lifted prices here today 25 to 50 cents a hundred-weight in the early trading to a new high since Oct. 15, but after the urgent buying orders had been filled the market weakened. Late sales of heavy-weight hogs were regarded as about steady with the finish on Monday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 11. -- Katherine Schissler, a Croatian woman whose apprehension had been requested by the French police in connection with the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Foreign Minister Louis Barthou of France on Oct. 9, 1934, was found in disguise today by the police in Sao Paulo after a two-month search.

The railroad built over the ocean from the mainland of Florida to Key West as part of the Florida East Coast Railway by the late Henry M. Flagler may be abandoned, according to a letter made public yesterday by the committee for $45,000,000 of the first and refunding 5 per cent bonds of the company.

Two more persons were arrested yesterday in the investigation into the fake-accident racket in which a physician and pseudo-lawyer already are under felony indictments. The prisoners, Jack Greenstein, 31 years old, a fruit dealer at 416 Washington Street, and his wife, Alice, 29, the mother of two children, of 829 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, were taken into custody by order of the New York County grand jury on misdemeanor conspiracy charges.

All banks and security and commodity markets in New York will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. Although the holiday is observed in only twenty-nine States, virtually all the out-of-town markets will be closed. Those remaining open include the Baltimore Stock Exchange, New Orleans Cotton Exchange, Savannah Naval Stores and Boston Wool Exchange.

The application in behalf of Professor Nicholas Roerich and others associated with him in founding the Roerich Museum to restrain Louis L. Horch from taking control of the museum and its activities was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman.

Milton Louis Livingston, president of the Continental Baking Corporation, who died on July 17. 1934, left an estate appraised yesterday at $961,347 gross and $910,344 net. He owned securities worth $773,097, including 2,100 shares of baking company stock, worth $13,925. He owned notes, cash and insurance aggregating $184,875.

A diversified entertainment in colorful settings was presented last night at the Lace Ball held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Sponsored by the Lace League, which comprises a group representing the American Lace Manufacturers Association, Inc., the event drew a large attendance and was featured by a fashion promenade of lace gowns.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- After only one voice had been raised in opposition, the Assembly today, by a vote of 96 to 38, passed a series of bills by Jane Todd, Republican, of Westchester, to pave the way for women to serve on juries.

If the United States should become involved in another major war, the present plans of the War Department call for its expenditure of probably $10,000,000,000 a year, Colonel Charles T. Harris, director of the planning branch of the War Department, said last night.
" The Prisoner of Shark Island," a Twentieth Century-Fox production directed by John Ford and featuring Warner Baxter, Gloria Stuart and Frank McGlynn Sr., opens today at the Center Theatre.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- Ernst Hanfstaengl, Nazi Press Chief, divulged here today that he had offered Harvard a scholarship of 25,000 marks in place of the 2,500 mark scholarship which he offered to his alma mater in 1934.

Los Angeles County, Calif., will be in the market on Feb. 24 with an issue of school bonds aggregating $8,393,000 and consisting of $3,758,000 of city high school district bonds; $4,279,000 of city school district bonds and $356,000 of junior college district bonds.

A group of life masks, an eight-inch "man-eating" alligator and an ancient map of New York City will feature the third annual hobby show of Columbia College, opening today in John Jay Hall. Autographs, and bows and arrows, linoleum blocks, cardboard models and amateur photographs will be on display.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- From the British standpoint the agreement reached at the naval conference between four maritime powers, if correctly reported, seems to be a compromise between political and naval necessities.

Officials of the game commissions of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania have issued appeals within the past few days for increased Winter feeding of birds and animals. With ice and snow covering the ground and depriving wild life of food sources, a terrific toll will result unless the public cooperates with conservation organizations in their benevolent work.

Several luncheons were given yesterday in conjunction with the fashion show entitled "Waves and Curves of 1936 Prevue," for the benefit of the Edgewater Creche in Englewood, N.J., held during the luncheon hour in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The definition of the word "asinine," its spelling, and whether it can be properly applied by one Representative to another, occupied a good share of the House's time today and part of the Congressional Record, at a cost of about $54 a page to print.

During the seventy years since ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S death, his fame has steadily risen. That of most of his eminent contemporaries has by comparison declined. SEWARD and CHASE and STANTON -- who speaks of them now except as remote and faded historical figures? But LINCOLN lives on in ever fresh remembrance and admiration, because the qualities which he displayed, and the human causes by which he stood, are not for an age but for all time.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11. -- Thrilling finishes marked the racing at Hialeah Park today. The third close result in a row came with the running of the featured Tavares Purse, fourth on the card. Robert Robertson's Lynx Eye, the favorite at $5 for $2 in a field of five sprinters, was declared the winner after the judges had compared their opinions with the electric eye decision.

Charging "a growing tendency to disregard efficiency and economy for other considerations" in the WPA organization, Walter M. Langsdorf submitted his resignation yesterday as deputy administrator to Victor F. Ridder, WPA chief.

On their face the real estate assessments for 1936 show an increase of $29,000,000, as compared with decreases since 1933 averaging nearly $1,000,000,000 a year. The rise is likely to prove as illusory, however, as that occasioned by Mayor LA GUARDIA'S earlier drive on the tax-exempt property of religious and charitable foundations.

The feeble and broken-hearted father of Samuel Drukman, slain garage employe, stirred on the witness stand yesterday by sudden emotion, pointed a quivering finger at three men and denounced them as the murderers of his son.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Father and son will meet in the final of the thirtieth annual Gold Racquet tournament tomorrow. The family battle was assured as Clarence C. Pell Sr. and Clarence C. Pell Jr. won their semi-final tests today on the courts of the Tuxedo Park Racquet and Tennis Club.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- The stock markets were irregular on profit-taking today, although the undertone continued firm, and there were several good features. British funds eased and were overshadowed by the activity of new issues. Foreign bonds were firm, Chinese gaining.

The world consumption of raw copper in 1935 amounted to 1,675,000 tons, compared with 1,444,000 in 1934 and a peak of 1,942,000 in 1929, according to the annual metal report of Brandeis, Goldschmidt Co., Ltd., of London. Consumption in the United States was 470,000 tons, against 372,000 in 1934 and 1,000,000 tons in 1928 and 1929.

Bernard Reiss, was re-elected president of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association last night at the annual meeting in the organization's quarters in the Criminal Courts Building. Other officers chosen were Alexander H. Kaminsky, first vice president; Jacob Lasker, second vice president; Robert Daru, third vice president; Charles A. Schneider, fourth vice president; Herman Hoffman, fifth vice president; Walter H. Carpenter, treasurer and financial secretary, and Meyer Halern, secretary.

" Die Walkuere" was the second performance of the special Wagner cycle yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House. It brought a very large audience, in spite of the repeated performances of the opera on previous subscription occasions, and the further fact that another "Ring" cycle will be given on Saturday nights in the same theatre.

On the eve of today's holiday trade interests yesterday increased price-fixing operations on the Cotton Exchange and the March delivery rose above 11.30 cents a pound for the first time this month. Despite strength in the near month and a buoyant stock market, pressure developed in distant deliveries, the October closing at the bottom with a loss of 12 points on the day.

Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Singer gave a dinner dance last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate Mrs. Singer's birthday and later took the guests to their apartment in the Towers for bridge.

Announcement that the $50,000 miniature distillery exhibit set up by the Distilled Spirits Institute would be taken from city to city on a nation-wide tour intended to educate consumers as to the methods of whisky production, was made last night by Dr. James M. Doran, executive director of the institute and chairman of the technical committee cooperating in the current Wine and Liquor Show at Grand Central Palace.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- More of Governor Lehman's measures for the better enforcement of the criminal law were defeated today in both the Senate and Assembly. Measures voted down in the Assembly included one already passed by the Senate, which would make a pistol or other weapon found in a vehicle presumptive evidence of illegal possession by all the occupants. Only 44 votes were cast in its favor, against 93 adverse votes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Spokesmen for about 1,000,000 building trades workers agreed with the Labor Housing Conference today on the broad lines of a national housing program which would include a system of Federal subsidies, the establishment of a permanent Federal housing agency and Federal standards in all public aid projects.

Myra Hess gave her first recital of the season at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Scheduled to appear here several weeks ago, the English pianist, who became a commander of the Order of the British Empire in the late King George's last New Year list, was obliged to postpone her return because of illness.

Despite adverse weather, chain store sales in January showed an increase of 8.1 per cent over a year ago, according to the monthly figures issued yesterday by Hammons Co., Inc. and Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc. The first twenty-five chains to report had an aggregate business of $139,099,024, as contrasted with $128,652,118 in the corresponding month of 1935.
An investment purchase in West Forty-second Street by Charles F. Noyes, head of the realty brokerage firm bearing his name, featured the Manhattan trading reported yesterday.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Aida," with Mine. Dusolina Giannini, Giovanni Martinelli and Lawrence Tibbett in the leading roles, which will take place this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the New York Diet Kitchen Association.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP). -- A spirited battle for the Presidential endorsement of Illinois Republican voters, in the usually lackluster Presidential primaries, was assured tonight.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 11. -- Lack of research has been the essential weakness of the railroad industry in the United States, Dr. C.M.A. Stine, a vice president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., said tonight in an address to rail and water transportation leaders at the ninth annual dinner of the Traffic Club of Wilmington.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 (AP). -- An army board of inquiry started a secret investigation today into the disappearance of Captain Edgar S. McClellan from the transport Republic.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 11 (AP). -- Two men of diverse views on the New Deal, Secretary Harold L. Ickes and Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia, spoke from the same platform here tonight in homage to Abraham Lincoln, the first Republican President.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 11. -- A letter received by the government from Mrs. Harold Street said her husband and John Trewin were arrested Jan. 27 at their mission station at Shnma, 250 miles southwest of Addis Ababa.

TOKYO, Feb. 11. -- In Japanese civilian political circles, where the fears of a naval race are causing secret anxiety, the proposals adopted at the London naval conference yesterday are received with relief. These circles believe Japan could substantially adhere to the terms formulated by the technical subcommittee.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11. -- An indignant protest came to Moscow today from the little town of Spirovo concerning the extraordinary behavior of a delegation of five poets who had come from the near-by city of Kalinin to enlighten a conference of young persons on the works of the famous Russian poet Vladimir Mayakovsky.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11. -- The Quartermaster Depot today awarded contracts for approximately 100,000 yards of cotton fabrics for the army clothing factory here, under invitation 175, as follows:

Melvin Lapman, St. John's University freshman, carried off the Eastern Intercollegiate indoor tennis singles championship yesterday by beating the first seeded star, Ernest Koslan of New York University, in the final-round engagement at the 369th Regiment Armory.

Joseph Castaldo, once known as "king" of the small artichoke industry of Greater New York, and four of his aides in the Union Pacific Produce Company of 203 West Street, waited in vain more than nine hours yesterday to learn their fate.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Among the New Jersey deals reported yesterday was one involving a part of the estate of the late Charles C. Wimpfheimer, facing Prospect, Cleveland and Poole Avenues, in Long Branch. The plot, 700 by 500 feet, was purchased by a client of Clayton Brower for the erection of a baking plant, including shipping rooms and a fifteen-car garage.

Impatient young men and several older heads have been talking a great deal lately about the "super-government" which has slowly and insidiously been built up in this country by the Supreme Court. Its unanimous decision voiding the Louisiana Press Law should help to clarify their ideas on this subject. Undoubtedly, a super-government is involved, but what is it? It is the Constitution itself.

Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, yesterday announced that members of her organization would be permitted to attend the dress rehearsal of Beethoven's "Fidelio" at the Metropolitan Opera House. While no date for the rehearsal has been set, Mrs. Belmont disclosed that Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, has granted permission for the Guild members to attend.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11. -- The "Saratoga" Ball to be given at the Surf Club, Miami Beach, on Saturday might will be featured by decorations representing the famous racing center half a century ago.

Low temperatures, with a minimum of 7 degrees in the city, again prevailed yesterday in the metropolitan area, with continued cold, fair weather predicted for today. Snow and slightly warmer weather tomorrow was forecast. Meanwhile, freezing temperatures ruled in other sections of the country from the Northwest eastward to the North Atlantic seaboard, with New England and the Chesapeake Bay regions still icebound.

Broadening his attack on the employe investment plan of the Associated Gas and Electric System, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. charged yesterday that income notes sold to employes in lieu of wages were being repurchased secretly at distress prices and that employes were being forced to sign "voluntary" petitions requesting him to discontinue his action against the system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A new Farm Bill was introduced in the Senate today by Senator McNary, the Republican leader, providing for increased tariffs, payments to farmers based on the domestic allotment plan and use of custom receipts to encourage production of new products and find new markets.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 13. -- The heaviest engagement yet recorded in the war of frontier posts on the Manchukuoan-Outer Mongolian borders is reported in Japanese dispatches from Hsinking.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 12. -- The question whether plays written for children ought or ought not to "talk down" to the audience was a matter of disagreement between a theatrical director and an educator here today.

The night before he was beaten and strangled to death in a garage at 225 Moore Street, Brooklyn, Samuel Drukman told a young woman friend that he had a business appointment at 7 P.M., March 3, 1935, the date of his murder.
Tomorrow will be St. Valentine's Day, just as surely as yesterday was Lincoln's Birthday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12 (AP). -- With military pageantry, patriotic and political groups paid homage to Abraham Lincoln today by memorial services at his tomb and meetings in his "home town."
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 12. -- Following is the text of former President Hoover's address here tonight:...

GENEVA, Feb. 12. -- The success or failure of any League of Nations oil sanction against Italy depends on the policy the United States adopts, says the experts' committee in its report, issued tonight. This responsibility is laid more squarely than diplomacy usually permits.

Motor vehicle taxes reached new high in 1935, both in the total collected and the amount levied against each vehicle, William J. Gottlieb, executive vice president of the Automobile Club of New York, announced yesterday.

Developments at the Brooklyn Museum come thick and fast these days, as one by one the reorganized galleries containing material from the extensive permanent collection are made accessible. A private view tomorrow afternoon from 3 to 6 will serve to unveil galleries on the second floor devoted to the art of China, India, Korea, Siam and Tibet, the objects displayed having been selected by Laurance P. Roberts, curator of Oriental art.

The Pettengill bill to amend the fourth section of the Interstate Commerce Act was assailed yesterday by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York as an attack on intercoastal and coastwise water lines and a threat to freight rates throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Nine additional applications have been received by the Federal Power Commission from utility companies for authority to export electrical energy from the United States to foreign countries. One of them, the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, asks permission to transmit from a point near Plattsburgh, N.Y., to Canada.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (AP). -- A suspected meningitis epidemic aboard the training ship California State was fought with new weapons tonight, supplied by the destroyer Tattnall and shortly afterward the California State's commander radioed, "No further danger."

Winning its first league start of the season in water polo, City College divided the laurels with Pennsylvania yesterday in their annual Intercollegiate Swimming Association engagements at the C.C.N.Y. pool. The Quakers triumphed in swimming, 52 -- 19, and lost a hard-fought water polo contest, 12 -- 10.

Legislators at Albany are aware, or should be aware if they are not already that the public is keeping a specially close watch this year on the progress of the crime-control bills sponsored by Governor LEHMAN. New legislation, of course, is not the only weapon at its disposal in the war against the gangster, the racketeer and the horde of lesser criminals; fearless administration of existing law is even more important.
I wish to express my appreciation of your editorial comment on the "uncivilized" woman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The administration was reported today to be still very much at sea over the question of new taxes, buffeted between political expediency on the one hand and budgetary requirements on the other.

The sixth offering of the season of Bizet's "Carmen" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House attracted the usual capacity crowd. The sixth presentation was marked by the first appearance of Rene Maison in the role of Don Jose and his performance earned the marked approval of the large assemblage.

The alumni of the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, at their Alumni Day meeting yesterday at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Medical Center, 630 West 168th Street, appointed a committee to draft a resolution conveying to Dr. LeRoy L. Hartman, originator of the Hartman solution for desensitizing the dentine of teeth, "the appreciation of the alumni for his great contribution to dentistry."

VIENNA, Feb. 12. -- The Austrian press today reprints an interview given in London by Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, the Vice Chancellor, to the diplomatic correspondent of The London Daily Telegraph, but withheld from publication until yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 12. -- Efforts on the part of State Legislatures to divert highway funds to emergency relief at the sacrifice of road construction and improvement were denounced by speakers at the twelfth annual convention of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States in the Hotel Ambassador here today.

Old Judge Charles A. Flammer sat within a golden pool of light in the cavernous, dark-paneled parlor of his home at 309 West 105th Street as darkness fell last night and looked back on New York of ninety years ago.

Dodd, Mead's Red Badge editors and The Forum Magazine announce a new $2,000 prize competition for the best mystery-detective novel by an American or Canadian author who has not previously had a mystery published by Dodd, Mead. Manuscripts must be submitted before Aug. 1, 1936.

After fighting with patrolmen who arrested him in a Riverside Drive apartment, and later kicking another policeman in the office of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, Jerry Bruno, alias Jerry the Lug, 40 years old, was held in $25,000 bail yesterday as a material witness in one of the vice ring cases.

Trust service for estates of $20,000 or less is destined to become one of the most powerful factors for social service and social security in this country, Robert V. Fleming, president of the American Bankers Association, said yesterday in an address at the midwinter conference of the association's trust division in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BERLIN, Feb. 12. -- Nazi secret police tonight controlled the offices of civil district governors under a law designed to remove hindrances from police under-cover activities against Communists and Catholics.

Substantial progress in the negotiations between employers and employes in the dress industry was made yesterday under mediation by Mayor La Guardia and there was definite indication that the threatened strike of 105,000 dress makers in this city and vicinity would be averted.

All the apartments have been rented in a recently remodeled group of five four-story houses at the southwest corner of Fifty-third Street and Second Avenue, known as 254 East Fifty-third Street, Cyrille Carreau, Inc., the agent, reported yesterday.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 12. -- To the Germans who compose nine-tenths of the galleries at these Winter Games, there has been no event yet half so exciting as the hockey match between Germany and Great Britain tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A chance for the United States to obtain benefits from rapidly increasing Japanese trade with Central and South America was seen in official circles today after the Department of Commerce revealed that San Francisco had applied for permission to create the first free port on the Western Coast.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, was arrested on a charge of illegal picketing yesterday as he led a group of forty strike sympathizers in front of May's Department Store, 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, at the noon hour. Eight other picketers, who protested when Patrolman Dominick Lagana led Mr. Thomas to a patrol wagon, were arrested for disorderly conduct and were taken along to the Butler Street station.

Dusolina Giannini, born in Philadelphia in 1903, a debutante in concert, with sensational success, in Carnegie Hall twenty years later and a singer with a long list of triumphs in concert and in opera in many lands since that time, made her American debut in opera yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Russell H. Johnson Jr. of Philadelphia was re-elected president of the American Kennel Club for his fourth consecutive term at a meeting of the board of directors held at the club's headquarters yesterday. Charles T. Inglee, executive vice president, and Perry B. Rice, secretary-treasurer, were others chosen as the entire slate was renamed.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 12. -- "Employers who are fatigued by Mexico's social and economic struggle can turn over their industries to the workers or the government -- that would be patriotic; but stop-Page of activities cannot be countenanced," declares President Lazaro Cardenas.
Mayor La Guardia made a direct and personal appeal to the Transit Commission yesterday for its aid and cooperation in bringing about speedy unification of all rapid-transit lines.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Tornadoes struck four Southern California cities tonight, injuring six persons. Flood and fire also figured in property damages exceeding $100,000. The cities are Long Beach, Alhambra. South Pasadena and Torrance, where they unroofed houses, uprooted trees, toppled oil derricks and started fires.

Twelve men who had listened for the last three weeks to intricate testimony about New York's small artichoke industry announced yesterday after deliberating twenty-four hours that they could not agree as to the guilt or innocence of Joseph Castaldo and four men accused with him of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 12. -- The Scandinavians' dominance of Olympic skiing competition continued today as Artur Larsson of Sweden set the pace for 115 skiers from twenty-two nations.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- French bargaining tactics on the size of capital ships continued to obstruct the progress of the naval conference today, although the drafting committee went busily ahead committing to writing this week's agreements on aircraft carriers, submarines and "light surface craft."

The third annual award of the Lincoln Medallion offered to the "outstanding citizen of New York" by the students of Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn, was made yesterday morning in the auditorium of the school, Ocean Parkway and West Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Average daily deposits of the 14,208 banks that are members of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation amounted to $41,628,000,000 in the last three months of 1935 Leo T. Crowley, chairman, announced today.

Although slowed up to some extent by the holiday, real estate trading in the city yesterday covered a wide area. The market was featured by the sale of a Chelsea site for a taxpayer, deals involving housing properties in the Bronx and the purchase of multi-family buildings in Queens.

DETROIT, Feb. 12. -- Amid settings of impressive beauty there was enacted on the stage of the Cass Theatre tonight the first presentation by and with Katherine Cornell of "Saint Joan," one of Bernard Shaw's noted contributions to the theatre.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- The redoubtable Sigurd Jorgensen carried off the Class A laurels in the invitation ski jumping competition today in ideal weather conditions. The Norway Ski Club star outclassed a formidable field to gain his third victory in three starts.

Totaling 303,900,000 pounds, consumption of scoured wool last year was the largest since 1923, when 311,300,000 pounds were used, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers. The August and October weekly average consumption surpassed any since 1918, while the December average of 5,550,000 pounds was the highest for that month since 1922.

The filterable virus already announced as the cause of the common cold can be kept alive in a test tube for at least twenty months, Dr. A. Raymond Dochez, professor in the Columbia University School of Medicine, said yesterday in an address at an alumni luncheon in John Jay Hall on the Columbia campus.
BERLIN, Feb. 12. -- Despite the unconcealed bitterness which permeated Chancellor Hitler's address at the funeral in Schwerin of Wilhelm Gustloff, no anti-Jewish demonstrations are expected.

OTTAWA, Feb. 12. -- The Canadian Government agreed today to permit a parliamentary inquiry into allegations that it had sold out the Western farmer to the private grain trade but indicated at the same time that it would in no way modify its policy of disposing of Canada's surplus at world prices.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Creation of a special committee to define publicity standards for trials, partly as the outgrowth of the Hauptmann case, was disclosed today by the American Bar Association.

AIX-EN-PROVENCE, Feb. 12. -- The end of the second trial of the three Croat Ustachis came before a courtroom crowded to capacity with spectators. Wild scenes during the first hearing of the case had resulted in strict orders from the court to prevent disturbances, particularly since Georges Desbons, defense counsel at the first trial, had been disbarred after he declared that the French Government did not want to go to the bottom of the case.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Political debate over whether President Roosevelt should be compared to Abraham Lincoln or to Andrew Jackson followed a tribute to Lincoln in the Assembly today.

Public offering will be made today by W.E. Hutton Co. and Goldman, Sachs Co., by means of a prospectus, of 17,500 shares of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock and 100,000 shares of no-par common stock of the Champion Paper and Fibre Company, formerly known as the Champion Coated Paper Company.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 12 (AP). -- Replying in an editorial in The Richmond News-Leader today to an attack made upon him in the House of Representatives yesterday by Representative John Flannagan. Democrat, of Virginia, Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman, editor of the paper and biographer of Robert E. Lee, said:

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 12. -- Although lacking its usual dash and driving power, the United States ice hockey team took another step toward the Olympic finals today by defeating Austria, 1 to 0.

Renouncing temporarily the affairs of the spirit, the drama discussed medical malpractice and murder at the Mansfield last evening. Samuel John Park's "Black Widow" was up for consideration, with Lucille La Verne grumbling her way through the part of a monstrous physician.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- War on opponents of his anti-crime bills was declared in a formal statement today by Governor Lehman, and immediately a storm broke around him. The storm came from leaders of both parties in the Senate and Assembly.

Victory in the first match of the high-goal division of the tenth annual New York Athletic Club mid-Winter polo tournament went to Blind Brook when it turned back the New York Athletic Club, 6 to 5 1/2, in an exciting game yesterday at the 105th Field Artillery Armory. Merrill Fink's goal, on a pass from Ted Watson, won the match in the last minute of play.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 12. -- Miss Sonja Henie, twice Olympic champion and nine times world champion in women's figure skating, the most famous personality in the Winter sports world, had a tantrum today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Managers for Senator Borah predicted today that he would enter the Republican National Convention with more than 200 pledged delegates, and that his initial strength would exceed that of any other candidate.

A famous scene from SHAKESPEARE has just been reenacted in the House of Representatives, where they are fond of quoting from the Bard. It happened that one Representative twice characterized a colleague's remarks as "ridiculous and asinine," whereupon the affronted gentleman twice demanded that the words be taken down, which is a form of parliamentary manoeuvre.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12. -- The cotton market here was rather quiet today and trading was limited because the New York Cotton Exchange was closed for the holiday. The general trend of prices was downward, but about midday there was a rally on a report that the cotton pool was opening bids for 50,000 bales of good grade cotton.
Increased midtown activity by firms in the textile and allied industries was reported by brokers yesterday, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Representative Kenney, Democrat of New Jersey, said today he would continue to urge construction of a rapid transit bridge at Fifty-seventh Street pending assurance by the Port of New York Authority that rapid transit train service would be installed over the George Washington Bridge between New Jersey and New York.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb.12. -- Displaying the same flawless technique which carried him to victory in fourteen previous tournaments since 1914, Clarence C. Pell .Sr. today won the Gold Racquet on the courts of the Tuxedo Park Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP). -- The Federal Advisory Council today renewed its warning that excess bank reserves, which now are $3,090,000,000, hold possibilities of inflation, and added a recommendation that they be greatly reduced or eliminated.

Four persons lost their lives and at least thirty-eight were hurt, many seriously, last night in a fire that swept the three-story building at 735 Lexington Avenue, at the southeast corner of Fifty-ninth Street, causing a stampede among 150 persons in Lum's Chinese Restaurant on the second floor.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Arrivals of hogs here today were heavier than expected, owing to milder weather, and the result was that prices dropped 15 to 50 cents a hundredweight. Hogs weighing under 180 pounds were weakest. Most sales showed losses of 25 to 40 cents compared with the prices on Tuesday, but a rally in the late trading lifted prices about 10 cents above the inside level.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Arguments on the suit of Franklin Township, N.J., and four property owners for a temporary injunction to restrain Rexford G. Tugwell, Rural Resettlement Administrator, from creating a "model community" within the township were heard in the District of Columbia Court of Appeals today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 12. -- Reorganization of the Interstate Commerce Commission to provide unified government regulation of railroad, motor and inland-waterway transportation is necessary to save those industries from "general chaos," Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Railroads, told 250 members of the American Warehousemen's Association here today.

A robber who answers to the name of George and his three accomplices were sought by the police yesterday after a $10,000 hold-up in the Madison Jewelers, a store at 1,194 Madison Avenue, near Eighty-seventh Street, about 2 P.M.

Paul Chesley, 29-year-old professor at Seth Low Junior College, in Brooklyn, and a brilliant student of zoology, committed suicide yesterday afternoon in a furnished room he had rented a few hours earlier at 519 West 123d Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A charge that shipping interests, paid by the mile on their mail contracts are opposing the Transflorida ship canal for selfish reasons was made in the House today by Representative Green of Florida.

The metropolitan area experienced another day of below-freezing weather yesterday. The lowest temperature was 11 degrees, at 8 A.M.; the highest, 24 degrees, at 1:15 P.M., and the average 18. The normal average for Feb. 12, based on the Weather Bureau's records of some sixty years, is 31.

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Base metal stocks were in the spotlight today on the mining market on the Stock Exchange here, influenced by the advance of International Nickel to new high ground on the industrial market here and in London.
BERLIN, Feb. 12. -- Mgr. Cesare Orsenigo, the Papal Nuncio in Berlin, called at the Foreign Office yesterday, it was learned in diplomatic quarters today.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of January: Total imports 70,020,000; exports of British products 34,460,000; re-exports 4,320,000; total exports 38,780,000; excess of imports 31,240,000.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12. -- Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart's Chance Ray ran a mile and a furlong in 1:49 flat, only three-fifths of a second slower than Blessed Event's track record, to win the Abraham Lincoln Grade A Handicap that topped a bargain bill of eight races at Hialeah Park today.

ATLANTA, Feb. 12 (AP). -- A Federal court indictment charging Alex S. Howell, brother of the chairman of Georgia's Democratic Executive Committee, with falsifying WPA records and using WPA workers to prepare copies of an anti-Roosevelt publication for mailing was returned today.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- House Republicans have joined with the Democratic leadership in a move for a thorough investigation of the Townsend Plan and the methods of its advocates.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 12. -- In an address here this afternoon Secretary Wallace again made plain his disagreement with the Supreme Court's decision on the AAA, quoted Lincoln's views indicating dissatisfaction with some decisions by the court and asserted that the new Federal farm program was a sincere attempt to help within the constitutional limitations set by the tribunal.

SCHWERIN, Feb. 12. -- Chancellor Hitler and other Nazi leaders warned today at the funeral of the assassinated Wilhelm Gustloff that such attacks would only mean a more determined and ruthless carrying out of the National Socialist program.

LINCOLN'S address of November, 1864 (brought freshly to public attention by the publication yesterday of a facsimile of the manuscript), illustrates again his mastery of English speech. GOLDWIN SMITH, Oxford professor and man of letters, said of the brief Gettysburg Address that "saving one very flat "expression it had no superior in literature."

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- Expectation that the loan that the French Government is seeking in London will be forthcoming sent prices of rentes up on the Bourse today by an average of 50 centimes. At the same time a report was current that the situation of the Treasury is not so bad as had been reported.
MONTE CAlq, LO, Feb, la. -- Mrs. Core Urquhart Brown Potter, I mother of Mrs. Fowler (Fifi) Me-I Cormick, recently became a French I citizen. Her stage career was me-1 teorie and her fame world-wide,

BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, in his first address as an avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, charged the New Deal tonight with abusing power and the public trust.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 12. -- Most of the United States' Winter Olympic ambitions now have been buried under an avalanche of failures and misfortunes.

READING, Pa., Feb. 12. -- Ferdinand Thun and Henry K. Janssen, textile manufacturers, each of whom is observing his seventieth birthday anniversary this month, were the surprised honor guests at a reception given for them today by most of their 8,000 employes in three Wyomissing mills.

The NRA, it will be recalled, had a Consumers Advisory Council. Its advice, it is true, was almost never taken, but its complaints and its very existence served the useful purpose of reminding the public that the activities of the NRA were antithetical to the interests of consumers.

The dismissal of Samuel Duff McCoy, author, newspaper man and Pulitzer Prize winner, as assistant director of the writers' project, a Federal relief undertaking for needy writers, was announced yesterday by relief officials together with plans for reorganization of the project.
Universal announced yesterday that it had purchased the screen rights to "Roxana," a new novel by Clarence Budington Kelland, for $25,000. Margaret Sullavan, it was said, will be starred in the film.

ROME, Feb. 12. -- The report of the Geneva committee of experts on oil sanctions, or at least as much as is available at present, has rather disappointed Italy. It is believed to make out not nearly as bad a case for an oil embargo as had been expected.
Mrs. Calvin Coolidge sailed last night for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen as "Mrs. Adams." This name did not appear on the passenger list.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP). -- A decrease of 72 cents in the per capita gross debt of cities of 100,000 population and over was reported by the Census Bureau today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Feb. 1 amounted to 312, 857,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. Compared with the previous week this total is 382,000 barrels lower, comprising 80,000 and 302,000 barrels in domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

IT was several days ago that Charley Peterson, the quiet billiardist, told of the college professor who was linking instruction in geometry with demonstrations on the billiard table. Students who have been cornered and questioned seemed highly in favor of this type of tutoring, but as yet there is no reported rush of geometry instructors for classroom billiard tables

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 12 (AP). -- The Ethiopian Government announced the recapture of the town of Kora Ali on the southern front today and disputed Italian claims that only 844 white Italian soldiers had died in Ethiopia since the start of the war.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- Jean Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris, decided today that the body of Jacques Bainville, eminent French historian who died Sunday, cannot receive Catholic funeral rites or burial in consecrated ground.

It is encouraging news that within a week the President hopes to submit to Congress what will in effect be a new budget. It will consist of a revision of the estimates prepared before AAA was declared to be unconstitutional and before Congress overrode the veto of the soldiers' bonus.

KATOWICE, Poland, Feb. 12. -- Jews were beaten in the streets here today following announcement of the verdict in the trial of twenty-one terrorists who placed bombs in a synagogue here and in several Jewish shops and houses in various parts of Upper Silesia on Dec. 8.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 12 (AP). -- There's another spot of trouble coming up in Olympic hockey circles, and just when officials had become confident that all disputes had been safely buried.

AIX-EN-PROVENCE, Feb. 12. -- Three Croats, members of the Ustachi Secret Society, tried here as accomplices of the assassin who killed King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Louis Barthou, French Foreign Minister, at Marseilles in October, 1934, will spend the rest of their lives on Devil's Island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- President Roosevelt paid tribute to the memory of Abraham Lincoln by placing a wreath at the base of the statue of the Civil War President in the Lincoln Memorial. President Lincoln also was eulogized in the Senate and the House.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Seven million dollars was willed to Northwestern University by Roger Deering, who died on Feb. 2 at Albuquerque.

New York money market closed for holiday. Tuesday's closing rate for Stock Exchange call loans, three-fourths of 1 per cent; for sixty-day time loans, 1 per cent; for prime commercial paper, three to four months, three-fourths of 1 per cent.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12. -- Increases in the prices to be paid collective farms and individual members of collective farms for grain delivered to the State were established today by the Soviet Government and the Communist party in a joint decree.

Reporting the largest net earnings in its history, the Continental Can Company. Inc., showed a net profit for 1935 of $11,223,578 after deducting all charges, including Federal, State and foreign income taxes and a $500,000 contingency reserve.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 12. -- Eight lives were known to have been lost in a fire that destroyed the Victoria Mansion Hotel here this morning. Police Chief Walter A. Curtis said tonight that search of the ruins might bring the total fatalities to fifteen.

Returning to the local concert platform after an interim of five years, Ruth Breton was rapturously received by a large gathering in Town Hall last night. The Kentucky violinist, a pupil of Franz Kneisel and Leopold Auer, did not seem to be in her best form last night, or else the years have not dealt gently with her artistry, for she has played far better on previous occasions in this city.

Labor unions in the building trades have signed an agreement for the use of the new method of setting tile being used in the ceiling of the Midtown Hudson Tunnel and the facade of the Rialto Theatre Building at Broadway and Forty-second Street.

TOKYO, Feb. 12. -- "These proposals are not hostile to Japan," a naval authority declared here today after reading press accounts of the naval agreement reached at the London naval conference. He added that the navy would not express its view, however, until the proposals had been officially communicated.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12. -- Senator Borah won first place today on the ballot in the Republican Presidential preference primary when his petition and certificate of candidacy were filed in the office of Edward J. Hughes, Secretary of State.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $1,200,000 of Penn-Jersey Water Company first collateral trust 5 1/4 per cent bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1960, by a banking group comprising Swart, Brent Co., Inc.; Herrick, Heinzelmann Ripley, Inc.; Boenning Co. and Bond Goodwin, Inc.

Former United States Senator George Wharton Pepper of Pennsylvania was elected president of the American Law Institute yesterday to succeed George W. Wickersham, who died on Jan. 25. Senator Pepper was elected by the council of the institute at a meeting held in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Is there not an instructive parallel between the conflict of the Commons and House of Lords in England in 1911 and that today between Congress and the Supreme Court? The Lords blocked social legislation somewhat similar to the New Deal measures. The Peers were hereditary and embraced the "law lords," who roughly correspond to our Supreme Court.

NEW ORLEANS Feb. 12. -- Heart Break steady going 6-year-old mare racing for Mrs H Torriente, captured her sixth rac in eight starts today in accounting for the six furlongs of the Abraham Lincoln Purse at the Fair Grounds.

Part of the receipts from the hockey match between the New York Americans and Chicago Black Hawks tonight at Madison Square Garden will be used to further the work of the girls', boys' and children's committee of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association of 331 East Seventieth Street.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 12. -- Water Witch, a forty-nine-foot schooner owned by C.A. Hansen of the Shore Acres Yacht Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., was declared winner of the annual Miami to Nassau race today on corrected time. Although finishing fourth behind Vadim S. Makaroff's staysail ketch Vamarie, which led the fleet into the harbor, Water Witch's allowance gave her first honors in 17:08:36.
The text of the address by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg at the annual Lincoln dinner of the National Republican Club here last night follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Congress was challenged by Senator Norris today to "remedy the situation" created by the invalidation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act by the Supreme Court "if it has the courage to do it."

SCHWERIN, Germany, Feb. 12. -- Wilhelm Gustloff, assassinated leader of the German National Socialist group in Switzerland, entered the party's Valhalla today as he was acclaimed in an impassioned funeral oration by Chancellor Hitler as "one of the immortal martyrs of the German Nation."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Wayne Chatfield Taylor, vice president of the Export-Import Banks and a close friend of George N. Peek, its former head, has been selected to be Assistant Secretary of the Treasury to succeed L.W. Robert Jr., whose resignation becomes effective Saturday.

A transfer of emphasis from "book knowledge" to character and personality in rating candidates for teaching posts was urged on the Board of Examiners yesterday by Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education.

The Declaration of Independence has been rewritten to bring it within the range of the "man on the street." Professor Lyman Bryson of Teachers College, Columbia University, revealed yesterday in announcing the formation of a "Laboratory in Readability" to translate "hard" books into easy readers.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Miss Helen Stephens, Fulton, Mo., track ace, successfully defended her national indoor 50-meter championship tonight, outracing a brilliant field to equal the world record of 6.4 seconds.

Characterizing higher education in the United States from 1920 to 1930 as a "pretty sloppy kind of affair," Dr. Stephen Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, speaking at the annual breakfast of the Hunter College Alumnae Association, held at the Hotel Astor yesterday, suggested that educators make an analysis of the current situation and prepare college students for it.

Forty-six amateur musicians, assembled through the medium of a newspaper advertisement, astonished themselves and their instructor-conductor last night by the skill with which they ran through the measures of Haydn's Surprise Symphony and Bizet's L'Arlesienne Suite, in their first rehearsal at the Juilliard School of Music, Broadway and 122d Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A two-hour conference was held at the White House this afternoon between the President and government officials to work out, if possible, a ship subsidy bill that can be enacted at the current session of Congress.
Tributes to Abraham Lincoln from President Roosevelt and Governor Henry Horner of Illinois were read yesterday at a luncheon of the Society of Illinois Women in New York at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Though Senator Norris's suggestion today that Congress has the specific constitutional right to limit by statute the appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court is tempting to the administration as a solution for its present judicial troubles, the idea is not likely to be pressed at this session of Congress.

The list of nominations for three of the six stakes to be run at the Spring meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club at Jamaica, and for which entries closed Feb. 3, were announced yesterday by Secretary John J. Kane. The six stakes attracted a total of 299 entries, headed by the Youthful, which drew seventy-eight nominations.

Salvador de Madariaga, delegate from the Spanish Republic to the League of Nations and chairman of the Committee of Thirteen of the League Council to consider the dispute between Italy and Ethiopia, arrived late yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to deliver a series of lectures on international affairs.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12. -- Limiting the Elis to a total of two foul shots in the last half, Princeton's basketball team came from behind tonight to down Yale, 29 -- 20, in a thrilling Eastern Intercollegiate League contest before a crowd of 1,000 in the university gymnasium.
Before the largest gallery that was ever enjoyed the final judging of a dog show in Madison Square Garden, the sixtieth annual exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Clu reached its climax last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A bill for the amendment of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which would permit trading in unlisted securities after June 1, the deadline now set by the act, was transmitted late today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, but was withheld from publication pending the return of Senator Fletcher, chairman of the committee.

Smoke, usually a danger signal, was mistaken for nothing more harmful than Chinese incense last night by a number of those in the Chinese restaurant at Fifty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue when fire was spreading throughout the building, according to Joseph Morisco of 30-12 Astoria Avenue, Astoria, Queens.

ALBANY, Feb, 12. -- A bill designed to end hasty marriages in the State was introduced today by Assemblywoman Jane H. Todd, Westchester Republican. The measure would require seventy-two hours to elapse between the issuance of a license and the marriage ceremony.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 12. -- The largest export business in Canadian wheat for any one day in several weeks, together with soaring prices in Liverpool, sent wheat values on the Grain Exchange here up today for a net gain of 1 1/8 cents a bushel, with May finishing at 84 1/2 cents, July at 85 1/4 and October at 84 1/8.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 12. -- Caustically attacking President Roosevelt again tonight at a Lincoln Birthday dinner, former President Herbert Hoover declared that the President's denunciations of "money-changers" and "entrenched greed" were not only an incitement to class war but a red herring across the path of failure."

The pinnacle of last night's recital by Artur Schnabel -- the fifth in his Beethoven sonata series at Carnegie Hall -- was his performance of the B flat major Sonata, Op. 106, known as the "Hammerklavier." It was an eloquent recreation of an immense work.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- A record-breaking brigade of athletes shattered four marks and set two new ones in the junior national A.A.U. track and field championships at Convention Hall tonight.
TRENTON, Feb. 12. -- Out of a conference to be held next week between Governor Hoffman and a joint committee of the Legislature may come a compromise agreement for financing emergency relief.

The heroism of the Rev. George Rosso, first assistant pastor of the Church of Our Lady of Peace, and of members of the Holy Name Society, who were trapped in Lum's Chinese and American Restaurant, at Fifty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue when fire swept the place saved many lives.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Steps to end speculation in the shares of the old Middle West Utilities Company were taken today when Daniel C. Green, trustee, obtained permission from Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson to discontinue transfer facilities for the stock.

In a sweeping attack on President Roosevelt's policies at the Lincoln dinner of the National Republican Club last night, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan appealed to Jeffersonian Democrats to join the Republicans in defeating the New Deal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Sales in department stores in January were larger than in the same month last year in all but the Cleveland Federal Reserve District, where there was a decline of 5 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Play in the women's national doubles and New York State singles squash racquets championships advanced to both finals at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

Steel production rose moderately this week because of continued support from the heavy industries, which offset the depressing effects of unusually cold weather and declining automobile production, the magazine Iron Age said in its summary yesterday. Ingot output was estimated at 53 per cent of capacity, an advance of 1 point.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- If Germany should try to use the Franco-Soviet pact as an excuse for sending troops into the demilitarized Rhineland zone or beginning fortifications there France would immediately summon the powers to action in fulfillment of the Treaty of Locarno.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The army's 1,150 war planes are at last fully equipped with radio communication and the utmost in military navigation devices, Signal Corps officers stated tonight.

F.A. Cauchois became the permanent owner of the C.J. Winninger Trophy at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, scoring his third straight victory in the cup competition featuring the Lincoln's Birthday shoot of the Winged Foot club.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Edwin D. Krenn and Miss Mae Clayton, divorcee and art student of Chicago, were married in Richmond, Va., on Dec. 22, 1934, The Chicago Tribune said today. Miss Lucile Gilman, a Chicago friend of Miss Clayton, confirmed a report of the marriage.

Admission, at Washington, that $9,970,000 gold "earmarked" at the New York Federal Reserve Bank (the largest single earmarking since 1933) was for account of China, added another to the queer financial consequences of our Government's Silver Purchase experiment.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- The stock markets generally were firm today, following overnight news of yesterday's strength in Wall Street. British funds were fractionally higher, although the business in them was small. European securities improved in the foreign markets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- All ranks of diplomatic, official and resident society turned out to hear and applaud the program given by Lotte Lehmann, soprano, and Emanuel List, bass, of the Metropolitan Opera, at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's eighty-ninth musical morning at the Mayflower.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Jackie Coogan and Betty Grable, dancing sweethearts of the films, submitted to a lie detector test today to prove that a $5,000 jewel robbery they reported early today was true and not merely a publicity stunt.

With 42 1/2 points in the senior division and 50 5-6 in the midget-junior section, representatives of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School romped off with both crowns in the ninth annual C.H.S.A.A. indoor track and field meet at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12. -- Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., one of the few women ever to speak at the current events series, talked to subscribers and their guests this afternoon at the Beaux Arts Theatre. Her subject, "Life in the Philippines," illustrated by slides, was based on experiences while her husband governed the islands.

Mischa Meller, young Russian-born pianist, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His program embraced two Bach-Busoni choral preludes, six sonatas by Domenico Scarlatti, Beethoven's sonata, Op. 13; a nocturne and three etudes by Chopin and Brahms's sonata in C, Op. 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Whether an inter-American conference will be held in an effort to consolidate peace in the Western Hemisphere will depend upon the character of the responses to the letters President Roosevelt has sent to the heads of the twenty Latin-American republics.

Abraham Lincoln, "vilified and abused" by the press of the nation during his Presidential office, should serve as a model example to public officials who might become "discouraged" by public criticism of their acts of office, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday afternoon.
The list of the Cunard White Star liner Ascania, leaving for Plymouth and London, include Mrs. Russell Lord, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Terry, J.L. Bradshaw, Captain H.B. Robinson and Miss E.J. Elliston.

BERLIN, Feb. 12. -- The Boerse continued firm today in the expectation that numerous companies will make better dividend showings this year. On the whole, however, price changes were merely fractional and the turnover remained small.

Twenty-nine of Broadway's thirty-one attractions chose to celebrate Lincoln's Birthday with matinees yesterday, and the results were generally pleasing. The business, it was estimated, was about 50 per cent better than that of the corresponding date last year, when twenty-one of twenty-six shows gave afternoon performances.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- Brief but definite assurance on taro points of British foreign policy was given today by Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, and J.H. Thomas, Secretary for Colonies, respectively, in reply to questions in the House of Commons.

In The Idaho Statesman are garnered the opinions of divers politicians of the neighborhood and State about Mr. BORAH'S entrance into the Presidential lists. There is a good percentage of rapture, but even some of the rapturous are in doubt as to the hero's intentions. "That's fine," says SAM GRIFFIN, leader of the Borah-for-President movement in Idaho.

Samuel S. Leibowitz, noted criminal lawyer and chief counsel for the Negro defendants in the Scottsbore case, agreed yesterday to join defense counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann if the convicted killer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. would tell him "the whole truth."

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 13. -- The Hsinking correspondent of the Domei News Agency said a detachment of Japanese-Manchukuoan troops routed at least 200 Mongolian soldiers after several hours of fighting at Olahudka, near Lake Bor, claimed both by Manchukuo and Outer Mongolia.

Miss Alice Paul, founder of the National Woman's party and chairman of its international relations committee, sailed yesterday on the Washington for Geneva, where she will defend the social, industrial and economic equality of women at the session of the International Labor Organization.
After two defeats in succession New York University's basketball team returned to winning form last night and gained an easy victory over Rutgers at the Violet gymnasium by 50 -- 28.

Mildred Cornell, 11-year-old Queens Girl Scout, whose mother taught her to bake, was judged yesterday afternoon the best pie-baking Girl Scout in the city. Her prize-winning effort (2 inches deep and 9 inches in diameter) received the "overwhelming" verdict of judges who eyed and tasted pies in a contest that had narrowed down to forty-two contestants from the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- From two of the men who swung the deal the Interstate Commerce Commission learned officially for the first time today how O.P. Van Sweringen, aided by a director of several of his enterprises and a millionaire fruit jar manufacturer, regained control of his vast railroad empire without spending a nickel of his own.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Threats that a State-wide campaign would be conducted this Fall against every legislator who voted for continuation of the 2-cent emergency gasoline taxes were made to day by representatives of the State Automobile Association, filling station owners and commercial travelers at a hearing in the Assembly Chamber on Governor Lehman's tax program.

I-oliday trade was notably active yesterday in local department stores. Increases over last year were quite general, with an average gain of about 5 per cent estimated over Lincoln's Birthday last !year. Apparel and accessories, home furnishings and toilet goods departments were particularly well patronized.

May I express my surprise at the attitude of your newspaper toward your government's silver policy? In an editorial Jan. 15 you quote at some length the opinion of a firm of New York bullion merchants as evidence of the "futility" of that policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Alarming conditions, which could not be revealed, make large appropriations for coast defense a matter of the utmost importance, Representative Parks of Arkansas, chairman of the War Department Appropriations Subcommittee, told the House today.

DAVID LAWRENCE laments the fact that the Supreme Court has become the football of partisan politics. Yet the very title of his book, "Nine Honest Men" (D. Appleton-Century, $1.50), is partisan in its implications. For it tacitly assumes that vicious characters have been going around the country impugning the integrity of the nine justices.

A crowd of 6,871 adults and children had paid 25 and 10 cents admission, respectively, by 7 o'clock last night at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, which officially opened its new quarters at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

Moving along rapidly on the wings of another of those rallies such as snatched the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate League from Columbia's grasp a year ago, the Penn quintet ran headlong into a Lion counter-rally in the final minutes of their game at the Columbia gymnasium last night.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP). -- James I. Young of Brooklyn, N.Y., a New York City mounted policeman, was shot and killed here tonight by an unidentified assailant.

In a letter to this column Peter W. Barrett of Tarrytown speculates on what the coming trout season holds in store for anglers of the metropolitan area and discusses the possibility of effecting much-needed improvements.

May I lament the futility and stupidity of the new Auto Law which Senator Baldwin wishes to enact in Albany? He has prepared a schelude of rules which will be the greatest possible nuisance and of the least possible efficacy.

ATHENS, Feb. 12. -- Inter-party skirmishes for control of the monarchy's first elected government gave the anti-Venizelists 144 seats today and the Venizeltsts 141, with fifteen Communists holding the remainder. The Venizelists are silent on Communist offers of cooperation.
Ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment by the Legislature at its present session was urged by nineteen Protestant clergymen in a letter made public yesterday.

Joe Di Maggio, the young San Franciscan who is expected to be one of Manager Joe MoCarthy's most important outfielders this year, has deserted the holdout ranks of the Yankees, Business Manager Ed Barrow announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12. -- South American governments are attributing communistic character to opposition movements which have no connection with communism, according to an editorial in today's Prensa.

The New School for Social Research last night inaugurated the second season of its "Modern Dance Recitals" series with a performance by Lillian Shapero and her group, and Mary Radin. The object of the series is to provide an opportunity for young dancers to appear before an audience without either the artistic or the financial responsibility of giving entire recitals of their own.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously recommended to the Senate today the extension, with only minor modifications, of the existing Neutrality Act until May 1, 1937. The move was made with the intent of shelving further neutrality discussion at this session of Congress.

The magic appeal that Notre Dame has for New York sports followers again will be in evidence tonight when a gathering of more than 18,000 jams Madison Square Garden for the eighth of the college court double-headers. In the feature attraction of a show that was sold out a week ago, the Ramblers will face N.Y.U., while Fordham will attempt to take the measure of City College in the opener.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- A housing program covering at least ten years and involving direct Federal expenditures of probably $300,000,000 to $400,000,000 in the first year took substantial form today as President Roosevelt conferred with Senator Wagner and administration experts for two hours.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, was commended for his activity in apprehending "the real offenders" in vice cases rather than "the unfortunate and often miserable women and girls," in a resolution adopted yesterday by the protective and correctional section of the Welfare Council.
TRENTON, Feb. 13. -- Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis was upheld by the Supreme Court today in refusing a certificate of incorporation asked by the Monument Optometrical Corporation of Trenton.

Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, physician to the Dionne quintuplets, is on the Julian Messner Spring list with a book on the care of children entitled, "Dr. Dafoe's Guidebook for Mothers." The book will be published in the Spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13. -- Carola Gitana, known in society as Miss Carola Collings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Zane Collings, tonight gave a recital of Spanish dances at the Plays and Players Clubhouse for the benefit of the Central City Auxiliary of the Seamen's Church Institute.

ROME, Feb. 13. -- Despite their successes in the East African campaign the Italians are somewhat sadly forced to admit that the Ethiopians still have upward of 350,000 men under arms. As far as the strengths and positions of the Ethiopian forces can be learned in Rome, they are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Only the faintest flutterings of the eyelids of the moribund "permanent" neutrality plan were produced by the report of the experts committee at Geneva that the success or failure of oil sanctions against Italy depends upon the degree of American cooperation. The reasons are several and obvious.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 13. -- William H. Kelly, former State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, announced today his resignation as chairman of the New Jersey Democratic Committee and chairman of the Essex County Democratic Committee so he would be eligible for the office of Collector of Internal Revenue for the Fifth District of New Jersey, including the eleven northern counties.
LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The government's bill for raising the school-leaving age from 14 to 15 had a mixed reception when it passed second reading in the House of Commons tonight by 282 to 152 votes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- Receipts of hogs here today were the heaviest in two weeks, but there was a marked expansion in demand. Some leading packers who have been out of the market for several days because of the limited offerings were aggressive buyers.

Health conditions last week compared unfavorably with those of the preceding week and a year ago, according to the Health Department's weekly summary of vital statistics. Births declined, deaths rose and cases of most contagious diseases increased.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, addressing the Washington Bond Club at a luncheon today, discussed informally the subject of unlisted trading in securities and some of the objectives which the commission hoped to attain gradually in obtaining more complete information for the public concerning such securities.

After successfully meeting an early challenge, the Long Island University quintet went on to register its twenty-second triumph of the season by downing Canisius College, 46 -- 31, last night at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium. It was the twenty-ninth straight victory over a two-year span for L.I.U.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 13 (AP). -- Federal electrical workers of the capital are preparing a petition asking the government to hand over the management of electrical plants to them, it was learned tonight.

MONTREAL, Feb. 13 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons downed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 1, tonight to go into the lead in the international group of the National Hockey League. The Maroons and the Leafs had been tied for top place before tonight's encounter.

LONDON, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press). -- The Marquess of Reading, former Viceroy of India and long prominent in British public life, left an estate of 290,000 when he died last Dec. 30 following a fatal chill. Of this estate, which in dollars amounts to $1,450,000, a legacy duty of about $365,000 is to be taken by the State.

An order permitting the reopening of bidding for the stock of the National Surety Corporation was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Valente. Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, has fixed an upset price of $8,250,000 for the stock on recommendation of the State Insurance Board. Bids must be submitted to Justice Valente by noon March 9.

Jewish farmers in the United States have weathered the economic difficulties of the last few years and are now making steady progress in agriculture, according to the annual report of Gabriel Davidson, general manager of the Jewish Agricultural Society, issued yesterday.

ALPINE, N. J., Feb. 13. -- Mrs. Manuel Rionda for the third consecutive year today opened Glen Goin, her home overlooking the Hudson, for a benefit Valentine bridge for two successive days, in the interests of the Bergen County S. P. C. A.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 12, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,496,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $29,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Mayor La Guardia, with the aid Of Borough President Samuel Levy, assumed the role of steam shovel operator yesterday morning and officially broke ground for the last link in the West Side Highway, from Forty-eighth to Fifty-ninth Street.
