When the link is completed the elevated roadway will be continuous from Canal Street to Seventy-second Street.
The New York Americans battled the Chicago Black Hawks to a 2-2 tie in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Two announcements were made yesterday regarding Ben Johnson, Columbia's national and international sprint champion. The New York Athletic Club first came through with the news that the Negro flash would make his debut in the Winged Foot games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

ROME, Feb. 13. -- Reports from Washington that a Pan-American conference has been suggested to study a proposal for linking the twenty-one American republics into something like an American League of Nations is received with ill-concealed satisfaction in Italy because it is thought that such an organization would mean the end of the Geneva League.

An event with a tradition of several decades behind it -- the annual St. Valentine's Kettledrum in behalf of the Samaritan Home for the Aged -- will be held today in the ballroom suite of the Plaza. It will be the sixty-third kettledrum for the benefit of the Home, which is one of the oldest organizations of its kind in New York, having been founded in 1867.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $90,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $3,000,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve reports issued yesterday. Actual reserve balances of the banks were down $85,000,000 to $5,784,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- A decline of 1 point in retail food prices and a moderate, but general, easing of wholesale prices was announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 13. -- Three persons were burned to death and four persons, including two firemen, were injured in two fires an hour apart shortly after noon here today.

In his campaign Governor CURLEY of Massachusetts promised the people "work and wages." He has kept his promise, notably in the executive department. Salaries and the number of employes have been increased. A joint legislative committee has been poking its nose into the enlargement of the executive budget.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- While the Democratic Senate passed four more bills of the Governor's anti-crime series. Assembly Republicans worked today on plans for "going after" Governor Lehman because of his statement yesterday that "powerful groups" were intent upon defeat of his law-enforcement program and were reaching into the Legislature to accomplish their purpose.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 13. -- The toll of known dead in the fire that destroyed the Victoria Mansion Hotel here rose to ten today as three more bodies were recovered. The police were certain that five more were in the ruins heaped where the $100,000 resort building had stood.

An assortment of ship's gear, including life preservers, signal flags, coils of rope and an improvised gangplank, will lend an appropriate nautical atmosphere to the Beaux-Arts cruise dinner dance which will take place tomorrow night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

The Skelly Oil Company has retired 91,520 shares of common and 53,700 shares of preferred stock, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's monthly report of reacquired stock filed with the New York Stock Exchange. The company also stated it had acquired an additional block of 2,200 shares of common stock.

Mr. HOOVER'S frontal attack, in his Portland (Ore.) speech of Wednesday on the New Deal program and the public debt incurred by it, indicated plainly enough the lines on which, in the coming political campaign, the aggressive fight against the Administration will be conducted.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 13 (AP). -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed today a lower court decision holding unconstitutional a subsection of the Bankruptcy Act and rejecting an application of the Tennessee Publishing Company for reorganization under Section 77-B of that act.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 13. -- Europe continues to demonstrate here in most disconcerting fashion its complete superiority to the New World in Winter sports, always excepting hockey.

New York University's well-balanced swimming combination captured its second meet of the season yesterday when it defeated the St. Francis College team, 46 to 25, in the Park Central Hotel pool. This was the first intercollegiate meet for the losers.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb, 13 (AP). -- Frank Spencer Meador, young investment clerk, received a divorce here today from Anne Gould Meador of New York.

The Whitney Museum of American Art announces that it has acquired for its permanent collection thirty-six works from Part I of the second biennial exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, drawings and prints, which closed Wednesday. The purchases were made from a fund of $20,000 provided for the purpose.

An injury to Joseph J. Lordi, New York A.C. player, marred the second round of play in the invitation squash tennis tourney at the Whitehall Club yesterday. Lordi suffered an inch-long cut under his left eye from the flying racquet of his opponent, F. Barry Ryan Jr. of the Yale Club.

BOSTON. Feb. 13. -- Colonel Frank Knox stated today as he ended his Boston visit, that he would not enter a slate of delegates in the Bay State pledged to his nomination for President. He asked, however, for Massachusetts support of his candidacy.

PARIS, Feb. 13. -- Completing the diplomatic conferences held here in recent weeks, Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin received an official visit from Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium today and concluded talks begun with Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia.
PARIS, Feb. 13. -- The French Cabinet ordered tonight the dissolution of all militant Royalist organizations in France. The decree Royalist leaders countered, "means nothing."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 13. -- President Roosevelt's name was entered in the Illinois preferential primaries today by petitions mailed to the Secretary of State here by the Cook County Democratic Chairman.

Senator VANDENBERG'S speech at the Lincoln dinner of the New York Republican Club showed that he is prepared to do two things. One is to write the Republican platform. The other is to stand upon it as a candidate for the Presidency without too violent urging being necessary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Behind closed doors, the subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Commerce now investigating the aviation safety problem, began today an inquiry into the crash near Kirksville, Mo., on May 5, 1935, in which Senator Bronson W. Cutting of New Mexico was among those killed.

OTTAWA, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits of the Dominion Government in the Bank of Canada decreased $2,230,441 in the week ended yesterday, according to the bank's weekly statement, issued today. In the same period deposits of chartered banks declined $721,087.

The downward trend of commodity prices continued in the last week. The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declining to 126.6 on Tuesday from 127.1 on the Tuesday previous. The markets were generally quieter.

John J. Leonardo, 22-year-old right-hander, who pitched for the Richmond club of the Piedmont League last year, has returned his signed contract to the Giant offices, Assistant Secretary Eddie Brannick announced yesterday.

The annual report of the Brooklyn Edison Company, Inc., for 1935 shows a net income of $10,708,475 after all deductions, equal to $8.57 a share on 1,249,039 capital shares outstanding at the year-end, compared with $10,341,929, or $8.28 a share on 1,249,270 shares in 1934.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 13. -- A great populace has descended upon Garmisch in these last days of the Winter Olympics and has utterly changed the face of things. It is no longer possible to get near any stadium where a contest is progressing without fighting through a milling crowd, most of which hasn't the slightest prospect of getting in, for all the tickets were sold out long ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Hiawatha of the Iroquois had a gangster stepbrother who "rubbed out" Hiawatha's bride, Minnehaha, and generally terrorized the tribe by methods suggestive of the Capones and Dutch Schultzes of today, the Smithsonian Institution revealed today.

Holders of Rhine-Westphalia Electric Power Corporation 7 per cent secured notes, which matured on Feb. 1, who live outside Germany, have been notified by the company of two offers of payment which have been approved by the German foreign exchange authorities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Present leadership in the air for the United States is stressed in the twenty-first annual report of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, signed by Dr. Joseph S. Ames, its chairman, transmitted by the President to Congress and made public here today.

Brokers with London connections report that a tremendous amount of business in American stocks is being handled on the London Stock Exchange. Most of the trading to date, it is indicated, has been done in the steel shares by traders anxious to profit by overnight news before the opening of the markets here.

Net profit of the Curtis Publishing Company and subsidiaries for 1935 was $5,576,779 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other deductions, according to a statement issued yesterday. This was equivalent to $6.44 a share on the 865,499 shares of $7 no-par cumulative preferred stock outstanding at the close of year.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 13. -The United States ice hockey team advanced to the final round of the Olympic competition tonight, defeating Sweden, 2 to 1, for its third straight victory in the current round-robin series.

The New York County organization slate of delegates to the Republican National Convention was announced last night by Kenneth F. Simpson, county chairman, at a meeting of the Republican County Committee, held in the public school at 214 East Forty-second Street.

President ROOSEVELT has sent letters to the heads of all the Latin-American Governments suggesting that a conference be held to consider ways of consolidating the peace which now prevails in the Western Hemisphere. This action on his part is a logical consequence of the policies pursued by the Administration in Latin-American affairs, and particularly of its reinterpretation of the Monroe Doctrine.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Secretary Swanson is in a critical condition from pleurisy at the Naval Hospital, where he was taken a week ago suffering from a fractured rib.

Marking its thirtieth anniversary, the Girls' Branch of the Public Schools Athletic League held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the home of James Speyer, 1,058 Fifth Avenue. Miss Catharine S. Leverich, president, in giving a resume of the Girls' Branch declared that thirty years ago it meant much for the girls of the East Side to get away to the organization's annual park fetes.

Resolutions urging delay in enforcement of new Federal alcohol control regulations, promotion of moderation in drinking, strict adherence to the tenets of good taste in liquor advertising and a halt on further taxation of the liquor industry were unanimously adopted yesterday at the first annual convention of the National Institute of Wine and Spirits Distributors, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Peradventure, which in recent starts had a hard time finishing better than fourth, redeemed herself today at the Santa Anita Track by winning the Belvedere Handicap for 4-year-olds and upward. The time for the mile and sixteenth on a sloppy track was 1:47 4-5.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 13. -- Over the signatures of forty Mexican Catholic Archbishops and Bishops an Episcopal letter has been addressed to brother prelates in the United States, Great Britain, Spain and Central and South America expressing thanks for their efforts to help those here who are "suffering dire persecution."
BERLIN, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Despite Germany's wide variety of taxes and network of obligatory contributions, Nazi collectors have shown marked efficiency in collections.

In this department yesterday there appeared a letter from a reader whose thoughts already are turning to Spring and trouting days. The burden of his missive was: "Why can't we have some streams near New York where the average fisherman can be reasonably assured of catching a trout or two ?"

In celebration of Mrs. Felix Warburg's sixtieth birthday anniversary and in tribute to her "dynamic leadership" in Jewish philanthropy, the New York chapter of Hadassah yesterday gave her an anniversary party in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. About 2,000 persons attended.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Marty Barry's second-period goal gave the Detroit Red Wings a 1-0 shutout over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game tonight before 8,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- A group of thirteen Senators, led by Senator Nye, decided today to oppose the compromise neutrality plan now sponsored by the administration providing for extension of the existing law, with small changes, to May 1, 1937.

A plan for the reorganization and expansion of the Bureau of Reference, Research and Statistics of the Board of Education to include a "laboratory" to analyze teaching methods and curricula was approved by the board in a resolution offered by James Marshall, Fusion member, at the board's meeting last night.

Former Governor Nathan L. Miller in a radio speech last night charged President Roosevelt with responsibility for a deliberate New Deal attempt to overthrow the Constitution and establish a new form of government alien to the American system, in defiance of his oath to defend the Constitution.

Dr. John R. Huffman of the New York A.C. employed his favorite weapon, the saber, to good advantage in retaining his national three-weapon championship last night on the Winged Poot strips. Having lost with both foil and epee to Jose R. de Capriles, he won with the third blade, 4 -- 1, for a final score of 8 to 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed in the six months from Aug. 1 to Jan. 31 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have been 2,932,092 tons, compared with 2,586,081 tons in the corresponding period a year ago.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in United States District Court, Brooklyn, signed yesterday an order confirming reorganization plans for Adolf Gobel, Inc., meat processors, of 24 Rock Street, Brooklyn. The plan provides for the payment in full of all claims against the company, which filed a petition seeking reorganization under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last April 26.

In an opinion handed down yesterday Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe ordered the General Electric Company to furnish an accounting in a damage suit brought by the Electric Machinery Manufacturing Company, which had accused General Electric of infringing on its inventions of a synchronous motor starting and control system.

John Wuest Hunt, 33 years old, who said he gave up a prosperous advertising business in Los Angeles to enter the "heaven" of Father Divine, Harlem Negro cult leader, was held without bail yesterday by Federal Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on a charge of sending to Postmaster General Farley one of 700 obscene letters described as viciously corrupt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Senate administration forces mapped plans today to turn back virtually all amendments offered to the farm bill.

A four-alarm fire destroyed a large part of the original building of Hunter College, on the old campus fronting on Park Avenue and running back toward Lexington Avenue on Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth Streets, early today. The blaze spread back through part of a newer building on Sixty-eighth Street before it was brought under control.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of securities of two companies formerly traded on the New York Curb Exchange and those of a third company now listed on the Chicago Stock Exchange. The applications were among seven ratified by the governors.
LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The city of Antwerp, Belgium, has filed on application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permanent registration of the New York Stock Exchange, of $10,000,000 of external loan sinking fund 5 per cent gold bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1928, and due on Dec. 1, 1958.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Recognition of anti-New Deal Democrats by appointment to the Cabinet in the event of Republican success in November is being seriously considered by some influential Republicans.

Three methods were used in the killing of Samuel Drukman in a garage at 225 Moore Street, Brooklyn, the night of last March 3, according to testimony given yesterday by Dr. M. Edward Marten, Deputy Chief Medical Examiner. He appeared before Justice Rogers and a jury in Supreme Court at the trial of Meyer Luckman, Harry Luckman and Fred J. Hull.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Public Service Company of Oklahoma has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement for the issuance of $16,000,000 first mortgage bonds, Series A, 4 per cent, due on Feb. 1, 1966, and $2,000,000 4 per cent serial debentures, due serially from Feb. 1, 1937, to Feb. 1, 1946, giving the underwriters and allotments as follows:

TSINGING, Kuku Nor, Tibet, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Half a million tribesmen, gathered from all parts of Tibet, Mongolia and West China amid Oriental pomp and magnificence, have paid tribute at the famed Kumbum Monastery, near here, to the Panchen Lama.
THE visitor came in, shook about a bushel of snow off his coat, surveyed his soggy hat with a gloomy air and remarked:
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13. -- The Junior League Players Committee, of which Mrs. Milton Price Harley is chairman, has issued invitations to a "Bermuda Bicycle Breakfast" (for two or more) Feb. 22.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Your editorial on the recent stamp of approval given Governor Hoffman by the executive committee of the Young Republicans of New Jersey will be carefully studied by many of us who are very definitely disturbed by the action of that body, supposedly responsible to the Young Republicans of this State in the determination of the organization's policies.

The snowstorm which swept the metropolitan area yesterday brought hardship to many districts of the city, but not to the lonely marshes off Jamaica Bay, where several hundred broadbills and black ducks slept soundly last night in the warmth of their fullest meal since the current cold snap began.

An aggregate number of 44,344 students have registered at Columbia University for the academic year 1935-36, according to figures made public yesterday by Edward J. Grant, registrar. A total of 14,732 students enrolled for the Spring session.
ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 13 (AP). -- An Ethiopian Government communique announced confirmation today of a reported recapture of Kora Ali, south of Sasa Baneh on the southern front, from the Italians.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure for the year.
OTTAWA, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Into the storm-tossed Olympic picture today stepped Thomas Langdon Church, Conservative House member for Toronto-Broadview.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13. -- Listing thirty matches leading up to the championship playoff between division winners, the 1936 schedule of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, executive secretary.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13. -- Two long shots showed the way home to the field of 3-year-olds engaged in the featured sixth race of seven furlongs at Hialeah Park today. Ceiling, 10 to 1, representing the Southland Stable, and Joseph Pepp's Paralda greeted the judges as named, three-quarters of a length apart. The Wheatley Stable's oft-disappointing Faust, the favorite, was a half length further back.

The New York Curb Exchange's committee on listing suspended yesterday dealings in the common and the $6 Class A preferred stocks of the Middle West Utilities Company on receipt of notice that transfer facilities for these issues would be discontinued at the close of business on next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Conflicting opinion of Department of Commerce authorities and subordinate officials of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection as to the latter's method of promoting public interest in the need for greater safety at sea culminated today in the suspension of Frederick L. Adams, chief investigator and special agent, and of Commander H. McCoy Jones, senior navigation officer, respectively second and third ranking executive officers of the bureau.

The first railway consolidation "deal" in recent years is being carried out by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe and the St. Louis-San Francisco railways, it was disclosed yesterday. Since 1929, much railway mileage has been abandoned but little sold. It has been distinctly a "buyer's market."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Information on the development of a new field artillery gun that outshoots the famous French 75s of World War days was in the hands of the House Appropriations Committee today.

As a lawyer examining a legal document, Mrs. Rebekah Greathouse of Washington cited flaws yesterday in the Constitution, from the woman's perspective, for members and guests of the National Woman's party. Her address at a luncheon at the Hotel Lexington was followed by adoption of resolutions on phases of the general subject of discrimination against women.

In an article captioned "Safety Campaign Pays Dividends in 1935," the Police Department's February issue of "Spring 3100" gives statistics showing that the number of fatal injuries from street accidents to children 16 years old and younger was lower than at any time in the past fourteen years.

The City College student council unanimously and "heartily" endorsed the majority report of the Associate Alumni declaring Dr. Frederick B. Robinson "unfit" to be president of the college, at a meeting yesterday, and authorized referendum among the student body to obtain a definite undergraduate opinion on the question.

BERLIN, Feb. 13. -- Improved dividend expectations further stimulated sentiment on the Boerse today, although the turnover remained small and price changes for the most part were merely fractional. Some specialties, however, were strong, Continental Linoleum gaining 2 1/2 points. German Linoleum 1 1/2. Vogel Wire 1 and Thuringian Gas 2.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nay Morris gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mr. and Mrs. Elbert F. Wilmerding, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Olmsted, Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher, Mrs. Charles Livingston Hyde, Dr. Lawrence Cole and Edward E. Irwin Martin.

Dr. DOUGLAS S. FREEMAN'S argument is hard to follow. The editor of The Richmond News-Leader began the debate by saying: "The percentage of illiteracy in the United States is directly proportionate to the support of President ROOSEVELT"
As busy a playwright as any, Helen Jerome, author of the successful "Pride and Prejudice," sails tonight on the Berengaria, and here are some notes on her manifold plays and plans:

A drive by teachers of the city for restoration of teachers' salaries to the 1932 level, preservation of full State aid for schools, and defeat of proposals for constitutional limitation on real estate taxes was started yesterday at a meeting called by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations at the Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Sixteenth Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 13. -- Eighty-three young men and women students from thirty-two colleges in the East convened this afternoon in the Jamison Auditorium at the New Jersey College for Women for a three-day session as a "model Senate."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13. -- Prince and Princess Chlodwig Hohenlohe-Schillingsfurst entertained tonight with a dinner at Las Palmas for their house guests, Mrs. F. Burrall Hoffman, who has just returned with them from a week with Mr. and Mrs. Harry Payne Bingham at their shooting box at Yemassee, S. C., and Mrs. John Gaston, who arrived today from New York.

Making his debut in the national squash tennis Class B championship, Robert Grant 3d of the Harvard Club, former metropolitan squash racquets titleholder, who has been playing squash tennis only for the past two months, survived the tourney's opening round.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York yesterday designated a special committee to study Federal legislation dealing with the merchant marine which has been introduced by Senator Copeland. A broad, new policy of Federal participation in shipping regulation is proposed and the conference, whose members represent more than 200 shippers in the metropolitan district, will seek details before throwing their support with or against the proposal.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade developed a stronger undertone today largely because of the unexpected advance yesterday in Winnipeg and Liverpool, but outside interest did not broaden to any great extent despite the large export sales of Manitobas yesterday.

" Future House," a small, modernly equipped model house that has been decorated as a garden home, will be open for public inspection from today through June 1 in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. With air-conditioning and all-electric kitchen equipment it can be built for $5,500 to $7,000 and furnished for about $1,500.
The Fordham University swimming team triumphed over St. Thomas College of Scranton, Pa., 47 -- 24, yesterday in the Maroon pool with Captain Bill Giesen and Walter Schirmer excelling for the victors.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- After setting aside $12,098,000 to pay its 1935 tax bill to Federal, State and local governments, the Commonwealth Edison closed the year with a profit of $10,274,000 for its stockholders, according to James Simpson, chairman, in the company's annual statement, which was issued tonight.

MOSCOW, Friday, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Soviet dispatches from Ulan Bator (Urga), Outer Mongolia, said today that ten Japanese-Manchukuoan soldiers were killed in Wednesday's border clash with Outer Mongolian forces.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 13. -- Charles Mathisen romped away with the 1,500meter speed skating crown in 2 minutes 19.2 seconds today, shaving 1.9 seconds off the former Olympic standard hung up by Clas Thunberg, the great Finn, in the 1928 games.
Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, defined the police as the servants of the people, in a dispute about police powers yesterday shortly after noon in Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday developed irregular price changes, as well as shifting differences between various months. Prices at the close were 4 points lower to 10 points higher. Whether a sharp break in French francs or the operations connected with the acceptance of bids on 50,000 government-financed cotton was responsible, March contracts were under pressure, while demand for the later months brought an improvement of $1 a bale in July at one time.

I beg to refer to the article published in last Sunday's edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES containing the comments of John W. White on the political situation in South America. In this article Mr. White undertakes to pass moral judgment on the governments of the leading South American countries.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Miss Anne Page, hard-driving star from the Merion Cricket Club of Philadelphia, gained her second national squash racquets title of the season today as she teamed with Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr. of Rye to defeat Miss Eileen Beresford and Mrs. Herbert Lancaster in the final match of the women's championship doubles tournament.

Five firemen were injured last night when flames which started in a restaurant at 34-40 Edgemere Avenue, Edgemere, Queens, engulfed the two-story frame and stucco building in which the eating establishment is located, damaging fourteen shops, stores and offices. Three alarms were turned in before the blaze was brought under control.

There was no speech last night at a banquet attended by 1,500 presidents of banks throughout the country, accompanied by the presidents of major industries, utilities and railroads who were their best customers.
PARIS, Feb. 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Historical errors annoy Representative Sol Bloom of New York, so he revealed today that he has enlisted the talents of Howard Chandler Christy, the artist, to set the public right about the Constitution.

TOKYO, Feb. 13. -- Yoshiyuki Kawashima, Japanese Minister of War, expressed concern today over what he termed a huge Soviet concentration of military power in the Far East, close to the borders of Manchukuo.

Funds for initial work on development of a Delaware River water supply for the city have been included in the city's capital outlay budget for 1936, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday in a letter to the State Chamber of Commerce.

The American Society of Painters, Sculptors and Gravers, seeking to establish as a general policy the payment of rent to the artist for the use of his work in certain exhibitions, announces the adoption of the following resolution:

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, appealed yesterday to Police Commissioner Valentine to help the WPA in curbing demonstrations against relief agencies in this city staged by Communists and other agitators under the guise of protests by WPA workers.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- The presence of Mrs. Roosevelt and Governor Lehman helped to attract a record attendance to Cornell's Farm and Home Week today.

Most commodity futures were slightly higher in light trading on the local markets yesterday. Coffee, sugar and cottonseed oil were easier. On the cash markets cotton and Straits tin were lower, while gains were made by the grains, butter, eggs, standard tin, silk, rubber and cocoa.

The continued cold weather has given us an opportunity to add one more activity for the 2,600 boys from tenement homes of the district east of Grand Central who are members of the Kips Bay Boys Club. The open-air playroof has been flooded, and afternoons and evenings the boys are enjoying ice skating there.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The stock markets here were irregular today on profit-taking, although the undertone remained firm, with the internationals and some of the home industrials continuing in active demand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee was asked by the American Federation of Hosiery Workers today to investigate reports of interference by Federal district courts in the attempt of the National Labor Relations Board to look into complaints made by workers against employers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Adequate military and naval preparedness was urged by General Malin Craig, chief of staff of the army, in a radio address over the National Broadcasting System tonight in connection with National Defense Week.

Politicians who have been bombarding the American public lately with radio speeches on current problems and the issues of the coming Presidential campaign, had the tables turned on them last night at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.
PARIS, Feb. 13. -- Paris was plunged once more into a high state of political fever tonight as a result of an assault on the Socialist leader, Leon Blum, by members of the Royalist Action Francaise.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- A radio address from England by Lady Astor and a program covering a wide range of subjects in social welfare, education and peace marked the opening today of the Third Annual Women's Congress. Seven thousand women, many from far away States, are attending the two-day convention, which is being held under the sponsorship of The Chicago Tribune.

Boris Lyman, 62 years old, who has conducted a jewelry store in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn for more than thirty-five years, was shot dead at about 7:30 o'clock last night as he frustrated an attempt of two men to rob his shop at 288 Saratoga Avenue, three doors from the corner of Pacific Street.

TRENTON, Feb. 13. -- Samuel Leibowitz, New York attorney, began a series of talks today with Bruno Richard Hauptmann by which he hopes to obtain "the truth" from the convicted kidnap-murderer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Connecticut River Power Company, a subsidiary of the New England Power Association, a registered holding company, was exempted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission from making a declaration under Section 6 (a) of Title I of the Public Utility Act of 1935, for the issuance of $20,300,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series A, sinking fund, due Feb. 15, 1961, and 3,440 shares of $25 par common stock.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, sailing tonight for Cherbourg and Southampton, will have among her passengers John Murray Anderson, theatrical producer; Lady Tennyson, Sir Alfred and Lady Booth and S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- In a five-hour session marked by turbulent debate and angry interchanges among some members, the $543,000,000 War Department Supply Bill moved slowly forward today.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers submitted the highest bid yesterday for a new issue of $20,300,000 of Connecticut River Power Company's first mortgage 33/4 per cent sinking fund bonds, Series A, due on Feb. 15, 1961. They offered a price of 103.279.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- President Roosevelt held a conference on housing, after which Senator Wagner announced that the President was determined to put through a $300,000,000 to $400.000,000 long range program of slum clearance and low-cost housing at the present Congressional session.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 4 per cent for the week ended Feb. 8, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase is slightly smaller than for the preceding week, when the deliveries rose 5 per cent.

New York's snow-fighting army of more than 23,000 men, wearied with three weeks of unceasing work on the city's glacial crust, threw down the pick-axes and the drills yesterday and picked up shovels to clear the streets of the new snowfall.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13. -- Two scientific expeditions were preparing here today to seek ocean secrets. Captain C. Allan Hancock of this city will head an annual cruise on the Velero III. Harry H. Hunnewell of Boston will lead the other expedition as skipper of the 136-foot schooner yacht Invader.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Showing a steady increase, Treasury silver stocks on last Tuesday amounted to 21.8 per cent of the volume of monetary gold, it was revealed today. The monetary value of silver stocks on that day was $2,118,600,000, on the basis of the Treasury daily statement for Feb. 11, as compared with $10,154,460,467 for gold.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 14. -- Messages from Hsinking to the newspaper Asahi declare that the Russian Consul General has begun preparations to withdraw all Soviet citizens. This action follows increased tension resulting from recent Russo-Japanese border clashes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (AP). -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company announced today it will ask the stockholders at the annual meeting on April 14 to authorize a $75,000,000 increase in the company's indebtedness.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Preston Delano, governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, said tonight the protection afforded by Federal agencies should prevent a recurrence of a collpase like that of 1929.

In analyzing the achievements and potentialities of the motion picture industry, the Rev. Dr. Joseph A. Daly, Professor of Psychology at the College of Mount St. Vincent and executive secretary of the Legion of Decency, emphasized yesterday that "decency means dollars and dirt deficits."

LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Deaths from blizzards, gales and cold may exceed 200 in Europe and the Near East, it was feared tonight, after milder conditions enabled a partial restoration of transportation and communication systems.

Ground-breaking ceremonies to mark the beginning of construction work on the Sixth Avenue section of the municipal subway system will be held on March 23, it was decided yesterday by the contractors and the Board of Transportation.

The Alexander Hamilton basketball team triumphed over Boys High, 40 to 24, yesterday in a Brooklyn Division P.S.A.L. game on the latter's court. The victors led throughout and enjoyed a 32-17 advantage at half time.

The Brooklyn Bar Association endorsed last night twenty of Governor Lehman's thirty-four anti-crime bills, after hearing a report by F.R. Serri, chairman of its committee on criminal law and procedure. The report recommended that "reformers" concentrate their attention on how to improve the personnel charged with the administration of justice, from police to judges, and how to "minimize the competitive chaos or anarchy in which business breeds racketeering."

A retired textile manufacturer of Germantown, Pa., Caleb Jones Milne 2d, appeared yesterday before a Federal grand jury as an unwilling witness against his grandson, Caleb Jones Milne 4th, whose ambition to get a job on the stage caused him to pretend that he had been kidnapped last Dec. 15.
Investors maintained their interest in Bronx realty yesterday when they purchased more apartment properties there.

The transfer of the function of fire prevention from the Fire Department to the Building Department by the Legislature in 1933 was indirectly responsible, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott charged yesterday, for the loss of six lives and the injury of thirty-nine persons Wednesday evening in Lum's Chinese Restaurant at 735 Lexington Avenue, on the southeast corner of Fifty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The report of League of Nations experts that an oil embargo against Italy would be effective only if supplies from the United States were cut off, coming from Geneva simultaneously with a report from Washington that the proposed neutrality law is dead, brings back to European powers, not excepting Great Britain, their favorite old bogy of non-cooperation by America.

Foreign exchanges broke sharply in terms of the dollar yesterday, continuing their reaction from the recent rise that carried the franc above gold export point and the pound sterling well above $5. Yesterday's decline was speeded by the threat of political difficulties in France following the assault on Leon Blum, the Socialist leader, by Royalists.

Resumption of trading in the markets here yesterday after the holiday interval was characterized, in the main, by a hesitant attitude. True, the share market began in lively fashion, with prices fractionally higher than they had been on Tuesday; railway and steel issues and a few of the communications, notably American Telephone and Telegraph, were in brisk demand early. Subsequently, not a little profit-taking was encountered and the progress from then on was irregular.

Certified copies of a warrant accusing Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt of mayhem in connection with a sterilization operation on her daughter, Ann Cooper Hewitt, 21 years old, reached New York Police Headquarters yesterday by air mail from San Francisco.

Samuel Duff McCoy, author and newspaper man, who has been discharged as director of the Federal writers' project here, sent a telegram yesterday to Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA Administrator, protesting against his summary dismissal and demanding a hearing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Instead of "Ethiopia," which was banned because of official fear that it would offend the sensibilities of foreign governments, "The Living Newspaper" section of the Federal Theatre Project in New York plans to present a skit on American agriculture, Jacob Baker, Assistant WPA Administrator, declared today.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday were larger than in the corresponding week last year, but were affected adversely by the holiday on Wednesday, which was observed in most of the cities reporting, thus reducing the impressive gains that had been registered this year.

Magistrate Brodsky, in Tombs Court yesterday, dismissed an assault charge against Joseph E. Solomon of 3,036 Bailey Avenue, the Bronx, a school teacher for eighteen years, who was accused of striking a 13-year-old pupil in Public School 65, Forsyth and Eldridge Streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Contracts made by the Columbia Pictures Corporation for remuneration of some of its executives were among the data filed as confidential that were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The new challenge to the Supreme Court by Senator Norris has stimulated other Senators to demand passage of some of the forty proposals affecting the court which are pending in Congress.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Two bills transferring the Bureau of Combustibles from the Department of Buildings to the Fire Department in New York City were passed today by the Senate. They are sponsored by Senator Mandelbaum, New York Democrat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- An active demand for securities of municipalities, counties and districts of States was shown today by the prices quoted on fifty-four such issues, bids on which were opened by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Mr. Toscanini revealed a short work of astonishing originality, spontaneity of expression and delight to the audience that attended the Philharmonic-Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall. This was the fourth of Antonio Vivaldi's cycle of concerti for strings, cembalo and organ, representative of the four seasons.

The threat of a strike of 105,000 dressmakers which has been hanging over the city for several weeks was definitely ended yesterday by agreements between employers and employes to be signed today or tomorrow at City Hall in the presence of Mayor La Guardia, whose repeated interventions in the situation averted the walkout.

LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- What were described as French efforts to link Europe's old political disputes to discussions of the four-power naval conference met a sharp rebuff today from the United States.
Edgar Kobak Will join the staff of the New York office of Lord Thomas as a vice president shortly after March 1, the agency announced yesterday.

Arturo Toscanini will not return to the leadership of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next year. The board of directors made this announcement last night "with regret." The great Italian conductor, who will be 69 years old next month, will conduct his last performance here on April 26.

The Music Education League has announced its program of contests and auditions for the current season. The league disclosed that registration in the contests is not limited to residents of Greater New York and that during the last twelve years approximately 200,000 persons have participated in the contests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Federal assistance to the aged, to the blind and to dependent children became a reality today, forty-eight hours after President Roosevelt had signed the Deficiency Appropriation Act which included the first Congressional appropriation to the Social Security Board.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Utility rate reductions totaling more than $100,000,000 have been achieved for New York consumers in the past five years, the Public Service Commission will say in its annual report, which will be submitted soon to the Governor and the Legislature.

While the fatal restaurant fire is being investigated, as it should be, it is comforting to read Commissioner MCELLIGOTT'S latest report, which reveals that the department has this fearful menace under better control today than ever before in the city's history. The statistics clearly prove this.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13. -- The new official Dartmouth song, "The Wearers of the Green," will be sung at the dedication of Dartmouth Hall at Hanover tomorrow. It was written by George Parmly Day, treasurer of Yale and a descendant of Eleazar Wheelock, the Yale graduate who founded Dartmouth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Lambs Club of New York may consider its social features as of a minor nature, but the government today asserted that those aspects of the organization "are not merely incidental but constitute an essential element in the club's life and a material factor in its continued existence."

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- An increase in revenues in the Secretary of State's office for the first time in six years, shown in his annual report for 1935, was submitted to the Legislature today. This increase is accepted here as reflecting a general improvement in business.

It is reported from Montreal by way of London that two scientists of that city, having spent some weeks in the study of health conditions among the Eskimos in the Eastern Arctic regions, discovered that tuberculosis is rapidly increasing among them, but that it is through contact with white men.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed transfer of the membership of Leonard Schafer to Dudley M. Cooper for $173,000, and confirmed the sale of the seat of the late W. Strother Jones to Nathaniel S. Howe and that of Hervey C. Lawder to James F. Cooke.

There is much argument on both sides as to the so-called moratorium for those sections of the Dwellings Law which require a toilet on the inside of every apartment as well as fire-stopping in the hails.
Two Princeton Club players, John K. Weeks and Ivy Lee Jr., will meet this afternoon in the final round of the Class B championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Harvard Club.
Sports lovers should be more interested than usually is the case in legislation which frequently gets on statute books by pressure of minority groups with special interests.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 14. -- The annual play by the Dramatic Association of St. George's School was given tonight. The dance of the sixth form will be tomorrow night's feature of the midwinter festivities.

The city's first school in which pupils of high school grade will major in art and music, the High School of Art and Music, at St. Nicholas Terrace and 135th Street, in the building formerly occupied by the New York Training School for Teachers, was dedicated yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia and members of the Board of Education.

Fifteen cash prizes totaling $4,250 and two medals will be awarded in the 111th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design, scheduled to open to the public on March 18 in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, it was announced yesterday by Jonas Lie, president.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association recently voted to revive, after a long lapse, the national interscholastic championship tournament, which, with the intercollegiate championships, will make a program in the schools and colleges that will create an incentive and high standard of play among the schools such as we never have had on a national scale.

Mayor La Guardia submitted the city's first capital outlay budget, aggregating $89,991,150, to the Board of Estimate yesterday with a message saying that not more than $35,967,000 of the budget would be spent this year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Two students who, on the night of Jan. 24, turned in twenty-nine false fire alarms and had the Fire Department and police going "round and round" during a sleet storm, received a suspended sentence for one alarm, gave personal bond for six, and won dismissals on the other twenty-two counts through the action of a police court justice yesterday, it became known today.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Elmer B. O'Hara, chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, and State Senator A.J. Wilkowski were sentenced by Judge W. McKay Skillman today to serve from four o five years in the State prison of Southern Michigan for their part in a vote recount fraud.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14. -- The Chaco peace conference recessed for an indefinite period today after appointing an executive committee to consider any matters that might come up during the recess. The conference can be called together again by its president, Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina, whenever he thinks it desirable or upon the request of any delegation.
Contracts of sale on town houses in the upper East and West Side areas of Manhattan provided the transactions of chief interest in yesterday's realty trading.

Quotations on the foreign exchange market experienced another abrupt reversal yesterday as a fresh wave of inflation talk cropped out in Washington and Wall Street. Renewing his drive for inflation, Representative Patman of Texas filed a petition to put before the House his plan to pay the veterans' bonus in currency.

Textile High School's tossers, 1935 city champions, sustained their initial setback in the Manhattan Division of the P.S.A.L. tournament yesterday. They were upset by the Franklin representatives, 21 -- 17, on the Public School 99 court. Close guarding marked the game, the score being 7 -- all at the intermission.

In a decision strengthening the control of Park Commissioner Robert Moses over concessions in Central Park, the Appellate Division voted unanimously yesterday to uphold the ruling of Supreme Court Justice Dore dismissing a suit by the Dieppe Corporation, which operated Central Park Casino, to restrain the commissioner from evicting the restaurant.

The oral agreement reached on Thursday by the Dressmakers Union and the five different manufacturing groups, averting a strike of 105,000 workers in the dress industry in the metropolitan area, was put in writing and signed by four of the five employer associations yesterday, it was announced by the union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The radio address of Secretary Hull to the Woman Congress Forum at Chicago was as follows:
A resolution against participation in the art exhibition in Germany to be held in concurrence with the 1936 Olympic Games was adopted last night at the American Artists' Congress in Town Hall.

From the lips of a frightened garage employe came testimony yesterday that Meyer and Harry Luckman called less than two hours before Samuel Drukman's death for the automobile in which his battered and strangled body was found crammed in the rear compartment.

The new epigrammatic touch in Mr. HOOVER'S speeches was more prominent than ever in his Lincoln Day address. But if a respectful suggestion is in order, it might be pointed out that there is serious danger of the epigrams being overdone.

New Utrecht High's sextet retained its hold on first place in the Metropolitan Interscholastic Hockey League by recording a 2-1 victory over Poly Prep in one of the two circuit clashes played last night on the Brooklyn Ice Palace Rink.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- The Vassar chapter of the American Association of University Professors today adopted a resolution urging repeal of the Ives Law, which requires an "oath of allegiance" from teachers.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- Bishop Clemens von Galen of Muenster, hitherto unpublished reports disclosed tonight, strongly denounced what he called the present persecution of the Catholic church in a sermon at Xanten, in the Rhineland.

PARIS, Feb. 14. -- Premier Paul Van Zeeland after a conference with Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin today returned to Brussels with some tangible assurances of French cooperation. On arriving he did not conceal that there were some clouds he would like to see dissipated and he submitted several questions for settlement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Resumption and continuation of Federal aid to the States to meet relief needs unprovided for in the Works Progress Administration and other divisions of the American Social Security Program were represented as an imperative necessity by delegates from twenty-five States to the Conference of the American Association of Social Workers, which opened a three-day session here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The assertion that the Senate lobby committee "has no power to compel answers to questionnaires" sent to members of the American Liberty League was made today by the executive committee of the league.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 14. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann's thirty-day reprieve will expire tomorrow. Next week Justice Thomas W. Trenchard will be asked to fix a new date for execution, which cannot be earlier than the week beginning March 17 or later than four weeks after that.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- Governor Lehman declared that "the outlook for farming and farmers is better both socially and economically than it has ever been before," at the closing exercises of Cornell's annual farm and home week today.

In spite of the howling elements, which have given to nocturnal gadding these past few weeks a faint resemblance to carrying relief to Nome, the more hardy trappers hang on -- even bait their gums with fresh lures to coax the hungry wanderers out of the storm.

Reports were current yesterday that the Treasury may take some "unusual" steps affecting the public debt, including, perhaps, the use of gold and silver "profits" to retire a portion of the debt. There is available for such use only about $429,000,000 of "profits," apart from the $1,800,000,000 still ear-marked for the use of the stabilization fund.

Rallying in the fourth quarter, the St. John's Prep quintet vanquished Cathedral Prep, 22 -- 20, yesterday on the latter's court to gain an exclusive hold on first place in the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. championship tournament. Prior to the battle the teams were tied for the lead, each having captured nine out of ten contests.

In an editorial "Against Sterilization" in your issue of Jan. 26 you made the statement: "Like the British Departmental Committee on Sterilization, this group of psychiatrists decides that * * * sterilization is scientifically justified only in a few rare, selected cases."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Sharp discussion on the question of restricting the powers of the Supreme Court marked the Senate debate today as the administration's farm bill moved toward a vote, now expected tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Harry F. Guggenheim, former Ambassador to Cuba and for years a leader in the development of aviation in this country, told the Senate Committee on Commerce today that in his opinion the interests of American aviation would be better served if the Federal agencies concentrated on working out proper regulatory measures.

Federal Judge Francis J. Caffey refused yesterday to grant the application of the National Exhibition Company, owners of the New York Giants, for an injunction to restrain The Morning Telegraph, The Morning Telegraph Sports News, Inc., and the New York Telephone Company from reporting baseball games at the Polo Grounds over a "teleflash" system reaching billiard parlors and restaurants.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The new army Conscription Law and the recently promulgated regulations for mustering German nationals abroad definitely put new duties on Germans of military age everywhere, from which even the subsequent acquisition of citizenship of another State cannot absolve them, according to juridical experts of both the Foreign Office and the War Ministry.

Public offering of the new issue of $20,300,000 of Connecticut River Power Company first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent Series A bonds, due on Feb. 15, 1961, and which were formally awarded yesterday to a banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers, is expected to be made on next Tuesday.

Recently many of my golfing friends have asked me: "How serious are the golf officials in their warning to the rank and file golfer that he should stop filling commodious golf bags with various and sundry types of clubs -- to say nothing of the full matched sets?"

TOKYO, Feb. 14. -- Soviet Russia's new policy of hitting back, instead of sending diplomatic notes, is evident in the latest frontier incidents. It is supported by complete confidence not only in the Soviet Far Eastern Army but in the steel and concrete fortifications near the Manchukuoan border and the small but growing submarine fleet at Vladivostok.
The city and the nation experienced some of the worst of the vagaries of Winter weather yesterday.

Contests for Borah delegates to the Republican National Convention have been assured in at least half the Manhattan Congressional districts as a result of the selections on the party organization slate, W. Kingsland Macy, former State Chairman, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Secretary Swanson's relatives expressed hope today that the navy leader's "rugged constitution" would pull him through the pleurisy attack for which he is under continuous treatment at the Naval Hospital here.

It is evident from the Washington dispatches that the Administration's housing program is still the focus of sharply contending forces. The welfare workers, the Mayors and the zealous advocates of Federal largess have been urging a policy of open-handed Federal grants for both slum-clearance and low-cost housing generally.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Sharply criticized for their action by the National Committee on Safety at Sea, Commerce Department authorities today decided to postpone decision on the fate of Frederick L. Adams, chief investigator and special agent, and H. McCoy Jones, senior navigation officer of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection, who yesterday were suspended from the service on grounds of insubordination.

Plans for the burial of Professor Constant B. Kubicki, 71-year-old linguist and piano teacher who died last Sunday at 74 East 109th Street and whose body was removed to the Bellevue morgue, were taken over yesterday by a committee made up of his former pupils and friends.

The retirement of Paul V. Mravlag from Vilas Hiekey and of Peter H. Troy from Abbott, Proctor Paine was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Troy will become a partner in Eastman, Dillon Co., while George Gund will become a special partner in Abbott, Proctor Paine.

ANY running comment on the New York A.C. program for this evening must be offered on a when-as-and-if basis, what with the state of the roads and the prevalence of coughing spells that may stop some of the athletes short of the starting mark at Madison Square Garden. With that proviso understood, the speculation in this corner might be -- in fact, will be -- set down as follows and to wit:

The completion of negotiations between the board of directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York and the Musicians Union for the season of 1936-37 was announced yesterday by the society. The principal point in the agreement provides for a twenty-four-week concert schedule next season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- An appropriation of $1,746,000,000 to pay the bonus was asked in the Senate today, with word from an administration spokesman that it would not require new taxes, as a fresh inflation threat developed in the House.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Opposition to playing the Army-Navy football game in the East every year developed in Congress again today with Representative Cochran, Democrat, of Missouri, urging that Westerners be given a look at the annual spectacle.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- Dexter Sears mushed to first place today in the first lap of the two-day dog race staged By the New York Sled Dog Club, driving the team of huskies owned by Dr. F.J. D'Avignon of Lake Placid. He was clocked in 1:48:05 for the thirteen-mile course, made slow by a heavy snowfall last night.

Their hands clasped together, Martha Weickers, 38 years old, and her sister, Clara, 40, were found dead of illuminating gas poisoning at 10 o'clock last night on the kitchen floor of their apartment on the third floor of 173 West 188th Street, a fashionable section of the West Bronx. The police said it was a suicide pact.

Following the fire which destroyed the interior of the main building of Hunter College early yesterday morning, officials of the institution planned to resume on Monday, in armories or some other temporary quarters, the classes of more than 3,000 day and 4,000 evening students which were interrupted by the blaze.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 14. -- The Olympic hockey tourney, which started with fifteen nations, of which four are left, has become a Frankenstein. If the purpose of the Olympic events is to further international friendship through sports, as the Olympic propagandists claim, then the hockey tourney has failed badly in its mission.

Those of us who have warm homes and warm clothing cannot afford to forget that the continued severe cold weather has brought great suffering to those whose food and clothing are always insufficient. The directors of our seven children's centers in tenement neighborhoods report that more children are coming in with thin, ragged and insufficient clothing than at any time during the depression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Reports of a conversation alleged to have been overheard in the lobby of the Willard Hotel here to the effect that members of the Federal Communications Commission could be "bought or controlled" were held to be without foundation in a report by the agency following an investigation of the incident.

Drew Pearson and Robert S. Allen, authors of "Washington Merry-Go-Round," have just signed a contract with Reynal Hitchcock to write a new book on the Supreme Court. The title will be "The Nine Old Men," and it is hoped to publish the book early in April.

Figures showing that there are four times as many cures among intelligent cancer patients as among the less intelligent class were given yesterday by Dr. Francis Carter Wood, cancer authority of Columbia University, during the annual Bulkley Lecture at the New York Academy of Medicine.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 14. -- Captain Marius Brophil, an Irish Red Cross representative, said today that 20,000 Italian soldiers had been "surrounded" in a huge battle recently on the northern front and "had no chance to come out alive."

In these days of "dissenting opinions" I hope you will accord me the privilege of expressing a few observations that occurred to me upon reading Mr. Chamberlain's review of my book on the work of the Supreme Court, entitled "Nine Honest Men."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The Kingdom of Greece has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $11,000,000 of 7 per cent refugee loan bonds of 1924, due on Nov. 1, 1964, and $17,000,000 of 6 per cent stabilization and refugee loan bonds of 1928, due on Feb. 1, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14, -- The International Seamen's Union acted today to protect itself against "subversive propaganda" and curb the power in its Pacific Coast organization of Harry Bridges, radical longshoremen's leader.
New York University's varsity swimming team conquered its third straight opponent yesterday when it turned back the Lafayette combination, 43 to 25, in the Park Central Hotel pool.
Two of the leading indoor players of Europe will take part in the national indoor tennis championships starting at the Seventh Regiment Armory in this city on Feb. 29.

John Harlan Amen, former Deputy United States Attorney General, presented his credentials yesterday to the clerk of the Federal court in the Southern District of New York and became a Special Assistant Attorney General, charged with prosecuting business rackets under the new anti-racketeering act which supplements the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The fact that profits in the first quarter of this year will be considerably above last year "places on workers the obligation to demand higher wages if the balance between producing and consuming power is ever to be restored," says the monthly survey of business issued today by the American Federation of Labor.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 14. -- Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee, national P.G.A. champion and leading money winner of 1935, took the lead in the $3,000 Thomasville open tournament today with a sub-par 69 for the first round of the seventy-two-hole event.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 15. -The Soviet Government yesterday ordered its consulate at Mukden, Manchukuo, closed, but an official spokesman declined to connect the order with recent clashes between Japanese-Manchukuoan and Soviet troops on the Outer Mongolian frontier.
Baseball Hall of Fame! But what is fame? It seems to me that it is the sort of knowledge that spreads outside of the circle in which a man moves.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14.Mr. and Mrs. Paulding Fosdick gave a dinner and bridge tonight at I1 Torte ]3lance. Those present were :Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice, -%r. and Airs, Austen Gray, Mr. and Mrs. Beverley m Bogert, Mrs. Edgar A. Bryan, Mrs. Seton Porter, Miss Margaret Stewart, Charles West, T. Chesley Richardson and Herman C. Huffer.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

LONDON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Blizzard death tolls in Europe and the Near East mounted to almost 300 tonight as severe cold continued unabated in Bulgaria and Rumania but softened to warmer weather elsewhere.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, in accordance with the consent decree of Jan. 29 terminating the anti-trust suit against it and others, has agreed with the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation upon an immediate recapitalization of the latter which will result in the dissolution of the voting trust under which its common stock is now deposited, Philip G. Gossler, president, said yesterday in his quarterly letter to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Lumber consumption during the first quarter of 1936 is estimated at nearly 4,900,000,000 feet, or at the rate of 20,000,000,000 feet for the year, with consideration to seasonal trends, in a report presented to the Department of Commerce by the special Lumber Survey Committee of the Timber Conservation Board.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 14. -- Senator Lonergan has offered an amendment to the pending Water Carriers Bill which would prevent boycotting, especially by foreign-owned lines, of Federally improved ports. He explained that ports in Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Jersey, Delaware, North Carolina, Texas, California, Oregon and Washington vould be affected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- To give added security to the banking system, proceedings have been instituted by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, for the elimination of from fifty to sixty unsound banks in five States, it was made known today.

Auctioneers held fifteen foreclosure sales of Manhattan real estate yesterday. The State Mortgage Commission acted as plaintiff in three of the sales, taking over a nine-story apartment house in West Eighty-second Street, three tenements on First Avenue and a Thompson Street corner.

D'ARCY M'NICKLE'S novel of Indian life in Western Montana, "The Surrounded" (Dodd, Mead, $2), is the old story of the generation that is caught between two worlds, "one dead, the other powerless to be born." It is also the story of two bloods at war in one man, for young Archilde Leon is the son of a Spanish father and a Salish, or Flathead, mother.

A bronze portrait bust of Elihu Root, who will observe his ninety-first birthday today, was presented yesterday to the Council on Foreign Relations, of which he is honorary president, by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, of which he is chairman of the board of trustees.
Don't you think it is a gross error for the Olympic Basketball Commitee to set up as part of its elimination tournament the strange course it intends to pursue for District I?

With their old rivalry assuming added luster, Glen Cunningham and Gene Venzke will toe the mark in the Baxter Mile tonight, feature attraction of the oldest of all indoor track and field meets, the New York A.C. carnival at Madison Square Garden.

Special contributions on Feb. 23 for diocesan high schools from churches of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn are asked by the Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the diocese, in a letter to the pastors.

The transatlantic passenger conference announced yesterday the new detailed rate schedules of passenger ships operating in the North Atlantic, revised by the principals of the conference at their meeting in Paris last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The administration's housing plans became enveloped in confusion today as President Roosevelt minimized the suggestion that a long-range program had been agreed upon and opposition began to mount within administrative circles to any substantial Federal participation in financing low-cost dwelling and slum-clearance projects.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday under the lead of the March position and closed with a net gain of 5 to 12 points. Reports that the pool manager had signified his intention of taking up actual cotton on 178,000 March contracts unless relations between contracts and spot quotations were satisfactory had a strengthening influence on the near month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Over the opposition of government officials the Senate Agriculture Committee today approved the Smith bill directing the sale of about 5,000,000 bales of government-owned cotton in weekly blocks of between 20,000 and 25,000 bales.
The State Athletic Commission yesterday went on record against a plan of Madison Square Garden to conduct what amounts to a lightweight championship elimination series without the board's approval.

CRYSTAL FALLS, Mich., Feb. 14. -- The right of President Roosevelt to "wrap himself in the mantle" of Josiah Royce, the philosopher from whose writings the President quoted in his last message to Congress, was disputed by Stephen Royce, the philosopher's son, here tonight.

RENO, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Mrs. Nancy Evelyn Gordon obtained a divorce today from Leon Gordon, Hollywood playwright, scenarist and actor. She charged cruelty. They were married May 7, 1928, in Melbourne, Australia.

John Toncoff, 22, 5 feet 10 inches, weight 175 and a right-handed hitter, was signed as a catcher by the Giants yesterday. No reason to add in the statistics that he's a right-handed thrower. They don't have southpaw catchers any more.

The Pratt Institute basketball team defeated the Brooklyn Poly quintet, 39 -- 27, at the Odd Fellows Hall last night. The victors led throughout, holding a 27-8 lead at the half. John Mardy led the scorers with 14 points.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Estimating that annual contributions to the Townsend plan organization ran as high as $1,200,000, Representative Bell, Democrat, of Missouri, today asked the House Rules Committee to report a resolution to investigate promoters of the plan.

A 14-year-old boy, who has been on the rolls of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, as Robert Doe, Charles Osborne and Robert Carr of 122 North Dewey Street, North Philadelphia, has been "positively" identified as the latter, according to officials of the institutions.

Strrett Brothers Eken, nc., cons:ruction, has moved its executiv offices from the Empire State Building, 350 Fifth Avenue, to the thirty-five-story Wall and Hanover Building at 63 Wall Street, where the irm has leased 10,000 square feet.

Retail distribution was adversely affected this week by fresh snows and low temperatures, sales in most sections failing to rise above the volume of the week preceding, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The spread over the 1935 comparatives also was narrowed, the agency says, the estimated increase for the country as a whole amounting to not more than 2 to 8 per cent.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 14. -- Police killed at least five persons as mobs rioted today in this Venezuelan capital in protest against a decree establishing a press censorship.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP). -- To the accompaniment of boos, Jack Dempsey scored, by remote control, a smashing triumph over his one-time manager, Jack Kearns, in the Chicago Stadium ring tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- House advocates of strict neutrality formed their lines today to oppose the leaders' plan to put through on Monday the extension of the existing Neutrality Law, which expires Feb. 29.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

A census of the physically fit among the 6,000 former members of the Police Department now on the retired list has been ordered by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, it was learned yesterday, as a step to the organization of the city's first reserve police force.

Mrs. Edith B. Riker, widow of John J. Riker, realty owner, left an estate appraised yesterday at $2,978,881, the bulk of which was inherited from her husband, who died in 1932. Mrs. Riker left her residuary estate to her niece, Alice Kimball of Newton Center, Mass., and the Bethlehem Day Nursery, the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, the Church of the Epiphany and Roosevelt Hospital.

Revision of the limits of the Hudson River south anchorage to facilitate the movement of large passenger ships to and from the new municipal piers north of Fortieth Street was urged yesterday by port groups and ship lines at a hearing before Lieut. Col. John W.N. Schulz, at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The New York Central Railroad was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to postpone until July 1, 191, a total of $9,478,737 of loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation falling due on several dates this year, and to withdraw from pledge with the corporation securities worth $50,000,000 through the substitution of other collateral.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14. -- The newspaper Pravda's recent attack upon Nikolai Bukharin was replied to today by the chief editor of Izvestia in an article over his own signature in that newspaper. The article is both a repudiation of the views attributed to him by Pravda and an apology for using phrases which could be misconstrued.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14. -- Twelve were named today as probable starters in tomorrow's Winter racing classic for 3-year-olds, the $25,000 added Santa Anita Derby.
Irving Fitch, Rochester commentator on outdoor activities, advises us that considerable opposition to the plan to fix simultaneous seasons on deer and grouse has developed among up-State gunners.

The market for new State and municipal financing will have another "breathing spell" next week when a total of only $10,684,675 in new issues are scheduled for award by fifty-eight municipalities. This compares with a revised total of $59,572,401 for this week.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 14. -- Austria's brilliant figure skater, Karl Schafer, successfully defended his Olympic crown in the singles today.

The Federal Relief Administrator's office in Washington yesterday invited Samuel Duff McCoy, author and newspaper man, to submit specific details of his charge that he was dismissed as director of the Federal writers' project here because of his opposition to Communist elements who sought to obtain control of the project.

Plan for seeking the passage of eight amendments to the New York State liquor regulations were discussed yesterday by restaurant owners representing twenty-two associations throughout the State which are affiliated with the Central Council Restaurant and Liquor Dealers' Association, Inc.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- The statement that recovery in world economic conditions and peace among all countries are dependent upon a revival of international trade and the discarding of "impracticable" theories of national self-containment and self-sufficiency, was made by Secretary Hull, in an address over the radio tonight to the annual Woman Congress in session here.

About 400 persons, including representatives of Jewish religious and philanthropic organizations, were present at funeral services for Peter Wiernik, editor of The Jewish Morning Journal, yesterday morning at Congregation Chorevey Torah, 885 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- Arrivals of only 6,000 hogs here today were less than half of what the trade expected, but despite the small supply there was only a fair demand. Sales were steady to 15 cents a hundredweight higher. The top price was lifted 15 cents to $11.15, and equaled the best figure since early in October, while the day's average was 5 cents higher at $10.80.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 14. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made a plea for privacy during a stop in Syracuse today, while waiting for a train to take her to her home in Hyde Park.

Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, accused Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott yesterday afternoon of "a cowardly and dishonorable" political attack on the Building Department in his published statements concerning the fire Wednesday night in Lum's Chinese Restaurant, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, in which six lives were lost and thirty-nine persons injured.
John Kieran's column today regarding Nap Lajoie and Eddie Collins gives me a pain. Why all this bunk about Collins being the brainiest ball player of his time.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14. -- Dmitri Shostakovitch officially went into eclipse today as the Soviet Union's favorite living composer. His ballet, "Limpid Stream," or "Sparkling Brook," as the Russian is sometimes translated, was removed from the repertory of the Bolshoi Theatre amid a barrage of hostile criticism of his works.

A resumption of activity in the field of State and municipal financing lifted the total of new bond offerings placed on the market this week to $25,878,000. The State and municipal loans accounted for $20,587,000 of the total. Last week $11,516,000 in new bond issues were marketed, and only $5,537,000 in the week last year corresponding with the current one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The bill prepared by the Securities and Exchange Commission to extend the deadline for trading in unliste securities on National Securities Exchanges beyond the present limit of June 1, and to permit, at the discretion of the commission, more extensive trading of this type in certain circumstances, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Fletcher, chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee, and referred to that committee.

The Department of Parks dismissed seventy WPA workers yesterday when they refused to work because they maintained the sleet might impair their health. The seventy workers were engaged in shoveling snow from the walks in the Heckscher Playground and on the Mall in Central Park.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Employes added to government payrolls in two years were reported by the Civil Service Commission today to number 211,078, a jump of nearly 35 per cent.
