The committee of the Dramatists Guild met that of the League of New York Theatres in the latter's rooms yesterday afternoon and discussed the purposed new minimum basic agreement. Eighteen persons were present and it was informal; every one, and very genial about it, reported progress.

ATLANTA, Feb., 14 (AP) -- Acting chiefs took over the police and detective forces here today after municipal authorities announced suspension of the regular department heads. This was "just the beginning,'' the announcement said, of a shake-up precipitated by an investigation into local rackets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Experimental airplane flights will be undertaken over the Azores route immediately by Germany looking to regular transatlantic service with the United States under an agreement reached tonight after a week of discussions by a German mission and the Interdepartmental Committee of Civil International Aviation of this country.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- The House of Commons was startled today when Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin was sharply criticized for his confessed blunders by Sir Austen Chamberlain, his former Foreign Secretary and brother of Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
The first railroad to report earnings for January, the Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, showed a decreased loss for the month. Its statement follows:

Suffering from strain and overwork, chiefly in connection with the threatened strike of 20,000 elevator operators and other service employes in buildings of the garment and fur districts, James J. Bambrick, president of the Building Service Employes Union, was reported at union headquarters yesterday to be ill at his home in Brooklyn.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company reported yesterday for 1935 a net profit of $7,883,496 after all charges, which was equivalent to $6.57 a share on the outstanding common stock. In 1934 the profit was $6,496,359, or $5.41 per share. Net sales and operating revenues last year amounted to $57,901,781, against $51,263,372 in 1934.

Price movements continued mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Copper and rubber were strong and activity was generally at an improved rate. On the cash markets the grains, cotton, butter, eggs and rubber advanced, while tin and silk declined.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation's success in reducing fees paid to bankruptcy officials in reorganization of million-dollar corporations was attacked and defended today in the United States Supreme Court.

PARIS, Feb. 14. -- Formal notification of the dissolution of the three royalist leagues grouped in the Action Francaise was served this morning on the leaders who began legal action to upset the Cabinet's order. The police search for evidence of illegal action was continued.

About the best that may be said of yesterday's share market is that the trade reports were reassuring enough to prompt new buying sufficient to offset the moderate amount of profit-taking that was in evidence. The market's "inflation" pulse continued to beat, but feebly, although the efforts of inflationists in Congress continue.

ROME, Feb. 14. -- Today's official war bulletin contains the first admission of a setback that the Italian staff has made since the beginning of the East African campaign. It states that on Feb. 10 an Italian garrison of sixty Dubats (native troops) at Curati, described as an observation post in the south, was attacked by considerable Ethiopian forces and overwhelmed after a strenuous resistance.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14. -- Nectarine, consistent 4-year-old daughter of Bull Dog, staged a courageous stretch drive to chalk up her third consecutive victory in the featured Valentine Purse today at Hialeah Park. The bay filly, judiciously ridden by Joe Renick, gave Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago her ninth success of the current meeting.

This week's abrupt turn of foreign exchange in favor of New York brought to a halt our gold export to Europe. It apparently also marked the end of the movement described as withdrawal of European capital from the United States, on the idea of wholesare currency inflation as a result of the Bonus Bill.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- Charles Corbin, French Ambassador to London, left suddenly for Paris today in an effort to break the deadlock which is delaying the end of the naval conference and jeopardizing its success.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Preparatory to sailing on the Berengaria of the Cunard-White Star line last night, Miss Eleonora Sears, famous tennis star, hiker, all-round athlete and present captain of the women's United States squash racquets team, expressed confidence in the squad that was leaving with her for the international match with the British next month.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- In a novel experiment to appease the American taxpayer, the Treasury Department will try conducting hearings on disputed income taxes in the payer's own bailiwick.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- Mgr. Cesare Orsenigo, Papal Nuncio, again called at the Foreign Office today and is understood to have lodged a protest against the arrests by the Gestapo [State secret police] of some 150 Catholic clergy and laymen as a violation of the concordat.

The domestic price of copper was increased 1/4-cent a pound yesterday. The advance, which will become effective today, was initiated by the Phelps Dodge Corporation and was met by the other leading producers. The new price, which is 9 1/2 cents a pound delivered in the Connecticut Valley, is the first change since Out. 7, last year, when the price was increased to 9 1/4 cents.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 14. -- Ivar Ballangrud rounded out the greatest individual Olympic performance in a dozen years today as Norway completed a clean sweep of the speed-skating championships of the fourth Winter Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Corrington Gill, deputy WPA administrator, announced today that the Philadelphia court ruling that veterans must receive preferential status in work relief employment would be fought "all the way."

Donald Lawson, one of the stars of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club team, scored an upset in the course of the Class B metropolitan squash tennis championship at the Harvard Club yesterday when he eliminated J.N. De Raismes of the Elizabeth Town and Country Club in the second round.

Winter-weary flower lovers got their first taste of Spring yesterday as the first carnation show New York has seen in twenty-three years was opened in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, with a pretentious display of 10,000 blooms.

More pilgrimages by school children to historic St. Paul's Episcopal Church, in the East Chester section of Mount Vernon, have been arranged by the vestry and the Rev. W. Harold Weigle, the rector, with school officials, it was learned yesterday. Revolutionary soldiers are buried in the yard of the church, which was founded in 1665.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The Boerse showed some liquidation today, which turned its tone irregular, although the turnover remained small. Some specialities continued strong, linoleums gaining up to 2 points. Accumulatoren 1 3/4 and Julius Berger 1 1/2.

Winter-weary flower lovers got their first taste of Spring yesterday as the first carnation show New York has seen in twenty-three years was opened in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, with a pretentious display of 10,000 blooms.

More pilgrimages by school children to historic St. Paul's Episcopal Church, in the East Chester section of Mount Vernon, have been arranged by the vestry and the Rev. W. Harold Weigle, the rector, with school officials, it was learned yesterday. Revolutionary soldiers are buried in the yard of the church, which was founded in 1665.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The Boerse showed some liquidation today, which turned its tone irregular, although the turnover remained small. Some specialities continued strong, linoleums gaining up to 2 points. Accumulatoren 1 3/4 and Julius Berger 1 1/2.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- President Roosevelt gave indications that he has not committed himself to a housing program. He nominated Robert H. Jackson to be Assistant Attorney General.

A lifelong friendship between Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott and Assistant Chief David J. Kidney was shattered last night when Mr. McElligott reduced his subordinate to deputy chief, cut his salary from $6,890 to $5,810 and transferred him from Manhattan to command of the Tenth Division in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

The $4,500,000 worth of checks mailed out by the Treasury to a total of twenty-one States are the first payments made by the Federal Government under the Social Security Act. They go to States whose provisions for old-age assistance, aid to the blind and aid to dependent children meet the requirements in that law.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14. -- World War veterans, their wives and their widows, regardless of whether their names are on the relief rolls, are entitled to preference over all others for jobs on Federal work-relief projects, Judge George A. Welsh ruled in the Federal District Court here today.
BOSTON, Feb. 14. -- The thirty-sixth series between the Harvard and Yale varsity hockey teams will start at the Boston Garden tomorrow night with the Crimson sextet a slight favorite to win.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -United States cotton export during January today were reported by the Commerce Department above those of last year. January shipments were 526,000 bales, valued at $33,991,000, against 466,000 bales, valued at $31,716,000, in January, 1935, and 886,000 bales, valued at $55,740,000, in December, 1935.
The devastation that Notre Dame football teams of old wreaked on all rivals was mild in comparison to what the Rambler quintet did to the once invincible hosts of New York University last night.

Since women vote in New York, there is no reason why they shouldn't sit on juries, as they do in so many other States. Governor LEHMAN wants the jury box to be ornamented with their presence. The Assembly passed bills to that effect, as did its predecessor in '35. The Senate chloroformed them.

The recommendations of the Securities and Exchange Commission to Congress regarding unlisted trading were variously received yesterday in different quarters of Wall Street, depending upon the interests affected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP). -- The present cold spell was reported today by the Weather Bureau to be the most severe in history in many places, and, possibly, the forerunner of more severe Winters generally.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Republican leaders in the Assembly are planning to force a showdown over Governor Lehman's recent statement that "strong groups" are intent upon defeating important measures in his law enforcement program, and his warning to the people that his anti-crime bills are in jeopardy in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Switzerland, which was signed on Jan. 9, will become effective tomorrow, carrying with it important concessions by Switzerland on products of agriculture and industry.

CHICAGO, Saturday, Feb. 15. -- Gangland early this morning observed the seventh anniversary of the St. Valentine's Day massacre by assassinating "Machinegun Jack" McGurn, one-time leader of the old Capone gang, who was suspected of participation in the killing of the seven men in a North Side garage in 1929.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 14. -- Spanish ladies, ballet dancers and Colonial dames in authentic heirloom costumes, mingled with gypsies, Mexican bandits, Brittany peasants and cowboys at the Beaux-Arts Ball Junior at the Montclair Athletic Club tonight for the benefit of the peace education program of the International Relation Council of New Jersey.

Reduction in supplies, caused by the recent severe storms, brought a jump of 6 cents a dozen yesterday in the wholesale price of eggs and caused another rise in the wholesale price of butter. Retail prices rose 2 cents a dozen on eggs and 2 cents a pound on butter, with further increases expected by Monday by the Department of Public Markets.

BOSTON, Feb. 14. -- A petition to the Legislature protesting against "the puritanical censorship of Boston which bans significant plays without proper hearing or cause" has been signed by 1,000 persons, including actors, educators and business men.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The War Department Appropriation Bill, carrying $545,226,318 directly, plus reappropriations and contract authorizations for the purchase of airplanes totaling $13,810,711 more was passed early tonight by a voice vote in the House.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14. -- Hitting its stride in the second half, Manhattan's basketball team outclassed Villanova in a rough battle at the Arena tonight, gaining a 34-to-31 decision in the first game of a double-header which attracted a crowd of 4,500.

Adverse weather which cut down store attendance, particularly of commuting customers, hampered retail trade here during the week. While a slight gain was shown for the first few days of the week, it was reported that an increase over a year ago for the entire period depends largely on how good trade is today.

The application of the Norman Thomas faction of the Socialist party for an injunction restraining the city from going ahead with transit unification was denied yesterday by supreme court Justice Joseph M. Callahan.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday plans to expand by approximately 25 per cent its telephone quotation department, which supplies the bid and asked prices on listed stocks to member firms. The move was necessitated by increased demand for this service, the number of quotations given out in January being 85,000, compared with 76,000 in December, 1935, and 51,000 in January of last year.
The semi-final brackets in the invitation squash tennis tournament of the Whitehall Club were completed yesterday with the playing of three matches in the third round.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 15. -- The Soviet Government agreed today to the establishment of a joint commission of Soviet, Japanese and Manchukuoan representatives to investigate incidents on the Soviet-Manchukuoan border on condition that a representative of a neutral nation be appointed to the commission.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- The stock markets here were irregular but active today. The outstanding feature was a further rise in aircrafts in anticipation of today's defense debate in Parliament. British funds were somewhat better, but lately they have been quiet because of the recent new issues.

Oratory fairly rumbled over the country on the evening of Lincoln Day. Eminent speakers volleyed and thundered over the radio. But one address, which held the riveted attention of the immediate audience, was carried over the air on a woman's voice. It was that of the wife of a Missouri farmer, Mrs. SIMMONS.

Snow fell and piled high drifts in East Rutherford, N.J., yesterday as it did in other places. And like other persons Barbara Ryley, 9 years old, and Doris Henry, 10, found the snow distasteful. They were, however, the only persons in East Rutherford to take immediate and drastic action about it.

Jack O'Brien, a tiny brown bear cub, born Thursday at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, was reported "doing nicely" in a make shift incubator in the office of Director R. Cheyne Stout in the elephant house, yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- Backing up its recent demand that the State discontinue mandatory price-fixing under the Milk Control Act, the New York State Conference Board of Farm Organizations today called for placing of price-fixing in the hands of the industry itself under supervision of the State.

Reasonable-minded citizens may be able to sympathize with the handicapped Street Cleaning Department in its task of trying to clear the city. At last it has succeeded in cutting a way through the ice at corners in some outlying districts so that pedestrians can cross without too great risk.

Announcement of the "red-carding" of four additional stores by the Fashion Originators Guild and the statement by the Associated Merchandising Corporation that it will limit its cooperation with the guild to the orinigal agreement covering garments down to $10.75, wholesale, featured the developments yesterday in the controversy which has arisen over the style protection program of the guild.

JUDGING by the skill of the four blind bridge players who competed against four opponents with normal eyesight in the exhibition staged by the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind on Wednesday night, the sightless are at least as good as the average in skill.

Until Friday morning William Jordan was just an obscure 10-year-old Negro boy living with his family in a poor section of Richmond, Va. He never had been far from his own neighborhood but had heard stories of the big cities "up Nawth."

APPARENTLY no latitude nor occupation can escape Mr. Williamson's inquiring eye: he knows the rigorous life of the seal fishers of Labrador, the jungle trails of South America and the hazards which beset the lobster fishermen of the Maine coast.

The tentmaker who became Persia's most famous poet is shown here, not as a great teacher and mathematician but as a schoolboy, growing from an eager, questing lad into a thoughtful young scholar, facing with fortitude the problems of life.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- "There will be no occasion for me to leave the party for I will be the Presidential nominee myself," was the reply Senator Borah made today to the whisperings of skeptics and the propaganda of supporters of his rivals that he would "walk out" on the Republican convention if rejected as the nominee.

Many reservations have been made for the dinner dance in aid of the Barat Settlement House which will take place on Feb. 24 in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. The funds realized will further the work of the Settlement at 228 Chrystie Street, which maintains an extensive educational and recreational program for adults and children in a crowded district of the city.

A rise of temperatures to a maxmum of 44 degrees, the highest point touched by the thermometer since 53 was recorded on Jan. 15, brought a thaw to New York yesterday, while the Northwest continued to suffer from extreme cold and shipping contended with storms and ice.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP). -- J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the "Gmen," said today that "kidnapping is well in hand in America."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- Officials of Federal work relief agencies made plans today to revamp the WPA Administration in this district to be on the safe side if the final decision goes against the government in the veteran preference ruling handed down here yesterday by Federal Judge George A. Welsh.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15. -- Cavalcade, 3-year-old champion in 1934, was withdrawn today from the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap next Saturday.

THE banquet season in New York reaches its peak in February. It is a season of about six months, running from October to April, and in that period innumerable societies, clubs, lodges and business organizations foregather to dine, to listen to speakers, and usually, nowadays, to dance.

HERR HELFRITZ writes of his travels in Arabia without any touching up of exciting moments, or any effort to heighten the emotional impact of the things he saw and did. But the adventures are there, and the surprises, and the weird impossibilities that were as factual as the sunshine.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 15. -- Dartmouth's hockey team took first place in the Quadrangular League tonight, shading Princeton in a sensational game, 4 -- 3, which saw the winning goal scored with thirty seconds to go. The defeat dropped the Tigers into last place.

GENEVA, Feb. 15. -- The effect on the policy of the League of Nations in the Italian war of the Washington administration's decision merely to extend temporarily the existing Neutrality Law is to discourage the imposition of the oil sanction, though not necessarily to prevent it.

In 1925 France and Germany appeared to be moving toward peaceful relations. Both nations, it seemed, had had enough of their centuries-old struggle. Briand and Stresemann, the French and German Foreign Ministers, learned to like and respect each other; at the end of 1925, with a bit of prodding by the British, they signed the Treaty of Locarno.

PHILADELPHIA. NEWS that more than $4,000,000 is to be spent under WPA auspices in reconstructing and developing the 183-acre Southwest Philadelphia tract known as the Municipal Airport follows years of agitation regarding this field.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, has not made and will not make any request to Tammany to name any particular persons as Congressional district delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

As a recognition of his bravery and skillful seamanship when he had charge of the lifeboat of the Ascania that rescued the captain and nine of the crew of the sinking British freighter Usworth in the North Atlantic on Dec. 14, 1934, the directors of the Cunard White Star Line have promoted E.J.R. Pollitt, R.N.R., the third officer, to be second officer of the Queen Mary.
MIAMI. -- One of the larger events in the mid-season Miami social calendar, the third annual Helen Lee Doherty Milk. Fund Ball, will be held at the Miami Biltmore Country Club on Thursday.

THOUGH off the beaten track of tourist travel, the George Washington Birthplace National Monument at Wakefield easily finds a place in the itineraries of Winter tourists among the historic shrines of Tidewater Virginia. Established as a National Monument by Congress in 1930, Washington's birthplace is now under the custodial care of the National Park Service.
Yale continued its twelve-year victory stretch last night by defeating Columbia's swimming team, 54 -- 17, in the Morningside Heights pool.

IT is playtime in Florida. Women are dancing in stunning evening gowns of chiffon, taffeta, satin. They are lying on the beaches with backs bared to the sun in bathing suits that give them the freedom of the sea. At the races they are checking their winnings, or losses, in crepes or tweeds, depending on the strength of the sun.

THE poets have awakened once more to the opportunities offered them by the theatre. "A poets' theatre in New York" (and in London and in Paris) is a vision which has appeared to many and of which many are endeavoring to achieve the realization.

The dismissal of the "Sanitation Commissioner" for laxity in snow removal, pledges for a new deal in crime enforcement in the Bronx and establishment of "bigger and better'' playgrounds for the borough's youngsters were a few of the incidents occurring yesterday when nine high school boys supplanted elected officials of Bronx County and for ninety minutes administered the affairs of the borough.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 15. -- Announcement of needs of $9,450,000 to provide endowment for professorial chairs, increase the scholarship, fellowship and loan funds and make possible the erection or renovation of a number of buildings at Mount Holyoke College was made tonight by President Mary E. Woolley in an address to nearly 100 alumnae at the closing session of the annual alumnae council.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15. -- William J. Bingham, athletic director and chairman of the committee for the direction of athletic activities at Harvard, in his annual report, submitted today, urges President Conant of Harvard to abrogate the agreement with the presidents of Yale and Princeton whereby the three football squads are not allowed to begin Fall football practice prior to Sept. 15.

LESLIE HOWARD is about to embark upan a new career, that of a motion-picture producer. Never quite content either in Hollywood or London studios, he is determined to act as his own Mr. Glogauer, and during the Summer will film "Bonnie Prince Charlie" in Scotland.

Long Island University's five remained unbeaten, but the Blackbirds received stubborn opposition from St. Thomas College before winning at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night. The score was 45 -- 36, but for all the first half and the early part of the second the victors were hard pressed.

Dr. Harry W. Laidler, city chairman of the left wing group of the Socialist party, announced yesterday that 1,452 old Socialist party members and about 200 new members, or about 62 per cent of the party's membership in this city as of December, 1935, had registered with the new left wing organization.

ASMARA, Eritrea -- There are lots of things that could be said against this colonial capital, which is not (to put it mildly) to be compared with Paris, London or New York in point of beauty, culture or comforts, but there is one respect in which Asmara surely takes all the palms.

IN her latest warm romance Maysie Greig prescribes a sure cure for a pretty girl's damaged heart. When a charming and wealthy young man jilts his fiancee the best thing she can do is to fall promptly and deeply in love with a more trustworthy and eligible candidate. And that is exactly what Pamela Harding did.

While bombs from Italian planes searched out the headquarters of the harried ruler of Ethiopia, and units of our own General Headquarters Air Force, in cold-weather manoeuvres, made simulated bombing raids on the cities of the Eastern seaboard, errands of very different character were being performed in the air.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Seven army teams scored a sweep in varsity events today, with the Cadet polo players turning back Yale, 15 to 10, in the feature of the program, which saw the West Point rifle squad triumph in two matches. However, Army did not have the same success in its night hockey battle and bowed to Williams, 4 to 0.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Feb. 15. -- Mrs. Margaret Hall, 72-year-old mother of Raymond Hall, local contractor, and Mr. Hall's adopted son, James, 5, were killed today by gas fumes that leaked from a broken feed line into her Summer home at 3,229 Central Avenue.

Mrs. Wiliam O. Hubbard gave a luncheon, yesterday at the Versailles for her debutante niece, Miss Lucy Gilbert Hutchinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hutchinson. The guests, all debutantes, included the Misses Peggy Kelsey, Betty Russell, Jane Ogden, Jerry Bergh, Mary Schley, Peggy Delafield, Jane Gray, Juha Booth and Patty Pittman.

EVERY one who was amused, appalled and vastly entertained by Netta and Biff of "Striplings" will eagerly welcome "Close of Play," which continues their fascinating story. The two youngsters, who lived in haphazard fashion on a dilapidated Sussex estate, continue to be intelligent, sensitive, original young savages.

LOS ANGELES. -- Throughout the West the Alien Deportation Bill introduced by Representative Martin Dies of Texas is gaining support. Providing that all aliens who fail to take out citizenship papers within one year be deported, the measure is held to offer solutions of several vexing social problems growing out of the presence of Mexicans and Spanish-Americans in nearly all of the Mountain, Intermountain and Pacific Coast States.
EVER since wireless went to sea, each disaster in which it figured as an element of safety has revealed necessity for new rules, regulations and devices.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- Winter has usually been a test for every regime in Germany since the World War. All upheavals in 1918 and since have happened in the wintertime, and even Cabinet crises used to arrive promptly every Christmas along with Santa Claus.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday reversed Friday's course and a setback left the list at the close with losses of 9 to 15 points. A statement by the pool manager that delivery on March contracts would be demanded only in the event of undue discounts on the near month under middling quotations at delivery points relieved market tension.

THE author of this book does not waste words. He plunges immediately into his story, beginning with the finding of the body of an unknown man floating in a city reservoir, and continuing with events that are even more startling.

Mr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra gave their second concert of the week in New York yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, and again they conducted an exceptionally interesting occasion. Two Bach preludes, transcribed by Pick-Mangiagalli, preceded a beautifully proportioned reading of the Beethoven Pastoral symphony.

When a shortage of seats developed yesterday afternoon at a conference called by the city council of the American Youth Congress in the auditorium of the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street, Morris Fleissing, a delegate from the Center seniors of the Lavanburg Home, climbed three stories to the church garret to look for more chairs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The American people are spending something more than $12,000,000 daily this year on Federal relief for the unemployed, and within a brief period President Roosevelt will put before Congress the problem of making provision for government aid for the next fiscal year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Colonel Henry Breckinridge, New York lawyer, told the Sentinels of the Republic here tonight that "Farley's mercenary army and the lesser roving bands in the States and cities are pests of locusts" that are "heading us to bankruptcy."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15. -- There was great activity in the fleet of coastwise steamers, principally lumber carriers, in the past week while operators of the vessels which had been idle here for many weeks bought supplies and placed their carriers in service as a result of an understanding reached with the maritime unions that have been on strike.

Share prices closed firm and generally higher yesterday, with the best showings made by the steel, copper and railways groups. During the half-day session, trading on the Stock Exchange aggregated 1,373,000 shares, compared with 1,252,000 the Saturday before.

The Real Estate Board of New York expressed opposition yesterday to the proposal for government subsidies for new low-rental housing and to government management of such housing, and urged instead that a Federal bank be created to make loans at low rates of interest to private enterprise to carry out such work.

The increase in the War Department Appropriation Bill, resulting in a record-breaking peace-time appropriation, was defended last night by Secretary of War Dern against criticism that the bill was passed to cope with internal disorders and break strikes "when labor takes the picket line."

Six research fellowships for women for 1936-37 were announced yesterday by the American Association of University Women through a committee of eight leading women scholars, who made the awards. Dr. Katherine J. Gallagher of Goucher College, Professor of History, was chairman.

THREE days ago, a little after midnight, the tolling of church-bells brought to the high window of my writing-room news that the King was dead. During the following day theatres were closed. Since then some have reopened, but all first nights, including that of Mr Cochran's revue, have been postponed until after the funeral.
After two months of leisurely discussions the naval conference at London is completing its deliberations and stands on the threshold of adjournment.

In stressing the need for a "friendly and companionate" relationship between parent and child, Dr. John Levy, Assistant Professor of Psychiatry of Columbia University and head of the Child Guidance Clinic of Columbia Medical Center, indicated yesterday that the machine age had brought on a different concept of the Fifth Commandment.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14. -- Blacklisted by the American Association of University Professors on the charge principally of interfering with academic freedom, the University of Pittsburgh has now received a "deadline," March 1, from Governor Earle for the meeting of certain requirements, with the threat of loss of State financial aid as the alternative.
BOSTON, Feb. 14. -- Excitement throbs at fever heat away Down East. All the Passamaquoddy population is afraid that their millennial visions are due to vanish and leave little behind.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Creation of a permanent rural electrification administration to spend $1,000,000,000 in bringing electricity to the farms was voted today by the Senate Agriculture Committee.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- The Bourse had a busy Saturday session today, with trading active throughout the list. Reduced rates for mid-month settlement had a favorable effect, as money was available at 3 3/4 per cent, down from the 4 3/8 per cent at the and of January.
BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, opening the national automobile show today, directed the attention of the German people to the United States' solution of the problem of motorization.

CAMDEN, S.C. -- Following the Virginians Horse Show yesterday, in which there were more than 240 entries of fine horses, Camden is looking forward to the Washington Birthday races on Saturday and the hunter trials on Friday.

FOR the benefit of Manuelistas, Mr. Cabell prints here the Biography of the Life of Manuel, rewritten for a limited edition in twenty volumes, now out of print and "equally applicable to the unrevised texts of the current Kalki editions."

More science and a more broadly-based and humanizing science in the schools was the text of speakers yesterday who addressed 520 teachers of science in the high schools of New York at their annual luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore.

AIKEN, S.C. -- Dates for the main Spring sports at Aiken have recently been announced. There will be three polo matches played each week (beginning with this week) until April 15. A match is scheduled for each Saturday afternoon by the Aiken Polo Association.

IF less thronged with openings than have been many of its predecessors this season, the week just traversed at any rate presents, as we pause to look back over some of the developments, a protean quota of give-and-take.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14. -- The stinging rebuke administered this week to Nikolai Bukharin, chief editor of the newspaper Izvestia, by the Communist organ Pravda and taken up by other important Soviet journals, by no means indicates a split is developing within the Russian Communist party.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Dr. Ray B. Westerfield, Yale professor, tonight called Dr. F.E. Townsend "a true child of the New Deal spree in utopian fairyland" and his pension plan "utterly absurd."

WINTER still holds with icy grip everything out-of-doors, but the calendar marches stoutly on toward Spring, and every twenty-four hours that the clock ticks off means one day nearer planting time. Beginners may be delaying their orders for seeds, plants and bulbs, but the more experienced are not procrastinating, for they know how suddenly snow and frost may disappear, and the ground be ready for digging.

It is hoped that the Alberta Legislature will go so far this session as to pass an enabling act for the benefit of Premier ALBERHARTS Social Credit plan. He has to make haste slowly. Conditions are not yet auspicious. Twice he has had to go, hat in hand, to Ottawa and borrow money of the Dominion Government.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15. -- Yale rose to a tie for fourth place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by defeating Cornell, 43 to 27, before 1,000 spectators in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium. Captain Tommy Wilson and Larry Kelley scored 11 points each with dazzling shots. Kelley played only two minutes of the second half.

The Yale fencing team defeated the New York University swordsmen in a dual meet held in the East Building, Washington Square College, yesterday, 14 to 13. The defeat was the first received in ten starts by the Violets, who won eight meets last year and one this season, before bowing to the Elis.

WASHINGTON. WITH sales of $550,180.65 for the first six months of the current fiscal year-topping by more than $118,000 sales for the corresponding period in the fiscal year 1934-35 -- the Philatelic Agency continues to be a money-maker for the Post-office Department.

The Philippines are listed for the first time as an independent dominion and Manuel Quezon appears as their first president in the Almanach de Gotha for 1936, the "Genealogical, Diplomatic and Statistical Annual," which makes its one hundred and seventy-third appearance in the familiar red and gold binding.
Said General Malin Craig, chief of staff of the army, in a report accompanying the military appropriation measure which was submitted to Congress last week:

Jubilant over the action of the Assembly in passing the mandatory woman juror bills last week, the New York State League of Women Voters has taken the initiative in mobilizing other large organizations for a concerted move on the Senate in support of similar bills pending there.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15. -- This week's ratification of the Chaco peace protocol by the Bolivian and Paraguayan Congresses is a tremendous personal victory for Argentina's Foreign Minister, Carlos Saavedra Lamas.

LOOKING all of his 26 years -- and not a day older -- Douglas Fairbanks Jr., fresh from a two-year sojourn in England, received the press last week on the eve of a brief, aeronautical excursion to Hollywood. With no more trace of Oxonian in his speech than he had the day he sailed to rediscover the Old World, the cinema's most famous "junior" had two rather weighty affairs upon his mind.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15. -- In the most bitterrly fought finish in the six runnings of the Nursery States No. 1, the Crescent Stable's virtually unknown brown colt Goya raced to a nose victory at odds of more than 60-1, paying $123,40 for $2 at Hialeah Park today.

DOCTORS are usually good story-tellers, both in talk and print. Perhaps it is because they live so near to the ultimate stuff of life that the tales of their experiences are utterly real and so carry the conviction and the emotional impact that the more sophisticated litterateur is apt to dilute with literary adornment.

THE recent announcement by Dean Leighton of Harvard College that many high school students at the age of 17 are mature enough intellectually and socially to enter college is not at all surprising. In now admitting about 40 per cent of its freshman public school graduates at 17 or younger.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Administration's $500,000,000 stop-gap farm relief program, little changed from its original form, was pushed through the Senate today by the combined forces of Senators from the South and West.

THE St. Louis Opera Company, Guy Golterman director, is preparing for a brief season of performances to be given in April in St. Louis, Mo. The orchestra will consist of sixty members of the St. Louis Symphony. A chorus of 150 is being rehearsed by Ernest Knoch, and a ballet of fifty St. Louis girls is in training under Rita De Leporte.

GOYA is a name with which to conjure for all writers eager to capture a general public; a magical name for all readers avid of sensation. His work, however, provides ample material for a more questioning attention.

TOKYO, Feb. 15. -- 4 Foreign Office spokesman said tonight that "nothing serious" was indicated by the reports of a new battle. The spokesman expressed confidence that the frontier controversy would be settled peacefully, but he did not express agreement with the suggestion made in Moscow that a group of neutral nations be called in to hear both sides' arguments.

An actual shortage of experienced executives and salesmen faces the export trade for the first time in years, Francis T. Cole, vice president in charge of service of the American Manufacturers Export Association, said yesterday. His organization at present is endeavoring to locate competent men to represent member companies in the Far East, Europe and Latin-American markets, and likewise to find executives to direct the operations of such salesmen.

TURIN. ITALY'S "Little Paris," as this city has been called since it became the center of fashions for Italian women, recently organized a national fashion show, as part of the campaign to create a typically Italian couture.

IN the heart of every American newspaper correspondent in Europe is a great longing. It is to tell frankly all he knows. But suppressions and censorships stand in his way. He may be sure of certain things but he cannot send the full facts because they will be denied and he has no way of proving he was right.

THE vast Exhibition of Chinese Art being held at Burlington House, London, receives the lion's share of attention in the February number of Parnassus. Several phases of the great Oriental show are discussed by experts in their respective fields.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14. -- Governor Earle's refusal to order State troopers into the anthracite region to end the bootlegging of coal may bring a little nearer to a climax a situation in Pennsylvania's hard-coal fields combining the tragic and the grotesque.

AFTER a quiet inquiry lasting nearly six months, a Senatorial committee headed by Senator Copeland of New York opened hearings last week in Washington in an effort to discover how safe -- or how unsafe -- air transport is in the United States.

PARIS, Feb. 14. -- Unusual bitterness, it appears now, will mark the general election to be held in France some time this Spring. That this is so follows from such incidents as the tear-gas-bomb throwing in the Sorbonne to prevent Professor Gaston Jeze from delivering his lectures and the assault made on the Socialist leader, Leon Blum, Thursday by members of the Royalist Action Francaise.

To commemorate New York under the "Union of States" plan at the new Washington Cathedral at Mount St. Alban, Washington, D.C., a subscription benefit of performances of "The Petrified Forest" at the Radio City Music Hall has been arranged for this Wednesday by the New York committee of the National Cathedral Association.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 15. -- Former President Gerardo Machado y Morales of Cuba expects to make his permanent home in New York, where his wife and daughters have been living since 1933, according to Fernando Villapol, his private secretary. The secretary declined to arrange for inteviews with or photographs of Genera Machado.

The American Can Company reported yesterday that its net income in 1935 was $17,310,303 after depreciation and Federal taxes. This was equivalent, after dividends on the 7 per cent preferred stock, to $5.83 a share for the common stock.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Operations in the wheat market on the Board of Trade today were restricted. Most of the trading was done within a range of 1/4 cent a bushel.

UP in the mountain country of Northwestern Montana is the valley of Sniel-emen -- Mountains of the Surrounded. It lies within the original Jocko Indian Reservation, home of the last of the Salish (or Flathead) people. It is the seat of the once famous mission of St. Mary, founded nearly a hundred years ago by Jesuits under the leadership of Pierre J. De Smet.

The Italian and French period furniture and the other art objects which were auctioned yesterday and Friday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries brought $38,038. Dr. Warren Smadbeck, Baron Hans Christian yon Hahn, Ernest G. Metcalfe and G.H. and C.W. Schumann were among those whose property was sold.

A motor man's thick, greasy glove snarled the handle of his air brake yesterday morning and led to a rear-end collision between elevated trains in which twenty-three persons were injured or suffered from shock.

A MEMORIAL to Abraham Lincoln has been undertaken by the Garden Clubs of Illinois. The project has been endorsed by the National Council of State Garden Clubs and other organizations. The Lincoln Garden will be situated on the shores of Lake Springfield, near Lincoln's home town.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday that New York University had received $267,682.27 in new gifts and Bequests, including nearly $1,500 from the estate of the late Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown. Donors to the university included Mr. and Mrs. Percy S. Straus, Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, Ogden L. Mills and Dr. George Blumenthal.

Tony Canzoneri, world's lightweight champion, gave advantages of height, weight and reach to Billy Hogan, Orangeburg welterweight, last night in their scheduled tenround bout before 5,000 boxing fans at the Ridgewood Grove Sports Club in Brooklyn, and then knocked out Hogan in 2 minutes 26 seconds of the fourth round.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- War has been declared between former Governor Joseph B. Ely and Governor James M. Curley. The one nominated Alfred E. Smith for the Presidency in 1932; the other may claim priority as the original Roosevelt man in the Bay State.

A concert in which noted French artists will participate will take place this evening at Carnegie Hall to aid the endowment fund of the Lycee Francais de New York. The concert will be given under the auspices of Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General here.

A MOVABLE house of new design, to be drawn behind a car, was announced last week by William B. Stout, the Detroit engineer. The Mobile Home, as the unit is called, is said to be different from the usual camp trailer, in which passengers generally ride.

IN the past few months there has been a noticeable relaxation of Nazi efforts to ruin the Vienna Opera. Whereas a year ago Berlin was detaching from our Staatsoper with all sorts of shining inducements as many leading artists as it could, singers from pretty much all over Germany are today receiving permission to go to Austria for guest appearances and in certain cases for prolonged engagements.

Five leading organizations of New York women will join in the sponsorship of an address by Salvador de Madariaga, chairman of the committee of five on the Ethiopian question for the League of Nations, on Thursday evening at the A.W.A. clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

A gang of at least twelve men staged a hold-up last night in the Murray 5-10-and-25 cent store at 242 First Avenue, the northeast corner of Fourteenth Street, the center of a busy market district. Forcing the proprietor to accompany them, the armed thugs looted cash registers in turn of between $300 and $400 and escaped without interference from nine cowed employes and twenty-five customers.

HENRY PRINGLE'S incisive study of President Taft is one of the outstanding sketches in the authoritative gallery of American worthies that reaches its eighteenth volume with this book. Another excellent one is it he portrait of Thoreau. It was written by Raymond William Adams and Henry Seidel Canby.

Luncheon parties are being planned by many subscribers to precede the gala concert which will be given under the direction of Albert Morris Bagby on the afternoon of March 17 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Music Lovers' Foundation, Inc.

THE termite has sometimes been held up before the reading public in such terrific and horrifying description of its menace to man and civilization as would easily make it Public Enemy No. 1 of the whole world, if the writers concerned were not under suspicion of depending more on imagination than on facts.

Two women were seriously hurt but three others and a man elevator operator escaped injury about 6:30 o'clock last night when an elevator in a six-story, eighty-family apartment building at 3,280 Rochambeau Avenue, the Bronx, fell from the fourth floor almost to the first, where it was halted by an automatic safety device.

THE coronation of Edward VIII as King and Emperor, a year hence, will call for the use of many symbols of royal power. Recent news from Tacoma, State of Washington, telling of the advancing price of ermine, is related to this ceremony.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 15. -- Heckling and hooting from the audience caused Bernarr Macfadden publisher of the magazine Liberty, to abandon efforts to make a speech tonight on national affairs before the Advertising Club of Baltimore.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 . -- Under the auspices of the Assembly, controlled by the Republicans, an inquiry into the "fundamentals" of the State's relief problem will be held on Feb. 25 and Feb. 26, with other hearings to follow if circumstances should seem to dictate such a course.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Three years of economic recovery have put farmers in the best financial condition since 1929. Gross farm income topped $8,100,000,000 last year, or $2,800,000,000 more than in 1932. Cash income was correspondingly increased, while expenses -- estimated at $4,000,000,000 for 1935 -- increased only slightly.

IN countless places of worship in India the folk of the hills and the plains will gather this month to do homage, on the centenary of his birth, to the memory of Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa, who found truth in all religions and is venerated as a great spiritual prophet.

Amid the confusion of numerous parties in Spain's general election today, there emerges a clear-cut fight between two dominant personalities: Jose Maria Gil Robles, the leader of Spain's brand of fascism, and Manuel Azana, former Premier and standard-bearer of democracy.

The pick of the city's public school music students, numbering 4,300 in choruses, bands and orchestras, will go on parade here next month in gala concerts before the biennial convention of the Music Educators National Conference.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 15. -- Final production figures for 1935 for five mines of the Patricia district of Northwestern Ontario show the total output for the year to be $3,520,321, compared with $1,899,173 in 1934, $1,158,470 in 1933, $1,268,780 in 1932, $914,291 in 1931 and $460,428 in 1930.

Alexander Hamilton Institute states that in the last reported month the number of unemployed had risen 12,194,000, while the total number of employed had declined to 38,476,000 -- this out of a once practically self-supporting population of over 125,000,000.

Earnings of the United Carbon Company and subsidiaries for 1935 were the largest in the history of the company, it was announced yesterday. The net profit after depreciation, depletion, provision for Federal taxes and contingencies was $1,872,405, which was equal to $4.70 a share on 397,885 shares of no-par common stock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14. -- Prospects for peace on the waterfront in this and other Pacific Coast ports are brighter than they have been at any time within the past year, as San Francisco tries to accustom itself to the spectacle of Harry Bridges exerting all his influence on the side of moderation and peace as against militants on his own side.

ARIZONA is rapidly awakening to the fact that she has attractive natural beauties, a distinctive charm and a colorful history. In the flush of this self-discovery, the youngest of the forty-eight States, and one of the largest, is developing a new assertiveness.

John Harlan Amen, Special Assistant Attorney General, announced yesterday that he would convene a special Federal grand jury "very soon" to launch a double-barreled investigation against all forms of racketeering in interstate industries by combining the Sherman Anti-trust Law with the recently "rediscovered" but more effective anti-racket law of 1934.

Utilizing one of the favorite motifs of fairy tales and folklore, the author adds a fillip of the supernatural to these stories which illustrate the traditions of Jewish life and faith. There is the fascination of the miniature in these tales of a Jewish thunbling, no longer than your middle finger, who, in spite of his size, was equipped with his full share of gayety and mischief.

"When creeters go meddlin' round what dey don' belong, dey is boun' to git into trouble." So spoke Gran'pappy when Nicodemus appeared, tearstained, unhappy, but determinedly tugging away at an alarmed bear cub on a rope.

With the "red carding" of seven leading retail establishments by the Fashion Originators Guild of America met by the stand of the eighteen member stores of the Associated Merchandising Corporation that they will confine their cooperation with the guild's style protection program to the "original agreement" covering merchandise wholesaling at $10.75 and above,

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 15. -Hartford's festival of music, sponsored this week for the first time by the Friends and Enemies of Modern Music, reached a climax tonight at the Avery Memorial when a ball took place.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- A varied sports and social program, including the annual presentation of the Junior League "Follies'' and the annual field day of the Augusta Cross Country Riding Club, will distinguish this week.

LAKE PLACID. -- The huge ice sheet of the indoor Olympic Arena here will be transformed into the bridge and deck of the "Good Ship Manhattan'' over the Washington's Birthday week-end for the tenth annual midwinter ice carnival.

Representatives of more than a score of New York realty and taxpayers' associations will go to Albany on Tuesday to take part in the legislative hearing on real estate and mortgage bills to be held that day in the Senate chambers.

Valuations of rapid transit properties and rights involved in pending plans for unification are being brought up to date by the Transit Commission, according to its annual report, made public yesterday.

The vast expansion of governmental activities has given rise to many questions in respect of immunity from the Federal income tax of compensation received by officers, employes and agents of the State and its political subdivisions.

ALTHOUGH it is a tale of murder, defensive and unpremeditated, this story is related without any recourse at all to the standard intricacies of crime and detection stuff which constitute the backbone, the fascination for most readers, of the mystery novels.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Strikes, threats of strikes and strike settlements constitute the grist of recent news in the industrial relations field.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Fire which apparently was started by a small portable oil stove took the lives of three persons early today in a two-story house at 5 Tompkins Avenue, in the Nepera Park section.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 15. -- Great Britain virtually clinched the Olympic ice hockey championship tonight by holding the United States to a scoreless tie.
The following table shows some important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

THE recent organization at Washington of the General Wild Life Federation is of special interest to all garden club members, as in this nationwide plan for the restoration of the wild life of the country garden clubs are allied with nature societies', sportsmen's organizations and game commissions.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Statements that mortgage interest rates in Westchester County are higher than in other comparable parts of the country were contradicted today by Dr. Joseph E. Hughes, president of the Westchester County Clearing House Association, at a luncheon of the local unit of the Federal Housing Administration at Normandy Tavern.

The Architectural League of New York will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary Tuesday with the opening to the public of its annual exhibition at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON'S Birthday, the traditional climax of the play and recreation season in the Far South and of the Winter sports program in the North, will focus attention this year on significant developments in the world of travel and play.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- Preparations are being made for the Washington Birthday celebrations in Nassau. Balls arranged by the leading hotels and other events scheduled for the daylight hours are expected to make the occasion one of the most spectacular of the season.

The Congressional mill grinds slowly. Though six weeks have passed since the beginning of the present session, only one major piece of legislation stands to the credit of Congress -- or rather, in this instance, to its discredit. This is the Soldiers' Bonus Bill, enacted over a Presidential veto.

Earl Maxwell, brother of Edith Maxwell who was sentenced to a prison term of twenty-five years by the Wise County Circuit Court of Virginia for killing her father, reviewed the case yesterday noon and told of the steps which the defense will take to obtain a new trial.

The annual meeting of the New York Academy of Public Education will be held on Tuesday evening at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The academy's medal for distinguished service in education will be presented to Dr. Freak P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education.

Jobless but not hopeless, mute but not thoughtless, the younger generation has been fumbling its way toward solution of its own particular problems in its own way. In the last few weeks an avenue of expression for its conflicting ideas has been furnished in a magazine devoted to all shades of opinion, through the enterprise of a girl who ranks as one of a number of leaders in her own age group.

Mgr. John A. Ryan, head of the Department of Social Ethics at the Catholic University in Washington, D.C., advocated yesterday a program of social justice which would retain the principal legislative features of the New Deal. He addressed delegates of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs, in session at the Hotel Roosevelt.

President Roosevelt has given his personal assurance of support for the New York World's Fair in 1939, George McAneny, president of the fair corporation, told 1,000 members of the Long Island Real Estate Board at a dinner last night in the Hotel Biltmore. Congress is being asked to appropriate $5,000,000 for Federal exhibits.

TOURIST bookings for the current season reveal that more persons are "traveling with a purpose" than ever before. There is scarcely a pursuit in the arts, sciences, religion, sports and general culture but that is today explored abroad by groups of the serious-minded.

THIS year marks the centenary of the publication of the most popular modern novel, "The Pickwick Papers" of Dickens. Bibliographically it is still the most intricate of the more familiar collected books, and the subject has a special literature all to itself.

It was thoughtful in the Founding Fathers and the most illustrious of their successors to get themselves born in the early months of the year. This makes it so convenient for the national conventions.

THOUGH Mr. Smith's very original book has a serious purpose, he pursues it by so entertaining a method that it is to be feared that his readers will be so seduced by the amusement it so liberally supplies as to skip the seriousness, at least on a first reading.

The New York Athletic Club polo team moved a step nearer a repetition of its last year's victory in the Metropolitan League last night when it turned back Boulder Brook, 9 1/2 to 8 1/2, in an exciting league match at the Squadron A Armory. However, the Winged Foot trio came close to being the victims of a sensational upset.

Between the last legislative session and the present one Governor Lehman conferred with criminologists, lawyers, police and other advisers; with them he laid plans to repair, lubricate and modernize the State's permanent machinery for prosecuting crime -- particularly the organized rackets of New York City.

OUR government's valiant and effective efforts to overcome the depression will rank among the rarest feats of statecraft. The exact measure of our accomplishments will be easier to determine when the administration of unemployment insurance supplies accurate and complete official records of unemployment.

With an astounding and monumental performance of Liszt's mammoth sonata in B minor, Egon Petri again established his right to be considered the rightful heir of his master, Busoni, as an interpreter of that composer's keyboard compositions, at his recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

LONDON. KING EDWARD VIII made aviation history on the first day of his reign, when he flew from Sandringham to London -- the first British monarch to use the air. For years, in his own phrase, the new King has looked upon flying as his main means of transport.

With Gene Venzke, Glenn Cunningham and Joe Mangan ready for a re-enactment of their thrilling Wanamaker Mile finish, what looks to be the outstanding athletic carnival of the indoor season will reach the boards on Saturday when the Amateur Athletic Union stages its forty-eighth annual national championships at Madison Square Garden.

WHATEVER wrench of the human imagination was originally responsible for the art of jugglery, it is fair to estimate that a good half of the male population has at one time or another indulged a youthful resolve to master the sleight-of-hand skill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- With the challenging approval of the Townsend Congressmen, the nationwide movement for paying $200 a month pensions to all Americans over 60, known as the Townsend Old-Age Revolving Pension Plan, is about to be investigated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The administration was startled this week when the House Appropriations Committee disregarded President Roosevelt's budgetary request to include provision in the Army Appropriation Bill for continuing work on the Passamaquoddy tidal power project in Maine and the Florida ship canal.

By the end of this month more than 5,000 persons will be employed throughout the country by the Federal Art Project of the Works Progress Administration, Holger Cahill, National Director of the Federal Art Project, notes in a preliminary report just made to Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

TODAY, Americans are on the threshold of new frontiers of science, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, declared at the Third Annual Woman's Congress during the past week in Chicago. Referring to "the immense mystery still beyond," Mr. Sarnoff pointed out that radio's ultra-short waves rank with the stratosphere as a potential resource of science.

MUCH of the present excellence in the decorative arts is the result of the close cooperation of decorator, architect and craftsman. In Renaissance days artistic unity came from the practice of having one person design the house, make its furniture and decorate it.

Warren A. Dow of the Commonwealth Fencing Club emerged first in a field of twenty-nine contestants to capture the metropolitan foils championship at the Salle d'Armes Vince yesterday. Dow ascended to the title, which was not defended by Joseph Levis of Boston, after two fence-off rounds, in which he was, opposed by Dernell Every of the New York A.C. and Emil Goldstein of the Salle d'Armes Vince.

THIS is a study of miracles, of the resurrection and of a future life in the light of psychic knowledge. Miracles are treated as supernormal rather than as supernatural, the resurrection as symbolic and life beyond the grave is described as being similar to our own, and evidenee for this discoverable by means of spirit communication.

CAIRO, Feb. 15. -- With the issuance of a royal rescript appointing a delegation to negotiate an Anglo-Egyptian treaty of alliance and after an exchange of letters between Premier Aly Maher Pasha and Sir Miles Lampson, British High Commissioner, to the satisfaction of all parties, it is expected that preliminary discussions preceding the actual negotiations will begin within a fortnight.

The National Dress Manufacturers Association, representing the jobbers, at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday morning ratified conditionally the oral agreement which averted the threatened strike of 105,000 dressmakers, including 84,000 in New York City.

THE biography of Jean Sibelius by Karl Eckman is the most complete account of this composer's life that has thus far been published. It appeared in the original Swedish last year. Now an English translation by Edward Birse has been issued by the Holger Schilds Forlag of Helsingfors.

Labor difficulties in Mexico, which for some time have been causing concern to the officials of United States companies operating there, assumed a more serious aspect last week when they threatened to extend to the utility companies in Mexico, D.F., and to the Southern Pacific Railway's workers.

The Presidential campaign of 1936 threatens to develop more demagogy and charlatanism than any other in the political history of this country. Instead of symposium of carefully considered policies, we are about to witness a pandemonium of sophistry and misinformation, tainted with symptoms of mental indigestion.
MOUNT PLEASANT, Texas, Feb. 15 (AP). -- John Patrick Temples had had a job in a side-street restaurant stirring stew and cooking hamburgers. He earned $4 a week.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Definite dates and plans for enlarging the 1936 Mohawk Drama Festival, which will present Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Coburn and other noteworthy performers in some of the world's greatest plays, together with innovations in the Institute of the Theatre at Union College, were announced today by President Dixon Ryan Fox of Union College.

PARIS has always been a mecca for students. Her great university, the Sorbonne, the School of Fine Art and Conservatory of Music have drawn them from every land. Formerly these students lived in lodgings in all parts of Paris, especially in the Latin Quarter and in the tiny, crowded streets around the different departments of the university.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP). -- A description of the "devastating effect of radio-telegraph competition on cable companies was contained today in a brief filed by Alfred E. Smith and George S. Gibbs with the Federal Communications Commission.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE are those who wonder whether the industry made a mistake in embracing all the new-fangled ideas that grace today's screen. They regard the success of Charles Chaplin's "Modern Times," produced by a man who continues to live in the cinema's pioneer era, and speculate on the virtues of the past.

Time was when Carl Goldmark's "Rustic Wedding" symphony was popular with orchestras the world over. But it has fallen into neglect of late years to such an extent that it probably was unfamiliar to a large proportion of those who gathered in Carnegie Hall to hear this music revived by Arturo Toscs. nini and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at last night's students' concert.

ROCHESTER Feb 15. -- Friendly difference of opinion with his brother, Stephen Royce, of Crystal Falls, Mich., is expressed by Edward Royce, a teacher at the Eastman School of Music, who declares himself "pro-Roosevelt" and defended the President's quotation from a "wise philosopher" in a message to Congress.
LONDON, Feb. 14. -- Great Britain is dealing herself a new hand for her difficult part in the game of European politics. Henceforth guns are to be her trumps.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty yesterday ordered that an accounting be filed to settle the claim of Mrs. Sally Kaiser of Deal, N.J., to her full share in the estate of her late husband, Emanuel W. Kaiser, who left an estate involving property in this State.

BRITAIN'S new Foreign Minister, Anthony Eden, aged 38, has one of the most difficult jobs in the world. Present portents do not suggest that it will become easier in the next few years, during which British foreign policy and the destiny of Europe will be shaped. Nobody knows better than Mr. Eden how hard it is.

Reports of earnings of eighteen principal gas and electric holding company systems for 1935 reveal gains in gross revenues, net earnings and net income over 1934, and an improvement of moderate proportions in operating efficiency. Four of the reports are for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 15. -- Dr. Walter E. Meanwell, athletic director, and Dr. Clarence W. Spears, head football coach, storm centers of the University of Wisconsin's athletic department war, were ordered dismissed today, effective July 1, by the Board of Regents.

HAROLD BRUST has lived an exciting life, a life of heavy responsibilities and the tension of eternal vigilance. And into this book he has concentrated so many exciting moments that he keeps the reader keyed to high pitch from beginning to end.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Racing over a hard-packed trail under a bright sun, Henry Wilson of Lake Placid today won the two-day dog derby sponsored by the New York Sled Dog Club in total elapsed time for the two heats of 3 hours 27 minutes 22 seconds.

NEXT Friday the 105th semi-annual convention of the National Puzzlers League will be held at Camden, N.J., when Officers Oedipus, Blackstone and C. Saw will direct the activities of the "mystics" who gather there.

Ray Morris, president of the Standard Investing Corporation, sent yesterday to stockholders a letter asking them to support the present management and asserting that the Phoenix Securities Corporation, headed by Wallace Groves, is attempting to assume management and control. Mr. Groves recently asked stockholders to send him proxies to be voted at the annual meeting on March 2.

The Communist party, through Rubin Shulman, campaign manager for Section 22, proposed yesterday a fusion on candidates at this year's election in letters to the Socialist party organizations of the Sixth and Eighth Manhattan Assembly Districts.
Of the letters relating to my communication concerning "covetousness" as a synonym of "love of money," one writer's request asking the derivation of the word deserves a reply.

THE dismal prophecy that it is only a question of time before radio puts an end to good reading, specifically the novel, is nonsense for several good reasons, according to The Saturday Review of Literature.

THERE have been so many books recently on the care of children that one's first reaction to a new one is to say. "Another? What's the use?" But a second look at Dr. Dwyer's volume stills all skepticism and replaces it with the conviction that for it, at least, there is use aplenty.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15. -- The Japanese report of a fight at Asailsumu was denied in Soviet dispatches from Ulan Bator, Outer Mongolia. Official Mongolian quarters were quoted as saying there had been no further border trouble since a clash on Feb. 12.

ICE-FISHING is one of the many Winter pastimes to which the inhabitants of the Eastern States are turning with enthusiasm this year. Many a gay party of young people and old is mobilized these days to motor to some frozen lake or pond for a day of fishing.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Feb. 15. -- Graduate study at Wellesley College has in recent years been tending increasingly toward original investigation. In line with this development Miss Gladys Baker of Geneva, N.Y., graduate student in the Department of Art, is sailing tomorrow to resume her work with the archaeological expedition digging at the site of Syrian Antioch.

PREDICTIONS as to the future of aviation sometimes appear which seem manifestly to have a touch of the Jules Verne about them. Men who have grown up with the young industry often hesitate to make forecasts, so rapid has been its development and so astonishing some of its achievements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- President Roosevelt's proposal to heads of Latin-American States for consolidating peace in the Western Hemisphere contemplates an extraordinary inter-American conference, sitting at Buenos Aires, to "determine how the maintenance of peace among the American republics may best be safeguarded."

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- Illinois suddenly became a Republican battle center when Senator William E. Borah entered the Presidential preferential primary. Organization Republicans had not expected the Idaho Senator to invade the State. Weeks ago the party State committee endorsed Colonel Frank Knox as a candidate.

A Beaux-Arts cruise dinner dance in behalf of the widespread educational work conducted by the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects of this city was held last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. A nautical motif, suggesting aspects ou the Society Cruise to NaSsau, B.W.I., to be conducted by the architects' society in March, was carried out in decorations of coils of rope, sails, life preservers, an improvised gangplank and other ship gear.

Cold and stormy weather continued to have a depressing effect on business in general in most sections of the country last week, retail trade being especially affected by the adverse conditions. Sales volume of department stores here was reported as being about equal to that for the same period last year, although some sections reported gains over the 1935 figures.

Mayor La Guardia, in a conference with representatives of the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations yesterday, told them he felt there was nothing in their dispute with the Building Service Employes Union that could not be amicably adjusted and so avert a strike.

If women were less ignorant about women, men would show less ignorance about them, too, is the contention of Mrs. Mary Ritter Beard, wife and collaborator of the historian, Charles A. Beard, and would give them their just place in the history of civilization and, therefore, in the body politic today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Secretary Swanson, who has been seriously ill at Naval Hospital, tonight took a decided turn for the better after a day of grave worry on the part of his friends and physicians.
AMERICAN broadcast performers, among them Leslie Howard, Lionel Barrymore and many others, frequently assert it is a mystery to them why listeners flock to the studios to watch a broadcast.

THE varied group of youngsters who have been brought before Justice Jacob Panken in Children's Court during the past few months had done a wide variety of improper things and received many different kinds of treatment, but one means of bringing them back to normal thinking and living has been applied to nearly all.

CARLOS CHAVEZ, Mexican composer-conductor, leader of the Orquesta Sinfonia de Mexico, will make his first appearance in Philadelphia as director with the Philadelphia Orchestra Friday afternoon, March 27, and Saturday night, March 28.

THIS tale of adventure starts with a radio call for help from a young woman who has attempted a solo flight from Havana to Miami and has lost her way. She reports that she has sighted an island and is about to land, and a second later she reports that she is being attacked.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- A warning that much of the civilized world was "witnessing deliberate efforts to dethrone reason by destroying intellectual values and loyalties" was voiced by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, speaking today at the midwinter convocation of the University of Pennsylvania.

Officials of Hunter College spent yesterday drafting a new classroom schedule to meet the emergency caused when fire destroyed the interior of the college's main building Friday morning. Sessions of the Hunter Normal School will be suspended indefinitely and no students will be allowed to enter the 63-year-old structure at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, which was swept by the flames.
A group of six Italians, headed by Dr. Max Ascoli, wrote a letter to THE TIMES on the internal situation in Italy and summarized their views by asking "What next?" They answered, "Italy."

IN the newspaper obituaries of King George little has been said of his relation to the world of books. There was little to say, for, like his father, he was not of the bookish type. The Daily Telegraph recalls in this connection the remark once made by Gladstone, concerning Edward VII, that he knew everything except what was written in books.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb, 15. -- According to a report made public today by De Witt Clinton Poole, director, the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University "has come through the period of initial trial, and the soundness of the ideas which inspired its establishment have been demonstrated."

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Feb. 15. -- "The Sunken Bell." Gerhardt Hauptmann's fantasy portraying a symbolic search for perfect beauty, will be presented by the Penn State Players next Friday and Saturday on the sixteenth anniversary of their founding.

The holographic will of the late Thomas A. Edison Jr., son of the inventor, in which he bequeathed 80 per cent of a $140,000 trust fund to his widow, Beatrice Edison, was voided yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin because it had not been properly executed.

Mayor La Guardia will renew his fight for a municipal yardstick power plant tomorrow when Mayors and officials from a number of cities in the State will convene at City Hall for a two-day conference during which municipal power plants will be the subject of discussion.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 15 (AP). -- The capital emerged tonight from two days of demonstrations which brought death to five persons, with the government of President Eleazar Lopez Contreras apparently firmly in control.

The two outstanding college basketball teams in the metropolitan district will be seen in action on the same court on Wednesday night when Long Island University meets Rice Institute of Houston, Texas, and New York University faces Manhattan in the ninth of the series of twin hills scheduled for Madison Square Garden.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 15. -- The United States won its first gold medal of the fourth Olympic Winter Games this morning when Ivan Brown, guide, caretaker and policeman of Keene Valley, N.Y., drove to victory in the two-man bobsledding competition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A preparation which, it is declared, enables the patient to pass through the process of labor in sound sleep and awaken refreshed after childbirth will be described before the graduate clinic of the Medical School of George Washington University Feb. 29.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- A caricature of President Roosevelt drawn for the cover of the next issue of The Owl, a student humor magazine at Temple University, has been withdrawn by order of the university authorities.

RIO DE JANEIRO. -- With the signing of the Brazilian-American reciprocity trade agreement the fate of twoscore commercial treaties was sealed and a new departure in Brazilian foreign commercial relations under the Vargas administration was established.

RETURNING to the scenes of his earlier book, "Southeast of Zamboanga," Mr. Hurley has added to his chronicles of life in Southern Mindanao with what is evidently a selection from a voluminous notebook. In some respects it is a more entertaining book than the first, probably because it makes no pretensions to consecutiveness.

FOREIGN nations often manifest astonishment at what they call the political instability in France. Those that have adopted authoritarian regimes (such as Germany and Italy) advise us to give up democracy, while the democratic nations, especially the two great Anglo-Saxon peoples, are at a loss to understand why democracy in France has assumed a form which to them seems very singular.

As part of a nation-wide campaign of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery to promote greater cooperation among different religious faiths, the committee has completed plans for a "Metropolitan Fellowship Dinner" in the Hotel Astor on Tuesday evening.

The Panchen Lama is going back to rehabilitate the Kingdom of Tibet after a voluntary exile of twelve years, and when he arrives at Lhassa, the capital, his first duty will be to ordain the infant who has been chosen as the reincarnation of the Dalai Lama, according to Gordon B.
