Enders, foreign adviser to the Panchen Lama and the only foreigner ever to hold a Cabinet post in the Tibetan Government.

Fred Fankhouse, the pitcher who won nearly one-third of Boston's thirty-eight victories during the Braves' (now the Bees) disastrous 1935 season, yesterday returned his signed contract to Business Manager John Gorman of the Dodgers.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 15 (AP). -Military authorities were understood tonight to have ordered precautions against the possibility of an Italian bombing-plane raid on the capital in retaliation for an Ethiopian victory as reported by a neutral observer in Tembien.

The Economy Act of 1932 under which the New Deal administration consolidated government departments and functions to effect administrative economy was assailed as unconstitutional yesterday in Federal court in an injunction suit seeking to restrain the Secretary of Commerce from requiring a shipping company to file a schedule of freight rates.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- German nationals temporarily or permanently residing abroad who are eligible for military duty or obligatory labor camp service have been ordered to report to the German consular officials nearest to their seat of foreign residence for registration.

Miss Helen G. Stevenson, chairman of the education committee of the Contemporary of Newark, has enlisted two nationally known educators and several prominent local instructors to participate in a symposium on "Education -- Today and Tomorrow" Tuesday afternoon and evening at Griffith Auditorium in Newark.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15. -- While the Soviet Government shares the confidence of the French Government that the mutual assistance pact will be ratified by the French Chamber, the Soviet press opened a vitriolic attack today on "reactionary" French Deputies who are opposing it, and both Pravda and Izvestia hinted strongly that these Deputies were under German Nazi influence.

LAST season the Detroit Institute of Arts organized an important exhibition of work by Frans Hals, and this year the artist similarly honored there is Peter Paul Rubens. Sixty paintings and a group of drawings have been assembled and were placed on view in Detroit last Wednesday.

NEXT Tuesday evening hundreds of New Yorker, headed by the Mayor and the president of Columbia University, will hail an unassuming, dark-eyed woman as a foremost citizen of the metropolis. They will pay tribute to Virginia Crocheron Gildersleeve for her quarter century of achievement as dean of Bernard College.

UNEMPLOYMENT, an International Problem," is a searching study made by the Royal Institute of International Affairs in England, a non-official and non-political body, founded in 1920, to encourage and facilitate scientific surveys of international questions.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- The end of the legislative week has brought a lull but no truce in the war between Governor Lehman and opponents in the Senate and Assembly over measures included in his program for the better enforcement of the criminal law.

IN view of the fact that Siegfried Sassoon is only 50, one may wonder that resignation to age should so early be the dominant note of a group of poems from his accomplished pen. The other note, scarcely less dominating, is a nostalgic attempt to recover the moods and the views of youth.

Many detective stories have been written, published and forgotten since "The Red House Mystery" first appeared back in the early Twenties, but Mr. Milne's venture into the field of mystery fiction has not been forgotten. Antony Gillingham is such a delightfully human sleuth, and Bill Beverly fills the Dr. Watson role so perfectly, and yet so differently, that the memory of them is not easily erased.

FOR the setting of his newest adventure the veteran Dane Coolidge has gone again to Northern Mexico, where that young but gigantic Rawhide Johnny Meadows bought him a copper mine. But that was after pretty Katie Shannon, the girl he loved, had started him on the road to prosperity by giving him a dollar "for luck."

Members of the Women's Auxiliary of the Polyclinic Hospital have taken over a pre-opening performance of the English comedy, "Mainly for Lovers," tomorrow night at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre to raise funds for carrying on their philanthropic projects.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 15. -Lee Handley's 3-year-old bay colt, Inscona, displayed a fine burst of speed in the stretch to take the featured Memories Handicap for a purse of $1,000 at Alamo Downs today. Jockey Lake was in the saddle.

Expansion of the curriculum of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy to include aviation and more detailed courses in the land operations of ship lines is being considered by the directors and by shipping interests in the New York Port district.

A century of stationary population, made possible through a universal and deliberate program of birth control, was advocated yesterday afternoon by Professor Henry Pratt Fairchild of New York University as the only method of establishing international peace.

The St. Patrick's Day parade on March 17 will have for its grand marshal Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., and will be the largest ever witnessed on Fifth Avenue, according to an announcement yesterday by John J. Sheahan, permanent chairman of the committee of arrangements.

SLOWLY but with rising acceleration a new type of American business man is growing up. The New Deal has aided his development but his beginnings go back to wartime. He may hail from El Paso, or Attica, Ind., or one of the great Pacific Coast cities, or perhaps one of the Southern or New England industrial centers.

LENGTHENING of the daylight hours is causing a marked improvement in reception of certain short waves from Europe. Among the transmitters heard clearly in New York during evenings of the past week are EAQ, Madrid, 9,870 kilocycles; GSB, Daventry, 9,580; 2RO, Rome, 9,635.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 15. -- The most moderate estimate of the number of persons who will have been present at the Olympic Winter Games here is now set at 350,000 to 400,000. This is based upon the report of the average number of passenger arrivals and departures obtained from the railway station and upon the official tourist service estimate of the number of arrivals by motor.

SUPERLINERS and other "queens of the sea" became cabin steamships last week by order of the Atlantic Conference, thus raising a flood tide of inquiry from all who travel the ocean ferry or hope to do so. The announcement involved changes in ratings, fares and accommodations, and a reclassification of passenger vessels plying between this country and Europe.

MONTREAL, Feb. 15. -- A fighting band of New York Americans spotted the Montreal Maroons a three-goal, first-period lead tonight and then fought back to force the game into a 4-4 overtime deadlock with as game a display as the National Hockey League has seen this season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A naval appropriation bill which mill push expenditures for national defense to a new peacetime peak will start its trip through Congress on Monday.

TO tell the news at once, Miss Green has deserted Paris and adjacent territory for, of all cities, New York. In case the reader might ask whether she is as familiar with Manhattan folkways as with those of the French, Miss Green has neatly evaded the issue.

A check of hospitals yesterday showed that eleven of those injured Wednesday night in the fire which swept Lure's Chinese-American Restaurant, Fifty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue, and took a toll of six lives, were still under treatment, one of them in a critical condition.

Concern over the threatened paralysis of the entire liquor industry when new Federal legislation goes into effect March 1 overshadowed all other trade problems in the minds of a thousand or more liquor dealers who came here from all parts of the country last week to attend the first national wine and liquor show at the Grand Central Palace.

ISTANBUL, Feb. 15. -- Four Moslem countries, Afghanistan, Iraq, Iran and Turkey lately agreed to conclude a treaty of friendship and non-aggression and already it has been initialed at Geneva. Signature is expected shortly after the solution of one or two minor points such as navigation on the Shat El Arab and tolls in the Euphrates.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 15. -- Sliding along as though they were out for a morning constitutional, Sweden's tireless skiers carried off the first four places in the 50-kilometer Olympic marathon today.

However friendly may be the feelings of King Edward VIII toward Germany, indications are accumulating that the attitude of the British Government toward that country is hardening. The negotiations that have been going on in Paris and London since the fall of the pro-Italian Pierre Laval appear to be leading toward a better Anglo-French understanding regarding the Rhineland and the Eastern problems.

LACKAWANNA, N.Y., Feb. 15 (AP). -- The Right Rev. Mgr. Nelson H. Baker, the "Padre of the Poor," whose charities have made his name known throughout the Catholic world, will be 95 years old tomorrow. He will celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood on March 19.

AN exotic note among current exhibitions is struck by the work of Julia Codesido, Peruvian artist, who comes to us sponsored by Orozco, Siqueiros and Waldo Frank. Coupled with Jose Sabogal, she is hailed as a leader of the present esthetic movement in her own country.

WASHINGTON. -- Rural electrification under the new Federal program costs approximately $300 per home, for installation and equipment alone, according to accumulative figures compiled from the records of the Rural Electrification Authority.

The dollar declined further yesterday on the foreign exchange market on continued vague talk of inflationary moves in Washington. Although the gold-bloc currency units did not get back to their gold-export points, bankers felt that only the reduced business of a Saturday market had forestalled that development.

WHEN King George died, at Sandringham; a tall, gaunt man with thinning white hair leaned over a desk in a hotel room in Hollywood and wrote an ode of lament. It was a poet's tribute to his King, one sailor man's tribute to the memory of another:

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 14. -- Adoption by the Southern Conference of athletic eligibility requirements more stringent than those in effect in most other important Conferences in the country ultimately may have a far-reaching effect upon eligibility regulations throughout America and do much to break up commercialization and professionalization in college and university athletics, educators here believe.

WHEN Gide passed through Italy a year or so ago he remarked that there is no literary movement here because action and art do not go together. He was not altogether mistaken, although the generalization was perhaps too sweeping.

In Mechanics Building, Boston, next Friday and Saturday the Eastern Dog Club will give its twenty-fourth annual dog show. A record entry has been received for the exhibition, which has held its place for many years as one of the best events of the Winter.

MADRID, Feb. 15. -- With the threat of another revolutionary general strike and violence in the streets hanging over their heads if the Socialists are defeated again, Spaniards will go to the polls tomorrow to elect 473 Deputies to their Parliament, which consists of only one house.

ADMITTEDLY it is only a rumor of next season, but already it is roaming down this one's wintry side streets. It is this: Katharine Hepburn would return to the legitimate stage in 1936-37 under the management of Max Gordon.

James J. Tierney, secretary of the Giants for the last fifteen years under the late Charles A. Stoneham, resigned yesterday, and Edward T. Brannick, assistant secretary, who has been with the club since 1905 through the Brush, Hempstead and Stoneham-McGrawMcQuade regimes, was named as his successor.

The new Federalism has been defined as a cooperative Commonwealth of national leadership and States' rights, a pooling of powers, national and State, in a coordinated plan for the common good. Its symbol might be the Governors' conference, with the President of the United States now a fully accredited member, seated at the council table in the White House.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- Manual Training High School of Brooklyn wrested the American two-mile relay championship from Seton Hall Prep tonight before more than 3,000 wildly cheering fans, who remained standing as five teams battled for the coveted title in the feature event of the third annual Seton Hall College track carnival.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday afternoon that he had received several letters from retired policemen offering to serve on the department's recently announced reserve force. He characterized these responses as "highly gratifying" and declared that the majority of retired members of the force "seemed to be in favor of the plan."

UNION CITY, N.J., Feb. 15. -- The twenty-second season for the Lenten drama, "Veronica's Veil," will begin tomorrow afternoon at St. Joseph's Auditorium here with the first of four special performances for children. Other performances will be given on Feb. 22, 23, and 29.

The romance of adventure and exploration will be a keynote of the gala dinner and entertainment to be held by the Adventure Society in behalf of its endowment fund on Wednesday night at the Ritz-Carlton. The function, which already has aroused widespread interest, will consist of dinner, an exhibition of world-famous precious stones and a pre-opening showing of the new Gaumont-British film "Rhodes -- The Empire Builder," starring Walter Huston.

Mayor La Guardia, in a vigorous defense of President Roosevelt's measures to bring Federal aid to the needy, declared last night that history would pay tribute to the human instinct of the President for his "courage and vigor in granting relief" long after the decisions of the Supreme Court are forgotten.

If the universe is expanding, as the relativists tell us? its age can be determined. Every fourteen hundred million years the radius is doubling. It is easy to calculate when the expansion began. The answer reads ten thousand million years. That is the age of the universe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The farm bill passed by the Senate would set up both temporary and permanent Federal aid systems under which farmers would be paid directly or through States for curtailing production for soil conservation and other economic uses of their lands.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14. -- President Roosevelt's suggestion this week to the heads of twenty Latin-American republics, that the peace agencies of the Western Hemisphere be consolidated at an inter-American conference, is likely to have as its greatest obstacle the memberships of South American countries in the League of Nations. The Monroe Doctrine is another stumbling block, but it is easier to get around.

John Varcica, 41-year-old chauffeur of the Department of Sanitation, died at 4:45 A.M. yesterday from shock and submersion received two hours earlier when he backed his two-and-a-half-ton truck, loaded with snow, into the North River at the foot of Whitehall Street.

FIFTEEN THOUSAND of Greater New York's Boy Scouts will gather in Madison Square Garden on March 27 and 28 to present a gigantic Scout-O-Rama -- a new spectacle and a new word in scouting. Plans for the show are being whipped into shape through a general committee headed by William H. Pouch, chairman, and through the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, of which President Roosevelt is president and Barron Collier is acting president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A charge that an important official of the Bureau of Air Commerce of the Department of Commerce, J.A. Mount, who was superintendent of maintenance for all the Federally regulated or controlled airways, had been dismissed for testifying before the Senate Commerce Committee was made a matter of record in the committee's investigation of air safety this afternoon.
THE touring situation, upon which the solvency of the dancers as a class ultimately depends, continues to show symptoms of improvement. Here are a few of the latest details of activity:
A rousing reception by an audience which filled every seat in the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon greeted the first performance of the season of Verdi's "Il Trovatore."

A slightly firmer tone developed in local commodity futures markets in yesterday's short trading session, but activity was light and price changes were small. On the cash markets cotton, corn, eggs and rye were easier, while butter, copper, tin and rubber advanced.

THE ski craze, which every week-end and holiday takes thousands of devotees from New York and Boston on snow trains to Winter sports fields in half a dozen States, is having an effect on the small communities on which these throngs descend.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 15. -- Closing its campaign at home, the Navy five was turned back by Columbia, 40 to 24, today. The visitors rolled up a 24-8 lead in the first half, but were held on even terms in the concluding session.

CYRUS HALL McCORMICK, born on his father's farm in the Valley of Virginia, on Feb. 15, 1809, invented the first successful horse-drawn reaping machine in 1831. The perfection and marketing of that invention in the generation before the Civil War gave to agriculture the greatest single impetus it had ever known.

THIS collection of forty essays, touching all sorts of subjects of current interest, has for its underlying theme Mr. Chesterton's belief that the vagaries of modern thought "point more and more to the truth of the unchanging philosophy which stands apart from them." That unchanging philosophy is realized for him in the Roman Catholic Church.
LONDON, Feb. 15. -- "Much anxiety'' is felt tonight by physicians attending Admiral of the Fleet Earl Beatty, Britain's greatest living naval hero, who is ill at his London home.

Mr. Scott lucidly explains the principles of occult metaphysics, psychology and ethics and interprets them in terms of theosophy, of the fine arts, science, medicine -homeopathy and allopathy -- astrology and psychometry.

CARTHAGE, N.C., Feb. 15 (AP). -- Foster relatives of Mrs. Elva Statler Davidson lost their fight to set aside her will in Moore County Superior Court today, but gave notice of an appeal to the State Supreme Court.

GLOVES to snap late Winter costumes out of their dullness, and to wear through the Spring, are being made in a myriad of colors. Skins of English glove suede in colors as clear and intense as those Vincent van Gogh used to record the sundrenched brilliance of the Arles landscape.

The improvement in net earnings of the railroads in 1935, which was timely to public financing by some companies, reflected in part a close hold on maintenance expenses, according to an analysis by Weingarten Co. Some companies held the ratio of maintenance disbursements in the first eleven months of 1935 below the average for the three years 1932 to 1934, but in general there was an increase in this ratio in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A ban against the filming of any motion-picture version of "It Can't Happen Here," Sinclair Lewis's most recent book, which deals principally with fascism, was reported by the author here tonight.

Listed bonds maintained a steady undertone in routine trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The volume was small even for a two-hour session, sales amounting to $8,837,100, compared with $10,501,800 on Saturday a week ago.

ACCIDENT records for the United States indicate that automobiles killed 36,400 people and injured 1,200,000 in 1935, with an accompanying economic loss in excess of one and one-half billion dollars. This rapidly mounting toll of fatalities has shocked the American public.
PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Winter residents of Palm Beach will have to dig more deeply than usual into their pockets this week for several major events whose proceeds will aid the less fortunate.

A series of lectures on "New Gardens for 1986" will be held under the auspices of the New York Junior League at its clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, on the mornings of Tuesday, Feb. 25, March 3, 10 and 24 as a means to begin a permanent educational fund for the North Mianus Garden Club in Greenwich.

Victor Ridder, WPA administrator, said yesterday that the seventy WPA workers, who were dismissed by the Park Department on Friday when they refused to shovel snow from walks in Central Park on the ground that the sleet would endanger their health, had merited dismissal.

WITH the completion of the Cunard White Star's Pier 90, at West Fiftieth Street and Twelfth Avenue, another giant joins the procession of great docks slowly creeping up the North River. The trend toward bigger ships has hastened the development of upper midtown pier facilities.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15. -- A new date for the execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann will be fixed by Justice Thomas W. Trenchard on Monday. The thirty-day reprieve granted by Governor Harold G. Hoffman expired at midnight tonight.

THREE issues of The Index of the Twentieth Century Artists, published by the College Art Association, have appeared in rapid succession. A.S. Baylinson, Richard F. Lahey, Peppino Mangravite, Reginald Marsh and Kenneth Hayes Miller are the painters to whom the November number is given over.

THEODORE DREISER in his introduction insists that Samuel Butler's "The Way of All Flesh" (Limited Editions Club) is the most honest book in the English language and one of its ten best novels. Hardly any one will take issue with this opinion.

IN this story of intrigue in a hospital in a South American city are assembled the materials for what might have been a striking and unusual novel. In many cities of South America (the new land of opportunity) there exist colonies of Europeans -- men and women who have been swept out of their homeland by the pressure of economic conditions, who tolerate their exile only in the hope of making their fortunes.

The fire which took several lives in a Chinese restaurant at Fifty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue on Wednesday night called attention dramatically to the fire inspection services of the city. When Fire Commissioner McElligott was asked what the inspection is at the present time, he said:

CRUEL ANGLER? Australia's Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals thinks Zane Grey, the author, is not a sporting angler. Last week it held that the American novelist's playing of giant swordfish and shark for many hours is cruel; that the dead fish are useless except for photo graphing.

RESERVATIONS have been arriving at the Metropolitan Opera box office for the farewell appearance of Lucrezia Beri, who has decided to end her operatic career this season. The manner in which the farewell will be managed has not been decided.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- True Negro spirituals sung by the descendants of plantation slaves will be presented at Demere Corners today before a large group of Cloister guests and Sea Island residents. Intense emotion is reflected in these "work songs" and "ring play songs."

Members of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance have taken over the performance of Katharine Cornell's revival of "Saint Joan," by George Bernard Shaw, the night of March 5 at the Martin Beck Theatre to raise funds for the organization.

ROME, Feb. 14. -- It is now well over three months since the Italians entered Makale, and the great advance that was to have taken them to Alaji and Lake Ashangi has not yet taken place. There have been two or three fierce engagements on the northern front in which each side claims to have inflicted severe losses on the other, but which have left the strategic situation virtually unaltered.

ROBERT W. CHAMBERS devoted his writing chiefly to historical romances and society novels. "The Girl in Golden Rags" takes an altogether different tack. It is the success story of a sturdy, stout-hearted widow, Anne Ardres, and her daughter Jaqueline, who gallantly struggled to win a living from their farm in upper New York State.

THE Los Angeles Public Library has become a central bureau of information on current motion pictures. So successful is the service that 401 other libraries in various parts of the country are following suit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The expected "rush" for the bonus has not materialized. Only 1,000,000 applications were received by the Veterans Administration at Washington and field offices during the two weeks following passage of the bonus legislation, or about 100,000 a day.

MUSIC HIGH SCHOOL: New York high school students for years have had facilities for the study of commercial subjects, textiles and mechanics; beginning this semester, they may choose to go to the High School of Art and Music, which occupies a handsome building on St. Nicholas Terrace, just south of City College, originally put up for the New York Training School for Teachers.

HOW to assure continuous bloom in the border is one of the most perplexing problems confronting the gardener, no matter what the dimensions of his flower beds may be. Planters who give enthusiastic descriptions of their "peony borders," "iris borders" and "bulb borders" seldom tell what comes before or after these specialties, which do not bloom all season, but remain in flower only a few short weeks.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The Pinehurst Country Club will be the scene next Friday of two events of major importance in the early-season program. The Tin Whistles Golf Club of the sand hills will hold its thirty-second annual tournament on the No. 2 course that day.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Feb. 15. -- The Woman's Board of Managers of the Dobbs Ferry Hospital sponsor a benefit program on Tuesday evening in the New High School here. The artists will include Miss Martha Atwood, soprano, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera Company; Stewart Ross, pianist; Miss Sally Gooden, dancer, and Miss Vandy Cape Mrs. Walter Merrill HalD, song satires.

Withstanding a second-half rally which threatened to end its long string of triumphs, the Manhattanville basketball team defeated the New College of Columbia University sextet, 29 to 25, at the Thompson gymnasium of Teachers College yesterday.

Mr. Lincoln's Day, which serves each four years as the great accelerator of the Presidential campaign, has come and gone, and the campaign has been duly accelerated. In the course of the last week numerous Republican spokesmen tried their hands at defining the issues; in addition, and most significantly,

LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 14. -- Failure of the House Appropriations Committee to include on the War Department bill an additional $12,000,000 for Florida's Atlantic-Gulf ship canal simply means that the project is definitely in the political pot for a good boiling.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Feb. 15. -Returning from a two-year expedition to the Orient with a complete collection of the birds and animals of Tibet and Western China, a twelve-ton cargo, Brooke Dolan, explorer and research expert of the Philadelphia Academy of Science, landed here today.

Dissension over the attitude of Roman Catholics toward the Federal Child Labor Amendment is disclosed in an editorial attack by The Brooklyn Tablet, organ of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, on the formation by Frank P. Walsh, attorney, of the "Catholic Committee for Ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment."

ABOUT 10 o'clock of a February morning, the old books used to begin, a son was born to Mary Washington in a plain farmhouse near the Potomac River, in Westmoreland. most famous of the counties of the Old Dominion of Virginia. The year was 1732, and Mary, second wife of the doughty Augustine Washington, was 28 years old and two years a bride.

Memorial services for the men who died in the sinking of the battleship Maine thirty-eight years ago, and dedication of a plaque in honor of Mgr. John P. Chidwick, chaplain of the Maine, were held last night at the 212th Regiment Armory, 120 West Sixty-second Street. President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and Cayetano de Quesada, Cuban Consul General, joined with the veterans' representatives in paying tribute to the dead of the Spanish-American War.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Secretary Morgenthau called his tax collectors to Washington recently for a "pep talk." He gave them to understand that Uncle Sam wants every penny collected that is due him for income taxes covering the last calendar year; that he wants the job done quickly -- in not more than fifteen months.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15. -- Champion St. Margaret Magnificent of Clairedale, superb sealyham terrier owned by the Clairedale Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. W.O. Penney of Riverhead, L.I., tonight won the best-in-show award of the seventh annual exhibition of the Elm City Kennel Club in the State Armory.

Representatives of Junior Leagues from 139 cities in the United States, Hawaii, Canada and Mexico will hold a five-day session in New York, beginning tomorrow, at the Waldorf-Astoria executive offices of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Inc.

TO be genuinely critical one must be in part detached. No matter how congenial the subject, one must be objective enough to retain some general perspective. Toward Charlie Chaplin, however, this column is wholly idolatrous.

S.N. BEHRMAN, whose "End of Summer" brings Ina Claire and Osgood Perkins to the Guild Theatre tomorrow night in the Theatre Guild's fifth bill of the season, is perhaps the least exhibitionistic of the playwrights.

Training to equip young women on relief to hold household jobs has been started in twenty-one States, New York City and the District of Columbia through the allotment of $500,000 of Federal funds, to be administered by the Women's Division of the WPA.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP). -Charging that a lobby was operating to defeat the "Chain Store" bill, labeled as intended to prevent trade discriminations, several angry Senators today shouted their disapproval of such actions and promised to bring up the measure for action possibly next week.

THE largest attendance at a local musical convention is anticipated when the Music Educators National Conference holds its biennial meeting here the week of March 29. Herman Smith, director of music of the Milwaukee (Wis.) public schools, is national president of the organization, and William Bridgeman of the New York Board of Education is directing chairman of this convention.

WE go around now saying that the depression is over. Maybe it is. Maybe we have turned the corner. Maybe more and more workers are being called back to jobs. But it is the experienced workers, the men and women who used to have jobs before, who are called back and there is still little room for the young who must serve apprenticeships before they can do skilled work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Warm debate preceded the Senate rejection of the McNary proposal which would have prohibited grazing of dairy and other cattle on lands taken out of production of crops under the Soil Conservation-Subsidy Farm Bill.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- Two men who were identified by a film taken at the time of the attack Thursday on Leon Blum, Socialist leader, were detained and interrogated by the police today. Both denied they took active part in the assault, asserting they were simply spectators.

PIONEERS are marching into radio's ultra-short-wave realm, long considered to be the wilderness of wireless. They are establishing a new ethereal empire, which may turn out to be a Utopia for the home-listener because static and fading are absent.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- More than 11 per cent of the students of Rutgers University hope to purchase new automobiles this year, according to a poll taken by The Scarlet Letter, the undergraduate yearbook. This would mean the appearance of more than 100 new cars on the campus.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP). -- A total of 25,000,000 persons will be covered by the old-age benefit plan when it first starts going, it was estimated here today. The figure was gleaned from one of the numerous studies undertaken by the Social Security Board.

In following your necrological news from day to day I find that the chronological data embraced in your biographical sketches indicate that the subjects of these reports had at 30 years of age an expectancy of only about thirty-one years as shown at death. The American Experience Table of Mortality gave them 35.33 years to live at 30, but they fell short of expectation.

PARIS, Jan. 30, 1936. FOLLOWING extensive work on the outside accomplished last year, the Paris Opera will shortly close its doors for a four-month period, and when it reopens, Charles Garnier's masterpiece will have been renovated for the first time in the sixty years of its existence.

A freak final-period goal enabled Brooklyn Prep to defeat La Salle Military Academy, 3 to 2, in a Metropolitan Interscholastic Hockey League game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The winners thereby handed the Oakdale, L.I., sextet its first setback in twenty-nine contests since early in 1933.

SNOW and low temperatures had their usual effect upon retail trade in the week, and sales figures did not show up well in comparison with a year ago. Losses were particularly sharp in the West and Northwest, while the South managed to report gains.

Seven new riders will make their initial appearance in a New York six-day bicycle race when the starting gun is fired in Madison Square Garden next Sunday night. Included in this number are three Italians, two Belgians, one Frenchman and one American.

ARCHITECTURE is the one art in which America's contribution is acknowledged as important -- even if that contribution is reduced to the invention of steel-cage construction and its development in "skyscrapers" that overtop every building erected by man at any time or anywhere else on the globe.

A substantial rise in sales, a general decline in operating expense ratios, particularly labor charges, and an advancing price trend contributed chiefly to the sharp increase in profits enjoyed by American corporations last year, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by accountants.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 15. -The Chamber Music Society of America will close its second Greenwich season with a concert by the Byzantine Singers, under the direction of Christos Vrionides, at the residence of Mrs. J. Stillman Rockefeller on Thursday morning.

Breaking a forty-two-year tradition, the Columbia Varsity Show will begin its rehearsals next week with women in its cast. Hitherto the "Pony Ballet," featured skit of the performance, has been composed of painted, perfumed and skirt-clad men, prancing about in the best tradition of a Follies review.

IT is not often that one comes across a novel which seems so intensely alive as does this story of a Manchester Jewess, "Rachel Rosing." Not only on account of the vividness of Rachel herself, though she dominates the book; each character walks into the reader's awareness as a human being, and it each is sometimes perplexing and inconsistent, so are persons we meet in real life.

THAT long lost Hecht and MacArthur picture, "Once in a Blue Moon," which was made in the Summer of 1934 and then placed in Paramount's dead-letter department, cropped up unexpectedly at a recent children's matinee at the Plaza Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Following is the text of the personal letter sent by President Roosevelt to President Agustin P. Justo of Argentina suggesting an inter-American conference to consider measures for consolidating peace in the Western Hemisphere:

I was interested in your remark on Dec. 16: "As the Japanese go marching through China in a general southward direction all is not evil that will spring up in their wake. Candor will not deny a certain validity to the pictures in yesterday's TIMES about the Chinese children in Manchukuo. * * *"

TEN hitherto unpublished letters by Giuseppe Verdi, written by the composer to Salvatore Marchesi, Italian baritone, husband of Mathilde Marchesi, were printed recently in Richard Capell's column of The London Daily Telegraph. The first letter of the series, written at Sant' Agata, Sept. 15, 1875, deals with the proposed revision of "Don Carlos."

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Shick gave a dance tonight at the Saucon Valley Country Club here to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Shick. The several hundred guests included many from New York and other cities.

WASHINGTON. -- In the "Reading List of References on Household Employment," a fourteen-page bulletin published by the Women's Bureau, the American housewife, for 5 cents, can obtain a fairly complete guide to the literature of the "servant problem."

Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under Secretary of the United States Treasury, speaking before the Columbia University Club Forum on Public Affairs at the clubhouse, 4 West Forty-third Street, charged yesterday that President Roosevelt's budget messages do not make clear all the truth about the mounting Federal deficit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- When former Governor Alfred E. Smith made his open threat at the American Liberty League dinner to "take a walk" from the coming Democratic convention if his assembled fellow-partisans endorsed in toto the administration of President Roosevelt. Philadelphia business men began rubbing their hands for joy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Several important retirements from the Treasury Department took place today. The resignations of Thomas Jefferson Coolidge, Under-Secretary; L.W. Robert, Assistant Secretary; E.G. Awalt, Deputy Controller of the Currency, and Robert Jackson, general counsel of the Internal Revenue Bureau, became effective.

Members of society here and in Chicago have formed patroness committees to sponsor a series of benefit performances by the Ruth Page Ballets, the first of which will take place on the night of March 1 at the Adelphi Theatre. Funds raised through the performances will be used to promote the work of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

ATHENS, Feb. 15. -- Eleutherios Venizelos today was accused by his political opponents of opposing Greece's pro-British orientation. The real reason for his March revolution, it was alleged, was his desire to make Greece serve Italy's interests by breaking up the anti-Italian Balkan Entente.

The Marine Midland Trust Company, successor trustee for holders of secured debentures of Aktiebolaget Kreuger Toll, announced yesterday that it had received $750,312 in full settlement of the 8 per cent bonds of the Government of Ecuador and 7 per cent bonds of the Mortgage Bank of Ecuador held by it as part of the collateral securing the debentures.

THE Muskegon Art Gallery, in Muskegon, Mich., has decided to form a water-color collection. Director Frank Atwood Almy, we are advised, purchased recently from the Macbeth Galleries in New York a group of eleven watercolors by contemporary artists.

Northbound yachtsmen coming home from their Florida Winter will find this Spring that they have an inside route all the way from Miami to the Delaware River. The last remaining outside run, that of some fifty-five miles from Little River to Winyah Bay in South Carolina, will be eliminated during the next few days by the opening of a new canal, according to Colonel W.G. Caples, the army district engineer at Charleston.

VIENNA, Jan. 20, 1986. WITHIN Toscanini recently gave his epoch-making performance of Brahms's "German Requiem" in Vienna one of the tokens of gratitude he received was a photographic reproduction of the complete Brahms manuscript.

At the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn the home combination of Frank Pfeifer and Pflug brothers, Carl and John, returned to the winning column by deefating Squadron A, 5 1/2 to 5, in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League match last night. The home forces triumphed when Major Fred Vietor, Squadron A back,

MOSCOW, Feb. 15. -- Steam engines to supply motive power for high-altitude airplanes in place of the present internal combustion motors are proposed by several scientists attending the conference here of the All-Union Scientific and Engineering Aviation Society.

FOR years admirers of the late-blooming hardy asters have been enchanted by their beauty, but distracted by their tall and often weedy habit of growth when an attempt was made to fit them into the general scheme of the hardy border.

KIPLING told the white men of imperial England to "take up the white man's burden" and though they were not very sure what the bur den was they were enthusiastic in their willingness to shoulder it. IT is not a human instinct to be sentimental over cats, on the printed page at any rate. Literature releases floods of tears upon the faithful head of the dog (in ordinary truth an amusing, decorative and amoral creature), but on the subject of cats writers proceed dry-eyed, with more variety and perhaps as a rule with more cerebration.

IN view of the general revival of interest in the wood block, it is especially timely that we should have this "Introduction to the History of the Woodcut," written by such an authority as Arthur M. Hind. Succeeding Mr. Campbell Dodgson as keeper of prints and drawings in the British Museum, Mr. Hind probably knows as much about the woodcut as any one living.

They call him Pat because his name is Paul Andrew Thompson, and he isn't quite the type for such an utterly commonplace name. He is a private investigator specializing in insurance cases, and the problem that is before him is to prove that Harry Mitchell committed suicide and did not die by accident.

TURIN, Jan. 24, 1936. A NOVELTY of prime importance was the first Italian hearing of excerpts of the Second and Fourth symphonies of Muzio Clementi, reconstructed by Alfredo Casella a century after their disappearance and conducted by him some days ago in a Sunday broadcast program of the Augusteo Orchestra in Rome.

The Board of Higher Education has appointed three of its members to draw up a plan for the extension of intramural activities at the three city colleges -- Brooklyn, Hunter and City College. Maurice Deiches, Professor Charles P. Barry and Joseph Schlossberg comprise the committee.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- The Utica Curling Club, winner of the 1935 event, gained the final of the Douglas Medal competition at the St. Andrew's Golf Club by defeating St. Andrew's, 21 to 7, today. In the other semi-final Ardsley defeated Mahopac, 12 -- 7, and will meet Utica tomorrow morning in a 17-end match.

Members of society here and in Chicago have formed patroness committees to sponsor a series of benefit performances by the Ruth Page Ballets, the first of which will take place on the night of March 1 at the Adelphi Theatre. Funds raised through the performances will be used to promote the work of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

The Marine Midland Trust Company, successor trustee for holders of secured debentures of Aktiebolaget Kreuger Toll, announced yesterday that it had received $750,312 in full settlement of the 8 per cent bonds of the Government of Ecuador and 7 per cent bonds of the Mortgage Bank of Ecuador held by it as part of the collateral securing the debentures.

TURIN, Jan. 24, 1936. A NOVELTY of prime importance was the first Italian hearing of excerpts of the Second and Fourth symphonies of Muzio Clementi, reconstructed by Alfredo Casella a century after their disappearance and conducted by him some days ago in a Sunday broadcast program of the Augusteo Orchestra in Rome.

The Board of Higher Education has appointed three of its members to draw up a plan for the extension of intramural activities at the three city colleges -- Brooklyn, Hunter and City College. Maurice Deiches, Professor Charles P. Barry and Joseph Schlossberg comprise the committee.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- The Utica Curling Club, winner of the 1935 event, gained the final of the Douglas Medal competition at the St. Andrew's Golf Club by defeating St. Andrew's, 21 to 7, today. In the other semi-final Ardsley defeated Mahopac, 12 -- 7, and will meet Utica tomorrow morning in a 17-end match.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 15. -- Ivan Brown and Alan Washbond successfully fought off the challenge of the great Swiss pilot, Fritz Feierabend, to win the two-man bobsledding competition today by the margin of 1.35 seconds and thus successfully defend the Olympic championship Hubert and Curtis Stevens won for the United States at Lake Placid four years ago.

AN interesting experiment has its beginning in the first issue of Signatures, a semi-annual magazine devoted to work in progress. The aim of the magazine is, in the words of the editors: "to publish the best available work from forthcoming books by established authors, as well as unusual work by younger unknown writers.

Many native Southerners now residing in New York have subscribed to the annual Dixie Dinner Dance of the New York Southern Society which will take place on Thursday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15. -The Earl of Carnarvon was host tonight at a dinner at the Everglades Club. He will depart tomorrow for London, after a visit with the Hon. Mrs. Frederick E. Guest.

VIENNA, Feb. 14. -- Efforts again are being made to solve the perennial problem of Austria. Although the outside world had not paid proper attention to it until the recent spate of interviews and inspired statements issued in London and Paris in connection with the gathering of diplomats for the burial of King George, efforts to discover a new Austrian formula began several months ago.

STIRRING events that occurred in the Hudson Highlands 150 years ago are sharply outlined in a collection of documents recently presented by President Roosevelt to the Dutchess County Historical Society. The documents, some of them unearthed in the archives of Canada, others in the files of the British Admiralty, have to do not only with the early days of Dutchess County but more particularly with British military activities in the Hudson River Valley in 1777-78.

ESCANABA, Mich. THE people of Michigan are giving renewed attention to the possibility of a suspension bridge at the Straits of Mackinac in the northern part of the State, where several miles of water divide the Commonwealth into upper and lower peninsulas.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 15. -- Sensational shot-making over a soggy battle ground and a day of stroking that saw the course record shattered by two strokes ended this afternoon as a rainstorm swept the Glen Arven links with Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee still in front of the field in the $3,000 Thomasville Open tournament.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- The Boerse closed the week with continued profit-taking, which made the trend irregular and for the most part weaker, especially at the close. The opening of the automobile show today and Chancellor Hitler's demand for several million "people's cars" gave auto shares some stimulus, Daimler gaining 3/4 point and Bavarian Motors 7/8.

OTTAWA, Feb. 14. -- Almost simultaneously with the opening of the Alberta Legislature under the first Social Credit government the world has known, seventeen Social Credit members made their debut in the Federal Parliament this week.

The failure of many New Deal projects may be laid to the administrators in charge of them, according to Dr. F.B. Stephens, municipal government authority from New Zealand, who is in New York completing a two-and-a-half-year study of municipal government in Great Britain, Europe and the United States.

CHAIN of motor camps and tourist hotels, providing in some cases more elaborate facilities for recreation than their prototypes in the United States, is being established along the route of the Pan-American Highway from the Texas border to the Mexican capital.

The scene of this strange tale of murder is Broken Heart Key, off the coast of Florid. On this island is one of the homes of Aaron Tuckerton, who has plenty of money and a disagreeable disposition -- not so disagreeable, however, as that of his son, and not much worse than that of his daughter.

THE universal appeal of modern Russian ballet, Adrian Stokes assures us, does not depend upon its beauty alone; it is due to the ballet's achievement of musical drama in complete form, an achievement of which opera, he adds, has notably fallen short. "

Again the little gray cells of Hercule Poirot are put to work on a murder mystery, and again the little Belgian is compelled to admit that he has no equal as a detective. Although Poirot has often expressed his intention of retiring, he always comes back, for all the world, as he expresses it, like a prima donna on another farewell tour.

THE official recognition by Downing Street" in 1887, Mr. Gibbon writes, "of the existence of the Canadian Pacific as a route to the Orient was reflected in Sir John Tenniel's cartoon in Punch, entitled "The New Northwest Passage.' "

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 (AP). -A.M. Chichester Jr.'s Billowy Wave won her third straight race and the second in three days as she accounted for the mile and seventy yards of the Montreal Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

PARIS, Feb. 13. -- The Summer openings came to an end with the leading couturiers, headed by Schiaparelli and Mainbocher, staging a revival of aspects of the sentimental days when girls wore high shoes and many petticoats. New silhouette prints are inspired by valentines and well-sealed love letters.

JAPAN has resigned from the League of Nations. She has terminated the Washington agreements. She has walked out of the Naval Conference in London. She is walking into China and so creating a situation in the Far East.

The State's contention that Fred J. Hull was in the garage at 225 Moore Street, Brooklyn, at or about the time Samuel Drukman was murdered there, the evening of last March 3, received support yesterday in testimony given by Arnold Drukman, brother of the victim.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Senator Vandenberg walked out of a recent meeting of the Foreign Relations Committee which had been in session for several hours behind closed doors. "Neutrality goes round and round," he told waiting newspaper men, shaking his head in a puzzled manner, "but it doesn't come out anywhere."

THE subject matter of Professor Cassel's new book, quantitative thinking in economics, has long been a favored question for debate among economists. A contribution, regrettably short, to this discussion from an eminent economist is therefore particularly welcome.

A Negro who broke away in Brooklyn City Prison five minutes before he was to have been released on bail stabbed and slightly wounded two keepers and a physician yesterday, and spread excitement among fifty other prisoners before he was subdued.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15. -- Louis B. Mayer, production head of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, denied tonight that the office of Will Hays had placed a ban on the filming of the Sinclair Lewis book. "It Can't Happen Here."

Officials attending the line-up at police headquarters yesterday morning were treated to a rare sight these days -- a man who held at least four jobs and whose income from them amounted to more than $200 a week.

THE first thing to be said about this autobiography is that 602 pages of it are not a page too much. The second thing is that, for all of cer tain external likenesses, it is not to be compared with the narratives of Bruce Lockhart and Vincent Sheean. Mr. Farson does not represent post-war youth hiding its disillusionment behind a gay smile or forgetting about it over a whisky and soda.
ROME, Feb. 14. -- As Premier Mussolini sees it, time and events work for Italy by pushing the Ethiopian conflict into the background and reducing it to its true proportions.
Gene Venzke outran his former nemesis, Glenn Cunningham, to win the Baxter Mile which featured the New York A.C. games at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The price of gold was higher here today at 140s 11 1/2d a fine ounce, and 127,000 of the metal was sold. Silver was lower at 19 7/8d an ounce cash, 19 3/4d for forward delivery. Credit was plentiful at one-half of 1 per cent, with the Stock Exchange closed. Bill rates were unchanged.

OMAHA, Feb. 14. -- Power will almost certainly be a major issue of the Nebraska campaign this year. Advocates of public ownership have asserted their intention to permit no candidate to escape stating an unequivocal position of sympathy with or hostility to this movement.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 15. -- Miss Sonja Henie, queen of the figure skaters for ten years, retained the Olympic crown today only after a lanky English girl, Miss Cecilia Colledge, gave the blonde Norwegian the closest contest of her career.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15. -- The Yale Literary Magazine, in celebrating its centennial anniversary Feb. 22, in connection with the annual alumni day exercises, will achieve the record of completing the first hundred years of life of any United States monthly magazine.

MANY high school graduates and office workers out of jobs are turning this Winter toward one of woman's older vocations under modern standardized conditions. They are taking the free six weeks' course in household service offered to girls between the ages of 17 and 25 through the cooperation of the New York City Board of Education, the Works Progress Administration and the Girls Service League.

Stormy weather took toll of retail business in many sections of the country last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Few buyers were in the market. Retailers reported that dress stocks are fairly complete, and some cancellations were received on back orders.

WHEN a tyrannical lady-ofthe-manor, who is both landlady and social despot over her English village, fails to return from her holiday abroad the villagers are both astounded and overjoyed. Even Mr. Theobald, the vicar, is as inwardly jubilant as

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Rumblings of a new gang war spread throughout the underworld today as law enforcement authorities sought with the traditional lack of success in such cases to find a solution of the slaying early this morning of "Machine Gun Jack" McGurn, once gunman for Alphonse Capone.

ROME, Feb. 15. -- The conversations held in Paris between kings and statesmen returning from King George V's funeral in London have served the purpose of convincing Italy of the unwisdom of concentrating her whole attention on East Africa to the exclusion of everything else, particularly her interests in Central Europe.

WITH its removal to Rockefeller Center last week the New York Museum of Science and Industry opened its doors once more to the public. From the elaborate ceremonies it might be concluded that an entirely new institution had been created.

STRANGELY unlike her usual pleasant, easy novels, Miss Corbett's new book is a venture in Americana. "Mount Royal" -- a series of four loosely connected novelettes -- tells the story of a typical Illinois town at the turn of the century.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- A busy program of sports has been arranged for this week to augment the usual round of social activities for Winter visitors. One highlight will be the St. Petersburg open golf tournament on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Lakewood and Pasadena courses.
A supper dance in behalf of the Prosperity Shop, a permanent thrift shop devoted to the needs of charitable organizations, will be held Wednesday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- Penn easily defeated Dartmouth at the Palestra tonight, 36 to 23, before 5,000 spectators, including members of the Columbia squad who stopped off on their way home from Annapolis.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15. -- Gaining revenge for a 1-point defeat last month at Cambridge, Princeton's basketball team tonight downed Harvard, 33 -- 27, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest in the university gym. It was the second victory this week over a Big Three rival for the Tigers, who defeated Yale Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- The present academic year has decidedly increased the opportunities for employment presented to graduates of the University of Pennsylvania through its Alumni Placing Service, but has brought little, if any, lessening of the pressing need for the financial assistance of undergraduate students.

The art property of Mrs. Richard T. Wilson of Newport, R.I., and New York, together with the private collection of W.H. North of Guildford, Surrey, England, and other properties will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The administration's social security program was defended by Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator, in an address made tonight before the conference of the American Association of Social Workers.

IN a corner of the sporting goods section of one of Moscow's busy department stores an elderly peasant woman, whose bare feet protruded rather obviously from beneath a voluminous black skirt, bent over a little girl of 8 and industriously sought to help the youngster select a pair of running shoes and a gymnasium outfit.

Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, announced yesterday that he would not be bound by the ruling of Federal Judge George A. Welsh in Philadelphia, establishing preference for World War veterans and and their families on Federal work relief jobs whether or not they were on relief rolls.

LOSS of gasoline and oil business to other States, decreased use of motor vehicles, reduced consumption of gasoline and oil and an increase in tax evasion have occurred in the States that raised gasoline tax rates last year, it is reported by the American Petroleum Institute.

AUTOMOBILE owners and makers will turn back the pages twenty-five years during the coming week to pay tribute to the men who blazed the way for the Dixie Highway and opened the South to tourist traffic.
In 1934 every hunter in this country who wanted to shoot migratory waterfowl was required to purchase a Federal stamp. Approximately 600,000 permits were sold.

Scores of meetings of faculties and teachers' committees in high schools and preparatory schools throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were arranged last week to organize the participation of teachers in the Constitution Contest being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The St. John's University five defeated St. Joseph's College quintet of Philadelphia, 30 -- 23, at the De Gray Gymnasium last night.

With the defending champion, W.C. (Billy) Coyle Jr. of the Montclair A.C. setting the pace, the second annual New York State squash racquets singles championship got under way at the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday.

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 16. -- Press dispatches from Manchukuo report that a force of Outer Mongolians, estimated at 1,000, with five armored cars attacked a Japanese-Manchukuoan border force, which retreated without casualties in the face of superior forces. The War Office has not received official confirmation.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, who is believed to reel off a higher annual motor mileage than any other ruler or head of State, opened the annual German automobile show today with the announcement that Germany had effectively solved the problem of producing synthetic gasoline and rubber.

ORDINARILY it is not considered news when a man drives an automobile down the street without an accident. Little is heard, therefore, of the motorists who go the year around without mishap, even though surveys reveal that they far outnumber the reckless few who figure most often in the news.

The immense wave of popular enthusiasm for the operas of Richard Wagner which has been steadily mounting in this city for the last six years broke with a crash and inundated the box office of the Metropolitan Opera House last night, when "Rheingold," the first performance of the "Ring" cycle to be given at a $4 top price on Saturday evenings, took place before a sold-out house.

New York's snow removal problem, which has been bothering the city for a month, was brought forcibly to public attention again last week when a new storm deposited five inches of sleety snow on the glacial remnants of one that occurred on Jan. 19.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- When trucks loaded with drills rumbled up the winding roads of Southern West Virginia on a sunny morning in the Summer of 1930 there was restrained rejoicing in the miners' shanties on the hillsides. For several years steady work at their usual occupations had been scarce, but the cavalcade clattering through the hills meant that construction of a four-mile hydroelectric tunnel from New River to Gauley Junction was to start.

A.L. Burns did some exceptional shooting at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He began his good work by breaking 99 out of 100 targets to take the high scratch derby. Then he won a leg on the doubles scratch prize with 29 out of 30 clays.

WASHINGTON. -- Uncle Sam today is collecting statistics through more than 100 Federal agencies. In a recently published directory the Central Statistical Board has listed all the Federal statistical agencies and practically every government department is shown to have a corps of statisticians on its payroll.

FEBRUARY is a good month in which to make friends with the birds of a great city. It is often deemed the dullest page in the bright almanac of birds. For all of nature February is the last, not the second, month of the year. It is the hour before the dawn when, it is customary to say, nothing of interest happens.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- Harvard won the first game of the thirty-sixth hockey series with Yale by handing the Blue a 5-2 defeat tonight before 8,000 partisan spectators in the Garden. The triumph sent Harvard into a second-place tie with the Elis in the Quadrangular League race.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 14. -- Plans announced by the Oklahoma State Government to sink a series of oil wells on the Mall here connecting the State Capitol and the Executive Mansion, and to hide the resultant slush pits in peonies and screen the corrugated iron "dog houses" with rambler roses, have served to dramatize the struggleI being waged between Oklahoma City's forces favoring estheticismI and those who believe in sheer utilitarianism.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Restored equality of trade rights and lessening of trade barriers afford "the most solid foundation of peace as well as prosperity," William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State, told the Chicago Council of Foreign Relations today in a statement of American foreign policy.

When 115 men, all arrested while attending a stag moving picture show, came before Magistrate Anthony Hoekstra in Jamaica Court yesterday, sentences were suspended and all were left to the mercy of their wives and families.

The ghosts that Dr. McComas has walked with apparently lacked nothing but spiritual reality. Their spoken thoughts were quite audible and numerous, but they originated in no other brain than that of the crafty medium. Likewise, their luminous forms were quite visible, but alas, only the result of ultraviolet rays played upon drawings in anthraeine

The murder of a gossip columnist and the disappearance of a musical comedy star who is the idol of the theatregoing public engage the attention of Clay Daizell, a young man who knows everybody worth knowing, with the exception of Mary Smith, the beautiful young actress whose strange disappearance has created such a stir.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, who represents the district that sent Mayor La Guardia to Congress several times, attempted yesterday afternoon to lead an unemployment demonstration parade out of Madison Square Park and a short time later was held in the East Twenty-second Street police station in "protective custody."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The following public hearings before Congressional committees have been scheduled for this week:
The list of scheduled openings in the art galleries of New York for this week is rather heavier than was that of the week preceding and among the promised events are several of particular importance.

ATHENS, Feb. 16. -- Former Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris gave Themistocles Sophoulis, Venizelist leader, today the conditions on which he would cooperate with the Venizelists. They are understood to have been transmitted to Eleutherios Venizelos in Paris.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- The money market eased slightly this week; call money being readily obtainable at 3 1/4 per cent, but it was necessary to apply to the Bank of France for longer-term accommodation, as the bank has absolute control of the market.

The Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent appealed yesterday morning in his sermon at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, for greater support of the church's work and disclosed that the National Council of the church was facing a shortage of $158,900 for 1936.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- Negotiations already entered into for the placing of French Treasury bonds in London are reported to be on the point of being satisfactorily concluded, but the exact terms are not yet known. It is believed the financing will involve 40,000,000 of nine or twelve month 3 per cent bonds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Angered by an attack made upon him by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin in a radio address today, Representative John J. O'Connor, Democrat, of New York, tonight telegraphed the priest an invitation to come to Washington and be kicked down Pennsylvania Avenue.

Appetite comes with eating. Mr. BORAH, having overcome his hesitations about candidating, is getting ready to plunge into the primaries in as many States as he thinks he has a chance in and can reasonably cover in his speechmaking circuit. Suddenly discovering that he is obscure, he feels it his duty to make himself known to as many voters as possible.

The Rev. Harry Emerson Fosdick, preaching yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, warned of the national danger to the character of our people because of economic dependence and plans like the Townsend scheme.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Unless advocates of ironclad neutrality show more strength in Congress than they have shown to date, leaders expect to dispose of this controversial question as well as the Agricultural Adjustment Bill before another week has gone.

A fraternal feeling between the sea gulls of East Rockaway Inlet and the vagrant wild ducks who seem to have no home of their own was strained to the breaking point again yesterday, and many fine feathers flew in the breeze off the Rockaway peninsula.

Abraham Karp, a lawyer who was disbarred as a result of the Seabury investigation into the magistrates' courts in 1930, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook as a material witness in the compulsory prostitution cases resulting from the raids conducted by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, on Feb. 1.

With United States champion Frank J. Marshall in the line-up, the Metropolitan Chess League team of the Marshall Chess Club played its first match with the International Chess Club of the Bronx in the second round yesterday and won by the score of 5 -- 3.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 16. -- A large number of fanciers gathered at National Hall today for the staging of the sanctioned match show held by the South Shore Cocker Spaniel Club, and were treated to some stirring competition. After a long session, Sands Point Sister, attractive solid-black entry belonging to Mrs. Peters Holmes of Glen Head, was named the best in show among the seniors.

Miss Jocelyn Sherwood gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home in East Sixty-first Street for Mr. and Mrs. Harold Aitken Bull, whose marriage took place recently. Mrs. Bull is the former Miss Peggy Parker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Congressional leaders who long have advocated strong cooperation between the United States and other American nations said today that President Roosevelt's plan for an inter-American conference sounded promising.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Stimulated by criticism in Congress during the past week of recent decisions of the Supreme Court on New Deal legislation, particularly the AAA decision, public interest in the pending Tennessee Valley Authority Act case remained keen tonight and there was again much speculation in Washington as to whether the court would hand down its ruling tomorrow.

The worldly man wastes his life by permitting himself to become the slave of the things of which he should be master, the Rev. William O'Connor declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The choice between "worldliness and other-worldliness" is the issue we all must face, he asserted.

After losing the opening game of his third-round match, W.C. (Billy) Coyle Jr., the present titleholder, rallied to win the next three and consequently moved into the quarter-final bracket of the New York State squash racquets singles championship at the Downtown A.C. yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16. -- One hundred and thirteen cars left here at midnight on what is described as the most dangerous automobile race in the world. The winner of the first section maintained an average speed of sixty-nine miles an hour for eight hours and thirty-seven minutes over 597 miles of country roads to Cordoba City.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 16. -- The Olympic hockey championships, born of trouble, closed amicably enough today as Canada defeated the crippled American team, 1 to 0, and thus presented the crown to Great Britain.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- King Winter established his throne at Niagara long weeks ago and has ruled with a tight, frozen grasp ever since.
Luis Angel Firpo knocked Jack Dempsey out of the ring in their epic battle more than a decade ago. But he did not knock him out.

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- Donald R. Richberg, former general counsel of the NRA, today told an Old South forum audience here that organizations and persons not well grounded in the history of the Constitution were seeking to re-establish in the United States the "divine right of kings" under a new and undemocratic disguise.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- The suggestion of William J. Bingham, Harvard's athletic director, that Harvard, Yale and Princeton abrogate the rule setting Sept. 15 as the opening day of football practice is characterized as "reaching a new high in equivocation, contradiction and complete surrender to one of the basic principles of 'big time' football," in an editorial appearing in tomorrow's Daily Princetonian.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16. -- Argentine public opinion heartily supports President Roosevelt's proposal for a Pan-American peace conference. It is taken for granted in official circles and editorial offices that President Agustin P. Justo will accept the invitation to make Buenos Aires the seat of the conference.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 16. -- Two persons were hurt, several fainted and a number were bruised and scratched today in a milling crowd which the Nazi Labor Service Corps kept in the Olympic ski stadium for more than two hours until Chancellor Adolf Hitler and other high officials departed.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 16. -- Nazi Germany demonstrated once again its genius for pageantry in the closing ceremony today of the fourth Olympic Winter Games, which in the point of attendance nearly equaled the record set by the Summer Olympic Games at Los Angeles in 1932.

The refusal of the Legislature year after year to enact a statute authorizing the judge in the trial of a criminal case to comment to the jury upon the evidence seems to indicate that, for a considerable period at any rate, there will be no relief from that quarter from an undesirable situation.

The indignation of Senator NORRIS and others with the Supreme Court for having declared the AAA unconstitutional seems to be owing less to their belief that the court's decision was legally unjustified than to their conviction that the AAA itself was an excellent if not an indispensable measure.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Lawrence V. Brown, '37, of Port Richmond, N.Y., has been elected chairman of the 1937 board of The Princeton Tiger, undergraduate humorous publication, it was announced here today by Thomas Alexander Parrott, '36, present chairman.

Nothing more convincingly reveals the development of the modern drama than to contrast a present-day romantic play with one drawn from the same source forty years ago. There is certain to be more theatre and less literature in the later version, and this is particularly true if its author be an actor-producer.

PARIS, Feb. 16. -- More than 100,000 persons took part today in the political demonstration staged by the Left parties to protest against last week's attack on Leon Blum, Socialist leader, by Royalists.

Opposite trends developed in the commodity futures markets here last week, with rubber, silk copper and tin gaining, and sugar, cocoa, hides and cottonseed oil losing for the week. On the cash markets only wheat, rye and beef prices ended lower, while gains appeared in corn, oats, butter, eggs, pork, cotton, silk, rubber, coffee, copper and tin.

The Theatre Union was at home to its friends last night at the Civic Repertory Theatre, swinging wide its left wing doors on the first of a proposed series of Sunday evenings in Fourteenth Street. Through the mist came the friends and comrades to find on the stage a revolutionary pot-pourri of song and dance, chants and drama, by turns funny and fervent and generally able.

MADRID, Monday, Feb. 17.--Returns from yesterday's general election that had been tabulated by 3 o'clock this morning showed that the Left ticket, headed by Francisco Largo Caballero, the Socialist leader, and former Premier Manuel Azana, was leading the Right ticket, headed by Jose Maria Gil Robles, by 20,000 votes.
The church is not a human organization but a "divine society," Bishop William T. Manning said yesterday in his sermon at St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, Chelsea, 346 West Twentieth Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- A burglar was shot and wounded fatally here tonight by a New Rochelle detective in one of the busiest sections of the city following an attempt to rob the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roland V. Vaughn. Mr. Vaughn is a lawyer and real estate broker and a collector of antiques.

Whether or not the Federal Theatre Project will pay standard theatrical union wages in connection with productions offered in legitimate theatres will be discussed this morning at a conference among Philip W. Barber, regional director, and Lester E. Lang, assistant national director of the project, and Vincent Jacobi, business manager for the Theatrical Protective Union, Local No. 1.

Climaxing a day of surprises, Hugh Alessandroni of the Fencers Club annexed the metropolitan epee championship, leading a field of thirty-four contestants through three rounds of competition on the strips of the Fencers Club last night.

MADRID, Monday, Feb. 17. -- A sharp swing to the Left in late semi-official returns in Spain's general election of yesterday indicated early today that the government Center party would hold the balance of power in the new Parliament.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 15. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.4, which compares with 83.5 the week before, 84 two weeks before, 83.9 three weeks before and 83.8 four weeks before.

Scores of Christian missionaries in the province of Hunan, China, are facing death at the hands of Communist bands which have been terrorizing that area since November, the Most Rev. Cuthbert M. O'Gara, C.P., Vicar Apostolic of Yuanling, China, said yesterday in an interview at Holy Cross rectory, 329 West Forty-second Street.
GENEVA, Feb. 16 (AP). -- The League of Nations will move tomorrow into its new $10,000,000 palace, a gleaming mass of white stone on the slopes overlooking Lake Leman.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average for 1927 as 100, stood at 71.2 on Feb. 12, against 71.3 a fortnight before, 71.5 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Every year or so Herman Christian comes down from his home in the Catskills to catch foxes on the Erskine Lakes Preserve in northern Passaic County, N.J. A tall, rugged man, well past middle age, expert in woodcraft and a lifelong student of birds, fish and animals, this picturesque outdoorsman is one of the East's foremost exponents of the ancient art of trapping.

VIENNA, Feb. 16. -- Foreign Minister Egon Berger-Waldenegg left unexpectedly for Florence, Italy, tonight. It was said he had gone for a week's holiday, accompanied by his wife, but it was not explained why this holiday was required at such an important time for Austria's foreign affairs when guarantees for the country's independence were under discussion.

Sir Hugo Cunliffe-Owen, chairman of the board of the British-American Tobacco Company, and Lady Cunliffe-Owen and Gustavus T. Kirby, treasurer of the American Olympic Committee, are among the passengers arriving this afternoon on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

Play in the Quadrangular Hockey League over the week-end left all four teams still in the running for the title and enabled Paul Guibord, captain and all-around star of the Dartmouth six, to add to his lead in the race for individual scoring honors. The Associated Press reports.

The average American city of more than 50,000 population collected general property taxes in 1935 equal to 101 per cent of the year's levy, the municipal service department of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., will report today as the result of a study of the trend of tax delinquency in the last six years.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The Reich Ministers of the Interior and Finance have warned municipalities to practice economy to accelerate the amortization of debts and to accumulate reserves. As ground for this warning, they assert that the Reich intends to make further financial demands upon savers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Earl Seibert, star Black Hawk defenseman, punched in the longest goal ever scored on Chicago ice tonight as Chicago whipped the Boston Bruins, 4 to 2, to tighten its hold on second place in the National Hockey League's American division.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16. -- Cyril Cane, British Consul General, disclosed today that his government has interceded with Governor Frank F. Merriam in behalf of Alexander Mackay, robbery convict condemned to die Feb. 28 for participating in a San Quentin prison break.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- The British security markets recently have been presenting some striking contrasts, the flux being ascribed to the changing of preferences in investments. Interest in industrial securities has lately had fresh stimulus from the growing list of increased profits, dividends and bonuses.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin demanded today that President Roosevelt "either sponsor openly the Frazier-Lemke Farm Bill or accept responsibility for its committee death sentence."
