PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- A proposed constitution has been prepared for the Evangelical and Reformed Church by a special committee, it was made known today by the Rev. Dr. William E. Lampe, secretary of the general merger committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The filing of eleven registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A new senior placement service designed, not to get jobs, but to assist candidates for graduation in getting the "right jobs" has been established at City College, according to announcement by President Frederick B. Robinson.

About 20,000 families, representing 80,000 individuals in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, already have been visited in the nation-wide health survey under the auspices of the United States Public Health Service, it was announced yesterday by Harry E. Seifert, survey supervisor for lower New York State.

A city-wide building department under one head and with deputies in the different boroughs instead of the present system of a Department of Buildings in each of the five boroughs was recommended by the Citizens Union in a letter, made public yesterday, to the New York City Charter Revision Commission.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- Life under the dictatorship produces nice conventions and social amenities in conformity with the well-known urge of human nature to adapt itself to the enforced conditions of its surroundings with as little friction as possible.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Fast-flying rumors of a deadlock in the Supreme Court over the TVA case tonight recalled pointed questions asked from the bench during oral arguments sixty days ago.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Republican leaders tonight were whipping into shape the resolution which will be introduced in the Assembly tomorrow night calling on Governor Lehman to identify the "powerful groups" which he charged with responsibility for killing part of his anti-crime program.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Two fast-running youths -- one of them a CCC worker -- captured an alleged hold-up man here tonight and with the aid of a drawbridge, which opened opportunely, recovered $7,000 of stolen jewelry.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Worry mounted in official German circles today over recent diplomatic activity in London and Paris, which Nazis said amounts to a "dagger pointed straight at Germany's heart."
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16.--Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 53 per cent of capacity, against 50 or 51 per cent in the preceding weeks of this year.

Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel, German bike stars, won an eight-hour professional team race, the first ever presented in the metropolitan area, at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 7,000 witnessed the event, which began at 3 o'clock in the afternoon and terminated at 11 P.M. Ten teams competed.

Shortly after the war Captain Liddell Hart of the British general staff came into prominence as a "debunker" of World War military reputations, and ever since he has written many interesting and convincing articles on military matters.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The feature of Great Britain's foreign trade in January was her sizable increase in imports, which were 8,107,000, or 13 per cent, larger than in January, 1935. The expansion was spread over food, raw materials and manufactured goods, and part of the increase in money value was due to higher prices.

More than 2,000 men and women, including many persons prominent in the social and musical life of this city, attended a concert at Carnegie Hall last night for the benefit of the Lycee Francais de New York, a non-profit educational institution recently established at the French Institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street.
BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- New England's "twangy dialect" and the "warm fluency" of Southern speech had a champion tonight in Professor William G. Hoffman of Boston University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Asserting that the President "has been compelled to limit his expressions of opinion to his public addresses and messages to Congress," the White House today revealed that Mr. Roosevelt has refused to comply with a request from Henry H. Curran that he state his views on the question of balancing the Federal budget.

TOKYO, Feb. 16. -- Two kites are flown in the Japanese press today, which, if they catch a favorable breeze from Moscow, herald an important change in Russo-Japanese relations. Appearing on Sunday, they obtain publicity without official responsibility, but the fact that conciliatory, even though un-sponsored, gestures are made at a moment of tension is significant.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Firemen recovered the bodies of four persons, two men and two women, from the wreckage of two homes in suburban River Rouge today after a gas explosion. Investigators said they believed all of the victims were dead of asphyxiation before the blast occurred.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 16. -- George L. Culver, president of the Culver Oil Company of Gladewater and Dallas Culver Aircraft, Inc., and Paul Snick of Dayton, Ohio, were killed late today in the fall of a private airplane in a street in Highland Park, adjoining Dallas.

Ratification of the agreements in the dress industry whereby the threatened strike of 105,000 workers in this city and near-by communities was averted will take place this afternoon at a meeting called by the Dressmakers Union in Madison Square Garden.

TRENTON, Feb. 16.--After a three-and-a-half-hour talk with Bruno Richard Hauptmann in the death house here this afternoon, Samuel Leibowitz, the new attorney in the case, announced that he was "making progress."

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 16. -- In a whirlwind finish, Johnny Revolta, national P.G.A. champion and leading money winner of 1935, withstood a threat from Victor Ghezzi, Deal (N.J.) professional, to win first money of $700 today in the Thomasville open golf tournament.

Captain J.F. Hottel, division commander of the Coast Guard, said yesterday that he would seek a ruling on the duties of the Federal Government with respect to the breaking of ice and the maintenance of lanes of traffic in the port waters during the Winter months.

The Cadet Chapel Choir of West Point, in full dress uniform, sang three anthems before a congregation of 1,400 persons yesterday at an evensong service at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The members of the choir have attended the church each year for the past fifteen years as guests of the Men's Association of the Parish.
The New York State Racing Commission yesterday went on record as unanimously opposed to the proposed law to legalize dog racing.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- After lowering the single-heat course record for the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic bob run four times today, drivers in the Adirondack Association A.A.U. senior four-man championship were forced to discontinue racing when Walter Marvin and his Red Arrows of Elizabethtown tore a long section of ice from the rim of Shady Corner on their second run.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 16. -- The practicability of the Nassau County homicide squad's office on wheels from the standpoint of celerity in getting telephone communication with the police broadcasting stations and other agencies used in the investigation of crime was demonstrated today at Valley Stream.
On Jan. 30, under the caption "Reich Anti-Jewish Law Is Applied to Hungary," a dispatch appeared in your paper which may be misleading to some readers.

By his superb playing at his first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, Robert Casadesus, the French pianist, entrenched himself firmly in the affections of local music lovers. When the artist made his initial appearance here recently as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony under Toscanini in the Brahms concerto in B flat major, the impression he made was not favorable, on the whole.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- Increases in dividends by important corporations and expectations of resumption of dividends by the steel trust, Mannesmann and the leading banks resulted in a firm Boerse the greater part of this week.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- The announcement made by Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury Department in Washington showing how China has used the proceeds from her sale of silver to the United States in November is regarded here as significant because it indicates China's desire to be in a strong position with funds of gold or its equivalent.

Mayor LA GUARDIA'S submission to the Board of Estimate of the city's first capital outlay budget is an event of considerable importance in municipal history. A generation ago New York took the initial steps looking to the establishment of the first municipal budget system in the United States.

Under the title "Youth and the Theatre" THE TIMES published a letter from a young reader, A.F. Lucca by name, in which he asked, "Why can't a young chap of 14 be admitted to a theatre without being accompanied by an older person?"
The desperate Canadiens of Montreal outplayed the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night, but the best they could do was battle to a 1-to-1 tie with Lester Patrick's Blue Shirts.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 (AP). -- The Fair Grounds race track resumed charity Sunday racing today before a crowd of nearly 10,000 persons. Proceeds were donated to the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

The sale by the Budd International Corporation, a subsidiary of the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company, of its controlling interest in the Pressed Steel Company of Great Britain, Ltd., was announced yesterday. Its holdings of ordinary shares in Pressed Steel were sold to the British Pacific Trust, Ltd., of London, for about $5,500,000 and its holdings of preference shares were sold to J. Henry Schroder Co. of London for about $500,O00.

The Bar Association and the New York County Lawyers Association united yesterday in approval of the bill which would permit defendants in divorce actions in New York State to remarry after one year of good conduct, instead of the three years required und the present law.

Foreign exchange rates declined in erratic trading last week. In marked contrast to the previous weakness of the dollar, which saw the exporting of gold for the first time since the Fall of 1934, midweek developments sent the dollar up to a high of 99.82 cents on Thursday, and it closed at 99.24 cents to register a gain of .16 cent for the week.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 16. -- Detailed terms of an agreement between officials of Coral Gables and representatives of its bondholders, believed by the City Commissioners to be the best possible under present circumstances, for refunding the municipal debt of about $11,000,000 have been made public by Mayor Roscoe Brunstetter.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, who with twelve others was taken in a patrol wagon to the East Twenty-second Street police station and held in "protective custody" when the police broke up an attempted parade from Madison Square Park to WPA headquarters at 111 Eighth Avenue on Saturday, said last night that the disorder was the direct result of "crass stupidity" on the part of the police.
Glass will be used lavishly in making the Queen Mary a "daylight ship," according to announcements yesterday from the Glasgow builders of the new Cunard White Star liner.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16. -- For ten years Mrs. Frances Jebb has lived at 1,036 West Washington Boulevard and never complained to her landlord, but when another tenant, Richard Godfrey, 18, started taking a draft horse to his apartment upstairs of an evening she called police.

The League of American Artists was voted into existence yesterday afternoon at the closing session of the American Artists Congress at the New School for Social Research. More than 400 persons attended. Paul Manship, Rockwell Kent, Peter Blume, George Biddle and Max Weber are among those who will serve on the central executive committee.

It is of memory and record that at the meetings of the American Historical Association in earlier days the lobbies and vestibules were emptied by the exclamation "Robinson's up!" In 1929 he was "up" making his address as president of the association, the highest recognition that could be given him by his fellow-historians -- the highest unless the tribute of his former students carried him to a greater height of honor.
The New York Rovers downed the Hershey sextet yesterday afternoon in Madison Square Garden before the season's largest crowd at an amateur hockey contest here. The score was 7 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Federal grants to the States to assist them in meeting the needs of those unprovided for under the Works Progress Administration and Social Security Act were urged in resolutions adopted at the closing session here today of the delegate conference of the American Association of Social Workers.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- Swooping down the Norsemen Hill at breakneck speed and then soaring majestically on his second leap to equal the slide's record, strapping Eric Bryntesen, one of Norway's premier skiers, captured the New York State Class A championship today.

Lloyd M. Crosgrave's denunciation of the "economy of scarcity" is highly commendable, but Mr. Crosgrave seems only partially conscious of the realities of the Democratic alternative of "economy of abundance," without which there is not so much point to denouncing Socialists and New Dealers.

The city, in 1935, rejected 2,233, 332 pound, or about 112 tons, of foodstuffs delivered by contractors and intended for consumption in city hospital and similar institutions, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. He made public a report by W.R. Bradley, chief of the inspection division of the Finance Department, to which the food inspection task was transferred by an act of the Legislature in 1934.

A charge that two recent New York State Workmen's Compensation Law rulings were unfair to voluntary hospitals was made last night by James U. Norris, president of the Hospital Association of New York State, in a letter to Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner of the State Department of Labor.

Wholesale markets here continued to feel the effects last week of the decline in retail sales activity in most sections of the country, as the result of the unusually severe weather conditions. The apparel division was particularly affected, as fewer buyers arrived in the market, because of the adverse weather and the unsettled labor conditions in the dress industry.

Dr. Henry S. Pritchett, president emeritus of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, warns Congress and State Legislatures, in the thirtieth annual report of the foundation, to be very cautious in enacting old-age pension legislation lest they encourage the organization of powerful pension lobbies able to exert vast political pressure and raid the public treasury for large sums. The report was made public yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- The death rate in the State last year was 10.8 per thousand population, the lowest in half a century, the Department of Health reported today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- The top price here for hogs last week was $11.15 a hundredweight, reached on Tuesday and again on Friday. It was the highest since early last October. The top average for a day was $10.90, on Tuesday. The average of all hogs for the week was $10.75, compared with $10.35 the previous week and $8.25 a year ago.
Formation of the Catholic Committee for Ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment was announced yesterday by Frank P. Walsh, attorney, who heads the organization.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 (AP). -- A 10-ton mail plane operated by the German Lufthansa organization has been missing since early Saturday after leaving Natal, Brazil, Friday night on a flight across the South Atlantic, it was disclosed tonight.
Net income of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., last year was $2,242,908, or $1.82 a share on common stock outstanding, against $2,102,058, or $1.71 a common share, in 1934.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16. -- A tropical fever spread by mosquitos that are able to survive bitter Siberian Winters is among the by-products of studies now being made of eternally frozen soil by Soviet scientists.

Notre Dame's fine performance against N.Y.U. at Madison Square Garden on Friday and Long Island University's continued success were noteworthy in a busy week in Eastern intercollegiate basketball circles.

IT turns out that Longshoreman James J. Braddock (union card displayed upon demand) hasn't been covering the waterfront as was threatened. The parade to the wharfs apparently is indefinitely postponed.
An increase of 6 per cent in food prices in New York City, as compared with September, 1935, was reported yesterday by the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

ROME, Feb. 16. -- The great offensive that Marshal Pietro Badoglio had been expected for a month to launch already is a thing of the past. Unknown to the outside world, a desperate battle raged all last week up and down the desolate valleys south of Makale and ended yesterday with what is said to have been the biggest victory Italy has won in her campaign against Ethiopia.

Taking the view that the future peace and security of the United States depends upon the success of the efforts of the League of Nations in checking "aggressor nations," a group of prominent Southern citizens has appealed to Southern members of Congress to exercise extreme care in the consideration of neutrality legislation.

Rain, fog and poor light were the conditions that confronted the gunners of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island yesterday. Notwithstanding these handicaps, the shooting was excellent. A.L. Burns finished with a card of 97 out of 100 targets, taking high scratch honors for the second day in a row.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The Admiralty announced tonight that it was investigating sabotage to the electrical machinery of the 10,000-ton cruiser Cumberland, now undergoing extensive refitting at the Chatham dockyard.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 16. -- Sixteen graduate fellowships in chemistry research were announced today by the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company. The announcement noted an increasing demand for research chemists and "a very definite shortage" of workers in this field.

While temperatures in the Northwest dropped to as low as 50 below and some sections were isolated by high snow drifts, New York and vicinity had temperatures averaging above the freezing mark, with no immediate change forecast.

The revival of "Norma" with Dusolina Giannini in the title role, the season's final appearance of Lily Pons and four Wagner operas will mark the eleventh week of the Metropolitan Opera season next week.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP). -- Fred Jacoby Jr. of North Bergen, N.J., today won the Sir Thomas Lipton Trophy for Class C and F outboards in the first annual international regatta here.

The Catholic Actors Guild had its usual quota of star performers appear in its behalf last evening at the St. James Theatre, where the twenty-second annual benefit entertainment was held. Just before the conclusion of a comedy monologue dealing with California sunshine, his recent operation and New York's seemingly ever present slush and ice, Eddie Cantor struck a serious note.

SOFIA, Feb. 16. -- Foreign correspondents in Bulgaria are much disturbed over a law drafted at the latest session of the Cabinet Council, under which penal servitude may be imposed on correspondents if their dispatches are adjudged by Bulgarian authorities to be "untrue or misrepresent facts and damage the interests of Bulgaria."

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Wheat markets of the world, especially those in the United States and Canada, have drifted into a condition where the majority of the operators have been so disappointed that they are not trading to any extent, and prices, as a result, are readily influenced by cold weather, crop conditions and the cash demand.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,314,970,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Charging that Great Britain is failing to carry out the spirit of the Balfour Declaration creating a Jewish homeland in Palestine, Rabbi Meyer Berlin, its honorary world president, told the opening session of the Mizrachi Zionist Organization of America today that appeals would be taken to the League of Nations, the United States and to the "cultural world" to show the injustice being done to Jews.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16. -- Trading in future contracts on the Cotton Exchange here last week was active at times, but was not in any large volume. Traders are still waiting for something definite to develop in Washington on the measures that Congress will adopt to control the production and prices of cotton.

The prices of cotton futures last week fluctuated within a narrow range. At the close net changes were from an advance of 11 points on March contracts to a decline of 7 points on the distant deliveries.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- Cornell's new head football coach, yet to be selected, will be handed the hardest gridiron slate the Ithacans have arranged since pre-war days. The 1936 schedule, completed today with the announcement Princeton will be met on Nov. 7 at Palmer Stadium, includes major opponents for seven of eight games.

A broken water main near Forty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue flooded parts of Grand Central Terminal and seeped into the engine room and Turkish bath of the Hotel Biltmore shortly after 9 o'clock last night.

Jock McAvoy, middle and light heavyweight champion of the British Empire, will oppose Jimmy Smith, Philadelphia veteran, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight. A capacity crowd is expected to see the battle, which will mark McAvoy's third appearance in this country.

The executive committee of the Welfare Council, representing more than 900 of 'the city's public and private welfare agencies, issued a statement yesterday assailing the Lyons Residence Bill, which would restrict employment in the Emergency Relief Bureau and other public Relief agencies to residents of New York City.

The Finch School Day Nursery will be the beneficiary of a concert by the Stradivarius Quartet on Wednesday night at the Lenox Little Theatre in East Seventy-eighth Street. A reception will follow the concert.

A performance of George Bernard Shaw's "Candida" will be presented Friday and Saturday nights at Seabury Hall by students of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church for the benefit of the Seminary's Associate Mission in Hays, Kan.

Several days ago THE NEW YORK TIMES published a letter from Dr. Robert A. Millikan in which he made the assertion that "the public is intensely interested in scientific advances and the way they are brought about." He lauded the newspapers for their efforts to make scientific information available to their readers, but deplored the scarcity of competent science reporters.

It is carrying hereditary right too far when a son of the late Professor JOSIAH ROYCE objects to President ROOSEVELT'S quoting from that philospher. The passages from JOSIAH ROYCE formed the peroration of the President's message to Congress in January.

Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University charged yesterday that the universities of the nation had placed a premium on wealth as a measure of human welfare by promising higher incomes to those who attended their courses. He related a story of one college president who admitted trading degrees for endowments.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Price fluctuations in grain futures here last week were restricted by the narrowness of the speculative trade. The range on wheat was only 2 cents a bushel between the high and low on the May and 1 1/4 cents on the July and the September.

The new nation-wide home-building program, which the administration is fostering and which awaits enactment by Congress, must start with providing for those with the lowest incomes, Senator Robert F. Wagner said yesterday in outlining the probable general form of the program.

CHATTANOOGA, Feb. 16 (AP). -- James G. Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville Banner, reported today to the directors of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association that definite plans were under way to manufacture newsprint in the South from Southern pine.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Birger Ruud of Norway, displaying great form under conditions that seriously handicapped all competitors, successfully defended his Olympic ski jumping title today as the fourth Olympic Winter Games came to a close.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- If the Court of Appeals sustains the right of the Public Service Commission to compel utilities to maintain continuing inventories showing the original cost of their property, the chief cause of delay in rate cases will be eliminated, the commission said today in its annual report to the Legislature.

Elna Lillback, the most interesting of last season's debutantes in the dance world, appeared again with her group at the Guild Theatre yesterday afternoon in a program consisting for the most part of new compositions. Again she revealed promising gifts both as dancer and choreographer, though, as is natural for a dancer of such brief experience, there are certain problems as yet unsolved.

Activity in the redeeming of bonds before maturity was reduced last week by the holiday for Lincoln's birthday. New announcements were principally for bonds of joint stock land banks to be redeemed in future months. A few small lots of municipal bonds were added for February, raising the month's total to $128,570,000, compared with $267,558,000 last month and $165,634,000 in February, 1935, at corresponding dates.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Birger Ruud of Norway, displaying great form under conditions that seriously handicapped all competitors, successfully defended his Olympic ski jumping title today as the fourth Olympic Winter Games came to a close.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- If the Court of Appeals sustains the right of the Public Service Commission to compel utilities to maintain continuing inventories showing the original cost of their property, the chief cause of delay in rate cases will be eliminated, the commission said today in its annual report to the Legislature.

Elna Lillback, the most interesting of last season's debutantes in the dance world, appeared again with her group at the Guild Theatre yesterday afternoon in a program consisting for the most part of new compositions. Again she revealed promising gifts both as dancer and choreographer, though, as is natural for a dancer of such brief experience, there are certain problems as yet unsolved.

Activity in the redeeming of bonds before maturity was reduced last week by the holiday for Lincoln's birthday. New announcements were principally for bonds of joint stock land banks to be redeemed in future months. A few small lots of municipal bonds were added for February, raising the month's total to $128,570,000, compared with $267,558,000 last month and $165,634,000 in February, 1935, at corresponding dates.

A suggestion that the causes of cancer may be fewer than has been supposed was put forward yesterday by Dr. Francis Carter Wood in his annual report as director of the Crocker Institute of Cancer Research at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- A determined legal fight in defense of the government's vast work relief program was predicted today by officials who awaited the return of Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, from Florida early this week before deciding what action would be taken to offset a decision by a Federal court in Philadelphia that World War veterans, their wives and widows, should receive preference on work relief jobs.

The net income of the National Distillers Products Corporation in 1935 was $7,009,237, equivalent to $3.44 each on 2,036,897 shares outstanding, compared with $11,134,768, or $5.51 each, on 2,022,083 shares outstanding in 1934 and $6,086,905, or $3.23 each, on 1,884,083 shares in 1933.

The cordial reception given to President ROOSEVELT'S proposal for a new inter-American conference gives assurance that a meeting will be held at an early date, at Buenos Aires, to consider ways of consolidating the peace which now prevails in the Western Hemisphere.

" The experience of nineteen centuries shows that Christianity works; without it society would go to pieces," said the Rev. McVeigh Harrison in his sermon yesterday morning at the Holyrood Episcopal Church, Fort Washington Avenue and 179th Street.

The forty-sixth annual service of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York commemorating the birth of George Washington was held yesterday afternoon in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square at East Sixteenth Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Major crimes showed a decrease of 3.5 per cent in the State last year, Edward P. Mulrooney, new Commissioner of Correction, revealed today in his first public announcement. The total was 45,717, as against 47,585 in 1934.

BERLIN, Feb. 16.--The Rev. Gerhard Jacobi, one of the outstanding leaders of the Confessional Synod, defied State and church authorities, the secret police and the Nazi official press, by mounting his pulpit in the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church tonight and delivering a challenging sermon on the text:
Plans for the erection of apartment houses on sites in Queens and the Bronx featured realty items reported over the week-end.

A suggestion that the Republican State Committee delay the election of eight delegates at large to the national convention will be made by former State Chairman W. Kingsland Macy at its meeting at the National Republican Club tomorrow, he announced yesterday.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 16. -- A suggestion to referees that the oft-debated slow whistle be eliminated and a change in the blocked-punt rule came late today from the National Collegiate Football Rules Committee as it ended a diagnostic clinic.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Little attention was given to trading in oats futures last week until the last few days, when cereal interests took most offerings in the pit and enlivened the trade with net gains of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel, the latter on the September contract, which finished at 28 1/8 cents.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Lard stocks in Chicago increased 2,767,718 pounds in the first fourteen days of February. Total stocks on Feb. 14 were 32,028,653 pounds, while on Jan. 31 stocks aggregated 29,260,935 pounds. Total stocks on Feb. 14, 1935, were 64,988,548 pounds.

The sharp attack upon Prime Minister BALDWIN in the House of Commons by Sir AUSTEN CHAMBERLAIN has led some public men and newspapers in London to forecast a split in the Conservative party. There is even talk of a political crisis in which the Baldwin Government may fall.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 16 (AP). -- A Legislature that hewed close to the line marked out by Governor Chandler ended its regular session at 3:55 A.M. today without considering a single revenue producing measure.
Shareholders of the Acme Glove Works, Ltd., will meet in Montreal on March 18 to consider a proposed recapitalization.

Better churches and Christians and better interpretations of "the living, eternal God and His Gospel than most of us preachers have ever been able to give," were enumerated as among the needs of today in an anniversary sermon at Cuyler Presbyterian Church, 360 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Frederic T. Steele, executive secretary of the church extension board of the Brooklyn-Nassau Presbytery.

Percy Grainger turned his only piano recital of the season at the Town Hall last night into an amiable, informal occasion. To Mr. Grainger music expresses definite pictures and emotions, and he does not hesitate to communicate to his audience, via program note or word of mouth, his impressions of the compositions he undertakes.

Koert D. Burnham, secretary of the Essex County Fish and Game League, takes issue with Arthur A. Davis of Rochester, member of the Conservation Department's advisory council, who recently advocated a later deer season.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Governor Lehman sent to the Legislature a message today renewing his declaration of war on organized crime, asserting that he intended to discharge his "full duty and responsibility" and asking the lawmakers to discharge theirs.
More than $8,000,000 has been lent in the New York area under Title I of the Federal Housing Act by the Morris Plan Bank of New York, it was announced yesterday.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows.

HENRY S. PRITCHETT, president-emeritus of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, reminds us that that organization has been engaged in the study of pensions and pension systems "longer, perhaps, than any other agency in this country." Mr. PRITCHETT'S own warnings regarding recent old-age pension schemes and legislation are worth a particularly attentive hearing.
New York's formidable squad of amateur boxers last night easily defeated Philadelphia and Newark in an intercity tournament of the Metropolitan A.A.U. at Madison Square Garden.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 17. -- Three of the four seeded players gained the semi-finals of the fourth annual women's New Jersey Class B squash racquets championship at the Montclair Athletic Club today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP). -- The Senate today broke all speed records for appropriation bills by approving in less than half an hour a $2,889,751,905 measure including $1,730,000,000 to pay the bonus and $440,000,000 for the new farm subsidy program.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- Outstanding in the stock markets here today was heavy buying of aircraft shares, sending prices soaring on prospects of big orders as a result of the rearmament plans. Activity at one time was so great that it was difficult to deal in some issues.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 (AP). -- Weather, jockeys and sixteen thoroughbreds were the subject of much talk today about the richest purse on the Aemerican turf, the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap, next Saturday.

Ferdinand Hirrigoyen, Mayor of Biarritz, is due to arrive today on the French liner Ile de France, accompanied by Mrs. Hirrigoyen. Others aboard the liner include Robert Bros, French sculptor, and Mrs. Bros, Marc Langevin, chief engineer of the metropolitan subway system of Paris; Ottavio Scotto, opera director; Herman Kosterlitz, director, and D. Rabinowitz and Joseph Pasternak, film producers, and Leon Baytout, French producer.

BELGRADE, Feb. 17. -- King Boris of Bulgaria, arriving here this morning from Sofia, was received at the station by Dowager Queen Marie, the Regent Prince Paul, Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and Defense Minister Pera Zhivkovitch. Outside court circles, no one had any inkling that Boris's visit had been fixed for today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Surprise spread through the crowded Supreme Court chamber today as the decision on the Tennessee Valley Authority Act was rendered.
The household dog -- dogdom's most popular representative -- entered his annual week of show-ring glory as the Bloomingdale's Pet Dog Show got under way yesterday with more than 700 entered.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17. -- John Macionis of Yale created a new intercollegiate swimming record of 2:10.6 tonight in winning the 220-yard free-style race from Dartmouth. He lowered his own record of 2:10.8, made as a freshman.

I DON'T get around very much, and all I know is what the grapevine route brings me. So I don't know quite what I'm supposed to say about Dawn Powell's "Turn, Magic Wheel" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50), which is allegedly a satire on the New York literary set. I can see that it is a good satire when Miss Powell is kidding the blurb writers, poor wretches.

BERLIN, Feb. 17. -- A report that Charlie Chaplin's new film, "Modern Times," had been banned in Germany is premature, it was said today at the Propaganda Ministry, and pending its presentation for review by the censor no decision will be forthcoming.
Increased activity in the downtown area, in addition to a continuance of leasing in the midtown district, was reflected in the business rentals reported yesterday, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP). -- With Chairman Wheeler predicting passage at this session, the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today reported out a bill designed to strike out of the Communications Act a provision that radio facilities must be allocated equitably among five zones, with allocations based on population density in various sections.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP). -- Asserting that "the rack and torture chamber may not be substituted for the witness stand," the Supreme Court today set aside the death sentences imposed on three Mississippi Negroes for murder.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The city of Tokyo, Japan, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for permanent registration of its 5 per cent loan of 1912 in the amount of 1,234,400 on the New York Stock Exchange, a step which was accepted here as indicating that the Government of Japan also will seek registration of its bonds on the Exchange before the deadline on March 31.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The condition of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Feb. 12 shows increases for the week of $59,000,000 in total loans and investments and $70,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $84,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $51,000,000 in government deposits and $36,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Plans to make Atlantic City a "super" resort and one of the leading seashore amusement centers of the world are being made by city officials, civic leaders and business groups, it was disclosed here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Plans are being prepared by administration officials for setting up additional power authorities similar to the TVA to make possible the marketing of electricity produced from Federal dams to three sections of the country. Enabling legislation had been held up pending the Supreme Court's decision on the TVA.

Action limiting retailer cooperation in the style-protection program of the Fashion Originators Guild of America to dresses wholesaling at $10.75 and above, and opposing the trade practices formulated by the guild, was taken yesterday by leading retail groups here and in other sections of the country.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- A light run of hogs here today met with only a fair demand and sales were 10 cents a hundred weight lower to 10 cents higher, compared with Friday's levels. Reports on the movement of fresh pork indicated the demand was not very brisk.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- Will Hays, head of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, who was here today on his way from Hollywood to New York, denied Sinclair Lewis's statement that Mr. Hays had banned the filming of the novel, "It Can't Happen Here."
Four boys were rescued from a huge cake of ice in the Harlem River, off 214th Street, last night after a harrowing thirty minutes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Here are some of the significant sentences in the Supreme Court majority's TVA opinion:

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 17. -- In order to forestall criticism that the Princeton A.A. was commercializing amateur track athletics for its own benefit, no admission charge will be made to the third annual Princeton invitation meet which will be held in the Palmer Stadium June 13, Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics, announced today.

The recommendation of the Governor's Commission on Unemployment Relief that the State Commissioner of Social Welfare be named by the Governor was challenged yesterday by David C. Adie, present holder of the State welfare post.

The final Coffee Dance in the Winter series for this season was held last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. Numerous dinners were given, the hosts and hostesses taking their guests later to the clubhouse for coffee and dancing.
WARSAW, Feb. 17. -- A vigorous attack on anti-Semitism in Poland was made today by Premier Koscialkowski in a speech to the Sejm introducing the budget.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Tuesday, Feb. 18. -- A revolutionary movement in Paraguay, backed by soldiers who defeated Bolivia in the Chaco war, has apparently succeeded.

Returns of Sunday's Spanish election of a new Cortes are too inconclusive as yet, and too much in dispute, to permit of positive conclusions. Certain results, however, seem pretty definite. The Spanish Republic still stands firm. There were no signs of a strong reaction toward restoration of the monarchy.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 17. -- Charging irregularities in yesterday's Democratic convention, which gave President Roosevelt his first pledged delegates, Dr. J.A. Lopez, a Puerto Rican resident of New York, has protested to both National Chairman James A. Farley and to Dr. Ernest Gruening, Director of Territories and director of the Puerto Rico Rehabilitation Administration, that the convention was "captured" by Republicans.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 17. -- Dartmouth defeated Cornell, 37 to 27, tonight in a rough basketball game. The victory advanced the Indians to second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
TURNING to the hockey wars, it now appears that Miracle Mike Karakas, goalie for the Chicago Black Hawks, may hold his job "for the duration," as the old soldiers used to say.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Even with its TVA victory in the Supreme Court today, the score against the government in New Deal cases stands at six to two. Of eight major suits, the administration has won only the TVA and the gold clause cases.
Mayor La Guardia stressed the need for new legislation permitting municipalities to build and operate power plants yesterday when he opened a two-day conference of New York State Mayors at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb 17 -- The political consequences to the New Deal of its overwhelming victory on one aspect of TVA in the Supreme Court today are by no means as agreeable as the legal. This background will serve to explain:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The dissenting opinion of Justice McReynolds on the TVA was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Definite plans of the New York Central Railroad to refinance $62,900,000 of demand bank loans on a permanent basis through the issuance of $15,000,000 to $20,000,000 of five-year serial notes and $35,000,000 or $40,000,000 of ten-year collateral bonds became known today at the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Repatriation by the Belgian Government of $96,687,400 of its external obligations in the last few months was disclosed yesterday by a letter from Count Robert van der Straten-Ponthoz, Belgian Ambassador to Washington, to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 17. -- The Board of Supervisors spiked the possibility of effecting contemplated changes in the government of Westchester County this year when it adopted this afternoon a resolution calling upon the County Commission on Government for a comparison between the cost of the recommended form of government and that of the existing system.

Responsibility rests upon the college-educated men of the country today to stem the tide of the kind of thinking that is expressed in catch phrases, Dr. George E. Vincent, retired president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said last night at the sixty-eighth annual dinner of the Brown University Alumni at the Biltmore Hotel.

A nation-wide campaign to mobilize public support for the Wagner slum-clearance and public rehousing program was started last night by the National Public Housing Conference with a rally at Cooper Union attended by more than 1,800 persons.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The Italo-Ethiopian war so far has cost the British Government 32,000 daily for the last seven months because of extra activities by the navy, air force and army to meet the supposed danger of an Italian attack in the Mediterranean.

A collection of books that have been censored or banned at various times in the United States was placed off exhibition yesterday in the browsing room of South Hall, Columbia University Library. The exhibit was prepared by Mrs. Albert C. Westphal, custodian of the room.

Creation of a new shade called "Sutter's Gold" was announced yesterday by Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director of the Textile Color Card Association of the United States. The color, of gleaming gold tone, will be widely promoted throughout the fashion industries, as it interprets one of the outstanding color movements here and in Paris, Mrs. Rorke said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Secretary Morgenthau is giving personal attention to the government's March 15 financing and has conferred about it with Dr. W. Randolph Burgess, deputy governor of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, the Treasury's fiscal agent, he made known today.

Viewing the Republican landscape o'er, a friend of unity can hardly help saying: "I pray you, brethren, do not so wickedly." In Wisconsin the Republican State Committee has had the effrontery to put in the field a set of delegates opposed to the nomination of Mr. BORAH, who seems especially calculated for Badger latitudes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The opinion of the Supreme Court majority in the TVA case, read by Chief Justice Hughes, was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The Supreme Court ruled today, 8 to 1, that the Wilson Dam at Muscle Shoals was constitutionally constructed, and it validated also the Tennessee Valley Authority's purchasing contract with the Alabama Power Company of transmission lines to carry surplus power to a market.

A third-period spurt that brought 23 points enabled the Grover Cleveland High School basketball team to defeat Far Rockaway, 41 -- 33, and remain undefeated in the Queens Division of the P.S. A.L. at Cleveland yesterday. The triumph was the fourth in a row fin the tourney and also the seventh straight for the Cleveland tossers.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, issued an order yesterday directing that the Queensboro Hospital shall be merged with the Queens General Hospital on March I in the interest of economy and efficiency.

Because the Supreme Court took its time about deciding the Tennessee Valley Authority case, all kinds of rumors sprang up, many of them of the most dolorous character. The justices, it was reported, were hopelessly and bitterly divided on the issue of the act's constitutionality.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 17. -- The Yorkshire County cricket team drew the first match of its West Indies tour, a two-day contest against a Jamaica schoolboy eleven that started Saturday and was concluded today. Jamaica made 194 in the first innings, to which Yorkshire replied with 222.

A new and simple treatment for loss of vision caused by trachoma and corneal opacities due to inflammation, which is declared to have improved sight in a large number of patients of all ages who could not be helped by any other available method was reported last night at a meeting of the section of ophthalmology of the New York Academy of Medicine, at 2 East 103d Street.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 17. -- A 44-year-old woman school teacher was shot and seriously wounded here today when the charge in an old muzzle-loading shotgun -- considered to be an antique and not known to be loaded -- was accidently fired.

Eleanor Steele and Hall Clovis, soprano and tenor, presented a program of song duets at the Town Hall last night. They began with a group in Italian by Steffani, Trajetta and Assioli. Then came a group in German by Schubert and Schumann, with an encore by Brahms.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Chairman Frank R. McNinch of the Federal Power Commission said today that the Supreme Court's decision "means a broad Federal yardstick."

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of Stanford University and chairman of the Congress on Medical Education, protested to that body today against admitting mediocre students to professional schools. The protest came in a paper read in Dr. Wilbur's absence.

MONTREAL, Feb. 17 (Canadian Press). -- The New York Americans' fight for their first play-off berth in the National Hockey League since 1929 is backed by the scoring punch of both forward and defense players, it was shown in weekly figures issued tonight by President Frank Calder.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- While the loan to France is purely a private one so far as Britain is concerned, it has been negotiated with the full approval of the British Treasury. Particular care has been taken to insure that it shall have no untoward effect on the foreign exchange market.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 17. -- Lincoln Ellsworth, American explorer, who flew across the Antarctic continent, was greeted as "good old Ellie" by thousands of Australians when he landed today from the rescue ship Discovery II at Williamstown, Melbourne's customs port.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Dr. Joseph B. Weaver, chief of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection, demanded today that two of his officers suspended pending a determination on insubordination charges be retained in government service.

A new method of geophysical prospecting by the transmission of electrical currents, which allows accurate and detailed mapping of the earth's structure to depths of 3,500 to 4,000 feet was announced yesterday as the 145th annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers opened here.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 18. -- The Japanese permanent garrison in North China will be doubled by the inclusion of new troops from Japan, reports the newspaper Yomiuri.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers will offer today $20,300,000 of Connecticut River Power Company 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage, Series A. bonds, due on Feb. 15, 1961. The bonds will be priced at 104 1/2 nad accrued interest, to yield 3.48 per cent to maturity. The offering will be by means of a prospectus.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17. -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., 21-year-old holder of the women's Western golf title, paced a field of national championship calibre in winning the qualifying medal today at the Palm Beach Country Club in the annual tournament for the championship of Palm Beach.

The State of New Hampshire will enter the market on Feb. 28, with new bond issues aggregating $2,130,000. The financing will consist of $1,000,000 of highway bonds, carrying 1 3/4 per cent interest rate, due in 1941 to 1944; $600,000 of 1 1/4 per cent revenue deficiency bonds, maturing in 1937 to 1942, and $530,000 of bridge bonds, due in 1937 to 1954.
VALPARAISO, Chile, Feb. 17. -- Firemen counted the bodies of twenty-nine persons burned to death in a fire which started among movie films in the Italo-Chilean Company building today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 17. -- In two and a half years the Tennessee Valley Authority has advanced far along the road marked out for it by the New Deal early in 1933.
A quarterly dividend of 25 cents was declared yesterday on the common stock of the Associates Investment Company. In each of the two preceding quarters 20 cents was paid.

Twenty-seven chattering, cigarette-puffing Romanies of the tribe that has lived on the Maspeth swamps for the last decade were photographed and fingerprinted in police headquarters yesterday and are to be arraigned today on charges of "suspicion of larceny."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP). -- Prosaic details of a proposed transaction in woolen underwear led off today the military court-martial of Colonel Joseph I. McMullen with having "dishonored the service."

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that Alderman A. Newbold Morris would introduce today in the Board of Aldermen six bills for the reorganization of the county government, which the union has prepared. Four additional bills prepared by the union, to supplement local laws, will be introduced in the State Legislature.

A reception for the participating artists yesterday afternoon at the Whitney Museum in Eighth Street marked the opening of Part 2 of the second biennial, which is composed of work in the water-color and pastel mediums. Beginning today the large exhibition, filling all of the galleries on the first two floors, will be open to the public until March 18.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 17. -- The winding Tennessee Valley, where leaders hope for creation of an American Ruhr, with industry and agriculture coordinated, hailed with noisy celebrations and expressions of delight the Supreme Court's support of the TVA today.

The new gallery directed by Karl Freund, which is called Karl Freund Arts, Inc., at 50 East Fifty-second Street, was formally opened yesterday afternoon with a reception and a distinguished patronage roster.
Aroused by the increasing number of suspicious accident claims against landlords, the Real Estate Board of New York has started a new drive to protect property owners from "ambulance chasing."

MADRID, Tuesday, Feb. 18. -- Jubilant Socialists and their extreme Leftist allies yesterday tried to celebrate their victory in Sunday's general election with a wholesale delivery of "model prison" inmates here. A principal plank in the Left coalition's campaign platform was amnesty for "political prisoners."

Both branches of Congress debated yesterday, and the House approved, the stop-gap bill, which now seems likely to be the only "neutrality" legislation enacted at this session of Congress. It would prolong for fourteen months the life of the present Neutrality Act, which would otherwise expire at the end of February, but would make certain changes in it.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- A concurrent resolution for a legislative investigation of the New York City administration was sprung on the Assembly at its session this evening by Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr., Brooklyn Democrat.

W. Palmer Dixon, home club star who formerly reigned over the national squash racquets field, yesterday advanced to the quarterfinal round in the annual New York State singles championship now in progress at the Downtown Athletic Club.

Out of the routine news from Washington comes a particularly significant and reassuring item. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has taken steps to eliminate some fifty or sixty unsound banks located in five States. No loss will be suffered by the depositors.

Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, who is said to have a gross income of more than $1,000,000 a year from the activities of his "strong arm" men in various rackets, was highly indignant yesterday when he appeared in the line-up at police headquarters, following his arrest at a hockey game in Madison Square Garden Sunday night.
ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The Democratic majority in the Senate overrode solid Republican opposition tonight and passed the bills appropriating $308,000,000 as recommended in the executive budget.
MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 17. -- The Mexican Congress, in a special session today, approved a measure proposed by President Lazaro Cardenas to increase the rights of workers.

The romantic and lyrical interpreter that Alexander Brailowsky showed himself to be in earlier seasons is still with us when he plays, especially when he plays Chopin, but the "romantic" is also acquiring something of sterner stuff, something more linear and less rhapsodic in tendency, as demonstrated in certain compositions that this pianist interpreted at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The threat of Chairman O'Connor of the House Rules Committee to kick the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin "from the Capitol to the White House" in retaliation for derogatory remarks made yesterday by the Detroit radio priest in a broadcast brought cheers and shouts from both sides of the House today when the telegram sent by Mr. O'Connor to Father Coughlin was read on the floor by Representative Sweeney of Ohio.

Bonds with a par value of $100,000 and a certificate of deposit for $142,000 in bonds were among the loot taken by five armed cracksmen who early Sunday ripped open the safe of the Peerless Weighing and Vending Machine Corporation of 22-19 Forty-first Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, after cowing two employes who were about to leave the building.

A runaway Eighth Avenue subway train, with no one aboard, tore down the steep incline under Ninth Street in Brooklyn at 9:30 A.M. yesterday and smashed head on into the forward car of a ten-car "lay-up" train toiling upward, with two men aboard.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange made an irregular recovery yesterday from Saturday's setback to close with a net gain of 6 to 7 points. The passage by the Senate of a new farm bill had a steadying influence though the upset in the stock market unsettled the tone at lone time and wiped out much of the early gain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The Frazier-Lemke bill has been called a farm measure, and it is that feature of the bill only which Father Coughlin has been mentioning. If it were that, a farm measure and that alone, I would be happy to support it, as I have all measures for bettering the condition of the farmers of this country.

Vain attempts of speculators to guess the purport of the TVA decision of the United States Supreme Court yesterday resulted in a wild upward rush of public utility stocks soon after noon, and an even more spectacular liquidation extended to the entire market thirty minutes later, when it became apparent that the first guess of the traders was wrong.

Between bets on baseball games and horse races, Samuel Drukman sometimes lost $500 a day and on one occasion more than $800, according to testimony yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Rogers and a jury in Brooklyn.

If mankind is to attain a higher level of civilization, the scientific research laboratories of universities and other institutions must receive a greater measure of financial support, according to Dr. Frederick M. Becket, former president of the Electrochemical Society of the Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Additional Federal funds for construction of the Midtown Hudson Tunnel were asked of President Roosevelt today by a delegation of spokesmen for New Jersey and towns in that State which lie near the entrance to the proposed tube.

ROME, Feb. 17. -- Alessandro Lessona, Under-Secretary for the Colonies, said today that the sanctions imposed against Italy by members of the League of Nations had left this nation economically prepared for war.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 17. -- In its lead editorial today, the Harvard Crimson defended the stand of William J. Bingham in his request to President Conant to abrogate the presidents' agreement among Harvard, Yale and Princeton as to the starting date of foot ball practice.

Reorganization of the Union Guarantee and Mortgage Company was hastened yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler granted an application, made by a committee of holders of 70 per cent of the mortgages and mortgage certificates guaranteed by the company, permitting them to intervene in the rehabilitation of the company by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

The Northern Pacific Railway will buy this Spring twelve locomotives, said to be the largest in the world, and 1,000 freight cars for about $4,000,000, Charles Donnelly, president, announced yesterday. The locomotives, of the Mallet, or 4-6-6-4, type, will be two feet longer than those of this type now owned by the company.

With predictions of further improvement in the paper industry in 1936, and with more than 800 persons registered for the various meetings, "paper week" opened yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The conventions include those of the American Paper and Pulp Association, National Paper Trade Association and the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17. -- Bagging three birdies on the concluding four holes, Willie Macfarlane of Tuckahoe, N.Y., 1925 national open champion, tied Tommy Armour of Boca Raton, Fla., at 140 in the thirty-six-hole Walter Olson $1,500 open golf tourney at the Miami Country Club today.

More than 20,000 dressmakers met at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and ratified agreements reached by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and its affiliate, the Dressmakers Union, with four employer associations. The ratification was unanimous.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17. -- Small, flower-adorned tables were arranged in the patio of Casa Eleda for the dinner for 200 which Mr. and Mrs. William Theodore Hoops gave tonight in honor of former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Mr. and Mrs. Grover Whalen, the latter their house guests.

Mme. Olga Karpovskaya, wife of Vyacheslaff Molotoff, President of the Council of Commissars and Premier of the Soviet Union, began an extensive tour yesterday of American factories making cosmetics and toilet accessories. She is the founder and director of the Soviet Tege, a cosmetic trust, which showed a net profit of $84,000,000 last year.
ROME, Feb. 17. -- Rumors of peace negotiations were rife in Rome political and diplomatic circles today, but there is as yet no confirmation either official or unofficial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Legislation that would place all postmasters under Civil Service, instead of only those of the Fourth Class as at present, was discussed with President Roosevelt today by a group of Congressional and administrative officials.

ENDA JESUS, Ethiopia, Feb. 16 (Delayed. By Military Plane to Asmara). -- The Ethiopian force was in full flight southward today after a smashing defeat in the six-day Enderta battle. Italian aviators, who made more than 100 reconnaissance flights, sighted retreating columns almost as far south as Alaji and bombed some of them.

Mrs. Arthur Bergh gave a luncheon yesterday at the Lombardy to celebrate the birthday of her debutante daughter, Miss Jerry Bergh. The other guests, several of whom are also debutantes, were the Misses Lucy Hutchinson, Lorraine Graves, Dorothea Lehmann, Margaret Sillcocks, Phyllis Gillespie, Audrey Thomas, Ida Louise Tobey, Priscilla Todd and Helen Huckins of California, who will be introduced to society next season.

The New Deal "is not so hot in Louisiana," it was reported here yesterday by Governor-elect Richard W. Leche of that State. But Governor J.C.B. Ehringhaus of North Carolina declared the New Deal had the "overwhelming support" of voters in his State.

ROME, Feb. 17. -- A desperate but futile Ethiopian counter-attack following a great Italian victory on the northern front was reported tonight by the Stefani News Agency correspondent in Asmara, Eritrea.

Daniel Gutman in a recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES wrote: "It is to be expected that Democrats as well as Republicans who represent interests such as Mr. Davis does will take up the cudgels against the present administration and engage in bitter and venomous attacks upon the President."
With the first Federal Theatre Project show in a Broadway house scheduled to open tonight, officials of the project and the stagehands' union had failed yesterday to reach an agreement on wages.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The first chapter of a story of the arming on land and in the air of the Sao Paulo revolutionists in Brazil in the Fall of 1932, describing their transfer of about $1,115,000 to the Guaranty Trust Company in New York and other events in connection with the buying of war equipment, was told today before the Senate Munitions Committee.
After a brief visit in New York, Walter Duranty, author of "I Write as I Please," is sojourning in Florida. He is working on a novel, tentatively entitled "Nerves of Granite."

BERLIN, Feb. 17. -- Germany is beginning to break through the boycott blockade established against her goods in America and elsewhere. Furthermore, she has been getting the best of the United States in the trade war which, on one hand, has virtually barred American finished goods from the German market, and on the other has led to abrogation by the United States of the most-favored-nation clause in respect to Germany.
A $120,000 apartment house and a $100,000 factory were among the projects filed with the Brooklyn Department of Buildings yesterday.

MADRID, Feb. 17. -- As disorders spread today on the heels of what appeared to have been a sweeping Left victory in yesterday's general election, the family of President Niceto Alcala Zamora moved from its residence in Francisco Giner Street into the Presidential Palace, which is virtually a fortress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Railroad Coordinator, will be informed by railroad labor tomorrow that the organized employes of the carriers will oppose his proposal for the consolidation of terminal facilities in eleven cities, it was reported here today after a meeting of the leaders of the Railway Labor Executives Association.

Final negotiations for the appearance of the Boston Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Serge Koussevitzky at the Berkshire Symphonic Festival were completed yesterday, according to an announcement by Miss Gertrude Robinson Smith, president of the undertaking.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine replied yesterday to Representative Vito Marcantonio's challenge for a gymnasium bout by offering to meet the challenger "with a flit-gun" in Madison Square Garden.

Sears, Roebuck Co. of Chicago have bought a membership in the New York Commodity Exchange, Inc., in the name of Fowler B. McConnell, assistant to the president of the company, the Exchange announced yesterday. J.C. Cuppia of E.A. Pierce Co., former acting president of the Exchange, sponsored the application of Mr. McConnell.
In celebration of its fiftieth anniversary the Architectural League of New York opened its annual exhibition last night in the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Feb. 17 (Canadian Press). -- Australia clinched the cricket series with South Africa today, overwhelming its opponents in the fourth test by an innings and 184 runs. In recording their third victory in the five-game series, the Aussies scored 439 runs, against 157 and 98 by the Springboks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Under procedure permitting only twenty minutes of debate on each side of the question and prohibiting the offering of amendments, the House today passed the compromise resolution to extend the existing Neutrality Act until May 1, 1937, with the addition of a prohibition on loans and credits to belligerents and an exemption in favor of American republics in any conflict with non-American powers.
A program of contemporary French music was given last night under the patronage of Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General here, at the New School, 66 West Twelfth Street.

As a visitor to New York during the last two snowstorms I have been impressed with the need for a more efficient plan of snow removal and a greater degree of cooperation on the part of the directing agencies.

Jack McAvoy, holder of the Lord Lonsdale belts emblematic of the middleweight and light heavyweight titles of Great Britain, scored a two-round knockout victory over Jimmy Smith, Philadelphia veteran, at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The bout had been scheduled for ten rounds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The separate concurring opinion of Justice Brandeis of the TVA, in which Justices Cardozo, Stone and Roberts joined, was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Cabinet members, labor leaders and pro-administration members of Congress praised the Supreme Court's decision on the TVA today, some asserting that it permitted a "yardstick" for measuring electric rates and indicated a "humanitarian" viewpoint.

MUNICH, Feb. 17. -- The second case of a United States citizen to be tried before the so-called People's Court opened here today when Kari Nisselbeck, a naturalized American of German origin who has been held in prison for the past nine months, was placed on trial charged with "attempting high treason."
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- There is every indication that the disastrous four-year trade war between Great Britain and the Irish Free State is being gradually abandoned without any great political palaver.

Well-known members of society, headed by Mrs. Albert Francke Jr., are sponsoring an unusual contest, set for this afternoon in the auditorium of the Children's Welfare Federation, in which the city's champion child yodeler will be chosen by a committee, of which Dr. Victor Nef, Swiss Consul General at New York, is chairman.

The Republican party stands today at the crossroads and must present a constructive program or "dissolve and disappear through sheer incompetence," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, told members of the Ninth Assembly District Republican Club last night at a meeting at the Hotel Greystone.

Mayor La Guardia intervened again yesterday in the new conflict between realty interests and the Building Service Employes Union, which revived the threat of a strike of 20,000 elevator operators and other service employes in the fur and garment district.

The New York Americans will present local hockey fans with a new face tonight at Madison Square Garden, where they will oppose the Montreal Maroons, Stanley Cup champions, in a National Hockey League encounter. The newcomer, Jeff Kalbfleisch, is expected to see service on the defense.

VIENNA, Feb. 17. -- Whether German or foreign, no member of the opera organization in the Third Reich will hereafter be permitted to accept engagements abroad unless he is a reasonably dependable Nazi, it is learned here.

A Congressional investigation of the Federal Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection was urged yesterday by the Morro Castle Safety at Sea Association, whose membership is made up of passengers who were saved when the Ward liner Morro Castle burned and of the relatives of passengers who were lost.

Except for a slight improvement in sugar futures, moderate declines were in evidence on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. There were no gains on the cash markets, where the grains, cotton, flour, butter, lard, hides, rubber, silk and standard tin declined.

An issue of $16,000,000 first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds of the Public Service Company of Oklahoma, due on Feb. 1, 1966, will be offered today at 101 1/2 and accrued interest by a banking group headed by Field Glore Co. and including Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., A.G. Becker Co., Harris, Hall Co., Inc., Bonbright Co., Inc., and Brown Harriman Co., Inc.

The Princess Ida of TENNYSON'S "Medley" in "the college like a man's" where women students were taught "all that men are taught" recalled with pride the foundress of the Babylonian Wall, the Rhodope that built the Pyramid, Clelia, Cornelia, "the Roman brows of Agrippina" and others whose "noble forms" in statues adorned the hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP). -- Army engineers promised quick action today on a flood control plan for the New York and Pennsylvania counties swept by floods in July with heavy loss of life and property.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Originally constructed at a cost of about $130,000,000, the Muscle Shoals project, including Wilson Dam, was intended as a war munitions plant. at which nitrates would be made. But it was not completed before the signing of the armistice, so became a "white elephant."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Although fewer orders for locomotives were received in 1935, the Baldwin Locomotive Works reported increased sales and a reduced loss in the twelve months, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday. Both surplus, however, and the company's investment in the General Steel Castings Corporation were smaller.

Net profit of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and subsidiaries for 1935 was $5,452,240 after Federal taxes, depreciation, interest, subsidiary dividends and other charges. After dividend requirements on the $7 preferred stock, on which there is an accumulation of unpaid dividends, the earnings were equal to 18 cents each on 1,540,542 no-par shares of common stock.
BERLIN, Feb. 17. -- The Boerse opened the week with continued liquidation, especially among former favorites. A few specialties continued firm. The turnover, however, remained insignificant.

TOKYO, Feb. 17. -- Eiji Amau, Foreign Office spokesman, denied today that the government was considering a non-aggression pact with the Soviet. Japan's policy toward Russia, he said, remains unchanged. It considers removal of the causes of aggression more important than non-aggression pacts and seeks to solve all outstanding questions with Russia one by one.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. Stevenson Scott of New York were guests this afternoon of Joseph E. Widener in the president's box at the Hialeah races.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Much preliminary work will be necessary before arrangements are completed for the inter-American peace conference that President Roosevelt has suggested in his letters to the heads of Latin-American States.

Allowances asked by attorneys and others in two reorganization proceedings were reduced yesterday in the Federal court here. Judge Knox cut requests for $138,734 in the case of the New York Athletic Club to approximately $86,500. Judge Mack reduced allowances in the reorganization of Fox Metropolitan Playhouses, in which counsel for a noteholders' protective committee are to receive $100,000 instead of the $125,000 asked.

Representative MARCANTONIO recalls that back in 1926 he was arrested, with Mr. LA GUARDIA, for picketing in a dress workers' strike. He goes on to ask, "How can I be condemned if I believe in 1936 what the Mayor taught me in 1926?"

All other marketwise topics were crowded into the background yesterday by the decision of the Supreme Court in upholding the right of the Tennessee Valley Authority to sell power from the Wilson Dam. In a word, the New Deal forces won a victory and the holders of utility securities were disappointed; there was disappointment, too, that the court did not pass upon other controversial phases of the TVA.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17. -- The heaviest, deepest and most holding racing strip in the history of Hialeah Park prevailed beneath sunny skies today. As a result, the featured Lonesome Pine Purse drew only three starters, and Mrs. Charles S. Bromley's 4-year-old gelding Brannon sped home by four lengths for his first triumph in five local starts.

Although Mr. Behrman is the most modest of our makers of comedy, he is also the keenest. In "End of Summer," which the Theatre Guild mounted in its own playhouse last evening, he has spun another one of those tolerant, witty, gently probing essays in modern thinking.

This evening's opening -- aside from the expected WPA's "Jefferson Davis" -- is "Come Angel Band," a realistic play about the South by Dudley Nichols and Stuart Anthony. It is to arrive at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, with a company including Curtis Cooksey, Elisha Cook Jr., Eleanor Lynn and Richard Taber.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- When the Supreme Court ruled today in its eight-to-one opinion that the government possessed the right as a measure of national defense and as an aid to navigation to build the Wilson Dam at Muscle Shoals and to sell the power produced at the dam, it declined to pass upon the government's authority to acquire or operate local or urban distribution systems.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17. -- Relations between the Soviet Union and Japan are probably less dangerous than they appear from the outside. This correspondent has gathered this view in recent days from the most authoritative sources among Soviet officials and Japanese and neutral diplomats.

The slate of delegates at large and alternates at large to the Republican National Convention, who will be elected today by the Republican State Committee at the National Republican Club, was completed yesterday, except for two alternates, by Chairman Melvin C. Eaton in a series of conferences with party leaders.

TRENTON, Feb. 17. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman indicated today that the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann may go once again before the New Jersey Court of Pardons, which has the power to commute his sentence to life imprisonment.

Five properties each in Manhattan and the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The Manhattan offerings included a ten-story apartment house at Broadway and 165th Street and an eight-story loft building at East End Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The House Rules Committee unanimously reported today the Bell resolution to investigate the activities of groups sponsoring money-raising drives for pension plans, including the Townsend plan.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 (AP). -- Professor Paul, far back in his four other starts this Winter, defeated seven other 3-year-olds in the one-mile feature event at the Fair Grounds today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- Cod liver oil today was offered to medicine in a new form: A paste which heals wounds on the body's surface.

Subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation have received orders for 35,500 tons of steel rails, it became known yesterday. The Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company has an order for 17,800 tons from the St. Louis-San Francisco, 3,000 tons from the Gulf, Mobile Northern and 700 tons from the Mobile Ohio Railroad.
ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Following is the text of Governor Lekman's special message to the Legislature this evening:

ALBANY, Feb. 17 (AP). -- A notable decline in the number of injuries, lives lost and accidents in the transportation utilities of New York State has resulted from the speeding up of grade crossing elimination and emphasis on safety devices, the Public Service Commission asserted today in its annual legislative report.

Owners of the twenty new 32-foot waterline class sloops were tendered a dinner last night at the New York Yacht Club by Vice Commodore E. Townsend Irvin and former Commodore George Nichols, at which plans for their racing next Summer were discussed.

ROME, Feb. 17. -- Two official war bulletins issued today described various phases of the Enderta battle and gave additional details of the present situation in Northern Ethiopia. Both tended to increase the proportions of the Italian victory.

Gustavus Town Kirby, treasurer of the American Olympic Committee, returned to the United States from Garmisch-Partenkirchen yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, bringing with him glowing reports of German Olympic facilities, of German non-discriminatory tactics and of the success of the Olympic ideal.

Heavy trading attended the progress of the TVA decision over the news tickers in Wall Street yesterday. When the flash appeared that the decision was being read, and by Chief Justice Hughes, a buying wave which surpassed any witnessed in many years took the principal utility shares up to the highest levels in many months.
Some time ago Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, delivered an address to representatives of various civic associations on the subject "The City's Water Crisis."

PARIS, Feb. 17. -- Official announcement was made this evening that an agreement had been reached between the French Treasury and a group of London bankers headed by Lazard Brothers Co. for a credit of 40,000,000 (about $200,000,000 at yesterday's exchange).
