WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- President Roosevelt conferred with a Congressional committee on proposed legislation to put all postmasters under civil service; received a New Jersey delegation which asked an additional $9,000,000 to build approaches to the Midtown Hudson Tunnel and discussed farm legislation with Representative Lemke, Senator Robinson and Representative Jones.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade had a heavy undertone the greater part of today, but the pressure was mainly on the May delivery. The weakness in stocks had considerable to do with the recession of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel in the near-by delivery, and there was also selling which the trade regarded as liquidation for Eastern account.

Public utility circles here did not disguise the feeling of frustration which developed when the Supreme Court's disposition of the TVA case became known, and in some quarters there was explicit criticism of the manner in which the case had been handled by the private interests involved.

MUNICH, Feb. 18. -- The appearance of a convict in penitentiary garb on the witness stand and the production of varied concrete testimony to prove an alibi featured today's session of the trial of Karl Nisselbeck, a naturalized United States citizen of German origin, here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- The price for hogs advanced 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight here today to a new high level since Oct. 9 and to the best level at this season in six years. Sales were made at $11.20 in the early trading, when supplies were light because the cold weather had delayed the arrival of trains.

MADRID, Wednesday, Feb. 19. -- At the Ministry of War late last night it was admitted that former Premier Diego Martinez-Barrios had called on War Minister Nicolas Molero and reported he had heard rumors of a military plot to seize the government and prevent the formation of a Leftist Cabinet.

Fire Department records show that fires and losses have decreased since 1933, when inspection for storage of combustibles was transferred from that department to the borough building departments, Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, declared last night.

As Mr. COOLIDGE'S preacher in the anecdote was against sin, so the Republicans at Albany are against crime; that is, generally and in theory. They set up the Commission on the Administration of Justice, the Law Revision Committee, the Judicial Council. But they are often reluctant to follow the recommendations of the bodies they establish.

The favorite author of critics of the New Deal has been Lewis Carroll. Washington under Roosevelt has almost daily reminded them of scenes from Alice in Wonderland. They have pictured Cheshire cats among the cherry blossoms, white rabbits and dormice in the brain trust, tricks in hearts at the microphones, and mad hatters all over the place.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18. -- The annual Romany performance, "Bagdad," was presented tonight before an audience of more than 500 in the Orange Gardens of the Everglades Club. Mrs. Frederick K. Herpel and Miss Nancy Gugenheim wrote the libretto for the musical spectacle, played against a background of minarets, mosques and palms.
The fortieth anniversary of the Colonial Daughters of the Seventeenth Century was celebrated at the annual luncheon of the society yesterday at the Motel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Representative Sol Bloom of New York offered 20 to 1 odds today that Walter Johnson would not succeed in throwing a silver dollar across the Rappahannock River on the 204th anniversary of George Washington's Birthday on Saturday.

The system of accounting decreed by the Federal Communications Commission for telephone companies doing more than $50,000 interstate business annually was upheld as constitutional yesterday by a Federal Statutory Court which tried the injunction suit instituted by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and twenty-eight subsidiaries and affiliates.

PARIS, Feb. 18. -- Contrary to the expectation that generally had been entertained that the conclusion of the 40,000,000 credit in London would have an encouraging effect on the Bourse and especially on rentes, the market today proved to be weak and fluctuating.
LONDON, Feb. 18. -- After having been kept alive since 1932 by artificial respiration, S. Crosby Halahan died today at Chiddingfold, Surrey, at the age of 65 years.

Jose de Capriles of the University Fencers Club won the national junior foils championship last night in the Columbia gymnasium. Competing in the final round of the annual event, de Capriles took eight of his nine bouts, losing only to Frank Ingoglia of the New York A.C.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The bulk of a fund of $1,115,000 deposited in the Guaranty Trust Company of New York in September and October of 1932 and used to buy airplanes, machine guns and rifle cartridges for revolutionists in Sao Paulo, Brazil, was raised in New York City the Senate Munitions Investigation Committee learned today.
The Police Commissioner has announced his plan to take "ringleaders into custody, but not to book them on charges."

With more cotton reported being released from the producers' pool, prices on the Cotton Exchange held yesterday within the narrowest limits in some time, closing 2 points higher to 6 points lower than on Monday. Trade demands absorbed contracts, while further arbitrage buying of July against sales of the same month in Liverpool imparted a steady tone throughout the greater part of the session.

Several card parties will take place in the near future to raise funds for charity. Members of the board of directors of the Catholic Young Women's Club will hold their annual luncheon bridge in behalf of the club on March 3 at the Plaza.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne appeared before a joint legislative hearing today to urge enactment of measures which would give the Conservation Commission the right to make regulations for hunting and fishing in the State.

President ROOSEVELT conferred again at the White House yesterday with a group of advisers including Treasury officials and heads of the chief credit agencies of the Government. The subject on the carpet was the question of canceling unused lending authorizations which have been voted by Congress during the past three years.

New York City again will have the indoor intercollegiate polo championship, according to the announcement yesterday from the tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America. This announcement set the dates for the Eastern, national, college and schoolboy play and assured championship polo in the rings of Squadron A in Manhattan and Squadron C in Brooklyn from March 11 through March 28.

Machinery for the speedy settlement of industrial disputes is provided in a local law introduced in the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly yesterday by Alderman A. Newbold Morris, Manhattan Republican.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--Two Catholic members of the House lashed from the floor of the chamber today at Father Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit, with one of them calling him a "silver-brick artist" and drawing a comparison with Judas Iscariot.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 18. -- The Brazilian Government has accepted with the greatest pleasure President Roosevelt's proposal for an inter-American peace conference and the Roosevelt gesture finds a response in all Brazilian hearts, President Getulio Verges said today.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York are being asked to approve at their annual meeting on March 16 a change in the company's name to the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., the annual report, issued yesterday, reveals.

Two more Yankee contracts were deposited in the hopper on Business Manager Ed Barrow's desk yesterday -- those of Tony Lazzeri, veteran infielder, and Roy Johnson, the big outfielder who wore Red Sox spangles last year.

Jobs in private industry for 122,000 unemployed workers were found in 1935 in this State by the State Employment Service working in cooperation with the State organization of the National Re-employment Service, according to a report submitted yesterday to Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, by William H. Lange, director of the State's public employment agencies.

Public-utility securities continued to suffer setbacks on the stock markets yesterday, owing to disappointment over the TVA decision on Monday. The largest proportional declines were in common stocks, while the largest declines in price developed in preferred stocks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The text of the compromise neutrality resolution passed by the Senate today, after the House adopted it yesterday, is as follows:

BERLIN, Wednesday, Feb. 19.--Although Foreign Office and Nazi party officials refused to comment directly on Switzerland's ban on Nazi party organizations, today's press comments, obviously officially inspired, are significantly bitter.

Registrations of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday were less than in the preceding week, but were slightly above the figures for the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week numbered 913 as against 962 reported a week ago and 905 recorded in the same period a year ago. Buyers in town yesterday totaled 431, which compared with 433 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull deprecated today suggestions that the revolution in Paraguay would have any effect upon the plans to hold a Pan-American peace conference. He said he could not assume that events in one or even two countries would have any material effect on the program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The compromise on what is miscalled "neutrality legislation," completed by Congressional action today, brought victory to two groups: the convinced pacifists and the determined isolationists. Though the international philosophy of the one is represented by a storm-cellar, and of the other by a wall, each got a part of what it is after.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, denied indignantly yesterday a charge made earlier in the day before Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy that a witness in the current compulsory prostitution cases had been beaten and blackjacked by detectives in Mr. Dewey's offices in the Woolworth Building.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- A bright red automobile, a law believed not to have been used in twenty years and a letter allegedly written "with intent to cause annoyance" caused the indictment today of Frank J. Bayer of 98 Harding Avenue, White Plains, over an $8.80 debt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The 5,392 active national banks in the continental United States, Alaska, Hawaii and the Virgin Islands on Dec. 31 had aggregate deposits of $24,847,733,000, the largest amount reported in the history of the national banking system, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, reported today in a summary of the last bank call.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Control over the export of tin was placed in the hands of Secretary Hull today by President Roosevelt through an executive order in accordance with a recent law giving him the power to license such exports to protect the public interest.

The Building Service Employes Union and realty owners in the garment and fur district reached an agreement yesterday, thus breaking the deadlock that for two weeks threatened to lead to a walkout of 20,000 elevator operators and other service employes in 1,200 buildings.

The American cargo and passenger ship City of Newport News saved the crew of thirty-three men from the foundering Greek freighter Stefanos Costomenis 500 miles at sea yesterday afternoon, hauling the exhausted men aboard after a twenty-four-hour chase through tossing seas and high winds.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- King Edward VIII held the first investiture of his reign at Buckingham Palace today, concurring in the honors and decorations awarded by his father in the new year's list and decorating with the Royal Victorian Order the sailors and soldiers who participated in King George's funeral.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18. -- The Kips Bay Boys Club of New York defeated the Yale freshman basketball team tonight, 26 -- 17. The yearlings led, 14 -- 8, at the half, but could not hold their advantage.

ROME, Feb. 18 (AP). -- France stands "fully in accord" with Great Britain concerning mutual assistance in the Mediterranean, the Italian Government disclosed tonight, as Fascist leaders strengthened precautions against "international emergencies."

Spear Co., a local retail furniture chain store organization, notified the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that stockholders will be asked at their annual meeting on March 10 to approve a plan to clear up accumulated dividends on the company's two issues of preferred stock by assenting to an exchange of shares.

Operators of freight ships in the intercoastal trade will meet in New York next month to seek an agreement for the formation of a new conference, which leaders in the trade hope will embrace all lines regardless of their past attitude toward conferences.

There would have been thirteen competitors in the Children's Welfare Federation's yodeling contest yesterday if Edward Hennessey, 10 years old, had not been too shy. The other twelve managed their O-lay-he-who-whos, but Edward got the giggles and retreated.

A jury in General Sessions yesterday convicted Ramon Flores, 26 years old, a Puerto Rican, of murder in the first degree in the death of Gloria Jackson, 13, a Negro schoolgirl, whom he hurled from the roof of a six-story tenement at 47 West 114th Street last Dec. 3. Her home was at 35 West 114th Street. The jury was out less than three hours.

The Associate Alumnae of Barnard College met last night to honor Miss Virginia C. Gildersleeve on her twenty-fifth anniversary as dean of the college. More than 900 persons gathered at the Hotel Biltmore and Dean Gildersleeve's speech was broadcast so that alumnae groups in other cities could hear her voice.
Providence has been merciful to the parents, and, shall we say, to the school authorities as well.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- All hopes of breaking records in the Adirondack A.A.U. bobsled races were abandoned today following an accident to members of the Elizabethtown Red Arrows crew. Only two heats were raced instead of four.

With only one vote in opposition, the Board of Aldermen approved yesterday Borough President James J. Lyons's bill which would require city residence for all persons on the relief administration staff as well as those receiving relief here.

GENEVA, Feb. 18. -- The Swiss Federal Council ordered today the immediate suppression of all central or regional German Nazi organizations in Switzerland. The decision was unanimous and was made in consequence of the assassination on Feb. 4 of Wilhelm Gustloff, the Nazi leader in Switzerland.

Gold mining, one of the world's oldest industries, attained the stature of a billion-dollar industry for the first time in 1935, largely as a result of the economic depression, it was reported yesterday to the 145th annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- Heavy profit-taking in armament shares was a feature of the stock markets today. Prices generally weakened, those of aircraft issues particularly, but support was renewed in the afternoon and resulted in some rallying. Business, however, was mostly quieter than yesterday as a result of the overnight Wall Street news.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- Vassar Collage trustees today announced gifts to the amount of nearly $263,000. This includes:

Distribution of food for starving birds, deer and small mammals in the vicinity of Bear Mountain began yesterday, the American Museum of Natural History announced, as the result of an appeal made on Saturday at the museum. The appeal was made by Dr. George H. Sherwood, curator-in-chief of the museum's department of education, in a lecture for children of museum members on "Spring Birds."

Led by William Giesen and William Schirmer, Fordham University's swimming team defeated New York University, 45 to 26, in the Park Central Hotel pool yesterday for its fourth triumph in five starts. Giesen and Schirmer each captured two races, with Giesen setting a new pool record for the 100-yard free-style test.

A new cold wave stretched across the country from the Rocky Mountains to the Atlantic Coast last night with a-sweep of near-zero temperatures as far south as Tennessee and Texas. At midnight, the last official reading, the mercury had fallen to 6 degrees in the city and the prediction was for continued cold today and clear skies.

Several operators' deals were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday. Apartment houses recently modernized and to be modernized were among the properties. An East Side business site also was resold.

BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Feb. 19. -- President Eusebio Ayala of Paraguay handed his resignation to the leaders of the revolution shortly before Monday midnight, according to messages received here yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18. -- An increase of $1,005,452, or 12.3 per cent, in net operating income of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for this year was forecast in a minimum budget report submitted today to Judge Carroll C. Hincks in the United States District Court here.

Major Loudon Greenlees, Scottish baritone, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. He sang music by Handel, Schubert, Wolf and Strauss to begin his program. Then came excerpts from operas by Boito and Giordano.

Only one seeded entrant remained in the tournament after the quarter-final-round play in the Class B squash tennis championship was completed at the Harvard Club yesterday. The lone survivor was Vincent Furno of the Columbia University Club, who was ranked second in the draw.

Apart from the pith and pertinence of the actual decision of the TVA case by the Supreme Court, that judicial body never showed itself truer to its high function. The judges refused to be hurried or harried. They ignored protests and clamor. Their duty being to examine all the details of a complicated case, they took their time about it, and then serenely issued the judgment of the court.

GENEVA, Feb. 18 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Sir Neill Malcolm, retired British Major General, has been appointed League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Coming From Germany. The appointment became effective Feb. 14.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18. -- Matching men's par on the last three holes, Mrs. Edwin H. Vare Jr., the former Miss Glenna Collett, six times women's national golf champion, defeated Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, Mo., by a narrow margin in the featured first-round match of the championship of Palm Beach at the Palm Beach Country Club today.
ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Three major measures in Governor Lehman's tax program were pushed through the Senate today as the Democratic majority rode roughshod over Republican opposition.

Field goals by Jack Levitt and Seymour Pessar in the last ninety seconds of the three-minute extra period enabled the De Witt Clinton High School five to top Evander Childs, 35 -- 32, at Evander, in a Bronx Division P.S.A.L. game yesterday.
CROWBOROUGH, Sussex, England, Feb. 18. -- Lady Doyle, in her serious illness, is taking consolation from the "hovering spirit" of her famous husband at the bedside, their son Denis said today.

ROME, Feb. 18. -- Official figures made public today gave the Italian losses in Marshal Pietro Badoglio's Enderta victory as 12 officers, 122 white soldiers and 62 native soldiers killed and 24 officers, 499 whites and 83 natives wounded. Only one bombing plane of the many engaged in the six-day fight, it is stated, failed to return to its base.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The House Rules Committee reported out today a five-hour limit on debate on the administration's Soil Conservation Bill. Predictions were made immediately by Speaker Byrns and Representative Jones, chairman of the Agriculture Committee, that the new farm-relief measure would be passed by Friday night without substantial change.
The New York Americans and the Montreal Maroons divided sixteen goals equally as they battled to an 8-8 tie in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The New York County grand jury, renewing an investigation into the shooting of Sergio Benscombe last April 28 in his apartment at 87 Hamilton Place, has handed up a first-degree murder indictment against Luis De Lanfuente, it was learned yesterday.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,774,250 barrels, compared with 2,763,750 in the preceding week, an increase of 10,500, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 39,500 barrels in the daily average output in California and a gain of 37,250 in Oklahoma were the important changes. Production was 126,150 barrels more than the calculations of 2,648,100 daily by the Department of the Interior for February.

Spurred by the fire that swept the Park Avenue building of Hunter College last Friday, the Yorkville Chamber of Commerce started a movement yesterday to obtain 100,000 signatures on a petition denouncing eighteen school buildings in the Yorkville section as "antique fire hazards" and asking that they be replaced or renovated.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Larry Aurie, star Detroit winger, suffered a fractured collar-bone while his Red Wing mates outplayed the Boston Bruins for a costly 2-1 National Hockey League victory tonight before 12,000 at the Boston Garden.

In older and longer-governed nations, and even in shorter-governed nations such as well-managed New Zealand, many of our amateur political methods would have been handled differently, much to our betterment.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith heads the list of Tammany delegates to the Democratic National Convention, made public yesterday by James J. Dooling, the leader, at Tammany Hall.

The first interest of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching is in the teacher, not the program nor a pension system. The emphasis in the annual report of its president, Dr. WALTER A. JESSUP, is on the spiritual resources of the American college, not on its administrative organization or its material equipment.

The consolidated net income of the United States Gypsum Company and subsidiaries in 1935 was $3,491,252 after depreciation, depletion, Federal taxes, loss on retirement of plant assets and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the earnings equaled $2.47 each on 1,192,103 shares of $20-par common stock outstanding at the end of the year.

At peak form, William E. Coyle, Montclair Athletic Club star, advanced one notch further in defense of his title as New York State squash racquets champion yesterday when he defeated Amos Eno, young Princeton Club star, in the quarter-final round of the championship at the Downtown Athletic Club.

Secret Service agents, acting on a search warrant obtained by Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, swooped down yesterday on half a dozen banks and safe deposit companies, and finally located 10,000 $20 gold pieces for which they had been hunting quietly for several weeks.

The proposed amendment to abridge the powers of the United States Supreme Court would "be no less than revolution," General Hugh S. Johnson, former head of the NRA, told the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night.

A banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,000,000 of water-works Bonds of the city of Los Angeles, Calif. The syndicate paid 100.017 for $900,000 due from March 1, 1937 to 1948, as 4s; $450,000 due from March 1, 1949 to 1954, as 2 3/4s, and $1,650,000 due from March 1, 1955 to 1976, as 3s.

Colonel Rafael Franco, who is to lead the new Paraguayan regime, was the chief Paraguayan commander in the war in the Chaco with Bolivia and won several important strategic victories that undoubtedly hastened the end of the fighting.

" The Trail of the Lonesome Pine," first feature picture filmed outdoors in the new three-component Technicolor process, opens this morning at the Paramount. A Walter Wanger production based on John Fox Jr.'s story, it features Sylvia Sidney, Fred MacMurray, Henry Fonda and Fred Stone.

Captain Jack, a sterling wire fox terrier owned by John Nickens of New York, was named best of the terriers at Bloomingdale's Pet Dog Show yesterday. The winning wire captured the hearts of the throng, which stood three deep about the large ring. Possessed of a fine terrier head with well-bearded jaw and in superb condition, the wire was a true representative of his group.

The medal of the New York Academy of Public Education for distinguished service in education was presented to Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, last night at the annual dinner of the academy at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18. -- Income tax refunds totaling almost $750,000 were awarded today by Federal Judge R.M. Gibson, to A. W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, and the estate of his brother, R.B. Mellon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Warren Lee Pierson has been elected president of the Export-Import Bank, it was announced today by R. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State and chairman of the board of trustees of the bank. Mr. Pierson, who has been general counsel for the bank since its creation, will supplant George N. Peek, who resigned as president after a disagreement with the administration.

BERLIN, Feb. 18. -- The Boerse was quiet today and movements were mixed. Heavy industrials were slightly weaker, and Vereingtestahl lost 1/8 point. Machinery shares were quiet, but Orenstein-Koppel gained 1/2 point. Chemicals weakened, Goldschmidt losing 2 1/2, while I.G. Farben showed resistance.

The railroads began 1936 with increased earnings, early returns for the period issued yesterday indicate. In the case of the Union Pacific, January was the first month of operation under the plan of merger of its subsidiaries, but the effects of economies to be derived from the merger will not become fully evident until later.

TRENTON, Feb. 18. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann will be resentenced to death tomorrow only a few hours before Samuel Leibowitz, New York attorney, makes a third and possibly final attempt to obtain from him a confession of the crime.

Frightened by a truck rumbling onto Pier 75, Hudson River, at West Thirty-fifth Street, and blinded by the heavy snowfall, Charlie, a grayish white horse, plunged overboard to his death in the icy waters of the Hudson River at 10:30 A.M. yesterday.

An indication that there is no disposition on the part of the Transit Commission to rush through to the public-hearing stage the Seabury-Berle transit unification plan came yesterday when the commission, representatives of the transit companies and of the city agreed, after a two-hour conference, to postpone the next meeting until March 16.

Business failures increased in the manufacturing and wholesale divisions but declined in the retail, construction and commercial service groups in the five business days ended Feb. 13, as compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 18. -- Isadore Blumenfeld (Kid Cann) was acquitted tonight of the murder of Walter Liggett, editor of a weekly newspaper here. The jury was out three and a half hours when it reported back that it had reached an agreement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The Senate passed today, without a record vote, the compromise neutrality resolution extending the existing law until May 1, 1937, with the addition of an embargo on loans and credits to belligerents and an exemption in favor of American republics at war with non-American States.

In order to understand "Come Angel Band," which was acted at the Forty-sixth Street last evening, you must know whether they hang Bird in the morning or free him. If they free him, it is drama. If they hang him, it is a Message. They hang him backstage with a thud and a choking sound at eleven o'clock and the curtain comes down to soft music.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- The wheat markets today broke away from the influence of Liverpool to a large extent, and while there was some selling early on the Board of Trade here by tired longs, a good class of buying developed on the dip, especially in the May, and a strong rally followed.

Charles M. Schwab confronted a dozen camera men and two dozen reporters yesterday on his seventy-fourth birthday for his customary interview. He was equipped with a pile of prepared statements on the desk in his office as chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, 25 Broadway, but he waved at them without distributing them, as something designed to "keep me from mixing in political things."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The Imperial Japanese Government filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $114,297,000 of external loan of 1924, thirty-year sinking fund 6 1/2 per cent gold bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1934, and $70,438,000 of external loan of 1930, thirty-five year sinking fund 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds, due on May 1, 1965.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Strong attacks on proposals to change the present emergency moratorium on mortgage foreclosures and the current deficiency judgment laws were made today at a legislative public hearing on numerous mortgage bills pending in the two houses.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 18. -- In the semi-final round of the annual Princess Hotel tennis tournament today B. Eve defeated W. Freisenbruch, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, and H.C. Smith turned back E. Freisenbruch, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3. The final is scheduled for tomorrow.
BERLIN, Feb. 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that it might be a considerable time before the administration's revised fiscal program, including requests for new or "substitute" taxes, was submitted to Congress.
MONTREAL, Feb. 18 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens and the Chicago Black Hawks battled through seventy minutes of fast hockey tonight to a 3-3 deadlock in a National Hockey League game.
MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 18. -- The strike along the entire route of the Southern Pacific Railway of Mexico, reaching from here to Nogales, will begin at noon Thursday unless the government intervenes.

Odds and ends: Indians were America's first conservationists. . . . Two hundred years ago the tribes in Kentucky, cognizant of the importance of the meat, fat and skins of bears in their daily lives, set aside game refuges and called them "beloved bear grounds," according to Vernon Bailey, naturalist.

The Group II team tournament of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association ended in a three-cornered tie among the New York Athletic Club, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club and the Bayside Tennis Club as a result of the final regularly scheduled matches played yesterday. Each team has won four of six engagements.

Six local laws designed to accomplish reorganization in county government in accordance with the constitutional amendment adopted last Fall were introduced yesterday in the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly by Alderman A. Newbold Morris, Manhattan Republican.
Seventy American stylists and buyers arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France after attending the Spring and early Summer fashion shows in Paris.
New cases of measles continued to increase last week, 902 being reported, compared to 603 during the preceding week and 549 for the week ending Feb. 1, the Department of Health announced yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, Feb. 18. -- A Republican Senator succeeded in getting the State Senate to appropriate $100 as a bonus to a non-existent veteran today, and thereby called attention to a growing list of such "grants" at the present session of the Legislature.

Sailing tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for the Spring session of this year's Leipzig Trade Fair will be a number of buyers and visitors headed by Herbert Johnson, its official representative in the United States.

That most of the top-notch horses in the various age divisions have been named for the nine stake events to be run at the Summer meeting at Aqueduct from June 8 to July 2 was revealed yesterday in the announcement by Secretary John J. Kane of the eligibles for the stakes.
The Broadway theatre tonight can pay its money and take its choice of these:

The annual report of the Atlas Corporation, issued yesterday, showed consolidated assets of the company and investment company subsidiaries amounting to $103,928,679 at the close of the year, with portfolio holdings based an year-end market values, compared with $110,517,809 at the end of 1934.

At the close of a day in which a woman hysterically testified that one of the defendants threatened her, her husband and Samuel Drukman, the State rested before Justice Erskine C. Rogers and a jury in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, in the trial of Meyer and Harry Luckman and Fred J. Hull for Drukman's murder.

The rewarding music on the program of the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, with Bernardini Molinari conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall, was the short and innocent overture to Wolf-Ferrari's "Secret of Suzanne" and Richard Strauss's tonepoem, "Don Juan."

PARIS, Feb. 18. -- Opposition to the Franco-Soviet pact of mutual assistance was strongly argued by a succession of Rightist Deputies when the debate on that subject was resumed in the Chamber of Deputies today.

The TVA decision will have a compelling effect in obtaining ratification of the St. Lawrence treaty with Canada for development of the St. Lawrence River, Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the State Power Authority, declared yesterday at a luncheon given by the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, to delegates attending the two-day conference of New York State Mayors at City Hall.

MADRID, Feb. 18. -- Leftist leaders issued assurances tonight of amnesty for more than 30,000 political prisoners in an effort to halt rioting in prisons, following the Left's apparent victory in Sunday's general election.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Asking an investigation of conditions causing the deadly silicosis and other industrial diseases, the House Labor Committee today charged "inhuman disregard" of worker-safety by contractors who built West Virginia's Hawk's Neck Tunnel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- The general court martial in the "breach of honor" trial of Colonel Joseph I. McMullen today refused a motion by his attorneys for a verdict of not guilty.

The world production of mine and scrap copper in January was 134,868 tons as compared with 134,500 in December, according to a compilation in the trade. Mine production was 111,633 tons, against 114,600. The apparent consumption was 126,790 tons in January as compared with 132,500 in December.
Edward J. Reilly, former chief of defense counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, told Supreme Court Justice Lockwood in Brooklyn yesterday that the case cost him $3,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the last state reception of the season, entertaining in honor of the army and navy.
Twelve properties, including tenements, dwellings and business buildings, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales in Manhattan yesterday, as follows:

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday a net income of $2,709,380 for 1935, excluding $318,155 revenues in suspense. The income was equal to $3.64 a share on an average of 744,300 common shares outstanding last year and compared with $3,154,618, or $4.26 each, on an average of 743,300 common shares for 1934.

When she called at the Travelers Insurance Company at 100 West Forty-second Street yesterday afternoon to collect $150 on an accident claim, Mrs. Sadie Esther Abramson, 45 years old, a divorcee, of 575 West 172d Street, was arrested on a fraud charge in her claim.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 18. -- Lincoln Ellsworth, American explorer, who has just returned from an airplane flight across the Antarctic Continent, declared today it was the duty of the Twentieth Century toward civilization to wipe the word "unexplored" off the map.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- A physician must study social problems as closely as he studies the human body if he is to achieve personal success or maximum usefulness, according to speakers who addressed the annual Congress on Medical Education of the American Medical Association today.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Educators and students protested against "emotional patriotism" and "flag waving" at a public hearing today on repeal of the Ives Teachers' Oath Bill, but failed to win any support from legislators who questioned them sharply and dwelt on the necessity of maintaining "Americanism."

The WPA Theatre Project, using Broadway simply as a tryout spot -- which is fair enough -- last night offered "Jefferson Davis" at the Biltmore Theatre. This is John McGee's play about the President of the Confederacy that is to start out next week on a tour of some 150 cities and towns of the South, the first of the Project's road companies.

Although all save one of the seven artists currently represented at the Marie Harriman Gallery are associated with or by every right belong to the French school, they run up a total of four nationalities, when we remember that Picasso is Spanish and that Vincent Van Gogh, despite his having done nearly all of his significant work in France, was Dutch.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- With Governor Lehman determined to take the fight for his law enforcement program to the people in a radio talk, opponents to his anti-crime legislation in the Senate and Assembly remained quiescent today insisting that the next move was up to the Governor.

The Fire Association of Philadelphia reported yesterday total admitted assets on Dec. 31 last, of $21,378,764, compared with $19,122,447 a year before. Net surplus amounted to $8,785,717, against $5,911,722, while policyholders' surplus was $10,785,717 at the year-end.

Consideration of refunding operations for more than $100,000,000 of the funded debt of Southeastern subsidiary operating companies of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation has been halted as a result of the TVA decision of the United States Supreme Court on Monday, officers of the parent company said yesterday, but arrangements for the sale of low-interest securities to replace debt of certain Northern subsidiaries will be sought.

Commodity futures were generally lower in comparatively quiet trading yesterday. Raw sugar futures were an exception with gains of 3 to 6 points. In the cash market, grains, raw sugar, butter and eggs were higher, while coffee, cocoa, lard, tin, cotton, silk and rubber were lower.

Womrath Bookshops and Libraries, Inc., operators of a chain of circulating libraries and book stores, is moving its executive offices to Union Square, it was announced yesterday. Now in the Butterick Building, Sixth Avenue and Spring Street, the company has leased the ninth floor of 12,000 square feet in the Everett Building, 45 East Seventeenth Street, corner of Fourth Avenue.

The exhibition of paintings by William Gropper at the A.C.A. has been extended to Feb. 23. Herman Baron, proprietor of the gallery, announces several sales and a record-breaking attendance, attributed in part to the American Artists Congress, which was in session last week.

The use of a silver nitrate solution to develop fingerprints on two extortion notes and a study of the notes by handwriting experts helped to trap Andrew Athanasiads, 29 years old, of 655 West l77th Street, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- A comprehensive plan for the creation of a Pacific Northwest power agency as a public corporation to develop and transmit electric power was transmitted to President Roosevelt today by the National Resources Board following yesterday's decision on the TVA by the Supreme Court.

In a setting reminiscent of the palace of Louis XIV at Versailles, a dinner was held last night at the formal opening of the new Cafe Louis XIV in La Maison Francaise, Rockefeller Center, for the benefit of the French Benevolent Society of the Ladies of St. Vincent-de-Paul.

BERLIN, Feb. 18. -- The yoke which all German editors willingly or unwillingly wear was pressed down firmly today on the shoulders of pastors and laymen issuing church weeklies and other official church journals.

BERLIN, Feb. 18. -- German exports, which had been rising steadily since the billion-mark subsidy plan became effective last June, suffered a relapse last month when they dropped to 381,800,000 marks -- a reduction of 8 per cent, compared with December.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- The question of how Hilda Price, a waitress, came to her death early on New Year's morning was mentioned for the first time today in the trial of Edward A. Cannon, 27, charged with her murder.

Four 16-year-old boys and a man accused of employing them were held in $1,000 bail each yesterday when arraigned before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on charges of possessing and passing counterfeit $10 Federal Reserve notes.

The share market, undaunted by the disappointment felt in investment circles over the United States Supreme Court's ruling on Monday upholding the right of the Tennessee Valley Authority to sell power from the Wilson Dam, gave a remarkable demonstration of strength yesterday wherein all groups, save the electric power section of the list, advanced briskly.
The ninth in the series of college double-headers in Madison Square Garden will be played tonight. It will be the last of the season with an intersectional flavor.

BERLIN, Feb. 18. -- Just how far the ideal of a self-contained Germany has been brought nearer attainment through her development of synthetic benzine and rubber is a topic that provokes only cautious speculation in German scientific circles so far despite the popular enthusiasm aroused by Chancellor Hitler's announcement at the auto show that German industrial chemists had conclusively solved both problems.
THEY certainly come tall from Texas. Four good men and true came tramping through the whirling snow and, for two of them, it was the first real snow they ever had sampled. They seemed to like it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--Tennessee Valley officials said today that they expected to speed up their work, now that the shadow of constitutional doubt, in their opinion, has been removed by the Supreme Court. Twenty-seven communities have signed contracts for TVA power.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The New York State Conference of Mayors unanimously adopted a motion presented by Mayor La Guardia yesterday favoring new legislation that would permit municipalities to conduct referenda on municipally owned and operated power plants.
Plans have been formulated for an enclosed four-mile automobile racing course to be built at Roosevelt Field, Mineola, L.I., according to The Associated Press.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- Whether or not an agreement is reached on battleships, the American delegation is willing to initial or sign any agreement already reached at the conference here of four naval powers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- President Roosevelt indicated at his press conference that the administration's revised fiscal program, including taxes, would not be ready for some time. The last State reception of the season, to the army and navy, was held tonight.

Old music that retains its fragrance and vitality constituted a real novelty in program-making at last night's concert at the Town Hall. The performance was by the choir of the Plus X School of Liturgical Music, College of the Sacred Heart.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18. -- J.E. Widener's Brevity again failed to make his 1936 debut at Hialeah Park today. The co-favorite with Marshall Field's Tintagel for the Florida Derby was a late scratch from the featured Orlando Purse, seven-furlong dash for 3-year-olds, but his stablemate, Rushaway, bore the scarlet, white and black silks to victory in a drive by a length and a half over Willard Wilson's Lancewood.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Creation by Congress of an independent housing authority was proposed today by the American Federation of Labor Housing Committee.

Exception must be taken to part of your editorial "Donors of Blood." It stated that 46 per cent of the 2,707 donors licensed in the city are on the list of the Blood Transfusion Betterment Association, and implied that this 46 per cent alone are "carefully selected men who must be physically sound and carry a Department of Health passbook which is both an identification and a certificate of health."
MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 18. -- A strike Thursday on the Southern Pacific Railway of Mexico loomed as a certainty today as officials and employes failed to reach an agreement.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- A new drive for a Constitutional amendment to permit use of pari-mutuel betting at the New York tracks was opened today. Backers of the program, however, were not very sanguine about eventual success in view of the blockading of the program last year.

UTICA, N.Y., Wednesday, Feb. 19. -- Firemen succeeded early today in extinguishing a gas blaze that had been burning under the city's main street intersection for nearly twenty-four hours, but the menace of gas explosions still existed.

Defying the city authorities in their prohibition of last Saturday's unemployment relief demonstration, which was broken up by the police when some 15,000 persons attempted to parade from Madison Square to the WPA offices in the Port Authority Building, the Unemployment Councils of Greater New York, a Left Wing-Communist organization, announced yesterday that it was planning another march as "a fitting answer to a Fascist-like violation of our democratic rights."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Regional labor boards reported to the National Labor Relations Board today that in the last few days Federal district court judges had sustained the Labor Act in five eases where temporary injunctions were sought by employers.

ROME, Feb. 18. -- In the light of recent communiques, it is felt here that not only have the fortunes of war turned definitely in Italy's favor, but that the international horizon is also showing signs of clearing. The Baldwin Cabinet is believed to be hesitating, and this is taken as a symptom of growing opposition in Great Britain to its past course.

President Roosevelt stands for the inviolability of religious liberty and the entire Bill of Rights, Secretary of War George H. Dern announced last night in delivering a message of support from the President to the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 19. -F. Bliss Price's Class A ice yacht Snow Flake took the lead in the point standing for the Board of Trade Cup today as the Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club resumed ice-boat racing on the South Shrewsbury River.

An action to have denied the probating of the will of Frank C. Hart, president of the Hartol Products, was started yesterday in Surrogate's Court by his first wife, Marion Alexander Hart, of 1,185 Park Avenue. She denied that Muriel Constance Woodworth Hart of Sharon, Conn., was the decedent's widow, or that Mr. Hart lived in Connecticut at the time of his death in a plane crash at Goodwyn, Ark., on Jan. 24.

The charges made by your correspondents who comment on your editorial "Donors of Blood" have been made against us on every possible occasion. Such as have any semblance of being based on facts we investigate, but when statements are made that "regardless of the amount of blood taken * * * the hospital must pay the standard fee of $40 to members.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The stock markets here were active today, particularly those for international issues, as a result of overnight views of Wall Street's recovery yesterday. Nickel International was prominent on the improved outlook for copper, reaching the highest price in years.

The suggestion that Democrats opposed to the New Deal be invited to cooperate with the Republican party in the impending campaign is being discussed in many places as if it were an innovation, when in fact it is just the reverse. The call for the very first Republican National Convention included dissatisfied Democrats, as follows:
TIENTSIN, Feb. 19. -- Commenting today on the North China tax situation, Major Gen. Hayao Tada, commander of the Japanese forces in that area, said:

SEVERAL moods fight for supremacy in Henry Seidel Canby's "Alma Mater: The Gothic Age of the American College" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50). There are ruefulness and romantic nostalgia and sympathy and a longing for older certainties, older simplicities. There are even moments when Mr. Canby almost convinces you that he is au fond the Old Grad who used to figure every football season in the sports column of the late W.O. McGeehan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Wayne C. Taylor, former vice president of the Export-Import Bank, was officially inducted into office today as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and important duties were assigned to him.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- Filling the first public engagement since his accession, King Edward visited today the British Industries Fair at Olympia, where general goods are displayed, and then, at White City, the textile section. At both places the King expressed pleasure over the progress of British industry.
Value of Dollar in Exchange. The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The Roosevelt administration will attempt to lay the blame for its failures on the Supreme Court, or on the Constitution itself, Senator Lester J. Dickinson of Iowa declared last night at a dinner of the New York Young Republican Club at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, today opposed proposals for the compulsory sale of specified amounts of cotton held by the government through loans made by the Commodity Credit Corporation, or a fixed schedule, on the theory that such procedure might have a depressing effect upon prices in the cotton market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Robert E. Clements, national secretary and co-founder of the Townsend plan, declared this evening that the House inquiry was "pure and unadulterated political persecution" and "the reflection of mind warped in crooked thinking."
Two more plays will add themselves to the Broadway puzzle this evening, the line-up being:...

Legal action will be taken by the R.H. White Company, Boston, and Strawbridge Clothier, Philadelphia, against individual manufacturer members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America to test their refusal to ship merchandise on order, and for refusing to show or accept new orders, it was announced yesterday by P.J. Reilly, executive director of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, of which the two stores are members.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (AP). -- For the second time Owen (Ownie) Madden, former New York beer runner, has been "rousted out" of Los Angeles, District Attorney Buron Fitts said today.

Representatives of the Midtown Realty Owners Association and the Penn Zone Association signed an agreement yesterday with heads of the Building Service Employes International Union, which is expected to preclude strikes and lockouts until the agreement expires on Jan. 31, 1939.

Everybody knows that a multitude of people who are troubled and anxious and vaguely discontented cannot be dealt with as if they were a class in logic. Hard and clear thinking does not go with their emotions and apprehensions. But the case is different with their leaders, their teachers.

The social revolution, it seems, is moving uptown. Until now the Julien Levy Gallery, at 602 Madison Avenue, has devoted itself mainly to considerations that may be classified as esthetic. In playing host to a one-man show by an American artist known to the world of exhibitions simply as Quirt (a name that, once having heard, you are not likely to forget), Mr. Levy offers this observation:

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- What had been intended as a secluded conference on the price-fixing feature of milk control by the State was interrupted today when Mrs. Rhoda Fox Graves, Senator from St. Lawrence, unexpectedly appeared on the scene and declared that the farmers were being "sold on the block."

The rebuilt north wing of Peace House, at Fifth Avenue and 109th Street, was dedicated yesterday afternoon by representatives of four religious denominations. It will be available for peace meetings and exhibitions showing the virtues of peace.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- The Assembly received today a favorable committee report on bills extending the moratorium on mortgage foreclosures until July 1, 1937, as a new bill for establishment of mortgage banks in the State was introduced.

Thirty-one persons, including five physicians, indicted by the Kings County grand jury yesterday in an alleged $500,000 insurance swindle, were being sought last night by the police, who carried bench warrants for their arrest.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday after hearing arguments on an appeal from a recent district court ruling which approved a plan for reorganization of the New York Railways Corporation.

Under the auspices of the directors of the Prosperity Shop, a supper dance was held last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador to augment the free milk fund of the Alice Hall Ali Committee, one of the various beneficiaries of all sales at the shop.

DUBLIN, Feb. 19. -- About 15,000 United States subscribers to the Irish Republican loan, whose applications for repayment were received too late, will be repaid under a bill that passed second reading in the Dail Eireann tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- To project into the campaign, without great danger of making it perilously paramount, the issue of the Supreme Court vs. the executive and legislative government arms, the administration requires as background a line of adverse 5 to 4 or 6 to 3 decisions.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP). -- Governor H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire threatened tonight to appeal to the Federal Government to order the Pennsylvania Railroad to divest itself of virtual control of the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Boston Maine Railroads.
VIENNA, Feb. 19. -- "Reports concerning the alleged conclusion of an agreement among Italy, Germany and Austria in Florence are nothing but nonsense," declared the Austrian Foreign Office tonight.

More than 1,000 persons at a mass meeting at Cooper Union last night approved unanimously a resolution protesting the action of the police last Saturday in detaining thirteen persons, including Representative Vito Marcantonio, at a relief workers' demonstration in Madison Square Park.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19. -- After receiving two setbacks in the Federal courts today in his fight against the proposed reorganization of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, Mayor S. Davis Wilson ordered the City Solicitor to file bankruptcy proceedings against the company.

As Bruno Richard Hauptmann was resentenced yesterday to die for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., it was pointed out that Governor Harold G. Hoffman alone has no power to pardon the prisoner or commute his sentence.

Defending the State Unemployment Insurance Law, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews declared yesterday that he suspected "a strong taint of politics in the criticism" directed against the act, and felt confident Governor Lehman and the State would check the attack.

More than 400 old tenements in New York have been ordered vacated since Jan. 1 because of structural defects or improper sanitary facilities, Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP). -- An uproarious session of the House Immigration Committee brought a charge today that Greta Garbo, Marlene Dietrich and Anna Sten achieved fame through American "ballyhoo."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 19. -American trustees of the Charles and Julia Henry Fund today awarded the Henry Fellowships of 500 each toy three Yale and three Harvard seniors for study at Cambridge and Oxford Universities during the next academic year.

The 18-year-old N.Y.U. sophomore Stanley Galowin, who has proved the sensation of the New York State squash racquets singles championship, gained another splendid victory yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club to reach the final round of the tournament.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19. -- May wheat continues to act tight, and further buying of that delivery today on the Board of Trade against sales of July, part of which was attributed to cash interests, put it to 9 3/4 cents a bushel over the new crop position, compared with 8 cents at one time yesterday.

The discovery last Summer in the northwestern part of North Dakota of deposits containing more than 20,000,000 tons of Glauber salt, of a market value of about $350,000,000, by Federal relief workers was reported yesterday at the 145th annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Influenced by a strong stock market, rapid progress of the new bill for agricultural assistance in Congress and a scarcity of the better grades of cotton in Southern markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange were steady a yesterday. Though fluctuations were narrow, a recovery in new-crop months left the list with a gain of 7 points to a loss of 4 points.

Celebration of Sears, Roebuck Co.'s golden jubilee this year calls for the expenditures of $9,500,000 worth of advertising in 851 newspapers situated in forty-four States, General R.E. Wood, president, announced yesterday. An increase of about $60,000,000 in merchandise purchases and an addition of about $7,000,000 to payrolls are also involved in the program, the most comprehensive ever undertaken by the organization, he said.

New York University's freshman quintet routed the Manhattan College yearlings, 44 to 27, yesterday at the University Heights gymnasium. Ed Williams led the Violets with thirteen points. After a close first half, at the end of which the Jaspers trailed, 21 -- 16, N.Y.U. put on the pressure to score handily.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- A poll of Republican workers to determine the strength of the rival candidates for the Republican nomination for President has been ordered by the Ohio Republican State Committee, upon the advice of Walter F. Brown, National Committeeman and a Hoover leader, it was learned here today.
BOSTON, Feb. 19. -- Six preliminary-round matches were played without an upset as competition in the national racquets championship got under way at the Tennis and Racquet Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 (AP). -Two physicians, accused in a civil suit by Ann Cooper Hewitt of sterilizing her through trickery, were ordered held for trial on charges of conspiracy to commit mayhem by Municipal Judge Sylvain J. Lazarus tonight.
Liquidators of Granby Consolidated Mining, Smelting and Power Company, Ltd., declared yesterday a liquidating dividend of $8 a share. On Dec. 2 last a distribution of $5 was made.

Federal legislation which is intended to extend the time for the construction of a bridge over the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street by the North River Bridge Company and to alter the conditions under which the Federal Government would supervise its construction was attacked yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Feb. 19. -Sheriff Walter H. Applegate began today to dispossess room by room former Warden and Mrs. James Bogert from the county-owned warden's residence here. When the warden and his wife, Minnie, who used to be the jail matron, awoke this morning they found the doors of their dining room and kitchen on the first floor of the house padlocked.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19. -- Increased offerings of hogs and prospects of a larger run the balance of the week caused a sharp slump in prices here today. Early sales were 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight lower, but the demand was not aggressive, and at the last the market was 25 to 40 cents lower with some underweights 50 cents lower.

In a decision yesterday refusing to approve for the present a proposed settlement of suits for more than $22,500,000 against the former directors of the New York Title and Mortgage Company and the Manhattan Company for $1,475,000, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler criticized severely the State Mortgage Commission, which refused to take any position as to the proposed settlement on the ground that it is not a party to the litigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP). -- Representative Sol Bloom injected a cablegram and a historical correction today into the dispute over whether George Washington tossed a silver dollar across the Rappahannock River.

A letter has come to THE TIMES, signed by six men and one woman who want to know why this newspaper is not as much interested in the freedom of the press in New York as in Louisiana. The point of this inquiry relates to an alleged attempt of District Attorney DODGE to interfere with The Daily Worker.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 19. -The answer to the question "What horse will win the world's richest purse on Saturday?" lies in the swirling clouds which concealed the Sierra Madre Mountains from the thousands who watched the races at Santa Anita today.

Continuing a trend established by previous reports for January, the Kansas City Southern and the New York, Chicago St. Louis reported yesterday increased earnings, for the month. Their statements follow:

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- Asserting that the 1939 World's Fair is in jeopardy because of lack of funds, Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr., New York City Republican, urged Governor Lehman today to call a conference to insure success of the project..

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $3,000,000 of Golden Gate Bridge and Highway District, California, Series C, 3 3/4 per cent bonds, dated July 1, 1935, due July 1, 1942 to 1971, by a banking group composed of Blyth Co., Inc.; Bankamerica Company, Dean Witter Co. and Weeden Co., Inc.

An analysis of the general trend of the paper industry in relation to the business cycle was presented yesterday at the meeting of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper industry at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The session was held in conjunction with the annual convention of the American Paper and Pulp Association which closes tomorrow.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- Major Gen. Sir Neill Malcolm, who has been appointed League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Coming From Germany, in succession to James G. McDonald of the United States, said tonight that he hoped to work "in perfect cooperation" with Sir Herbert Samuel and his associates in their new drive to help the Jews in Germany.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19. -Displaying a dazzling attack throughout, the Yale sextet defeated the Brown University hockey team tonight, 9 to 2, before some 400 fans. The Elis tallied three goals in the first session and were never headed.
The basic tax rate on real estate in New York City will be 2.65 for 1936, a six-point drop from last year's rate of 2.71, Controller Frank J. Taylor said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- A comprehensive investigation of the money raising and spending activities of officials of the Townsend plan movement, as well as of all other old-age pension drives, was voted by the House today, with only four members dissenting. The vote was not recorded.

The National Biscuit Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1935 a net income of $9,986,020 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges but exclusive of $721,451 of costs of a strike, which amount was charged to insurance and contingent reserve.

Joe Mangan, the ailing New York A.C. miler, yesterday canceled his entry in the 1,500-meter run which will feature the forty-eighth annual American indoor championship meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. But since he also had entered the 1,000-meter event, the chances are that he will race in that instead of in the "metric mile."

In your issue of Feb. 11 was an account of the death of Morris R. Poucher. The simple statement that he "entered the chemical industry in his youth" gives all too incomplete a picture of one who played so important a part in the creation and full development of the American dye industry.

The holdout brigade of Marse Joe McCarthy's Yankees was reduced to seven yesterday when the signed contracts of Myril Hoag and Don Heffner reached Business Manager Ed Barrow -- although the term "holdout" is one that Barrow does not apply to any unsigned player until he has failed to report at the training camp.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The loss of a propeller caused the British passenger liner Nova Scotia of the Furness Withy Line, bound for New York from the Virgin Islands, to send out an SOS at 9:20 o'clock last night from a point about 600 miles east of St. Augustine, Fla., and 300 miles south of Bermuda.

MIAMI, Feb. 19. -- Robert E. Bryant, sportsman pilot and theatre owner of Rock Hill, S.C., landed here at 6:01 P.M. today after a flight which apparently broke the world's non-stop, non-fueling distance record for light planes by 120 miles.

The assembly of more than a thousand persons of differing faiths in united and urgent insistence upon religious freedom and in furtherance of cooperative effort in emphasizing spiritual values in our national life is a sign to go forward. It is as a sound of marching in the tops of the mulberry trees.

Your paper carried a story recently about steps taken by the District Attorney of New York County directed toward the investigation and possible prosecution of the editors of The Daily Worker, under the Criminal Anarchy Law passed in 1902 and used only once -- during the Lusk investigation and Palmer raids of 1920-21.
SENECA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- This village gave a party for Tommy in observance of his twenty-first birthday tonight and it took twenty-one bombs to keep him awake.

MADRID, Feb. 19. -- More street demonstrations in favor of immediate amnesty for 30,000 imprisoned revolutionists and more prison riots today caused the resignation of Premier Manuel Portela and his Cabinet. Manuel Azana, who was Premier during most of the second Republic's first two years, soon thereafter formed a Cabinet at the request of President Niceto Alcala Zamora.

Although falling off slightly from the large volume reported in the last few days, business leasing continued yesterday as the chief item of interest in the current realty market in this city and surrounding territory.

Chancellor HITLER'S announcement that synthetic rubber is an accomplished German fact will not astonish chemists. "Buna," as this supposedly new product is called, is made from lime and coke among other things. Beyond that nothing is disclosed. It is enough.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Secretary and Mrs. Cordell Hull gave a "diplomatic dinner" tonight at the Carlton Hotel, entertaining a company which included Ambassadors, Ministers and Charges d'Affaires of many nations represented in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The French Government has made a direct but fruitless appeal to the United States to agree at the London Naval Conference to battleships smaller than the present maximum limit of 35,000 tons, it was revealed today.

Quick action by a clerk in a midtown fur store resulted in the capture of a man accused of being one of three who held up the establishment late yesterday afternoon and in the recovery of about $12,000 worth of furs.

BREMEN, Germany, Feb. 19. -- An application by the F.W. Woolworth Company for permission to acquire more commodious business quarters in this city has been rejected by the Bremen Senate under the "law for the protection of small retail merchants," which is primarily aimed at chain stores regardless of the nationality of the owners.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 19 (AP). -- Four railroad presidents in a report submitted to the New England Governors and made public here today by Governor Theodore Francis Green suggested three possible courses for dealing with the New England railroad situation but declared they did not feel they could make any specific recommendations at this time in view of the trusteeship of the New York, New Haven Hartford.

A report of an investigation begun several weeks ago and submitted yesterday to Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, revealed that the WPA organization in this city has been defrauded of more than $1,000,000 as a result of a racket within the WPA in the hiring of automobiles, trucks and equipment for projects.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 19 (AP). -Two walls of a three-story building collapsed today, killing five firemen who were fighting a blaze that destroyed the Odd Fellows Lodge Building, eighty-seven years old and a landmark in downtown Columbus. A dozen other firemen were injured, several seriously, in a fight of five hours in a temperature of 10 degrees below zero.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 19. -The Empire State combination of Howard A. Tryon of Elmira and Jack Ryerson of Cooperstown, former Yale star, won the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Miami Biltmore amateur four-ball golf championship today.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- By unanimous vote the Assembly today passed and sent to Governor Lehman the bills transferring the New York City Bureau of Combustibles from the Department of Buildings to the Fire Department. The measures were sponsored by Senator Mandelbaum, New York Democrat.

One of the "gravest dangers to our democracy" has been "the open attempt made by President Franklin Roosevelt, Tugwell et al. to fan the flames of class hatred in America," according to Colonel Theodore Roosevelt.

The Cunard White Star liner Majestic arrived yesterday from Europe on what the majority of her crew are afraid will prove to be her last eastbound voyage. She made her first trip to New York in May, 1922. In January, 1925, the Majestic averaged twenty-five knots from the Ambrose Channel to Cherbourg Breakwater, which was her best crossing.

The underlying easiness in almost all the basic commodities in the last few weeks and the strength in security prices, especially equities, are developments which appear to some persons in the financial community as anomalous. Usually stock and commodity prices over long periods decline or rise together.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- Governor Lehman made known today that his proposed radio appeal to the people of the State to bring pressure on their representatives in the Legislature to pass promptly law-enforcement bills would also include his response to the Assembly's resolution calling on him to support his recent statement that the program was in jeopardy because "strong" groups were intent upon defeating it.

Evidence of increased interest in the city's children because of the larger number of persons contributing in 1935 to the Children's Aid Society was cited yesterday by William Church Osborn, president of the society, at its annual meeting at the Bank of New York and Trust Company, 48 Wall Street.

Although weather conditions this week did not check the advance in steel production, which rose a half-point to 53 1/2 per cent of capacity, the almost complete tie-up of inland waterway facilities and growing congestion in railroad yards and warehouses were felt and will check activity unless relief appears, says The Iron Age in its weekly summary.

After writing for several years about historical and biographical themes, Dan Totheroh has caught up with the present in "Searching for the Sun," which was put on at the Fifty-eighth Street last evening. To be candid about it, the result is no better.

The Board of Higher Education granted 564 degrees to City College students who completed their studies last month at a meeting last night. The graduates will receive their certificates at the ninetieth commencement exercises of the college in June.

LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 19. -- Dr. L. Gillmor Long, perched on a crane fifty feet above ground in zero cold, amputated the right arm of John McCoy with a mechanic's hacksaw today. The operation freed McCoy, who had been suspended two hours after a crane cab had plunged twenty feet from is seventy-foot-high track and landed on a steel girder.

The "Siegfried" performance given yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, one of the best performances of the present season, was eloquent of what the word "ensemble" can mean at the hands of a world-famous organization.

The rapidity with which share prices were bid up yesterday forenoon, following the brisk upward movement on Tuesday, provided an open invitation for profit-taking; one which was accepted by many recent purchasers. Most of the pressure was exerted in the final hour, and the closing was irregularly lower.

With their Metropolitan League season closing next Wednesday, the Columbia University and New York Athletic clubs continued in their first-place deadlock last night in the Class A squash tennis competition when each team scored its twelfth triumph in thirteen starts.

Efrem Zimbalist gave his sole New York recital of the season in the Town Hall last night in the endowment series of that institution. The violinist, who returned recently to this country after a nine months' world tour, was heard by a large audience, which listened attentively to his scholarly, if not always highly exciting, interpretations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- With its investigation due to end in forty-eight hours, the Senate Munitions Committee held two stormy sessions today, in the course of which witnesses testifying about the sale of war materials to South American revolutionists denounced each other as "liars" and "grafters."

The annual report of the Italian Superpower Corporation for 1935, made public here yesterday, shows total income of $1,474,988, including $1,410,651 in foreign currency valued at the rates of exchange on the dates of receipt and net income of $626,140 after charges, expenses, exchange losses and taxes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- All ranks of diplomatic, official and resident society turned out today for Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's ninetieth musical morning at the Mayflower Hotel, given in celebration of her golden wedding anniversary and the close of an exceptionally brilliant concert season.

Tammany and the Republican bosses, especially in this city, have often been good friends. It is curious that the Republicans haven't learned a better discipline from these competent instructors. On the same day Tammany published its lists of delegates and alternates to the Philadelphia convention and the Republican State Committee chose its delegates at large and alternates to the Cleveland show.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19. -Reversing the outcome of their previous meeting for the national golf crown at Interlachen last August, Miss Patty Berg, rising young star of Minneapolis, defeated Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, six times American titleholder, in the second round of the championship of Palm Beach at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

Total deposits of 152 banks in this city, including commercial banks and trust companies, private banks, savings banks and industrial loan banks, were $16,018,754,800 on Dec. 31 last, a high record, according to a tabulation by The American Banker.

TRENTON, Feb. 19. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann's attorneys took to him this afternoon the news that he is to die the week of March 30. They then tried for four hours and a half, but without success, to get a confession to the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP). -Flames smoldering beneath the city's business district were extinguished today and scores of workmen swarmed into an excavation at the chief business corner to repair gas and water mains.

RCA Communications, Inc., has filed with the Federal Communications Commission its brief in opposition to the petition of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, Inc., for permission to add Oslo, Norway, to its list of points of communication.

Opposition by anthracite operators to union demands for increased wages and shorter hours was indicated yesterday by spokesmen for the industry following the final meeting of the operators negotiating committee, at the Anthracite Institute, 19 Rector Street. The miners and operators start negotiations Monday for a new agreement to replace the one expiring March 31.

A manifesto urging Canada to provide a haven for a "reasonable number" of "selected" refugees from Germany if the flow of exiles from that country does not cease was adopted yesterday at Toronto by leading representatives of all Christian denominations in Canada, including Church of England, Baptist, Presbyterian, Roman Catholic, United Church and Friends, according to the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

WARSAW, Feb. 19. -- General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, went tonight in great secrecy to the Bialowicza forest to shoot a lynx he saw during his visit to Poland last year. He will have the former imperial hunting lodge to himself, as the Presidential hunting party ended yesterday, and President Ignaz Moscicki has returned to Warsaw.

Because of an attack of influenza, Gennaro Papi was unable to conduct the operas "Pagliacci" and "Gianni Schicchi," which he was scheduled to direct on last night's triple bill, consisting of those favorites and the ballet "Serenade," at the Metropolitan Opera House.
TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP). -- Reorganization of the Tampa Police Department was an outgrowth today of the fatal Joseph Shoemaker flogging.
Plans for the first tour of the newly organized New York Festival Orchestra, a PWA concert unit, were disclosed by Lee Pattison, director of the Federal Music Project for New York City and State.

A jury in the Brooklyn Supreme Court returned a verdict early this morning of guilty of murder in the second degree against Meyer and Harry Luckman and Fred J. Hull in the killing of Samuel Drukman almost twelve months ago. The jury returned its verdict after having deliberated 6 hours and 40 minutes from the time it received the case at 7:30 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP). -- The "old clothes" business of Joseph Silverman of New York, excess army supplies dealer, today brought two former members of the Democratic National Committee to the witness stand at the court-martial trial of Colonel Joseph I. McMullen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Politics took a conspicuous place at the White House today. Postmaster General Farley called twice on President Roosevelt to discuss current developments, including, it is supposed, the selection by Tammany of Alfred E. Smith to lead its delegation to the Democratic National Convention.
ROME, Feb. 19. -- The expected meeting between Fulvio Suvich, Italian Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, and Foreign Minister Egon Berger-Waldenegg of Austria took place in Florence today.
