WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The administration's substitute for the AAA was subjected by two Democratic members of the House today to the most severe criticism that has marked consideration of the measure in either legislative branch. On constitutional and economic grounds the pending bill was denounced by Representatives Tarver of Georgia and Lamneck of Ohio.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19. -The Paramount Theatre was filled to capacity tonight for the eleventh annual Kiwanis benefit for under-privileged children of the county, to which screen, radio and stage stars contributed their services. Phil Baker and Lou Holtz were masters of ceremonies. Arthur Hammerstein, Sam H. Harris and Walter Batchellor formed the producers' committee and were assisted by C.W. Carroll, Kiwanis chairman.

Mayor La Guardia expressed the hope yesterday that honestly conducted lotteries could be legalized in this State when he received a gift of two new ambulances from the charity committee of the Grand National Treasure Hunt at the City Hall.

Long Island University and New York University passed each other in going in opposite directions at Madison Square Garden last night. The Blackbirds, whirling along toward an unbeaten year and the final Olympic basketball tryouts, routed Rice, co-champions of the Southwestern Conference, 45 to 29.

LINCOLN ELLSWORTH said in Melbourne that the twentieth century owes it as a duty to civilization to wipe the word "unexplored" off the map. To be sure, he went on to say, that in Antarctica there are 100 years of surveying and mapping to be done, and there are only sixty-four years left in the twentieth century.

The mysterious Zelik Josefowitz, international financier, whose safe deposit vault in New York was stripped by Secret Service agents of $338,000 in hoarded gold in a raid secretly conducted last Tuesday, retained counsel yesterday by telephone from abroad.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 20 (AP). -Japan's voters participated today in a national election, the first in four years, which some political observers thought might result in the overthrow of the Cabinet of Premier Keisuke Okada.

A big and clever Lynbrook High School team held Garfield High completely at bay until late in the game and scored a 21-to-12 victory before 1,500 fans in Madison Square Garden yesterday after Emerson High of Union City topped South Side High of Rockville Center, 28 to 17, in opening a Long Island-New Jersey scholastic basketball double-header.

Uncertainty about the future of the National Youth Administration's effort to provide socially desirable work for jobless young people in this city ended yesterday when relief authorities at Washington allocated $430,000 to finance the out-of-school employment program until June 30.
One of the most important pictures ever acquired by the Toledo Museum of Art, Toledo, Ohio, was purchased here recently as a gift from Edward Drummond Libbey, founder of the institution.
AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 19. -- Amherst took the first game of the Little Three basketball series tonight by defeating Williams, 37 -- 31, in a hard-fought contest.

Governors Island, encountering surprising opposition from Blind Brook, came through to the high-goal title in the last game of this year's New York Athletic Club indoor polo tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory last night.

At a reception given yesterday afternoon in the South Room of the Commodore, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Rouse Jr. of Baltimore announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Rouse, to Edwin L. Hotchkiss of Troy, N.Y., son of Dr. William O. Hotchkiss, president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and Mrs. Hotchkiss.

ROME, Feb. 19. -- The first step toward cutting off Ras Kassa and Ras Seyoum, who are still in Tembien with 40,000 men, was announced in today's official war bulletin, which gives news of the occupation by Marshal Pietro Badoglio's forces in Northern Ethiopia of the small town of Gaela, on the main road from Sakota to Abbi Addi.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The political tug of war between France and Great Britain continued today to delay the initialing of the new naval agreements already reached, although the four-power conference here has completed 90 per cent of its work.

A record Feb. 19 low in the city of 1.8 degrees above zero at 7 A.M. rounded out yesterday a full month of bitter weather. There have been only two colder days this Winter, 2 degrees below on Jan. 23, four days after the cold spell started, and 1 degree above on Jan. 24.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The government made it clear in the House of Lords today that it would not sponsor any tampering with the covenant of the League of Nations. The occasion was an onslaught on the covenant by Lord Rennell, who said Britain could not be committed forever to supporting in all circumstances such an unworkable instrument and bear the main liabilities it entailed.

Ahead at the intermission by a 35-to-15 count, the St. Francis College basketball team coasted to a 49-to-27 triumph over Cathedral College of Manhattan on the winner's floor in Brooklyn last night. The triumph was the eleventh in eighteen starts for the Franciscans.

The adoption by Congress of a compromise neutrality resolution disposes of this question at the present session, but the debate over American foreign policy will continue. This is because no group is entirely satisfied with the resolution as it stands. It does not build a high enough wall around the United States, with enough barbed wire on it, to please the isolationists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Complaints in about 70 per cent of the cases brought before the National Labor Relations Board involved charges of discrimination against workers because of union affiliation and the refusal of employers to bargain collectively with the designated representatives of employes, according to a summary of the board's work made public today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The Export-Import Bank, of which Warren Lee Pierson was elected president yesterday, will consider the discounting of paper for American exporters at reasonable rates, maturing over a period of five years, when guaranteed by exporters or otherwise secured to the satisfaction of the bank.

Auctioneers put up six properties in Manhattan and two in the Bronx at foreclosure sales yesterday. The list included a variety of dwellings, tenement houses and a hotel on the West Side. All were bought in by the plaintiffs.
Two more apartment house plans yesterday were added to the rapidly lengthening list of projects in the city.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19. -Staging a thrilling second-half rally, the C.C.N.Y. basketball team tonight downed Princeton, 36 -- 30, in the university gym. Captain Sol Kopitko, center, led his team to victory, making 12 points.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- A drastic bill, backed by Attorney General Bennett and designed to ban race-horse tipster services, was introduced in the Legislature today, sponsored by Senator John T. McCall and Assemblyman George W. Stewart, Democrats, of New York City.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange, at a special meeting before the market opened yesterday, suspended trading in common stock of the Pierce Oil Corporation upon information from W.H. Coverdale, president of the company, that its stock was virtually valueless.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19. -- The Sage Stable's fleet 5-year-old, Bright Haven, today made amends for being left at the post in his last start by scoring a clean-cut victory in the Grade A handicap that topped the regular Wednesday eight-race program at Hialeah Park.

Mrs. Alice Duer Miller, author; Alexander Woollcott, critic and author, and Richard Collet, managing director of the D'Oyle Carte Opera Company, are among those sailing tonight for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic. Others sailing include Mr. and Mrs. David Brookstone, J.E.O. Benham, Major and Mrs. C.T. Lawrence, Mr. and Mrs. E.H. Cooper, Mr. and Mrs. P.C. Henderson, J.H. Denton, Mr. and Mrs. F.C. Robinson and Mr. and Mrs. Holland Duell.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMY AT ENDA JESUS, NORTHERN ETHIOPIA, Feb. 18 (Delayed). -Two Polish Red Cross workers with the force of Ras Mulugheta, the Ethiopian War Minister, at Amba Aradam were captured by the Italians after the Battle of Enderta. They have been sent to Rome. They are Dr. Maximillian Stanislas Belau, 36 years old, and Deutz Medinsky, 26.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation has filed a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington for the registration of an issue of $60,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent fifteen-year debentures, to be offered by a group of underwriters headed by Dillon, Read Co. and Hayden, Stone Co., J.C. van Eck, chairman of the executive committee of Shell, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- New Dealers admitted today that they had cited the words of Herbert Hoover and his Secretary of the Interior in defending the PWA's slum clearance case before the Supreme Court.

An ultra-violet ray process of recording sound photographically on motion-picture films, which is expected to open an "era of new realism" in the reproduction of musical tone and improve the "film speaking voices" of many screen actors, was described and demonstrated here last night at a meeting of the Atlantic Coast section of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19. -Washington's Birthday will be marked here by social events, including novel entertainments and many private parties. Commander and Mrs. George S.G. Cavendish of Cedar Hill Farm, Media, are giving an informal supper and dance in honor of the Misses Mary and Sarah Meigs, daughters of Dr. and Mrs. Edward B. Meigs of Washington, who are passing the Winter here.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- Asserting that the cream of the armaments share boom has been skimmed for the time being, The London Daily Herald publishes an index showing that the value of the stocks of a comparatively small group of armament and aircraft companies has increased by more than 38,500,000 since the government's rearming plans became known.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- President Roosevelt discussed polities with Chairman Farley of the Democratic National Committee, conferred on the tax program with Treasury officials, and was initiated into the Knights of Pythias.

Almost without exception, the organized sportsmen's groups of New York State are squarely behind Commissioner Lithgow Osborne in his efforts to obtain for the Conservation Department broad discretionary powers in the regulation of fishing and hunting.

An annual rent subsidy as a substitute for Federal grants for housing was proposed yesterday by Harold Riegelman, special counsel and authority on housing, at a luncheon of the National Republican Builders in the Town Hall Club.

Citing numerous instances to support his contention, Joseph H. Zelch, credit manager for Gimbel Brothers, New York, declared last night that the modernization credit plan worked out by the Federal Government under authority of the National Housing Act is one of the soundest programs ever offered the public and should be continued.

Former Supreme Court Justice James C. Van Siclen of Brooklyn and C. Walter Randall, former president of the Nassau County Bar Association have brought suit in the Supreme Court against Irving T. Bush for $250,000 for circulating a letter in which the plaintiffs allege they were libeled.

Addressing 600 men and women at a dinner in the Hotel Astor last night to commemorate the sixtieth anniversary of the founding of the Society for Ethical Culture, Mayor La Guardia declared that the present generation had "made a mess of things," and made a plea for a new, intelligent and disinterested leadership.

Columbia increased its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by defeating Harvard, 47 to 33, last night in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. It was the Lions' fourth victory in as many starts in the circuit and it was earned after a keenly waged contest that was closer than the score indicated.

Plans for a Brooklyn housing development adjoining the old Long Island Railroad freight line to Brighton Beach were announced yesterday by Watson, Kristeller Swift, attorneys for the prospective buyers, a Brooklyn building group.

Cotton-textile mills will wind up the first two months of this year with one of the smallest sales volumes they have experienced since the depth of the depression, selling agents reported yesterday. The situation is quite similar to that of the early part of last year, when uncertainty over the gold clause decision held back buying, except that the lack of demand is even more pronounced this year.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 19 (AP). -- A rubber workers' strike which grew out of a departmental "sit-down" reached major proportions tonight after closely knit picket lines brought production to a virtual standstill in the vast plants of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

One hundred and ninety-two dogs, the largest number exhibited in any one day thus far, were shown in the third session of the pet dog show at Bloomingdale's yesterday. Sporting and non-sporting dogs were passed upon.

Carl Schroeder, Swedish tennis champion, who arrived in this country on Monday to prepare for the coming national indoor title tournament which starts at the Seventh Regiment Armory at the end of this month, engaged in his first real workout since his arrival on the board courts of the Park Avenue drillshed yesterday.

ROME, Feb. 19. -- The Giornale d'Italia prints today a long summary of the hitherto unpublished report of the interministerial commission, headed by Sir John Maffey, appointed in the Spring of 1935 by the British Government "to study British interests in Ethiopia," following the Italian offer in January, 1935, to discuss the Ethiopian question with Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- President Roosevelt conferred again today with Treasury officials with indications that much of the time was given to consideration of methods to replace revenues lost by the Supreme Court decision invalidating AAA processing taxes.
Most commodity futures were lower in active trading on the local markets yesterday. On the cash markets wheat, butter, eggs and tin advanced, while corn, rye, oats, rubber and silk declined.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 19. -- Colonel Rafael Franco flew to Asuncion from his exile here today and immediately assumed the Provisional Presidency of Paraguay. He installed himself in the Government House and began conferring with military leaders regarding the formation of a Cabinet which is to serve with him during the period of de facto government.

The New York Edison Company has filed with the Public Service Commission of New York an application for permission to reduce the interest rate on its forthcoming $55,000,000 of first lien and refunding Series D bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1965, from 3 1/2 per cent, which was originally asked, to 3 1/4 per cent, it was learned in official circles of the company yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 19. -- The Boerse was quiet and weak today. Automobile securities, which recently experienced sharp rises, had the most serious losses, Daimler dropping 2 1/2 points. Heavy industrial shares were sluggish, but Mannesmann lost 1/4 point.

BERLIN, Feb. 19. -- Some irritation, tempered by amusement, was created in official circles here tonight by inquiries regarding a rumor sent out from Florence that Egon Berger-Waldenegg, the Austrian Foreign Minister, and Fulvio Suvich, Italian Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, in discussing matters of interest to their two countries there, were "formulating an agreement" that in effect would pledge Germany to a complete change in her Central European policy.

About one-third of the pay cuts imposed on more than 7,500 Jersey City and Hudson County, N.J., civil employes in 1932 and 1933 will be restored next July 1, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Frank Hague in Jersey City. The Mayor said this action had been agreed on by the City Commission of Jersey City, the Hudson County Board of Freeholders and the Board of Education.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 20. -- Miss Etta Liberman of 116 Saratoga Avenue, this city, a native of Canada, who has taken out her first citizenship papers here, reported today that she and Miss Rose Applebaum of Ottawa, a friend, were held for twenty-six hours in a Cuban internment camp by mistake while on a cruise to Havana last month.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Dr. Tatsukichi Minobe, Japanese author and political scientist, was shot in the right foot at his home today. His assailant was arrested at the scene.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- In answer to the solicitations of Congressional leaders to submit quickly the rest of his "must" program so that it might be enacted and Congress adjourned by May 1, President Roosevelt is expected to use his brief respite at Hyde Park House to draft an outline of new taxes needed, at least those required for raising nearly $500,000,000 for the farm program.

A jury was selected yesterday in Federal court for the trial of John T. Brook and former Representative Benjamin L. Fairchild, president and former director, respectively, of the defunct Pelham National Bank, together with six other officers of the institution, on charges of misappropriation of funds and of making false reports to the Controller of the Currency.

A middle-aged man haunted by his own photograph on criminal "wanted" posters, impelled by conscience, destitution and a yearning to return to the sea, surrendered Tuesday to the Department of Justice and confessed that he was the warrant officer who had embezzled about $20,000 from the paymaster of the Atlantic Fleet twenty years ago.

For the second year in a row, William E. Coyle of the Montclair A.C. succeeded in capturing the New York State squash racquets singles crown by defeating Stanley Galowin, 18-year-old player from the City A.C., in yesterday's final at the Downtown A.C.

JOLIET, Ill., Feb. 20 (AP). -- Members of a citizens' committee investigating Illinois penal institutions today heard a dozen convicts charge that gambling, liquor and narcotics figured in Stateville Penitentiary life in former years.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20. -- A suit to recover $12,741,457 for the City of Philadelphia and its gas consumers was filed today in Common Pleas Court by Mayor S. Davis Wilson against the United Gas Improvement Company and a subsidiary, the Philadelphia Gas Works Company.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- The secret British Government report published yesterday in the Giornale d'Italia in Rome concerning the interests of this country in Ethiopia seems much less sinister today in view of explanations obtainable at Whitehall.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20 (AP). -- A three-goal scoring burst in the first period gave the Maroons their winning margin in a 6-3 victory over the injury-ridden Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game tonight.

Cleto Locatelli and Izzy Jannazzo, contenders in the race for a fight with Barney Ross for the world's welterweight championship, will clash in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. It will be the second meeting between the pair, Locatelli having pounded out a convincing triumph over his East Side foe in their first clash, two months ago.
LONDON, Feb. 20. -- Louis Lumiere, inventor of the cinematograph, was the central figure today at the fortieth anniversary of the first public exhibition of movies in Britain.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- Warning against the danger of depletion of the ground water supply in Brooklyn, Queens and the rest of Long Island, Governor Lehman called upon the Legislature in a special message today to pave the way for a new study of conditions on which to base early corrective action.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 20. -- "Please take me to a police station; I do not know who I am or how I got here," said a well-dressed young woman today to a patrolman in the central business part of Baltimore.

The Murray Hill Hotel, which stands in the busy Grand Central area as a monument of an older and more leisurely New York, will be modernized within the next few months to meet the changing needs of the present.

Negotiations for a new issue of about $90,000,000 of Pacific Gas and Electric bonds have progressed to a point where the filing of a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission is probable in about two weeks, it was said yesterday in financial circles.

PARIS, Feb. 20. -- Edouard Herriot, from the tribune of the Chamber of Deputies, today took occasion to remind the French Parliament of France's debt to the United States. The Chamber was discussing the proposed pact with Soviet Russia, and Deputies who were opposing its ratification raised the question of the pre-war Russian debts to France that have never been paid.

Staging a sensational comeback in the second half, the St. John's University five overcame a twelve-point lead and snapped George Washington University's fourteen-game winning streak, 29 to 37, in the De Gray gymnasium last night.
With the Bronx taking the lead, real estate trading was featured yesterday by sales of multi-family buildings throughout the city.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- H.G. Wells's film, "Things to Come," made by Alexander Korda's London Films at a cost of $1,000,000, which will have its premiere at the Leicester Square Theatre tomorrow, was shown to the press and the trade tonight.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20. -- Members of the Garden Club of Palm Beach were guests of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman today at an illustrated lecture given by Mrs. Benjamin F. Warren of Grosse Point, Mich., their guest, on Chinese gardens. Later tea was served.

In the feature of a novelty day at Bloomingdale's pet dog show yesterday, the award of dog of most breeds went to Dewey, the exhibit of Miss Jeanette Loeb of Manhattan. A minimum of five distinct breeds was traced to Dewey by David Livingston of the S.P.C.A.

The progress and significance of arbitration in the settlement of commercial disputes was stressed yesterday at a luncheon in honor of Charles L. Bernheimer, chairman of the arbitration committee of the State Chamber of Commerce and honorary president of the American Arbitration Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Criticism of speeches they had made in Philadelphia was leveled at Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and Robert V. Fleming, president of the American Bankers Association, in a letter sent to them by South Trimble, clerk of the House of Representatives, and read to the Senate today on motion of Senator Wheeler.
